title: MEAN, GREEN STREETS; Security in Brown
description: Mayor Koch wants to cut back on New York's army of traffic agents in favor of more armed police on foot patrol. He says some motorists will heed only a gun-toting officer in blue.

title: A GUIDE TO REALPOLITIK
description: FOR THE RECORD Selected Statements 1977-1980. By Henry Kissinger. 332 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $12.95. By GADDIS SMITH

title: INDUSTRY TAKES BOLD NEW STEPS TO DEVELOP THE ELECTRIC CAR
description: THE internal-combustion engine may have been king of the road for the last 70 years, but as a result of the gasoline hysteria that has struck the United States twice in the last decade, its chief competitor - the electric car - is again being seriously considered as an alternative.

title: Art View; THE CASE OF MADAME'S SHOULDER STRAP
description: Sometimes a painting acquires a reputation that is almost more interesting than the artist who painted it. Circumstance conspires to separate the work from the remainder of the artist's oeuvre, surround it with notoriety, and leave it a permanent object of curiosity. Neither significant esthetic merit nor a significant lack of it is in itself sufficient to guarantee a painting this unusual status. What is required is that it connect - or perhaps one should say, collide - with established taste, cause public misunderstanding, and appear to outrage conventional morals while in reality, and certainly in the eyes of posterity, it remains a perfectly respectable and thoroughly benign work of art. What is required, in other words, is for the painting to become an unintended episode in the comedy of culture.

title: Except on Israel, Unity Is Elusive At Islamic Summit
description: Saudi Arabia reportedly spent more than $1 billion playing host to the kings, sheiks and prime ministers of the Islamic world last week, but did it get its money's worth? The four-day meeting, held at an opulent, new, French-built conference center in Taif after opening ceremonies in Mecca, pledged Islamic nations generally to take up the Arabs' economic and political ''holy war'' against Israel and its supporters. But the conference made no progress toward ending the shooting war under way for more than four months between Iran and Iraq.

A long and eventful chapter in the history of United States coinage came to an end on Jan. 16 when Frank Gasparro, chief sculptorengraver of the U.S. Mint, retired after nearly four decades with the bureau.

title:
TV View;
THE FORMULA'S THE THING ON 'SOAPS'
description: The scene is set in what appears to be a dank, secluded patch of woodland. Two persons in elegant evening attire emerged from a large, gas-guzzling automobile. The attractive young woman is anxious to get financial support for her oil-rich but cash-poor father. The middleaged man with a British accent will agree if she promises to marry his nephew, whom he describes as ''a Denver version of the Prince of Wales.'' Scheming Fallon Carrington would prefer to marry the ruthless uncle, Cecil Colby (names are often the most creative elements in this type of enterprise), but he is far too sophisticated to be entrapped by a passing affair. ''Passion dies, power remains,'' he tells her. As if that's not enough, he confesses that ''at my age, vengeance is as sweet as sex.'' Poor bitchy Fallon is overwhelmed by such profundities but still manages to agree to marry Cecil's harmless nephew. In other words, dear viewer, we are smack dab in the middle of soap-opera territory.

title: Tracy Austin, Leg Injured, Won't Play Detroit Event
description: Top-seeded Tracy Austin has withdrawn from the $150,000 Women's Tennis Association tournament scheduled here for next week, the association announced today.

title: Janet E. Tonka Engaged To Kenneth C. Leonard
description: Janet Eve Tonka of Stamford, Conn., and Kenneth Carl Leonard of Bronxville, N. Y., who are with the General Foods Corporation in White Plains, plan to be married March 7 in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Yonkers.

title: OLDER CITIES CONTINUE POPULATION SLIDE
description: WASHINGTON IN 1830, Andrew Jackson was in the White House, South Carolina was threatening to nullify Federal laws, a revolution in France was putting Louis Philippe on the throne and America's first railroad - a 14-mile stretch of the Baltimore & Ohio that had been under construction for two years - was hauling its first passengers in horse-drawn rail cars.

title: Vermont's House Backs Dead Man's Re-election
description: The re-election of a dead man to the Vermont House was upheld by legislators yesterday despite an assertion by his opponent that the victory was unconstitutional.

title: GENERAL FOODS NEGOTIATING A BID FOR OSCAR MAYER
description: The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it was negotiating for the acquisition of Oscar Mayer & Company in a stock and cash transaction valued at roughly $464.6 million.

title: Suarez Jumps His Battered Galleon
description: Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez, leader of the center-right coalition that has guided Spaniards along the path to democracy, astonished everyone last week by handing in his resignation to his friend and patron, King Juan Carlos.

title: Anne Gresham Bride of Dr. Stephen Morse
description: Anne Marsden Williams Gresham, an artist, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Stephen Scott Morse, an assistant professor of microbiology at Rutgers University. The Rev. Craig Biddle 3d performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Richmond.

title: Michigan State 60 Ohio State 54
description: Kevin Smith scored 22 points tonight, including four last-minute free throws, to lead Michigan State to a 60-54 upset that knocked Ohio State out of first place in the Big Ten.

title: No Headline
description: 10 ENGINE PART FALLS FROM PLANE: Sheriff's officers in Leesburg, Va., wheeling away engine cowling, or collar, of a Northwest Airlines jet. The cowling fell shortly after the plane took off yesterday from Dulles International Airport near Washington. No injuries were reported, and the plane returned safely to Dulles.

title: New Jerseyans
description: OCEAN COUNTY was obscure in the early days of New Jersey. According to Pauline S. Miller of Toms River, the County Historian, it was sort of a backwater, a place that people ran away to. However, the county played an unusual and little-known role in prolonging the peace negotiations that ended the Revolutionary War.

title: HOW CALDOR'S $8,000 GREW TO $313 MILLION
description: ABOUT 30 years ago, with $8,000 in savings and the loyal support of his wife, a young man newly out of the Army opened a tiny, secondfloor store selling toys, housewares, luggage and gifts at a discount on Main Street in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor;

title: Acknowledging An Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: GREENWICH TAPPING NEW WATER SOURCES
description: FACED with about 19 days' supply of water, town officials of Greenwich have so far declared an emergency but demanded only voluntary compliance with water conservation measures. Even so, the Connecticut-American Water Company, which supplies Greenwich and nearby towns in Westchester County, has been empowered by the Connecticut Public Utilities Control Authority to stop service to those who flout its conservation recommendations.

title: Children's Books
description: WHEN NO ONE WAS LOOKING By Rosemary Wells. 218 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $8.95. (Ages 12 to 15)By ANNE TYLER

title: DISPUTES ON STAFF ARE HINTED
description: Marxist Perspectives, a scholarly journal that since its first appearance in the spring of 1979 achieved surprising financial status and considerable academic prestige, is ceasing publication after only 10 issues.

title: SWEET SOLUTIONS TO A TART PROBLEM
description: There aren't many desserts that spark more sweet controversy than lime and lemon pies. Perfectly made, these are among the finest confections that the American kitchen has to offer. The problem in preparing these citrus treats is finding a proper binding agent, one that will produce a smooth, melting, tender filling that can survive slicing without seeming overly runny. Some cooks favor egg yolks, others swear by cornstarch. Our nominations for the best lime and lemon pies are outlined here; one uses yolks, the other cornstarch. In either recipe, one may substitute lemon juice for the lime juice, or vice versa. Lemon meringue pie 4 tablespoons cornstarch 1/4 teaspoon salt 1 cup plus 6 tablespoons sugar 1 1/2 cups water 3 eggs, separated 2 tablespoons butter 1 1/2 teaspoons grated lemon rind 5 tablespoons lemon juice 1 nine-inch baked pie shell (see recipe).

title: Connecticut Journal; RUSTIC RUMBLINGS...A FOREST GROWS
description: MORE families moving into new development houses in rural areas have found unexpected elements intruding on their rustic settings - farm machinery and animals.

title: Future Events Mixed Menu
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:Italian FoodFeb. 4 - Cocktails at 7:30, then, at 8:45, tortellini followed by chicken with veal and all the trimmings that make up the Italian feast the Metropolitan Opera Guild will hold in the Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center for Beni Montresor. The guest of honor designs stage sets and costumes for opera, ballet and theater, directs operas, films and ballets and writes and illustrates children's books. But can he cook? He can and does in his spacious, sparsely furnished Greenwich Village apartment. Tonight's dinner party is on the eve of the opening at the Library of ''The Magic of Montresor,'' a 20-year retrospective of his work. Opera companies on both sides of the Atlantic are lending some of his designs to the four-month show. All good parties end with a surprise, as will this evening's when four Metropolitan Opera stars step up to serenade the Italian-born artist, who, at 54 years of age, still looks like a matinee idol. Proceeds will be used by the Met for its many projects other than opera production. Tickets are $150 from 582-6067.

title: THE NEW INSTITUTIONALISM
description: President Reagan faces a risk that public expectations for fast action will deflect his attention from developing a longerterm strategy of governance. He should seize the opportunity to articulate a theme by which his Administration's vision for America may be known. It could be called: the New Institutionalism.

title: A CONGLOMORATE THAT WORKS
description: LOS ANGELES I T is often characterized as enigmatic. It tells what it cares to about itself, and generally that is not much. It seems to discard more prevailing wisdom than it follows. Big as it is, it tends to keep its head low. And it is widely heralded as one of the best-managed companies in the world of business.

title: Home Clinic; HOW TO REMOVE WALLPAPER THAT HAS BEEN PAINTED
description: STRIPPING old wallpaper that has been in place for many years - often required before a new covering can be hung or because the old paper is finally starting to let go - is usually a time-consuming job that becomes particularly frustrating when the paper has been painted.

title: GAS SUPPLY LOOKS FINE, BUT PRICES MAY RISE
description: WASHINGTON FOR motorists trying to decide on a new car or the feasibility of a long vacation trip, there is both good and bad news in the gasoline outlook for 1981. The good news is that, barring further interruptions or reductions of crude oil from overseas, gasoline should be relatively plentiful. The bad news is that prices will be rising about twice as fast as in 1980 - and twice as fast as inflation - so that consumers will probably be paying about $1.45 a gallon by the end of the year.

title: TALE OF A SWISS SPY: HAVEN WAS READY IF BERN FELL
description: The recently dismissed director of the Swiss intelligence service's top-secret operations rented and refurbished a hotel in Ireland in the 1960's to serve as the home in exile for the Swiss Government should the country fall under enemy occupation.

title: THE GAME HAS CHANGED, BUT NOT RED AUERBACH'S IDEALS
description: THE game of basketball is supposed to be a no-contact game of skill played by five men trying to put a basketball through a hoop extended 10 feet off the floor and preventing their opponents from doing the same.

title: Leisure; A NEW APPROACH FOR RAISING ASPARAGUS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Dr. Stephen A. Garrison is associate professor of horticulture at Cook College, Rutgers University. By STEPHEN A. GARRISON

title: by Ellen Mitchell
description: THE major road construction under way on the South Shore is along Sunrise Highway in Islip. The project typifies many highway improvements on the Island - 20 years have elapsed between the planning stage and the work.

title:
Art;
MODESTY AND FUN AT THE RUTGERS GALLERY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ''THE David and Mildred Morse Collection: A Promised Gift'' is the title of an exhibition that opened recently at the Rutgers University Art Gallery, where it will remain through March 1.

title: HOW A 1936 SCREWBALL COMEDY ILLUMINATES MOVIE HISTORY
description: Gladys has bleached blonde hair, a hopelessly romantic nature and a remarkably good temper. However, when Haggerty, the managing editor of the New York Evening Star, leaves her standing at the altar for the dozenth time, Gladys loses her patience. She hops into a cab and goes to the newspaper to demand an explanation. Dressed in her virginal bridal veils, still clutching her bouquet of forget-me-nots and lilies of the valley, she stands in the middle of the newsroom whining, threatening and, finally, throwing things.

title: Vermont
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Guide; BLACK HISTORY MONTH
description: In a tradition dating to the 1920's, February has become recognized as Black History Month, and a number of programs will be presented in New Jersey.

title: Fiscal Reminders of The Once-Forgotten
description: What Congress gave the ''forgotten middle class'' in student grants and loans during the 1970's, the Reagan Administration may try to take away, according to Secretary of Education Terrel H. Bell.

title: OTTAWA ELEVATOR CHANGES COURSE
description: The shape of high-rise buildings has been largely determined by their elevators and that technology has been a vertical one. A new Otis Elevator Company design for an elevator in the Parliament Hill Peace Tower in Ottawa, however, changes direction and travels on an incline for part of its journey.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Business Editor: Before there can be any major change in the Social Security system, there should be private pension systems upon which each retiree could depend in addition to Social Security.

title: Notre Dame Downs South Carolina, 94-84
description: Kelly Tripucka scored 26 points tonight as Notre Dame rolled to a 94-84 basketball victory over South Carolina.

title: RAVITCH HOPES HE'LL FIND THE SILVER LINING IN ALBANY
description: Richard Ravitch recently completed his first year as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the agency ultimately responsible for the performance of New York City's subways. In that year, many riders would say, the subways have grown worse, with more delays and breakdowns, more crime and higher fares. Mr. Ravitch himself has described the system as ''in a state of emergency'' and said its recovery depends on a big transfusion of money.

title:
Gardening;
FORCED BULBS BRING A HINT OF SPRING
description: IF the recent frigid weather hasn't whet your appetite for the return of spring, nothing will. One of the best cures for the midwinter blahs is to have something cheerful and spring-like blooming around the house.

title: A GUIDE TO CAPITALISM
description: WEALTH AND POVERTY By George Gilder. 306 pp. New York: Basic Books. $16.95.

title: NEW CHIEFS AT ARCO
description: Thornton F. Bradshaw, 63 years old, president and chief operating officer of the Atlantic Richfield Company, was named chairman of the RCA Corporation last week. He will replace Edgar H. Griffiths, who unexpectedly announced plans to resign when he reaches the age of 60 in July.

title: Nora M. Grace, Publishing Aide, Fiancee Of Colum O'Donnell, Account Executive
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Peter Grace of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nora Mary Grace, to Colum Peter O'Donnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene E. O'Donnell of Marlborough, Mass.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: A strike over wages and benefits by 8,000 members of the Canadian Union of Public Employees has halted some municipal services in the Vancouver area.

title: U.A.W. Loses the Battle of Athens
description: United Automobile Workers took Strike Three last week in their effort to organize workers at a General Motors Corporation plant in Athens, Ala. The union's defeat signaled continued deep resistance to unionization among workers in the rural South.

title:
Speaking Personally;
A LITTLE BOY'S LAUGHTER ERASES THE PASSAGE OF TIME
description: MY 4 1/2-YEAR-OLD son usually starts looking for me to come home from work as the dinner hour approaches. When I pull the car into the driveway, I'll spot his face on the inside of the living-room bay windows.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: ROASTED PEANUTS: TOLL OF THE DROUGHT
description: WAKEFIELD, Va. O N the outskirts of this southeastern Virginia hamlet, which claims to be the original peanut capital of the world, a battered green and white sign reminds visitors that the first commercial peanut crop in the United States was grown near here and that Virginia peanuts are, ''Still First and Still Finest.''

title: New Agreements May Avoid the Worst for Poland
description: For a change, opposing sides in Poland's volatile experiment with independent unions joined forces last week, hoping to restore calm and avoid national catastrophe.

title: Mailbox; Al Davis's Image Is 131 Years Old
description: To the Sports Editor: With his self-cultivated image of a successful entrepreneur who fought his way out of the ghetto to his sparkling success, Al Davis is merely following a long line of deceitful boors descended from Charles Dickens's character Bounderby, the industrialist archetype of the tiresome ''self-made'' braggarts. They have been around since 1850.C.W. GRIFFIN

title: C.W. Post 87 Old Westbury 71
description: Mike Dias scored 20 points and Jerry Britton 18 as they led C.W. Post (10-7) to an 87-71 victory over Old Westbury (11-8) at the victors' Connolly Gymnasium last night. The victory was C.W. Post's sixth in its last seven games.

title: THE REGION IN SUMMARY
description: If nothing lasts forever, PCB's, the industrial chemicals linked to a variety of ills, including cancer, come close. Little wonder, then, that hundreds of Beacon Falls, Conn., residents turned out last week to protest a Federal plan to store PCB's there.

title: DEATHS IN MAJOR U.S. FIRES LINKED TO WEAK SAFETY RULES AND APATHY
description: If the Stouffer's Inn conference center in Harrison, N.Y., had been built on the other side of the highway, fire safety experts believe, most of the 26 victims would have survived the arsonist's fire that swept it last month. For in White Plains, just across Interstate 287, a full sprinkler system is required. In Harrison, it is not.

title: For Aviation Buffs
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Journal
description: A MAJOR new survey of Westchester County's top executives indicates that there is less dissatisfaction today with the county as a business location than there was two years ago.

title:
Art;
SHEDDING LIGHT ON TIFFANY'S CREATIONS
description: BROOKVILLE CONVINCED that there's more to Louis Comfort Tiffany than the high price tags on the lamps, bric-a-brac and windows he created, the C.W. Post Art Gallery on Saturday will open ''The Age of Tiffany,'' an exhibition designed to prove that Tiffany was a major American artist and not just a hot commercial property.

title: HOW IT WAS BEFORE LEGALIZED ABORTION
description: JAN. 22 was the anniversary of the Supreme Court decisions that made abortion legal. It is easy to forget that only eight years ago, abortion was illegal and unavailable in most of our United States. Only when the mother's very life was threatened were doctors allowed to terminate a pregnancy. Not even in cases of rape, incest, serious health problems or genetic fetal abnormalities was abortion legal. It is easy to forget what women did back in those days.

title: Debra S. Goodman Plans Bridal in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Goodman of Harrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Susan Goodman, to Dr. Charles Norman Glassman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Glassman of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: The Last Place to Cut the Budget
description: For the moment, the hardest job in the Reagan Administration belongs to David Stockman, the young budget director. How shall the budget be cut? It's up to him to figure out which agencies should be chopped off at the knees and which should sacrifice merely a finger or two. There are, naturally, no volunteers. But in a period of boiling inflation, the budget must be cut and the man with the hatchet deserves, if not sympathy, at least suggestions of the most important priorities. Here is the most important one: hunger.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL OMEN?
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Romantic realism. Today's teen-age girls are tough-minded kids. The books they buy with their spending money are novels that depict the ugly side of society they know through experience or from watching television, a society fraught with unwed pregnancy, broken homes, drugs, homosexuality and incest.

title: STAMFORD'S CORPORATIONS BUILD HOUSING DOWNTOWN
description: 61 203 324 9322 By ROBERT TOMASSON

title: OTHER WAYS OF RECOVERING OIL
description: The new oil recovery technology being pioneered by Amoco and Shell Oil, using carbon dioxide injection, may not be the only means of exploiting the oil left in the well after primary and secondary recovery methods fail.

title: COMMERCIALIZTION STIRS TOWN'S IRE
description: PATCHOGUE PROMPTED by the specter of the town's thoroughfares developing into a series of signaled intersections separating strips of fastfood restaurants, drive-in movies and bars, the Town of Brookhaven is considering a new highway zoning category aimed at limiting commercial development along highways and bypasses.

title: Huntington Housing And Young Couples
description: Concerning the recent article ''Huntington Officials Resisting Challenge to One-Family Zoning'': Your children and mine just might get a chance to have a dream come true - if this is not killed by unfounded rumors first.

title: Nuptials on June 12 For Ann Brockway
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Brockway of Seattle have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Elizabeth Brockway, to Paul Ainsworth Murtaugh 3d, son of Paul Ainsworth Murtaugh of Mamaroneck N.Y., and Mrs. Robert S. Wilson of Berkeley Heights, N.J.

title: LOPSIDED UNITED NATIONS POSITION ON NAMIBIA
description: To the Editor:

title: 10,000 Cambodian Refugees In Urban Resettlement Plan
description: Officials are planning to resettle 10,000 Cambodian refugees, in groups of 300 to 1,000,

title: FORMER HOSTAGES LEAVING NEW YORK AFTER 2 DAYS OF CELEBRATION
description: After 48 hours packed with Broadway shows, a ticker-tape parade, mayoral receptions, a belated Christmas party and extravagant candlelit dinners, most of the 21 Americans who were released from Iran 12 days ago and who had come to New York City to savor its brand of welcome slowly began to leave yesterday for their hometowns and, in many cases, another round of welcome celebrations.

title: No Flak From Jones Over a B-1 Bomber
description: If Gen. David C. Jones winds up getting shot down by Reaganauts, or if he is ultimately forced to bail out, it won't be because he didn't try to appease his conservative critics or please his new bosses. In Congressional testimony last week, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff banked sharply away from his previous position on the B-1.

title: WASHINGTON
description: I N the 1981 sweepstakes for tax relief for business there is one unassailable front runner. Business wants faster depreciation writeoffs - that is, deductions from taxable income - for the cost of the equipment, vehicles and buildings that comprise its productive assets.

title: VIRGINIA OVERCOMES DUKE, 68-47, FOR NO. 23
description: Jeff Lamp and Lee Raker led a 14-3 spurt in the last 11 1/2 minutes of the first half and a 13-point run midway in the second that helped give undefeated Virginia a 68-47 Atlantic Coast Conference basketball victory over Duke today.

title: PENNSYLVANIA GOVERNOR PROPOSES SALE OF 725 STATE LIQUOR STORES
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh has proposed selling 725 state-owned retail liquor stores to private owners. Governor Thornburgh said this week that consumers would be better served if Pennsylvania's 48-year-old monopoly on the sale of hard liquor and wine was ended. The Governor said Wednesday that legislation would be introduced in the State Senate to permit the creation of as many liquor outlets as local sentiment and ordinances would allow.

title:
Stamps;
NEW YEAR OF THE ROOSTER
description: Farewell to the Year of the Monkey and welcome to the New Year of the Rooster which begins for the Chinese this Thursday. It is observed with dragon dances, fireworks and elaborate ceremonies in many nations of the Orient, as well as in the Chinatowns of America - and more quietly on stamps.

title: Life Grows Longer For the Jets' Fans
description: To the Sports Editor: I have been thinking a bit about the very sad letter you received from a 63-year-old Jet fan (Mailbox, Jan. 4) who emotionally pointed out that insurance company actuarial tables predict his death in 1992, thereby preventing his witnessing the Jets in the playoffs. Nor did he see much hope in shifting allegiance when considering the unhappy position of the Giants.

title: HOW THE ARTS MIRROR THE RETREAT OF MANHOOD
description: Whatever happened to men? That question may have occurred to those who think that the two most compelling male presences that we have lately seen on the New York stage are those of Jack the Ripper, in Alban Berg's opera ''Lulu'' at the Met, and the Elephant Man in the play of that name. There are pleasanter people to look at when the curtain goes up, but those two are the ones that weld us to our seats. And they are, respectively, a mass murderer and a freak.

title: HALF THE U.S. ON THE DOLE
description: President Reagan, who said in his inaugural address, ''Government is not the solution to the our problem; government is the problem,'' will be taking on a formidable adversary in his fight to cut public spending - half the country. According to a recently updated analysis by A. Gary Shilling & Company, an consulting firm, more than 110 million Americans relied directly or indirectly on Uncle Sam for at least 25 percent or more of their income in 1979.

title: WATER PROBLEMS 'COMPOUNDED,' STATE AIDE SAYS
description: LYNDHURST RESERVOIRS serving rationed communities in northeastern New Jersey continued their steady decline last week as state officials voiced increasing gloom over the deteriorating water-supply situation.

title: GROUP HELPS STATE KEEP EMPLOYERS AND GET NEW ONES
description: NEW HAVEN ''WE were at the 11th hour,'' said Barry Banducci, an executive of the Allen Group Inc. An Allen subsidiary, the G & O Manufacturing Company, whose 350 employees make truck radiators, had apparently exhausted all options in seeking a site for a modern new factory to replace the four dilapidated buildings it was using. The parcels offered by city development officials were unsuitable. A move outside New Haven, perhaps to one of the other states where G & O operates factories, seemed inevitable.

title: Tribal Right to College Education Denied by Michigan State Court
description: The claim of three Indian tribes that an 1817 treaty entitles them to free education at the University of Michigan has been rejected by the State Court of Appeal.

title: ED KOCH: THE MAN BEHIND THE MAYOR
description: William H. Honan is the editor of The Times's Arts and Leisure section. By William H. Honan His Honor, the Mayor of New York, was dedicating a new shopping center in Brooklyn not long ago. He seemed to have the crowd with him as he approached his peroration when suddenly a black member of the racially mixed audience called out: ''We want John Lindsay!''

title: Elizabeth H. Furey To Be Wed in May
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Haywood Furey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Furey of Pittsfield, Mass., to Martin LeBoutillier 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. LeBoutillier of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A May wedding in planned in Pittsfield.

title: Reagan Won't Walk A 'One-Way Street'
description: Applying no smoothly Presidential coating to the unvarnished antiCommunism of his campaign, Ronald Reagan asserted last week that the Soviet Union was bent on the ''promotion of world revolution and a one-world socialist or Communist state'' and was prepared ''to commit any crime, to lie, to cheat'' to further that goal.

title: Frank Lloyd Wright
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Times Magazine February 1, 1981
description: William Safire 10 On Language Let the Reader Beware Russell Baker 14 Sunday Observer Warm-Weather Friend William H. Honan 18 The Man Behind the Mayor An old friend's view of how His Honor is doing and why he does it in his own inimitable way. David Abrahamson 22 Life in an Ocean Pressure Cooker Experiments simulating deep-sea dives show that men can endure underwater pressures much greater than scientists suspected.

title: MATH STILL LAGGING, TEST SCORES SHOW
description: HARTFORD WITH charts, graphs, statistics and five assistants at his side, Mark R. Shedd, the State Commissioner of Education, discussed last week the results of the minimum proficiency tests taken in October by the state's 42,273 ninth-grade public school students.

title: BRONFMAN HEADS JEWISH CONGRESS
description: Edgar M. Bronfman, an international distillery executive long active in Jewish affairs, has been elected president of the World Jewish Congress. The action was taken during last week's plenary assembly of the organization in Jerusalem.

title: China's Protestants Meet
description: More than 100 Chinese Christians met in Peking today for the third congress of the country's Protestant organization. The Three-Self Patriotic Committee, so-called because it is self-administering, self-supporting and self-propagating, is an officially recognized body established in 1954 when Chinese Protestants cut links with other countries.

title: SAUDIS GAIN CREDIT AT ISLAMIC MEETING
description: Saudi Arabia, Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization came away as the principal beneficiaries from the four-day Islamic conference held here this week, according to Western and Arab diplomats.

title: Artificial Feet
description: Three-year-old Sammy Perkins lost his feet in June 1979 when he strayed into a field and was run over by a hay mower on the family farm in Williamston, Mich. Surgeons at the Edward W. Sparrow Hospital in Lansing reattached the feet.

title: CHIROPRACTORS WILL APPEAL VERDICT WON BY A.M.A.
description: Five chiropractors will appeal a jury verdict that the American Medical Association and other professional groups were not guilty of conspiring to monopolize health care, their attorney said last night.

title: No Headline
description: Edward Fiske, alas, himself unwittingly falls victim to the prejudice against left-handedness inherent in the English language.

title: STUDYING CYCLES OF PRIMITIVE ROCK
description: GUIDE P.22 By JOHN ROCKWELL

title: STUDIO 54'S EX-OWNERS IN NEW YORK TO FINISH SENTENCES IN TAX CASE
description: uf814Steven Rubell and Ian Schrager, the former owners of Studio 54, have returned to New York to stay at a ''halfway house'' for the remainder of their jail terms for Federal income tax evasion.

title: Susan E. Frelinghuysen Married in Capital
description: Susan Emily Frelinghuysen and Robert Dudley van Roijen were married yesterday in Georgetown, Washington. The Rev. Sanford Garner of Christ Episcopal Church in Georgetown, performed the ceremony in the home of the bridegroom's mother, Mrs. Robert Dudley van Roijen.

title: William Gopallawa, 83, Ex-Sri Lanka President
description: William Gopallawa, the first President of Sri Lanka and a former Ambassador to the United States, died of a heart attack at a Colombo hospital yesterday, a family spokesman said.

title: Eaddo Hayes To Be Bride
description: Eaddo Williams Hayes, creative services coordinator at Home Box Office, a Time Inc. subsidiary, and Peter DeLacy Kiernan 3d, an advertising representative for Fairchild Publications of Capital Cities Communications Inc., will be married in April.

title: SAN FRANSISCO ACTS ON BUS DRIVER CRIME
description: The disclosure that a number of city buses have former convicts behind the wheel has made for some uneasy riders, particularly since a driver with a record of sex crimes was charged with raping a woman he met on his bus.

title: SONG: STEVE ROSS AT ALGONQUIN
description: The Algonquin Hotel, which has traditionally been satisfied to let the aura of its celebrated guests be its primary lure, has, for the first time in 40 years, put public entertainment in its Oak Room, where the round table of Alexander Woollcott, Robert Benchley, Dorothy Parker and George S. Kaufman once held forth.

title: CHURCHILLIAN SITES ON A THREE-DAY TOUR
description: Many visitors to Britain, especially those who have made several trips there, like to see places associated with great men of the past. Some people visit as many of Sir Christopher Wren's buildings as they can; some make a pilgrimage to the spots in the Lake District frequented by the Romantic poets; some seek out the settings of the main events in Henry VIII's tempestuous life.

title: 3D INDIAN POINT PLANT IS CLOSED AFTER A LEAK IN A TURBINE BUILDING
description: The State Power Authority's nuclear power plant at Indian Point was shut down today because of a malfunction in the plant's steam turbine section.

title: BYRNE TO INTRODUCE $5.6 BILLION BUDGET ASKING NO NEW TAX
description: Governor Byrne will present a $5.6 billion state budget to the New Jersey Legislature Monday that requires no new taxes but forecasts higher fares for the state's 500,000 commuters and tuition increases of 9 percent at Rutgers University.

title: Strike Ends At Roosevelt
description: Mutuel ticket agents at Roosevelt Raceway ratified a new three-year contract with the harness track tonight and ended their two-week strike.

title: ANOTHER WAY OF LIFE
Theater in Review; 'OPAL' STAGED WITH A PARADISE OF PROPS
description: HUNTINGTON SOME plays are destined for a deservedly quick demise on Broadway and an inexplicable afterlife on the year-round stock-theater circuit. Such is the case with ''Everybody Loves Opal,'' an alleged comedy that ran for almost three weeks in 1961 - when the theater was an affordable alternative to the tube.

Your article highlighted the high-risk nature of teen-age pregnancy and its correspondingly high rates of infant mortality and child neglect. However, it erroneously stated that the Camden program was somewhat of an innovative approach to multi-specialty comprehensive care.

title: by Gene Thornton
description: PHOTOGRAPHY As portrait photographer, John Coplans belongs to the school of Avedon and Arbus, rather than, say, to the school of Fabian and Bradford Bachrach. Or so it would seem from the large, rather grim black and white portraits on view at Daniel Wolf Inc., 30 West 57th Street, through Feb. 28.

title: GARDEN'S BIG FIGHT CARD IS THREATENED BY INQUIRY
description: The beleaguered boxing promotion company Muhammad Ali Professional Sports, Inc. (called Maps), whose chief executive officer has been missing for a week, signed over its rights to yesterday's world championship bantamweight fight in Philadelphia to its co-promoter. Also the Maps bank account has been frozen by the Wells Fargo branch in Beverly Hills, Calif., that is investigating a possible embezzlement of ''millions of dollars.''

title: Evangelicals Get; Inspiration and; Warnings, Too
description: They came to show their unity but found themselves divided. Still, the thousands of Christian evangelicals who gathered for a joint convention in Washington last week went undeterred about planning new conquests, both political and spiritual.

title: Columbia 71, Dartmouth 57
description: Vernon Outlaw scored 22 points and grabbed 13 rebounds tonight in leading Columbia to a 71-57 Ivy League victory over Dartmouth.

title: FROM CAVALLI TO CABARET WITH JAN DE GAETANI
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about the performing arts. By ALLAN KOZINN

title:
COMMENT;
SCIENTISTS IN BUSINESS
description: In our groping efforts to cope with America's steadily worsening productivity problem, American business is ignoring one of the greatest resources at its disposal - the country's vast reservoir of highly trained scientists.

title: Monica St. Leger Sings Dual Repertory
description: Monica St. Leger, who appeared Jan. 22 at the Abraham Goodman House concert hall, had a curious voice: a soprano whose size seemed constrained as much by a lack of robust breath support as by any inherent limitations. She sang in a fragile way, floating some lovely, tiny pianissimos on top and coloring the voice somewhat monochromatically with a delicate, quick vibrato.

title: COMPANY CAR POOLS SEEM HERE TO STAY
description: MATRIMONY was an unexpected result of the 3M Corporation's employee ride-sharing program. Two recently widowed employees of the giant Minnesota company met, became friends and eventually married through their van-pooling group.

title: TWO SOUTH AFRICANS STIR MILLROSE DISPUTE
description: Last October a black South African, Matthews Motshwarateu, won the Diet Pepsi national 10-kilometer road racing championship in Purchase N.Y. The race was sanctioned by The Athletics Congress, America's governing body for the sport.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1981
description: International Most Polish workers called off strikes following an agreement between the Government and the independent union Solidarity that provides a 40-hour, five-day workweek next year and several nonworking Saturdays this year. The union will also be allowed to present its views on the Government-owned radio and television system. (Page 1, Col. 6.) A sharp reduction in foreign aid for developing countries proposed by David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, has disturbed the Western allies and is regarded by diplomats and members of Congress as an early test of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s foreign policy leadership. (1:5.)

title: PLAN FOR EVACUATING AREA NEAR NUCLEAR PLANTS ASSAILED
description: A plan for evacuating the area around the Indian Point nuclear plants in case of an accident was sharply criticized by officials and the public at its first public hearing this week. Afterward, Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, urged a Federal agency to hold up approval until there were major revisions in the plan.

title: Bridge; PLAYING THE PENALTY
description: Perhaps 99 players out of 100 know what a penalty card is: A defender's card that has been exposed to view in some irregular way. But not one in a hundred could correctly state the penalty. It is true that the card must be left exposed and must be played at the first legal opportunity, but there is more to it than that, as the diagramed deal from the world women's team championship last fall in Valkenburg, the Netherlands reveals.

title: BIG ATOM WASTE SITE REPORTED FOUND NEAR BUFFALO
description: The Army and a defense contractor dumped more than 37 million gallons of radioactive caustic wastes from the World War II atomic bomb project in shallow wells at Tonawanda, N.Y., near Buffalo, between 1944 and 1946, a New York State toxic waste task force reported yesterday.

title: CENSUS INDICATES MANY INCREASES FOR URBAN AREAS
description: Although many central cities in the industrial North suffered sharp population declines in the 1970's, new figures from the 1980 census provide a far less bleak picture of the health of the metropolitan areas that surround them.

title: Mary Catherine Hicks Engaged
description: Mary Catherine Hicks and David Ivanovitch Obolensky plan to be married March 21. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Thomas Hicks of Nashville, parents of the future bride.

title: Cuban Offenders Get a Reprieve
description: Altogether, the 1,700 Cuban refugees being held in Federal prisons around the country either have been convicted of or have admitted committing, in Cuba, 544 robberies, 20 armed robberies, 473 thefts, 333 burglaries, 222 assaults, 121 homicides, 61 narcotics violations, 39 cases of arson and 11 prostitution offenses. Nevertheless, there were indications last week that the Justice Department is planning to let at least some of them resettle here.

title: CALIFORNIA STARTING '82 GOVERNOR RACE
description: Tom Bradley, whose father was a Texas sharecropper and whose mother worked as a domestic, has begun a campaign to win his third term as Mayor of Los Angeles. Few people here expect him to lose and many expect him to use his office as a base to run for Governor of California next year.

title: MURDOCH IS GAINING IN BID TO BUY PAPER
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher of The New York Post and other newspapers, is making good progress with his bid to buy The Times of London and its affiliated publications.

title: The Feel of Space Travel in a Porsche 935
description: When the Penthouse Momo Porsche 935 exits the first infield turn on the road course of the Daytona Speedway, the result simulates the leap to hyper-space in ''Star Wars.''

title: Reagan Plans Addresses On Economic Problems
description: President Reagan plans to deliver a televised address Thursday seeking to focus national attention on the economy, a White House official said today.

title: Mugabe Defuses a; Political Land Mine
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe again demonstrated his political dexterity last week, writing a compromise ending to a 17-day political crisis. He returned at least nominal responsibilities for defense and security matters to Joshua Nkomo, his rival but junior partner in the Government coaliton. As Minister Without Portfolio, Mr. Nkomo also will assist in ''tasks which require special handling in the national interest,'' Mr. Mugabe said.

title: FREED HOSTAGES CAPTIVES OF JOY
description: ''IT'S so good to be able to go outside without handcuffs or a towel over your head,'' an ex-hostage, Marine Sgt. Rodney V. Sickmann, said. Soon he may be able to show his face without attracting crowds and confetti. But not last week. The sergeant and the 51 other former hostages - back in America after 444 days as Iranian prisoners - were captive guests of honor at a coast-to-coas t party.

title:
Gardening;
FORCED BULBS BRING A HINT OF SPRING
description: IF the recent frigid weather hasn't whet your appetite for the return of spring, nothing will. One of the best cures for the midwinter blahs is to have something cheerful and spring-like blooming around the house.

title: Kentucky 71, Georgia 68
description: Jim Master, a freshman, put Kentucky ahead to stay with a basket from the corner early in the second overtime period and then hit two free throws with 18 seconds left as the Wildcats defeated Georgia, 71-68, today in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: About Long Island
description: THIS is a tale of two cities, one out here, one over there to the west. Midwinter. The Island has been having a normal winter. The Long Island Rail Road has been smitten by those mysterious stoppages euphemistically called 15-minute delays on the Port Washington line. The talk is of how one wishes the temperature would rise like - even instead of - the heating bills. The kids have come and gone from the holiday vacations and the bleak season is in full swing.

title: Politics; KRAMER AND KEAN: A SHIFT IN EMPHASIS
description: THOMAS H. KEAN of Livingston, the former Assembly Speaker, and Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer of Paterson joined the race for the Republican nomination for Governor at virtually the same time last week. Both sounded very much alike, but sported new semi-conservative images.

title: Food; CHINESE NEW YEAR:HAPPY EATING
description: MOST people do not require a special occasion to have Chinese food. In fact, judging from the crowds waiting for tables at the Island's Chinese restaurants on Sunday evenings, a Chinese dinner may be a weekly routine in some families. This week and next, to celebrate the Chinese New Year, it will be especially appropriate.

title: Carole Forrey Engaged To Christopher Garvey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Forrey of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carole Jane Forrey, to Christopher M. Garvey, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Garvey of Stanton, Del.

title: Jessica Robins Fiancee Of Peter Miller, Designer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Robins of Riverdale, the Bronx, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jessica Robins, to Peter Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip M. Miller of Rochester. A wedding in September is planned.

title: Sarah McCarty Fiancee of Peter Solmssen
description: The engagement of Sarah Elizabeth McCarty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Reed McCarty of Louisville, Ky., to Peter York Solmssen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R.G. Solmssen of Bryn Mawr, Pa., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: TEST FOR HAIG SEEN IN DISPUTE OVER AID
description: A Cabinet-level dispute in the Reagan Administration over proposed reductions in foreign aid has become an early test of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s foreign policy leadership, diplomats and members of Congress said today.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Reached agreement w ith Tommy Boggs, pitcher, on a one-year c ontract. BALTIMORE (AL) - Reached agree- m ent with Kiko Garcia, infielder, on a one- y ear contract. HOCKEY TORONTO (NHL) - Acquired Rene Rob- e rt, right wing, from Colorado for future c onsiderations.

title: THE CASBAH IS CAVING IN, BUT RESTORATION PROJECTS ARE FACING MANY PROBLEMS
description: The Casbah, with its maze of cobblestone stairs and alleys, windowless homes and flat, connecting roofs, is crumbling.

title: Dr. Philip Glick to Marry Dr. Drucy S. B. Borowitz
description: Rabbi Eugene B. Borowitz and Dr. Estelle Borowitz of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Drucy Sarette B. Borowitz, to Dr. Philip Leon Glick. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Glick of Encino, Calif.

title: LIFE IN AN OCEAN PRESSURE COOKER
description: David Abrahamson is a freelance writer. By David Abrahamson Nine days ago, three men climbed inside a cramped compression chamber at Duke University, planning not to re-emerge until the end of this month, or perhaps early March. They are preparing to proceed to the frontiers of experimental science, and then perhaps even further, out beyond the knowns and givens of physics and physiology. And the direction they are headed - although they will not descend an inch -is ''down.'' If everything has gone according to plan, the chamber will have been pressurized until it reached a simulated underwater ''depth'' of 2,132 feet early last Thursday evening. And since Friday morning the men will have been performing a complicated series of physiological and neurological tests to determine how well they are standing up under the crushing pressure.

title: EASTPORT ASKS TO JOIN SOUTHAMPTON TOWN
description: EASTPORT THE residents of this rural hamlet that straddles two towns are challenging the recent denial by the Brookhaven Town Board of their request to let its western portion secede from Brookhaven and become a part of the Town of Southampton.

title: A STORMY MARKET BUFFETS DEALERS
description: AS Detroit's much-celebrated smaller, more fuel-efficient automobiles began rolling off assembly lines last fall, many new-car dealers voiced cautious optimism that the severe downturn in the automobile market had finally ''bottomed out.''

title: Long Islanders; MEETING A CHALLENGE:WRITING JINGLES
description: SHELTON LEIGH PALMER of Huntington turns 23 next Friday. And all he's done so far, he says, is play everything from the clarinet to the synthesizer, compose, perform in - and book -bands, study accounting, graduate from film and television school, work for a leading jingle writer, turn out tunes for the likes of Tootsie Rolls and Vicks Formula 44 and organize a couple of music businesses, the latest being Shelton Leigh Palmer & Company, which produces music for films, television and radio.

title: Wagner 119, Hunter 78
description: Howard Thompkins scored 29 points, shooting 14 of 18 from the floor, to lead Wagner College to a 119-78 rout of Hunter yesterday at Sutter Gymnasium, Grymes Hill, Staten Island.

title: RISE OF SMALL CARS ADDS TO SHOWROOM JARGON
description: DEALERS always have new names and phrases to bat about at the start of a new model year, but the jargon of the showroom in this year of the small car is apt to confuse salesmen as well as customers.

title: 20 West Berliners Are Held In Protest Over Housing
description: The police here battled youths protesting a city housing shortage in the second straight day of demonstrations and arrested at least 20 people, the authorities said.

title: PLANE SKIDS, SHUTTING LA GUARDIA
description: La Guardia Airport was closed late last night after the right landing gear of an Eastern Airlines plane from Miami collapsed while the aircraft was taxiing down a main runway, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration reported.

title: Physician to Marry Dr. Carolyn Riester
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hubert A. Riester of New Hope, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Carolyn E. Riester, to Dr. William H. O'Connor. Both are third-year residents in internal medicine at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: Miss Vincent Wed To Anthony Seton
description: The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Lesley Anne Vincent to Anthony Mitchell Seton, both of Mill Valley, Calif. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
WHY INDEXING WAS A BIG MISTAKE
description: I T started slowly. In 1962, the Civil Service and military pension systems were indexed to the Consumer Price Index. Total outlays for the programs amounted to $2 billion or 1.9 percent of the total Federal budget. After that, indexing proceeded gradually -until it took a giant leap forward in 1975 with the implementation of indexing for the Social Security System. By 1980, $173.5 billion of outlays, or 29.9 percent of the budget, was linked to one or another price index and the proportion can be expected to rise in the future.

title: Kathleen Rafferty Bride of Executive
description: Kathleen Rice Rafferty and George D.F. Lamborn, senior managing director of Shearson, Loeb Rhoades, were married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church. The Rev. Hays Hamilton Rockwell performed the ceremony.

title: Long Island Journal
description: ALARMED by the increased number of thefts of religious articles from their houses of worship, rabbis in the Five Towns are studying a plan to inscribe special markings on the articles to make them easily identifiable if stolen.

title: Base Scholarships On Athletic Ability
description: To the Sports Editor: I cannot agree with the Rev. Edmund P. Joyce's position that sports scholarships should be reserved solely for those young men capable of doing college work. While enforcing such a requirement might be a way to restore the reputation of the various universities tainted by recent scandals, it threatens to exclude from the professional sports ranks those athletes who, due to their background, interests or lack of native intelligence, simply cannot succeed at academic endeavors, and for whom sports are the only realistic opportunity for upward social mobility.

title: RECALLS PRESENT A VARIETY OF PITFALLS FOR CONSUMERS
description: NOTHING can take the joy out of car ownership faster than the hassle and expense of frequent repairs. Sometimes the car has a chronic problem despite the best attempts to fix it, or a letter may suddenly arrive warning of a potentially hazardous problem with the car that the owner never suspected.

title: Reattached Limbs
description: Manuel Escobar, a 30-year-old lifeguard at a Manhattan athletic club, had his legs cut off by a subway train in July 1979. A surgical team at Bellevue Hospital reattached them after removing damaged bone and tissue.

title: Connecticut Guide; by Eleanor Charles; BIRD LECTURE BY PETERSON
description: Roger Tory Peterson, whose system for identifying birds is credited with making avid bird-watchers of thousands of Americans, will give a slide-lecture on Connecticut birds at 2:30 P.M. next Sunday in the Kline Geology Laboratory at Yale University.

title: FORTUNATELY FOR GISCARD, HE'S GOT OPPONENTS
description: The polls disagree: One puts President Valery Giscard d'Estaing slightly ahead of Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist; another puts him slightly behind and a third has them dead even for the April presidential elections.

title: ANDREW J. ROBINS
description: Rabbi Andrew J. Robins, spiritual leader at Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I., for 27 years until he retired in 1977, died Thursday after a long illness at his home in Searingtown, L.I. He was 68 years old.

title: RANGERS END TRIP BY BEATING NORTH STARS
description: It was almost no contest tonight as the Rangers dominated from start to finish and walloped the Minnesota North Stars, 7-3, in the Met Center before a capacity crowd of 15,595.

title: FIBAK AND TANNER REACH FINAL
description: Wojtek Fibak of Poland and Roscoe Tanner eliminated two French semifinalists today and advanced to tomorrow's final of the $250,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis championships.

title: RELATING TONAL QUALITY AND PRICE IN BUYING A CARTRIDGE
description: Having delved - or at least dipped - into theoretical aspects of cartridge design last week, let's now leap from theory to practice for a closer look at recent entries into this fiercely competitive field.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS PARADE IN SHADOW OF 52 HOSTAGES
description: Several hundred veterans of the Vietnam War marched today in counterpoint to the heroic reception of the former American hostages, expressing the wounded feelings of many Vietnam veterans around the country and offering themselves the parade they said nobody gave them when they came home from war.

title: Defense Costs
description: To the Business Editor: A procurement practice not mentioned in ''Why Defense Costs So Much'' (Jan. 11) concerns the Buy American strictures of the Defense Appropriations Act. These virtually exclude imports from defense procurement of textiles, food and specialty metals.

title: Social Security
description: To the Business Editor: In ''How to Reform Social Security'' (Jan. 11) Prof. Michael J. Boskin proposes that we extend the entry age of Social Security recipients by a month per year for 36 months, or three years in all - to 68 from 65 years.

title: A Pragmatic Choice; Saves Miss Jiang
description: Perhaps fearing she would be more dangerous dead than alive, China's leaders sent Jiang Qing back to prison last week. As the curtain finally fell on the Peking show trials of leaders of Mao Zedong's Cultural Revolution, his widow, defiantly shouting ''to rebel is justified,'' received a suspended death sentence.

title: No Headline
description: OREGON STATE STAYS UNBEATEN, WINS 17TH

title: PROSPECTS
description: Addressing the Economy

title: MEANING OF ALBANY CAUCUS RIFT UNCLEAR
description: A week after declaring that ''conflict is often constructive,'' State Senator Vander L. Beatty led six members of the New York State Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus in removing themselves from the organization's letterhead this week and forming a separate minority coalition.

title: A CLOSE SAVE: Rod Schutt of the Pittsburgh Penguins trying to slide a
description: goal in the back door. Dave Parro, goalie of the Washington Capitals, made the save.

title: WINTER: THE CHAPPED LIPS FACTOR
description: It's probably as good a gauge of cold winters as the thermometer. Chap Stick, almost a generic antidote for parched lips, is enjoying a boom.

title: THE REAGAN SHOW
description: The Reagan Show has been in dress rehearsal these last few days, and not surprisingly, the performance has been a little rough.

title: Making Maps to The Human Cell
description: ''The proper study of mankind is man,'' said Alexander Pope, but it's easier said than done; nevertheless, in an ambitious project now under way at the Argonne National Laboratory near Chicago, Drs. Norman G. and Leigh Anderson, a father and son team of scientists, have set out to identify, catalogue and eventually provide a description of each of the 50,000 or so protein products that constitute the working parts of human cells.

title: THEATER: 'GINGHAM DOG' BY WILSON IS REVIVED
description: Lanford Wilson's ''The Gingham Dog'' was presented on Broadway in 1969, when it lasted only five performances, and scarcely has been around since then. It was written before Mr. Wilson became celebrated - ''The Hot l Baltimore'' was done in 1973 -and it is very much a play of the 60's. A young black woman finds militancy; a good old boy from Kentucky grows disillusioned, and an interracial marriage fails. Fortunately, Mr. Wilson wrote about this without sentimentality and with only the smallest trace of cant, and fortunately ''The Gingham Dog'' has been revived at the Network Theater.

title: Hofstra 102, Stony Brook 61
description: David Taylor scored 25 points and pulled down 16 rebounds to lead Hofstra to a 102-61 victory over Stony Brook today.

title: U.S. AGENCY INHERITS A PLAN FOR IMPROVING AUTO SAFETY
description: JOAN CLAYBROOK, the most active director of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in the agency's short history, left the Reagan Administration a parting gift last month: a five-year plan for new auto industry regulations.

description: Peru vows to expel Ecuadorean 'intruders' 3 Poland plans to review case of ar- rested U.N. employee 3 Around the World 4 Greece and U.S. begin talks on new defense pact 6 Koreans in U.S. title: SEMINAR ADVISES WOMEN ON CAREERS WITH THE CITY
description: Anne Sabatino was a secretary for the New York City Housing Authority, but she felt her career in local government was not going anywhere. Frustrated by the lack of opportunities for advancement and the fact that she earned less than blue-collar workers, she traded in her ''jewelry and pretty clothes'' for ''the baggy blue uniform of a housing fireman.''

title: No Headline
description: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova overcame several poor service games tonight to post a 6-3, 7-5 victory over third-seeded Wendy Turnbull and advance to the final of the $200,000 Avon women's tennis tournament.

title:
Art;
AN UNREALIZED AIM IN A LOOK AT GIANTS
description: ROSLYN HARBOR TRACING the genesis of a movement as diverse and sometimes even as contradictory as Abstract Expressionism is an ambitious undertaking, even for an institution as rich in exemplary holdings as, say, the Museum of Modern Art. For the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art to undertake it, with no collection to draw on and dependent solely on loans, is ambitious in the extreme.

title: Stage View; CALDWELL'S 'MACBETH'- MORE SHOW THAN SENSE
description: Whenever a new manager or a new director takes over the stage of the Vivian Beaumont at Lincoln Center, the first thing he does is try to solve the problems of the Beaumont. This, I suggest, is precisely the wrong thing to do. Only an architect will ever solve the problems of the Beaumont, stage and auditorium alike, and there'll never be money enough for that until something at the Beaumont has actually succeeded. If anything is finally going to succeed at the Beaumont, it'll be because the new people in charge have tried to solve the problems of the play immediately at hand. First you have to lick ''Macbeth,'' which is hard to do in any theater, and then you can start to worry about the cramped seats, the ambiguous apron, the wraparound audience that doesn't wrap itself around the actors, and all that.

title: Myra Kestenbaum, Violist, Plays Bach and Brahms
description: The viola recital Myra Kestenbaum gave in Alice Tully Hall on Monday night was her debut, but she was not a fledgling performer. She had been principal violist of the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra for seven years under Neville Marriner until her resignation last year to pursue a solo career. She has performed on the West Coast and has been on the faculty of the San Francisco Conservatory.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: EDMUND WILSON Our Neighbor From Talcottville. By Richard Hauer Costa. Illustrated. 173 pp. Syracuse: Syracuse University Press. $11.95.

title: ROUTE 25 REFLECTS L.I.'S DEVELOPMENT
description: COMMACK NEARLY everything that's old, new, good or bad about the Island is reflected along Route 25, including uncertainty about its future in a gloomy economy.

title: Review Paperbacks; New and Noteworthy
description: THE FINE ARTS IN AMERICA, by Joshua C. Taylor. (University of Chicago Press, $7.95.) The progress of painting, sculpture and the graphic arts in the United States from their pre-colonial origins to the present. This thoughtful survey by the director of the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American Art centers on the leading practitioners and the forces that affected their work. The 250 marginal black-and-white illustrations were chosen to document the text.

title: CARTER ASSOCIATES STILL UNDER INQUIRY
description: While Jimmy Carter's Presidency has expired, Government investigators have still not completed three separate criminal inquiries involving close associates of the former President and his brother Billy.

title: N.H.L. All-Stars; AT INGLEWOOD, CALIF.  FEB. 10,; CONFERENCE ROSTERS Prince of Wales
description: Goal - Don Beaupre, Minnesota; M ario Lessard, Los Angeles. Defense - Mark Howe, Hartford; L arry Robinson, Montreal; Randy Car- l yle, Pittsburgh; Borje Salming, Toronto; R ay Bourque, Boston; Bill Hajt, Buffalo.

title: Elizabeth Virginia Knick Wed
description: Elizabeth Virginia Knick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Knick of Danville, Va., and Jonathan Seth Brooks, son of Ruth Brooks of Jamaica, Queens, and the late Aaron Brooks, were married yesterday. Rabbi Ralph Silverstein, the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: CHANDLER OUTPOINTS LUJAN TO KEEP TITLE
description: Jeff Chandler peppered Jorge Lujan with a variety of head shots and retained the World Boxing Association bantamweight championship on a unanimous 15-round decision today.

title: Janine Drucker Is Fiancee
description: The engagement of Janine Amara Drucker to Donald Gary Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Gordon of Schenectady, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Gindin of Plainfield, N.J., and her father, Dr. William D. Drucker of Milwaukee.

title: WEATHERING STORMS OVER INDIAN POINT
description: AFTER another unfavorable ruling last week on Consolidated Edison's operation of Indian Point 2, Joyce Hergenhan, the utility's senior vice president for public affairs, was asked how management was taking the nuclear plant's problems. In her view, she replied, there have been worse periods - specifically a financial crisis in 1974 and the 1977 blackout.

title: MINDING THE AILING A. &. P.
description: T HE blood is still being spilled at the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, that faded giant of supermarkets struggling to return to profitability. Last week, the company that was once the nation's biggest food chain said it was dropping 100 of its 550 employees at its headquarters in Montvale, N.J. It has already shut down some 1,900 stores over the last five years and has lost $56 million in that period. And the losses continue - $13.9 million in the third quarter last year and another, as yet unspecified loss in the fourth quarter.

title: Charles Fisk, Pianist, Plays Schubert, Bartok
description: Music audiences should take note of Charles Fisk, a young pianist who made his debut at the Abraham Goodman House last Sunday evening. Mr. Fisk has an unusually intelligent musical mind and an impressive ability to transmit his feelings.

title: HOW SYLVAN TERRACE RECAPTURED ITS 19TH CENTURY CHARM
description: If Mme. Jumel's ghost still steps out on her Jumel Terrace balcony, as legend says, she must now be sneaking extra peeks at what has happened to Sylvan Terrace, once the carriage lane leading from the 1765 Morris-Jumel Mansion to the Albany Post Road.

title: THE RUSSIA REAGAN FACES
description: The Soviet Union that Ronald Reagan faces as he and his advisers sit down in the Oval Office to map American strategy for the 1980's may be less formidable than he thought. But this is not necessarily a cause for rejoicing. Greater dangers may arise from debilitating Soviet weaknesses than from supposed Soviet military might.

title: GUN CONTROL: IS IT TIME FOR IT?
description: THE year 1980 ended on a tragic note, thanks to handguns. Dr. Michael Halberstam, a Washington physician, writer and TV commentator, and John Lennon, the most famous member of the Beatles, were murdered in December.

title: Military Analysis
description: The advent of a new Administration in Washington finds the Navy deploying power on three oceans and the Mediterranean Sea with forces that senior officers regard as barely adequate for a one-and-a-half-ocean fleet.

title: Headliners; Hot Potato
description: It could have been worse. Rather than calling him home for ''consultations,'' the State Department could have left Robin Berrington to cook in the Irish stew he created last week with a personal letter that somehow turned up in the Irish Times. Mr. Berrington, cultural affairs officer in Dublin, described Ireland as, among other things, ''an isolated provincial country'' and ''pretty small potatoes.'' Ambassador William Shannon, by way of apology, said, ''The Irish are famous for their sense of humor, and I think I shall have to rely on it in this instance.''

title: First U.S. Weather Satellite Sent To a 'Scrap Heap' in Upper Orbit
description: The SMS-1 weather satellite, which gave East Coast television forecasters their first cloud map pictures, has become the first United States weather unit to be parked in an upper orbit ''scrap heap.''

title: NORDIQUES CONQUER ISLANDERS FIRST TIME
description: The Quebec Nordiques finally got their act together against the New York Islanders tonight, and the plot contained a number of surprises. The main one was that the Nordiques, next to last in the National Hockey League points race, beat the Islanders, 5-1, for the first time in their history.

title: NOTEBOOK:A RELAXED MRS. HARRIS ON STAND
description: ON the second day of Jean S. Harris's testimony last week, in the 12th-floor courtroom of the Westchester County Courthouse, at least one spectator, a woman in a white sweater, was thinking ahead.

title: BUS DRIVERS ARE ALERTED TO 'HIDDEN' HANDICAPS
description: A training film being shown to bus drivers at the Surface Transit Training Center in upper Manhattan features the following dialogue between an agitated passenger and a patient bus driver:

title: ATHLETES WITH INJURED KNEES FIND SHORT CUT ON ROAD TO RECOVERY
description: When Ray Chester of the Oakland Raiders suffered torn cartilage in his left knee while running a pass pattern in the end zone last season, he anticipated a painful operation and a long recovery. To the tight end's delight, however, he started exercising the day after surgery, and two weeks later caught a touchdown pass in New Orleans.

title: A DOGRIB BIBLE, 'ENITL'E-CHO,' TAKES SHAPE IN CANADA
description: Herb Zimmerman Nohtsi enitl'e-cho dok'e wots'ikw'o ha tlichoyati k'alaiwo. Or to put it another way, Herb Zimmerman is translating the Bible into an Indian language, Dogrib. Translating the Bible into another tongue is a difficult assignment in itself. Mr. Zimmerman must also translate the Bible into another culture, one in which, among other things, kings and ceremonial footwashings and even shepherds are utterly foreign.

title: Dance View; THE CLEVELAND BALLET REFLECTS ITS ORIGINS
description: With the New York debut of the five-year-old Cleveland Ballet in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's ''Ballet America'' season, a certain pattern has begun to emerge and one suspects it will hold true for other companies in the series. In each case, each troupe has revealed the line of American ballet from which it is descended.

title: Thomas Nyfenger, Flutist, Plays Paganini and Bach
description: Debuts usually introduce new performers. Thomas Nyfenger, on the other hand, has played with distinction in various New York orchestras and chamber groups since 1963.

title: THE SOCIAL COSTS OF BUSING FOR DESEGREATION
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Dancing' the Meringue
description: As an Australian temporarily living in the United States, I read the article on meringue with mixed pleasure (''Doing the Meringue,'' by Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey, Dec. 21).

title: Mary Smyth Duffy Affianced to David Bain
description: Dr. and Mrs. John L. Duffy of Laurel Hollow, L.I., and Andes, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Smyth Duffy, to David Haward Bain, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Bain of Port Washington, L.I. A wedding is planned for June 6.

title: Fire Death Rates
description: In Large Cities Deaths per million persons, 1974-77 average. Excludes transportation fire deaths and deaths of nonresidents. Source: National Center for Health Statistics. 1 NEWARK64.8 2 BIRMINGHAM, Ala.59.8 3 BOSTON58.5 4 CLEVELAND54.0 5 LOUISVILLE, Ky. 53.6 6 BALTIMORE 53.1 7 ATLANTA 52.8 8 PHILADELPHIA 49.9 9 CHICAGO 49.5 10 BUFFALO 47.3 11 WASHINGTON 46.3 12 JERSEY CITY 45.1 13 DETROIT 44.8 14 PORTLAND, Ore. 44.1 15 SAN FRANCISCO 42.9 TULSA, Okla. 42.9 16 MEMPHIS 42.7 17 PITTSBURGH 42.5 18 OKLAHOMA CITY 42.3 19 FORT WORTH 40.5 20 INDIANAPOLIS 39.2 21 CINCINNATI 38.7 TOLEDO, Ohio 38.7 22 ST.

title: Home Clinic; HOW TO REMOVE WALLPAPER THAT HAS BEEN PAINTED
description: STRIPPING old wallpaper that has been in place for many years - often required before a new covering can be hung or because the old paper is finally starting to let go - is usually a time-consuming job that becomes particularly frustrating when the paper has been painted.

title: SMELT AND HARD TIMES REVIVE 'TOWN' ON LAKE OF ICE
description: Smeltania, a town built all on ice, was born in the Great Depression of the 1930's and died in the affluent 50's. It has been resurrected in the current recession.

title: PRELIMINARY STUDY TRACES COURSE OF FATAL MGM BLAZE
description: On the morning of Nov. 21, hundreds of guests in the 26-story MGM Grand hotel and casino in Las Vegas, Nev., slowly became aware of a fire ''by smelling smoke or seeing smoke, hearing people yelling or, eventually, helicopters flying around the building,'' according to a preliminary report by a team of Federal, local and private investigators.

title: An Airline Seeks Help From Above
description: When the Federal Aviation Administration two weeks ago extended the deadline for meeting new ozone limitations in aircraft to February 1982, many domestic carriers already were installing catalytic converters in their engine-powered air-conditioning systems. And they were calculating costs.

title: Dining Out; A GOOD PLACE TO SAMPLE SUSHI
description: TAIKO, a Japanese restaurant in Rockville Centre, has the friendliest sushi bar on the Island. For anyone who is unfamiliar with sushi or shashimi and is interested in sampling these Japanese raw fish delicacies, Taiko's sushi bar would be a good place to start.

title: HOW DO OUR CHILDREN LEARN?
description: THE never-ending search for what is best for youngsters in the constantly changing elementary curricula continues to reveal more and more of less and less. There is not much evidence to indicate what cycle we are in after evolving around the ''solutions'' of ''departmentalization, team-teaching, nongradenness, continuous progress, individually prescribed programs, open space, I.T.A.,'' and so on. Every new idea, new approach has been able to carry with it groups of educational leaders who have jumped on these ideas if for no other reason than to be innovative.

title: Westchester Housing; STAYING WARM AND SOLVENT TOO
description: HOMEOWNERS are spending more for heat and trying to use less of it, and in this year's record cold many are pondering the best fuel to use and how much they can conserve without damaging their homes.

title: CONCERT: ROSTROPOVICH IN PENDERECKI 'TE DEUM'
description: Rarely does a work speak so powerfully at first hearing as Krzysztof Penderecki's ''Te Deum'' did in its New York premiere in Carnegie Hall on Friday night. Mstislav Rostropovich led the National Symphony Orchestra and Robert Shafer's Oratorio Society of Washington in a performance that completly overshadowed Yehudi Menuhin's earlier contemplative performance of Beethoven's Violin Concerto. ''Te Deum'' seemed a major work of the human spirit, passionately asserting moral and physical claims.

title: PRESENTING MCCANN & NUGENT
description: Elin Schoen, author of ''Tales of an All-Night Town,'' is at work on a novel. By Elin Schoen Hume Cronyn stared at his pipe. He was trying to describe Nelle Nugent and her partner, Elizabeth I. McCann. Finally, he said, ''I had lunch with Sam Cohn today. He's a very important agent with I.C.M. And Sam said to me that Liz and Nelle are among the greatest Broadway producers ever.''

title: AUTHOR, JOURNALIST AND HISTORIAN
description: Roger Place Butterfield, a historian and journalist, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Hartwick, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: ChamberSong Quartet Presents Handel Arias
description: ChamberSong seems like an appropriately mellifluous name for an ensemble of four young musicians who together offer an unusual but beguiling combination of sonorities: Anni Baker, soprano; Linda Chesis, flutist; David Krakauer, clarinetist, and Joyce Lindorff, harpsichordist and pianist. Because Miss Lindorff was indisposed last Tuesday night, Robert Kopelson acted as her able deputy at ChamberSong's concert in the Abraham Goodman House.

title: PART OF HOMECOMING WAS A 'NEED FOR HEROES'
description: WASHINGTON FROM Olyphant, Pa., to San Diego, the cheers were thunderous, the tears were genuine, the emotions were unabashed and overflowing. People stood on cars and fences and shouted themselves hoarse at the passing motorcades or wept by their television sets. In their homes and offices, they sang ''God Bless America'' along with President Reagan and Bruce Laingen, the former charge d'affaires in Teheran.

title: Straddles
description: To the Business Editor: William G. Shephard Jr.'s interesting article ''Puts, Calls, and Now Straddles'' (Jan. 25) mentions only the buy side of straddles. The sell side can also be profitable, especially the variation sometimes called the spraddle.

title: Editors' Choice
description: AMBITION, by Joseph Epstein. (E.P. Dutton, $13.95.) An ambitious defense of ambition. JOURNEY AROUND MY ROOM, edited by Ruth Limmer. (Viking Press, $13.95.)

title: A FLOW OF PENSION FUNDS INTO PROPERTIES IS FORESEEN
description: Investment in real estate by pension funds - which currently hold about 1 1/4 percent of their approximately $600 billion worth of assets in property - could more than double in the next few years because of tax legislation passed by Congress and signed into law last December.

title: SUSPECT IN COPTER HIJACKING HAD LOST JAIL VISITOR'S RIGHTS
description: A Legal Aid Society employee accused of hijacking the helicopter used in last Sunday's attempted escape from the Federal detention center in Manhattan had been the subject of an extensive legal battle last year over his right to visit inmates of city prisons.

title: Rhode Island 56, Rutgers 49
description: Rhode Island rattled Rutgers with a zone defense that limited the Scarlet Knights to 19 seconds-half points and scored a 56-49 Eastern Eight victory today.

title: At Home
description: THE furnace died last night, and it's 40 degrees in the kitchen at 6 A.M. I can't find my slippers or the water kettle, and a radio announcer with a terrible cold tells me that there's quite a lot of weather this morning.

title: Art; FROM CAMEL BONES TO DIVERSE 'SENSIBILITIES'
description: PURCHASE THOUGH not in themselves outrageous, Nancy Graves's realistic mockups of camels caused quite a commotion when they first appeared at the end of the 60's. One of the creatures is included in the artist's semi-retrospective that originated in the Albright-Knox Gallery in Buffalo and is now installed at the Neuberger Museum (State University).

title: Michigan 74, Wisconsin 67
description: Mike McGee's 25 points enabled Michigan to recover from a slow start and down Wisconsin, 74-67, today in a Big Ten game.

title: Staten Island 88, Brooklyn 76
description: The College of Staten Island defeated Brooklyn College, 88-76, last night at the loser's court.

title: SCHOOL WILL GROW, COUNTERING TREND
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE ALTHOUGH school enrollment is declining all over the Island, with many institutions consolidating and others restructuring grades, one school district has just voted to build an addition that will convert a high school building into a four-year school. Groundbreaking for the new wing is expected to start by late spring.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This isn't meant to take anything away from the hostages. We just want to remind people that there are guys without arms and legs lying in that hospital right now who never got a parade, and that there are still people missing in Vietnam who may still be alive. Where are the yellow ribbons for them?'' - Gregory Steele, a Vietnam veteran and an organizer of a veterans' march yesterday in Indianapolis. (22:3.)

title: TO CUT BACKLOG, FEDERAL COURT EXPANDS ON L.I.
description: IN an effort to cut back a growing backlog of cases, Federal officials have arranged to rent expanded court space at Hofstra University and are pressing Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato to fill two vacancies on the Eastern District's bench.

THE War of 1812 scarcely had ended when English potters began shipping to Boston, New York, Philadelphia and Charleston cargoes of the colorful Staffordshire tableware that collectors now call Old Blue or Historical Blue. The platters, coffee and tea pots, cups and saucers, tureens and complete dinner sets, all designed especially for the United States market, became the first American collectibles.
