At a time when few traveled extensively, the Historical Blue pieces showed a growing America to Americans.

title: SERVED RIGHTS UNIT
description: Irving Sheu Kee Chin, a lawyer, Chinatown civic leader and the first person of Chinese descent to serve on New York City's Human Rights Commission, died Friday at the age of 50 of a heart attack.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
A VOTE FOR TUNNEY
description: THE cover of the March issue of ''Boxing Today'' carries the titles of seven pieces inside the magazine, and it was the last one that caught the eye first. ''Most Underrated Heavyweight Champion,'' it reads. This had to be Gene Tunney, or so it seemed until the pages were turned to the start of Bill Libby's article. ''Ezzard Charles,'' Libby writes, ''may have been the greatest light heavyweight ever, and he was one of the great heavyweights ... probably the most underrated titleholder in the history of the division.''

title: Maryland 72, Georgia Tech 64
description: Greg Manning scored 11 of his 21 points in the first seven minutes of the second half today, helping Maryland to pull away from Georgia Tech and score a 72-64 Atlantic Coast Conference victory.

title: Miss Oursler, Nurse, Bride
description: Theresa Noel Oursler and Dr. Michael Thomas Rey were married yesterday by Town Justice George M. Bergerman of Orangetown, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Oursler Jr. of Nyack, N.Y. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Rey of Massapequa Park, L.I.

title: FUMBLES AT THE MIKE FILL THE SUPER BOWL
description: I GREW up with Larry Kelley, Tom Harmon and Doc Blanchard, and I know things are more complicated now, what with outside linebackers and wide receivers and blitzes and sacks. But I could not understand what those announcers were talking about during last Sunday's Super Bowl. It isn't my brain; we all know the legs go first.

title: Pro Bowl in Hawaii Again
description: The National Football League Pro Bowl game will return to Honolulu's Aloha Stadium in 1982 for the third straight year. It will be played next Jan. 31.

title: THE MORAL HISTORY OF CZESLAW MILOSZ
description: NATIVE REALM A Search for Self-Definition. By Czeslaw Milosz. Translated by Catherine S. Leach. 300 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $12.95.

title: SOME POSITIVE THINKING ABOUT HARLEM
description: tv pg garisto trimmed --------------------------------------------------------------------- Leslie Garisto is a freelance writer with particular interests in film and television. By LESLIE GARISTO

title: Article 246848 -- No Title
description: A new Grand Prix show jumping event, with $50,000 in prize money, will be held at the Meadowlands Aug. 1 through 2.

title: CONGRESSIONAL FIGHT ON PINELANDS LOOMS
description: WASHINGTON THE first round in what could be a bitter Congressional battle over the Pine Barrens was fought last week when Representative James J. Florio, a strong supporter of the Pinelands Commission's master plan, asked environmentalists to help him beat back efforts to weaken the plan.

title: NEW AT HARVARD: SELF-ASSESSMENT 101
description: T HE son and grandson of chief executives, he was born and raised to lead the major corporation his family had founded. He had never questioned his destiny, and in his early 30's, he decided to cap his training with a degree from the Harvard Business School. He was in for a surprise.

title: FACILITIES AND COSTS AT 7 TOURING CENTERS
description: THE following ski touring centers have some kind of a warming shed, where skiers can purchase refreshments or consume their bag lunches in comfort. It is a good idea to phone ahead to check on snow conditions.

title: No Headline
description: The article on nuclear terrorism prompted me to dig back in my library to refresh my memory of how the late J. Robert Oppenheimer assessed the weapon-detection issue when he testified before the Special Committee on Atomic Energy (United States Senate).

title: WHY THE WORLD DID NOT LISTEN
description: THE TERRIBLE SECRET Suppression of the Truth About Hitler's ''Final Solution.'' By Walter Laqueur. 262 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $12.95.

title: by Gene Lambinus
description: Poignant Pilgrimage Last December, Robert Faurisson, a suspended Lyons University lecturer, published a book in France maintaining that the Holocaust never happened. The German concentration camps, he claimed, were not death camps at all.

title: AN OLD ART CITY'S ANTIQUES FAIR
description: The ancient Tuscan city of Arezzo, with its Roman ruins, medieval walls, Renaissance architecture and incomparable Piero della Francesca murals, has always been a magnet for art lovers. But on the first weekend of every month, when its Piazza Grande is filled with a motley collection of ramshackle furniture, musty paintings and stained silverware, it is a lodestone for connoisseurs, bargain hunters and junk dealers as well.

title: HE WON HIS CRUSADE TOO LATE TO SEE IT
description: MARTIN L. GREENFIELD of Great Neck was a happy man last Dec. 3. He saw himself nearing the end of a long campaign. In another week, he would be going off to Washington to witness the unveiling of the design of a new United States postage stamp, commemorating the Touro Synagogue in Newport, R.I., the oldest existing Jewish house of worship in the country.

title: Hall of Fame Vote Called Outrageous
description: To the Sports Editor: The recent Baseball Hall of Fame voting was not merely cautious, curious and controversial, but outrageous. A total of 168 writers of 401 lacked the objectivity to vote for Juan Marichal.

title: GOLD, THROUGH THICK AND THIN
description: E ACH time the price of gold sinks, as it did last week, the metal's investment value is again questioned by investors, particularly those who bought bullion in the past year as a hedge against inflation.

title: THE VILLIAN OF 'AMADEUS' IN REAL LIFE
description: The name of Antonio Salieri is very much in the air these days, thanks to Peter Shaffer's ''Amadeus.'' In case you are living in Ch'pyangong and missed the news, the Shaffer play is about Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and his rival Antonio Salieri, and much of it is based on fact. Salieri was the court composer in the Vienna of Mozart's day, internationally famous, a prominent teacher, a man universally respected. And yet there was the rumor that Salieri had poisoned Mozart to get rid of him.

title: TENNESSEE SENATOR CAMPAIGNS FOR 1982
description: Senator Jim Sasser was up before dawn recently, traveling through rural Tennessee in the start of an exhausting, 16-hour day campaigning for re-election, as if the voting were next week.

title: Andrea Nemecz, Pianist, Presents Schumann
description: Andrea Nemecz made her New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall late last Sunday afternoon as a winner of Artists International's Young Musicians Auditions. Miss Nemecz hails from Hungary, and since 1976 she has been a piano pupil of Sascha Gorodnitzki at the Juilliard School, where she received her bachelor's and master's degrees.

title: Westchester Guide; by Eleanor Charles; THE CIRCUS IS COMING
description: While Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus advertises itself as the greatest, the Hanneford Circus, which originated in Ireland in 1621 claims to be the oldest. It performs in Westchester at 1 and 4:15 P.M. on Feb. 14, 15 and 16 in the County Center, White Plains.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Jersey Cease-fire In the Crossfire Over Gun Crimes
description: They insist they've both been fighting crime, but that hasn't stopped Governor Byrne and the New Jersey Legislature from tangling with each other as well. Last week, it appeared the Legislature had won.

title: OSHA, E.P.A.
description: To the Business Editor: The most disturbing aspect of ''OSHA, E.P.A.: The Heyday Is Over'' (Jan. 4) is its implicit assumption that the only people who will decide the future of job safety and health are the lobbyists, economists, and politicians. What these people don't say is often more revealing than what they do:

title: Reprieve Granted in Libel Case
description: Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court ordered today that a Louisiana newspaper not be forced to pay a $175,000 libel judgment while it files a formal appeal with the Court. Robert McHale, former city attorney, had won the jury award as a result of an editorial in The Lake Charles American Press.

title: Through the Night, With the Light
description: In the phrase of that Wiesbaden psychiatrist, the mental health of America, too, is ''remarkably good.'' The hostages' wild passage to freedom left the home front giddy; politicians in particular were determined to drag out the celebrations. But there's no sign of rage or depression of the sort that casts everything in dangerous blacks and whites. Americans have kept their sense of reality and of the grays in the world around them. They've enhanced democracy by making heroes of diplomats. The nation is certifiably mature.

title: ISLAND HOPPING ALONG YUGOSLAVIA'S ADRIATIC COAST
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ELAINE B. ULMAN is a freelance writer who lives in Northampton, Mass. By ELAINE B.ULMAN

title: Clubs That Admit Women Lose Use of Jaycees Name
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that the Philadelphia Jaycees and other chapters that admit women may not call themselves Jaycees anymore.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN TUCSON
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- FRANK A. TINKER is a freelance writer who lives in Tucson, Ariz. By FRANK A.TINKER

title: CHINESE NEW YEAR: HAPPY EATING
description: CELEBRATIONS in Connecticut of the Chinese New Year, which begins Thursday, are expected to be quieter than the raucous displays of fireworks that usually mark the occasion in New York City's Chinatown. But the start of the Year of the Rooster is as special a time to the Chinese and Chinese-Americans here as elsewhere, a time to settle debts, patch up quarrels, visit relatives and friends and wipe the slate clean.

title: BBC FILMS IN MARCH AT MODERN MUSEUM
description: The Museum of Modern Art will present 12 films made by the British Broadcasting Corporation from March 16 to March 24.

title: IRAN IS STILL A VERY LIVELY ISSUE IN CONGRESS
description: Printing presses and Xerox machines were working overtime on Capitol Hill in the wake of the return of the 52 Americans held hostage in Iran. The news releases that flooded the House and Senate press galleries used words like ''barbaric'' and ''uncivilized'' to denounce the Iranian Government. Many members of Congress urged President Reagan to renounce immediately the agreement with Iran that had secured the hostages's freedom.

title: Dining Out; FINE SEAFOOD IN UNREFINED SETTING
description: HARTFORD IT isn't every restaurant in Connecticut that can claim - as the Honiss Oyster House Company does - to have served Mark Twain, Babe Ruth, Andre Previn and Steve Martin, or to have the very booth where Buffalo Bill Cody ate regularly when he was in town with his Wild West Show.

title: Emigration Trap
description: Edward D. Lozansky, a physicist in the Soviet Union, had trouble getting work because he was a Jew. He and his wife, Tatyana, decided to leave the country. Officials told them that parental permission was needed. Mrs. Lozansky's father, a Soviet general, declined to consent. That, the Lozanskys said, was how they became ensnared in an emigration trap.

title: Tax Shelters
description: To the Business Editor: My congratulations to Gerald J. Robinson, author of ''Lawyers and Avoiding Taxes'' (Jan. 18). His may be a first! At least it is the first I have noted a lawyer willing to take a public stance on a moral issue involved in the law. It has been my experience that the lawyers usually hide behind the adversary principle they espouse, exempting themselves from making moral judgments - a stand I find deplorable. LEONARD SZERLIP Morristown, N.J., Jan. 19, 1981

title: REP. HOWARD TO TRIM PUBLIC TRANSIT BILL
description: Representative James J. Howard, the senior House authority on public transportation, says he will not renew in this session of Congress last year's fight to pass a large, multiyear mass transit and highway bill.

title:
Antiques;
OLD MILL IN SUSSEX TAKES ON NEW ROLE
description: LAFAYETTE SIX YEARS ago, Don Kihlstrom and his wife, Karen, bought an old brick home on the north side of town here, proceeded to fix it up and sell antiques under the trade name of ''Bogwater Jim.'' What attracted them to this small Sussex County town was an unspoiled, oldfashioned, passed-by quality.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS IN ALBANY SPLIT ON WELFARE INCREASE
description: Breaking with the Republican leadership in the New York State Senate, James L. Emery of Geneseo, the Assembly's Republican leader, announced yesterday that he would oppose an increase in the state's basic welfare grant level.

title: THE MANUFACTURING OF A MONSTER
description: THIRTY-TWO autumns ago, Arthur Stone was tied to a tree in his backyard from 1 to 3 o'clock every afternoon. Arthur was a strange little boy. He never talked, he banged his head against his crib and he often went into rages and bit people.

title: No Headline
description: The Concerned Citizens Association of East Northport, Northport and Greenlawn is a community service group, organized in direct opposition to the Matinecock Court proposal. Our group is to be a watchdog organization for our young community in order to prevent the effects of creeping urbanization on our area. Housing Help Inc. is a local community group with no housing construction experience. It has ''bought'' the experience by joining with National Housing Partnership, which is a for-profit corporation with a significant number of bankers and big business executives on its board of directors. Also, N.H.P. has no experience in building on Long Island; its building experience has been concentrated in innercity areas.

title: WIERATHER CAPTURES CUP DOWNHILL RACE
description: Harti Weirather won his second World Cup downhill ski race of the season today, finishing six-hundredths of a second ahead of Peter Wirnsberger, his Austrian teammate. As a result, Weirather pulled even with Steve Podborski of Canada at the top of the downhill standing, with two races remaining.

title: CAREFREE LUXURY IN ACAPULCO; by Marilyn Bethany
description: s anyone who has ever designed a tropical retreat can attest, it is not easy to do justice to paradise. When Bruce Bierman, a New Yorkbased designer, went to Acapulco to revamp the house shown here, he visited some of the other homes in this international vacation community. He was surprised and disappointed by what he saw. ''Most of the houses fell into one of two camps: stiff in the name of elegance or tacky in the name of informality.''

title: PEOPLE CATCHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: L.S.U. 92, Florida 75
description: Rudy Macklin and Howard Carter combined for 53 points as Louisiana State shook off a sluggish performance and won its 18th straight game tonight, 92-75, over Florida in the Southeastern Conference.

title: St. John's Beats Fordham; Tempers Flare
description: Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's basketball coach who never before displayed anger toward an opposing coach or player, had to be restrained from hitting Tom Penders, the Fordham coach, early in an exciting game at the Rose Hill Gymnasium yesterday.

title:
Gardening;
FORCED BULBS BRING A HINT OF SPRING
description: IF the recent frigid weather hasn't whet your appetite for the return of spring, nothing will. One of the best cures for the midwinter blahs is to have something cheerful and spring-like blooming around the house.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
HOUSING REINVESTMENT BEARING FRUIT
description: MANY theorizers believe that urban revival can take place only if there is a marriage of public and private interests. For the most part, however, there has been more talk than action along these lines.

title: JUVENILE JUSTICE: IF THE SYSTEM WORKS, END IT
description: HOW about a new motto for the juvenile-justice system? I suggest ''If something works, can it'' as appropriate. You say that I should offer some factual examples to substantiate the need for such a motto. How about the recent fate of the State Division for Youth's urban homes in the county?

title: Station Hustlers
description: To the Editor:

title: Sound; RELATING TONAL QUALITY TO THE PRICE OF CARTRIDGES; by Hans Fantel
description: GUIDE p.23

title: Pierre Huybregts, Pianist, Plays Schumann, Liszt
description: A Belgian pianist, Pierre Huybregts, played an enigmatic debut recital at Alice Tully Hall Thursday evening. The more complex passagework in Schumann's ''Symphonic Etudes'' seemed to confuse and even intimidate him; and though any debut is an ordeal, it is a shame that here Mr. Huybregts so often communicated a sense of stress rather than the richness of his subject matter.

title: On the Economy, Old Targets and Renewed Promises
description: Ronald Reagan welcomed his first Prime Minister (Edward P.G. Seaga of Jamaica), gave his first press conference and left for his first weekend at Camp David. To be fair, the big initiative - the Reagan plan for economic revitalization - remains to be detailed (D-Day is now soon after Lincoln's Birthday). But when all else was done and said - including President's promise that his will was not be a ''caretaker government'' - the new Administration's first full week gave a good imitation of hitting the ground running on some else's track.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
O'Neill Loses in Hartford
description: Governor Byrne wasn't the only one who took it on the chin from his legislature last week.

title: Georgetown 69 Nevada-Las Vegas 68
description: Eric Smith hit a pair of free throws with three seconds to play today to put Georgetown ahead to stay in a 69-68 victory over Nevada-Las Vegas.

title: SETTING THE SCENE FOR A LIFE OF CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY CLOSES RESTAURANT A 2D TIME
description: The New York City Department of Health said that a lower Manhattan restaurant, closed for violation of health ordinances, defied an order by reopening without correcting the violations.

title: The Left-Hander's World
description: As author of ''The Natural Superiority of the Left-Hander,'' I was particularly sympathetic to the sinistral complaints of Edward B. Fiske (''Left Rights,'' Dec. 7). Our world was clearly designed by and for right-handers. After years of cataloguing the hundreds of items seemingly devised for the sole purpose of encumbering and humiliating us (corkscrews, turnstiles, wristwatches, apple corers, etc.), I have found only two modern institutions that actually favor left-handers: the game of baseball and highway toll booths. JAMES T. DE KAY, Irvington, N.Y.

title: PIAF'S LIFE AND LOVES MAKE A MUSICAL
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Cliff Jahr is a freelance who writes frequently about the theater. By CLIFF JAHR

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; 9 Salvadorans Are Killed As Police and Leftists Clash

title: COAST GROUPS URGING VIOLENCE FACE CURB
description: Prompted by an outbreak of antiblack and anti-Semitic activity and an apparent rise of Ku Klux Klan and Nazi activity in California, Attorney General George Deukmejian is backing a proposed state law that would outlaw groups that teach and advocate violence.

title: Tracey Lorenze Fiancee Of Anthony Emposimato
description: Mr. and Mrs. George D. Lorenze of Short Hills, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marguerite Tracey Lorenze, to Anthony D. Emposimato of West Orange, N. J., president of American Import and Forwarding Services, a freight-forwarding company at Newark and Kennedy Airports.

title: AS WATER LEVELS FALL, RESTRICTIONS ARE ON THE RISE
description: WITH only about two weeks' supply of water remaining, residents of Port Chester and Rye will get stiff mandatory restrictions placed this week on the use of water, while Westchester County - with an average of 130 days left - has as a whole also adopted civil penalties for water wastage. Voluntary compliance continues in Greenwich, Conn.

title: At Home; by Shelby Moorman Howatt
description: THE furnace died one recent night and it was 40 degrees in the kitchen at 6 A.M. I couldn't find my slippers or the water kettle. A radio announcer with a terrible cold told me there was quite a lot of weather that morning. Gale warnings all over Long Island Sound. Frozen sleet bouncing off the World Trade Center. Gale warnings, frozen sleet, and the beginnings of what may be a major blizzard in the suburbs. The man sounded bouncy despite his cold but he got an even bigger charge out of telling me that ''the kiddies might get to play hookey today.'' This guy deserved pneumonia.

title: TWO WHO ARE 'SUPER SUPERS'
description: If building superintendents can be likened to ship captains, then for Leo Braun and George Banks their quarterdecks are the basements of two Manhattan buildings that have been their separate charges for a combined total of 58 years.

title: By Richard Levine and Don Wycliff; Safety Net for The Disturbed
description: An average of 60 times a day, New York City police receive a call about an emotionally disturbed person. For officers answering these calls, the potential for harm - to the disturbed person and themselves - is great and available tactics are few.

title: Botha Speeds Up; Election Clock
description: Although Prime Minister P.W. Botha has done nothing to alter the basic inequality of South Africa's black majority, his occasional hints that someday he might have provoked a backlash among even more conservative whites. To strengthen his leadership of the ruling National Party against these so-called ''verkramptes,'' Mr. Botha last week scheduled general elections for April 29, 18 months before they are required.

title: SAILING TOWARD SUMMER
description: In the depths of February, it is lovely to fantasize about heading south and spending the rest of the winter basking on the deck of a luxurious yacht.

title: Nuclear terrorism is a frightening prospect
description: NEST's $50 million-ayear program to evaluate and counter such action provides some comfort; however, a major part of its activities involves locating and defining an atomic bomb after a threat has been received with the target city named. But what if the extortion note merely identifies the location as ''a heavily populated urban center''? HERBERT KOMMEL, Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Meadowlands Gets All-Stars
description: The National Basketball Association today awarded its 1982 all-star game to the Meadowlands Arena. The 20,000-seat arena, which will be the home of the Nets, is scheduled for completion in June, and the game will be played Sunday, Jan. 31.

title: ACID RAIN THREATENS PRINCETON'S GARGOYLES
description: PRINCETON OLD, venerable Princeton University may be succumbing at last to the ravages of the industrial revolution, says Prof. Sheldon Judson, chairman of the university's geology department.

title: Alice Marie Bender Fiancee of Thomas Patrick Gibbons
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Bender of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice Marie Bender, to Thomas Patrick Gibbons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Gibbons of Baltimore. A wedding is planned in June.

title: A PLAYWRIGHT'S NOVEL
description: TSOTSI By Athol Fugard. 167 pp. New York: Random House. $8.95.

title: POLITICAL GIVING LED BY NO. 1 EMPLOYER
description: CONNECTICUT'S biggest employer was also the state's largest political contributor in Federal elections last year. In perhaps the ultimate ''giving at the office,'' employees of the vast United Technologies Corporation, which is based in Hartford, contributed through the corporation's political action committee a total of $153,150 to 161 Republican and 60 Democratic candidates for the United States Senate and House of Representatives.

title: TWO NEW PLAYS MAKE THEIR NEW JERSEY DEBUTS IN PRINCETON AND NEW
description: BRUNSWICK By JOSEPH CATINELLA PRINCETON AFEW twists in the first act of Percy Granger's ''Eminent Domain'' are directed with great beauty by Paul Austin. We're in the dusty library of a Middle Western professor who has not had anything published for five years. This eccentric, despairing man is expecting his younger antagonist, a voguish teacher whose field is Elizabethan lore but who actually prefers westerns and murder mysteries.

title: Samuel Payne, Banker, Weds Dr. Dee G. Appley
description: Dr. Dee G. Appley of Greenfield, Mass., a psychotherapist in private practice in Greenfield and an adjunct professor of psychology at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, was married yesterday to Samuel B. Payne of Shelburne, Mass., an advisory director and former president of the investment banking house of Morgan Stanley & Company. The Rev. Stephen D. Howard, minister of All Souls Unitarian church in Greenfield, performed the ceremony at the bride's home.

title: ONE MAYORAL DUTY THAT WAS BREATHTAKING
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: JUILLIARD ORCHESTRA
description: The Juilliard School began its weeklong Festival of Contemporary Music on Friday with a boisterous evening of orchestral music played by the Juilliard Orchestra and conducted by Eleazar de Carvalho.

title: Judith C. Silverman Fiancee of Engineer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Silverman of Cranford, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Carol Silverman, to Lawrence Sletzinger, chief engineer of the Harvard Medical School's ultrasound laboratory in the department of radiology.

title: BYRNE PASSES ELECTION CHANGES
description: Governor Byrne said today that he would not sign a bill to make available money for public financing of gubernatorial candidates unless he could also sign measures calling for an open primary and a runoff election.

title: Explosives Truck Blows Up
description: A truck loaded with explosives blew apart on Route 53, uprooting trees and breaking windows for miles around. Officials said shock waves had been felt 20 miles away. Three firefighters who were about 600 feet from the truck when it exploded Thursday were injured, but none seriously.

title: Drs. Judith Steinberg and H.B. Dean 3d Wed
description: Dr. Judith Ellen Steinberg and Dr. Howard B. Dean 3d, residents in internal medicine at the University of Vermont Medical Center Hospital in Burlington, were married last evening at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Civil Court Judge Charles S. Whitman Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: EXCERPTS FROM JAIL ESCAPE PLAN
description: Following are excerpts from a three-page typed document, titled ''Code Name: Blue Magic,'' that law-enforcement authorities said was found in a 1979 search of the apartment of Thomas McCreary. Mr. McCreary was arrested last week on charges of hijacking a helicopter in an unsuccessful attempt to pluck a prisoner from the roof of the Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan.

title: Wedding Planned By Susan E. Utley
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Dexter Utley 2d of Bedford, N.Y., and Woodford, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Elizabeth Utley, to Bernard Peter McParland Jr., son of Mr. McParland of Rochester, N.H. and Judith C. McParland of North Hampton, N.H.

title: Hard Times And Hopes
description: Eugene Kennedy's article, ''Hard Times in Barberton'' (Dec. 7), gave a fair description of our economic disruptions caused by the closing of Seiberling and slowdowns of smaller companies. He rightly closed on a hopeful note because the general attitude of Barbertonians is to take personal responsibility for their community survival.

title: A LEAK CUTS SHORT ON UNDERCOVER CRIME INVESTIGATION
description: Confidential information about an undercover investigation into organized crime in the New York metropolitan area was divulged to some major targets of the inquiry, abruptly bringing a halt to the clandestine police operation, according to law enforcement authorities.

title: Pro Bowl: Talent, Not Tradition
description: Because it is so much of a team game, pro football has more difficulty in projecting its top players than do baseball or basketball in all-star games. Thus the National Football League's Pro Bowl, since its inception 30 years ago, has had difficulty in attracting attention.

title: DETROIT BATTLES HARD TIMES WITH A HARD SELL OF SMALL CARS
description: ''MOVING the iron'' is what the process of making and selling cars is called in Detroit, and if ever the American automobile industry needed to ship the tonnage, 1981 is the year.

title: AH, THE POETRY READING
description: E all love astounding statistics. For example, every four seconds somebody in the United States is thinking up a Poetry Reading. I am confident that on the whole this is a good thing. Besides, nothing that has its comic side can be all bad.

title:
Dining Out;
AN EXTRAVAGANCE OF INDIAN CUISINE
description: KING MIDAS is the county's second full-scale Indian restaurant, and a very good addition to our culinary resources it seems to be. First of all, ''full-scale'' hardly does it justice: It is an extravaganza of an Indian restaurant, large and theatrical, a fitting counterpart to the amplitude and drama of Indian cooking.

title: Theater; A DETERMINED FORCE FOR SAVING THE SHUBERT
description: NEW HAVEN THE Friends of the New Haven Shubert Theater, a nonprofit corporation chartered by Connecticut, exists solely to raise funds for the renovation and perpetuation of the theater as a historical, cultural landmark, according to Don Gastwirth, its vice president and general counsel.

title: Adelphi 73, Merchant Marine 72
description: KING'S POINT, L.I., Jan. 31 - Steve Donelon, a freshman reserve, hit from the corner with two seconds remaining to give Adelphi a 73-72 victory over the Merchant Marine Academy tonight. Adelphi improved its record to 9-7; the Merchant Marine fell to 6-9.

title: Tremors Continue
description: The admission of the late former Shah of Iran to the United States for medical treatment set off a political earthquake that only recently subsided.

title: TRACING THE GERMAN CONNECTION
description: NINE sites throughout the state are playing host this year to ''The Germans of New Jersey,'' a traveling exhibition of memorabilia that has been designed and developed by the Newark-based New Jersey Historical Society. Financial support was provided by the state's Committee for the Humanities.

title: BOBBY JONES: A FIRST-CLASS SIXTH MAN
description: D ARRYL DAWKINS is in foul trouble and Billy Cunningham calls for Bobby Jones. Julius Erving needs a rest, and the Philadelphia 76ers' coach calls for Bobby Jones. An opposing forward is on a scoring spree and the call goes to Bobby Jones, who has added dimension and style to pro basketball's sixth man.

title: Ralph Evans Performs Various Violin Sonatas
description: Sometimes all the elements of a recital seem securely in place, yet the final impression is still disappointing. Such was the case Jan. 20 at the 92d Street Y, where a young American violinist named Ralph Evans put together an unusual, challenging program, played it fairly well and didn't really make much of a mark.

title: Doubts on Abscam Cloud a Conviction
description: Of the defenses offered in Abscam, former Representative Richard Kelly's was easily the most unusual: He simply was collecting evidence in his own secret inquiry, he said, when he was captured on videotape taking $25,000 from an undercover agent. Last week a Federal jury in Washington found that no more convincing than any other argument, and Mr. Kelly and two co-defendants guilty of conspiracy and bribery.

title: THE NEW COLLECTIVES-REACHING FOR A WIDER AUDIENCE
description: ''Ifound the art scene in Manhattan too closed in,'' says Stefan Eins, a 39-year old artist from Austria who has been living in New York since the 1960's. ''I felt it lacked nourishment, and a broad enough audience. I said, why not move to a really bad area of the city, and see if I can establish a base there.''

title: PERU WARNS ECUADOR ON FURTHER 'INTRUSIONS'
description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry of Peru accused Ecuador today of carrying out an air attack against Peruvian positions on their disputed jungle border and warned of stronger military reprisals if incursions continued.

title: BLANDA TRIBUTE CAPS YEAR OF THE RAIDERS
description: When the Oakland Raiders qualified for Super Bowl XV by winning the American Conference championship in San Diego three weeks ago, George Blanda, huskily trim at 53 years old, shouldered through their noisy locker room to where Jim Plunkett was getting dressed. The old Raider quarterback and kicker who once came back from obscurity, congratulated the young Raider quarterback, who this season came back from obscurity and now wears George Blanda's number.

title: Art; NEW MUSEUM SHOWS SCULPTURES OF STEEL
description: HEMPSTEAD FAMLI, an acronym for the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island, which recently opened here, has done its utmost to do away with the temple image of a museum. Most importantly, its name reduces things to a human level, and, as its name suggests, a family would feel comfortable there.

title: Sheryl Israel, a Legal Aide, Is Fiancee of Barry Spiegel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth M. Israel of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheryl E. Israel, to Barry J. Spiegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Spiegel of Nanuet, N.Y.

title: Philadelphia Transit Violence
description: A gang of 40 to 70 juveniles boarded a Broad Street subway early today, held the doors shut at the next station and robbed and terrorized passengers, the police reported.

title: Neal Karelitz Is Fiance Of Susan J. Lichtenberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan A. Lichtenberg of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Joy Lichtenberg, to Neal Karelitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Karelitz of Boston.

title: AS BUYERS SWITCH TO SMALLER CARS, LIMOUSINE MAKERS FEEL THE PINCH
description: MANUFACTURERS of the posh limousine, the sophisticated armored car and the grim hearse are all feeling the pinch as shifting public tastes, the recession and the energy situation bring changes to their industry.

title: School Employees Vote A Strike in Philadelphia
description: The Philadelphia School District's 4,800 nonteaching employees voted overwhelmingly today to strike, a move that will shut down the city's 280 public schools for the second time in a year.

title: No Headline
description: Sandra Palmer survived tricky winds on the back nine today but took a four-stroke lead after three rounds of the Ladies'Professional Golf Association's $100,000 Deer Creek Classic.

title: THEATER
description: Political theater is a rare commodity on the New York stage. One valuable example, Athol Fugard's ''A Lesson From Aloes,'' a cry of anguish from the conscience of South Africa, has been struggling to survive at the Playhouse Theater.

title: Cathleen Weber Fiancee Of Douglas R. Henning
description: Comdr. Lawrence Kirkwood Weber Jr., U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Weber of Hibernia, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cathleen Laile Weber, to Douglas Raymond Henning, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Valentine Henning of Garden City, L.I.

title: Spanish King Holds Talks On Choice of New Premier
description: King Juan Carlos of Spain held talks with parliamentary leaders today amid indications that a minority in the divided governing party remained opposed to the party's choice of a successor to Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez, who resigned without warning Thursday.

title: Pittsburgh Officer Is Suspended In Incident of Russian Roulette
description: A rookie city policeman has been suspended for five days for allegedly forcing a woman officer to take part in Russian roulette with a service revolver.

title: Home Clinic; HOW TO REMOVE WALLPAPER THAT HAS BEEN PAINTED
description: STRIPPING old wallpaper that has been in place for many years - often required before a new covering can be hung or because the old paper is finally starting to let go - is usually a time-consuming job that becomes particularly frustrating when the paper has been painted.

title: Jan Rise Liss Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour H. Liss of New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jan Rise Liss, to James Littlefield Coddington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Parker L. Coddington of Sudbury, Mass.

title: The State Of the Humanities
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Coming Up Short In the Census
description: City officials claimed a victory, but Federal officials denied defeat in the latest skirmish of the numbers war between New York City and the Census Bureau.

title: THE 51ST STATE
description: Go West, young slum dwellers! Laid-off steel worker, trade your unemployment check for an Amtrak ticket! Decaying Eastern cities, give way to the frontier of the Sun Belt!

title: Book Ends; PUBLISHING,FAITHFULLY
description: To those who still believe that literature counts in a book world that, on the noisy surface, seems dominated by trendy publishers, fashionable lawyer-agents and flashy acquiring editors, the most respected imprint in American publishing today reads: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; KIT WILLIAMS
description: Once upon a time there was a red-bearded man named Kit Williams who painted his shoes green and lived in a 200-year-old weaver's cottage in a corner of Gloucestershire, England. He dreamed of a treasure he would fashion himself and then bury - a pendant in the shape of a golden hare, set about with rubies, moonstones, citrines, turquoise, mother-of-pearl and faience. From its paws would dangle golden bells, each of a different pitch.

title: DEMOCRATS REPORT NEW ALLEGATIONS AGAINST DONOVAN
description: Saying that the nomination of Raymond J. Donovan as Secretary of Labor ''presents a complicated case and a difficult decision,'' five Democratic members of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee today released a report containing new allegations of wrongdoing by the nominee and his construction company.

title: SONG: 'HARRY RUBY'S SONGS MY MOTHER NEVER TAUGHT ME'
description: Harry Ruby, with his collaborator, Bert Kalmar, was one of the most successful pop songwriters of the 1920's and 30's. The team's songs included ''Three Little Words,'' ''Who's Sorry Now?'' (with a third partner, Ted Snyder) and ''Thinking of You,'' which has just returned to Broadway in ''The Five O'Clock Girl.''

title: Reporter's Fines Halted In Confidentiality Case
description: A magistrate yesterday halted payments of $500 a day that she imposed more than four months ago against a reporter held in contempt because she refused to disclose a news source.

title: IN POOR HOME MARKET, BIG BUILDERS FARED BEST
description: Although dismal housing market conditions and tight credit caused almost a third of all small custom builders to close shop, at least temporarily, in 1980, most major builders survived the downturn in relatively good shape. Their earnings were generally down, but they reported smaller losses than the rest of the industry - or even slight gains.

title: Crime
description: It is almost 10 years since James McClure started writing his South African procedurals featuring Lieut. Tromp Kramer and his Bantu sidekick, Sgt. Mickey Zondi. The first was ''The Steam Pig'' in 1972, and there have been six since then, the most recent being THE BLOOD OF AN ENGLISHMAN (Harper & Row, $10.95).

title: THOUGH AIRLINES AIL, HOST STAYS ALOFT
description: While much of the airline industry has been caught in a downdraft, some air travel-related businesses have been soaring along nicely. Take Host International, the diversified food service and merchandising company. Most of its sales come from the chancy business of selling food and other wares to airline travelers, not while they are comfortably ensconced on planes, but during the restless, clock-watching, baggage-hunting time they spend in airports before or after their flights.

title: Jane Milliken And a Curate Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Milliken 2d of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Post Milliken, to the Rev. William Hague, son of Mrs. James Duncan Hague of Pebble Beach, Calif., and the late Mr. Hague. A wedding is planned in May in New Canaan.

title: Practical Traveler; CATCHING THE RIGHT SHOW ON A CRUISE
description: Before selecting a cruise, it may be prudent to find out the type of shipboard entertainment it will provide. On most liners, each evening and many an afternoon will doubtless offer a choice of attractions. Their nature, quality and variety can vary substantially from cruise to cruise, however, and what some passengers may find thoroughly enjoyable, others may not like at all.

title: It's Not Too Late
description: ''I hope the attached check is not too late,'' a donor wrote in a letter that accompanied a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Indeed, it arrived very much in time.

title: U.S. IS EXPECTED TO USE CHUN VISIT TO END TENSION WITH SOUTH KOREA
description: The Reagan Administration intends to use the visit of President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea to end the friction that has marred relations between the two countries in recent years and to demonstrate a more subdued approach to human rights issues than the Carter Administration used, senior Administration officials said today.

title: PRINCE MYSHKIN OF THE AUDEN CIRCLE
description: LETTERS TO CHRISTOPHER Stephen Spender's Letters to Christopher Isherwood 1929-1939. With ''The Line of the Branch'' - Two Thirties Journals. Edited by Lee Bartlett. Illustrated. 219 pp. Santa Barbara, Calif.: Black Sparrow Press. Cloth, $14. Paper, $7.50.

title: BRITAIN'S LABOR PARTY IS DOWN AND MAY BE OUT A LONG TIME
description: Back in the 1960's and 1970's, when Sir Harold Wilson was Prime Minister and leader of the Labor Party, he liked to soothe internal squabbles by reminding his political colleagues that the party was ''a broad church'' able to accommodate a wide ideological range. An unwieldy but often effective coalition, he said, it had the virtue of not being rigorous or doctrinaire.

title: Candi James Is Married To Robert W. Selander
description: Candice James, manager of international compensation for the United Brands Company in New York, and Robert William Selander, a vice president of Citibank, N.A. assigned to San Juan, P.R., were married yesterday afternoon in the Harkness House for Ballet Arts. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church of the Unitarian Church of All Souls performed the ceremony.

title: FURS ARE FLYING
description: After a difficult nine months, when sales were between 15 and 20 percent below 1979 levels, the nation's fur industry rebounded strongly and finished 1980 with domestic sales up 10 percent, to $944.2 million. However, while Nancy Reagan and record cold weather deserve much of the credit for last year's sudden turnaround, the final figures represent a continuation of what has been a decade of impressive growth for the industry.

title: CROSS-COUNTRY SKIERS CUT A SWATH
description: ALTHOUGH the cross-country ski season in Connecticut got off to a good start with early January snows, conditions have deteriorated since under unseasonable warmth. Some areas, however, retain enough snow for skiing and enthusiasts said last week that they were hoping that a predicted drop in temperature would save what remains on the ground and that possible snow flurries would add to it.

title: CITY DEMOCRATS RE-EXAMINE JUDICIAL NOMINATION SYSTEM
description: The system for nominating judges in Manhattan - under criticism for permitting decisions by anonymous panels and for producing unbalanced slates - is being re-examined by Democratic leaders.

title: HOW TO SEARCH THE RECORDS ON A BUILDING
description: Whether out of personal curiosity or for an upcoming business venture, digging up the history of an apartment building or a house could prove useful. There are basically two ways of going about this task: either by setting forth into the mazes of public records solo or by using the expertise of a professional record searcher.

title: JURY AWARDS 2.8 MILLION FOR BLINDING IN INFANCY
description: A 27-year-old New Jersey man, blinded shortly after birth through an unauthorized test of oxygen levels in his incubator, was awarded $2,887,000 by a Manhattan jury in a malpractice suit he brought against New York Hospital. The plaintiff, in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, was Daniel Burton Jr. of Union City.

title: Air Routes
description: To the Editor:

title: Anne G. Tomkins Wed to William Baffert
description: Anne Graves Tomkins, daughter of Lloyd Tomkins and Calvin Tomkins, both of New York, was married in Tubac, Ariz., yesterday to William Jeffrey Baffert, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gamble Baffert of Nogales, Ariz. Msgr. Charles Baste performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church.

title: SOUTH KOREAN, IN U.S., ASKS BUSINESS LEADERS FOR MORE INVESTMENT
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea, assuring American business leaders that his country had overcome the political and economic turmoil of the last year, yesterday urged greater economic cooperation between the two nations.

title: THE MADISON AVENUE ZOO
description: In one of his adventures, he wends his way through a maze of welltrimmed hedges; in another, he finds an oasis in a mirage-filled desert; in a third, he plays out the well-known metaphor in a china shop. The Merrill Lynch bull, apparently, is so effective in television commercials that other big advertisers were bound to emulate it. So it seemed last weekend when NBC's Super Bowl audience met the Exxon's reincarnated tiger, navigating a labryinth of office machinery.

title:
Dining Out;
NEW SITE, NEW CHEF, BUT SAME OVENS
description: THE HIMALAYA, an Indian restaurant once in Tinton Falls, was reviewed on these pages three years ago. Since then, it has moved to the Highlands and acquired a liquor license and a new chef.

title: MUGABE'S AMERICAN HOPES
description: The settlement that brought Robert Mugabe to office last April in an independent Zimbabwe was a remarkably happy outcome for Western diplomacy. It ended a bitter racial war. And it opened the possibility of a stable and prosperous state, oriented to the West, in a troubled region of Africa.

title: FEDERAL BOXING INVESTIGATIONS: THE FOCUS IS ON TWO PROMOTERS (page 4)
description: The following article is based on reporting by Michael Katz and James F. Clarity and was written by Mr. Clarity.

title: AFTER 25 YEARS,KARAJAN RETURNS TO VERDI'S 'FALSTAFF'
description: Recordings of Verdi's ''Falstaff'' appear at fairly regular intervals, but each new one tends to be something of a special event. This is as it should be, for like the last operas of Wagner, Mozart and Monteverdi, ''Falstaff'' is unique in the Verdi canon. It is a score of dazzling compositional sophistication, yet one warmed by the wisdom of an octogenarian whose passionate concern for human beings and their foibles burns as brightly as ever. Herbert von Karajan has now recorded the opera for a second time (Philips 6769 060, three disks), nearly 25 years after his first and still current version on the Angel label, and this new performance presents the opera with all the respect and careful preparation it invariably seems to inspire from musicians.

title: MERGER OFFERS CALDOR NEW OPPORTUNITIES
description: ABOUT 30 years ago, with $8,000 in savings and the loyal support of his wife, a young man newly out of the United States Army opened a tiny, second-floor store selling toys, housewares, luggage and gifts at a discount on Main Street in Port Chester.

title: SURPRISES OF COMEDY AND SADNESS
description: A FEW GREEN LEAVES By Barbara Pym. 250 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $10.95.

title: NEW RULES AROUSE CONCERN ON SHIPPING OF NUCLEAR WASTES
description: FEDERAL regulations issued last month that forbid state and local governments from banning the trucking of nuclear wastes over their streets are causing concern among town and county authorities, who say that nuclear shipments are a threat to public safety.

title: DANCE: DEBUTS REINVIGORATE CITY'S 'VIENNA WALTZES'
description: The New York City Ballet pulled its all-time pop ballet out of the drawer for the first time this season Friday night at the New York State Theater, and it was very much top-drawer. ''Vienna Waltzes'' has been a foolproof crowd-pleaser since its creation in 1977, but on this occasion, some debuts and a superlative cast gave it a special edge.

title: KOREANS IN U.S. CITE 'ORDER' TO HAIL CHUN
description: Koreans and Korean-Americans living and working in New York said yesterday that strong pressure was put on them by South Korean employers and, indirectly, the South Korean Government, to participate in welcoming the visiting South Korean President, Chun Doo Hwan, and show support for his regime.

title: COOK POSTS 66, LEADS DELAYED CROSBY BY 1
description: At long last, after two days of postponements, the Bing Crosby National Pro-Am got started today, to the gratification of its field of 168 professionals and 168 amateurs. The sky was azure blue and a bright sun warmed the crisp coolness of the air to one-sweater weather. The three golf courses on which play rotates - Pebble Beach, Spyglass Hill and Cypress Point, all par 72 - were still rather muddy from more than five inches of rain this week, but were playable.

title: About Cars
description: MY first car was a well-used '36 Ford, and I loved it, even though the little slantback had no radio or clock, or much of anything else. Options in those days consisted of things like a taillight for the right rear fender - and mine didn't even have that. Still, the Ford was functional and fun, and who needed power coathooks or any of the frou-frou that now can nearly double a vehicle's price?

title: DEBATE ON DRINKING AGE RESUMES
description: FOR more than three hours last Tuesday, members of the General Assembly's General Law Committee listened to a parade of speakers offering sharply conficting advice on what to do about Connecticut's drinking age.

title: Hannah Sexton, Accountant, Fiancee of J. Craig Entwistle
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Sexton of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hannah M. Sexton, to J. Craig Entwistle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean E. Entwistle of New City, N.Y.

title: Averhart Beats Gellineau in 600
description: The city's public high schools were not entered in the 20th annual Iona College Spike Shoe Club track meet at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday, but two former P.S.A.L. athletes scored victories.

title: STATE PANEL STUDIES TRAINING OF DOCTORS
description: John Kuhn left his wife behind and moved to the island of Grenada. David Spense had his sights set on Rome, but ended up in Ensenada, Mexico. Tom Rizzo saw an advertisement in a newspaper and went off to Tampico, Mexico.

title: ROLLS SET TO MARKET 3 NEW CARS THIS SPRING
description: This spring, for the first time in 16 years, Rolls-Royce Motors Ltd. is bringing out a new series of four-door sedans. The least expensive will sell for about $110,000, five times the price of the most expensive Cadillac sedan and $35,000 more than the average price that Americans paid for a home last year.

title: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: The last price controls on domestic oil were abolished by President Reagan. Companies immediately began to increase the price of gasoline and heating oil by several cents a gallon. The President also announced the termination of the Council on Wage and Price Stability, and he put a two-month freeze on pending regulations by Government agencies.

title: SPECIAL-INTEREST POLITICAL AID UP SHARPLY IN NEW YORK
description: Political action committees for corporations, unions and other special interests played a major role in New York State's Congressional campaigns last November, pouring more than $2 million into 39 contests for the House of Representatives.

title: HOW THE U.S. MIGHT FIND A LOT MORE OIL
description: LEVELLAND, Tex. S OME three decades ago, the parched red earth hereabouts covered the most magnificent oilfield in the world, fueling this nation's postwar economic joyride and virtually dwarfing the nascent gushers of Saudi Arabia.

title: NO WOMAN IS AN ISLAND
description: OTHER PEOPLE'S WORLDS By William Trevor. 243 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $10.95.

title: THE 'MYSTIQUE' OF THE DIESEL STILL ALLURING TO BUYERS
description: HEAVIER in build, simpler in design, much smokier and a bit noisier than its cousin the gasoline car, the diesel continues to be the belle of the ball in the American automobile market.

title:
The Lively Arts;
KIRKLAND AND BISSELL TO DANCE ON L.I.
description: IN an attempt to bolster the Eglevsky Ballet's winter season, Gelsey Kirkland and Patrick Bissell, two of the ballet world's current controversial figures, will join the company as guest artists this weekend on the Island.

title: CONSUMER RATES
More About Programs For Pregnant Teens
description: I am delighted to hear that at least one New Jersey agency was financed by the Office of Adolescent Pregnancy Programs of the Federal Department of Health and Human Services. I would like to congratulate Rutgers University, and I am sure that Camden will greatly benefit from this service.

title: TAX SHELTERS
description: To the Business Editor: The preposterously naive piety of Gerald J. Robinson's appeal to tax lawyers merely emphasizes the futility of moral exhortation as an effective antidote to tax fraud. With their outrageous $100-perhour-plus fees, tax attorneys are gleefully riding the crest of one of America's few growth industries. The tax-shelter racket also serves the economic function of providing lucrative jobs for the growing hordes of new lawyers perennially entering the parasitic profession. Is Mr. Robinson's appeal some kind of sophisticated joke, designed to deflect us from the hard path of tax reform? C. W. GRIFFIN Denville, N.J., Jan. 19, 1981

title: Claire D. Blaine To Be Wed Aug. 1 To L.C. Robert Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Blaine Jr. of St. Davids, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claire Denise Blaine, to Lawrence C. Robert Jr. of New Orleans.

title: HOW DO YOU SQUEEZE MORE MILES FROM A GALLON OF GAS?
description: HOW to drive just as far, just as fast, while spending less on gasoline - that is the question, and the Federal Government and private companies are teaching the driving tips that provide the answer.

title: JOHN MARQUIS CONVERSE, SURGEON
description: Dr. John Marquis Converse, an internationally known plastic surgeon, died yesterday at his home in Southampton, L.I. He was 71 years old.

title: CHINESE PRESS ACCUSES BUREAUCRATS OF WASTING MONEY ON FOREIGN TRIPS
description: Chinese bureaucrats have come under official criticism in the press for squandering valuable foreign exchange on trips abroad disguised as technical inspection tours.

title: GEORGE BAINBRIDGE
description: George Bainbridge, a retired administrator and director of the Wayne extension of Fairleigh Dickinson University, died Wednesday of a heart attack while visiting in New York City. Mr. Bainbridge, who was a resident of Rutherford, N.J., was 70 years old.

title: A WATERCOLORIST WITH CONTROL
description: MONTCLAIR WATERCOLOR is not a forgiving medium. Harshly demanding, it has a fickle fluidity that requires the artist to be certain of himself, to demonstrate an imperious self-confidence and authority.

title: OLD NEIGHBOR, THE MOVIE HOUSE, RETURNS
description: TWO dollars does not begin to cover the price of admission to a single film shown at most Westchester County movie theaters these days. But at the Pickwick Theater in Dobbs Ferry, $2 will now buy admission to two currently popular films.

title: Cosmos Shift Away From Import System
description: The philosophy that brought the Cosmos out of obscurity and made them the most glamorous team in the North American Soccer League apparently no longer prevails.

title: A SUMMER CAMP FOR YOUNGSTERS WHERE FOOTBALL IS KING
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ANDREW H. MALCOLM is chief of the Toronto bureau of The Times. By ANDREW H.MALCOLM

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Jails Arab as Soviet Spy
description: An Arab physician convicted of spying for the Soviet Union has been sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment by an Israeli court. Dr. Jahar Sayege, who lived in East Jerusalem, was arrested in October and accused of carrying out espionage missions in Israel and the occupied West Bank. He was accused of having been recruited for espionage while studying medicine in Moscow.

title: About Westchester; by Lynne Ames
description: often locally - at least once a month, and considers her voice to be ''almost as good'' as it was the day she began her career at the age of 14.

title: Literary Reductivism
description: To the Editor:

title: SEWER SUIT CHARGES PATTERN OF CORRUPTION OVER 10-YEAR PERIOD
description: A DECADE of racketeering in the Southwest Sewer District, involving fraud, illegal payoffs and kickbacks, is portrayed by District Attorney Patrick Henry of Suffolk County in a civil suit he has filed in Federal Court against two former Suffolk politicians, three contractors and a pipe supplier.

title: Collectors Increase, As Do Gun Values
description: THERE is a rapidly-growing group of gun collectors in this country whose fascination with modern and antique firearms has doubled or tripled the value of many pieces in the last decade.

title: USED-CAR DEALERS EXPECT SALES TO STAY BRISK
description: THE used-car market was buoyant in 1980, according to both wholesale and retail dealers, and sales are expected to remain strong into the prime spring selling months.

title: William Paley And CBS
description: It was nice to read a logical rationale for why William S. Paley is the right person to pick and test his eventual replacement (''An Intimate Talk With William Paley,'' by Tony Schwartz, Dec. 28).

title: Favored Wayward Lass Triumphs by 12 1/2 Lengths
description: Wayward Lass, winning by 12 1/2 lengths, captured the seventh running of the $56,400 Searching Stakes for 3-year-old fillies yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Harriet Goss To Be Bride of Gary Madeira
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Middlebrook Goss Jr. of Middlebury, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Harriet Wheeler Goss, to Harry Rosengarten Madeira Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Madeira of Haverford, Pa., and Northeast Harbor, Me.

title: THEATER: 'EL HERMANO' FROM ROMULUS LINNEY
description: For years the one-act play has been an endangered species, sometimes encountered in print but too rarely given a position on the professional stage. In its series of marathons, the Ensemble Studio Theater has been in the vanguard in attempting to reclaim the short dramatic form.

title: L.I. DISTRICT IS UPHELD ON DIPLOMAS FOR HANDICAPPED
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Albany has upheld the awarding of diplomas to two mentally handicapped students in Suffolk County in 1979 although they had not passed the state's basic competency test.

title: UConn Surge Sinks Manhattan by 75-58
description: Manhattan College played a good first half before a crowd of 2,000 in Draddy gymnasium yesterday, but Connecticut had an even better second half and left with a 75-58 victory.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN ORCHESTRA
description: It's an unlikely story: an unknown young Sri Lankan conductor organizes his own orchestra, survives into his second season of Carnegie Hall concerts and wins enthusiastic applause and reviews. But that is what has happened to Rohan Joseph, a former pianist and computer programmer who now finds himself in charge of the American Philharmonic Orchestra. That ensemble completed the highly successful second concert of its second season Thursday night. It was so successful, in fact, that the American Symphony Orchestra had better look to its laurels.

title: GREEKS ARE TOUGHER IN PARLEY WITH U.S.; Two Sides Discussing New Accord on Military Bases in Exchange for Substantial Aid Plan
description: Greek and American officials have opened negotiations here on a new agreement on military and economic cooperation that would guarantee the continued operation of American bases in Greece in return for substantial economic and military aid.

title: An All-Long Island Fuel Cooperative
description: The recent article on cutting fuel costs (''Long Island Housing'' column) was informative.

title: No Headline
description: How unfortunate for all of us benighted television viewers that Mr. Paley did not apply his vaunted ''innate sense of taste'' and ''intuitive feeling about what is good and what isn't'' to his CBSTV programming down through the years since the medium's inception! GAYE CAMPBELL, New York City

title: Home Clinic; HOW TO REMOVE WALLPAPER THAT HAS BEEN PAINTED
description: STRIPPING old wallpaper that has been in place for many years - often required before a new covering can be hung or because the old paper is finally starting to let go - is usually a time-consuming job that becomes particularly frustrating when the paper has been painted.

title: MEAN, GREEN STREETS; Windfalls
description: Ben Yehouda stopped his cab for a red light at 65th Street and Lexington Avenue one recent morning and suddenly saw money flying around outside. So did Alvin Smalls, a passenger in another cab.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW
description: February 1, 1981 NONFICTION AMERICA DANCES. By Agnes de Mille. 13 CONVERSATIONS WITH A DANCER. By Kitty Cunningham with Michael Ballard. 13 EDMUND WILSON: Our Neighbor From Talcottville.

title: GIFTS FROM STUDENTS AID NEEDIEST
description: ''Somehow this does not seem like much compared to the $10,000 I spend for tuition each year, and perhaps I have no conception of what poverty is,'' wrote Sally Elisa Blount, a Princeton student, in a note accompanying a gift of $10 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''I think it's time for me to start acknowledging its existence.''

title: Janet Lynn Savadel Betrothed
description: Mrs. Dorothy Savadel of Bonita Springs, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Janet Lynn Savadel, to Thomas G. Sorell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald P. Sorell of Port Washington, L.I. A June 6 wedding is planned. Miss Savadel, daughter also of the late Austin J. Savadel, is a sales representative with Ship 'n Shore in New York, a division of General Mills Apparel Corporation. Mr. Sorell is with the corporate bond department of Kidder, Peabody & Company, New York investment bankers.

title: Chachaji
description: To the Editor:

title: Home-Court Edge A W.B.L. Strategy
description: To the Sports Editor: When I attended a professional basketball game between the New Jersey Gems and the Minnesota Fillies of the Women's Basketball League at the South Mountain Arena in South Orange, I discovered the origin of the mysterious home-court advantage.

title: A BOUNTIFUL CRUISE TO BERMUDA AND THE BAHAMAS
description: There was a moonless night on our cruise to Bermuda and the Bahamas when my wife and I stood in the bow of the Oceanic and marveled at glittering galaxies moving across a black velvet sky. There was a squally gray morning of heaving seas and lowering clouds when we clung to the taffrail over the wake and watched silver sheets of hail surge by without dropping a stone on board. And there was a crisp afternoon when we lazed in deck chairs, swathed in blankets, and watched the sun swell, redden and shoot shafts of fire through mountainous clouds as it plunged toward the horizon.

title: Miss Moseley, Jeffrey Berry Are Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Moseley 3d of Hamilton, Mass., have anmnounced the engagement of their daughter, Cassandra Hamilton Moseley, to Jeffrey Savage Berry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Berry of New Canaan, Conn. A June wedding is planned in the Moseley Chapel at the Governor Dummer Academy in Newbury, Mass.

title: A MOVING ART
description: PAVLOVA Repertoire of a Legend. By John and Roberta Lazzarini. Illustrated. 224 pp. New York: Schirmer Books. $35.

title: Marine Sentenced to Die For North Carolina Murder
description: A military jury has decided on a death sentence for Marine Lance Cpl. Armando Rojas of West New York, N.J., who was found guilty of the murder of Pfc.

title: A 'CLASSIC' CAR THAT'S BUILT FOR SHOWING OFF
description: LOS ANGELES WHAT'S it like to own a Clenet? Well, you give your keys to a parking attendant at a fancy beachside restaurant and later find your car parked right across the front door, so that irate Rolls-Royce and Ferrari owners have to walk around it. And you pull up to a luxury hotel where a suite will cost you $500 a day and block the driveway for 45 minutes without erasing the manager's smile.

title: PORCHES: A WAY OF LIFE THAT SEEMS GONE
description: WHEN did the porches of my youth give way to backyard concrete extensions of the home known as patios? Our present patio, surrounded by thick, flowering shrubbery, creates a haven of quiet privacy. The sun, reflecting off the cement pavement, makes lounging on the chaise a hot, sticky affair. From that vantage point, if I squint my eyes just so, I can count the acorns on the impressive oak tree overhead and by turning my head I can watch the ants, busily carrying food back and forth to their ant hill. Back and forth, back and forth. I don't see my neighbor, but I know she is sitting on her patio, too.

title: Sabres 5, Whalers 3
description: Andre Savard scored twice in the final period and Tony McKegney added what proved to be the game-winner as Buffalo rallied in the third period.

title:
Gardening;
FORCED BULBS BRING A HINT OF SPRING
description: IF the recent frigid weather hasn't whet your appetite for the return of spring, nothing will. One of the best cures for the midwinter blahs is to have something cheerful and spring-like blooming around the house.

title: A Loss of Words
description: Meyer Levin, the author, went to claim a bag at La Guardia Airport last December after a flight from Chicago. No bag.

title: Iona 61, Army 58
description: Tony Iati hit two free throws with 10 seconds remaining to give Iona College a 61-58 victory tonight over Army.

description: A committee of nine Harvard University faculty members, administrators and students has recommended creating a special foundation to reduce ''alienation and estrangement'' of the campus's minority students.

title: ELECTRONICS MAKING CARS MORE EFFICIENT
description: BUYERS can expect little change in the next few years in the engines and drive trains of cars, but microprocessors and other electronic aids - sometimes called ''black boxes'' - are being installed, and these offer a variety of possibilities.

title: M.J. Volow to Wed Fiona Irving
description: Michael Irving of Rowayton, Conn., and Flora M. Irving of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Fiona Irving, to Mark Jason Volow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Volow of Valley Stream, L.I.

title: ALL-AMERICAN LESSON
description: To the Editor:

title:
Architecture View;
LEON KRIER'S CALL FOR A RETURN TO URBAN CLASSICISM
description: The deceptively benign and very beautiful drawings by Leon Krier at the Max Protetch Gallery (37 West 57th Street, through Feb. 7) do not at first glance look like a revolutionary statement. The title of the exhibition, ''Architectural Drawings for the Reconstruction of the European City: 1967-80,'' sounds more like an act of urban renewal than an act of resistance.

title:
Camera;
COLLECTORS OF PHOTOGRAPHS TELL WHY THEY COLLECT
No Headline
description: Nebraska 57, Kansas 54

title: AIR FORCE RECRUITING FORMER PILOTS AND NAVIGATORS
description: With more planes than it has pilots, the Air Force has begun a major effort to persuade former pilots to reenlist.

title: NEW FUNDS FOR HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: W HERE does a growing family turn when it outgrows its home? Usually it buys a bigger home, but these days, with interest rates at twice their levels of just a couple of years ago, such a move is often impossible. The alternative? A smaller loan to add a room or two to the existing home.

title: RULING BARS PLEA-BARGINING SUITS AGAINST PROSECUTORS
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled in Manhattan that prosecutors have ''absolute immunity'' from damage suits involving plea bargains. The decision affirmed a lower court, which ruled for the first time that an absolute-immunity doctine should be extended to a prosecutor's conduct in plea bargaining. The affirmation came from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: No Headline
description: Philippines Opposition Plans to Run in Election

title: New Jersey Journal
description: WHAT'S ''new'' in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, the taking of wine with communion, is as old as the church itself, according to Msgr. Richard Groncki, director of the archdiocese's Office of Worship.

title: Harvard 71, Cornell 69
description: Tom Mannix sank a 17-foot jump shot with five seconds left in overtime and gave Harvard a 71-69 victory over Cornell tonight. It was the Crimson's third straight Ivy League triumph.

title: Randi B. Greenblatt, a Nurse, Is Engaged to David S. Bleier
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herman Greenblatt of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Randi Beth Greenblatt, to David Scott Bleier, son of Beatrice Bleier of Englishtown, N. J., and the late Howard H. Bleier.

title: OUTLOOK FOR TAX RELIEF
description: DEPRECIATION: Business representatives still support faster writeoffs via the Conable-Jones 10-5-3 bill, but its heavy revenue losses point to enactment of something closer to the 1980 Senate Finance Committee 2-4-7-10 bill with 15- or 20-year write-offs for buildings. Prospects: excellent.

title: Kollek On Jerusalem
description: I am very grateful to The New York Times and to David K. Shipler for the article ''In Search of Jerusalem'' (Dec. 14). In many ways, it has caught the atmosphere of our city.

title: TEANECK AND ARTISTS: THRIVING SYMBIOSIS
description: TEANECK THIS Bergen County town has long been known as a place where the arts flourish. Its reputation seems justified, considering that it stages a two-day folk festival each spring that encompasses music and dance, the visual arts and crafts.

title: STRIKE THREAT EASES IN POLAND AS TALKS PRODUCE AGREEMENT
description: Workers in the west of Poland called off strikes today after an agreement was reached early this morning between the Government and the Solidarity union movement, bringing prospects for calm in the country's labor troubles.

title: NO END TO CURIOSITY ABOUT DANCE IN CHINA
description: ''Ihad no idea what was there. I went completely innocently. All I knew was that they had a revolution and that they'd broken up family units and dragged people into the country to grow cabbages. That was my image.'' The speaker is Laura Dean, the experimentalist choreographer. The ''there'' is China, which she and six other representatives of American dance visited in November. And fabled, exotic China turned out to be a country with a dance community avid for details of the exotic traditions of American dance, so different from their own state-controlled and sometimes politically inspired arts.

title: A TOWN LOOKS FOR SNOW
description: SALISBURY FOR weeks residents here have been watching the weather with more than passing interest. Heavy rains or prolonged thawing, they know, could force cancellation of a 55-year-old tradition, the Annual Salisbury Ski Jumps.

title: Music; A GUEST TO CHALLENGE PHILHARMONIA SKILLS
description: ''ACONDUCTOR has to establish a certain level of trust with his musicians,'' said John Nelson, music director of the Indianapolis Symphony, who will be returning to his former orchestra, the Greenwich Philharmonia, for two guest appearances next weekend. ''The musicians, after all, have been selected because of their competence. And what will bring them the most satisfaction, and therefore inspire them to the greatest achievement, is a sense of disciplined freedom. This can arise only if they develop a bond of mutual trust with the conductor.''

title: NEW SALES PLANS EMERGE FOR TRUCKS
description: AUTOMOBILE manufacturers have apparently come to terms with the fact that the consumers of the 1970's who flocked to buy light-duty and pick-up trucks for personal use have dwindled away.

title: TRI-STATE PLANNING: IS A CHANGE NEEDED?
description: THE Tri-State Regional Planning Commission, a planning organization for New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, drew renewed attention last week after a blue-ribbon task force, appointed by the Governors of the three states to investigate ''mounting criticism,'' issued a 223-page report, ''New Directions for Regional Planning.''

title: NANCY CAROL KOFF BETROTHED
description: Beth Gincher of New York and Richard H. Koff of Hollywood, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Carol Koff, to Douglas Keith Ritter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Ritter of Stamford, Conn.

title: THE ACTOR WHO CHANGED THE SCREEN'S FRENCH LOVER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Dan Yakir, a New York freelance writer, has a special interest in films. By DAN YAKIR

title: DONOVAN STAGED A STRONG DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON RAYMOND J. DONOVAN says he does not recall the date, but he distinctly remembers that he once met Harry Gross. The encounter, says Mr. Donovan, executive vice president of the Schiavone Construction Company in Secaucus, took place on a Schiavone work site - the subway project on 63d Street in Manhattan.

title: A CASE AGAINST CASINO GAMBLING
description: THE apparent financial success of gambling casinos in Nevada and New Jersey has aroused the enthusiasm of casino supporters in other states where economic conditions and budget demands have induced a search for new tax revenues.

title: Notes; SIX NEW CRUISE SHIPS IN THE OFFING
description: Not too many years ago it looked as if ships would die out as a mode of transportation. As a means of crossing the world's oceans, they have practically faded away, but as a way of enabling travelers to enjoy a cruise vacation at sea they are flourishing, so much so that at least five liners are now under construction, and a sixth is planned.

title: Recordings; STUDYING INNOCENCE IN THE CYCLES OF PRIMITIVE ROCK
description: GUIDE P.22 By JOHN ROCKWELL

title: SURVIVAL IS TOUGH AT AUTO GRAVEYARDS
description: ISLAND PARK, L.I. JIM'S AUTO WRECKING is 27 acres filled with labyrinthine paths winding between piles of corpses of cars and parts of cars. It is at 1 Railroad Place, off the foot of Long Beach Road in this South Shore community. The last time the visitor was there he got out of the driver's seat of a 1965 Ford station wagon for the last time; one of Jim's men looked the car over for the first time and gave the visitor $40 for it.

title: EX-ANTIPOVERTY OFFICIAL CONVICTED
description: The former head of a New Brunswick anti-poverty agency known as Minorities United to Save Themselves was found guilty yesterday of fraud and misconduct in office. The former official, Moses Williams of New Brunswick, was found guilty by a jury in Superior Court after a three-week trial. A Middlesex County assistant prosecutor, Barry Albin, contended that Mr. Williams hired two college students and approved their pay records for 40-hour weeks although they actually worked just half that time.

title: O'NEILL SHUNS A DECLARATION OF EMERGENCY FOR DROUGHT
description: SARCASTIC advice to the people of Greenwich and other droughtstricken towns in Fairfield County, such as ''let them drink Perrier,'' was muted last week by growing public awareness of the water shortage.

title: REAGAN AND CHUN
description: President Reagan's ''era of national renewal'' moves another step in its international phase with the reception tomorrow of President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea as one of his first state guests. However, the timing of Mr. Chun's 11-day visit to the United States poses a troublesome question in light of the fact that the South Korean Presidential election takes place in February.

title: UConn Sports Fan Sees No Ennui
description: As a UConn soccer fan since the early 70's, I read with incredulity John Cavanaugh's article (''Victories on Court Add Zest at UConn,'' Jan. 25) on U. Conn student support of athletics. His statement that ''a general feeling of ennui on the part of students toward the university's athletic teams'' demands a factual response.

title: On The Isle; by Barbara Delatiner; ORIGINAL MUSIC
description: If you've got it, why not flaunt it? Exactly. So today in two different concerts, Long Island composers will hear their works performed. At Hofstra University's John Cranford Adams Playhouse, compositions written by four members of the music faculty - Herbert Deutsch, David Hollister, Albert Tepper and Raymond VunKannon -will be played at 3 P.M. by music-faculty members, including Mr. Deutsch, Blanche Abram, Naomi Drucker and Morton Estrin. Tickets to the Hempstead concert are $3; for students and the elderly, $1.50.

title: Celia Lippitt Engaged to James Snow 3d, a Law Student
description: Miss Celia Haigh Lippitt and James Byron Snow 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Snow Jr. of Newtown Square, Pa., will be married May 23. Announcement of their has been made by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Devereux Haigh Lippitt of New Bern, N.C. Miss Lippitt was presented in 1977 at the Terpsichorean Ball in Raleigh, N.C. She is an alumna of Chatham Hall in Virginia and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

title: Sports of The Times; The Maps Boxing Scandal
description: EVER since Muhammad Ali Professional Sports, Inc., began promoting big fights, its lavish spending has been suspect. ''Where is Maps getting all its money?'' people in boxing wonder. ''Where are all these millions coming from?''

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: WE SPEND TOO MUCH ON DEFENSE
description: R ONALD REAGAN has come to power on a platform of alleged United States military weakness and imminent world dominance by the Soviet Union. Mr. Reagan calls for huge increases in military spending as the chief means of showing the world that the nation is still No. 1. The military budget is again to be used as the central symbol of America's world role.

title: The Threat of Nuclear Terrorism
description: Granted, nuclear threats from psychotics, political guerrillas or fortune hunters are not to be taken lightly (''Combating Nuclear Terrorism,'' by Larry Collins, Dec. 14).

title: Redman's Porsche Leads In 24-Hour Daytona Race
description: Brian Redman drove a Porsche Turbo 935 into a big lead tonight, seven hours into the grueling 24-Hour Pepsi Challenge sports car endurance race.

title: ODDS ARE 20,564,000 TO 1 AGAINST WINNING THIS SWEEPSTAKES-AND IT'S JUST AS WELL
description: THERE, I have done it! I've complied! But in a way, I am afraid I might win. Last month we and more than 20 million others in the nation received an attention-getting, plasticized post card alerting us that four computerized cards that could drastically change our life had been mailed to us.
