The cards were from our neighbor, The Reader's Digest, which was sponsoring a $500,000 Sweepstakes.

title: Further Renovation At Dixwell Questioned
description: Regarding the Dixwell destruction (''60's Dream of Renewal Fades With Time,'' Jan. 11): Mayor Lee blames the planning (''a lot of it came out wrong''); Mr. Giles sees ''errors from a planning standpoint''; Mr. Garris blames ''city politics and city government'' as well as the fact that ''the gym and pool (at nearby Winchester and Hillhouse schools) are not available.''

title: FRENCH FRIES WITHOUTPEANUT OIL
description: At the main crushing plant of the Dothan Oil Mill Company, in Dothan, Ala., the superintendent is now serving as the night watchman. And it's not a case of demotion at one of the country's largest processors of peanut oil.

title: by William Safire
description: Let the Reader Beware A new linguistic form called ''haigravation'' is rearing its head in Washington. It is the tendency of the new Secretary of State to change the state of parts of speech - from noun to adverb, from noun to verb. The new top man at Foggy Bottom, Gen. Alexander Haig, studded his testimony at confirmation hearings with locutions like ''I'll have to caveat my response, Senator,'' and ''I'll caveat that ... .'' ''Caveat,'' as used by generals like Julius Caesar, is the third-person singular present subjunctive of the Latin cavere, to beware. Standing by itself, ''caveat'' in Latin means ''Let him beware''; in English, the word is a noun synonymous with ''warning.'' It is also part of the Latin phrase ''Caveat emptor,'' ''Let the buyer beware,'' the new slogan of the consumer-protection movement. Until now, ''caveat'' has been a noun; in haigravation, it has become a verb. ''I'll caveat that'' means, presumably, ''I'll say that with this warning.'' (I'll caveat the reader that this locution will soon be followed in literary circles with ''I'll asterisk that.'') Not to be outdone, Senator John Glenn asked the witness, ''Will you burdenshare?'' This is a heavy new verb formed from ''burden-sharing,'' diplomatic jargon for ''My taxpayers won't kick in any more until yours do.'' But Glenn is not in Haig's verbifying league. ''Not in the way you contexted it, Senator,'' was a four-star reply about immorality in high places. To context something, in this lingo, is ''to place it in context.''

title: WOOD FUEL FOUND TO SURPASS ATOMIC ENERGY IN U.S.
description: Americans are turning to wood fuel in such numbers that wood has now overtaken nuclear power as a source of energy in this country, according to a study published today by the Worldwatch Institute.

title: YEAR OF THE ROOSTER: LOVE AND GOOD LUCK
description: ''YOU don't have to be Chinese to celebrate Chinese New Year,'' said Lucille Liang, who was born in Sichuan, China, and came to the United States 18 years ago to attend graduate school. Mrs. Liang runs Liang's Chinese cooking school upstairs from her tidy, wellstocked Chinese food and gift shop in Pleasantville. ''Many of my students who are not Chinese love to celebrate Chinese New Year because they have an excuse to prepare a Chinese banquet.''

title: LITER PRICING AT THE PUMP
description: Converting to the metric system is creating problems and confusion at the nation's 1.5 million gasoline hoses. When the price of gasoline passed $1 a gallon in the summer of 1979, gas station owners' meters only recorded per-gallon prices in three digits, and needed to be replaced with four-figure meters.

title: HARRY PLATT OF TIFFANY'S: THE URBANE NEW YORKER
description: If there's a beautiful going-on, chances are Harry Platt will be there. If there's a beautiful woman having lunch at Doubles, chances are Harry Platt will be with her. If there's a beautiful life, chances are Harry Platt is leading it.

title: PRESIDENT'S MEN JOCKEY FORACCESS TO OVAL OFFICE Deaver
description: After less than two weeks of existence, Ronald Reagan's Administration is still in flux, not unlike the universe just after the Big Bang, with power centers and fields of force slowly beginning to condense and coalesce into stars.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 15 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $15.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 2 3 6 ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Putnam's, $12.95.) A man who has made it big in early 20th-century America struggles against the corruption that engulfs his life. 3 2 19 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942. 4 4 24 FIRESTARTER, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Eight-year-old Charlie can look at anything and turn it into flames. 5 5 16 COME POUR THE WINE, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $12.95.) A woman's long journey to self-discovery. 6 6 18 LOON LAKE, by E.L. Doctorow. (Random House, $11.95.) The strange, lyrical adventures of a young man during the Depression. 7 12 11 THE HIDDEN TARGET, by Helen MacInnes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $12.95.) Young American woman ensnared in an international terrorists' plot.

title: Antiques; CONTROVERSY'S WINDS SWIRL AROUND A VANE
description: Acontroversy has developed over an 18th century American weather vane that Phillips, Son & Neale plans to auction March 28 at its Madison Avenue (at 72d Street) Galleries. The auction house stated last December in its advance publicity that the weathercock is the one Henry Wadsworth Longfellow referred to when writing about Paul Revere's nocturnal ride on April 19, 1775.

title: POLES TO REVIEW U.N. AIDE'S CASE
description: The Polish Government has privately promised an early review of the case of Alicja Wesolowska, the United Nations employee arrested in 1979 during a visit to her homeland and sentenced to seven years on charges of spying, officials here have disclosed.

title: Ohio Municipal Strike Is Settled
description: Settlement of a municipal employees' strike was announced late tonight. Police officers, firefighters and other employees have stayed off the job since Jan. 23 in a wage dispute.

title: Chess; A LOST INITIATIVE
description: The highest score on the United States team in the Olympiad in Malta was turned in by Yasser Seirawan, who played second board. The 20-year-old Seattle grandmaster took eight points in 11 games to win a silver medal.

title: TO WRITE SOMETHING GOOD AND MAKE A MARK
description: ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON A Life Study. By Jenni Calder. Illustrated. 362 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: Crafts
description: SOUTH ORANGE WITH Feb. 14 just two weeks away, it's time again for the annual invitational Valentine show of jewelry at the Whichcraft Studio and Gallery here.

title: Toxic Shock Cases Sharply Decline
description: The specific reasons for the turnabout were as unclear as the causes, but findings released last week by the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta left little doubt that cases of toxic shock syndrome declined dramatically during the last months of 1980.

title: Jets 2, Maple Leafs 0
description: Markus Mattsson, the Winnipeg goaltender, stopped 38 shots to gain his first shutout of the season. The victory was the second on the road for Winnipeg in 25 games.

title: Susan D. Conway Fiancee of Banker
description: Susan Dolores Conway, who is in her second year at the Fordham University School of Law, and Joseph James Petrelli, an assistant vice president in the municipal bond department of Citibank, plan to be married June 20 in Quogue, L.I.

title: AMERICA'S ETHNICS FROM A TO Z
description: HARVARD ENCYCLOPEDIA OF AMERICAN ETHNIC GROUPS Stephan Thernstrom, Editor. Ann Orlov, Managing Editor. Oscar Handlin, Consulting Editor. 1,076 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $60.

title: Music View; THE RISE OF THE GREATER MIAMI OPERA
description: If you were to be asked which is better, prose or poetry, you probably would shrug and decline to answer such a foolish question. And yet apparently sensible people still can be found arguing whether opera should be sung in English or the original language. Just as prose has a function that poetry cannot usurp, and the other way around, so opera needs to presented in the language of the audience as well as in the language of the composer. Both the New York City Opera and the Metropolitan Opera have enjoyed success with such dual presentations, but probably no company in this country is now investigating the idea's educational potential so thoroughly as the Greater Miami Opera.

title: A HALF-MILE SLALOM FOR FOUR-WHEELERS
description: YORKTOWN ''THIS is my Walter Mitty,'' said Bob Marlow, describing the icekhana - a kind of time trial or slalom for automobiles across frozen Lake Osceola in this northern Westchester hamlet.

title: AFTER 25 YEARS, ANOTHER 'FALSTAFF' FROM KARAJAN
description: GUIDE P.23 By PETER G. DAVIS

title: Paperback; Best Sellers
description: MASS MARKET

title: New Orleans
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ECONOMY SLOWS SALES OF THE IMPORTS
description: WITH a powerful punch the American economy has done what the American auto industry has been struggling to accomplish: It has knocked some of the wind out of Detroit's foreign opponents.

title: Connecticut Housing; BUILDER CONFRONTS HISTORIC DISTRICT
description: BRIDGEPORT AT the gateway to the Black Rock Harbor Historic District lies an overgrown, empty corner lot. For more than a year, Robert Napoli, a Trumbull builder, has been trying to obtain permission to build a cluster of three duplex houses on the three-quarter-acre site, each priced at about $60,000.

title: PHILADELPHIA BATTLE OVER ALL-MALE CLUBS REFLECTS A WIDER DISPUTE
description: W. Thacher Longstreth, tall and grayhaired, strolled down the long corridors and through the vaulted dining halls and walnut-paneled lounges of the Union League of Philadelphia, moving with the grace of a man at ease in his own home.

title: CRIME FIGURE'S DEATH STALLS HAZARDOUS-WASTE INQUIRY
description: THE death last November of an alleged mob figure suspected of playing an important role in illegal hazardous-waste operations in New Jersey has set back Federal and state investigations into related organized-crime activities.

title: MOSCOW'S GOOD REASONS TO WORRY ABOUT SOVIET MOSLEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. TO ACT ON POSSIBLE LEAKS AT ATOMIC SITE UPSTATE
description: ''When we heard about Love Canal, we were kind of happy it didn't happen to us,'' said Joseph T. Kluge, whose home is just across a field from Union Carbide's Linde plant here. ''Now look what's happened.''

title: You Knew Who I Was?'
description: NOW that the celebrations and the parades are mostly over, Sgt. Kevin Hermening, the tall Marine who at age 21 had been the youngest hostage, is home in Milwaukee. As with several others, it develops that his isolation for 444 days had been eased by a thin thread to what was going on here in sports. But when he got to Wiesbaden, West Germany, and phoned home, he was surprised to learn that Bud Selig, the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers baseball team, had invited him to meet some of the Brewer players.

title: L.S.U. Is Streaking Without a Superstar
description: Louisiana State's 92-75 victory over Florida Saturday night was its 18th in a row, enabling the Tigers, without superstars, to equal the school record set in the first of its two eras of superstars.

title: SECOND THOUGHT ON IRAN
description: To the Editor:

title: OF MEESE AND MEN; by William Safire
description: The character of the embryonic Reagan Administration may not be what it seems to be. On the surface is a placid scene of cabinet-style government, with a deferential White House staff limited to the gentle chores of coordination, and with a well-meaning though not well-briefed chairman of the board presiding at Cabinet meetings and conducting newly decorous press conferences at which even those reporters who consider themselves female piranhas are called ''young ladies.''

title: The Korean Connection - and More
description: It's not just the luck of the draw that brings South Korea's Chun Doo Hwan to Washington today in the second week of the Reagan Presidency. President Chun needs the legitimizing approval of the United States, his country's chief ally and customer. And he wouldn't be here if President Reagan weren't willing, up to a point, to oblige. What happens may thereby define the new Administration's approach to an old and thorny problem - doing business with the ''free'' world's authoritarian regimes.

title: KAREN KOVEL, A PSYCHOLOGIST, WED TO DR. ROBERT C. ADAMS
description: Karen S Kovel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. EphraimKovel of Brooklyn, married yesterday to Dr. Robert Christopher Adams, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Adams of Milford, Conn. Rabbi Michael Rosen and the Rev. William Kelly, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Terrace on the Parkin Flushing, Queens.

title: HAIG SAID TO REMOVE AMBASSADOR TO SALVADOR IN SIGNAL OF NEW POLICY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has relieved Robert E. White of his duties as United States Ambassador to El Salvador as a sign of a new policy in Central America, according to State Department sources.

title: BETTER SALES OF 'K' CARS AT CHRYSLER
description: Sales of the Chrysler Corporation's ''K'' cars have increased significantly in the past few weeks, enabling the auto maker to keep open assembly plants that were scheduled to shut this week.

title: KEY KOREA DISSIDENTS MOVED TO JAILS AWAY FROM SEOUL
description: Kim Dae Jung, the leading opponent of South Korea's military-supported Government, and 14 democratic activists convicted with him for sedition have been moved from detention in Seoul to widely separated prisons, according to Japanese Christian sources.

title: Payton a Free Agent
description: Walter Payton, the Chicago Bears' running back who already is the highest-paid player in the National Football League, became a free agent Sunday and will reportedly seek $1 million a year.

title: Bon Jour Jeans Account
description: Bon Jour Paris Fashions, a seven-year-old designer-jeans company, has decided to move its advertising out of its in-house operation and into D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/ DeGarmo. The promised budget is between $3 million and $4 million.

title: TOP CHANGES CONTINUE ON CBS NEWS
description: The biggest transition at CBS News in many years will occur Friday, March 6, when Walter Cronkite makes his final appearance as anchorman on the ''CBS Evening News.'' The following Monday evening, Dan Rather will take over as anchorman. In the meantime, CBS has announced a series of high-level management changes in the news division that will work around Mr. Rather.

title: S.I. Man Is Held In Death of Girl, 6
description: A 19-year-old Staten Island man was accused early today of hurling a 6-year-old girl to her death from the roof of her six-story apartment building, the police said.

title: THE U.N. TODAY
description: FEB.,2, 1981 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Scientific and technical subcommittee of the Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space

title: A Little Nest
description: What this country needs, according to experts at an annual home builders' meeting, is no-frills housing: 1,000 square feet, one bath, and forget the family room and sauna. The house they're describing sounds a lot like Levittown's four rooms and an unfinished attic of 34 years ago, with one obvious difference.

title: BANI-SADR ATTACKS HARD-LINE CLERICS
description: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr has begun what appears to be an offensive against his clerical opponents in a speech reported today by the official Pars press agency.

title: Paper Product
description: This is the time of the year when college sports publicists send out flyers extolling the feats of their all-America basketball candidates, trying to entice reporters, sportscasters and coaches to vote for a particular player.

title: THE ADIRONDACKS ARE A PRESERVE, NOT A RESERVOIR
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: The crisis touched off by the abrupt resignation of Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez last week has assumed dimensions far larger than a similar event might be expected to cause in a more stable Western European parliamentary democracy.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HI, MOM!

title: Super Moment First In $235,000 Strub
description: Super Moment, ridden by Fernando Toro, held back until the stretch and upset the favored Doonesbury in winning the $235,000 Charles H. Strub Stakes at Santa Anita today.

title: Florida Gas President
description: W.J. Smith, 53, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of the Florida Gas Transmission Company, a gas pipeline company based in Winter Park, Fla. He succeeds Edgar O. Bottler, 57, who is returning to the Continental Group, the parent company with headquarters in Stamford, Conn., as vice president.

title: F3
description: Red Smith A Gift From Red Blaik

title: Brett Given Award By Baseball Writers
description: George Brett of the Kansas City Royals, whose .390 batting average last season was the highest in the major leagues since Ted Williams batted .406 in 1941, was honored as the major league player of the year last night at the annual awards dinner of the New York chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: Chinese Sees Disaster When Planets Line Up
description: A Chinese meteorologist is predicting fairly frequent natural disasters in the northern hemisphere in the next 20 years after a rare planetary alignment takes place next year, the New China News Agency said.

title: Market Place; Flexible Bonds For Long Term
description: IN a time of wildly fluctuating interest rates, few investors are willing to purchase long-term bonds. People who already own such issues have taken a beating. With current rates at or near record levels, most holders of long-term bonds have heavy losses -some amounting to more than a third of capital.

title: Ferragamo Is Eying Canada
description: Vince Ferragamo, the Los Angeles Rams' quarterback, will meet in Toronto tomorrow with Harold Ballard, owner of the Hamilton TigerCats, to discuss playing in the Canadian Football League next year, Ferragamo's agent said in a radio interview on ABC last night.

title: ROCK: ELVIS COSTELLO SHOWS RANGE AND CONSISTENCY
description: ELVIS COSTELLO and the Attractions, who opened a three-night run at the Palladium on Saturday, are a spectacular rock-and-roll band. On records, Mr. Costello's virtuosic and prolific songwriting and his dramatically expressive singing have tended to overshadow the contributions of the Attractions, and records have been the only way for most Americans to get to know them in the two years since they last toured the United States. But at the Palladium, Mr. Costello, the pianist Steve Nieve, the bassist Bruce Thomas and the drummer Pete Thomas were particularly impressive as a unit. The sound they have forged together has become so closely identified with Mr. Costello's songs and his singing that it's difficult to imagine one without the other.

title: Alabama Judge Is Jailed On Drug Charges in Florida
description: A 41-year-old Alabama circuit judge was being held in the St. Lucie County jail today on charges of possessing marijuana and carrying a concealed firearm, Sheriff Lanie Norvell said.

title: College Payoffs Alleged
description: Several former Wichita State University basketball players received thousands of dollars in cash, clothes, airline tickets and ''forgiven'' loans over the last three years from coaches and wealthy team boosters, The Kansas City Times reported in tomorrow's editions.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avon Products Inc. named Robert Fry president of Avon Fashions.

title: Three Are Accused Of Abusing Russians
description: Three persons who said that they were members of the Jewish Defense League were issued summonses for harassment after they alledgedly were abusive to diplomats at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.

title: 80 Ice Fishermen Rescued From Floe on Lake Erie
description: Eighty ice fishermen were trapped on a five-mile-long ice floe for several hours when it broke loose from the shore of Lake Erie near Toledo today, the Coast Guard said, but all were rescued. Their cars, vans and fishing huts remained afloat and will probably not be recovered.

title: ENERGY DEPT. REPORTS CAPPING WASTE TANK THAT HOLDS RADON
description: The Federal Department of Energy, which last year acted to cap possible radiation leaks at the site of a World War II ordnance works near Buffalo, expects to take additional measures this spring, a high official of the department said yesterday.

title: Pan Am Fare Rollback
description: Pan American World Airways has agreed to roll back its fares in 35 United States-to-Latin America markets to conform with guidelines issued by the Civil Aeronautics Board, the board announced today. The board has found that Pan Am's fares have exceeded the guidelines by as much as 10 percent in the last three months, but the company said it had filed such fares inadvertently and would make refunds to customers. Among the domestic markets where rollbacks will take place are Houston, Los Angeles, Miami, New York, San Francisco, San Juan, P.R., and Washington.

title: Legislation About Tax Straddles
description: The major news in the commodity markets last week had nothing to do with the behavior of prices. Rather, it concerned the introduction of a bill in Congress last Tuesday that would, in effect, forbid the common use of commodity futures tax straddles.

title: Scores of Windows Are Smashed In West Berlin's Housing Unres
description: Groups of radicals smashed windows of shops and banks in 130 separate attacks over the past three days in the latest upsurge of violence over West Berlin's housing shortage, the police said today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE OPPRESSED MIDDLE: Politics of Middle Management. Scenes From Cor- porate Life. By Earl Shorris. 393 pages. Anchor Press-Doubleday. $13.95.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1981
description: International A Polish labor protest was called off by the independent union's National Coordinating Commission, headed by Lech Walesa. A one-hour strike was to have been held tomorrow to show Solidarity's support for private farmers who are demanding their own union. Mr. Walesa said the strike would be rescheduled ''if there is any attack on us or on farmers.'' The union's press spokesman said the Governmentunion agreements reached on Saturday ''were far from satisfactory.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Resumption of talks on arms control with Moscow is planned by the Administration, officials said, despite harsh comments last week about the Soviet Union by President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. The officials said, however, that talks would be impossible if the Soviet Union intervened in Poland, which is one of the major concerns of the new Administration. (A1:5.)

title: British Opinion Poll Reveals Support for Labor Splinter
description: An opinion poll published today indicated that an alliance of the proposed Social Democratic Party and the existing Liberal Party would win the largest bloc of votes if parliamentary elections were held now.

title: 'THINGS CHANGE,' MRS. CHENNAULT FINDS
description: Anna Chennault slips into her office and sits behind a big, hand-carved, lacquered desk, twisting the pearl and diamond ring on her right hand, speaking demurely, laughing gently and suddenly breaking into a fit of coughing.

title: Slipping Islanders Defeated by Bruins, 6-3
description: The New York Islanders are starting to talk to themselves. No wonder. The defending Stanley Cup champions, who are leading the league in points, lost for the third time in their last four games today when the Boston Bruins defeated them, 6-3, at Boston Garden.

title: POP PIANIST: HAZEL SCOTT ENJOYS SOLO
description: THREE years ago, when Hazel Scott was 18 years old, Art Tatum, the jazz pianist, who had known her since she was 8, recommended her to take over his post as solo pianist at the Three Deuces on West 52d Street. Since then, Miss Scott has never again worked alone - or with bass and drums or a larger group - until she moved into the Hideaway in the Waldorf-Astoria a few weeks ago.

title: Arrows' Streak Is Snapped at 19
description: Don Ebert's goal nine seconds into the overtime period enabled the St. Louis Steamers to snap the New York Arrows' 19-game winning streak with a 4-3 victory today in a Major Indoor Soccer League game at Nassau Coliseum before 8,873.

title: INDIAN PT. SHUTDOWN TO LAST SEVERAL WEEKS AT MINIMUM, STATE POWER
description: AUTHORITY SAYS By EDWARD A. GARGAN

title: PIANIST:GRANT JOHANNESEN PLAYS SCHUMANN, SCHUBERT AND FAURE
description: There are great personal issues at stake in Schumann's ''Fantasie'' in C (Op. 17). The work quotes Beethoven, addresses Clara Wieck - and struggles continuously with musical and physical passions. Only part of that struggle could be heard when Grant Johannesen played the work at his piano recital at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night. The opening notes didn't seem torn from the grounding bass. The triumphant insistence of the second movement was harsh rather than grand. And syncopations and unsettling caprices were heard as through a scrim.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in early editions of Metropolitan Report on Saturday incorrectly identified the speaker at a meeting at Brooklyn Technical College. He was City Councilman Abraham G. Gerges.

title: New Talent in Academia
description: It's back to the academic world for Harold R. Brown, who was Secretary of Defense in the Carter Administration. He has signed on with a national-security think tank operated by the John Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies in Washington.

title: A Sensible Beginning for a Double Biography
description: Lindy's is long gone, the Stork Club is a park and Owney Madden's speakeasy at 33 West 56th Street has been taken over by a foundation, of all things.

title: The American Express
description: Another all-America campaign is more in the open. At American University, in Washington, there has been a determined effort for some time to promote Russell (Boo) Bowers, a senior who averaged 21.9 points a game in his first three seasons and was averaging 25.5, fourth in the nation, after 10 games this season.

title: Index; International
description: Nature-lovers mourn as bases bloom in Negev A2 Anna Chennault, back from Pe- king, finds ''things change'' A3 Pope is expected to name Bishop of Orleans to Paris post A4 Around the World A5 Iranian President begins appar- ent offensive against clerics A6 Korean dissidents transferred to prisons away from Seoul A8 Government/Politics About Washington: Putting life into the law A12 The choice for C.I.A.'s No. 2 post is an electronic spying expert A14 Liberals support reforms, but have different approach A14 Reagan's first Congressional test is a request to raise debt ceiling A17 Departing head of F.A.A. cites im- provement in air safety A17 How New York City engineered a victory in Albany B3 Is Koch using criticism of Carey as a pressure tactic? B3 General Around the Nation A12 Redevelopment fever creates ten- sion in Chicago's Uptown A12 Atlanta murder investigation is focus of much criticism A13 Ex-hostage says he almost es- caped embassy grounds A15 Education/Welfare Queens parents defy Macchiarola on transfer of pupils B3 Style Relationships A16 Schools stereotype children with one parent A16 They come to the aid of corporate parties A16 Childbirth is eased in a chair A16 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Redman's team wins at Daytona in a Porsche C4 Basketball: Archibald leads East to 123-120 All-Star victory C1

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; South Africa Said to Plan More Raids Against Rebels

title: SCHOOLS STEREOTYPE CHILDREN WITH ONE PARENT
description: Despite a dramatic increase in the number of single-parent families in America during the last decade, a new survey suggests that the nation's schools continue to stigmatize them as abnormal - because of their family situations -not only in school policies and practices, but also in the attitudes of school personnel.

title: SOL RAUNHEIM
description: Sol Raunheim, a stockbroker who also had been editor and publisher of a Westchester community publication, Spotlight, died Saturday at his home in New York City.

title: No Headline
description: Ships Collide in Baltic Fog

title: FOR ICEBOATERS, A FAST BUT COOL PACE IS THE NORM
description: SAILING on ice will never achieve the popularity of sailing on water, but it's devotees would agree with the late Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College from 1915 to 1946, who said that ''iceboating is poetry.''

title: WATSON,BRYANT SHARE CROSBY LEAD AT 136
description: The final round of the 40th Bing Crosby National Pro-Am tomorrow promises to be a wild and woolly one, with the contenders barely aware of what the competition is doing miles away on some other golf course.

title: COPPOLA RISKS ALL ON $22 MILLION MOVIE
description: Francis Coppola, the Academy Award-winning director of ''The Godfather II,'' narrowly averted bankruptcy last week by pledging $1 million in personal property and by preparing to pledge another $7 million.

title: Bridge: Europeans Have Managed To Put a Price on Kibitzing
description: Watching expert bridge players at work is one of the few forms of passive recreation that are absolutely free. This generalization is true on this side of the Atlantic, but has less validity in Europe, where admission charges are common on major occasions.

title: JOHN F. O'BRIEN
description: John F. O'Brien, a financial research analyst, died Saturday at Veterans Administration Hospital in the Bronx.

title: 36 Evacuated From TankerDrifting Off Virginia Coast
description: Thirty-six crewmen were evacuated tonight from an 800-foot tanker Aikaterini, drifting 40 miles off Chincoteague in the Atlantic, after Coast Guard teams determined that an extinguished engine-room fire still posed a potential danger.

title: Workers in Steubenville Returning After Strike
description: Both the police and fire departments reported full shifts early today after a settlement was reached late last night to end a municipal employees' strike.

title: Washington Watch; Battles Over Ex-Im Cuts
description: WASHINGTON BUDGET slashers and business community representatives are battling over prospective cuts in lending authority of the Export Import Bank, a Federal lending agency that in 1980 supported 18 percent of American exports of manufactures.

title: SUZANNE SLESIN BRIDE OF MICHAEL STEINBERG
description: The marriage of Suzanne Slesin to Michael Steinberg took place yesterday at the New York home of Mr. and Mrs. Roy V. Titus, stepfather and mother of the bride. Rabbi Bernard Mandelbaum, vice president of the Synagogue Council of America, performed the ceremony.

title: HOSPITAL CORPORATION IMPROVES ITS FINANCES, CITY HALL SAYS
description: New York's municipal hospital system, which over the last decade has required increasingly larger subsidies from the city, next year will require $100 million less than expected, the Koch administration said yesterday.

title: by Henry S. Bienen
description: The terms ''globalists'' and ''regionalists'' have become epithets used to discredit individual foreign-policy makers and to call into question their positions.

title: DANCE: WORKS BY RACHEL HARMS
description: THE sheer glee with which Rachel Harms tackles choreographic problems is enough to make her weaker works tolerable and her stronger works bracing. Saturday night's program by the Rachel Harms Dance Company at the Emanu-El Midtown Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association featured works of both kinds.

title: CARTER AIR AGENCY LEADER CITES SHARP REDUCTION IN FATAL CRASHES
description: Langhorne M. Bond, who served a tempestuous term as head of the Federal Aviation Administration, says he ended almost four years on the job with a sense of satisfaction that his tough enforcement of rules had played a significant part in reducing fatalities in air crashes.

title: Georgia Peat Bog Flooded To Quell Smoke on Highway
description: Firefighters battling a peat bog fire along a heavily traveled section of Interstate 75 began flooding the bog today after other attempts to quell the smoldering peat failed. The underground peat fire has been smoldering since mid-January, and its smoke led to two accidents that killed four people last week.

title: Advertising;  2 Esmark Units Shift Agencies
description: TWO Esmark Corporation subsidiaries decided on new agencies as last week ended. The winners were Grey Advertising and Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson. Grey comes up with STP and Rosenfeld, Sirowitz with International Playtex for Ghirmack Hair Care products.

title: Bittersweet Memories
description: In a television documentary on the old Negro Baseball League, Jimmy Crutchfield, who was leaving baseball in the 1940's when blacks were first allowed in the majors, recalls a dream: ''I singled off a lefthanded pitcher and the ball crossed over second base. I started running, but I couldn't get to first base.''

title: No Headline
description: POLISH LABOR UNION CALLS OFF A STRIKE SET FOR TOMORROW

title: CONVERT FROM JUDAISM MAY BE ARCHBISHOP OF PARIS
description: A successor to the retiring Archbishop of Paris, Francois Cardinal Marty, is expected to be announced soon, and church sources here say Pope John Paul II will name Bishop JeanMarie Lustiger of Orleans, a convert from Judaism.

title: Siege in Italian Prison
description: Inmates held six guards hostage in the city's Marassi prison for four hours today, releasing their captives once authorities agreed to transfer five inmates to other facilities, the police said.

title: MUSIC: ITZHAK PERLMAN APPEARS WITH LINCOLN CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: Now that Itzhak Perlman has joined the small, select company of classical-music superstars, his appearance Sunday afternoon as guest artist with the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society in Alice Tully Hall might, on the face of it, seem to negate the whole idea of chamber music as a meeting of equals. When the same concert was repeated Monday evening on the Public Broadcasting Service's ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series, many viewers may well havetuned in just to see the violinist at work.

title: SEARCH BY BRASCAN FOR U.S. INVESTMENTS IS GAINING INTENSITY
description: In recent months, Trevor Eyton, president of Brascan Ltd., the investment holding company, has been distributing a new sort of calling card to investment bankers and companies in the United States - a 40-page leatherbound red book about Brascan's financial record and holdings.

title: Ford Opposing Taiwan Plan
description: The Ford Motor Company is trying to dissuade Taiwan from establishing a joint venture with a Japanese auto maker to produce 200,000 small cars annually, a Ford executive said Friday.

title: CORPORATE ISSUES FACE TREASURY COMPETITION
description: Underwriters are unsure how many corporate bond issues will come to market this week. Despite the formidable competition from $8.5 billion of new Treasury issues, $350 million and possibly more of debt issues are scheduled, plus $210 million of convertible debt offerings.

title: Will the Grain Embargo Go Stale?
description: President Reagan wants to decide this week what to do about the embargo on grain sales to the Soviet Union. Calling it off would keep his promise to American farmers; carrying on would signal his commitment to diplomatic ''linkage'' in facing down the Kremlin. Candidate Reagan said the embargo was a poor way to punish Moscow for invading Afghanistan. But many Reagan supporters think lifting it without a Soviet concession would be dangerous appeasement.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you build in wages and other benefits based upon an exaggerated Consumer Price Index, you ratchet up inflation at a time when productivity is not rising,And that is a problem.'' -Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. (D2:6.)

title: Catholics Clash With Police In Streets of Londonderry
description: Roman Catholic rioters hurled fire bombs and stones at policemen today in a three-hour street battle in Londonderry, the authorities said.

title: New President For Deutsch, Shea
description: Coming East to find his fortune is Charles L. Gould, long-time San Francisco ad man, who has been named the new president of Deutsch, Shea & Evans.

title: Emirates Raise Oil Price by $3
description: The United Arab Emirates today announced a $3 per barrel increase, to $36.56, in the price of its high-quality crude oil.

title: GRIFFITH'S RCA ROLE
description: Edgar H. Griffiths, who resigned as chairman and chief executive of the RCA Corporation, is to be paid an estimated $200,000 a year for five years as a consultant when his resignation becomes effective on July 1.

title: Roosevelt Reopening Tonight, After Strike
description: Racing at Roosevelt Raceway was scheduled to resume tomorrow night following the parimutuel ticket agents' overwhelming ratification of a new three-year contract.

title: No Headline
description: Gear Problem Diverts Plane

title: PIANIST: GREGORY HAIMOVSKY
description: IT is difficult to explain why a pianist of Gregory Haimovsky's talent is not better known to the general public. His generous recital of Schumann, Brahms, Chopin, Haydn, Liszt, Debussy and Messaien at the Abraham Goodman House last Saturday evening demonstrated a highly sensitive ear and a technique secure enough to deal confidently with any style of music.

title: Stenmark Triumphs; Phil Mahre Is 2d
description: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden, in 12th place after the first heat, turned in a brilliant second run today to win the Arlberg-Kandahar World Cup slalom ski race.

title: French Trot Record Set by Classical Way
description: Classical Way, leading all the way, set a record at Vincennes race track today in winning the $125,000 Prix de France, the second leg in the triple crown of French trotting.

title: Sporting Gear; Tennis Backboard for Practicing
description: A tennis backboard with a new concave design enables players to practice their shots alone and to keep a rally going for extended periods. The backboard's curved surface is designed to loft the ball into the air, returning it with a waist-high bounce and at a speed and distance that simulate actual play. The backboard, with 15 molded panels of Baydur polyurethane that are bolted together to form a surface of 8-by-14, weighs 400 pounds. The panels interlock so that the seams do not cause erratic returns. Hardware is available to fasten the backboard to 10-foot high fence posts around a tennis court or against a flat wall. The backboard costs $2,500, with shipping charges prepaid in the continental United States. The unit can be purchased from the Jimmy Connors Rally Champion Enterprise, Room 1, Box 23-4A, Sterling, Va. 22170. The telephone number is (703) 471-9737.

title: AS THE SAUDIS SPEAK OF WAR AGAINST ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Bergen County Fires Are Termed Arson
description: A series of fires that badly damaged the Borough Hall and firehouse in this Bergen County community were deliberately set, fire and police investigators said.

title: Sabres 4, Jets 0
description: Craig Ramsay and Ric Seiling scored first-period goals, and Don Edwards, the Buffalo goalie, stopped 23 shots in the Sabres' victory over Winnipeg. It was Edwards's second shutout this season. The Sabres are unbeaten in their last six games.

title: FRANCE CONFIRMS REPORTS IT HAS HANDED OVER 4 MIRAGE JETS TO IRAQIS
description: France, which is officially neutral in the war between Iran and Iraq, confirmed today that it had turned over four of 60 F-1 Mirage fighter-bomber jets to Baghdad.

title: NATURE LOVERS LAMENT SURRENDER OF NEGEV TO ARMY
description: Environmentalists and nature lovers in Israel have discovered that they are going to have to pay a high price for their country's peace treaty with Egypt.

title: THE OMBUDSMAN AND HIS PROGENY
description: The recent death of Professor Stephan Hurwitz, who in 1955 became Denmark's first ombudsman, brought to mind my first meeting with that precise, soft-spoken legal expert shortly after his appointment as Parliamentary Commissioner for Civil and Military State Administration.

title: Late De Paul Surges Rout Syracuse, 91-69
description: Mark Aquirre scored 18 points and sparked two bursts in the second half that carried De Paul to a 91-69 basketball victory over Syracuse today.

title: HELPED TO POPULARIZE 'BE-BOP SINGING' STYLE
description: Joe Carroll, a jazz and comedy vocalist who, with Dizzy Gillespie, popularized ''be-bop singing'' in the 1940's, died of a heart attack yesterday. Mr. Carroll, who was 65 years old, lived in Brooklyn and was on his way to a hospital when he died.

title: East Germans Take World Bobsled Title
description: CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 1 (AP) - The East German team of Bernhard Germeshausen and Hans Jurgen Gerhardt won the world two-man bobsled title today, ahead of East Germany's No. 2 sled of Horst Schoenau and Andreas Kirchner.

title: LIBERALS BACK FEDERAL REFORMS, BUT ON THEIR TERMS
description: Many liberals have come to agree with conservatives' arguments for putting reins on the Federal Government, but they are putting forward very different ideas on how it should be done.

title: N.B.A. EAST TOPS WEST BY 123-120
description: As Al Bianchi left the dressing room today before the start of second-half play, the assistant coach of the West all-stars said: ''They're running plays, that's not fair. You're not supposed to do that in all-star games.''

title: Barber Memorial Next Monday
description: A memorial service for Samuel Barber, who died Jan. 23, will be held next Monday at 5 P.M. at St. Bartholemew's Church, Park Avenue and 50th Street. The service will include works by the composer performed by the following artists: John Aler, John Browning, Irwin Densen, Rosalind Elias, Alice Garrott, David Garvey, Esther Hinds, David Jolley, Dennis Keene, Gary McGee, Leontyne Price, Richard Vrotney, Ransom Wilson, Randall Wolfgang, Marilyn Zschau and the choir of St. Bartholemew's Church, directed by Jack H. Ossewaarde.

title: Town Highway Chief Charged in Thefts
description: The highway superintendent of the Town of Union Vale has been arrested on charges of stealing gasoline and building materials valued at $3,000 to $4,000 from the Dutchess County town.

title: M.A.C. Bonds Drop Sharply
description: The new 10 5/8 percent Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds due 2008 with attached warrants fell sharply in price when trading began Friday. Prices of other tax-exempt bonds were generally lower since distribution of the $100 million M.A.C. issue began Jan. 19.

title: STAGE: 'PENQUIN TOUQUET,' RICHARD FOREMAN DREAM
description: Richard Foreman, the director, doesn't dream big dreams. He dreams mesmerizing small ones and then inflates them until they fill the stage. In ''Penguin Touquet,'' his new theatrical piece, Mr. Foreman is dreaming about spinning waiters, bearded saxophone players, blind men, large gray rocks, scissor-crazed barbers, fish soup, a town called Great Poetry - and, yes, penguins. Are his dreams any more profound than yours or mine? No, but then you and I are not capable of turning our subconscious ramblings into an evening of hallucinatory theater. Mr. Foreman is. ''Penguin Touquet'' may not be an intellectual revelation, but it's surely one of the season's most audacious displays of fantastic stagecraft.

title: U.S. Issues on Sale As Policy Is Debated
description: The credit markets are facing the prospect of buying and distributing $8.5 billion of Treasury notes and bonds just as plans for fiscal and monetary policy in the coming year are being drawn up.

title: No Headline
description: Floyd's 6.04 World Best

title: GUITAR RECITAL: EDUARDO FERNANDEZ AT Y
description: EDUARDO FERNANDEZ'S guitar playing was so precise and varied at his recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday n ght, that he seemed to be playing at a keyboard equipped with a multitude of stops. The tone not only altered from voice to voice in contrapuntal textures, but it also shifted within a single phrase, as if it were being produced by a trained vocalist.

title: Split Time
description: For years, Nelson Burton Jr. has been one of the best bowlers on the professional circuit, but when he goes to a tournament now, he is assured of a place in the finals because of his dual role as competitor and television commentator.

title: CHINA PLAYS DOWN SUPPORT OF ASIAN REBELS
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China, in a conciliatory gesture to the non-Communist nations of Southeast Asia, said here today that Peking would seek to prevent its ties to the Communist parties of the region from harming its relations with the five non-Communist Governments.

title: LAKER SEEKS ROUTES IN ASIA AND AUSTRALIA
description: Sir Freddie Laker, the British airline operator, is now trying to bring lower-price air travel to the heavily protected markets of the Middle East, Southeast Asia and Australia.

title: Y. T. ZEE
description: Dr. Y. T. Zee, former dean of students at Western College for Women in Oxford, Ohio, died yesterday in St. Petersburg, Fla., where she resided.

title: TEACHERS AGAINST TUITION TAX CREDITS
description: To the Editor:

title: REDEVELOPMENT STIRS FEARS IN A CHICAGO COMMUNITY
description: Fearing for their lives in a West Side public housing project, Sally Wells and her family moved in 1972 to what they hoped would be a better life in a more promising part of the city. They moved to Uptown.

title: INQUIRY CRITICIZES LIQUOR AUTHORITY
description: The chairman of a State Senate investigation committee asserted yesterday that there had been ''a virtual top-to-bottom'' breakdown in the licensing and supervision of bars and retail liquor stores by the State Liquor Authority that could lead to corruption in the agency.

title: American Express Picks Familiar Name
description: It seemed like a routine announcement from the huge American Express Company. Howard L. Clark Jr., a 36-year-old investment banker from Blyth Eastman Paine Webber, was named an executive vice president and chief investment officer, effective next Monday. He is to succeed Richard F. Blanchard, 61, who will retire after 28 years with the company, including more than 12 as executive vice president.

title: Anti-Klan Group Plans Action Against Racism
description: Representatives of a group named the National Anti-Klan Network have called for a ''spring offensive against racism and terror'' in April, charging that violence by such groups as the Ku Klux Klan and the Nazis amounts to a ''national emergency.''

title: A Dog With Culture
description: When he lost his Soviet citizenship and came to the United States with his wife in 1974, Mstislav Rostropovich brought only his cello and a pet dog.

title: People
description: * William D. Badger, Michael D. Drazen, John A. Dunning, Craige D. Johnson, Michael Kahn, John LaRock and Anthony J. Lenge have been elected senior vice presidents of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn Inc.

title: No Headline
description: PERU CLAIMS VICTORY: ECUADOR SAYS BATTLE GOES ON

title: Chess: Stubbornness Plus Bravado Equals a Real Donnybrook
description: When one player is obstinate and the other nervy, you have the makings of a great fight. After the encounter between Grandmasters Ljubomir Ljubojevic of Yugoslavia and Anthony Miles of Britain in the Riga Interzonal Tournament in 1979, Miles (who won when his opponent went astray) published analysis showing how he intended to improve the defense. When they locked horns again in the Olympiad in Malta, Ljubojevic - who could hardly have overlooked the challenge - stubbornly tried to justify his attack. Once again the sassy Miles triumphed, but I would not bet that Ljubojevic's obstinacy has been exhausted.

title: HOW COOPER TIRE STAYS HEALTHY
description: Fourteen months ago the 800 production workers at the Cooper Tire and Rubber Company's Findley tire plant conceded they were in danger of becoming victims of their own success.

title: AS NEW KNICK MOVE FORWARD, THEY MUST DEAL WITH THE PAST
description: THE Remark is usually waiting in any conversation. The New York Knickerbocker players have come to expect it, so much that they start cringing when the first words appear.

title: BILL ON TAX SUITS, SOUGHT BY KOCH, IS PASSED QUIETLY
description: With barely a whisper, the State Legislature passed and Governor Carey signed a bill last week extending restrictions on tax suits by commercial and industrial property owners - even though similar provisions had been declared unconstitutional by a state court the week before.

title: A NOBEL PRIZE FOR CARTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Cookies and Their Place in the Cause of Literacy
description: It started three years ago when a friend talked Wally Amos into donating some of his Famous Amos cookies as an incentive for a children's reading program conducted by a California library.

title: DAIRYMEN YIELDING LITTLE ON SUBSIDIES
description: As the Reagan Administration prepared last week for an assault on the milk price laws, dairy industry spokesmen indicated they would accept some minor modifications in it so long as these did not result in changing the twice-yearly adjustments of price support levels nor lower their amount.

title: New York Political Notes
description: Is Mayor Koch doing to Governor Carey what he did to Jimmy Carter? Politicians are raising that question after the Mayor said twice in the last 10 days that the Governor was in political ''trouble.'' Mr. Koch - while praising

title: PLAY: SYRACUSE PREMIERE FOR SOUTH AFRICAN WORK
description: SYRACUSE WHEN a visitor recently extolled the handsome new John D. Archbold Theater by saying, ''It looks like a million dollars,'' Arthur Storch, artistic director of the Syracuse Stage, corrected him: ''No, $1.3 million.'' In the eight years that he has been in Syracuse, Mr. Storch has become even more cost-conscious than he is estheticallyminded.

title: Teaching Science
description: In a small room next to the physics lab at Massapequa High School, beneath a large poster of a pensive Albert Schweitzer, students are learning science by playing ''Splat.''

title: Ralston Picks New Head
description: William P. Stiritz, 46 years old, will be the next head of the Ralston Purina Company, the diversified foods, agricultural products and restaurant corporation. The St. Louis-based company has set into motion a three-step plan by which Mr. Stiritz will succeed R. Hal Dean, 64, in the top slot.

title: by Jeff M. Hulewicz
description: The courage that the Poles have demonstrated by standing up to the Russians is being applauded everywhere. Nowhere is this approval being expressed more strongly than in the United States. As a second-generation American of Polish ancestry, I can personally attest to this fact. Everywhere I go, there seem to be infectious outbursts of pride among Poles. On a personal level, after years of enduring witless Polish jokes and hearing my last name badly mispronounced, I am experiencing something strange and new: a sense of dignity in my Polish heritage.

title: PUTTING LIFE INTO THE LAW
description: One morning soon, an old lawyer will end a long habit and stay home, no longer driving his pickup truck to the bus stop for the daily commute to a fine-print world where precedent resists strategem.

title: WALTER E. TRAVERS JR.
description: Walter E. Travers Jr., a senior partner of Travers, Dean & Fernandez, New York stock brokers, and the secretary-treasurer of the old Empire City Racing Association, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan.

title: THE DANCE: ZE'EVA COHEN'S SOLO
description: Ze'eva Cohen has been dancing solos for 10 years now. She started with a relatively new concept, that of the solo program that draws from a wide contemporary repertory rather than the performer's choreography alone. That omnibus approach is now more popular, but few of its practitioners have Miss Cohen's resonant performing style. Seen on Saturday at the New York University School of the Arts Theater in a program of five solos by five choreographers, Miss Cohen has a look of her own, with long, expressive arms, a deft attack and a face that flickers with emotion.

title: POLITICS MAY HINDER DEBT LIMIT INCREASE
description: ''It's not the easiest issue upon which to vote,'' Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the Republican whip, told reporters late last week.

title: DIVORCE COSTS RISE UNDER NEW LAW
description: Six months after major changes in New York's divorce law went into effect, many of the state's matrimonial lawyers say they are raising their fees because their work is now more complex and time-consuming.

title: ERIC HEIDEN A YEAR LATER: HIS PRIVACY IS GOLDEN
description: AYEAR ago this month, Eric Heiden set himself up for a lifetime of awards. In the Winter Olympic Games at Lake Placid, N.Y., he won all five men's speed-skating events - 500, 1,000, 1,500, 5,000 and 10,000 meters. No one had ever done this before. No one had ever won five gold medals in one Winter Olympics. His achievement stands with Mark Spitz's sweep of seven swimming gold medals in the 1972 Olympics. It made Eric Heiden a worldwide celebrity, with a strange twist.

title: ANGOLA TRIES PRAGMATIC POLICY
description: The Minister of Planning, Roberto d'Almeida, searched for the right word in English to describe the Government's new approach to Angola's economic problems. It was ''pragmatic.''

title: VOICE OF AUTHORITY STILL MALE
description: A WOMAN'S voice is many things to many people. Some regard it as soft and soothing, others as shrill and screechy. One thing it apparently is not is a voice of authority.

title: Central African Republic Votes on New Constitution
description: The people of the Central African Republic voted today on a proposed new constitution that would officially restore democracy.

title: By Bim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials S.W.A.T. Instructor

title: NOMINEE FOR DEPUTY DIRECTOR OF C.I.A. AN ELECTRONIC-AGE INTELLIGENCE EXPERT
description: For a man considered by many to be America's master spy, Bobby Ray Inman is something of an anomaly. He has never taken part in a covert operation or spent much time collecting intelligence data in the field. His name evokes the spirit of a country music ballad more than an espionage thriller.

title: Bozell & Jacobs Gets Kingsley, Boye Account
description: Bozell & Jacobs is the new agency for Kingsley, Boye & Southwood, a brokerage firm, whose advertising was previously done by Rapp & Collins, a direct-marketing subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: MISSING PROMOTER TAPED TALKS
description: Harold Smith, the missing chief executive of Muhammad Ali Professional Sports, Inc., (called Maps) taped many of his conversations with other boxing figures, according to two Maps employees. The tapes could possibly help in the current New Yorkbased Federal investigation of the sport.

title: No Headline
description: EX-HOSTAGE SAYS HE ALMOST GOT OVER EMBASSY WALL

title: Carnation Account Moved To SSC&B New York
description: William J. Weithas Jr., president of SSC&B, confirmed from Palm Beach, Fla., Saturday that the agency has transferred most of the $30 million-plus Carnation business from Los Angeles to the larger New York office.

title: La Guardia Accident Investigated by U.S.
description: Federal officials began their investigation yesterday into what caused the right landing gear of an Eastern Airlines plane to collapse Saturday night as it taxied down a runway at La Guardia Airport.

title: PLAYERS AND FANS NOT IN MUCH ACCORD ON ALL-STAR CHOICES
description: THE Boston Celtics, without representation on the starting National Basketball Association all-star team selected by the fans, would have had three starters if the N.B.A. players had chosen the squad. Larry Bird, Robert Parish and Nate Archibald were among the leading votegetters in a New York Times poll in which 216 of the league's 253 players cast ballots. The fans preferred Dan Roundfield, Artis Gilmore and Reggie Theus.

title: AMERICAN AND SOUTH KOREA UNITS BEGIN A JOINT MILITARY EXERCISE
description: SEOUL South Korea, Monday, Feb 2 (Reuters) -- The United States and South Korea have begun the first joint military exercise since the inauguration of President Reagan, the Korean-United States Combined Forces Command said today.

title: Heating Oil Prices Up 4.1 in 15 Days
description: Home heating oil prices rose 4.1 cents a gallon in a 15-day period in January in the New York City-Long Island area, according to the latest survey of 45 dealers by Long Island Consumer Action. The average price was $1.178 a gallon, 17 cents higher than on Dec. 1, the group said.

title: ATLANTA'S MURDER INQUIRY IS FOCUS OF MUCH CRITICISM
description: Inside the long-abandoned showroom of the old Leader Lincoln-Mercury dealership on West Peachtree Street here, a team of police officers is busy sifting tips, ideas and pieces of evidence, hoping that something will emerge as a key to solving the case of Atlanta's missing and murdered children.

title: The Economy
description: Big cuts in Federal spending and taxes must go hand in hand, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said. Citing the need to reduce Government outlays by ''tens and tens of billions of dollars,'' he suggested that a mechanism might be developed that would tie the actions together. (Page A1.)

title: SOME FLXIBLE BUS REPAIRS DELAYED
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that its program to reinforce the undercarriages of its Flxible buses was a month behind schedule nationwide, but that repairs of New York City buses were not affected by the delay.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Frequent mention is made of the ''hat trick'' in hockey (three or more goals in a game by one player). Why is it called the hat trick?

title: DANCE: LIMON TROUPE IN ITS 2 NEWEST WORKS
description: THE Jose Limon Dance Company, with one week left at the City Center, has come up with a particularly relaxed season. There is no attempt to match the opera-house theatrics of the ballet companies, and this accent on intimacy suits the company.

title: TV: LILY TOMLIN GOES LAS VEGAS
description: LILY TOMLIN'S career has included successes in nightclubs, on the stage, on recordings and, except for the disaster of ''Moment by Moment,'' in the movies. Yet, in key respects, she is a television person. She first received national attention in ''Laugh-In.'' Her subsequent specials introduced a repertory of characters who would later, in ''Appearing Nitely,'' impress theater critics, many of whom choose to downplay or ignore her television connections.

title: THEY COME TO THE AID OF CORPORATE PARTIES
description: When a corporate sponsor was needed for Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza's collection of 57 paintings by old masters, which was to travel to this country, a call was made to Mabel Brandon. When the actor Donald Sutherland was here for this year's Kennedy Center honors and wanted to locate an acupuncturist for his ailing back, he telephoned Carolyn Peachey.

title: TAXES COMPLICATED BY CHANGES IN LAW
description: There is both good news and bad news for taxpayers who, with calculators and pencils at hand, are getting ready for the annual bout with their income tax returns. The 1980 forms are largely unchanged from last year's, which is something of a relief. But the task has been complicated by new legislation, including some bills enacted in the final days of last December, as well as by hundreds of court cases and rulings handed down last year that have clarified the tax treatment of certain issues and actually changed the rules in other cases.

title: TALKS ON ARMS REMAIN LIKELY, U.S. AIDES SAY
description: Administration officials said today that despite last week's strong criticism of the Soviet Union by President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., plans were being developed for resuming discussions with Moscow on key arms control questions.

title: Miss Palmer Captures Golf by 2 Strokes
description: Sandra Palmer overcame trouble on the back nine and held off a challenge by Amy Alcott today for a two-stroke victory in the Ladies Professional Golf Association's $100,000 tournament at Deer Creek.

title: CHINA STEEL PROJECT IS POSTPONED
description: China's planned $5 billion Baoshan Steel Works, which only two years ago was considered the crown jewel of the nation's industrial modernization drive, is being put into mothballs halfway through the first phase of its construction. And, despite the estimated $1 billion committed on the project to date, there are growing indications that it may be abandoned altogether.

title: CHILDBIRTH IS EASED IN A CHAIR
description: It is an idea whose time came thousands of years ago, went out for Western civilization two centuries ago and now seems on the verge of a comeback. The premise: that women were intended to give birth sitting or squatting and not lying down as they have done ever since 1738 when Francois Mauriceau, obstetrician to the Queen of France, proposed facilitating the physician's task by having patients recline for delivery.

title: HUGH J. ADDONIZIO, 67, EX-MAYOR OF NEWARK JAILED 5 YEARS, DEAD
description: Hugh J. Addonizio, a former Congressman and two-term Mayor of Newark who was sentenced to 10 years in Federal prison and fined $25,000 for conspiracy and extortion died early this morning at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 67 years old.

title: Capitals 7, Oilers 4
description: Rolf Edberg and Dennis Maruk scored two goals apiece as Washington defeated Edmonton.

title: QUEENS PARENTS DEFY MACCHIAROLA ON PUPIL TRANSFER
description: After three years of legal battles, rallies, boycotts and charges of racism, a largely white intermediate school annex in the Rosedale section of Queens will be closed today, and its youngsters have been ordered to attend a largely black school two miles away.

title: DELAWARE BANK BILL CAUSES CONCERN
description: A bill moving rapidly through the Delaware legislature, intended to make that state a tax haven for American banks, could result in large tax revenue losses for New York City and the state of New York, according to bank officials and consumer groups.

title: Full Diary of Anne Frank To Appear for First Time
description: The diary of Anne Frank, the tale of the Jewish girl's ordeal in hiding from the Nazis during World War II, will be published next year in full for the first time, the Dutch War Documentation Institute has announced.

title: Accounts
description: * Corning Glass Works to Lavey/ Wolff/Swift for its medical products business.

title: Troops Sent to City in West India In Attempt to Quell Student Riots
description: Troops entered the western Indian city of Ahmadabad today to quell student riots.

title: Chinaglia Scores 5
description: Giorgio Chinaglia scored five goals and Francois Van der Elst added three as the Cosmos routed FC Birsfelden of Switzerland's Second Division today by 9-0 in an exhibition match.

title: Ludlum Offer Rejected
description: The directors of Blue Bell Inc. unanimously rejected over the weekend the $40-a-share offer made to the company by Allegheny Ludlum Industries Inc. The directors repeated their contention that the offer was not worth $40 a share and was ''totally inadequate.'' Allegheny Ludlum indicated late last week that if Blue Bell's board rejects its proposal it would withdraw it this morning.

title: CHUN IS IN WASHINGTON FOR TALKS WITH REAGAN
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea arrived here today on an official visit that is expected to symbolize a new approach to United States-South Korean relations after four years of uncertainty during the Carter Administration.

title: COST OF INDUSTRIAL SUPPLIES
description: Prices for industrial supplies rose sharply in January, with many increases effective when contracts were renewed at the start of the year, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday.

title: by Michael M. Yoshitsu
description: The Iran-Iraq war has complicated Japanese policy toward the Persian Gulf area. For leaders in Tokyo, the conflict emphasizes Japan's inability to diversify its sources of oil supply and to shift away from its dependence on the Middle East. During the second half of 1980, Japan signed new oil-delivery agreements with Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates to cover the shortfall that resulted from Japan's rejection, in April, of Iranian price demands and the disruption of Iraqi supplies in September. Third-quarter and fourth-quarter increases in deliveries from both Gulf states not only raised their share of Japan's oil imports from 37 percent to 52 percent, but also sharpened Japanese anxiety over peace and stability in the region.

title: Tanner Tops Fibak In Pro Indoor Final
description: Roscoe Tanner, striving to regain a place in the top 10 tennis players after a disappointing year in 1980, scored a 6-2, 7-6, 7-5 victory over Wojtek Fibak of Poland today in the final of the United States Pro Indoor championship.

title: Rookie Leads N.F.C.  In Pro Bowl Victory
description: A year ago, Eddie Murray was not sure that he was good enough to play professional football. But today, he kicked four field goals to lead the National Football Conference to a 21-7 victory over the American Football Conference in the Pro Bowl game.

title: Labor Hopeful On Chrysler
description: Leaders of the United Auto Workers union are optimistic that $622 million in wage concessions intended to win more Government loan guarantees for the Chrysler Corporation will be ratified by the rank-and-file.

title: News Analysis
description: Governor Byrne, conceding that he finds ''it's easier to throw a bomb than it is to catch one,'' has given the New Jersey Legislature a potentially disruptive issue in a year when members of both the Senate and Assembly must run for re-election.

title: Article 249769 -- No Title
description: The strike-delayed opening of Roosevelt Raceway's 1981 harness racing season tonight was highlighted by a $6,135 payoff on the third-race triple. The Great Herb, the victor, returned $71.80 for $2; Scotch Santa, second, $5.60, and C.V. Terrific, third, $12.20.

title: PETITIONS SEEK WRITER'S RELEASE
description: Nearly 27,000 signatures have been collected on petitions seeking the release of a suburban Buffalo woman from an Iranian prison. The petition drive to free Cynthia Dwyer, a 49-year old free-lance writer arrested last May 5 on suspicion of being a spy, has collected 26,896 signatures.

title: OFFICE IN BRONX SEIZE 84 PERSONS AS ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: Eighty-four suspected illegal aliens, many of them crowded into a tractor-trailer truck, were seized in the South Bronx yesterday after shots were fired without warning at two police officers responding to a report that ''suspicious persons'' were getting out of the truck.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WINE AND POEMS

title: 7 Debt Collectors To Pay $90,000 Fine
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - Seven affiliated debt collection agencies agreed to pay $90,000 in civil penalties to settle charges that they illegally harassed debtors, the Federal Trade Commission announced.

title: Sports of The Timees; A Snub at Cooperstown
description: UP at the lectern, Hank Greenberg, who once hit 58 homers for the Detroit Tigers in one season but has now dissolved into a tennis player, was extolling Bill Veeck as the initial recipient of the Lifetime Achievement award from Baseball magazine. In his introduction, Hank Greenberg mentioned that Bill Veeck, baseball's maverick owner for 40 years, should be in the Hall of Fame.

title: OPERA: MARILYN HORNE IN 'L'ITALIANA IN ALGERI'
description: PIERRE PONNELLE'S ''L'Italiana in Algeri,'' as distinct from Rossini's comedy of that name, returned to the Metropolitan Opera last night. This is the production with which Mr. Ponnelle made his New York debut in 1973, as both director and designer of the sets and costumes. In years to come, this production and Mr. Ponnelle's nightmarish ''Der Fliegende Hollander'' may serve as prime exhibits in the museum devoted to showing what went wrong with opera in our time. This is the era of the self-important, antimusical director, and Mr. Ponnelle's work typifies the age.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH PRESIDENT REAGAN CONDUCTED BY FIVE REPORTERS
description: Following are excerpts from an interview by five reporters with President Reagan at the White House today:

title: Boston College, Harvard Gain in Beanpot Hockey
description: Boston College defeated Boston University, 5-2, and Harvard upset favored Northeastern University, 10-2, in the opening round of the Beanpot Tournament at Boston Garden tonight before a sellout crowd of 14,456.

title: No Headline
description: IRAN SAYS IT HAS KILLED OVER 200 IN BATTLES WITH KURDS AND IRAQIS

title: Honda Prices Up
description: The American Honda Motor Company, importer of the Japanese autos, announced retail price increases averaging 4.2 percent, or $276. American Honda, which is based in Gardena, Calif., said its price increase would raise the cost of its cheapest model, the Civic 1300 hatchback, to $4,599 from $4,399. Honda said the higher prices were necessary to offset higher shipping costs and ''fluctuations in value between the dollar and the yen.' BELL SYSTEM BONDS 13.45 13.35 12.41

title: Warnaco Is Buying Jones Apparel Group
description: Warnaco Inc., a leading apparel manufacturer, said it had reached an agreement in principle with the owners of the Jones Apparel Group Inc., a New York-based apparel concern, to acquire the company for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.

title: WINFIELD FINISHES BUSINESS WITH YANKEES AND PADRES
description: Dave Winfield completed his unfinished business yesterday on two mattershis contract with the Yankees and his ticket problem with the San Diego Padres.

title: JUDGE LIFTS A BAN ON PENTHOUSE MAGAZINE
description: A Federal District judge today lifted a three-day injunction against distribution of the March issue of Penthouse magazine.

title: THE MARK OF GOTHAM
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW HOME FOR THE CORNER SHOP
description: Shirley Steeger, chairman of the board of the Spence-Chapin Corner Shop, which is approaching its 30th anniversary this spring, likes to tell how a friend could not find the store's new site on Third Avenue.

title: Domains in Ferment
description: It sounds like some feudal kingdom where the right to water the monarch's rosebush could be traded for the honor of turning down the royal bedsheet. In New York State, supermarkets fuss because they are not permitted to sell wine or liquor.

title: ADMINISTRATORS TRY TO FIND CONFIDENCE THEY'VE LOST
description: ONE way to gauge the mood of an era is through the themes of its conferences. The theme for public school educators at the moment is ''How to Rebuild Confidence in the Schools.'' In fact, the school managers appear to be groping for confidence in themselves.

title: GENIE OUT OF THE BOTTLE
description: A little bit of freedom can be a dangerous thing. That has never been more graphically demonstrated than in the Polish workers' revolt, which appears to be moving perilously closer to the stage when Soviet troops will cross the border to crush it.

title: Japan's Foreign Reserves Rise
description: Japan's foreign reserves rose $1.27 billion last month to reach a 22-month high of $26.50 billion by the end of the month, the Government said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Boeing Company announced yesterday that it had a 14.6 percent rise in net income, to $165.7 million, or $1.72 a share, for the fourth quarter of 1980, from $144.6 million, or $1.50 a share, for the corresponding period of 1979. Sales rose 14.2 percent, to $2.7 million from $2.3 million.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.50-20.00** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CANADA BUYING UNIT OF PETROFINA
description: Petro-Canada, the Government-owned oil company, is in the final stages of an agreement to acquire Petrofina Canada Ltd. from Belgian interests for $1.2 billion (in American funds), the two parties reported today.

title: Shuffle Among Recruiters
description: When Deutsch, Shea & Evans, the New York-based recruiting advertising specialists, was acquired last May by Foote, Cone & Belding, F.C.& B., which had five recruiting operations of its own in the West, transferred them to Deutsch, Shea & Evans. Charles L. Gould, who has just been named president of Deutsch, Shea, will operate with offices in both San Francisco and Los Angeles. Net income 1,800,000 1,900,000

title: The Washington Star
description: The Southern Baptist Convention hopes to become the first denomination to operate its own television network, which, if fully developed, could reach 163 million people, according to the Rev. Jimmy Allen, president of the convention's radio and television commission.

title: QUEENS PARENTS CONDUCT CLASSES AT CLOSED SCHOOL
description: They took places at the head of classes yesterday, sitting in for the teachers who had moved out. Some of them just milled about in the hallways. They were the parents of students at the largely white annex of Intermediate School 231 in Rosedale, Queens, and they said they would fight to keep their school.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Alaska Airlines filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 500,000 units, with each unit consisting of one share of cumulative preferred stock and one share of common stock, to be offered through a Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. group.

title: United Technologies Gains 15%; Dart, Texas Instruments Are Up
description: The United Technologies Corporation, a major manufacturer of aircraft engines, flight systems, elevators and air-conditioners, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 advanced 15 percent on a sales increase of 19.1 percent.

title: Kibbee Nominates Kingsborough Head
description: Leon M. Goldstein, the president of Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn, has been nominated to be the acting deputy chancellor of the City University of New York by Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, the university's chancellor.

title: Exxon Lifts Prices On Its Heating Oil
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it had raised East Coast prices of residual fuel oil by 0.7 cent to 6 cents a gallon after a similar move by Venezuela, a major supplier. The oil is used to heat large apartment buildings and run electric power stations.

title: MRS. HARRIS ADDS DETAILS TO LOVE-RIVALRY ACCOUNT
description: Jean S. Harris, charged with the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, parried with the prosecutor in her first full day of cross-examination today, and expressed new anger and contempt for Lynne Tryforos, her rival for the doctor's affections.

title: M-G-M: THANKS FOR 52 YEARS OF SHOESHINES
description: Bobby Cox went to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer on April 6, 1928, to get a job in pictures. He got a job as a shoeshine boy instead.

title: Sears Centers Sold
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company today announced the sale of two shopping centers, one in California and one in Rhode Island, to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for $45 million. The shopping centers are Inland Center in San Bernardino, Calif., and Midland Mall in Warwick, R.I., Sears said in a statement.

title: DALI AIDE IS EMBROILED IN A $300,000 SCANDAL
description: A note of estrangement has entered the relationship of Salvador Dali, the ailing 76-year-old Surrealist, with his controversial financial manager and private secretary, Enrique Sabater, who has become embroiled in a new scandal.

title: Bible Appears in 275 Languages
description: The Bible, the world's most widely distributed book, is available complete in 275 languages, the Bible Society in London reported today. It said parts of the Bible appeared in 27 more languages last year, making a total of 1,710 languages in which at least one book of the Bible is available. The Guinness Book of World Records says about 2.5 billion copies of the Bible have been printed.

title: POSTAL CHIEF HAILS 1980 DESPITE DEFICIT
description: The United States Postal Service ended 1980 with a $306 million deficit, but Postmaster General William F. Bolger called it a ''banner year'' in productivity and in record mail volume.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arkansas Louisiana Gas Company asked the Arkansas Public Service Commission for a $76 million increase in natural gas rates effective March 5.

title: Groundhog's Forecast: 6 Weeks More, Maybe
description: Punxsutawney Phil saw his shadow today, and legend says that means winter weather will continue for six more weeks. But Charles Erhard, president of the Punxsutawney Groundhog Club, said that Phil was hedging his forecast a bit.

title: HAUTE COUTURE'S STILL-POTENT MAGIC
description: Paris, Jan 30 - The haute couture has fought its way back from what seemed only a few years ago to be a no-return position. The rise of the French ready-to-wear industry in the 1980's coincided with the social revolution of the time and threatened to put an end to genteel clothes and the institution that, for more than a century, was the arbiter of world fashion trends.

title: Labor's Pains in Britain
description: The right wing of the British Labor Party is up in arms again, this time over rules that reduce its role in selecting party leaders. The new defeat, following Labor's endorsement last fall of nuclear disarmament for Europe and withdrawal from the European Common Market, was too much for at least four former Labor ministers, who have set out to establish a rival social democratic party.

title: WITH COLD IN FORECAST, CITY PREPARING TO HELP THOSE WHO LACK HEAT
description: Expecting a new cold wave in the next few days, city housing officials began preparing workers in the emergency repair program yesterday for complaints from tenants whose apartments lack adequate heat.

title: Allegheny Ludlum Cancels Blue Bell Bid
description: Allegheny Ludlum Industries withdrew its approximately $504 million tender offer for Blue Bell Inc. after Blue Bell directors rejected it as not being worth $40 a share.

title: PRESIDENT PROMISES FULL TIES TO SEOUL
description: President Reagan, in an action that showed his determination to move away from the Carter Administration's emphasis on human rights as a key factor in foreign policy, agreed in a meeting today with President Chun Doo Hwan to normalize relations with South Korea.

title: ROCK-FUNK-JAZZ: SUN RA AND DR. JOHN AT CLUB 57
description: born rock-and-roll pianist and singer, and Sun Ra, the big-band leader and jazz visionary, have more in common than one might suspect. Dr. John was born in 1941, and the generally accepted birthdate for Mr. Ra is 1915, but both made their first recordings as band leaders in the second half of the 50's. Both are firmly rooted in musical traditions, but both have been tireless experimenters. They are both interested in esoteric philosophies, and their performances often have ritualistic overtones.

title: COACH SAID TO HAVE PAID FOR STUDENT'S ABORTION
