description: A former Wichita State student says that the basketball coach, Gene Smithson, arranged and paid for her to have an abortion after she became pregnant by a star player, according to an article in The Kansas City Times.

title: Scott Paper Earnings
description: The Scott Paper Company's fourthquarter profit rose 15.5 percent, to $35 million, or 90 cents a share, from $30.3 million, or 78 cents a share, in the 1979 quarter, the company reported today. Revenues were $523.6 million, up from $479.3 million. Strikes at some plants during the third quarter, however, slashed profit for the full year to $133.5 million, or $3.43 a share, from $137.1 million, or $3.52 cents a share, in 1979, despite a rise in sales to $2.08 billion from $1.91 billion.

title: Army Says Weapons Leak Toxic Gas at Alabama Depot
description: The Army said today that poison gas was leaking from some of the 140 nerve-gas and mustard-gas weapons stored at Anniston Army Depot, but that the fumes were inside containers and posed no danger to the public.

title: RANGERS LOSE IN FINAL SECONDS
description: A shot by the Kings' Billy Harris with nine seconds left was inadvertently tipped into the Ranger goal by New York's Dave Maloney, giving Los Angeles a 3-2 victory at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Again, the Primary Crap Game
description: Floating crap games may benefit from uncertainty, but the time of elections ought to be settled. Incumbents have enough advantages in campaigning. Their power, in New York, to keep shifting primaries to their presumed benefit is one advantage too many. The shuffle has begun again, and this year the harm can be especially great.

title: Continental Corp.  Elects President
description: John Pierre Mascotte, 41 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Continental Corporation, a major property and casualty insurer, effective Feb. 15. He will succeed John B. Ricker Jr., 63, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer of the New York-based company, whose assets amount to around $8 billion.

title: BANK ALLEGED A $21.3 MILLION FRAUD BY SPORTS GROUP
description: The Wells Fargo National Bank charged today that it had been defrauded of $21.3 million by a group of sports promoters and companies that used the name of the former heavyweight boxing champion Muhammad Ali.

title: Norbert Segard Dies of Cancer; French Official Was a Physicist
description: Minister of State Norbert Segard died of cancer yesterday, the Government announced today.

title: KNICKS' SCALES SIDELINED WITH ACUTE TONSILITIS
description: DeWayne Scales, the knicks' rookie forward, was admitted to Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday suffering from acute tonsilitis.

title: FEDERAL JUDUCIAL PANEL CONSOLIDATES LAWSUITS ON ASPECTS OF CENSUS
description: A Federal court panel has consolidated nine cases challenging various aspects of the 1980 census and assigned them to a judge in Maryland, Census and Justice Department officials said today.

title: CITY BALLET: 'WESTERN SYMPHONY' AND 'FIREBIRD'
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Western Symphony'' is probably an acquired taste, beyond its most accessible level of folkloric confection. On Sunday night at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet gave the dance a performance that brought out its witty subtexture without losing sight of its drawling good humor.

title: NEW POLICE TECHNOLOGY FINDS TALES OF CRIME IN MOLECULES
description: CRUSHING caseloads and declining financial support are forcing police laboratories around the country to search for fast and effective new techniques for analyzing clues and solving crimes.

title: Market Place; Golden Nugget: Glowing Profits
description: after some thought that the bloom was off the rose - did not trade on the New York Stock Exchange most of yesterday.

title: SWIFT U.S. RETRIBUTION FOR TERRORISTS CALLED DOUBTFUL
description: President Reagan opened a new phase in what one official called a ''growth industry'' in counterterrorism last week when he promised ''swift and effective retribution'' against such international terrorism as the seizure of the United States Embassy in Iran.

title: Cleric Asks Khomeini To State His Position In Iran Power Struggle
description: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, reacting to a new attack by President Abolhassan BaniSadr on hard-line clergymen in the Government, appealed to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini today to intervene in the power struggle.

title: CONSERVATIVE GROUP TO MONITOR TV
description: A coalition of predominantly conservative organizations said today that it would begin a monitoring and advertising-boycott campaign to reduce ''violence, vulgarity, sex and profanity'' on television.

title: ANCIENT DICTIONARY OPENS WINDOW ON ISLAMIC PAST
description: IN 14th-century Yemen, then a thriving place along trade routes to the Orient, there was a king with an intellectual bent. He wrote numerous scientific tracts, including one dealing with the cultivation of grains, and was knowledgeable in health and astronomy. But his magnum opus was a six-language dictionary, a work of impeccable scholarship.

title: L.I.U. 95, Siena 83
description: Coming back from a 6-point first-half deficit, Long Island University turned a disciplined game into a rout last night by defeating Siena College, 95-83.

title: FILING STATUS: KEY FACTOR IN DETERMINING TAX RATE
description: Your TaxesA Guide to Preparing 1980 ReturnsSecond of 12 articles.- By DEBORAH RANKIN

title: Union Oil Spending Plan
description: The Union Oil Company of California said today that it will spend $2 billion on exploration and capital projects this year, up from $1.7 billion in 1980. The company said it planned to increase oil and gas exploration activity and development drilling, both domestic and overseas, and develop geothermal, uranium and oil-shale resources. Union said it will drill 607 wells in the United States this year, up from 492 last year.

title: Tax Court Overrules the I.R.S. on Semantics of Charity
description: David Rockefeller had to go to court to do it, but he has fought off an attempt by the Internal Revenue Service to collect an additional $91,561 from him and his wife for the years 1970 and 1971.

title: Knight-Ridder Net Up
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. reported today that fourth-quarter profit rose 18.4 percent from a year earlier, to about $29 million, or 90 cents a share, from $24.5 million, or 75 cents, in the 1979 quarter. Revenues increased to $303 million from $267.2 million. For the full year, the company said net income was $92.9 million, or $2.87 a share, on revenues of $1.09 billion, compared with $88.4 million, or $2.69 a share, in 1979, on revenues of $979.9 million.

title: Bridge: Experts Think of a Squeeze As the Bidding Is Going On
description: Inexperienced players who regard a squeeze as a species of black magic, something they know about in theory but never achieve in practice, might be surprised to learn that an expert may think about squeeze possibilities during the bidding, before he even sees the dummy. Admittedly this is rare, but it arose on the diagramed deal played in a duplicate game and reported by Ernest Gray of Silver Spring, Md.

title: Satellite Lives Again
description: The Einstein astronomy observatory has returned to full operation after an onboard control mechanism that failed last August inexplicably came back to life, according to flight controllers at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md.

title: Treasury Note Auction Today
description: Treasury note and bond financing gets under way today with $3.75 billion of 3 1/2-year notes dated Feb. 17, 1981 and maturing Aug. 15, 1984.

title: INDIA'S AMNESTY FOR TAX EVADERS
description: In an attempt to flush out the billions of dollars in currency that circulate here in an underground economy, the Government of India is offering high-yield bonds that are to pay handsome rewards to tax evaders.

title: AUDIT REPORTS REAGAN COMMITTEE EXCEEDED PRIMARY SPENDING LIMITS
description: Auditors for the Federal Election Commission contended in a report made public today that Ronald Reagan's campaign committee exceeded the $294,400 legal spending limit by $137,737 in last year's New Hampshire primary election.

title: TV: CBS TESTS SHOW FOR YOUNG
description: ''SIGN ON,'' being broadcast on CBS-TV at 4 o'clock this afternoon, is a pilot for a possible series that would represent the first daily network program for young viewers to be developed in more than 20 years. Moreover, the project is produced by the Children's Television Workshop, which has given public television ''Sesame Street,'' ''The Electric Company'' and ''3-2-1 Contact.''

title: TIME TO REMEMBER OUR VIETNAM HEROS
description: To the Editor:

title: RAIN ENDS A DRY SPELL, BUT SHORTAGE REMAINS ACUTE
description: Rain swept across the New York metropolitan area yesterday following last month's record dry spell, but water engineers said the storm, while welcome, had a minimal effect on the region's water shortage.

title: Three Officers Acquitted In Beating in Philadelphia
description: Common Pleas Court Judge Stanley L. Kubacki today issued a directed verdict of acquittal for three police officers accused of beating a member of the radical group Move after a shootout with the police in August 1978.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Reached agreement with Rick Matula, pitcher, and Brian Asselstine, outfielder, on one-year contracts. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Reached agreement on contracts with Bob McClure, Jamie Easterly, Doug Jones, Paul Mitchell, Rene Quinones, and Weldon Swift, pitchers; Jim Gantner, infielder; Bill Foley and Steve Lake, catchers, and John Poff, outfielder.

title: People
description: * John Schenck, formerly promotion manager of People magazine, joining The New York Times as promotion director of the advertising department.

title: ...BUT HER HUSBAND SCORES POORLY IN HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: SALVADOR POLICY CHANGE DISPUTED

title: STAGE: LINNEY'S 'PIXIE SHEDMAN'
description: AT one point in Romulus Linney's ''The Captivity of Pixie Shedman,'' the hero announces, ''Bad writing is bad enough; bad Southern writing is the worst.'' The audience giggles - very nervously. If Mr. Linney recognizes bad Southern writing when he sees it, why has he included so much of it in his new play? Surely this veteran dramatist (''The Sorrows of Frederick'') and novelist (the current ''Jesus Tales'') knows better, but on this occasion he seems unable to control himself. ''Pixie Shedman,'' which opened at the Phoenix Theater last night, is a tortuous autobiographical exorcism that belongs in a drawer, not a theater.

title: U.S. EDUCATION CHIEF BARS BILINGUAL PLAN FOR PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: In his first major official act, Secretary of Education T.H. Bell today revoked proposed regulations that would have required public schools to teach foreign-speaking students in their native languages.

title: MRS. REAGAN'S RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE TESTING TRAP. By Andrew J. Strenio Jr. 328 pages. Rawson, Wade. $14.95.

title: PAT MEHAFFY
description: Pat Mehaffy of Little Rock, retired chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, died Saturday after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: MGM Film Sale
description: The British Broadcasting Corp. said it had purchased 56 films for $10.5 million from MGM Productions for showing on British television. The package includes ''Gone With The Wind'' and ''Ben Hur.''

title: UAL Sees Gain In Preliminary Net
description: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, yesterday announced preliminary net earnings of $35.5 million, or $1.20 a share, for the fourth quarter of 1980, compared with a loss of $12.5 million for the 1979 period. United Airlines' earnings suffered from a strike in 1979.

title: MISCHA MISCHAKOFF
description: Mischa Mischakoff, who was concertmaster of the NBC Symphony Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini, orchestras, died of heart failure Sunday evening in Little Traverse Hospital in Petoskey, Mich. He was 85 years old.

title: Q. What is a tidal bore?
description: A. A tidal bore is a steep wave, or waves, that travels up some rivers almost like a wall of water with the arrival of the tide, particularly an exceptionally high tide. Bores occur in streams with funnel-shaped shores or shallow bottoms and at wedge-shaped entrances along coastlines with large variations in tides.

title: SCHWEIKER SAYS SOCIAL SECURITY IS HIS 'TOP PRIORITY'
description: Richard S. Schweiker said today that his ''top priority'' as Secretary of Health and Human services was the financial solvency of the troubled Social Security system.

title: Dow Falls 15.10 Points, To 932.17; Decline Eighth In 10 Sessions Under Reagan
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 15.10 points yesterday as prices of former stock favorites continued to erode. It marked the eighth decline in the 10 trading sessions since President Reagan took office on January 20.

title: St. John's Turns Back Boston College, 76-71
description: St. John's gained first place in the Big East Conference last night by running up a 15-point lead at halftime in a 76-71 victory over Boston College.

title: U.S. PUT OFF REPORT ON HUMAN RIGHTS TO AVOID EMBARRASSING CHUN
description: The Reagan Administration asked Congress to delay publication of an annual worldwide report on human rights violations to avoid embarrassing the visiting president of South Korea, Chun Doo Hwan, Congressional aides said today.

title: STATE DEPT. NOMINEE IS CHALLENGED
description: Democrats on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that William P. Clark Jr. was unqualified for the post of Deputy Secretary of State because he lacked foreign policy experience.

title: STATE COMMERCE HEAD DEFENDS TAX-INCENTIVE UNIT
description: The state's Director of Commerce today criticized as ''inaccurate'' and ''misleading'' a report that found that tax incentives offered by the state to attract business may not be saving or creating jobs or bringing in new business.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1981
description: International A willingness to discuss arms cuts was expressed by President Reagan in an interview in the Oval Office. He said he would confer with Soviet leaders whenever they were ready to discuss ''a legitimate reduction of nuclear weapons,'' but he insisted that the United States should have a military ''presence'' in the Middle East to deter any ''reckless'' moves by the Soviet Union. (Page A1, Column 6.) A muting of discord over human rights was pressed by President Reagan as he agreed to normalize relations with South Korea. At a White House meeting with President Chun Doo Hwan, Mr. Reagan pledged that the 39,000 American troops now in South Korea would remain there. (A1:5.)

title: Heiden Receives Sullivan Award
description: Eric Heiden, who set five Olympic speed-skating records in winning five gold medals at the 1980 Winter Olympics, received the prestigious Sullivan Award tonight as the nation's outstanding amateur athlete.

title: ANTITERRORIST POLICE IN ITALY ASSERT THE WORST IS OVER
description: Italian police officers in charge of the fight against terrorism believe that they have crippled the terrorists as much as is militarily possible and that it is now up to the politicians to create the social and political conditions in which political violence will no longer appeal to the young.

title: Female Soldier Is Convicted In Fatal Hanging of Another
description: A jury at a court martial today found a female soldier guilty of second-degree murder in the hanging death last September of another woman who was a soldier at Fort Story.

title: Steel Output Up in Week
description: Steel production in the United States rose to 2.43 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, up 1.1 percent from the previous week's 2.41 million, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: HOSTAGE RELEASE PITTED PHYSICIANS AGAINST JOURNALISTS
description: FEW recent events have produced as much confusion or as sharp a clash between public interest and individual privacy over the issue of medical confidentiality - as have the physical and mental health of the freed hostages.

title: CHRYSLER WORKERS BACK CONCESSIONS
description: Members of the United Automobile Workers have ratified wage concessions for the Chrysler Corporation by a 3-to-2 ratio, the union announced today. What the employees approved amounts to a 13 percent pay cut.

title: SECRETARY BELL'S VIEW OF A DEPARTMENT IN TRANSITION
description: Secretary of Education T.H. Bell, a 59-year-old educator from Utah, heads a department that the Reagan Administration has pledged to eliminate. Last week, Mr. Bell, who served as Utah Commissioner of Higher Education for the last four years, spoke with Edward B. Fiske, education editor of The Times. Following are excerpts from their discussion:

title: Anything for His Art
description: When word got around that Lee Strasberg planned to spend Sunday afternoon roller-skating at Manhattan's Roxy Roller Rink, some of his friends were alarmed.

title: DISPUTE ON MOON SECT SIMMERS IN CATSKILLS
description: People at the Rainbow Diner just outside this rural mountain hamlet will tell you that the name of the town is pronounced ''ACK-cord'' and that they don't have much use here for ''Moonies.''

title: THE SPACE SHUTTLE IS DELAYED UNTIL APRIL
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday another delay in the first test flight of the space shuttle because of ''an accumulation of minor problems.'' The launching, which had been set for March 17, has been rescheduled for no earlier than April 5.

title: HUGH J. ADDONIZIO 67, CONVICTED OF EXTORSION AS NEWARK'S MAYOR
description: Hugh J. Addonizio, a former United States Representative and twoterm Mayor of Newark who spent five years of a 10-year sentence in Federal prison and was fined $25,000 for conspiracy and extortion, died yesterday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 67 years old.

title: S.I. MAN KILLS BABY AND BROTHER-IN-LAW
description: A Staten Island man drowned his 6-month-old baby, fatally shot his brother-in-law and critically wounded his parents-in-law late last night, the police said.

title: To End the Legacy of Poison
description: The seepage of toxic chemicals at Love Canal and the contamination of the Hudson with PCB's are only the beginning. The New York Assembly has now issued a new list of ''environmental crimes'' involving reckless burial of hazardous wastes. This time the defendants are the Federal Government and contractors, charged with dumping radioactive and explosive materials underground decades ago, without adequately protecting long-term safety.

title: CHINA STRENGTHENS WORKERS DISCIPLINE
description: The Communist Party, in a growing effort to increase discipline, has ordered that political study sessions be resumed in Government offices and state-run factories and is trying to make attendance mandatory, according to Chinese sources affected by the order.

title: GUTS IN BUDGET-CUTTING
description: A demanding test of the courage and integrity of the Reagan Administration, the Congress, and the news media will take place during the forthcoming budget struggle.

title: DO BODY ACTIONS INVITE ASSAULT
description: THE way people dress and act and the places they frequent have long been recognized as factors that could enhance the chances of becoming a victim of crime. Now a new study suggests that the way people move their bodies may also unconsciously invite assault.

title: Administrator's Long Haul
description: Wealthy business executives often resist Government service, saying they can't afford the financial sacrifice. But apparently even men of more ordinary means find taking a top Washington job a bit of a personal burden.

title: New Financing Plan For Coal-Gas Project
description: The main sponsor of the $1.9 billion Great Plains Coal Gasification Project announced a new, ''entirely different'' financing plan today that it believes can overcome objections that have brought the pioneering synthetic fuels venture to near collapse.

title: 2D OPINION PLAN FOR OPERATIONS CALLED A SUCCESS
description: Programs that require patients to obtain a second doctor's opinion before undergoing elective surgery can avoid ''surplus'' surgery and save money, according to the findings of the country's oldest and largest such program.

title: DOUGLAS, WHOSE DC-3 OPENED ERA OF MASS AIRLINE TRAVEL, DIES AT 88
description: Donald W. Douglas, who brought mass airline travel to the world with his prewar DC-3, died Sunday in Desert Hospital, Palm Springs, Calif. Mr. Douglas, who had been in declining health for several months, was 88 years old.

title: Black Hawks 8, Penguins 4
description: Reg Kerr and Tim Higgins scored two goals apiece and Tony Esposito continued his mastery of Pittsburgh. Kerr broke open a tight contest with 23 seconds remaining in the second period with his 21st goal of the season

title: No Headline
description: Rates for new three- and six-month Treasury bills sold yesterday declined for the second consecutive week as the new three-month bill averaged 14.66 percent, down from 15.20 percent at last Monday's auction, and the six-month issue averaged 13.74 percent, down from 14.12 percent earlier.

title: Fire Erupts on Disabled Tanker
description: Fire rekindled itself aboard a disabled tanker off the coast of Virginia today. The 36-member crew of the Aikaterini was evacuated last night because of a fire earlier in the day.

title: Consultant Seen Replacing Sawhill
description: Edward O. Vetter, a 60-year-old former senior executive of Texas Instruments Inc, apparently has the inside track to become chairman of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, Washington sources said yesterday. Mr. Vetter would succeed John C. Sawhill as head of the public corporation; the position carries an annual salary of $175,000, one of the Government's highest.

title: Early Habits Stay With N.B.A. Players
description: Julius Erving shoots 15-foot, line-drive shots. Artis Gilmore still dribbles too much. Then there is Nate (Tiny) Archibald's ballhandling and penetration, Eddie Johnson's hesitation moves, Otis Birdsong's outside shooting and Adrian Dantley's physical play.

title: AFTER DECADES OF WORK, ARTIFICIAL HEART IS READIED FOR TRIAL IN HUMANS
description: DAY and night artificial hearts, small, medium and large, pump with a ceaseless liquid clicking sound in a bare laboratory room here. They will be kept going until they break. One of the hearts has been clicking out its message of durability and survival since April 7, 1978.

title: A Town With a Prize-Winning Case of Somnolence
description: One would think that since Margaret Thatcher, Britain's Prime Minister, comes from the town of Grantham, its people would be prone to boast. But such is not the case.

title: POLES REPORT PROGRESS IN EFFORT TO END WILDCAT STRIKES
description: The Polish Government and leaders of the country's independent labor union reported today that they had made some progress in a series of talks aimed at ending the wildcat strikes that erupted in southern Poland over local grievances.

title: The Insidious Jellybean
description: The fact that the country may be going on a jellybean binge as a result of President Reagan's much-publicized fondness for the candy has at least one dental expert worried. Jellybeans are ''terrible for your teeth,'' according to William Delaney, dental director of the Onondaga County Health Department in Syracuse.

title: PUBLIC PREFERS A BALANCED BUDGET TO LARGE CUT IN TAXES, POLL SHOWS
description: Balancing the Federal budget is much more important to the American public than a large tax cut, but there is little enthusiasm for the cuts in Federal spending President Reagan is likely to propose to reach that goal, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: REAGAN IS PREPARED TO HOLD ARMS TALKS IF SOVIET IS SINCERE
description: President Reagan said today that he was willing to talk to the Soviet Union whenever its leaders were prepared to discuss ''a legitimate reduction of nuclear weapons,'' but he insisted that the United States should have a military ''presence'' in the Middle East to discourage any ''reckless'' moves by the Soviet Union.

title: THE REGIONIn Elephant-Bite Suit
description: A 68-year-old Long Island woman who was bitten and slammed against a fence by a baby elephant at the Jungle Habitat wildlife park in New Jersey has been awarded $200,000 in damages.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 3, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the drafting of an international convention against the use of mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Administration Is Said to Agree On Care in Reducing Foreign Aid
description: The State Department said today that agreement had been reached within the Reagan Administration that foreign aid cuts would have to be made carefully and in a way that ''does not detract from our ability to meet our international interests.''

title: Jennings, Perkins Sign With Giants
description: Dave Jennings, the Giants' all-pro punter, and Johnny Perkins, the wide receiver, have signed multiyear contracts, the team announced yesterday.

title: Advertising; Managing Creation At McCann
description: SOME who are very close to the McCann-Erickson scene say that Al Scully was the glue that held its creative department together following the brain drain that accompanied the departure of William M. Backer and the Miller Beer account in the spring of 1979.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 27-year-old woman and her 5-year-old daughter were killed in an early-morning fire confined to their apartment at 957 Kelly Street in the South Bronx.

title: WORKER CO-OP TRIES TO SAVE MANUFRANCE
description: After floundering for years, Manufrance, a once-mighty French equivalent of Sears, Roebuck & Company, filed for bankruptcy last October. But now 500 of the workers who lost their jobs when the plant finally shut have formed a cooperative and insist they are going ''to carry on.''

title: SPENDING ON BUILDING UP AGAIN
description: Spending for new construction in the United States rose for the fifth consecutive month in December, but, as a result of declines in the spring recession, the yearly total was six-tenths of 1 percent below 1979, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Index; International
description: Antiterrorist police in Italy say the worst is over A2 Ambassador fears deterioration in U.S. ties to Saudi Arabia A3 China gets serious again about workers' indoctrination A3 State Sullivan assays Gover- nor Byrne's budget B3 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A18

title: DIPLOMAT FEARS DECLINE IN U.S.-SAUDI TIES
description: Unless the Reagan Administration soon makes ''discernible, measurable progress'' toward a comprehensive peace settlement in the Middle East, relations between the United States and Saudi Arabia ''will begin to deteriorate,'' according to John C. West, the outgoing American Ambassador.

title: Merchant Marine 85, Queens 74
description: The Merchant Marine Academy took the lead for good late in the second half and went on to an 85-74 victory tonight over Queens College.

title: Campaign Aide to Bush Reported In Line for Peace Corps Director
description: Loret Miller Ruppe, who headed George Bush's Presidential campaign in Michigan last year, will be named director of the Peace Corps by President Reagan, Congressional and Ruppe family sources said last week.

title: MAJORITY IN POLL BELEIVE U.S. SHOULD HONOR IRAN PACT
description: The American public wants to abide by the agreement with Iran that obtained the release of the 52 hostages, but shows almost no interest in either friendship or revenge as a future policy toward that nation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Saudi Airline Buys Pratt Engines
description: Saudi Arabia's flag carrier, Saudia Airline, agreed to purchase $60 million worth of Pratt & Whitney JT9D-7R engines to power its recently acquired European Airbuses, Pratt & Whitney officials said.

title: KUSH IS UNABLE TO RECALL SLAP
description: Frank Kush, testifying in a $2.2 million damage suit brought by one of his former players at Arizona State University, said today he did not recall having slapped him on the helmet.

title: State Commissioner Resigns in Jersey
description: Ann Klein has resigned as State Commissioner of Human Services, saying she was interested in running for governor and wanted time to ''fully explore the potential for becoming a candidate.''

title: COMPTROLLER STEPS UP HIS ATTACK ON ONCREASING STATE WELFARE AID
description: Asserting that New York State's welfare recipients already receive double the average benefits of recipients in the Sun Belt states, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan today stepped up his attack on plans to increase the level of the basic welfare grant.

title: MEDIA 'EXPLOITATION OF THE WORST SORT
description: To the Editor:

title: Familiarity
description: Maybe it was just Western folksiness. Maybe he just wanted to put the proceedings on a more casual level. But we can't help regretting that Senator Orrin Hatch chose to preface a recent meeting with 12 leaders of the women's movement with ''Do you mind if I call you by your first name?''

title: Revco Drug Chain Is Sued by U.S.
description: The Justice Department sued to prevent Revco D.S. Inc., the largest American drugstore chain, from acquiring a group of Texas drugstores.

title: THINK BIG, BUT NOT TOO BIG, FOUNDERS SAY
description: In its first year, Ammirati & Puris Inc. took a rather haughty approach for a fledgling advertising agency with no clients whatsoever: It turned down business representing $3 million in billings.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They don't subscribe to our idea of morality. They don't believe in an afterlife.

title: UPSTATE TOWN SAYS IT WAS MISLED OVER ATOMIC WASTES
description: Town officials seeking information from the state and the Federal Government on potential hazards from a World War II atomic-waste dump were repeatedly put off and sometimes apparently misled, according to letters and other accounts in town files.

title: Soldiers Said to Marry To Raise Pay Benefits
description: Some soldiers, eager to qualify for extra pay allowances, are reportedly entering into marriages of convenience with other soldiers at the military base.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed Elaine R. Bond senior vice president and director of corporate systems.

title: No Profit Seen At D.& H. Rail
description: The Delaware & Hudson Railroad, which has received $50 million in Federal loan guarantees over the past five years, appears to have no chance of becoming profitable, according to a new Federal report.

title: LAND REFORM IN EL SALVADOR IS NOT A ' CRUEL HOAX'
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Cutting Back On Book Publishing
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it was cutting back on its general book publishing activities, through a series of changes that the company characterized as a restructuring and refocusing. As part of the program, a spokesman said, up to a third of the division's full-time employees might be laid off.

title: F.T.C. STAFF EASES VIEW IN OIL CASE
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission has backed away from proposals for breaking up the eight largest oil companies in the United States.

title: CONOCO, CITIES SERVICE PROFITS IMPROVE
description: Conoco Inc. announced yesterday that it had a 26 percent gain in fourth-quarter net income, to $241 million, or $2.23 a share, from $191 million, or $1.77 a share, in the similar period a year earlier. Revenues increased 37 percent, to $5.2 billion from $3.8 billion.

title: Garwood's Insanity Defense Is Assailed by Prosecutors
description: Prosecutors declared in their final arguments today that there was little evidence that Pfc. Robert R. Garwood of the Marines was mentally ill in the 14 years he was allegedly held captive in Vietnam.

title: POLL ON REAGAN BASED UPON 1,512 INTERVIEWS
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Jan. 26 through 29 with 1,512 adults around the United States.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Cannon Mills Company's board of directors late yesterday rejected a proposed offer frol a group of investors headed by Harold S. Geneen and Ira J. Hechler to buy the textile company for $376 million in cash. The announcement came as a surprise, because Cannon's previous reaction had been favorable.

title: GENERAL MOTORS REPORTS '80 LOSS OF $763 MILLION
description: Although it managed to earn $62 million in the fourth quarter, the General Motors Corporation, for decades one of the most profitable giants in American industry, yesterday reported a 1980 loss of $763 million. It was G.M.'s first full-year loss since 1921.

title: A FAILURE IN GLOBAL ECONOMICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking the Measure Of Magazine Audiences
description: The controversy over magazine-audience research reached new heights yesterday with name calling and innuendo entering into the otherwise scholarly discussion.

title: Pabst Chief Adds Post
description: Frank C. DeGuire, the 49-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of the Pabst Brewing Company, has been named to the additional post of president. He succeeds Anthony J. Amendola, 54, who came to the Milwaukee beer corporation as president about 17 months ago.

title: A MORON SHORTAGE
description: Americans are in revolt against the professions. George Bernard Shaw wrote almost 75 years ago that ''all professions are conspiracies against the laity,'' and more and more laymen seem to agree.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: It all started experimentally enough in the main room of Xenon last week, with Lotte Lenya singing "Mack the Knife" on the stereo system and two models wearing paper dresses on the makeshift runway.

title: 21 BOEING PLANES GOING TO AUSTRALIA
description: Ansett Transport Industries Ltd. of Australia has mandated Hambros Bank Ltd. to arrange a $550 million loan package to buy 21 Boeing aircraft, banking sources said.

title: WHICH ROAD U.S.?
description: ''America is mounting a horse,'' declared President Ronald Reagan, thus providing journalists with a rather stale but quite acceptable cliche for commenting on the likely foreign policy road to be traveled by the ''Republican horse'' in the next four years. Of course, only time will give an exhaustive answer to that question. But the outlines of the new Administration's foreign policy, now increasingly discernible, give rise to concern and anxiety in the world.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: While there is such great excitement and massive coverage by the media of the return of the Americans held hostage in Iran, it is time to focus some attention on the Americans who are still unaccounted for in Vietnam and who seemingly have been forgotten.

title: Companies
description: General Motors posted a $763 million loss in 1980, its first fullyear loss since 1921, despite fourth-quarter earnings of $62 million. G.M.'s final-quarter gain was a sharp improvement over a $567 million loss in the previous quarter, but a drop from the $426 million net of the 1979 final quarter. (Page A1.)

title: Nordiques 4, Whalers 2
description: A power failure midway through the second period didn't stop Quebec from surging past Hartford. With Quebec leading by 2-0, the lights went out for a couple of seconds during a break at 9:45 of the second before emergency power came on.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Psychiatry at the Crossroads Edited by John Paul Brady, M.D. and H. Keith H. Brodie, M.D. 243 pages. Saunders Press, Philadelphia. $14.95.

title: Atlanta Mayor Asks Council For 160 More Police Officers
description: Mayor Maynard Jackson of Atlanta today called the unsolved slayings of 14 black children and the disappearances of three other children here a ''great challenge,'' and asked the City Council to add 160 officers to the police force this year.

title: Dr. Edward B. Leahey Jr., 33, Dies; Columbia Research Cardiologist
description: Dr. Edward B. Leahey Jr., a research cardiologist at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died last Thursday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center of a rare heart ailment. He was 33 years old and lived in Nyack, N.Y.

title: GARDEN CARD SET BACK FURTHER AS ALI REFUSES PROMOTER'S ROLE
description: ''This Is It!'' became virtually ''That's That!'' after the failure last night of an attempt to have Muhammad Ali replace Muhammad Ali Professional Sports as co-promoter of the Feb. 23 boxing show at Madison Square Garden.

title: Israelis Attack Vehicle Near Lebanese Port
description: Israeli soldiers ambushed a Palestinian guerrilla vehicle last night inside Lebanon, killing the occupants, the military command said this morning.

title: COOKE WINS GOLF PLAYOFF
description: John Cook won his first professional golf tournament today by beating four other players in a sudden-death playoff of the 40th Bing Crosby National Pro-Am. Cook, starting his second season on the PGA Tour, won on the third extra hole.

title: OUSTER OF ALL INSPECTORS GENERAL BY REAGAN CALLED POLITICAL MOVE
description: The main proponent of the law that established inspectors general to investigate waste and corruption in 13 Federal agencies says that President Reagan violated the spirit of the law by dismissing all the incumbents on his first day in office.

title: PHILADELPHIA CONFRONTED BY SECOND SCHOOL STRIKE
description: As the financially troubled public schools here suffered their second strike of the school year today, Mayor William J. Green asked all nine members of the school board to resign so that he could make his own appointments.

title: NORMAND POIRIER
description: Normand Poirier, an assistant editor of Newsday and a magazine writer, died Sunday at Beth Israel Medical Center after a long illness.

title: Real Estate; Converting Old District In Paterson
description: brick mills at the foot of the Great Falls.

title: New York, Eastern Issue Shuttle Figures
description: New York Air reported yesterday that it carried 37,676 passengers on its shuttle service between New York and Washington in January, its first full month of operation. The carrier said it flew 8.06 million revenue passenger miles (one passenger flown one mile) for the month and had filled 58.1 percent of available seats.

title: CREMATION IS GAINING
description: Cremation, a widespread practice in ancient times, is rapidly becoming more acceptable in the United States because of shifts in our personal values and our environmental situation.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have only recently begun to try my hand at cooking. One of many things that puzzles me is the difference between tomato paste and tomato puree. Can you tell me?

title: YOKO ONO ON HER OWN 'WALKING ON THIN ICE'
description: ''WALKING on Thin Ice,'' the Yoko Ono single that Miss Ono and John Lennon were remixing the December night Mr. Lennon was murdered, will be released next week by Geffen records.

title: TIMES SQ. PLANS TIED TO PROGRAM REAGAN OPPOSES
description: The Urban Development Action Grant program, which the Reagan Administration said today it would try to eliminate, is important to New York City and its plans to revive the Times Square area.

title: Ex-Mailman Guilty of Role In Slaying of Iranian Exile
description: A former mailman pleaded guilty today to a charge that he had accepted $500 in return for letting his postal truck be used in the slaying of an exiled Iranian leader opposed to Iran's revolutionary regime, a Federal prosecutor said.

title: WEINBERGER ASSERTS U.S. WILL HELP SAUDIS TO BUTTRESS FORCES
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Reagan Administration wanted to do everything it could to improve Saudi Arabian defenses and would treat with sympathy any request by Israel for stationing of American forces on Israeli territory, although he said he regarded such a step as hypothetical.

title: BEGAN CHILDREN'S READING PROGRAM
description: Margaret Craig McNamara, the founder of a nationwide program to encourage poor children to read, died of cancer yesterday morning at her home in Washington. Mrs. McNamara, who was 65 years old, was the wife of Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank.

title: Key Bouts At Garden In Jeopardy
description: The fight card Harold Smith put together was still up in the air yesterday and apparently about to float away. It seemed almost certain that the light-heavyweight unification bout would be the first victim of efforts to save the Feb. 23 boxing show at Madison Square Garden.

title: Borden's Snack Account To McDonald & Little
description: McDonald & Little in Atlanta has become the agency for Borden's Snack Group, which recently moved to Atlanta.

title: 5 CHARGED WITH TRADING ON SECRET MERGER DATA
description: Five men were charged in Manhattan yesterday with using secret information from employees of Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, two prominent investment banking houses, to buy stock in major companies that were ''the targets of confidential merger and acquisition discussions.''

title: Dutch Pact Questioned
description: The Dutch Parliament adopted by 77 votes to 70 today an opposition motion calling on the Government to rescind its decision to allow the export of two Dutch-built submarines to Taiwan. The Government had agreed last November to grant export licenses for the submarines to the Rotterdam-based Rijn-Schelde-Verolme shipbuilding concern. The submarine order, expected to be concluded this summer, is part of a $500 million package deal with Taiwan that also includes nuclear reactor components.

title: Tennessee Supreme Court Upholds the Death Penalty
description: The Tennessee Supreme Court has upheld the death penalty, defending it against a charge that it was unconstitutionally vague in its definition of cruel murders.

title: Mrs. Reagan Will Meet Press
description: Nancy Reagan will meet the press next week but will not answer any questions, her press secretary said today. ''She's not at ease right now in that kind of situation,'' said Sheila Patton, the First Lady's press secretary.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We cannot ignore, let alone accept, the fact that, under the direction not of the workers but of instigators, Solidarity is being steered in the direction of political opposition.'' - Stanislaw Kania, Polish party leader. (A3:1.)

title: OXFORD'S ALL SOULS TAPS ITS FIRST FEMALE FELLOW
description: A Harvard University law student has become the first woman to be named a fellow of the 542-year-old All Souls College at Oxford University in Britain.

title: Dr. Morris Weitz, 64, a Professor Who Wrote Books on Philosophy
description: Dr. Morris Weitz, Richard Koret Professor of Philosophy at Brandeis University, died Sunday at a Boston hospital after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived in Newton, Mass.

title: DIVER TEAM BREAKS A PRESSURE RECORD
description: A team of divers at Duke University, housed in an eight-foot-diameter ball, today broke the world record for a simulated dive when they survived pressure equal to that felt at 2,250 feet under water.

title: 33 FOR CARTWRIGHT
description: Bill Cartwright, the Knicks' center, was too much last night for the guard-oriented San Diego Clippers. Cartwright took 19 shots, more than usual, made 12 of them and scored a season-high 33 points to pace the Knicks to a 101-98 victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: Reagan Names Ex-Aide To Post in Health Dept.
description: President Reagan today nominated David B. Swoap, former director of the California Department of Social Welfare, to be Under Secretary of Health and Human Services. The 43-year-old nominee is now legislative director for Senator William L. Armstrong, Republican of Colorado.

title: FRANK D. PAULO, 67, THE SURROGATE OF RICHMOND COUNTRY SINCE 1961
description: Frank D. Paulo, the surrogate of Richmond County since 1961, died of a heart attack Monday at Staten Island Hospital.

title: Reliance Group's Earnings Are Up
description: The Reliance Group Inc. yesterday reported fourth quarter operating income from continuing operations of $23.1 million, or $3.24 a share, an increase of 17 percent compared with the $19.7 million, or $2.15 a share, earned in the comparable period of 1979.

title: Major Consumers Reduce Oil Use
description: Oil consumption by the 21 members of the International Energy Agency declined 7.5 percent last year, and the outlook for 1981 is for another drop, of between 1 and 2 percent, Hiromichi Miyazaki, the agency's chairman, said today.

title: Lufthansa Sells Boeings
description: Deutsche Lufthansa A.G., West Germany's international airline, said today that it had sold its five remaining Boeing 737 aircraft to the Far East Air Transport Corporation, Taiwan, for an undisclosed sum. The airline had sold 17 Boeing 737's last November to People Express, a United States carrier, and will introduce in February the first of 37 Boeing 737 advanced aircraft it has ordered.

title: Wichita State Is 'Clean,' Athletic Director Says
description: Wichita State's athletic director, Ted Bredehoft, said yesterday that the National Collegiate Athletic Association had not informed him of any investigation into basketball program violations cited by a newspaper. He said the school had ''a clean ship.''

title: Housing Authority Acts to Save Water
description: Water-flow restrictors will be installed in showers in all 263 city housing projects to help alleviate the water shortage, the Housing Authority said.

title: Two Reagan Choices Hinted
description: J. Lynn Helms, retired president of the Piper Aircraft Corporation, is a leading candidate to be appointed administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, persons familiar with the regulatory agency said today. Also, Arthur Teel, a Tallahassee, Fla., lawyer who headed President Reagan's transition team for the Department of Transportation, was said to be the leading candidate to head the Urban Mass Transit Administration.

title: DEMOCRATS TWEAKING ADMINISTRATION ON DEBT LIMIT
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today approved President Reagan's proposal to increase the Federal debt limit $50 billion, to $985 billion, but Democrats warned that Republicans would have to provide floor votes if the bill was to be approved by the House.

title: Standard Brands Profit Up
description: Standard Brands Inc., a packager of consumer foods, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 rose 25.4 percent to $32.6 milllion, or $1.14 a share, from $26 million, or $1.14 a share, a year earlier. Sales climbed 14 percent, to $867.4 million from $759.9 million. Earnings for the whole year increased 21 percent, to $104.4 million, or $3.65 a share, from $86.4 million, or $3.04 a share, while sales grew 20 percent, to $3 billion.

title: Natural Gas Deal
description: The Columbia Gas System said today that it had agreed to purchase half the natural gas produced by Standard Oil of California's Chevron U.S.A. unit in the Whitney Canyon and Carter Creek areas of southwest Wyoming. The company estimated its share of the natural gas at more than 500 billion cubic feet. It said the gas would come from a processing plant to be built by Chevron and would be delivered over a 15-year period, starting in 1982, at a rate of 55 million cubic feet a day.

title: Reagan And the Hispanics
description: During the election campaign, the Carter Administration introduced regulations that would have required public schools to teach non-English-speaking students in their native languages.

title: Operating Officer Is Named at Sloane
description: Edward M. Sullivan, 45 years old, has been named chief operating officer of W.& J. Sloane, the 30-unit furniture and home-furnishings chain with stores in New York, Houston, Washington and San Francisco. As chief operating officer, he succeeds Theodore Chaudron, 46, who resigned as president.

title: Arnold Kramer, 81, the Chairman And a Founder of Trimfit Hosiery
description: Arnold Kramer, a founder and chairman of the Trimfit Inc., a hosiery manufacturing concern, died Monday night at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mr. Kramer, who lived in Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla., was 81 years old.

title: Grey Advertising Wins Northwest Air Account
description: New York-based Grey Advertising, which also has a Minneapolis-St. Paul office, has just beaten out three other agencies and landed the advertising account of Northwest Airlines, which has its headquarters in Minneapolis.

title: SHRIMP SHELLER
description: EVERY now and then, my son Jacques, who is well on the way to becoming a cook in his own right, arrives home to tell me about a new technique he learned or a new gadget he's been using. Recently he reported to me on a bizarre-looking plastic tool called a Zipout. It is intended to shell and clean shrimp with one quick thrust.

title: BACHELOR COOKING, LEARNED LATE IN LIFE
description: AFTER they had helped one another put on the white plastic aprons, the 11 men, whose ages ranged from 58 to 94, took their places on the bridge chairs and patiently waited for Marcie Kanowitz to begin the class.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HARDY BIENNIAL

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average weekly cost of feeding a family of four in New York City rose by 45 cents to $101.72 during the period from Jan. 19 to Jan. 30, according to market basket survey of the Department of Consumer Affairs. During the same period a year ago, the market basket cost an average of $90.97.

title: City College 59, Lehman 55
description: Michael Richardson poured in 25 points and paced City College to a 59-55 victory over Lehman in the City University Conference last night. The victory, on the losers' court, gave City an overall record of 5-14, including 5-5 in the conference's North Division.

title: Garwood's Jury Delays Consideration of Verdict
description: After hearing final arguments by defense attorneys in the court-martial of Pfc. Robert R. Garwood, a 34-year-old marine accused of collaborating with the enemy in the Vietnam War, the jury of five Vietnam veterans decided today to wait until tomorrow to begin deliberations.

title: New Jazz at the Public Scheduled to Resume
description: The Public Theater's concert series devoted to improvisational music, New Jazz at the Public, is back in business after several months of inactivity. Nancy Weiss, who produced jazz concerts and was host of two jazz radio shows in Boston before moving to New York, has been chosen as the new coordinator of the series by the Public Theater's Joseph Papp.

title: Ex-Hostage and Wife Improve
description: Robert C. Ode, a returned Iranian hostage, and his wife were reported ''doing very well'' today at National Hospital in Arlington, Va. Mr. Ode, 65 years old, was hospitalized last week suffering from bronchitis and exhaustion.

title: Careers; Job Outlook In Security Field Is Up
description: PRIVATE eyes are more watchful than ever. In these security-conscious days, business is thriving for such companies as Pinkerton's Inc. Its founder, Allan Pinkerton, began doing business as a detective in 1850.

title: McKay in Hospital
description: Coach John McKay of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers has been hospitalized for tests. His wife, Corky, would not disclose the nature of the tests or how long he would be in the hospital.

title: SABER PREPARED TO SURVIVE END OF FEDERAL AID
description: Long before Dennis W. McCarthy opened a brightly painted turquoise-and-white refinery here in 1975, the Federal Government had begun to build a vast regulatory framework to help keep the nation's small independent refineries in business.

title: Chun, Ending Visit, Thanks The U.S. for Its Help
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea ended his official visit here today by thanking the United States for its economic and military aid and renewing an invitation to the President of North Korea to meet with him.

title: Tkaczuk Out For 2 Weeks
description: Walt Tkaczuk, the Rangers' senior player, will be sidelined at least two weeks because of an eye injury suffered in Monday night's 3-2 loss to Los Angeles.

title: THE DOOR WAR
description: Andrei Gromyko looked more dour than usual when he called upon the First Secretary. ''Comrade Brezhnev,'' he said, ''I hardly know how to begin.''

title: Olympic Partners Now N.H.L. Rivals
description: Tonight they will be opponents, whacking each other when the occasion warrants, but a year ago they were teammates and Olympic gold medalists.

title: U.S. Picks Replacement For Envoy in El Salvador
description: The Reagan Administration, moving quickly to restore a high-level diplomatic presence in El Salvador, will send Frederic L. Chapin, a career diplomat, to that country as acting Ambassador, officials said today.

title: Economic Scene; U.S. Resistance To Tax Cutting
description: THE latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, published yesterday, reveals the barriers President Reagan will face in getting his economic program through Congress and convincing the public that he knows how to bring inflation under control. Two-thirds of the respondents said they believed the economy was the nation's most important problem. Despite this concern and Mr. Reagan's long campaign for a cut in personal income taxes by 30 percent in the next three years, the poll found that 70 percent of the public prefers a balanced budget to a tax cut.

title: Mitchell to Sawdon & Bess
description: Sawdon & Bess Advertising, a subsidiary of Ted Bates & Company, has brought in Martin M. Mitchell Jr. from Wells, Rich, Greene to be executive vice president and general manager. The 43-year-old executive was president of W.R.G. Canada, and before that a senior vice president in New York. His first agency job was at J. Walter Thompson.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Thousands of gallons of water could be conserved if all the girls and women who wash their hair daily could make it a once-a-week affair. For the duration of this serious drought, vanity could be watered down. MARY R. MACARTHUR Convent Station, N.J., Jan. 23, 1981

title: CUOMO COUNTERS ATTACK BY REGAN ON WELFARE RISE
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today denounced as ''poorly reasoned'' and ''narrow'' a report by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan that said a proposed increase in New York's basic welfare grant would be harmful to economic development and discourage recipients from seeking employment.

title: WHICH SHYLOCK FOR OUR TIME?
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslav Oil Drilling
description: The Naftaplin Oil Company of Yugoslavia will drill 40 offshore wells in the Adriatic within the next five years at a cost of $600 million, company officials said today. Naftaplin has spent $300 million so far on offshore drilling but only natural gas has been found in commercial quantities.

title: Ex-Hostage Negotiates On Rights to His Diary
description: Sgt. Rodney V. Sickmann of the Marines left Iran with a diary in his trouser leg and is negotiating with a New York literary agent for the sale of publication rights.

title: THEATER: A BRITISH 1776
description: TALK about too little and too late! ''Has 'Washington' Legs?,'' a comedy by the British writer Charles Wood, is a savage attack on the Hollywood movie industry, the Bicentennial hoopla of five years ago, and our romantic, schoolbook illusions about the American Revolution. While he was at it, why didn't Mr. Wood also include a few jokes about Bo Derek, Watergate and the Lincoln assassination? Then he'd be at least as with it as Bob Hope.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard FACES IN MY TIME. By Anthony Powell. Illustrated. 230 pages. Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $14.95.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: EVERY once in a while, a little square of white flutters somewhere in the city and it brings back memories. The little square is called a handkerchief, and, for women at least, it is almost as extinct as a corset, but not quite as extinct as the bustle.

title: Virginia Triumphs in Overtime
description: Terry Gates, a reserve forward, hit a foul shot with six seconds left in overtime - his only point of the game -enabling undefeated Virginia to score an 80-79 victory over North Carolina in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: Post 82, Adelphi 67
description: Greg Dixon, with 17 points, led C.W. Post to an 82-67 victory over Adelphi tonight. The victory was the Pioneers' fifth straight and seventh in their last eight games; their record is 11-7. John Horton of Adelphi (9-8), led all scorers with 20 points.

title: COLD COMFORTS: A COOK'S ELIXIRS FOR WINTER'S ILLS
description: ''F EED a cold, starve a fever,'' may be an adage much out of fashion, but at our house the first part of that recommendation still is considered gospel. (The second part we regard as highly suspect.) Although the current conventional wisdom offered by doctors is to eat only when you feel like eating, we stubbornly harbor the belief that taking nourishment is a positive vital life sign, much to be encouraged.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said it was discussing with Alcan AluminiumU.K., its 78 percent-owned subsidiary, the purchase of the unit's 10.1 million minority shares outstanding.

title: Doubly Honored
description: There are many men of the year these days. But Dong Kingman, the water colorist, will be one of the few to be so cited twice in one week.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1981
description: International A bigger military role in the Mideast by Washington was sugggested by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. In a news conference, he said that the Reagan Administration wanted to do everything it could to improve the defenses of Saudi Arabia. He also said he favored production and deployment of the neutron bomb, which is relatively low in blast effect but high in lethal radiation. (Page A1, Column 3.) Polish ''instigators'' were denounced by Stanislaw Kania, the Communist Party leader. He accused them of transforming the independent union into a political opposition and sowing anarchy. The attack came only three days after the union and the authorities reached an accord that has eased Poland's labor unrest, and Western diplomats theorized that the party was under pressure from Sovietbloc countries to maintain a harder line toward the labor movement. (A1:1-2.)

title: 1. Flowers and a Gift Idea
description: Magritte-Hennessy is the professional name of Margarita Hennessy, a flower designer who owns a business called the Whole Blooming Works, housed in a loft in the wholesale flower district. Miss Hennessy, who selects and arranges flowers for restaurants and parties, has come up with an interesting gift idea. She ''plants'' spring blooms in painted papier-mache boxes from India and includes the lid so that the box is reusable after the flowers have faded. The arrangements come in three sizes, priced at $10, $15 and $25, and will be delivered free in Manhattan. Orders must be prepaid. The Whole Blooming Works is at 111 West 28th Street; telephone is 695-3247.

title: HEADMASTERS BRIDLE ON ISSUE OF ADMITTING WOMEN
description: For nearly a century, the Headmasters Association has prided itself on harmony. This all-male association, many of whose 100 members are from some of the nation's most exclusive preparatory schools, has meticulously avoided controversy and shunned confrontation. For decades, it has met in secret and allowed no visitors.

title: Bridge: Signals From Whist Days Still Serve Useful Purpose
description: A method of defensive signaling that dates to the days of whist is virtually obsolete. But it serves a useful purpose, and is perhaps overdue for a revival.

title: TV: STORY OF AUSCHWITZ BY A SURVIVOR
description: THERE is a program about Auschwitz tonight at 8 on WNET-TV, Channel 13, a program called ''Kitty - Return to Auschwitz,'' and it is probably unlike any other you have seen in the welter of television that deals in fact or in fiction with the exterminationcamp horror.

title: POLISH OFFICIALS ARE SAID TO FEAST ON FRUITS OF OFFICE
description: The war against corruption that was promised six months ago is beginning to look more like only a rearguard skirmish, but public anger at the abuses of power and privilege by Communist officialdom has not abated.

title: Dow Gains 9.13 in Late Rally
description: The stock market finished moderately higher yesterday with some of the energy, technology and gold issues posting the biggest gains. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was up by only about 2 points at 3:30 P.M., closed ahead 9.13 points, to 941.38. Analysts said that bargain hunters and short-covering were responsible for much of the late rally.

title: FOUNDATIONS ARE NOT THAT LIBERAL
description: To the Editor:

title:
RED SMITH;
Cooney On TheJob
description: FIGHT managers, promoters, lawyers and other denizens of the halfworld have been thronging through Madison Square Garden this week like shoppers through Macy's, only it isn't pantyhose they're after. They have been meeting in one emergency session after another, trying to repair the Garden's gaudy boxing card of Feb. 23 and enable the show to go on without financial aid from Maps, whose bankroll is frozen like a well-digger's feet in Montana.

title: PROFITS OF DOW, AVON AND CYANAMID GAIN
description: The Dow Chemical Company, the nation's second-largest chemical concern behind E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 soared 24.7 percent on an increase in sales of 13.1 percent.

title: MET OPERA: MARILYN HORNE IN 'ALGERI'
description: PIERRE PONNELLE'S ''L'Italiana in Algeri,'' as distinct from Rossini's comedy of that name, returned to the Metropolitan Opera Monday night. This is the production with which Mr. Ponnelle made his New York debut in 1973, as both director and designer of the sets and costumes. In years to come, this production and Mr. Ponnelle's nightmarish ''Der Fliegende Hollander'' may serve as prime exhibits in the museum devoted to showing what went wrong with opera in our time. This is the era of the self-important, antimusical director, and Mr. Ponnelle's work typifies the age.

title: Rutgers 90, Manhattan 57
description: With four scorers in double figures, led by Kelvin Troy's 16 points, Rutgers evened its record at 10-10 by beating Manhattan on the losers' court Tuesday night, 90-57.

title: Sit-In Continues At Queens School
description: A sit-in continued yesterday at an intermediate-school annex in Rosedale, Queens, as parents maintained their effort to keep the largely white annex open so their children would not have to attend the school's predominantly black main building in Springfield Gardens.

title: The Economy
description: Tax cuts must not be contingent on spending cuts, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said, because businesses and individuals must be able to count on the tax cuts. But by the time the tax cut is voted, ''we will have forced the hand of Congress'' on spending reductions, Mr. Regan added. Budget Director David A. Stockman, meanwhile, said the tax-cut proposal and the budget-cutting plan would both be part of a ''balanced economic package,'' but said he would not ''hold tax cuts hostage forever.'' (Page A1.)

title: Miss Krupsak Returning to Assembly, as a Counsel
description: She finally became Lieutenant Governor of New York, and recently ran unsuccessfully for the United States Senate. But Mary Anne Krupsak began her state political career in the New York Assembly, and that's where she's going to return.

title: STOCKMAN IS RUFFLING FEATHERS IN SEEKING BUDGET CUTS
description: The Reagan Administration has moved fairly smoothly through its first fortnight, but the rush to put together an economic package has produced a few bumps and made David A. Stockman, the energetic, hard-driving budget director, the target of a bit of private grumbling from his colleagues.

title: GROOMED FOR A DROUGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Corrupt Polish officials feast on the fruits of office A2 Iraqis reported to get about 100 Soviet-made tanks A4 Around the World A5 Clark recommended for State Department despite reservations A7 Government/Politics Democrats in Illinois Legislature boycott Governor's speech A8 Stockman efforts to cut U.S. budget cause grumbling A20 Cuomo denounces Regan's stand on welfare grant increases B3 Times Sq. plan tied to grant program that Reagan opposes B4 Democrats tweaking Administration on debt limit D20 General Around the Nation A8 Mrs. Harris continues to maintain account of shooting B1 Four killed and eight injured in fire at Jersey home for elderly B1 The City B3 Many New Jersey 18-year-olds are driving to New York to drink B3 The Region B4 Aliens describe 2,000 mile tripin locked truck as ''hell'' B4 Health/Science Team at Duke University sets deep-diving pressure mark B6 Education/Welfare Admitting women confronts Headmasters Association B1 Features/Notes Woman in the news: G. H. Brundt- land, Norway's Prime Minister A6 About New York B3 Notes on People B5 Going Out Guide C20 Obituaries Margaret Craig McNamara, founder of reading program B6 The Living Section Food Cold comforts: a cook's elixirs for winter's ills C1

title: IRAQIS REPORTED TO GET ABOUT 100 SOVIET MADE TANKS
description: Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries have reportedly been cooperating in recent weeks in the shipment of arms, including tanks, to Iraq for use in the war against Iran.

title: IRAN SEEKS TO DISCUSS JAILED AMERICAN
description: The Iranian authorities have asked for a meeting with Swiss diplomats tomorrow morning to discuss the fate of an American woman who has been imprisoned in Teheran for nine months, the State Department said today. Switzerland represents United States interests in Iran.

title: MAYOR ASSAILS 'SLOW DISPOSITION' OF CASES UNDER TOUGH GUN LAW
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that New York State's six-month-old strict law on pistols did not seem to be working and that he was prepared to request that special sections of the courts be set up to handle cases involving guns.

title: WINE-TASTING COURSES: SURVEY OF WHAT'S AVAILABLE IN MANHATTAN
description: One sip of wine in class may be worth a thousand sips alone. Taking a good wine course means learning to taste and analyze wine. It also means learning the characteristics of major wine regions and how to buy wine, order wine in a restaurant, read a label and judge quality. Most important, perhaps, a sound course takes the mystique out of wine and enhances the pleasure.

title: DAYS OF CAPTIVITY: THE HOSTAGES' STORY
description: FROM THOSE INSIDE, AN ACCOUNT OF HOW THE EMBASSY FELL AND HOW THEY ENDURED CAPTIVITY THE EMBASSY OCCUPIED The Narrators

title: FOLLOWING UP ON DOWN
description: To The Living Section: After reading the praiseworthy and banal thoughts from those secretaries about Tom Margittal's comments concerning them and down coats, I've decided that secretaries have a lot in common -- typing, steno and a complete lack of proportion about what was probably an offhand remark. If it was an attempt at wit, I hope Mr. Margittal's souffles rise to the occasion better than his sense of humor. Keith Powell Greenwich, Conn.

title: Rev. Falwell's Innocence
description: As in a 15th-century morality play, the Rev. Jerry Falwell, founder of the Moral Majority, and Bob Guccione, publisher of Penthouse magazine, played their parts faithfully. Mr. Falwell, representing Good, had to sue Penthouse when he learned that it was publishing, among its salacious nude photos, an interview he had given to two freelance writers. Mr. Guccione, personifying Temptation, had to plead the First Amendment - the part that safeguards freedom to publish without prior restraint.

title: No Headline
description: Four residents of a boarding home for the elderly in Point Pleasant Beach, N.J., were killed last night when a smoky fire swept the three-story frame house, a hospital spokesman said. At least 15 other elderly persons were injured, eight of them seriously.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday accompanying the first article in the series ''Your Taxes'' misstated the new ceiling on the dividend exclusion.

title: Coradian Seeking Private Concern
description: The Coradian Corporation of Latham, N.Y., has signed a letter of intent to purchase the Advanced Telephone and Communications Corporation of Needham, Mass., for an undisclosed amount of cash, notes and stock.

title: LOST AND FOUND DEPT.
description: Yesterday suddendly at the office I lost one of my oldest and dearest punctuation marks. Comma had been with me from the beginning separating thoughts numbers movie stars and so on.

title: People
description: * Robert N. Harris has been elected an executive vice president and Eugene Hatton and Jerome De Bord have joined Creamer Inc./Chicago as executive vice presidents.

title: U.S. VW Sales
description: Volkswagen of America said sales of its American-built cars rose 9 percent in late January but finished the entire month 8.5 percent below the January 1980 level.

title: Dell'Aglio Pleads Guilty To Wire Fraud Charge
description: Frank Dell'Aglio, whose involvement proved the kiss of death to two ad agencies, faces up to five years in prison after pleading guilty to a Federal grand jury information that had charged him with wire fraud.

title: CABINET UNCERTAIN ON SOVIET GRAIN
description: President Reagan's Cabinet, scheduled tomorrow to discuss lifting the restriction on grain sales to the Soviet Union, is expected to put off a decision on the increasingly sensitive question until a Cabinet committee can study it further.

title: MUSIC: JULLIARD STRINGS
description: WRITING music for string quartet has proven to be one of the 20thcentury composer's most favored activities, and the literature has been extraordinarily enriched over the last 80 years. That being the case, the Juilliard String Quartet had no trouble selecting three interestingly contrasted works for its Monday night concert in the Juilliard Theater, the second evening in the Juilliard School's continuing Festival of Contemporary Music.

title: REVIVED ISLANDERS TROUNCE KINGS BY 8-1
description: The Los Angeles Kings tonight proved the incentive that the Islanders had been looking for. After losing three of their preceding four games, the league-leading Islanders rose up and thumped their closest pursuers, 8-1, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: DIAMOND RECESSION HITS ISRAEL
description: When unemployed diamond workers demonstrated recently in front of this city's diamond bourse, they took up a chant of ''bread and work,'' a variation on Lenin's slogan during the Russian Revolution calling for peace, bread and land.

title: Chrysler Offer to Ottawa
description: Chrysler Canada Ltd., fighting along with its parent Chrysler Corporation to stave off bankruptcy, has made compromise proposals aimed at resolving conflicting demands from the Canadian and American governments, a Government source in Ottawa said late today.

title: An Overlooked Rizzuto
description: He's never made it into the Baseball Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N.Y., and Phil Rizzuto, the Yankee shortstop-turned-broadcaster, thinks he knows why.

title: REAGAN IS REPORTED READY TO ELIMINATE URBAN AID PROGRAM
description: A group of the nation's mayors reported today that they had been informed that President Reagan intended to eliminate a $675 million urban aid program aimed at generating private investment for shopping centers, factories and other projects in downtown areas.

title: House Prices Average $80,600
description: The average price of houses sold in the United States rose to a record $80,600 in the final three months of 1980, two Government agencies reported today. However, a separate Government housing price index declined slightly in the fourth quarter and showed a lower annual increase than in previous years.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Austin, Nichols & Company has named Robert W. Beck vice president for finance.

title: 10 F.A.L.N. SUSPECTS WON'T ATTEND TRIAL
description: Ten alleged members of the Puerto Rican terrorist organization F.A.L.N. will probably make no appearances before a jury and will not present a defense in their trial here on Federal charges of conspiracy, armed robbery, illegal possession of weapons and automobile theft.

title: by Moira Hodgson
description: This year, as Chinatown prepares for the celebration of the Year of the Rooster, 4679 to be exact, I am reminded of the Chinese New Years I spent in Vietnam during the late 50's. My father was in the British embassy and our servants were Chinese refugees, part of a large immigrant population that had settled in Saigon. Each Chinese New Year our house was ritually cleared of evil spirits, a ceremony practiced by Chinese refugees all over South East Asia.

title: Pakistani Press Curbs Protested
description: Newspaper and news agency journalists throughout Pakistan stopped work for two hours today to protest press censorship, the chairman of the Newspaper Employees Confederation reported. President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq imposed press censorship in October 1979 after postponing general elections and dissolving all political parties. Journalists wearing black armbands met here today and decided to set up a committee to campaign against the press curbs.

title: CHILDREN'S-BOOK PRIZES AWARDED
description: Authors of a novel on a girl's rivalry with her twin sister while growing up on a Chesapeake Bay island and a picture book of animal fables were named yesterday winners of the 1981 Newbery and Caldecott Medals, the nation's highest awards in children's books.

title: Commodity Appointment
description: Philip F. Johnson, a 42-year old Chicago lawyer, has been picked to head the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, a well-placed industry source said today. Mr. Johnson, a partner in Kirkland & Ellis, is chairman of the commodities subcommitee of the American Bar Association. Born in Springfield, Ohio, Mr. Johnson holds a bachelor's degree from Indiana University and took his legal training at Yale University. The appointment is expected to be announced shortly, the source said.

title: Anne X. Alpern Is Dead; Ex-Pennsylvania Justice
description: Former Justice Anne X. Alpern of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court died Monday at Montefiore Hospital in Pittsburgh. Judge Alpern, who was also former Attorney General of Pennsylvania, was believed to be in her 70's.

title: Harsco Directors Reject Crane Offer
description: Directors of the Harsco Corporation have rejected a $38-a-share takeover offer by the Crane Company, a Harsco spokesman said.

title: DEMOCRATS IN ILLNOIS SENATE HOLD RUMP SESSION TO REAGAN PODIUM
description: Democrats in the Illinois State Senate, defeated for the presidency of the chamber in a surprise move last month by outnumbered Republicans, met in an unauthorized session today and elected a Democrat in a bid to regain the presidency.

title: TWO WHO CREATED A LIBRARY ON ROOSEVELT ISLAND
description: Roosevelt Island is a place of 5,500 people situated in the swirls and eddies of the East River. While many older city neighborhoods are struggling to retain their character, Roosevelt Island, with its new Manhattan zip code of 10044, is slowly evolving a sense of community.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.50-20.00** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SMITH SAYS LIFE WAS IN DANGER, DENIES FRAUD CHARGES
description: Harold J. Smith, the boxing promoter missing for more than a week, said last night that bank managers and officers of various Wells Fargo National Bank branches in California had kidnapped his son and threatened the lives of his family to cover up a ''$200 or $300 million'' swindle of the bank.

title: 'Conversation With Arrau' On WNCN Next Week
description: ''Conversations With Arrau,'' a series of interviews with the pianist Claudio Arrau, will be broadcast on WNCN-FM (104.3) next Monday through Saturday at 7 P.M.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 4, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Scientific and technical subcommit- tee of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M.

title: Petrofina Confirms Sale to Petro-Canada
description: Petrofina S.A. confirmed that it had agreed to sell its Petrofina-Canada unit to Petro-Canada, the Canadian state oil agency, for about $1.46 billion in Canadian funds.

title: Bilingual Education, and Federal Duty
description: Secretary of Education Bell, in revoking the bilingual education regulations proposed by his predecessor, appears to be assailing a dragon when in fact he is only flogging a dead horse. The regulations have already been mortally wounded by Congress. It has forbidden the department to put them into effect pending legislative debate - wake might be more accurate -in the spring.

title: A 'Threat' Is Cited in Kush Case
description: Frank Kush acknowledged today in court that an Arizona State University booster had told him he witnessed a ''confrontation'' between the coach and Kevin Rutledge, a former player who contends that Kush punched him in a game in 1978.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE are a few ironies involved in writing a column on food. When we print a recipe for, say, from four to six people, I am often asked how to increase the ingredients to prepare the same dish for from 12 to 20. And if the recipe is for what might be called ''crowd cookery,'' I am asked how to reduce the recipe for a small group, say four to six.

title: Joblessness in Germany Rises
description: The number of unemployed people in West Germany rose in January to 1,308,600, the highest in five years, the Federal Labor Office said today. The unemployment rate was 5.6 percent.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Florida Power & Light filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $125 million of 30-year first mortgage bonds, to be offered in early March through a group led by Salomon Brothers.

title: HAROLD B. WAKEMAN
description: Howard B. Wakeman, former senior vice president and director of the Long Island Lighting Company, died Monday at his home in Garden City, L.I. He was 79 years old.

title: LOWER NEW YORK DRINKING AGE LURES JERSEY YOUTHS
description: ''In 10 minutes I'll be legal,'' said Anne Doyle, who turned 18 at the stroke of one recent midnight in the Cuckoo's Nest, a rock-music club on Route 303 here.

title: Wells Fargo Seals Fraud-Suit Papers
description: The Wells Fargo National Bank, which has charged that a group of sports promoters stole $21.3 million from its Beverly Hills branch, refused today to discuss details of the alleged theft and said that it had sealed court documents detailing the purported fraud.

title: Persistence Pays Off for Simmer
description: If you want to make a struggling hockey player happy, tell him the story of Charlie Simmer. He'd probably even like to hear it twice. It goes like this:

title: BILL TO CURB CAR IMPORTS PLANNED
