description: The chairman and the ranking Democrat on the Senate trade subcommittee said today that they would introduce legislation to restrict entry of Japanese cars into this country, intensifying pressure on the Reagan Administration to negotiate import restraints.

title: ORDERS RISE IN MONTH AT FACTORIES
description: New orders for factory goods rose 1.9 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported today. The increase was viewed as a new sign of underlying strength in the economy.

title: News Analysis
description: At diplomatic lunches, in the delegates' lounge and along the corridors here the talk has turned to the sharp criticism of Secretary General Kurt Waldheim and Donald F. McHenry, the former United

title: THE WOMAN AT THE HELM IN NORWAY
description: Gro Harlem Brundtland, a 41-year-old physician, was designated today as Norway's new Prime Minister without sentimentality or much excitement.

title: Jersey Suing to Get U.S. Census Results
description: NEWARK (AP) - A state commission filed suit against the United States Census Bureau, charging that its date for releasing a new count was so late that New Jersey would not have time to redistrict for 1981 elections.

title: TV: LITTLE ROCK, 1957: 'CRISIS AT CENTRAL HIGH'
description: ''CRISIS AT CENTRAL HIGH,'' on CBS-TV tonight at 8:30, is structured around the confrontation nearly 24 years ago over school integration in Little Rock, Ark., between Federal and state authorities and between President Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Orval Faubus. The restrained script was written by William Link and Richard Levinson, whose previous outstanding credits include ''That Certain Summer'' and ''The Execution of Private Slovik.'' Along with David Susskind of Time Life Films, Mr. Link and Mr. Levinson also served as executive producers.

title: GALA FOR ISRAEL TO SEE 'CHOSEN'
description: What is described as the largest theater party ever held will be part of a celebration on May 11 in 32 countries marking the 33d anniversary of the State of Israel. The party will feature the premiere of the film ''The Chosen.''

title: HENDERSON SINGS MERCER LIKE MERCER
description: BILL HENDERSON, who sang with Count Basie's orchestra in the 1960's and more recently has been both actor and singer in television and films (his most recent film appearance is ''Inside Moves''), has come into Michael's Pub with a collection of Johnny Mercer songs to which he brings a singing style that suggests the jaunty quality that Mr. Mercer had as a singer, even while he reveals his own individual manner.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH MYTH
description: Asthma is a psychosomatic disease, caused by emotions. FACT: Stress and emotional upset can trigger attacks, but only in a person who already has asthma. In most patients, emotional problems result from, rather than cause, the asthma.

title: Herb Brooks Will Coach American Hockey Squad
description: Herb Brooks, who coached the United States Olympic hockey team to a gold medal a year ago and was later considered for a head-coaching job with the New York Rangers, has been named coach of the United States national amateur team that will play in the world championship tournament in Sweden in April.

title: BAN ON RABBIT'S FEET UPSETTING TO FRENCH
description: PARIS NOTHING unsettles the French more than having someone tinker with tradition, particularly when it involves food. Recently, a fuss has arisen over the rabbit's foot - or lack of it.

title: Waldheim Bids Arms Parley Work to End Nuclear Race
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations urged delegates to the 40-nation disarmament conference today at the start of their annual session here to give ''priority attention'' to ending the nuclear arms race.

title: Brooklyn College to Stage 'Little Mary Sunshine'
description: ''Little Mary Sunshine,'' the 1959 spoof of musical comedies that had one of the longest Off Broadway runs, will be presented in the Gershwin Theater in Brooklyn College's Center for the Performing Arts from March 4 through 8.

title: Professionals Under Pressure
description: The yellow ribbons have vanished, the ticker tape has been swept up and already some pundits are wondering sourly what all the cheering was about. Other Americans have been held captive, it is said; the hoopla is discounted as a media event, a distraction from national humiliation. All that may be debatable; but there is one point that alone justifies all the cheers. As the detailed account in today's Times makes clear, the Americans in Teheran acquitted themselves with high honor,

title: St. John's Names Law School Dean
description: Dr. Patrick J. Rohan, a professor in the St. John's University Law School since 1958, has been appointed dean. Dr. Rohan, 47 years old, of Bronxville, who has also been a visiting professor at the Columbia and New York University Law Schools, succeeds the late Dr. John J. Murphy.

title: U.S. Intelligence Units Criticized by a Top Aide
description: Adm. Bobby Ray Inman, the director of the National Security Agency, who has been nominated to be Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, said today that intelligence agencies had underestimated the Soviet military threat.

title: MRS. HARRIS STICKS BY STORY OF NIGHT OF FATAL SHOOTING
description: A weary but controlled Jean S. Harris, standing trial for murder, held to her account today of what occurred on the night Dr. Herman Tarnower was shot in his bedroom, but added new evidence of her considerable scorn for Lynne Tryforos, her rival for the doctor's love.

title: Hatfield Asks New Post For Military Readiness
description: Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, asked Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger yesterday to create a new office to help overcome shortcomings in the preparedness of American armed forces.

title: Connecticut Court Kills Bus Fare Rise
description: HARTFORD (AP) - The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a 15-cent fare increase imposed by the Connecticut Transit Company last March was illegal.

title: Frank Dodd in Race
description: Senator Frank J. Dodd, Democrat of West Orange, became the fourth person to announce formally that he is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor.

title: SENATE APPROVES DONOVAN, REJECTING BRIBE ALLEGATIONS
description: The Senate, rejecting allegations by underworld informers, completed President Reagan's Cabinet today by approving the nomination of Raymond J. Donovan as Secretary of Labor.

title: Chinese Is Jailed for Killing Swan
description: A Chinese District Court sentenced a young construction worker to three months in jail today for shooting a swan in a Peking park, the Peking Evening News reported.

title: TREASURY SECRETARY REJECTS LINKING TAX CUT TO BUDGETARY REDUCTIONS
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today rejected the idea of linking tax cuts to spending reductions. Tying the two, Mr. Regan argued, would remove a principal feature of the Administration's tax plan: providing assurances of multiyear tax reductions on which both business and individuals can count.

title: KOCH FOES JOIN TO OPPOSE BID TO 'FORECLOSE' ELECTION
description: Political opponents of Mayor Koch -including two of his former Deputy Mayors and his 1977 campaign treasurer - protested yesterday that he was ''trying to foreclose the 1981 mayoralty election before it begins.''

title: FOR 3-STAR O'NEALS, FILMS ARE BETTER THAN EVER
description: The O'Neal family has rivaled the Fondas this week. With 17-year-old Tatum O'Neal signed today to star in Polygram Pictures' ''Captured,'' Ryan O'Neal, his son and his daughter are each starring in a motion picture for a different studio.

title: ON SPAIN'S ECONOMY
description: The resignation of Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez last week reflects the crisis in Spain's economy and the worsening of longstanding regional tensions. Recognized unemployment stands at 12 percent, up from 10 percent a year ago, and inflation has averaged nearly 18 percent since 1973. The 1980 balance-of-trade deficit was unprecedentedly large.

title: DOLLAR SOARS AGAIN; MARK AT 3-YEAR LOW
description: The dollar continued its surge on European currency markets today, largely at the expense of the West German mark, which fell to its lowest point in three years.

title: LITTERED CLEANUP
description: To the Editor:

title: Velasquez, in Spill, Breaks Collarbone at Gulfstream
description: Jorge Velasquez, who last week rode his 4,000th winner at Gulfstream, suffered a broken collarbone today in a spill in the fifth race at Gulfstream.

title: COURT UPHOLDS CANNON AIDE'S PAY IN 1976 CAMPAIGN
description: Members of Congress may legally keep their staff aides on the Congressional payroll while the aides are working full time on re-election campaigns for extended periods, according to a unanimous decision issued by a Federal appellate court here.

title: Holy Cross 68, Army 60
description: Gary Witts scored 17 points, including the basket that put Holy Cross ahead for good, and the Crusaders went on to topple Army tonight, 68-60. Nearly-flawless foul shooting in the final minutes insured the triumph.

title: LUNCHTIME IN HOLLYWOOD: DEALS A LA CARTE
description: LOS ANGELES LUNCH in Hollywood - as in any corporate maze - means a multitude of things. What you eat is the least of them. ''Actually,'' one studio executive says, ''if we're getting close to the deal, close to saying 'Let's have the lawyers in,' I'll serve lunch in the conference room next to my office. Those lunches tend to be very Spartan - diet cola and salads without dressing, and both participants trying to one-up each other by eating less.''

title: PROGRESS IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR ACADEMY TO DROP ITS BAN ON APPLICANTS WITH SICKLE-CELL GENE
description: The Air Force Academy, which since 1973 has been the only major service academy to exclude applicants with a single gene for sicklecell anemia, dropped its ban yesterday.

title: Refiners Raise Prices of Fuels
description: Several of the nation's largest refiners yesterday raised wholesale prices for gasoline, home heating oil and diesel fuel by up to 5 cents a gallon, continuing a round of increases begun after President Reagan's decision to lift Federal oil price controls.

title: NEW YORK'S WINE CROP IS THREATENED BY FREEZE
description: A devastating freeze in the vineyards of upstate New York threatens to wipe out most of the grape crop of 1981, and a severe cutback in wine production is in prospect. Potential losses in some types of grapes, especially the tender European varietals, are running 80 to 90 percent, and the overall loss for the state is expected to be more than 50 percent.

title: TENNECO REPORTS RISE OF 22%; COMMONWEALTH OIL ADVANCES
description: Tenneco Inc. reported fourth-quarter earnings of $200 million, or $1.56 a share, up 22 percent from earnings of $164 million, or $1.50 a share, for the similar quarter in 1979.

title: Trudeau Wins Court Test On Canadian Constitution
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, faced with strong opposition from the provinces and hesitation in Britain, won his first court case today over his plan to establish a new Canadian constitution.

title: WHAT'S TAXABLE INCOME? I.R.S. TAKES BROAD VIEW
description: Your TaxesA Guide to Preparing 1980 ReturnsThird of 12 articles.- By DEBORAH RANKIN

title: Paper Mate Campaign Is Planned for July
description: Gillette's Paper Mate division brought out its Eraser Mate, a ballpoint pen with erasable ink, early in 1979 to sell for $1.98.

title: News of the Theater; A Show for Lena Horne
description: LENA HORNE is returning to Broadway. She will be in a one-character show, as yet untitled, that is being written by Samm-Art Williams and that may be staged, not directed, by Arthur Mitchell. Mr. Williams wrote ''Home,'' which was a Tony nominee last season, and Mr. Mitchell runs the Dance Theater of Harlem. Meanwhile, the show, according to one of the producers, is a kind of ''hybrid'' - some music, some autobiography, some history and a lot of Miss Horne. It will open at a Nederlander theater on April 12.

title: Assembly Unit Rejects 21 as the Drinking Age
description: A bill to raise the minimum drinking age in New York State to 21, from 18, was rejected today by the Assembly's Committee on Commerce, Industry and Economic Development.

title: HUNT IS ON FOR SOURCE OF PCB'S IN NATURAL-GAS LINES
description: The discovery last month of a toxic chemical - polychlorinated biphenyls, also called PCB's - in a Long Island homeowner's naturalgas system has led to a nationwide hunt for the source of the pollution.

title: LAW FREEING BANKS NEAR IN DELAWARE
description: The Delaware Legislature passed complex new banking legislation late tonight that is expected to have a nationwide impact on consumer credit regulations and costs. It could also result in revenue losses for New York.

title: MOST MAJOR BANKS DROP PRIME TO 19 1 2% FROM 20%
description: Responding to declining loan demand and the lower cost of funds, most of the nation's leading banks reduced their prime lending rates yesterday to 19 1/2 percent from 20 percent.

title: GAP IN THE SUNBELT
description: To the Editor:

title: POLISH LEADER CHARGES 'INSEGATORS' TRY TO MAKE UNION AN OPPOSITION
description: In the toughest speech he has delivered, Stanislaw Kania, the Polish Communist Party leader, has said that instigators are transforming the Solidarity independent trade union into a political opposition and sowing anarchy.

title: ILLEGAL ALIENS TERM 2,000 MILES IN LOCKED TRUCK 'HELL'
description: It was ''like a hell'' on the nonstop 2,000-mile trip for 85 men and women locked into a truck for nearly three days on a trip from El Paso to New York, Manuel Roberto Mejia said yesterday. Mr. Mejia, who was one of the people in the truck, spoke Spanish, using the word ''infierno'' to describe conditions on the long ride.

title: ROCKWELL SELLS UNIT
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said it had sold its General Aviation division to the Gulfstream American Corporation for an undisclosed price.

title: Rev. Falwell Won't File Suit Against Penthouse
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell said today that he would not file a lawsuit seeking damages from Penthouse magazine for publishing an interview with him in its March issue.

title: Advertising; Reaching The Top At O.& M.
description: year climb.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE WHIRL OF COUTURE
description: PARIS WITH all the couture shows here now compressed into four days, and the American manufacturers, the big spenders of the 1950's and the 1960's, no longer coming, the grand evenings at three-star restaurants are a thing of the past. Invitations are now for a plate of spaghetti or some Chinese food.

title: Helen Reddy to Divorce
description: Helen Reddy, the Australian-born singer, filed for divorce Monday from Jeff Wald, her New York-born husband and manager of 12 years.

title: Nets Show Interest In Williams
description: The New Jersey Nets said yesterday that the lines of communication were open for attempting to acquire Gus Williams, the former Seattle SuperSonic guard who is a free agent.

title: A Supporter for Massey?
description: Maurice F. Strong, the Canadian millionaire oilman and environmentalist, may be returning to the public eye -there are reports in Toronto that he may make a major investment in financially troubled Massey-Ferguson Ltd.

title: Maryland Seeks to Force Agnew To Pay $200,000 to End Lawsuit
description: The State of Maryland asked a judge today to order former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew to pay $200,000 to settle the bribery case that drove him from office in 1973.

title: TENTATIVE APPROVAL FOR CPE HOBART BID
description: An Ohio securities official yesterday gave a unit of Canadian Pacific Enterprises, CPE (U.S.) Inc., clearance to pursue a takeover of the Hobart Corporation, but only if the parent conglomerate, based in Montreal, provided further financial disclosure.

title: RECORD YIELD AT TREASURY SALE
description: The Treasury auctioned $3.75 billion of 3 1/2-year notes yesterday at a record average yield of 13.37 percent. The previous record yield was 13.31 percent on 3 1/2-year notes sold last Nov. 17.

title: Winston Network Sells TDI Transit Ad Unit
description: Winston Network, the biggest operation in transit advertising, with about $43 million in revenues last year, has reached an agreement to sell off of its TDI unit to Ackerley Communications in Seattle for $11.61 million.

title: SENATORS RECOMMEND CLARK FOR STATE DEPT. DESPITE RESERVATIONS
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to recommend the confirmation of William P. Clark as Deputy Secretary of State, despite objections from Democrats that Mr. Clark was ''an embarrassing appointment'' who was unqualified for the post.

title: For Circus Performers, It's Action That Counts
description: Modern actors are well-known for their tendency to explore a character or stage movement and talk endlessly about hidden meanings in a script. Circus performers, on the other hand, don't indulge in such over-intellectualizing, according to Paul Binder, who's been training both actors and circus performers lately.

title: Tentative Accord Reached For Philadelphia Schools
description: A tentative settlement was reached tonight in a judge's chambers by negotiators for the school district and the union representing the 4,300 blue-collar workers whose strike forced closing of schools for 225,000 Philadelphia students.

title: New Man at Superior Oil
description: Another step in preparation for the retirement of Howard B. Keck, 67, as chairman of the Superior Oil Company has been taken with the hiring of Fred C. Ackman, 50, as executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Houston-based corporation.

title: Ampco Is Extending Buffalo Forge Offer
description: Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation said it would extend until tomorrow its $25 per share tender offer to the shareholders of Buffalo Forge Company. The offer was to have expired at midnight last night.

title: REAGAN DELAY STIRS CONCERN OVER SCIENTIFIC POLICY POSTS
description: Three months after his election, President Reagan has not appointed a science adviser or filled any of a dozen or so top scientific and medical policy posts in his Administration.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (AL) - Completed sale of club t o Jerry Reinsdorf and Eddie Einhorn. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed Moose H aas, pitcher, to multiyear contract.

title: Market Place; Outside Counsel And Takeovers
description: Acorporate executive would be foolish not to rely on experienced outside counsel in the baffling world of corporate tenders. But in three key cases in recent years, major corporations have received a black eye from the Securities and Exchange Commission, which rarely takes sides in such cases. The corporations were charged with overstepping the rules, and though they had acted on the advice of outside counsel, the advisers emerged unscathed.

title: Learning How to Count Foreign Aid
description: Foreign policy makers in Washington tend to view the world through one of three prisms: East-West, West-West or North-South relations. The Reagan Administration's focus is East-West; it has been making stern noises about the Soviet Union and wants to spend added billions on a military buildup. That may be sound, but there is danger in forgetting that most future Soviet-American contests will involve the third world and the Western alliance.

title: U.S. Looks Into Charges Soviet Broke Arms Pact
description: The Reagan Administration is examining alleged Soviet violations of the 1972 strategic arms treaty as part of a review of arms control policy toward Moscow, the State Department said today.

title: CHAINS LIFT CREDIT RATE
description: Macy's New York, the state's largest retailer, yesterday said it would increase its annual interest rate on revolving credit accounts to 19.8 percent from 18 percent, or to 1.65 percent monthly from 1.5 percent. The company's 17 stores from New York City to the Albany area are said to serve more than a million charge accounts.

title: CETA'S BRIDGE 'TO NOWHERE'
description: To the Editor:

title: 'SCULPTURE '81' WILL OPEN AT LEVER HOUSE FEB. 18
description: "Sculpture '81," an exhibition reflecting the diversity of styles that have emerged among black sculptors, will open Feb. 18 at Lever House, Park Avenue and 53d Street.

title: Around the World; MRS. BRUNDTLAND INSTALLED AS NORWAY'S PRIME MINISTER
description: Gro Harlem Brundtland was formally installed today as Prime Minister of Norway. She said in a speech afterward that her Labor Government would continue a policy of full employment and social welfare and base its national security on membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: REAGAN TRUST MANAGER GETS HIGH MARKS
description: When Raymond J. Armstrong visits companies he wants to invest in, one thing he looks for is "managements that have big egos, where their reach exceeds their grasp." That way, he says, "we know that management is going to do a super job for us."

title: Around the Nation; FALWELL SAYS HE WILL PRESS $10 MILLION PENTHOUSE SUIT
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell said today that he would pursue a $10 million damage suit against Penthouse, even though a Federal judge refused to block distrubution of an issue of the magazine that includes an interview with him.

title: CUOMO IS ENJOYING HIS STAY IN PRO TEM ROOM AT THE TOP
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had finished a speech, and a woman rose to ask a question. "Governor Como," she began, and Mr. Cuomo raised a hand.

title: SYRACUSE SIGNS BOISCLAIR
description: - Bruce Boisclair, who played baseball last year in Japan with the Hanshin Tigers after four seasons with the Mets, has been signed to a minor league contract with the Toronto Blue Jays' Syracuse affiliate in the International League.

title: STEEL EXECUTIVE TO PAY $7,500
description: A former Bethlehem Steel Company executive accused of embezzling nearly $1 million in corporate funds has agreed to pay the company $7,500.

title: 20 MAFIA SUSPECTS HELD IN SICILY
description: The police arrested 20 suspected members of Mafia gangs in Catania and nearby villages in overnight raids, court officials reported today.

title: Notes on People; UPSTAGED PRESIDENT
description: "I thought people danced at balls," President Reagan said yesterday, commenting on last month's 10 inaugural ball. "Instead there were were wall-to-wall people, and Nancy and I had to dance on the stage."

title: The Freedom Workers
description: Put yourself in the mind of the Polish worker and ask this question: What can the West do to help me win more freedom?

title: BORG, CONNORS MCENROE GAIN
description: - John McEnroe was awarded a forfeit victory over Illie Nastase, Bjorn Borj and Vitas Gerulaitis struggled en route to three-set victories and Jimmy Connors achieved a two-set triumph today in the first round of the $500,000Challenge Cup tennis tournament.

title: MISS HILL TAKES LEAD IN U.S. FIGURE SKATING
description: - Priscilla Hill, scoring high in her speciality, took a narrow lead over the co-favorites Elaine Zayak and Lisa-Marie Allen after the compulsory figures phase of the national figure skating championships tonight.

title: REAGAN SHOULD OPPOSE THE RIGHT TO LIFE MOVEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Improvement; USED PROPERLY, RADIANT HEATERS CAN SAVE ON HOME FUEL BILLS.
description: In an effort to cut down on energy costs, many homeowners have long been turning down the thermostat on their heating systems. Many have tried to get by with simply wearing warmer clothing, and this is workable for manypeople.

title: CONCERT: THE JUILLIARD'S PHILHARMONIA IN FESTIVAL
description: Over the years, numerous works by Marga Richter, Frances Thorne and Lester Trimble have been performed in New York, but for the Juilliard Festival of Contemporary Music concert given by the Juilliard Philharmonia under the direction of Jose Serebrier Tuesday night, each composer was represented by a piece for large orchestra that had not been heard here previously. Miss Richter's was "Blackberry Vines and Winter Fruit" (1976), Mr. Thorne's was "The Eternal Light" (1979) and Mr. Trimble's was "Sonic Landscape" (1958, revised1968).

title: ISRAELI SEES AIR DEFENSE SETBACKS IF SAUDIS OBTAIN F-15 EQUIPMENT
description: A senior military analyst here said today that Israel would be compelled to establish a new line of air defense and early warning equipment if the United States sold Saudi Arabia jet fighter equipment that would enable the Saudis to strike targets inside Israel.

title: RAIDERS-N.F.L. TRIAL IS PUT OFF
description: - A trial of the National Football League's opposition to the relocation of the Oakland Raiders in Los Angeles was postponed today until March 23.

title: FRANCE SAID TO GET IRAQ OIL
description: Iraq has resumed shipping crude oil to France, and has scheduled shipments of about 60,000 barrels daily for the remainder of February, oil company sources said today.

title: 'BIG 6' CITIES SEEK A SHARE OF MEDICAID COST SAVINGS
description: The Mayors of New York's "Big Six" cities asked today that the Legislature require counties to share the billion-dollar savings from the state takeover of local Medicaid costs proposed by Governor Carey.

title: TO THANK ALGERIA
description: To the Editor

title: Notes on People; CARTER'S RETURN SUNDAY FROM VIRGIN ISLAND VACATION
description: Jimmy Carter, his wife, Rosalynn, and their son Chip, who have been vacationing on St. John in the Virgin Islands since Jan. 27, plan to fly back to Georgia Sunday. Amy Carter returned to Plains on Monday to re-enter school there.

title: DOW MARKS TIME; AIRLINES GAIN
description: Airline issues and specialty stocks moved higher yesterday, while popular market averages generally showed little change. The Dow Jones industrial average edged ahead 0.60, to 941.98, with advancing stocks outnumbering declines by 9 to 5. Volume totaled 45.5 million shares, down slightly from Tuesday's 46 million. Analysts said one reason for yesterday's indecisive market action was that investors were awaiting President Reagan's speech on the economy, scheduled for tonight. Airline stocks benefited from a move by the Civil Aeronautics Board granting the carriers greater flexibility in raising air fares. The C.A.B. cited higher fuel costs resulting from the recent decontrol of domestic crude oil prices. Strength in the airlines accounted for a gain of 3.94 points, to 400,52, in the Dow transportation average. On the active list, American Airlines climbed 1 point, to 11-1/8. UAL Inc., the volume leader, gained 3/4, to 22-1/2. Pan American World Airways moved up 3/8, to 5. The company reported sharply higher earnings, reflecting the gain on the sale of its headquarters building in New York City. Elsewhere, Northwest Airlines and the Trans World Corporation each gained 7/8.

title: THE SWIFTLY GROWING FIELD OF TAPESTRIES AND THE FIBER ARTS
'SPIRIT' SHOW HIGHLIGHTS CONTEMPORARY PAINTING
description: Having dipped its toe into the turbulent waters of 20thcentury international painting with the post-Impressionist exhibition last year, the Royal Academy of Arts has now dived right in with its current show, "A New Spirit in Painting."

title: GERMAN'S SEEM UNWILLING TO DEPLOY NEUTRON ARMS
description: A Government spokesman suggested today that Bonn was no longer willing, as it had been in 1978, to permit deployment of neutron weapons on West German territory.

title: NOTRE DAME 60, LA SALLE 59
description: - Kelly Tripucka had 6 of his game-19 points during a 16-4 Notre Dame scoring surge to open te second half tonight as the Irish beat La Salle, 60-59.

title: TENTATIVE BUDGET-CUT LIST DISTRIBUTED ON CAPITOL HILL
description: A preliminary list of suggested budget reductions that was prepared by the Reagan Administration and is being circulated in Congress includes severe cuts in such programs as food stamps, meals for poor schoolchildren, jobs for the unemployed and compensation for workers who have been laid off.

title: WORKER'S PROBABLY 'LETHAL DOSE' OF RADIOCACTIVITY IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is investigating a rare and probably "lethal dose" of radioactivity that has put a 38-year-old Oklahoman in a Tulsa hospital with external bleeding and what the agency termed "destroyed bone marrow."

title: New Haven Led by the example of the National Playwrights Conference of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, many theaters and other organizations offer playwrights an opportunity to see their new plays in staged readings or workshops, but there is a shortage of places that provide a next step of theatrical nurturing.  Too often, plays are prematurely jumped to the commercial arena.
description: To relieve that pressure on a nascent work, LLoyd Richards, artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater and dean of the Yale School of Drama as well as artistic director of the National Playwrights Conference, this year instituted a "Winterfest - a word of Mr. Richards's devising -- is a repertory season of new plays, full professional productions of four works in progress.

title: Around the Nation; REAGAN DESIGNATES RANCH A 'WESTERN WHITE HOUSE'
description: President Reagan has signed documents designating his Santa Barbara County ranch as the Western White House and has planned a visit there Feb. 19, The Santa Barbara News-Press reported today.

title: The City; FLU HAS PEAKED, HEALTH CHIEF SAYS
description: The outbreak of flu has peaked in the city with a few weeks left in the flu season, the Health Department said.

title: BRITISH MISSIONARY COUPLE SLAIN BY BLACKS AT SCHOOL IN ZIMBABWE
description: Two unidentified blacks beat a British missionary couple to death in Zimbabwe last night, apparently in revenge for a South African raid into neighboring Mozambique, a church spokesman said today.

title: Books of the Times
description: AZTEC. By Gary Jennings. 754 pages. Illustrated with Endpaper Maps. Atheneum. $15.95. AYYO! -- as the characters in Gary Jennings's dazzling and hypnotic historical novel are wont to exclaim. The Bishop of the See of Mexico in New Spain writes at least one true thing in the reports he sends to his Emperor Don Carlo. Mixtli, the 63-yearold Indian narrator of the chronicle accompanying the Bishop's reports, is indeed "an Aeolus with an inexhaustible bag of wind" and a "human cataract" who 'cannot be restrained." Mixtli's autobiography goes on for more than 700 word-crammed pages.

title: The Region; MINIMUM-BET RULE DROPPED IN JERSEY
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission voted, 3 to 2, yesterday to drop immediately its regulations requiring low minimum bets at blackjack, roulette and dice tables. The action followed arguments by casino spokesmen that low-bet tables were unprofitable and representative of "overregulation" they said was halting further development.

title: JUAN CARLOS UNDAUNTED BY BASQUE PROTEST
description: King Juan Carlos emerged successful today from a confrontation with Basque legislators close to the terrorist organization E.T.A.

title: REFINISHING MAPLE PIECES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores antiques for dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title:
Design Notebook;
MODERN-LIFE BATTLE: CONQUERING CLUTTER
description: There are two kinds of people in the world -- those who have horror of a vacuum and those with a horror of the things that fill it. Translated into domestic interiors, this means people who live with, and without, clutter. (Dictionary definition: jumble, confusion, disorder.) The reasons for clutter, the need to be surrounded by things, goes deep, from security to status. The reasons for banning objects, or living in as selective and austere an enviornment as possible, range from the esthetic to the neurotic. This is a phenomenon of choice that relates as much to the psychiatrist as to the tastemaker.Some people clutter compulsively, and others just as compulsively t hrow things away. Clutter in its highest and most organized form i s called collecting. Collecting can be done as the Collyer b rothers did it, or it can be done with art and flair. The range i s from oldnewspapers to Faberge.

title: DROPPED TV NEWS SPOT STIRS COAST POLICY FIGHT
description: - The cancellation of the "Evening Edition" news program KQED-TV, this city's public-television station, has generated several hundred viewer complaints and a policy struggle at the station.

title: Decision to Produce Plutonium Is a Challenge to U.S. in Dispute Over Delays in Supplies
description: The highest officials of India's Atomic Energy Commission said here today that they had authorized the reprocessing of spent nuclear fuels into much more toxic and dangerous plutonium oxide.

title: JOSEPH P.D'AREZZO
description: Joseph P. D'Arezzo, a vice president for AMF Inc. died Monday of a heart attack while in Venice on a business trip. Mr.D'Arezzo, who resided in Alexandria, Va., was 63 years old.

title: Home Beat; DANCER, PAINTER, POTTER
description: A MULTIFACETED artist is one way to describe Richard Zelens. Since he came to New York 20 years ago from Dubuque, Iowa, he's been a dancer, studied art at Cooper Union, and painted fabrics in association with Alan Campbell.

title: HERS
description: LOOKING out upon the world from where I am -well into the middle years, enjoying those academic attainments possible to one who kept her nose clean and pressed to the grindstone before the current economic crisis, yet with enough family to suggest proper attention to that ''feminine'' sphere - looking out from this place, I ask myself what it is I lack, what, in fact, most women lack. My question is unrelated to looks, a waistline, a fashionable wardrobe, or the possession of living room furniture that would not be scorned by the Salvation Army. These are ends either unobtainable, or too easily obtained by efforts I do not care to make. My lack is rather of something central, interfused, vital, something I feel is not there, has never been there.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS ,
description: Gardening Workshops, Building 272, Gateway Recreation Area, Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn.

title: Commodities; OATS FUTURES PRICES RISE IN MIXED GRAINS MARKET
description: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mixed yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after losing much of the momentum behind the sharp advances on Tuesday.

title: BRITISH AEROSPACE SHARES
description: Arrangements have been completed for the sale of shares in state-owned British Aerospace, the underwriters of the issue, Kleinwort, Benson Ltd., said today. The Government will retain between 48.37 percent and 50 percent of the company, the underwriter added, but the exact number of shares to be sold will depend on the number purchased by employees. A further announcement with details of the offering will be made tomorrow.

title: JERSEY BASED STORE CHAIN NAMES CHIEF
description: Herbert Kurtz, 54, who was president of the Rockower Brothers men's wear merchandising company until its liqidation was completed last December, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Ups 'n Downs, a specialty-store chain based in Secaucus, N.J., with close to 200 units. He suceeds Burton B. Brous, 52 who resigned and will become a consultant to the company.

title: GANNETT REPORTS GAIN
description: The Gannett Company said today that fourth-quarter earnings were $47.9 million, or 88 cents a share, up 15 percent from $41.6 million, or 77 cents a share, in the last three months of 1979.

title: PLEA BY TEXAS OFFICIAL'S WIDOW
description: The widow of Price Daniel Jr., former Speaker of the Texas House, pleaded not guilty today to murder charges in her husband's death. Vickie Daniel, 33 years old, is accused of killing Mr. Daniel Jan. 19 at their home north of Liberty.

title: MAVERICKS LOSE, 116-68
description: - The Dallas Mavericks hit the lowest point of their first season in the National Basketball Association tonight in a 116-68 loss to the Houston Rockets. The Mavericks, with the worst record in the league, 8-47, had the previous season low, 73 points, against Philadelphia.

title: 'EXPERIENCED' ENVOY TO SALVADOR
description: The appointment of Frederic L. Chapin, a career diplomat with Defense Department experience as acting head of the United States Embassy in El Salvador was made, the State Department said today, because of the need for "an experienced diplomat" in that post during a "critical time" in El Salvador.

title: The Region; MARGIOTTA TRIAL SET FOR WESTBURY
description: A Federal judge ruled that the fraud trial of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman, would be held in the Federal Court in Westbury, L.I. Mr. Margiotta wanted the Westbury court rather than the Federal Court in Brooklyn, as Government prosecutors wanted.

title: MAX TACHNA
description: Max Tachna, A New York lawyer who was active in civic affairs in the 1920's and 1930's, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 94 years old and lived in Baldwin, L.I.

title: REGAN UP FOR BANK POSTS
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate his Treasury Secretary, Donald T. Regan to be United States governor of the International Monetary Fund for five years, United States governor of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development known generally as the World Bank, for five years, governor of the Inter-American Development Bank for five years, and governor of the Asian Development Bank and the African Development Fund.

title: NEW BUSINESS TAX ASKED BY CONNECTICUT GOVERNOR
description: Gov. William A. O'Neil called tonight for a new tax on unincorporated businesses to balance a $3 billion state budget for the fiscal year starting July 1.

title: MORAL MAJORITY ESTABLISHES BEACHHEAD IN NEW YORK
description: Last autumn, candidates for office throughout New York State received a two-page questionnaire in the mail. The first page asked the usual questions about some of the usual issues - capital punishment, welfare, the equal rights amendment, abortion.

title: News of Music
description: An unusual number of books on classical music subjects are scheduled to be published this spring. One reason for this burst of activity, according to an editor at Doubleday, which is readying Luciano Pavarotti's autobiography for March publication, is the extraordinary amount of music that may be heard and seen on television nowadays.Mr. Pavarotti's many telecasts have made him an especially popular figure, even among people who have never seen him in a live performance.

title: WELLS FARGO BANK SAYS ALLEGATION OF A $200 MILLION FRAUD IS ABSURD
description: The chariman of the Wells Fargo National Bank, which contended Monday that it had been defrauded of $21.3 million by several boxing promoters, today termed "preposterous" assertions by one of the promoters that the bank had actually lost more than $200 million.

title: REP. HINSON OF MISSISSIPPI ARRESTED IN THE CAPITAL ON A MORALS CHARGE
description: Representative Jon C. Hinson, Republican of Mississippi, was arrested on a morals charge today in a public men's room in the Longworth House Office Building, the Capitol Police said.

title: U.S. GRAIN AND THE RUSSIANS
description: Thirteen months ago the United States curtailed grain shipments to the Soviet Union in reaction to Moscow's military intervention in Afghanistan.

title: U.S. CAR MAKERS ADDING MORE ALUMINUM, PLASTIC
description: American auto companies, in an effort to increase fuel efficiency by making lighter cars are using more parts made of aluminum and plastic. "The most exciting development programs currently under way in Detroit include doors, hoods and trunk lids made from reinforced plastics," said Gregory Galagher, transportation market manager for PPG Industries' Fiber Glass division in Pittsburg.

title: CONCENTRATION FOUND IN CORPORATE OWNERS
description: A senate staff study of who owns America's 100 leading corporations has found a high degree of concentration, rooted in overlapping institutional stock holding and interlocking directorates.

title: GARE AND WILSON SUSPENDED
description: - Danny Gare, right wing of the Buffalo Sabres, and Behn Wilson, defenseman of the Philadelphia Flyers, have been suspended for three games as the result of match penalities received an automatic fine of $200 for the match penalty.

title: Watchdogs That Can't Bark
description: Firing 15 inspectors general from the major executive departments was an odd beginning for the new Administration, dedicated as it is to controlling the bureaucracy and fighting waste and fraud.

title: ALOUETTES DENY OFFERING WALKER A $2 MILLION DEAL
description: Representatives of the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League denied today reports that they had made a $2 million offer to Herschel Walker, Georgia's freshman running star.

title: MRS. PERON IS ACQUITTED BY COURT OF MISUSING PRESIDENTIAL FUNDS
description: A federal judge acquitted former President Isabel Martinez de Peron and two aides today of charges they misspent presidential reserve funds during her 21-month Government, which was overthrown by the armed forces in 1976. The decision gave support to growing speculation that Mrs. Peron, 50 years old today, may soon be released.

title: REAGAN ENCOUNTERS RESISTANCE TO PLAN TO RAISE DEBT LIMIT
description: President Reagan visited Capitol Hill today in search of support for his econimic recovery program, but he found instead stiffening bipartisan resistance to his request for a $50 billion increase in the Federal debtceiling.

title: The Region; FREIGHTER DETAINED; EX-CONVICTS IN CREW
description: NEW HAVEN (AP) - A freighter with former Canadian convicts among its crew was detained in New Haven Harbor pending a formal inspection of conditions on board, a Coast Guard officer said.

title: MCGOFF INQUIRY TO PROCEED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission's broad inquiry into the financial dealings of John P. McGoff, the newspaper publisher, can proceed, the United States Court of Appeals here has ruled.

title: SALAZAR IS PREDICTING A RECORD AT MILLROSE
description: When Alberto Salazar talks numbers, New Yorkers now listen. And Salazar is talking again, this time about tomorrow night's 5,000-meter run in the Wanamaker Milrose Games at Madison Square Garden.

title: LORD AVIE WINS HUTCHESON
description: - Lord Avie, last year's champion 2-year-old and the likely favorite for this year's Kentucky Derby, won the $56,800 Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream in the final strides today in his first start of the season.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Before those who practice intolerance, who disdain coexistence, institutions and the most elementary norms of freedom of expression, I want to proclaim once more my confidence in democracy and in the Basque people." - King Juan Carlos of Spain after Basque separatists in Guernica interrupted his speech. (A3:4.)

title: KAISER TO ASK F.C.C. ACTION ON ABC NEWS
description: Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said yesterday it intended to bring action against ABC News before the Federal Communications Commission. The announcement followed a statement by ABC News Tuesday that it was changing the forum for Kaiser to respond to an ABC report last April on the alleged hazards of aluminum wiring.

title: FUEL PRICE RISES EXCEED ESTIMATE BY WHITE HOUSE
description: Gasoline and heating oil prices are rising much fafter than the Reagan Administration predicted when it decontrolled crude oil prices last week, and evidence is mounting that they will climb even further, analysts say. Yesterday, for example, three major suppliers, the Exxon Corporation, Texaco Inc. and the Shell Oil Company, announced new increases for both products.

title: Atomic Commission Cites Risk of Blackouts Without Operation of 3 Mile Island Reactor
description: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has suggested that Three Mile Island's Unit 1 reactor, inoperative since the March 28, 1979, accident that severely damaged the Unit 2 reactor, could resume limited operation to avoid power blackouts in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Maryland.

title: Around the Nation; FORMER HOSTAGE FILES SUIT AGAINST IRANIAN GOVERNMENT
description: Sgt. Gregory A. Persinger, one of the 52 Americans recently released from Iran, has filed a $120,000 lawsuit against the Iranian Government in a move that apparently challenges the agreement between the United States and Iran that secured the Americans' release.

title: NETS BEATEN, 110-102
description: - When Mike Newlin scores 30 points or more, or when they lead at halftime, the Nets have a good chance for victory.

title: DIPLOMAT RECALLS LONG MONTHS WITHOUT AN EMBASSY
description: A hopeful sign that the 50 Americans being held in the United States Embassy in Teheran might be shifted by the militants to the custody of the Iranian Government came one afternoon early last March: 50 metal clothing lockers were suddenly installed in the suite of the American charge d'affaires, L. Bruce Laingen, in the Iranian Foreign Ministry.

title: TAKEOVERS SEEN FALLING IN 80'S
description: Corporate merger activity in the 1980's should decrease despite a recent surge in such transactions, according to a survey by Touche Ross & Company, an international accounting and management consulting firm.

title: WHAT TV COVERAGE MIGHT DO TO TRIALS
description: To the Editor:$

title: 'ALOES' WILL CLOSE SUNDAY
description: "A Lesson From Aloes," by Athol Fugard, and starring Maria Tucci, Harris Yulin and Zakes Mokae, will be closed Sunday after its matinee performance at the Playhouse Theater, 359 West 48th Street. Producers cited a "dip in box office receipts" as their reason for closing the play after 101 performances.

title: CAPITAL GAINS DEDUCTION: HELP IN SAVING ON TAXES
description: People who made profits on stocks last year - there was ample opportunity with the sharp run-up in the stock market during the final days may be able to spare some of their earnings from taxes by taking advantages of the favorable capital gains deduction. But the reporting rules can be complex, and taxpayers often are chagrined to discover that a minor miscalculation about the timing requirements that determine whether a gain is long-term or short-term can result in a major difference in the taxes owed.

title: 700 JOBS ARE INVOLVED
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it was transferring its two major subsidiaries from New York to Detroit, dealing an unexpected blow to the Koch administration's efforts to keep jobs in the city.

title: WILDWOOD REJECTS BEACH FEES
description: Voters in Wildwood decided overwelmingly today to keep their Cape May County resort as one of the last New Jersey shore communities with free beaches. In a binding referendum on the issue, the final vote was 533 in favor of beach fees and 948 against, according to a tally reported by the City Clerk's office.

title: P.L.O., DENOUNCING U.S., PLEDGES A STEPPED-UP GUERILLA STRUGGLE
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization, addressing a meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission here, concluded an attack on the Reagan Administration today with the warning that it was "determined to escalate our armed and political struggle in order to restore our usurped rights."

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: o Airco Inc., Montvale, N.J., has elected B. Joseph Werner corporate vice president of government activities to head the Washington office, and David J. Daffey president of the Airco Welding Products division. o Audio Dynamic Inc., Great Neck, L.I., has elected Edward M. Siegel vice president, general counsel and secretary. o Colgate-Palmolive Company has appointed William G. Cooling vice president and controller and Thomas J. Volpe vice president and treasurer. o Di Giorgio Corporation, San Francisco-based marketer of consumer goods and building materials, has elected to its board Donal E. Guinn, chairman and chief executive officer of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company. o Exxon Company U.S.A. has named Carl R. Patterson senior vice president. o Fedders Corporation, Edison, N.J., has elected Stephen L. Feilinger, Frederick P. Hagee and G. Nino Palescandolo corporate vice presidents. o Itek Corporation, Lexington, Mass., has named Robert P. Henderson, chief executive, to the additional post of chairman. o Macy's New York has named Joseph Cicio senior vice president. o Levi Strauss & Company, San Francisco, has elected to its board Rene C. McPherson dean and professor of management at the Standford Graduate School of Business. o Nantucket Industries Inc., a manufacturer of women's lingerie and men's underwear, has named John Wineapple president of Nantucket Hosiery Mills Inc., a division. o Northearn Telecom Ltd., Toronto, has appointed Donal A. Chisholm president of new-line function, innovation and development. o Radiation Technology Inc., Rockaway, N.J., has appointed Zvi Blank general manager of the newly formed Reactor Component Test division. o Sam P. Wallace Company, Dallas, a diversified international contractor, has elected to its board Joseph P. Husny, chairman and chief executive officer of Miron Inc., Quebec, Canada, and Farid M. Djouhri, president of Redec International, Paris. o Teleprompter Cable TV has appointed Richard J. Morris senior vice president for operations. o Triangle Industries, Holmdel, N.J., has elected to its board Edward o Northearn Telecom Ltd., Toronto, has appointed Donal A. Chisholm president of new-line function, innovation and development. o Radiation Technology Inc., Rockaway, N.J., has appointed Zvi Blank general manager of the newly formed Reactor Component Test division. o Sam P. Wallace Company, Dallas, a diversified international contractor, has elected to its board Joseph P. Husny, chairman and chief executive officer of Miron Inc., Quebec, Canada, and Farid M. Djouhri, president of Redec International, Paris. o Teleprompter Cable TV has appointed Richard J. Morris senior vice

title: GROUNDBREAKING HELD AT SITE OF OLD BREWERY
description: New York City and state officials held groundbreaking ceremonies yesterday for a project to turn the old Rheingold Brewery site in the blighted Bushwick section of Brooklyn into an industrial park.

title: GARDEN CARD LOSES TWO TOP TITLE BOUTS
description: A second major bout left Madison Square Garden's Feb. 23 boxing show yesterday, possibly headed for New Orleans. Like a helpless fighter on the ropes, Sam Glass, the remaining promoter, clung to the belief that the card could be saved. But in Detroit, Prentiss Byrd, the assistant manager ofThomas Hearns, who was to have defended the World Boxing Association's welter-weight title against Wilfred Benitez on the once-glamorous card said, "That's it for our participation." John Yopp, a business associate of Emanuel Steward, Hearns's manager and trainer, said he would like to promote the welterweight fight in New Orleans in March.

title: Currency Markets; DOLLAR DIPS AS GOLD RISES IN EUROPE, FALLS IN U.S.
description: Gold prices climbed above $500 an ounce yesterday in European trading. They declined in New York, however, finishing at $493. The dollar weakened in relation to all other major currencies except the British pound.

title: BRIEFS
description: o Arkansas Louisiana Gas Company said it ended 1980 with an increase of 49 billion cubic feet in total gas reserves behind its five-state system. o Babcock & Wilcox signed a $78 million agreement to furnish two boilers to the Taiwan Power Company. o Corror & Black Corporation reached an agreement in principle for a business combination with Flenniken Insurance Services, an insurance brokerage and agency firm in Knoxville, Tenn. o Dome Petroleum awarded contracts valued at $45 million to two Vancouver companies. o Fluor Corporation formed a new subsidiary, Fluor Supply Company, by merging the two entities formerly known as White's Industrial Supply Company and Fluor Oil Field Supply Company. o Hiram Walker-Consumers Home Ltd. shareholders approved a name change, to Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. o Hospital Corporation of America paid about $36 million in cash to acquire hospitals in Edmond, Okla., and La Habra, Calif., adding 397 beds to the hospital management company's operations. o Jacobs Engineering Group Inc. received a contract to engineer and design a 5,000-barrel-a-day test facility to determine the feasibility of chemically cleaning coal for use as boiler fuel. The contract was let by the Arco Coal Company, a subsidiary of Atlantic Richfield Company. o Oneok Inc. said its capital investment in the fiscal year ending Aug. 31 would total $119 million, compared with $64.7 million a year earlier. o NBI Inc. declared a 3-for-1 split of its common stock. o Turbo Resources Ltd. directors will recommend a 3-for-1 stock split for shareholder approval at the annual meeting in May. o Varlen Corporation completed the previously announce agreement to buy all of the locamotives of the bankrupt Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad Company, along with related inventories and plant facilities, for $23 million.

title: Company News; TRADE RESTRAINT SUIT CITES FRANK PERDUE
description: Frank Perdue, the largest seller of premium-priced branded poultry in the New York area, was charged yesterday in a Justice Department civil suit with engaging in illegal restraint of interstate commerce involving his distributors and competitors.

title: THE WORLD'S ULTIMATE TERRORISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic's Notebook; DEMISE OF 'FRANKENSTEIN' NOT A TRUE HORROR FLOP
description: ASIDE from the $30 top ticket price at "Amadeus," January's most talked-about Broadway phenomenon may well have been "Frankenstein." This horror play, which came and went in one night to the tune of $2 million, is discussed with the pity, awe and gallows humor that only recently had been reserved exclusively for Michael Cimino's $36 million film catastrophe, "Heaven's Gate." If my ghoulish friends are any indication, theatergoers who didn't see "Frankenstein" are envious of those who did. This flop may be the hottest posthumous ticket since the David Merrick-Edward Albee-Mary Tyler Moore-Richard Chamberlain musical of "Breakfast at Tiffany's" folded in previews in the mid 1960's.

title: CANADIAN SALES OF PAPER SLOW
description: Canadian's paper and pulp industry expects to ship 20.9 million metric tons of products this year, up only 1 percent from 1980,the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association reported yesterday.

title: LEAKING STRENGTH
description: The widespread leaking of classified defense information has become a far more serious problem than is commonly appreciated. The national-security establishment is large and contains many points of view, differences of opinion, and ideological feuds. As in almost any organization, these disagreements lead to bureaucratic and political infighting that takes on a life of its own.

title: DESPITE LOW JOBLESS RATE, LINCOLN, NEB., HAS FEW JOBS
description: "If you can't find a job in Lincoln these days you probably couldn't find one anywhere," Mayor Helen Boosalis said last October, commenting on Lincoln's enviable standing as the city with the nation's lowest employment rate.

title: FOREIGN PRESS RIDICULES U.S. SELECTION OF CLARK
description: President Reagan's choice of William P. Clark as Deputy Secretary of State was ridiculed today in a number of foreign newspapers. An Amsterdam daily, De Volkskrant, called him a "nitwit," The Daily Express of London ran a headline reading "Ask Me Another," and a Johannesburg paper said in a headline, "Don't-know Man Gets Nod from Reagan Top Policy Slot."

title: SHAPING URBAN POLICY
description: The President's Commission for a National Agenda for the 80's recommended in December that the struggle to revitalize our older cities be abandoned. In fact, the opposite course should be pursued. The whole country will be weakened even more if the decline of these cities continues.

title: HARRIS CROSS-EXAMINATION ENDS WITH BITTER EXCHANGES ON RIVAL
description: The cross examination of Jean S. Harris ended today with her angry denial that she intended to kill Dr. Herman Tarnower and then herself because, as the prosecutor put it, "if you couldn't have him, nobody else would."

title: STUBBORN BRITONS CLING TO EMBATTLED ATLANTIC ISLANDS
description: The barman is throwing darts in the corner. An old man rubs his hands before the burning heat in the fireplace. A strapping Celt, red-haired and ruddy faced, finishes a can of Tennant's lager, revealing the cheesecake picture of a buxom Scottish lass smiling from its aluminum sides.

title: The Region; CREDIT CARDS STOLEN FROM A FIRE VICTIM
description: WHITE PLAINS (AP) - Two employees of the Westchester County Medical Examiner's office have been charged with stealing the credit cards of one of the 26 persons killed in the Stouffer's Inn fire on Dec.4.

title: INQUIRY AT FIRST PENN
description: The First Pennsylvania Corporation said a committee of three directors would investigate the performance of its management in the period preceding its near-bankruptcy last year. The committee will make recommendations to the full board against current or former officers or directors of the company, officials said.

title: SCOTT IS FOUND GUILTY OF MURDER, FACES LIFE
description: - James Scott, the light-heavyweight boxer, was convicted today of murdering a Newark man to cover an armed robbery. Surrounded by his family, Scott accepted the verdict passively. is attorney, William Kunstler, leaned over and embraced him.

title: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 4 (AP) --Chuch Aleksinas hit a career-high 27 points and Connecticut rolled to a 79-70 victory over Providence in a Big East game tonight before 8,281 fans at the Civic Center.
description: Aleksinas, a f-foot-11 inch center, connected on 11 of 15 field-goal attempts and grabbed seven rebounds as the Huskies lifted their record to 16-3, including 5-2 in the conference.

title: Thursday, February 5, 1981
description: THE ECONOMY President Reagan faced bipartisan resistance to his plan to raise the United States debt ceiling by $50 billion. A Senate Democratic caucus voted not to support the increase, and Republicans are not the target of a lobbying effort on behalf of the plan.(Page A1.) As the President met with the legislative leaders, a list of budget cuts recommended by the Administration circulated in Congress. Targets include social programs and space and energy projects. (A17.)

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; PALESTINIANS SAY THEY FIRED ON ISRAELIS NEAR BEIRUT

title: MCGRAW HILL EARNINGS UP
description: McGraw-Hill Inc., a diversified communications company, yesterday reported sharp increases in its profits for the final quarter of 1980 and for the full year and attributed the gains to a broadening of its operations into information systems and other related businesses. For the fourth quarter, the company's net income rose 13.2 percent, to a record $24.8 million or $1 a share, from $21.9 million, or 86 cents a share, in the comparable 1979 period.

title: PUBLIC TV EXPECTING $150 MILLION GIFT
description: The Annenberg School of Communications at the University of Pennsylvania is expected to announce soon the final plan for donating $150 million over a 15-year period to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. It would make the first such major privateto-public gift transaction specifically linking television and radio programs with higher education.

title: EX-DEMOCRATIC LEADER IN KENTUCKY INDICTED IN FRAUD BY U.S. JURY
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted the former chariman of the state's Democratic Party on 22 counts for his alleged participation in a state insurance fraud scheme.

title: A JERSEY 'NIGHTMARE'
description: John J. Fay, New Jersey's Ombudsman for the Institutionalized Elderly, had just come from the scene of the fourth rooming-house fire in about six months to claim the lives of elderly, frail residents and heard himself saying something he never thought he would say. "I think we'd be better off putting these people back into Marlboro State Hospital and lobbying for for new, safe housing for them," he said. "We're just playing Russian roulette by leaving them where they are."

title: Gardening; FOR COLOR, A PALETTE OF PLANTS
description: BORED with green house plants? You can grow something with p urple leaves and white ribbony stripes, or yellow leaves w ith a touch of green on the edges.

title: SCHUBERT SEEKS END TO CURB ON EXPANSION
description: The Shubert Organization, which owns almost half of Broadway's legitimate theaters, has gone into Federal court to try to end restrictions placed on it in 1956 curtailing the organization's purchase of new theaters.

title: REDDING LEAVES ST. JOHN'S SQUAD
description: Curtis Redding, a starter for St. John's, quit the basketball team yesterday for what he said were personal reasons. Redding, a 6-foot 5-inch senior transfer student from Kansas State, was averaging 7.5 points a game in his second season with the Redmen.

title: MORTGAGE RATE CUT BY GREAT WESTERN
description: Great Western Savings and Loan today followed other lenders in cutting home mortgage rates, reducing its best rate to 15-1/2 percent from 16 percent.

title: Helpful Hardware; SILVER CARE PRODUCTS
description: While there is no substitute for hand rubbing to get a lovely glow on silver, there are products that will help you get and keep that glow more easily. The latest thing in silver care is the development of small paper strips treated with a nontoxic substance that, when placed in a drawer or cabinet with silver, will keep polished silver from tarnishing.

title: TIMBER CUTTERS' NARROW VIEW OF FORESTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: RECITAL: TRIO PLAYS PREMIERE
description: The sound of a harpsichord, oboe and flute playing together suggest a certain sort of mid-afternoon summer light. At any rate, such an image occurred to this listener at the Abraham Goodman House on Monday night, as the Lucarelli/Norell/Siebert Trio brought skill and sensitivity to the three instruments.

title: Market Place; DOUBTS ON BID FROM UNC
description: There are those on Wall Street who doubt that UNC Resources can find the necessary funds to follow through on a plan to acquire Western Airlines. The doubters prefer the logic of an earlier plan to bring together two regional carriers, Western and Continental Air Lines. According to sponsors of the UNC merger plan, they are speaking of a wedding of a fuel producer with a fuel user, a curious characterization in that UNC producer uranium and not airplane fuel. Western is fighting the UNC attempt, Meanwhile, its merger plan with Continental is up for approval by the Civil Aeronautics Board, with a decision expected by the end of March.

title: MANY KIDNEY PATIENTS ARE UNABLE TO RETURN TO WORK, STUDY FINDS
description: About half of all kidney patients receiving dialysis are unable to return to their jobs and many require special help in caring for themselves, doctors reported today in a preliminary study.

title: SYRACUSE 74, SETON HALL 62
description: - Dan Schayes scored a game-high 18 points, sparking Syracuse to a 74-62 triumph over Seton Hall in the Big East Conference tonight.

title: A DESIGNER WORKS WITH TWO BUDGETS
description: The two questions that immediately arise when it comes to choosing an interior designer are "What style?" and "How much?" Designers nowadays are easily categorized, and although their styles can range from minimal to traditional, they also tend to fall into in what may be increasingly more important divisions: the lavish spenders versus the budget minded.

title: Around the Nation; EXPERT EXPLAINS EXPLOSIVES AT CHICAGO SEDITION TRIAL
description: A bomb expert today explained the use of explosives to the jury at the begining of testimony in the Federal sedition trial of 10 alleged members of the Puerto Rican terrorist organization F.A.L.N.

title: Challenging the Mayor
description: Automation House, where things may be presumed to happen by themselves, is hardly the appropriate place to draft a candidate to run against Mayor Koch. Yet a small, disparate group of people met there the other day to announce their determination that if Mr. Koch is to stay in City Hall, he should first have to beat a worthy opponent. They're right. The voters would benefit from hearing Mr. Koch challenged by a serious, ambitious candidate willing to be exposed to the tests of office.

title: DR. JULIAN J. HIRSHFELD, A CHEMIST IN THE TEXTILE INDUSTRY, DIES AT 74
description: Dr. Julian J. Hirshfeld, a leading textile chemist, died last night of heart failure while being taken by helicopter to Duke University Hospital in Durham. He was 74 years old.

title: C.A.B. LETS AIRLINES RAISE FARES
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday that it had authorized the nation's airlines to increase fares immediately to cushion the effects of sharp increases in fuel prices.

title: MT. ST. HELENS SEISMIC READINGS MONITORED CLOSELY BY SCIENTISTS
description: Mount St. Helens spouted two large steam plumes today, but scientist monitoring the volcano said that they were more concerned about an increase in seismic activity in the last 24 hours.

title: RANGERS DOMINATE ISLANDERS BY 9-3
description: Led by Don Maloney's three goals, the New York Rangers routed the Islanders, 9-3, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: NEW YORK TO FIGHT ANY CUT IN U.S. DEVELOPMENT FUNDS
description: A total of $42 million in Federal funds that could generate nearly half a billion dollars in private investment would be lost to New York City if the Federal Urban Development Action Grant program is abolished, city officials said yesterday.

title: Notes on People; BIPARTISAN UNION
description: Anthony Toby Moffett, a Connecticut Democrat who was re-elected to the United States House of Representatives last November, plans to be married next month to a lawyer who four years ago worked for President Gerald R. Ford's re-election.

title: AFGHAN PEACE MOVES: MIXED MOTIVES
description: Pakistan and Afghanistan are edging closer to talks that conservative Moslem diplomats fear could cripple the Afghan insurgents and legitimize the Soviet-installed Government in Kabul.

title: 'FOUND' MONEY FROM A LOTTERY HELPS NEEDIEST
description: Some gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund come from donors who have acquired wealth unexpectedly and wish to help those who need it more than they do.

title: ERVING GETS 33 AS 76ERS TOP CELTICS, 107-104
description: -The Boston Celtics saw too much of Julius Erving tonight and a sellout crowd at the Spectrum saw an abundance of free-throw shooting as the 76ers posted a 107-104 victory.

title: SOVIET SKATERS TRIUMPH
description: - Irina Vorobieva and Igor Lisovski of the Soviet Union captured the pairs competition today at the European figure skating championships. Second Second place went to Christina Reigel and Andreas Nischwitz of West Germany.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column in The Living Section yesterday gave an incorrect address for the Asthma and Alergy Foundation of America. The foundation is at 19 West 44th Street, New York, N.Y. 10036

title: U.N. Events; THE U.N. TODAY; Feb. 5, 1981 GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Advisory Committee to the Preparatory Committee for Unispace 1982 of the Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M.

title: Notes on People; AN EX-HUSBAND'S PLEA FOR INCREASED ALIMONY
description: Although he has now received alimony, as a result of an appear of his divorce decree, Walter H. Bowart told a judge in Tucson, Ariz., that merely being the husband of the former Peggy Mellon, an heiress to the Mellon banking fortune, had left him "penniless."

title: REAGAN'S '81 CAMPAIGN: TO SELL LINE ON ECONOMY
description: With the initial wave of appointments and executive orders completed and the American hostages home from Iran, President Reagan is turning to the task of building public momentum for the economic package he plans as the keystone of his Administration.

title: RISE IN BANKRUPTCY LAID TO NEW LAW
description: The number of American declaring personal bankruptcy jumped 82 percent during the first year of a new law that made such filings easier, a loan industry group reported today.

title: Advertising; YANKEE COMES HOMES
description: "We are the largest unknown advertising agency in New York," is the most frequently heard complaint from agency leaders.

title: IRAN FREES ONE AMERICAN AND HAS HEARING FOR ANOTHER
description: The State Department said today that one of three Americans being held prisoner in Iran was released last night and a hearing on another's case was held today.

title: BLUE BELL ELIMINATES TOP 2 BOARD POSTS
description: Blue Bell Inc., the nation's second-largest manufacturer of jeans after Levi Strauss, has eliminated the offices of chairman and vice chairman, thus unseating Edwin A. Morris, 77 years old, and Rodger S. LeMatty, 73. The two men, who had each been associated with the company for nearly 50 years, will remain as directors, according to the company, to be employed "in an advisory capacity."

title: DE PAUL WINS,69-58
description: - SkipDillard poured in 30 points to lead DePaul to a 69-58 victory over Detroit tonight.

title: FEMALE SOLDIER GETS EIGHT YEARS FOR HANGING DEATH AT ARMY BASE
description: Specialist 5 Nancy Jean Varraso has been sentenced to eight years in prison by a military jury that convicted her of second-degree murder in the hanging death of a female soldier with whom she was involved in a homosexual triangle.

title: PHILADELPHIA REPORTER CLEARED OF CONTEMPT ON ABSCAM QUESTION
description: Under a court agreement, contempt charges against a reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer were dropped today after she testified that she had talked to a United States Attorney the night details of the Abscam investigation began to filter to the press.

title: 'WIDOW'S TAX' ASSAILED IN CAPITAL
description: The so-called "widow's tax," which penalizes wives who survive their husbands, was assailed today at a public hearing on Capitol Hill, and several senators promised an overhaul of inheritance taxes this year.

title: DOWN WITH TOY CHESTS
description: In the Home Improvement column of Jan. 22., Bernard Gladstone described the making of a toy chest designed to help keep children's rooms neat. Such a chest probably looks very nice but is the least desirable way to store toys.

title: 4,300 CAPTIVE KOREANS
description: To the Editor:$

title: PAN AM POSTS PROFIT DUE TO BUILDING SALE
description: Pan American World Airways reported yesterday that the sale of a subsidiary lifted earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 to $197 million, in contrast to a loss of $40.7 million a year before, adjusted for the merger of Pan Am and National Airlines.

title: Around the World; U.N. PANEL CITES ARGENTINA IN MISSING PERSONS SURVEY
description: A United Nations human rights commission said here today that Argentina alone accounted for more than half of the 11,000 to 13,000 people who have been reported missing and are assumed to be victims of political terrorism.

title: KOCH SAYS HE MIGHT BACK A FARE RAISE
description: Mayor Koch said today that he might support another increase in bus and subway fares if the money were used for capital improvements to the transit system.

title: Credit Markets; 10-YEAR U.S. NOTES YIELD 12.89%
description: The Treasury sold $2.5 billion of 13 percent notes due in 1990 yesterday at an average yield of 12.89 percent, down from 13.07 percent for similar notes last November.

title: LETTERS On Medical Consent
description: To The Home Section When it comes to the issue of consent to medical treatment Insuring Medical Aid if Parents Are Absent," Jan. 22, the lack of common sense of hospitals and doctors never ceases to astound me. Consent, while important, should not be an end in itself.

title: COVER-UP IS DENIED BY KUSH
description: - Frank Kush, the former Arizona State football coach, denied in court today that he had told a group of assistants to stick together even if it meant lying. The denial came after Robert Hing had read Kush a sworn statement given in 1979 by Bob Owens, a former assistant. Mr. Hing is the attorney for Kevin Rutledge, the former Arizona State player seeking $2.2 million in damages from Kush and others in a suit that alleges that Kush harrassed him and once punched him.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchange issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the share holdings officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: FLATTENING TV SCREENS
description: Like everything else electronic, television sets are getting smaller and flatter. Within a few years, there will be hand-held television sets as small as pocket calculators, followed by sets with giant screens that are thin enough and light enough to hang on a wall.

title: UNION LEADER ADVISES LOCALS; Walesa Acts After Talks Founder in Strike-Bound Southern City Over Ouster of Officials
description: Poland's labor troubles took a turn for the worse today when the talks between the Government and strike leaders broke down in the southern province of Bielsko-Biala. The independent Solidarity trade union told its chapters to be ready to act if force were used to break the strike.

title: Clean Coal for Staten Island
description: Six years after the initial application, a coal-burning power plant proposed for Staten Island has finally cleared - well, almost cleared - its major regulatory hurdle. This will not please many Staten Island residents who fear it will add to the filth and stench that already descends on them from New Jersey industries. But it should please all other citizens: this plant will be a surprisingly clean neighbor - and it will reduce New York's dependence on imported oil.

title: COLOMBIAN LEADER VISITING U.S.
description: President Julio Cesar Turbay of Colombia left here today for New York where he will undergo a general medical check-up and eye tests, Government sources said. He is expected to return to Bogota next Wednesday.

title: LET'S NOT SAVE THE STUDENT LOAN PROGRAM BY DESTROYING IT
description: To the Editor:$

title: The City; 12 HURT IN HOTEL FIRE
description: Three firemen and nine guests were injured in a fire at the Wellington Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 55th Street.

title: KENTUCKY 102, AUBURN 74
description: - Sam Bowie gave Kentucky a 9-2 lead and finished with 23 points as the Wildwcats routed Aubur, 102-74, in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.

title: Advertising; STOUFFER USING CREAMER TO TEST FROZEN ENTREE
description: The Stouffer Food Corporation, the leader in frozen entrees, has moved into seven test markets with a new line called Lean Cuisine.

title: WEAN'S PROJECT IN CHINA HALTED
description: Wean United Inc. said it had been advised that the Chinese Government has told a consortium of Western companies to halt work on a $500 million rolling mill project in Shanghai.

title: GOLDEN NUGGET UNIT HAS GAIN IN JANUARY
description: Golden Nugget's Atlantic City Casino Hotel posted a $10.8 million gross "win" and total revenues of more than $14 million for the month of January, its first full month of operation. Stephen Wynn, the company's chairman, said.

title: JAN. 21-31 CAR SALES OFF BY 26% DETROIT, Feb.4(AP) - Domestic sales of American-made cars dropped 26 percent in the last 10 days of January from the comparable period last year, the nation's auto makers reported today.
description: For the full month, sales of American-made autos fell 20.1 percent from January 1980, which was a boom period because of sales-incentive contests sponsored by General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor Company dealers.

title: LEON ALPERT
description: Leon Alpert, former president and chairman of the board of the Loral Electronics Corporation, died yesterday at the age of 75 at his home in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: IRANIAN FACTIONS TOLD BY KHOMEINI TO STOP 'BITING ONE ANOTHER'
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini accused Iran's quarreling politicians today of "biting one another like scorpions," and urged them to behave more like their American counterparts. "You'll never see two parties in the United States working against U.S. interest," said the Ayatollah, who habitually speaks of the United States as the "Great Satan."

title: Evans and Milonas Say He Makes the Judiciary a 'Scapegoat'
description: The chief administrative judge of the New York State court system accused Mayor Koch yesterday of making "a scapegoat" of the judiciary by suggesting that the state's strict gun law had not worked well because cases moved too slowly through the courts.

title: Index
description: International

title: CHARGES DISMISSED IN PHILS' DRUG CASE
description: - A magistrate dismissed all charges tonight against a Reading, Pa., physician accused of illegally prescribing amphetamines for seven Philadelphia Phillie players. Before the case was closed, though, the doctor testified that he prescribed pep pills for the players at their request.

title: RAMADA'S MEDICAL UNIT TO PARACELSUS
description: Ramada Inns announced the sale of "substantially all assets" of its wholly owned medical division to the Paracelsus Hospital Corporation for about $32 million in cash and an assumption of liabilities.

title: Bridge; SOUTH AFRICA WINS THE STAR THAT NEW YORK CITY LOSES
description: A small and regrettable paradox concerns one of the world's great players: He resides in New York City, but plays most of his bridge in Johannesburg, South Africa.

title: The City; FERRY SERVICE SOUGHT FOR ROOSEVELT ISLAND
description: New York City will seek a private company to operate an East River ferry service between Roosevelt Island and Manhattan to supplement the tramway service, Deputy Mayor Nathan Leventhal said yesterday.

title: MOODY'S LOWERS MASSEY RATING
description: Moody's Investors Service has lowered its rating on the debt of the International Harvester Company, an action likely to limit credit sources and increase borrowing costs for the manufacturer of trucks and construction and agricultural equipment.

title: A GERIATRIC SERVICE: BRIEF RESPITE CARE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Liliane Droyan Kodner is a freelance writer. Liliane Droyan Kodner

title: GENERAL FOODS PLANS TO BUY OSCAR MAYER
description: The General Foods Corporation, the nation's largest packaged foods maker, will buy Oscar Mayer & Company for about $464.6 million in cash under an agreement in principle announced by the companies yesterday.

title: A DEGIGNER WORKS WITH TWO BUDGETS
description: THE two questions that immediately arise when it comes to choosing an interior designer are ''What style?'' and ''How much?'' Designers nowadays are easily categorized, and although their styles can range from minimal to traditional, they also tend to fall into in what may be increasingly more important divisions: the lavish spenders versus the budget minded.

title: HEAD OF LUTHERANS CALLS PAPAL AUDIENCE HELPFUL
