description: The president of the Lutheran Church in America said yesterday that a recent audience with Pope John Paul II alleviated some of his fears about what he termed the Pontiff's "ambiguous" proclamations on ecumenical relations.

title: A LIFETIME SUPPLY OF RECYCLED WATER
description: WHEN guests visit John and Rosalind Cusack's home in Evergreen, Colo., they often praise the ''great well water.'' They always blanch when they find that the ''well'' is a small sewage treatment plant that recycles every drop of the home's waste water.

title: U.S. APPELLATE JUDGE QUITS OVER HIS SALARY AND BENEFITS
description: Judge William Hughes Mulligan announced yesterday that he was resigning from the Federal appeals court in Manhattan, one of the country's most important courts, because he found the financial rewards inadequate.

title: Advertising; CYANAMID PICKS CHALK
description: American Cynamid has assigned its Cyalume Lightstick to Chalk, Nissen, Hanft. The new product is a chemically activated emergency or "fun" light that burns for 12 hours. There is a four-inch version selling for about $1 and a six-inch version selling for about $1.79, or three for $4.99. C.N.H.'s first assignment is in test market and should be rolling out nationally in late winter or early spring.

title: HARLEM YOUTH, 19, IS FOUND GUILTY OF SLAYING PUSHER HE HAD ROBBED
description: A 19-year-old Harlem youth who law enforcement officials said wore a bullet-proof vest and answered to the nickname "Frank Nitti," was found guilty yesterday of murdering a narcotic dealer he had robbed earlier.

title: JUSTICE POWELL REBUFFS A PAPER ON PLEA TO BLOCK A LIBEL PAYMENT
description: A Supreme Court Justice refused yesterday to free a Louisiana newspaper temporarily from having to pay a $175,000 libel judgement.

title: transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Agreed to contract terms with three pitchers Larry Bradfor, Rick Mahler and Ike Pettaway. CHICAGO (AL) -- Signed Scott Meier, catcher, and Bill Almon, infielder, and assigned Almon to Edmonton of Pacific Coast League. Named Sam Ewing manager of Appleton farm club of Midwest League. CINCINNATI (NL) --Agreed to terms with Frank Pastore, pitcher, on a one-year contract. OAKLAND (AL) Signed Matt Keough, pitcher, to a four-year contract. METS (NL) - Signed four players: Aristraco Tirdado, 17, pitcher from Puerto Rico, assigned to Shelby of the South Atlantic League; Jose Andular, 17 outfielder from Dominican Republic, assigned to Kingsport of Appalachian League; Fernando Moscat, 18, shortstop from Dominican Republic, assigned to Little Falls of New York - Penn League, and Miguel Sanchez, 17, outfielder from Dominican Republic, assigned to Kingsport. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Bruce Boisclair, outfielder, and assigned him to Syracuse of International League.

title: U.S. MAY CONDUCT BROAD INQUIRY ON GRUMMAN BUSES, OFFICIALS SAY
description: Federal officials say they may open a fullscale investigation into structural problems in buses manufactured by the Grumman Flxible Corporation.

title: Are Urban Action Grants Expendable?
description: Some of the Reagan Administration's budget-cutting ideas are merciless, such as the contemplated amputation of the food stamp program; unless it is resisted, perhaps two million poor people will go hungry. But other proposed cuts are not as brutal as they look. A case in point is the proposal to do away with urban development action grants.

title: FRAN WARREN TO OPEN STINT AT MICHAEL'S PUB ON FEB. 17
description: Fran Warren, who came to prominence as a teen-age singer with Claude Thornhill's band in the 1940's -- "A Sunday Kind of Love," was one of her big hits -- will open a four week stint at Michael's Pub Feb. 17, accompanied by Lou Forester, pianist; Steven Bill, guitarist; Ann Yarborough; French hornist; Jerry Sanfino and Al Epstein, saxophonists, and Shelly Horn, percussionist.

title: PROTEST IN TENNESSEE FAILS TO DETER JAPANESE PLANT
description: Officials of the Nissan Motor Company said today that they had no intention of canceling plans to build a $300 million truck assembly plant here despite a jeering, stone-throwing labor demonstration that "shocked" the Japanese owners and embarrassed public officials.

title: The Region; GRAND JURY CLEARS CORRECTION OFFICER
description: A Dutchess County grand jury has reported "no evidence" on an extortion charge against John Hues, a state correction officer with 27 years' service who is now retired.

title: WASHINGTON-MOSCOW NAME-CALLING: WHAT DOES IT MEAN?
description: For more than 10 days, Moscow and Washington have been exchanging verbal fusilades.

title: FOUNDER OF KORVETTES STILL ACTIVE IN RETAILING
description: Eugene Ferkauf, who founded Korvettes and who put the discount house squarely on the map of American merchandising, is in the midst of enlarging the Penfield Retail Corporation, the retailing company that he started about five years ago.

title: REAGAN SPEECH TO BE TELEVISED
description: President Reagan's economic message will be televised live tonight starting at 9 o'clock by CBS, NBC and ABC, Channels 2, 4 and 7 in New York City. It will be rebroadcast in its entirety at 11:35 P.M. on WNET-TV, Channel 13 in the city. The speech will also be broadcast at 9 P.M. by radio WCBS -AM, WINS and WOR lin the city.

title: Finance Briefs
description: Harken OIl & Gas filed 700,000 shares of common with the Securities and Exchange Commission, to be offered through a group heade by Bateman Eichler Hill Richards Inc.; o Pfizer filed $150 million of debentures due 2006, convertible into Plizer's common stock. The offering will be made by a Lazard Freres & Company group.; o Public Service Company of New Hamphire is offering 2.2 million shares of common at $15 a share. Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. and Kidder, Peabody & Company Inc. are co-managers of the underwriting group.

title: MUSIC: PHILADELPHIANS PLAY STRAVINSKY'S 'RITE OF SPRING'
description: MOZART and Stravinsky have a great deal in common -- or at least Stravinsky thought so, for he went out of his way to demonstrate the relationship in the works he wrote during his high NeoClassical period of the 1940's. Twenty years before that time, though, audiences would scarcely have thought to associate the radical young Russian composer of colorful pagan ballets with the elegant Viennese classicist.

title: HOW TO DECIDE AMONG CAMPS
description: This is the time of year when parents are inundated with summer camp brochures and exhorations from their children to send them to the camp of their choice -- or their best friend's choice.

title: TV: 'A LOVE LETTER TO JACK BENNY' ON NBC
description: "A Love Letter to Jack Benny" on NBC-TV at 9:30 P.M., is one of those television packages put together largely with scissors and glue. Using clips from the past, they are usually compiled for anniversaries. Bot Hope had one recently to celebrate his 30th year before NBC cameras. Tonight's entry, with Irving Fein and Fred de Cordova as executive producers, comes out of the Jack Benny Estate Television Company.

title: NEW YORK AIR PLANS TWO BOSTON ROUTES
description: New York Air said today that it would begin daily service from both Washington and New York to Boston at discount prices beginning Feb. 15. New York Air said it would offer a one-way Boston-Washington fare of $59, compared with a normal coach fare of $103.

title: PHILIPPINE PLANTERS AND WORKERS FIGHT SUGAR CONTROLS
description: Sugar planters and their workers, whose troubled relationship has long symbolized the social and economic ills of the Philippines, have joined forces against a common foe: the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: SAMPSON: MATURITY MAKES DIFFERENCE
description: - For Ralph Sampson, the invitation to have breakfast with Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was logical and wonderful. Sampson, a Virginia sophomore, had heard himself compared to AbdulJabbar and he had studied films of the older man's illustrious career. Then, when their paths crossed last month, the two chatted about the weather, surfing and European travel, and discussed Sampson's career.

title: REAGAN'S BUDGET PROPOSALS INCLUDE DEEP CUT IN SYNTHETIC FUEL PROJECTS
description: The Reagan Administration proposes to make major cuts in the Government's ambitious synthetic fuels program by eliminating five large projects. It would also slash its financial support for the new Synthetic Fuels Corporation by about a third, or $5.3 billion, according to an unpublished document drafted by the Office of Management and Budget. The proposal also envisions that the main emphasis of the development corporation be shifted and that private sponsors be required to supply 40 percent, rather than 25 percent, of the cost of plants to be built with the help of the corporation. 'In short, Government would aid demonstration of synfuels capability but not subsidize building significant capacity,' said the working paper, though to have been written by the budget director, David A. Stockman. It said the Government would thus save $9.1 billion through the 1985 fiscal year. It would also reduce possible disruptions in the credit markets, since the Government loan guarantees would not be so large as first planned. Word of the proposals has already brought criticism from Capitol Hill and prompted expressions of dismay from other supporters of synthetic fuels projects. McClure Opposes 'Axiang' Project James A. McClure, the Idaho Republican who heads the Senate Energy Committee, said in a conversation last night that, when he heard that synthetic fuels were to be 'axed out,' he quickly asked that the proposals be reconsidered. 'I'm trying to find out what the signal is,' he said. 'You still can't read very well' how firmly the Administration is committed to the proposals.

title: GREYHOUND POSTS DECLINE IN PROFITS
description: Greyhound Corporation, a diversified transportation, consumer products and financial services company, said today that its net income for the fourth quarter last year dropped 11.9 percent, to $33.2 million, or 75 cents a share from $37.7 million or 86 cents share, in 1970's final quarter. Revenues rose to $1.3 billion from $1.2 billion a year earlier.

title: News Summary
description: International Poland's labor troubles worsened as negotiations between the Government and strike leaders broke off in a southern province. The independent national union told all its chapters to be ready to begin sit-ins if force was used to break the walkout. The province is the only region where strikes were continuing, but other areas where negotiations were still under way remained tense. (Page A1, Column 1.) Information on two Americans in Iran was reported by the State Department. It said that Mohi Sobhani, an Iranian-born American citizen held since Sept. 6 on spy charges, had telephoned a brother to report he had been freed. The department also said it had learned that a hearing had been held for Cynthia B. Dwyer, who has been imprisoned since May 5, and that "a disposition" of her case was expected about Monday. (A1:1-3) India raised a nuclear challenge to Washington over what New Delhi regards as uncalled for delays in releasing nuclear fuel under a purchasing accord. Indian officials said they had authorized the reprocessing of spent fuels into much more powerful and hazardous plutonium oxide.(A6:3.)

title: ENERGY-EFFICENT HOMES AND CARS INCREASE MODERATELY
description: SINCE the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo, efforts to conserve energy in private housing and transportation have been sizable, though they still fall far short of the potential conservation possible, according to the Federal Department of Energy.

title: Advertising; A SCIENCE MAGAZING BECOMES AGGRESSIVE
description: Science '81, a consumer magazine from the American Association for the Advancement of Science, has just begun a highly competitive advertising campaign in which it takes on similar magazines not only on the grounds of efficiency but also on quality of audience.

title: Around the Nation; PROSECUTION WITNESS SAYS IRANIAN THREATENED CARTER
description: A witness described as a former Savak double agent has testified that another Iranian opposed to the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini made bombs and threatened to kill President Carter whom he held responsible for the downfall of the Shah of Iran.

title: Q&A
description: Q. When the waste line leading from our kitchen sink to the main sewer line in the basement clogged recently, we had a contractor clean it out with a power auger. When he finished he told us the drain had been blocked by grease, soap, etc., and that if we wanted to keep it clean we should pour half a cup of liquid bleach down the drain every month. Is this really a good idea? --G.R.R. Clark, N.J. A. It can't do any harm -- but I doubt if it will do much good. It often helps to use a regular drain cleaner at intervals, but bleach is not real drain cleaner. Your best bet is to practice prevention: Don't pour grease or fat down the drain, and don't allow coffee grinds or similar waste to be flushed down the drain. When you use soap, make sure you flush it away with hot water.

title: Sports of the Times; THE BEST DEFENSE? IT'S ATTACK
description: In boxing, taking one punch in order to land two is the way of the counterpuncher. Joe Louis,Sugar Ray Robinson and Bob Foster were among the best at that. But the new prototype is Harold Smith, the mystery promoter.

title: Going Out Guide
description: TOTAL RECALL New York is truly a wonder city, one of the few towns that can recreate for you an evening of listening to one of the all-time pop singers performing her hits of nearly 40 years ago on the premises of one of the most famous nightclubs of the same era. All this is by way of saying that Maxene Andrews, one of the three Andrews Sisters, is visiting, through Feb. 17, the Copa, successor to the Copacabana, at 10 East 60th Street (755-6010).

title: TROUBLED PACIFIC TELEPHONE
description: Pacific Telephone and Telegraph, the largest and most troubled of Ma Bell's children, is bracing for life as an orphan.

title: MAN ACCUSED OF $330,000 FRAUD FROM BANK ON FALSE CREDIT CARDS
description: A 29-year-old man was charged yesterday with stealing more than $330,000 from Chase Manhattan Bank by presenting sales receipts for false credit cards.

title: Ex-Vietnam Prisoner Is Accused of Collaborating With Enemy - He Has Pleaded Insanity
description: The case against Pfc. Robert R. Garwood of the Marine Corps, accused of collaborating with the enemy in Vietnam, was given to a jury of five Marine officers today after two and a half months of trial testimony from fellow prisoners of war in Vietnam and half a dozen psychiatrist.

title: BRIDGE'S SHUTDOWN RETURNS 3 TOWNS TO A HARSHER AGE
description: The great arc of the bridge, a modern steel giant softened by the sunlight and shadows of a bright winter's day, dwarfs the aging buildings and the people who dwell in the narrow places between the bluffs that rise abruptly from the water's edge in this old Mississippi River town.

title: AUTHORS' SERIES TO BEGIN FEB. 16
description: Norman Mailer, Tom Wolfe, Joyce Carol Oates, William Styron and Susan Sontag, reading from old and new works and answering questions from the audience, will open the first season of a series of literary programs sponsored by the newly founded National Committee for the Literary Arts at Lincoln Center.

title: Belated Recognition
description: ''When I was at Yale in the late 30's,'' Morton Gottlieb said, ''I appeared in a few productions of the Dramat, the undergraduate drama society, but they apparently didn't think I knew enough about the theater, so I was only made an associate member.''

title: Nanci Alker McCarter Married to Paul E. Opel
description: Nanci Alker McCarter and Paul Emerson Opel, graduates of Bennington College, were married at the Black Friar Inn in Bennington, Vt., yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Catherine Cadieux, pastor of the North Bennington Congregational Church, United Church of Christ.

title: MANHATTAN APARTMENTS: MORE PRIVACY AND LESS EXPENSE
description: ''There are many evils between tenants and landlords,'' Herman Langfer, an active builder in the New York metropolitan area, remarked the other day.

title: RESIDENTS ATTACK ACCORD ON HOOKER CORP. CLEANUP
description: Residents who live near a leaking toxic waste dump four times bigger than Love Canal are threatening to block a cleanup agreement between the Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation and the Federal and state governments.

title: No Headline
description: Time Inc. Earnings Fall Time Inc., the diversified forest products and communications concern, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1980 dropped 9 percent to $39.2 million, or $1.39 a share, from $43.1 million, or $1.54 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979.

title: PORT AUTHORITY IS TIGHTENING ITS WATER SPIGOTS
description: The automatic window-washing equipment that crawls up and down the twin 110-story towers of the World Trade Center has been turned off, and the cleanliness of 43,600 once-glistening windows is being left to the mercies of nature.

title: REAGAN AND SALT
description: Does the Reagan Administration seriously want a new strategic arms agreement with the Soviet Union? Mr. Reagan himself told a group of interviewers the other day that anytime Soviet leaders ''want to sit down and discuss a legitimate reduction of nuclear weapons, I'm willing to get into such negotiations.''

title: BROWN AT HELM OF A.T.&T.
description: When Charles L. Brown became chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company two years ago, he quickly established that he would not be bound by telephone company tradition.

title: BIG PRIVATE BANK POSTS DEFICIT
description: The National Bank of North America, the nation's 30th-largest bank, reported yesterday that it lost $10.77 million before taxes in the fourth quarter.

title: BANKER'S LEVERAGE ON POLAND
description: If Soviet tanks do not determine Poland's future course, Western bankers can. The leaders of the Polish Communist Party would never admit it, but the second-strongest foreign leverage on Poland is the huge debt to Western banks that Poland, unlike other Communist countries has racked up.

title: Handleman's New Head
description: Frank M. Hennessey, 42, a certified public accountant and a partner of Coopers & Lybrand, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Handleman Company, a major distributor of records and tapes to chain stores, effective March 2. He succeeds David Handleman, 65, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the corporation, based in Clawson, Mich., a suburb of Detroit.

title: TREASURY BONDS SOLD AT 12.68%; (000 ommitted in dollar figures)
Toll of Black Children Rises to 15 in Atlanta Area
description: A black child whose body was found today has been identified as a 14-year-old boy who disappeared Jan. 3. The child, Lubie Geter, was the 15th black youngster to have been found dead in the Atlanta area in the last 19 months, officials said.

title: ISRAEL SAYS IT WILL NOT ASK THE U.S. TO SEND IN G.I.'S FOR DEFENSE ROLE
description: Israel said today that it would not ask for the stationing of American troops on its soil and did not want to depend on any foreign army for its security.

title: REFUNDS: MAIN BOUT AT GARDEN
description: Tom Kenville's nose, which was trying to mind its own business, was threatened yesterday as many of the customers who had bought tickets for the soon-to-be-officially-canceled Feb. 23 boxing card at Madison Square Garden demanded refunds.

title: EX-GOV. GRASSO OF CONNECTICUT DEAD OF CANCER
description: Former Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut, the first woman to be elected governor in her own right in the United States, died here today. She was 61 years old.

title: S.E.C. Seeks Market Link
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed a rule that would bring the concept of a national stock market system a step closer by the end of summer.

title: 12 WOULD-BE GOVERNORS TOOT WHISTLES
description: A dozen candidates for Governor of New Jersey climbed aboard the only train used for nonstop politicking today and rode to Washington.

title: ARREST REOPENS UNSOLVED SLAYING OF TWO HUNTERS UPSTATE IN 1952
description: The unsolved shotgun slaying of two hunters in the wooded hills of Orange County in 1952 was reopened today with the arrest of a 54-year-old Newburgh man whose sister, authorities said, broke a 28-year vow of silence to turn him in.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 19.50 19.50 15.25 DISCOUNT RATE* 13.00 13.00 12.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 16.75 16.33 12.93 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.74 14.63 11.75 6-MO. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 'FORT APACHE, THE BRONX,' WITH PAUL NEWMAN
description: THE controversy over Daniel Petrie's ''Fort Apache, the Bronx,'' about life at an embattled police precinct station house in the South Bronx, recalls the controversy over William Friedkin's ''Cruising'' except for one important detail: ''Cruising'' turned out to be a dud, a big, fat soggy mess of a bomb that never went off, while ''Fort Apache, the Bronx'' looks as if it's going to be a hit, a movie that will be seen by a lot of people. The film, which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, is a tough-talking street melodrama, both shocking and sorrowful, acted by Paul Newman and a huge cast with the kind of conviction that can't be ignored.

title: TAX RISES AND WAGE FREEZE HINTED BY MAYOR OF DETROIT
description: Mayor Coleman A. Young gave the city the bad news about Detroit's deepening financial problems today, acknowledging that tax increases and wage freezes are likely when he unveils a new budget two months from now.

title: FROM LAWBREAKERS TO PRODUCTIVE CITIZENS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Maryland Bank In Shift to Delaware
description: The First National Bank of Maryland, the state's second-largest bank, will move its credit card division to lower Delaware, bringing with it between 300 and 1,000 jobs, an official of the Maryland Bankers Association said.

title: BRUINS TOP RANGERS AS MIDDLETON GETS 2
description: Don Maloney, a hero last night at Madison Square Garden with three goals in a 9-3 rout of the Islanders, did his best to carry on for the Rangers tonight with two goals at Boston Garden. But they were offset by two goals from Rick Middleton, and the Bruins won, 6-3.

title: Soon, a musical that follows Nora out the door.
description: PERHAPS you've never wondered what happened to Nora after she left Torvald Helmer in ''A Doll's House.'' Perhaps you've never cared. But did she find someone else? Was Torvald bereft? What happened to the three kids, anyway? Ibsen never told us, although now Betty Comden, Adolph Green, Larry Grossman and Harold Prince will. They are working on ''A Doll's Life,'' a musical that will begin just at the point where ''A Doll's House'' ended. ''Goodbye,'' Nora said then, and slammed the door. You were wrong, however, in thinking that she just disappeared, and ''A Doll's Life'' will find her again. It is supposed to open on Broadway in the spring of next year.

title: Brazilians' Iraq Road Job
description: A Brazilian construction company, Mendes Junior S.A., has been awarded a $280 million contract to build an 80-mile stretch of highway in western Iraq, the company said today. Mendes is already building a railroad in Iraq under a $1.2 billion contract.

title: 54-YEAR-OLD 'NAPOLEON' IS CITY'S HOTTEST TICKET
description: It's a four-hour, 54-year-old silent film, and it's the talk of New York. Practically everyone seems to have seen Abel Gance's spectacular ''Napoleon,'' which ends its much-extended run at the Radio City Music Hall this weekend. Those who haven't are talking about it anyway. Tickets - at a $25 top - are harder to find than people who will admit they haven't seen the film, though no one yet seems to have handed over the $250 that tickets fetched at the London Film Festival last year.

title: SOVIET-BLOC NATIONS SAID TOP PLEDGE ARMS TO SALVADOR REBELS
description: Indications that the Soviet Union and Cuba agreed last year to deliver tons of weapons to Marxist-led guerrillas in El Salvador are contained in secret documents reportedly captured from the insurgents by Salvadoran security forces.

title: ROSELAND SCHOOL DISPUTE: THE PARENTS FEEL ABUSED
description: The standoff between the city and residents of Rosedale, Queens, persisted yesterday as determined parents continued to occupy an intermediate-school annex that the School Chancellor had ordered closed.

title: Leading Entries in Millrose Track
description: 6:05 P.M. - P.S.A.L. two-lap relay. 6:10 - Club and college two-mile relay, handicap. 6:25 - Club and college one-mile relay, handicap. 6:40 - Masters one-mile relay. 6:45 - Suburban high school one-mile relay. 6:50 - One-mile walk: Todd Scully, Ron Kulik and Randy Mimm. 7:00 - Pole vault: Dan Ripley, Steve Smith, Tom Hintnaus, Ralph Haynie and Randy Hall. 7:00 - P.S.A.L. one-mile relay. 7:15 - Women's 60-yard hurdles heats: Stephanie Hightower, Candy Young, Vera Komisova, Benita Fitzgerald and Carol Lewis. 7:25 - 60-yard high hurdles heats: Renaldo Nehemiah, Greg Foster, Dedy Cooper, Rod Milburn and Yuri Cherva- nyev. 7:35 - Women's 60-yard dash heats: Alice Brown, Brenda Morehead, Chandra Cheeseborough and Ludmilla Kondra- tyeva. 7:45 - 60-yard dash heats: Stanley Floyd, Houston McTear, Mel Lattany, Harvey Glance, Carl Lewis, Herschel Walker and Aleksandr Aksinin. 7:55 - Women's 60-yard hurdles final. 8:00 - 60-yard high hurdles final. 8:05 - High jump: Franklin Jacobs, Benn Fields, Dwight Stones, Nat Page, Jeff Woodard, Jim Pringle and Leo Wil- liams. 8 :45 - Women's high jump: Sara Simeoni, Andrea M atay, Joni Huntley and Colleen Rienstra. 8 :45 - College two-mile relay. 8 :55 - 800-meter run: Peter Lemashon, Mark E nyeart, Sam Summerville and John Marshall. 9 :00 - College one-mile relay. 9 :05 - Women's 800-meter run: Robin Campbell, L orna Forde, Joetta Clark and Delisa Walton. 9 :10 - College one-mile relay. 9 :15 - 1,000-yard run: Don Paige, Mark Belger, M ike Boit and Bill Martin. 9 :20 - College one-mile relay. 9 :25 - Jesse Abramson 400-meter dash: Tony D arden, Willie Smith, Bert Cameron and Bill Green. 9 :30 - Women's one-mile relay. 9 :35 - Mel Sheppard 600-yard run: Chris P erson, Fred Sower- by, Clyde Edwards, Anthony Tufariello and M ike Solomon. 9 :40 - College one-mile relay. 9 :45 - High school mile: Brian Pettingill, J ohn Hinton, Kevin King and Lloyd Gellineau. 1 0:00 - International. 1 0:50 - Women's one-mile relay: Tennessee S tate, Atoms, Stanford T.C., Morgan State and D.C. I nternational. 1 0:55 - College two-mile relay: Villanova, V irginia, Rich- mond, Rutgers, Fairleigh Dickinson and P rinceton. 1 1:05 - College one-mile relay: Seton Hall, F airleigh Dickin- son, Morgan State and Maryland.

title: MRS. HARRIS FINISHES TESTIMONY BY INSISTING THAT SHE BROUGHT GUN ONLY TO KILL HERSELF
description: Jean S. Harris stepped down today as a witness in her three-month-old murder trial, insisting at the end of her testimony that she could not have intentionally killed Dr. Herman Tarnower after giving him ''14 years of my life.''

title: Mitsubishi Resumes Sales to Chrysler
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said it would resume production and shipment of its compact cars to the Chrysler Corporation, its ailing American partner, next month.

title: HAITIAN-CUBAN COST PUT AT $532 MILLION
description: Federal officials said today that the Government had spent about $532 million to handle the entry and resettlement of 125,000 Cubans and 12,400 Haitians who emigrated to the United States last year.

title: L.I.U. 92, Northeastern 77
description: Riley Clarida, shooting 9 for 11 from the floor, scored 24 points and pulled down 10 rebounds as he led Long Island University to a 92-77 victory over Northeastern in Brooklyn Thursday night. The Blackbirds (11-7), who got 20 points from Jeff Meriweather and 17 from Robert Cole, led, 40-30, at halftime. Pete Harris scored 24 points for Northeastern (15-4).

title: Rutgers Triumphs In Final 2 Seconds
description: A bank shot by Chris Nieberlein with two seconds to play gave Rutgers a 73-71 victory over West Virginia in an Eastern Eight basketball game tonight.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1981
description: International Washington assured NATO members that the Reagan Administration would make no decision on the possible production of the neutron bomb without ''thorough, prior consultations'' with the allies, according to Administration officials. They said that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had advised the allies in messages to disregard comments about the enhanced radiation bombs made by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger because they did not represent an official position. (Page A1, Column 1.) Soviet criticism of President Reagan and his foreign policy continued in Moscow's press. In an unusually sarcastic commentary, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda asserted that Mr. Reagan suffered from ''the childhood ailments of power.'' (A3:1-3.)

title: HALT IN URANIUM FOR INDIA URGED
description: Senator John Glenn asked President Reagan today to suspend shipments of uranium fuel to India in view of statements by the Indians that they have authorized the reprocessing of spent nuclear fuels in apparent violation of an agreement with the United States.

title: Index; International
description: Glenn urges President to block uranium shipment to India A2 Philippine opposition plans to boy- cott presidential election A2 Pakistan becoming a leading sup- plier of military manpower A2 French and West German leaders meet in Paris A3 Israel rejects any American mili- tary presence on its soil A4 Around the World A5 Islamic mediators in Iran-Iraq war to visit Teheran soon A6 Government/Politics White House Notes: Reagan wins with one-liners A13 Navy Secretary urges doubling of shipbuilding program A24 Committee rejects Carey nominee for Industrial Commissioner B1 A dozen would-be governors hop a political train B2 Official calls annuities for survi- vors of U.S. judges inadequate B3 Council approves legislation to regulate funeral homes B3 Was hostages' parade a ticker- tape record? B3 General Around the Nation A8 Commercial salmon fishing in Co- lumbia River fading A8 Rosedale parents refuse to budge in school sit-in B1 Mrs. Harris insists she did not in- tend to kill Dr. Tarnower B2 The City B3 Residents near toxic dump threaten to block cleanup pact B3 Cold delays transportation serv- ices in metropolitan area B4 Inquiry on legal profession is stir- ring battle B7 Features/Notes Issue and Debate: disclosing the names of intelligence agents A10 Notes on People B4 Weekend Weekender Guide C1

title: A MARINE COURT FINDS GARWOOD HELPED FOE AS A VIETNAM P.O.W.
description: Pfc. Robert R. Garwood of the Marine Corps was found guilty today of collaborating with the enemy and assaulting a fellow soldier while a prisoner of war in Vietnam 14 years ago.

title: Spy for East Germany Jailed
description: Gerhard Arnold, an East German-born computer expert, was sentenced today to 30 months in prison for spying for East Germany. He was found guilty of passing information, mostly on data processing, between 1960 and 1978. The judge said that he had been decorated six times by East Germany, but that his activities had been mitigated by a confession and his failure to fulfill some orders from the Ministry of State Security, the East German intelligence agency.

title: INQUIRY ON LEGAL PROFESSION STIRS BATTLE
description: The Federal Trade Commission, which last year overcame efforts in Congress to curtail its activities, appears headed for a battle over an investigation of the legal profession.

title: Market Place; Flow General And New Cells
description: FLOW GENERAL INC., a small biomedical company that landed an important contract to produce interferon last year, has become a speculative favorite in the stock market as a result of a different product. The company has scheduled initial clinical trials of transplants of skin made from cells taken from the patient's own body.

title: Iowa 76, Northwestern 65
description: Vince Brookins scored 27 points to equal his career-high total and Kevin Boyle had 16 to lead Iowa to a 76-65 victory over Northwestern tonight.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Friday; BROOKLYN POETRY AND JAZZ
description: Allen Ginsberg, the poet, and David Amram, the composer and musician, will team up tonight at the Downtown Cultural Center of the Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association, 111 Willoughby Street. Starting at 8, Mr. Ginsberg will read from his works. Then Mr. Amram's jazz quintet will perform. And then, no doubt, as they have done before, Mr. Ginsberg will read and Mr. Amram will improvise a jazz accompaniment. Admission is $3. Reservations: 596-2222. 'BLACK & WHITE' DOWNTOWN

title: Lockheed Exchange Offer
description: The Lockheed Corporation today offered to buy back its $101 million of outstanding 4 1/4 percent debentures by exchanging $11.25-a-share convertible preferred stock for them.

title: STRIKE IN SOUTHERN POLAND ENDS AS GOVERNMENT YIELDS
description: BIALA, Poland, Friday, Feb. 6 - A 10-day general strike that gripped this southern manufacturing city ended early this morning when the Government agreed to accept the resignations of the provincial Governor and three deputies.

title: WHEN FAUCETS YIELD ONLY RUSTY TRICKLES
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Class Sunday In Stanislavsky Method
description: When Sonia Moore, an authority on Konstantin Stanislavsky, offered a free class last month on the method evolved by the great Russian actor, director and theoretician, more than 100 would-be audience members had to be turned away. So she is offering another free class Sunday at 7:30 P.M., in the SoHo Repertory Theater, 19 Mercer Street.

title: PANEL BARS CAREY'S NOMINEE TO HEAD LABOR DEPARTMENT
description: The Labor Committee of the Republican-led State Senate today recommended the rejection of Governor Carey's nomination of Meyer S. Frucher to be the state's Industrial Commissioner. Its action followed the refusal of the current Commissioner, Philip Ross, to respond to a committee subpoena.

title: Buffalo Forge Denied Injunction
description: The New York Supreme Court yesterday denied a request by the Buffalo Forge Company for a preliminary injunction to halt a takeover by the Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation.

title: PARTNERING AS AN ART, BY EDWARD VILLELLA
description: A dancer named Pierina Legnani became famous when, in 1892, she whipped off 32 fouettes in a ballet called ''Aladdin.'' Vaslav Nijinsky is famous for his enormous leap through a window in ''Le Spectre de la Rose.'' But ballet is not all star turns. Much of it depends on two bodies moving almost as one.

title: BUSINESS APPLAUDS REAGAN'S ANALYSIS
description: Top business leaders and economists said yesterday that, while President Reagan was effective in communicating to Americans the sacrifices needed to achieve his program, they found little that was new in the economic message.

title: Epilogue to a Long Friendship With Marc Connelly
description: When Marc Connelly's play, ''Hunter's Moon,'' opened in London in 1958, an English choreographer, Pauline Grant, was engaged to stage its single dance sequence.

title: Pepsico Earnings Off 9.2%
description: Pepsico Inc., the nation's secondlargest soft drink producer, said today that its net income for the final quarter of 1980 dropped 9.2 percent from the 1979 period, largely because of a $17.8 million write-off in the company's trucking business. Profit for the three-month period fell to $60.4 million, or 67 cents a share, from $66.5 million, or 73 cents a share. Revenues climbed 17.4 percent.

title: DEVIOUS DEVICE TO TRIM A BUDGET
description: To the Editor:

title: HAIG ADVISES ALLIES TO DISREGARD TALK OF NEUTRON WEAPON
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has advised Washington's allies in Europe to disregard comments by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger on the possible production of the neutron bomb because they did not represent an official position, Administration officials said today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE RAT ON FIRE. By George V. Higgins. 183 pages. Knopf. $10.95.

title: White House Notes
description: For years, President Reagan's rivals have assumed that his background as an actor is a political liability, and once again last night he showed why it is not.

title: ART: A STRATEGY FOR VIEWING THE WHITNEY BIENNIAL
description: A NEW Whitney Biennial Exhibition is upon us. It opened this week at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street, where it will occupy three full floors until April 5. It is - as expected - a big show. It is also an occasionally repulsive show. There are whole stretches of it, moreover, that are extremely boring. All the same, it is a show that everyone interested in the art of our time will want to see. It is a show that really tells us something about the condition of our culture. You may think you have correctly gauged the plight of the contemporary artist. You may even think you have some appreciation of the plight of the contemporary museum curator in search of new art. But believe me, you don't know the half of it until you have seen this Biennial.

title: NEW YORK STATE ELECTIONS NEED PUBLIC FINANCING
description: To the Editor:

title: Stealth Bomber Report
description: Is Assailed as Political The Washington Star

title: A DAY OF LOBBYING FOR WOMEN'S RIGHTS ISSUES
description: Mary Tyler Moore, Gloria Steinem and Bella Abzug went to see Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House. Dr. Benjamin Spock talked with Senator Ted Stevens. Former Congresswoman Patsy Mink met with Senators Mark O. Hatfield and Robert J. Dole.

title: MANY LISTENED TO A DIFFERENT DRUMMER
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Fluor Engineers & Constructors, a subsidiary of Fluor Corporation, executed the final contract covering engineering services on the 745-mile Alaska segment of the Alaskan natural gas transportation system.

title: President Is Named, By Dart and Kraft
description: Warren L. Batts, the 48-year-old former president of the Mead Corporation, who joined Dart Industries as president just three weeks before its merger with Kraft Inc. last Sept. 25, has been named to the same post at the combined Dart and Kraft Inc.

title: N.W. Ayer to Handle Time-Life Products
description: N.W. Ayer ABH International's Direct Response division will be doing advertising for four products from Time-Life Books, Alexandria, Va.

title: OPERATION IS REPORTED ON BLOCKAGE IN BRAIN THAT LEADS TO STROKES
description: A Johns Hopkins Hospital neurosurgeon said today that he had successfully performed the first operation to remove arterial blockage in the brain, one of the major causes of strokes.

title: ROBERTA PETERS MARKS 30 YEARS AS A SOPRANO AT MET
description: It has been 30 years since a pretty young woman from the Bronx named Roberta Peters stepped out before her first audience and was propelled into virtually instant stardom in the world of opera. The setting was the Metropolitan Opera, and her surprise debut as a lastminute stand-in for an ailing soprano in Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' created a sensation that started her on a flourishing career.

title: TO DETER THE INCREASING CRIME WITHIN PRISONS
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA HISTORY IN ONE QUICK AND CHEERFUL PERFORMANCE
description: NOVITIATES at the altar of grand opera can save themselves a lot of time and trouble by going to see the Broque Opera Company's ''The Ring of the Fettuccines'' tonight and tomorrow night in Greenwich Village. With merciful brevity and an ingratiating lack of depth, this crash course in opera history compresses every memorable tune and every improbability of plot worth remembering into a 55-minute amalgam of tongue-in-cheek entertainment. If you miss this weekend's performances or feel you need to take the course again, ''The Ring of the Fettucciness'' will be repeated next Friday and Saturday.

title: Kennecott Net Has Big Gain
description: The Kennecott Corporation, the nation's leading domestic copper producer, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 rose to $160.8 million, or $4.84 a share, from a strikedepressed $52.5 million, or $1.58 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979.

title: COUNCIL ADOPTS BILL TO REGULATE FUNERAL HOMES
description: New York was on the verge of becoming the first major city in the United States to regulate funeral homes yesterday when the City Council approved legislation requiring them to post prominently a price list for all goods and services.

title: FILM IMAGE PROVOKES OUTCRY IN SOUTH BRONX
description: A black prostitute, demented by drugs, calmly murders two rookie policemen. A mob of Puerto Ricans and blacks attacks a station house and has to be subdued by tear gas and nightsticks. Two white officers, enraged by assaults on the police, hurl an innocent Puerto Rican teen-ager to his death from a tenement roof.

title: Chamber Music at Dairy In Park zunday
description: A free concert of chamber music will take place at noon Sunday at the Dairy in Central Park, 65th Street, north of the Wollman Rink.

title: Hijacking of Jet Is Foiled, By Ruse at San Juan Airport
description: A man who said he was fleeing both the Mafia and the police tried to hijack an Eastern Airlines jet to Cuba today but was tricked into leaving the plane at San Juan when the crew told him they had landed in Havana.

title: 23,000 LIFESAVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'FEAR NO EVIL'
description: EVER since a beginner writer-director named George Romero assembled a cast of amateurs in Pittsburgh and made millions with ''Night of the Living Dead,'' there have been sporadic outbreaks of the deadly show-business virus in the provinces from Staten Island to the Deep South.

title: CITY BALLET: THREE WORKS THAT HAVE IMPROVED OVER THE YEARS
description: SOME ballets do improve with age - especially if they are revised. Three such sterling examples went on view Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. They were George Balanchine's ''The Four Temperaments'' and ''Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme'' and Jacques d'Amboise's ''Tchaikovsky Suite No. 2.'' Each was receiving its first performance of the New York City Ballet season.

title: ANTI-CONSUMERISM WINS ABATTLE
description: To the Editor:

title: 22 COUNTRIES AVAIL THEMSELVES OF PAKISTANI SOLDIERS
description: With two divisions of troops now reported to be assembling for deployment to Saudi Arabia, Pakistan is becoming the third world's leading supplier of military manpower after Cuba.

title: Village Spanish and exotic TriBeCa.
description: CONSIDERING the current rage for seafood and the equal interest in finding bargains, the popularity of Cafe Espanol on Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village is easy to understand. For, though most of the selections on the Spanish and Mexican menus leave much to be desired, there are several savory and satisfying appetizers and copious seafood main courses that are exceptional buys. Add to that the snug and engaging adobe hacienda setting and the friendly, concerned and generally efficient staff, and you have the makings of a pleasant dinner, especially before or after Off Broadway theater.

title: THE ATTRACTIONS OF OSCAR MAYER
description: Oscar Mayer & Company, the Middle Western meatpacking concern, has been a familiar brand in many American households. But the closely held, conservatively managed corporation, troubled recently with faltering profits, was less well regarded in the financial community - and seemed an unlikely target for acquisition.

title: Reagan Makes Choice For Human Rights Post
description: Ernest Lefever, the head of a conservative research group who has said that the promotion of human rights abroad is not the responsibility of the United States, has been chosen by President Reagan to assume the State Department's top human rights post, Government officials said today.

title: OFFICIAL CALLS ANNUITIES FOR NEW U.S. JUDGES' FAMILIES TOTALLY
description: INADEQUATE By PETER KIHSS

title: NAVY SECRETARY ASKS DOUBLING OF NEW SHIP ORDERS
description: The new Secretary of the Navy, John F. Lehman Jr., urged today that Congress permit the Navy to double its shipbuilding program next year as a first step toward restoring United States maritime superiority over the Soviet Union.

title: GULF WAR MEDIATORS TO VISIT IRAN
description: Reports from Iran said today that a group of Islamic leaders would visit Teheran soon to try to end the war with Iraq, and some Arab diplomats here suggested that the Iranian refusal to consider any peace moves might be softening.

title: How Resnais made a success with science.
description: ''FIVE years ago, I was doing research for a film about human memory,'' Alain Resnais, the French director, was saying. ''Not coincidentally it was for a pharmaceutical company that had developed a drug that was supposed to improve memory. My research put me in touch with Dr. Henri Laborit, a well-known behavioral scientist. Although the film was never made, we became friends - not close friends, but we would see each other perhaps three or four times a year.

title: PAPER GRAPHICS TO TURN MILK CARTONS INTO TOYS
description: At breakfast one morning, Marjorie Weinberg, a mother of two, looked at the milk carton in front of her and thought it would make a good toy. But Mrs. Weinberg, a graphic designer and printmaker, didn't stop there.

title: 'EAST OF EDEN,' THE ARMY AND A SERIES
description: CERTAINLY in terms of sheer bulk, ''East of Eden,'' beginning Sunday at 8 o'clock on ABC-TV, commands notice this weekend. The first installment of this new television version runs for three hours; the second, Monday at 9, lasts two hours, and the final three hours will be shown Wednesday, beginning at 8.

title: Hinson Pleads Not Guilty To a Reduced Charge
description: Representative Jon C. Hinson, Republican of Mississippi, pleaded not guilty today to a charge of attempted sodomy and was released without bail pending a trial scheduled for May 4.

title: HOSTAGES' PARADE SET A RECORD, DIDN'T IT?
description: In hot pursuit of superlatives, New York City's Sanitation Department concluded yesterday that last Friday's ticker-tape parade for the returned American hostages was the largest event of its kind ever held in lower Manhattan - sort of.

title: IRAN SAYS MRS. DWYER WAS TRICKED IN HOSTAGE PLOT
description: An Iranian prosecutor pressing spy charges against Cynthia B. Dwyer, an American freelance journalist, was reported today to have charged that two revolutionary guards tricked her last year into participating in a fictitious plot to free the 52 American hostages.

title: Penn Central Opens Talks on GK Again
description: The Penn Central Corporation's on-again, off-again takeover plans for GK Technologies Inc. may be on again. GK Technologies said yesterday that Penn Central, the revitalized corporate successor to the defunct Penn Central Transportation Company had requested an opportunity to discuss acquiring it again.

title: Shaw & Koulermos Wins Bonds Stores Account
description: ''Get to Bonds. Dress to Win,'' is the new advertising theme created by Shaw & Koulermos to win the Bonds Stores account, which is expected to bill more than $1 million.

title: SHE'S 50, AND GIVES A ROUSING PARTY TO SAY SO
description: At the sound of a drum roll, a birthday cake with 50 glowing candles was wheeled into the darkened banquet room and everyone but Josephine Piscitelli sang ''Happy birthday to you.'' She sang ''Happy birthday to me.'' Quite loudly.

title: Owners of Sex Club Indicted in Tax Case
description: Three men described as the owners of Plato's Retreat were indicted in Manhattan yesterday for tax-evasion involving the alleged skimming of $2.3 million from the club.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is time to recognize that we have come to a turning point.

title: White House Social Secretary Is Appointed
description: Mabel Brandon, the founding director of a Washington company that specializes in organizing cultural and social functions for corporate clients, has been named White House social secretary.

title: 8.6% of Harcourt Bought by Warner
description: Warner Communications Inc., the entertainment giant, said yesterday that it had bought an 8.6 percent stake in Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., the diversified book publishing company. In response, Harcourt said that it does not look upon Warner as a company with which it ''wants to do any business whatsoever.''

title: MANY LISTENED TO A DIFFERENT DRUMMER
description: To the Editor:

title: Indiana 89, Wisconsin 64
description: Tony Brown made his first five shots and scored 12 of his 18 points in the first half tonight to help Indiana to an 89-64 victory over Wisconsin. The Hoosiers, the Big Ten leaders, raised their league record to 7-2 and their overall mark to 14-7.

title:
RED SMITH;
The King of the Boards Is a Smiling Irishman
description: WHEN Eamonn Coghlan was 11 years old, he joined the Metropolitan Harriers in Dublin because he thought it would please his father, who had been a runner in his youth and was active as a track and field official in later years. On his first day in the club, there was a one-mile cross-country race Eamonn wanted to enter.

title: BLUES: EMBELLISHMENTS BY B.B. KING
description: B.B. KING is the world's best-known blues performer largely because he has learned how to package the blues for mass consumption. He is immensely talented, but for the few blues singers and guitarists who are his peers, talent hasn't been enough. Only Mr. King has successfully conquered Las Vegas and the Soviet Union, among other unlikely locales for blues appreciation, without making drastic alterations in his music.

title: CUTTING TAXES WITHOUT INFLATION
description: The combination of near-record high interest rates, a soso economic recovery, and a $60 billion deficit have led to an intense search for new answers to the country's economic questions. Thus far, the Kemp-Roth tax-cut approach - a 10 percent per year reduction in tax rates for three consecutive years - - appears to be the major find. However, there is considerable ambivalence about Kemp-Roth because of its inflationary potential. Another policy that would provide its promised supply-side gains in productivity without the demand-side result of increased inflation would find a broader constituency.

title: Five-Day Strike Is Ended In Schools in Philadelphia
description: The five-day strike by nonteaching employees in the Philadelphia school district ended today with overwhelming approval of a new contract that provides no pay increase in the current fiscal year.

title: G.O.P. ADMITS NEED TO REVISE TAX CUTS
description: Key Republicans on Capitol Hill now concede that President Reagan's tax-cut package will have to undergo major revisions before it can attract enough Democratic votes to insure passage by Congress.

title: Strength Spurs Sara Simeoni's Leap to Success
description: Sara Simeoni of Italy, the world-recordholder and Olympic champion in the women's high jump, will compete in the 74th annual Wanamaker Millrose Games tonight at Madison Square Garden. Along the way, she may dispel a few misconceptions about her event.

title: MANY LISTENED TO A DIFFERENT DRUMMER
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN IS WINNER IN HOUSE ON BILL TO RAISE DEBT LIMIT
description: The House of Representatives handed President Reagan his first victory on Capitol Hill today in a politically sensitive vote to increase the debt limit by $50 billion, to $985 billion.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 6, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Scientific and technical subcommit- tee of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M.

title: ANTI-CONSUMERISM WINS A BATTLE
description: To the Editor:

title: GISCARD-SCHMIDT TOPICS: REAGAN AND SOVIET
description: The leaders of France and West Germany met here today to discuss the shadowed state of East-West relations, along with engaging in some anxious speculation about the foreign policy of President Reagan.

title: U.N. Panel Says Cambodia's Ills Spring From Genocide by Pol Pot
description: A United Nations report said today that genocide committed by the Pol Pot regime was at the root of all of Cambodia's problems of the last five years.

title: Richmond; WHITE HOUSE TO SEEK BUDGET CUTS OF $40 BILLION IN 1982 FISCAL YEAR
description: The White House has informed members of Congress that it is aiming for a reduction of $40 billion to $50 billion in the Federal budget for the fiscal year 1982, making cuts in virtually every major Federal endeavor except the military, Republican Congressional sources said today.

title: Trade Deficit Up in Quarter
description: The United States merchandise trade deficit doubled to $5.6 billion in the last three months of 1980, with the increase largely attributable to rising oil imports, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: I.R.A. Threatens to Stage New Ulster Hunger Strikes
description: Irish Republican Army guerrillas in two Northern Ireland prisons said today that they would begin new hunger strikes March 1 to back demands for political prisoner status.

title: Wrong Turns on Human Rights
description: A once-promising American commitment to human rights may have been swept under the red carpet rolled out this week for Chun Doo Hwan. During his White House visit, the South Korean President got about all he wanted: a legitimizing pat from President Reagan, a promise of hardware and an assurance that American troops will stay in South Korea. And butter would have melted on Mr. Reagan's toast to Mr. Chun: ''In the short time you've had, Mr. President, you've done much to strengthen the tradition of 3,000 years' commitment to freedom.''

title: RETURN OF ARCTIC WEATHER DELAYS MANY COMMUTERS IN RUSH HOUR
description: As bitterly cold weather descended again on New York City yesterday, some of the metropolitan area's transportation systems showed signs of mechanical frostbite.

title: 23 IN IRANIAN PARLIAMENT ASK DEBATE ON HOSTAGE ISSUE
description: Twenty-three members of Parliament today requested an open debate on the ''doubts and questions'' that have arisen over the Iranian-American agreements that led to the release of the 52 hostages.

title: Hamilton Leads Skating
description: Scott Hamilton took the early lead today over David Santee, the three-time runner-up, in the compulsory figures competition at the United States figure-skating championships.

title: CAREY'S NEIGHBOR TO GET $6,400 IN LAND SEIZURE
description: Dr. Philip D'Arrigo, the Scarsdale dentist who had challenged the state's right to seize an acre of his land next to Governor Carey's summer home on Shelter Island, has officially won the battle.

title: Funds' Assets Rise Sharply to Record
description: The total assets of the nation's money market funds rose sharply again this week, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. In the week ended Wednesday, aggregate assets of the 99 funds tallied by the institute jumped $2.9 billion, to a record $86.8 billion.

title: energywatch
description: JAN. 30, 1981 A change in calculation methods raised crude supplies by 9 million barrels to 369.3 million.

title: The Economy
description: The ''worst economic mess since the great Depression'' now faces the U.S., President Reagan said a wide-ranging speech on the nation's economy. Among the solutions he proposed were 10 percent reductions in personal income taxes in each of the next three years and new corporate tax measures aimed at encouraging investment. These would be matched by spending cuts, but he offered few details on these. (Page A1.) Businessmen applauded the President's presentation of the problems, but felt it lacked specific new details. (A13.)

title: MUSIC: ZUKERMAN PLAYS BRAHMS
description: LAST fall Pinchas Zukerman played a wonderfully vital performance of the Brahms Violin Concerto with Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic. Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, he embarked on a twoprogram survey of the complete Brahms sonatas for violin and viola. And for all the mastery of the playing, the results were less impressive.

title: London Times Printers Reject Murdoch Plan
description: Leaders of the two main printers' unions at The Times of London and The Sunday Times today rejected a pay freeze and staff reductions demanded by Rupert Murdoch as conditions for his purchase of the newspapers.

title: Your Taxes; A Guide to Preparing 1980 Returns; Fifth of 12 articles.-
description: The family home is the best hedge against inflation for millions of Americans, in large part because the nation's tax laws encourage home ownership.

title: Brock Backs Relief From Auto Imports
description: Bill Brock, the United States special trade representative, said today that the auto industry should get some form of temporary protection against Japanese imports as part of broader tax relief and deregulatory policies to help revive it.

title: Protocol Chief in Chicago
description: Chicago's Mayor, Jane Byrne, has hired the former operator of the North Shore School of Etiquette, Noreen McBride, to fill the newly created position of director of protocol.

title: Books
description: Pictures From the Black Past By Julius Lester SOME TIME AGO: A Historical Portrait of Black Americans, 1850-1950. By Chester Higgins Jr. and Orde Coombs. 206 pages. Anchor Press/Doubleday. $17.95.

title: VIRGINIA DEFEATS WAGNER, 76-79
description: Virginia's undefeated basketball team, surprisingly, trailed Wagner by 4 points midway through the second half at Madison Square Garden last night. Seahawk fans were elated, hardly able to believe their team from Staten Island had a chance to beat the mighty Cavaliers, who are ranked No. 1 in the nation by The Associated Press.

title: Chrysler Rebuffed By Borg-Warner
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation will not agree to the Chrysler Corporation's request for price reductions from its suppliers and has been strategically withdrawing as a supplier to Chrysler, its chairman, James F. Bere, told security analysts.

title: DISCLOSING INTELLIGENCE AGENTS' NAMES
description: The December issue of Covert Action Information Bulletin, the latest of the irregularly published magazine, contained a listing in boldface type of what was said to be the names of eight senior officers of the Central Intelligence Agency serving with fictitious diplomatic titles in eight foreign countries.

title: Strings in Rockland
description: The Manhattan String Quartet will present a program of works by Mozart, Shostakovich and Dvorak tonight at 8:30 in the Rockland Center for the Arts, 27 South Greenbush Road in West Nyack.

title: Rutledge's Fear Of Coach Cited
description: A college football player delayed filing a $2.2 million damage suit against Frank Kush, the former Arizona State coach, because of fears for his safety, the player's father testified today.

title: WARNS OF 'CALAMITY' IF TAXES AND U.S. SPENDING ARE NOT CUT
description: President Reagan, saying the United States was ''in the worst economic mess since the Great Depression,'' appealed tonight for support for sweeping spending and tax cuts.

title: Sometimes Energy Can be Free
description: To President Reagan, conservation is a faintly dirty word that means being hot in the summer and cold in the winter; it may be necessary in a pinch but it is disagreeable policy and terrible politics. Well, perhaps not. A thus-far less successful California politician is out to prove him wrong. Gov. Jerry Brown has been pushing an ambitious energy program based on the notion that conservation can be a political winner. There may be a free lunch after all, and it may be available nationally.

title: FISHING AS WAY OF LIFE WANES ON COLUMBIA
description: When they ran wild and free, the Columbia River and its tributaries were filled with salmon, as the fish, in their last act before dying, came in from the sea to leave their eggs in the gravel creek beds where they had been hatched.

title: News Analysis
description: With an oratorical directness and an aura of sincerity that he has made his political trademarks, President Reagan tonight set aside the nuances of economic analysis to try to seize the attention of the

title: METS DROP MADDOX
description: Elliott Maddox was working out in Shea Stadium yesterday morning when a groundskeeper summoned him to the office of Frank Cashen, the Mets' general manager. When Maddox arrived, he got the word: The club was asking waivers on him for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.

title: Why Rush to Convict the Gun Law?
description: Mayor Koch, a justifiably proud parent of New York's stiff new gun law, now wants to disown it, or at least to rebuke the judges who, he says, have made it flop. What's the hurry? In fact, it's too early to tell whether the law is working; the past few months' figures make no strong case either way. Worse, even if Mr. Koch's estimate turns out to be right, his analysis of who's to blame is unsubstantiated and may well be wrong.

title: Advertising; Young Miss Magazine's New Look
description: PARENTS MAGAZINE ENTERPRISES is discontinuing the 28-year-old, digest-size, advertising-free Young Miss magazine with the June issue, only to revive it in August as a standard-sized, totally new advertising medium.

title: Deputy Attorney General Choice Wins Senate Panel Endorsement
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today voted, 18 to 0, to recommend the confirmation of Edward C. Schmults, a New York lawyer, as Deputy Attorney General.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS OFF; GRACE AND SEARLE GAIN
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, a leading defense contractor with strong positions in military aircraft, submarines, tactical missles and gun systems, reported yesterday that weakness in its nondefense business spurred by the depressed economy caused earnings in the fourth quarter to fall 8.8 percent on a sales increase of 18.2 percent.

title: TRAM RUNS EXPECTED BY END OF FEBRUARY
description: The Roosevelt Island tramway, which has been shut down on and off since early last November, is expected to be running by the end of this month, a spokesman for the state's Urban Development Corporation said.

title: Ramada Outlook
description: Ramada Inns Inc. said it expected 1980 net income to rise to 60 cents a share on revenues of $450 million, compared to previous year's earnings of 57 cents a share on revenues of $375.6 million. Speaking to analysts in Atlantic City, Ramada officials said, however, that they had lowered their estimates from a year earlier for year-end earnings from 1982 gaming operations.

title: Tektronix Work Halt
description: Tektronix Inc. said today that it would close its operations for a week beginning March 16 because of a decline in orders, affecting 19,000 employees. The company also said that, beginning on April 5, employees will take one day every two weeks as vacation or unpaid absence until further notice.

title: PHILIPPINE OPPOSITION TO BOYCOTT PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION
description: The opposition coalition formally announced today that it would not run a candidate against President Ferdinand E. Marcos in the presidential election that Mr. Marcos intends to call for May.

title: Carter's Political Envoys Told They Must Leave
description: The Reagan Administration has informed the American ambassadors abroad who were political appointees of the Carter Administration that their resignations have been accepted and that they should begin to make plans to leave their posts.

title: ART: THE GLORIES OF BENIN'S ROYALTY
description: ''IMAGES OF POWER: The Royal Court of Benin'' at the Grey Art Gallery and Study Center (33 Washington Place) comprises 65 works, most of which date from the 16th to the 18th centuries. Drawn mainly from private collections in New York, these bronze heads and plaques, together with miscellaneous works in ivory, wood and terra cotta, celebrate the lives of the Oba, or god-kings of the city-state of Benin.

title: Vatican Banker Linked To Sindona Is Arrested
description: A top executive of the Vatican's private bank was arrested today and accused of taking part in a fraudulent bankruptcy linked to the jailed financier Michele Sindona, the police said.

title: Spacey Music for Kids
description: A world of rockets, planets, shooting stars and space music will be offered for children at Avery Fisher Hall tomorrow when the Little Orchestra Society presents ''Outer Space: A Musical Odyssey.'' The program, the second in a three-concert series for young people, will take place at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. Tickets, at $3.50 to $8.50, are available at the box office and may be reserved by calling 757-5496.

title: RACIAL 'JUSTICE'
description: A South African court recently cleared three black nationalists of murder charges and then condemned them to death anyway for their part in an abortive guerrilla action. In Florida and North Carolina, last year, all-white juries acquitted, despite strong indications of guilt, whites accused of murdering blacks and antiracist white radicals.

title: Honoring 65 Years of Service to Teachers College
description: Soon after the death in 1915 of his aunt, Grace Hoadley Dodge, one of the founders of Teachers College, Cleveland E. Dodge was elected a trustee of the college and he's been one ever since.

title: EXPLORING THE NEW AMSTERDAM AVENUE
description: AMSTERDAM AVENUE, that West Side thoroughfare which starts in ordinary circumstances on the north side of 59th Street and ends in a lordly parkside sweep at 193d, might well be shrugged off by your casual tourist as an unremarkable street, needed mostly to take traffic off its parallel roads. Except that bordering its sidewalks are Lincoln Center, the magnificent Cathedral of St. John the Divine and three of the city's outstanding universities, Columbia, City College and Yeshiva. And except that it is beginning, in its 60's, 70's and 80's, to catch some of the glamour of its resurrected neighbor, Columbus Avenue.

title: MINORITIES AND MR. REAGAN
description: PricePresident Reagan gave the Congressional Black Caucus a warm dose of soft sell this week, but its members remain anxious about what his Presidency means for their constituents. His election has emboldened Congressional conservatives to try to roll back civil rights gains. With the Federal budget deeply in deficit, each day sets off new alarms about radical cuts in social programs. The challenge for minorities is how to reconcile their natural interests with the nation's urgent economic needs.

title: News Analysis
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill's first budget message to the General Assembly last night may offer an indication of the political strategy that he will follow if, as expected, he seeks election to a full term next year.

title: PUBLISHING: BUDD SCHULBERG'S HOLLYWOOD DAYS
description: By EDWIN McDOWELL

title: BILL HENDERSON SINGING A LA MERCER
description: BILL HENDERSON, the vocalist and actor who is singing a program of Johnny Mercer songs at Michael's Pub, met the late Mr. Mercer only once.

title: Ford of Canada
description: Ford of Canada cut sticker prices on some models and said it would offer below-market interest rates for credit buyers of most cars and trucks.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN ADDRESS REPORTING ON THE STATE OF THE NATION'S
description: ECONOMY Following is a transcript of President Reagan's address to the nation last night from Washington on the economy, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Saban Will Be Named Yankees' President
description: Lou Saban, a college and professional football coach for 30 years, will become president of the Yankees in the next week or two. George Steinbrenner, for whom Saban has worked in Tampa, Fla., for the last six months, would not confirm the appointment, but a source close to the Yankees said that Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner, would announce it later this month.

title: Celtics Lose 3d Straight As Bucks Win by 113-103
description: The Celtics scored the first 12 points tonight but the Milwaukee Bucks, aided by 20 points from Marques Johnson, beat Boston, 113-103.

title: HIGH HEELS AND ANGELS
description: T HERE are a lot of parties at the White House and in the diplomatic reception rooms of the State Department each year, which is why Clement Conger, the curator of both, is one of the few men in his profession concerned with fashion. At the moment, Mr. Conger is hoping that the spike heels he's spotted around are not indicative of a trend.

title: ART: RUDY BURCKHARDT, MUNICIPAL RESOURCE
description: ONE of our more valuable New Yorkers - though one who never tries to be conspicuous - is called Rudy Burckhardt. He is a very good photographer: someone who can look at a city and get it exactly right without even seeming to point the camera in any particular direction. He is a very good writer, too. The autobiographical essays in his most recent book, ''Mobile Homes'' (Z Press, $6), are sharp, funny and touched with wonder. He has had all kinds of adventures, both seemly and unseemly, and he gets them down on the page without a word wasted.

title: Red Clay Ramblers to Join Stanley Band at N.Y.U.
description: Two leading groups in the renaissance of bluegrass music, Ralph Stanley and the Clinch Mountain Boys, and the Red Clay Ramblers, will perform tomorrow night at 8 in New York University's Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place, south end of Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village.

title: Creamer Named Agency For Narragansett Brewing
description: Creamer Inc. has just been named agency for the Narragansett Brewing Company, Cranston, R.I. That may be a bit newsy, but the real news will be if the client really spends in ''the low seven-figure range'' for advertising, given the negative attitude toward advertising the new management of Falstaff Brewing, the parent company, has.

title: A.& S. Is Acquiring A Korvettes L.I. Site
description: Abraham & Straus said yesterday that it had completed negotiations to acquire the Korvettes store site in the Sunrise Mall, in Massapequa, L.I., which will be reopened in the late fall as an A.& S. suburban branch store.

title: Nets Cease Talks To Sign Williams
description: The New Jersey Nets broke off negotiations today for Gus Williams, a free-agent guard formerly with the Seattle SuperSonics, after Williams asked for more than the $2.6 million he was offered, said Charlie Theokas, the Nets' general manager.

title: Dow Adds 4.78 Points, To 946.76
description: Potential takeover situations, former glamour issues and several airlines moved higher yesterday to spearhead a general advance in the stock market. Defense, precious metals, oil service and selected energy stocks also displayed gains.

title: Jenkins, Streck Share Stroke Lead on 65's
description: Two struggling qualifiers who have not won in a while led the opening round of the Wickes-San Diego open today with seven-under-par 65's. Tom Jenkins, winner of the Philadelphia Classic in 1975, and Ron Streck, who won at San Antonio in 1978, shared the one-stroke advantage.

title: RY COODER FINDS PUBLIC FOR HIS MUSICAL GOULASH
description: 8888), on Sunday and Monday, calls the blend of gospel, soul, blues, country, Mexican, Hawaiian, Bahamian and rock-and-roll music he plays ''we're-all-in-the-same-boat music.'' Sitting in a commandeered office at Warner Bros. Records, which he has recorded for since 1970, the 33-year-old guitarist and singer explained:

title: Greenthal Tenants To Get Rent Refunds
description: Charles H. Greenthal & Company has agreed to refund to tenants at least $190,000 in illegal rents and possibly as much as $950,000, according to Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General.

title: THEATER: JANE LAPOTAIRE SCORES IN 'PIAF'
description: JANE LAPOTAIRE, the star of ''Piaf,'' doesn't look exactly like the legendary French singer and certainly doesn't sound like her. But I don't think anyone is going to mind too much. In Pam Gems's play, which arrived at the Plymouth by way of London last night, Miss Lapotaire does just what great actresses are supposed to do. With utter directness, not artifice, she creates the illusion of a full and complex life. Miss Lapotaire's performance burns with such heartstopping intensity that one never questions her right to stand in for the ''little sparrow,'' who died at age 47 in 1963; one embraces her instantly and totally. While it is far more difficult to embrace Mrs. Gems's rather frail play, I guess we can't have everything. Let's be thankful for Miss Lapotaire.

title: THEATER ENJOYS BIGGEST BOOM IN YEARS
description: Despite sharply higher ticket prices and the national recession, the Broadway theater is enjoying its biggest boom in many years. Attendance, which showed no growth in the previous two seasons, is up 24 percent so far this season - almost double what it was seven years ago - and gross receipts are up 39 percent.

title: PHILHARMONIC: BERNSTEIN LEADS IN AN ALL-AMERICAN PROGRAM
description: NO one conducts American music better than Leonard Bernstein. He has its inflections, its rhythms and its spirit in his blood and he knows how to put the whole package across. Last night the New York Philharmonic's Laureate Conductor led the orchestra in a full evening of the native product: three established classics and a New York premiere.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Dan G raham, catcher; Bob Bonner, shortstop; M ike Boddicker and Tom Row, pitchers; F loyd Rayford, third baseman, and Drungo H azewood, outfielder, to one-year con- t racts. CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Bobby Molina- r o, outfielder; Fran Mullins, infielder, and R ick Seilheimer, catcher, to one-year con- t racts. CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Time Black- w ell, catcher, and Dennis Lamp, pitcher. HOUSTON (NL) - Signed Joe Sambito, p itcher, to five-year, $3 million contract. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Signed Bob W elch and Steve Howe, pitchers, to two- y ear contracts and Robert Castillo, pitcher, t o one-year pact. Sold contract of Gary T homasson, outfielder, to Tokyo of Japan's C entral League. METS (NL) - Asked waivers on Elliott M addox, infielder-outfielder, for purpose of g iving him unconditional release. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed Paul Moli- t or, second baseman, to one-year contract. MONTREAL (NL) - Signed Andre Daw- s on, center fielder, to five-year contract e stimated at $4 million. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed Victor C ruz and Dale Mohoric, pitchers, and Jose R odriguez, outfielder, to one-year con- t racts. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Signed Gene Rich- a rds, outfielder, to three-year contract e stimated at $1.1 million and Jerry Mumphrey, o utfielder, to one-year contract estimated at $ 200,000. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Mike Barlow, R afael Santana and Phil Huffman, pitchers, a nd Garth Iorg, infielder-outfielder, to one- y ear contracts.

title: SOVIET IS MOCKING REAGAN ON MORALITY
description: The Soviet press continued its assault today on President Reagan, his foreign policies and his associates. In an unusually sarcastic commentary, the Communist party newspaper Pravda said the new President was suffering from ''the childhood ailments of power.'' It seized on Mr. Reagan's comments about the differences between Soviet and American morality and mockingly redefined the distinctions.

title: European paintings.
description: THE auction market for 19th-century European paintings has in recent seasons attracted an ever-larger audience of bidders and substantially higher prices. Whether this enthusiasm will continue will be seen next week when New York's two top art auction houses offer sales of several hundred paintings, including works from the Barbizon School, the Belle Epoque period and paintings of Oriental subjects.

title: GAS PRICE DECONTROL IS HINTED
description: Administration officials are considering a plan to seek early removal of price controls on natural gas, a move that could lead to higher costs for consumers.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan's Cuts Stir Skepticism
description: RONALD REAGAN has begun to use the Presidency as what he calls a ''bully pulpit,'' quoting Theodore Roosevelt. But Mr. Reagan faces a congregation full of skeptics and agnostics about his ability to stop inflation, cut Government spending, balance the budget and revitalize the economy.

title: Grumman Net Up 43.7% in Quarter
description: The Grumman Corporation, one of the country's leading producers of military and commercial aircraft, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter increased 43.7 percent, to $10.2 million, or 78 cents a share, from $7.1 million, or 66 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979. Sales rose 16.1 percent, to $497.3 million, from $428.3 million.

title: DESPAIR AND RISING HOPE ARE MINGLED IN BED-STUY
description: Warming his gnarled hands over the dancing flames of a trash-can fire on Fulton Street in Brooklyn, Timothy Smiley spoke sadly about his community.

title: DRESSES THAT ARE OLD LACE
description: Pat Kerr Tigrett is a collector. She collects Edwardian christening dresses, 18th-century court costumes, Victorian paraphernalia. But mostly she collects lace. Someday she hopes to open a lace museum, but meanwhile she enjoys it by wearing it. She will mix pieces of 17th-century Milanese lace with 18th-century Duchesse lace in dresses that are classic in structure but luxurious by virtue of their material.

title: GUERRILLAS IN EL SALVADOR DYNAMITE POWER STATION
description: Leftist guerrillas dynamited a key power station today blacking out the nation's third largest city, armed forces spokesmen said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Applied Magnetics Corportion shareholders approved a plan to sell all the company's assets, including its magnetic head and key electrosonic divisions, and the subsidiary Geo Corporation as continuing concerns.

title: No Headline
description: IRANIAN RIGHTISTS BREAK UP RALLY BY DEFIANT LEFT

title: 'APACHE' FILM'S DEBUT PROTESTED
description: Nearly 75 chanting and placard-waving demonstrators began a rally to protest the opening of the film ''Fort Apache, the Bronx'' at the Gemini Theater at Second Avenue and East 64th Street yesterday at noon. They said the movie showed stereotyped portrayals of blacks and Puerto Ricans.

title: TIGHTEN FOOD STAMPS, BUT DON'T DEPRIVE THE NEEDY
description: In its effort to balance the Federal budget, the Administration is looking hard at the food-stamp program. David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, is considering a 20 percent cut, and the new chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, Jesse Helms, thinks a 40 percent slash is possible.

title: Books of The Times
description: Crimes Against Fiction By ANATOLE BROYARD SAVANNAH BLUE. By William Harrison. 287 pps. Richard Marek. $12.95. DEATH AND THE GOOD LIFE. By Rich- ard Hugo. 215 pps. St. Martin's Press. $10.95.

title: COGHLAN TAKES MILE IN 3:53
description: Don Paige and Suleiman Nyambui set world indoor records, and Eammon Coghlan ran the fastest mile in Madison Square Garden history last night in the Wanamaker Millrose Games.

title: SOME GOLDEN AGERS HAVE FLING AT CASINO
