description: As the Golden Agers of Saint Adalbert's Roman Catholic Church rolled down the Garden State Parkway in New Jersey in their chartered tour bus, they became part of a caravan.

title: High Jordanian Diplomat Is Kidnapped in Beirut
description: The chief Jordanian diplomat here was kidnapped today. About 20 men surrounded the residence of the Jordanian charge d'affaires, Hisham Moheisen, just before dawn, security officials said, and fired automatic weapons, killing a Jordanian guard and a passer-by.

title: U.S. Delegate Assails Arabs At U.N. Meeting in Geneva
description: The American representative at the United Nations Human Rights Commission, discussing the Israe@li-occupied territories, criticized the Arab delegates today for what he said was their outpouring of ''so much hatred, so many lies, such squalid racism, such despicable anti-Semitism.''

title: Toxic Chemical Laws Signed
description: Mayor William J. Green signed two bills into law yesterday requiring industries to disclose the names of toxic chemicals that they use, make, store or emit in the city. The laws require that the information be available to the general public, not just industry employees.

title: Nancy Reagan Is Honored By Wolf Trap Foundation
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - Nancy Reagan has accepted the honorary chairmanship of the board of directors of the Wolf Trap Foundation, it has been announced.

title: No Headline
description: Wells Fargo Loss Called Ordinary Embezzlement

title: SINATRA'S GOOD DEEDS
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTITRUST NOMINEE IS REPORTED
description: William F. Baxter, a Stanford University law professor who says the Justice Department's antimerger guidelines may be too tough, is in line to become the assistant attorney general in charge of the antitrust division, Administration sources reported today.

title: BRITISH COLUMBIA SEEKS CAPITAL
description: The last time William Bennett visited New York City he was a furniture store owner who jogged, went to the theater and dined here with local friends. On his current visit, which ends this morning, Mr. Bennett was not pushing furniture.

title: Boeing Plans $250 Million Issue
description: The Boeing Company said today that it planned to sell $250 million of convertible subordinated debentures, due 2006, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Jean Williams Is Married To John Philip Angier
description: Jean Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Williams of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., was married yesterday to John Philip Angier of Newton, Mass. Edward G. English, City Clerk of Newton, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: Son of U.N. Attache Named in Rape Case
description: The son of a Ghanaian diplomat at the United Nations was detained briefly after being identified as a suspect in a rape case, the police said, but was released after claiming diplomatic immunity.

title: 'THE CAR BOOK' SHOULD GO BACK TO THE SHOP
description: To the Editor:

title: GUARDING THE SKIN AGAINST WINTER
description: A PRIL may have been the cruelest month on T. S. Eliot's calendar, but those who are shivering at cold bus stops are more likely to give the title to any one of the three that make up winter.

title: THE PEPPER ROUTINE CAN ANNOY A DINER
description: 18 By MIMI SHERATON

title: AN AMERICAN HURDLE TO NUCLEAR PROGRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK CITY JOBLESS RATE ROSE TO 8.8% LAST MONTH
description: New York City's unemployment rate rose 1.1 percentage points last month, but Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said that, over all, the city's economy ''turned in a strong performance'' last year.

title: 2 Get Prison Terms In $10 Million Fraud
description: A couple convicted in December in a swindle that involved more than $10 million were sentenced in State Supreme Court to serve between four and two-thirds and 14 years in prison.

title:
Patents;
Organism Producing Antibiotics
description: WASHINGTON A PATENT issued this week is the first granted for a microorganism since the Supreme Court decided last June that forms of life created in the laboratory are patentable.

title: COMMANDED JEWISH WAR VETERANS
description: Benjamin Kaufman, the executive director of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States from 1945 to 1959 and a former national commander of the organization, died Thursday at the Mercer Medical Center in Trenton. He was 86 years old and lived in Trenton.

title: Index; International
description: Radical Filipino nuns live in the slum where they work 2 Hua appears on Chinese televi- sion, creating a puzzle 3 Around the World 5 Spanish church denounces divorce bill as governing party meets 22 Government/Politics Lawyers' assessment: Cameras in court are quickly forgotten 6 Congressional action required on Reagan plan to cut spending 7 General Around the Nation 6 Bar association to weigh rights of prisoners 6 A group of senior citizens chal- lenges the nickel slots 23 The Region 24 The City 25 Contrasts in Bedford-Stuyvesant 25 Education/Welfare New York City's home relief rolls at five-year low 254 Arts/Entertainment Group demonstrates to protest opening of ''Fort Apache'' 9 Elizabeth Taylor, in rehearsal, talks of Broadway debut 9 U.S. budget cuts are proposed for arts and humanities 9 Two novels of crime and suspense are reviewed 31 Style Consumer Saturday: Guarding the skin against winter 26 Liability insurance: Beyond basic coverage 26 Dresses that are classic and old lace 26 De Gustibus: the pepper routine 26 Dresses that are classic and old lace 26 De Gustibus: the pepper routine 26 Sports Coghlan takes mile in 3:53; Paige sets record in 1,000-meter run 27 Garden card dropped; new site sought for Cooney-Norton 27 Geoffrion uses hockey skills to coach indoor soccer players 27 Knicks rout Bulls, 112-94, to end Chi- cago winning streak 29 2 share lead at 136 in Coast golf 29 Kuhn won't suspend Jenkins, but issues drug warning 29 George Vecsey on the legend of Wilt Chamberlain 30 Obituaries Frederika, the exiled Queen Mother of Greece 32 Mary Parkman Peabody, civil rights activist 32 Features/Notes Going Out Guide 11 About New York 23 Notes on People 30 Saturday News Quiz 31 News Analysis Drew Middleton assesses outlook for early Iranian counterattack 4 Leonard Silk analyzes Reagan's economics ''lesson'' 33 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 20

title: SENATE VOTES RAISE IN U.S. DEBT CEILING
description: The Senate gave final approval today to a $50 billion increase in the debt limit. Republicans reluctantly provided the margin of victory in the 73 to 18 vote as Democrats gloated.

title: Jenkins, Kuhn Reach Accord in Drug Case
description: Ferguson Jenkins of the Texas Rangers, who was convicted in Canada last December of narcotics possession, promised yesterday to donate $10,000 to a drug-education program for young people as part of an agreement with the commissioner of baseball.

title: Birthday Marked for 'a Four-Letter Dirty Word'
description: The birthday that got all the attention yesterday was President Reagan's 70th, but in New Jersey a few diehard admirers of an earlier political figure marked the 225th birthday of Aaron Burr.

title: STATE PREPARES FAREWELL FOR MRS. GRASSO
description: Handwritten notices canceling committee meetings and news conferences were taped to doors in an unusually quiet State Capitol today.

title: Barsac Gets Seatrain Unit
description: Barsac N.V., a private investment group, said yesterday that it had closed a contract to acquire Seatrain Gulf Services Ltd., a unit of Seatrain Lines Inc., for $3.6 million in cash. Seatrain Gulf Services is engaged in logistics and transportation management in the Middle East. Seatrain Lines, citing a loss of about $1 million on the sale, said the proceeds would be used to finance its tanker business.

title: Robert E. Sessions, 72, Founded Management Counsel Business
description: Robert Evans Sessions, a management consultant, has died of a stroke at South Highlands Hospital, Birmingham, Ala. He was 72 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Dr. Reagan Approaching Surgery
description: A funny thing seems to have happened in the preparation of President Reagan's televised summons to economic sacrifice Thursday night. The inflation crisis was graphically proclaimed, in a blizzard of statistics and with a rumpled dollar bill and three coins to denote ''the worst economic mess since the Great Depression.'' The promise of lower taxes was reiterated at emphatic length. But the pain and sacrifice of the coming budget surgery were never really described.

title: Sports of The Times; Legend of Wilt Chamberlain Flies High
description: THE plane was soaring 37,000 feet above America, somewhere between lunch and the movie, when Bill Cartwright of the New York Knickerbockers decided to take a stroll.

title: Economic Analysis
description: In his television address on the economy Thursday night, President Reagan declared that the United States was in ''the worst economic mess since the Great Depression'' and warned that ''we are threatened with an economic calamity of tremendous proportions,'' a theme that echoed the ''economic Dunkirk'' paper of his budget director, David A. Stockman. Although Mr. Reagan insisted he did not want to subject his audience to a ''jumble of charts, figures and economic jargon,'' he set out to explain ''where we are, how we got there and how we can get back'' - in effect, laying out an economic primer that might lead the American public to understand and support his effort to ''turn things around.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in The Times yesterday misidentified Donna Long, who left court with Pfc. Robert R. Garwood, the marine found guilty of aiding the enemy in Vietnam. She lives with him.

title: 'EACH EXECUCTION DOUBLES THE KILLING'
description: To the Editor:

title: EDWARD LAFARGE, 79, PROFESSOR OF ART AT A SCHOOL IN RHODE ISLAND
description: Edward Hooper LaFarge, a professor of art at the Rhode Island School of Design for 30 years, died Jan. 28 at the Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The inmates have taken over the asylum. The Democrats, who have been telling us that it's all right to raise the national debt, are going to vote against it.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RULING THE ROOSTER

title: THE CHIEF IS HAILED 26,554,983.7 TIMES
description: No sooner did Ronald Reagan take the oath of office than the Marine Band burst into the traditional Presidential anthem, ''Hail to the Chief,'' and from that moment on no single step of Mr. Reagan's comings and goings throughout his Presidency would go unheralded by this musically inane fanfare.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Signed Dale Murphy, o utfielder. CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Harold Baines, o utfielder.

title: EUROPEANS WARN JAPAN ON EXPORTS
description: The French and West German Governments agreed today that Japan must curb its exports to Europe and increase its imports from the Common Market countries.

title: Geoffrion Finds Role in a New Sport
description: Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion has found a new sport to help occupy part of his time. Geoffrion, a Hall of Fame forward who scored 393 goals in 16 seasons and later coached three teams in the National Hockey League, is the technical adviser of the Atlanta Chiefs during the indoor season of the North American Soccer League. He also does commentary on the team's television broadcasts.

title: Peace for Mrs. Grasso
description: Only in November did the severity of Ella Grasso's illness become evident. Always tenacious, she was eager to serve a full half of her second term as Connecticut's Governor, until Dec. 31.

title: SOME COSTLY HELP IS VERY POPULAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Hostage Says Some Preferred to be Killed
description: Some of the Americans held captive in Iran for 444 days became so depressed they wanted to be shot, one of the released hostages said yesterday.

title: MARY PEABODY, 89, RIGHTS ACTIVIST, DIES
description: Mary Parkman Peabody, the mother of former Gov. Endicott Peabody of Massachusetts and a prominent civil-rights and antiwar activist of the 1960's, died of heart failure yesterday at Cambridge Hospital in Cambridge, Mass., where she resided. She was 89 years old.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: WANTED: Candidate with charisma, cash and cavalier attitude toward popularity polls to run for Mayor of large, troubled city against entrenched incumbent. Field wide open. Must be believer in things like ''long odds'' and ''upset victory.'' Resume should have detailed reply to question ''How'm I doing?'' Quixotic touch can't hurt. Whether employment temporary or permanent determined in November.

title: 50% CUT IN U.S. ARTS AID DRAFTED BY BUDGET HEAD
description: The Office of Management and Budget has proposed cuts of up to 50 percent for the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Humanities, and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 19.50 19.50 15.25 DISCOUNT RATE* 13.00 13.00 12.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 16.94 16.80 13.33 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 15.10 14.74 12.08 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 13.95 13.85 12.12 TREASURY NOTES 13.14 13.00 11.86 TREASURY BONDS 12.62 12.54 11.56 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 13.70 13.59 12.72 MUNICIPAL BONDS 10.80 10.80 8.20 6-MONTH SAVINGS 13.985 CERTIFICATES * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: IN EAST ROOM: LIGHTS, CAMERA, BIRTHDAY CAKE
description: Ronald Reagan made his debut in ''The President's Surprise Party'' tonight, and he played his leading man's role to perfection.

title: Poland's Ticking Clock
description: Another round of strikes in Poland may now really be ended. The holdouts in the southern industrial city of Bielsko-Biala won some further local political concessions mainly because Solidarity, the national union, feared division in its own ranks even more than it fears provoking the Russians. But the latest settlement settles nothing. It is only a matter of time before the next round begins.

title: WITNESS REFUSES MORE TESTIMONY ON TOXIC WASTE
description: A convicted toxic-waste dumper, claiming immunity as a Congressional and New York State ''legislative aide,'' has been seeking protection from New Jersey officials who he says are trying to ''suppress'' his revelations of corruption.

title: DROP IN USE OF OIL RAISES EXPECTATIONS OF GLUT BY SUMMER
description: A new glut in world oil supplies may be developing, officials of Western governments and international oil companies say, and by summer more oil may be available to consumers than they require. Moreover, the growing supplies are putting pressure on some OPEC producers to cut back the surcharges they have added to their official oil prices.

title: Warner Named In Harcourt Suit
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. sued Warner Communications, alleging that Warner filed a false and misleading statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in explaining its recent purchase of 8.6 percent of Harcourt's outstanding shares.

title: Black Caucus Elects Rep. Gray
description: Representative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat of Pennsylvania, has been elected vice chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus. Mr. Gray, a 39-year-old second-term House member, will hold one of four executive positions in the caucus. He served as secretary of the organization in the 96th Congress.

title: CHURCH ASSAILS DIVORCE BILL AS SPAIN'S KEY PARTY MEETS
description: On the eve of an important congress of the governing party, the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy has once again denounced a draft bill that would permit divorce by mutual consent in Spain.

title: The 'Bradford Cup'
description: As the great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-grandson of William Bradford, Governor of Plymouth Colony in Massachusetts, Bernard Weist had a lot of old family bric-a-brac lying about his New Orleans home.

title: CONGRESS TO HAVE KEY ROLE IN EFFORT TO CURB SPENDING nation
description: The Reagan Administration's plan to hold down growth in Federal spending would require action by Congress on hundreds of separate, often unrelated issues.

title: Revco-U.S. Accord
description: The Justice Department announced a proposed antitrust settlement today that would allow Revco D.S. Inc., the nation's largest drugstore chain, to purchase the 144-unit Skillern Drug division of the Zale Corporation, the largest drugstore chain in Texas. As part of the settlement, Revco agreed to sell off between 28 and 31 of its own drugstores in Texas by Jan. 31, 1982. The Government had alleged in a suit that Revco's proposed acquisition of Skillern would violate antitrust law by lessening prescription drug competition in three Texas metropolitan areas.

title: PRESIDENT IS PRAISED FOR ECONOMIC TALK
description: Many Congressmen today praised President Reagan as a masterful communicator after his economic speech to the nation, but a counterattack against his proposals for sweeping cuts in Federal spending is already gathering force on Capitol Hill.

title: The Economy
description: The U.S. unemployment rate was unchanged at 7.4 percent last month, indicating that the economy was stronger than expected. The number of employed workers rose by 414,000, while unemployment rose by 62,000. (Page 1.) In New York City, the unemployment rate rose to 8.8 percent in January from 7.7 percent. (8.)

title: U.S. Advises Embassies On Neutron Bomb Issue
description: The State Department has sent instructions to United States embassy officials in Western Europe on how to respond to criticism stemming from reports of comments by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger on the possible deployment of neutron warheads.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $2.6 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a $2.6 billion decline in the nation's basic money supply. The drop was a mild suprise to analysts, who said that the slower money supply growth of recent weeks indicated that the high interest rates of the last few months have been effective.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: ''The Car Book'' and your editorial report that the cost of a new alternator for a BMW 320i is $422 while the actual suggested retail price is $372.18. Even with labor factored in, the total replacement cost is less than reported in the book.

title: Blue Cross Agrees To Aid Chrysler
description: Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Michigan said it had agreed to take a $17.5 million loss in an effort to help the Chrysler Corporation obtain its Federal loan guarantees.

title: GISCARD AND SCHMIDT AFFIRM U.S. LINKS
description: The leaders of France and West Germany issued a statement today declaring their readiness to cooperate with the Reagan Administration in a spirit of trust to meet the dangers of a deteriorating international climate.

title: Oregon State Wins, 69-54
description: Steve Johnson keyed a surge to start the second half and Ray Blume kept the pressure on with 18 secondhalf points as unbeaten Oregon State rolled to a 69-54 victory over California tonight.

title: ELIZABETH TAYLOR: TAKING NEW GAMBLE
description: For the first time in Elizabeth Taylor's career, there will be no one on the set to shout ''cut!'' There will be no way to stop the action and start over again if something goes wrong - a security blanket always present at the shooting of her more than 50 films. Instead, Miss Taylor is going to be left entirely to her own devices the night of May 7, when she makes her Broadway debut as Regina Giddens, the greedy, heartless heroine of Lillian Hellman's melodrama ''The Little Foxes.''

title: Armed Guards Ride Buses On Coast to Protect Drivers
description: Two more Bay Area transit drivers were attacked today, one day after a bus driver was shot to death. Mayor Dianne M. Feinstein ordered armed undercover policemen to be posted on buses as angry drivers threatened to shut down public transit unless they got more protection.

title: Barry Rosen Signs Contract With a Literary Agent
description: One of the former hostages in Iran, Barry Rosen of Brooklyn, and his wife, Barbara, yesterday signed a contract with the literary agent Julian Bach to represent them in the sale of a book and a series of articles.

title: PRESIDENTIAL HONORIFICS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Share Golf Lead At 136
description: Cesar Sanudo, who grew up in San Diego and has struggled on the PGA Tour, scored 69 today and was tied with Ray Floyd for the lead after the second round of the San Diego open.

title: Tracy Austin Withdraws With Damaged Hip Nerve
description: Tracy Austin, the top-seeded player in the $150,000 Avon Tennis Championships tournament opening Monday, has withdrawn with a damaged nerve in her hip, an injury that could hamper her play for some time to come.

title: HARRIS ATTORNEYS REST THEIR CASE IN MURDER TRIAL
description: The defense rested today in the Jean S. Harris murder trial, with the final witnesses, two psychiatrists, suggesting that Mrs. Harris was exhibiting drug-withdrawal symptoms at the time she drove to Purchase, N.Y., and shot Dr. Herman Tarnower. On Monday, the prosecution will begin its rebuttal.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1981
description: International Fighting broke out in Teheran between Iranian leftists, who were holding a demonstration that had been banned by the Government, and Islamic right-wing extremists. Thirty-nine persons were reportedly treated for bullet or stab wounds. About 5,000 members of a faction of the Marxist-Leninist Fedayeen movement and the leftist Peykar group had gathered to protest the deterioration of Iran's economy. (Page 1, Column 5.) Poland's printers threaten to strike if the Government censorship of the press is not relaxed by Tuesday. They are members of the independent labor union and are concerned over an apparent return to heavy censorship. They will call a strike Friday if the Government does not relax its rules. (1:3-5.)

title: MARYLAND SETTLES JOB BIAS SUIT
description: Maryland has agreed to pay at least $205.000 to women allegedly denied employment by the Baltimore police because of discriminatory height and weight requirements, a state official said yesterday. Assistant State Attorney General Stephen B. Caplis said the $205,000 was a partial payment resulting from the 1973 suit. The money is meant to cover part of the difference between what each woman would have earned if she had been hired by the police and what she made after the rejection.

title: CONCERT: ROBERT BLACK'S NEW MUSIC ENSEMBLE
description: In a city full of honorable, industrious new-music groups, Robert Black's New York New Music Ensemble has become one of the most indispensable - as two recent Carnegie Recital Hall concerts have affirmed. Thursday night, the group presented a program of music by Luigi Dallapiccola and Donald Martino, as part of the League-ISCM Concert series. And Jan. 27, there was a concert of its own, with particularly notable New York premieres by two University of Chicago faculty members, Shulamit Ran and Ralph Shapey.

title: Radioactive Jewelry In Western New York
description: ALBANY (AP) - Forty-eight pieces of gold jewelry have been identified as radioactive in a statewide testing program, the state's Health Department said.

title: French Oil Imports Dip
description: French net imports of oil fell 7.85 percent last year, to 803 million barrels, or about 2.2 million barrels a day, customs officials reported today.

title: Istanbul Security Official Is Slain by Terrorists
description: A deputy security chief of Istanbul and an aide were shot to death by terrorists near that city tonight, sources close to the city's security services said.

title: Brown Political Unit Pays State
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s campaign committee says it has paid the state nearly $4,000 that was spent in putting together a computerized correspondence list. Mr. Brown has denied published reports that the names were those of political supporters but said his group would repay the money anyway. The disclosure appeared in campaign finance reports submitted Tuesday to the Secretary of State's office. The campaign committee, Californians for Effective Government, recorded $157,089 in contributions from Oct. 21 to Dec. 31, 1980.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 32. 1. A devastating freeze in the vineyards pictured above, threatens to wipe out most of the 1981 grape crop in (California/France/Italy/New York/Spain).

title: CANADA GARUNTEES FUNDS FOR MASSEY
description: The federal and Ontario governments announced plans today to guarantee $168 million (American) of new equity for the nearly bankrupt Massey-Ferguson Corporation.

title: NEW YORK CITY'S HOME RELIF ROLLS AT A 5-YEAR LOW
description: The number of people on home relief in New York City has dropped to a five-year low, Mayor Koch said yesterday. He attributed the reduction to efforts by the city's Human Resources Administration and its Department of Employment to find jobs or provide job training for the hard-core unemployed.

title: NEW YORK CITY MAY DIG A WELL AT SHEA STADIUM TO WATER FIELD
description: Because of the drought emergency, the city is looking into the possibility of digging a well under Shea Stadium to supply the New York Mets with water to keep their ball park green.

title: Pistons Allow McAdoo To Confer With Nets
description: Bob McAdoo, who has played in only six games this season for Detroit because of injuries, has been granted permission to talk with the New Jersey Nets about terms for signing with the club, Pistons' General Manager Jack McCloskey said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline in Business Day on Thurs- day incorrectly identified the company in the accompanying story. It was the International Harvester Company.

title: SUN COMPANY PLANS TO BUY BACK STOCK
description: The Sun Company said it will buy back up to 2 million shares of its common stock on the open market by year-end.

title: New Bond Issues FRIDAY, FEB. 6, 1981 UTILITY BONDS Moo dy's urrent IssuesRat ing d&Asked Chng Yield So Wst Bell Tl 14 1/4s20 Aaa -98 1/4 1/4 14.50 Sthrn Bell Tel 12 7/8s20 Aaa 3/4-92 1/2 13.99 Sthrn Calif Ed 13 1/2s10 Aa -92 5/8 ...  14.58; CORPORATE BONDS Honeywell 14 1/8s11 A -98 1/2 1 14.34 Conoco 13 1/4s11 Aa -96 1/8 1/2 13.79 Cities Serv 13 7/8s11 A -97 1/2 1/2 14.23; INTERMEDIATE NOTES GMAC Vrn 13.45s90 Aaa -96 1/4 ...  *15.95 Tenneco 13 3/8s91 A -98 3/8 1/8 13.67; INTERNATIONAL ISSUES
description: * Yield to fix Source: First Boston Corp.

title: LIABILITY INSURANCE: BEYOND BASIC COVERAGE
description: Nowadays, when liability claims can be substantial, even bankrupting, consumers have a greater need to understand what they are buying.

title: SOME ECONOMISTS DISPUTE PREMISES OF PRESIDENT'S SPEECH ON ECONOMY
description: About 500 of President Reagan's political supporters met here today in private sessions to plan a grass-roots campaign to put public pressure on Congress to approve Mr. Reagan's economic program.

title: Hearing Set in Offer To Acquire Hobart
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee scheduled a Feb. 16 hearing into the proposed acquisition of the Hobart Corporation by a subsidiary of Canadian Pacific Ltd., a diversified Montreal-based holding company.

title: Musical Score
description: The first United States performance of Dmitri Shostakovich's 13th Symphony, by the Philadelphia Orchestra 11 years ago, was made possible only because Mstislav Rostropovich, the Russian cellist and conductor, personally smuggled the symphony score out of the Soviet Union.

title: Koch Is 'Furious' At Bench Criticism
description: Mayor Koch said he was ''furious'' with the state administrative judge and his city deputy for objecting to Mr. Koch's statement Tuesday that some judges were ''abusing'' the latitude they had in sentencing defendants under New York's new gun control law.

title: SAGA THRIVES ON SERVING FOOD
description: Back in 1948, Hunk Anderson, Bill Laughlin and Bill Scandling were seniors at Hobart College in Geneva, N.Y., getting their education under the G.I. Bill. Keen to supplement their pocket money, they hatched the idea of selling lecture notes to fellow students. That caught on, and so they dabbled at peddling advertising space on desk blotters to local shopkeepers.

title: New York School Stars Will Face Philadelphia's
description: The best high school players from Philadelphia and New York City will be matched against each other in a ''Big City Basketball Classic'' here Saturday, March 21.

title: PAISLEY AND 500 PROTESTANTS STAGE ULSTER SHOW OF FORCE
description: The Rev. Ian Paisley, making a dramatic show of Protestant force, secretly gathered 500 men into a military formation on a bleak hillside in Northern Ireland late last night and vowed that they were prepared to fight ''to the death'' against reunification with the Irish Republic.

title: THE LOGIC AND WORTH OF FARE-FREE TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Connors Defeats Borg
description: Jimmy Connors, ending a losing streak that had lasted since late in 1978, defeated Bjorn Borg, 7-5, 6-3, in the third round of the $500,000 Tennis Challenge tonight.

title: Your Money; Saving Charges On Credit Cards
description: THE credit-card war in the New York area has been heating up as three banks have decided to buck the general trend and not charge an annual fee on their MasterCard and Visa credit cards. This has enhanced the consumer's ability to shop for credit-card bargains. Giving up one card for another has no effect on an individual's credit rating, bankers say.

title: IN MADRID HOSPITAL AS AN EXILE
description: Frederika, Queen Mother of Greece, who has been living in selfimposed exile since the ouster of King Constantine in 1973, died last night while on a visit to her daughter, Queen Sofia of Spain. The Queen Mother was 63 years old.

title: BAR GROUP TO WEIGH PRISONERS' RIGHTS AND LEGAL DEATH
description: Proposed guidelines defining the legal rights of prisoners and a proposed ''determination of death'' law will be considered here next week at the American Bar Association's winter convention.

title: 'RADICAL' NUNS SHARE PVOERTY OF MANILA SLUM
description: ''It's a little protection against rape,'' said Sister Christine Tan, indicating her habit and veil, as she and another nun walked through the teeming, ugly slum, one of the many that make up much of Manila, where she and five other nuns have chosen to live.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS AND TAX CREDITS
description: Much of the opposition to tuition tax credits for parents of private-school students contains three serious flaws. It rests on misinformed notions about private schools; it overlooks the critical reasons why more and more parents are turning to private schools; and it obscures a more serious issue, the deterioration of public education.

title: More Refiners Raise Wholesale Prices
description: Several large refiners, including the Gulf Oil Corporation, Conoco Inc. and the Cities Service Company, raised wholesale prices of gasoline and home heating oil yesterday by between 2 and 3.5 cents a gallon.

title: AFTER 5 YEARS, JUDGES AND LAWYERS SEE COURTS ADJUSTING TO THE CAMERA'S EYE
description: Five years after reporters' cameras and tape-recorders began appearing in courtrooms throughout the country, lawyers are still debating whether their presence affects the legal process. But there appears to be a growing consensus among judges and prosecutors that the legal process is not affected.

title: EMPLOYMENT RATES SHOW U.S. ECONOMY RETAINING STRENGTH
description: The economy remained surprisingly strong last month despite continued very high interest rates, according to data released today in the Labor Department's monthly employment survey.

title: WHEN INFLATION WAS 1% AND DROPPING
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET CRACKDOWN ON JEWISH
description: STUDIES To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: PLEASE USE********; State Dept. Comments on Report On Arming of Salvadoran Rebels

title: Military Analysis
description: The war between Iraq and Iran has slowly been gathering momentum as signs multiply that Iran is preparing a major offensive for the spring.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 31. 1. President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea. 2. 36. 3. He was charged with engaging in illegal restraint of interstate commerce involving his distributors and competitors. 4. New York. 5. Yoko Ono, the vocalist, and John Lennon, the backup guitarist. recorded the song before his murder in December. 6. The Wells Fargo National Bank has charged that it has been defrauded of $21.3 million by a group of sports promoters and companies that used the name of Muhammad Ali, the former heavyweight boxing champion. The charges have endangered a major fight card set for Madison Square Garden on Feb. 23.

title: Suit in Florida Challenges U.S. Release of Refugees
description: Attorney General Jim Smith of Florida filed suit in Federal District Court here today contending that the Immigration and Naturalization Service did not follow its own policies when it classified refugees from Cuba and Haiti as ''entrants pending status'' and then released them into the community.

title: Indian Pt. Shutdown Could Last 2 Months
description: The Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant at Buchanan, N.Y., could be out of service for up to two months, a spokesman for the State Power Authority said.

title: Bridge: Use of 'Crash' Convention Aids Some 2-Suited Hands
description: One of the more exotic conventions met with in modern tournament play is called ''Crash.'' It is a conventional defense to a strong artificial club opening, and the overcalling side designates three calls that will show certain two-suited hands: the same color, the same rank or the same shape - which may mean clubs and hearts or spades and diamonds.

title: GAIN 4TH IN ROW
description: Stock prices rose in moderate trading yesterday, reflecting a favorable response to President Reagan's economic message Thursday night.

title: Headmasters Approve Admission of Women
description: The Headmasters Association, breaking 88 years of tradition, voted yesterday to change its bylaws to permit the entrance of women. The association, which consists of headmasters of some of the country's most exclusive preparatory schools, decided the measure at the close of its three-day annual conference in Princeton, N.J.

title: Court Is Asked to Reinstate Two Abscam Convictions
description: The Justice Department asked a Federal appeals court today to reinstate the convictions of two former City Council leaders, asserting that the two had accepted bribes in the Abscam case ''without hesitation.''

title: WARSAW PRINTERS' UNION IS A THORN IN CENSOR'S SIDE
description: The Communist authorities here are coming to realize an uncomfortable fact: control of the press may be exerted through censors, compliant editors and fainthearted journalists, but there are others who have a hand in the final product and they get the last crack at it - the printers.

title: News Union Plans Health Study
description: The Newspaper Guild has announced a wide-ranging study of the health effects of operating video display terminals commonly used by reporters and editors in newspapers. The guild president, Charles Perlik Jr., said yesterday that the study, in conjunction with Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York City, would involve about 2,000 workers, both VDT-users and nonusers. He said that four to six guild locals in the United States and Canada would participate.

title: THE WORLD BELOW
description: You have all probably asked yourselves at one time or another, ''What makes a great subway rider?'' With us today to answer that question is one of the 10 greatest subway riders in New York. Would you tell us your name, sir?

title: CENSORSHIP OF CODE WORK BACKED
description: A committee consisting of university representatives, private researchers and National Security Agency officials agreed today to the elements of a plan for voluntary censorship of information about research on codes and code-breaking.

title: Miami Businessman, Cuba-Born, A Contender for Immigration Job
description: A Miami businessman emerged yesterday as a leading candidate for the position of Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: HUA IS BACK IN PUBLIC VIEW BUT REASON UNCLEAR
description: In an unusually long telecast tonight, Chinese television devoted nearly 20 minutes to a dinner last night attended by Hua Guofeng, the Party chairman, who had not been seen in public since Nov. 27.

title: NEW SITE IS SOUGHT FOR COONEY-NORTON
description: To the surprise of no one, the tinseled boxing show scheduled for Feb. 23 at Madison Square Garden has been canceled. Plans for the card, which was to have featured a heavyweight bout between Gerry Cooney and Ken Norton, as well as three championship fights, came to an official end at the Garden yesterday morning when Sam Glass, the president of Tiffany Promotions, told a news conference, ''The Feb. 23 show is off.''

title: Hammer Gives $250,000 To British Arts Academy
description: The British Royal Academy of Fine Arts has announced that it received a $250,000 donation from Armand Hammer, chairman of the Los Angeles-based Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: PERDUE EXPANDS INTO RESTAURANT BUSINESS
description: Frank Perdue, the poultry producer and television pitchman whose chickens are the largest-selling premium brand in the New York area, is expanding beyond the supermarket shelf and into his own restaurant.

title: Nurses Lose Plea On City Contract
description: The Board of Collective Bargaining has affirmed the recommendations of an impasse panel that call for pay increases of 8 percent in each year of a two-year contract for 5,500 nurses at 17 city hospitals, according to Arvid Anderson, chairman of the independent board.

title: Autopsy on Atlanta Victim Rules Death a Strangulation
description: Lubie Geter, the 15th black child found slain in the Atlanta area in the past 18 months, died of strangulation, an autopsy showed today. A civil rights leader, meanwhile, asked Vice President Bush to declare the city eligible for Federal disaster funds.

title: NEARLY 40 YEAR LATER, ANOTHER MARINE
description: At 5:30 A.M. on Dec. 29, my fatherhood took on a new dimension and was tested by loss.

title: U.S. Cautioned on Latin America
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria said today that ''demonstrative support'' for dictatorships in Latin America by the Reagan Administration could have serious effects on relations between the United States and Europe. Speaking at an international management conference, Dr. Kreisky said that American backing for dictatorships could provoke anti-American feelings in Europe worse than those caused by the Vietnam War.

title: INCOME ADJUSTMENTS EASE TAX BURDEN
description: f9838 By DEBORAH RANKIN

title: VETERAN POLITICAL BATTLER MAY BE IN BIGGEST FIGHT
description: Meyer S. Frucher has fought so many political battles for so many other people that somehow, somewhere, he was bound to get into one of his own.

title: 3 Workers Killed in a Blast On Oil Barge in Bayou Area
description: Three persons were killed today when an explosion and fire ripped through an oil storage barge in a remote bayou of Terrebonne Parish. A fourth person was missing, the authorities said.

title: GRAIN TO SOVIET URGED
description: A delegation of farm leaders told President Reagan today that he would lose the support of American farmers who voted for him last fall if he did not soon end the United States curtailment of grain sales to the Soviet Union.

title: No Headline
description: Skalbania Buys a Half Share In The Montreal Alouettes

title: OREGON STATE, UNBEATEN BUT UNNOTICED, COMES EAST
description: CORVALLIS, Ore. THE Oregon State Beavers say they are ready to introduce themselves to the East Coast. When they journey to the unfamiliar territory of Long Island's Nassau Coliseum next Saturday to meet St. John's, they intend to demonstrate to the East and a national television audience just how good they are.

title: Iran Toys With Its Remaining Captives
description: The 52 embassy hostages may be home from Iran, but all the captive Americans are not.

title: PROFITS INSERVICE
description: For one of Wall Street's large oldtimers -Bear, Stearns & Company, a private partnership with more than $100 million in capital - the sprouting newcomers have meant burgeoning new business.

title:
GARDENING;
GOVERNMENT STUDIES AID HOME GARDENER
description: THE years of the Lincoln Presidency were so dominated by the Civil War that many other achievements of that period are often ignored. This is true in the field of agriculture, in which decisions were made that are still contributing toward making our agriculture the most prosperous and our population the best fed of any nation.

title: FUGITIVE-HUBTER: HERO--OR BRAGGART?
description: PATERSON WITH characteristic reserve, Robert J. Challice puts it this way: ''I will do anything, risk anything, pay any price and go anywhere to get done what I have to do.''

title: St. Peter's 66, Manhattan 54
description: William Brown scored a career-high 25 points yesterday to lead St. Peter's to a 66-54 victory over Manhattan College at Manhattan's Draddy Gymnasium.

title: About Westchester
description: MOUNT VERNON THE ambiance mikes are up, and although the radio audience can't see it, the crowd is dancing. From those decked out in full ''punk'' regalia - pink hair, leopard-print T-shirts and an occasional safety pin - to others in chinos and Shetland sweaters, some 300 young people are bouncing up and down to the beat.

title: Dr. Barbara Cohlan Bride of Physician
description: Dr. Barbara Cohlan and Dr. David Perlmutter, senior residents in pediatrics at Children's Hospital in Philadelphia, were married last night at the bridegroom's home in Penn Valley, Pa. Rabbi Michael Monson performed the ceremony.

title: AFTER MISTAKES, ANGOLA TURNS TOWARD 'REALISM'
description: It is a rich country by African standards, but for many of its people, finding food and clothes is a struggle. The Government is resolutely Marxist, but it seeks capitalist investment and management advice. South African planes and helicopters and ground forces have often penetrated its territory, but its leading party theoretician speaks of coexisting peacefully with South Africa.

title: SEVENTY-NINE STORIES TO READ AGAIN
description: THE COLLECTED STORIES OF ELIZABETH BOWEN 784 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Etna Rumbles and Spews Lava
description: Mount Etna, Europe's most active volcano, rumbled this morning and spewed 1.2 miles of lava from a crater on its northeast side, cutting a glowing red swath through the snow.

title: IT'S DECISION TIME FOR BRIDGE IN HAMPTONS
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH BEFORE he can build a bridge, Suffolk Legislator John Rosso will have to mend some political fences. On Tuesday, the Suffolk County Legislature is expected to consider a proposed $6.8 million reconstruction of the West Bay Bridge at Westhampton Beach. Approval of the highly controversial project will largely depend on how much the plan's sponsor, Mr. Rosso, Republican of Mastic, is willing to cooperate with his colleagues. Neither the cooperation nor the approval appears likely.

title: BISHOP PLANS GREATER ROLE FOR L.I. ROMAN CATHOLICS
description: Bishop John R. McGann of the Rockville Centre Diocese on Long Island is planning to give Roman Catholics a greater voice in the operations of the diocese, in line with recommendations contained in a recently completed three-year study of church priorities and resources.

title: Elizabeth Sullivan Sets August Bridal
description: Elizabeth Ann Sullivan of Haverford, Pa., a corporate paralegal with the Philadelphia law firm of Wolf, Block, Schorr & Solis-Cohen, plans to be married in August to Mark William Hansler, who is in his first year at the Villanova University School of Law.

title: Body Freezing
description: Commercial cryonics, the deep freezing of human bodies immediately after death in the hope that science might one day discover a way to restore them to life, came under a cloud in California in May 1980.

title: A LIFETIME OF LISTENING
description: When I became a music critic I had worked at the piano almost since babyhood, had gone through the studies that all musicians go through - harmony, counterpoint, theory, even composition and conducting - but my only real talent, such as it was, was listening. I cannot remember ever not listening to music, wrapped in it, living with it and living it, totally responding to it. Virgil Thomson once had some amused, disparaging words to say about musical addicts. I happen to be an addict.

title: Crime
description: Leaving the vein of fantasy that characterized ''Liars and Tyrants and People Who Turn Blue,'' Barbara Paul has now, in FIRST GRAVEDIGGER (Doubleday, $8.95), tried to paint the picture of a complete heel. He is an antiques agent working for a respected Pittsburgh firm, and suddenly his boss makes it clear that he is no longer welcome. Miss Paul has dreamed up a novel idea for the modus operandi of a murder. The agent talks a sorry, suicidal friend into doing it for him and then committing suicide. What are friends for?

title: Connecticut Housing; CONDOMINIUM DECAY RAISES OWNER'S COST
description: THE roofs are leaking, decks are rotting away, paint is peeling from window frames. Cars bounce and skid on driveways that are cracked and collapsing after years of neglect.

title: Safe Box Mystery
description: The puzzling theft of $2 million in valuables from a safe-deposit box in Armonk, N.Y., was reported last Octo-ber.

title: ALARM ON DEBT SERVICING
description: For the second time since 1973, worries about the ability of lessdeveloped countries to service increasingly large amounts of debt, much of it owed to commercial banks, are surfacing.

title: A VALENTINE SELECTION OF BON MOTS
description: LAST St. Valentine's Day, instead of fattening my body with chocolates from a heart-shaped box, I decided to enrich my mind with heart-sprinkled poetry. I discovered a feast of allusions to that anatomical pump, deliciously confusing and paradoxical, more than enough to sate the most voracious literary appetite.

title: Westchester Journal
description: IS the political climate in Westchester right for cloud-seeding? That depends on whom you use as a barometer. County Legislators Carolyn L. Whittle, Democrat of White Plains, and Sandra Galef, Democrat of Ossining, say ''Yes'' and recently proposed in a letter to County Executive Alfred B. DelBello that Westchester consider a cloud-seeding program from March through September. They believe this would produce a 10 to 20 percent increase in precipitation. The estimated cost for the venture would be $100,000.

title: 10 Jersey Counties On Rationing List
description: Mandatory water rationing now exists in all of Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Somerset and Union Counties, and in these other New Jersey communities: Hunterdon County - Tewksbury, Lambertville, West Amwell.

title: Strange Book Fellows
description: ''Those who are well have no need of a physician, but those who are sick.''

title: * To the Editor:$
description: The Reagan Administration asked that the annual report on human rights be delayed until after the visit of Chun Doo Hwan, as an act of diplomacy.

title: Headliners; Another Embarrassment
description: Representative Jon C. Hinson may have a tough time explaining this one - even to the voters in Mississippi who returned him to Congress in November. Mr. Hinson had managed to disarm a potentially explosive campaign rumor that he might be a homosexual, but last week he was arrested with another man in a restroom in the Longworth House Office Building and was charged with sodomy, a felony. The charge was later reduced to attempted sodomy, a misdemeanor, and the conservative Republican pleaded innocent.

title: Critics' Choices
description: Each week several Times critics will offer tips on attractions around town.

title: Christopher O'Riley Offers Piano Works
description: Even before he made his New York recital debut in Goodman Concert Hall on Wednesday night, Christopher O'Riley had demonstrated that he was a pianist to be reckoned with. A member of Gunther Schuller's New England Ragtime Ensemble, he is also known for his playing in the Berkshire Music Center Fellowship Program at Tanglewood, for performances with the New England Conservatory Contemporary Music Ensemble and as winner of the second prize in the 1980 Montreal International Piano Competition. Presented here by Pro Musicis, Mr. O'Riley showed not only that he is a pianist and musician of skill, intelligence and stylistic awareness but also that he has strong convictions about the pieces he plays and the ability to project them to his listeners.

title: Norway Calls A Woman to Lead
description: Gro Harlem Brundtland, selected last week as Norway's new Prime Minister, listed Joan of Arc as one of her heroines (along with Golda Meir). She was shy about explaining why, but the ruling Labor Party has been sliding in the polls and Dr. Brundtland, its vice chairman, is its most popular personality.

title: THE DANCE: KATHY KROLL AT OPEN EYE
description: Solo dance programs are risky unless you're a seasoned performer with a strong stage personality and choreographic viewpoint. Kathy Kroll, who performed Friday at the Theater of the Open Eye, is a fairly strong dancer with the blurred look of a late-starter.

title: Man, 75, Is Fifth to Die From Jersey Hotel Fire
description: The death toll from Tuesday's fire at the Keifer's Quarters hotel has risen to five with the death of another elderly resident, authorities said today.

title: Violist and Pianist Combine in a Recital
description: Two excellent young musicians, Thomas Jansons and Arianna Goldina, gave a recital last Sunday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Jansons is a violist from Canada currently studying in New York, and Miss Goldina is from Latvia, where she studied the piano before coming here.

title: PROTEST OVER TOXIC WASTE SITE
description: I WANTED to remain complaisant. It would be easier that way. I could peer through the frosty windows into the hemlocks around my home and consider that everything was safe. My consciousness wanted no menace, no danger, no fear lurking in my Connecticut Valley town.

title:
Gardening;
GOVERNMENT STUDIES AID HOME GARDENER
description: THE years of the Lincoln Presidency were so dominated by the Civil War that many other achievements of that period are often ignored. This is true in the field of agriculture, in which decisions were made that are still contributing toward making our agriculture the most prosperous and our population the best fed of any nation.

title: No Headline
description: JERSEY YOUNGSTER, 15, STUNS SKATE WORLD

title: Herrick Quartet, Group With Unusual Makeup
description: The Herrick Quartet's unusual makeup - flute, violin, viola and cello - almost ensures unusual programming, and indeed, its Friday evening concert at Carnegie Recital Hall included lesser-known music by famous composers (Haydn, Mozart, Vaughan Williams) and music by composers that most people have never heard of at all.

title: BRITONS ARE URGED TO SAVE BY MINDING P'S AND Q'S
description: Lord Simon of Glaisdale, one of Britain's most prominent lawyers and a graduate of Cambridge University, has asked Parliament to help the nation economize by making cuts - not in the budget but in the English language.

title: HOW'S SHE DOIN? IT'S ALL SISTERHOOD
description: Her hair is darker, and there is a lot more of it. But you can see the resemblance around the nose. The smile too, is familiar, and so are certain gestures and vocal inflections. They are eerily reminiscent of Mayor Koch, which is no big surprise when you consider that she is the Mayor's younger sister.

title: WHEN TWO KAYES GET TOGETHER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Neil A. Martin is a freelance writer who frequently reports on the television scene. By NEIL A. MARTIN BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. Two years ago, the composer and lyricist Sylvia Fine Kaye wrote, produced and was the on-camera narrator of ''Musical Comedy Tonight,'' a 90-minute primer on the history of the American musical theater. The public-broadcasting presentation was generally well received by the critics and later won a Peabody Award.

title: Truman Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FERMENT IN REAGAN'S TREASURY
description: TO the casual eye, little has changed in the Treasury Department. The portraits of past Secretaries still stare down from the walls in a corner of the second floor. Bureaucrats bustle through the marble-floored corridors. Even the offices of the top officials remain unchanged - redecorating has been banned for budget reasons.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Unveiling Budgets, And Honing Knives
description: ''There are no applause lines in this budget message,'' Governor Byrne told the New Jersey Legislature last week. He could have saved his breath.

title: Reutemann Captures Grand Prix
description: Carlos Reutemann of Argentina outsmarted his rivals before the race even started today and won tne South African Grand Prix in a Saudia-Leyland Williams.

title: Music; PERFORMING HONORED AT SARAH LAWRENCE
description: ''FROM the very first days of Sarah Lawrence College,'' said Charles De Carlo, its president, ''music, and specifically the performance of music, has been given a major place in our curriculum. This is unusual at small lbieral arts colleges, where the emphasis is generally on learning about things, rather than doing them. Composers have always participated in the making of music on our campus - both as teachers and as performers of their own works - and when we stopped to realize what a striking number of really distinguished creators have worked and lived here over the years, we decided a little festival was in order. The way things are turning out, I think we're going to have a very happy occasion.''

title: OUTLOOK: EUROPE'S MANAGEMENT APPROACH
description: WHEN French-born Michel L. Besson talks about his most pressing goal as the new chairman of the CertainTeed Corporation, a United States building materials manufacturer that is majority-owned by one of France's largest companies, his credo hardly distinguishes him from American executives.

title: INSIDE A TURBINE AT INDIAN POINT
description: BUCHANAN IN the giant steam-turbine building of Indian Point 3 the other day, the scene resembled an operating room. Like a seriously ill patient, the massive turbine had been opened, and its steel innards lay exposed as workmen struggled to remove the remaining parts.

title: Classroom Violence
description: Frank Skala was teaching a ninth-grade class in social studies at Campbell Junior High School in Queens in October 1977 when five young intruders entered and turned his classroom into a national news event. While horrified students screamed and cried, the intruders broke the teacher's nose, threw him to the floor and stomped on him.

title:
Stamps;
A NEW BRITISH SET OF FOUR FOR VALENTINE'S DAY
description: The hearts and flowers of a traditional valentine, provided this week by Great Britain with no symbol of sentimentality omitted, is replacing the fire crackers and dragons of last week's Chinese New Year. The custom of exchanging valentines is part of a rich folklore heritage that Britain is tapping for its first special set of stamps for 1981.

title: Dining Out; ECLECTIC DINER OF GREEK HERITAGE
description: NORWALK THE word ''diner'' connotes an around-the-clock eatery, more often than not a truck stop. But anyone visiting the new Silver Star Restaurant-Diner expecting the classic long counter with a few booths is in for culture shock.

title: Barbara S. Frees Bride of Educator
description: Barbara Susan Frees, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Frees of Yonkers, was married yesterday to Dr. Donald Grunewald, president of Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Dr. Grunewald is a son of Tina Durham of Chatham, Mass., and Key Biscayne, Fla., and the late Harry A. Grunewald.

title: Miss Henderson, Student, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Frederick Henderson of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Frederick Henderson, to Jerald De Forrest Ball, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Ball 3d of Big Piney, Wyo.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The Delft Trio, a group of young musicians from the Middle West, came to New York last Tuesday evening and played music by Shostakovich, Brahms and Jon Polifrone at Carnegie Recital Hall. Alan Heatherington was the violinist, while David Low and Richard Boldrey played the cello and piano, respectively.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''This is a message to the parents that whatever the grievance, the appropriate forum is not a school building.''

title: Meeting the Press, at Least Halfway
description: It won't be long before journalists start complaining about President Reagan's relations with the media, but for the moment some credit is in order. He not only seems willing to improve the Presidential news conference institutionally, but also to pay a certain price for the changes.

title: BRITAIN DEBATES IMMIGRATION AND RACE
description: A Government attempt to resolve the longstanding question of what constitutes British citizenship has touched off a national debate about immigration and a growing problem in race relations.

title: MARTIN KANE TO MARRY LISE HOLLANDER JUNE 28 IN SPAIN
description: The engagement of Lise Hollander to Martin Charles Kane, son of Edward Kane of Millville, N.J., and the late Betty Kane, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gino Hollander of Pizarra, Spain, formerly of New York. A June 28 wedding is planned in Pizarra.

title: REGIONS SOVIET BLOC: FOR POLAND,THE MEDICINE MAY WORSEN THE DISEASE
description: WARSAW THE ironic twist in the labor revolt that shook Poland and the entire Communist order last year is that the widespread economic discontent that sparked the unrest is likely to be increased by the measures taken to settle the crisis.

title:
On the Isle;
UP IN AIR
description: This is Aviation Month, among other things. And if that news stimulates you, perhaps you'll be interested in how the East Meadow Public Library is commemorating the occasion. Take today, for example. Starting at 1 P.M. with ''To Fly,'' a film that usually doesn't leave the National Air and Space Museum in Washington, the afternoon will also include ''Restoring the Jenny,'' a slide-talk by William Kaiser, curator of the Cradle of Aviation Museum at Mitchel Field, on Charles Lindbergh's plane; and a program about the NinetyNines, an international organization of women who are pilots.

title: ARTWORKS ARE GRANTED A PROMINENT PLACE OUTDOORS AS PUBLIC CONSTRUCTION
description: IN THE CITY SLOWLY RESUMES By EDITH EVANS ASBURY

title: Louisville 82, Florida State 73
description: A layup by Scooter McCray with nine seconds remaining sent the game into overtime, and Derek Smith sank six free throws in the extra period as Louisville pulled away from Florida State for an 82-73 Metro Conference victory today.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Rosedale Defiant On Bias Rulings
description: The struggle has become an American classic, of sorts: White parents, denying any racial motivation, refuse to obey orders to send their children to a predominantly black school outside their neighborhood, in defiance of school board, courts or government.

title: REGIONS ASIA: OPTIMISTS NOW REIGN IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO ONLY three or four years ago, optimists about the Japanese economy were as scarce here as Fords or Chevrolets. Government planners, businessmen, academics and ordinary Japanese were the world's greatest crepe-hangers when it came to talking about their nation's prospects. Japan's economic glass was always half empty, regardless of mounting evidence that Japan had come through the 1973-74 oil crisis better than any other major industrialized nation.

title: Carol Urquhart-Fisher Bride of William Beam
description: Carol Loanne Urquhart-Fisher and William Bradley Beam, who are with the American Express International Banking Corporation, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner). The Rev. Allen Warren 3d performed the ceremony.

title: AN INDEPENDENT MIND
description: PHILOSOPHY AND PUBLIC POLICY By Sidney Hook. 288 pp. Carbondale: Southern Illinois University Press. $17.50.

title: Theater; MUSICAL ON CIVIL WAR: A GOOD CRY
description: ''SHENANDOAH,'' at An Evening Dinner Theater in 1978, was soggy with sentimentality, the lyrics seemed simple to the point of idiocy and the music was almost nonexistent. Now, having seen a new production at the same theater and directed by Dallas Johann and starring Gary Marshal, one can see why it ran for 1,050 performances on Broadway.

title: Design; AN A-FRAME ATOP THE DAKOTA
description: The designer, Ward Bennett, calls it a Manhattan A-frame, and indeed it does resemble that style of vacation house with its characteristically steep-pitched roof. But rather than clinging to a mountainside near a ski resort, this one-room A-frame is perched atop the Dakota, one of New York's most celebrated apartment houses, and its views are not pristine wildernesses and moonlit landscapes but the woods and meadows of Central Park and the skyline of Manhattan.

title: Maria M. Matturro Engaged To William A. Bottiglieri Jr
description: The engagement of Maria Milo Matturro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Matturro of Scarsdale, N.Y., to William A. Bottiglieri Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bottiglieri of the Bronx, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Margot Johnson Wed to Bogdan Lenkiewicz
description: St. James Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Margot Grace Johnson, daughter of Mrs. Nels G. Johnson of Bismark, N.D., and the late Justice Johnson, to Bogdan Lenkiewicz, son of Mrs. Bohdan Lenkiewicz of New York, and the late Mr. Lenkiewicz. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Hyde, retired rector of St. James.

title: COLD DAY AT GRAND CENTRAL
description: JAN. 8, 10 A.M., Grand Central Terminal, New York City temperature 12 degrees. A voice descending from the vaults above, prophetic, a desperate cheerfulness edging the stern facts: ''Attention. Due to emergency malfunctions, all New Haven trains leaving or departing this morning will be delayed up to one hour. We will keep you informed.''

title: BETH BODEK TO BE MARRIED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Norman Bodek of Stanford, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Beth Carin Bodek, to George Simone 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simone Jr. of Cranston, R.I.

title: UConn Beaten by B.C., 76-71
description: John Bagley scored 26 points and Dwan Chandler got 14 in leading Boston College to a 76-71 Big East Conference victory over Connecticut tonight.

title: RESPONDING TO READERS' QUESTIONS
description: It has been quite a while since this column responded to inquiries from its readers, and we'll try to catch up with a few of them. As a rule, we cannot answer questions by personal letter or offer consultation on an individual basis. But from time to time we devote this space to answering questions of general interest.

title: A.I.A.W. Accused Of N.C.A.A. Ploy
description: To the Sports Editor: I am amused by the reaction of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women to the decision by the National Collegiate Athletic Association to conduct women's championships in 12 sports, including fencing. The arguments against the N.C.A.A. seem to be the same used by the National Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association to avoid being over-run by the A.I.A.W.'s expansion into fencing.

title: BUSINESS FINANCE: WORLD ACCOUNTING STANDARDS UURGED
description: THE ever-quickening pace of international trade has given rise to a call to establish a global set of accounting standards. Accounting, advocates of such a system say, is the language of business, and it should speak with a common vocabulary, which would make international commerce more efficient.

title: DAY TRIPS INTO THE PAST
description: Hyde Park, the Mark Twain House, masterpieces of Impressionist art and Ming Dynasty artifacts are among the lures of a series of day trips to historic sites in the next several months.

title: OUTLOOK: LOCKING UP ADVANCED TECHNOLOGIES
description: WASHINGTON AS the developing countries, aided by their relatively low wage scales, become increasingly competitive in traditional manufacturing industries, the developed nations are rushing to dominate the hightechnology sector, hoping to provide the jobs and exports they will need in the future.

title: Detroit Faces a Bath in Red Ink
description: One thing Detroit doesn't need is more bad news. But last week, in his annual state of the city address, Mayor Coleman A. Young said that declining income tax revenue would mean whopping deficits - $100 million or more - this year and next.

title: LISA HAMMER TO BE BRIDE
description: The engagement of Lisa Beth Hammer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Hammer of Livingston, N.J., to Ronald J. Marx, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Marx of Roslyn, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents. Miss Hammer and her fiance, who plan to be married in September, were graduated last May from the University of Maryland.

title: Citizens Are Vexed and Ingenuity of Kremlin Is Tested Because of Problems With Supply
description: The produce department of a grocery store 10 blocks north of the Kremlin contained only five items today; spongy small green apples covered with brown spots, cabbage, potatoes, carrots and onions.

title: IRAQIS PAUSE OUTSIDE IRANIAN CITY TO AWAIT RESULT OF INDIAN PARLEY
description: uf814BASRA, Iraq, Feb. 7 (Reuters) - Iraqi forces have moved to within a mile of the besieged southwest Iranian city of Susangird, but it was unclear whether they would soon move to capture the city.

title: No Headline
description: As a native of Baltimore who spends a great deal of time in Washington, I found Lynn Rosellini's gratuitous reference to our city (an ''outsider'' status in Washington is ''worse than living in Baltimore'') somewhat amusing and aggravating.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: SO LONG, SEE YOU TOMORROW, by William Maxwell. (Ballantine, $2.95.) seeing a stepmother replace his deceased mother in his father's life, sharing the agonies of a close friend whose family is battered by divorce, murder and suicide. Our reviewer Robert Towers called this memoir in the form of a novel ''strong and poignant,'' abundant with the pleasures of beautifully controlled writing.

title: IN PURSUIT OF RARITIES AMONG JAZZ RECORDS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Leo Haber writes frequently about recorded music. By LEO HABER

title: DOINGS OF A SPORTING MAN
description: AN OUTSIDE CHANCE Essays on Sport. By Thomas McGuane. 243 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95.

title: More on Traveling Light
description: To the Editor:

title: On Mixed-Use Zones
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out; SEAFOOD IN A PLEASANT SETTING
description: EPICUREAN in Great Neck is a place to keep in mind for casual seafood dinners in a pleasant setting. Actually, the wood-paneled dining room, with its softened lighting provided by glittery but effective modern chandeliers and its tables covered with spotless napery and adorned with fresh flowers, is fairly elegant. The walls are not strung with netting, as in the usual seafood restaurant. But the management does not require jackets for male patrons, jeans are permitted, and a relaxed tone prevails.

title: PURDUE 68, INDIANA 66
description: Kevin Stallings hit a pair of foul shots with five seconds remaining today and Purdue took advantage of Indiana's poor performance at the free-throw line to beat the Hoosiers by 68-66 in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: Export of Bobcat Pelts Halted
description: A Federal appeals court has banned the export of North American bobcat pelts until Government wildlife experts develop a method for counting the bobcat population. The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia criticized the Endangered Species Scientific Authority Wednesday for allowing the killing and export of about 80,000 bobcats each year. The ruling was a victory for the environmental group Defenders of Wildlife in its suit against the Scientific Authority, which is part of the United States Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: INVITATION TO ALCHOHOL ABUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: CASTLE IN VERONA STIRS UP A DISPUTE
description: VERONA AT THE turn of the century, Frederick Kip's home was his Rhinestyle castle, the 30-room stone edifice having been built by the textile machinery manufacturer atop one of Essex County's highest mountains. Today, this symbol of sequestered affluence is the center of community controversy.

title: Practical Traveler; IN TIME OF EMERGENCY, MANY STILL TURN TO TRAVELERS AID
description: Though not so visible as they once were, Travelers Aid Societies throughout the United States continue to provide services for thousands of travelers each year. They help cope with all sorts of crises, some of them almost endemic because of the nature of travel today.

title: Iowa 77, Illinois 66
description: Steve Krafcisin's 14 second-half points helped Iowa to a 77-66 Big Ten Conference victory today over Illinois.

title: THE WOOING OF WOMEN ATHLETES
description: Grace Lichtenstein is the author of ''Machisma: Women and Daring'' to be published in May by Doubleday. By Grace Lichtenstein Sharron Backus, women's softball coach for the University of California at Los Angeles, sat in her office not long ago anxiously awaiting replies to letters mailed to six hot recruiting prospects, all high-school juniors. The letters had been ''soft-sell,'' but they did mention the many athletic scholarships available for women at U.C.L.A. ''I don't like to hassle them,'' Miss Backus said, but, as she noted, competition among universities for women softball stars was ''cut-throat.''

title: TALC COATING ON RICE CALLED PERIL
description: The director of the Puerto Rico Cancer Institute has urged the island's government to ban a talc coating that is added to most rice sold here, out of concern that it may contribute to the risk of stomach cancer.

title: REPATRIATION ASKED FOR DIPLOMATS SON
description: The United States asked Ghana's mission to the United Nations yesterday to send home a diplomat's 19-year-old son because the youth has been implicated in at least two rapes in the last month on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

title: Connecticut Guide; 'LA BELLE EPOQUE'
description: The William Benton Museum of Art on the Storrs campus of the University of Connecticut has an exhibition called ''La Belle Epoque,'' a collection of Art Nouveau watercolors, posters and drawings by Belgian artists who originated the style. UConn is thus helping commemorate Belgium's 150th independence celebration.

title: TUITION VINES LINES; Body Count
description: Counting crowds of people isn't easy. Basically, one should count noses, on the assumption that they correlate, one-to-one, with bodies. But for crowds of more than 100, as at a parade, shortcuts must be found. These include reasonable geometric computations, aerial surveys - and a talent for estimating which result will satisfy important and interested people.

title: International Economic Survey
description: February 8, 1981 OUTLOOK

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Clearance on Items From the British Isles
description: The mailing-list notices are out for Dickens of London's clearance in Mamaroneck. It is not ordinarily an off-price shop, but the markdowns during the rest of the month start at 30 percent on men's and women's first-quality apparel and accessories. Reductions go to considerably beyond 50 percent on pale stripings in silk shirtwaist dresses, down from $165 to $65, and in cotton, down from $115 to $35, by Stephens Bros. of London and made in Ireland.

title: Guess Who Came to Dinner in Peking?
description: A lunar New Year dinner with a Vietnamese defector does not rate high even on the list of Peking diplomatic perquisites, but Hua Guofeng, China's all-but-purged party Chairman, is in no position to be choosy.

title: FRIENDS AND HEROES
description: PERSONAL IMPRESSIONS By Isaiah Berlin. Edited by Henry Hardy. Introduction by Noel Annan. Illustrated. 219 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: Film Borrowers' Names Sought by Moral Majority
description: The Moral Majority, which wants parents to have more say in sex education courses, is asking the Washington State Library to identify borrowers of a 21-minute movie entitled ''Achieving Sexual Maturity.''

title: Jeanne Walker Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Walker of Chapel Hill and Carolina Trace, N.C., have announced the engagment of their daughter, Jeanne Marie Walker, to Randolph Lowe McKee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rhomas Lowe McKee of Augusta, Ga. The wedding is planned for March 14 in Sanford, N.C. The bride is a house parent at the Jackson-Feild Children's Home in Emporia, Va., and her fiance is director of admission at the Georgia Baptist Medical Center in Atlanta.

title: FOSTERING MEDIOCRITY IN THE ARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY ENDS BET MINIMUMS AT CASINO TABLE GAMES
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission, heeding industry complaints that ''overregulation'' was cutting casino profitability and hindering development of the industry in Atlantic City, took a key step in deregulation last week by eliminating its requirements for low-stakes table games.

title: FOR SALE: ILLITERACY ON THE CAMPUS
description: IT WAS my abominable luck to go to college at a time when students could not easily avoid preparing their own term papers. Weekends and vacations were spent squinting in the library, lacerating cuticles in the card catalogue, inching through indexes, building bibliographies and feeding nickels into insatiable photocopying machines.

title: Walking in London
description: To the Editor:

title: Ipswich, Aston Villa Win And Remain Tied for Lead
description: Ipswich score three goals in seven minutes today and edged last-place Crystal Palace, 3-2, to remain in contention for the English soccer championship. Ipswich remained the co-leader with Aston Villa, which scored a 3-1 victory at Everton.

title: APPLIACE SALES COOL 10% IN '80
description: Shipments of major home appliances, such as dishwashers, gas and electric ranges, refrigerators and air conditioners, fell 10 percent last year, to 31.7 million units. A drop in disposable income and the imposition of credit controls and high interest rates, which had a severe impact on housing construction, were major factors behind the decline.

title: February 8, 1981
description: NONFICTION AMERICA, LOST & FOUND. By Anthony Bailey. 12 DADDY KING: An Autobiography. By the Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. with Clayton Riley. 13 FACES IN MY TIME.

title: Paul Pearson, a Rutgers Official, To Head Miami University in Ohio
description: Dr. Paul G. Pearson, executive vice president of Rutgers University, has been named president of Miami University.

title: Caroline Reid Becomes Bride Of a Physician
description: Caroline Baskin Reid, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Roddey Reid of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday evening in Manhattan to Dr. Michael Sorell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Sorell of Tamarac, Fla. The Rev. F. Reid Isaac, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, and Rabbi Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the Burden Mansion.

title: John Jay 55, Lehman 54
description: Curtis White hit a basket with two seconds left Saturday night as John Jay College defeated Lehman College in triple overtime, 55-54. John Jay, playing on its home court, had lost its last three City Conference games in double overtime. White led all scorers with 18 points.

title: Alma L. Harward Married to a Cleric
description: Alma Lippincott Harward, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Vernon Judson Harward Jr. of Northampton, Mass., was married at St. John's Episcopal Church there yesterday to the Rev. Stewart Andrew Pollock, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald O. Pollock of Cooperstown, N.Y. The Rev. Charles S. Tyler of St. John's and the Rev. Robert E. Herst of the First Presbyterian Church, Cooperstown, performed the ceremony.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
HOLOCAUST'S 'LOST HERO'
description: For the ninth consecutive year the Judaic Heritage Society is issuing a medal to honor its "Man of the Year." In the process, it is focusing new attention on a still-unsolved mystery that had its beginnings in the Holocaust.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE Morris Canal has left few physical traces. A busy trade route across New Jersey in the 19th century, it has all but disappeared as the 20th century approaches its end. For those who would recall what it looked like, half a mile or so remains in a preserved stretch in Waterloo Village, in Stanhope.

title: AN ARRAY OF TREASURES FOR DEVOTED SAVOYARDS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard Traubner writes frequently on operetta and musicals. By RICHARD TRAUBNER

title: SENATORS GIVE CLARK ANGRY ADVICE, BUT STILL CONSENT
description: Twenty-four years ago, Maxwell H. Gluck, a Republican businessman nominated to be United States Ambassador to Ceylon, became a minor footnote in diplomatic history when he told an astonished Senate Foreign Relations Committee that he could not name Ceylon's Prime Minister. Senator William J. Fulbright, then chairman of the panel, and other committee members were appalled by Mr. Gluck's lack of qualifications and preparation for his post. Mr. Gluck nevertheless won confirmation from the Senate in a unanimous voice vote.

title: REGIONS ASIA: INDIA: SATELLITES, SCARCITY
description: WHILE both astrologers and economists are issuing pessimistic forecasts for India, the forebodings are tempered by the realization that, as bad as things may become, they have never been very good.

title: SALVADOR LAND REFORM, AND U.S. POLICY
description: Does the summary removal of Robert White as Ambassador to strife-torn El Salvador signal a change in United States policy? The centerpiece of that policy has been support for El Salvador's sweeping land-reform program, one of the most significant in LatinAmerica's history.

title: SARI JILL SCHLUSSEL IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Phillip M. Schlussel of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sari Jill Schlussel, to Matthew J. Leeds, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Leeds of New York. Miss Schlussel, an audiologist, and her fiance, an associate with the law firm of Wien, Lane & Malkin, will be married this spring. Miss Schlussel's father is president and chairman of United Coverage Consultants Inc., insurance brokers in New York, where Mr. Leed's father is a dentist.
