title: Mortality-Rate Statistics Called Matter of Semantics
description: I am writing to comment on a letter to the Westchester Editor from Gladys Elson in which she stated that we had ''... a low ranking in many accounts, for example, 13th in cancer mortality and 27th in cardiovascular disease mortality ...''

title: Canadiens 6, Bruins 2
description: Rejean Houle scored two goals for Montreal, which ended a five-game unbeaten streak by Boston.

title: Editors' Choice
description: AMBITION, by Joseph Epstein. (E.P. Dutton, $13.95.) An ambitious defense of ambition.

title: REGIONS LATIN AMERICA: BRAZIL RIDING A TREADMILL
description: RIO DE JANEIRO SPURRED by considerable Government coaxing, Brazilian exports raced ahead in 1980. But petroleum prices were also on the rise, and by year end, the country found its $5 billion boost in exports exceeded by a $5.6 billion increase in its expenditures for imported oil.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title:
CAMERA;
WHAT QUALITIES DOES A GOOD PHOTOGRAPHER HAVE?
description: When amateur and professional photographers get together they often discuss equipment and techniques at some length, but it is not often that photographers take time to consider what makes a good picture.

title: REGIONS: A PINCHED PROSPERITY IN EUROPE
description: Slow Growth Seen Pinching Most of Europe By PAUL LEWIS

title: GOVERNING LIBERIA, BY TRIAL AND ERROR
description: Here and there within Liberia's nine-month-old military regime are bright, educated civilians who have voluntarily suffered the insults of soldiers, demands made at gunpoint, incarceration of relatives and barely legible but clearly bullying letters from on high - all in the hope that patience will win out and the country will endure.

title: Albany Notes
description: With Governor Carey gearing up for his re-election drive next year, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo must be gearing up too, right? Wrong.

title: Miriam Herman Is Married
description: Miriam R. Herman of New York, widow of Murry S. Herman, was married in Manhattan yesterday evening to Allan E. Miller, a widower of Hollywood, Fla. Rabbi Isaac L. Swift of Congregation Ahavath Torah in Englewood, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Regency.

title: Military Analysis
description: The estimated dollar costs of Soviet strategic nuclear forces in the period from 1971 to 1980 were two and two-thirds the comparable United States expenditures in the same field of weaponry, accoording to a research study by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: BUSINESS FINANCE: GROWING COAL SALES AID SHIPPING
description: THE booming worldwide demand for coal is helping to spur the construction of a new class of ocean-going freighter and has brought widespread calls for deepening port channels to accommodate the larger, more efficient ships.

title: LOS ANGLES IS IN SEARCH OF A CANYON AS A TRASH DUMP
description: A wag once remarked that the Grand Canyon offered a lot of room for disposing of old razor blades. But nature imitates art, and the quip has been recalled often in recent weeks by Los Angeles County officials grappling with a curiously parallel situation.

title: Dorella Maiorescu Covers Wide Period on the Harp
description: Dorella Maiorescu, a harpist who came to this country from Rumania in 1969, presented an evening of music at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday. It was a generous, almost overly generous program that reached from the Baroque to the present.

title: Stage View; THE FORMULA WASN'T INFALLIBLE
description: Iam gradually coming to the conclusion that for a musical comedy to become successful in the 1920's, it needed to concentrate on just three things: (a) the dress, (b) the jewels, and (c) the title. There had to be a dress, of course, and of course it had to be stolen. Well, borrowed. You'd have thought that after the phenomenal success of the show called ''Irene,'' and the ineradicable memory of a tune called ''Alice Blue Gown,'' nobody would have dared use the device again. And you'd have been wrong. Instead of biting their lips and wishing they'd thought of it, librettists everywhere simply appropriated it, blithly repeating its non-surprises for the delectation of one and all.

title: THAT SEARCH FOR THE ULTIMATE BARGAIN
description: IT'S Sunday, and it's chilly. No matter. The Roosevelt Raceway parking lot is as crowded as a county fair in August, long aisles jammed elbow to elbow with people in search of the Ultimate Bargain.

title: Social Security
description: To the Business Editor: Michael Boskin's thoughtful analysis of the snowballing problems of the Social Security System, ''How to Reform Social Security'' (Jan. 11), was timely. While various holding actions will be necessary in the short run, the only effective and equitable long-run solution is Professor Baskin's third suggestion: ''separate the transfer and annuity components of the system.'' The annuity component simply pays back to each employee his own contributions and those his employer makes on his behalf plus accumulated interest, assuming an average life expectancy. (Those living longer than average would receive a larger total amount; those dying earlier, proportionately less). This component constitutes a true insurance scheme based on actuarial principles.

title: IRISH LAUD DIPLOMAT CALLED HOME BY U.S.
description: The American diplomat who was recalled to Washington last weekend, after a letter he wrote to a friend calling Ireland ''dull'' and ''small potatoes'' was published by The Irish Times, has been winning praise from many Irish.

title: 'CADDIE,' AN AUSTRALIAN WOMAN ON HER OWN
description: Caddie (Helen Morse), the title character in Donald Crombie's new Australian film set in the 1920's and 30's, is a heroine beloved in literature of all ages, though not always literature of the best kind. She's Woman Alone, Facing the World as Best She Might, with Courage, Fortitude and Determination. Sometimes she's a saucy Moll Flanders or an even saucier Fanny Hill. More often, unfortunately, she's bred in the sentimentality of novels such as Olive Higgins Prouty's ''Stella Dallas'' and Barry Benefield's ''Valiant Is the Word for Carrie.''

title: Ben Holt, Baritone,; Sings Vivaldi and Ravel
description: Soon after the baritone Ben Holt began his debut concert in Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday afternoon, it was clear that, though this was his first solo appearance, it will not be his last. Mr. Holt was presented as the winner of the First Annual Vocal Competition of Independent Black Opera Singers Inc., an organization founded five years ago to aid the careers of black male singers. Mr. Holt, a native of Washington, has studied at Oberlin Conservatory and Juilliard.

title: Price, Not Passion, Rules Auto Buyers
description: THE place was Allentown, Pa. The year was 1956 and the car was a new Lincoln, living for the moment in showroom splendor, gleaming charcoal and white, an outrageous symbol of the time, a temptress. I remember sitting in front of the dealership in my old Ford, slathering over the longer-lower-wider look and confronting the two major questions of my life: whether to hock everything and put a downpayment on the Lincoln or to go off and join the Navy.

title: 3 Killed, 12 Hurt in Collision
description: A head-on collision between a truck and a car yesteray killed three persons and injured 12, including nine illegal Mexican aliens hidden in the back of the truck, the state police said. Killed were John Wilson, 22 years old, Clarence Soleau, 24, and Kenneth Pelican, 23, all of Elton, La.

title: Movies in Rome
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE SHOW AT 2 GALLERIES IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK ''NORTH of New Brunswick, South of New York'' is the title of an art exhibition currently shared by the Robeson Gallery at RutgersNewark (350 High Street) and City Without Walls (140 Halsey Street). It remains on view through Feb. 16.

title: Reagan and Chun Exchange Favors
description: Private persuasion followed by public reward seems to define the human rights policy of the Reagan Administration, at least as applied so far to the anti-Communist dictatorship of South Korea's Chun Doo Hwan.

title: No Headline
description: In the early 1950's, I became the first woman accepted into the Directors Guild of America, as a first assistant director. The tests (which went on for hours) included an oral exam, and I recall vividly the entire body of male members asking me such questions as: ''Would I go in a submarine, if asked to?'' or ''How would I handle myself if the shot called for helicopter shooting?''

title: I.R.A. BOMBS A BRITISH COAL SHIP
description: Irish Republican Army guerrillas claimed responsibility today for setting off a bomb on a privately owned British coal ship off the northern Irish coast.

title: Wake Forest 86 Georgia Tech 56
description: Frank Johnson scored 8 points and contributed a key assist during a 20-6 second-half spurt today as Wake Forest crushed Georgia Tech, 86-56, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: Music; FACULTY AT HARTT IN CHAMBER RECITAL
description: THE extraordinarily busy chamber music schedule this week is largely centered on Connecticut campuses. Following are some programs to consider:

title: REGIONS EUROPE: FRANCE AIMS FOR TOMORROW'S MARKETS
description: PARIS AT a time when other Western industrial economies are stuck in the doldrums, France is staging an economic reorganization that it hopes will revitalize its industries by making them more competitive.

title: THE OUTLOOK FOR MAJOR CURRENCIES
description: THE wide fluctuation of interest rates last year became the major factor affecting the value of world currencies, and the pattern is expected to continue through 1981. ''Interest rates are always important, but they were overwhelmingly the tail that wagged the dog last year,'' Alan Teck, a vice president of the Chemical Bank, said.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE OWLS AND THE GEESE: 2 TALES OF NATURE IN WINTER
description: THE snowy owl is one of the rarest and most spectacular of the birds that occasionally visit New Jersey. This winter, no fewer than three - more than in any winter in 15 years - have dropped in on us, two at Island Beach State Park in Ocean County and one in Liberty State Park in Hudson County. They arrived in December and probably will be around through the winter.

title: REGIONS ASIA: SKEPTICISM OVER TRADE WITH CHINA
description: PEKING AT a breakfast meeting recently with visiting New York Congressman Steven Solarz, a group of American businessmen who live here began venting their long pent-up grievances about doing business in China.

title: Leisure; DURING THE DROUGHT, GROW CACTUS
Jeremiah Was Right
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: The manufacturer of the Capri, a sporty compact car, was incorrectly identified in some copies of the Greater New York Automobile Show section in The Times last Sunday. The car is made by the Ford Motor Company and is marketed by its Mercury division.

title: Volcano's Lava Dome Grows
description: A ''nonexplosive eruption'' has more than doubled the size of the steaming lava dome rising in the center of Mount St. Helens' mile-wide crater, according to the United States Geological Survey. The dome grew laterally and vertically, reaching a height of about 600 feet, according to the scientists. The Forest Service said it would continue its ''eruption'' watch.

title: Drawing a Bloody Line in the Andes
description: Spanish explorers marched out of colonial Quito 400 years ago and discovered the Amazon, so Ecuador claims title to land they found. The problem is, that land is a large portion of Peru, including what are now productive oilfields.

title: HAIG, QUICK TO LEAP FIRST IN THE POOL, ALSO MAKES SOME WAVES
description: The first weeks of a new Administration inevitably produce jockeying for power and vigorous efforts at image-making. Among the Reagan Cabinet, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig, Jr., has quickly won a reputation as the best prepared, most experienced bureaucratic maneuverer, and the most forceful in asserting his authority over a broad domain.

title: 2 Lichtman Sisters Will Become Brides
description: Dr. and Mrs. Marc M. Lichtman of East Williston, L.I. have announced the engagements of their daughters, Karen Lynn and Vivian Sarah Lichtman. Karen and her fiance, Frederic Lee Sax, son of Mrs. Karl Sax of Irvine, Calif., and the late Mr. Sax, plan to be married in May.

title:
Art;
PAPER IS THE MESSAGE, NOT JUST THE MEDIUM
description: PAPER, a material that has been literally in the background of art for centuries, is now coming into its own. It may have been the advent of collage in the early years of this century that stimulated the appreciation of paper as an art medium in its own right rather than a mere vehicle for a print or drawing. Whatever the stimulus, the last two decades in particular have witnessed an increasingly experimental approach to the manufacture of paper and its uses as a vehicle of esthetic expression.

title: St. Augustine
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPPLY SIDE SUN LIGHTS A REGANOMIC RAINBOW
description: WHEN President Reagan talked in his economic address about savings and borrowing, about Government competing for credit with citizens and about incentives for business investment, he was using the language and concepts of ''supply-side'' economics, the still untested theory that cutting taxes and the Federal budget will produce noninflationary growth.

title: 4 BILLS IN ALBANY SEEK TO ATTRACT PLANTS WITH HIGH TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Assembly approved a package of four bills this week intended to spur the development of high-technology industries in New York State.

title: BUSINESS FINANCE: THE WORLD'S HIGH-FLYING STOCKS
description: INVESTORS around the globe returned to the equities markets in large numbers during 1980, causing most of the world's major stock exchanges to record impressive gains. Capital International, a Swiss-based group that compiles international stock market data, reported a 21.5 percent increase in 1980 in its World Index, a weighted dollar-based average of the performance of some 1,100 securities listed on 18 national exchanges.

title: 2 WOMEN AND 2 CHILDREN DIE IN A FIRE IN JERSEY CITY
description: Two women and two young children were killed in a fire that raced through a four-story yellow clapboard apartment building in the city's downtown section early this morning. A third woman collapsed and died moments after she escaped from the flaming building.

title: JOHN C. DEVLIN
description: THE charm and serenity of a Connecticut marshland have been reproduced in a diorama for display in the Thames Science Center, which overlooks the Thames River in New London.

title: U.S. Reports Major Fuel Savings From Trucking Industry's Efforts
description: Using such fuel-saving options as wind deflectors and fan clutches, the trucking industry saved enough fuel from 1973 to 1979 to heat the homes of 1.8 million American families in those years, the Transportation Department has said.

title: RECRIMINATIONS FLY AS SYMPHONY REMAINS SILENT
description: NEWARK THE sound of the New Jersey Symphony has been stilled for four months, but the fury is beginning to mount as management, the musicians, the conductor and the trustees become increasingly frustrated by a faltering fund drive that threatens not only the remainder of the current season, but also the orchestra's very existence.

title: THUNDER FROM THE RIGHT
description: OPENER Peter Ross Range is a freelance writer based in Washington. By Peter Ross Range carcely three hours after Ronald Reagan took the oath of office at his Inauguration, Jesse A. Helms, the conservative Republican from North Carolina, took the floor of the Senate to oppose confirmation of Caspar Weinberger as the new President's Secretary of Defense.

title: BOSTON UNIVERSITY 74, IONA 72
description: Brett Brown hit two free throws with 13 seconds remaining today to give Boston University a 74-72 victory over Iona at the Mulcahy Center.

title: Weinberger Begins Shifting Pins on His Pentagon Maps
description: To hear the Reagan high command tell it, the military forces it inherited from the Carter Administration amount to little more than a thin red, white and blue line. But last week, in his first press conference as Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger, suggested that the line could be stretched farther than it is.

title: LOVE AND MONEY
description: Given the uncertain business outlook, merchants who sell flowers and candy, two perenially popular Valentine's Day gifts, may be expecting some effect in their sales. However, according to historical data compiled by Elizabeth Allison, an economist at Data Resources, these traditional tokens of love and affection sell better during bad economic times than more prosperous periods.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Pointepienu is a small dance company from Montreal whose name very openly communicates the aims of its founder, Louise Latreille. The ''pointe'' refers to the toe dancing of classical ballet's technique, in which all seven company members were trained.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
NOTRE DAME'S NEW MAN
description: GERARD FAUST (''Gerard is the patron saint of expectant mothers''), Notre Dame's new football coach, had come east to whisper sweet nothings into the ears of large young scholars with sloping necks, and his time was rationed into bite-size morsels like those pickled navels served at cocktail parties. He had described the scenic splendors of the Notre Dame campus to a couple of New Jersey high school seniors faster than light and violent as a crime of passion - they laughed at his description of the statue of Father Corby with upraised hand giving group absolution to the troops before Gettysburg, known to the student body as Fair Catch Corby - and had managed to fit in a meeting at the Meadowlands, where it was announced that Notre Dame would play Army there in 1983.

title: TUITION VINES LINES; Moonbelt
description: One of the simplest ways to blunt the arrows of outrageous fortune is to look to your horoscope. ''What could I expect?'' the astrology buff says.

title: SILENT FILMS HAD A MUSICAL VOICE
description: In the 1920's the old Capitol Theater in New York had a staff of a half dozen working under a music director to prepare a score for each film. Full orchestras were as common in the greatest movie palaces as in opera houses. Without them, the villainy, farce and droning sound of the projector might have disappointed many who had come to be thrilled by moving pictures.

title: Riding Tall
description: The kindest judgment on President Reagan's first gestures toward the Soviet Union is to note that he has obviously spent most of his White House time studying the American economy. The priority is right. No amount of nose-thumbing at Moscow will do much harm if in the end Mr. Reagan tames inflation, stimulates growth, improves the military and relieves dependence on foreign oil. No foreign exertions will do much good if he fails.

title: THE BIGGEST CLAIM AGAINST IRAN: $450 MILLION
description: I T was a tale reminiscent of ''The Treasure of Sierra Madre,'' the B. Traven novel that later become the film classic starring Humphrey Bogart and Walter Huston. A New York metals importer named William Bikoff listened wide-eyed while on a quick trip to Iran as local mining engineers spun tall stories of vast, untapped mineral riches just waiting to be scooped out of the unmarked desert.

title: NEW YORK'S G.M. EMPLOYEES SHAKEN BY JOB SHIFTS
description: The 700 New York employees of General Motors who learned last week that their jobs were being transferred to Detroit are ''in an agony of suspense, waiting for the other shoe to drop,'' as one of them said.

title: Miss Bayliss Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Bayliss of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Madeline Therese Bayliss, to Jeffrey Thomas Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Allen of Avon, Ohio.

title: Boxing and Banks: A Strange Alliance Strangely Awry
description: Harold J. Smith came out of nowhere a year ago and, using the name of a famous friend, the lure of big bucks and his own flamboyance, turned the world of professional boxing on its ear. Last week, Mr. Smith, chairman of Muhammad Ali Professional Sports Inc., a Los Angeles-based boxing promotion concern which only leased the boxer's name, was up to his own ears in trouble, and he had plenty of company.

title: THE PACE FAMILY:POWER IN SUFFOLK POLITICS
description: POLITICAL families still stand out as rare breeds in politics - the Kennedys, the Wagners, the Roosevelts and, closer to the Island, the D'Amatos in Nassau County and the Cohalans in Suffolk. Now, another political family - the Paces of West Islip - is emerging as a powerful force in Suffolk County politics.

title: 'SPETTERS' VIEWS DUTCH MOTORCYCLE RIDERS
description: ''Spetters,'' which opens today at the Beekman Theater, is a resolutely humorless (though sometimes unintentionally funny) Dutch movie about three young men who dream of finding fame and fortune in motorcycle racing and, instead, find themselves. The search is unrewarding and seems interminable.

title: No Headline
description: Guillermo Vilas of Argentina beat Jose Higueras of Spain, 6-3, 6-3, today and gained the final of the $75,000 Mar del Plata tennis tournament, a Grand Prix event.

title: Charles B. Ferster, 58; Psychology Researcher
description: Charles B. Ferster, whose research in experimental psychology contributed to the development of the psychotherapeutic technique known as behavioral modification, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Washington Hospital Center. He was 58 years old.

title: THRILLERS AND KILLERS
description: THE DANCE CARD By John R. Feegel. 314 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $11.95.

title: CONSUMER RATES

Antiques;
WEBSTER HOME A SMALL MUSEUM
description: WEST HARTFORD BUILT before 1740 - the exact date never has been documented - the old frame and clapboard red house in which Noah Webster was born stands today a scant two and a half city blocks from the business center of this prosperous Hartford suburb.

title: VIEWS A PORTFOLIO FROM AROUND THE NATION
description: CARTOON CAPTIONS with human rights cartoon Chuck Ayers The Akron Beacon Journal with Poland cartoon Ranan Lurie Die Welt King Features Syndicate with Central America cartoon Dennis Renault The Sacramento Bee with Stockman cartoon Charles Powell The News and Observer Los Angeles Times Syndicate Views A portfolio from around the nation with Reanult's Central America cartoon ''If our military advisers aren't successful, we bomb Hanoi and mine Haiphong; then we defoliate Danang and Hue and we set up strategic hamlets here around Saigon.''

title: MUSIC SERIES OF THE NEW AT JUILLIARD
description: The Juilliard School's Festival of Contemporary Music came to a rousing close Friday night at Alice Tully Hall with an orchestral program by Gerhard Samuel and the Juilliard Symphony that offered three premieres. But after the last echo had abated, the evening seemed as much the conclusion of a two-part Donald Martino festival. Mr. Martino's music had been showcased on a League-I.S.C.M. program the previous night, and his Cello Concerto (1978) easily dominated Friday's proceedings.

title: Home Clinic; HOT-WATER HEATER A BIG ENERGY USER, BUT WASTE CAN BE AVERTED
description: STUDIES have shown that, in many homes in this area, the second biggest consumer of energy is the hot-water heater (the first is the central heating system).

title: Cooney, Norton in Accord
description: The managers of Gerry Cooney and Ken Norton agreed yesterday that the bout between the heavyweights would take place late next month or early in April. They expect the winner will get a shot at the World Boxing Council title held by Larry Holmes.

title:
OPINION;
WHERE WILL WE PUT ALL THE OLD PEOPLE
description: ALL the people who died last week in the fire at a boarding home for the elderly in Point Pleasant Beach, as well as those who died in earlier fires in Bradley Beach and Keansburg, were old, most were poor, some were mentally retarded or senile, many were bereft of family and none could really speak up for themselves.

title: REGIONS EUROPE: CAN THATCHERISM SURVIVE BRITISH SLUMP?
description: LONDON WHEN Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher discusses the very serious economic recession that Britain is experiencing, she often employs homely metaphors to explain her conviction that better times must follow, if only the course is held true.

title: Long Island Journal
description: MUM'S the word for Valentine's Day, which will be celebrated next Saturday. ''With the high prices of roses,'' said Mary Berson, owner of Giese Florist in Hicksville, ''I'm encouraging my customers to buy locally grown chrysanthemums this year.''

title: Theater in Review; 'MANCHA' RESTS ON LAURELS
description: GLEN COVE IF you haven't seen ''Man of La Mancha'' before, the Northstage Theater-Restaurant revival should suffice as a facsimile of a once majestic musical. After all, the original director, Albert Marre, is in charge and the cast consists of ''La Mancha'' veterans, some of whom have served on continual active duty in one company or another for more than a decade. All's well on paper.

title: A NANNY IN ARABIA
description: THE PRINCE AND I By Rosemarie Buschow. 250 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $12.95.

title: QUICK, BEFORE IT CRUMBLES: RUNNING ON THE WEST SIDE HIGHWAY
description: AS I trot up the Carlisle Street ramp, I hop over several months' accumulated trash. In the kaleidoscopic way that images come and go when you run, apprehension overtakes me.

title: Audrey Coxe, Travel Agent, Sets Nuptials
description: Mrs. Charles Eugene Kew of Greenwich, Conn., and Eckley B. Coxe 4th of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Audrey Owens Coxe, to Lawrence Hayden Cadwallader, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Cadwallader of Greenwich.

title:
Gardening;
GOVERNMENT STUDIES AID HOME GARDENER
description: THE years of the Lincoln Presidency were so dominated by the Civil War that many other achievements of that period are often ignored. This is true in the field of agriculture, in which decisions were made that are still contributing toward making our agriculture the most prosperous and our population the best fed of any nation.

title: Louisiana State 94 Mississippi State 89
description: Rudy Macklin, a senior forward, and Howard Carter, a sophomore swing man, combined for 37 second-half points tonight that erased a halftime deficit and led Louisiana State to a 94-89 victory over Mississippi State.

title: CITY IS THE LATEST OWNER OF A 'POOR MAN'S PARADISE'
description: 472-4142. By JILL JONNES

title: SOUTH AFRICANS REACH A QUIET MILESTONE
description: In what was initially meant to be seen as a symbolic and even a political turning point, a racially mixed official council started discussions here this week on South Africa's constitutional future.

title: Amy M. Rosen Will Be Married March 7 To Timothy Carden, Aide to Gov. Byrne
description: Amy Maude Rosen of Lawrenceville, N.J., director of special transportation programs for the New Jersey Department of Transportation, and Timothy Loomis Carden of Trenton, cabinet secretary to Governor Byrne of New Jersey, plan to be married March 7.

title: TRANSITIONAL PAINS AT THE FORD FOUNDATION
description: Not long after he settled into his imposing office as the new president of the Ford Foundation, Franklin A. Thomas ordered blinds for the floor to ceiling windows and installed a screen of decorative planters. In the days of McGeorge Bundy, Mr. Thomas's predecessor, the curious had an unobstructed view of the president, who was frequently spotted with his feet on the desk in relaxed conversation.

title: Echoes, Icons and Moscow Relations
description: The message to Moscow was clear. ''It's not going to be business as usual,'' James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff said last week.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Once upon a time and not so long ago, the art that came out of Munich and Vienna before 1914 was in the very trough of fashion. If you had inherited a painting by Franz von Stuck, some graphic work by Kolo Moser or Carl Moll, or some pieces of Jugendstil furniture, your friends were embarrassed for you.

title: Ramapo College Article Draws Lively Responses
description: Michael Specter's article on Ramapo College (Jan. 18) seemed to cry out for additional comment about that institution during its exciting formative years (1972-74).

title: MUSIC
description: In the late 60's, Philip Glass formed his own ensemble and began to write all his music for it. Akin to a rock band, the ensemble used electronic or amplified instruments and remained small enough to tour and make money for its members.

title: FEAR OF CRIME IS CREATING TEAR GAS BOOM ON COAST
description: In California these days, strangers can be found any night of the week clustered around instructors who tell them, ''Aim for the eyes.'' Employers are offering enrollment in the classes as a new kind of fringe benefit. At dinner parties, people who used to spend all evening discussing the high cost of real estate here are comparing notes on their respective brands of tear gas.

title: Ruth-Ann Bernstein to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Bernstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ruth-Ann Bernstein, to Mitchell David Spaiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Spaiser of Riverdale, the Bronx. Mr. Bernstein is manager of production control and administration for NBC News. Mr. Spaiser's father is a building contractor in the Bronx.

title: Holman Beats Roth to Win U.S. Open Bowling by 21
description: Marshall Holman of Medford, Ore., took advantage of three consecutive open frames by Mark Roth to win the $131,000 United States Open bowling tournament today. First prize was $21,000.

title: Father of Kidnapped Girl Held for Staging Abduction
description: Sheriff's deputies yesterday arrested the father of a 17-month-old girl kidnapped three days ago and released unharmed and charged that he had staged the abduction, possibly as a publicity stunt.

title: LOW INTEREST TO FARMERS RAISING PRICES
description: While much of the nation's economy has been chilled by record interest rates, one group has been well insulated from the rise in the cost of money: farmers.

title: British Columbia Phone Workers Occupy Offices in Contract Fight
description: Union workers are occupying major offices of the British Columbia Telephone Company in a protest over stalled contract talks.

title: REAGAN AND THE WORLD
description: After less than three weeks in office, the Reagan Administration finds itself in a political confrontation with the Soviet Union and facing potential crises in Poland and El Salvador even before it has had time to put together a comprehensive program for dealing with the dozens of other foreign policy problems demanding answers.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Collegiate Spirit Gets Out of Hand
description: When first-place Ohio State's hockey team visited second-place Northern Michigan for a two-game series last weekend, the matchup was billed as a pivotal encounter of the Central Collegiate Hockey Association season.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ACAPULCO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ALAN RIDING is chief of the Mexico City bureau of The New York Times. By ALAN RIDING

title: REGIONS AFRICA: ZIMBABWE'S PEACE BRINGS PROBLEMS
description: AFTER 15 years of contending with international sanctions and decades of civil war, the economy of this African country, formerly called Rhodesia, was unshackled last year amid conditions of relative peace and huge pent up demand for goods and services.

title: Rose Colombosian, Helped Start First Yogurt Plant in the Nation
description: Rose Krikorian Colombosian, who with her husband founded the first yogurt manufacturing plant in the nation, died Wednesday.

title: REPORTS ON POLISH LABOR UNREST SCARE OFF MANY FOREIGN VISITORS
description: Wieslaw Wilk paid a visit to the Sheraton Hotel in New York last April and the manager told him that a strike by the hotel staff was expected.

title: Antiques; THE WHIMSICAL DUMMY BOARD
description: Dummy boards - two-dimensional wooden figures of people or pets painted to effect the look of three-dimensional carvings - were popular from the 17th through the 19th century, at first in Europe and later in America. These figures, which served a variety of utilitarian and decorative purposes, may soon become as much in demand again, this time with collectors who are occasionally finding them in shops, at antiques shows and at auctions. For the charm and folk-art appeal of these whimsies is immediate and undeniable. A major reason is that they are classic examples of the artistic device known as trompe l'oeil - they do indeed fool the eye. The only problem posed for enthusiasts is finding dummy boards: as far as is known, few appear to have been made in this country and fewer still survive.

title: Thanks for Good Advice, And Is There Any More?
description: It's taken me four weeks to understand that the first part of The Sunday Times I now turn to is the Opinion section of the Westchester Weekly, and I'll bet you'd like to know why.

title: Livio Caroli, Oboist, Plays Some Rarely Heard Music
description: Livio Caroli, an oboist from Italy now living in New York, made his solo debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Monday night, but in fact, Mr. Caroli is new neither to the performing stage nor to this city's audiences. He has served as principal player with orchestras in Rome, Venice and Milan, and is very active as a player and teacher in New York.

title: 36 Food Places Named By City for Violations; Of Health Regulations
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 36 food establishments found to be violating health code regulations. The report, by Commissioner Renaldo Ferrer, also listed seven establishments that had been reopened following correction of earlier violations. The establishments are: VIOLATIONS Ray's Lunch, 61 Canal St. Hing Lung Bakery, 54 Mulberry St. Pete Smith Bar, Whitehall Terminal, Staten Island Ferry Stadium Cafe, 3359 Broadway. Leo Lindy's, 380 Lexington Ave. Wunam Kitchen, 806 Second Ave. Toyo Restaurant, 306 Fifth Ave. Classic Food Shop, 530 Seventh Ave. Alpine Tavern, 871 Seventh Ave. Atika Restaurant, 12 E. 44th St. La Chaumiere, 310 W. 44th St. Pauline's Restaurant, 43 W. 39th St. Isla Verde Bakery, 2407A Grand Concourse, Bronx. Tropic A Gogo, 896 Hunts Point Ave., Bronx. San Martin Quisquera, 243 Willis Ave., Bronx. Veterans Luncheonette, 536 E. 168th St., Bronx. B & B Lunch, 761 E. 169th St., Bronx. Apples Coffee Shop, 1911 Ave. M, Brooklyn. Sylvia's Coffee Shop, 501 Brighton Beach Ave., Brooklyn. Cuckoo's Nest, 2076 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. Underhill Luncheonette, 176 Underhill Ave., Brooklyn. 5th Ave. Bar, 8001 Fifth Ave., Brooklyn. Brian & Jack's, 6802 Eighth Ave., Brooklyn. John's Luncheonette, 47-46 Bell Blvd., Queens.

title: POWER STRUGGLE IN COMMON MARKET FOCUSES ON BUDGET
description: The Common Market is preparing to take the Governments of France, West Germany and Belgium to court for refusing to pay their full share of the community's 1981 budget approved last year by its new Parliament.

title: PLAY'S THEME:LESBIANS WITH OUT APOLOGY
description: JANE CHAMBERS is a playwright who speaks for the cause of women in general and lesbians in particular. Ask her which has been the greater obstacle in her life: her gender or her sexuality, and she answers: ''That's easy - judgments are based on seeing; one of the things about being gay that doesn't get in the way is that, most of the time, you can't see it, but being a woman is something you have to deal with every minute.''

title: LAWSUIT HALTS A DRUM AND BUGLE CORPS
description: AN internal power struggle has factionalized the Kingsmen Drum and Bugle Corps of Kings Park to the extent that many people fear that the future of what is generally regarded as one of the finest competitive drum corps in the state may be jeopardized.

title: DUKE'S FREE THROWS TOP MARYLAND,55-54
description: Tom Emma sank two free throws with three seconds remaining to lift Duke to 55-54 victory over Maryland in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game today.

title: Millrose Results; Track and Field; FRIDAY NIGHT; AT MADISON SQUARE GARDEN; WANAMAKER-MILLROSE GAMES Leading Track Events
description: Women's 60-Yard Hurdles - 1, Benita F itzgerald, Tennessee, 7.80 seconds; 2, S haron Colyear, Boston University, 0 :07.82; 3, Candy Young, F.D.U., :007.85; 4 , Stephanie Hightower, Columbus, Ohio, 0 :07.95; 5, Carol Lewis, Willingboro T.C., 0 :07.97 Men's 60-Yard High Hurdles - 1, Re- n aldo Nehemiah, Athletic Attic, 6.98 sec- o nds; 2, Greg Foster, Muhammad Ali T .C., :007.05; 3, Rod Milburn, Houston A thletics, :007.15; 4, Dedy Cooper, Bay A rea Striders, :007.18; 5, Rod Wilson, Vil- l anova, :007.31 Women's 60-Yard Dash - 1, Chandra C heeseborough, Tennessee State, 6.6 sec- o nds; 2, Alice Brown, L.A. Shaklee T.C., 0 :06.6; 3, Brenda Morehead, Toledo, Ohio, 0 :06.6; 4, Michelle Glover, Willingboro T .C., :006.9. Men's 60-Yard Dash - 1, Stan Floyd, H ouston, Tex., 6.15 seconds; 2, Carl L ewis, U. of Houston, :006.21; 3, Emmit K ing, Tuscaloosa, Ala., :006.23; 4, Mel L attany, U. of Georgia, :006.24; 4, Harvey G lance, Auburn T.C., :006.25; 5, Herschel W alker, U. of Georgia, :006.29 C.H.S.A.A. Two-Mile Relay - 1, Lough- l in (George Baskins 2:05.6, Phil Gist 1 :59.4, Al Averhart 1:58.5, Ken Wilson 1 :54.7), 7 minutes 58.2 seconds (Millrose r ecord; previous record, 7:59.6, by L oughlin, 1975); 2, Holy Trinity, 8:01.7; 3, S t Anthony's, 8:03.5; 4, Molloy, 8:06.5; 5, S pellman, 8:06.7 500-Yard Run - 1, Ed Yearwood, Long I sland Alliance, 55.5 seconds (Millrose r ecord; previous record, 0:56, by Bert C ameron, 1980; Garden record; previous r ecord. 0:55.8, by Jim Kemp, 1967); 2, S tanley Redwine, U. of Arkansas, 0:55.7; 3 , Herman Frazier, Philadelphia Pioneer, 0 :56.4; 4, Kevin Jones, Northwood Insti- t ute, 056.8; 5, Kevin Price, Long Island Al- l iance, 0:57.

title: EAST BERLIN SOFTENS ATTITUDES ON BONN
description: Four months after straining East-West relations with curbs on border crossings, the East Germans have begun to send out small signals indicating that they want to reopen a dialogue with West Germany.

title: Lucy G. Gelb To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Gelb of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Gates Gelb, to Frank M. Sisto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Sisto of Clifton, N.J.

title:
TV View;
'ENACTING' THE KENT STATE TRAGEDY
description: In the beginning, the ABC-TV project was called ''Kent State: A Requiem'' and was scheduled to run for four hours over two nights. This evening at 8, the production emerges simply as ''Kent State,'' and, reduced to three hours, it will be shown in one sitting. The change in title is significant. ''A Requiem'' suggests an element of editorializing. Although the producers are clearly outraged by the killing of four Kent State students by National Guardsmen during an antiwar demonstration in May 1970, an effort has been made to place the tragedy in broad perspective. The time was one of escalating emotions on all sides. Breaking developments in the Vietnam War and domestic protests generated their own terrible momentum, sweeping up both involved and innocent bystanders as so many pawns in an inescapable drama.

title: 'ROMEO AND JULIET' OPENS BALLET SEASON
description: PETER MARTINS has performed many of the full-length classics, but never ''Romeo and Juliet.'' ''It's the one last thing left for me,'' said the 35-year-old dancer, noting, ''you don't want to do Romeo when you're 40.''

title: CRAFTS
description: NEWARK ''SCULPTURE in Clay From Puerto Rico,'' an exhibition now on view at the Newark Museum, proclaims the island's new vitality in ceramics. The 40 pieces here represent the work of 13 members of Grupo Mano, a San Juan artists' collective that has evolved in the last decade and recently gained international recognition.

title: Florida Has Highest Percentage Of Elderly Residents, Study Says
description: Florida leads the nation in the percentage of residents who are 65 years old or older, but California and New York have the highest numbers of elderly residents, according to a study.

title: OVER 70:WHO'S WHO
description: Many executives over 70 exert great control over their companies, most of them as chief executives. They include: Edward Ball, 92, St. Joe Paper.

title: No Headline
description: Sally Ogle Davis and others imply that the themes of ''women's films'' (i.e., friendship, love, parenthood) are secondary to our lives and of interest only to women, but our society can only benefit when we raise love and tenderness to the same level as power and violence.

title: Westchester Guide; TARRYTOWN CONCERTS
description: One of the best music bargains in the county is a $20 subscription to concerts sponsored by the 32-year-old Sleepy Hollow Concert Association. The next offering is a recital by Emanuel Ax at 8:30 P.M. Saturday in the Washington Irving High School, Tarrytown, where the accoustics are exceptionally good from any seat in the house.

title: Homosexuals March in Toronto After Police Raid 4 Steam Baths
description: About a thousand demonstrators for homosexual rights marched down Toronto's main street early today, disrupting traffic and briefly besieging a police station to protest the arrest of 253 men in raids on steam baths.

title: THE NORDHAUS CURE FOR INFLATION
description: To the Business Editor: Experience tells us that Professor Nordhaus's proposed remedy of fighting inflation by producing slack in the economy also must be removed from the ''shelf of anti-inflation medicines.''

title: NORTH STARS TIE ISLANDERS AT 5-5
description: Steve Christoff scored his second goal of the game at 18 minutes 41 seconds of the third period to give the Minnesota North Stars a 5-5 tie with the Islanders tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Harvard
description: To the Business Editor: In ''New at Harvard: Self-Assessment 101'' (Feb. 1), I find it most interesting that the Harvard Business School would toy with the disciplinary contexts for studying and doing business - that growth out there should be related to psychological economy. And, that growth inside - psychological development, personal profit and domestic enrichment - should be a legitimate context for business and even determine an alternative teaching method based on sharing and consciousness.

title: REPORT ON STUDENT FAILURES STIRS NEW CONCERN ON SCHOOLS IN CAOITAL
description: Despite several years of concerted effort to improve public schools in the nation's capital, two recent developments have raised serious questions about the future of public education here.

title: Miss Griffith of Adelphi Excels in Princeton Relays
description: June Griffith, winner of the 400-meter run in the Millrose Games last night, anchored Adelphi University to a gold-medal performance in the sprint medley and a silver-medal effort in the 880 at the third Princeton University women's relays today at Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Bell Says No to Bilingual Rules
description: Calling them ''harsh, inflexible, burdensome, unworkable and incredibly costly,'' Secretary of Education Terrel H. Bell last week withdrew Federal rules on bilingual education proposed by President Carter. The regulations, which had already been frozen by Congress until June, would have required school districts with more than 25 foreign-speaking students to provide instruction in their native languages as well as in English, at a estimated five-year cost of $1 billion.

title: N.C.A.A. Is Called Hungry for Power
description: To the Sports Editor: I wholeheartedly agree with Candace Lyle Hogan when she writes: ''What the N.C.A.A. voted to give women was less than what women already had.'' (''Female Athletes: More to Lose Than Just Their Organization,'' The New York Times, Jan. 25).

title: Behind the Best Sellers; MICHAEL CRICHTON
description: Even before Michael Crichton wrote the first word of ''Congo,'' 20th Century-Fox thought enough of his story-telling ability to buy the movie rights. ''I didn't want to discuss the novel in detail, so I told them only that I was going to do an African adventure story,'' said Mr. Crichton during a recent visit to New York from his home in Los Angeles.

title: YOUTH PROJECTS GROW IN PLEASANTVILLE
description: PLEASANTVILLE LAST weekend, a group of seventh and eighth graders from Pleasantville Middle School beat the village police officers - at basketball that is, in a match organized by Del LeFevre, the Police Department's youth officer, and Terry Geallis, a Recreation Department employee. Played at the middle school, the game represented one phase of this village's ongoing, multifaceted projects involving youth and community life.

title: RONALD REAGAN, ECONOMIST
description: Given what's been happening with inflation, the national debt, take-home pay and the like, it would perhaps be a good moment to elect a President who knows something about economics. It turns out that the man who was elected in November, while better known for his activities in Hollywood and Sacramento, is just such a man.

title:
Gardening;
GOVERNMENT STUDIES AID HOME GARDENER
description: THE years of the Lincoln Presidency were so dominated by the Civil War that many other achievements of that period are often ignored. This is true in the field of agriculture, in which decisions were made that are still contributing toward making our agriculture the most prosperous and our population the best fed of any nation.

title: Flames 5, Penguins 4
description: Willi Plett scored the winning goal with 53 seconds left to play.

title: WEATHERIZATION:DON'T OVERDO IT, SAY CONTRACTORS
description: The wallpaper was stained and peeling. There were splotches on the bedroom ceiling. Rafters in the attic were discolored and some beams showed clear signs of rot. All indications pointed to a leaky roof.

title: PAUL T. HASKELL
description: Paul T. Haskell, vice president of the Foreign Credit Insurance Association, died Tuesday at Memorial Hospital in Morristown, N.J. Mr. Haskell, who lived in Convent Station, N.J., was 63 years old.

title: Dance View; AVANT-GARDE IN RUSSIA, 1913
description: ''Victory Over the Sun,'' an avant-garde Cubo -Futurist opera presented in Russia in 1913, is not an opera in the conventional sense. Kazimir Malevich designed the Cubist-style costumes and the back cloths. Mikhail Matiushin composed music that was meant occasionally to be sung off pitch by actors who recited more than they sang. Aleksei Kruchenykh wrote a text and Velimir Khlebnikov wrote a prologue, both of which were fragmented, out of syntax, or emphasized units of sound. All these men were leading figures in Russian modernism.

title: PRESERVING THE HOMES WHERE O'NEILL LIVED AND WORKED
description: Eugene O'Neill's family cottage in Connecticut is being lovingly restored, complete with an old O'Neill rocking chair. The rickety stage in Provincetown, Mass., where his plays were first performed, is to have a modern successor, a new Provincetown Playhouse combined with a Eugene O'Neill Archival Center. A continent away, the playwright's tile-roofed California villa has been taken over by the National Park Service and awaits renovation to become a magnet for his admirers.

title: ANN FREEDMAN, E.R. SPOONT, DENTISTS TO Be WED IN JUNE
description: The engagement of Dr. Ann R. Freedman to E. Robert Spoont, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Spoont of Key Largo, Fla., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Freedman of East Hills, L.I., parents of the prospective bride.

title:
Long Island Housing;
ENERGY DEVICES GET TESTS IN HOMES
description: LAST winter, Wendy Burnett, a real-estate agent in Water Mill, received an unusual request from a client - find four homes that could be rented over the winter. The homes would not be occupied, the client said, but the heat would be kept on at all times.

title: REGIONS MIDDLE EAST: SOARING INFLATION SHAKES ISRAELI SOCIETY
description: JERUSALEM IN the 1960's, Levi Eshkol, Israel's late Prime Minister, is said to have remarked that the problem with Israelis is that they wanted to live like Americans but not to work like them. The tale may well be apocryphal, but if it described Israelis 15 years ago, it could also describe the inflationary mood here today: Israelis wish inflation would subside, but none appear prepared to make the necessary sacrifices.

title: MANHATTAN LAWYER A JUSTICE PROSPECT
description: A 36-year-old New York lawyer, Rudolph Giuliani, is reportedly one of two front-runners for a major Justice Department post, assistant attorney general in charge of the Criminal Division.

title: COLLEGE TRIES TO CORRECT DEFICIT
description: NEWARK OFFICIALS of Essex County College are scrambling to meet a stateimposed deadline of Feb. 16 that calls for resolving a budget deficit that may reach $1.3 million by June 30.

title: TUITION VINES LINES; Double Jeopardy
description: For Government to pay tuition tax credits, says Terrel H. Bell, the new Secretary of Education, is a matter of ''fairness and equity.'' Why? Because parents who send their children to private schools are ''in effect, paying twice for education.

title: Index; International
description: Around the World 4 East Germany easing tough stance toward West 5 British Commissioner in Canada issues warning on constitution 6 Britons are urged to mind their p's and q's 8 Irish praise 'honesty' of diplomat recalled by U.S. 9 Iraqi troops pause outside Iranian city to await outcome of parley 10 Manila beautifies a slum section for Pope's visit 11 Tensions in Poland cause drop in foreign tourism 14 Government/Politics Reagan playing key role in per- sonnel changes 19 Senate Democrats tell of new alle- gation against Labor Secretary 21 Bias suit against U.S. a test for Reagan Administration 25 Overhaul of New York liquor agency leadership urged 31 City proposes new measure to pro- tect tenants of lofts 37 Carey says state will test Japa- nese buses 38 Metropolitan area Congressmen to head subcommittees 52 Health/Science Five specimens of rare Japanese crested ibis captured 22 Progress in life expectancy falters in poor nations 23 General Around the Nation 24 Reporters challenge a proposal at Bar Association convention 27 Los Angeles looking for new dumping sites 29 A company cited for dumping toxic wastes plans health tests 32 Ghana asked to send home a diplo- mat's son implicated in rapes 33 Two persons die in a Jersey City fire and three are missing 36 Education/Welfare New troubles befall Washington, D.C., schools 28 Return of hostages continues to at- tract gifts for neediest 48 Arts/Entertainment ''Caddie'' opens at the Plaza 53 Music debuts in review 54 ''The Earthling'' on Guild screen 55 Style How's she doin'? It's all sister- hood 56 Dault-Millau guide upgrades two restaurants 56 News Analysis Bernard Gwertzman examines Reagan's foreign policy goals 1 Drew Middleton on Soviet-Ameri- can strategic arms spending 17

title: COURSE OF BIAS CASE TESTS REAGAN STAND
description: The Reagan Administration, in its first major decision on a civil rights case, is scheduled to tell a Federal judge Monday whether it intends to accept the terms on which the Carter Administration settled a job discrimination suit filed against the Federal Government by a group of blacks and Hispanic Americans.

title: Making It in Washington
description: Lynn Rosellini claims Jimmy Carter ''never even understood the rules of Washington's social scene (''A Capital Game of Power,'' Jan. 4). I think he understood them only too well and chose not to participate, even though not cozying up to the ''right people'' probably cost him the election more than any other factor. If such shallowness is so all important in Washington, it proves to me that Jimmy Carter is the one who has ''class'' for not running the country by such seedy little ''rules.'' GERALDINE GIBBS, Toledo

title: OUT OF ONE FRYING PAN, NONALIGNED GATHER ANEW
description: Twenty years after it was first scored as a sort of harmonic theme for chamber ensemble, the nonaligned movement has evolved into a dissonant and even cacaphonous piece for a swollen orchestra with augmented brass. With nearly 100 foreign ministers gathering to offer their own interpretations tomorrow, the result is certain to sound more like John Cage or Spike Jones than Beethoven.

title: Boxing to Feel Effects of Scandal
description: There are boxing people and fans who feel that passing scandals cannot seriously smirch a sport that has thrived in a state of sullied reputation for as long as punches have been thrown for pay in this country. A man enjoying a mudbath is intrepid when threatened with mudslinging.

title: Rebecca Ritter and Kenneth Daniels Will Be Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warren Edward Ritter of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca de Loache Ritter, to Kenneth Steven Daniels of New York and Newton, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Daniels of Newton. A May wedding is planned in the Congregational Church of Manhasset.

title: REGIONS EUROPE: THE GERMAN LOCOMOTIVE LOSES STEAM
description: BONN AT the economic summit meeting of Western leaders here in 1978, West Germany staunchly resisted calls for it to use its head of economic steam like a locomotive to tug Europe's lagging economies out of the recession that the oil crisis of 1974 had induced.

title: A Cabinet Officer's Agenda
description: The detailing of the intractable minutiae facing a Cabinet officer on Day One is a first-class exercise in practical government (''Open Letter to a Cabinet Member,'' by Shirley M. Hufstedler, Jan. 11).

title: COST ANALYSIS NEEDS ANALYZING
description: W ITH the appointment two weeks ago of Murray Weidenbaum as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, ''cost-benefit analysis'' may become as identified with the Reagan Administration as ''zero-based budgeting'' was with its predecessor. Regulators, Professor Weidenbaum has prominently argued, should be required by law to prove that the measurable benefits of a proposed regulation exceed measurable costs.

title: PRODUCTIVITY: JAPAN HAS A BETTER WAY
description: A S American productivity growth has slipped from positive to negative, most of the public blame has focused on this or that government activity. But whatever part of the blame is truly ascribable to the government, and there is certainly some, it is clear that much of the productivity problem lies within the jurisdiction of the private sector. The productivity problem will only be cured if the private sector is willing to cure itself.

title: Article 255899 -- No Title
description: TO QUERY CALL: (201) 836-6852. By ELLEN RAND

title: THE STRUGGLE OF WOMEN DIRECTORS
description: In "The Struggle of Women Directors," you quote director Karen Arthur as having said, "She (Jane Fonda) told the woman who had directed her in a documentaruy ... on Vietnam ... that women shouldn't direct."

title: In Iran-Iraq War A Bombing Run Down Memory Lane
description: Since returning from exile near Paris two years ago, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has forgotten politesse, canceling French contracts worth billions of francs, including power plants and a Metro for Teheran. France jogged the Imam's memory last week by delivering four Mirage F-1 fighter-bombers to Iran's mortal enemy, Iraq.

title: Spanish Police Foil Bank Holdup
description: Two gunmen took five hostages in a suburban bank today before they were overpowered by the police. The authorities said no one was hurt and no money was taken by the men, who were apparently under the influence of drugs. The police said they met the gunmen's request for heroin and syringes but recovered them after the arrests.

title: THE NEW ALBUMS FROM DIAMOND AND MANILOW
description: T he latest albums by Neil Diamond and Barry Manilow, ultra-popular purveyors of pop schmaltz, are typically glittery products with mass appeal. Mr. Diamond's soundtrack for his first starring movie, ''The Jazz Singer'' (Capital SWAV-12120) is an expansive score that uses two orchestras, a choir and a rock band. The project embodies the contradictory ambitions that have plagued Mr. Diamond ever since he grew from a successful pop tunesmith into a superstar entertainer with artistic pretensions.

title:
Dining Out;
ONE OF THE BEST IN THE COUNTY,ALAS
description: LA CREMAILLERE in Banksville has enjoyed a very good press since it was taken over in 1962 by the owners of Manhattan's La Caravelle. Those were heady days for La Caravelle: only a few years later, after the demise of Le Pavillon, a leading guide to dining would call it ''the finest restaurant in New York on almost every count.'' With the changes in ownership at La Cremaillere, Westchesterites had a vision of being only a lazy pastoral drive away from a French restaurant of the highest standards.

title: PISANI PERSEVERS ON SMOKE DETECTORS
description: ALBANY AFTER 15 years in legislative office, Senator Joseph R. Pisani, Republican-Conservative of New Rochelle, says he has learned the value of ''compromise,'' although he prefers to use the word negotiate.

title: MONITORING EARTHQUAKES
description: AS far as earthquakes are concerned, living in Westchester County may not be nearly as risky as, say, living on the San Andreas fault in California, but there have been enough tremors in the area in the last year or so to make seismologists question past assumptions.

title: Animal League's Position Described
description: As president of the League for Animal Protection, and as one personally involved in the situation described in the recent article about our organization (''Controversy Arises Over League's Power to Seize Animals''), I must be allowed to refute misconceptions detailed therein.

title: POP: MAXENE ANDREWS
description: When Maxene Andrews, once of the Andrews Sisters, started her solo act a year and a half ago, she acquired Phil Campanella as a piano accompanist. But, with Mr. Campanella, she got much more than an accompanist. She also got a very talented comedian who helped her make her act much more than just another nostalgic journey to the 30's and 40's.

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVES AT 70: REAGAN HAS LOTS OF COMPANY
description: H ENRY G. WALTER Jr., the chairman and chief executive of International Flavors and Fragrances Inc. since 1963, rides a bicycle across Manhattan to work most mornings. Mr. Walter, a tall, athletic man wearing a yellow sweater bright enough to shame a canary, paces around his office while speaking of energy and vision. ''The election of a man that age,'' says Mr. Walter, ''has got to help us old folks.''

title: Royal Help for a Democratic Cause
description: Required by Spain's two-year-old democratic Constitution to name a successor to Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez, King Juan Carlos last week postponed a long-planned trip to the United States to await the result of deliberations by the Suarez party, the Union of the Democratic Center.

title: SOME SIGNPOSTS ON THE ROAD TO COLLEGE
description: ''I THINK my daughter didn't get into Yale because of her teeth,'' the woman said with a sigh. ''I told her to take care of her teeth. Or maybe she wasn't poised enough. What do you think?''

title: Ashley Smith Affianced to Andrew Mikell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ramon Thorp Smith of Canton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ashley Bartlett Smith, to Andrew Davis Mikell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Mikell of Williston, Vt.

title: POLICE INCREASE EFFORTS TO PROTECT SOVIET ENVOYS FROM HARASSMENT
description: The New York City Police Department has set up a special task force of about a dozen plainclothes officers and intelligence agents in an effort to curb the growing harassment of Soviet diplomats in the city.

title: TREES MAKE GOOD NEIGHBORS
description: ISTAND at my window every day now and watch him. Without fail he is at it. With every swing of his ax, every hiss of his saw, anger and frustration swell inside me. I feel as if I'm about to burst into violence at his profane destruction of my land and home.

title: No Headline
description: A proposal for a model state law governing public access to official records has emerged as one of the biggest issues at the American Bar Association's winter convention here.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IN WHAT was regarded as an unusual environmental project, a team of eight faculty members and students at Jersey City State College has completed a year's study on the possibility of restoring the lake in North Hudson Park in North Bergen.

title: PCB Pollution Is Found In State Office Building
description: Tests conducted by the State Health Department show extensive PCB contamination in the 18-story state office building here, officials said today.

title: FOOD BUILDS CHARACTER' MOVIE MAKERS DISCOVER Times'
description: Whether as ''Caterer,'' ''Food Designer'' or ''Gastronomic Technical Adviser,'' the names of people who provide on-camera edibles may soon be permanent fixtures in the growing list of screen credits that follow the film. Not long ago, the Cafe Royal in London and a host of other haute cuisine concerns took bows for the food that became a menu for murder in ''Who Is Killing the Great Chefs of Europe?'' Soon, audiences may routinely learn who put the hamburger, as well as the foie gras, under the klieg lights.

title: Tennessee Sets Back Kentucky
description: Dale Ellis, who did not start tonight after having missed a practice, scored 22 points as a reserve and led Tennessee to an 87-71 Southeastern Conference victory over Kentucky.

title: AN ALTERNATIVE TO RAPPROCHEMENT WITH TEHERAN
description: To the Editor:

title: RESCUING THE MANNHEIM MUSIC
description: The German city of Mannheim must have been an exciting spot for musicians between 1743 and 1778. During those years of Karl Theodor von Sulzbach's rule as Elector Palatine, the Mannheim court orchestra was famous throughout Europe for its unprecedented virtuosity and brilliance. While it may not be historically correct to say that the modern symphony orchestra was actually born in mid-18th-century Mannheim, that city was the scene of extraordinary changes in orchestral technique and compositional styles, developments that were to affect the course of musical history. Despite the importance of the music written for the Mannheim court orchestra, little of it is actually played today in live concert. As with so much neglected repertory these days, recordings come to the rescue, in this case a boxed set called ''The Mannheim School'' featuring the Camerata Bern (Archiv 2723 068, three disks).

title: CROSS-SOUND FERRY SERVICE: TIME TO EXPAND
description: WHILE there are grounds to disagree with specifics of a recent bleak five-year economic forecast for Long Island, no one will argue with the observation that the Island is a costly transportation ''dead end.'' Time-consuming traffic congestion through New York City and on the Throgs Neck and Whitestone Bridges is an expensive impediment to business and an aggravation for every driver who, for whatever reason, travels off the Island.

title: ART PIQUES A COMMUNITY'S INTEREST IN ITSELF
description: KEYPORT TED MILLER wanted to inspire an entire community to care about its history, but the right opportunity had not come along. He thought about how to involve his neighbors and interest residents of the surrounding area in celebrating the 150th anniversary of Keyport, once a great seaport town whose roots dip down to the Revolutionary War.

title: No Headline
description: It is ironic that Douglas S. Cramer, who said directing ''is a very, very tough job ... a merciless, constant pounding'' and who doubted ''if a woman could stand up to it,'' is the same man who produced ''Wonder Woman.'' TOM WATSON, Syracuse

title: D. S. Waskover to Wed Pamela Weisfeld April l2
description: Pamela Weisfeld, a buyer of children's accessories and girls' furnishings for Bloomingdale's, and Donald S. Waskover, an assistant court administrator for the Superior Court of New Jersey in Bergen County, plan to be married April 12.

title: Children's Books
description: GUNNER'S RUN By Rebecca Orr. 150 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $8.95. (Ages 10 to 13) By ARLENE M.PILLAR

title: REGIONS NORTH AMERICA: CANADA:POOR PROSPECTS AND FRAGILE UNITY
description: CALGARY, ALBERTA IT was the start of an evening of car races here not long ago when the track announcer asked the spectators to rise for the recorded playing of the national anthem, ''O Canada.'' Not five seconds into the solemn song there was a jarring scratching sound as the record needle was lifted. ''You all know the rest,'' the announcer said, dispensing with the national formality. ''Now on with the races.''

title: General Bradley Leaves Hospital
description: General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, the nation's only living five-star general, was released yesterday from the Beaumont Army Medical Center at Fort Bliss, where he had been treated for a mild viral infection. General Bradley, who lives at the fort, will be 86 years old Thursday.

title: THE NORDHAUS CURE FOR INFLATION
description: To the Business Editor: Prof. William Nordhaus, in ''Inflation Remedies: Real and Make Believe'' (Jan. 25), labels as a genuine anti-inflation policy the inducing and maintaining of economic slack such as unemployment and excess capacity, while recognizing that such a policy costs $150 billion in lost output for each percentage point of inflation reduced.

title: Rally of 500 Protests Rent Rises
description: About 500 tenants supporting a call for a citywide rent strike gathered in Washington Square Park yesterday to protest rising rents and lack of heat. Leaflets were handed out asking tenants to support calls to roll back rents and eliminate fuel surcharges, ideas termed ''demagoguery at its lowest'' by Seymour Zuckerman, president of a landlord group.

title: UPS AND DOWNS OF FORDHAM RECRUITING
description: Perry Allen stretched his huge hand toward Tom Penders and sealed his son's decision to attend Fordham with a handshake. ''Now you have to live with me for four years, too,'' Mr. Allen said Friday night, obviously pleased that Jimmy, a 6-foot-7-inch forward on Norwalk High School's undefeated team, would be under Penders's tutelage.

title: COLLEGES IN A SHRINKING MARKET
description: THE University of Bridgeport has created a series of newspaper advertisements that explain, as a headline puts it, ''why our students actually have an advantage over those at Harvard, Columbia and Princeton.'' Sacred Heart University of Fairfield noted in its annual report that, among other achievements, ''we are the first university to win an award for academic advertising.'' And Central Connecticut State College in New Britain has cars in its parking lot that are adorned with blue and white bumper stickers reading, ''Support public higher education at C.C.S.C.''

title: HARVARD
description: To the Business Editor: As a guest lecturer in Prof. James G. Clawson's course last fall, I found the class rigorous and as engaging intellectually as emotionally. Meeting the students enrolled in the course can undermine the unfortunate stereotype often associated with the Harvard Business School.

title: WHAT MAKES AN ACTOR CHOOSE A CERTAIN ROLE?
description: REGEN KAKUTANI By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

title: Jerusalem Dig
description: To the Editor:

title: MANILA BEAUTIFIES SLUM FOR THE POPE
description: When Pope John Paul II visits the Tondo dockside slum here this month for what the church schedule of his visit calls an ''encounter of the Holy Father with the poor,'' he will speak to them from a large platform now being put up.

title: A FAMILY'S FIRST SKIING TRIP
description: MARTIN TOLCHIN is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times. By MARTIN TOLCHIN

title: New York Times Magazine February 8, 1981
description: William Safire 11 On Language Working Like Banshees Russell Baker 18 Sunday Observer On Top of the World Peter Ross Range 22 Thunder From the Right The New Right is a new political presence. Under Jesse Helms, it may flail the G.O.P. as well as traditional Democratic programs.

title: OUTLOOK: TOUGHENING ATTITUDES ON WORLD TRADE
description: WASHINGTON THE international trade negotiating agenda for 1981 and beyond is likely to be dominated by American demands for greater access to world markets where it has a competitive edge even as it seeks to protect some of its less competitive traditional manufacturing industries.

title: Stargazer's Almanac
description: Many astrologers probably chuckled along with the rest of your readers at Bruce Feirstein's spoof of mass-market astrology (''The Old Stargazer's Almanac,'' Jan. 4). However, significant research is being done by serious astrologers - not a few of whom hold degrees in psychology and related disciplines. After all, astrology is nothing if not the oldest method of probing the human psyche - and a remarkably accurate one at that. MARLENE MASINI RATHGEB, New York City

title: E.P.A. to Study Air in 7 Cities
description: The Environmental Protection Agency plans to spend $555,764 to sample air in seven cities to determine the effect on health. The cities are Houston; Cleveland; Bakersfield, Calif.; Granite City, Ill.; Tampa, Fla.; Riverside, Calif., and Owensboro, Ky.

title: ART SAMPLER
description: THERE are those who still believe that one of the principal roles of painting is to depict a recognizable image from life and experience. And then there are those - and many are painters - who believe that painting should be about painting and nothing else.

title: Jane Howard Fiancee of Clarence Martin Jr.
description: Jane Elizabeth Howard, who is in her second year at the Harvard Law School, and Clarence Augustus Martin Jr., a second-year student at the Duquesne Law School, plan to be married June 13 in Calvary Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh.

title: Judge Denies Bid by ABC News To Get Presley Autopsy Report
description: A Chancery Court judge has rejected an attempt by ABC News to obtain an autopsy report on Elvis Presley on the ground that the document is not a public record.

title: PLEASURE AND LOSS
description: HOUSEKEEPING By Marilynne Robinson. 219 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95. By LE ANNE SCHREIBER

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1981
description: International Labor turmoil in Poland grew with a call by independent trade union officials for a general strike in southwestern Poland tomorrow. Workers in other parts of the country were asked to stage one-hour work stoppages. Solidarity union officials said the general strike in Jelenia Gora and five neighboring provinces, including the copper-mining center of Legnica, would be called off only if the Government sent a delegation to negotiate grievances. (Page 1, Column 6.) Food is scarce in Moscow and in some provincial centers the shortage, especially of meat, is worse than it has been for several years. It is not clear whether shortages are worse on a national basis than a year ago, or the year before that. The food distribution system is so chaotic that while there are shortages in some regions, there are surpluses in others, but nowhere is food plentiful. (1:6.)

title: NORTH CAROLINA 79, FURMAN 64
description: Charlotte, N.C., Feb.7 (AP) -- North Carolina State, sparked by the outside shooting of Scott Parzych and key baskets by Thurl Bailey, overcame St. Joseph's, 47-42, tonight in the second game of the 23rd annual North-South tournament.

title: Robin Lens Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Karl Lens of Fair Lawn, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Lens, to Arthur M. Silverman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Silverman of West Orange, N.J. The future bride and her fiance are graduates of Syracuse University. She is an assistant buyer at Lord & Taylor in New York. Mr. Silverman is studying for a master's degree at the Boston University Graduate School of Business.

title: No Headline
description: Judy Rankin sank four short birdie putts for a four-under-par 68 today as she moved from fourth place into a tie for the lead with JoAnne Carner after three rounds of the $125,000 Elizabeth Arden tournament.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: On Language; WORKING LIKE BANSHEES
description: Working Like Banshees Kimble Mead

title:
Photography View;
DOCUMENTS OF A VANISHING PAST
description: Facing each other from opposite walls of the Witkin Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, are the photographs of Wright Morris and Manuel Alvarez Bravo (through Feb. 7). Morris and Alvarez are both in their 70's now, and each has achieved considerable renown, Morris being perhaps even better known as a novelist than as a photographer. But what a difference in their work: Alvarez all Mexican passion and morbidity, Wright all Midwestern restraint and rectitude.

title: Ikle Is Picked for Defense Post
description: President Reagan plans to nominate Fred C. Ikle to be Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, the White House announced today. Mr. Ikle, 56 years old, who served as a foreign policy adviser to Mr. Reagan in the 1980 Presidential campaign, headed the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency in the Nixon and Ford Administrations.

title: NancyJane Falk And Dean Rosow To Marry in June
description: Mrs. Arthur L. Falk of New York and West Hartford, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, NancyJane Falk, to Dean A. Rosow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Rosow of West Hartford. A June wedding is planned.

title: 4 Flxibles Removed From Service By a Connecticut Transit System
description: Four Grumman Flxible buses are being taken out of service by the Southeast Regional Transit system because of defects like those that have halted the use of Flxibles elsewhere.

title: I can only conclude that Mr. Specter thinks that innovative and experimental are synonymous with static and inflexible. By what logic can he imply that fealty to the Ramapo mission can best be demonstrated by slavishly following a 1960's formula, by disregarding the fact that society changes, that an institution should be sensitive and responsive to those changes?
description: Mr. Specter would have better spent his time speaking to members of the current Board of Trustees, who might have enlightened him, rather than to persons no longer involved in decision-making at Ramapo or to those who have not had sufficient experience there to have the historical perspective Mr. Specter attempted to portray.

title:
DINIG OUT;
New Role for Old Railroad Station
description: EVEN though the Englewood railroad station has not seen a train for almost 30 years, commuters and others are flocking to it once again since its conversion into a sophisticated new restaurant.

title: Lawyer Is Fiance Of Lauren Richman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harold Richman of West Hartford, Conn. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Jane Richman, to Joel P. Trachtman, an associate with the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling.

title: REAGAN AIDES SEEK SHARP CUTBACKS TO MAKE AMTRAK MORE SELF-SUFFICIENT
description: President Reagan's budget analysts have proposed stringent new requirements to make Amtrak more self-supporting that could lead to the elimination of many train lines while increasing ticket prices by as much as 400 percent. The tentative plan was prepared by the Office of Management and Budget as part of an effort to bring about sharp reductions in Federal outlays. At the heart of the Amtrak plan is an attemp to make riders on the national railway pay more for service and to reduce the need for a Federal subsidy to keep the trains running in the next five years.

title: CITY PAPER UNIONS SEEK BIG INCREASES
description: In newspaper negotiations just getting under way, unions representing nearly 10,000 employees on New York City's three major dailies say they will be seeking big pay increases to bolster wage scales eroded by inflation.

title: TALKS ABOUT THE PATH TO SUCCESS
description: NEWARK FOR George Theophilus Walker of Montclair, whose latest work, ''In Praise of Folly,'' will be given its premiere Thursday by the New York Philharmonic under Zubin Mehta, success has not come in a rush, nor was it easily won.

title: COURT UPHOLDS U.S. ON SEIZURE OF SWINDLER IN BAHAMAS
description: A Federal appeals court has refused to free a man who complained that Government agents kidnapped him in the Bahamas and brought him back to the United States to serve a sentence for defrauding a brokerage firm.

title: REGIONS LATIN AMERICA: BANK CRISIS A KEY TEST IN ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES THE scene outside an Argentine bank late last year was a familiar one, with lines of depositors pushing anxiously forward to read the note taped to the locked doors: ''The Central Bank of the Republic of Argentina,'' the note read, ''has ordered the liquidation of DAR Savings and Loan Association by Resolution 400 of date 23 December 1980. The deposits of those who extended them enjoy the gaurantee established by Article 56, Section B of the law of financial entities.''

title: DRESDEN'S SALVAGED TREASURES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- FARNSWORTH FOWLE, a freelance writer, is a retired New York Times reporter and correspondent. By FARNSWORTH FOWLE

title: QUOTATION
description: ''I think the prices stink. Reagan's just paying back the guys who backed him.'' - Charles Blaugh, a Brooklyn Mercedes Benz owner, commenting Tuesday on the higher gasoline prices caused by deregulation of crude oil.

title: EXHIBIT HONORS A RARE ARTISAN
description: HADLYME OPENING a small white leather binding in his Hadlyme workshop, Arno Werner, an 82-year-old bookbinder of the old school, showed it was empty. He ran his palm over the perfectly preserved 16th-century tooling and shook his head. ''These dealers,'' he said, ''they buy up the old books, take all the pages out and sell them individually for a fortune.''

title: Film View; WHEN PUZZLES BECOME PROVOCATIVE
description: What would drive a man to murder a prostitute who resembled his wife? That's the riddle of ''From The Life of the Marionettes,'' a movie that, like so many current films, has a question at its very heart and deliberately leaves that question unanswered. What would prompt a young girl, in ''Les Bons Debarras,'' to drive her half-wit uncle to suicide? Why would a mother, like the mother in ''Ordinary People,'' love one son so much more than she loves the other? What keeps a writer, in ''Like a Turtle On Its Back,'' from being able to write?

title: A VALENTINE SELECTION OF BONS MOTS
description: LAST Valentine's Day, instead of fattening my body with chocolates from a heart-shaped box, I decided to enrich my mind with heartsprinkled poetry. I discovered a feast of allusions to that anatomical pump, deliciously confusing and paradoxical, more than enough to sate the most voracious literary appetite.

title: OVERHAUL IS URGED FOR LIQUOR AGANCY
description: After a two-and-half-hour interrogation of New York State's Liquor Authority chairman, State Senator Roy M. Goodman said last week that it was ''imperative to have a major overhaul'' of the agency's leadership.
