title: Art View; BRONZE MAKES A COMEBACK
description: Is the art of sculpture entering upon a new age of bronze? It is beginning to look that way. Some older sculptors long identified with other media have lately been returning to this venerable material - one of the most ancient in the entire history of human culture - and a new generation of sculptors appears to be taking to it with enthusiasm. Two months ago Anthony Caro, whose abandonment of bronze for painted steel some 20 years ago marked one of the decisive artistic shifts of the 1960's, turned up in New York with a large exhibition of elegant bronze sculptures. Now the Hamilton Gallery, 20 West 57th Street, has mounted an exhibition of 15 contemporary sculptors who, though very different in the styles they employ, have in common the fact that they are currently working in bronze. Some of them are clearly new converts to the medium.

title: INDONESIA: A GLUT OF VOLCANOES AND MANY RITUALS
description: Every year Mount Merapi on the island of Java erupts. Sometimes it spews fiery clouds of gases into the air and overflows with streams of bubbling molten rock, driving wild pigs into the lower jungles, turning rivers miles away into cocoa-colored torrents and devastating lush tropical terrain. Other times, Merapi only belches, shudders and settles down.

title: Steve Scott Posts A World Best in 2,000-Meter Run
description: Steve Scott broke the world indoor mark for the 2,000-meter run tonight with a time of 4 minutes 58.5 seconds at the Mason-Dixon Games.

title: Sasetru Ruled Bankrupt
description: Sasetru, Argentina's largest industrial and financial conglomerate, has been ordered to file for bankruptcy, ending efforts by private Argentine and foreign banks to supervise a more gradual and less costly liquidation.

title: A Bar Mitzvah 'First'
description: When Lyle Jay Kellman reached bar mitzvah age in 1963, his parents were going through a divorce, so the bar mitzvah was set aside. Now, however, the young man is about to make up for lost time and in an unusual way.

title: Landlords Penalized On Heat Charges
description: Landlords charged with failing to provide heat and hot water are barred from getting two-party rent checks from welfare tenants under a new city policy.

title: By Red Smith; The Mess At the Gate
description: TWELVE horses were in the starting gate at Aqueduct when all of a sudden the steed in the No. 11 stall broke through and stumbled. An instant later, all the gates flew open and the whole field came out. No. 11 slammed horses on both sides of him. In a chain reaction, others interfered with others. Ultimately, seven escaped from the tangle and completed the course in good enough order for the stewards to regard them as starters. Ontrack and offtrack bets of $254,000 on the five others were refunded.

title: Squires Sets Record In Central Park 25k
description: Pete Squires of the New York Athletic Club set a meet record of 1 hour 19 minutes 53 seconds yesterday in winning the New York Road Runners Club 25-kilometer race at Central Park.

title: Maple Leafs 6, Rockies 6
description: Ian Turnbull and Bill Derlago scored successive goals in the third period to give Toronto a tie with Colorado. The Maple Leafs' winless streak was extended to seven games.

title: Washington Watch; Policy Loans Cause Trouble
description: WASHINGTON ONE of the last bargains in interest rates will end if the American Council of Life Insurance carries the day with state legislatures. Borrowing against the cash value of a life policy is a popular way of squeezing out of a financial hammerlock. With most consumer loan rates in the high teens, you pay only 8 percent when borrowing against a new life policy and an even more modest 5 to 6 percent against policies bought before 1975.

title: U.S. Bobsledder Dies
description: CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 8 (AP) - Jim Morgan, a bobsled driver from Saranac Lake, N.Y., died today from injuries sustained in an accident during the third heat of the world four-man bobsled championships.

title: Western Bid For Continental
description: An administrative law judge has recommended approval of the proposed merger of Continental Airlines and Western Airlines, saying the new carrier, which would be the country's seventh largest, poses no threat to competition.

title: REAGAN'S PLANS ON RESEARCH CUTS ARE SAID TO AIM AT 'SOFT' SCIENCES
description: The Reagan Administration would permit planned increases in Government support for basic research in the socalled hard sciences, such as physics and chemistry, but would sharply curtail support for programs in the behavioral and other ''soft'' sciences, according to proposed budget revisions circulating in Congress.

title: Sun Chemical Lifts Stake
description: The Sun Chemical Corporation said that its executive committee had authorized the company to raise its stake in the Chromalloy American Corporation to about one-third of Chromalloy's outstanding voting securities.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arco Publishing Inc., a Prentice-Hall company, has appointed Peter C. Grenquist general manager and chief executive officer.

title: JUDITH TIERSTEN MARRIED
description: The marriage of Judith Ann Tiersten to Harvey Cohen took placeyesterday at the bride's home in Maplewood, N.J. Cantor Theodore Aronson of East Orange, N.J., performed the ceremony. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham I. Simon of New York, has three sons from a previous marriage, which ended in divorce. Mr. Cohen is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William P. Cohen of Newark.

title: From Public to Private
description: Thomas E. Frank, 42, president of Executive Industries, a motor home manufacturer based in Anaheim, Calif., is planning to take his publicly owned corporation private. To do so, he formed his own company that will make an offer to acquire all of the Executive Industries stock for $5.50 a share - $2 in cash and the remainder in a negotiable note.

title: GERULAITIS CONQUERS MCENROE
description: Maybe it is time to take Vitas Gerulaitis seriously again on the tennis tour. After sliding from fourth to ninth in the world rankings and admittedly on holiday for the second half of the 1980 season, Gerulaitis collected the $175,000 first prize in the Molson Challenge today with a 6-4, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 victory over John McEnroe.

title: President Named At Chicago Bank
description: Earl F. Hord, 48 years old, has been named president of the Independence Bank of Chicago, the nation's largest black-owned bank with more than $101 million in assets. He succeeds Alvin J. Boutte, 51, who was named chairman, while continuing as chief executive officer of the 17-year-old bank.

title: by Richard J. Margolis
description: Big-city liberals got just what they deserved last November - a kick in the jeans from rural voters. If liberal Democrats are serious about rebuilding the allegedly shattered New Deal coalition, they will have to figure out a way to recapture rural affections. These have been fading for some time - since the 1920's, in fact, when the Democratic Party began staking its life and its fortune on the urban vote.

title: RECENT QUAKES SPEED UP COAST'S DISASTER PLANNING
description: Alarmed by a recent series of tremors and by a Federal warning that they are ''essentially unprepared'' for catastrophe, Federal, state and local officials are stepping up disaster relief planning for the major earthquake that scientists regard as inevitable. But they are warning Californians that they would be on their own in the first devastating hours of any major quake.

title: Safety Knockout
description: In December 1979, following the death of Willie Classen, the New York State Athletic Commission was in the midst of a furor over the lack of safety at boxing bouts. Urged by State Senator Roy M. Goodman, head of the Senate's Committee on Investigations, the commission implemented several safety measures, including the mandate that an ambulance had to be present at each bout.

title: VIOLIN: FREIDMAN PLAYS RESPIGHI
description: Respighi's Violin Sonata in B minor was the novelty of Erick Friedman's recital at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night. This work used to be a Jascha Heifetz specialty, and perhaps Mr. Freidman played it as a tribute to his former mentor because this year marks Mr. Heifetz's 80th birthday.

title: DANCE: BALLETS CANADIENS
description: LES Grands Ballets Canadiens from Montreal, last seen in New York a decade ago with its smash-hit, ''Tommy,'' returned for an all-toobrief appearance last weekend at the Herbert H. Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Noah Is Winner
description: Yannick Noah of France completed his sweep of higher ranked opponents and won the $200,000 United Virginia Bank tennis tournament today when Ivan Lendl had to default in the second set.

title: Waltrip, in Buick, Takes Auto Sprint
description: Darrell Waltrip, driving a Buick Regal, captured the $159,000 Busch Clash 50-mile race today at International Speedway.

title: A TOOL FOR THE U.S.-IRANIAN SETTLEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Promotions Accompany A Birthday
description: WARING & LaRosa, at $60 million in billings, is celebrating its 13th anniversary with promotions at the top. Taking one step forward are Joseph A. LaRosa, the new chairman and still creative director; Saul Waring, the new president; Morton A. Grossman, finance chief, and John W.J. McCrosky, head of marketing and account service, both executive vice presidents, and Chuck Cohen and Robert M. Oksner, who are joining the senior vice president ranks.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In a National Football League game, an attempt at a field goal falls short, with the kicking team recovering the ball in the field of play beyond the yardage needed for a first down. The defensive team did not touch the ball. Is it a first down? Can the player who recovered the ball continue to advance? If a defensive player recovers the short attempt, is he permitted to run with the ball?

title: Carey Takes Day for Sightseeing
description: Governor Carey of New York took a break from business today and spent part of the day on a boat ride around Hong Kong island under sunny skies.

title: African Radio Starts Broadcasts
description: Africa No. 1, called the most powerful transmitting radio station on the African continent, began broadcasting here this weekend. The station, built with financial and technical help from France, will be on the air 18 hours a day including 6 hours of programs from Radio France International, government officials said. It is situated 300 miles southeast of Libreville

title: KNICKS TOP NETS AGAIN
description: Since Michael Ray Richardson led a third-quarter surge that carried the Knicks to a 116-102 victory over the Nets today, he was asked if he felt any sympathy for a team that was struggling with a 15-44 record.

title: Israel Urged to Indict U.S. Paper's Correspondent
description: The Israeli police have recommended that the government indict an Israeli correspondent for The Washington Star for naming the head of Israel's internal security service in an article published in The Star last August. Under Israel's Official Secrets Act, the maximum penalty for disclosing such information is 15 years' imprisonment.

title: DISBURBED HUMANS ARE NOT ANIMALS
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope Sends First Greetings To North Korea in 30 Years
description: Pope John Paul II today issued the first Papal message to North Korea in three decades, sending his greetings to ''the beloved brothers and sisters of the North so close to my heart.''

title: Flyers 6, Whalers 6
description: Paul Holmgren scored on a pass from Rick MacLeish at 15:04 of the third period to give Philadelphia the tie.

title: LESLIE ALLEN SCORES UPSET OVER HANA MANDLIKOVA
description: Unseeded Leslie Allen scored the biggest victory of her career when she toppled Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 6-4, today in the final of an Avon women's tennis tournament.

title: RAIN ADDS JUST A DROP TO SUPPLY
description: A cold front advancing from Pennsylvania and New Jersey brought a chill drizzle into New York yesterday, slicking the streets and sidewalks and whetting the curiosity of those who wonder how much rain it takes to dull the edge of the current drought.

title: Citibank Division Assigned to SSC&B
description: Citibank, a subsidiary of Citicorp, has assigned its estimated $10 million New York banking division to SSC&B, which is already handling its Person-To-Person personal finance operation.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE SHOCK OF THE NEW. By Robert Hughes. 423 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $29.95.

title: TV: 'GUESTS OF NATION' AND MISTER LINCOLN
description: THEATER pieces dominate tonight's schedule on WNET, Channel 13. At 8, there is Neil McKenzie's ''Guests of the Nation,'' a finely tuned adaptation of a Frank O'Connor story. At 9, Herbert Mitgang's ''Mister Lincoln,'' a solo performance starring Roy Dotrice, can be seen in a recording videotaped last year before an audience at Ford's Theater in Washington.

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1981; Companies
description: Semiconductor makers are bracing for a poor year. Mounting competition from Japan is combining with soft demand and lower prices to worsen the downturn in earnings that began in the fourth quarter of 1980. Semiconductor sales rose 26 percent last year, compared with 36 percent in 1979. (Page D1.)

title: NEW EVIDENCE BACKS EX-ENVOY ON HIS ROLE IN CHILE
description: For six years Edward M. Korry, United States Ambassador to Chile from 1967 to 1971, has insisted that he was not involved in and indeed tried to stop White House efforts to induce a military coup in Chile in 1970 to prevent Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens, a Marxist, from assuming the presidency.

title: JEALOUSY: ROOTS OF RAGE AND REVENGE
description: J EALOUSY, one of the most powerful and most perverse of human emotions, has become a central point of contention in a Westchester County murder trial that has attracted nationwide attention.

title: Cowens's No. 18 Retired by Celtics
description: The Boston Celtics retired the uniform number of Dave Cowens at a ceremony at halftime of the game with the San Diego Clippers today.

title: ST. PATRICK'S MARSHAL
description: As a youth he sang the songs of Ireland on the concert stages and music halls of Dublin and his native Belfast, and since emigrating to the United States, Joseph Kennedy has organized Irish concerts and festivals in the New York area.

title: Screenwriter Turns His Ardent Fantasy into a New Film
description: He may not be the first man to pine for a glamorous television reporter, but Steve Tesich may be the first smitten viewer to translate his fantasy into film.

title: 5 Vietnamese Die in Capsizing
description: Five women drowned when a boat carrying 53 Vietnamese capsized last night off the east coast of the Malay Peninsula, the police said today. The boat was headed for Singapore when bad weather and rough seas forced it to change course. Thirty-eight are known to have survived and 10 are missing.

title: Another Black Child Listed as Missing in Atlanta
description: Atlanta police began searching today for another young black child, hoping to find the boy before having to turn the case over to a special force that is investigating the deaths or disappearances of 17 black youths.

title: Pedestrian Hit; Officer Is Suspended
description: A police officer was suspended and arrested on charges of intoxicated driving and leaving the scene of an accident after a pedestrian was struck at Hunts Point and Lafayette Avenues in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, according to the police.

title: Fireman in Jersey Charged With Arson
description: A 19-year-old volunteer firefighter in this northern New Jersey community has been charged with setting several blazes at municipal buildings, including his own firehouse, authorities said.

title: 5 DIE IN BUSHWICK BLAZE SET BY FIREBOMBER
description: Two women and three children were killed in a fire in a Brooklyn apartment building last night. The fire was caused by an arsonist who threw a bottle of flammable liquid into the front door that ignited, the Fire Department said. Three firemen suffered minor injuries fighting the fire.

title: CONTRACTORS' OVERRUNS ON CONSTRUCTION COSTS ASSAILED IN CITY STUDY
description: Requests for additional money by contractors doing capital construction for New York City cost the city $32.2 million between January 1977 and December 1979, according to a study released yesterday by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin and Carol Bellamy, City Council President.

title: UNION GAIN FOR SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS
description: With unemployment mounting sharply, Spanish labor has demonstrated new signs of pragmatism and moderation, dealing a recent rebuff to the Communist-dominated Workers' Commissions in plant elections and giving important victories to the Socialists' General Workers' Union.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 9, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Scientific and technical subcommit- tee of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ZAPATA RETAINS TITLE
description: Hilario Zapata retained his World Boxing Council junion-flyweight title today by stopping Joey Olivo of the United States in the 13th round.

title: Arrows 9-2 Victors
description: Steve Zungul scored three goals to raise his season's total to 82 as the New York Arrows defeated the Hartford Hellions, 9-2, in a Major Indoor Soccer League game today at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Man Found Guilty In Slaying of Ex-Nun
description: WHITE PLAINS (UPI) - A 37-year-old man has been convicted of the murder of a 70-year-old former nun who was stabbed 39 times in her Mount Vernon apartment last April.

title: MIME TOURED COUNTRY WITH OWN COMPANY
description: Claude Kipnis, the French-born mime who toured the United States with his own company to critical acclaim, died of cancer at the Mount Sinai Medical Center yesterday. He was 42 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: MOVIE STAR SEEKS CAREER OPPORTUNITY
description: MIAMI IT was a warm, gray day, and Paul Newman was sitting in a hotel room, taking a break from his latest film and thinking desultorily about leaving the movie business. These were hardly new thoughts for Mr. Newman; indeed they had occurred frequently over the last few years. Still, it seemed ironic that the 56-year-old actor should be entertaining such heretical notions at the moment his career had reached another peak: not only did his new movie ''Fort Apache, the Bronx'' open to critical acclaim last Friday, but his portrayal of a police officer was also hailed as one of his finest performances in years.

title: Koch Court Proposal Is Opposed by Fink
description: The State Assembly Speaker, Stanley Fink, warned yesterday that a call from Mayor Koch for special court sessions for violators of the state gun law might really be a call for ''judge shopping.''

title: AS A PARTY TAMPERS WITH A VOTERS' RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-HOSTAGE ASSAILS LACK OF PRECAUTION
description: Col. Leland J. Holland, the former hostage who was military attache at the American Embassy in Iran, said today that the crisis of the embassay takeover by Iranian militants was exacerbated when American documents fell into the militants' hands.

title: WALTER A. DARBY JR.
description: Walter A. Darby Jr., a New York City lawyer who specialized in admiralty law until he retired in 1976, died Friday at his home in Mount Sinai, L.I. He was 62 years old.

title: Reagan Signs Measure
description: Increasing Debt Limit

title: TWINS: A SPECIAL IDENTITY
description: What is so endlessly fascinating about identical twins? There they are in a new photo book, gazing out of the pages two by two. They talk about themselves and about each other, and some answer the question that often comes to mind: do twins have a special, almost magical relationship that ordinary people do not?

title: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS
description: Following are excerpts from Chief Justice Warren E. Burger's address today before the American Bar Association, meetSpecial to the New York Times ing here for its winter convention:

title: U.C.L.A. Defeats Notre Dame
description: U.C.L.A., a team with speed and firepower, and Notre Dame, a team with muscle, height and firepower, played an unusually low-scoring but exciting basketball game today that the Bruins won, 51-50, even though they failed to score a field goal in the last 7 minutes 45 seconds.

title: THE LEFEVER NUDGE; by William Safire
description: Wither ''human rights'' in the Reagan Administration? Will the United States fling its arms around right-wing dictators and stop trying to end torture and to foster the growth of democracy?

title: 'Protecting' Costly American Cars
description: If the high sticker prices on the 1981 econo-mobiles have got you down, remember, things could be worse. In fact, if Detroit gets its way, they will be.

title: Rochelle Fran Moskowitz Bride of Douglas Lowenstein
description: Rochelle Fran Moskowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Moskowitz of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Douglas Lowenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lowenstein of New York. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony at the Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Japan Car Flow To U.S. Eases
description: Japanese automobile exports to the United States in the first three months of 1981 will dip below 450,000 units, down from 461,000 units in the first quarter last year, Japan's top trade official said Friday.

title: Ex-Broadway Musical Star Is Charged in Slaying of Girl
description: A voice teacher who once had the male lead in the original Broadway production of ''Oklahoma!'' faced first-degree murder charges today in the shooting death of a girl who was his student.

title: MILLIONS IN THEFTS PLAGUE JERSEY AREA
description: Clusters of huge wholesale warehouses that have sprung up since the mid-1970's in the Hackensack Meadowlands have become the targets of burglaries running into millions of dollars. In the most recent large break-in, thieves made off last weekend with $1.5 million in jade statuary and gold jewelry imported from China.

title: The Talk of Greenwich
description: At the Greenwich Country Club, lunch is being served on paper plates, and the martinis come in plastic cups. In one apartment complex downtown, a resident called the police the other day to report that a neighbor was drawing a bath. Even the Town Hall bathrooms sport signs imploring, ''Don't Be a Flusher.'' With water supplies even lower than in other communities around New York City, a kind of nervous jocularity can be found in Greenwich these days. Residents joke about their predicament (''We've been cold all winter - now we're cold and dirty''). They discuss their new toilet habits with the earthiness of soldiers and espouse water conservation with gusto and civic pride. But they are also afraid.

title: Seton Hall, F.D.U.  Disqualified in Relay
description: The rivalry between the Seton Hall and Fairleigh Dickinson one-mile relay teams, two of the best in the nation, resulted in a near-fight and a double disqualification today in the final event of the 10th annual Princeton Relays.

title: No Headline
description: MOSCOW ACCUSES U.S. OF 'MILITARY HYSTERIA' AND WAR ON DETENTE

title: HARD YEAR FORECAST FOR ELECTRONICS
description: United States semiconductor manufacturers, faced with falling prices, softening demand and mounting competition from the Japanese, are girding for a year of depressed profits and tough management decisions.

title: MEDICAL DEDUCTIONS BROADENED IN YEAR
description: In a warren of windowless rooms in the New Executive Office Building, a block from the White House, a team of economists from southern California has been drafting ''scenarios'' that show President Reagan's economic policies bringing about a dramatic slowing of inflation. One such projection shows the nation's inflation rate dropping from more than 10 percent now to roughly 6.5 percent in 1982 and even lower, to possibly less than 5 percent, by the 1984 elections.

title: First of two articles.
description: ''Sex has been a good business for me,'' says Duane Colglazier, president of Pleasure Chest Ltd., which he describes as the nation's largest seller of sexual paraphernalia.

title: A Valentine Presented to Agnes de Mille
description: The new Greenwich Village Trust for Historic Preservation presented Agnes de Mille, the choreographer, with a valentine yesterday for her efforts as a founding member of the trust.

title: STAGE: 'WEEP NOT FOR ME: INSIDE THE SOUTH BRONX
description: IT'S just coincidence, of course, but right now the Negro Ensemble Company is presenting a new play that might well serve as an answer to the controversial new film ''Fort Apache, the Bronx.'' Gus Edwards's ''Weep Not for Me,'' which opened at the Theater Four last night, is a view of the South Bronx from the inside: its characters are middle-class black people who have lived there for 15 years and have nowhere else to go. To be sure, Mr. Edwards doesn't present the neighborhood as a Shangri-La: his South Bronx, like the one in ''Fort Apache,'' is a hell of crime, drugs and bombed-out buildings. But the playwright unearths both the dignity and the wit of people who do their best to keep going in desperate circumstances.

title: World Cup Downhill To Gerry Soerensen
description: Gerry Soerensen of Canada came from the 30th starting position to score her first World Cup victory in the downhill today.

title: A $500,000 Pillowcase
description: EVEN now, nine months later, the awe of the moment remains in Larry Holmes's voice when he talks about it. ''Harold Smith had this big bag, I think it was a pillowcase and it was full of money, packs of money,'' Larry Holmes was saying. ''He told me he had $500,000 in there just for me if I'd let him promote me. He had two cashier's checks from the Wells Fargo Bank, too, each for $500,000 - that's $1.5 million total. But that $500,000 in cash, I ain't never seen that kind of money before or since. I got a lot of money. But all I ever see is the checks or the bank statements, I never see the money itself. I never touch it. The time that Harold came here last May to try and sign me, I saw the money. And that was somethin' to see.''

title: Teaching Athletics; The last in an occasional series on how various subjects are taught.
description: There are no uniforms, no squad lines and hardly a whistle in sight. But the biggest change in gym class in the last 10 years is coeducation. With certain exceptions, such as wrestling and swimming, girls and boys at White Plains High School are pursuing sports as they do algebra, English or history - together.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1981
description: International Poland's leading opposition group will be investigated, the Government said. The official announcement of an ''inquiry'' into the Committee for Social Self-Defense, an ally of the independent labor union Solidarity, appeared to indicate a crackdown. Meanwhile, talks between Solidarity leaders and a Government delegation aimed at averting a general strike today in the southwestern town of Jelenia Gora were recessed at the delegation's request. It said it wished to consult authorities in Warsaw. (Page A1, Column 6.) Custody of Cynthia B. Dwyer will be given by Iran to the Swiss Embassy in Teheran, and she might leave Iran today, the State Department reported. Mrs. Dwyer was found guilty of espionage by an Iranian revolutionary court yesterday and ordered to leave the country. According to her family in Amherst, N.Y., near Buffalo, Mrs. Dwyer went to Iran as a free-lance journalist last April to write about the revolution. (A1:5.)

title: ABOUT WASHINGTON
description: His appointments calendar gleams as bare and uneventful now as the streets of Plains, Ga. When the telephone rings, he casually picks it up himself and says, ''Schultze,'' speaking with an almost blue-collar bite that clashes neatly with the think-tank stereotyping of his retreat.

title: MUSIC: TEAMWORK FROM BRIOSO QUINTET
description: ONE of New York's promising young chamber groups made an appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon. It is the Brioso Quintet, an ensemble of wind players, all of whom study or have studied at the Juilliard School.

title: Toy Fair Promises Advertising Support
description: Toy Fair is coming and the big guns of the business are now making their promises to the distributors and retailers about all the advertising support their products will get.

title: No Headline
description: Smith Still Plans $8.1 Million Boxing Card

title: Bridge: Language Obstacles Aside, Bidding Can Be a Problem
description: It used to be quite common in world championships for players to mishear or misunderstand an opposing bid. Although English is the international bridge language, English as spoken by a Pole is rather different from English as spoken by a player from Taiwan.

title: ATHENS SEEKS TO COMMIT U.S. TO BACKING BALANCE OF POWER WITH TURKEY
description: Greece will seek formal assurances from the United States on the security of its frontiers and the preservation of the balance of forces in the Aegean during the current negotiations over the American bases here, according to Foreign Minister Constantine Mitsotakis.

title: FATHERS AND SONS TALK ABOUT GROWING UP
description: Thirteen-year-old Jimmy was troubled. He did not understand his sudden feelings of sexual excitement nor the ways in which his body was changing. So he announced, ''I decided to talk to a man who might have the answers -Dad.''

title: BODY SUBSTANCES MAY OFFER A SOLUTION TO ALLERGIES
description: Scientists have discovered substances, produced naturally by the body, that suppress the key initiator of allergic attacks in susceptible individuals.

title: News Analysis
description: At 5 A.M. on Friday, there was an arresting tableau in the meeting hall of the textile factory in Bielsko-Biala, where Solidarity, the independent labor union, chalked up its latest victory over the Government at the negotiating table.

title: by Sam Allalouf
description: The idea of creating competition among health-care providers commands sufficient support in the Reagan Administration to make it central to a strategy designed to contain rising health-care costs.

title: SADAT STILL SUPPORTS 1978 ACCORDS OVER OTHER PROPOSALS, ISRAELIS SAY
description: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt has assured Israel that he will not allow a European peace initiative to interfere with the Camp David accords, Israeli officials in Jerusalem said today.

title: India's Nuclear Blackmail
description: India is again threatening to reprocess spent nuclear fuel supplied by the United States, thus separating out plutonium that could be used to make additional fuel - or nuclear bombs. Officials of India's atomic energy program say they will soon test a reprocessing facility at Tarapur, near Bombay, using their own nuclear materials. After that, they add, they will feel free to reprocess the fuel from the United States.

title: Travelers Reports 4th-Quarter Drop
description: The Travelers Corporation, the second-largest stock insurance company behind the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, reported Friday that weakness in its casualty-property operations caused operating earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 to slip 9.2 percent, to $97.3 million, or $2.30 a share, from $107.1 million, or $2.52 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979. For the full year, operating net dropped 5.7 percent, to $365.6 million, from $387.6 million.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ENDURING SPIRIT

title: 24 GREEK SOCCER FANS DIE IN STAMPEDE AFTER MATCH
description: At least 24 Greek soccer fans were killed and dozens injured after being trampled on by other spectators trying to force their way out of a crowded stadium, the police said.

title: DAVE WINFIELD FINDS BASEBALL AND BUSINESS THE PERFECT MIX
description: ON the 19th floor of the Summit Hotel, high over Lexington Avenue, the odd couple was stirring early: Dave Winfield, 29 years old, 6 feet 6 inches tall, crisp and cool; his agent, Albert S. Frohman, 54 years old, 5 feet 4 inches short, rumpled and emotional.

title: TEHERAN TO FREE CYNTHIA DWYER TODAY, U.S. SAYS
description: The State Department said today that the Swiss Embassy in Teheran would take custody tomorrow of Cynthia B. Dwyer, an American found guilty of espionage by an Iranian revolutionary court and ordered to leave the country. The Swiss will try to have her on a flight out of Iran the same day.

title: SALUTE TO 13-YEAR OLD
description: When his teacher decided to do something about the garbage-strewn mud flats around Junior High School 22 on the Lower East Side, Eduardo Cruz was right there. The 13-year-old ninth grader not only joined classmates in clearing the lots and planting daffodils and tulips, but he was also there after school and on weekends, tending the garden and winning over neighborhood vandals to the community cause.

title: MUSIC:STAR-SCAPE SINGERS
description: ANY choral composer and director who instructs his singers at the top of his lungs to ''blow up a balloon in the cathedral of the Cosmos,'' obviously has some very unusual ideas about music. Well, during the first half of a concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, Kenneth G. Mills could be heard blowing up that cosmic balloon as he led the Star-Scape Singers in his own compositions.

title: PROOF OF SOVIET-AIDED TERROR IS SCARCE
description: Officials with access to United States intelligence services say they have little evidence to substantiate Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s allegation that the Soviet Union trains, equips and provides funds for international terrorists.

title: ANOTHER TIME, ANOTHER TRUNNION'S TROUBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Warrants Add To Bond Appeal
description: STUNG by heavy losses experienced over four years of sliding bond prices, few investors are willing to make commitments for new longterm issues without an escape hatch.

title: One-Year Wonder
description: If 6-foot-8-inch Kevin Magee leads the nation's college basketball scorers this season, which he is currently doing with a 29.3 average, he will become the tallest player since 1962 to do so. If he continues his current average, he will also become the first player since 1963 to win the scoring title with an average under 30. And being a junior college transfer, playing his initial season at California-Irvine, he will become the first player ever to lead in scoring during his first year at a school.

title: WNET-TV Will Present A Hepburn Retrospective
description: A series of five early films starring Katharine Hepburn will be shown weekly on WNET-TV, Channel 13, beginning Saturday with ''Morning Glory'' (1933), which pairs Miss Hepburn with Douglas Fairbanks Jr. ''Alice Adams'' (1935), with Fred MacMurray, will be shown on Feb. 21, followed by ''A Woman Rebels'' (1936), Feb. 28; ''Bringing Up Baby'' (1938), with Cary Grant, March 12, and ''Stage Door'' (1937), with Ginger Rogers and Adolphe Menjou, March 14.

title: Rapp & Collins Gets RCA Record Club Account
description: Rapp & Collins has just become the agency for the RCA Record and Tape Club, which was formerly with TLK/ Direct Marketing, a subsidiary of Tatham-Laird & Kudner, for 15 years.

title: 600 WHITES IN QUEENS BACK SCHOOL BOYCOTT
description: Six hundred white residents of Rosedale, Queens, gathered at a tumultuous rally yesterday in support of a boycott of a predominantly black school. At the same time, four black members of the local school board were meeting to urge white parents to return their children to the school, Intermediate School 231.

title: MURDOCH'S PUBLISHING EMPIRE
description: One day last month the 70-year-old mother of Rupert Murdoch, Dame Elizabeth Murdoch, received a telephone call from her son at the family estate near Melbourne, Australia.

title: LEBANON'S CRY FOR HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: Sporting Gear Compact Sport Binoculars
description: The Bushnell Sportview Compact is a new, rugged, nine-and-onequarter-ounce binocular that is only three and a half inches in height. The Sportview has a designation of 7 power, 21 millimeters, which means the magnification is seven times and the diameter of the front lens is 21 millimeters. It has a field of view of 460 feet, which is the diameter of what is seen at 1,000 yards. The body of the Sportview is covered in grained, non-slip vinyl, with front lenses protected from dust by coated optical glass plates. There are also roll-down rubber eyecups to make viewing easier for those who wear glasses. The binoculars, including a neckstrap and a pouch, sell for $110. For information as to where they can be purchased, write to Bushnell Optical Company, 2828 East Foothill Boulevard, Pasadena, Calif. 91107.

title: A FASHION EDITOR'S LINE FOR THE FULLER FIGURE
description: Sandy Head wears size 16 on top and size 14 on the bottom and has spent her adult life trying to find clothes that fit her. Not just any clothes, but fashionable clothes in good fabrics. As a fashion editor at Mademoiselle magazine, she had to dress the part. So she ended up making a lot of her own clothes. She also made clothes for other women she knew.

title: Biles Names Nolan As Defensive Aide
description: Dick Nolan, a proponent of the 4-3 flex defense, has been named defensive coordinator of the Houston Oilers under Coach Ed Biles, who helped develop the 3-4 defense.

title: KENTUCKY'S S.E.C. HOPES FADE
description: The Kentucky boosters brought a cake to Tennessee's Stockley Center Saturday night to celebrate what they hoped would be Coach Joe B. Hall's 200th victory in college basketball. Instead, they returned to Lexington, Ky., with the cake and left the celebrating for another day.

title: Timely Experiment
description: Though the decision on ambulances may offend some boxing reformers, Prenderville talked about an experiment that may increase protection for some boxers.

title: JANUARY SUBWAY SERVICE ASSAILED AS THE WORST IN THE LINES' HISTORY t hree years
description: Service on the New York City subway system deteriorated last month to what appears to be the lowest level on record. More than three times as many trains either failed to leave their terminals or broke down en route this January as in January 1977, according to Transit Authority data.

title: Paterson Lays Off 100 CETA Workers
description: The City of Paterson has laid off more than 100 employees paid under a federally financed job training program, and officials say more cutbacks may be ordered as work continues on a new municipal budget.

title: Stenmark Triumphs, Increasing Cup Lead
description: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden won the World Cup special slalom ski race near here today and increased his overall lead in the series over Phil Mahre of Yakima, Wash.

title: Mike Quarry Loses
description: Bunny Johnson, the British lightheavyweight champion, stopped Mike Quarry of the United States in the seventh round of their 10-round bout today.

title: FORMER GOV. GRASSO HONORED IN CAPITAL
description: Thousands of mourners, some of whom waited in a cold drizzle for up to an hour, filed through the State Capitol today to say farewell to former Gov. Ella T. Grasso.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Is a society redeemed if it provides massive safeguards for accused persons and yet fails to provide elementary protection for its law-abiding citizens?'' - Chief Justice Warren E. Burger. (D10:1.)

title: L.I. Dog Takes Pinscher Show
description: It was specialty day in the metropolitan area for the doggy set yesterday, with shows being held on 13 sites in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: BONDS OFFERED THIS WEEK COULD TOTAL $1 BILLION
description: As much as $1 billion of corporate debt issues could be brought to market this week, although bankers caution that their plans are only tentative.

title: Excerpts from speech, page D10.
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, warning that crime has created a ''reign of terror in American cities,'' called today for a ''damage-control program'' to deal with rising crime rates.

title: WAR AND TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: SELLING ACADEMICS' PATENTS
description: As American companies accelerate their efforts to acquire and develop new technology, academic research is drawing increasing attention.

title: Happy Ending, Sober Moral to a Fire
description: It sure sounded like good news last week when 350 residents had to flee a smoky, dangerous New York hotel fire - and no one died. After the big fires in Las Vegas and Westchester County, in which more than 100 were killed, people around the country were coming to expect the worst. Tired of tragedy, they may now be tempted to think that deadly high-rise fires are coming under control. They aren't.

title: BILL LEE
description: Bill Lee, a partner in Moffitt-Lee Productions, which created the the comedy series ''Fridays'' for ABC-TV, died of cancer at CedarsSinai Hospital last Tuesday.

title: Me and Casey, Riding The Rails
description: In June 1975, I rode a freight train for the first time - the Union Pacific ''hot shot'' nicknamed ''The Triple S'' for ''SuperSonic Slingshot.'' It's well known as one of the fastest freights to roam the West, a high-priority cargo haul that runs daily from Salt Lake City to Portland, Ore., reaching speeds of more than 60 miles an hour, kind of quick for 4,000 tons of train.

title: Chess: Keeping Up With Sosonko Is Too Much for Gheorghiu
description: One of the most innovative opening analysts these days is the Dutch grandmaster Genna Sosonko, a Russian emigre. He produced an exciting new gambit in his fourth-round game with Florin Gheorghiu, a Rumanian grandmaster, in the 43d Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands.

title: LENNON MURDER SUSPECT PREPARING INSANITY DEFENSE
description: Mark David Chapman, the man accused of murdering John Lennon last December, is undergoing mental tests in the prison infirmary on Rikers Island and conferring with his attorney on the insanity defense to be used at his trial.

title: Death Toll Raised to 66 In Fire at Circus in India
description: The death toll in yesterday's flash fire in a circus tent in the southern city of Bangalore rose to 66 today after six hospitalized victims died. The cause of the fire remained unknown.

title: Advertising; Mentholatum Leaves J. Walter Thompson
description: Because of conflict, the 91-year-old, privately held Mentholatum Company of Buffalo has moved its products from the J. Walter Thompson Company, and assigned one of them to Jordan, Case & McGrath.

title: Sports World Specials; The Snow Bowl
description: Last month, as the Super Bowl was ending its run of 15 years at warm-weather sites - Los Angeles, Pasadena, New Orleans, Miami and Houston have been the only hosts - the Detroit-area's Super Bowl committee was in Louisiana trying to rev up interest for the 1982 game.

title: 5-0 Bumphus Outpoints Pappa in 8-Rounder
description: McAFEE, N.J., Feb. 8 (UPI) -Johnny Bumphus, a winner in the Olympic Trials last year, ran his pro record to 5-0 today with an eight-round unanimous decision over Victor Pappa of Philadelphia.

title: HAMILTON SKATING VICTOR
description: Scott Hamilton flashed his way to the national senior men's figure skating title at the Sports Arena late last night, succeeding Charlie Tickner. Ten new champions were crowned.

title: Thailand Closes 2 Crossings On Border With Laos
description: Thailand closed two Mekong River crossings into Laos today because Laotian troops were firing into Thai territory, Radio Thailand reported.

title: IMPERIALIST ISLAM
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Wings 3, Canucks 2
description: Reed Larson scored two goals in the first seven minutes as Detroit defeated Vancouver in a penalty-filled game.

title: 400 SAC Planes Take Part In Response to Mock Attack
description: The Strategic Air Command, responding to a simulated attack on the United States, sent about 400 bombers and tankers aloft today in the command's largest air operation in 35 years.

title: 43 Injured in Crash Of Tour Bus Upstate
description: A bus loaded with weekend skiers from the New York metropolitan area overturned during a snowstorm on a steep, icy road in the Adirondack Mountains, injuring 43 of the 47 persons on board, the state police said.

title: Laurence Olivier Is Made Member of Order of Merit
description: LONDON (AP) - Queen Elizabeth II has chosen the actor Laurence Olivier, whom she made a life peer in 1970, for membership in the exclusive Order of Merit, Buckingham Palace has announced.

title: DESPITE A DECREASE IN COMPLAINTS, POLICE WORRY ABOUT CORRUPTION
description: The number of complaints of corruption and serious misconduct brought against New York City police officers has declined for the second consecutive year, but police officials are worried that a ''changing trend may have already begun'' in the direction of more complaints and perhaps increased corruption.

title: EVERYTHING UNDER THE MOON--AND THE SUN
description: LONG before there was any literature on the subject, before, indeed, the printed word existed, men who hunted and fished were aware that at certain times of the day, month or year their prey was easier to harvest.

title: Sabres 3, Blues 3
description: Rob McClanahan of the Sabres scored midway through the third period to cap a three-goal outburst and give Buffalo a tie with St. Louis.

title: NORTH STARS TIE RANGERS, 3-3
description: The New York Rangers put great pressure on Gilles Meloche, the Minnesota North Stars' goalie, in the third period last night, but they had to settle for a 3-3 tie at Madison Square Garden.

title: BARNARD IS BOLSTERING ITS BUILDINGS' SECURITY AFTER RAPE OF STUDENT
description: Barnard College plans new security measures, including 24-hour guards in some college-owned apartment buildings near the Morningside Heights campus and new dormitory identification cards.

title: Cuevas Stops Prada
description: Jose (Pipino) Cuevas, the former World Boxing Association welterweight champion, dominated from the opening bell last night and knocked out Jose Benarado Prada in the second round of their scheduled 10-rounder.

title: Willow Scores In Ocean Race
description: Williwaw, a 48-foot yacht owned by Seymore Sinnett of Perth Amboy, N.J., took first on corrected time in the opening event of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference today.

title: Technical Problem
description: When the New Jersey Gems of the professional Women's Basketball League were looking for a new coach, one came to them. And they couldn't be happier.

title: 4 IN INTENSE RACE FOR POST AS DEMOCRATIC CHAIRMAN
description: In terms of the travel, money and time it is taking, the race for election to the post of Democratic national chairman is coming to resemble a Presidential nomination race more than the old way of deciding such matters in a smoke-filled room.

title: Parun Wins Title
description: Onny Parun of New Zealand defeated Larry Stefanki of the United States, 3-6, 6-4, 7-5, to win the New Zealand Masters tennis singles title at Christchurch today.

title: by Arthur Macy Cox
description: President Reagan has criticized the SALT II treaty because it does so little toward reducing nuclear weapons. In a White House interview with five reporters last week, he again stated his position on strategic arms limitation talks with the Russians: ''Anytime they want to sit down and discuss a legitimate reduction of nuclear weapons, I'm willing to get into such negotiations.'' What is interesting about this is that Leonid I. Brezhnev also has been seeking a substantial reduction in the two countries' nuclear arsenals for many months. One of the great myths about SALT is that the Soviet Union is opposed to deep cuts in strategic weapons.

title: GROOMS' LIFE ON THE BACKSTREACH: A SMALL PIECE OF THE FOREFRONT
description: ELMONT, L.I. CHRIS MUNISTERI laughed and dug his pitchfork into a pile of horse manure and hay. ''Do I love horses?'' he said. ''I better. I guess you have to love them to get up at 4 in the morning and do this.''

title: Commodities; Absorbing Big Surplus Of Silver
description: The silver futures market, still hobbled by the antispeculative curbs imposed by exchanges more than a year ago, was hit again last week by the most bearish supply-demand figures traders have seen in 20 years. But if the figures should have depressed prices further, they failed.

title: The Age of 1,000,000,000,000
description: Children are no longer impressed by the idea of a millionaire, nor should they be in an age when the idealized mansion once known as the ''$100,000 house'' may well cost six or eight times that. In this era, fantasies of individual wealth have escalated to billions and to billionaires (Howard Hughes? J. Paul Getty? Daniel Ludwig?). As for national arithmetic, society has wafted up to a still higher plateau. The inflation that besets us affects not just money but numbers. It is now the Age of the Trillion.

title: Citizens Budget Group Economizes on Words
description: Having concluded that ''gold costs too much,'' the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group dedicated to economy in government, has decided to transmute its annual Gold Medal for exceptional service to New York City into a simple ''Award for High Civic Service.''

title: Birth Rights
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League has offered a lot of innovations to the sport - higher scoring, six-man teams and so on.

title: POLITICAL INFIGHTING IN IRAN CASTS DOUBT OVER FUTURE OF REVOLUTION MOHAMMED ALI RAJAI
description: Iran's bitter political infighting has grown even fiercer since the release of the American Embassy hostages, casting doubt on the future course of the revolution, which is two years old this week.

title: BUDGET AGENCY SEEKS CUTS ON AIRPORTS AND WATERWAYS
description: The Office of Management and Budget is proposing new taxes that would allow the reduction of Federal subsidies for the support of airports and waterways, according to Administration and Capitol Hill sources.

title: Drought in Portugal Forces Emergency Power Curbs
description: Portugal took emergency measures today to fight its worst drought in 30 years after the government warned of a national crisis unless rain falls in the next few weeks. There has been virtually no rain in Portugal for the last 40 days, although this is normally the wettest season of the year.

title: WARSAW ANNOUNCES PLAN TO INVESTIGATE KEY DISSIDENT GROUP
description: The Government announced today that it would conduct an ''inquiry'' into the activities of the country's foremost opposition group, the Committee for Social Self-Defense, which is closely allied with Solidarity, the independent labor union.

title: Index; International
description: Officials at third-world parley in India will face divisive issues A3 Sadat says he is still committed to agreements, Israelis report A4 Around the World A5 Greece seeks to commit U.S. to balance of power in Aegean A6 the leaders of a block of some 100 Congressmen who prided themselves that they never have voted for a debt limit bill and that they never have voted for a budget resolution.''

title: Greek Freighter Sinks
description: A Greek freighter carrying a cargo of iron bars sank a few miles off the eastern Aegean island of Skyros today and at least three of its 11 crew members died, the Ministry of Merchant Marine said. The authorities said the 1,360-ton Tenia was traveling from Bulgaria to Egypt when its cargo shifted and caused the vessel to sink. They said three crewmen were rescued and that five were missing.

title: SEARCH FOR NEW PRESIDENT OF CITY COLLEGE IS NARROWED TO 3 CANDIDATES
description: A two-year search for a new president of City College has narrowed from more than 200 nominees to three candidates, and university sources say an appointment could be made this month or next.

title: Miss Little Rallies for Playoff Victory
description: Sally Little won the $125,000 Elizabeth Arden golf tournament in a sudden-death playoff today when Judy Rankin hit into the water on the third extra hole.

title: Pacer Technology Head
description: David F. Long, 53, has been promoted to president and chief executive officer of Pacer Technology and Resources, a major producer of cyanocrylate adhesives - popularly known as instant glues or super glues. He succeeds Hugh F. Stock, 47, who becomes chairman of the company, which is based in Campbell, Calif.

title: THIRD-WORLD PARLEY TO FACE DIVISIVE ISSUES
description: Foreign ministers and senior officials from most of the 94 countries professing nonalignment settled in today for a four-day conference during which they will try to reconcile the movement's differences that have widened since the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan and the war between Iran and Iraq.

title: New York City Plans Note Sale
description: New York City plans to sell up to $200 million of short-term notes on Feb. 17, including revenue anticipation notes and its first issue of tax anticipation notes since December 1974, officials said Friday.

title: DEEPEN THOSE RESERVOIRS NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW BASE IS URGED FOR MOBILE FORCE
description: The staff of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has recommended a far-reaching shift in the command structure of the Rapid Deployment Force, bringing to a climax a yearlong struggle among the Army, Navy and Marine Corps for control of the new force.

title: Seven Are Killed in Crash Of Small Plane in Carolinas
description: Workers recovered seven bodies today from the wreckage of a twin-engine Cessna aircraft that crashed more than a mile north of Horace Williams Airport.

title: COURTNEY LORD, REALTY MAN, MARRIES KAREN ANN ROBBINS
description: Karen Ann Robbins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton I. Robbins of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in Manhattan at noon yesterday to Courtney Lord of Washington, son of Mrs. Max J. Lorberbaum of New York and the late Mr. Lorberbaum. Rabbi David Posner of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony at the St. Moritz.

title: DEFECT IN SNOWMOBILES REPORTED
description: MOLINE, ILL. Feb.8 (AP) Deere & Company said Friday that it had notified the Consumer Product Safety Commission of a potential defect in some of its 1980 Model Liquifire snowmobiles that can result in the loss of steering.

title: Crane Ruling In Harsco Bid
description: The Crane Company said it had won a preliminary Federal court injunction blocking the Pennsylvania Securities Commission, the Pennsylvania Attorney General and the Harsco Corporation from enforcing Pennsylvania's takeover disclosure law in regard to Crane's offer to buy 1.6 million Harsco common shares.

title: ANALYSTS PONDERING FED POLICY OUTLOOK
description: In a holiday-shortened week, the credit markets will grapple with the familiar questions about the state of the economy and the amount of credit the Federal Reserve intends to supply to the banking system.

title: WILLOUGHBY FARR
description: Willoughby Farr, a stockbroker and member of the New York investment banking concern of Hans Utsch & Company, died Saturday at Princeton (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. Mr. Farr, who was a resident of Plainsboro, N.J., was 46 years old.

title: James Brown, 83, Dies;
description: A Retired State Justice

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: James Galanos, one of Nancy Reagan's favorite designers, is in town to show his spring/summer collection today, and Saturday he took a short break at the Plaza to talk - very rapidly and with his head characteristically tilted back. He had this to say:

title: HINSON OF MISSISSIPPI TO RESIGN, AIDE SAYS
description: Representative Jon C. Hinson, who was arrested last week on homosexuality charges, ''definitely'' will resign his position, his administrative assistant said today.

title: JACK Z. ANDERSON, REPRESENTATIVE FOR 7 TERMS AND EISENHOWER AIDE
description: Former Representative Jack Z. Anderson, who served seven terms in Congress, died yesterday at his home in Hollister, Calif. He was 76 years old.

title: SHOULD EVERYONE LEARN TO WRITE FOR THE THEATER
description: WRITING for the theater should be made an educational key to unlocking young people's talents, says Gerald Chapman. Mr. Chapman, who headed a young people's playwriting project in Britain, this month embarked on a similar program in the United States.

title: Barnes Is Named To Head Mellon
description: J. David Barnes was officially elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Mellon National Corporation and its principal subsidiary, the Mellon Bank, it was announced yesterday.

title: NORSEMEN DID KNOW A THING OR TWO ABOUT MONSTERS
description: Ancient Norse seafarers sometimes saw a giant merman rising erect from the surface of the northern seas. ''This monster is tall and of great size and rises straight out of the water,'' said a 13th-century chronicle called The King's Mirror, ''It has shoulders like a man's but no hands. Its body apparently grows narrower from the shoulders down, so that the lower down it has been observed, the more slender it has seemed to be. But no one has ever seen how the lower end is shaped.''

title: Fordham Trounces Army, 75-57
description: Fordham routed Army, 75-57, last night at the Rose Hill Gymnaisium in a game that was less a tribute to Fordham's devastating play and more the result of a disorganized performance by the Cadets.

title: HOUSTON AIDES BEGIN VACCINATIONS IN AN EFFORT TO CURTAIL MEMINGITIS
description: Health officials vaccinated students, teachers and staff members of a southside Houston elementary school today, hoping to curtail a meningitis outbreak that has killed 10 persons and afflicted at least 53 others in the state.

title: 'Birdie' Delayed to Feb. 25
description: The opening for ''Bring Back Birdie,'' the musical in previews at the Martin Beck Theater, has been postponed from Feb. 19 to Feb. 25 to give the cast more time to rehearse and perform. The show, directed by Joe Layton, stars Donald O'Connor and Chita Rivera.

title: A BIASED FEDERAL CAREER TEST THAT AFFRONTS THE MERIT PRINCIPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Krugerrand Sales Fall
description: Krugerrand sales fell to 284,423 ounces of coins last month from 287,641 ounces in January 1980, the International Gold Corporation said today. Sales of one-ounce coins totaled 259,908 in January 1981, against 287,641 in January 1980 and 348,603 in December 1980, the company, an agency of the South African Government, said. The agency said half-ounce coins totaled 27,445, compared with 47,769 in December 1980, quarter-ounce coins 35,702, compared with 94,706, and one-tenth-ounce coins 18,666, against 414,189.

title: 2,910 Dog Stories, the Non-Shaggy Variety
description: For most of big-time dogdom, the opening of the 105th Westminster Kennel Club show in the warm hollows of Madison Square Garden yesterday meant the imminent approach of the moment of truth: tomorrow night, when Americans are told just who is really top dog in this country.

title: Jerry H. Bretz, Specialist On Effects of Flood, Dies
description: Jerry Harlan Bretz, a geologist whose theory on the effects of vast flooding in Washington State evoked ridicule and finally acceptance, died last Tuesday at his home in Homewood, Ill. He was 98 years old.

title: Bridge: When Slam Is in Prospect, 'Bashers' and Science Differ
description: When a slam is in prospect, there have long been two schools of thought. One school calls for scientific exploration, exchanging information in the hope of reaching an accurate contract. The second school believes in bashing, jumping directly to slam when it appears that the overall strength is adequate.

title: AIRLINE PILOTS GROUP THREATENING STOPPAGE TO GET AIR SAFETY STUDY
description: Airline pilots may strike for one day on March 2 if the Federal Aviation Administration does not agree to study questions about air safety, a spokesman for the Airline Pilots Association said today.

description: Behind Ecuador-Peru war, long- smoldering resentment A2 Spain's ruling party ends parley still divided A3 Canadian premiers to will petition Britain on constitution issue A4 Around the A21 Going Out Guide C11 Notes on People C13 News Analysis John Vinocur on West German So- cial Democrats' problems A3 Frank Lynn on government aides and political campaigns B8 Linda Greenhouse on Chief Jus- tice Burger's plea on crime B9 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A22

title: ALLBRITTON BIDS FOR RIGGS BANK
description: Joe L. Allbritton, former owner and publisher of The Washington Star, announced a tender offer yesterday of $67.50 each for common shares of the Riggs National Bank. He is seeking 600,000 shares, which would raise his holdings from 15.4 percent to a controlling 35 percent.

title: Ogden to Acquire Buffalo Forge
description: The Ogden Corporation said that it had agreed to acquire the Buffalo Forge Company for $32.75 a share, or about $70 million, in 10-year Ogden promissory notes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We want to send a message to people coming to New Jersey that carrying guns won't be tolerated and that New Jersey jails will have a welcome mat out for criminals who use guns.'' - Assemblyman Martin A. Herman. (A1:1.)

title: Learning the Rosedale Lesson
description: After permitting 30 white parents to occupy a school building in the Rosedale section of Queens for more than a week, New York City officials evicted them efficiently and peacefully over the weekend. The expulsion should have taught the parents what they had failed to learn during their sit-in - that the battle over Intermediate School 231 and its Rosedale annex is basically finished.

title: Geo to Acquire Realites Publication
description: Geo, which is owned by Gruner & Jahr U.S.A., the American arm of the German publishing company, is about to acquire the Englishlanguage edition of Realites, which was being published here under a licensing agreement. According to reliable sources, Geo plans to fold Realites and send Geo to its subscribers.

title: ZIMBABWE SEEKS AID FROM U.S. IN POSSIBLE TEST OF REAGAN POLICY
description: Zimbabwe has invited the United States to a foreign aid donors conference that could be a test of the Reagan Administration's commitment to the economic development of southern Africa.

title: KEY MEMBER BREAKS WITH LABOR PARTY
description: Shirley Williams, the former Education Secretary, completed her break with the Labor Party today, a long-awaited move that signaled the creation of a new party in British politics.

title: Smith Calls to Say 'Show Will Go On'
description: In what he called ''the never-ending saga of 'This Is It,' '' Sam Glass, co-promoter of the canceled Feb. 23 boxing card at Madison Square Garden, said he received a telephone call yesterday from Harold Smith, in which Smith told him, ''The show will go on.''

title: U.S. AIDES SEE POLE'S PROMOTION AS BID BY WARSAW TO LOOK FIRM
description: State Department specialists said today that they regarded the elevation of Poland's Defense Minister to the post of Prime Minister as an effort by the Polish leadership to demonstrate firmness in the face of continuing disorder.

title: JOHN H. MATHIS, RETIRED EXECUTIVE
description: John H. Mathis, retired president and chairman of the Lone Star Cement Corporation of New York City and a lawyer who was an assistant to J. Edgar Hoover in the 1930's, died of a heart attack Friday at the Gloucester Walter Reed Memorial Hospital in Virginia. He was 72 years old and lived in Port Haywood, Va.

title: Dow Falls 5.12 in Slow Trading
description: The stock market finished moderately lower yesterday in much slower trading, with some of the energy and special-situation issues posting the largest declines.

title: REAGAN SAID TO PLAN $32 BILLION INCREASE IN MILITARY OUTLAYS
description: The Reagan Administration is fashioning a military budget that calls for an increase of $32 billion over President Carter's proposed budgets for this year and the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, according to officials at the Pentagon and in military-related industry.

title: EASING FEDERAL CONTROL OF PUBLIC LAND
description: The new Secretary of the Interior, James G. Watt, arrived in Washington with a reputation as a tough hired gun, riding into town with pistols blazing in behalf of the West's ''sagebrush rebellion.''

title: Rebels Are Said to Attack 13 Sites in Uganda
description: Rebels who said they were seeking to overthrow the Government of President Milton Obote attacked five army barracks, seven police stations and a prison early today, Ugandan sources here and in neighboring Kenya reported.

title: RESEARCHERS AROUND WORLD PLUMB THE ESSENCE OF GRAVITY
description: WHAT is gravity? Of the basic forces it is the least understood. Does it, as Einstein proposed, take the form of waves, ranging from the vanishingly small to miles in length, the way light and other forms of electromagnetic radiation do? No one knows for sure. But now the effort to find out - an effort that has been growing for years - has taken on heroic proportions as scientists around the world hone existing instruments and devise new ones for a variety of tests.

title: LUIGI PROVIDENZA
description: Luigi Providenza, founder of the 28,000-member Italian Catholic Federation, died yesterday.

title: Tampax Has Hired Ruder & Finn Firm
description: In the wake of the scare over toxic shock syndrome, apparently related to the use of tampons, Tampax Inc., the country's leading manufacturer of the women's sanitary product, which has never had outside public relations counsel, has retained Ruder & Finn, the largest independent public relations firm.

title: Market Place; Trader Caution Shown on NCH
description: THE NCH Corporation, once a Wall Street darling, has been out of favor for years. In the fiscal year ended April 30, 1975, NCH began losing momentum. The company, which manufactures and sells industrial chemicals from factory door to factory door, earned $1.61 a share that year, an increase of only 9 percent.

title: Puerto Rico Prison Inmates Strike to Protest Conditions
description: More than 500 inmates in three prisons went on strike today, protesting prison conditions by refusing to leave their cells to eat.

title: FREE AGENCY IS HOCKEY TOPIC
description: The National Hockey League's owners met again yesterday with representatives of the N.H.L. Players Association in Los Angeles in an effort to reach agreement on just how much freedom a free agent should have.

title: Construction Due At Army Terminal
description: A shipping company said the Army had agreed to lease a portion of land at the Military Ocean Terminal for development by the company.

title: French Socialist Visits Peking
description: Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist Party candidate in France's presidential election this spring, arrived today and began talks with Hu Yaobang, the Communist Party general secretary.

title: JOEY BISHOP, AT 63, SAVORS DEBUT
description: AFTER Saturday's matinee of ''Sugar Babies,'' Joey Bishop sat in his dressing room at the Mark Hellinger Theater, nibbling at a bowl of chili and applying an icepack to a strained left knee.

title: Out-of-Tune Solo Due
description: He's president of the Clarion Music Society and attends eight to 10 concerts a week, and if there's one thing Thomas Newbold Morgan knows, it's what a violin is supposed to sound like.

title: Uncle Sam May Want 'You,' but Not Ed Feuz
description: ''It's a Catch-22 situation,'' Ed Feuz complained after the Georgia man's latest attempt to serve his country. Mr. Feuz, it may be recalled, was dismissed from the National Guard after it was discovered that he had five children, three more than Army regulations allow for his pay grade.

title: No Headline
description: Talking Businesswith Luis S. Mendez of Dillon, Read What Investors Can Expect

title: Fed May Curb Money Funds
description: The Federal Reserve Board is considering imposing reserve requirements on money market mutual funds, Frederick H. Schultz, a Fed governor, said yesterday.

title: St. Bonaventure 63 Rhode Island 58
description: Mark Jones hit four free throws in the final minute tonight to spark St. Bonaventure to a 63-58 upset of Rhode Island in an Eastern Eight game.

title: Bank of America Names Cashier And World Operations Officer
description: Two senior appointments were made yesterday by the Bank of America to fill the jobs left vacant by Samuel H. Armacost, 41, who is moving up to president and chief executive officer, and Leland E. Prussia, 51, who will become chairman. The changes were set in motion because A.W. Clausen, 57, who had been president and chief executive, will become president of the World Bank on July 1.

title: Air Canada Gets Loan
description: The United States Export-Import Bank said today that it would lend Air Canada $26.5 million toward the purchase of three Boeing 727 jet aircraft. The bank said in a statement that the airline would make a $9.3 million cash payment and a private bank would lend $26.5 million to complete the $62.3 million sale. The Ex-Im Bank will charge annual interest of 8 1/2 percent.

title: MILACRON'S AIM: NO. 1 IN ROBOTS
description: After a year on the job, the welder at IngersollRand's upstate New York compressor assembly plant shows no signs of getting bored. Or hungry. Or tired. The welder is a robot.

title: KOCH MOVES TOWN MEETING IN BROOKLYN AFTER HECKLING
description: More than 100 people began booing and jeering shortly after Mayor Koch opened a town meeting at the John Jay High School in Brooklyn last night, and the Mayor promptly moved the meeting from the school's large auditorium to a smaller room, screening out the most virulent critics.

title: PROPOSED MINERS PACT IN WEST OFFERS A FORM OF COST-OF-LIVING PAY
description: A tentative separate settlement has been reached between a Western coal strip-mining company and the United Mine Workers union while bargaining continues here for a new industrywide three-year contract.

title: Band of Musick Will Play In Central Park on Sunday
description: In observance of Washington's Birthday, the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation will present a concert by the Band of Musick of the Federal Music Society, a group of professional musicians who have mastered the techniques of early American instruments, at the Dairy in Central Park at noon next Sunday.

title: SPAIN'S RULING PARTY ENDS PARLEY WITH ITS RANKS STILL BADLY DIVIDED
description: Spain's center-right ruling party, jolted by the resignation of Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez, ended an occasionally acrimonious three-day congress today without having resolved major organizational and ideological differences.

title: Hofstra 87, West Chester St. 76
description: David Taylor scored 29 points, grabbed 16 rebounds and blocked six shots tonight to lead Hofstra to an 87-76 victory over West Chester State in an East Coast Conference game. Gary Cheslock added 20 points and pulled down 11 rebounds as the Flying Dutchmen improved their league record to 4-5, 9-11 over all. West Chester (1-9 and 5-13) was paced by Kevin Givens with 17 points.

title: Harvard Takes Beanpot In Upset of Boston College
description: Harvard stunned heavily-favored Boston College tonight, winning the 29th Beanpot Tournament, 2-0, before 14,456 fans at Boston Garden.

title: FORD RE-ENTERS RACING FIELD
description: At the turn of the century, the Ford Motor Company had a problem: Sales were slow, and imports captured much of the public's fancy. So Henry Ford went racing.

title: IN BELMONT AREA OF SOUTH BRONX, FEAR AND CRIME ARE REMOTE CONCERNS
description: Lena Simeone walks alone at night, without fear, in an area of New York City that has become a national symbol of urban decay, hopelessness and even lawlessness.

title: L.I.R.R. TIED UP BY BREAKDOWN
description: Tens of thousands of rush-hour commuters were delayed by a series of breakdowns on the Long Island Rail Road last night, including one in which a train struck a shopping cart left on a main track, a railroad spokesman said.

title: News Analysis
description: West Germany's Social Democrats are going through a kind of identity crisis that is making it increasingly difficult for Chancellor Helmut Schmidt to govern the nation effectively.

title: N.H.L. All-Star Rosters; Prince of Wales
description: Goal-Don Beaupre, Minnesota; Mario Lessard, Los Angeles. DefenseMark Howe, Hartford; Reid Larson, Detroit; Randy Carlyle, Pittsburgh; Robert Picard, Toronto; Ray Bourque, Boston; Rod Langway, Montreal.

title: REASON FOR MAKING TRIPS STUMPS U.S. AGENCIES 26.8% OF THE TIME
description: The reason most frequently cited by Federal agencies for trips by their employees is ''unknown.'' Among 10 listed reasons, ''unknown'' accounts for 26.8 percent of the explanations for travel given by agencies surveyed by the Office of Management and Budget. Site visits account for 25.5 percent; relocation, 14.8 percent, and training, 11.5 percent.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS TO ALLAY FEARS ON CUTS IN AID
description: President Reagan told a group of county executives and state legislators today that his proposed cuts in assistance to local governments would be softened by easing restrictions and requirements governing the use of Federal aid.

title: SAN DIEGO COUNTY BASKING IN BENEFITS OF SOLAR ENERGY LEGISLATION
description: In the two years since San Diego County adopted the nation's first law requiring more use of solar energy, this sun-drenched city has become a national leader in its use and development, according to industry and government officials.

title: OTHERS REMAIN AT 19 1 2%
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank, lowered its prime lending rate yesterday to 19 percent, the lowest level among the nation's largest banks.

title: STAGE: 'THE PREVALENCE OF MRS. SEAL'
description: ''THE Prevalence of Mrs. Seal,'' a new comedy by Otis Bigelow at the Manhattan Punch Line, is a slapdash mixture of ''Dracula,'' ''Frankenstein'' and almost any other horror story one could name. If it were funny, it would be ridiculous, as in Charles Ludlam's Ridiculous Theatrical Company or ''The Rocky Horror Show.'' Instead, it is arch, about as quaint and crack-brained a creature feature as one might encounter in a year of Saturday movie matinees.

title: MOHOMED CHAGLA, INDIA OFFICIAL
description: Mahomed Ali Currim Chagla, an Indian jurist and statesman who served as his country's Foreign Minister and Ambassador to the United States, died of a heart attack yesterday, his family reported in Bombay. He was 80 years old.

title: Goodrich Net Up 53.4% in Quarter
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said today that its 1980 fourth-quarter earnings climbed 53.4 percent, but that profits for the year dropped 25 percent because of reduced production.

title: Energy
description: The U.S. is going to the international market to buy oil for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The Energy Department said it would seek 20,000 barrels a day. The move, which goes against Saudi Arabia's wishes, would be the first direct foreign purchases for the controversial reserve in two years. (Page D1.)

title: 200 From Rosedale March at Annex Site
description: Some 200 white residents of Rosedale, Queens, marched outside Public School 138 there chanting, ''No annex, no school,'' at the start and end of the school day yesterday in their protest against the closing of a predominantly white intermediate-school annex at the school. School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola closed the annex Jan. 30 and ordered its 375 students to enroll at the main school, Intermediate School 231, where most of the students are blacks.

title: Accounts
description: * Young Miss magazine to E.T. Howard Advertising.

title: Syracuse Sets Back Georgetown, 66-64
description: Marty Headd's driving hook shot with five seconds left tonight gave Syracuse a 66-64 victory over Georgetown in a Big East Conference game.

title: De Paul 83, Creighton 57
description: Mark Aguirre scored a game-high 24 points, all but 2 in the opening half, and Terry Cummings added 18 tonight as No. 3-ranked De Paul trounced Creighton, 83-57.

title: News Analysis
description: If Chief Justice Warren E. Burger intended to touch off a vigorous debate by calling yesterday for a renewed war on crime, he succeeded almost immediately.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT MOVING AHEAD WITH CHARLESTON SEGREGATION CASE
description: The Justice Department pressed forward today with a desegregation suit that was filed against the public schools of Charleston County, S.C., in the final weeks of the Carter Administration.

title: Fluor Wins Saudi Contract
description: The Fluor Corporation said today that it had won a $500 million contract from the Jubail Petrochemical Company to design and construct a polyethylene plant in Saudi Arabia. Jubail Petrochemical is a joint venture between the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation and Exxon Chemical Arabia Inc. Construction of the plant will begin in early 1982. The plant will produce 260,000 metric tons a year of low-density polyethylene, a material used in the manufacturing of consumer items.

title: BEHIND ECUADOR WAR, LONG-SMOLDERING RESENTMENT
description: The consensus emerging among diplomats here and in Quito is that the small border war between Peru and Ecuador that ended last week was precipitated by Ecuador in an attempt to draw new boundaries.

title: El Paso Is Prepared To Take Gas Loss
description: The El Paso Company, the sole United States importer of Algerian natural gas, said today that it was prepared to take a charge against earnings of up $375 million if the United States and Algeria were unable to agree on a new price for Algerian liquefied natural gas exports.

title: G. S. DEVINE, FORMER PRESIDENT OF C. & O. AND B. & O. RAILROADS
description: Gregory S. DeVine, former president of the Chesapeake & Ohio Railway and its affiliate, the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad, died Saturday at St. John's Hospital in Cleveland. He was 74 years old and lived in Cleveland.

title: Trenton Police Head Beaten in His Home
description: T. Howard Waldron, who as Trenton's Public Safety Director heads both the Police and Fire Departments, was severely beaten and his brothers were also assaulted yesterday by three masked men broke into the Waldrons share.

title: INTEREST RATES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Short-term and long-term interest rates rose substantially yesterday, mostly because of a large volume of new Treasury securities that dealers are still trying to place among investors, analysts said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ampex Corp. has been awarded contracts valued at $12 million to supply videotape to three major video program duplicators.

title: Decontrol Bus Travel
description: Congress has loosened the Government's grip on airlines, trucks and railroads. Now, say reformers, it's time to add intercity buses to the list, and they're right. Reducing regulation in this important industry should pay dividends in higher productivity.

title: The Haze Comes Home
description: Those summertime hazes that come north from the Gulf of Mexico on the strength of tropical air masses are in many cases bringing air pollutants back to their places of origin, according to a study published in the current issue of the journal Science.

title: PLAN FOR WESTWAY GAINS ENDORSEMENT FROM U.S. SECRETARY
