description: The Secretary of Transportation said yesterday that he supported the controversial Westway highway project and that its construction was ''only a question of timing and funding.''

title: CHAMBER: CONTEMPORARY WORKS FEATURED AT JUILLIARD FESTIVAL
description: LAST Thursday's edition of Juilliard's weeklong Festival of Contemporary Music featured things old, things new, things borrowed and things violent, if not blue. This rather improbable wedding of 20th-century chamber music styles at the Juilliard Theater began with Benjamin Lees's Sonata Breve for Piano, a 1956 update of Lisztian virtuosity, and ended with the infanticidal musings of ''Medea,'' a dramatic cantata for soprano and 12 instruments by 21-year-old Ronald Caltabiano.

title: Mix-Up Imperils Records in 5,000
description: The capacity crowd of 18,211 left Madison Square Garden Friday night after having watched Suleiman Nyambui of Tanzania better the American all-comers record and unofficial world indoor record for the 5,000-meter run. It also saw Alberto Salazar, an Oregon senior, finish second and better the American record.

title: by Steven Larrabee
description: In deciding whether to lift the grain embargo that Jimmy Carter imposed on the Soviet Union after its invasion of Afghanistan, the Reagan Administration should give priority to longterm strategic interests over short-term domestic political considerations.

title: CANADA PREMIERS TO PETITION BRITAIN
description: Six of Canada's ten provincial premiers, who oppose a plan by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau to establish a new constitution, announced today that they would take their case to London, where final approval must be given.

title: CONCERT: ROSTROPOVICH LEADS VESPERS
description: MSTISLAV ROSTROPOVICH'S series of concerts celebrating the 25th anniversary of his American debut continued Sunday night at Carnegie Hall with his conducting the most unusual one of the lot. This was a performance, which lasted 65 minutes without intermission, of Rachmaninoff's rarely heard Vespers (Op. 37) -or ''All Night Vigil'' or ''Vigil Service''; the title is variously translated.

title: HAIG JOINS GOVERNORS OF SIX STATES AT HARTFORD RITES FOR MRS. GRASSO
description: Amid military pomp and solemnity, former Governor Ella T. Grasso was buried today in her native Windsor Locks, Conn., four days after she died of cancer at the age of 61.

title: Havana Plans Lenin Monument
description: A 29-foot-high monument to Lenin is to be built soon in Havana, the Yugoslav press agency reported today.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE;
description: Big-name performers such as Laurence Olivier, Henry Fonda, Gregory Peck and Frank Sinatra have been induced to make lucrative television and radio commercials, but Richard Burton has held out - until now.

title: Michael Schimmel, Accountant And Philanthropist, Is Dead at 84
description: Michael Schimmel, an accountant and philanthropist, died last Wednesday at the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 84 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.00-19.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WARNER, CURTISS SHOW RISE
description: Warner Communications Inc., the diversified entertainment company, reported yesterday that fourth-quarter operating earnings rose 32.3 percent, to $44.6 million, or 76 cents a share, from $33.7 million, or 59 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

title: LITTLE MISS WAS BORN TO SELL
description: Once upon a time, in the kingdom of Strawberryland, there lived a little girl named Strawberry Shortcake. She had a red dress, a floppy pink bonnet and a will of such sugar-coated iron that her image - and sometimes her strawberry scent - was soon imprinted upon greeting cards, bedding, pajamas, gift-wrap paper and party hats. Retailers loved her because, even before her first birthday, Strawberry Shortcake had rung up sales of $100 million.

title: Sharp Rises Sought In Some Apartments
description: An association of apartment-building owners said that rents for nearly 900,000 New York City apartments should be increased sharply to cover rising costs for fuel oil, taxes and mortgages.

title: KNIGHT TO REMEMBER
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN AT BAR PARLEY SEEK RISE IN STATUS AS LAWYERS AND JUDGES
description: More than a century after the first woman was admitted to the practice of law in the United States, in Iowa in 1869, women lawyers are still playing a secondary role in the legal profession and its many leadership organizations and are actively seeking to improve their status in those groups.

title: by Malcolm W. Browne
description: COSMOLOGY, like horse racing, is at its best when a photo finish seems likely. Two rival theories about the ultimate fate of the universe are running neck and neck just now, and the excitement of the race has spurred astronomers, mathematicians, particle physicists, chemists and theorists to search their specialties for clues that might contribute something to the outcome.

title: Missiles Launched in Test Of Air Command Readiness
description: Two unarmed Minuteman 3 missiles were launched today as part of a Strategic Air Command drill that suddenly ordered hundreds of bombers and jet tankers into the sky yesterday, an Air Force spokesman said.

title: REAGAN'S CONTESTED HIRING FREEZE CALLED A SUCCESS
description: Although President Reagan's freeze on Federal hiring has run into some legal obstacles and criticism from skeptics, Administration officials say that it is working and will remain in force.

title: CHEAP LABOR VIA MONOLINGUAL EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. REAGAN'S SPECIAL CAUSE
description: Lady Bird Johnson planted trees. Betty Ford campaigned for women's rights. Rosalynn Carter supported mental health.

title: Glass Sculpture at Museum
description: The Hudson River Museum is showing an exhibition of new glass sculpture, drawings and furniture by Larry Bell.

title: FILM: ROBERT YOUNG'S 'ALAMBRISTA!'
description: ''Alambrista'' was shown as part of the Festival of American Independent Feature Films at the Paramount Theater. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin published in The New York Times on Sept. 23, 1979. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Campbell Soup Company, Camden, N.J., has appointed Alden T. Leavenworth president, Latin America.

title: Missing Atlanta Youth Found Alive in Florida
description: Lee Gooch, a 15-year-old black youth missing from Atlanta since early January, has been found in Florida, a police spokesman said today. The police were trying to confirm reports that another missing child, 11-year-old Patrick Baltazar, was sighted in Atlanta over the weekend.

title: EX-PATIENT SAYS TARNOWER SHOUTED AT A 'JEAN' ON PHONE DAY HE DIED
description: A former patient of Dr. Herman Tarnower testified today that she heard the doctor shout in a telephone conversation on the morning of the day he was shot: ''Jean, I want you to stop bothering me.''

title: Tass Accuses the C.I.A.  Of Terrorism in Europe
description: The Soviet Union said today that the American Central Intelligence Agency was reputedly involved in terrorism in Italy, Spain, Greece and Portugal.

title: WOMAN WANTED IN JAILBREAK TRY INVOLVING COPTER GIVES HERSELF UP
description: A 30-year-old woman sought on charges of hijacking a helicopter in an attempt to pluck a prisoner from the roof of the Federal jail in lower Manhattan walked into a Federal court room last night and turned herself in.

title: PROTESTANT SCHOOLS OPEN AT RATE OF THREE A DAY
description: TRUMBULL,Conn. THE English lesson Louise Beckett was teaching her fourth graders illustrated the use of pronouns through a passage about the Japanese custom of removing shoes before entering a house.

title: NEW FACES IN CONGRESS MEAN SWEEPING CHANGE IN SCIENCE POLICY
description: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC and technological issues seldom provoke bitter partisan battles in Congress, but extensive changes in the makeup of key science-related committees in the new Congress portend some significant shifts in American science policy.

title: CHARITABLE DONATIONS AND CASUALTY LOSSES
description: Your TaxesA Guide to Preparing 1980 ReturnsEighth of 12 articles.- By DEBORAH RANKIN

title: TV: 'THE CHOICE' ON CBS FOCUSES ON ABORTION
description: THE subject is abortion. It is being considered by a 20-year-old college student who doesn't want her pregnancy to interfere with her fiance's career opportunities. Her 38-year-old mother, on the other hand, finds herself unexpectedly pregnant at a point when her husband is burdened enough with assorted midlife crises. Decisions, decisions.

title: No Headline
description: IN the gray gloom of his garage, Tom Seaver was pitching. The Cincinnati Red right

title: Man, 22, Is Charged In Slaying of Father
description: WHITE PLAINS (UPI) - A man allegedly killed his father - apparently with an ax - and critically wounded his mother in the family home in Greenburgh, the police said.

title: Mobil Lifts Outlay To $5 Billion in '81
description: The Mobil Corporation said it will spend $5 billion in capital and exploration expenditures in 1981, nearly double its 1980 earnings and up 27 percent from the prior year.

title: THE CO-SOVEREIGNTY OF STATES
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Shuffles Aides in Broadcast Group
description: CBS, which announced executive shifts in its news division last week, yesterday announced a restructuring of its broadcast group. Among the changes announced by Gene F. Jankowski, president of the group, was the promotion of Thomas F. Leahy to senior broadcast vice president, a new position with responsibility for the CBS owned television stations, the CBS Radio division and the recently formed CBS Cable division.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Net Off 15.8% in Quarter
description: Ogilvy & Mather International yesterday was the first of the publicly held agencies to issue its financial report on the fourth quarter of 1980.

title: CENTRAL PARK'S PINETUM FLOURISHES AS AN OUTDOOR LAB
description: IT is not Longfellow's forest primeval - the pines are not murmuring. Nor is it Conrad's ''silent sea of pines.'' But if a forest geneticist and a philanthropist have their way, a collection of young pine trees ringing the north end of the Great Lawn in Central Park will grow into a tall year-round Manhattan landmark of evergreens that will provide the taste of a forest for humans, as well as sustenance and shelter for wildlife. The trees have already become a resource for scientists.

title: Zale, Peoples in Pact
description: The Zale Corporation, target of an unwelcome takeover proposal by Toronto-based Peoples Jewellers Ltd., said it had agreed to suspend litigation against Peoples and that the Canadian company had agreed to refrain from purchasing more Zale stock.

title: Editor Admits Selling Coverage And Sees Nothing Wrong With It
description: The editor of a weekly newspaper accused of selling favorable front-page news coverage to Mayor James Conway said yesterday that he saw nothing wrong with that practice.

title: An Appraisal
description: It is hard not to think that the Westway could have been built by now, so prolonged has been the debate over this immense highway, landfill and park project for Manhattan's West Side. It was first proposed in the early 1970's, and the controversy that surrounds it seems to have grown more intense with each passing year.

title: DOUBT CAST ON RELEASE OF NUCLEAR DATA
description: A report by the staff of the House Interior Committee has concluded that the managers of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant withheld information related to the severity of the 1979 reactor accident and made misleading statements to state and Federal officials.

title: CURB ON CODE STUDIES STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: A decision by a group of scholars to restrict publication of computer research on secret codes has heightened a two-year controversy in the academic community and raised questions about a contradiction between a researcher's right to academic freedom and an intelligence agency's job of protecting national security.

title: 2 Charged in Arson That Killed Five
description: Two men who were evicted two weeks ago from a Brooklyn tenement were charged early this morning with arson-homicide in connection with a fire there Sunday that killed two young mothers and three of their children, the police said.

title: James Brown, 83, Dies;
description: A Retired State Justice

title: U.S. TO BUY FOREIGN OIL FOR RESERVE
description: The Government, in a policy shift, is returning to the international market to buy oil for the country's strategic petroleum reserve, the Department of Energy disclosed today.

title: by Donald J. Newman
description: There is widespread disillusionment with the way we treat criminals in our society. Almost all public officials are calling for tougher measures as the means to control or prevent crime. The key thrusts are punishment (now called ''just dessert''), deterrence, and confinement. Parole is under fire.

title: BRIARD ADVANCES TO WESTMINSTER FINALS
description: The top-winning Briard in the history of the breed in America, Ch. Phydeaux What's Happening, became the first finalist in the 105th Westminster Kennel Club show, which opened a two-day run in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: MRS. DWYER BOARDS PLANE IN TEHERAN AFTER DELAY IN HER DEPORTATION

title: Onassis Yacht Christina Again in Limelight
description: The famous yacht Christina, upon which the late Aristotle Onassis wooed the late opera star Maria Callas and the shipping tycoon's last wife, Jacqueline Onassis, figures in a $60 million tax claim on the inheritance of Christina Onassis, Mr. Onassis's daughter.

title: Allied Leases Outlet
description: The Allied Stores Corporation said it had leased the former Korvettes outlet in the Green Acres shopping center in Valley Stream, L.I., and will reopen the 190,000-square-foot unit as a Gertz store next fall.

title: NO DELUGE; 1,600 Jobs to Go ...
description: Ronald Reagan has never posed as a champion of women's rights. He opposes the Equal Rights Amendment, arguing that its goal can be better advanced through statute. He thinks it's time to put a woman on the Supreme Court, but he welcomed the campaign support of groups whose key objective is to move women out of the workplace and back into the home.

title: by Zhores Medvedev
description: The grain embargo that America imposed on the Soviet Union in January 1980 after the Afghanistan invasion has had an important stimulative effect on Soviet agricultural policy, forcing the leaders to mobilize all reserves and potentials for the development of agricultural production and to implement some new reforms.

title: WILL LONDON LOSE D'OYLY CARTE?
description: The D'Oyly Carte Opera Company said today that, after more than 100 years of performing the comic operas of Gilbert and Sullivan, it would close down on July 18 unless it could find new sponsors.

title: Emergency Drill Marks Coast Quake's Anniversary
description: Officials marked the 10th anniversary of the disastrous San Fernando earthquake today by testing emergency plans for handling an imaginary quake in which hundreds would die, freeways would collapse and gas lines would break.

title: SAUDIS LIFT SOME OIL PRICES 12%
description: Saudi Arabia has increased the price of oil it is supplying under temporary contracts to countries that lost supplies as a result of the Iran-Iraq war, oil industry sources said yesterday. The new price is $36 a barrel, 12 1/8 percent higher, or $4 above the standard Saudi price.

title: Bank of America Bid
description: The Bank of America today submitted the highest bid, $150 million, at a tender called by the Argentine central bank for the Banco Internacional, which is owned by the bankrupt Argentine holding company Sasetru Sacifiaie, central bank sources said.

title: Terydale Trustees Sell 4 Properties
description: Trustees of Terydale Realty Trust, who said Friday they would liquidate the trust in a bid to block an unfriendly takeover bid by a New York group, disclosed that they had already sold off some of the trust's properties.

title: Israel Warns Egypt on Delay In Resuming Palestine Talks
description: Israel warned today that Cairo's unwillingness to reopen the stalled negotiations on Palestinian autonomy was a breach of the accords reached at Camp David and might release the Israelis from fulfilling some of their commitments under the pacts.

title: Offshore Oil Output Rising
description: World production of offshore crude oil will increase from 500,000 barrels a day in 1980 to one million barrels daily this year, the Oil & Gas Journal, an industry letter, predicted today.

title: PARAMOUNT'S $1 MILLION SAVES COPPOLA'S STUDIO AND NEW FILM
description: Paramount Pictures came to the rescue of Francis Coppola's Zoetrope Studio today by purchasing a $500,000 interest in ''Interface,'' a movie that Zoetrope has in the planning stage, and by giving the Academy Award-winning writer-director a $500,000 personal loan.

title: WHATEVER HAPPENED TO SUPPLY AND DEMAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Chairman Resumes Fuller Post
description: William V. Lawson 2d, 56 years old, a former chairman and president of the George A. Fuller Company, has returned to the company to become chief executive officer and, once again, chairman of the big New York-based international general contractor and builder.

title: Seatrain Asks Its Creditors To Help It Avoid Bankruptcy
description: Seatrain Lines Inc., the troubled shipping company, pressed a campaign yesterday to persuade creditors to accept delays in payments of its debts so that it would not be pushed into Chapter 11 or bankruptcy.

title: Fed Backs Irving
description: The Irving Trust Company said it had received Federal Reserve Board approval to consolidate its Los Angeles Edge Act subsidiary into its Miami Edge Act subsidiary. Edge Act corporations are empowered to conduct only international business. Irving Trust said the consolidated corporation had been given authorization to set up branches this year in Atlanta, Chicago, Dallas and Grand Cayman Island, the bank said.

title: Q. If the common cold is caused by a virus, why is it frequently traced back to exposure to cold weather?
description: A. Exposure to cold weather will not cause you to catch a cold. You can only catch a cold after being exposed to another person who has the infection. In cold weather, people are indoors more often and in closer contact with others who might spread cold viruses.

title: JERSEY SHIFTS FUNDS FOR WATER AID
description: The New Jersey Legislature, in a rare emergency step, voted unanimously to reappropriate $26 million in unspent bondissue revenues late today for diversion pipelines and other projects to ease the water shortage in the northeastern part of the state.

title: JOINT CHIEFS' HEAD RETAINED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan has decided to retain Gen. David C. Jones as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Pentagon officials said today, thus ending three months of suspense and handing another rebuff to some conservatives on Capitol Hill.

title: New Jersey Casino Shifts Ownership
description: Control of the financially troubled Brighton Hotel and Casino has been sold to Dallas-based Inns of the Americas and two businessmen from Binghamton, N.Y., it was announced today.

title: High Wire Act at the Khyber Pass
description: Nothing would better suit the Soviet Union than a deal that sanitized its seizure of Afghanistan, cut off help to the insurgents from Pakistan and relieved pressure on its occupation army of 80,000. If that is the purpose of Pakistan's overture to the Soviet puppet regime in Kabul, there is reason for concern. What is Moscow threatening to elicit this nervousness?

title: Fate of Jordanian Envoy In Doubt After Deadline
description: A deadline set by a telephone caller for the execution of a kidnapped Jordanian diplomat passed today with no word of his fate and no response from Jordan or Iraq to the demand that they extradite seven Syrian defectors.

title: Filing Date Set For Marathon
description: The New York Road Runners Club announced yesterday that beginning June 2 it would accept requests for entry forms for the New York City Marathon on Oct. 25.

title: STATE PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITALS FORCED TO CHANGE OR CLOSE
description: ERODED from without by changing philosophies of psychiatric care and dwindling financial support, and crippled from within by demoralization of staff and patients alike, many state mental hospitals around the country are being forced either to close their doors or change the way they operate.

title: SINGER-BAND LEADER
description: Bill Haley, the singer, guitarist and band leader whose original recording of ''Rock Around the Clock'' has sold 22.5 million copies since 1955, died yesterday of natural causes at his home in Harlingen, Tex.. The 55-year-old entertainer was one of the pioneers of rock-and-roll.

title: Faye Dunaway to Portray Joan Crawford in Movie
description: Joan Crawford will be portrayed by Faye Dunaway in the film ''Mommie Dearest,'' based on the book by Miss Crawford's daughter, Christina.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PAPERING THE HOUSE

title: IRAN AND IRAQ SAID TO AGREE TO VISIT BY ISLAMIC LEADERS
description: Iran in the presence of a United Nations representative. The Russians also reportedly accepted the idea that the participation in such talks of the Afghan regime of Babrak Karmal would not mean that either Pakistan or Iran recognized his Soviet-backed Government.

title: Anchorman Faces Driving Count
description: Charles B. Kuralt, 46 years old, the former roving correspondent who is now a television anchorman for CBS News, was stopped at 12:10 A.M. yesterday near the San Francisco International Airport and arrested for ''misdemeanor driving while intoxicated,'' a Highway Patrol spokesman said.

title: U.S. TO DELAY REQUIREMENT FOR AIRBAGS AND AUTOMATIC PROTECTION IN CARS
description: The Reagan Administration proposed today to change Federal automobile safety rules so that manufacturers could postpone installing airbags or other automatic crash protection for at least one year.

title: First National Stores
description: First National Supermarkets said it would close 14 supermarkets in its Portland division within the next two weeks, affecting about 430 employees. Seven of the stores are in Maine, six in New Hampshire and one in Vermont. The company said the stores being closed were too small to be profitable.

title: DOCTORS SAY LOWENSTEIN SUSPECT CANNOT BE HELD CRIMINALLY LIABLE
description: Psychiatrists for both the prosecution and defense have concluded that Dennis Sweeney, who is accused of killing former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein, cannot be held criminally responsible for the slaying, Mr. Sweeney's lawyer said yesterday.

title: BURGER'S CALL TO ARMS; by Tom Wicker; Burger's Call To Arms
description: Two cheers for Chief Justice Burger, who told the American Bar Association the other day that defense against crime was as vital to national security as ''the budget of the Pentagon.'' In fact, it's probably of more immediate concern to most Americans.

title: OPPONENTS OF FLOURISHING SEX INDUSTRY HINDERED BY ITS OPEN PUBLIC
description: ACCEPTANCE By WILLIAM SERRIN

title: TUDOR CITY SWAP GAINS APPROVAL OF PLANNING UNIT
description: The New York City Planning Commission yesterday approved the transfer of city park land along the East River to the Helmsley real estate interests in exchange for two private parks in Tudor City on which the developer had long sought to erect a high-rise residential building.

title: ASSEMBLY IN ALBANY ADOPTS A NUCLEAR SAFETY PACKAGE
description: The Assembly passed legislation today aimed at imposing more stringent safeguards on operators of nuclear power plants, on the safety and training of the people who run them and on the transportation of radioactive materials.

title: Advertising; Consulting Firm for Casinos
description: ''I HAVE decided that I'm going to work with winning corporations,'' said Jack Byrne, the bearded, one-time agency creative type, who now has many irons in the fire.

title: CULOTTES STEP SMARTLY FOR SPRING
description: They are turning up on women in runway seats at fashion shows everywhere, including the recent spring and summer openings of the haute couture houses in Paris.

title: POPULISM'S TAINT
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. REPORT SAYS STATUS OF RIGHTS IMPROVED DURING '80
description: The State Department's annual survey of human rights reported today that torture, disappearances, and inhuman treatment of prisoners had continued to decline during the last year of the Carter Administration.

title: News Analysis
description: In ruling that there is no legal bar to Senate aides' doing political campaign work on government time, a Federal court has pointed up a gray area in campaign ethics at virtually all levels of elective office.

title: CHRYSLER PARING DIVISION
description: The Chrysler Corporation, in an economy move, plans to phase out its Mopar division, which supplies independent retailers with replacement parts for Chrysler cars and trucks, industry sources said yesterday.

title: Suit Contends Weather Forecast Led to the Death of a Fisherman
description: The widow of a fisherman lost at sea has filed a $2.2 million suit charging that the Government issued a faulty weather forecast that prompted her husband and others to go to sea as a bad storm approached.

title: Eastern and World Setting New Fares
description: Eastern Airlines and World Airways announced fare changes affecting flights from New York.

title: Ailing Fighter Retires
description: Park Chan Hee, under medical care after having been injured in his recent unsuccessful attempt at regaining the World Boxing Council flyweight title, announced his retirement today. Doctors believe he has kidney problems.

title: A Theological Difference TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: Malcolm W. Browne, in his piece ''Science and the Dramatic Vision: A Critique,''(Jan. 20) makes a common error. He begins, ''Enmeshed in Judeo-Christian tradition is the notion that knowledge is sinful.'' There are such strands in Christian thought, but this idea has never played a significant role in Jewish tradition. Too often intelligent observers attribute to the ''Judeo-Christian tradition'' concepts which are entirely Christian, ignoring theological differences between the two religions. RANDY TIFFANY MARJORIE YUDKIN Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Carter Aide's New Post
description: John P. White, 43, a Carter Administration official whose most recent job was deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget, has been appointed chairman of the Interactive Systems Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif. Peter Weiner, who founded the computer software products company in 1977, is president and chief executive officer.

title: Garwood Defense Asks Judge to Void Conviction
description: Defense lawyers, asserting that jurors ignored evidence that Pfc. Robert R. Garwood of the Marines was mentally ill, asked a military judge today to throw out their client's conviction for collaborating with the enemy in Vietnam.

title: Greek Opposition Assails Plan for Frederika's Funeral
description: The Government's decision to permit the burial in Greece this week of Queen Mother Frederika has brought strong criticism from the political opposition and threatened to revive friction over the monarchy, a recurrent cause of instability in modern Greek history.

title: DANCE: THE EGLEVSKY BALLET AND TWO FAMILIAR FACES
description: WHAT were all those people doing at the sold-out performances of the Eglevsky Ballet last weekend at Hofstra University's Adams Playhouse in Hempstead, L.I.? They turned out, frankly, to see Gelsey Kirkland and Patrick Bissell as guest artists in their first stage appearance since a celebrated contretemps with American Ballet Theater.

title: REAGAN IS ASKED TO GIVE TOP POLICY ROLE TO STATE DEPT.
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger have proposed a framework for foreign and defense policy formulation that would give the State Department the lead in most fields but put a few interagency working committees under Pentagon leadership.

title: SCHLITZ, ANHEUSER-BUSCH GAIN
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, which slid to fourth place from third among brewers in total beer sold last year, said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings for 1980 were $2.2 million, or 8 cents a share, compared with a loss of $44.8 million in the same period last year. Gross sales fell 2.9 percent, to $217.8 million from $224.3 million. These sales figures included excise taxes of $27.9 million in the 1980 quarter and $29.5 million in the period a year earlier.

title: FRENCH PHOTOGRAPHER DIES IN U.S. OF WOUND RECEIVED IN EL SALVADOR
description: MIAMI,Feb.9 (AP) A French photographer who was shot and seriously wounded by sniper fire during guerrilla warfare in El Salvador last month died here tonight, hospital officials said.

title: Morgan, at 37, Goes to Giants
description: Joe Morgan, the veteran second baseman who became a free agent after playing last season with Houston, signed a one-year contract with the San Francisco Giants today.

title: Paisley Begins a Drive in Ulster Against Closer British-Irish Ties
description: The Rev. Ian Paisley, the militant Ulster Protestant leader, today began a campaign against British efforts to improve relations with Ireland.

title: by Tom Buckley
description: IN ''Anatomy of a Volcano,'' which will be seen from 8 to 9 o'clock tonight on WNET-TV, Channel 13, the ''Nova'' series studies the eruption of Mount St. Helens with its accustomed intelligence and professionalism.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1981
description: International In a Government shake-up in Poland, Prime Minister Jozef Pinkowksi was dismissed and was replaced by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Defense Minister. The general, a Soviet-trained officer with a reputation for professionalism, is generally regarded as a moderate. (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington reacted calmly to the shake-up in Warsaw. State Department specialists said they did not believe that the promotion of Gen. Jaruzelski presaged a crackdown. They said they viewed the change as an effort by Poland's leadership to demonstrate firmness in the face of continuing labor turmoil. (A12:3-4.)

title: Roth Novel on the Way
description: Philip Roth's latest novel will appear in full, serialized, before it is published as a book, but the four parts of the book will run in three different magazines.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard GONE CRAZY AND BACK AGAIN. The Rise and Fall of the Rolling Stone Gen- eration. By Robert Sam Anson. 361 pages. Doubleday. $14.95.

title: Pro Basketball Notebook; Huston Faces an Adjustment to Another New Team
description: With the approach of Sunday's National Basketball Association trading deadline, uncertainty grips the families of many players. At noon yesterday, at the Dallas-Fort Worth airport, Geoff Huston said goodbye to his family, and flew to Cleveland to join the Cavaliers.

title: Basques Strike to Protest Murder by Rebel Group
description: A general strike closed down most businesses and heavy industry in the three northern Basque provinces today in protest over the assassination of a nuclear engineer by the separatist organization E.T.A.

title: Hackensack Water Sees Lag
description: The Hackensack Water Company said it expects sharply lower earnings, and perhaps a loss, in the first quarter because of continuing drought and water conservation measures in the metropolitan New York area.

title: Diabetic Receives Sophisticated Pump
description: Monte Patterson, a 41-year-old diabetic, has become the first person to receive a sophisticated, electronically controlled insulin pump that can respond to his instructions, doctors at the University of New Mexico have reported.

title: BOXING CASE FIGURE BELIEVED AIDING F.B.I.
description: L. Benjamin Lewis, who resigned abruptly last month as operations officer of the Wells Fargo National Bank branch in Beverly Hills, appears to be cooperating with Federal agents investigating the theft of at least $21.3 million from the bank.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 10, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Scientific and technical subcommit- tee of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: A PEOPLE'S CONSTITUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Chrysler raised the base sticker prices of its imported cars by an average of 1.2 percent today, dealers said. The increases apply to the Dodge Colt and Plymouth Champ, which went up 1.3 percent, and the Dodge Challenger and Plymouth Sapporo, which went up nine-tenths of 1 percent.

title: A WHIMSICAL BALANCHINE MAPS JUNE TCHAIKOVSKY BALLET FESTIVAL
description: George Balanchine gave a party for an old friend named Peter Tchaikovsky yesterday at the Russian Tea Room. Billed as a press conference to announce details of the New York City Ballet's upcoming Tchaikovsky Festival, which will take place from June 4 to 14 at the New York State Theater, the occasion had the choreographer in one of his slyest moods as he addressed the reporters and City Ballet dancers who packed an upstairs room at the restaurant.

title: JERSEY TO LENGTHEN SENTENCE IF GUN IS USED IN CRIME
description: A bill mandating a minimum three-year prison term for anyone using a gun in the commission of a violent crime in New Jersey received final legislative approval today when it cleared the Assembly, 71 to 1.

title: MUSIC: OSCAR SHUMSKY, VIOLINIST
description: THIS season's programs by the Jupiter Symphony are combining chamber music with orchestral works, and the first of these amalgamations took place in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night. The focal point of the evening was the violinist Oscar Shumsky, who first appeared as the lone performer of Bach's Unaccompanied Partita in B minor (BWV 1002). After easily dispatching this difficult assignment, he gradually welcomed an increasing number of instrumental participants, first to play a Mozart Trio (in E flat, K. 498) and then concertos by Bach (in A minor, BWV 1041) and Mozart (in B flat, K. 207).

title: Texas Air Bids to Get Continental
description: Texas International Airlines, in a surprise takeover move, announced yesterday that it had acquired 9.5 percent of Continental Air Lines stock and would try to gain control of that carrier.

title: Steel Output Down 1.9%
description: Steel production fell 1.9 percent, to 2.39 million tons, in the week ended last Saturday from the previous week's 2.43 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: G.A.O. PREDICTS ELECTRONIC MAIL WILL REDUCE POSTAL SERVICE ROLE
description: The General Accounting Office said in a report today that an increasing use of electronic mail would dramatically change the United States Postal Service in the next two decades, sharply reducing the volume of conventional mail and cutting postal employment by two-thirds.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Steve Trout and K en Kravec, pitchers, and Greg Pryor, in- f ielder, to one-year contracts. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed Dale B erra, infielder, to a one-year contract. ST.

title: SCHWEIKER'S WAR ON SEX EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: POLISH PRIME MINISTER OUSTED;DEFENSE CHIEF TO REPLACE HIM; WORKERS END SOME WALKOUTS
description: Prime Minister Jozef Pinkowski was dismissed yesterday and Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Minister of Defense, was nominated to replace him at a meeting of the Central Committee of the Polish Communist Party.

title: 2 Italian Rightists Arrested
description: Two young right-wing extremists were arrested today after a brief gunbattle with a night watchman outside a Rome bank from which they were trying to steal money. The watchman and one of the youths received minor bullet wounds, the police said.

title: Olympia Has Shelved Its Premium Brand
description: A little bit of this, and slightly more of that: Olympia Brewing out in Washington State did not have a super premium brand when that suds category was going through a low roof, so it brought out Medallion Special and assigned the advertising to Chiat/Day. The brand was as far as the test phase in three West Coast markets and Springfield, Ill., when the brewery decided the economy just was not auspicious. So it shelved the product until a better time.

title: No Headline
description: Matthew Saad Muhammad will defend his World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title against Vonzell Johnson at Bally's Park Place Casino on Feb. 28 here, it was announced today.

title: NEW CLOTHES FROM 'THE MAN OF THE HOUR'
description: JAMES GALANOS has been this country's best dressmaker for a very long time. Like most national monuments, he is often taken for granted. But yesterday, at the introduction of his spring and summer collection at the Plaza Hotel, everybody was paying rapt attention to each pleat, tuck and ruffle. There were plenty of all three. Galanos has never been one of your spare, unvarnished modernist designers.

title: Jordan, Case Gets A Squibb Account
description: Jordan, Case & McGrath, which last week got some Mentholatum business, learned yesterday that it was the new agency for Theragran, the multi-vitamin from the Squbb Corporation's pharmaceutical division.

title: Reflections of the Harris Case
description: A soap opera's deepest appeal is not in its function as an entertainment but in its ability to impose continuity on an otherwise jumbled life. Consider, for instance, the uprooted American.

title: Suit Filed on Insulation Rule
description: Retailers and installers of urea formaldehyde foam in Massachusetts, the only state to ban use of the home insulation, have filed suit challenging state orders that they pay for its removal. The class-action suit, filed yesterday in Superior Court by 33 retailers and installers, asks the court to overturn the regulations established last year.

title: DOLLAR RENT A CAR SUES RCA AND UNITS
description: The Dollar Rent A Car Company filed a $30 million antitrust suit yesterday in Los Angeles Federal court against the RCA Corporation and two of its subsidiaries, the Hertz Corporation and the National Broadcasting Company.

title: Intruder, 25, Is Stabbed to Death By Man, 63, He Shot, Police Say
description: A 63-year-old man stabbed an intruder to death after the man shot his 65-year-old roommate during a robbery in their home last night, the police said. The 63-year-old man, Frank Regman, was also shot as he attacked the intruder with a knife, according to the police.

title: Subdued Messing Ready for All-Star Soccer at Garden Tonight
description: Shep Messing is still flamboyant and outspoken, but he no longer is the character he was in his days at New York University and Harvard, and with the United States Olympic team and the Cosmos.

title: CAMPBELL SQUAD CAPTURES N.H.L. ALL-STAR GAME, 4-1
description: The Campbell Conference was looking for its first victory over the Prince of Wales Conference as the National Hockey League held its 33d All-Star Game tonight at the Forum, home of the Los Angeles Kings.

title: PAKISTAN'S ROLE IN EFFORTS TO RESOLVE THE AFGHANISTAN PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Anglo Energy Selects New President
description: William J. Johnson, 46, has been named president and chief executive officer of Anglo Energy Ltd., an onshore contract driller based in New York. He succeeds Albert Van de Maele, 66, who will become chairman of the executive committee. Peter Lawson-Johnston, 53, continues as chairman.

title: YANKEE STADIUM 'RIP-OFF,' CONTD.
description: To the Editor:

title: POLAND'S FOUR-STAR PREMEIR
description: Poland's new Prime Minister may be the answer to the search for a leader who can stabilize the situation in the country and forestall political and military intervention by the Soviet Union.

title: A Public Relations Man
description: ''The sex trade, by tradition man and woman's oldest business, has become a multibillion-dollar business with the characteristics of many conventional industries - a large work force, high-salaried executives, brisk competition, trade publications, board meetings, sales conventions.'' - news item in The New York Times.

title: SHIFT IN FUEL PLANS HINTED
description: Secretary of Energy James B. Edwards said today that he favored transferring from his department to the Synthetic Fuels Corporation at least three major synthetic fuels projects, each worth $1 billion or more. Supporters of the projects fear that such a transfer of responsibility would result in the projects' being abandoned.

title: ANDERSON CALLS CAREY'S BUDGET A 'MAGIC SHOW'
description: Warren M. Anderson, the State Senate majority leader, today called Governor Carey's budget a ''magic show'' of nonexistent tax relief and local aid. He then proposed an immediate state assumption of any increases in local Medicaid costs and a full restoration of local revenue sharing to cities, towns and villages.

title: MRS. DWYER ON WAY HOME AFTER 9 MONTHS IN IRAN JAIL
description: Cynthia B. Dwyer, who spent more than nine months in a Teheran jail on espionage charges, was in Dubai yesterday on her way home to Amherst, N.Y. yesterday. She had stopped briefly in Dubai on the Persian Gulf after leaving Iran and her husband, John F. Dwyer, said she was expected to arrive in New York this afternoon by way of Switzerland.

title: Court Orders New Vote in Fight Over Leadership in Illinois Senate
description: The Illinois Supreme Court ordered Gov. James R. Thompson Jr. today to reconvene the State Senate and preside over a new election to choose a Senate president.

title: German Terrorists Refuse Food To Stress Call for P.O.W. Status
description: Justice Ministry officials confirmed today that 21 convicted and suspected terrorists had begun a hunger strike in jails throughout West Germany to demand better conditions and prisoner-of-war status.

title: Ryder Systems Gains
description: Ryder Systems Inc., the truck leasing concern, said fourth-quarter earnings rose to $17.6 million, or $1.01 a share, from $15.8 million, or 94 cents a share, in the 1979 quarter. Sales rose to $455 million from $393.9 million. For the year, earnings were down to $56.5 million, or $3.32 a share, on sales of $1.69 billion, compared with $63 million, or $3.73 a share in 1979 on sales of $1.45 billion.

title: SAFETY BOARD URGES IMPROVEMENTS IN FIREPROOFING OF JUMBO JET BAYS
description: Prompted by investigations into the second worst single-plane accident in history, the National Transportation Safety Board yesterday recommended consideration of major improvements in the fireproofingof baggage and cargo compartments on jumbo-jet airliners.

title: 3 HOSTAGES PASSED TIME WRITING, BUT ONLY ONE ACCOUNT EMERGED INTACT
description: At least three of the former hostages devoted part of their 444 days in captivity to writing about their plight, but apparently only one brought out an account intact.

title: TV: 'LIVING TREASURES OF JAPAN,' NINE ARTISTS WITH UNIQUE SKILL
description: BEAUTY is sometimes better described than defined and in ''Living Treasures of Japan,'' the National Geographic special tonight on WNET-TV, Channel 13, at 8 o'clock, the description is done by showing artists demonstrating their skills.

title: Advertising; How to Read Ralph Ginzburg
description: RALPH GINZBURG'S ads are easy enough to spot. Always the grabbing, stimulating headline. Yesterday's displays in The New York Times and The Daily News were ''Reward!'' The offer: a ''Positively Free! Free!! Free!!!'' magazine subscription. Typical.

title: CRUMBLED ITALIAN TOWN HOPES NEGLECT ISN'T ITS FATE
description: SANT'ANGELO DEI LOMBARDI, Italy, Feb. 9 - Two and a half months after an earthquake destroyed virtually this entire southern Italian town, there is still utter desolation here.

title: Miss Austin Undergoing Treatment for Sciatica
description: Tracy Austin is undergoing therapy and taking medication for a painful back condition diagnosed as sciatica, Dr. Robert Kerlan said today, He said he did not believe her career was threatened.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THERE are reasonable buys to be found in eggs, lamb and chicken this week and in some vegetables, but the news in fruit is not good. The cheaper apples and pears we've been seeing in the market lately have gone down in quality; those tasted have been woolly in texture and lacking juice. Large strawberries are arriving from Florida and California, but so far they have been poor. Sinking your teeth into one is like biting into a ball of cotton wool. But small California navel oranges are still good at 10 for $1. They are the best buy in fruit, along with bananas at 99 cents for three pounds.

title: City College Wins
description: Steve Sykes of John Jay College missed a foul shot with two seconds left that enabled City College to win, 43-42, in a CUNY Conference contest at the Nat Holman gym last night.

title: WAGE GAINS OF BLACK MEN OVERSTATED, STUDY FINDS
description: The economic progress of black men, in relation to whites, has been overstated as a result of the way Federal census statistics on earnings are published, a federally financed study contends.

title: 20 Salvadoran Educators Arrested by the Government
description: Security forces seized members of the National University's administrative body today on charges of violating a provision against meeting in groups of more than four, a Government spokesman said.

title: A C.I.A. FAMILY
description: Joe Kiyonaga was a moral man, an ethical man, a courageous man, a family man. And he was a spy. Joe had no problem with that. He'd served with the (JapaneseAmerican) 442d Regimental Combat Team in World War II. He'd slogged and fought his way up the length of Italy and on to France, and he viewed his service with the Central Intelligence Agency as more of the same - the defense of his country.

title: It's Boxing Hoopla Time Again
description: Harold Smith's presence was felt yesterday at a news conference called to announce that Larry Holmes would defend his heavyweight title against Trevor Berbick - an admitted diver, but of the underwater type - on April 11 at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: SMOKY FIRE IN LAS VEGAS KILLS 5 AND INJURES SCORES
description: A smoky fire raced through some upper floors of the Las Vegas Hilton Hotel tonight, injuring at least 30 people.

title: Ampco Improves Its Buffalo Forge Bid
description: The Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation yesterday increased its offer for the Buffalo Forge Company to $34 a share, or about $73.7 million, one day after the Ogden Corporation said that it would pay $67.5 million to acquire Buffalo Forge.

title: Careers; Options: A Growing Field
description: AT the American Stock Exchange's second annual institutional seminar on stock options, held last week, it was apparent that there were many job opportunities in the options field.

title: INQUIRY SOUGHT ON PERFORMANCE OF U.S. INTELLIGENCE IN IRAN CRISIS
description: Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, today asked for a Senate investigation of whether ''there was a U.S. intelligence failure'' in the fall of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and the seizure of the American hostages in Iran.

title: Reliance Increases Chris-Craft Stake
description: Reliance Financial Services, a unit of the Reliance Group Inc., reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its ownership of Chris-Craft Industries to 8.1 percent.

title: E.P.A. Approves 2 Incinerators To Dispose of PCB's by Burning
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had approved two incinerators that will destroy PCB's by burning them, an advance that it called a major step toward solving a big disposal headache.

title: TEXAS LAWYER I GIVEN JAIL TERM FOR HIS ROLE IN LIBYA SWINDLE PLOT
description: uf814 By The Associated Press

title: OLDER ITALIAN WINES OFFER CLUES ON WHICH YOUNG ONES TO AGE; by Terry Robards
description: SPANNAS from six different vintages were lying in a metal rack against a wall at the back of the store. They were priced attractively, and were apparently plentiful.

title: Haig Takes Command
description: Even in his well-tailored civilian clothes, Secretary of State Haig looks like a general of the Army. He may seem vaguely uncomfortable in his private dining room and vast antiquefurnished reception rooms on the eighth floor of the department, but he is approaching his job with an air of confidence and command.

title: Miss Bellamy Trying to Win Soviet Woman's Release
description: In 1978, Ida Nudel, a Soviet economist who had spent seven years trying to obtain permission to move to Israel, hung a banner from her Moscow balcony saying, ''K.G.B., give me my visa.'' She did not get her exit visa, and a few weeks later she was convicted of ''malicious hooliganism'' and sentenced to four years' exile in Siberia.

title: CITY AND STATE OFFER PLAN TO REBUILD TIMES SQ. AREA
description: The first formal step in New York City's long-debated redevelopment project for the Times Square area was taken yesterday with the release of a combined city-state proposal specifically describing the intended scope of the plan.

title: NEW YORK'S CETA PROGRAM DOES WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Mirror Net Advances by 14.3%
description: The Times Mirror Company, a major publishing concern, today reported a 14.3 percent rise in fourthquarter earnings, to $42.4 million, or $1.24 a share, from $37.1 million, or $1.09 a share, in 1979's final quarter. Revenue was up 11.4 percent, to $495 million from $444.2 million.

title: Turner Wins Satellite Suit
description: A Federal judge has ordered RCA American Communications Inc. to provide satellite relay service for Ted Turner's Cable News Network and WTBS, his Atlanta-based television station.

title: Evidence in Abscam Trial Chosen By House as Key to Lederer Case
description: The House ethics committee has decided to rely on trial evidence, which could be set aside by a judge, in considering the conduct of Representative Raymond Lederer, Democrat of Pennsylvania, who was convicted of bribery as a result of the Abscam investigation.

title: Silver Margins Down
description: The Commodity Exchange Inc. yesterday reduced margin requirements for silver and copper trading, effective today.

title: The Chief's Justice and Crime
description: Chief Justice Burger obviously struck home with his free-swinging speech on crime and punishment in America. Never in a dozen years on the high bench has he provoked such strong response, mostly favorable, and from far beyond his familiar audience of the American Bar Association. It did not matter that he has said it all before, even before he reached the Supreme Court. It was, after all, as a proven law and order man that President Nixon chose him. It is not the Burger message that has changed. The country has.

title: Athens to Let Constantine Stay for Just a Few Hours
description: In a last-minute bid to avert political violence and a revival of the traditional schism between monarchists and republicans, the Government today persuaded King Constantine to stay here for only a few hours on Thursday.

title: NEW TRIAL ORDERED IN FLOOD-PASSMAN BRIBERY CASE
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned the conviction of Dr. Murdoch Head and ordered a new trial on charges that he conspired to bribe former United States Representatives Daniel J. Flood and Otto E. Passman.

title: A QUEST FOR THE BEST CHOCOLATE VALENTINES
description: WITH Valentine's Day just three days away, it seems timely to point out that anyone who gives chocolate as an expression of affection will probably be invited to join in the eating of the luscious gift, a consideration that should weigh heavily in its favor. With that in mind, the following are among the city's richer and more mellow chocolate gift candidates. Some are new, others are already local classics.

title: Coalition in San Francisco To Fight Homosexuality
description: Calling San Francisco the ''Sodom and Gomorrah'' of the nation, a coalition of fundamentalist groups has announced that it intends to spend $3 million on a media campaign attacking homosexuals.

title: GENETIC UNIT SET UP BY HUTTON
description: The E.F. Hutton Group yesterday announced the formation of a company to market advances in gene-splicing and other biotechnolgy. The new company, DNA Science Inc., based in New York, has entered into a research agreement with the Yeda Research and Development Company of Rehovot, Israel. Under the agreement, DNA Science and Yeda have formed a jointly owned company, Taglit Inc., which means ''discovery'' in Hebrew, that will fund research projects at the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot.

title: Wings Honoring Women
description: The Wings Club, an organization of top aviation executives, has been giving Men of Achievement awards since 1975, honoring those who have made contributions to aviation, such as Gen. James H. Doolittle and Neil Armstrong.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 11, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Scientific and technical subcommit- tee of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: CAREY APPOINTEE MADE JOB OFFER, INCUMBENT SAYS
description: New York State's Industrial Commissioner, Philip Ross, told the Senate Labor Committee today that his appointed successor, Meyer S. Frucher, had offered to keep him on a state payroll for a transition period.

title: POLISH COURT DENIES APPEAL BY FARMERS FOR A TRADE UNION
description: The Polish Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by private farmers that they be allowed to form an independent trade union.

title: JUDICIARY ASKS ALBANY FOR 47 MORE JUDGES
description: Officials of the state's judicial system said today they needed 47 new judges to run the courts more effectively, but under questioning from the Legislature's fiscal committees could not explain how they had arrived at that number.

title: Garden Fight Refunds to Begin Friday
description: Refunds of tickets for the canceled Feb. 23 boxing show at Madison Square Garden will begin Friday, the Garden said yesterday.

title: Suit Charges Monopoly
description: The United States Surgical Corporation has been charged in a $75 million suit with monopolizing distribution and sale of surgical stapling products throughout the nation in violation of antitrust laws.

title: LONG-TERM BOND PRICES DROP
description: Long-term bond prices declined yesterday, continuing the trend of the last three weeks, which has sent yields near record levels. Nevertheless, investors have remained reluctant buyers.

title: Dow Up 1.45 in Light Trading
description: Earnings prospects dominated stock market strategy yesterday, as broad indicators showed small changes in continued light trading. Prime Computer, plunging 4 3/4 points, to 29 1/4, was the most active issue. This followed a company statement that first-quarter profits are under pressure because some customers are stretching out order and shipment schedules.

title: Goldhirsh Group Plans 2 Technology Books
description: Bernard A. Goldhirsh, who has already given reading America four magazines in an 11-year period, is now shooting for six. At his Boston offices, where control is maintained over Inc., Sail, Motorboat and Marine Business, planning is now going on for High Technology, which is due out in September, and Technology Illustrated, due out in October.

title: Protect the Poor from Getting Poorer
description: Welfare payments in New York: should they be seen as so high they serve as a magnet for the poor from other states, as State Comptroller Regan sees them? Or should they be recognized as cruelly low, unchanged for seven years, as if poor people are immune to inflation? The correct and humane answer should be obvious and it calls for an increase in the basic welfare allowance. Finally, the outlook is promising.

title: AFTER 103 YEARS, GOVERNING PANEL OF BAR GROUP MAY INCLUDE WOMAN
description: Delegates at the American Bar Association's midyear convention today opened the way for a 33-year-old California lawyer to assume the highest post ever held by a woman in the nation's largest organization for lawyers.

title:
RED SMITH;
The Ugandan Dane With a Punch
description: THE flower of American letters has been invited to the Waldorf today to learn at first hand the answer to the question: What is an Ayub? Top Rank Inc., a fight promotion firm, will seize the occasion to present an Ayub to the press, specifically Ayub Kalule, the Ugandan Dane from Kampala via Copenhagen, whom the World Boxing Association regards as junior middleweight (154 pounds) champion of the world.

title: WHERE THE FRENCH SELL THEIR WEAPONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Clarence E. Eldridge, 92, General Foods Executive; CLARENCE E. ELDRIDGE, 92, GENERAL FOODS EXECUTIVE
description: Clarence E. Eldridge, a former vice president of the General Foods Corporation and former executive vice president of the Campbell Soup Company, died Saturday at his home in Seminole, Fla. He was 92 years old and a former resident of Manhattan and Pine Plains, N.Y.

title: Oignons Farcis (Stuffed onions)
description: 6 large onions, about 3 pounds 3 tablespoons butter 1 cup finely chopped mushrooms 1 teaspoon finely minced garlic 1/2 pound ground veal, pork or beef 1/4 cup fine fresh bread crumbs 1 egg, lightly beaten 1/4 cup finely chopped parsley 6 tablespoons finely grated Parmesan cheese 1 cup unsalted chicken broth.

title: Parliamentary Elections Set for June 30 in Israel
description: After a month of political maneuvering and bargaining, Parliament voted unanimously today to set June 30 as the date for new elections.

title: Off-Duty Officer Kills A Boy, 17, in Brooklyn
description: A 17-year-old youth in a stolen car was shot and killed by an offduty police officer who was moonlighting at a construction site in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Real Estate; Light, Air And Zoning In Midtown
description: NEW YORK CITY is trying to revamp its midtown zoning. The idea is to divert development pressures from the East Side to the West Side and to simplify the negotiating process for builders. But the city's tentative plan contains some controversial approaches to evaluating a proposed building's impact on the environment. One of these methods is ''daylighting,'' which deals with how a building relates to the light and air on its street.

title: Q. While making a chocolate cake, I found I did not have on hand the sweet chocolate that the recipe called for, but that I did have bittersweet chocolate. I went out and bought sweet chocolate but wonder if the bittersweet could have been substituted.
description: A. Yes. All standard baking chocolates are interchangeable as far as chemistry is concerned. The only difference is the degree of bitterness, and that is a question of taste.

title: AUTO FRAMES A GAUGE TO SUCCESS
description: For generations, blue-collar workers here have gauged the health of the local economy by the number of rectangular steel auto frames along the edge of the 140-acre manufacturing complex operated by the A.O. Smith Corporation.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DIARY SGT. RODNEY V. SICKMANN KEPT WHILE A HOSTAGE IN IRAN
description: Following are excerpts from a diary kept by Sgt. Rodney V. Sickmann, a marine, while he was a hostage in Iran. He made the first entry on Feb. 3, 1980, three months after he was captured by Iranian militants. ''Santa Claus'' and ''Mailman'' were nicknames given to captors.

title: Bulls 116, Kings 115
description: Ricky Sobers hit a 20-foot jumper with five seconds remaining to give Chicago the victory. Sobers scored 16 of his 22 points in the final quarter and was 12-for-12 from the free-throw line. He has made 48 straight foul shots, a club record.

title: WILLIAM KENNY
description: William Kenny, a former deputy fire chief who served 35 years in the Hartford Fire Department, died here today at St. Francis Hospital.

title: Braniff Route Support
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board recommended today that Braniff International be awarded nonstop authority to Venezuela from New Orleans, Houston and Dallas-Fort Worth.

title: News Analysis
description: There is considerable hope in Western Europe that President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. will bring flexibility, nuance and coherence to the management of

title: FIRST TO SHOW CORNELL, GIACOMETTI
description: Julien Levy, an art dealer and writer who introduced New York to the work of such artists as Max Ernst, Alberto Giacommetti, Joseph Cornell, Arshile Gorky and Henri Cartier-Bresson, died yesterday at San Rafael Hospital in New Haven. He was 75 years old.

title: BRAINS HUNT FINANCIAL BRAWN
description: SEVERAL influential critics called the Brains the most impressive new American rock band of 1980. On their first album, ''The Brains'' (Mercury), they achieved a rich, luminous sound with the help of the gifted British producer Steve Lillywhite, and last spring they gave memorable live performances up and down the East Coast. But new American bands, especially bands as intelligent as the Brains, don't always find it easy to translate critical acclaim into commercial success. ''We played in New York, Philadelphia and some other Northeastern cities before the album came out, and we were totally broke and sleeping on floors,'' said Tom Gray, the bespectacled, studious-looking lead singer, songwriter and keyboard player for the Atlanta-based quartet, the other day. ''These days we're sleeping in beds, but we're still broke.''

title: Lockridge Bout Is Off
description: Rocky Lockridge of Paterson, N.J., has the flu and will not defend his United States Boxing Association featherweight title against Javier Flores on Feb. 19, promoters at the Ice World Arena announced today. A 10-round replacement bout has been arranged between Johnny Verderosa of New York, undefeated in 14 bouts, and Jean LaPointe (23-8-1), a former Canadian junior lightweight champion.

title: Bridge: A Hero of 60's Novel Series Makes Comeback on Cruise
description: The only series of novels ever written in a bridge setting appeared in the 1960's. The author was Don Von Elsner, and the hero was a bridge professional named Jake Winkman who became entangled with criminals and blondes when not at the card table.

title: Massey-Ferguson Predicts '81 Loss
description: Victor Rice, chairman of Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Canadian farm-equipment manufacturer, predicted another loss for the troubled company in the 1981 fiscal year.

title: Philadelphia Urban League Finds Race and Economics Divide City
description: The Philadelphia Urban League, in a report on problems of blacks here, said today that the city ''remains divided by race, geography and economics.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * BarclaysAmerican Corporation will offer $75 million of 14 3/4 percent notes at 99.8, to yield 14.738 percent in 7 years, through a Merrill Lynch group.

title: Olivier Rebbot Dies; French Photographer Wounded in Salvador
description: Olivier Rebbot, a French freelance photographer, died last night at Hialeah Hospital in Miami as the result of wounds suffered Jan. 15 when he was hit by sniper fire in San Francisco Gotera, in eastern El Salvador. He was 31 years old and had lived in Manhattan for nine years.

title: A Collector's-Item Check
description: While President Reagan now laughs off his earlier years as a liberal Democrat, reminders keep cropping up. For example, an anonymous source has turned up a canceled personal check in the amount of $50, drawn on the Bank of America in Hollywood, dated Sept. 14, 1948, and signed by Mr. Reagan.

title: G.T.E.'s Profit Up 9.4% in 4th Quarter
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, the largest non-Bell telephone system, reported yesterday that net income for the fourth quarter of 1980 increased 9.4 percent over the last quarter of 1979.

title: IRAQ SAID TO ADVANCE IN IRAN AFTER LEADERS MAKE A VISIT TO FRONT
description: Iraqi forces have begun a local offensive against Iranian troops in the hills of Ilam Province after a visit to the battlefront by President Saddam Hussein over the weekend, Arab diplomatic sources said today.

title: No Headline
description: Marvis Frazier says he has recovered from a pinched nerve in the neck that he suffered in November and plans to resume sparring this week to prepare for an undercard fight April 10 at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: REAGAN'S ELDER SON BEING INVESTIGATED
description: Michael Reagan, the elder son of President Reagan, was accused of felony violations of California securities laws in court documents unsealed today.

title: Mr. Stratton Off Base
description: It seems that when he has trouble shutting the window on a freezing day, Representative Samuel Stratton would not hesitate to start a conflagration to heat up the air all around. At least we infer as much from his behavior, specifically his conclusion that America needs a censorship act to save it from a leaking Secretary of Defense.

title: News of the Theater; A Musical 'Stage Door' To Open in the Autumn
description: ''STAGE DOOR,'' the musical version of the 1936 play by Edna Ferber and George S. Kaufman, has found a producer and a director. The producer is Karen Kantor; the director is A.J. Antoon. Miss Kantor says the musical, which is budgeted at $1.8 million, has a book that is ''99 percent finished'' and ascore that is ''75 percent finished.'' She also says she will get it on Broadway next fall.

title: PUBLISHERS SEE A FUTURE IN TRADE PAPERBACKS
description: Erica Jong's novel ''Fanny,'' a best-seller last year, will appear in paperback this spring - but instead of the usual rack-size, massmarket paperback, ''Fanny'' will be issued as a $6.95 trade paperback.

title: PUG NAMED WESTMINSTER'S BEST
description: Ch. Dhandy's Favorite Woodchuck, a fawn pug better known as Chucky, stood alone on the rich brown-carpeted ring at Madison Square Garden last night as the supreme winner of the 105th Westminster Kennel Club show.

title: U.S. DOUBTS MOSCOW WILL INVADE POLAND
description: The State Department said today that the United States regarded a Soviet military intervention in Poland as ''neither imminent nor inevitable not justifiable.''

title: Kheel's Right to Pursue Libel Action Is Upheld
description: A State Supreme Court judge ruled yesterday that Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, could continue an $8 million libel suit against Rupert Murdoch, the publisher of New York magazine and other publications.

title: CONSUMER DEBT UP MODESTLY
description: In an indication that consumers remained cautious in their borrowing habits during December, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that installment debt during that month rose at an annual rate of 6 percent, or by a seasonally adjusted $1.62 billion.

title: ROBINSON OF ABC NEWS QUOTED AS SAYING NETWORK DISCRIMINATES
description: Max Robinson, a co-anchorman on ABC's ''World News Tonight,'' was summoned to New York yesterday by ABC News president Roone Arledge, after having been quoted as telling a college audience on Sunday that ABC had discriminated against him and other black journalists. Mr. Robinson is reported to have said that they were excluded from coverage of the Presidential inauguration and the return of the hostages from Iran.

title: News Analysis
description: As President Reagan prepares to march up Capitol Hill and fight for a massive package of budget and tax cuts, he is clearly riding at the head of a powerful political army. Even many Democrats concede that the last election signified a widespread public desire for less government, and as Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Massachusetts, said after the President's economic speech last week, ''The honeymoon is still on.''

title: AT DINNER PARTIES, THE DIVERSITY OF OPINION REMAINS A CONSTANT
description: WHEN it comes to the cosmic subjects discussed at dinner parties - the economy, strategic arms negotiations, human rights, interest rates, the stock market - differences in opinion aren't usually a matter of gender. There are men and women conservatives, men and women liberals, men and women optimists and men and women pessimists. There are also both men and women who don't really know what they're talking about but enjoy listening to their own voices.

title: WHEAT SALE TO NICARAGUA DELAYED
description: A $9.6 million sale of American wheat to Nicaragua is being held up in the State Department while reports of arms shipments through Nicaragua to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador are reviewed, United States official said today.

title: Firefighters Urged To Keep Union Link
description: Leaders of the Uniformed Firefighters Association in New York City have reversed their position on ending their ties with the 170,000-member International Association of Firefighters and are recommending that members in the New York City local vote against disaffiliation in a referendum.

title: CATERING, DOWN-HOME AND NATURAL
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- B.H. Fussell is a freelance writer who specializes in food. By B.H. FUSSELL

title: Cable Franchise Set
description: The American Television and Communications Corporation, a subsidiary of Time Inc., said its Indianapolis unit, American Cablevision of Indianapolis, had been awarded the cable franchise for that city.

title: JOCKEY RAMOS SUSPENDED AFTER ATTACK AT GULFSTREAM
description: Alberto Ramos is under suspension at Gulfstream Park until March 9 for going after Michael Lee, a fellow jockey, with a knife.

title: by Tom Buckley
description: STRANGE, isn't it, that a drama about cancer presented in the afternoon for young viewers should turn out to be far more honest, unsparing and dramatically effective than almost every variation of the same overworked theme seen on evening television.

title: A NO-FLOUR SOUFFLE THAT'S EASY TO MAKE; by Pierre FraneyZ
description: LIKE many other French chefs, I am often asked if I do not become bored with food preparations. The answer is an unmistakable no. More often than not I cook for my family seven days a week, and on those rare occasions when I am alone I cook for myself.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: A63-YEAR-OLD man misplaced things all the time, couldn't remember anything and became so disorganized that he was unable to do his work at the office. A doctor told him he was senile and nothing could be done, but he went to the behavioral neurology center at Boston's Beth Israel Hospital where psychological tests and a psychiatric interview revealed that the man was severely depressed.

title: CURTIS REDDING'S SEASON OF DISCONTENT
description: Curtis Redding will be in St. John's Alumni Hall tonight when the Redmen play Connecticut in basketball. A few weeks ago, he would have been in the starting lineup. This time, he will be sitting in Section 8 with two brothers and a sister. Last week, Redding, once a local schoolboy hero and one of the most exciting prospects in basketball, quit the St. John's team because he was getting less playing time and had lost his starting job. His action disappointed many people, including his last three head coaches - Lou Carnesecca, Jack Hartman and Mark Reiner.

title: Miss Nadig Nears Ski Crown
description: Marie-Theres Nadig of Switzerland virtually clinched the women's World Cup with a triumph in the giant slalom today.

title: ELEPHANT GARLIC SUPPLY IS INADEQUATE FOR DEMAND
description: ''By Christmas, we were receiving 85 calls a day and 440 letters a day,'' says Nyda Delageane, who, with her husband, Jim, has been raising elephant garlic on their farm in California's Napa Valley and selling it by mail for the last three years. ''It's now dropped to about 100 letters a day.''

title: F.T.C. JUDGE SAYS BAYER CAN'T UPHOLD AD CLAIMS
description: A Federal Trade Commission judge today ruled that the maker of Bayer aspirin had insufficient evidence to substantiate advertising assertions that its products were superior to other aspirins or analgesics.

title: A NEW POLISH PERIL IS SEEN IN MOSCOW
description: A number of Western diplomats here, including several who have in the past accused Washington of scandal-mongering in suggesting that a Soviet intervention in Poland was possible at any moment, said today that they felt the situation had reached a dangerous stage.

title: Southern Fried Chicken
description: 1 fryer, cut in 6 or 8 pieces 1 cup milk 2 tablespoons grated onion 1 tablespoon dry mustard 1 tablespoon sugar 1 clove garlic, mashed Salt and pepper to taste Flour for dusting Wesson oil or Crisco shortening for frying.

title: ECONOMIC ADVISORY UNIT NAMED
description: President Reagan today announced the creation of an Economic Policy Advisory Board, an outside group of 12 prominent Republicans, most of whom have held high Government economic posts.

title: Index; International
description: Chirac, a former ally, challenges Giscard A3 Abduction of Jordanian envoy jolts normally blase Beirut A3 Report of aid to Salvadoran rebels delays wheat sale to Nicaragua A4 Around the World A5 U.N. says it wrongly accused Israel of an atrocity in Lebanon A6 Iraqis open local drive in Iran after President visits front A6 General Around the Nation A12 Accused Nazi war criminal goes on trial in Cleveland A12 Bank suspends manager accused of fraud by boxing promoter A14 Texas lawyer gets jail term in Libya swindle plot A16 Californian in line to become bar group's top-ranking woman A22 A medical witness gives a slide show in Jean S. Harris's trial B2 Warner executive pleads guilty in theater case B2 The City B3 Economic gains of black men overstated, study finds B7 LINCOLN'S BIRTHDAY Tomorrow is Lincoln's birthday. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street sweeping. Federal offices - Open. State and municipal offices - Closed. Postal services - Regular schedules. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets - Open. Transportation - Regular schedules. Libraries - Closed. Schools - Open tomorrow, closed Friday.

title: Accounts
description: * Guinness-Harp Corporation to Keenan & McLaughlin Inc., for Bass Ale and Worthington 'E' lager.

title: Female Basketball Player Missing and Believed Slain
description: A charge of second-degree murder was filed against an Omaha man today as authorities continued to search the banks of the Missouri River for traces of a missing women's pro basketball player, Connie Kunzmann.

title: Irish Win to Give Phelps 200th Triumph at School
description: Orlando Woolridge scored 18 points and Tracy Jackson added 17 tonight to pace Notre Dame to a 89-63 victory over Boston University and give Digger Phelps his 200th coaching victory at the school.

title: Robert G. Anderson, 57, Canadian Wheat Expert
description: Robert G. Anderson, a wheat geneticist on the agricultural field staff of the Rockefeller Foundation, has died of acute leukemia at the Health Sciences Center in Winnipeg, Manitoba, at the age of 57. Mr. Anderson, a Canadian, made his home in Winnipeg.

title: EXECUTIVES' CRIME FEARS STUDIED
description: About 40 percent of America's major business executives fear that they, a relative or a business associate will be kidnapped, according to a crime study published yesterday by a private research organization.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''And I can assure you, by morning I'll be hung in effigy.

title: SCHAFFNER'S 'SPHINX'
description: THOUGH ''Sphinx,'' the melodrama that opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, is set in contemporary Egypt and is about longlost treasures of pharaohs and some of their monuments, it hasn't much in common with the Sphinx or even a sphinx. It never stops talking and never does it make a bit of sense. It's unhinged. If it were a person, and you were trying to be nice, you might say it wasn't itself.

title: SABOTAGING THE HUNT FOR ENGLISH FOXES
description: CROCKHAM HILL, England WEARING boots and a heavy jacket against the morning chill, Nicholas Couldry crept through the underbrush, listening for the sound of the huntsman's horn, as he followed a pack of hounds through the misty Kent countryside. But although it was a typical English fox hunt, he was not hunting the fox; he was hunting the hunters.

title: People
description: * Jerome B. Sexton named senior vice president/director of human resources for D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, St. Louis.

title: Top Soviet Navy Officers Are Killed in Air Crash
description: The commander of the Soviet Union's Pacific Fleet and two other high-ranking naval officers are among an unspecified number of military people killed in an air crash, the armed forces newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda said today.

title: BANK SUSPENDS BRANCH MANAGER ACCUSED IN LOSS OF $21.3 MILLION
description: Wells Fargo National Bank said today that it had suspended Gene Kawakami, manager of one of its largest branches here, as an investigation continued into alleged fraud involving a loss of more than $21.3 million by the bank.

title: Ogilvy and Marriott
description: Ogilvy & Mather in New York does advertising for the Marriott hotels, while the agency's Chicago and San Francisco offices do advertising for nearby Mariott Theme Parks. Now the Theme Park division has been named to promote Playland in Rye, N.Y., and Ogilvy's Chicago office has been given the job.

title: FIRST LADY'S GIFT DRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: OCCIDENTAL'S PROFITS SLIP
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation reported yesterday that earnings for last year's fourth quarter fell 26 percent from the comparable 1979 period, largely because of a substantial drop in production and profit margins on the company's Libyan operations.

title: LEGISLATURE AGAIN SEEKS DEATH PENALTY
description: For the fifth consecutive year, the State Legislature, over Governor Carey's opposition, is seeking to reinstate the death penalty for some cases of murder.

title: Saunders Leasing Blocks French Bid
description: Saunders Leasing System, a Birmingham, Ala., trailer and truck leasing system, said it had obtained a Federal court order barring a French company from increasing its holdings in the company.

title: Appointee Astray
description: While Governor Carey has been shopping for a bus factory in Japan, his choice for New York Industrial Commissioner, Meyer Frucher, has been alone in Albany, unable to land the job. At least for the time being, the Senate Labor Committee has turned him down.

title: LUTECE AT 20: ANDRE SOLTNER LOOKS BACK
description: LUTECE, one of New York's leading French restaurants, celebrates its 20th anniversary this week. For more than a decade it has been owned and operated by Andre Soltner, its original chef, and he has maintained a staunchly classical cuisine.

title: Goodyear Tire Is Up 82.6%
