description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest tire maker, said today that record results in its international business helped produce an 82.6 percent gain in profits in the fourth quarter last year and a 62.2 percent rise for the entire year.

title: SADAT BACKS EUROPEAN INITIATIVE
description: President Anwar el-Sadat today encouraged Western Europe to press ahead with plans for a Middle East peace initiative of its own, saying it should concentrate on persuading Israel and the Palestinians to recognize each other's right to nationhood and on guaranteeing their future security.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE NATION; Louisiana Court Denies Plea for Stay of Execution

title: REAGAN WON'T CUT 7 SOCIAL PROGRAMS THAT AID 80 MILLION
description: In his budget-cutting proposals for the fiscal year 1982, President Reagan plans to spare seven basic social programs that cost $210 billion annually and have 80 million beneficiaries, the White House announced today.

title: World Bank-Mexico Pact
description: The World Bank will lend Mexico $280 million for agricultural development, official sources said today. The loan, over 15 years at 9 1/4 percent, will be handled by Nacional Financiera, Mexico's state development bank, they added. The credit will form part of a $795 million Government project to improve farming.

title: 4 Are Convicted of Setting Fires In a Queens Apartment Complex
description: Four persons convicted of setting fires in a Queens apartment complex were sentenced in State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday to 12 1/2 to 25 years in prison.

title: Israeli Gunboats Attack Targets in South Lebanon
description: Israeli naval gunboats shelled suspected Palestinian bases along the southern Lebanese coast early today and a ground force made a a quick foray into the area, the Israeli military command said.

title: GRACE PLANS VENTURE WITH DUTCH RETAILER
description: W.R. Grace & Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with Vroom & Dreesmann B.V., the largest retailer in the Netherlands, for the formation of an equally owned joint venture encompassing almost all of Grace's non-restaurant retailing operations.

title: The Economy
description: Installment debt rose in December at a 6 percent annual rate, or a seasonally adjusted $1.62 billion, the Federal Reserve Board said. The rise, below the 11.4 percent growth rate for personal income, indicated that consumers remained cautious borrowers. (Page D1.)

title: VICE ADM. JAMES DOYLE, LEADER OF AMPHIBIOUS FORCES IN KOREA
description: Vice Adm. James Henry Doyle, commander of the Amphibious Task Forces that carried out the landing at Inchon and the later evacuation of nearly 200,000 soldiers and civilians from Hungnam in the Korean War, died Monday at the Naval Regional Center in Oakland, Calif. He was 83 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Citibank Prime Remains at 19 1/2%
description: Citibank, the nation's second-largest commercial bank, said yesterday that it would leave its prime lending rate unchanged at 19 1/2 percent, despite a New York competitor's reduction to 19 percent on Monday. Citibank, which now reviews its prime rate each Tuesday, did not elaborate on its decision.

title: Jody Powell Signs Contract With a TV Talent Agent
description: The fact that Jody Powell, until recently the White House press secretary, is seriously looking for work in television was underscored yesterday when it became known that he had signed a representation contract with Ralph Mann, chairman of the ICM talent agency, which has some big TV-news people as clients.

title: G.M.'S V-5 ENGINE
description: The General Motors Corporation plans production of the auto industry's first V-5 engine, a diesel to be produced by the Oldsmobile division, Metalworking News, a trade journal, reported.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1981
description: International Farmers in Poland were rebuffed by the nation's Supreme Court, which rejected their request to establish an independent union. However, the court softened the ruling a bit by instructing the farmers to take their case before the Warsaw city administration, which could register their organization as an ''association'' with no collective bargaining rights. Meanwhile, negotiators resolved several key labor disputes. (Page A1, Column 1.) Washington's concern about Poland was expressed by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. who said, through his spokesman, that the United States regarded Soviet military intervention as ''neither imminent nor inevitable nor justifiable.'' The State Department seemed to rule out any emergency economic aid to Warsaw, but said, five hours later, that the matter was under review. (A1:2.)

title: Pennsylvania Seeks Drought Aid
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh, citing ''severe drought conditions,'' has asked the Federal Government to provide financial assistance for water companies and people trying to find alternative water sources. In a formal request yesterday to the Small Business Administration, he asked for approval of low-interest disaster-relief loans to assist in financing over $16 million in water projects.

title: Economic Scene; The Politicizing Of Economics
description: THE doctrinal strife within the Reagan Administration among schools of economic thought bearing such tags as supply-siders, conservative Keynesians and monetarists points up the disarray within the economics profession itself. In the midst of that disarray, politicians feel at ease in choosing those economic advisers who tell them what they want to hear.

title: SEIZURE OF JORDSANIAN ENVOY SHOCKS EVEN BLASE BEIRUT
description: The mysterious abduction here five days ago of the chargee d'affaires of Jordan has shaken Beirut, a city so inured to violence as to be blase, heightened tensions in the Arab world and provided a look at what seems to be a shadowy underground battle between rival Arab nations.

title: BID FOR ABITIBI IS DROPPED BY FEDERAL COMMERCE
description: The announcement that the Reichmann family of Toronto will seek control of Abitibi-Price Inc., the world's largest newsprint producer, once again brings publicity to an intensely private family that controls more than $3 billion (Canadian) in assets.

title: Wendy Kesselman Wins Prize for Play
description: Wendy Kesselman has been named the winner of the third Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, given to a female playwright for ''a work of outstanding quality for the English-speaking theater.'' Miss Kesselman, who won for ''My Sister in This House,'' was presented the $2,000 award by Geraldine Fitzgerald, the actress and director, in a ceremony last night at the Players.

title: U.N. CONCEDES IT ERRED ON ISRAELIS
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim acknowledged today that the United Nations had wrongly accused Israel of blowing up the bodies of five Palestinian terrorists killed by Israeli soldiers on Christmas Day.

title: Winter Storm Is Blamed For 7 Deaths in Nation
description: By The Associated Press Driven by high winds, the biggest storm of the winter swept from the Rockies to the Great Lakes yesterday, bringing blinding snow and freezing temperatures that contributed to at least seven deaths.

title: Boy Convicted of Arson In Jersey Fire Fatal to 7
description: A Hudson County jury deliberated less than 15 minutes today before convicting 16-year-old Kevin Madison on seven counts of murder by arson.

title: WILLIAM S. HILLMAN
description: Dr. William S. Hillman, senior plant physiologist at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, L.I., died Monday at the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital, after a long illness. He was 51 years old and lived in Bayport, L.I.

title: TV: 'MUSICAL COMEDY II,' WITH THE DANNY KAYES
description: ALTHOUGH it went on to win some prestigious awards, ''Musical Comedy Tonight'' was not one of my favorite television efforts. Neither is ''Musical Comedy Tonight II,'' which can be seen this evening at 9 o'clock on WNET-TV, Channel 13.

title: AN EVENING OF CAROL HALL
description: CAROL HALL is an ingratiating composer-performer of modest talent and immense personal charm. On Sunday and Monday in the 92nd Street Y's ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series, she performed several songs from her Broadway hit, ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas,'' and previewed new material from her forthcoming show, ''Good Sports.''

title: GAS DECONTROL TIMING UNCLEAR
description: The Reagan Administration is firmly committed to speeding up the pace of natural gas decontrol but cannot yet specify a precise timetable, the Administration's trade team today told its counterpart from the European Common Market.

title: NO-SALT COOKING WITH VEGETABLES: ONIONS
description: IF you work at preparing food without salt, as I have for the past 18 months, it becomes evident early on that certain foods, because of their flavor and texture, are better suited to a no-salt regime than others. If I were to name the four foods that seem naturally adaptable to low-sodium cooking, they would be onions, tomatoes, eggplants and mushrooms. All are inherently rich in flavor and have a pleasant texture.

title: Tax Official to Remain
description: Mark L. McConaghy, the 40-year-old deputy chief of staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation, has abandoned earlier plans to enter private law practice and instead will serve as the committee's chief of staff. He will succeed Bernard M. Shapiro, who, along with Mr. McConaghy, said in November that they would resign for personal reasons.

title: Du Pont's Shapiro Joining Law Firm
description: Irving S. Shapiro, chairman and chief executive officer of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and one of the nation's most influential executives, announced yesterday that he would join a New York law firm after retiring at age 65 from the giant chemical corporation on April 30.

title: REAGAN ASKED TO DELAY SELECTION OF NEW CHIEF FOR SAFETY AGENCY
description: President Reagan has been asked by a key Senator not to appoint a new chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission pending possible Congressional reorganization of the small but controversial agency.

title: BRINGING BACK 'SPOOKS' TO REVITALIZE THE 'PLANT'
description: The victims of the ''Halloween massacre'' may soon be vindicated. They were the old Central Intelligence Agency hands summarily dismissed by Admiral Stansfield Turner in a largescale purge on Oct. 31, 1977, because he ''preferred to get new young people, to promote promotions and flowthrough.'' Most of them were highly trained and experienced intelligence officers of the senior and middle levels; some were station chiefs in London, Vienna, Bonn, Ottawa, and Latin America. It is said in Washington that William J. Casey, the new Director of Central Intelligence, will bring back many of these former ''spooks'' to rehabilitate the ''plant.''

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CALIFORNIA (AL) - Purchased contract o f Luis Sanchez, right-handed pitcher, from V era Cruz; put John Montague, relief pitch- e r, on waivers. CHICAGO (AL) - Thad Bosley and Rusty K untz, outfielders, CLEVELAND (AL) - Len Barker and M ike Stanton, pitchers, agreed to terms.

title: Fusae Ichikawa, 87, Led The Japanese Feminists
description: Fusae Ichikawa, a feminist leader and legislator, died today. She was 87. Born to a farm family in Aichi Prefecture, she rebelled against her father, saying it was because he beat her mother and favored the subservient role of women.

title: Texaco to Install Offshore Gas Rig
description: Texaco Inc. said it plans to install a natural gas production platform in 288 feet of water in the Santa Barbara Channel, the first rig devoted to gas production in the rich offshore energy field.

title: WARNER EXECUTIVE PLEADS GUILTY IN WESTCHESTER THEATER INQUIRY
description: A top executive of Warner Communications pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to Federal charges that followed an investigation into the bankrupt Westchester Premier Theater.

title: EXPERT TESTIFIES 3D TIME ON KEY TARNOWER INJURY
description: The deputy medical examiner of Westchester County used color slides in a darkened courtroom today to demonstrate a key prosecution argument in the murder trial of Jean S. Harris - that tissues found in Dr. Herman Tarnower's chest wound came from the palm of his hand.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT is not just the drought, or the R-46 undercarriages, or the interest rates, or the murder rate, or the all-too-flxible FLXIBLE buses. It is everything: ''Hard and sinister times are here, and a major flowering of phobias is upon us,'' says David C. Anderson, a New Yorker who should know - editing, as he does, Police Magazine, the constabular bimonthly.

title: HONG KONG-PRETORIA TIES GROW
description: Hong Kong is emerging as an increasingly important trading partner for South Africa, offering Pretoria an eager market for gold and diamonds as well as a chance to trade quietly with China.

title: Pentagon Would Sell F-16's For First Time to a Neutral
description: The Defense Department today disclosed a proposal to sell F-16 jet fighters to Austria in what would be the first scuh sale to a neutral country.

title: Ex-City Aide Held In $250,000 Theft
description: The former maintenance director of a city-owned industrial park in Brooklyn has been charged with masterminding the theft of $250,000 from the complex through fraudulent maintenance contracts, bogus billing and kickbacks from suppliers, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office said.

title: PIZZA-MAKERS MEET TO EAT AND INNOVATE
description: NAPLES Mount Vesuvius has been dormant for decades now, but it goes on wearing its tuft of smoke on the murals and business signs of pizzerias from New York to Tokyo. Naples with its fiery mountain is indeed the capital of the globe-girdling empire of pizza pie.

title: OHIO MAN ACCUSED OF NAZI CRIMES
description: A 60-year-old Ukrainian was accused today in Federal District Court here of being a Nazi collaborator who hid his past as a war criminal to become an American citizen.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anacomp Inc. signed a multimillion-dollar agreement with NCR Corporation to develop an information system for a large Middle West hospital over the next three years.

title: Publication Focuses On Cancer Patients
description: Four men from Romaine Pierson Publishers, which has three medical journals and a trade magazine, have founded Dominus Publishing in Roslyn, L.I., to publish a medical publication called Your Patient and Cancer.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BIG SOUND

title: TAX CREDITS ARE CLAIMED FOR WIDE RANGE OF COSTS
description: Your TaxesA Guide to Preparing 1980 ReturnsNinth of 12 articles.- By DEBORAH RANKIN

title: Philippine General Crash-Lands
description: Three military helicopters, including one that carried Gen. Romeo Espino, the head of the Philippine armed forces, crash-landed in bad weather on an island in Leyte Province today.

title: Rise Urged In Europe Fare
description: The world's major airlines recommended today that passenger fares between Europe and the United States be increased by an average of 7 percent, chiefly to cover fuel price rises.

title: PEROT'S CASE AGAINST IRAN POSES THREAT TO ACCORD
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer millionaire who once dispatched a paramilitary team to free two of his employees from an Iranian prison, is now bringing a vigorous legal challenge to the agreements that led to Iran's release of the 52 American hostages.

title: 2 Brothers Charged In Arson Deaths of 5
description: Two brothers were charged with the arson deaths of two young mothers and three children in a Brooklyn tenement from which the brothers were evicted last week.

title: CHARLOTTE MOLDS
description: ELEGANCE often comes easy, created by a single well-placed flower or just a bit of garnish. And it happens that some of the most elegant desserts I can think of also are among the simplest to prepare. I have in mind the charlottes, especially the classic charlotte aux pommes and the sumptuous charlotte russe, which was invented by the great Antonin Careme in the 19th century.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The day had begun with a four-car rush-hour fender bender in Brooklyn that gave Frank J. Macchiarola's back a painful jolt. Later in the morning, the School Chancellor was hung in effigy in Rosedale, Queens, and awarded the sobriquet ''Ayatollah Macchiarola'' by angry Queens parents.

title: ROSEDALE PICKETS AT CITY HALL ASK ACTION ON ANNEX
description: About 200 white parents and children from Rosedale, Queens, picketed City Hall today in their campaign to reopen a school annex in their community.

title: U.S. DEVELOPING PLANS TO COMBAT VIOLENT CRIMES
description: Justice Department officials are developing a package of legislative proposals to increase the Federal Government's ability to fight violent crime.

title: 'Surrogate Motherhood'
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I have been following the controversial topic of surrogate motherhood with great interest (''Kentucky Attorney General Calls Surrogate Motherhood Illegal,'' Jan. 28). I do not think this new adoption process poses any new question of morality if a woman chooses to allow the true father of her artificially inseminated child to adopt after birth. However, I do not understand why the very term ''surrogate motherhood'' is used, because it implies a situation that is not scientifically accurate, and perhaps this contributes to the problems regarding the legality of the process.

title: Decompression Is Modified for 3 Who Set Record Simulated Dive
description: Three divers who recently set the record for the world's deepest simulated dive had to undergo recompression today after one of the men began experiencing pain in his joints.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Company, Wayne, N.J., announced that Lloyd N. Cutler, counsel to President Carter, had returned to the board of directors.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard IDLE HANDS. By William O'Rourke. 435 pages. Delacorte. $12.95.

title: DOW BROADENS PRODUCT LINES
description: The Dow Chemical Company, the country's secondlargest chemical concern, circles the globe, making and marketing a vast assortment of products and services that produced more than $10 billion in revenues last year.

title: FILM: 'THE LAST METRO,' MELODRAMA BY TRUFFAUT
description: ''Le Dernier Metro'' (''The Last Metro'') was shown at the 1980 New York Film Festival at Avery Fisher Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby published in The New York Times last Oct. 12. The film opens today at the Coronet Theater, Third Avenue and 59th Street.

title: A WEEK TO REMEMBER OUR VIETNAM VETERANS
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. Man Accused of Bank Fraud
description: A Huntington, L.I., man was arrested today and charged with cheating two Westchester County banks out of more than $7,200 by passing stolen checks, authorities said. The suspect, Henry Fogelman, 27 years old, was charged with passing the checks at branches of the Marine Midland Bank and the Scarsdale National Bank last summer.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: St. Valentine's Day on Saturday reminds us that proper sentiments are in order. Even the British stiff upper lip has relaxed into a fond smile. The British Post Office has issued its first stamp honoring the day, full of hearts, cupids and doves, as well as a silhouette of the Queen. The United States has nothing so official, but shops are full of ideas based on the loving thoughts.

title: Gen. Claude Vanbremeersch, 60, Retired Chief of Staff for France
description: Gen. Claude Vanbremeersch, who retired as Chief of Staff of the French armed forces in January on the ground of ill health, died in an army hospital today, military sources said. He was 60 years old.

title: Market Place; Intermediate Bonds Favored
description: WHEN a successful professional investor who normally much prefers common stocks to bonds sees real opportunities in the latter, something may be happening in the market.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.00-19.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AMAX AND INTERNORTH DECLINE
description: Amax Inc., the diversified natural resources producer, said a decline in shipments of molybdenum, a refined ore used primarily in steel production, contributed to a 13.9 percent decline in fourthquarter earnings.

title: Comsat Selects Antenna Maker
description: Radiation Systems Inc. became the only authorized manufacturer today of a satellite antenna developed by the Communications Satellite Corporation.

title: Burroughs May Shut 3 Detroit Plants
description: The Burroughs Corporation said it may close three Detroit-area production plants over the next several years because of higher unionized wages and production costs in Michigan.

title: CHIRAC, EX-ALLY, CHALLENGES GISCARD
description: Jacques Chirac, the Mayor of Paris, appeared before a news conference today to explain why he is running for President in the April elections.

title: DROUGHT PRODUCES A NEW WATER ETHIC
description: ONCE it was taken for granted. Water was plentiful and it came out of our taps in seemingly never-ending amounts. No longer. Today, in short supply and with the real possibility of reservoirs supplying the area drying up, water has come to be regarded as something semiprecious, a resource to be carefully husbanded, the subject of serious restrictions and family rules regarding its consumption and conservation. There is among us, in short, a new water ethic.

title: Long-Term Bond Yields Rise
description: Long-term interest rates rose yesterday, and for some types of bonds, yields are now at record levels, while others are only slightly less than their peaks.

title: No Headline
description: SCIENTISTS DESCEND INTO VOLCANO'S CRATER: At Mount St. Helens in

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of H.I. Feldman in The Times on Jan. 27 incorrectly identified the architect of the Schwab House at 73d Street and Riverside Drive. The architect was the late Sylvan Bien.

title: St. John's Holds Off UConn
description: Wayne McKoy played one of the finest defensive games in his four varsity seasons for St. John's last night, and Larry Washington had his best scoring effort in his 15-game career for the Redmen. The combination helped St. John's open a 14-point lead and then hold on for a 72-65 victory over Connecticut.

title: NEEDIEST CASES AMONG THE YOUNG
description: ''My first concern is for young people who have lost faith in our society and in themselves,'' Etta G. Bischoff of Tomkins Cove, N.Y., wrote in a letter accompanying a donation of $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Zimbabwe Threatens to Act Against Feuding Guerrillas
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe vowed today to take harsh action against feuding black guerrilla groups.

title: Wanda Hendrix, Actress Of 40's and 50's, Dead
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Wanda Hendrix, the diminutive actress who achieved stardom in her teens and played in about 20 movies in the late 1940's and 1950's, died of pneumonia in Burbank, Calif., on Feb. 1.

title: Coe Sets IndoorMark
description: Sebastian Coe turned in a world indoor best performance in the 800-meter run today with a time of 1 minute 46 seconds.

title: DELATA PLANS $7 BILLION FOR PLANES
description: In a statement that seemed aimed in part at spurring competition among aircraft manufacturers, Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it planned to spend $7 billion to acquire about 140 new fuel-efficient airliners over a 15-year period, starting in 1986.

title: ENERGY-EFFICIENT SOLAR HOMES: THE SEVEN MAJOR TYPES
description: ''SOLAR'' is commonly associated with any house that has a glassy roof of solar energy collectors, but all houses that receive sunlight could be called solar houses. Most houses, however, waste the sun's valuable energy. To be an efficient solar house, it must be specially designed to trap solar radiation and use it effectively.

title: REAGAN TRYING TO BE SENSITIVE TO NEEDS OF CONGRESS
description: President Reagan originally intended to give his State of the Union Address next Tuesday night, but when the White House found out that Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, had a long-standing out-of-town engagement that night, the President shifted the date to Wednesday.

title: Ingersoll-Rand Closing
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company said today that its British subsidiary planned to close its compressed air products plant in Manchester, which employs about 460 workers, because of falling demand. The company said the closing would take effect in July, although some employees might be placed elsewhere in the company. The plant has been operating on short time for two months, and about 100 layoffs have occurred in the past 18 months, the company said.

title: HAYAKAWA MAY FACE TOUGH SENATE RACE
description: California will elect a Senator next year, and the polls show that the Republican incumbent, S.I. Hayakawa, who has said he will run again, may be hard pressed by opponents who bear such politically potent names as Brown, Goldwater and even Reagan.

title: Banks Closed in State
description: Because of Lincoln's Birthday, all banks in New York State will be closed today. The New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and all commodities markets will remain open.

title: BLURRING THE BOUNDARIES BETWEEN ART AND FURNITURE
description: IT used to be easy. Artists painted pictures or made sculptures - and their works were there to be looked at but not touched. For a chair to sit in, a bed to lie down on or a lamp to read by, one went to the department store or the designer showroom. The making of functional furniture belonged to the cabinetmaker, the industrial designer, even the architect, but not the artist.

title: 6 CHILDREN DEAD AS A FIRE BURNS HOUISE IN NEW JERSEY
description: Six children were killed before dawn today when a fire swept their old frame home in this rural South Jersey community.

title: Billy Carter Sends Back $1,000 on Libyan Loan
description: Saying it was all he could afford now, Billy Carter sent Libya a $1,000 check last month as part of his repayment of a $220,000 loan he received from the Libyans.

title: Plant Cleaning Up A Radioactive Spill
description: Technicians at the Oyster Creek nuclear power plant began removing 25,000 gallons of what was described as ''slightly radioactive'' water from the floor of a waste storage facility, where it had accidentally leaked.

title: RESEARCHERS CHALLENGE CONCEPTION OF SAVINGS FROM OUTPATIENT CARE
description: Two researchers at Mount Sinai Medical Center have challenged studies showing that care in an outpatient clinic, when feasible, costs less and was equal to or better than care at a hospital.

title: Music from Marlboro Features Chamber Music
description: The ''Music From Marlboro'' concert at Alice Tully Hall Monday evening offered mostly young musicians with a more mature artist included for seasoning. The seasoner was the violist Philipp Naegele; the youngsters were John Bruce Yeh, clarinetist; Peter Orth, pianist; Carmit Zori, violinist; and Marcy Rosen, cellist.

title: FOR ANTIQUES BUFFS, BIG SHOW ARRIVES
description: The 37th National Antiques Show, Madison Square Garden.

title: Savings Units Cite Outflow
description: New interest-bearing checking accounts have provided little help so far for financially strapped savings institutions, the president of an industry group said today.

title: Company Purchases M. Lowenstein Stock
description: A Liechtenstein-based investment company has acquired 6.6 percent of the M. Lowenstein Corporation, a diversified textile manufacturer, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: SOLAR CHART
description: Architect/Cost Construction Heating System- Jefferson B. Riley, architect with the firm of Moore Grover Harper, Essex, Conn. 06426. (203) 767-0101. House: $125,000 (1979) System: $5,000 The 2,700-square-foot heavily insulated house is composed of three adjacent woodframe struc tures, ranging from one- to three stories, that step up a rocky hillside. Solar heat is captured by very large, south facing windows and skylights on the steeply pitched roofs. At night, thermal draperies are drawn to prevent heat loss through the doubleglazed glass. (The $5,000 attributed to passive solar features in the house includes the $2,000 cost of thermal draperies.) During sunny winter days, the heavily windowed southern portion of the house collects solar energy, and excess heat is ventilated to the north side of the house. A small wood stove in the kitchen and an oil- fired hot air furnace provide back-up heat. In summer, deciduous trees around the house are in leaf and pro vide shade for the large expanses of windows. In the future, active solar hot air collectors will be placed on the roof to reduce reliance on oil back-up. - Harrison Fraker, Architects, 729 Alexander Road, Princeton, N.J. 08540. (609) 452-8235. House: $110,000 (1978) System: $5,285

title: MURDOCH REFUSES PLEDGE ON THE TIMES OF LONDON
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher who is negotiating to buy The Times of London, said today that he would not become a ''hostage'' to a promise to keep the paper publishing indefinitely.

title: ETHICS OF MURDOCH PAPERS UNDER SCRUTINY AS HE PREPARES TO BUY LONDON
description: TIMES By JONATHAN FRIENDLY

title: WHEELCHAIR MAKER VS. CRITICS
description: In 1919, a mining engineer named Herbert Everest was caught in a mine cave-in that broke his back and confined him for the rest of his life to a wheelchair. Wheelchairs, in those days, were large, cumbersome contrivances that could not be folded up when not in use. Mr. Everest used to grouse a good deal about how hard his chair was on him.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Mike Squires, f irst baseman, to two-year contract. Named L oren Babe special assignment scout and a dded Duane Schaffer, Larry Munroe, Bart J ohnson and Marvin Lane to scouting staff. CINCINNATI (NL) - Won arbitration j udgment from Dave Collins, outfielder, w ho must accept $267,500 salary for 1981. He h ad sought $360,000. METS (NL) - Purchased contract of B ruce Bochy, catcher, from Tucson of Pa- c ific Coast League, a Houston affiliate, and a ssigned him to Tidewater of International L eague. MINNESOTA (AL) - Lost arbitration j udgment to Ron Jackson, first baseman, w ho will receive $200,000 salary for 1981. The t eam had offered $92,000. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Signed Ozzie Smith, s hortstop, to one-year contract. SEATTLE (AL) - Won arbitration judg- m ent from Julio Cruz, second baseman, who m ust accept $106,000 salary for 1981. He had s ought $160,000. Signed Dave Heaverlo, p itcher, who had filed for arbitration, to o ne- y ear contract. TAIYO, Japan - Signed Pete LaCock, f irst baseman, to two-year contract. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Jim Clancy a nd Joey McLaughlin, pitchers, to one-year c ontracts.

title: LAWYERS IN ANGRY CLASH AT HARRIS TRIAL
description: A daylong cross-examination of Dr. Louis Roh, a major prosecution witness in the murder trial of Jean S. Harris, was interrupted today by an angry exchange between lawyers.

title: 5 NOMINATED FOR WRITING PRIZE
description: Five books, including one by a writer who died in 1969, were nominated yesterday for the first P.E.N./Faulkner Award for ''the most distinguished work of fiction published by an American writer'' in 1980.

title: G.E. HELD GUILTY OF $1.25 MILLION BRIBE
description: A Federal jury found the General Electric Company guilty today of paying a $1.25 million bribe to an official in Puerto Rico to secure a $92 million contract to build a power plant.

title: GETTING YOUR BOOKS PUT IN APPLE-PIE ORDER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Carol Vogel is a freelance writer who is continually rearranging her books. By CAROL VOGEL

title: Q. My living room has a parquet wood floor, most of it covered with carpet. The wood that is exposed is very worn looking. What can I do to restore the original looks of the exposed wood floor? - E.P., New York
description: A. Assuming you don't want to lift up the carpet and refinish the entire floor, your best bet is to fold the carpet back all around the room, then use a wood floor stripper, made for cleaning and stripping wood floors, to get all the dirt and old finish off. Then refinish with two or three coats of wood sealer, or by applying a couple of coats of shellac.

title: AIRPORTS SNARLED
description: Driving but welcome rain, accompanied by gusty winds, drenched New Yorkers yesterday and fog caused delays at the airports. Winds of up to 49 miles an hour blustered through the city. In northern New York State, gusts up to 82 miles an hour were reported, and in Franklin County a concrete-block garage was blown down.

title: Market Place; Mining Outlook At United Park
description: CAN an old lead-and-zinc mine that produced silver as a byproduct find new life now that silver has mushroomed in price? Some Wall Street people are guessing that the United Park City Mines Company can do just that. Until recently, the Utah mine was operated by Park City Ventures, jointly owned by the Atlantic Richfield Company's Anaconda division and Asarco Inc. Both companies are also major shareholders in United Park.

title: U.S. AND CANADA GET PLEA TO HALT NIAGARA POLLUTION PENDING STUDY
description: An international commission recommended today that the United States and Canada halt all discharges in the Niagara River until a "comprehensive" study could be made of toxic substances entering the Great Lakes.

title: STAGE: DEATH-CAMP LIFE IN 'A DAY AT HARMENZ'
description: IN the long line of concentration-camp literature, the stories of Tadeusz Borowski occupy a special, horrifying place. As the author urged himself: ''Tell about the daily life of the camp, about the hierarchy of fear, about the loneliness of every man. But write that ... a portion of the sad fame of Auschwitz belongs to you as well.'' His collection, ''This Way for the Gas, Ladies and Gentlemen,'' is a heart-stopping study of man attempting to accommodate himself to the Holocaust, of victims abetting executioners, of survivors paying a supreme price in guilt.

title: 'MY BLOODY VALENTINE'
description: ''MY Bloody Valentine'' probably won't make you shiver with fright, but it's almost certain to make you squirm, first with irritation and then with revulsion.

title: Ceiling Collapses In Brooklyn School
description: A 9-by-15-foot section of plaster ceiling collapsed in a firstgrade classroom in a Brooklyn school yesterday, but no one was hurt, the Board of Education said.

title: Virginia Wins, 51-46; Extends Streak to 26
description: Lee Raker of Virginia hit two free throws with 13 seconds left and Ralph Sampson hit two more with one second left as the undefeated Cavaliers beat North Carolina State, 51-46, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, part of a sentence was omitted from the ''Hers'' column in The Home Section last Thursday. The corrected sentence appears today on page C2.

title: U.S. Steel To Spend More
description: David M. Roderick, the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said today that the nation's largest steel company would continue to build up its cash position and would increase capital spending to about $1.3 billion for the coming year from $975 million last year.

title: SPARING OF SOCIAL PROGRAMS: REAGAN BIDS FOR A CONSENSUS; News Analysis
description: President Reagan's abrupt announcement yesterday sparing seven basic social programs from budget cuts was a response to criticism that his Administration was not keeping its word in promising not to hurt the ''truly needy.''

title: The Unwanted People
description: Officially the place does not exist, but 25 miles north of Pretoria there it is: a sea of squatter shacks spreading out over the veld. The tiny houses are made of knocked-down packing cases and corrugated iron strips - the occasional better ones of mud bricks.

title: Aid Given to Retain Full S.I. Ferry Service
description: New York State has approved $624,000 in additional financing to avoid a reduction in rush-hour service on the Staten Island Ferry. The city's Department of Transportation said it would have been forced to cut back from five boats to four boats by Feb. 16 without the assistance. The new funds will keep the fifth boat in operation until May or June.

title: IN POLITICS, 'PROCESS' IS UP AND POLICY DOWN
description: Something is wrong in American politics. The politics of issues have given way to the politics of process. Policy choices - the difficult decisions concerning the distribution of wealth, provision of services, and the tax burden - seem less visible. Instead, politicians deal with the process questions. Management is the central issue for Presidents and mayors, for Congressmen and councilmen. But management is not an issue. Education, sanitation, poverty, and national defense should be the subjects of debate.

title: POSTMASTER GENERAL SUGGESTS DEREGULATION OF RATES
description: The Postmaster General called today for Congress to consider deregulation of the Postal Service if the Postal Rate Commission rejects its application for a rate increase.

title: CALCULATING TAX OWED: HOW THE BILL MAY BE CUT
description: Your TaxesA Guide to Preparing 1980 ReturnsTenth of 12 articles.- By DEBORAH RANKIN

title: German Historian Tells Of Tattoos at Death Camps
description: A West German historian testified today in the trial of a man alleged to have been a Nazi death camp guard that prisoners of war trained to be guards were tattooed on the arm.

title: THE FLAWED LOGIC OF SECRETARY BELL
description: To the Editor:

title: RAIL COMMUTER LINES IN BOSTON SHUT DOWN BY STRIKE OF TRAINMEN
description: Trainmen and conductors walked out on strike at midnight tonight, shutting down the rail commuter lines into Boston, a spokesman for Boston & Main Railroad reported.

title: Companies
description: Delta Air Lines said it planned to spend $7 billion to buy about 140 new airliners in a 15-year period beginning in 1986. That would be in addition to the $3 billion of Boeing 757's that Delta decided to order last year. Delta said that it hoped Boeing, McDonnell Douglas and Airbus would compete for $5 billion worth of the new orders and that it would buy $2 billion more of Boeing 757's. (Page D1.)

title: U.S. EXPELS CUBAN ENVOY, SAYING HE BROKE TRADE BAN
description: The State Department declared a Cuban diplomat persona non grata today, charging that he had sought to lure American businessmen into illegal trade, and gave him one week to leave the country.

title: U.S. MOVING TO SELL OIL LEASES ON COAST IN 4 DISPUTED SPOTS
description: In his first major action as Secretary of the Interior, James G. Watt today proposed reversing an act of the Carter Administration by offering for sale leases to drill for oil and gas in four disputed areas off northern California.

title: TRADE PANEL ENDS EFFORTS TO MAKE RULES FOR DRUG ADS
description: The Federal Trade Commission has dropped a five-year effort to set rules controlling the advertising of overthe-counter, nonprescription drugs.

title: RATINGS EXEMPTION URGED FOR TV DOCUMENTARIES
description: Roone Arledge, president of ABC News and Sports, has called on the three principal television networks to exempt special news programs and documentaries from the weekly prime-time audience-popularity ratings. Mr. Arledge said the action would encourage the networks to program more news in prime time.

title: China Cancels More Contracts
description: China has asked the consortium building the second phase of the $5 billion Baoshan Steel Works, near Shanghai, to stop work and cancel all existing contracts, the consortium's lead company said today.

title: HOUSTON SYMPHONY SETS JULY TCHAIKOVSKY FESTIVAL
description: The Houston Syumphony will present a Tchaikovsky festival in the summer, featuring all the composer's symphonies, piano concertos and some of his ballet music.

title: Reagan and Son Discuss Stock Sale Investigation
description: President Reagan and his son, Michael, have discussed the allegations that the younger Mr. Reagan sold fraudulent stock and diverted to his own use $17,500 invested in a gasohol project that he started, the White House said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TREND-SETTING?

title: SPANISH CHIEF BORN TO POWER
description: At a recent lunch in Madrid marking the publication of a new book, Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo y Bustelo proferred some advice to its author, Juan Luis Cebrian, editor of the newspaper El Pais. ''Some of the language is a bit old-fashioned,'' he said. ''You should beware of anachronisms when writing in Spanish.'' Such cultivated aloofness is characteristic of Mr. Calvo Sotelo, who was asked by King Juan Carlos yesterday to form the country's next Government. He strikes his compatriots as somehow Anglo-Saxon in his manner.

title: Ruling on Zeller's
description: A Quebec Superior Court judge today granted a request by a senior executive of Zeller's Ltd. for an injunction to prevent shareholders from voting Friday on a proposed merger with the Hudson's Bay Company, which owns 57 percent of the common shares of Zeller's and is offering $18 a share (Canadian) for the rest. The Zeller's board has recommended accepting the offer, although management opposes it. Hudson's Bay officials were unavailable for comment on the court action.

title: News Analysis
description: To the outside world the appointment of Poland's Minister of Defense, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, as Prime Minister may seem like an ominous step toward militarizing the Government and preparing the armed forces for a crackdown on the unions and their supporters.

title: SEA TRAIN FILES UNDER CHAPTER 11
description: After weeks of negotiations to prevent the collapse of Seatrain Lines, three Italian creditors with unpaid bills amounting to slightly more than $1 million forced the financially ailing shipping company into bankruptcy proceedings yesterday.

title: LINCOLN'S BIRTHDAY
description: Today is Lincoln's Birthday. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended.

title: Times Co.  Net Off 7.8% In Quarter
description: The New York Times Company yesterday reported a 7.8 percent decline in net income in the fourth quarter, ended Dec. 31, 1980. The company earned $10.7 million, or 89 cents a share, down from $11.6 million, or 97 cents a share, in the comparable 1979 period.

title: Where Are the Democrats?
description: Barely 90 days ago, many Democrats were clamoring for a New Liberal Agenda. Now, when it counts, they can't even get together on the old one.

title: Harrell and Levine Play Beethoven, Schubert
description: Lynn Harrell and James Levine engaged in intelligent repartee in Avery Fisher Hall last Sunday afternoon. Mr. Harrell's cello matched the phrasing and timbre of Mr. Levine's piano in works by Beethoven, Schubert and Debussy. Mr. Levine always answered in kind.

title: New Ethanol Plant
description: United Bio-Fuel Industries announced plans for a $160 million plant here to convert municipal and industrial waste into ethanol. The process would be used to produce 50 million gallons of ethanol annually for use in gasohol, a gasoline substitute. Full-scale production is expected to begin within three and a half years, when the plant would employ

title: SOME GYPSY MOTH EGGS FOUND SURVIVING COLD
description: DESPITE the hopes of many residents in New England and the New York metropolitan area that gypsy moth eggs would be killed by this winter's extreme cold, this has not been the case, according to the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station in New Haven.

title: WALDHEIM AIDE TO PRESS FOR AFGHAN TALKS
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim announced the appointment today of his special representative to promote peace talks on Afghanistan.

title: F.C.C. Eases G.T.E. Order
description: The Federal Communications Commission agreed today to relax the conditions it imposed on the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation when it approved the company's 1979 acquisition of the Telenet Corporation.

title: WARRANTS ARE ISSUED FOR 3 INSIDER CASE
description: Warrants were issued yesterday for the arrest of three of the four defendants in a Government case that charges former investment bankers at Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb with using confidential information to profit in trading stock.

title: Mets Get Catcher
description: The Mets yesterday purchased the contract of Bruce Bochy, a catcher, from the Houston Astros' Tucson farm club of the Pacific Coast League. Bochy, a 6-foot-4-inch, right-handed hitter, was assigned to the Mets' Tidewater club of the International League.

title:
NOTES ON PEOPLE;
In Which the Government Insists on Not Cutting Funds
description: As soon as the 1970 census figures were published, folks in Parkdale, Mo., knew there had been a mistake. The village's population was put at 971, and that, they knew, was about three times the actual count.

title: BATTLE FOR CONTROL OF FOX IS SURFACING
description: A high-level corporate struggle that has been fought behind closed doors at 20th Century-Fox for the last year is expected to erupt Feb. 27 at the next board of directors meeting.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 12. 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Scientific and technical subcommit- tee of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: KOCH RUNS AFOUL OF DRY GREENWICH
description: Mayor Koch's observations about how residents of Greenwich, Conn., have acquired a certain air of distinction during the drought emergency landed him in hot water yesterday in the affluent New York City suburb.

title: 2 CITY BOROUGHS MAY BE HOLDING SOURCE OF WATER
description: The United States Geological Survey is conducting a study to determine whether New York City can utilize the underground supply of 1.5 trillion gallons of water that is believed to lie under Brooklyn and Queens.

title: REAGAN SEKS SHIFT OF SOCIAL PROGRAMS TO STATES' CONTROL
description: The Reagan Administration is shaping proposals that would shift the bulk of the responsibility for welfare, housing, health care and food programs from the Federal Government to the states, White House officials said today.

title: TEXT OF GROMYKO'S RESPONSE TO A LETTER FROM HAIG
description: Following is the text of a letter from Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that was made public today by the Soviet Embassy in Washington: Dear Mr. Secretary, I have carefully studied your letter of January 24 transmitted through the U.S. Embassy in Moscow and take note of the wish expressed therein to work for development of relations between the Soviet Union and the United States. This corresponds to our intentions, too.

title: THE THIRD WORLD'S READY-MADE HOT SPOTS
description: To the Editor:

title: New Labor Secretary Acts to Kill Plan to Label Perilous Chemicals
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan, in his first major action since taking office, killed a Carter Administration order to require labeling of hazardous chemicals and delayed implementation of more than 20 pending regulations.

title: HOTEL BUSBOY CHARGED WITH ARSON IN LAS VEGAS FIRE THAT KILLED EIGHT
description: The Las Vegas police said tonight that they had arrested a 23-year-old busboy at the Las Vegas Hilton Hotel on charges of arson and homicide in the blaze that swept through the 30-story building last night, killing eight persons, injuring 198 others and causing an estimated $10 million in damage.

title: Monument Closed for Cleaning
description: The Washington Monument was closed today for its annual cleaning and safety checkup.

title: New York City Notes Rated Investment Grade
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. yesterday assigned a MIG-3 rating for both tax and revenue anticipation notes that New York City plans to sell next week, giving a lift to the city's plans to borrow on the strength of its own creditworthiness.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cyclops Corporation signed a joint venture agreement wiht Union Drilling Inc. to begin exploratory gas and oil drilling activity on the more than 50,000 acres of land in West Virginia and Ohio currently controlled by Cyclops.

title: Reagan's Polish Dilemma
description: If the Soviet Union were on the verge of bankruptcy, would we offer our financial aid? Of course not; the collapse of the Soviet economy would be proof that Communism does not work, a realization devoutly to be wished.

title: Sports of the Times; The Death of a Bobsledder
description: THE phone call from her brother John had awakened Kelly Ann Morgan in the middle of the night at her apartment in Saranac Lake, N.Y. Quickly, the oldest sister of the 11 Morgan children dressed and drove to her parents' home. In the darkness before dawn, she quietly walked into their bedroom and gently awakened them.

title: Taxi Fleets Seek 50 Night Surcharge
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission agreed to consider a new request from taxi fleet operators for a 50-cent surcharge for night service to encourage more drivers to work at night.

title: STATE DEPT. BRIEFING: WAGNERIAN AND RISKY
description: After a long day yesterday of confusion and hectic clarification of the Reagan Administration's policy toward Poland, William J. Dyess, a State Department spokesman, promised today to be more cautious at his daily briefing and wash his mouth out with soap if he ever answered another question that began with the word ''if.''

title: A Concert-in-the-Round At Third Street School
description: The Third Street Music School Settlement deserved a bigger audience than the 40 or so who showed up for its ''Music New to New York'' series Monday night. Three fine musicians, Ruth Dreier, cellist, Edmund Neimann, pianist, and Curtis Macomber, violinist, played a relaxed concert-in-the-round, featuring music of Ross Lee Finney, Arnold Franchetti and Mario Davidovsky along with the premiere of ''Scudding,'' written by Libby Larsen for Miss Dreier.

title: MGM Grand Seeks New Insurance
description: MGM Grand Hotels Inc. reportedly is in the process of contracting for $170 million in retroactive liability insurance to cover claims arising from the Nov. 21 fire at its Las Vegas, Nev., hotel-casino.

title: Oxy Unit Buys Crestmont
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that the board of its OPI Holding Corporation subsidiary had approved the acquisition of the remainder of the Crestmont Oil and Gas Company for $24 a share and that a previously announced merger would become effective on or after Feb. 27.

title: CAPITAL DOES AS REAGANS DO, SINCE POWER IS ALWAYS 'IN'
description: When Nancy Reagan's California hairdresser announced plans not long ago to open a salon here, 50 Washington ''hair groupies'' telephoned for appointments.

title: NETS TRAILING BULLS BY 15 WITH 2:34 LEFT, TRIUMPH IN OVERTIME
description: More than half of the 6,934 persons who showed up at the Rutgers Athletic Center to see the New Jersey Nets play the Chicago Bulls tonight left with 2 minutes 34 seconds remaining and the Nets trailing by 15 points. They missed seeing the Nets rally to win in overtime, 135-133.

title: U.S. to Take 2,000 Vietnamese
description: About 2,800 Vietnamese refugees from Malaysia will be resettled in third countries this month, a United States spokesman announced today. He said 2,000 would go to the United States.

title: Keeping Connecticut Solvent: Round Two
description: Not sadder, maybe, but surely wiser after his first round of budget politics, Gov. William O'Neill of Connecticut has now announced the second. Without his new fiscal plan for the coming year, next year's deficit could reach $200 million. Even with it, the Governor may not be able to close the gap. Yet his proposals seem a fair enough attempt precisely because they seem fair enough.

title: F.C.C. to Move Headquarters
description: The Federal Communications Commission, citing potential savings in rental costs, voted today to move its headquarters from downtown Washington to suburban Rosslyn, Va. The acting chairman, Robert E. Lee, said the commission voted 4 to 1 in favor of the move, which is subject to Congressional approval. The transfer of the agency's 1,600 employees would occur in two steps, in the fall of 1982 and the spring of 1983.

title: DOW OFF 6.14 POINTS
description: Stock prices gave ground yesterday as investors nervously eyed the continued high level of interest rates and awaited details of President Reagan's economic program, to be released next week.

title: GOV. BROWN SEEKS BUSINESS AID
description: A year after building his Presidential campaign on the theme of revitalizing American industry, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has proposed a $22 million package of state incentives aimed at protecting and invigorating California's high-technology businesses.

title: HOME BEAT
description: FOR the last three years, Stephen Schermeyer, far right, and Bertram Seides, designers based in Quogue, L.I., have collected postWorld War II pieces of furniture. Recently, they began to think about ways to manufacture similar objects.

title: NOT-SO-STARTLING DECISION ON TELEVISING TRAILS
description: To the Editor:

title: Kodak Introduces Two New Cameras
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it had developed a new instant camera with two lenses and an electronic flash, and a new compact traditional camera with a built-in electronic flash.

title: CECIL (TINY) THOMPSON
description: Cecil (Tiny) Thompson, a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, died Monday at the age of 77. Mr. Thompson, a longtime Calgary resident, was a goaltender who played 10 seasons for the Boston Bruins, helping them to the Stanley Cup in 1929, and two for the Detroit Red Wings. Four times he won the Vezina Trophy as the National Hockey League's best goalie.

title: GET ME A Z-PLATE LIMO WITH A DIRECT-DIAL LINE TO ZURICH, AND DRINKS
description: Vamos EAST MEREDITH, N.Y. - It was the big deal. You know the deal. The one where the guys grin at you in the halls as they slap your back and say ''megabucks.'' That deal. We were closing it with that fellow. The fellow from that third-world country. You know the one. The country where in '63 this one bunch wiped out this other bunch. Maybe it was '72. It was in the headlines. It was on TV. You'd remember. Where now they've got all this gas, or chrome, or copper. Maybe it's ammonia. You know which one. They use it for cars. Maybe they use it to make fertilizer.

title: O.-T.-C. Price Rule Changed
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission agreed today to require daily ''last-sale reporting'' of prices for high-volume over-the-counter stocks within the next year.

title: An Appraisal; 499 PARK, THE INTENT IS SERIOUS
description: GEORGE KLEIN is a builder who has set out to make his mark in New York in an unusual manner - through ar- An Appraisal chitecture. Mr. Klein, who has been building in Brooklyn for a number of years, has made his move into Manhattan by commissioning three of the nation's best-known architectural firms, I.M. Pei & Partners, Edward Larrabee

title: No Headline
description: Cynthia B. Dwyer returned to the United States yesterday after spending more than nine months in an Iranian jail as an accused spy. At a jammed news conference at Kennedy International Airport shortly after she was reunited with her family, Mrs. Dwyer called the espionage accusation ''complete nonsense.'' She said that she had probably been seized as a scapegoat after the abortive attempt last April 25 to rescue by force the 52 Americans being held hostage in Iran.

title: 10 CONVICTED IN CHICAGO F.A.L.N. TRIAL
description: After two hours of deliberation today, a Federal jury delivered verdicts of guilty on all 13 counts against 10 persons on trial here as terrorists.

title: OFFICIAL REAFFIRMS WARNING ABOUT RICE
description: Dr. Angel Roman-Franco, director of the Puerto Rico Cancer Institute, who has urged that a talc coating added to most rice sold on the island be banned, today reaffirmed his concern that it may increase the risk of cancer after questions were raised about whether he had reversed his position.

title: Stay of Execution Granted To Slayer in New Orleans
description: David Dene Martin, a convicted murderer who had already moved to the death house and had asked for what he wanted for his last meal, won a delay of execution today from a Federal judge.

title: IN ISRAELI VILLAGE, JEWS AND ARABS ERASE STEREOTYPES
description: ''Even though we live side by side, we don't know each other,'' said the tall Arab, Farhat Igbaria. ''We don't know anything about the customs of the other side. I believe if we can bring together Jews and Arabs, we can bring change.''

title: Investigation Finds No Evidence Of Wiretapping at G.O.P. Office
description: A seven-month investigation of the suspected wiretapping of the office of Mary Crisp, former chairman of the Republican National Committee, found no evidence of any electronic eavesdropping, the District of Columbia police said today.

title: FINDING PRIVATE AND GOVERNMENT SOLAR SPECIALISTS
description: INFORMATION about energy-efficient designs and professionals who specialize in this field is available from a number of government and private sources. The National Solar Heating and Cooling Information Center, P.O. Box 1607, Rockville, Md. 20850 (toll-free 800-523-2929 or from Pennsylvania, 800-462-4983), has reams of printed information about energy specialists, locations of energy-efficient homes and other information agencies.

title: 152 Sought in Toledo Thefts
description: The police here began rounding up 152 persons today in an undercover operation that netted more than $1.4 million in stolen property. With two officers posing as truck drivers who would buy stolen goods, the police made 544 purchases in over 11 months, Police Chief John Mason said.

title:
NOTES ON PEOPLE;
Fatigued Willie Mays
description: Willie Mays gave some New Jersey schoolchildren a scare yesterday morning when he fainted while giving a talk at Duberson Junior High School outside Atlantic City.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE* 19.00 19.00 15.25 DISCOUNT RATE** 13.00 13.00 12.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 16.50 16.72 14.58 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 15.55 15.48 12.20 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.72 14.63 12.22 TREASURY NOTES 13.46 13.38 11.84 TREASURY BONDS 12.95 12.86 11.65 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 13.93 13.84 12.84 MUNICIPAL BONDS 11.00 11.00 8.30 6-MONTH SAVINGS 13.985 CERTIFICATES * Split rate, 19.00-19.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: W. Atlee Burpee Account Goes to Rapp & Collins
description: On April 1, no fooling, Rapp & Collins, the direct-marketing advertising subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach, will officially become the ad agency for the W. Atlee Burpee Company, marketers of seeds and garden supplies and the country's oldest catalogue house.

title: U.S. Mission Visits Argentina
description: A United States Congressional mission arrived in Argentina last night on the first leg of a factfinding tour of South America. The five-member mission, led by Senator Thad Cochran, Republican of Mississippi, will confer with Argentine Government officials on ways to improve relations. The mission will also visit Brazil and Peru.

title: Tenneco Gas Find
description: Tenneco Inc. said its KX4 No. 4 natural gas confirmation well in the north coast marine area off Trinidad and Tobago had tested at a rate of 35.6 million cubic feet of natural gas a day from one zone and 32.8 million from another, indicating a ''substantial natural gas accumulation in the area.'' The company said the new well was about 30 miles north of Chaguaramas in 450 to 600 feet of water. Tenneco said it was operator for a group including AGIP, the Italian state-owned oil company, Deminex and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: 300 PICKET MACCHIAROLA IN SCHOOL DISPUTE
description: More than 300 white parents and children picketed the home of School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola in Brooklyn last night while 150 to 200 blacks demonstrated outside the Queens home of Borough President Donald R. Manes in the continuing dispute over the closing of a predominantly white school annex in Rosedale, Queens.

title: Nation's Population Center Crosses the Mississippi
description: For the first time in history, the East no longer holds the bulk of the nation's people. The center of population has crossed the Mississippi River.

title: Japanese Expect Steel Output to Fall in '81
description: The Japanese steel industry, after strong production last year, is projecting a gloomier outlook for 1981 because of declining demand.

title: Technology; Tiny Capsules In Medical Use
description: FOR more than two decades, while the space program was demonstrating to Americans that engineers could design a capsule capable of shielding astronauts from incredible temperature and pressure extremes, capsule technology has advanced less publicly but more broadly on another front. Increasingly smaller capsules have been designed for ever more difficult and specific tasks, especially in medicine.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Cheveresan Nicolae Chravalot, a 44-year-old burglary suspect from Manhattan, was listed in stable condition with a bullet wound in a hip after he was shot by a police officer during a struggle following a break-in in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn. ... Proabortion slogans and feminist symbols were spray-painted on the ground floor of the Neighborhood Church of Greenwich Village at 269 Bleecker Street.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1981
description: International U.S. concern about Poland was rejected by Soviet Foreign Minister Gromyko in a letter to Secretary of State Haig that the Soviet Embassy made public in Washington. Officials speculated that Moscow was irritated by the harsh statements issued by the Reagan Administration about Soviet policy and was countering with its own criticism. (Page A1, Column 5.) Iran's Moslem clergy was warned to stay out of government affairs by Ayatollah Khomeini on the second anniversary of the Islamic revolution. The Islamic leader said that continued ''interference in executive affairs'' could turn the people against the clergy and plunge Iran into turmoil. (A5:1-3.)

title: Mallinckrodt President Named Chief Executive
description: Raymond F. Bentele, the 44-year-old president of Mallinckrodt, Inc., has been named chief executive officer of the chemical and health-care products corporation. He succeeds Harold E. Thayer, 68, who continues as chairman.

title: CONSERVATIVE PARTY'S CHIEF TO GET JOB AS HEAD OF POSTAL RATE PANEL
description: Kieran O'Doherty, a founder of the New York State Conservative Party, will be designated chairman of the Postal Rate Commission by the Reagan Administration, according to political sources in New York and Washington.

title: DANCE: KAROLE ARMITAGE
description: PUNK rock and Merce Cunningham? Karole Armitage drew upon both sources for a wildly interesting and even slightly wild experimental dance concert at the American Theater Laboratory Tuesday night.

title: ELECTORAL OPTIMISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Willliams Violin Concerto Has New York Premiere
description: The St. Louis Symphony Orchestra presented the New York premiere of a violin concerto by John Williams in Carnegie Hall last Friday night. The orchestra, conducted by Leonard Slatkin, and the soloist, a young Soviet emigre, Mark Peskanov, probably gave as good an account of the work as it will ever have.

title: PUBLIC RADIO BROADCASTS FROM TOWN HALL PLANNED
description: TOWN HALL and National Public Radio in Washington are close to an agreement that could have a far-reaching impact on both organizations. The agreement, which could be implemented as early as next fall, will make Town Hall the site of frequent live, nationwide broadcasts, co-produced by the network and a variety of musical organizations ranging from classical to avant-garde to jazz.

title: 'FRIENDS OF THE FAMILY': WHERE TO SEEK GUIDANCE
description: THE United States Department of Health and Human Services has joined forces with three private organizations in a campaign aimed at disseminating educational materials on the problems of parenthood.

title: I.T.T. Expects Rise in 1980 Net
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday that it expected consolidated earnings for 1980 to rise to $6.12 a share from $2.65 a share in 1979.

title: TO HELP THE DISABLED OF ALL NATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: NICARAGUA SEEKING ACCORD IN SALVADOR
description: Alarmed by the suspension of American economic aid last month, Nicaragua's Sandinist Government has begun pressing El Salvador's leftist guerrillas to seek a political settlement rather than an armed victory in their conflict with the United States-backed junta.

title: JOHNSON TO PHASE OUT U.S. DIAPER BUSINESS
description: Johnson & Johnson Inc. announced yesterday that it was leaving the increasingly crowded disposable diaper market in the United States. Johnson, a leading maker of health care products, will withdraw its product in this country over the next four months. It will continue its overseas business, however.

title: JERSEY SIBLINGS RIVAL THE BEST IN TRACK AND FIELD
description: Carl and Carol Lewis are not the Eric and Beth Heiden of track and field. But give them time. They have already made the United States Olympic team. They hold assorted world and national rankings and have made Willingboro, N.J., more than an outpost off the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Acquires Underwood, Jordan
description: Guess Ogilvy & Mather was serious about moving into the public relations business. It has just reached an agreement to acquire Underwood, Jordan Associates, specialists in public relations for public utilities.

title: Bolivia Reports Uncovering Plot
description: The Bolivian military Government said today that it had uncovered a plot to assassinate prominent figures, including army officers, church leaders and members of the press. Four Bolivians and an unspecified number of foreigners involved in drug trafficking and left-wing politics were detained yesterday, the statement said.

title: RETAIL SALES UP STRONG 2%
description: Sales by American retailers in January rose 2 percent, seasonally adjusted, over December, the Commerce Department said today.

title: PUG TO CONTINUE ON SHOW TOUR
description: A fawn pug is the dog of the year in America, and he is not going to rest on his laurels. Ch. Dhandy's Favorite Woodchuck, more familiarly known as Chucky, was named Tuesday night as best of the 2,9l0 dogs at the Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden. It was the first time in the event's 105-year history that a pug had been chosen best in show.

title: GISCARD ROLLS OUT RED CARPET FOR SADAT
description: After years of diplomatic chilliness, the French Government went all out today to welcome President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, who is here on a campaign to encourage Western European involvement in a Middle East settlement.

title: Wilkins Memorabilia Given to the Smithsonian
description: Although he must now use a wheelchair as a result of a stroke, Roy Wilkins went to Washington on Tuesday to present his collection of memorabilia from his long career as a civil-rights crusader to the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Korvettes Herald Square
description: Korvettes Inc., which closed all of its remaining 15 stores on Christmas Eve, will reopen its Herald Square store in Manhattan on Monday for a limited period, reliable trade sources said yesterday. It will be operated for Korvettes by the Schottenstein interests of Columbus, Ohio. Joseph A. Ris, chairman of Korvettes, was not available for comment.

title: Albany Panel Seeks State U. Tuition Rise
description: ALBANY (AP) - Undergraduate tuition for the State University of New York should be raised $150 next fall, the executive committee of the board of trustees recommended.

title: PARTNER MAY HAVE SHOT OFF-DUTY OFFICER
description: A bullet removed from the right arm of an off-duty police officer who fatally shot a 17-year-old alleged car thief in Brooklyn on Tuesday could have come from a gun fired by the officer's partner at a moonlighting construction job, the police said last night.

title: TEXASGULF CHAIRMAN AND 6 AIDES KILLED IN WESTCHESTER JET CRASH
description: A small corporate jet carrying executives of Texasgulf, a mining and oil company based in Stamford, Conn., crashed in rain and fog last night during an instrument approach to Westchester County Airport. All seven persons aboard, including the concern's chief executive officer, were killed.

title: Tests Show Athlete Had 2 Chromosome Types
description: Stella Walsh, the Olympic track star who was slain last year, had both male chromosomes and incomplete chromosomes bearing both male and female characteristics, according to a final report released today by the Cuyahoga County coroner.

title: Schmidt Says He Will Resist Pressure From Party's Left
description: The West German Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, said today that he would not bow to left-wing dissidents in his Social Democratic Party.

title: REGENTS PLAN ON FOREIGN MEDICAL SCHOOLS OPPOSED
description: The Association of American Medical Colleges yesterday urged the New York State Board of Regents to abandon its plans to accredit profit-making foreign medical schools, contending that this would downgrade the quality of medical care throughout the state and possibly the country.

title: Nicaragua Regime Shuts Offices of Rights Group
description: The Nicaraguan Government ordered the temporary closure of the local Human Rights Commission last night, charging that its director, Jose Esteban Gonzalez, had embarked on a campaign of defamation against the Sandinist regime.

title: Article 002314 -- No Title
description: The Sysco Corporation, a billion-dollar company recently listed on the New York Stock Exchange, leads an industry - food-service marketing - that even Sysco's president terms ''practically invisible.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Conductron Corporation will offer 12,000 units containing $12 million of its 12 1/2 percent debentures due 1996, and 360,000 common shares, through a Drexel Burnham group.

title: Bill Blass's Scorecard: Mrs. Reagan 1, Mr. Reagan 0
description: One of Nancy Reagan's favorite dress designers, Bill Blass, was at Yale on Tuesday night to chat with a small group of students about design in general, and wound up defending Mrs. Reagan against critics who say she spends too much money on clothes.

title: CAREY IS BILLING $24,166 FOR TRIP TO THE FAR EAST
description: Governor Carey and his entourage of 10 people spent $24,166 - exclusive of food - on a business trip to Tokyo and Hong Kong this month and will charge the state for that amount, according to his top aide.

title: REALISTIC WOOD GRAIN EFFECT CAN BE EASILY PAINTED
description: VERY often a do-it-yourselfer will want to finish a cabinet or piece of furniture so that it will look like natural wood -even though the object is made of metal or has been previously painted over so there is no wood grain visible.

title: Charges Dropped In Extortion Case
description: All charges have been dropped against a man who had been accused of taking part in extorting protection payoffs from houses of prostitution in Manhattan.

title: MUSIC: NATIONAL ORCHESTRAL ASSOCIATION
description: SOLO virtuosity is one of the primary ingredients of Claus Adam's Cello Concerto, which received its New York premiere in Carnegie Hall Tuesday night. As played by Stephen Kates and the National Orchestral Association, conducted by Jesse Levine, Mr. Adam's work made its virtuoso intent abundantly clear right from the soloist's first entry - hardly a surprise from a composer who is himself a distinguished cellist, having served as a member of the Juilliard String Quartet from 1955 to 1975.

title: SINATRA LICENSE ASSURED AFTER GAMING BOARD VOTE
description: Frank Sinatra, who was barred from Nevada's gambling industry more than 17 years ago because of his purported ties to organized crime, was authorized to re-enter the industry today by a unanimous vote of the Nevada Gaming Control Board.

title: NEW YORK POLICE MOVING TO CURB FALSE AUTOMATIC BURGLAR ALARMS
description: The Police Department in New York will give precinct commanders throughout the city the discretion to ignore silent automatic burglar alarms when they are set off at houses and businesses where there have been repeated false alarms.

title: Wilkinson Offers To Buy Out Scripto
description: Wilkinson Sword Inc., which owns 56.5 percent of Scripto Inc., said that it would offer $2.375 a share cash for the remaining 1.491 million shares of Scripto, a maker of ballpoint pens and cigarette lighters. Wilkinson Sword is a subsidiary of the Allegheny Ludlum Company.

title: PILOT UNION AGREES TO STAY ON THE JOB
description: A walkout of airline pilots set for March 2 was averted yesterday when the Reagan Administration said it would name a ''Presidential task force'' to decide the number of pilots needed to operate new airliners.

title: Widow of Ex-Marine Urges Mental Help for Garwood
description: A woman who says she loves Pfc. Robert R. Garwood of the Marine Corps today told a military jury that the convicted collaborator was ''a quiet, gentle person'' who needed psychiatric help and should not be sentenced to prison.

title: Miss America in His Past, Mrs. America in His Future
description: For 25 years, Bert Parks lent his smile and cheeriness to the job of master of ceremonies of the Miss America Pageant in Atlantic City. Then early last year, he was suddenly dismissed by the pageant sponsors, who hired a younger man to replace him.

title: CHILD ARTISTS CREATE A CAPITALIST VENTURE
description: SAN FRANCISCO IN 1968, a group of San Francisco artists, unhappy about the way art was being taught to their children in the public schools, got together and formed their own summer program in the Alvarado School here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Now about Poland. First of all I must say in a totally definite way that the internal affairs of this sovereign socialist state cannot be a subject of discussion between third countries, including the U.S.S.R. and the U.S.A. If one is to speak, however, of outside attempts to exert influence on the internal situation in Poland, then it is necessary to state that such attempts do take place and they are being undertaken precisely on the part of the U.S.A. and other Western powers.''

title: ADVANCE PLANNING FOR TOMATO CROPS
description: IF there is a sunny corner in the garden, any planter worth his trowel tries to raise at least one, two, maybe three tomato plants. They are easy to grow and the rewards are satisfying.

title: CON ED OFFERING FLOW RESTRICTORS
description: To help conserve water, Con Ed has given out 209,000 flow restrictors inside customers' monthly bills, at local customer-service offices and at the Conservation Center on the ground floor of the Chrysler Building, 405 Lexington Avenue (between 42d and 43d Streets). The flow restrictor reduces the water flow from the shower head from five to 10 gallons to two or three gallons per minute.

title: SOUTH KOREANS ELECT A PRO-CHUN ELECTORAL COLLEGE
description: South Koreans voted yesterday for members of an electoral college that later this month will give President Chun Doo Hwan a full seven-year term.

title: IRANIANS, MARKING 2D ANNIVERSARY, WARN OF A CRISIS
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini marked the second anniversary of the Islamic revolution today with a ''serious warning'' to Iran's Moslem clergy to stay out of the Government's affairs.

title: Chemical Raises Dividend
description: The Chemical New York Corporation yesterday raised its quarterly dividend to 96 cents a share from 87 cents, payable April 1 to shareholders of record March 13. Chemical said the increase reflected the company's improved performance in 1980, particularly significant gains in return on assets, return on equity and retention of earnings. The last dividend increase was in the first quarter of 1980, when it was raised to 87 cents a share from 79 cents.

title: People
description: * Paul J. Goldsmith named executive vice president of Rumrill-Hoyt and general manager of the New York office.

title: Point Fixes Detailed by Informant
description: Henry Hill, a Government informer with admitted links to organized crime, says that he helped rig nine Boston College basketball games in 1978-79, from which he made $75,000 to $100,000 in gambling profits. He also says three players involved ''probably made about $10,000 each.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Baldwin Technology Corporation, Stamford, Conn., a manufacturer of graphic arts equipment and packaging systems, has elected John A. McKenna president and chief executive officer.

title: 18 Fire Violations In Jersey Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY (UPI) - Fire officials found 18 minor fire code violations in a resort hotel-casino, but approved the facility on the condition the violations would be fixed by Feb. 20.

title: Taxi Drivers of Athens on Strike
description: The 13,000 taxi drivers in this Greek capital began a 48-hour strike today to back demands that Governmentregulated fare scales be raised to cover a 12 percent increase in gasoline prices last month. The increases put the price of a gallon of regular grade at $3 and of premium grade at $3.34.

title: Toro Co. Reports Large Retrenchment
description: Reeling from two consecutive years of adverse weather conditions, the Toro Company, a leading maker of lawn care and snow removal equipment, said yesterday that it was slashing its executive ranks and cutting back production in a major retrenchment program.

title: SOVIET NATURAL GAS CAN CHOKE AMERICA'S ALLIES
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS PARNIS AND A ROCKEFELLER GET AWARDS
description: THERE are only a handful of people who can bring out a crowd of 800 on a rainy night in New York for an awards ceremony, and judging by the turnout last night for the fifth annual New Yorker for New York Awards given by the Citizens Committee for New York City, two of the recipients of this year's award, the fashion designer Mollie Parnis and Laurance S. Rockefeller, qualify as top draws.

title: by Barbara L. Isenberg and Mary Smith
description: GRAB bars in a bathroom are a must for safety, particularly for children or the elderly. Mounted sturdily on the wall with two-inch screws next to a bathtub or toilet, a grab bar will make moving on a wet, slippery floor steadier. Grab bars come in many sizes, with finishes from basic chrome and brass to gold plate.

title: FLXIBLE AND STRAPLESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tribune Net Off 28.1% in Quarter
