description: The Tribune Company, the privately owned publisher of The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News in New York, said today that its earnings dropped substantially in the fourth quarter of 1980 from the 1979 level, but said profits for the full year set a record for the seventh straight year.

title: Icebreaker Tests Waters
description: Of Arctic for Shipping

title: REAGAN NAMES 2 FRIENDS IN SERIES OF APPOINTMENTS
description: President Reagan today made a series of appointments, giving diplomatic positions to two close friends and selecting a construction company executive to oversee worker safety and health issues in the Labor Department.

title: Mr. Schweiker's Bad Idea
description: It is particularly disheartening to find the very people who most abhor abortion also opposing any effort to provide contraceptives and family planning guidance to the poor. If they really want to reduce the incidence of abortion, why resist programs that help to avoid pregnancy in the first place?

title: INDOOR TRACK AIDED
description: American track and field, beset by financial problems and reduced public exposure, has received a large lift. The Mobil Corporation announced yesterday that it would sponsor the national indoor championships and finance a Grand Prix program that would pay prize money to the clubs of amateur athletes.

title: Index; International
description: Jews and Arabs get behind stereo- types in Israeli village A2 Sadat gets a warm welcome in Paris A3 Around the World A4 U.S. expels Cuban, saying he broke trade ban A9 Text of Gromyko letter to Haig A12 Government/Politics Senator Hayakawa may face tough 1982 Senate race A18 Reagan names 2 friends as diplomats in series of appointments A19 Carey billing state $24,166 for Far East trip B8 General Around the Nation A14 Clash between lawyers interrupts Harris murder trial B2 Cynthia Dwyer back in U.S. after nine months in Iranian jail B5 The ethics of Rupert Murdoch's newspapers stir debate B9 Third suspect seized in copter escape attempt at U.S. jail B10 Features/Notes Man in the news: Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo, Spain's Premier-elect A7 Notes on People C26 The Home Section Home Blurring boundaries between art and furniture C1

title: Plane Crash in Louisiana Kills 4
description: A twin-engine plane crashed and exploded while attempting a landing in rain and fog at the Houma-Terrebonne Airport, killing the pilot and her three female passengers, the authorities said.

title: Brazilian Union Leader Wins Support in the U.S.
description: Brazil's most prominent labor leader, Luiz Ignacio da Silva, who faces a miitary trial for leading an auto workers' strike, was offered support today by American union leaders and liberal Congressmen.

title: Gunmen in Guatemala Kill 4 Convicts in Raid
description: Gunmen intercepted a prison van today, shot to death four of the six prisoners inside and kidnapped the two others, a police spokesman said. The spokesman said the attack took place on the highway from Guatemala City to Santa Cruz del Quiche, 98 miles to the northwest.

title: Bridge: Beginners Finding It Easier To Share Duplicate Games
description: In recent years it has become progressively easier for beginners to become duplicate players. Nearly all clubs and tournaments provide novice games, and New York City, following Westchester County's example, now has an annual pro-am game. It will be played at the New York Statler Hotel on the evening of Feb. 21, a Saturday, with some 300 players taking part.

title: Kings 99, Jazz 87
description: Otis Birdsong scored 20 of his 26 points in the second half to lead the Kings over Utah.

title: Clutterers United
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: As a Grade A specimen of the genus clutterbug, I take comfort in Ada Louise Huxtable's article ''Modern-Life Battle: Conquering Clutter'' (Feb. 5).

title: U.N. RIGHTS UNIT CRITICIZES ISRAEL
description: The United Nations Human Rights Commission today condemned Israel's policies concerning the occupied Arab territories, including alleged ''war crimes that are an affront to humanity.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: Leonard Silk A PRESIDENT IN LOVE: The Courtship Letters of Woodrow Wilson and Edith Bolling Galt. Edited by Edwin Tribble. 225 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $11.95.

title: GIVE SHAKESPEARE HIS OWN PACE
description: ITHINK it is time we began to take Shakespeare at his word, or at least remember what his word was. He spoke, and I quote from the Prologue to ''Romeo and Juliet'' of ''the two hours traffic of our stage,'' a phrase I take to mean that his audience got out of the theater roughly two hours after it had been let in.

title: WIND AND RAIN LASH NEW YORK STATE...AND WASH OUT A 'DROUGHT DAY' CEREMONY IN WESTCHESTER
description: Westchester County marked its first official Drought Day today. Naturally it rained. As County Executive Alfred B. DelBello affixed a waterconservation poster to a bus shelter here, onlookers were soaked by a thumping downpour. David Tooley, director of communications for Mr. DelBello, said he thought the rain was just ''a publicity stunt.''

title: Banker to Lead Rollins Burdick
description: Charles R. Hall, 51, an executive vice president of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, has been appointed chairman and chief executive officer of the Rollins Burdick Hunter Company, a leading insurance brokerage concern, effective April 1. He will succeed Adrian B. Palmer, 70, who will become chairman of the executive committee of the Chicago-based company.

title: WESTERN SQUAD WINS ALL-STAR SOCCER, 8-5
description: The Western Stars scored four unanswered goals in the last period and defeated the Eastern Stars, 8-5, in the all-star game of the Major Indoor Soccer league at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Advertising; Charter Setting Up Video Unit
description: CHARTER PUBLISHING, whose best-known properties are The Ladies' Home Journal and Redbook, has joined the growing host of magazine companies that have set up units to explore the possibility of becoming program suppliers to the video industry.

title: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz Gets Tuscan Yogurt Products
description: The wonder boys at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson have struck again. This time the new client is Tuscan Dairy Farms in Union, N.J. The products, for which Tuscan is talking about a $3 million budget, are Tuscan frozen yogurt pop and Tuscan low-fat yogurt drink.

title: Reynolds, Thomas Cook Plan Camel Expeditions
description: Those cigarette companies certainly never tire in their search for ways to get their brand names before the public. R.J. Reynolds Tobacco, the biggest and probably the most innovative, has a new agreement with Thomas Cook, the travel people. Cook will mount three tours called Camel Expeditions: to the Ecuadorean jungle, a sailing and diving tour of the Caribbean, and a white-water canoeing trip in Maine.

title: by Carolyn G.Heilbrun
description: THE other day a friend and colleague who has, like me, spent many years laboring on behalf of everything the Moral Majority opposes, suggested over a drink that we write a comedy of manners. I knew just what he meant. Our occupation - the questioning of dogma - had gone clean out of fashion. (''I only wish,'' I told him, echoing one Victorian speaking of another, ''that I was as certain about anything as the Moral Majority is about everything.'') We decided to ignore the pieties flowing over us from Washington and points south, and take refuge in frivolity. There are times, we knew, when one's attitude toward politics should be that of the late Robert Hutchins toward exercise: When he felt like exercising, he lay down till the feeling passed.

title: Text of Gromyko letter is on page A12.
description: The Soviet Embassy today made public a letter from Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. rejecting American expressions of concern about Poland and complaining that the United States had not said ''a single kind word'' about Soviet efforts on behalf of the American hostages in Iran.

title: ARCADES TEND TO MAKE ONE FEEL AT HOME
description: THE word ''arcade'' has had its ups and downs. Initially, in great cities, it stood for a home that wasn't home - middle ground, marked out by the hand of a master, where one was neither indoors nor outdoors.

title: WHERE TO FIND FREELANCE LIBRARIANS
description: Organizers of libraries may be found through several sources. There are library consulting concerns that cater to private individuals as well as libraries and there are freelance librarians. Library schools can provide the names of graduate students and alumni who are available, with fees to be negotiated on an individual basis.

title: 5 Entertainers in Turkey Accused of Leftist Ties
description: Turkish military authorities told four popular music artists and a young actress today to give themselves up to the security forces by March 13 or face loss of citizenship.

title: CBS Net Up 8.8% In the 4th Quarter
description: CBS Inc. reported yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 8.8 percent, to $69.6 million, or $2.50 a share, from $64 million, or $2.29 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenues climbed 5.4 percent, to $1.17 billion from $1.11 billion.

title: Harvard Law School Getting New Dean in July
description: There'll be a new dean of the Harvard Law School on July 1. He's James Vorenberg, an expert on criminal law, who will replace Albert M. Sacks, who announced some time ago that he wanted to step down and concentrate on teaching.

title: 4 Enter Not Guilty Pleas In Lottery Rigging Case
description: A Pittsburgh television announcer, a state official and two others pleaded not guilty today to charges that they rigged a Pennsylvania Lottery drawing for $1.2 million last year.

title: REVUE: 'REAL LIFE FUNNIES'
description: ABOVE the set of ''Real Life Funnies,'' a new musical revue at the Manhattan Theater Club, there is an electric sign that reads ''Attention: All Dialogue Reported Verbatim.'' Throughout the evening, usually right after a joke, the sign lights up - just to remind us that every last line in this show has been appropriated from real life. Since ''Real Life Funnies'' has next-to-no laughs, it's hard to know what we're supposed to think about the sign. Are this revue's creators boasting about their skill at eavesdropping, or are they just trying to blame anonymous New Yorkers for their own witlessness? Maybe they're just trying to distract our attention from the activity on stage - in which case, for that alone, they deserve our thanks.

title: Rockwell Increasing Capital Spending
description: The Rockwell International Corporation expects to increase its capital spending over 1980 by 25 percent, to $350 million, Robert Anderson, chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting here. ,

title: RCA Appoints Head Of New Subsidiary
description: The RCA Corporation has established a new subsidiary, RCA Communications, as a holding company for its communications services. Eugene F. Murphy, 45 years old, who has been with the organization for 17 years, was named president and chief executive officer of the subsidiary, chairman of its three units and a group vice president of the parent corporation.

title: THE DANCE: NIKOLAIS'S 'ORGAN'
description: It's Alwin Nikolais time at the City Center-55th Street Theater again, and the Nikolais Dance Theater, with Murray Louis as its guest, has arrived equipped with more new works than usual.

title: MAYORS AGREE THAT UDAG MUST REMAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Failures At 19-Year High
description: Commercial and industrial business failures resumed their steep climb in the latest statistical week, reaching the highest level in 19 years, Dun & Bradstreet reported yesterday.

title: Inside, Looking Out
description: Despite President Reagan's stated opposition to busing, his Department of Justice is proceeding with a desegregation suit filed by the Carter Administration against the schools of Charleston County, S.C. If successful, the suit is almost certain to result in many of the county's 45,000 pupils being bused to non-neighborhood schools.

title: Offer for Abitibi Delayed a Week
description: A takeover bid for Abitibi-Price Inc., the Toronto-based company that is the world's largest newsprint producer, was ordered delayed for a week by the Ontario Securities Commission.

title: by Joseph S. Nye
description: There is a good chance that a significant interruption of the international oil supply will occur in the next few years. It has happened twice in the last seven years. A year-long loss of Persian Gulf oil could devastate the world economy, create havoc in financial markets, and possibly lead to armed conflict. Yet, few of our long-term policies such as price decontrol, conservation subsidies and standards, fuel conversions, and synthetic-fuel programs will significantly reduce our short-term vulnerability. The danger is imminent, and we are not adequately prepared.

title: 6 TEXASGULF EXECUTIVES VICTIMS OF PLANE CRASH: CLARENCE E. DREW, 55,
description: COMMUNICATIONS Clarence Edward Drew joined Texasgulf as manager of corporate communications in February 1978 after an extensive career in public relations with General Electric, General Telephone and Electronics and the International Paper Company.

title: Knicks Take 6th In a Row
description: Ray Williams scored 24 points and Campy Russell 20 to lead the Knicks to their sixth straight victory, a 122-111 decision over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight. The winning streak is the Knicks' longest since the 1974-75 season.

title: YANKS AND MICHAEL START FRESH
description: On a cool, rainy morning, with the palm trees bending in the wind beyond the outfield fence at Fort Lauderdale Stadium, Gene Michael began his career as Yankee manager today.

title: energywatch
description: Feb.6 Crude oil stocks rose to 374.9 million barrels. The increase reflects higher levels of crude oil imports and a decrease in refinery output.

title: GETTING PROFESSIONAL HELP IN PREPARING TAX RETURN
description: Your TaxesA Guide to Preparing 1980 ReturnsEleventh of 12 articles.- By DEBORAH RANKIN

title: SENATOR TOWER FAVORS MORE U.S. ASSISTANCE FOR THE TURKISH JUNTA
description: Senator John G. Tower expressed the need here today for more American military and economic aid for Turkey. The Texas Republican, who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, repeatedly expressed his belief in ''the good motives'' of Turkey's military rulers and in their intention to restore parlamentary democracy ''as soon as is practicable.''

title: A PARTY FOR KRIOZIA: BEAUTIES AMONG THE BEASTS
description: Everyone in fashion knows the Italians give the best parties - and stage the snappiest fashion shows. That's what has helped catapult Milan into its place as one of the world's fashion centers, along with Paris and New York, in just the last five years.

title: Commons Suspends Paisley For a Breach of Etiquette
description: The House of Commons voted today to suspend the Rev. Ian Paisley, the Northern Ireland Protestant leader, for a week because he called a Government minister a ''liar.''

title: SCHOOL CLOSINGS
description: New York City schools are closed today in observance of Lincoln's Birthday, and schools throughout the metropolitan area will be closed Monday for Washington's Birthday.

title: 5 SHARE LEAD AT 66 IN HAWAII GOLF
description: Tom Watson, struggling back from a double bogey, scrambled to a six-under-par 66 and tied four others for the first-round lead today in the $325,000 Hawaiian open golf tournament.

title: Which Way Is Up
description: The British, as usual, have a word for it - upmarket - and the goods sold in upmarkets, naturally, are upgoods. Americans have adopted the word and applied it to the latest thing in retailing, the Upscale Shopping Plaza.

title: Schaefer Posts Profit in Period
description: The F.& M. Schaefer Corporation, owner and operator of the country's 11th-largest brewer, reported yesterday that it had a profit of $1.1 million, or 18 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980 contrasted to a loss of $524,000 in the fourth quarter of 1979. Sales rose 11.3 percent, to $48.1 million from $43.2 million.

title: NAZI DEPORTATION TRIAL CENTERS ON IDENTITY CARD
description: The latest of the Federal Government's accelerated efforts to uncover and prosecute former Nazis in this country may turn on questions of the authenticity of an alleged Nazi identification card issued 38 years ago in Poland.

title: Funds' Asset Rise Nears Record Rate
description: New money flowed into the nation's money market funds at a nearrecord rate in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The assets of the 100 funds measured by the institute jumped by $2.9 billion, to $89.8 billion.

title: GARDEN APARTMENTS IN QUEENS BECOMING PRIVATE HOUSES
description: It might almost be called the Gillman Solution to the Queens garden-apartment problem, although Sol Gillman would probably shrink from the honor.

title:
RED SMITH;
Free Agent Fisk
description: FIRST an item in the paper reported that the Mets were getting ready to trade John Stearns, their catcher when he is healthy. Then came word that Carlton Fisk of the Red Sox had been declared a free agent. Any connection?

title: General Bradley to Mark Birthday on Valentine's Day
description: Yesterday was the 88th birthday of the nation's highest-ranking soldier, General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, but the milestone will not be celebrated until tomorrow, at a Valentine's Day party.

title: A VALENTINE FROM THE RENAISSANCE
description: Mania and her Frantics are not a rock band. They are frenzied mythological figures, who will cavort tomorrow night at Alice Tully Hall during the highlight of a spectacle that includes costumed dancers, singers and musicians on Renaissance instruments.

title: DISRAELI DISPLAYED IN COLUMBIA SHOW
description: The two worlds of Benjamin Disraeli - Dizzy, the novelist and dandy, and Lord Beaconsfield, the personal and political empire builder for Queen Victoria - are accented in an exhibition that will be in the rotunda of Low Memorial Library at Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street, for the next two weeks.

title: REAGAN'S ECONOMISTS IN ACCORD
description: Administration economic officials said today that a struggle between two groups of advisers had ended with a decision to base budget revenue and spending projections to be released next week on a relatively conventional economic outlook.

title: Producer of 'Fantasticks' Takes to the Stage
description: During the 21 years that the Off Broadway musical ''The Fantasticks'' has been running, its producer and sometime-star, Lore Noto, has sent the cast out to give more than 50 performances for patients in hospitals in the metropolitan New York area.

title: News Analysis
description: Raymond J. Donovan, the new Secretary of Labor, is serving notice that he will not be slow to carry out President Reagan's mandate to ease the regulatory burden on business.

title: THE AMERICAN HANDICAP IN DEVELOPING SUPERIOR CRAFTSMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW BLAKEY MESSENGERS
description: FOR 25 years Art Blakey's small group, the Jazz Messengers, has gone through a steady turnover in personnel by maintaining a level of musicianship that is paralleled only by Woody Herman's ability to keep his constantly changing Thundering Herds stocked with exceptional young musicians over an even longer period. During these years Mr. Blakey's Messengers have launched an impressive list of jazz stars, including Horace Silver, Lee Morgan, Jackie McLean, Donald Byrd, Johnny Griffin, Benny Golson, Wayne Shorter, Bobby Timmons, Junior Mance, Freddie Hubbard and Woody Shaw.

title: THEATER: HENRY FONDA IN CONNECTICUT
description: it's a lifelong commitment. And it's very much a two-way romance. Cast as a failing old cowboy in ''Showdown at the Adobe Motel,'' Mr. Fonda is still working hard and stretching himself. He continues to be as much enriched by the theater as the theater is by him.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Friday misstated the extent to which price controls on natural gas have been removed. Only four types of gas, including that from wells below 15,000 feet, have so far been decontrolled. All new gas and some old gas will be decontrolled in 1985, but most old gas will continue after 1985 to carry some price limitation.

title: Reagan Names U.S. Treasurer
description: President Reagan today nominated Angela M. Buchanen, former national treasurer for the President's election committee, as Treasurer of the United States.

title: BONN OFFICIAL OPENLY CRITICAL OF REAGAN APPROACH
description: For the first time since the inauguration of President Reagan, an associate of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has openly complained about the new Administration's policy.

title: Plant Agrees to Sell Major Canadian Unit
description: Plant Industries Inc., a New York-based manufacturer, said it had agreed to sell its Canadian manufacturing operations to Vulcan Industrial Packaging Ltd. of Toronto for $15 million.

title: ART: SHOW OF NEW WORKS SETS EXAMPLE AT MODERN
description: ALTHOUGH its title - ''New Works on Paper I'' - is anything but prepossessing, the new exhibition that John Elderfield has organized at the Museum of Modern Art is nonetheless something of an event. For it is a show of contemporary art that is, first of all, a considerable pleasure to look at. It has been carefully and intelligently selected - no small feat considering the immense quantity of work competing for attention nowadays - and, as an extra bonus, it is also very intelligently discussed in the accompanying catalogue. It is certainly the best museum exhibition to be devoted to contemporary art in many years. Both in terms of its quality and its topicality, it reminded this observer of the important exhibitions organized at the Modern in the 1940's and 1950's by Dorothy Miller - exhibitions that set a standard now all but forgotten, alas, elsewhere in the museum world.

title: The Economy
description: Lenders are restricting credit to individuals as consumer-loan losses increase at U.S. banks, finance companies and retail operations. Those in the lower-income brackets or without real estate to use as collateral will find credit especially difficult to get. Lenders attribute the losses to last year's combination of recession and inflation and to a 1979 bankruptcy law that raised the amount of property individuals can protect against seizure by creditors. (Page A1.)

title: Another Piaf Tonight on 60th St.
description: The accent is on Edith Piaf, the French popular singer whose story is being enacted on Broadway, in another tribute, ''Mesdames, Messieurs ... Piaf!'' It will be presented tonight at 8 in the French Institute/Alliance Fran,caise, 22 East 60th Street (355-6100), and is described as a ''multi-media evocation'' of Piaf by Eduardo Kotliroff, who has immersed himself in documenting her life, and by Irene Benavente.

title: Constantine Returns To Greece for 5 Hours For Burial of Mother
description: Falling to his knees and kissing the soil, the deposed King of Greece made an emotional and politically charged visit here today after a 14-year absence.

title: WILDERNESS EVENTS AT THE CITY'S DOOR
description: A chill wind whips through the tall marsh grass, and a flock of Canada geese take flight over the bay. Along a path that cuts through a thicket of holly and bayberry trees, a hardy band of visitors inspect animal tracks. It could be a winter landscape in the Rockies or the Adirondacks, but the scene is repeated this time of year every weekend in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: MARKETING GOALS SHAPED BY U.S. GYPSUM TEAM
description: Robert J. Day, 55, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the United States Gypsum Company, a gypsum producer based in Chicago. He succeeds Edward W. Duffy, 61, who was named vice chairman.

title: ARTHUR B. LAWRENCE
description: Arthur B. Lawrence, who had been a senior partner in the former investment banking concern of F. S. Smithers & Company, died Wednesday at his Manhattan home.

title: Missing Fight Promoter Delays News Conference
description: Harold J. Smith, the chairman of Muhammed Ali Professional Sports Inc., also called Maps, said in a brief telephone interview today that he was in hiding in Los Angeles but would not hold a news conference here tomorrow, as he previously indicated he would.

title: Rights of N.B.A.  In Italy Upheld
description: A National Basketball Association team retains rights to a player it has drafted when that player passes up the N.B.A. and goes instead to Europe's Italian League, Telford Taylor ruled yesterday.

title: Panel Will Review Amax Mine Venture
description: A $190 million molybdenum mining venture in Canada by a unit of the Amax Corporation will be reviewed by a federal Government panel to see if it can proceed.

title:
ADVERTISING;
People
description: * Morton Bailey Jr., publisher of The Dial magazine, has resigned and will be replaced by George Marketos, a senior vice president of Channel 13.

title: EX-IM BANK VS. BUDGET CUTTERS
description: From his top-floor office, the chairman of the Export-Import Bank looks out over the wintry green of Lafayette Park and across Pennsylvania Avenue to the White House.

title: ESTHETIC OF THE FAKE STIRS ROCK WORLD
description: WHEN Deborah Harry of the popular rock group Blondie made a television commercial recently for a jeans manufacturer, she was indulging in utter fakery. The camera followed her through a fake loft district and into a fake Bohemian nightspot, where John Lurie, who leads a New York combo called the Lounge Lizards, was playing fake jazz on his saxophone.

title: Bridge: Feeling for Self-Destruction At Table Is Not Uncommon
description: Many players commit technical suicide over and over again at the bridge table. An example is the diagramed deal, played in a duplicate game recently at the Manhattan Club.

title: MAYOR'S NOMINATIONS FOR THE SCHOOL BOARD UPSET CHICAGO BLACKS
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne went on vacation today, leaving black leaders upset over her plan to remove two black school board members and replace them with white women, including a foe of busing for desegregation.

title: Peabody Coal Settlement
description: The Mississippi Power Company, a unit of the Southern Company, said yesterday that the Peabody Coal Company had agreed to pay it $55 million to settle a six-year-old breach-of-contract suit.

title: No Headline
description: IRAN MOVES TO FREE 4 DETAINED BRITONS

title: Italian Doctors Strike for 2d Day
description: Doctors at Italy's state-run hospitals stayed off their jobs for the second day today, leaving thousands of patients without physicians' care. Authorities said skeleton crews of doctors were handling only emergency operations in Milan and that the only exception to the strike was in the earthquake-stricken region east of Naples.

title: Tashi at Hunter Sunday
description: Works by Mozart, Kodaly and Weber and the New York premiere of Bill Douglas's ''Celebration II'' will be performed by the chamber trio Tashi on Sunday at 2:30 P.M. in the Hunter College Assembly Hall, 69th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues.

title: Ticking rarities
description: WATCH, clock and silver collectors will be heading for Sotheby Parke Bernet's York Avenue galleries at 72d Street, hour repeater watch - it chimes - with calendar by Lepine (up to $60,000) and an 18-carat gold Swiss chronograph with a minute repeater, perpetual calendar and moon phases (up to $45,000). As for the silver, the top lots are two American jeweled and gold chalices in Gothic style from 1900 (up to $30,000) and a pair of French Empire silver tureens by Joseph-Gabriel Genu of Paris (up to $30,000).

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: Signed Randy Milligan, outfield- e r, No. 1 pick in January draft. Assigned h im to Lynchburg, Va., of Carolina League.

title: DR. WESLEY F. CRAVEN, EXPERT ON COLONIAL AMERICA
description: Dr. Wesley Frank Craven, an author and a scholar of Colonial American history, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 75 years old.

title: Art of Elderly at N.Y.U.
description: An exhibition of paintings by members of the Katharine Engel Center for Older Adults is on view at New York University's Loeb Student Center Gallery, 566 La Guardia Place in Greenwich Village. The show features 24 abstract and realistic paintings by 20 men and women whose median age is 76.

title: THREAT OF SPRING FLOODS DECREASES AT MOUNT ST. HELENS
description: Although a new lava dome inside the crater of Mount St. Helens has recently grown several hundred feet, specialists monitoring the volcano said yesterday that, in at least one respect, its threat to the surrounding countryside had substantially diminished.

title: Birth of Marilyn Monroe Shown to Be Legitimate
description: Eighteen years after Marilyn Monroe's death, the widely held belief that the movie star was born illegitimate has been disproved. Authorities say they have found copies of her birth certificate at the home of a dead man they believe was her father.

title: HEARST AGREES TO ACQUIRE MORROW FOR $25 MILLION
description: In a move that caught the publishing industry unaware, the Hearst Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the 55-year-old William Morrow & Company for $25,250,000.

title: CERONE WINS SALARY CASE
description: The Boston Red Sox lost another of their star players yesterday when a labor arbitrator declared Carlton Fisk a free agent, three weeks after the team traded Fred Lynn for fear of losing him.

title: MUSIC: 'IN PRAISE OF FOLLY'
description: ERASMUS'S character Folly is not a humble creature. ''What could be more fitting,'' she says, ''than for Folly to trumpet her own merits abroad and sing her own praises?'' Some 450 years later, on Thursday night in Avery Fisher Hall, Folly had another chance to trumpet her merits.The New York Philharmonic, under the direction of Zubin Mehta, presented the premiere of George Walker's ''In Praise of Folly'' - inspired by Erasmus's encomnium of the same name.

title: A POWER PLANT'S GRIM PROMISE
description: To the Editor:

title: Beware the Disaster Mongers
description: When will the defenders of the public health learn to pursue their mission without scaring the public to death?

title: Making Equal Mean Equal in Colleges
description: Last fall there were 33,499 students enrolled at Texas A & M University, 32,197 of them white. Meanwhile at Texas Southern, another public university, there were 5,511 students, 58 of them white. This pattern of racial separation is not an aberration confined to Texas. It can be found in 18 states.

title: STAGE: 'CHILDREN'S CRUSADE,' MUSICAL BY A YOUNG TROUPE
description: IN 1212 a group of children, led by a French shepherd boy named Stephen of Cloyes, set out to rescue Jerusalem from the Saracens. The Children's Crusade ended abruptly before the youngsters could reach the Holy Land. Apparently, they were captured by pirates and sold into slavery. From the bare bones of this historical incident, Kenneth Cavander and Richard Peaslee have created an idealistic onehour children's musical, ''The Children's Crusade,'' playing at the First All Children's Theater.

title: REAGAN NEARS END OF MEETINGS WITH AIDES ON BUDGET
description: President Reagan reached the halfway point in his budget consultations today by meeting with three more Cabinet officers and approving plans to seek reductions in public service job programs, unemployment compensation and synthetic fuel projects.

title: 6 TEXAS GULF EXECUTIVES VICTIMS OF PLANE CRASH
description: Wednesday night's crash of a corporate jet in Westchester County killed six of the top executives of Texasgulf Inc.. Following are obituaries of five of the executives. Detailed information on the sixth, 35-year-old Albert D. Woodling, was not immediately available.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS CHOICE ABHORS SCOLDING AS U.S. TOOL
description: Ernest W. Lefever, a prolific writer and public speaker who is under consideration as the director of human rights policy in the State Department, has in the past seemed to question the value of the policy and of the job he is expected to fill.

title: CITY IS SPONSORING 2,200 SMALL HOUSES
description: Standing amid the rubble on a lot near the South Brooklyn waterfront yesterday, Mayor Koch announced a city-sponsored program for the construction of 2,200 moderately priced one-family and twofamily houses in 10 impoverished neighborhoods.

title: U.S. Plans to Sell Jordan 24 Antitank Helicopters
description: The Reagan Administration plans to sell to Jordan 24 Cobra helicopters equipped with precision-guided antitank missiles, Congressional sources confirmed today.

title: PEROT RULING OPPOSES IRAN ASSET DEAL
description: A Federal District judge in Dallas said today in a preliminary ruling that the Federal Government had no power to seize $3 billion in Iranian assets still frozen in the United States.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: A wildcat stike by coal miners in two southern West Virginia counties has put thousands of miners out of work, industry and union officials said today.

title: Dollar Gains; Gold Declines
description: The dollar, continuing to respond to high interest rates in the United States, rose sharply against all major currencies yesterday. Gold prices fell to $495.80 a troy ounce in New York and to below $500 an ounce in Europe.

title: TRAGEDY STRIKES TEXASGULF
description: After meeting with his company's principal stockholder, the Canadian Government, Charles F. Fogarty of Texasgulf Inc. was returning Wednesday to corporate headquarters in Stamford, Conn., from Toronto.

title: Concert Dance Company In Brooklyn College Series
description: The Concert Dance Company of Boston will perform ''You Call that Dancin' '' and ''Pilobolus,'' tomorrow at 2 P.M. at Whitman Hall of Brooklyn College.

title: by Tom Buckley; Langella tells of Egyptian adventures.
description: THE curse of the Pharaohs, it turns out, works most powerfully on those who make movies about it, as Frank Langella has learned with ''Sphinx,'' which was not exactly greeted with enthusiasm by the reviewers after its opening in New York on Wednesday.

title: by Mimi Sheraton; Tempura treats, a neighborhood spot.
description: Astoria Hotel, is a Chinese puzzle of dining rooms - public and private, some serving food Western style at tables and chairs, others serving in the Japanese fashion with guests seated at low tables on tatami-matted floors. Of all the settings on these large and sprawling premises, the one providing the most exceptional food is the tempura bar - a traditional counter seating area where cooks deep-fry the crisp coated seafood, fish and vegetables to order and in full view.

title: Flyers 4, Canucks 3
description: Brian Propp scored two goals tonight and led Philadelphia to a 4-3 victory over Vancouver, the Flyers' first triumph over the Canucks in four games this season. Philadelphia had to stave off a third-period Vancouver surge to clinch the victory. Rick MacLeish scored a power-play goal from the left circle at 11:44 of the final period to give the Flyers a 4-1 lead, but Vancouver closed to within 4-3 on goals by Ivan Boldirev at 12:53, his 21st of the season, and by Jerry Butler at 16:29.

title: COMPETITORS FOR CARTER LIBRARY SITE WAIT FOR A CUE
description: A spirited competition appears to be developing for the honor of building the library to house Jimmy Carter's Presidential papers.

title: WAR HERO SANK THE SCHARNHORST
description: Adm. Lord Fraser, one of the Royal Navy's key officers in World War II, died yesterday in a nursing home in London. He had celebrated his 93d birthday just seven days earlier.

title: Mobil, Amoco Increase Prices
description: The Mobil Corporation and the Amoco Oil Company yesterday raised their wholesale fuel prices by as much as 3 cents a gallon.

title: Avondale Shipyards Expands Repair Unit
description: Avondale Shipyards, a unit of the Ogden Corporation, said it would double its ship-repair capacity in New Orleans by building another floating drydock and support facility for $50 million.

title: Dow Unit Purchase
description: The Galveston-Houston Company said it had sold substantially all of the operating assets of its fluid services division to the Dowell division of the Dow Chemical Company for $46 million in cash. The assets sold include operations and equipment in Louisiana and Texas but exclude the company's barite producing properties in Missouri. No other details were disclosed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've realized we're not going to be a city of 12 million people, so we don't have to build high-rise buildings everywhere.'' - Anthony B. Gleidman, New York City housing commissioner. (B3:1.)

title: Water Conservation Rules Set by Philadelphia Mayor
description: Warning that dry conditions are ''becoming more serious than the drought of the mid-60's,'' Mayor William J. Green yesterday imposed a mandatory water conservation program on the city.

title: BLACK EXPERIENCES AND INSIGHTS ON ART
description: CHANNEL 13 is unusually active with above-average projects Sunday. Heading the list, at 7:30, is the start of a new 13-week series called, ''With Ossie and Ruby.'' Produced by the Dallas-Fort Worth station KERA, the program stars Ruby Dee and Ossie Davis, husband and wife and veterans of stage, television and blacklisting in the McCarthy days of the 1950's.

title: Shakespeare Theater in Connecticut names Coe artistic director.
description: PETER COE will be the new artistic director of the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., which has not had an artistic director since Gerald Freedman left after a season in 1979. Mr. Coe says he is ''absolutely thrilled'' about his new job, and that his mission at Stratford is positively clear. ''Good, solid, authentically interpreted Shakespeare,'' he says, ''that's what this Stratford needs.'' In the last few seasons, the American Shakespeare Theater has done Shakespeare imaginatively and innovatively, but hardly authentically, even its warmest friends say. Mr. Coe apparently intends to change this.

title: BUSBOY AT HOTEL IS SAID TO ADMIT HE CAUSED FIRE A10)
description: A high police official said today that a busboy accused of arson and homicide in the Hilton Hotel fire that killed eight persons had admitted causing the fire but insisted that it had been done accidentally with a marijuana cigarette.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: EVEN as alternative spaces go, they're a little far out. But the small ground-floor window cases of the Municipal Parking Garage on Eighth Avenue at 54th Street are once again the setting (through Feb. 21) for an art show. The 10 windows, fronting on Eighth Avenue, are filled with works by a group of English artists known as Bobsband U.K. Included are a trayful of live soap bubbles; a sculptured ''still life'' of apples, bananas and beer cans, painted in camouflage colors, and a composition of sliced white bread.

title: Blues 3, Canadiens 3
description: Blair Chapman scored his second goal of the game at 13:21 of the third period to give the St. Louis Blues a 3-3 tie with the Canadiens tonight.

title: DELAWARE FLOODS PORT JERVIS AREA, AND 3,000 FLEE
description: Tons of ice and river water clogged behind massive ice jams in the Delaware River flooded low-lying residential and commercial neighborhoods early this morning, forcing an estimated 3,000 people to flee their homes.

title: Index; International
description: Human rights choice abhors U.S. scolding of nations A2 Around the World A4 U.S. affirms nonintervention in Poland A5 West German openly complains of Reagan policy A7 Senator Tower favors more U.S. aid for Turkey A8 Arab oil nations plan fund to help U.N. agencies A9 Government/Politics Mondale and Kennedy form politi- cal action committees A16 Albany minority caucus guest list stirs controversy B3 General Around the Nation A10 Black leaders in Chicago upset by appointments to school board A10 Competition appears to be brew- ing over site of Carter library A12 Reuters names a new chief execu- tive A18 Some companies limit number of executives on same plane B2 Health/Science Flood threat at Mount St. Helens said to have diminished A11 Obituaries Ketti Frings, won Pulitzer for ''Look Homeward, Angel'' A16 Dr. Wesley Frank Craven, author and scholar A16 Admiral Lord Fraser, former British navy chief A16 Weekend Weekender Guide C1

title: China Calls for Reduction In Nuclear Weapons Stocks
description: China said today that the United States and the Soviet Union must greatly reduce their nuclear arsenals if all nuclear powers are to join in a total testing ban.

title: REASON FOR CRASH PUZZLES OFFICIALS
description: Directors of Texasgulf named a new chairman as part of a reorganization of the company's management. Page D1. By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

title: J. IRA SEEBACHER
description: J. Ira Seebacher, managing editor of Photo Weekly and former sports editor of The New York Morning Telegraph for 35 years, died Feb. 5 at his home in New Castle, N.Y. He was 70 years old.

title: NEW YORK'S DEFAULT ON 'CHILD-NAPPING'
description: To the Editor:

title: CAREY PROMISES A QUICK RESULT FROM ASIA TRIP
description: Governor Carey showed videotapes to the press today of his trip to the Far East and said New York would see ''immediate results'' from his efforts to sell the state abroad.

title: POLISH LEADER ASKS 90 STRIKE-FREE DAYS TO DEAL WITH CRISIS
description: The new Prime Minister of Poland, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, appealed today for three months without strikes - ''90 days of peace'' - to allow his Government to deal with the nation's economic crisis.

title: 7 ARAB OIL COUNTRIES SAID TO CREATE A FUND TO AID U.N. AGENCIES
description: United Nations officials report that seven Arab oil-producing countries in the Persian Gulf are about to announce a $250 million yearly fund for United Nations aid agencies.

title: ISLANDERS BEATEN BY PENGUINS
description: The New York Islanders tried to get over a slump and a Pittsburgh jinx at the same time tonight, but it proved too much of a burden. The Penguins scored three goals in the final four minutes at the Civic Center and defeated their favorite foes, 5-3.

title: BELLEVUE REPORTS A LOSS OF SIGHT IN 2 HEROIN PATIENTS
description: At least two young New Yorkers who used heroin have suffered severe loss of sight as well as other serious symptoms, according to doctors at Bellevue Hospital-New York University Medical Center.

title: Congressmen Seek Hobart Inquiry
description: Two senior Congressmen urged the Government today to investigate the hostile $500 million takeover attempt of the Hobart Corporation of Troy, Ohio, by a unit of Canadian Pacific Enterprises Ltd.

title: STOCK BUYBACK SEEN AT LANE BRYANT INC.
description: Lane Bryant Inc., which has been threatened by a Canadian takeover for more than a year, is close to removing the threat by buying back almost 20 percent of its stock from the companies that had sought to acquire it, sources said yesterday. .

title: No Headline
description: REUTERS NAMES NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE

title: CHARLIE CHAN BACK WEARING A USTINOV MASK
description: OF all of the pre-World War II pop artifacts that have recently been resurrected and recycled by Hollywood, the most welcome by far is Charlie Chan, the inscrutable detective created by Earl Derr Biggers and brought to the screen in dozens of low-budget movies, most often in the person of Warner Oland and Sidney Toler. Charlie Chan is supposed to be Chinese but, in fact, he's as American as apple pie, Maxene Andrews and Chandu the Magician. As much as any other public figure before Pearl Harbor, he reassured Americans of their place in the world, solving drawing room mysteries in 70 minutes or so and dispensing wisdom that came straight from domestically manufactured fortune cookies.

title: ART OF SHADOW-BOX VALENTINES
description: Carl Federer loves festivals, and Valentine's Day is one of his favorites. Then he can get out his figurines of cupids and doves, the silver lace and the beautiful old papers he has been collecting all his life, which cram the studio of his East Side apartment. Mr. Federer calls himself a vitrinier, since one of his best-known arts is making shadow boxes encased in glass. Professional decorators order them to give the exact touch of fantasy to a room, or private clients want to set off their treasures.

title: Judge Orders Trainmen To End Boston Walkout
description: A Federal judge ordered trainmen back to work today after their one-day walkout stranded 35,000 commuters in the Boston area and shut down the Boston & Maine Railroad.

title: ART: 50 UTRILLO YEARS AT THE WILDENSTEIN
description: AN exhibition of Utrillo's paintings, such as that now at the Wildenstein Gallery (19 East 64th Street), can be a stressful experience. Not because Utrillo is a difficult or great artist - he is neither -but because his art has been so dulled by overreproduction as almost to defy description, let alone illumination.

title: THEY'RE SINGING SONGS OF LOVE IN ALL THE CLUBS FOR VALENTINE'S DAY
description: IT may be, as H.L. Mencken once said, that ''to be in love is merely to be in a state of perceptual anesthesia.'' But those minstrels of anesthesia - those who sing love songs on this Valentine's Day - are quite able to perceive what they are doing.

title: Qaddafi Seeks Socialist 'Nuns'
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, has urged women to become revolutionary ''nuns'' and preach socialist doctrine in the same way Christian nuns spread the Gospel of Christ. The official Libyan press agency quoted Colonel Qaddafi as telling a public meeting in Benghazi: ''We need a revolutionary nuns movement because we consider that the Christian nuns movement is a challenge to Moslem women.''

title: AMID NEW SPIRIT, PITTSBURGH OPENS CENTER
description: Vincent Barth has seen many faces of Pittsburgh, but the one he likes best is the one he sees each day as he takes his morning walk along the slope of Mount Washington.

title: RANGERS WIN WITH 55 SHOTS,8-6
description: The Rangers took a season-high 55 shots on goal last night against the worst team in the National Hockey League, the Winnipeg Jets, and scored eight goals in the process. But it wasn't until the 55th shot, by Dave Maloney on an empty net, that the Rangers clinched an 8-6 victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: McNamara Joining Board
description: Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, will become a director of the Washington Post Company July 1, the day after he retires from the bank, the company's chairman, Katharine Graham, announced today. Mr. McNamara, a former president of the Ford Motor Company and Defense Secretary from 1961 to 1968 under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, previously announced his decision to retire from the bank when he reaches the age of 65 this June. He has headed the bank since 1968. The Washington Post Company includes The Washington Post newspaper and Newsweek magazine and is also involved in television broadcasting and program production.

title: VERMONT DISTINCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: INVENTORIES DROP: RATIO IMPROVES
description: Inventories held by United States businesses fell slightly in December, the first such decline in five years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Continental in Suit To Block Texas Bid
description: Continental Air Lines, the Los Angeles carrier that is seeking a merger with Western Airlines, filed suit in Federal court in Los Angeles in an attempt to block a hostile takeover by Texas International Airlines.

title: 'DOGS OF WAR,' FORSYTH'S MERCENARIES
description: THOUGH it begins and ends with stunningly photographed battle sequences in Central America and West Africa, ''The Dogs of War,'' John Irvin's screen adaptation of Frederick Forsyth's best-selling novel about mercenaries, is notable for a reticence that has about it a kind of existential sorrow. The film, precise and unsentimental in its details, refuses at first either to condemn or justify the activities of men who, if they operated at the domestic level, would immediately be categorized as hired killers.

title: BRIEFS
description: * General Electric of Britain secured an order for two steam turbine electric generator sets from the Calgary Power Company of Canada.

title: Class-Action Suit Is Filed On Illinois Medicare Claims
description: Two legal aid societies have charged in a Federal court suit that thousands of Medicare claims filed by Illinois residents were mishandled by a Texas company under contract to the United States Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Advertising; Corporate Name Building
description: AMONG the 400 Allied Chemical Corporation executives who gathered in the Morris Township, N.J., headquarters yesterday to hear Edward L. Hennessy Jr., the chairman, announce plans for a new name and a new logotype was Thomas F. Garbett, who was one of them in spirit but not in fact. That's the way it is with ad agency people when they are working on an account.

title: CORRECTION
description: CBS News reports that it inadvertently provided incorrect information about its scheduling for an article in The Times yesterday about television documentaries and news ratings. The correct figure for the documentaries CBS ran in prime time during 1980 is 12 hours. ABC also ran 12 hours of documentaries, and NBC 10.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.00-19.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.N.A. Not available because banks were closed for Lincoln's BirthdaySalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Market Place; Mesh Product From Vulcan
description: CALL it a measure of the speculative character of the current stock market. In mid-January, the Air Force announced, after three years of testing, that an aluminum honeycomb mesh effectively prevents explosions in fuel containers penetrated by gunfire. The Air Force agreed to purchase fuel tanks containing this mesh.

title: MUSIC: ROCHESTER PHILHARMONIC OFFERS A STEVENS-PICASSO STUDY
description: ON the basis of its concert Wednesday night in Carnegie Hall, the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra is serving its community well. Of course, a real judgment about such service could only be made on the basis of week-in and week-out concerts, variety of programming, quality of guest conductors and the like; tour concerts are always polished to an unusual degree. Still, the program offered at least an honorable attempt at the new, and by a Rochester composer, to boot; an earnest and exciting statement of a 20th-century landmark, and an intelligent, intense account of a masterpiece.

title: CALF WITH ARTIFICIAL HEART KILLED
description: The Jersey calf that lived a record 267 days with an artificial heart, was put to death yesterday after antibiotics failed to clear up an infection, a university spokesman said.

title: BRITONS ASSAIL CAR PLANT CLOSING
description: British auto workers held mass meetings today to protest the decision announced by Peugeot, the French auto maker, to close a plant in Scotland, costing about 4,800 workers in Britain's hard-hit motor industry their jobs.

title: BANKS AND RETAILERS REPORT HIGH LOSSES ON CONSUMER LOANS
description: Losses on consumer loans have increased sharply at banks, finance companies and retailers around the country. As a result, many of these institutions are cutting back on credit to individuals, an informal check with the creditors shows. Individuals in the lowerincome brackets, and those who do not own real estate that can be used as collateral, may find it especially difficult to obtain credit.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption with the television listings yesterday incorrectly identified Miguel Ferrer. He is a son of Jose Ferrer.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: SERVICE COMPANY IN BIG GAIN By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

title: Kaiser Files F.C.C. Complaint Against ABC
description: The Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation has filed a formal complaint against ABC-TV with the Federal Communications Commission, alleging that the network improperly refused to allow Kaiser to respond to a television program on the hazards of aluminum wiring.

title: Garden Seeking Cooney-Norton
description: Madison Square Garden, which was to have been the landlord for the ''This Is It'' boxing spectacular of Feb. 23, is trying to become the promoter for the biggest event from that card, the Gerry Cooney-Ken Norton heavyweight fight.

title: U.S. VOWS TO KEEP HANDS OFF POLAND
description: The Reagan Administration pledged today that it would continue to follow ''a policy of strict nonintervention'' in Polish affairs and said it looked forward to constructive relations with the Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the new Polish Prime Minister.

title: British Suspect to Be Named In 12 Other 'Ripper' Deaths
description: Peter Sutcliffe, a 35-year-old truck driver charged last month in one of the so-called Yorkshire Ripper murders, will be charged in the 12 other ''ripper'' slayings, State Prosecutor Maurice Shaffner said today.

title: IT'S LINCOLN'S BIRTHWEEK IN SCHOOL AT MT. VERNON
description: Helen DelVecchio's fifth-grade classroom at the Pennington-Grimes School swelled with African tribal music this morning - the 172d anniversary of Abraham Lincoln's birth - as students accompanied a tape recording using reproductions of ancient percussion instruments.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 13, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Scientific and technical subcommit- tee of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ENERGY OFFICE REPORTS FORMER COUNSEL GAVE $4 MILLION TO CHARITY
description: A Carter Administration official in the Department of Energy distributed $4 million to four national charities the day before he left office, and the Reagan Administration is trying to get the money back.

title: A DELICACY FOR WEILL FANS: CHORAL SOCIETY'S 'BERLINER' REQUIEM
description: For those who thought the Kurt Weill renaissance had peaked, the New York Choral Society has yet another delicacy in store. It is the ''Berliner'' Requiem, a relic of Weill's work in Germany and a relatively unfamiliar piece. His fascinated followers can feast on it tomorrow evening at Carnegie Hall, and also hear the better known ''Carmina Burana'' by Carl Orff and ''Legacy,'' written in 1977 by the society's conductor, Robert DeCormier in memory of his son.

title: Economic Scene; Antitrust Issues Facing Reagan
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN has not yet named his assistant attorney general to head the antitrust division of the Justice Department, but the man likely to get the job is Prof. William F. Baxter of the Stanford University Law School. Mr. Baxter has the distinction of being professionally competent in economics as well as in law. In an interview this week, he made clear that, if he gets the post, he intends to ''pursue an antitrust policy based on efficiency considerations.''

title: MUSIC: BRAHMS SOIREE CONCERT, WITH CHORALE, AT TULLY HALL
description: SOIREE CONCERTS is an organization drawn mostly from faculty and students at the Manhattan School of Music and devoted to the recreation of the diverse concert formats common in the last century. Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall, the group turned to Brahms, and the result at its best was charming.

title: Flaherty & Company Agency Sold to TBWA
description: After two years on his own, James B. Flaherty, 45-year-old president of Flaherty & Company, has decided that entrepreneurship was not his thing, so he has sold his $3-million-in-billings agency to TBWA Advertising for cash and stock.

title: 6 TEXASGULF EXECUTIVES VICTIMS OF PLANE CRASH
description: Frank Joseph Claydon Jr. was vice president of Texasgulf Inc. and president of the Texasgulf Chemicals Company, in Raleigh, N.C., where he lived with his wife and three children. He was 46 years old.

title: 'AMERICAN POP' GROWN-UP ANIMATION
description: RALPH BAKSHI (''Fritz the Cat,'' ''Heavy Traffic,'' ''Coonskin'' and ''The Lord of the Rings'') continues to push animation techniques to the outer limits more frequently explored by film makers who call themselves avant-garde, but who seldom are. His newest film, ''American Pop,'' is a dazzling display of talent, nerve, ideas (old and new), passion and a marvelously free sensibility. The man may well be a genius, though that sort of pronouncement will have to wait on time.

title: NONSEXIST CHILD REARING: ONE ADVOCATE'S PROJECTION
description: If she were a schoolteacher, Letty Cottin Pogrebin would greet her students by saying: ''Good morning, tall people and short people, children of every racial, economic and ethnic background. Good morning, talented dancers and athletes and budding writers and scientists, musicians and magicians, carpenters and clowns. Good morning, firstborns, middle children, youngests, only children, adopted children, orphans and twins.''

title: 2 KILLED AS POLICEMAN FOILS HOLDUP ATTEMPT AT EAST HARLEM STORE
description: Two men were killed last night when a police officer interrupted a holdup attempt by one or more men in an East Harlem grocery store, according to the police. They said at least one person in the store had been held hostage at gunpoint.

title: Frank Church Joining Law Firm in Washington
description: Add to the list of no-longer-out-of-work former Congressmen the name of Frank Church, a Democratic Senator from Idaho for 24 years, until his defeat last November.

title: Burning and Sinking Some Waste At Sea Backed by Federal Official
description: The burning and sinking of some hazardous wastes at sea offers an attractive alternative to dumping them on land, an Environmental Protection Agency official said yesterday.

title: Two-Borough Tour to Climb Brooklyn Arch; Borough-Trotting Tour To Climb Brooklyn Arch
description: When the Soldiers and Sailors Monument at Brooklyn's Grand Army Plaza was dedicated in 1892, the top of the 80-foot-high arch was first opened as an observation platform. The arch has been closed to the public for years, but the Friends of Central Park will provide a rare opportunity this weekend to climb all 116 stairs to the top as part of a three-hour, two-borough tour.

title: PUBLISHING: TWO AUTHORS AT WORK AT HARRIS TRIAL
description: FOR the last few months, the writers Diana Trilling and Shana Alexander have been spending each working day at the Westchester County Courthouse in White Plains, where a jury is being asked to decide the fate of Jean Harris in the fatal shooting of her lover, Dr. Herman Tarnower, author of ''The Complete Scarsdale Medical Diet.''

title: ATLANTA SHAKES UP INVESTIGATIVE UNIT
description: Atlanta officials late today announced a major shake-up in the special police task force investigating the case of the city's missing and murdered black children. The net result of the action is to strengthen the ranks of the task force with more seasoned criminal investigators, an area in which the group has been criticized in recent weeks as being significantly weak.

title: GROWING WITH LEHMAN AGAIN AFTER SOJOURN IN WASHINGTON
description: Roger C. Altman, 35, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance in the Carter Administration, has returned to Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. as a managing director. Now, however, Mr. Altman will be responsible for a new business development and planning department at the securities concern.

title: A POWER PLANT'S GRIM PROMISE
description: To the Editor:

title: Friday; 'MOBY-DICK' IN GARDEN CITY
description: ''Moby-Dick'' fans, whaling buffs and others with stamina are invited by the English department of Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I., to a 24-hour marathon reading of Melville's epic novel of the sea, starting today at 1 P.M. in Room 306 of the University Center. An old ship's log, scrimshaw, a whale's tooth and products made from whales will be on display for atmosphere. From time to time, listeners will even hear whale sounds as background music. You can attend all or part of the event, participate or just listen. No charge. Information: (516) 294-8700, extension 7416. THE SOUNDS OF SILENTS

title: 2 WORLDS OF TAKEMITSU, JAPAN'S LEADING COMPOSER
description: Toru Takemitsu is known in two guises. In the world of classical music, and more particularly in that island of classical music that concerns itself with the new, Mr. Takemitsu is considered the best known and probably the best composer ever to emerge from Japan. Anyone wishing to test that proposition in concert can buy a ticket to the Feb. 23 Carnegie Hall concert of the Tokyo String Quartet, which will present the world premiere of Mr. Takemitsu's String Quartet No. 1.

title: KETTI FRINGS, STAGE AND FILM WRITER
description: Ketti Frings, a screenwriter and playwright whose dramatization of Thomas Wolfe's ''Look Homeward, Angel'' won the Pulitzer Prize in 1958, died of cancer at Cedars Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles on Wednesday. She was 61 years old.

title: TESTIMONY ENDS IN DISAGREEMENT AT HARRIS TRIAL
description: Testimony in the Jean S. Harris murder trial ended today. Judge Russell R. Leggett dismissed the jury for the weekend, saying that ''we've covered a lot of ground since Nov. 21'' and scheduling summations for Monday.

title: 6 TEXASGULF EXECUTIVES VICTIMS OF PLANE CRASH: GORDON MCKEE JR., 50,
description: VICE PRESIDENT

title: TEXAS MILLIONAIRE DISCONCERTS CAPITAL WITH BID FOR BANK
description: Joe L. Allbritton, a fast-talking Texas millionaire who portrays himself as a ''little old country boy,'' has disturbed the staid business establishment here with his bid to control the capital's largest and most prestigious financial institution, the Riggs National Bank.

title: Shearson Seeking Boston Company
description: Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., a major brokerage house that has grown rapidly in recent years through acquisitions, plans to acquire the Boston Company, a money management firm, the two companies announced.

title: News Analysis; REAGAN AND THE LATINS; Foreign Policy Third in a series of occasional articles on international problems facing the Reagan Administration.
description: After years of taking Latin America for granted, the United States is finding that much of the region no longer shares its view of the world or yearns for a return to the days of American domination.

title: UNLIKE TEXASGULF, SOME CXONCERNS LIMIT JOINT FLIGHTS
description: Unlike some corporations, Texasgulf Inc., the company that lost six of its executives in a jet crash Wednesday night, had no policy limiting the number of top officials traveling together on the same airplane.

title: A NEW ROLE IN U.S. FOR WOLFF BROKERS
description: Bruce Cleland, 33 years old, has been named president of Rudolf Wolff Commodity Brokers Inc., the American arm of a giant British metal brokerage house, Rudolf Wolff Ltd. He succeeds Helmut J. DeLille, 37, who resigned.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1981
description: International A plea for ''90 days of peace'' in Poland to allow the Government to deal with economic troubles was issued by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the new Prime Minister. Lech Walesa, the leader of the independent union, said that it ''agreed in principle'' with a strike moratorium but wanted more talks with the Government on some persisting differences. (Page A1, Column 6.) The Times of London will continue publishing, Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher, announced. He said he had completed accords with the unions and that he would assume control of the newspaper within 48 hours. He vowed that he would not lower the standards of the paper, which is widely regarded as one of the best in the world. (A3:1-3.)

title: AMID ROSEDALE FUROR, SCHOOL AS USUAL
description: Long before the boycotts, news conferences and outrage, Intermediate School 231 - a three-story beige-and-blue structure in a parklike setting off the Belt Parkway in Laurelton, Queens - was just another city school.

title: COMPUTER ISSUES DROP AND DOW IS OFF 5.89
description: Several computer issues fell sharply yesterday in response to adverse earnings developments as the general market registered its third decline of the last four sessions.

title: PACT GIVES MURDOCH THE LONFON TIMES
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher, has successfully completed union agreements necessary to buy The Times of London, and he said tonight that he would assume full control of the paper within 48 hours.

title: SELF-PORTRAIT OF THE MORAL MAJORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: Q UESTION: What caused the biggest stir at the party celebrating the opening of the new Italian Trade Center on Wednesday night: Gina Lollabrigida wearing a turquoise mink coat over a low-cut turquoise dress, or free food from six of New York's best Italian restaurants?

title: WHITE HOUSE TRIUMVIRATE EXERCISING WIDE POWER
description: While the nation watches its new President, the Washington political community has its eyes on the men whom staff members at the White House are calling the Big Three.

title: MONDALE AND KENNEDY FORMING DEMOCRATIC FUND-RAISING UNITS
description: The two most obvious potential Democratic Presidential candidates for 1984, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, are forming political action committees to provide money for other Democrats and visibility for themselves.

title: RECORD RUN (SORRY, KONG) AT EMPIRE STATE
description: Officials of the Empire State Building, who forbid most people, including upwardly mobile joggers, to climb their stairs for fun or curiosity, allowed 30 men and 8 women to run up the skyscraper's stairwell to the 86th-floor observation parapet yesterday.

title: Athletic Director At S.M.U. Quits
description: Russ Potts, who revived the Southern Methodist sports program with ''Mustang Mania,'' resigned as athletic director today, but he said the move had nothing to do with an investigation that, he confirmed, is under way.

title: LATER RETIREMENT AGES PROPOSED
description: Far-reaching changes in the financing of Social Security, including later retirements and a cut in the payroll tax, were proposed today by Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, the ranking minority member on the Senate Special Committee on Aging.

title: No Headline
description: ZIMBABWE ARMY ORDERED TO SMASH MUTINY

title: Court Victory Gained by Poet Charged in Slaying of Wife
description: A significant victory in a battle to get out of prison was won yesterday by James E. Lewisohn, a poet and former University of Maine professor who was convicted of killing his wife.

title: 6 TEXASGULF EXECUTIVES VICTIMS OF PLANE CRASH: CHARLES F. FOGARTY, 59,
description: BOARD CHAIRMAN Charles F. Fogarty was chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Texasgulf Inc. a worldwide oil and mining concern with headquarters in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Fogarty, who lived in Darien, Conn., was 59 years old.

title: by Herbert Stein
description: Watching the other night on the McNeil-Lehrer show - that interminable drip-drip-drip of talk on the barely-conscious consciousness that is the penance we pay for watching television at all - Edwin Meese 3d and James Baker 3d, outwardly so different, the one so cherubic and the other so Gary Cooperish, but nevertheless so nearly identical, so interchangeable in words and thoughts, carried my mind back through many Administrations, and many freshman White House officials appearing on television talk shows in their charming innocence and confidence that they knew what they were doing and that all within their purview was in order, like newly engaged coal stokers on a tramp steamer, decked out in dress whites and assuring all that everything was neat and clean below, which could perhaps be forgiven because they have not yet been there, or if they have been there nonetheless feel that there is about to be a new beginning, like the schoolboy starting a new term, with newly sharpened pencils and an unmarked notebook, who imagines himself capable of everything but knows in the back of his mind that before the term is over he will again be a struggling ''C,'' a thought that is still far back in the minds of new White House counselors and chiefs of staff as, securely lodged behind the White House fence - significantly, they did not come out to the TV studio but stayed in the Roosevelt Room, where the cameras came to them - like novices in the abbey, who will never have to go out to lunch, or look for a parking place, or shop for a new suit, so well-clothed are they in their official status, they expect always to agree with each other on what is right to do, and Cabinet Secretaries expect always to acknowledge the propriety of being denied access to the President, and the press always to accept the truth and reasonableness of what they have to say, and who cannot now imagine becoming a Hamilton Jordan, or a Haldeman or Ehrlichman or, who is for my generation the father of them all, a Harry Hopkins, the archetype of the cynical White House operator, but who at least had never claimed to be, or had given the impression of being, something else, which was at least in part because he never had the need or temptation to appear on TV, since it didn't then exist, or even on the radio - at least I don't remember, although I saw him in newsreels, ever hearing his voice, which I think of as being high and reedy, probably because he was thin and smoked a great deal, although that impression could easily be wrong - which is not to say that he had that passion for anonymity that his patron wanted in White House staff members, a requirement that I didn't appreciate until recently, when I understood that Cabinet members live for two things, the attention of the President and the attention of the public, and if the White House staff denies them the former and competes with them for the latter there will be a prompt end to that innocence so charmingly displayed by Messrs.

title: 40 Bombs Are Set Off in Corsica In an Apparent Retaliation Move
description: About 40 bombs exploded in Government offices, banks and vacation homes in Corsica during the night in apparent relatiation for prison sentences meted out to 14 Corsican nationalists by a Paris court yesterday.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE COMPANY OF WOMEN. By Mary Gordon. 291 pages. Random House. $12.95.

title: EXPENSIVE AND BAFFLING
description: About 8 P.M. on Jan. 29, four boys aged 13 to 16 boarded a northbound No. 6 IRT train at Lexington Avenue and 110th Street. One of them wore goggles and a couple had light bulbs in their pockets.

title: REAGAN'S PLANNERS MAY ELIMINATE WATCHDOG MEDICAL REVIEW GROUP
description: Nine years after the Federal Government established a group to evaluate the work of doctors who treat the poor and the elderly, the Reagan Administration is quietly planning to overhaul, and possibly abolish, the watchdog program.

title: Some Static on the Party Line
description: Individuals have attitudes, but governments need policies. Unless it soon draws that distinction, the Reagan Administration will not achieve its goal of addressing the world with a clear and single voice. For a team that has yet to make a difficult foreign policy choice, it is throwing up altogether too much static.

title: WHY DO STRIKERS GET FOOD STAMPS?
description: To the Editor:

title: W.R. Grace Buys Lighting Systems
description: W.R. Grace & Company said it had acquired Lighting Systems International Inc. for more than 200,000 shares of Grace common stock, valued at more than $11 million.

title: ART: THE KACHINA SPIRIT
description: AMONG the ancient peoples of North America, few have proved as tenacious as the Hopi Indians, who as of now and through May 8 are the subject of an exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History. ''Hopi Kachina: Spirit of Life'' is its title, and it was organized by the California Academy of Sciences with the cooperation of the Hopi.

title: 6 TEXASGULF EXECUTIVES VICTIMS OF PLANE CRASH: ROBERT J. BOYLE, 51, VICE
description: PRESIDENT Robert John Boyle was vice president for research, engineering and construction for Texasgulf. He was 51 years old and lived in Wilton, Conn.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1981
description: International Seeking support on El Salvador, the Reagan Administration will send high-level diplomatic missions to several foreign capitals in Western Europe and Latin America with documentation that is said to present a ''convincing case'' that the Soviet Union and its allies are supplying arms to Salvadoran guerrillas. (Page 6, Columns 3-5.) Moscow has resumed issuing visas to large numbers of Jewish citizens. Some have been seeking to emigrate for almost a decade. Approval of the visas nearly halted last summer, but, according to members of the Jewish community in Moscow, the official attitude became more lenient about a month ago. The reason for the policy change was in dispute. (24:1-3.)

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article about Faye Dunaway in The Times on Tuesday incorrectly implied that she would appear in a television version of ''Evita.'' The production is based on books about Eva Peron, not on the musical.

title: IRANIAN OFFICIAL ASSERTS OIL EXPORTS ARE UP TO 1.5 MILLION BARRELS A DAY
description: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament suggested in a speech over the Teheran radio yesterday that, despite the war with Iraq, Iran had managed to increase its oil exports to nearly twice the immediate prewar level.

title: WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY
description: Washington's birthday is Feb. 22. But it will be observed Monday throughout the country.

title: DOWN AND OUT WITH THE POVERTY SWELLS
description: The latest word from Washington is that the Reagan Administration will distinguish between the poor and the truly poor when it starts cutting Government services. The truly poor will have nothing to worry about from the budget cutters. They will be treated as the elite of poverty, meaning that Government benefits will continue to arrive as usual.

title: GETTING OUR SIGNALS LACROSSED
description: Eddie Joslin, a 14-year-old White Plains high school student, was recently asked by a New York Times reporter how he liked playing lacrosse with girls, as now required by his high school's interpretation of Federal law. Eddie, nursing a hand sprained in a recent game, said: ''You've got to be more careful with them. You don't want to hurt them or anything.''

title: ST. GOBAINS WIDENS HOLDING IN OLIVETTI
description: St. Gobain-Pont-a-Mousson, the diversified corporate giant apparently chosen by the French Government to lead the development of an advanced communications industry, has raised its stake in Olivetti. St. Gobain says it has expanded its holding in the big Italian office equipment maker to 30 percent from 23 percent and may increase it to 33 percent.

title: WAR FEAR EASES
description: The threat of civil war appeared to be receding today after Prime Minister Robert Mugabe used what remained of the old Rhodesian Army and Air Force to crush rebellious former guerrillas with nominal loyalty to Joshua Nkomo, a member of his Cabinet.

title: CERONE'S PAY RISE IRKS STEINBRENNER
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees principal owner, responded angrily today to Rick Cerone's victory in salary arbitration, questioning Cerone's loyalty and evaluation of his worth.

title: AND ARTIFICIAL HEARTS, WHICH ARE COMIMG, RAISE KEY LEGAL, ETHICAL,
description: Although research and development leading to an artificial heart has been federally funded for 17 years, until recently the project had received little attention. The low profile may have been forced on it by lack of money, perhaps by the desire to get on with the work before the device became an issue. But recent news about permission to experiment on humans raises questions about this biomedical technology that need to be answered soon, especially because the University of Utah's artificial-heart group is preparing to perform the first implant in a human.

title: PRESSURES OF A 31.08 BAROMETER READING
description: In case you didn't notice, the barometric pressure in New York soared to a record high of 31.08 inches of mercury shortly before 9 A.M. yesterday, the National Weather Service announced.

title: PEKING IN WINTER: VACUUM-CLEANER BAG IN A FREEZER
description: Longtime residents say there are at least three things worse than December in Peking: January, February and March. Dusty, sooty, cold and dry, Peking in winter is like living in a vacuum-cleaner bag in a freezer. It is the kind of place that makes Americans homesick for overcast Februarys in Des Moines. New Yorkers, enduring their own cold and dry winter, will find no sympathy here, though they may be comforted to know that the inhabitants also see every breath of air they take.

title: FLOATING TRADITION
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Safety in the Ring
description: WHEN Willie Classen was knocked through the ropes Nov. 23, 1979, no ambulance was parked in the wings of Madison Square Garden. It took 30 minutes to flag down an ambulance in the street and take Classen to a hospital, where he died five days later.

title: THE PROPER MONTH FOR A PRIMARY
description: To the Editor:

title: GAF HAS LARGE LOSS
description: The GAF Corporation reported yesterday that a large restructuring write-off caused a loss of $246.2 million in the fourth quarter, contrasted to a profit of $7.6 million, or 50 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979. Sales slipped 6.6 percent, to $172.6 million, from $184.8 million.

title: SUSPECT SAYS HE WAS A 'CUSTOMER' IN FATAL HOLDUP, BUT HE'S ARRESTED
description: A man who tried unsuccessfully to convince the police that he had been just another customer of an East Harlem grocery store was arrested yesterday in the Thursday evening robbery and shootout at the store.

title: Lucas Is Dominant, Even on a Bad Ankle
description: Maurice Lucas of the Nets has been hampered recently because of tendinitis in his ankle, but he was unstoppable tonight. Playing both center and forward, he had game highs of 31 points, including the last 4, 13 rebounds and 6 blocked shots as the Nets beat the Indiana Pacers, 103-100, at Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: GAINS ARE REPORTED IN SHOCK SYNDROME
description: Researchers at several laboratories appear to be closing in on the cause of toxic shock syndrome, a condition that has been associated with the use of tampons and has been fatal in about 8 percent of reported cases.

title: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1981; The Economy
description: Producer prices rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent in January, in line with economists' predictions that the inflation rate would accelerate in the first quarter of 1981. The increase, which was larger than the rises of last fall, was caused mainly by sharply higher fuel oil and gasoline prices, the Labor Department said. The figures, however, did not reflect the effects of the decontrol of oil prices announced Jan. 28. (Page 1.)

title: Ex-Police Officer Found Safe in Mountain Search
description: Eric Enell, a retired police captain, was found safe amid sheer cliffs on Mount Palomar today, six days after he went up the mountain to search for his godson.
