title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Cal Ripken, t hird baseman, and Dallas Williams, out- f ielder, to one-year contracts. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Lost arbitration j udgment to Dave Frost, pitcher, who will g et $112,500 salary in 1981. CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Marc Hill, free- a gent catcher; Tony Bernazard, second b aseman, and Lamarr Hoyt, pitcher. CHICAGO (NL) - Agreed to contract t erms with Mike Krukow, pitcher. CLEVELAND (AL) - Agreed to contract t erms with Jerry Dybzinski, infielder. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Named Rick Re- n ick batting instructor. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed seven p layers: Frank Di Pino, Rickey Keeton and R ich Olsen, pitchers; Ned Yost, catcher; Ed R omero, infielder, and Marshall Edwards a nd Kevin Bass, outfielders. MINNESOTA (AL) - Signed Darrell J ackson, pitcher; Glen Adams and Bombo R ivera, outfielders, and Ray Smith, catch- e r, to one-year contracts. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Lost arbitra- t ion judgment to Johnnie LeMaster, shor- s top, who will get $155,000 salary in 1981. W on judgment from Greg Minton, pitcher, w ho will get $180,000 salary. SEATTLE (AL) - Agreed to contract t erms with Mario Guerrero, shortstop.

title: DEMOCRATS WARNED OF DISTRICTING PERIL
description: Democrats seeking to prevent a possible loss of the House of Representatives in 1982 hope to start soon to catch up with the Republicans in preparing for redistricting battles in state legislatures, according to a Democratic National Committee staff memorandum being circulated among party leaders.

title: AREA OF LOUISVILLE DAMAGED BY BLASTS of residents of Louisville
description: -A series of explosions, possibly resulting from an accumulation of a flammable industrial solvent, ripped through the sewers beneath an old section of Louisville early today, leaving craters in streets and millions of dollars in damage.

title: Atlanta Colleges Back Site for Carter Library
description: Atlanta colleges and universities competing for Jimmy Carter's Presidential library have agreed on a compromise site, 219 acres of abandoned highway land, that the former President appears to be seriously considering.

title: POLISH PREMIER PROMISES OPENESS
description: Poland's new Prime Minister, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, told the nation tonight in his first news conference that the Government wanted to keep open channels of communication with the people.

title: FINAL TAPE REVEALS NO PROBLEMS ON TEXASGULF JET, U.S. AIDE SAYS
description: A tape recording of the final messages between the control tower and a corporate jet that crashed Wednesday night near the Westchester County Airport provides no evidence of trouble aboard the plane, the head of a Federal investigating team said today.

title: Computer Sciences Charges Dismissed
description: A Federal court dismissed all charges in a price-rigging case against the Computer Sciences Corporation and six current and former employees.

title: Baltimore Defeats Arrows; Zungul's Streak Stopped
description: Third-period goals by Ade Coker at 1:44 and by Mark Liveric at 14:52 enabled the Baltimore Blast to defeat the New York Arrows, 4-2, tonight in a Major Indoor Soccer League game at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Combustion Engineering
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. reported that earnings in the fourth quarter rose 21.1 percent, to $42.4 million, or $1.30 a share, from $35 million, or $1.06 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979.

title: A PRINTER WITH THE PROPER RESPECT FOR THE POET'S ART
description: Peter Kavanagh, who is both management and labor at the Peter Kavanagh Hand Press, has a blunderbuss of a tongue, and the verbal scattershot peppers landlords, publishers, literary dabblers and a rather large gallery of miscreants. Finally, he takes aim at himself for going on too long about Kavanagh and his peeves.

title: FOES OF MARCOS MARCH IN MANILLA TO FOREWARN POPE OF GRIEVANCES
description: Nuns, seminarians, students and workers demonstrated in downtown Manila today in the largest protest against the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos since the lifting of martial law last month.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. The letter was in response to one from Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who had warned about Soviet intervention in Poland. Mr. Gromyko rejected this expression of concern and complained that the United States had ignored Soviet efforts in behalf of the American hostages in Iran.

title: The Heart of the Matter
description: Everywhere we look we see hearts. Little gold hearts and big chocolate hearts. Sunglasses shaped like hearts. Pillows shaped like hearts.

title: MOSCOW ABRUPTLY RESUMES ISSUING EXIT VISAS TO JEWS
description: Without explanation, the Soviet Union has resumed issuing visas to large numbers of Jews who have long sought to emigrate.

title: For Fisk, Praise but No Offers
description: Carlton Fisk, who was declared a free agent Thursday by a labor arbitrator, received several compliments but no announced job offers yesterday.

title: City Notes' Yield Estimated at 9 1/2%
description: Investment bankers estimated yesterday that New York City's $100 million of tax anticipation notes, due April 22, might be sold next week with a yield of 9 1/2 percent or higher. The yield could differ, they added, if the overall level of interest rates changes next week.

title: AT LEAST 40 DIE IN DUBLIN CLUB FIRE
description: At least 40 people were killed and 200 injured in a fire that swept through a nightclub here early today, the police reported.

title: TOMATO JUICE: IN QUEST OF QUALITY
description: What the world needs, apparently, is a chateau-bottled, vintage tomato juice. Only such a precise and controlled designation can assure tomato juice connoisseurs of a consistent flavor and texture.

title: THEY FELL IN LOVE AT FIRST SIGHT
description: I saw and loved. -Edward Gibbon

title: CUT IN U.S. AID TO ARTS OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - Artists and their Federal patrons, some loudly and some cautiously, are protesting threats by Reagan Administration budget cutters to impose drastic reductions in Government subsidies for the arts.

title: G.O.P. SLATE NEEDS A REPUBLICAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Breaks Out on Indian Jet
description: An Indian Airlines plane with 121 people on board caught fire at a Madras airport today, the Press Trust of India news agency reported. No casualties were reported.

title: Lawford's Son Pleads Not Guilty
description: A drug case against Christopher Kennedy Lawford, son of Peter Lawford, the actor, was continued for six months today in Roxbury District Court. Christopher Lawford, 25 years old, pleaded not guilty to a charge of illegal possession of heroin. The case will automatically terminate in six months if there are no further problems. Mr. Lawford, is a nephew of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachussets.

title: MIDWEST FEARS IMPACT OF OIL DECONTROL
description: President Reagan's decontrol of oil prices has raised fears in Iowa and a number of other Middle Western states that they could be among the principal victims in any national petroleum shortage.

title: STORING VITAMINS, FROM A TO K
description: So vitamins are on sale this week. Is it worth it to buy a threeyear supply? Or will the vitamins go bad? How will you know if they do go bad? Is there any danger in consuming vitamins after they've lost their potency? What's the best way to store them?

title: Canada's Tangle - and Ours
description: There seems to be no way that Britain can make Canada formally independent without meddling in that country's internal affairs. This is the crux of a constitutional crisis that has half of Canada in an uproar and has now forced the early retirement of Sir John Ford, Britain's envoy to Ottawa. The crisis has a moral: Empires are easier made than unmade. Still, Americans have no cause for complacent clucking, since Washington sooner or later will have to cope with a comparable dilemma, in Puerto Rico.

title: DOUBTS ABOUT DAY CARE
description: There are no doors on the toilets. One child sleeps on a mat on the floor. One has a small box to keep things in and a peg on a wall. Mobs run around screaming all day. Privacy is nonexistent.

title: CORPORATE SALES AND EARNINGS REPORTS
description: RAGEN PRECISION IND. (O) Qtr to Dec. 31 1980 1979 Sales 7,964,103 6,801,367 Net income 146,752 278,934 Share earnings .07 b.15 b-Adjusted for a 6 percent stock dividend distributed April 7, 1980. RESORTS INTERNATIONAL (A) Qtr to Dec. 31 1980 1979 Revenue 77,000,000 87,700,000 Net income b4,100,000 10,500,000 Share earnings .37 .83 Year rev 373,500,000 375,000,000 Net income 45,200,000 c91,100,000 Share earnings 3.85 7.20 b-Including $2.1 million tax credit and $3.6 million pretax provision for the estimated loss on disposition of certain airline operations. c-Including $4.6 million tax credit. RIVERSIDE GROUP (O) Qtr to Dec. 31 1980 1979 Revenue 9,900,000 1,600,000 Net income 362,000 b223,000 Share earnings .20 - Year rev 23,200,000 7,500,000 Net income 708,000 b764,000 Share earnings .40 - b-Net loss. 1979 results are on a pro-forma basis. The company was spun off from Charter Co. in March 1979.

title: Cannon Mills
description: The Cannon Mills Company said that higher cotton and manufacturing costs helped depress net income in the fourth quarter, ended Jan. 1, by 48.9 percent, to $9 million, or 96 cents a share, from $17.6 million, or $1.88 a share.

title: Cubans Seeking Asylum Invade Ecuador's Embassy
description: A group of Cubans broke into the Ecuadorean Embassy in Havana today, took the Ambassador and two other diplomats hostage and demanded political asylum, a Government spokesman said.

title: LOYALIST VS. NATIONALIST IN NORTHERN IRELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY WATER SUPPLY UP TO 140 DAYS, BUT PLEA ON WASTE IS RENEWED
description: The heavy rains and balmy, snow-melting temperatures of midweek combined to push water reserves in New York City's three reservoir systems to nearly 40 percent of capacity, officials said yesterday.

title: Robin, Class E Craft,Is Winner in Florida
description: The 36-foot yacht Robin survived lightning, freakish waves and 40-mile-an-hour gusts in winning the 370-mile St. Petersburg-to-Fort Lauderdale leg of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference series.

title: KEOGH BENEFITS FOR YOUNGSTERS
description: Some years ago the idea was advanced that Keogh retirement plans could be used for teen-agers and college students, with some help from parents or grandparents. Little has been done with the idea, however, by banks and others who advertise Keogh plans and their tax advantages.

title:
PATENTS;
A Technique For Raising Shrimp
description: A method for raising shrimp is explained in a patent received this week by the Farm Fresh Shrimp Corporation, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Charles and Timothy Dugan obtained patent 4,249,480 for the company.

title: PREPARING FOR TAX AUDIT: CAREFUL RECORDS VITAL
description: Your Taxes: A Guide to Preparing 1980 Returns

title: PRESIDENT REJECTS A RETROACTIVE CUT IN PERSONAL TAXES d'Estaing
description: President Reagan has rejected a plan to make his proposed 10 percent cut in personal income taxes retroactive to Jan. 1 and instead plans to ask Congress to begin the decrease on July 1, Administration sources said today.

title: 4 Refiners List Price Increases
description: Texaco, Gulf, Cities Service and the Sun Company yesterday raised wholesale gasoline and home heating oil prices by as much as 2 cents a gallon, the forty-third such increase by United States refiners since President Reagan decontrolled domestic crude oil and gasoline prices on Jan. 28.

title: This is the first of a series of articles to appear in coming weeks that will follow one program the Reagan Administration wants to cut - food stamps -through the legislative process.
description: Not long ago, a lobbyist for the dairy industry dropped by to see Carolyn Cheney, a key staff aide of the House Agriculture Committee. The topic of their talk was organizing support for the food stamp program, one of the biggest targets of President Reagan's planned budget cutbacks.

title: LONG-TERM RATES HIT NEW HIGHS
description: Long-term interest rates rose yesterday to record levels as investors and securities dealers, doubting forecasts that the economy would weaken early this year, pushed 30-year Treasury bond yields above 13 percent.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 14. 1. In an unusual action, the Soviet Embassy in Washington made public the contents of a confidential letter in which Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko rebuked an American official. To whom was the letter addressed and what was at issue?

title: Dr. William Goldring Dead at 82; An Authority on Kidney Diseases
description: Dr. William Goldring, professor of medicine at the New York University School of Medicine and an authority on hypertension and renal diseases, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE* 19.00 19.00 15.25 DISCOUNT RATE** 13.00 13.00 12.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 16.70 N.A. 14.67 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 15.28 N.A. 12.85 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.56 N.A. 12.90 TREASURY NOTES 13.56 N.A. 12.22 TREASURY BONDS 13.17 N.A. 12.62 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 14.10 14.06 11.32 MUNICIPAL BONDS 11.20 11.00 8.35 6-MONTH SAVINGS 14.680 CERTIFICATES * Split rate, 19.00-19.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. N.A. Not available because banks were closed for Lincoln's Birthday Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MURDOCH, IN 'CHALLENGE OF MY LIFE,' BUYS LONDON TIMES FOR $28 MILLION
description: Rupert Murdoch bought The Times of London and its affiliated publications today for $28 million, making him one of the most powerful Fleet Street publishers of the 20th century.

title: Faldo Cards 62 and Leads Hawaiian Open by 2 Shots
description: Nick Faldo of Britain birdied five holes in a row and shot a 10-under-par 62 to take the lead today after two rounds in the $325,000 Hawaiian open golf tournament.

title: KNICKS WIN 7TH IN A ROW
description: Sly Williams appeared to be the Knicks' designated scorer last night as they routed the Detroit Pistons, 120-92, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Addition to Mozart Picture
description: Any Mozart discovery is automatically important. Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was, after all, one of the supreme musical minds. Thus the newly discovered symphony in F major, even though it is a juvenile work, will add to the picture of the young composer's development.

title: TEXT OF A STATEMENT BY GARWOOD
description: Following is the text of a statement read today in the court-martial of Pfc. Robert R. Garwood by Capt. Lewis Olshin on Private Garwood's behalf:

title: JERSEY GUN BILL BECOMES A LAW IN BYRNE'S CAR
description: Governor Byrne has quietly signed a bill he opposed, mandating a three-year prison sentence for anyone who uses a gun in the commission of a violent crime, his press aides confirmed today.

title: 11 SUBWAY 'ANGELS' HELD IN MELEE
description: Eleven members of the Guardian Angels, a group of young people whose members have vowed to fight subway crime, were arrested last night on charges that they started a melee and assaulted a man on an IND subway train in Brooklyn, the Transit Authority said.

title: Cracked Pots
description: Brown University's annual Friday-the-13th tribute to ''Josiah S. Carberry'' again took place yesterday on the campus in Providence, R.I.

title: Bess Truman's Party
description: The customary yearly ''surprise'' party for Bess Truman was held yesterday with Valentine's Day decorations and a cake at her home in Independence, Mo. It was the 96th birthday of President Harry S. Truman's widow, who was said to have been well pleased with it all.

title: ACTED ON BROADWAY FOR 30 YEARS
description: Jean Dixon, whose acidulous delivery and superb comedy timing enlivened such Broadway hits as ''Once in a Lifetime'' and ''June Moon'' and such films as ''My Man Godfrey'' and ''Holiday,'' died Thursday after a long illness. She was 85 years old and lived on Fifth Avenue and in Annisquam, Mass.

title: RUIN OF 2 WALL STREET CAREERS
description: Why would two sociable young men, graduates of the Harvard Business School, successfully embarked on highly lucrative investment banking careers, have risked those careers and their reputations in an allegedly illegal scheme that yielded a few hundred thousand dollars?

title: CITY INSPECTIONS AT BUILDING SITES ARE SAID TO DROP
description: The New York City Buildings Department no longer makes enough inspections of construction projects to know whether fire and safety codes are being met, according to department officials, architects and engineers.

title: PRIVATE FUNDS WILL REFURBISH REAGAN QUARTERS
description: The White House announced yesterday that it would cost $200,000 to refurbish the private living quarters of President and Mrs. Reagan, but that the entire bill would be paid by private donors.

title: Revillon Freres Plans Expansion
description: Revillon Freres, the diversified French industrial and financial group best-known for its luxury fur business, said it would license its name worldwide in ready-to-wear women's clothing, accessories and fragrances.

title: CHEAP CHOCOLATE WORRIES THE SWISS
description: ''What we sell is the Swiss image in chocolate,'' said JeanBernard Bosset, marketing director for Tobler, the company reknowned for its triangular-shaped chocolate and nougat candy. ''We appeal only to a small, upper-income customer.''

title: A.T.&T. PROPOSES WATS DISCOUNTS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, responding to a Federal order, proposed today to offer evening and weekend discounts to its business customers who lease WATS lines.

title: Disabled Ironworker Awarded $2.2 Million
description: A 46-year-old disabled ironworker who became depressed and who ''considered himself a failure'' because he couldn't ''bring home the bacon'' was awarded $2.2 million by a Manhattan jury, his lawyer said.

title: POLICE DOUBT BUSBOY'S ACCOUNT OF HOW VEGAS HOTEL FIRE BEGAN
description: The police said today that they doubted that a fire that killed eight persons and injured 198 others Tuesday night at the Las Vegas Hilton could have been started by the accidental touch of a marijuana cigarette to flameproof drapes, as a busboy arrested in the case is said to have admitted.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No one should interpret this good news as a sign that the drought is over.

title: Corsican Separatists in France Take Responsibility for Bombings
description: Corsican separatists claimed responsibility today for three Paris-area bombings during the night, including one that seriously damaged the Italian tourist office and another that destroyed 15 parked cars.

title: THIRD-WORLD PARLEY URGES PULLOUTS FROM 2 NATIONS
description: Soviet-supported countries were thwarted here tonight when foreign ministers from the nations professing nonalignment adopted a resolution calling for withdrawal of foreign forces from Afghanistan and Cambodia.

title: Bancshares Posts Loss
description: Bancshares of New Jersey yesterday reported a loss of $16.9 million for 1980, compared with net income of $5.5 million in 1979. The bank holding company said its 1980 loss resulted primarily from bad real estate loans by the company's biggest subsidiary, the Bank of New Jersey, but it did not state the amount involved.

title: Toward a Vital Times Square
description: Finally there is a 42d Street Development Project that promises to be more than idle chatter. After years of false starts, the city, with the help of the Urban Development Corporation, has committed itself in a new study to ending the area's long, sordid slide. This belated resolve and the lively state of Manhattan's real estate market may be the right combination at the right time to turn Times Square around.

title:
PATENTS;
A FLUID POWER SYSTEM
description: motor, that can be used to propel small vehicles, such as bicycles, wheelchairs and golf carts. The converter can transmit power, such as from a small motor or bicycle foot pedals, using hydraulic principles.

title: REAL HEARTS HAVE THEIR REASONS
description: Dorfman 2,513,0MANCHESTER CENTER, Vt. - Invariably, at this time of year, I become aware of a recurring, pleasant sensation in the middle of my chest. It is identifiable and very familiar: a convergence of genes about my heart. My father's genes, surely.

title: Pennsylvania's Lottery Has an Untimely Start
description: The nightly drawing in the state's lottery, televised live, was delayed and conducted off-camera today after an elderly volunteer began the drawing too soon.

title: 'Trixie True' Musical to Close
description: The Off Broadway musical ''Trixie True, Teen Detective,'' featuring Marilyn Sokol, will close after tomorrow evening's performance at the Theatre de Lys. The production, which opened last Dec. 4, will have given 85 performances and nine previews.

title: COMSAT ADVANCES 29.3%; Communications Satellite
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation announced that earnings in the fourth quarter rose 29.3 percent, to $9.7 million, or $1.22 a share, from $7.5 million, or 94 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979. Revenues increased 18 percent, to $82 million, from $69.5 million.

title: Wheelabrator Unit Gets Mexico Job
description: The M.W. Kellogg Company, a subsidiary of Wheelabrator-Frye, was awarded two new fertilizer and ammonia plant contracts by Petroleos Mexicanos, the petroleum and petrochemical agency of Mexico.

title: FINAL TESTIMONY IS HEARD IN SUIT TO LIMIT DOMESTIC SURVEILLANCE
description: A Federal district judge heard testimony today on a proposed settlement of a suit that could provide more stringent guidelines for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Domestic operations of the Central Intelligence Agency are also covered.

title: EX-AIDE WHO GAVE AWAY $4 MILLION
description: Paul L. Bloom today found himself happily staring at seven television cameras and parrying questions from a roomful of reporters after almost a year away from the limelight.

title: TO VENT THE DEADLY SMOKE OF HIGH-RISE FIRES
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG-LOST MOZART WORK TO HAVE MAY PREMIER
description: A missing childhood creation of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's has been found in Bavaria and will have its premiere performance in May - 216 years after the 9-year-old genius composed it.

title: DANCE: ELIZABETH STREB'S 'FALL IN LINE' AT THEATER LAB
description: A 10-by-12-foot wooden plane rising 8 feet from the floor at a 35-degree tilt filled center stage of the American Theater Laboratory on Thursday and provided the dance space for Elizabeth Streb's new ''Fall Line.'' But this piece of equipment - the ultimate in raked stages - enabled Miss Streb to burrow back into the possibilities of the resilient human body rather than extend the space through which the body moves, as earlier ''equipment pieces'' by other choreographers did. One of the most interesting members of the new ''post-modern'' generation of choreographers, Miss Streb is adept at turning bursts of pure, athletic energy into witty, risky and surprisingly touching dance. And she has done it again here, with remarkable simplicity and sophistication.

title: HIGHER FUEL COSTS LED JANUARY'S RISE IN PRODUCER
description: The prices that producers charge retailers for finished goods rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, a significant acceleration from the pattern of last fall, the Labor Department reported today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOOKING BACK

title: Springs Mills Alters Frozen Food Unit
description: Springs Mills Inc. announced a major restructuring of its frozen food business and a write-down of $20 million to $22 million in three areas.

title: Continental Air Request Denied
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board denied a request by Continental Air Lines that it strike down a $13-a-share tender offer by Texas International Airlines.

title: Toyota, Nissan Set Records
description: Japan's two leading auto makers said today their worldwide exports in January reached record levels, buoyed in part by an increase in shipments to the United States.

title: Lillian Carter Mends
description: In Americus, Ga., Lillian Carter was reported ''doing just fine'' yesterday in a nursing home, where she will undergo therapy for a hip injured in another fall at her home.

title: THREAT TO KENNEDY AIDE REPORTED
description: Several attempts and threats have been made in the past two weeks on the life of Richard E. Burke, administrative assistant to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, lawenforcement officials said today.

title: 2 REGULATORY UNITS FACING BUDGET CUTS
description: The Federal Trade Commission and the Consumer Product Safety Commission, two independent consumer-oriented agencies, are facing sharp budgetary cuts by the Reagan Administration.

title: Books of The Times
description: Nagging at Charm By ANATOLE BROYARD UNRELIABLE MEMOIRS. By Clive James. 171 pages. Knopf. $10.

title:
PATENTS;
Rollers Can Apply Plastic Coating
description: Luggage, golf clubs' grips, cosmetic cases and clothing can be coated with plastic economically using a metal roller patented this week.

title: SAXOPHONIST: BUDDY TATE
description: Ever since he first came to New York with Count Basie's Orchestra in 1939, Buddy Tate has played his tenor saxophone with a big, buoyant, swaggering attack that was the epitome of the Texas style in which he grew up. In the 30 years since he left the Basie Band and has been leading his own groups, Mr. Tate has retained that distinctive, identifying ebullience, adding to it a richly polished development of ballads.

title: U.S. DOLLAR UP SHARPLY IN VALUE
description: The dollar surged against European currencies today, reaching its highest levels in several years. Trading was hectic, first on the Continent and later in New York.

title: LOANS TAILORED TO REGION
description: An array of highly innovative financing mechanisms has developed in New England during the past five years to meet the needs of the region's rapidly changing economy, according to a regional planning official.

title: TOLL OF RUSSIAN OFFICERS IN CRASH IS SAID TO BE 70
description: As many as 70 Soviet military officers, including up to 24 admirals and generals, may have died in a plane crash last Saturday that killed three top commanders of the Pacific Fleet, Western sources asserted today.

title: Innocent Man Freed After 10 Months
description: A 23-year-old Brooklyn man who spent 10 months in jail awaiting trial on murder and robbery charges was released when shown to be a victim of mistaken identity.

title: Woodcock Sees China 'Turning Corner' in '90's
description: China faces a decade of enormous economic and social problems, including tensions from the ''displacement of millions upon millions of workers,'' according to Leonard Woodcock, the departing American Ambassador.

title: Off Broadway League And Equity Reach Pact
description: Actors Equity and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers have settled on the terms of a new contract.

title: No Headline
description: Lewis P. Seiler, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, the parent company of Lord & Taylor and other department stores across the country, died yesterday in Delray Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 75 years old and had retired in 1976 after 40 years with the company. Mr. Seiler, a soft-spoken, low-keyed executive, took over Associated's presidency in 1959 when it had sales of $290 million and built its volume to $1.4 billion.

title: Israeli Fighters Shoot Down Syrian Jet Over Lebanon
description: Israeli jet fighters shot down a Syrian MIG today over the Bekaa Valley in eastern Lebanon. The clash was the latest incident in what appears to be increasing Israeli pressure on Lebanon in recent weeks.

title: COMPUTERIZED WELFARE SYSTEM IS HAILED BY OFFICIALS IN WISCONSIN
description: A computerized welfare system has not only cut costs, state officials assert, but has also improved the delivery of services to the poor.

title: CARTER AIDE DEFENDS SENDING $4 MILLION TO CHARITIES
description: The four charities that were given $1 million each by the Department of Energy just before the Carter Administration left office said today that they had already distributed much of the money. They expressed dismay at attempts by the Government to get it back.

title: Jewish Arts Festival Opens On Tuesday at Columbia
description: A program of readings, discussions, music and films will be offered as part of a Jewish Arts Festival at Columbia University starting Tuesday under the sponsorship of Columbia's Council of Jewish Organizations.

title: Versatile Miss Forde Victor in Toronto 600
description: Lorna Forde has a chronic sore back. She is willful. Her confidence wavers in midrace. She argues with her coach over whether she is a quarter-miler or half-miler.

title: CAR SALES OFF FROM '80, BUT SELLING RATE GAINS
description: Sales of domestic cars fell 7.8 percent in early February from the level a year earlier, reports from the nation's major manufacturers indicated today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amdisco Corporation contracted to sell its Union City, Calif. plant property for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: STOCKS OFF AMID RATE FEARS
description: Friday the 13th was another down day for the jittery stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.03 points yesterday, to 931.57, bringing its decline over the last three sessions to 17 points.

title: 'Robin Hood' to Be Staged At the Riverside Church
description: ''Robin Hood,'' set in 12th-century England but exploring present poverty, will open March 19 at the Riverside Church.

title: HAMSHO, A SYRIAN STREET FIGHTER, NOW BATTLING FOR TITLE SHOT
description: Mustafa Hamsho is a 26-year-old Syrian who arrived illegally in this country when he jumped a Greek ship in New York in 1974 and went to work in a cousin's Oriental bakery on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. He says his fight tomorrow in Atlantic City against Curtis Parker is ''like all other fights, just a fight.''

title: MATCHLESS ART
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A list of Sullivan Award winners that appeared in the sports pages on Feb. 3 included two errors. The winner in 1946 was Arnold Tucker, football player, and in 1949 Dick Button, figure skater.

title: Executive Suite
description: William F. Snyder, a former Schenectady television news anchorman, has been appointed Governor Carey's director of communications, at a salary of $57,780 a year.

title: U.S. SEEKS ALLIES' BACKING ON SALVADOR
description: The Reagan Administration will seek to rally support in Western Europe and Latin America next week against what it sees as Soviet support for leftist guerrillas in El Salvador, officials said today.

title: U.S. Approves the Export Of Reactors to Taiwan
description: The United States has approved the export to Taiwan of two nuclear reactors that are to operate at Yenliao, 30 miles from Taipei.

title: Canadian Concern Lifts Bache Stake
description: The First City Financial Corporation, a Canadian concern controlled by the Belzberg family, which holds large financial and real estate properties in Canada, has increased its stake in Bache Group Inc. to almost 20 percent.

title: SEWAGE PIPELINE TO CUT DUMPING INTO THE HUDSON
description: New York City and New Jersey officials agreed yesterday to a plan for chemically treating thousands of gallons of sewage that otherwise might have been dumped in raw form into the Hudson River once the New York Exposition and Convention Center is built.

title: Western Washington Earthquake Is Felt as Far South as Portland
description: A strong earthquake that rattled western Washington tonight was felt as far south as Portland, Ore., officials said.

title: Grandson for Hussein
description: King Hussein of Jordan has become a grandfather for the first time.

title: Execution Decreed for Killer Of Louisiana Police Officer
description: A judge today sentenced 32-year-old Robert Wayne Felde to death in the electric chair, as he had requested, for the 1978 slaying of a policeman. Mr. Felde had pleaded insanity based on delayed stress from his experiences in the Vietnam War.

title: MOVE TO CUT REGULATORY COSTS NEAR
description: President Reagan will issue an executive order soon that could reduce industry's cost of Government regulation by hundreds of millions of dollars, White House officials said today.

title: AIR FORCE SEEKS NEW BOMBER AND DEVELOPMENT OF A RADAR-EVADING PLANE
description: The Air Force is preparing a recommendation to Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger calling for immediate production of a new version of the B-1 bomber while proceeding to develop the radar-evading Stealth aircraft, according to Pentagon and Congressional officials.

title: NEW TV TRANSMITTER CAUSING RECEPTION PROBLEMS
description: A new wave of complaints and inquiries about poor television reception has poured into television repair shops recently as WNEWTV, Channel 5, has joined WCBS-TV and WABC-TV, Channels 2 and 7, on a new transmitter atop the World Trade Center.

title: SAVE THE WEST SIDE HIGHWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCK: MCGUINN-HILLMAN BAND
description: The McGuinn-Hillman Band, which performed at the Bottom Line on Tuesday and Wednesday, is merely the latest version of the Byrds, the 1960's folk-rock quintet that influenced countless Los Angeles rock groups over the last decade. Roger McGuinn, the Byrds' original lead singer and guitarist, and Chris Hillman, its bassist, now lead a four-man band that also includes the pedal steel guitarist Al Perkins, a one-time member of the Flying Burrito Brothers.

title: Turkey Opposes U.S. Move On Military Aid to Greece
description: Foreign Minister Ilter Turkmen said today that Turkey was opposed to any move by Washington to give guarantees to Greece that it would help maintain the ratio of military aid between the two nations at 10 to 7 in Turkey's favor.

title: 'World According to Garp' To Start Filming April 10
description: Production will begin in New York on April 10 on the movie version of John Irving's novel ''The World According to Garp.''

title: Henderson Hospitalized to Cure Drug Habit
description: Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson says that a cocaine habit has hurt his professional football career and caused him to enter a hospital, where he is trying to free himself of the addiction, The Dallas Times Herald reported today.

title: MAN KILLS TELLER BEFORE HE IS SHOT BY POLICE OFFICER
description: A 27-year-old man who the police said was ''very unhappy'' about having been rejected by his girlfriend fatally shot the woman yesterday in a crowded midtown bank where she worked as a teller. The man was then fatally shot by an off-duty policeman.

title: DANCE: PREMIER OF NIKOLAIS 'TALISMAN'
description: Alwin Nikolais, a major American artist, works in mysterious ways. When modern-dance used to be synonymous with psychological dancedrama, with the use of the body language to convey emotion, he was one of the first to move in a totally new direction.

title: MANY FROM LOVE CANAL STILL UNSETTLED
description: Nine months after they left their Love Canal neighborhood for a succession of motel rooms and temporary military housing, Marie Pozniak and her family are still searching for a new home and new roots. For them, she said, ''Love Canal didn't end.''

title: NUCLEAR PROPONENT SEEN FOR ENERGY POST
description: W. Kenneth Davis, a former chief of nuclear reactor development for the Atomic Energy Commission, will be named Deputy Secretary of Energy, according to a number of well-placed industry sources.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to make what it sees as Soviet-bloc support for El Salvador's insurgents an early test of relations with both its allies and the Soviet Union.

title:
PATENTS;
Device Improves Satellite Transmission
description: For use in the transmission of speech, a system has been invented for communications satellites that compresses the words at the transmitter and expands them again at the receiver.

title: Notes on a Couple of Women in the Money Game
description: Angela M. Buchanan, nominated by President Reagan to be United States Treasurer, said yesterday, ''It's a job I'm exceptionally qualified for, and I say so without false modesty.''

title: THE PROPER MONTH FOR A PRIMARY
description: To the Editor:

title: RETHINKING TRANSIT
description: The Reagan Administration's intent to reduce Federal aid to mass transit and eventually to phase out operating subsidies has alarmed mayors and transportation officials across the country.

title: CHRYSLER SAID TO GET $140 MILLION IN CANADIAN LOAN GUARANTEES
description: A Canadian cabinet committee has given approval in principle for about $140 million (Canadian) in loan guarantees for Chrysler Canada Ltd., Government sources confirmed today.

title: Lane Bryant Details Purchase of Its Stock
description: Lane Bryant Inc. confirmed that it had purchased 907,200 shares, or 19.5 percent, of its common stock from the Hatleigh Corporation and Mico Enterprises, both of Canada, for $20.9 million.

title:
PATENTS;
Instrument Helps Heart Diagnosis
description: An instrument to be used in studies of heart conditions was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration by staff members at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif.

title: OPERA: NEW IN 'TRISTAN'
description: Since the Metropolitan Opera's current revival of ''Tristan und Isolde'' has come in for some harsh criticism, most particularly in the casting department, hopes for better things were pinned on the season's eighth performance Monday night. On this occasion, the lovers were sung by Roberta Knie and Richard Cassilly, both for the first time with the company.

title: 2 MORE CHILDREN ARE FOUND DEAD OUTSIDE ATLANTA
description: The remains of two children were discovered today at opposite ends of the city, intensifying the fear and agony that have gripped Atlanta in recent months over the deaths of 15 young black children and the disappearances of three others. One of the bodies found today was identified as an 11-year-old boy missing since Feb. 6.

title: Petro-Lewis to Buy Occidental Holding
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, a little-known Denver-based oil exploration company, agreed yesterday to pay more than $200 million for most of Occidental Petroleum Corporation's 17 percent interest in a nonproducing oil and gas field off the coast off California.

title: ARGENTINA'S GRAIN CROP IS LARGER
description: Greatly improved Argentine corn and sorghum crops will offer the Soviet Union a chance to buy much larger quantities of feed grains from that country in the spring, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: RULING ALLOWS EX-MEDICAL CHIEF OF FIRE DEPT. TO GET HIS PENSION
description: Dr. Seymour S. Cutler, former chief medical officer of the Fire Department, will be permitted to collect a $17,400-a-year pension as a result of an administrative decision that he did not substantially violate department regulations by maintaining a private medical practice.

title: HISTORIC STATUS EASES 'VILLAGE' GROWTH
description: On Downing Street, an 81-year-old woman who has lived on the same block since she was 5 anxiously awaits the fate of her city-owned building. Terrified that it will be sold to the highest bidder and that a developer will force her out of her lifelong home, she asks angrily: ''Where am I going to go? Why can't they just leave us alone?''

title: U.S. Pledges to Free A Cuban Refugee in Atlanta
description: The Federal Government has agreed to release a Cuban refugee who is the plaintiff in a suit seeking freedom for 1,800 Cuban refugees from Federal prisons.

title: Explosions Disrupt East 55th St.
description: Explosions of undetermined origin beneath East 55th Street in Manhattan shortly after midnight today sent four manhole covers into the air, shattered scores of windows and set off burglar alarms, according to the police and Consolidated Edison. No injuries were reported. A spokesman for Con Edison said the cause of the explosions, on East 55th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues, had not been determined.

title: OFF-DUTY OFFICER IS SHOT IN DISPUTE IN TOPLESS BAR
description: An off-duty policeman was shot in the stomach and seriously wounded yesterday by the owner of a topless bar in Queens. There were two reports by law-enforcement officials on the incident.

title: Rome Police Seize Three As Red Brigades Spokesmen
description: The police arrested two prominent lawyers and the editor of a left-wing magazine today on charges of acting as spokesmen and propagandists for the Red Brigades terrorist organization.

title: SAVE THE WEST SIDE HIGHWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: GRANTS GIVEN TO PHILIP GLASS, ROBERT WILSON
description: The Rockefeller Foundation announced yesterday that it had awarded three-year grants of $90,000 each to Philip Glass, the composer, and Robert Wilson, the playwright, director and designer. These two grants and one of the same magnitude to the playwright Sam Shepard and his Magic Theater in San Francisco in 1979 constitute the largest individual arts awards in the foundation's history.

title: THEATER: 'DANTON'S DEATH' AT LA MAMA
description: Dressed identically in what look like white karate costumes, actors and actresses kneel on the ends of long, wide, intersecting ribbons of cloth and are each formally served a glass of red wine and a piece of bread. They eat the bread, drink the wine and turn over the glasses. Then each person rises and exits, and the cloth is swept away as if it were soiled linen.

title: Kidnapped Tennessee Boy Found Safe 20 Miles Away
description: A 6-year-old boy kidnapped in pajamas from his home by two armed men in ski masks and held for $200,000 ransom was found alive today, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported.

title: HEREWITH, A VALENTINE MESSAGE TO A MARRIAGE
description: LET'S hear it for marriage. That was my first thought as I awakened one morning last week to our 37th wedding anniversary. Never mind that marriage is an old idea, a flawed institution, a crumbling tradition. That all around me married folks are giving up the battle to stay together. That I have friends whose marriage was a disaster and whose only hope for salvation lay in divorce.

title: EXPERTS URGE USE OF A CRITICIZED TUBERCULOSIS VACCINE
description: An antituberculosis vaccine whose efficacy was questioned last year, after a report that it failed to work in a large study in India, should still be used to immunize children against the disease, according to two groups of experts convened by the World Health Organization.

title: OUTLOOK DIM ON ECONOMY
description: WASHNGTON ALREADY trailing the nation as a whole in economic growth and per capita income gains, New Jersey and most of the 18 states of the Northeast and Middle West will continue to lag begin national averages in the next two decades, according to an analysis by the Northeast-Midwest Institute.

title: NO CHANGES SOUGHT ON EXCLUDING ALIENS
description: The Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy has decided not to recommend any change in the law that bars certain classes of aliens, including Communists and homosexuals, from the United States.

title: Gregory J. Blasi Fiance Of Dr. Anne Kossowan
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Kossowan of Hamilton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Anne Carol Kossowan, to Gregory J. Blasi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Blasi of Delray Beach, Fla. A May 2 wedding is planned.

title: Physician Clarifies Statement on Bulemia
description: Sandra Gardner's article of Jan. 25 on bulemia was, in general, clear and accurate.

title: JERSEY SHORTAGE REALLY GOES BACK A LONG WAY
description: The dry spell is entering its eighth month, but that isn't the only reason that about half of New Jersey's 7.3 million people and most of its industry are under mandatory water rationing. Also to blame, say state officials, is a water storage and distribution system that has fostered imbalances in supplies and made correcting them difficult and costly.

title: Margaret L. Brim Bride Of Peter McCabe, Writer
description: Margaret Lowry Brim, a television producer, and Peter McCabe, a writer, were married yesterday at the bridegroom's home in Sag Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Armando Cuellar, rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Sag Harbor, performed the ceremony.

title: N.Y.C. PROBLEM ISN'T SUPPLY, BUT HIGH CONSUMPTION
description: During New York's 1949 drought, Fridays were dubbed ''water holidays,'' a genteel designation for a 24-hour period during which no one was supposed to bathe or shave. A beard was considered a ''badge of honor'' and the Broadway Master Barbers Association asked all its members to eliminate as many shampoos as they could.

title: BEHIND THE BESTSELLERS
description: Richard Simmons, author of the ''Never-Say-Diet Book,'' used to weigh 268 pounds. Then one day, while working as a ''fat model'' in Europe, he says he discovered a note resting under the windshield wiper of his car. It said: ''Fat people die young. Please don't die. Anonymous.'' It was, he says, the inspiration he needed to go on a diet, and today, the five-foot seven-inch Mr. Simmons is a svelte 138 pounds.

title: Reagan Exemptions Make the Budget Fight Even Grittier
description: Budget director David A. Stockman to Congressional liaison Max Friedersdorf during a White House photo opportunity: ''It's really going to be tough to sell. I'll help you all I can.''

title: COMEDY: SHIFFMAN AND VANCE
description: A comedy program that draws from the same type of lode that opened to such skitmasters of bygone years as the Second City is opening the new first-floor cabaret of the Manhattan Theater Club on East 73d Street.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART There are modes of Realism in which the depiction of concrete detail is so concentrated - and so obsessive - that the visual result bears a distinct esthetic kinship to pictorial abstraction. Richard Britell's new paintings at the Staempfli Gallery, 47 East 77th Street, are a particularly vivid example of this phenomenon. Mr. Britell's subject matter is drawn from the world of pre-modernist architecture.

title: Teheran Releases The '53d Hostage'
description: Cynthia Dwyer, unregretful and still, in her husband's word,''irrespressible,'' returned to the United States last week, deported by Teheran after nine months in prison that ended with a conviction for spying.

title: Scientists/Business
description: To the Business Editor:

title: POLISH BEST SELLER: HOW TO OUTWIT THE SECRET POLICE
description: The latest best seller in Poland is a 23-page pamphlet that can fit inside a breast pocket, costs the equivalent of 60 cents and contains the kind of information that has never seen print here before.

title: 17 DIE IN BRAZILIAN SKYSCRAPER FIER
description: At least 17 people were killed and 30 injured today in a fire that swept through a 23-story office building in the heart of Sao Paulo's business district, a police spokesman said.

title: Pedroza Knocks Out Ford, Keeps Featherweight Title
description: Eusebio Pedroza of Panama retained the World Boxing Association featherweight championship today with a 13th-round knockout of Patrick Ford.

title: THE INSCRUTABLE WEST
description: ''WATCH OUT FOR THE FOREIGN GUESTS!'' China Encounters the West. By Orville Schell. 178 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $8.95.

title: Joel Cook Fiance Of Kate P. Biddle
description: Mr. and Mrs. Livingston L. Biddle 3d of Ligonier, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kate Page Biddle, to Joel Hammond Cook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Cook of Kennebunkport, Me.

title: Bruins 5, Kings 4
description: Steve Kasper scored at 3:51 of the final period to give Boston the victory.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Gregory Gelman, Violinist, Presents Bach and Franck
description: It seemed as if two different violinists were playing at Gregory Gelman's debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday night. The first was awkward, his shaky bow arm sounding individual notes without pulse and phrases without rounded breathing.

title: Murdoch Trades Up, Gets a Bargain Too
description: The brief courtship has been rocky and the object of pursuit temperamental. But last week, the labor unions of The Times of London yielded to Rupert Murdoch the concessions they had long refused the previous owner, allowing him to complete his purchase of the newspaper.

title: Connecticut Guide; 'CLOSED ECOSYSTEM'
description: It is possible to raise edible fish in a solar greenhouse, use the waste fish water to nourish the plants, grow algae to feed the fish in another pool and use the sun-warmed water from the pools to help heat the house.

title: Unspoilable Milk
description: Milk that could be stored safely in paper cartons for half a year without refrigeration - that was the promise outlined in early 1978 by a Dallas carton manufacturer, Brik Pak. The milk and its vacuumsealed carton were to be sterile.

title: Donna Koopersmith Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Koopersmith of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Ann Koopersmith, to Neil Jeffrey Jenchol, son of Robert Jenchol of the Bronx and the late Beatrice Jenchal. A September wedding is planned.

title: IN CORPORATE LAW
description: In ancient times, say 30 or 40 years ago, clients went to lawyers like patients go to doctors. They generally established one-on-one relationships, the identity of a lawyer's client being no more ambiguous than the name of the patient on the doctor's examining table.

title: Tax Split
description: ''Corporations merge and diverge strictly for tax benefits, and nobody questions it as a sham,'' David Boyter said. ''Why should couples be treated differently than corporations?''

title: YOUNG POETS SPARK INTEREST IN READINGS
description: and poetry readings in particular - appear to be enjoying renewed popularity. As an example, after five years of struggle, the Phoenix Poetry Series, produced by a group of young poets, is emerging as one of the New Haven area's major poetry forums. It opened its winter season early this month at the New Haven Colony Historical Society, 114 Whitney Avenue, with F.D. Reeve, poet, novelist and playwright who teaches at Wesleyan and Yale universities and is the father of Christopher Reeve, the actor.

title: Sharon Guess Is Fiancee
description: The engagement of Sharon Patricia Guess to Thomas C. Ireland, son of Eunice Ireland of Hyannis, Mass., and the late John F. Ireland, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George J. Guess Jr. of Glen Rock, N.J. Miss Guess is a senior casualty underwriter with the North American Reinsurance Corporation in New York. Her fiance is employed by Sanders Associates in its Ocean System Division in Laconia, N.H.

title: SCHOOL IN HOBOKEN HONES CIRCUS SKILLS
description: HOBOKEN IT TOOK many months of training, but when the time came, the 28-year-old trapeze artist and equilibrist really had her act together. Clad in a purple sequined leotard, Christiane Glover, together with her husband and partner, Philippe Vercruyssen, who is the same age, swung with ease on a trapeze strung from the 25-foot-high ceiling, She then moved on to her balancing act, walking on a large ball up a 20-foot ramp.

title:
On The Isle;
CELLO AT COE HALL
description: Sharon Robinson, one of the leading young lights of the concert stage, will bring her celebrated cello to Coe Hall today for the Friends of the Arts Chamber Music Series. The winner of the 1979 Avery Fisher Award, Miss Robinson, accompanied by Samuel Sanders on piano, will play Beethoven, Rachmaninoff, Chopin and a new work by Ned Rorem based on Shakespeare's poetry. The concert is at 2:30 P.M. at the Planting Fields Arboretum, Planting Fields Road in Oyster Bay. Tickets are $7; members $5. Reservations: 922-0061.CHILDREN'S HOURS

title: AFTER EXILE, SINATRA DOES IT HIS WAY IN LAS VEGAS
description: Richard Bunker, the chairman of the Nevada Gaming Control Board, was nearing the end of a long soliloquy last week about gambling, the prosperity of Nevada and the public's perceptions of Frank Sinatra. Mr. Bunker was the last to speak at a five-hour hearing at which Mr. Sinatra was seeking permission to reenter the gambling business 17 years after he had been banned because of alleged ties to organized crime.

title: BUSINESS CONDITIONS
description: Compared to other businesses that rely on increases in disposable income for rising sales, toy makers did not have a really disastrous year in 1980.

title: Associate Is Held in Kidnapping
description: A woman's business partner was charged today with hiring a man and a teen-ager to kidnap her 6-year-old son. the authorities said. Sam R. Huskey, 34 years old, of Knoxville, was charged with arranging the Thursday night abduction of the child, Zachary Kent Taylor, from the home of his mother, Evelyn Taylor. The child was released unharmed.

title: EMILE FRANCIS BRINGS HIS HIGH-FLYING BLUES TO TOWN
description: EMILE FRANCIS has waited five years and one month for this weekend. Francis, the man who revived the Rangers as their coach and general manager in the 1960's and then was dismissed in 1976, returned to New York as president of the first-place St. Louis Blues.

title: SCULPTURE PROJECT STIRS GLEN COVE
description: GLEN COVE ALTHOUGH no sketches have been prepared, no chisel yet lifted, a proposed sculpture project for Glen Cove's Village Square has already become the focal point of some protests. Money, not esthetics, is the cause.

title: Laetrile Study Finds Cyanide Up, But Toxic Effects Are Minimized
description: Oral doses of laetrile produce higher levels of cyanide in the bloodstream, but the controversial drug produces no serious short-term toxic effects, doctors at the Mayo Clinic reported yesterday.

title: THOMAS'S 'HAMLET'-FRENCH OPERA IN THE 'EPIC' TRADITION
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert Lawrence, conductor, writer and opera specialist, is artistic director of the Friends of French Opera. By ROBERT LAWRENCE

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: A Different South Bronx Paul Newman's new movie ''Fort Apache, the Bronx'' takes an uncompromisingly bleak view of the South Bronx. Virtually all the local residents in the film are prostitutes, pimps, drug addicts and thieves, and this characteristic, of course, is what has made it controversial.

title: Headliners, Philanthropy Made Simple
description: After they're through being angry with him, Ronald Reagan's people may want to recruit Paul Bloom.

title: EAST END PUTTING UP LUXURY HOMES,COUNTERING BUILDING SLUMP
description: EAST HAMPTON WHILE homebuilding on the Island is off more than 80 percent from a peak that ended in 1972, the East End is in the throes of a construction boom that is seeing an appreciable increase in luxury resort units, but a decline in the availability of housing for yearround working-class residents and middle-income residents.

title: Julia Ireland, Actress, Plans June Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Livingston Ireland 3d of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Julia Ireland, to Kevin Boyd McCollum, son of Dr. and Mrs. David H. McCollum of Stafford, England.

title: Theater; 'GOODBYE PEOPLE' NOW A WINNER
description: HUNTINGTON STATION BROADWAY'S two-time loser, ''The Goodbye People,'' comes up a winner at the PAF Playhouse. This is Herb Gardner's comedy drama about an elderly man's impossible dream of reopening his frankfurter-tropical drink stand (''Max's Hawaiian Ecstasies''), which has been closed for ''renovation and remodelization'' for 22 years.

title: CHURCHES CONVENE TO CURB REGULATION
description: Fears that Government intrusion could hamper spiritual freedom brought together 300 representatives of 90 percent of the nation's organized religions for ''possibly the most inclusive such gathering in American history,'' according to William P. Thompson of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., who convened the gathering.

title: RENATO AND ALBIN IN NEW 'CAGE AUX FOLLES'
description: Renato (Ugo Tognazzi) and Albin (Michel Serrault), the determinedly cute homosexual couple of the fantastically successful French film ''La Cage aux Folles,'' are back in a not-quite-all-new comedyadventure, ''La Cage aux Folles II,'' which opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse and other theaters.

title: General Jones Survives the Cut For Reagan's Squad
description: Ever since Inauguration Day, a stream of top-ranking Carter Administration holdovers has walked the plank. Last week, Gen. David C. Jones became a notable exception.

title: THE 'WHY' FOR ONE RUGGER IS THE FAIR COMPETITION
description: RUGBY players are often asked ''Why do you play?'' because of the game's image - that of burly men with missing teeth thumping one another silly in a cross between football and a street brawl, drinking beer and singing bawdy songs afterward, and limping most of the next week.

title: Music View; MYTHS JUST KEEP COMING BACK
description: Historians must feel at times that their struggle to beat back fiction is useless, if not actually a crime against nature. Maybe man needs legends as surely as he needs air, water and empty calories. The urge to throw a mythological haze around past events is so powerful and so prevalent in every age that some kind of primal force must be behind it. Truth, as hard to seize and hold as a raindrop, wants to flow downhill into myth as surely as water wants to flow down to the sea.

title: Flames 4, Sabres 4
description: Dan Labraaten scored three goals, including Calgary's last two, as Calgary rallied in the final period to salvage a tie with Buffalo.

title: BIOSYNTHETIC INSULIN FACES TEST
description: Plans for the first nationwide test of laboratory-produced insulin, hailed by doctors as a major advance in the treatment of diabetes, were announced THursday at the Henry Ford Hospital.

title: STUDENT AT ADELPHI SLAIN BY POLICEMAN
description: An Adelphi University student was shot and killed by a Garden City policeman early this morning during a melee outside an on-campus bar.

title: SCIENTISTS BUSINESS
description: To the Business Editor: Dr. Schulhof lauds the ''scientific approach to problem-solving'' without defining the method or explaining its relevance to long-term planning or productivity upturns. He prizes a scientist's ability ''to concentrate his efforts only on aspects of a problem that have the potential to affect the outcome.'' But he does not note this method's difficulties and shortcomings.

title: GADGETRY INVADES THE UPPER RANKS OF NEW AUDIO EQUIPMENT
description: Looking for ways to hoist itself from its current slump, the American car industry evidently relies on bright ideas. For example, you can now buy a Cadillac with a computer-controlled seat that ''remembers'' your preferred driving position. Somebody else may adjust the seat differently. But when you get back into your car, you just touch a button and the memory-controlled seat will automatically conform itself to your figure. It is hoped, apparently, that this will be recognized as an advance in transportation, even though it would be much cheaper to adjust the seat by hand.

title: BIG SUPLUSES WON IN HOUSE VICTORIES
description: Most of the state's 39 members of the House of Representatives have substantial surpluses of campaign cash, giving them a built-in advantage for the next election.

title: THE SILENT SUFFERING OF EAST TIMOR
description: No doubt there are more remote places, particularly on Timor, an island on the eastern fringe of the far-flung Indonesian archipelago (see map below), but on a Sunday morning last year, the village of Uatolare, inland from East Timor's southern coast, could have served as a metaphor for the end of the world.

title: ROME'S MONUMENTS GO UNDER WRAPS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PAUL HOFMANN, formerly a Times correspondent, lives in Rome. By PAUL HOFMANN

title: Suit Against Lance Is Dimissed
description: A Federal lawsuit charging Bert Lance, budget director under President Carter, and a group of his associates with fraud in an effort to gain control of Financial General Bankshares Inc. has been dismissed. Federal District Judge Oliver T. Gasch on Wednesday dismissed the class action lawsuit that had been filed by a group of Financial General stockholders.

title: Hatchet Waved, Hatchet Buried?
description: Aware of the irony, Prime Minister Robert Mugabe last week sent white-led black troops of the old Rhodesian African Rifles to put down fighting among rival black guerrillas waiting to be, or just integrated into the new Zimbabwe Army. ''I am determined to descend on them like a hammer,'' he said.

title: SCHOOLS GET GRANT TO TREAT ALCOHOLISM
description: ALCOHOLISM prevention programs in Westchester high schools are expanding in an effort to accommodate a sizable waiting list. The latest effort - a $125,000 program to reduce alcohol and smoking abuse at three county high schools - was announced last week by the county's Department of Community Mental Health

title: Home Clinic; WHAT TO DO WHEN A FLUORESCENT LAMP FLICKERS,BLINKS OR HUMS
description: FLUORESCENT lights will generally burn for many hours without needing maintenance, and they cost far less to operate than incandescent lamps of comparable brightness. But they do occasionally develop problems that require minor maintenance - in addition to the obvious need for replacement when they eventually burn out.

title: AN ALCHEMY UNDIMMED BY TIME
description: MOUNT VERNON YEARS ago, when small businesses abounded in America, coffee roasters dotted the metropolitan area. But today, the number has dwindled and, as Herbert Goldstein puts it, ''If it weren't for my three sons who were willing to take over the business, I probably would have sold out to a large conglomerate.''

title: Diane Brophy, Teacher, Married to Charles Spencer 4th
description: Diane Elizabeth Brophy, daughter of John Greene Brophy of Watertown, Conn., and the late Mrs. Brophy, was married yesterday to Charles Eldridge Spencer 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer 3d of Middlebury, Conn. The Rev. John G. Fanning performed the ceremony in St. John of the Cross Roman Catholic Church in Middlebury.

title: No Left Turn for Nonaligned Nations
description: Boldness and clarity weren't expected from a meeting in New Delhi last week of 94 nonaligned countries. But their foreign ministers did resist the strenous attempts of Vietnam, Afghanistan and a minority of others to give nonalignment a definite pro-Soviet cast.

title: EAST HAMPTON EYES NEW WINDMILL RULES
description: EAST HAMPTON BECAUSE two East Hampton artists want to harness wind energy to light and heat their homes on adjoining property here, the town is trying to formulate a windmill ordinance that would legalize a modern-day version of the wide-blade mills that dotted the East End in the 18th and 19th centuries.

title: Nicaragua, Lost and Found
description: The Reagan Administration should be delighted with the first results of its hard-headed pragmatism in Central America. On the way to power, many Republicans insisted that Nicaragua was ''lost,'' its Government incurably Marxist and any American aid out of the question. But all this sounded much too defeatist in Nicaragua, especially to free-enterprise centrists who were counting on help from Washington to halt the leftward slide of an unsteady revolution.

title: Art; BUT JUST WHAT DOES ALL THIS MEAN?
description: YONKERS THE Hudson River Museum has for some years been one of Westchester's two major cultural attractions, with the Neuberger at Purchase being the other. Most of the credit for this goes to Richard Koshalek who, during his four years as the museum's director, not only made it solvent, but altered its exhibition policy radically.

title: 30 YOUNG DANCERS GET THE BIG CHANCE
description: PRINCETON ONE BY ONE for three hours, the young men and women stepped onto the stage, and one by one - and fighting back anxiety - they danced for four judges sitting in the center of the darkened auditorium. Microphones and television cameras recorded them.

title: NATIONAL MOOD HELPS SHAPE CONGRESS COMMITTEES
description: As Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. walked through the halls of the Capitol recently, he was approached by two freshman lawmakers with the same request: They wanted appointments to the Select Committee on Aging, which considers problems of the elderly.

title: TO ELLA GRASSO, LIFE WAS A CHALLENGE
description: During a blizzard in 1978, Ella Grasso started out in a State Police car for the Armory in Hartford to direct rescue work, but the car got stuck in the deep snow on Farmington Avenue, a mile from the building.

title: IS IT OR ISN'T IT A NURSERY SCHOOL
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE IF children from the ages of 2 1/2 to 4 go to a facility three and a half days a week and receive supervised instruction, are they attending a nursery school?

title: Mary B. Carton Is Wed To Daniel S. Gregory Jr.
description: Mary Bradford Carton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence A. Carton of Lake Forest, Ill., was married there yesterday to Daniel S. Gregory Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory of Westwood, Mass. The Rev. Frederick W. Phinney performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Eileen Smith, Scott Oakford Plan Nuptials
description: Eileen Lloyd Smith and Scott Isdale Oakford, both of New York, plan to be married May 16.

title: Patricia Hearst Plans Appeal
description: Patricia Hearst Shaw, the newspaper heiress, will ask the United States Supreme Court to overturn her 1976 conviction on San Francisco bank robbery charges, her attorney has said. The petition, to be filed Feb. 23, will be based on Mrs. Shaw's contention that F.Lee Bailey, who represented her at the trial, had a conflict of interest because he had a contract for a book about the case.

title: NEW YORK STATE LED IN U.S. AID RECEIVED IN 1980
description: New York continues to rank first among the 50 states in Federal dollar aid received, obtaining $9.47 billion in 1980, or $600 million more than in 1979. But it dropped from fourth to sixth place in per capita aid, according to new figures from the Treasury Department.

title: Anne Dunn Bride Of F.C. Lawrance
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., yesterday, Anne Dudley Dunn and Francis Cooper Lawrance, both of Southport, were married by the Rev. Ray H. Averett Jr.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Like their counterparts in other cities, New York officials are apprehensively awaiting the budget cuts that President Reagan will ask from Congress this week. The ranks of the watchful include the staff of the State's Financial Control

title: BIG SALES CREATE SENSE OF WONDER AMONG BROKERS
description: The limousine glided to a stop at 120 East End Avenue and a blond, tanned woman got out, followed by a tall gentleman wearing dark glasses. They took the elevator to a top floor, where the doors opened upon a spacious foyer.

title: RUTGERS TO SALUTE A DISTINGUISHED SON
description: NEWARK PAUL ROBESON will be the subject of a day-long symposium next Saturday at the Rutgers-Newark building named for him. Paul Robeson Jr. is expected to be among the participants at the session, which will be held at the Robeson Campus Center, 350 High Street.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PHILADELPHIA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- DONALD JANSON is a Times reporter who lives in Swarthmore, Pa. By DONALD JANSON

title: A SOVIET ENVOY DENIES MOSCOW SUPPLIES ARMS TO SALVADOR GUERRILLAS
description: A senior Soviet representative denied today that Moscow was supplying arms to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador but conceded that the Kremlin was sending arms to Cuba and Ethiopia without putting any restrictions on transshipments to other countries.

title: TAXES DOWN HOME
description: As the push to lower Federal income taxes gathers momentum, a recent analysis shows that Americans paid an average of $934 to state and local governments for the 1979 fiscal year, up $46 from the previous period. This was more than double the average amount paid in 1970.

title: Walter E. Clark, 75, a Co-founder Of Boarding School in Lake Placid
description: Walter E. Clark, who was the co-founder with his wife, Leonora, of the North Country School in Lake Placid, N.Y., died Thursday in San Juan, P.R. Mr. Clark, who was a resident of Keene, N.Y., was 75 years old.

title: VANDALS PLAGUE FUNDAMENTALIST CHURCH IN 'VILLAGE'
description: A small fundamentalist church in Greenwich Village whose pastor has vocally denounced homosexuality, abortion, sex education and the proposed equal rights amendment was vandalized twice last week.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Coat Clearances At Dress Barn Chain
description: Dress Barn is a women's apparel chain with 34 branches, including those called Clothes Barn in New Jersey. This year at least 10 more are planned there, in Massachussetts and in Connecticut. Most of the 17 stores in this state are in Fairfield County. There are four in Westchester and one in Putnam County.

title: TWO INFLUENTIAL PURVEYORS OF HARD-CORE FUNK
description: Funk permeates popular music. There's funk in hits by the Bee Gees and Barbra Streisand; there's funk in the glossy poprock of Steely Dan, the harder rock of the Rolling Stones, and the more experimental rock of the Talking Heads. There's funk in most varieties of black pop and disco. And there's a musical genre called funk which emphasizes whatever it is that makes music funky.

title: HAIKU, TANKA, HOKKU, SENRYU, CHOKA
description: 8 FROM THE COUNTRY OF EIGHT ISLANDS An Anthology of Japanese Poetry. Edited and Translated by Hiroaki Sato and Burton Watson. Introduction by Thomas Rimer. Associate Editor Robert Fagan. 652 pp. Cloth. Seattle: University of Washington Press. $17.50. Paper. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $9.95.

title: GONE FISHING-WITH A FRIEND
description: A YEAR has passed since Jimmy Durante died in Santa Monica, Calif., at the age of 86. A giant in his day, he will always be remembered for his ability to make one laugh.

title: SUKHOTHAI, SIAM'S ANCIENT CAPITAL
description: The very name - Sukhothai - had promised enchantment throughout more than a decade of frequent visits and occasional residence in Thailand. But in all those years the idea of a round trip by road of 460 miles from Bangkok had deterred me. And I had never met anyone who had actually visited the fabled city, the first capital of Siam, which lasted only a bit more than a century and yet fixed many of the directions of Thailand's culture, art and statecraft. The Thais do most of their sightseeing away from Asia, and Sukhothai is not yet on the well-trodden tourist path.

title: ANDREW ALFOELDI
description: Prof. Andrew Alfoeldi, an authority on Roman history and a memberemeritus of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., died Thursday at Princeton Hospital.

title: SURVIVAL INTERNATIONAL: LAST HOPE FOR TRIBES
description: More than 20 years ago, an Oxford-educated Irishman embarked on a career of exploration in which he traversed the widest part of South America by jeep, explored 6,000 miles of the Amazon, climbed the Himalayas, and crossed Indo-China and the Far East.

title: BIGGEST QUAKE IN 16 YEARS STRIKES PACIFIC NORTHWEST
description: An earthquake aftershock startled many residents of western Washington this afternoon, less than a day after the Pacific Northwest's largest earthquake in 16 years rattled dishes and shook pictures on walls from northern California to British Columbia.

title: THE WRONGS OF PASSAGE
description: LITTLE BOY BLUE By Edward Bunker. 301 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: M.I.T. Tuition Rising to $7,400, Above Harvard and Yale Figures
description: Tuition at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, increasing for the 12th consecutive year, will rise July 1 by $1,200, from $6,200 to $7,400.

title: Diane Sherlock Fiancee of Alfred Lewis 3d
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul Sherlock have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Linda Sherlock, to Alfred Baker Lewis 3d, son Mary Elizabeth Lewis and Dr. Lewis Jr., both of New York.

title: JERRY LEWIS SETTLES SUIT
description: Jerry Lewis will pay the Hellzapoppin Company, in which Alexander H. Cohen, the theater producer, is a general partner, $39,000 to settle a claim arising out of losses incurred when Mr. Lewis allegedly refused to rehearse adequately for Mr. Cohen's 1977 Broadway-bound play, ''Hellzapoppin.'' The producer closed the updated version of the pre-World War II Olsen and Johnson musical after its Boston run at a loss of more than $1.2 million.

title: PINELANDS OFFICIAL AWAITS ORDERS
description: MEDFORD ''ABSTAIN.'' That was the response of the newest member of the state's Pinelands Commission on every issue that came up for a vote on Feb. 6, the date of his first meeting as a commissioner.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
N.J. Compromise On Gun Control
description: It seems like common sense to many Americans and easier for politicians to advocate than an outright ban on handguns: criminals who use guns should go straight to jail - no plea bargaining, no suspended sentences. But while laws to that effect are becoming increasingly common, there is serious doubt over whether they make any difference in crime rates.

title: Burger Sounds the Charge on Crime
description: Nobody ever accused Chief Justice Warren E. Burger of being soft on crime. But last week he surprised even many lawyers when he took off the gloves in a speech to the American Bar Association in Houston, calling for urgent measures to combat a ''reign of terror in American cities'' and urging an overhaul of a failed criminal justice system.

title: ATLANTA INQUIRY ALTERED AS MORE YOUTHS ARE FOUND SLAIN
description: In the most dramatic week of developments since the start of investigations into the disappearances of black children here, the remains of two more youngsters were found, the scope of the investigation was changed and the leadership of the special investigating team was reshuffled.

title: Last Testament On Human Rights
description: Ernest Lefever, the Reagan Administration's choice for Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, has condemned ''public preaching to friend or foe.'' But whether he likes it or not, Congress has directed the office he is to head to assess foreign countries' records on rights.

title: PROBLEMS IN APPLIED MATHEMATICS
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE ATTRACTING MORE MANUFACTURERS FROM ABROAD
description: HARTFORD CONNECTICUT ranks as one of the states most preferred by manufacturers from other countries who are establishing facilities in the United States.

title: A CULT FOLLOWER SUES PARENTS AND 4 OTHERS IN ALLEGED ABDUCTION
description: A 27-year-old woman filed suit last week in Buffalo against her parents and four ''deprogrammers,'' alleging that she was kidnapped and held for a month to prevent her from returning to a center for transcendental meditation.

title: SHOP MIXES ANTIQUES AND KNITS
description: In the last few months a number of uptown and downtown stores have opened that offer a particularly serendipitous mix of merchandise - clothing and furniture. But the one that seems to successfully combine these disparate worlds in the most winning manner is a charming little place called James D. Mittens & Co.

title:
Antiques;
NEWARK MUSEUM SLATES LECTURES FOR COLLECTORS
description: NEWARK IF YOU are interested in china, jewelry or cut glass, a series of lectures at the Newark Museum may point you in the right direction for buying and collecting antique pieces. The lectures get under way on Feb. 25.

title: 750 Attend Klan Rally For Fishermen in Texas
description: About 750 people today attended a Ku Klux Klan-sponsored fish fry and cross-burning ceremony to support Texas fishermen protesting increased competition from Vietnamese refugees.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on Hugo Montenegro by the Associated Press in some editions of The Times last Sunday incorrectly credited the scores for the films ''The Good, the Bad and the Ugly,'' ''A Fistful of Dollars'' and ''For a Few Dollars More.'' The scores and themes were composed by Ennio Morricone.

title: Geoffrey Caswell Fiance of Madge Williams
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hatcher C. Williams of Dyke, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Madge Ray Williams, to Geoffrey Chase Cameron Caswell of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Cameron Caswell of Darien, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: IN PARIS, STREET MUSICIANS ARE CHANGING THE TEMPO
description: This is a good town for fiddlers. In any given week, Isaac Stern may turn up, or Henryk Szeryng, or Itzhak Perlman. But even if they are not around, there is a good chance you can catch Vinh Pham at the Concorde or Joseph Townsend at Le Forum des Halles.

title: BASQUE'S DEATH IN JAIL BRINGS CALL FOR MASS STRIKE
description: Basque nationalists called today for a general strike in their region to protest the death of a suspected Basque terrorist while he was being held by the Madrid police.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Barrett
description: Patricia E. Barrett, a vice president of Citibank N.A., and Donald B. da Parma, a partner in the New York law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan, were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland performed the ceremony.

title: THE ELECTRIC MUSICIAN
description: THE ODYSSEY OF AN AMERICAN COMPOSER. The Autobiography of Otto Luening. Illustrated. 605 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $22.50. By DONAL HENAHAN

title: Barbara Davidoff Colman Wed
description: Barbara Davidoff Colman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Davidoff of Elmont, L.I., was married at the Central Synagogue yesterday to Dr. Martin Weintraub, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Weintraub of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman officiated. Previous marriages of the couple ended in divorce.

title: NUMBER POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: Cat craze. According to the ''Guinness Book of World Records,'' the United States now has a cat population of 23 million - a statistic that suggests that feline fanciers are one of this country's fastest growing minorities. The rage has been accompanied by a rapidlylengthening shelf of books - 200 at last count - that deal with the lovely, lovable, often vexingly independent creatures. Some are designed to provide information, others merely to amuse. Three of the latter sort, collections of cartoons, have brought their authors overnight fame and fortune.
