description: U.C.L.A. Holds Off Arizona State, 64-61

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: FLORA TRISTAN'S LONDON JOURNAL, 1840 Translated by Dennis Palmer and Giselle Pincetl. Illustrated. 259 pp. Charlestown, Mass.: Charles River Books. $20.

title: No Headline
description: My reply to the author of ''The Only-Child Phenomenon'' is that ... I, too, was an only child - but not the favored one! LARRY GOLDEN, Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: Steve Lohr's really first-class article is flawed by one error. Rising oil costs post-1973 were not more difficult for the United States than for Western Europe and Japan.

title: GOVERNMENTS BUILDING FOR U.N. DELEGATIONS
description: Like many New Yorkers, foreign diplomatic families are discovering that the apartments they rented years back are about to be turned into cooperatives. Some governments are reluctant to purchase this expensive housing at the same time that they must bear rising rental costs for consulates, trade and diplomatic missions.

title: BLACK SCHOOL GROUP EXHORTS PARENTS
description: MONTCLAIR THE large yellow button in Willie Troy's lapel proclaims him a member of the New Jersey Association of Black Educators. Mr. Troy, a General Motors production supervisor, has never been a teacher, but he believes so strongly in the association's motto - ''Education Breaks the Chains of Ignorance'' -that he always wears his button.

title: JAZZ: DIZZY GILLESPIE'S DREAM BAND AND HIS BOB FIVE
description: Dizzy Gillespie, the trumpeter who helped break new ground in jazz with the creation in the 1940's of be-bop and who was a leading figure in mixing Latin and African-American musical elements, will be the focus of two concerts at Lincoln Center Monday night.

title: D'AMATO SUPPORTS RAISING AGE FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has decided to support an increase in the age for Social Security eligibility. Without increasing the age for collecting payments to age 68 or thereabouts from the current 65, the Social Security system would run unsupportably high deficits, he said.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Journal
description: OSSINING may become a tourist center with 50,000 to 100,000 visitors a year spending $1,000,000 or more if a bill now before the State Legislature is passed to provide ''urban cultural parks'' in 14 communities around the state.

title: FIRE CLAIMS A SHORE LEGEND
description: BAY HEAD HE HAD a face like an eagle, except when he smiled, and skin like bleached saddle leather. His face had a wrinkle etched in it for every port he had visited in 75 years and his hands bore the creases of a million boat lines.

title: Scholars Have Their Innings
description: Forget, for a moment, the contributions to baseball history of Ruth, of Cobb, of DiMaggio, of the San Diego Chicken. Consider, instead, the baseball niches occupied by Joe Bauman, Harry Stovey and, yes, Jayne Mansfield. The Baseball Research Journal certainly has.

title: Operator Error Blamed For a Nuclear Accident
description: DAISY, Tenn., Feb. 14 (UPI) - An operator error has been blamed for a nuclear plant accident that set off an emergency alert and sent 100,000 gallons of radioactive water raining down on 13 workers at the plant.

title: A BRILLIANT KING'S TOUR
description: Brilliancy prizes have been given for glorious queen sacrifices, for subtle piece sacrifices that bear fruit only many moves later, and for cascades of sacrifices that overwhelm the opponent with nonstop power. But who ever heard of getting the palm for a successful king run through a minefield?

description: Max Robinson, the co-anchor on ABC's ''World News Tonight'' who was quoted as having told a college audience Monday that ABC News had discriminated against him and other black journalists, issued a statement yesterday claiming the report, by The Morning Union in Springfield, Mass., was a ''distortion of my remarks.'' The newspaper has said it stands by its story.

title: ALL AROUND THE TOWN: MISSONI
description: They've been called everything from ''collectable wardrobe classics'' by a man who owns several to ''uppity snob apparel'' by a man who owns none at all.

title: Pact for Sale of Forest Reported
description: The Federal Government has agreed to purchase 10,000 acres of forest in this area and plans to make it part of the Green Mountain National Forest, local officials said. The tract would increase the size of the forest to almost 64,000 acres. The $1.8 million deal is expected to be closed within several weeks, the officials said.

title: BUSINESSMEN WHO PRAY TOGETHER
description: I T'S eight o'clock on Tuesday morning in the seventh-floor private dining room of the New York Stock Exchange. Twenty businessmen - stock brokers, floor traders, analysts, lawyers and investment bankers - wander in. Opening their briefcases, each removes a Bible.

description: This is a dummy item ... This is a dummy item ... DELETE! William Safire 11 On Language Beyond Compare Russell Baker 16 Sunday Observer The Dreamer's Progress James Atlas 23 The Private Hemingway Henry Kamm 34 The Silent Suffering of East Timor Since it was abandoned by Portugal in 1975, East Timor has undergone revolution, civil war, invasion by neighboring Indonesia and famine. The tragic toll of Timorese lives lost is estimated to be upward of 100,000.

title: TORONTO REJECTS STUDY OF RAIDS ON HOMOSEXUAL BATHS
description: This city's Board of Police Commissioners has decided not to investigate police raids on four homosexual bathhouses that led to a downtown demonstration.

description: A $160 million plant here will make ethanol from municipal garbage and from agricultural, industrial and forest wastes, using a process developed by the Gulf Oil Chemicals Company and the University of Arkansas Biomass Research Center.

title: Tests Show Police Bullet Killed a Harlem Grocer
description: The police said yesterday that ballistics tests showed that a bullet that killed an East Harlem grocer during an attempted robbery early Thursday evening had been fired by a police officer.

title: Manila Presses Hunt for Priests
description: The Defense Ministry has offered rewards of $4,000 each for the capture, dead or alive, of two Filipino ''rebel'' priests, military sources said today. They alleged that the priests, identified as Conrado Balweg, a Roman Catholic in his mid-30's, and Cesar Barona, whose denomination was not immediately known, had sided with Communist guerrillas.

title: Fur Dealer's Price List Prompts A Warning to the Owners of Cats
description: A price list circulated by a fur dealer has prompted the Bucks County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals to warn pet owners to keep a close watch on their cats.

title: 3 EGGSHELLS OVER THE QUOTA
description: AS responsible citizens, we must not underestimate the importance of garbage. Gradually it is becoming more prominent in our daily lives. Twenty-five years ago garbage was strictly refuse to be disposed of, without any particular significance. Today, garbage is a vital force, contributing to the emotional highs and lows of millions.

title: Jack Glenn, News Film Director And Producer of Documentaries
description: Jack Glenn, a former senior director of the March of Time news films and a documentary film maker, died Thursday after a brief illness at Cabrini Medical Center. He lived in New York City and was 76 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Photography View column in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday, an incorrect closing date was given for the exhibition of photography by Manuel Alvarez Bravo and Wright Morris at the Witkin Gallery. It closes March 7.

title: VILAS TOPPLES GERULAITIS
description: John McEnroe and Guillermo Vilas, both of whom who failed in their last two quests for the Pepsi Grand Slam of Tennis, advanced to the clay-court final today with impressive victories.

title: American Sex
description: Although many mourn a decline of quality in American goods and services, two commodities are generally deemed to have improved: food and sex.

title: ISRAELI FANS TURN OUT TO CHEER ON BIBLE SCHOLARS
description: Occupied West Bank - As the tournament begins, cheers cascade down from the spectators to the contestants participating in what some view as Israel's national pastime.

title: SOLIDARITY MATURES AS A MASS MOVEMENT IN NEW CLASS STRUGGLE
description: ''People believe in socialism. The only problem is that some people at the top cannot believe that the people really believe in socialism.'' Adam Wendorf, Communist Party secretary at the Elmor factory in Gdansk.

title: No Headline
description: Residents of Port Jervis began returning to their homes today to survey the damage caused when tons of ice and water from the Delaware River inundated low-lying residential and commercial areas. The flooding early Thursday forced 3,000 people to flee their homes.

title: CONFESSIONS OF AN AUSTRALIAN CHARMER
description: UNRELIABLE MEMOIRS By Clive James. 171 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.

title: Dining Out; CHINESE, AND IT'S ALL SEAFOOD
description: ABOUT two months ago, Secret Sea, one of the most unusual Chinese restaurants in the New York area and quite possibly in the entire country, opened in Manhasset. It is a Chinese seafood restaurant.

title: WIZARDS, 5 DANCERS ON WHEELS
description: Some of the best dancing in New York may be seen in the city's roller rinks and on the sidewalks where the summer skaters go. And so the lure of the Wizards, a popular ''rollerdancin' '' company seen on Friday at the Symphony Space, was great.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: On a typical Saturday night, at a cocktail party somewhere in the ivy-covered halls of Wellesley College, one often finds ambitious young Harvard men who describe themselves as being on ''shark mode.'' LISA RACHELLE DI MASI, Wellesley, Mass.

title: Ruth Sloan Engaged to John Derr Jr., Medical Student
description: The engagement of Ruth Buckwalter Sloan, daughter of Mrs. H. Paul Sloan Jr. of Rye, N.Y., and Pentwater, Mich., and the late Rev. Dr. Sloan, to John William Derr Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Derr of Pleasant Ridge, Mich., has been announced by the future bride's mother. An April 25 wedding is planned at the Drayton Avenue Presbyterian Church in Ferndale, Mich., where Dr. Sloan was minister for nearly 20 years.

title: SCHWEIKER IS WRONG ON TEEN PREGNANCY
description: Jr. PHILADELPHIA -Secretary of Health and Human Services Richard S. Schweiker has announced his opposition to Federal programs of sex education and to using Medicaid funds for providing birth-control assistance. It was not clear whether his news conference statement represented Administration policy or merely his personal sentiments. In either case, one can only presume that he believes that the Carter Administration's approach to the problem of adolescent childbearing was ineffective, or, as some conservatives have complained, retrogessive because Government programs license sexual activity and weaken family authority.

title: On Language; BEYOND COMPARE
description: Beyond Compare Kimble Mead

title: Art View; TWO ILLUMINATING STYLES OF THE LATE 1950'S
description: The art galleries just now are fairly bursting with exhibitions of new art, and both the Whitney and the Guggenheim Museums are currently crammed with it. Yet, as it happens, two of the most interesting exhibitions at the moment are devoted to paintings from the 1950's. One is Alex Katz's show at the Robert Miller Gallery. The other is Gene Davis's at the Frank Kolbert Gallery. They offer us very different experiences, of course. Mr. Katz's paintings are figurative - mainly portraits, in fact. Mr. Davis's are abstract. They differ in weight, too. Mr. Katz's paintings are wholly realized, and strike us as representing by far the more solid accomplishment, whereas Mr. Davis's are more in the nature of a quest - a search for some firm artistic ground he could call his own. Yet both these exhibitions afford us an illuminating perspective on the art of the late 50's - on the breakdown of Abstract Expressionist orthodoxy and the ensuing scramble for alternative styles. They thus provide the kind of perspective we are unlikely to find in textbook accounts of the period.

title: TELEVISION'S DAY IN COURT
description: It was by no means the most dramatic televised trial. Like the vast majority of trials covered by television cameras, the trial of two Miami Beach police officers, Noel Chandler and Robert Granger, accused of committing a burglary, was of only local interest and got a total of less than three minutes exposure on WPLG's news programs. But because the accused had objected to the presence of a single camera in the rear of the courtroom, Chandler and Granger v. the State of Florida became the test case that led to last month's unanimous decision by the Supreme Court of the United States which declared that the televising of trials, even in the face of a defendant's objection, is within the bounds of the Constitution. The ruling neither endorsed nor opposed television in the courtroom. It simply said that it was constitutional for states to experiment if they so choose.

title: REAGAN: A KEY TO THE PRIMARY
description: RONALD REAGAN could be the most important figure in the current campaign for Governor of New Jersey. His victory last November has raised the spirits of the state's minority party -the Republicans - so high that the Democrats look like the underdogs going into the fight.

title: WOMEN PLAYWRIGHTS SHOW NEW STRENGTH
description: For years, women playwrights were a silent minority. They were insecure, filled with feminine guilt or in hiding; they were infrequently produced, especially on Broadway. Today, women playwrights are prolific and their plays are ubiquitous, appearing with regularity in regional theater, Off Off Broadway, Off Broadway and in the bright spotlight of Broadway itself. Currently, there are three plays by women on Broadway, and a fourth, Susan Nanus's ''The Survivor,'' begins previews this week. Leading the others promised for later this season is Beth Henley's ''Crimes of the Heart,'' after its highly acclaimed engagement at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: Sokolow Dance Program Will Focus on Jewish Life
description: A company of dancers and actors under the direction of Anna Sokolow will perform a program dedicated to the traditions and experiences of the Jewish people on March 18 at 8 P.M. at the concert hall of the Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street. The program includes Miss Sokolow's ''From the Diaries of Franz Kafka'' and ''Excerpts from the Old Testament.''

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Owners Continue Football's 'Big Lie' On Fan Support
description: To the Sports Editor: Dave Anderson's condemnation of Al Davis for trying to move the Oakland Raiders (Sports of The Times, Jan. 13) is well put but does not go nearly far enough. In particular, his contention that ''other franchises have been moved with justification when the people in a city no longer cared'' reflects the Big Lie of the sports owners: that teams almost always do not get the support they deserve.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE The week opens and closes with performances by two always interesting women choreographers. Sunday, there's Elizabeth Streb at the American Theater Laboratory in three works that have some of the risk, stamina and high energy of athletics. A deft and elegant pure-dance performer with a vivid stage personality, Miss Streb would never be mistaken for a hundred-meter dasher.

title: OFFICIALS AT ODDS OVER MISSILE PLAN
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and the Air Force appear to be on a collision course over the basing of the proposed MX intercontinental missile.

title: JOH TATE: OUT TO PROVE HE BELONGS IN THE RING
description: THE last time John Tate was seen in a boxing ring, his head lay flat on the apron and one leg twitched ominously. Death was in the air that night in Montreal: Cleveland Denny had been pounded toward his final coma by Gaetan Hart, and John Tate a former champion - lay quivering in the ring.

title: MURDOCH
description: Rupert Murdoch bought the prestigious Times of London and The Sunday Times last week after winning a union accord to abolish more than 600 jobs and allow the introduction of computerized printing methods.

title: JAZZ: BERG AND HARRELL
description: Jazz Forum, which began holding weekend jazz sessions a year and a half ago at 50 Cooper Square, moved last week to new and spacious quarters at 648 Broadway, near Bleecker Street. Mark Morganelli, the founder of Jazz Forum, celebrated the occasion with an unprecedented (for Jazz Forum) four-day engagement of a jazz group, the Bob Berg & Tom Harrell Quintet, which is playing at the New Forum through tonight.

title: TWO MEN ARE SEEKING TO DETERMINE IF THEY ARE THE LINDBERGH BABY
description: Forty-nine years have passed since the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., son of the pioneering trans-Atlantic flier. The case continues to haunt many minds, including those of government officials who in an age of freedom-of-information laws must respond to questioners.

title: Houston Symphony Sets July Tchaikovsky Festival
description: The Houston Symphony will present a Tchaikovsky festival in the summer, featuring all the composer's symphonies, piano concertos and some of his ballet music.

title: KNICKS ARE BURSTING WITH WINNING SPIRIT
description: Mike Saunders, the trainer, tended to Michael Ray Richardson, who was sprawled over the training table. Marvin Webster discussed a wager he had made with Willis Reed that he was a better shooter than the former Knick captain. Bill Cartwright talked about good cigars with General Manager Eddie Donovan. Campy Russell watched a replay of a Detroit Piston-Seattle SuperSonic game, and Sly Williams read some fan mail.

title: House Allowed Own Post Office
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has rejected an appeal by Dexter W. Daughtry, a former House mail clerk found guilty of possessing stolen mail, who had asked the court to throw out his conviction on the ground that laws governing mail theft could not apply to the House Post Office because it was not run by the United States Postal Service. In a ruling Thursday, the three-judge panel said the House of Representatives got so much mail that it had a right to operate its own post office.

title: OTHER BUSINESS President; REAGAN'S GLOOMY CHARTMAKER
description: President Reagan went on television 10 days ago to brace the country for the economic program he'll unveil on Wednesday. He painted a bleak picture then, but are things really so bad?

title: Four Leading Cases A.T.&T.
description: Justice Department sought breakup of Bell System including sale of all 23 operating companies and Western Electric. But proposed settlement reportedly requires sale of just three subsidiaries and parts of Western Electric.

title: FAMILY TROUBLE
description: MEETING ROZZY HALFWAY By Caroline Leavitt. 294 pp. New York: Seaview Books. $11.95.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: f718 WHO'S ON FIRST, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Avon, $2.95.) C.I.A. agent Blackford Oakes gets deeply embroiled in the 1950's race to put a satellite in orbit, a contest that involves a Hungarian freedom fighter, a Russian physicist, a K.G.B. archfiend, an indolent United States Government and a completely evil U.S.S.R. In his review, Newgate Callendar remarked that this thriller had a pungent, swiftly moving plot, but that most of its fun lay in its witty asides that reflect the personal beliefs and politics of one William F. Buckley Jr.

title: Patricia Ruhl Graffin, Singer, Is Wed to John Stearns Rath
description: Patricia Ruhl Graffin, widow of George Davies Graffin, was married at noon yesterday to John Stearns Rath, a widower of New York and Litchfield, Conn.

title: MIAMI'S TOURISM HOPES HIGH DEPITE RAIN AND COLD
description: For the last several days, intermittent rain has been falling in this area, which earlier this season suffered the longest cold spell in its recent history.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1981
description: International Lech Walesa was confident that his union would cooperate with the Polish Government's appeal for 90 days of labor peace. ''I'm confident everything will work out,'' he said following a meeting with Mieczyslaw Rakowski, the new Deputy Prime Minister in charge of local affairs. The Solidarity union has scheduled a special meeting Wednesday to consider the Government's appeal. Union leaders said privately that they believed it would be accepted. (Page 1, Column 6.) Moscow is not arming leftist guerrillas in El Salvador, the Soviet Embassy's second-ranking diplomat in Washington said, but the diplomat, Vladilen M. Vasev, acknowledged that the Soviet Union sent arms to Cuba and their being sent on to other countries. (1:5.)

title: Icebreaker Is Stuck in Arctic Sea With a Damaged Steering Device
description: The icebreaker Polar Sea is stuck in an ice flow in the Arctic Sea with a damaged steering mechanism, a pilot for the United States Coast Guard said today.

title:
Dining Out;
APPEARANCE,ALAS,ISN'T ON THE MENU
description: THE Villa D'Este in Cedar Grove bears little resemblance to the famous 16th-century Villa D'Este near Tivoli, Italy, with its lovely terraces and staircases. However, the Cedar Grove namesake is an Italian restaurant that, notwithstanding the statues in the parking lot, has a surprisingly understated and elegant interior.

title: 2 ACCUSED OF STEALING TIME ON A SCHOOL'S COMPUTER
description: Two former directors of the computer department at the New York Institute of Technology have been charged with illegally using the school's computer in a data storage scheme that netted them at least $40,000, according to Denis E. Dillon, the Nassau County District Attorney.

title: Perot 2, Iran 0
description: Still another unsettling ingredient was stirred into Teheran's political cauldron last week - the possibility that some elements of the agreement that freed the embassy hostages may come unstuck. In a preliminary ruling, a Federal District judge in Dallas said that the Government could not, as provided, block court orders or lawsuits against Iran.

title: OFFICIAL NATIONAL LEAGUE BASEBALL SCHEDULE FOR 1981
description: CHICAGO HOMES GAMES April 9, 11, 12Mets 24, 25, 26Phillies 28, 29Cardinals May 1, 2, 3Braves 4, 5, 6, 7Astros 19, 20, 21Reds 22, 23, 24Expos 25, 26, 27, 28Pirates June 5, 6, 7Dodgers 9, 10, 11Giants 12, 13, 14Padres 23, 24, 25Phillies July 3, 4+, 5, 6Cardinals 7, 8, 9Expos 16, 17, 18Braves 19, 20Astros 31Reds August 1, 2Reds 10, 11, 12, 13Mets 14, 15, 16Pirates 17, 18, 19Dodgers 21, 22, 23Giants 24, 25, 26Padres September 11, 12, 13Expos 15, 16Pirates 21, 22Cardinals 23, 24Mets 25, 26, 27Phillies ROAD GAMES April 14, 15, 16Expos 17*, 18*, 19Phillies 20, 21, 22Cardinals May 8*, 9*, 10Braves 12*, 13*, 14*Reds 15*, 16*, 17Astros 29*, 30, 31Mets June 2*, 3*, 4*Pirates 15*, 16*Dodgers 17, 18Giants 19*, 20*, 21Padres 26*, 27*, 28Expos 29*, 30*Mets July 1*, 2Mets 10*, 11*, 12+Pirates 21*, 22*, 23*Braves 24*, 25*, 26Reds 27*, 28*, 29*Astros August 4*, 5*, 6*Phillies 27*, 28*, 29*, 30Dodgers 31*Padres September 1*, 2*Padres 3, 4*, 5, 6Giants 7, 8*, 9*Cardinals 18*, 19, 20Expos 28*, 29*Pirates 30*Mets October 1*Mets 2*, 3*, 4Phillies

title: 2 More Meningitis Cases Found
description: Doctors have diagnosed two more cases of meningitis, involving a 3-year-old boy still hospitalized and a 17-year-old who recovered, but they say that the new cases were unrelated to a school outbreak that caused serious concern. The cases diagnosed yesterday raised the number in Houston and Harris County this year to 38. But officials said the new cases were unrelated to an unprecented clustering of five cases at Dodson Elementary School.

title: TOLL RISES TO 49 DEAD, 129 INJURED IN BLAZE AT DANCE HALL IN DUBLIN
description: The toll in an early-morning fire that engulfed a popular Dublin discotheque today rose to 49 dead and 129 injured. Many of the victims were teen-agers who were among 800 young people attending a dance competition.

title: Mailbox; Super Bowl Sites Stir Cold Reaction And a Suggestion
description: To the Sports Editor: Now that the euphoria of Super Bowl XV is over, I believe it is time for the commissioner to reassess the need to have this annual game played in warm-weather sites or domed stadiums.
To the Editor:

title: David Perry Sings, Plays Lute and Guitar
description: In this much-deplored age of specialization, David Perry is a jack of at least two trades. In his Goodman House recital of Tudor and contemporary music last Saturday evening, he not only played the lute and the guitar but sang to his own accompaniments.

title: BOCA RATON, Fla.
description: The BocaWest resort community here has something new - luxurious duplex houses, each with a private pool 12 feet by 20 feet in its backyard. They will sell for $175,000 to $240,000, said William J. Lee, director of residential development. The only connection between the side-by-side houses will be the wall separating the garages. Occupants will hardly be aware their house is attached to another.

title: Bridge; A COMEDY OF ERRORS
description: In any major event bridge experts, like their opposite numbers in the chess world, quite reasonably expect peace and quiet in which to operate. There have been occasions when players in the final of a national championship have found themselves a partition removed from a disco, but by and large the organizers manage quite well.

title: EDITORS CHOICE
description: THE COLLECTED STORIES OF ELIZABETH BOWEN. (Alfred A. Knopf, $17.95.) Seventy-nine stories, many of them masterpieces.

title: No Headline
description: Irwin's 62-196 Leads By 5 Shots in Hawaii

title: Kimberly Gordon, Physician, Is Bride
description: Dr. Kimberly Gordon and Dr. James Newman Tucker, residents in pediatrics at the Children's Hospital in Pittsburgh and graduates of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Christopher J. Emerson performed the ceremony in the First Church of Christ in Woodbridge, Conn.

title: CONNECTICUT POINTS THE FINGER AT 395 WATER COMPANIES
description: There aren't many towns in Connecticut where water is in short supply, but in those where it is, the supply is very short indeed. For people in parts of Fairfield County, Groton and Manchester, the situation is serious. For people here, it is critical.

title: ABSCAM DEFENDANTS WINDING UP HEARING
description: After three weeks of intensive effort at a Brooklyn hearing, lawyers for four former or current members of Congress and three other men hope they have shown that their clients' Abscam convictions and indictments should be thrown out because of ''outrageous governmental misconduct'' during the undercover investigation.

title: McGaffigan: The Right Man for the Yanks?
description: As he runs laps in the outfield or throws beside the dugout, Andy McGaffigan knows that this is an unusually good year to be a right-handed pitcher trying to make the Yankees.

title: THE SENATE'S 'ODD COUPLE' HAS MANY UNRULY OFFSPRING
description: When the dust had settled after Election Day, the Senate Appropriations Committee, long the redoubt of some of the chamber's more influential barons, found itself headed by two relatively youthful and independent-minded members, Senators Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, and William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin.

title: ART VS. ARTIFACTS IN MONTCLAIR
description: MONTCLAIR WHAT is the difference between artifacts and art? It's an old, but venerable, question - at times, even a nagging one - that applies to the current exhibition of Turkmen tribal carpets at the Montclair Art Museum.

title: MUSIC: BANDINAGE GROUP
description: Badinage, consisting of Julianne Baird, soprano, and six fine musicians using period instruments, played music of Telemann Friday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall in honor of the composer's 300th anniversary.

title: Susan Johnson Fiancee of Li Pei
description: Mrs. Glenn Dawson Johnson of Locust Valley, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Susan Gerd Johnson, to Li Chung Pei, son of I.M. Pei, the architect, and Mrs. Pei of New York.

title: BY ZENAS BLOCK
description: W HY do many big, otherwise well-managed companies fail, and fail big, when they try to start a new business? What leads to such costly missteps as Du Pont's venture into synthetic leather, Singer's experience with office machinery, Gillette's attempt to market pocket calculators and digital watches or General Electric's entry and exit from the computer business - ventures that penalized the companies hundreds of millions of dollars before they were finally jettisoned?

title: AGE-OLD RIVALS CAST A SHADOW OVER CANADIANS
description: More than two centuries after Britain and France fought for control of North America, they continue to cast a long shadow over Canada's internal politics and foreign relations.

title: Food; A SUPERMARKET WHERE TROUT SWIM
description: GREAT NECK THE lines at the cookie counter were the longest, and the staff could barely keep up with the demand for chocolate-chocolate chunk. David's Cookies, which have been satisfying the Manhattan sweet tooth for a year and a half, had finally come to the Island. They are just one feature of a new supermarket here called the Food Emporium.

title: CAN YOU NAME THESE HOUSE PLANT FLOWERS?
description: Since many house plants are grown for their foliage and not their flowers, it takes the close-up lens of a camera to reveal the beauty of this unfamiliar world. The delicate flowers shown here were taken from commonly grown house plants and photographed by John Lynch, an amateur gardener and photographer. His heightened sense of awareness made this unusual blossomtime a reward of beauty rather than a thing of naught.

title: Wendy Darling to Be Bride Of Philip A. Lotz on July 18
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wells A. Darling of Huntington Bay, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Darling, to Philip A. Lotz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred S. Lotz of Cazenovia, N.Y.

title: Why Federal Spending Must Be Cut
description: Not many years ago, the very idea would have had many Democrats sputtering with outrage. ''Unconscionable!'' they would have shouted had a Republican President dared try to slash domestic spending at a time of high unemployment and threatened recession. But this year, the roar of the budget cutter in the White House brings nary a whimper of opposition. Indeed, on the matter of reining in the budget, there is no opposition at all.

title: Cannie G. Crysler, Edwin Schafer Jr., Teachers, to Wed
description: Mrs. R. Godwin Crysler of Haverford, Pa., and Edwin W. Crysler Jr. of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cannie Godwin Crysler, to Edwin Hampton Shafer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shafer of Montrose, Pa.

title: PRODUCER PRICES STILL ON CLIMB
description: Producer prices increased by nine-tenths of 1 percent in January, the Labor Department said last week. The monthly increase was the largest since last August, when prices at the wholesale level rose 1.2 percent. The January jump was fueled by energy prices, which rose 2.7 percent in the month.

title: 4 Sentenced in Bid-Rigging Case
description: Four convicted bid-rigging conspirators were sentenced to prison terms and the paving companies of which they were officials were fined a total of $175,000 Wednesday by Federal District Judge Woodrow W. Jones. The sentences ranged from a six-month suspended sentence to four months in jail. The convicted bid-riggers were Grady Thomas, vice president of the Crowder Asphalt Corporation; Henry Grathwohl Jr., president of Crowder; Jon R. Reynolds, president of the L.A. Reynolds Company, and Charles E. Wuertenberger, former president and chairman of the board of the Rea Construction Company.

title: 2 MONTH'S RAIN RAVAGES AREA OF PHILIPPINES
description: It began raining here in mid-December, the kind of heavy seasonal rains that made this timber region in northern Mindanao one of the richest in the country. But most of the hills have now been logged bare, and promised reforestation has not appeared, nor has flood control. So when the rains came, so did floods, the worst in 20 years.

title: FINDING THE PEOPLE WHO FIND THE OIL
description: DENVER I N this lofty city, where oil exploration and production companies are formed at the rate of one a week, there is an acute shortage of the experts who find the oil in the ground -petroleum geologists, and their close cousins, petroleum geophysicists. About 1,000 of the 4,000 jobs currently available are unfilled, and similar shortages are reported in other oil patches around the country.

title: Filing Claims On Oil Spills
description: It is not my practice to correct ordinary inaccuracies in newspaper stories, since I generally assume that haste and imperfect communication are the source of such inaccuracies. However, the recent story titled ''State and U.S. Contest Cleanup of Oil Spill 13 Years Ago'' goes beyond such inaccuracies.

title: CONSUMER RATES
WHERE TEXANS BUILD CASTLES IN THE SAND
description: On June 3, 1979, a gigantic eruption at the Ixtoc I offshore well in Mexico's Bay of Campeche produced the world's biggest oil spill, and in August of that year the currents of the Gulf of Mexico carried tons of chocolate-colored goo onto the wide beaches of one of the nation's newest resorts, South Padre Island in south Texas.

title: Martha McCurdy Engaged
description: The engagement of Martha Grace McCurdy, daughter of M. Barbara McCurdy of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Joseph R. McCurdy, to Warren C. Moran Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moran of Wilmington, Del., has been announced by the future bride's mother.

title: U.S. STUDY SEES REPRISAL PERIL IN NEUTRON WEAPONS
description: United States deployment of neutron warheads in Western Europe might ''increase Soviet propensities'' to use regular nuclear weapons in a war, according to a Government report made public today.

title: Leisure; ALOE, A GOOD LUCK PLANT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Charles Marden Fitch has written several books on gardening. By CHARLES MARDEN FITCH

title: WATERBURY AND BRASS EXHIBITED
description: WATERBURY BUT for brass, Waterbury would be no city, an exhibit at the Mattatuck Museum shows. ''Metal, Minds and Machines: Waterbury at Work'' celebrates the remarkable 19th-century transformation of an isolated farming community into a diverse industrial city and a national power in brass manufacturing.

title: Food; FEEDING A CROWD
description: HEAD TO COME

title: Martha Behrens Married to W.S. Connolly
description: Martha Treble Behrens, an international reinsurance broker with Willcox, Baringer & Company in New York, was married last evening in Boxford, Mass., to William Sims Connolly, an assistant treasurer in the international banking division of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. The Rev. Stuart C. Nutter performed the ceremony in the First Church Congregational.

title: Nancy B. Hurlbut Wed To Thomas J. Marcacci
description: Nancy Bingham Hurlbut, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Wilbur Bingham Hurlbut of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday in Menlo Park, Calif., to Thomas John Marcacci of Mountain View, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Marcacci of Vineland, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the Menlo Park Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Robert H. Roe of the Peninsula Bible Church in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: JET CRASH ADDS TO CONCERN OVER PLAN FOR AIRPORT
description: FOES of expansion at Westchester County Airport turned out last week in Greenwich, Conn., for the second public meeting on the issue in the last two and a half months. It was one of several developments during the week aimed at curbing noise in communities around the Westchester-owned airport on the New York-Connecticut border.

title: Melanie Schneider Married
description: Melanie Schneider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Schneider of New York, was married last evening to Jeffrey Tucker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Tucker of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Alive in academe. ''Many college and university literature departments are reluctant to 'teach' fiction published more recently than 1950,'' we reported a few weeks ago. This statement has evoked questions from a number of readers. When colleges do venture to teach the works of living writers nowadays, whose do they chose? What books are going to represent contemporary literature in the minds of members of the 80's generation?

title: Pamela Cusick Noble Engaged to Educator
description: Pamela Cusick Noble, who is studying for a master's degree in biostatistics at the University of Vermont, and Dr. Takamaru Ashikaga, director of the biometry facility at Vermont's College of Medicine, plan to be married July 25 at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: Stage View; OH,FOR THE PIAF WHO GOT AWAY; by Walter Kerr
description: I should think that someone might still get a play out of ''Piaf'' simply by answering a few of the questions that author Pam Gems has permitted to hover, quivery and forlorn, over her evening. The production at the Plymouth, staged by Howard Davies and based on the Royal Shakespeare Company's London original, has a certain energy of its own, abrupt and bristling. Actress Jane Lapotaire, fists doubled up on her nonexistant hips and looking ever more like a molting cockatoo, could no doubt round out a portrait of the legendary Edith Piaf if she were only given scenes to act instead of flippant phrases to toss off over her shoulder in passing. The evening can, in truth, be called provocative. But what is provocative about it is not the roll-call of lovers, the log of multiplying car crashes, or the career ups-and-downs that are so telegraphically brushed in. The challenge, the tease, the mystery is all in the gaps between.

title: Austrian Leader in Cairo
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria met with President Anwar el-Sadat today within hours of arriving from Vienna for a four-day official visit. The Middle East News Agency said they would discuss the Middle East. Mr. Kreisky has long maintained that the Palestine Liberation Organization should be included in Arab-Israeli peace talks.

title: New Polish Chief Pleads for Respite
description: Poland's party chiefs have gone through three Prime Ministers in 13 months in an effort to find one who can bring the country under control. But Wojciech Jaruzelski, who took over last week, is something else.

title: A NOSE FOR TREASURE AND A TASTE FOR
description: PROFIT THE LAST MAFIOSO The Treacherous World of Jimmy Fratianno. By Ovid Demaris. Illustrated. 463 pp. New York: Times Books. $15.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: STUDENTS often seem to be clamoring for something, especially at Wesleyan University in Middletown, where student activism has remained fashionable long after it has declined elsewhere. But some undergraduates at Wesleyan are now demanding that something be taken away from them - some of their housing.

title: 'POPEYE' SOUND BETTER WHEN HEARD AT HOME
description: B ecause its modest scale almost perversely defies the current trend in movie music toward bigness, ''Popeye'' (Boardwalk SW 36880) is the rare film score that works better as a record than as an actual soundtrack. Concocted by Harry Nilsson and Van Dyke Parks, semi-legendary pop eccentrics who haven't been heard from in a while, the music completely eschews the bombastic, technological effects that today's Dolby-equipped theaters virtually demand from film music. Instead of illustrating the action with slam-bang pyrotechnics, Mr. Nilsson, who wrote the songs, and Mr. Parks, who arranged and orchestrated them, chose to enter into the spirit of the cartoon and evoke a gentle, slightly wistful, childhood world.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Each week several Times critics will offer tips on attractions around town.

title: Bookshelf; THE GALAPAGOS,LITERARY ENGLAND AND RIDING TRAINS AND PLANES
description: It is hard to resist the image of blue-footed boobies on the hunt, ''dropping like rain'' to land with a stupefying crash upon schools of fish. Or to be less than beguiled by the facts of blue-footed booby courtship, in which the male and the female ceremoniously exchange presents of symbolic nesting materials.

title: POETS CONVENE AT IND, AND RHYME IS THE REASON
description: The compatibility of poetry and the subway received a severe test yesterday at the 42d Street IND station in Manhattan. A coalition of community groups sponsored a poetry reading in the promenade of the station to call attention to deteriorating service, but the offerings of child and adult bards alike were often drowned out by the roar downstairs of the trains the poets said didn't appear often enough.

title: FOUR LEADING CASES
description: A.T.&T. - Justice Department sought breakup of Bell System including sale of all 23 operating companies and Western Electric. But proposed settlement reportedly requires sale of just three subsidiaries and parts of Western Electric.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The scope of it is absolutely staggering - I wish I had a penny for every pound of heroin that's getting through.'' - Victor J. Rocco, chief of the criminal division in the United States Attorney's office for the Eastern District of New York. (1:1.)

title: Sunday Observer; THE DREAMER'S PROGRESS
description: The Dreamer's Progress Patrick McDonnell

title: Apologist Draws Criticism From Watchful Father
description: To the Sports Editor: Andy Geiger (''Despite the Abuses, Athletics Can Enrich a College Education,'' The New York Times, Jan. 11) makes some convincing points about the desirability of participating in big-time intercollegiate football. He then dismisses the Pac-10 scandal with a few self-congratulatory remarks and by suggesting that separate squads for freshmen have been discontinued by the football powers because of the costs involved.

title: COGHLAN ELATED BY FAST VICTORY IN TORONTO
description: Eamonn Coghlan sat and sipped a cola drink. As befit a 28-year-old executive of the Irish Travel Board, he wore an Irish national green running shirt covered by a green T-shirt that said ''Discover Ireland.''

title: No Headline
description: Jeff Reardon, the No. 2 relief pitcher of the Mets, signed one-year contract yesterday for about $70,000 plus incentives and ended his threat to boycott spring training.

title: FOLK: DAVID BROMBERG
description: Folk music's closest equivalent to Woody Allen is probably David Bromberg, the New York-bred singer-guitarist, who came out of retirement on Thursday to celebrate the Bottom Line's seventh anniversary. Mr. Bromberg, who recently gave up performing to study violin-making full time in Chicago, has long been a critically controversial figure on the folk scene. And for obvious reasons.

title: Sharif Kahn, Desaulniers In U.S. Pro Squash Final
description: Sharif Kahn and Michael Desaulniers, the top-seeded players, moved into the final of the United States pro squash racquets championship today.

title: Europeans Treat Sadat Very Well
description: ''I have not come here to sell out Camp David,'' Anwar el-Sadat told the European Parliament last week. But with negotiations stalled until the Reagan Administration decides on a policy and Israel elects a new Government, the Egyptian leader seemed to be encouraging the Europeans to show him their wares.

title: 23 Hired by Federal Agency From 26,000 Job-Seekers
description: Twenty-three persons began working at the Social Security Administration here this week, the first group hired from the more than 26,000 who stood in line last September, when it was rumored that 1,500 jobs were available.

title: No Headline
description: Before my retirement, I was a senior officer of a medium-sized corporation. I considered it important to interview a cross section of applicants for executive positions in my company.

title: SCARSDALE STUDENTS TO GET TRIP TO CHINA
description: THE date is not set yet, but in all likelihood by the beginning of March, 15 students from the Scarsdale Alternative School, three of their teachers and two professors from the University of Massachusetts will be flying to Peking for a month of study and travel at the invitation of the Chinese Government.

title: Mine Workers Vote Today On End of Strike in West
description: United Mine Workers members will vote tomorrow on a tentative agreement that could end a 30-day strike by 930 employees at five Western mines owned by the Peabody Coal Company, a company negotiator said today.

title: ANOTHER SHOW FOR ERNIE COBB
description: PALISADES PARK, N.J. WHEN the Harlem Wizards basketball team puts on its show anywhere close to the New York area, the players gather near Yankee Stadium and climb into a brown van for the trip. Thursday night they were going over the George Washington Bridge when one of the Wizards turned to Ernie Cobb.

title: GROWERS BAR ORANEGS FROM MARKET AS PRICES DIP
description: California growers are blocking about 3.5 billion navel oranges from reaching the nation's grocery stores to prevent further erosion in the low price of oranges.

title: Beisbol
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Security
description: To the Business Editor: Rudolph G. Penner in ''Why Indexing Was a Big Mistake'' (Feb. 1) has adopted a browbeating attitude toward the beneficiaries of the indexing of social programs, particularly Social Security recipients. He repeatedly refers to such beneficiaries as ''special interest'' groups and implies that they are gorging themselves at the trough of ''ordinary tax-paying workers.''

title:
Future Events;
Future Events Birthdays & Parades
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:Parade a la ModeFeb. 20 - It's pronounced the French way, the ''Parade'' that the Metropolitan Opera presents tonight as its first new production of the season at a premiere arranged by the Metropolitan Opera Guild. The production was put together by John Dexter, the Met's director of production, and it consists of three one-act works from the French musical theater, beginning with Erik Satie's ''Parade,'' his 1917 ballet based on a theme by Jean Cocteau; ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges,'' the fantasy opera Maurice Ravel wrote in 1925 from a story by Colette; and ''Les Mamelles de Tiresias,'' which Francis Poulenc wrote in 1947 as his first opera and which he based on a poem by Guillaume Apollinaire. The child's fantasies from the new production inspired the bright blue, yellow, green and red decor for the supper party that follows for the cast and holders of $125 opera tickets on the Grand Tier of the opera house. Guests will dine and dance under an umbrella of balloons rising from floral table centerpieces. The supper menu is smoked trout downed with vodka, filet mignon downed with wine, ice cream with cassis, and coffee with cognac. The $200 tickets for the entire evening include the $125 center orchestra seats and $75 for the party, from 582-6067, to benefit the Met.

title: Laura Eimicke To Be a Bride
description: Laura Suzanne Eimicke, a candidate for an M.A. degree in dance at Columbia University, and Brooks James Klimley, a Kellett Fellow at Corpus Christi College, Oxford University, plan to be married in July in New York.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
70-to-80% Saving On Winter Apparel
description: During February, prices are cut by 70 to 80 percent nearly storewide on women's first-quality winter apparel at Gilbert Vincents in Ossining - except on belts, scarves and lingerie. Antique and contemporary jewelry is reduced 20 percent. The usual initial saving is up to 50 percent, although some merchandise begins at the manufacturer's suggested retail price.

title: NOW, THE TEST
description: The public is full of expectations, mostly optimistic, about President Reagan. But after the ''new beginning'' he promised at the Republican National Convention and again as President in his first nationally televised address 10 days ago, this is the week he must begin filling in the blanks in those vague hopes.

title: No Headline
description: Tennessee Defeats Vanderbilt, 77 to 72

title: 'THIS IS GOD'S WORLD'
description: An extraordinary feature of life in South Africa is the schizophrenia of its politics. The Afrikaners who hold power and the black majority of the population see two entirely different political realities. And the gulf between the perceptions seems wider than ever today.

title: Marilyn L. Castaldi Bride Of H. A. Singer, Lawyer
description: Marilyn L. Castaldi, daughter of Mrs. F.V. Castaldi of Woodbury, N.J., and the late Dr. Castaldi, was married yesterday to Howard A. Singer, son of Victor Singer of North Miami, Fla., and the late Helen Singer. Civil Court Judge Richard Lee Price performed the ceremony at a private townhouse in New York.

title: Linda Boardman, Teacher, Affianced
description: Linda Christine Boardman, a teacher at the Brearley School, and Lieut. Philip Malloy Drumheller of the Merchant Marine will be married in June.

title: ITEL IN BANKRUPTCY: TRYING TO SALVAGE THE LITTLE THAT'S LEFT
description: SAN FRANCISCO J AMES H. MALOON, the chairman of the bankrupt Itel Corporation, says he is much calmer now about the situation. The shock of the discovery last August of just how bad things really were with the company, which leased everything from computers and aircraft to containers and rail cars, has begun to wear off.

title: BATTLED FOR INDONESIA'S FREEDOM
description: Lambertus Nicodemus Palar, a prominent figure in Indonesia's struggle for independence and later his country's chief delegate to the United Nations and Ambassador to Washington, died Thursday in Jakarta, his family has reported. He was 80 years old.

title: IMAGINATION IS THE PASSPORT TO THE WORLD OF LONG ISLAND
description: From my frost-coated window I look out on a chilling winter scene. I indulge myself in dreams of less icy possibilities - perchance to dream of a winter vacation in some sunnier somewhere. My nocturnal dreams are all reruns of my prime-time daily reveries, and I don't need a psychiatrist to analyze them for me. How Freudian can it be to dream now of sunshine and moonglow in the Virgin Islands, or to have romantic yearnings for the Romance-language resorts? Especially if the temperature hovers between zero and the teens.

title: Watt Fulfills Expectations on Oil Production
description: Sometimes controversies erupt, and sometimes they are as predictable as the tides. Disputes between Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt and environmentalist groups fall into the second category.

title: Hesburgh to Retire Next Year
description: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh has announced that he will retire from Notre Dame University next year, after 30 years as the Roman Catholic school's president, the longest tenure of any major university president in the nation. Father Hesburgh, who graduated from Notre Dame, will be 65 years old on May 25, 1982.

title: Observations on the Only Child
description: Where were all the only children when I was growing up (''The Only-Child Phenomenon,'' Jan. 18)? Didi Moore's sensitive article clearly points out that it is finally acceptable and socially correct for us ''closet'' onlies to step forth and stop apologizing for our singularity.

title: No Headline
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States. FOOTNOTES ''Cosmos'' has been the hardcover nonfiction best bestseller of the season.

title: Mary Ann Kaufmann, Banker, Wed in Midwest
description: Mary Ann Kaufmann of Edina, Minn., daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Kaufmann of Menands, N.Y., was married yesterday in Minnetonka Beach, Minn., to Dennis I. Hansen of Plymouth, Minn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Hansen of San Diego. Judge Eugene Minenko of the Fourth Judicial District of Hennepin County performed the ceremony at the Lafayette Club.

title: SIMPLE, STARTER HOUSE IS BUILDER'S CHALLENGE
description: ''We must get away from large houses on large separate lots because people don't want to be stuck with the energy costs or the responsibility any more,'' said 55-year-old Otto Paparazzo, as he leaned against the snow-covered mailbox of one of the homes in his latest venture and pondered the future of residential development.

title: Susan Derrey Wed To Michael K. Bird
description: Susan Fairbairn Derrey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fairbairn Derrey of Westfield, N.J., was married there yesterday to Michael Kevin Bird, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Bird of Stamford, Conn.

title: REAGAN SETTING UP 6 CABINET COUNCILS TO SHAPE POLICIES
description: President Reagan plans to set up a network of six Cabinet councils to serve as the formal bodies for debating and shaping the major policies of his Administration, his counselor, Edwin Meese 3d, said today.

title: HEROIN TRADE RISING DESPITE U.S. EFFORTS
description: After more than 15 years of trying to develop ways to fight the influx and distribution of heroin in the United States, law enforcement officials say that their efforts are still not succeeding and that in some parts of the country, especially New York, the problem is worse than ever.

title: Prisoner of Surprise
description: James Vorenberg pronounced himself ''awed'' and ''shocked,'' though he really shouldn't have been. Having been a faculty member since 1962 and associate dean of the Harvard Law School since 1977, he might well have expected to be appointed dean, as he was last week. Mr. Vorenberg, an expert on criminal law, will replace Albert M. Sacks, an expert on constitutional law, who replaced Derek Bok, who became president of Harvard.

title: Index; International
description: Allies upset by Norway's proposal of a nuclear-free zone 3 Kremlin hestitantly commemo- rates death of Dostoyevsky 3 Around the World 4 U.S. still undecided on amount of military aid to El Salvador 6 Greek parties launch election campaign 9 Polish dissident book tells how to deal with secret police 12 London and Paris still affect Canada's sovereignty 14 Two-month rain devastates once- rich timber area in Philippines 17 U.S. study says neutron warhead might provoke Soviet response 19 Israeli fans turn out to cheer for Biblical scholars 20 Government/Politics No changes recommended in ad- mission criteria for aliens 28 Opposing sides sharpen cam- paigns on abortion amendment 38 In Cleveland, Felix Rohatyn makes another rescue attempt 39 Battle is shaping over MX missile project 40 New York State led in total U.S. aid received in 1980 61 General Around the Nation 24 Atlanta inquiry altered as more youths are found slain 24 Miami Beach tourism down but hopes are up 34 Cult follower sues parents and 4 others for alleged abduction 44 Industry/Labor A.F.L.-C.I.O. prepares for first skirmish with Reagan 29 Growers keeping oranges off mar- ket to help prices 35 Education/Welfare The fortunate give thanks by remembering the neediest 62 Health/Science Virginia plant to convert garbage into ethanol 23 Antituberculosis vaccine backed by health experts 27 Arts/Entertainment Jerry Lewis to pay $39,000 to settle ''Hellzapoppin'' suit 67 Fred Shiffman and Dana Vance are comedy team 68 The Wizards, rollerdancers, at the Symphony Space 68 Music debuts in review 69 Style All around the town: Missoni 70 A shop that mixes antiques and knits 70 Obituaries Lambertus Nicodemus Palar, for- mer Indonesian diplomat 44

title: Westchester Guide; NOW 'AARON COPLAND' CAMP
description: The Westchester County Music and Arts Camp, operating for many summers on 1,000 acres in North Salem, was renamed the Aaron Copland Music and Arts program last month by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello.

title: A BELATED RECOGNITION BY THE CHIEF JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: City Council Meetings Scheduled This Week
description: The following City Council meetings have been scheduled for this week: TUESDAY - Committee on Economic Development, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Housing and Buildings, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. WEDNESDAY - Committee on Consumer Affairs, City Hall, 10 A.M. THURSDAY - Committee on Health, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on General Welfare, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. FRIDAY - Committee on Transportation, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Subcommittee on Waterborne Transportation, City Hall, 11:30 A.M.; Committee on Governmental Operations, 250 Broadway, 23d floor, 1:30 P.M..

title: No Headline
description: UCONN DEFGEATS SYRACUSE

title: An Australian Feminist
description: To The Editor: Phyllis Rose's unfair review of ''My Brilliant Career'' (Jan. 4) and her facile dismissal of Miles Franklin as a mediocre writer show an unfamiliarity with facts and an insensitivity to feminist research goals.

title: 1820 WINDMILL TO BE RESTORED
description: SOUTHAMPTON Town officials have received $22,979 in Federal funds to repair a 161-year-old windmill that was given to the town half a century ago with the stipulation that it be maintained by the local government.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Westway Wins a Federal Blessing
description: Seven years and two months ago, Nicholas Perrone tried to drive his dump truck up the West Side Highway and ended up falling though it instead, demonstrating conclusively that the time had come to close the dilapidated elevated roadway. Last week, Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis said with equal certainty that the time had come to build a new one.

title: Long Islanders Need More Than One Channel
description: The Long Island Coalition for Fair Broadcasting Inc. was formed in response to the failure of New York City-based television stations to meet their obligation to cover the news and public affairs of special local interest to 2.8 million Long Islanders.

title: Dance View; CANADIANS IN SEARCH OF IDENTITY
description: Les Grands Ballets Canadiens, from Montreal, now touring the United States, put in a brief appearance at Lehman College for the Performing Arts - its first New York engagement since it sold out the City Center for four weeks 10 years ago with Fernand Nault's rock ballet, ''Tommy.'' In the interim, one of Canada's other two major ballet troupes, the Royal Winnipeg Ballet, has been seen here twice. But locally our image of Canadian ballet has been conditioned by the frequent visits since 1973 of Toronto's National Ballet of Canada.

title: Man, 40, Is Found Murdered
description: A 40-year-old man identified as Walter Montgomery was found shot and stabbed to death yesterday in a room at the Madison Hotel at 21 East 27th Street, the police said. The police said they had found a gun and a knife in the man's room. They said they did not have a motive for the slaying.

title: Maria Powell, Soprano, Offers Unusual Program
description: A young American soprano, Maria Powell, made her debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday afternoon. Her program rummaged through some pretty dusty areas of the lieder literature (Richard Trunk and Leo Blech) and ended with some equally exotic names from France and Italy (Edouard Tremisot, Andre Flegier and Alfredo Catalani).

title: Bus Conductor Is Slain in Peking By Youths He Told Not to Smoke
description: Youths attacked and killed a bus conductor who had stopped them from smoking, The Peking Evening News reported today.

title: South America Rises in Soccer
description: The World Cup tournament is still 16 months away, but it is becoming increasingly evident that the South Americans will have the edge when the premier soccer event in the world is played in Madrid in July 1982.

title: Ads at the Movies
description: To the Editor:

title: ALDEBURGH FESTIVAL'S HALL OPENS TO TOURS
description: The Maltings, the concert hall founded by Benjamin Britten and Peter Pears at Snape, near Aldeburgh in Suffolk, England, will be open for tours for the first time this summer. The opening is part of a $1.8 million appeal by the Aldeburgh Festival-Snape Maltings Foundation to help run the Maltings complex, which includes the Britten-Pears School for Advanced Musical Studies.

title: DUTY-FREE SHOPS SET IN CANADA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ANDREW H. MALCOLM is chief of the Toronto bureau of The Times. By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

title: RAINFALL ALONE WON'T END THE REGION'S JITTERS OVER DROUGHT
description: The heavens, which have borne much of the blame for the water shortage in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, furnished a measure of relief last week. Rain, along with balmy temperatures that melted snow, provided New York reservoirs with an additional 44 billion gallons, raising the levels from an average of 31.7 percent of capacity to 39.9 percent.

title: Bush Assets Put in Blind Trust
description: Vice President Bush and his wife, Barbara, converted their investment assets, including 17,000 shares of common stock, into a blind trust valued at about $900,000, Mr. Bush's press secretary, Peter Teeley, said yesterday. He said the trust did not include Mr. Bush's bank accounts or his homes in Maine and Texas.

title: Kidnapping, With a Twist, in Beirut
description: The identity and motives of those who carried out Beirut's latest political crime - the abduction of Jordan's charge d'affaires - remain murky, but one effect is plain - deterioration in relations between Jordan and Syria almost to the vanishing point.

title: Elsie Brewster McCabe Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Emmet McCabe of Englewood, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elsie Brewster McCabe, to William Tredick McIntire Smith. He is the son of Mrs. George Robert Leslie of Englewood and Fishers Island, N.Y., and Hudson Ashley Smith of Alpine, N.J., and Scottsdale, Ariz. A September wedding is planned.

title: No Headline
description: Skiing With Children To the Editor: Apropos the article, ''A Zermatt Ski Holiday, With an Infant Daughter in Tow'' (Travel Section, Jan. 4), on a recent trip to Quebec, I made a great discovery.

title: Computers' Role In the Classroom
description: I was interested in the recent article ''Computers Get a Bigger Role in Many L.I. Schools.'' I teach in B.O.C.E.S. III.

title: No Headline
description: I was disappointed that Didi Moore did not mention a very important advantage that being an only child provides.

title: Antiques; ENGLISH FURNITURE RETURNS TO FAVOR
description: The gaveling at Christie's on the Prescott Collection two weeks ago dramatically confirmed that English furniture has returned to favor in this country. At that record-breaking sale, prices on virtually everything from an Elizabethan bed to a George III hanging shelf soared to from two to 10 times the auction house's most optimistic expectations. It was, in the judgment of many bidders, one of the most important collections of English furniture ever sold at auction in New York.

title: NARRATIVE RECALLS DEADLY ATTACK BY WHALE IN 1820
description: The sinking of the whaler Essex by a sperm whale that struck head-on, forcing the 20-man crew to take to the sea in lifeboats, is dramatically recalled in a narrative, lost for a century, that was found recently.

title: Long Islanders; LOOKING FOR A DATE ON A WINTER CRUISE
description: LIKE a lot of other people, Daniel Habib of Plainview went on a cruise this winter - two weeks in waters off the Bahamas. Unlike most people, he was cruising on business, aboard the 400-foot Glomar Challenger, a research vessel used by a consortium of universities in their efforts to plumb the secrets of the ocean.

title: WATER SHORTAGE LINKED TO DELAY ON NEW PROJECTS
description: Fundamental, long-term problems led to the water shortage in the Northeast, including the unwillingness of many officials and citizens to pay the rising costs of developing new water resources and disputes that caused delays in increasing supplies, experts say.

title: HESITANT SOVIET APPLAUDS DOSTOYEVSKY
description: Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoyevsky died a hundred years ago in a country still called Russia and a city still called St. Petersburg. But he remains a vivid presence in Leningrad and the Soviet Union, a presence that has never given comfort to the Kremlin.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: If you crave a bit of elegance these dreary winter days, you will find some very well-dressed ladies and gentlemen sharing cocktails or coffee at the Bridge Gallery, the county art gallery off the second floor of the County Office Building on Martine Avenue in White Plains.

title: THOSE ALLURING OPEN-REEL TAPES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Alan Rosenthal writes frequently on musical subjects. By ALAN ROSENTHAL

title: A STORYTELLER'S SHOPTALK
description: When I was 27, back in 1966, I found I was having trouble concentrating my attention on long narrative fiction. For a time I experienced difficulty in trying to read it as well as in attempting to write it. My attention span had gone out on me; I no longer had the patience to try to write novels. It's an involved story, too tedious to talk about here. But I know it has much to do now with why I write poems and short stories. Get in, get out. Don't linger. Go on. It could be that I lost any great ambitions at about the same time, in my late 20's. If I did, I think it was good it happened. Ambition and a little luck are good things for a writer to have going for him. Too much ambition and bad luck, or no luck at all, can be killing. There has to be talent.

title: ARTISTS FIND A SPECIAL LIGHT ON L.I.
description: WHILE many people think of the South Fork as a ''summer place,'' for Long Island artists there are significant attractions that have nothing to do with the hedonistic joys of vacation days. Not the least of these is the light, which has a particularly lucid quality at this time of year.

title: Article on Health Aides Is Termed Misleading
description: There were several incorrect and misleading statements in the article, ''A Health Inspector's Lot Is Not an Easy One,'' by Linda Lynwander, which appeared on Jan. 11.

title: WASHINGTON
description: When Ronald Reagan moved into the White House, there was a tendency here to regard his promises to cut the budget, cut taxes and be tough on the Soviets as so many New Year's Resolutions soon to be destroyed by the brutal facts and politics of the day.

title: ROCKVILLE CENTRE WEIGHS OWN CABLE TV
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE ALTHOUGH a group of residents recently proposed that the village build what would be the first municipally owned and operated cable television system in New York State, they have not persuaded village officials - who are evaluating offers from four cable television franchise companies - that a municipality should be involved in a proprietory business.

title: 23d Street
description: A vacant commercial building at 148 W. 23rd Street will be converted into a 114-unit rental project by developer Donald Zucker. Mr. Zucker's public relations agency announced the project last week, adding that more than 40 percent of the apartments would have woodburning fireplaces. Fireplaces, the agency said, are a trademark of Mr. Zucker.

title: FOR DISABLED, A HELPING HAND
description: WHITE PLAINS RICHARD MANLEY is a 30-year-old college graduate who lives in Elmsford and works full time in an executive position for the County of Westchester.

title: law FILIPINO REBEL IS STILL HELD IN ISOLATION DESPITE THE LIFTING OF MARTIAL
description: - Despite the lifting of martial law last month and the release of more than 100 political prisoners, Cristina Montiel, whose husband was arrested Dec. 3, has still not been permitted to see or communicate with him, nor has he been allowed to consult a lawyer.

title: HISTORICAL SOCIETY SEEKING SITE FOR ITS ARCHIVES-AND POSSIBLY A MUSEUM
description: WITH the county's tricentennial celebration just two years off, Westchester is looking for a suitable site to house the archives - and possibly a museum - for its Historical Society.

title: Merle Duskin Is Fiancee Of Leo G. Kailas, Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Victor Dorman of Kings Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Dorman's daughter, Merle Sue Duskin, to Leo George Kailas, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Kailas of Fort Lee, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: COUPLE WIN SUIT OVER CONDEMNATION OF 2 BUILDINGS
description: A Brooklyn couple have won a court victory over how much money they should receive for two apartment buildings the city had condemned for a rehabilitation project in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

title: Stenmark's Slalom Victory Equals Cup Record of 62
description: Ingemar Stenmark captured his 62d World Cup ski victory today, matching a feat first achieved by Austria's Annemarie Moser-Proll.

title: Lebanon Premier Assails Israelis After Their Air Battle With Syria
description: Prime Minister Shafiq Wazan demanded today that Israel be put on international trial for ''nonstop aggression'' against Lebanon.

title: The Sentencing of Private Garwood
description: The quality of mercy is not strained, even in the Marine Corps. Pfc. Robert R. Garwood, convicted of collaborating with the enemy and assaulting a fellow prisoner while a captive in Vietnam, last week was sentenced by his court martial jury to be reduced to private and dishonorably discharged.

title: Reagan Campaign Aide To Be Peace Corps Head
description: President Reagan has announced the selection of Loret M. Ruppe as director of the Peace Corps. Mrs. Ruppe, 45 years old, whose husband, Philip, is a former Congressman, was co-chairman of the Reagan-Bush Committee in Michigan.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE IS READY TO BEGIN A COUNTDOWN REHEARSAL TONIGHT
description: With a decade of fitful development behind it and the future of the nation's space program riding on its success, the space shuttle Columbia is standing on its launching pad here, primed for a critical ground test that could clear the way for the revolutionary flying machine's maiden orbital voyage.

title: The Deregulation Dash
description: However slowly and deliberately it may move in other areas, the Reagan Administration is sprinting on Federal regulatory reform. Last week, to the consternation of consumer activists and organized labor and to the delight of the business community, the Administration moved promptly on several fronts to fulfill the President's promise to ''ease burdensome regulations on American business.''

title: THE TROUBLE WITH U.S. FORCES IN WEST GERMANY
description: To the Editor:

title:
New Jersey Housing;
DEVELOPER'S SILENT PARTNER IS THE SUN
description: WHEN Frank Gambony started in the building business more than 25 years ago, he worked on 750-square-foot Cape Cod houses that sold for $11,950.

title: Billy Carter to Sell Land To Avoid Losing Home
description: Billy Carter said today he would sell some land to help pay a debt of $105,123 to the Internal Revenue Service to avoid foreclosure on his Marion County home.

title: North Stars 7, Whalers 4
description: A goal by Al MacAdam and another by Steve Christoff, his second of the game, broke a 4-4 tie and helped carry Minnesota to victory over Hartford.

title: EXPLORING MANHATTAN'S OPEN SPACES
description: The photographs by Marvin E. Newman on view until March 3 at the Urban Center in the historic Villard Houses (457 Madison Avenue at 51st Street) are extremely skillful and revealing images of New York. Remarkably evocative of the city's gigantism and rapid change, of the ceaseless activity and impact of huge buildings constantly going up and down, this group of 40 color and black-and-white pictures presents the Manhattan of legend and reality with greater fidelity to its spirit and construction than any photographic display that I have seen in a long time. These are not the usual romantic views of towers seen through morning mists or sunsets; the beauty of these images is in their sharpness, clarity and accuracy. It is their sense of New York's sheer, overwhelming size and vitality and continuous physical transformation that catches the city so dramatically and well. Mr. Newman has a superb reportorial and urban eye.

title: About Long Island
description: SEARINGTOWN BEFORE memory is obliterated, perhaps someone will invent a prefabricated stoop. Suburbs don't have stoops, probably because no one walks in front of the houses and, thus, there is no need to sit on the stoops to watch the passing parade.

title: CITY OPERA UNVEILS SPRING '81: INNOVATION, TRADITION (AND MISS SILLS)
description: REGEN Schonberg By HAROLD C. SCHONBERG

title: Music; ARTISTS IN RESIDENCE AT ARDSLEY SCHOOLS
description: IT may be something of a cliche to say that the students of today are the audiences of tomorrow, and yet in this time of school austerity programs, that simple premise may be lost in the budgetary shuffle. But in Ardsley, community support and imaginative leadership have helped establish an extraordinary series of artist residencies in the public schools.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: ANYONE who might be perplexed about how to save water, or indifferent about doing so, during the current emergency can draw some inspiration from Robert Navara of Teaneck. In a recent letter to the Hackensack Water Company, Mr. Navara shared some of his waterconservation efforts at home.

title: BY ELAINE BUDD
description: EAST HADDAM TWO years ago, Linda Erthein, newly arrived in East Haddam from New York City, took weaving lessons at Carol Clifford's studio. Today they, with 23 other artisans, are the founders of the recently opened Connecticut River Artisans Cooperative in East Haddam's historic district.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL UNITS VIEWED IN NEW ROLE
description: AS Suffolk County municipal governments confront monumental environmental problems that may well determine the quality of life in the 1980's, many of the environmental control agencies established in the 1960's are being consolidated with other departments. Advocates of the centralization say that it strengthens the role of the environmentalists and integrates them in other governmental functions. Critics - observant of the movement to attract new industry to the Island - warn of compromise and a diffusion of the agencies' power as watchdogs.

title: THE PENNY STOCK EXCAHNGE
description: The Denver Stock Exchange has not a single floor broker. It has no specialists, no ticker, no trading posts, no trading floor. The Denver Stock Exchange is a 16-page tabloid newsletter that covers the news of the over-the-counter penny stocks traded in the lively Denver market.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE LEADING COLLECTOR OF ANTISLAVERY TOKENS
description: Black History Week begins today, and for John Harris of Neptune, N.J. that signals the start of a busy round of numismatic talks and exhibits. Mr. Harris is widely known in hobby circles as perhaps the number one collector of antislavery tokens - base-metal tokens made and distributed in the 18th and 19th centuries by abolitionist groups in Great Britain and the United States. He has assembled a virtually complete collection of this material and is called upon frequently to display it and lecture on the subject.

title: NEITHER RAIN NOR THAW...
description: ALTHOUGH threatened by rain and a protracted thaw, the annual Salisbury Ski Jumps went off last weekend ''without a snag, an injury or a complaint,'' said Cicily Hajek, president of the Salisbury Winter Sports Association, sponsor of the 55-year-old event.

title: WE CAN BRING THE DISAFFECTED BACK INTO SOCIETY
description: ALL EDUCATORS, but especially school administrators and counselors, have a concern about the small army of disaffected and disruptive students in our schools.

title: ANTITRUST: BIG BUSINESS BREATHES EASIER
description: F OR nearly a century, antitrust battles in the United States were largely couched in ideology and politics. Since the Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890, the Federal ''trustbusters'' were viewed as tribunes of society, preserving some strain of Jeffersonian populism in America, protecting the little guy from the predations of Big Business. Accordingly, antitrust actions were vote-getters, frequently begun just before elections.

title: Ex-Hostages Honor Rescuers
description: Six of the former American hostages in Iran, standing in a cemetery amid 444 flags, joined torches today to light an eternal flame in memory of the eight servicemen who died trying to save them last April. The ceremony was performed by Michael Metrinko, Donald Cooke, Gary Lee, Regis Ragan, Charles Scott and William Royer after the unveiling of an unfinished monument to the rescuers.

title: Few Clues, More Bodies in Atlanta
description: Last Thursday, having grown impatient over its lack of progress, Atlanta officials reorganized the task force assigned to solve that city's baffling series of murders and disappearances of black children. As if confirm their feelings, on Friday, the remains of two more youngsters were found.

title: HIGH NOON FOR THE MARLBORO MAN
description: His brawny good looks made Marlboro the nation's best-selling cigarette and inspired a slew of wind-burned and denim-clad imitators. Last week, a new challenger to the Marlboro man strolled out of the advertising pages of national magazines.

title: Canadiens 6, Capitals 1
description: Guy Lafleur scored one goal and had two assists for the Montreal as the club extended its home unbeaten streak to 15 games.

title: DID A SPARK FROM THE 1960'S START THE FIRE AT CAREY HIGH?
description: THE item on the all-news station about my old high school lasted for about 10 seconds and was squeezed between reports on the expressway's bumper-to-bumper traffic and the latest wind-chill factor. ''Because of the fire that damaged part of the school,'' the announcer said on this winter morning, ''H. Frank Carey High School in Franklin Square will be closed again today.''

title: THE CONCERTO WARHORSE THAT GUITARISTS LOVE
description: J oaquin Rodrigo's ''Concierto de Aranjuez'' is not only the most frequently performed and recorded work in the guitar's small concerto repertory, but one of the few guitar compositions to have escaped the instrument's exclusive realm and entered the standard orchestral literature. With its gorgeous, bittersweet Adagio and the typically Iberic rhythms that fill its outer movements, ''Aranjuez'' has become a favorite ''Spanish piece'' for orchestras that put on pops concerts. It has also been taken up by many a jazz player (most notably Miles Davis), and has appeared lately in a disco version and in a transcription for harp.

title: Jewish Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: All-Glued Aircraft
description: If aircraft builders could glue all parts of a plane together instead of using metal rivets and welds, the craft would weigh 15 percent less and cost 20 percent less to build, the Air Force calculated. In January 1980, the Air Force was reported in the second year of an $18.4 million program to test this idea, and the results were described as ''more successful than we expected.''
