title: Supportive Father
description: Whatever else it promised, the Reagan Presidency offered hope of a respite from news stories on the escapades of First Brats and First Brothers trading on their relationship with the man in the Oval Office. Last week, after less than a month, the respite ended with the disclosure that First Son Michael Reagan was under investigation for violations of California securities laws. Young Mr. Reagan, through his attorney, denied any wrongdoing and the White House affirmed that ''The President is confident that the charges will be proven to be baseless.''

title: BRAZIL'S INDIANS HAVE SEEN TOO MUCH PROGRESS
description: In ''Tristes Tropiques,'' a classic of anthropological literature, Claude Levi-Strauss recorded his impressions of an Indian tribe in the middle of Brazil's western wastelands some 40 years ago. ''The couples embrace as if seeking to recapture a lost unity,'' he wrote, watching them drift off to sleep huddled on the ground near a fire for warmth. ''I can sense in all of them an immense kindness, a profoundly carefree attitude, a naive and charming animal satisfaction and ... something which might be called the most truthful and moving expression of human love.''

title: New Earthquake Reported From Region East of Naples
description: An earth tremor was reported today from the area east of here that was hit by a devastating quake in November.

title: Hostage Is Reported Freed At Embassy in Havana
description: A group of 29 would-be Cuban emigrants occupying the Ecuadorean Embassy freed one of their four hostages tonight, according to a diplomat close to the situation. They had threatened to kill the hostages unless asylum was granted.

title: GAINFULLY EMPLOYED SENIOR CITIZEN REAGAN
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Guide; BLACK HISTORY MONTH
description: Black History Month is just about at the halfway mark, but the schedule marking the celebration continues to be a full and diverse one.

title:
Dining Out;
CHOOSING DISHES FROM NAPLES NORTH
description: ONE of the first restaurants visible from the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway as one crosses into Westchester is Venezia di Notte in Yonkers. The place is certainly noticeable: its facade features a large illuminated map of Italy, the most famous cities marked by light bulbs. The enchanting name implies promise of northeastern specialties like rissoto, polenta, tripe and fish; we looked forward to our visits. But disappointments are all the keener when expectations run high, and we were disenchanted rather frequently here, not only in the few northern dishes offered but in others besides.

title: Julia Hamilton Engaged to Shaw Mudge Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bill L. Hamilton of Stamford, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Julia Katherine Hamilton, to Shaw Mudge Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mudge of Greenwich, Conn., and Harrington, Me. A June wedding is planned.

title: BYRNE SEES FEDERAL AID ON WATER
description: WASHINGTON WELL into the last year of his eight years in office, Governor Byrne did something last week at which he has become an old hand: He visited the White House and asked the occupant to help New Jersey cope with one of its problems.

title: DEFICIT FOR CIVIC CENTER CAUSING CONCERN
description: HARTFORD ON Feb. 6 last year, more than 14,000 people witnessed the official reopening of the Coliseum in the Hartford Civic Center. Mayor George A. Athanson hailed the event as a manifestation of ''the people's faith in Hartford.'' The music, reflecting optimism, included ''Happy Days Are Here Again.''

title: GADGETRY INVADES THE UPPER RANKS OF AUDIO EQUIPMENT
description: Looking for ways to hoist itself from its current slump, the American car industry evidently relies on bright ideas. For example, you can now buy a Cadillac with a computer-controlled seat that ''remembers'' your preferred driving position. Somebody else may adjust the seat differently. But when you get back into your car, you just touch a button and the memory-controlled seat will automatically conform itself to your figure. It is hoped, apparently, that this will be recognized as an advance in transportation, even though it would be much cheaper to adjust the seat by hand.

title: IF IRAN WERE SPLIT INTO EASTERN AND WESTERN SPHERES OF INTEREST
description: To the Editor:

title: HE MADE 'LA CAGE' AND IT MAKES HIM SAD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Dan Yakir, a freelance writer, has a special interest in films. By DAN YAKIR

title: KEYBOARD HARBINGERS OF THE BACH TRICENTENNIAL
description: No body of music has been subjected to a greater diversity of presentation and interpretation than Bach's keyboard music, which only proves its abiding value and universal appeal. Over the years Bach has been played on the harpsichord, clavichord, piano, synthesizer, koto, kazoo and heaven knows what else, as well as in countless arrangements for various instrumental combinations. In what form it may next appear is anybody's guess, now that the composer's tricentennial is approaching in 1985 - a big year for the Baroque, for 1985 also marks the 300th birthdays of Handel and Domenico Scarlatti.

title: GOPOD FORTUNE IN 1980 IS MARKED IN GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: Helping others by giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is often chosen as a way of expressing gratitude by those who have enjoyed good fortune or who find themselves better off today than a year ago.

title: Barbados
description: To the Editor:

title: BATTLER FOR A CLEAN HUDSON
description: ''I'D fight for any river, but in truth, this river is one of the most biologically productive ecosystems on the face of the earth,'' said Robert H. Boyle, standing before a sweeping view of the Hudson River at his Cold Spring home. On this cold, windy day, a slight haze obscured the Bear Mountain Bridge to the south.

title: Contaminated Water Called Safe
description: Health officials say that contamination of drinking water, which has made the water taste vile, is much worse than originally thought. But a state health department spokesman stressed yesterday that the water was still safe to drink. The source of the contamination is still being investigated.

title: REPORTER LICENSING WEIGHED BY UNESCO
description: A plan to create a new international organization to licence journalists and insure that they comply with the ''generally accepted'' ethics of their profession will be introduced here on Monday at a meeting organized by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

title: OF AN EPIC MOVIE AND TINY LADY
description: The recent presentation at Radio City Music Hall of Kevin Brownlow's reconstituted, four-hour silent version of Abel Gance's 1927 classic, ''Napoleon,'' was the sort of unexpected popular triumph that makes writing about movies worthwhile. It's difficult to imagine seeing this extraordinary film in any other auditorium that would match the epic, just slightly dated grandeur of Gance's film, which, like the Music Hall, needs all the loving care it can get to survive in this era of fast food and other forms of immediate gratification. There was also something appropriately profligate in the use of the 60-member American Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Carmine Coppola, to play the accompanying musical score that had been composed by Mr. Coppola.

title: HOW PEOPLE TOLD A LEADER GOODBYE
description: THE memorials and tributes to Ella T. Grasso did not end with the state funeral for Connecticut's 83d Governor. Gifts for the Ella Grasso Foundation are still arriving. Through last Tuesday, donations totaled $2,800 for the fund, which was set up to finance scholarships and fellowships for young persons interested in studies or careers in government.

title: Jet-Car Driver on a New Course
description: For most rookie stock-car drivers, the 200-mile-per-hour speeds at the Daytona International Speedway are a big challenge. But for Stan Barrett, 200 m.p.h. is barely rolling.

title: Christina Skalny Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard L. Skalny of Rochester have made known the engagement of their daughter, Christina Skalny, to Albert M. Van Wagenen 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Wagenen 3d of Rye, N.Y. The couple, graduates of St. Lawrence University, will be married in May.

title: Girls Set U.S. Mark Of 1:45.5 in 800 Relay
description: Most Saturdays at the 102d Engineers Armory, the schoolboys hold the center stage at the track and field meets. Yesterday, at the Nassau Coaches meet, the girls took over the spotlight.

title: CIVIL WAR-LINCOLN BUFFS REFLECT AN AMBIANCE OF BYGONE TIMES
description: Along about 8 o'clock Thursday night, they dimmed the lights in the Seventh Regiment Armory's fourth-floor Rumpus Room and the Civil War Round Table and the Abraham Lincoln Group of New York once again turned the clocks back to their favorite era.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ROYAL HEIR MARRIES COMMONER: Prince Henri of Luxembourg and Maria Teresa Mestre leaving the cathedral of Luxembourg. Miss Mestre, 24-year-old daughter of a Cuban emigre, raised ''some doubts as to her suit-ability as a future Grand Duchess,'' court sources said, but Prince Henri dismissed all reservations. Among witnesses were King Baudouin of Belgium, Prince Philip of Britain, Prince Rainier and Princess Grace of Monaco.

title: Gallery View; THE WEALTH OF IRISH CONTRIBUTIONS
description: As to the extent of the Irish contribution to world literature, everyone is more or less of the same mind. The history of poetry in the 20th century would have a big hole in it if W.B. Yeats were to be taken away. The history of the novel would lack central energy if no one mentioned James Joyce. It looks as if the plays of Oscar Wilde, J.M. Synge, Sean O'Casey and Samuel Beckett will be performed as long as people want to see live actors on a stage. Among storytellers, the Irish - from Somerville and Ross in the 1880's through Elizabeth Bowen and Sean O'Faolain and onward - have had the gift of making us sit up and say, ''What happened next?''

title:
Dance;
AN INTRICATE NEW WORK BY SARA RUDNER
description: IN sweat pants, sweat shirt and jazz shoes, Sara Rudner generates movement like an electric engine. She is among the fastest-moving dancers in memory of many experts in the field, and has become a modern dance cult figure.

title: Zurich Clarinet Trio Plays Graupner, Rousseau
description: In case you were thinking that by themselves three clarinetists could not possibly come up with a diverting concert program, consider the ingenuity of the Zurich Clarinet Trio in its New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Tuesday night.

title:
Antiques;
SHOW TO RAISE FUNDS
description: GUILFORD JUST as private homes do, museum houses maintained by historical societies regularly need repairs and utility bills must be paid. In years past, endowment funds and membership fees usually defrayed such costs. Today, with rising service charges and inflation, many societies need other ways to raise money. A favorite method is to sponsor an antiques show, such as the one this coming Friday and Saturday for the benefit of the Hyland House at 85 Boston Street, not far from the Town Green.

title: A LESSON LEARNED IN TIBET
description: WHEN I travel, I enjoy comparing notes with my counterparts in other places - places that often share some of the problems facing Westchester County. So when I made a trip to Tibet, 12,000 feet above sea level at the ''Roof of the World,'' I looked for an opportunity to discuss shared problems and solutions.

title: MAPLE LEAFS DEFEAT RANGERS, 6-3
description: The Rangers, plagued by penalties, yielded three power-play goals in the first period and four in all in losing to Toronto, 6-3, tonight at Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: OFFICE RENTS: UP AND UP
description: Businesses seeking new office space in Buenos Aires are in for a surprise, according to a recent survey by Richard Ellis, a British real estate agency. The Argentine capital had the world's most expensive office space in 1980, about $65 a square foot.

title: THE WINTER OF 1980-1981 FROM COLD TO PARCHED
description: WESTCHESTER goes from one weather crisis to another. Early in January, it was the frigid temperatures; there were six days of zero or below-zero temperatures in the northern part of the county before the 19th of the month. The coldest day of that arctic-like period occurred Jan. 12, when the temperature fell 10 to 15 degrees below zero - setting a 40-year record in Yorktown and a 75-year record in Carmel.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
GOOD RIDDANCE TO PRICE CONTROLS
description: The Carter ExperienceFormer President Carter's Council on Wage and Price Stability contended that its wage-price standards dampened inflation considerably. The General Accounting Office disagreed, in a 1980 report titled ''The Voluntary Pay and Price Standards Have Had No Discernible Effect on Inflation ''.

title: A RISKY VENTURE AT THE MET
description: ROCKWELL TRIMMED VERSION By JOHN ROCKWELL

title: Alice L. Ober Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Ober Jr. of Monkton, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice Lawrence Ober, to Harry L. Curtis 3d, son of Mr. Curtis Jr. of Lynnfield, Mass., and Mrs. Morton Margolis of North Andover, Mass.

title: NONALIGNED ASSAIL INDUSTRIAL LANDS ON ECONOMIC ISSUES
description: A conference of 94 nations professing nonalignment that ended here last night was unanimous in denouncing the world's industrial countries over economic issues.

title: INDOOR AND OUTDOOR DELIGHTS OF WINTERING IN CONNEMARA
description: Some of its natives still refer to Connemara as the edge of the world. A maritime expanse of rocky, mountainous bogland dotted with lakes in Ireland's County Galway, it is the westernmost wilderness in Europe, and not a place that recommends itself for a winter vacation. But when my husband, Paul, and I set out from the city of Galway on a counterclockwise circuit that rambled for 10 days through 250 miles of Connemara's perimeter, the advantages of an off-season visit became clear.

title: Connecticut Housing; REPAIRS:A CONDOMINIUM DILEMMA
description: WHEN the 524 unit owners at Cromwell Hills, a condominium development near Hartford, found out that they needed $750,000 for the rebuilding and resurfacing of roofs, they estimated it would cost each owner about $1,500 - hardly an amount that the residents, whose average annual income is $25,000, had readily available at short notice.

title: A TURN TO THE RIGHT IN SPAIN
description: Until now, the story of Spain's transition to democracy has had a bright, fairy-tale ring to it: Brave King Juan Carlos and his handsome Prime Minister, Adolfo Suarez, slaying the dragons of reaction and burying the dark legend of a once-violent people. But an embittered Mr. Suarez has just twisted that cheery plot line by suddenly resigning after four-and-a-half years on the job.

title: Straws in the Wind Of Policy on Bias
description: With the Reagan Justice Department still lacking an Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights and Attorney General William French Smith without a track record on desegregation issues, the Administration's policy remains largely unknown. Last week, there were signs that while the winds of change may slow, they have not stopped entirely.

title: Marjorie A. Lane To Marry in May
description: Marjorie Anne Lane, tour and travel account executive at Berkshire Place, a New York hotel, plans to be married in New York in May to Alan B. Heilbron of New York, manager of performance reporting and budgeting with the RCA Corporation.

title: Kjersti Warren Wed To Peter Chester
description: Kjersti Warren of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Warren of Seneca Falls, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Minton Chester, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hawley T. Chester Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. John Karrer performed the ceremony at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich.

title: YALE OPENS $6 MILLION CAMPAIGN FOR ITS JUDAIC-STUDIES PROGRAM
description: Yale University has begun a campaign to raise more than $6 million to centralize and enlarge its Judaic-studies program, university officials said yesterday.

title: WILLIAM P. REUSS
description: William P. Reuss, a retired first vice president of the Franklin Savings Bank, died Friday at his home in Hopatcong, N.J. He was 71 years old.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WHERE THE BUFFALOES BEGIN By Olaf Baker. Illustrated by Stephen Gammell. Unpaged. New York: Frederick Warne & Co. $8.95. (Ages 8 to 10) By GEORGE A.WOODS

title: PANEL URGES TAXES TO CLEAN UP REACTOR
description: A committee overseeing the cleanup of the damaged, highly radioactive reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant has recommended that most of the estimated $1 billion cost of decontaminating the reactor be paid by taxpayers.

title: A RELIGIOUS ROMANCE
description: THE COMPANY OF WOMEN By Mary Gordon. 291 pp. New York: Random House. $12.95

title:
Art;
SHOW AT RIDGEFIELD: SURROGATE FOR SOHO
description: RIDGEFIELD PEOPLE who intend to visit New York's SoHo district to look at new paintings and somehow never quite make it now have an alternative. The Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield has mounted an exhibition of uncompromisingly original work entitled ''Acquisitions Plus'' that will be shown through April 13. Seeing the show is good deal like visiting several SoHo galleries in the summer, when they tend to show a single work by all the artists they have exhibited in the previous season.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY
description: Washington's birthday is Feb. 22. But it will be observed tomorrow in New York City and throughout the country.

title: TRYING TO PUT THE BRAKES ON STOP SIGNS
description: Thousands of stop signs are erected each year in the residential neighborhoods of this country. Recently, one was taken down. ''It causes air and noise pollution and wastes energy,'' Doris Gootnick said of the stop sign that had been outside her home in Plainview, Long Island. ''We were safer without it.''

title:
STAMPS;
U.N. PROCLAIMS 1981 AS YEAR FOR DISABLED PEOPLE
description: The lame and the halt, the blind and the deaf, the ravaged victims of disease, the crippled victims of disasters, the mentally ill, the retarded - the 500 million ''disabled'' of the world - all these have been made the focus of special concern this year by proclamation of the United Nations.

title: N.Y.U. PROGRAM OF REBUILDING DRAWING TO CLOSE
description: ''We've not got much elbow room,'' John M. O'Mara, the vice president of real-estate operations for New York University, recently remarked.

title: Sara Robinson Will Be Bride Of Paul Farhi
description: Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Westover Robinson of Evans Mills, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sara Walton Robinson, to Paul Aaron Farhi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Pierre Farhi of New York. A May wedding is planned in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: U.S. vs.I.B.M.
description: The Justice Department's landmark suit against the International Business Machines Corporation is the most vivid illustration of the difficulty and expense of the big antitrust cases in which a basic restructuring of a major industry is sought as the remedy.

title: Theater; A VETERAN OF DRAMA STARS AT LONG WHARF
description: NEW HAVEN THE place was the men's dressing room of the Long Wharf Theater, deserted at 10:30 of a weekday morning. Margaret Barker, a grayhaired woman wearing a Shetland sweater, well-cut slacks and boots, sat in a straightback chair. She is 73, slender and the fine bones of her face suggest a former model. Her well-modulated voice is a a touch husky. She wore a wedding ring. ''I never married,'' she said. ''That's for my performance.''

title: Cynthia D. Reiche, Scott Schumacker, Lawyer, Affianced
description: Cynthia Dalzell Reiche, who teaches Latin and Greek at the Nightingale-Bamford School, plans to be married in July in Princeton, J.J., to Scott Frederic Schumacker, a lawyer in Philadelphia.

title: A VISIONARY PAINTER PRESENTED ON STAGE
description: YONKERS ONE of the most endearing entertainments that has ever been put on in a museum is ''Thomas Cole, a Waking Dream,'' which can be seen at 3 P.M. today at the Hudson River Museum. It runs for 75 minutes; admission is free. Audiences have been coming away from it in two minds as to whether what they have seen is theater, in any strict sense of the word, or whether it is indeed a waking dream.

title: SOVIET INSIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: POLISH UNION CHIEF INDICATES HE BACKS 90 STRIKE-FREE DAYS
description: Lech Walesa, the independent union leader, met with officials today and indicated later that he hoped the union could cooperate with the new Government's plea for 90 strike-free days.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW ELIZABETH MOVES TO AVERT A DISASTER
description: ELIZABETH THE rupture of a valve on a 30,000-gallon tank-truck that was being prepared for the loading of sulfur trioxide a few weeks ago created a highly visible cloud of white caustic gas about 100 feet wide and 1,000 feet high. It also set into motion disaster plans at the Allied Chemical Corporation, where the incident occurred, and at City Hall.

title: A FULL-LENGTH 'OTHELLO' BY BONNEFOUS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lee Edward Stern, the dance critic of WNYC, writes frequently on the performing arts. By LEE EDWARD STERN

title: ISLANDERS AND BLUES SETTLE FOR 1-1 STANDOFF
description: The battle for first place in the overall National Hockey League standing ended in a standoff tonight when the Islanders and the St. Louis Blues played to a 1-1 tie at Nassau Coliseum. The result left the clubs tied with 78 points although the Blues have two games in hand.

title: PRODUCER AND PERFORMER
description: LIVE AT THE VILLAGE VANGUARD By Max Gordon. Introduction by Nat Hentoff. Illustrated. 146 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95.

title: ATHLETIC SURGERY MUST PROGRESS; Athletic Surgery Must Progress
description: To the Sports Editor: Arthroscopic surgery is one of the three major advances in sports medicine, in our generation (''Athletes With Injured Knees Find Short Cut on Road to Recovery,'' The New York Times, Feb. 1). The other two, sports podiatry and the concept of muscle strength and flexibility balance, have to do with medical treatment of athletic injuries.

title: Deborah Toby Scheiner Is Engaged to Ronald Hoxter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Scheiner of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Toby Scheiner, to Ronald Alan Hoxter, son of Curtis Hoxter of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Hoxter. A May wedding is planned.

title: AUSTRALIA'S PRIDE IS IT'S 'NEW WAVE' OF FILMS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Keith Connolly is film critic of The Herald, Melbourne. By KEITH CONNOLLY MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
WHY BLAME BOXING IN SCANDAL
description: ''B OXING'S Biggest Scam,'' was the caption on one story. Another piece referred to it as ''a $20 million-plus embezzlement in boxing.'' On the air and in the papers, there have been repeated references to a ''boxing scandal'' with, naturally, the assertion that the collapse of Harold J. Smith's high-octane fight promotion in Madison Square Garden had given the Sweet Science ''another black eye.''

title: SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Business Editor: The implied contract with retirees has to do with what that pension will buy, not the actual number of dollars paid. In essence, retirees would not need or demand cost of living increases if the Government, whose responsibility it is, kept the cost of living stable. Buying a loaf of bread does not create inflation, for crying out loud! MARILYN HOGAN Detroit, Feb.1, 1981

title: PURVEYING HARD-CORE FUNK
description: Funk permeates popular music. There's funk in hits by the Bee Gees and Barbra Streisand; there's funk in the glossy poprock of Steely Dan, the harder rock of the Rolling Stones, and the more experimental rock of the Talking Heads. There's funk in most varieties of black pop and disco. And there's a musical genre called funk which emphasizes whatever it is that makes music funky.

title: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.
description: A N outsider from the static North gazes in awe at the extent and variety of the new housing in Palm Beach County. Last year, the area was the third fastest-growing in the country and this year it expects to be second only to Dallas.

title: CONCERT: ERIC BENTLEY
description: Eric Bentley, the playwright, teacher, critic, lyric writer and translator of Bertolt Brecht and Jacques Prevert, returned to his occasional career as nightclub entertainer on Thursday and Friday evenings at s.n.a.f.u., at the Avenue of the Americas and 21st Street, to sing a program celebrating St. Valentine's Day.

title: PICASSO, OF COURSE, IS EVERYWHERE
description: THE SHOCK OF THE NEW By Robert Hughes. Illustrated. 423 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95. By VIVIEN RAYNOR

title: Hotel Union Votes to End Strike
description: The largest of eight unions on strike against the Greenbrier, the luxury resort hotel, voted unanimously yesterday to end their two-month walkout, union officials said.

title: Maria de Oliveira Is Married To Adilson Lima do Carmo
description: Seton Hall University's Immaculate Conception Chapel in South Orange, N.J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Maria de Oliveira, daughter of Jonas Leao de Oliveira of Belo Horizonte, Brazil, and the late Geraldine Goulart de Oliveira, to Adilson Lima do Carmo, son of Mercedes Lima do Carmo of Belo Horizonte and the late Jaulino do Carmo. The Rev. Nicholas DiMarzio, associate executive director of Catholic Community Services of the Archdiocese of Newark, performed the ceremony.

title: RIDING THE PENNSYLVANIAN: VIEW, COMFORT AND LORE
description: For Matthew Oliver, conductor on the Pennsylvanian, riding the train is a nice way to make a living, and he wants to make sure everyone else aboard enjoys it as much as he does.

title:
Gardening;
COLD,DROUGHT MAY AFFECT SPRING PLANTS
description: THE severe cold this winter probably has already taken a toll of plant life. Tender broadleaf evergreens such as English hollies show leaf burn. Whether they will suffer greater damage than mere defoliation must wait until spring or summer for a final determination. Those in the more exposed locations have suffered the greatest damage.

title: O-P CREDITS TK Management, American Style
description: Faulting American business managers for pursuing the wrong goals is like blaming politicians for being responsive to their constituencies (''Overhauling America's Business Management,'' by Steve Lohr, Jan.4).

title: Treating Allergies From the Inside Out
description: Scientists care less about what people are allergic to - ragweed, lobster or the neighbor's cat - than why 35 million Americans are allergic to begin with, and how the allergic response works. Recently, two teams of researchers, working independently and chiefly with animals, have penetrated that biological labyrinth and say they have found the key to allergy treatment, perhaps to prevention.

title: CLEVELAND TESTING ADVICE OF ROHAYTN
description: When city officials finally began to get Cleveland's default-ridden books into order and looked for a way out of its financial crisis, they did what a growing number of other public officials have done: They called Felix G. Rohatyn.

title: Campus Sharks and Horror Shows
description: William Safire observes that ''the metaphoric extension of 'horror show' is relatively recent'' (''A La Mode,'' On Language, Dec. 28).

title: ELECTION COMMISSION, EDITORIAL CAMPAIGNS ARE NOT YOUR PROVINCE
description: In a suit that has national implications for press freedom, the Reader's Digest Association on Tuesday is to ask the United States District Court here to enjoin the Federal Election Commission from investigating the preparation, dissemination, and promotion of an article about a political figure.

title: SKI TOURING ON CANOE-PORTAGING TRAILS IN THE ADIRONDACKS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- DAVID KEMP is a writer who lives in New York. By DAVID KEMP

title: Williams & Co. Launches Its Own Political Firm
description: Shirley Williams last week dropped the other shoe. She quit the British Labor Party's National Executive Committee, signaling her intention to form a new party from among Labor's frustrated right wing.

title: Ullrich Takes Biathlon
description: Frank Ullrich of East Germany, winner of the Olympic gold medal in the 10-kilometer biathlon, took his fourth world title in the distance today at the world biathlon championships. His time was 33 minutes 8.57 seconds for the event, which combines cross-country skiing and rifle shooting.

title: READINGTHE TORAH
description: Most of the groups who meet together to address the issues of business ethics are Christian, but there are others as well. Once a month, about 35 to 40 members of the Wall Street community assemble to hear how Jewish biblical tradition and Talmudic law can be applied to modern-day commerce and money-making.

title:
Gardening;
COLD,DROUGHT MAY AFFECT SPRING PLANTS
description: THE severe cold this winter probably has already taken a toll of plant life. Tender broadleaf evergreens such as English hollies show leaf burn. Whether they will suffer greater damage than mere defoliation must wait until spring or summer for a final determination. Those in the more exposed locations have suffered the greatest damage.

title: A LIFETIME OF FREE PASSES FOR SOME WHO MISSED BASEBALL
description: OF all the perquisites being passed around to the former hostages, none seems more durable than the free, lifetime passes being ponied up by major league baseball. I know, because I checked it out with my 10-year-old son.

title: POLICE AND ANGELS GROUP GIVE 2 VERSIONS OF IND CLASH
description: The New York City transit police and the Guardian Angels, the volunteer youth group that patrols the subways, yesterday gave conflicting versions of the melee on a subway train in Brooklyn that led to the arrest Friday night of 10 members of the group and one passenger.

title: LANDLORD IS JAILED IN 3 DEATHS FOR VIOLATING FIRE CODE
description: A South Jersey landlord has been sentenced to 30 days in jail for failing to install smoke detectors in a house in which three persons died in a fire last December. His lawyer said the conviction had been appealed.

title: About Westchester
description: THEY were there for the blackout of 1977, the severe snowstorm of January 1978 and the train crash in Dobbs Ferry last November. And if a breakdown at the Indian Point nuclear power plant should ever necessitate an evacuation, they will be there, too.

title: Mitterrand Visiting North Korea
description: Francois Mitterrand, the French Socialist Party's presidential candidate, left here today for a one-day visit to North Korea, according to the New China News Agency.

title: WAS DETERGENT BAN REALLY NECESSARY?
description: IN two weeks, on March 1, it will be 10 years to the day that Suffolk County banned the sale of almost all detergents, thereby establishing a reputation as a pioneer in the movement to safeguard the environment. During those years, while stores stocked a variety of substitute products, Suffolk residents presumably took what they thought was the high road to clean water by learning to do the laundry with soap.

title: INDEPENDENTS PURSUE TV ACTION
description: THOUSANDS of people are trying to turn their castles in the air into television packages. However, they are having trouble finding sponsors to back them and stations willing to give them air time.

title: Theresa Sutton Is Married
description: The marriage of Theresa Sutton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Sutton of Lindenhurst, L.I., to John W. Fryback, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Fryback of Bluffton, Ind., took place yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Charles Amstein performed the ceremony. The bride is marketing services manager for Aramis International, a division of Estee Lauder Inc., the cosmetics concern, in New York, where her husband is executive vice president and a partner of Elms Capital Management Inc., a money-management concern.

title: SOME SAY THIS IS AMERICA'S BEST TV STATION
description: BOSTON Can a local commercial television station afford to originate dozens of hours of its own shows, offer regular prime-time programs on health, the law and minority issues, feature five separate newscasts a day and spend $500,000 on a series of Saturday-morning children's programs?

title: Lydia G. Gefvert, Broker, Is a Bride
description: Lydia Gardner Gefvert, a member of the American Stock Exchange and a floor broker and specialist for Bear Stearns & Company in New York, was married yesterday to James Rhodes McKeon, a financial analyst with the International Business Machines Corporation in Suffern, N.Y. The Rev. Frederick W. Phinney performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Notes; KNOXVILLE,TENN. TO BE HOST FOR WORLD'S FAIR OF 1982
description: Travelers who like to go to World's Fairs have not had one to go to since the World's Fair of 1974 in Spokane, Wash., but here is early warning on the next one: It will be in Knoxville, Tenn., and it will open on May 1, 1982.

title: THE PRIVATE HEMINGWAY
description: Ours has not been a great period for literary correspondence. The telephone, the hurried pace of life and the languishing of the habit of informal written discourse, once manifest in memoirs and diaries, have contributed to an epistolary malaise. The gregarious, fluent letters of Byron or Henry James reflect less beleaguered epochs.

title: STATE BEGINS BATTLE TO KEEP FEDERAL AID
description: WASHINGTON NEW JERSEY officials have begun the long fight to save several state programs the Reagan Administration hopes to slash in its budget cutting.

title: POPE MAY FIND A FEW POLISH PARALLELS IN HIS VISIT TO MANILA Paul II
description: When Pope John Paul II arrives in this overwhelmingly Roman Catholic country Tuesday, he may find surprising parallels with his native Poland.

title: STOCKS THAT DON'T PAY DIVIDENDS
description: T OM BROWN INC., an oil drilling and exploration company, won top honors last year in the portfolio of the Rowe Price New Horizons Fund, a mutual fund that invests in small growth companies. It soared 338 percent in price. The fund's other leading performers, climbing anywhere from 216 percent to 181 percent, were Tandy Corporation, Cray Research, Quotron Systems and Avantek Inc.

title: Nature Unit Buys Island Where Bald Eagles Nest
description: Placentia Island, one of the largest undeveloped islands in Blue Hills Bay, situated in an area where the American bald eagle has nested on and off since 1920, has been purchased by the Maine chapter of Nature Conservancy.

title: DENVER
description: Next to petroleum geologists, hydrogeologists are the most popular breed. For oil shale exploration companies, many of whom operate in semi-arid Colorado, water in large volume is the key to production.

title: UNDEFEATED OREGON STATE TROUNCES ST. JOHN'S, 57-45
description: Out of the Far West came the powerful Oregon State Beavers, undefeated and with a No. 1 ranking. But they did not look the part, even though they won.

title: No Headline
description: Any manager I know could cite examples of executives who lost their posts over disagreements with their bosses in which the competence of neither was in doubt, so William Niskanen's sobering experience does not surprise me.

title: 'STORE OIL' IS EASIER SAID THAN DONE
description: The facts are as simple as they are depressing. Three times in the past seven years, events outside the control of Western countries have sharply diminished world oil supplies. Simultaneously, their inability to produce or to conserve to protect themselves has become painfully public knowledge, laying them open to unacceptable leverage by oil producers.

title: ARTIST'S NAME MISSPELLED
description: TRY TO USE THIS ON ART PAGE, PAGE 28, IF POSSIBLE. Artist's Name Misspelled

title: No Headline
description: The article on only children was interesting to me, as a feminist, particularly the comments indicating that there will very likely be more and more families with only one child.

title: Which Came First
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I.HOUSE RACES: HOW MONEY COUNTS
description: AN analysis of campaign spending in six Long Island Congressional district elections last November points up many of the problems and potential evils associated with election campaign financing.

title: 'Big Holes' in Busboy Story Of Las Vegas Fire Reported
description: Arson investigators are taking a close look at statements by two friends of the busboy held in connection with the Las Vegas Hilton fire, and have also found new evidence that will ''throw big holes'' in his story, the authorities said today.

title: Long Island Journal
description: A GROUP of Riverhead merchants have requested additional police protection because of an increased number of burglaries, robberies and muggings in the downtown business district.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Conn. Crime Fight Runs Out of Room
description: When Connecticut legislators passed a bill last year to stiffen sentences for serious crimes, they apparently had only a vague notion of how rapidly the measure might increase the state's prison population. Last week they found out, and some state officials expressed fear that when the law takes effect in July, it will create more problems than it solves.

title: WHO'S WHO IN HIGH-STYLE SHOE DESIGN
description: Every aspect of fashion design has its stars, and in the realm of shoes there are currently five: Manolo Blahnik, Maud Frizon, the team of Susan Bennis and Warren Edwards, and Todd Ricci. Their shoes are special not just because they are handmade by artisans working with fine skins and fabrics, but primarily because their designs are innovative, trend-setting, even witty, the kind of designs that appeal to people who care not only about fashion in general but shoes in particular. Their clients include athletes, singers, models, actors and actresses, socialites, executives and fashion designers.

title: WAMBAUGH BACK
description: ''The Glitter Dome,'' Joseph Wambaugh's first novel in three years, will be out in June, and nobody is more surprised than ex-police sergeant Wambaugh.

title: Embattled Judge
description: The charge was murder. The Brooklyn District Attorney alleged that Elisia Fominas, 24 years old, had participated last September in the dismemberment of her 3-year-old daughter by a previous marriage.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Unwelcome Boom

title: A 'MIRACLE WORKER' VISITS NORTH JERSEY
description: SOUTH ORANGE THE Rev. Ralph A. DiOrio brought his ''ministry of healing'' to New Jersey last weekend and literally laid them in the aisles. In three jammed services in college auditoriums, the priest performed the Biblical ''laying on of hands.'' In so doing, he saw more than 100 people who had complained of various ailments topple to the floor at his touch and then, minutes later, stand up and say that their pains had been relieved. In the interim, all had been in a trance of sorts.

title: Daphne Milliken Fiancee of S.L.Webbe
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Minot K. Milliken of New York and Hulls Cove, Me., of the engagement of their daughter, Daphne Clark Milliken, to Scotson Lindsay Webbe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Scotson Webbe of Northfield, Ill.

title: Derating TV News
description: Television journalism could be greatly enhanced if the three major networks adopt the suggestion of Roone Arledge, the president of ABC News. He wants all documentaries and special news programs removed from the prime-time ratings game.

title: THE DEBATE SHARPENS ON A NEW WORLD INFORMATION ORDER
description: Tomorrow in Paris, third world, Communist and Western experts will resume discussion of a controversial ''new world information order,'' a restructured system of world communications sought by many developing countries to promote their political and economic goals.

title: JET CRASH ADDS TO CONCERN OVER AIRPORT
description: FOES of expansion at Westchester County Airport turned out last week in Greenwich for the second public meeting on the issue in the last two and a half months. It was one of several developments during the week aimed at curbing noise in communities around the Westchester-owned airport on the New York-Connecticut border, but the only one giving a direct reading of the amount of public concern.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Times Sq. Revival Aims for Song and Dance - and More
description: If there's really a broken heart for every light on Broadway, many of them probably belong to real estate developers. For years, they have submitted plan after plan to rebuild the gaudy, seedy, dangerous but potentially valuable property around Times Square and, for years, they have been thwarted, sometimes by community group opposition and sometimes by City Hall.

title: Two American Balloonists Abandon Flight in India
description: Mechanical troubles today forced two American balloonists to cut short their attempt at the first nonstop, round-the-world balloon flight, officials here reported.

title: GREEK PARTIES START ELECTION CAMPAIGN
description: With pink carnations, revolutionary songs and promises of change, Andreas Papandreou and his opposition Panhellenic Socialist Movement held a pre-election victory party here recently.

title: No Headline
description: I can give my daughter much more - both emotionally and socially - if she remains my only dependent.

title: Practical Traveler; A PRE-DAWN LANDING,AND THEN?
description: Just before 3 o'clock on a recent Sunday morning, my wife and I arrived at Kennedy International Airport on a flight from Barbados that was more than four hours late. As we were collecting our baggage, we saw a Carey bus to Manhattan waiting outside. Three minutes later, as we and many other passengers were hurrying toward the terminal door, the bus pulled away. The driver apparently was unaware that a jetliner with nearly 200 passengers had just arrived.

title: Pro Transactions; BASEBALL
description: Signed Jeff Reardon, relief p itcher, to one-year contract for $70,000 plus i ncentives. CHICAGO (AL) - Signed to 1981 con- t racts Dewey Robinson and Mark Teutsch, m inor league relief pitchers.

title: Thomas Edward Winter Weds Pamela F. Williams
description: Pamela Fairchild Williams and Thomas Edward Winter were married last evening at the Long Ridge Congregational Church in Stamford, Conn., by the Rev. George Eckstein.

title: P.L. Kennard Weds Patricia M. Cassidy
description: In the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, Patricia Mary Cassidy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edgar Cassidy of Kensington, Md., was married to Peter Laurence Kennard, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Walter Kennard of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. John O'Hare performed the ceremony.

title: Scientists Yield on Code Censorship
description: Ever since the apple episode, delving into secret knowledge has been a risky business. Last week, a group of scholars, after balancing the perils to national security against the rewards of academic freedom, decided to let the Government prune the tree.

title:
COMMENT;
TAXES AND OPTIONS
description: F ACTS: XYZ Corporation rewarded John Smith, one of its officers, for a fine performance by granting him an option on the company's stock. Mr. Smith exercised the options in June, paying $500,000, in borrowed money, for stock that had a fair market value of $900,000 at the time. Being a corporate officer, he was constrained from selling the stock for at least six months - or else, under Securities and Exchange Commission rules, he would have to return any profits to the company.

title: Nature Watch; NATURE WATCH; HARBOR SEAL; Phoca vitulina
description: Size: Averages 5 feet long. Color: Variable: yellowish gray with brown splotches, brown with gray splotches.

title: CAIRO SEEMS TO ADOPT CLOSER TIES TO P.L.O. BEFORE NEW U.S. TALKS
description: Recent indications from Cairo suggest that the Egyptian Government is shifting its position toward the Palestine Liberation Organization in anticipation of a new phase in the Middle East peace negotiations with the Reagan Administration.

title: UNDERSTANDING THE COUNSELOR'S ROLE
description: TWO high school seniors talked to me recently about the ineptness of their guidance counselors. Both felt that their counselors lacked information, had little time for them and cared even less.

title: SURVIVING A GUILT TRIP IN THE CITY
description: A FAMILY phenomenon has crept onto the scene virtually unnoticed by those faceless folks who make and monitor the rules for family behavior. Although I have scoured my woefully skimpy collection of ''How to Be a Better Parent'' books, I have yet to find a chapter dealing with the subject. It is a nettlesome, guilt-fraught topic: ''What to Do When You're Staying in the City Overnight - and You've Left the Children at Home.''

title: PLAN PROVIDING AID TO SMALL BUSINESSES
description: UP to 35 small businesses in the county can obtain free ''needsassessment consultations'' in a Private Industry Council program. Intended to increase profits and expand job opportunities, the Small Business Management Advisory Program will provide a consultant for up to five days. Applicant companies must show that they have been in business in Westchester for at least three years and employ 10 to 500 people. Companies must also demonstrate an ability to employ people who are eligible under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

title: STATE CREATING DRY-DAY PLAN IT HOPES NEVER WILL BE USED
description: WEST TRENTON IN A specially designated room at State Police headquarters here, a newly formed emergency preparedness staff drawn from all cabinet departments in the state government is hard at work these days on a plan that everybody hopes will wind up in the trash bin.

title: OPPOSING SIDES STEP UP EFFORTS ON ABORTION MEASURE
description: This weekend, for the first time in its 12-year history, the National Abortion Rights Action League is limiting the agenda for its annual meeting to one topic: the human life amendment.

title: CLASHING DESIGNS RUFFLE STONY CREEK
description: STONY CREEK DRIVING under the railroad bridge and down by the waterfront, a visitor passes businesses that have been here for generations: Brainerd's Garage, Paines Store, Betts Marine. There are Victorian mansions and summer cottages, along with small houses made from handhewn pink granite quarried a few miles away.

title:
Gardening;
COLD,DROUGHT MAY AFFECT SPRING PLANTS
description: THE severe cold this winter probably has already taken a toll of plant life. Tender broadleaf evergreens such as English hollies show leaf burn. Whether they will suffer greater damage than mere defoliation must wait until spring or summer for a final determination. Those in the more exposed locations have suffered the greatest damage.

title: Caren Sara Siebert To Be Wed May 9
description: The engagement of Caren Sara Siebert, daughter of Mrs. Preston G. Siebert of Ossining, N.Y. , and the late Mr. Siebert, to Edward Breen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Breen of Cheshire, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's mother.

title: More on Jogging
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn College Debut For the Oakland Ballet
description: The Oakland Ballet will make its New York debut March 13 at 8 P.M. at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

title: Garden State Group Plays Tchaikovsky and Handel
description: A new string ensemble, the Garden State Chamber Orchestra, crossed the river from New Jersey last Thursday evening for a concert at the Abraham Goodman House. Its 21 members all sound like strong, professional players; their conductor, Frederick Storfer, is very much in charge; and Richard Rood seems an especially fine young concertmaster.

title: No Headline
description: Leonardo da Vinci was pictured as a singular achiever in ''The Only-Child Phenomenon.'' He was born illegitimate and grew up with his father, who had other children in his third and fourth marriages.

title: WIDE VARIENCE SEEN IN PRISONERS TERMS
description: Wide differences have been found in the length of prison sentences criminals serve in various states. A survey in next week's issue of The National Law Journal suggests that the prison sentences served by felons often depends less on what the crime was than on where it was committed.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 17 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $15.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 2 3 21 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942. 3 2 8 ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Putnam's, $12.95.) A man who has made it big in early 20th-century America struggles against the corruption that engulfs his life. 4 4 18 COME POUR THE WINE, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $12.95.) A woman's long journey to self-discovery. 5 5 26 FIRESTARTER, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) E ightyear-old Charlie can look at anything and turn it into flames. 6 14 5 CONGO, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $10.95.) Three intrepid Americans search for lost diamonds in the jungles of modern Africa. 7 6 34 RAGE OF ANGELS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $12.95.) An idealistic young woman lawyer triumphs over two vengeful men.

title: No Headline
description: The Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, said today that he would meet soon with Reggie Jackson to discuss a new contract.

title: William Brice, Flutist, Nancy Garniez, Pianist
description: William Brice, flutist, and Nancy Garniez, pianist, made their debut as partners in a joint concert at Carnegie Recital Hall last Wednesday night. Together, they played sonatas by Mozart and Schubert, Faure's Fantasy (Op. 79), Roussel's ''Joueurs de Flute'' and Isang Yun's ''Garak.'' Mr. Brice was heard alone in a Bach Partita and Miss Garniez in two Brahms Intermezzos and a Rhapsody.

title: Dianna R. Dennis to Be Married
description: The engagement of Dianna Robin Dennis to Lawrence Lowell Bright of Elverson, Pa., has been announced by Thomas Gordon Dennis of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Anne Pyle Dennis of Keane Valley, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bright of Isleford, Me.

title: U.S. STILL UNDECIDED ON AMOUNT OF AID TO SALVADOR
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to make an international issue of alleged Soviet-Cuban support for El Salvador's leftist guerrillas has not yet been matched by a decision on how much United States military aid, including American advisers, should be given the Salvadoran armed forces.

title: CONTENTS
description: February 15, 1981 NONFICTION THE ARRIVAL OF B.B. KING: The Authorized Biography. By Charles Sawyer. 8 EARTHLY PLEASURES: Tales From a Biologist's Garden.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC Those who attended violin recitals some sixty years ago will remember a young man who played with an inordinate amount of skill and sensitivity. Now over 80, Joseph Fuchs will be playing again this Monday night in Alice Tully Hall; he has appeared often enough in recent years to insure that the evening will be a lot more than merely nostalgic.

title: A TALK WITH MARY GORDON
FUEL PRICE DEBATE DELAYS RULING ON RENTS
description: HOW much has the cost of fuel oil risen since July? If it has gone up 20 percent, 10,000 Westchester tenants may be faced with a rent increase. But even a discussion of a mid-season fuel increase has been tabled temporarily, to the delight of tenants and the dismay of landlords. Instead, the Rent Guidelines Board is working on next year's guidelines.

title:
Gardening;
COLD,DROUGHT MAY AFFECT SPRING PLANTS
description: THE severe cold this winter probably has already taken a toll of plant life. Tender broadleaf evergreens such as English hollies show leaf burn. Whether they will suffer greater damage than mere defoliation must wait until spring or summer for a final determination. Those in the more exposed locations have suffered the greatest damage.

title: AN ATLANTIC CITY FIRST: CASINO OWNERS SELL INTEREST
description: Gamblers lost $63.5 million in Atlantic City's six casinos last month, but they dropped only $3.9 million of it at the Brighton Hotel and Casino. Last week the owners of the unprofitable Brighton became the first in the New Jersey casino industry to sell their controlling interest.

title:
TV View;
THE TREND TOWARD SANCTIMONIOUS SENSATIONALISM
description: Ahysterical woman uses a hand gun to fend off two psychotic rapists. Male and female teen-agers sell their bodies on the streets of San Francisco. Inmates at a maximum-security prison openly describe the horrors of their lives. These are only some examples of the decidedly stronger fare being offered to television viewers these days. Of course, February is a ''sweeps'' month, meaning that the ratings are more important than ever to local stations; the ability of sex and violence to attrack audiences has been firmly, if not notoriously, established. And while there is nothing terribly new about the presence of rapists, prostitutes or convicts on the home screen, either in dramatizations or in newscasts and documentaries, a sweeps period, scheduled three times each year, inevitably triggers a heavily publicized avalanche of topical and titillating themes: Teen pregnancies! Male models! Pornography! The subjects are certainly legitimate enough for investigation, but, as time passes, the television treatments have become noticeably more detailed and candid. The line between concern and exploitation, between required realism and prurience, has become uncomfortably fuzzy. Needless to say, most treatments of sex-and-violence subjects are couched in the rhetoric of noble motivations. The film or news report is always offered as an exercise in consciousness-raising, designed to alert the country to some festering social problem. In fact, television seems to have entered what might be called an era of sanctimonious sensationalism.

title: Carter Trustee Foresees the Sale Of Peanut Warehouse in Georgia
description: Former President Jimmy Carter's peanut warehouse in Plains, Ga., is likely to be sold within the next two months, according to Charles H. Kirbo, an Atlanta lawyer who is a Carter trustee.

title: HERZOGENAURACH, West Germany
description: A T first glance, this town, with a population of 12,500, resembles all the other farm towns that dot the fertile Aurach River valley in hilly northern Bavaria. But Herzogenaurach stands more for football cleats and running shoes than agriculture. It is the home of both Adidas and Puma, the world's largest manufacturers of athletic footwear.

title:
Camera;
A BEVY OF NEW BOOKS
Wake Forest 58, Duke 52
description: SALEM, N.C., Feb. 14 (AP) - Frank Johnson scored all 12 of his points in the second half, including two free throws with six seconds left, as Wake Forest toppled Duke today, 58-52, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: HALT OF MAXYTAXYS STRANDS WESTPORTERS
description: WESTPORT ''I FEEL like Cinderella,'' said John Waxman. ''Unless I make the 6:05 train, there's nothing but a pumpkin there.'' Mr. Waxman, a publisher, commutes daily from Westport into New York City and has used Westport's public taxi service, Maxytaxy, to get home from the station because his poor eyesight prevents him from driving a car.

title: 25 years of shake-ups
description: June 1956 - Nationalist anti-Stalinist ele- ments led by Wladyslaw Gomulka gain con- trol of Communist Party from Edward Ochab after riots in Poznan. Dec. 1970 - Strikes and riots in Gdansk, Szczecin and Gdynia leads to resignation of Mr. Gomulka. He is replaced by Edward Gierek. Feb. 1980 - Prime Minister Piotr Jaroszewicz is dismissed, apparently because of dis- content over economic policies, and re- placed by Edward Babiuch. Aug. 1980 - Prime Minister Babiuch is re- placed by Jozef Pinkowski following 11- day strike by workers on the Baltic coast. Sept. 1980 - Party leader Gierek is forced out after two months of labor strikes. He is replaced by Stanislaw Kania. Feb. 1981 - Prime Minister Pinkowski is dismissed and replaced by Defense Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski.

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;
'SIGN HERE, DEAR'-AND BEWARE
description: D URING the next two months, millions of traditional husbands will utter the identical command to millions of traditional wives: ''Sign here, dear.'' The document is the joint income tax return and most women will comply automatically. But that can be a hazardous course, especially if a divorce is brewing or if the husband is cheating on taxes and the wife knows - or even suspects.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. IS SET FOR SKIRMISH WITH REAGAN
description: The American Federation of Labor and Council of Industrial Organizations, uncharacteristically subdued since President Reagan took office, is preparing to fire opening salvos at the new Administration at a weeklong meeting of its executive council that begins Monday in Bal Harbour, Fla.

title: Dining Out; LUNCH IN A ONE-ROOM SCHOOLHOUSE
description: CANNONDALE SOME individually prepared, home-style cooking can be found in tiny establishments that offer an example of worthwhile goods in small packages. A case in point is the Schoolhouse Cafe and Riverside Garden in June Havoc's Cannon Crossing complex. This minuscule restaurant serves only lunch in an old-fashioned one-room schoolhouse that seats 32.

title: PIANIST: CLAUDIO ARRAU PLAYS LISZT, SCHUMANN
description: It is difficult to say exactly what was missing in Claudio Arrau's playing during much of his recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night. The 78-year-old pianist certainly was at home; his fingers and mind knew where the music was going and what it was doing.

title: A SHOPPING CENTER BETS ON LAS VEGAS
description: ''All right, girls,'' chirped pudgy, animated Fred Lewis, jangling in a dark velvet evening jacket and a bright red T-shirt, ''we want a lotta winkin', a lotta flirtin'. Everybody have a good time.''

title: THE GOOD NEWS FROM TROUBLED ZIMBABWE
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW GUERRILLAS GET WEAPONS
description: To the Editor:

title: SLUGGISH ECONOMY IS FORECAST
description: Despite surprisingly steady business signals in January, many corporate economists expect sluggish economic activity in the United States through the first half of 1981. But they see the economy picking up in the second half, building toward a robust 1982.

title: ADELPHI STUDENTS MOURN CLASSMATE SLAIN BY POLICEMAN ON L.I. CAMPUS
description: While Adelphi University students mourned a classmate who was shot and killed yesterday by a Garden City policeman, the Nassau County police said that a grand jury investigation of the shooting would begin this week.

title: SPENCER IS GETTING EARLY START
description: After a winter of hard work, Jim Spencer reported to the Yankees' early camp here 12 pounds lighter than last season and determined to avoid the slumps and sufferings of 1980.

title: Dollar Strong in Tokyo
description: The United States dollar rose sharply on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today, opening at 207.00 yen after closing Friday at 205.50 yen. Dealers said early trading was slow, with the dollar at the 206.80-207.10 level.

title: Sjoebrend Captures World Speed Skating
description: With Hilbert van der Duim of the Netherlands, the defending champion, out of contention after a fall in the opening 1,500-meter race today, Norwegian skaters dominated the men's speedskating world championships.

title: Gasoline Stocks At High Levels
description: The stockpile of gasoline at American refineries is fast approaching a record inventory that may cause slowdowns or shutdowns of the facilities and could eventually restrain gasoline price increases, an oil industry expert said today.

title: From Congress to a Bar
description: During his six years in Congress, Edward P. Beard, a one-time house painter, liked to think of himself as the working man's Congressman.

title: CHINESE APPEAR WARY IN BUYING ARMS FROM THE WEST
description: For nearly a decade the United States and some of its principal NATO allies have sought to sell arms to China. Recently they have been joined by Japan.

title: Leading Witness in Trial Of Israeli Aide Is Beaten
description: The leading prosecution witness in the bribery trial of Aharon Abuhazira, Israel's Minister of Religious Affairs, was assaulted by a religious extremist today but was not seriously injured.

title: MUSIC: CHORAL SOCIETY SINGS WEILL REQUIEM AND ORFF
description: THE first half of the New York Choral Society program in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night offered two tepid homages to the grim reaper. Kurt Weill's ''Berliner'' Requiem, composed to typically mordant Bertolt Brecht poems, sits mournfully somewhere between Weill's early austere idiom and his more popular cabaret style.

title: By Jim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials Old Problems

title: BOSTON PREPARES TO RETRENCH AS TAX CUTS DRAIN TREASURY
description: The financial storm clouds seen on the city's horizon last fall, after voters approved the nation's most sweeping proposal to limit property taxes, are intensifying.

title: ARMY ASKS EXEMPTION FROM HIRING BAN IN PLEA TO ADD 30,000 CIVILIANS
description: The Army has asked the Reagan Administration to exempt it from the freeze on Federal hiring so that more than 30,000 civilian workers can be added to the Army's labor force over the next 18 months.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS PRESS THEIR BUDGET PLAN AS PROTESTS MOUNT
description: Vice President Bush and some key members of Congress urged support today for the budget package that President Reagan plans to present to Congress Wednesday, but representatives of groups fearing that they could be hurt urged caution in reducing government spending.

title: Summations Today In the Harris Trial
description: Lawyers in the Jean S. Harris murder trial will present their summations today, with Joel Aurnou, for the defense, beginning at about 9 o'clock and George Bolen, the prosecutor, starting after lunch.

title: GATEWAY PANEL AND MILITARY VIE FOR SITE
description: New Defense Department claims on acreage at Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island are undermining long-pending plans to include the fort in the Gateway National Recreation Area, citizen groups asserted yesterday. They are urging the reversal of the latest military move.

title: Striking Teachers Jailed Over Picketing Dispute
description: Seventeen striking teachers and their negotiator went to jail today rather than obey a court order requiring them to post $1,000 bonds for allegedly violating an earlier order against mass picketing.

title: TAXI PANEL CALLS FOR DATA TO SUPPORT 50-CENT NIGHT FEE
description: The chairman of a committee of the Taxi and Limousine Commission that this week will consider a 50-cent surcharge for nighttime taxi rides in New York City said yesterday that the charge would not be approved unless the commission could obtain accurate income reports from all segments of the taxi industry.

title: Burglary Is Tied To Guardian Angels
description: A 17-year-old youth who said he was a Guardian Angel was arrested on a burglary charge Sunday night when he was apprehended inside a token booth at Manhattan's Fulton Street Station, according to the transit police.

title: Jill Brown, Lawyer, Wed to Alan Frumin, a Senate Aide
description: Jill Meryl Brown, a trial lawyer for the Federal Trade Commission in Washington, was married in Silver Spring, Md., yesterday to Alan Frumin, assistant parliamentarian of the Senate.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When you start manipulating a system that treats three million people a day you'd better be a little careful before jumping off the cliff.'' - Dr. James H. Sammons, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, speaking of proposals to cut Medicare and Medicaid. (A12:3.)

title: THE EGALITARIAN LUNCH HOUR, CAPITAL STYLE
description: Between the courses of chopped liver and strawberry cheesecake, the regulars can lean back, dab crumbs from their lips and murmur about supply-side economics, food-stamp cuts, or whatever phenomena are passing through the capital city.

title: Randi Greenwald Wed to Lowell Turnbull
description: Randi Jay Greenwald, an assistant general counsel for Action, the agency that includes the Peace Corps and Vista, was married at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington yesterday to Lowell David Turnbull. He is a partner in the Washington law firm of Leva, Hawes, Symington, Martin & Oppenheimer.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ EAST

title: FOUNDATION TO SEEK LOWER HEALTH COSTS
description: Concluding that finding a doctor is no longer a problem for most Americans, but that the cost of medical care is, the nation's largest private health-care philanthropy has decided to switch its focus from accessibility to economics.

title: Wallner Wins Jump
description: Hans Wallner of Austria jumped 104.5 and 101 meters to take first place today on the second day of the World Ski Cup competition before 18,000 spectators.

title: Robert K. Adams, 72, a Producer Of Television and Theater Shows
description: Robert K. Adams, a radio and theater actor and then a producer of television and stage attractions, died Friday while visiting friends at Jekyll Island, Ga. Mr. Adams, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 72 years old.

title: SPORTING GEAR
description: Sporting Gear Carbon/Fiberglass Tennis Racquets

title: Bridge: Percentages Should Decide When to Bid a Grand Slam
description: Most players know they should not attempt a grand slam unless the odds are substantially in their favor. The percentage chance to make it a borderline proposition varies between 55 percent and 69 percent, depending on such factors as vulnerability, denomination and type of scoring.

title: S.E.C. UPHOLDS LILCO IN BATTLE WITH CRITIC ON A-PLANT SPENDING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has allowed the Long Island Lighting Company to bar one of its critics from having a proposed resolution circulated in advance proxy material for its annual shareholders' meeting.

title: Andrea Jaeger Wins
description: Second-seeded Andrea Jaeger, giving away 20 years of experience to her opponent, beat Virginia Wade today, 6-3, 6-1, in the final of a $125,000 Avon tournament.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE HOUR OF OUR DEATH. By Philippe Aries. Translated from the French by Helen Weaver. Illustrated. 651 pages. Knopf. $20.

title: Largest Jersey Utility; Seeks 3 Rate Rises
description: NEWARK (UPI) - The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, which is already seeking the largest rate rise ever requested by a New Jersey utility, will ask for two additional fuel adjustment increases this year, officials of the utility say.

title: CANTILENA CHAMBER PLAYERS TO OFFER TANEYEV QUARTET
description: A piano quartet by Sergei Taneyev, dating from 1907, will be performed for the first time in New York by the Cantilena Chamber Players at the 92nd Street Y on Feb. 25 at 8 P.M.

title: Rat Program Faces Budget Cut
description: The nation's $13 million rat-control program has been given only $1 million in the 1982-83 budget submitted by President Carter, according to Don Berreth, the director of information for the national Centers for Disease Control. Some health officials doubt that the remaining amount will be included in the final Reagan Administration budget.

title: Jew Who Hijacked a Plane Is Reported Missing in Soviet
description: Iosif Mendelevich, who was involved in an attempt to hijack a Soviet plane 11 years ago, reportedly has disappeared from a Soviet labor camp, his sister said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday gave an incorrect starting time for a ground test of the space shuttle Columbia. The rehearsal countdown is now scheduled to begin at 7:15 P.M. today. Article on Page A10.

title: The Real Dimensions of Westway
description: A cheer for Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis for restating the Federal commitment to New York's Westway. And a tribute to Senator D'Amato for emphasizing the obvious to the highway's bitter opponents: the new Congress will not be appropriating mass transit subsidies in amounts that make any ''trade-in'' of Westway funds attractive.

title: ISRAEL COUTURIER SOLD TO A MASS MARKETER
description: Its customer list bore the names of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, Farah Diba and Leah Rabin, wife of the former Israeli Prime Minister, among others.

title: 10-YEAR-OLD BOY DIES AFTER A LIFELONG FIGHT AGAINST RARE DISEASE
description: At the age of 10, Michael Hammond was finally going to start school this week. But Michael, who had to be covered with vegetable shortening each day to ease the pain of his rare skin disease, died before he had the chance.

title: Former Premier Deplores Political Feuding in Iran
description: Former Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan today sharply criticized Iran's President, Prime Minister and Chief Justice, saying that a struggle for power had grown into a dangerous feud.

title: TRAIN EVERY DOCTOR TO SAVE LIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: JULIA FRANK WED TO DAVID PICK
description: At Temple Beth Sahlom in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday, Julia Frank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Frank of Far Rockaway, Queens, was married to David Pick of Rego Park, Queens.

title: MACHINE TOOLS: MADE IN U.S.A.
description: When Governor Carey came here recently to encourage Japanese companies to invest in New York State, one of the few plant tours he took was at Okuma Machinery Works.

title: STEVE ALLEN, THE CONGLOMERATE
description: Steve Allen is signing some letters at the same time as he is skimming a manuscript at the same time as he is getting ready to utter a thought into a tape recorder. Before he can polish all that off, a script for a benefit is dumped on his desk. Then a letter arrives confirming that he is to appear with the Milwaukee Symphony. He shakes his head, emits his familiar ''heh-heh-heh'' laugh, reaches up to straighten his glasses.

title: ON MINERAL POLICY
description: Alarms are once again being sounded about mineral supplies, not only by the industrial consumers of such minerals but also by individuals and organizations concerned with United States national security. The dangers cited include United States vulnerability to price gouging by cartels, political instability in exporting countries, and an extended ''resource war'' with the Soviet Union. Proposed remedies are as diverse as stockpiling, mining wilderness areas, building military bases abroad, and putting responsibility for mineral exploration in the Department of Defense.

title: SALVADOREAN REBELS FIND SUPPORT EBBING
description: The failure of last month's guerrilla offensive against El Salvador's civilian-military junta has led several governments and political parties in the region to reconsider their previous unconditional support for the country's Marxist-led Democratic Revolutionary Front.

title: RANGERS LOSE, 5-4 AS BLUES STOP RALLY
description: The St. Louis Blues, despite a penalty-filled second period in which they yielded three goals, triumphed over the Rangers last night, 5-4, at Madison Square Garden.

title: John Boylan, Who Guided Budget In Vermont's Senate, Dies at 73
description: Former State Senator John Boylan, who as chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee had almost total control over the Vermont state budget for two decades, died yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: Test-Firing of Space Shuttle Rescheduled for Thursday
description: The test-firing of the space shuttle Columbia's main engines was delayed again today and rescheduled for Thursday.

title: Balloonists' Voyage Was Ended in India; For Lack of Drafts
description: The two Americans who aborted their around-the-world balloon voyage over northern India said today that a futile search for air currents had led them to end the trip.

title: Mexico Output Of Oil Slowed
description: Bad weather in the Gulf of Mexico is threatening to delay crude oil production in southeastern Mexico, according to a report published Saturday by the official Government newspaper, El Nacional.

title: FIREMAN AND CHEF HURT IN BLAZE AT EAST SIDE HOTEL
description: A fireman and a chef were severely injured last night during a twoalarm apartment-hotel fire on Manhattan's East Side near the United Nations that was designated suspicious by fire marshals. Another fireman received a minor injury.

title: WHEN KOCH TOOK OVER CITY HALL
description: To the Editor:

title: Pecci Tops Panatta
description: Victor Pecci of Paraguay won Colombia's round of the Marlboro Cup yesterday, defeating Adriano Panatta of Italy, 4-6, 6-3, 7-5.

title: Split Decision to Hamsho
description: Mustafa Hamsho, working inside with a powerful left, won a split decision from Curtis Parker today to gain a shot at the middleweight boxing champion, Marvin Hagler.

title: SENATE GROUP BEGINNING INQUIRY ON DOCK UNION'S LINKS TO CRIME
description: The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations is expected to receive testimony in the next two weeks that payoffs to union officials in Atlantic and Gulf ports were routinely shared with people in organized crime in New York.

title: Skeleton Found in Atlanta Is Identified as Boy, 11
description: A skeleton discovered Friday has been identified through dental records as that of Jeffrey Mathis, an 11-year-old black who disappeared nearly a year ago, the Fulton County Medical Examiner's office said today.

title: CROINKITE TO JOIN BROADCAST AWARDS
description: Walter Cronkite, within a month of his retirement as the country's leading television news personality, will participate in ceremonies of the 1979-80 Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University awards in broadcast journalism.

title: No Headline
description: POLISH CHIEF FLIES UNEXPECTEDLY TO PRAGUE FOR TALKS

title: The Logical Choice
description: She's been an active volunteer in the war against arthritis for a dozen years now, and somehow this seemed like just the right year to ask her to act as host for the Arthritis Foundation's national cable telethon.

title: 14 Guatemalans Are Found Dead; Marks on Bodies Indicate Torture
description: Fourteen bullet-riddled bodies of young people, all showing signs of torture, were found east of the capital today, the police here said.

title: Senator Backs Reagan Plan
description: The economic program that President Reagan plans to announce this week will bring inflation down to a ''reasonable level'' by 1984, provided it is approved by Congress, the Senate Budget Committee chairman said today.

title: BUT, LET'S LOOK
description: Mayor Koch's budget for 1981 states, ''New York City is a better place now than it was a few years ago.'' But a service crisis is growing citywide. Crime set new records in 1979 and 1980. The subways seem ready to collapse. Housing blight is spreading. Race relations are polarized by mayoral invective. In a televised interview on ''CBS Newsmakers'' on Feb.1, the Mayor reiterated that all was well. Let's examine some of his claims.

title: East German Chief Says Reunification Is Possible
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, said today that it was possible that Germany could be reunited under Communism, an assertion that marked a significant switch from his previous insistence that the nation was permanently divided.

title: Quality of Life Said to Decline
description: The overall quality of life in the United States took a turn for the worse in 1980, after barely holding its own the previous year, according to the nation's largest conservation group.

title: Thousands in Basque Area Protest Death of Rebel
description: Thousands of people demonstrated in the Basque region last night, and stones and gasoline bombs were thrown at Government buildings after the death in police custody of a suspected Basque separatist guerrilla, Jose Ignacio Arregui Izaguirre.

title: IN ZIMBABWE, 2 RIVAL FACTIONS COUNT THE DEAD
description: The three railway refrigerator cars were drawn up today on a siding that is normally used for grain exports. A handwritten sign on the first of them identified their contents. ''Corpses,'' it said.

title: LET'S START DAYLIGHT SAVING TIME ON MARCH 1
description: To the Editor:

title: Damaged Icebreaker Stays On Record Arctic Course
description: The icebreaker Polar Sea pushed through heavy Arctic Sea ice today despite a mechanical problem that disabled the ship's rudder, the Coast Guard said.

title: LEDERER TRIUMPHANT IN 2D LEG OF 5-MILER
description: Michael Lederer, a sub-4-minute miler from Darmstadt, West Germany, captured the second leg of the Manufacturers Hanover Five-Borough FiveMile Challenge series yesterday at Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

title: Bills Hire Hawkins
description: The Buffalo Bills today announced the hiring of Ralph Hawkins as defensive backfield coach.

title: Dumping the Poor Into State Laps
description: ''All of us need to be reminded that the Federal Government did not create the states: the states created the Federal Government.'' Historians quarrel about the accuracy of that inaugural observation by President Reagan but there's no disputing his intention to redefine Washington's role. The White House is already devising plans to push welfare, health care and housing programs onto state and local governments.

title: GREEK AMBIVALENCE ON TURKEY PERSISTS
description: A senior Greek official spoke glowingly of the improved atmosphere of the current Greek-Turkish talks, referred to his many Turkish friends and served a visitor Turkish coffee, then settled down to discuss ''the Turkish threat'' at length.

title: WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY
description: Washington's birthday is Feb. 22, but it will be observed today in New York City and throughout the country.

title: 2 PUBLISHERS ACCUSE U.S. ELECTION AGENCY OF RIGHTS VIOLATIONS
description: The Federal Election Commission, created by Congress to prevent illegal campaign practices, has come under increasing attack from critics who say that it has overreached its authority and violated the First Amendment rights of individuals and publications.

title: Two Reported Arrested in India For Negligence in Fire at Circus
description: Police authorities have arrested two circus employees for negligence in the fire eight days ago that caused the death of 75 people during a children's matinee, a newspaper said today.

title: Connecticut Limits Welfare Abortions
description: HARTFORD (UPI) - Connecticut returned yesterday to a strict policy limiting most abortions paid with welfare funds, and Planned Parenthood announced a fund-raising drive to help poor women terminate pregnancies.

title: ONE NEW YORK RESERVOIR NEAR ROCKY BOTTOM
description: The Sodom Reservoir looks like a misplaced moonscape these days - a vast gray surface strewn with rocks and boulders. In the middle is what appears to be a small frozen lake.

title: Flatbush Post Office Looted
