description: Thieves smashed through an upper-floor window of the Flatbush Station Post Office in Brooklyn between Saturday afternoon and yesterday morning, looted packages and made off with some postal equipment, a postal inspector said. Officials said an adding machine was missing and that several boxes, some containing bronzed baby shoes, were strewn on the floor. Stamps, money orders and cash were locked in a wall safe.

title: Possibility of Arson Is Raised in Dublin Fire
description: The police said today that they were keeping an ''open mind'' on whether arson was the cause of a fire early Saturday in which 48 young people died. They said they were also investigating reports by some survivors that several exits at the Stardust disco were locked.

title: MCENROE DEFEATS VILAS IN FINAL
description: John McEnroe overcame stiff 20-mile winds and 24 unforced errors in the first set and beat Guillermo Vilas in the final of the trouble-plagued $300,000 Pepsi Grand Slam of Tennis today, 6-7, 6-4, 6-0.

title: s; Micheletti of Blues Suffers Knee Injury
description: Joe Micheletti, the Blues' defenseman, returned to St. Louis today to have his right knee examined by a team physician.

title: NETS RALLY AND PRODUCE 3D STRAIGHT VICTORY
description: For the first time this season, the Nets won their third straight game today as they beat the Golden State Warriors, 134-132.

title: DYNAMITE WRECKS SCHOOL IN ITALY
description: A dynamite blast caused major damage to an accounting school in this northeastern Italian town today. The police said 22 classrooms and two gymnasiums at the Cecilia Deganutti Technical Institute were destroyed. No injuries were reported and no motive was immediately suspected.

title: JAPANESE REASSESS CHINA PLAN
description: Japanese Government and business officials, stung by the growing number of large industrial projects that have apparently been shelved by China, are now questioning the future of economic relations between the two countries.

title: American Women Win 3 Judo Medals
description: The American women won one gold medal today, three for the meet, and the Japanese men swept the four weight division titles on the second and final day of the second Pacific Rim Invitational judo championship.

title: A Long Row Home
description: They may be gone for a while, but there's still a chance to say goodbye to Curt and Kathleen Saville. The couple aren't leaving until later this week, but once they sail away on a Morocco-bound freighter, there's no telling when they might get back home to Providence, R.I.

title: Some Spending Also Takes Courage
description: Cutting the Federal budget will be hard enough. But it will take even more political heart to increase spending where it is urgently needed: for salaries in all three branches of Government, notably including those for officials who will be administering the cuts of almost everything else.

title: CONSERVATION IS ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: FASSBINDER'S NAZI FABLE A HIT
description: MUNICH, West Germany RAINER WERNER FASSBINDER, the director, has made his first big commercially oriented film and, just as he seems to have hoped, it is making money and reaching a wide audience.

title: Law Firm Retains Its Penchant for Political Figures
description: After a four-year absence while serving the Carter Administration in diplomatic posts, William J. vanden Heuvel is rejoining the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan as a senior partner.

title: Mile-Run Battles With Coghlan, Ovett and Coe Spice Scott's Life
description: TORONTO Since 1977, Steve Scott has been America's best miler. But he admits he is getting a little bored by running one mile race after another, almost always against the same people.

title: 30-Kilometer Race Is Taken by Nijboer
description: Gerard Nijboer of the Netherlands, runner-up in the marathon at the 1980 Moscow Olympics, won the 30-kilometer Ohme road race today in 1 hour 32 minutes 34 seconds.

title: JOHN STUART HAFER
description: John Stuart Hafer, president emeritus of Curry College here, died today at his home in Mashpee, on Cape Cod, after a long illness, the school announced. He was 67 years old. .

title: MEDICAL LEADERS GROWING WARY OVER REAGAN HEALTH-CARE PLANS
description: After initial euphoria over the election of a new, staunchly conservative President, organized medicine is growing uneasy and wary over what the Reagan Administration has in mind for the nation's health-care system.

title: DANCE: POMARE'S 'LAS DESENAMORADAS'
description: ELEO POMARE is a talented choreographer of provocative wit, whose company has not had much exposure in New York City recently. Mr. Pomare, however, remains loyal to the Harlem Cultural Council's Dancemobile series, with which he performed at its beginnings in 1967.

title: HOW TO FIT $2 MILLION INTO A BAG
description: The Nevada Gaming Control Board has permitted Frank Sinatra, crooner of all crooners, intimate of racketeers and Presidents, to re-enter the gambling business.

title: SPENDING ON NAVY SHIPS MAY RISE UNDER REAGAN
description: Shipyards in the United States could get as much as $15 billion in additional revenues under the Reagan Administration's five-year plan for the construction of naval vessels, analysts calculate.

title: LEARNING TO MIX LOVE AND MONEY
description: He has a good job. She has a good job. In the currently fashionable jargon, they are a ''dual-career couple,'' and on Saturday, several dozen of these couples turned out for a Valentine's Day seminar on how they could best combine love and money.

title: NORTH CAROLINA TOPS MARYLAND BY 76-63
description: Al Wood scored 28 points as North Carolina built a 20-point lead and then held on to defeat Maryland, 76-63, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game today.

title: Commodities; Stocks Slim But Sugar Prices Slip
description: SUGAR futures prices have once again defied the forces of supply and demand. After a year in which global cane- and beet-sugar output failed to match the rise in consumption for the first time since 1974, prices last week were back where they were a year ago.

title: ABORTION RIGHTS GROUPS EXPECT HARD TIMES
description: Opponents of the proposed constitutional amendment to ban abortion heard sobering if not pessimistic appraisals of their chances for success as the National Abortion Rights Action League concluded its two-day annual meeting today.

title: Man Shot to Death In a Bowery Theater
description: A 20-year-old man who the police said was a member of a Chinatown gang was shot to death as he sat in the balcony of a Bowery theater that shows Chinese films.

title: For Campion, Playing Now Means Losing
description: Bill Campion, the former Manhattan College basketball star, walked though the lobby of the Edison Hotel and out onto West 47th Street in Manhattan carrying three large duffel bags, which he stuffed into the trunk of a taxi idling at the curb. Bending his 6-foot-10-inch body into the back seat, Campion headed for Madison Square Garden, where later he would walk onto the court, as he does nearly 230 times a year, no longer a focus of attention.

title: Mrs. Carner Wins
description: JoAnne Carner made par on the first hole of sudden death today to win the $100,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament at Pasadena Golf Club from Dot Germain.

title: Dutch Soldier Hurt in Lebanon
description: Christian militiamen fired submachine guns today at a United Nations checkpoint in southern Lebanon, slightly injuring a Dutch soldier serving in the peacekeeping force, an official of the world body reported.

title: U.S. Yacht Ondine First to Reach Rio
description: Three boats crossed the finish line today to complete the 13th Buenos Aires-Rio de Janeiro sailing regatta, but officials said the final results probably would not be known before Wednesday.

title: Union Chief Opposes U.S. Tuition Credits
description: The president of the union representing supervisors and principals in New York City public schools charged that the Reagan Administration's support of Federal tax credits for tuition would lead to a dismantling of the nation's public school system.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Is it true that there once was a dirt path, which resembled a keyhole, from the pitcher's mound to the batter's box?

title: Hynes Seeks to Add More Fire Marshals
description: The Fire Department will present the Reagan Administration with a plan for an arson control program, according to Commissioner Charles J. Hynes.

title: Spaniard Keeps Title
description: Carlos Hernandez of Spain retained his European junior-lightweight boxing title after he and his Spanish challenger, Jose Luis Vicho, fought to a 15-round draw last night. A crowd of 3,000 saw the match at the Sports Palace. Hernandez won the title by defeating Natale Vezzoli of Italy in Valladolid, Spain, nearly three years ago.

title: U.S. ATTACHE CALLED K.G.B. TARGET
description: An assistant military attache at the United States Embassy in Moscow was recalled to Washington because an unsuccessful attempt by the K.G.B. to blackmail him into becoming a Soviet spy, a British newspaper reported today.

title: LEGISLATOR HOME IN BUFFALO TO EXPLAIN BUDGET CUTS
description: s BUFFALO, Feb. 13 - The wind comes howling across Lake Erie, creating snowy gusts that buffet the new Buffalo Hilton Hotel, which was built with Federal subsidies as the centerpiece of a waterfront development project for which the city seeks $20 million more from Washington.

title: News Analysis; REAGAN AND SOUTHERN AFRICA; Blacks and Whites Preoccupied With Thought That a New Lurch in Policy May Be on Its Way; Foreign Policy; Fourth in a series of occasional articles on international problems facing the Reagan Administration.
description: A little more than four years ago Andrew Young, newly appointed head of the United States Mission to the United Nations, gazed out the window of his Atlanta office and confidently predicted that the Carter Administration's efforts would set in motion a transition to majority rule in South Africa in only four years. When it was remarked that it seemed a short time for so momentous a change, Mr. Young thought for a moment and replied, ''It's not so short.''

title: Gullett Holds Off
description: Don Gullett, who has been attempting a comeback since a rotatorcuff injury in 1978, postponed his arrival at camp until the weather warmed.

title: BUSH URGES BROOKLYN REPUBLICANS TO BACK REAGAN'S ECONOMIC PLANS
description: Vice President Bush visited New York yesterday to seek support for the Reagan Administration's economic proposals, which are expected to be disclosed Wednesday by President Reagan.

title: Stenmark Upset by Phil Mahre
description: Coming from behind and winning ski races in the second run has been one of Ingemar Stenmark's specialties. But today it was Phil Mahre's turn.

title: Staying Close to Home
description: For years, Penn State's football image was tainted in the eyes of some critics by the caliber of the Nittany Lions' opposition. So the school went out and built up a prominent national schedule, one that was rated the most difficult in the country by The Times' computer assessment last fall. A highlight of the 1980 Penn State season was a road victory over Missouri.

title: 2 Beatles Reunite for Lennon Tribute Album
description: Ringo Starr joined Paul McCartney on this Caribbean island today, and immediately drove to the home of George Martin, the Beatles' former producer. Mr. Martin is reported to be seeking to organize the first reunion of the Beatles in 12 years.

title: East Germans First
description: East Germany emerged as the top nation in the biathlon by winning the senior and the junior relays at the world championships today. East Germans earlier won two individual championships, and were second twice and third once. West Germany surprised by finishing second in the men's relay, ahead of the Soviet Union, and in front of strong teams from Norway and Finland.

title: Index; International
description: Neapolitans shrug amid a city about to topple on them A2 Reporter's Notebook: Third world issues are handled gingerly A3 Greek ambivalence toward Tur- key persists A3 Government/Politics About Washington: egalitarian lunch hour, capital style A10 Senate group beginning inquiry on dockers' ties to crime A11 Medical leaders express wariness about Administration plans A12 Buffalo Representative explains plans to reduce spending A20 Byrne may yet win fight to change Jersey campaign-fund law B2 Bush, in New York, seeks support for economic proposals B3 Assemblyman says Carey budget could hurt minorities B3 General Around the Nation A10 Westchester jet crash puzzles in- vestigators B2 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Petty wins Daytona 500 with a gamble C1 Baseball: J.R. Richard's come- back route C1

title: BYRNE MAY YET WIN JERSEY FIGHT TO CHANGE CAMPAIGN FUND LAW
description: Governor Byrne, despite opposition from Democratic and Republican leaders, may yet win his fight to change New Jersey's campaign financing law, even though the gubernatorial primaries are less than four months away.

title: PARENT'S DATING: A CHILD'S REACTIONS
description: ''C OME for dinner,'' she told him on the third date. ''I want you to meet my children.'' He arrived with flowers and a bottle of wine and not a twinge of foreboding. He liked children.

title: Irwin Triumphs by 6 With a Record 265
description: Hale Irwin won the Hawaiian open by six strokes today, but he said his big lead was something of a handicap. ''It sounds absurd, but it's hard to play with a five-stroke lead,'' Irwin said after scoring his first victory on the PGA Tour since the 1979 United States Open.

title: MAJOR PHOSPHATE DEPOSITS FOUND
description: Geologists conducting phosphate research on the continental shelf have discovered major deposits of the mineral, which is crucial in making fertilizers. Dwindling domestic phosphate stocks have raised fears of American dependence on foreign sources.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1981
description: International The failure of the guerrilla offensive in El Salvador has led several governments and political parties in Latin America to reconsider their unconditional support for the Marxist-led Democratic Revolutionary Front. The front for the first time has come under strong pressure from its traditional allies to to seek a political solution to its conflict with El Salvador's civilian-military junta. (Page A1, Column 1.) More factional fighting in Zimbabwe between former guerrillas loyal to the political parties in Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's Government seemed less likely. The guerrilla force known as the Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army, which is tied to Mr. Mugabe's party, was disarmed and trucked out of Entumbane Township, near Bulawayo, where fighting broke out last week, taking about 300 lives. (A1:3.)

title: Louisville Nears Metro Conference Title
description: Louisville, playing at home, can clinch the regular-season Metro Conference championship tonight with a victory over Memphis State. A championship for Louisville was expected before the season began in November but appeared doubtful six weeks later.

title: J.R. RICHARD FACES ANOTHER CHALLENGE
description: PITTSBURGH JAMES RODNEY RICHARD laughed at his joke, a staccato laugh that leaped evenly from both sides of a mouth that no longer droops on the left where he was paralyzed.

title: Holovak of Patriots Is Hired by Oilers
description: The chief scout for the New England Patriots, Mike Holovak, has been hired by the Houston Oilers as assistant general manager, the National Football League club announced today.

title: DR. PAULINE A. THOMAS BRIDE OF FREDRIC M. BELL
description: Dr. Pauline A. Thomas, a pediatrician, was married yesterday to Fredric M. Bell an architect with Warner Burns Toan Lunde in New York. The Rev. Martin Dacey of the Holy Name of Jesus Roman Catholic Church in Swoyerville, Pa., and Rabbi Jerald Bobrow officiated at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Tyssul G. Thomas, parents of the bride, in Forty Fort, Pa.

title: CONCERT DANCE COMPANY: 'AMERICAN TRIBUTE' SERIES
description: THE Concert Dance Company of Boston, which appeared on Saturday in the ''Tribute to American Dance'' series at the Brooklyn Center at Brooklyn College, is that rarity in contemporary modern-dance groups, a company that draws not from the works of one choreographer but many.

title: Soviet Swimmers Dominate Meet
description: The Soviet Union dominated the Grand Premier swim meet again today, winning all but two events. In two days of competition, Soviet swimmers won 13 of 17 events in this preparatory meet for the European championships at Split, Yugoslavia.

title: NEAPOLITANS SHRUG AT CITY ABOUT TO TOPPLE ON THEM
description: Shoulder-high concrete walls have been built across many of the streets and squares of the old center of Naples. They have been built to keep people away from houses that were shaken by the earthquake that struck the region last Nov. 23 and that are now in danger of collapsing. There is also a proliferation of signs on the streets, put up by the police, saying simply ''danger'' or ''collapsing.''

title: Record 15 Penalties Mar Rout by Arrows
description: Branko Segota scored three goals today for a season total of 25 and led the New York Arrows to a 6-1 victory over the St. Louis Steamers in a Major Indoor Soccer League game at Nassau Coliseum.

title: CONCERT: GLASS ENSEMBLE IN A RETROSPECTIVE SERIES
description: 813PHILIP GLASS'S four-concert retrospective series at Town Hall, which ended last night, provided reaffirmation that a stereotyping of his work as ''minimalist'' has little bearing now on what he does. It also served, with Mr. Glass already embarked on a further career as a composer of operas, to remind laggard American audiences of what Europeans have long recognized: that this earlier work counts as some of the most important produced by an American composer in the 1970's.

title: Payton Free; Owners Not
description: IF a free agent in pro football were truly at liberty, as a free agent in baseball is, the Giants and the Jets, along with several other National Football League teams, presumably would be throwing money at Walter Payton now. For openers, start the bidding for Walter Payton at $1 million a season.

title: The Economy
description: Economic activity is expected to be sluggish in the first half despite surprisingly steady indicators for last month, according to corporate economists. But they see business activity picking up in the second half, leading to strong gains in the gross national product in 1982. The tone of Federal Reserve's monetary policy is seen as a major factor in any upturn. (Page D1.)

title: Cruise Missile Passes Test
description: The Defense Department said that a cruise missile fired off the California coast today traveled 300 miles to attack a designated ground target in Nevada. The missile's sophisticated guidance system was tested successfully, a department spokesman said.

title: Holiday Closings
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges, banks across the nation, including the Federal Reserve Bank, and all commodities markets will be closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday.

title: PACER'S LOUIS ORR: BODY BELIES HIS SKILL
description: As Louis Orr's popularity grows in the National Basketball Association, so does the number of stories about him. Chuck Daly, the Philadelphia assistant coach, tells about the time that Darryl Dawkins, the 76er center with a reputation for shattering backboards, collided with Orr, the Indiana rookie, when they went up for a rebound.

title: Washington Watch; Reagan to Drop An Export Curb
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT Reagan is about to reverse the order President Carter signed shortly before the new Administration took office restricting the export of hazardous products that are banned or controlled in the United States.

title: MUSIC: THOMAS LEADS MOZART
description: THE sensuous, quicksilver lyricism of Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 23 in A (K. 488) and the weighty ruminations of Bruckner's Ninth Symphony made a potentially effective musical juxtaposition on the American Symphony Orchestra's program in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. As matters turned out, it seemed fairly clear that Michael Tilson Thomas, guest conductor for this concert, was somewhat more attuned to Bruckner than Mozart, not an uncommon situation among younger conductors these days.

title: Sara E. Nathan Is Married to Joel D. Kazis
description: At Temple Shearith Israel (the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue) yesterday, Sara E. Nathan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar J. Nathan 3d of New York, was married to Joel D. Kazis, son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert J. Kazis of Newton Centre, Mass. Rabbis Louis C. Gestein and Marc D. Angel officiated.

title: Vandals Smash Storefronts In Downtown Cleveland
description: About 60 youths smashed store windows and looted the displays early today in a 45-minute rampage in a one-block area of downtown Cleveland.

title: CITY BALLET: TWO DEBUTS AT SEASON'S CLOSE
description: THE New York City Ballet's winter season at the New York State Theater came to an end last weekend. But because its directors believe ballet to be a steadily evolving art, the company has always emphasized continuity of development rather than gala openings and grand finales. Therefore it was not strange that Saturday night's program featured two debuts. This season may have been ending, yet there are seasons to come and the dancers who made their debuts will surely be seen again in those ballets in the future.

title: Nurse Keeps Cool in Escape Attempt at Prison
description: It was a frightening situation, but Nelda Cushman says she didn't fear for her life Saturday night when she was seized by two desperate inmates and held hostage for two hours during an attempted escape at the Nevada Maximum Security Prison in Carson City.

title: Lillian Gish Recalls a Part
description: One reason she consented to be honorary chairman of the Friends of French Opera benefit performance of Ambroise Thomas's ''Hamlet,'' says Lillian Gish, is because she has ''a special affection for the role of Ophelia, Hamlet's ill-fated lady.''

title: SKALBANIA HAS HAD HIS FUN SPENDING $50 MILLION FOR TEAMS
description: rent side of Vancouver, British Columbia, would want to own a few sports teams of his own.

title: Versatile Acquires Vickers
description: The Versatile Corporation of Vancouver announced the acquisition of Vickers Canada Inc. of Montreal for an undisclosed sum. Versatile manufactures agricultural equipment and components for the oil and gas industry, while Vickers is a heavy industrial manufacturer. They also have shipyard operations in common.

title: TATE WINS IN COMEBACK BOUT
description: ''If you go to the cotton fields, you don't always pick 100 pounds,'' said John Tate after having scored a unanimous decision over Harvey Steichen today in a heavyweight bout. ''Sometimes you just pick 87. I'm satisfied with 87.''

title: TV: 'ONLY THE BALL WAS WHITE'
description: THE history of the black baseball leagues in the first half of this century certainly deserves more than half an hour, but ''Only the Ball Was White,'' on Channel 13 tonight at 9:30, manages at least to suggest the fascinating dimensions of the story. Made with frankly loving care, the documentary was produced and directed by Ken Solarz for Chicago's public-television station WTTW-TV. Paul Winfield is the narrator.

title: POLICE KILL SUITOR SEEKING TO ENTER HOUSE BY FORCE
description: An unarmed Brooklyn man was shot to death on the fire escape outside his former girlfriend's apartment early yesterday morning by a policeman who thought the man was armed and firing through the window, a police spokesman said.

title: MOST SKI MERCHANDISE IS MOVING SLOWLY
description: A lack of snow and high interest rates have wrought varying degrees of havoc on the ski industry this season, especially west of Michigan. Many ski dealers are stuck with last year's inventory, strapped for cash and reluctant to borrow money to buy new merchandise.

title: No Headline
description: TRAITORS, MOZAMBIQUE CHARGES: Mozambican Army officers on display at a public rally Saturday in Maputo. President Samora Machel accused eight of them of complicity in the South African commando raid into Mozambique last month. President Machel did not indicate what their fate would be.

title: TODAY'S EQUIPMENT IS UP WITH THE TIMES
description: GRAYING outdoorsmen often extol the pleasures of yesteryear that have been lost in the frantic rush of the atomic age, but all would admit that today's wanderer of forest, river and meadow has splended equipment at his disposal.

title: Flying Paster Wins Santa Anita Feature
description: Flying Paster scored a two-length victory in the 43d running of the $159,200 San Antonio Stakes at Santa Anita today.

title: Red Smith; The Wailing Of George 3d
description: IF Rick Cerone has a spark of compassion in him, his heart must bleed for George M. Steinbrenner 3d. Since an arbitrator raised Cerone's salary by $330,000, George 3d has been plunged in grief, not so much over the arbitrator's liberality with Steinbrenner's money but because of Cerone's disloyalty to the New York Yankees, their players and fans and George M. Steinbrenner 3d. George feels that the difference between the $350,000 the Yankees offered and the $440,000 that Cerone wanted was a petty reason for taking the club to arbitration, showing grievous ingratitude on the catcher's part.

title: PETTY, ON GAMBLE, TAKES HIS 7TH DAYTONA 500 RACE
description: Richard Petty got a break when Bobby Allison ran out of gas late in the race today, then Petty took a calculated risk and went on to win his seventh Daytona 500.

title: BLACK LEADER ATTACKS CAREY BUDGET
description: The senior ranking black in the Democratic-led Assembly denounced Governor Carey's proposed budget today, saying it would destroy many programs that benefit members of minority groups.

title: JET'S TURN BEFORE WESTCHESTER CRASH PUZZLES INVESTIGATORS
description: The investigation into the crash of a corporate jet near Westchester County Airport last Wednesday night has been narrowed to the plane's sudden departure from its course in the last two miles of its flight, a Federal offficial said yesterday.

title: SPAS WENKOFF SINGS A SUBTLE TRISTAN
description: AT the first night of the Metropolitan Opera's revival of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' a few weeks ago, the Bulgarian tenor Spas Wenkoff was rightly praised in his debut as Tristan. This is a murderously difficult part, after all: the first Tristan, Ludwig Schnorr von Carolsfeld, died a few weeks after the premiere in 1865, and Wagner's enemies were quick to suggest that the part had done him in.

title: KNICKS TOP SUNS, WIN 8TH STRAIGHT
description: The hottest team in the National Basketball Association cooled off the second hottest club tonight as Campy Russell and Bill Cartwright led the Knicks to a 115-101 victory over the Phoenix Suns.

title: London's Giant Panda To Get U.S. Valentine
description: A giant panda from the London Zoo will be sent to the United States next month for mating with a female at the Washington Zoo, according to a report in The Sunday Times.

title: Letter Perfect
description: A letter was sent to several newspapers in the last few days extolling the baseball abilities of a 17-year-old slugger from San Antonio. The information, including a blue resume that resembled a scouting report and a press clipping, was enough to convince anyone that Craig Magan is quite a prospect.

title: PIANO: PETER SERKIN'S 'GOLDBERG'
description: PETER SERKIN played Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations in Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon as if he were the legendary harpsichordist Johann Gottlieb Goldberg himself, playing for the insomniac Count Keyserlingk, who listened to the work during sleepless nights. His piano performance had that sort of dusky intimacy, each note taking rounded shape in the surrounding silences.

title: Report on Guyana Election Says It Was Rigged
description: Guyana's general election in December was ''rigged massively and flagrantly'' in favor of the ruling People's National Congress, a team of international observers reported today.

title: FEDERAL SUPPORT FOR DAIRY PRICES CRITICIZED ANEW
description: Just south of the shops of Chelsea and a block away from the Roxy roller disco, a mountain of butter is piling up. The 2.5-millionpound hoard, stacked in 68-pound cartons and stored at a bonechilling 2 degrees below zero, is only a tiny part of a Government stockpile of dairy products that now stands at more than one billion pounds of butter, dry milk and cheese.

title: Geography Lesson
description: In October 1980, the American League vetoed the sale of the Chicago White Sox to Edward J. DeBartolo Sr., a Youngstown, Ohio, businessman. He needed 10 of 14 votes and got only eight.

title: Canada Accord For Chrysler
description: The Government is expected to approve on Tuesday loan guarantees of $140 million (Canadian) for the Chrysler Corporation's Canadian affiliate.

title: OIL TOWN BOOMS WITH NEW TECHNOLOGY AND PRICES
description: What has been going on lately in Giddings is a throwback to the early, glory decades of the oil era: Muddy boots, black gold and greenbacks are everywhere. Roughnecks have been cutting loose in the bars at night and paying their way out of jail in the morning. Newcomers have been sleeping in the park, in cars, wherever they can. Instant millionaires have watched their royalties roll in.

title: THE LANGUAGE GAP
description: Talk about restoring U.S. influence in the world has focused on weapons, intelligence, hard political and economic bargaining. But it has overlooked one vital tool in understanding and swaying other countries. Effective use of these other resources requires a knowledge of foreign languages, which we have been losing for over a generation.

title: BUILDING AN OIL RESERVE THE THRIFTY WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: NUANCES OF THE THIRD WORLD
description: Shah Mohammad Dost, Foreign Minister of Afghanistan, said at a news conference Thursday that he was disheartened and surprised by a resolution, drafted at the conference of nations professing nonalignment, that called for withdrawal of foreign forces from his country.

title: WEST GERMAN POLICE EVICT 70
description: The police evicted 70 squatters from an abandoned power plant today after they had occupied the building and announced plans to live there. No violence was reported, but the police said some of the youths had to be carried out.

title: Guyana Oil Company
description: Guyana plans to set up a national petroleum corporation to supervise oil exploration and development, Energy and Mines Minister Hubert Jack said today. He told the National Assembly that prospects for finding oil in commercial quantities were good.

title: Met Is Replacing 'Tristan' With 'Flute' Tomorrow
description: The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that its scheduled performance tomorrow evening of ''Tristan'' would be replaced by ''The Magic Flute.''

title: REAGAN MOVING ON U.S. EXPORT BARS
description: The Reagan Administration, having organized a team of officials to deal with international trade issues, is now moving to speed up a drive to eliminate Government hindrances to exports.

title: A DISMISSED PROTOCOL CHIEF FINDS THE PROPER ETIQUETTE
description: What is the correct behavior for a government official who comes under embarrassing public criticism?

title: CITING ECONOMIC GROWTH, ANALYSTS PREDICT RATE RISE
description: Amid signs that the economy is continuing to grow, many credit market analysts say the forces of inflation and heavy borrowing demands might cause interest rates to increase.

title: Hiring Fairly, Without a Quota
description: Efforts to make job tests fair to minorities invariably arouse the suspicion that standards of merit are being sacrificed to politics. The danger does exist. But it seems to have been exaggerated in the discussion of the terms by which the departing Carter Administration agreed to settle a suit against Federal hiring practices.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. OPPOSES WIDE FEDERAL CUTS
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. issued a statement today opposing wholesale cuts in Federal programs, calling for job and training programs for the unemployed and supporting tax relief for the poor and for industries and regions in economic difficulty, rather than general tax relief.

title: 1,000 Seek 300 Jobs At New Marriott Inn
description: BUFFALO (AP) - About 1,000 people lined up to apply for 300 jobs at the new Marriott Inn that is to open March 25 in suburban Amherst. Twenty persons were interviewing applicants for jobs such as housekeeper, desk clerk, bartender, cook and waitress.

title: Praise From Menotti
description: When it comes to opera, the Opera Ensemble of New York is definitely small potatoes. The two-year-old company, which was organized by its musical director, Ruth Bierhoff, and its production director, John J. D. Sheehan, to provide a showcase for aspiring singers, doesn't even have an orchestra or a theater to call its own.

title: WHITE VIEW OF QUEENS SCHOOL CLASH...
description: Twelve years ago Sandra Petker and her family moved from the Canarsie section of Brooklyn into a house in Rosedale, Queens, that they had bought for $40,000.

title: 2-5 LORD AVIE BEATEN IN A 8-HORSE PHOTO
description: The king is not dead, exactly, but the throne was shaking a bit in South Florida tonight. Lord Avie, 2-year-old champion of 1980, was the 2-to-5 favorite among the nine 3-year-olds in today's Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park, but came up a little short in his usual late run. The champion finished third in a three-horse photo after having had dead aim in midstretch.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TO KNOW-HOW

title: NEED FOR HUNTER COLLEGE'S 2 NEW TOWERS IS DISPUTED
description: Dr. Jo Ann McNamara, a professor of medieval history at Hunter College, stood in the middle of Room 902, a bare, dim 10-by-12-foot office with four beaten metal desks and one telephone.

title: Frederick Luehring, 99, Is Dead; Coached Basketball at Princeton
description: Frederick Luehring, basketball coach at Princeton from 1912 to 1920 and later director of health and physical education at Pennsylvania, died Feb. 1 at his home in Swarthmore, Pa. He was 99 years old.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt BRAIN. By Robin Cook. 283 pages. Putnam. $11.95. AN ISLAND CALLED MOREAU. By Brian W. Aldiss. 173 pages. Simon & Schuster. $10.95.

title: YIDDISH BOOK COLLECTION GROWS IN NEW ENGLAND
description: FLORENCE, Mass. THE books began arriving in a flood here at the National Yiddish Book Exchange last summer as soon as word went out that a handful of young scholars were attempting to rescue the brief but intense literary flowering of a rapidly dying culture.

title: The Kids Were Unknown Until Lionel Hampton Joined
description: The main thing wrong with the McDonald's Tristate High School Jazz Ensemble is that the musicians, while arguably among the top-ranked high school players in the New York metropolitan area, are also rank unknowns.

title: HEMLINES: TREND IS DOWN, BUT ANYTHING IS ACCEPTABLE
description: Hemlines that shinny up and down the leg from season to season are not much use to anyone. Designers have found that they instill such feelings of apprehension and insecurity that they do not induce women to buy clothes of any kind, especially in a time of rising prices.

title: Mediator Schedules S.I. Transit Talks
description: A Federal mediator has called a meeting of union leaders and officials of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Operating Authority, whose union employees have worked without contracts for more than three years.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a sports article Saturday dealing with Rick Cerone's salary dispute, and again yesterday in Red Smith's col- umn, Jesse Simons was identified in- correctly. Mr. Simons, the arbitrator who ruled in the dispute, left New York City's Office of Collective Bargaining 11 years ago.

title: Harvard's American Rep To Tour Europe in 1982
description: The American Repertory Theater of Harvard will tour four European cities with two productions during the summer of 1982.

title: P.S. 196 Reopening After Fall of Ceiling
description: A Brooklyn elementary school where a ceiling collapsed last week will reopen today, a Board of Education spokesman said, engineers having determined that the building is structurally sound.

title: AN INSECURITY BUDGET
description: The one major increase in the budget to be announced by President Reagan tomorrow evening is a multi-billion-dollar jump for the military -in the name of national security.

title: THEFT-PROOF TRASH CANS
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAKESPEARE AS SHAKESPEARE INTENDED
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: THE SINE NOMINE
description: IF music, as Shakespeare had it, is the food of love, it was a healthy repast served up by Harry Saltzman directing the Sine Nomine Singers last Saturday night in the Abraham Goodman House. In honor of Valentine's Day, the 24 singers evoked the mischievous ministrations of Cupid himself.

title: Man Accused of Extortion At Five Las Vegas Resorts
description: Dennis J. Waugh, 28 years old, is under arrest on charges of trying to extort $10 million from five resorts here last week.

title: UNEASINESS GROWING IN HONG KONG OVER THE FUTURE OF LEASED PROPERTY
description: The failure of London and Peking to resolve the long-term future of Hong Kong is producing increasing signs of nervousness in this normally optimistic British colony.

title: Grand Juries in Five States To Investigate Auto Thefts
description: Grand juries in five states are to begin an investigation this week of the multimillion-dollar business of stolen automobiles, The Chicago Tribune reported today.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 17, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 3 P.M.

title: MAJOR STEP IN VACCINES FOR ANIMALS REPORTED
description: AN important step toward production of a foot-and-mouth disease vaccine by gene-splicing methods has been reported by West German research workers.

title: INTELLECTUALS COMPLAIN OF ABUSES
description: Iranians who criticize Islamic rule were denounced by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini today as 38 intellectuals circulated a letter charging that Iran again was subjected to repression and injustice.

title: FORDHAM BEATS WAGNER, 69-52
description: Mark Murphy, a sophomore guard, scored 18 points and Dud Tongal had 17 as Fordham defeated Wagner, 69-52, in a college basketball game last night at the Rose Hill Gymnasium in the Bronx.

title: Nitrogen Fixing
description: Scientists at Cornell University have reported success in a step toward the creation of new crop varieties that can fix atmospheric nitrogen, converting it from an inert gas to chemical compounds that can be absorbed by the roots of plants.

title: Kodak Net Up 37.4%; Dresser Climbs by 22.4%; EARNINGS
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest producer of photographic products, reported yesterday that earnings for the fourth quarter rose 37.4 percent while results for the full year were up 15 percent.

title: KARL RICHTER, CONDUCTOR, DIES AT 54 LEADER OF MUNICH BACH ORCHESTRA
description: Karl Richter, a leader in reviving interest in Baroque music and a conductor and organist best known for his Bach interpretations, was found dead in a Munich hotel room yesterday. The 54-year-old musician had apparently died of a heart attack, authorities said.

title: Tornado Kills 4 in Burma
description: A tornado swept through the village of Kutkhai, about 550 miles northeast of here, on Thursday, leaving four people dead, more than 80 injured, and a path of destruction that leveled or damaged 400 buildings in five minutes, the newspaper Botataung reported today.

title: Officials Seek Cause Of Fire That Hurt 2
description: Fire marshals yesterday were seeking the cause of a fire in an East Side apartment hotel that injured two people, one of them critically.

title: SPECIES SURVIVAL LINKED TO LOPSIDED SEX RATIOS
description: SCIENTISTS have long wondered why various species of animal, including human beings, sometimes produce lopsided ratios of male to female offspring. For example, in two species of seal it has been found that females giving birth early in the season produce 12 males for every 10 females. Those who pup late produce a male-to-female ratio of 8 to 10, evening the score. Human mothers under stress tend to produce fewer boys than girls.

title: Smalley Gets $2.4 Million In 4-Year Twins' Pact
description: Roy Smalley, the Minnesota Twins' shortstop who was to have gone to arbitration today for a ruling on his contract, instead signed a four-year, multimillion dollar pact with the club.

title: ANGELS SAY ROLE RIDING SUBWAYS HINGES ON PUBLIC
description: After a weekend in which a dozen youths who said they were Guardian Angels were arrested in three subway incidents, the leader of the Angels said he would discontinue the subway patrols ''if that is what the public wants.''

title: Eric Paepcke Dies in Washington; Landscape Planner for U.S. Sites
description: Eric Paepcke, a landscape architect who did work for the Naval Academy, the National Academy of Sciences and United States Embassies overseas, died yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital here after a heart attack. Mr. Paepcke, who was 75 years old, lived in the Georgetown district and formerly in New York.

title: BELL ASKS SCHOOLS TO BOLSTER COURSES
description: 14ATLANTA, Feb. 16 (AP) - Without abandoning their commitment to equal education for underprivileged children, the nation's schools must return to a tougher curriculum that challenges all students and demands discipline, Education Secretary T.H. Bell said today.

title: TIRE GRADING IS CRITICIZED
description: Grading automobile tires for consumers is not as simple as A-B-C, argue the rubber manufacturers who oppose the Federal Government's new tire-grading system, which Uniroyal Inc. alone has embraced.

title: International
description: Common Market Finance Ministers urged the United States to reduce the broad gap between interest rates in America and Europe. This gap, they said, had caused the dollar's sharp rise on currency markets and the concurrent weakness of their own currencies. The officials were said to have acted in response to Bonn's effort to seek an internationally coordinated reduction of interest rates to reduce pressure on the German mark. (Page D1.)

title: AMERICAN ENVOYS ARRIVE IN BONN TO SEEK BACKING ON EL SALVADOR
description: American officials arrived in Bonn today on the first leg of a diplomatic mission seeking European support against what the Reagan Administration feels is intervention by the Soviet Union and its allies in the guerrilla conflict in El Salvador.

title: Crash Mars Daytona Race
description: Bob Ballantine of Ellicott City, Md., suffered a bruised lung, a broken rib and multiple bruises yesterday in an accident in the Sportsman 300 race at Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: INDIA'S FARMERS, IN A HUGE RALLY, EXPRESS SUPPORT FOR MRES. GHANDI
description: Hundreds of thousands of farmers converged on this city today for a rally to demonstrate support for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and her Government's agricultural policies.

title: SYMPTOMS OF SCHIZOPHRENIA
description: * Delusions of control, such as thinking a computer is hooked into one's brain, controlling all thoughts and actions.

title: Shell Finds Oil Off Argentina
description: A group of three Royal Dutch/ Shell affiliates has found oil in what has a good chance of being Argentina's first commercial offshore discovery, Energy Secretary Daniel Brunella said at a weekend news conference.

title: Miners in Wales Vote To Begin Strike Today
description: Leaders of 26,000 coal miners in South Wales voted today to begin a strike tomorrow over the planned closing of as many as 50 unprofitable mines, but Energy Minister David Howell asked them to discuss the dispute with the National Coal Board.

title: Malaysia Said To Cut Oil Cost
description: Petronas, the Malaysian state oil company, has reduced its prices for high-quality, light crude oil by 50 cents (United States) a barrel, retroactive to Feb. 1, oil industry sources said today.

title: MUSIC: NEIKRUGS, FATHER AND SON
description: TWO generations of the Neikrug family came together Sunday evening for a concert at the 92d Street Y. George Neikrug was the cellist, while his son, Marc, not only played the piano but composed some of the music on the program as well.

title: REVIEW SAID TO FIND NO CAUSE TO RENEGE ON HOSTAGE ACCORD
description: A Reagan Administration interagency committee has reportedly found no substantial legal obstacles to carrying out the terms negotiated with Iran for the release of the 52 American hostages, Administration officials said today.

title: TV: FORENSIC MEDICINE AND RETURN OF 'RUMPOLE'
description: ''RUMPOLE of the Bailey'' returns to public television this evening, but before the fictional British barrister can resume his blustery ways, the ''Nova'' series is offering a far less sanguine and more bloody portrait of crime. On WNET-TV, Channel 13, at 8 o'clock, ''The Science of Murder'' enters the incredibly painstaking world of forensic medicine to find incriminating evidence in a strand of hair or the saliva on a cigarette butt.

title: Politics Isn't Any More Important Than Friendship
description: It began as a chance encounter in a stairwell of an Indianapolis hotel and now has blossomed into a friendship that transcends partisan politics.

title: Danforth Stepping Down As Coach at Tulane
description: Roy Danforth, Tulane basketball coach, who was unable to regain his winning touch after moving from Syracuse, resigned today and took a job as assistant athletic director.

title: SHIP REPAIR YARDS OF EUROPE ENCOUNTER GROWING DEMAND
description: The slowdown in international trade, the result of a series of oil price explosions that have shaken the world economy since 1974, has pushed Europe's shipbuilders to the brink of insolvency. But for ship repair yards, the recession turns out to have a silver lining.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Beverage Corporation, Baltimore, has appointed Edward A. Weisman executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: IT'S NO CRIME TO BE ACCUSED
description: To the Editor:

title: JOSEPH W. KAUFMAN, A PROSECUTOR AT NUREMBERG WAR CRIMES TRIALS
description: Joseph W. Kaufman, a lawyer and judge who served as a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials after World War II, died of apparent heart failure Friday at his home in Washington. He was 81 years old.

title: TOP ISRAELI COURT BARS TAKEOVER OF AN ARAB ELECTRICITY FRANCHISE
description: Israel's Supreme Court today blocked a Government bid to take over an Arab-run electric company's franchise on the occupied West Bank, but it approved the takeover in East Jerusalem, the predominantly A@rab sector of the city annexed by Israel.

title: Chess: Christiansen Bests Spassky To Earn a Tie With Karpov
description: One of the greatest American successes in recent years was Larry Christiansen's tie for first place with Anatoly Karpov, the world champion, in the Linares, Spain, international tournament. The 24-year-old United States co-champion from Modesto, Calif., and his Russian rival each scored 8-3. FINAL STANDINGS Player W. L. D. Pts. Christiansen 6 1 4 8 Karpov 5 0 6 8 Larsen 5 2 4 7 Ribli 3 1 7 6 1/2 Spassky 2 1 8 6 Kavalek 2 1 8 6 Portisch 3 3 5 5 1/2 Ljubojevic 1 2 8 5 Glijoric 3 4 4 5 Quinteros 2 5 4 4 Bellon 3 7 1 3 1/2 Garcia 0 8 3 1 1/2

title: No Headline
description: Talking Businesswith French of National Steel and Shipbuilding Shipbuilders Wary of Future

title: WHY NOT CREATE A 'HEALTH BELT' IN THE SOUTH BRONX?
description: Everyone from Ronald Reagan to Rosa Perez on Tinton Avenue knows that the South Bronx is ill. It suffers from unemployment, illiteracy, arson and despair. Public policies have failed to deal effectively with these issues. Now there is a new solution, The Urban Jobs and Enterprise Zone Act, but that approach to reindustrializing our cities is doomed.

title: SELLING TACTICS FOR JEANS SHIFT AFTER SHAKE-UP
description: After a series of management shakeups and a short-lived takeover bid from Allegheny Ludlum, Blue Bell Inc., the No.2 jeans manufacturer, is struggling to get its house in order and compete more aggressively with the big Levi Strauss & Company.

title: British Report Trade Surplus
description: Britain today announced a record surplus in its trade with the rest of the world last month.

title: Market Place; Esmark-Mobil: Idea for Others
description: IN a time when old-line companies sell at anemic price/earnings ratios of 5 or less, managements are looking for ways to impress investors with underlying values. One approach is to streamline operations, spinning off segments that the company is not prepared to exploit fully. It could become a habit.

title: DANCE: 'DOILIE SISTERS'
description: CERTAIN aspects of the dance and mime show called ''The Doilie Sisters'' at La Mama might best be overlooked. For instance, some scenes were supposedly set in 1990, although this was in no way an example of speculative or science-fiction theater. One could also overlook the offering's coy title. ''The Doilie Sisters'' had little to do with doilies and nothing to do with the Dolly Sisters, the Hungarian stars who worked for Florenz Ziegfeld between 1911 and 1917.

title: And 'Ethical ' Censors at Unesco
description: There is a dangerous new burst of solicitude for the safety of journalists at the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in Paris. The agency seeks opinion on a plan to license correspondents for ''safe conduct'' passes, to be earned by a favorable rating for the ''ethics'' of their work.

title: PUERTO RICO'S AGRICULTURAL WOES REFLECT DANGERS OF RAPID GROWTH
description: West of the capital, past the sprawling suburbs, the interminable auto graveyards and an abandoned sugar mill, 5,000 acres of prime farmland lie idle, plowed under several years ago to make way for an ambitious government project to grow rice.
To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Virginia Trounces Georgia Tech, 83-42

title: Cabby Found Slain
description: The driver of a gypsy cab was shot and killed in Harlem, apparently in a robbery, the police said.

title: WELLS FARGO SUSPENDS COAST OFFICER IN INQUIRY IN TENNESSEE LAND DEAL
description: The Wells Fargo National Bank said today that the manager of its Hollywood branch had been relieved of his duties pending an investigation into his possible role in an investment scheme involving real estate in Tennessee. He was the third Wells Fargo branch manager in the last month to be suspended or dismissed.

title: Providence Routs St. John's, 73 to 57
description: St. John's remained in one of the worst scoring slumps in the team's history tonight as it went more than 11 minutes without a basket for the second consecutive game.

title: ECONOMIC FALLACY
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THERE were a lot of slick pompadours, leather jackets, tweedy overcoats and pale faces at P.S. 1 Sunday afternoon. P.S. 1 is the public school turned art gallery at 46-01 21st Street, Long Island City, and the occasion was the opening of its new exhibits. Some came for the New York/New Wave exhibit, intelligently mounted by Diego Cortez, which featured the work of such artists and photographers as Robert Mappelthorpe, Larry Williams, Leslie Schiff, Marcus Leatherdale, Allan Tannenbaum, Alan Suicide, John Sex and William Coupon. Others came to see Adrienn Scott's slick fashion videotape exhibit, a commercial counterpoint featuring Issey Miyake's now legendary fashion show at Studio 54 two years ago.

title: Lakers' Scout Notes Knick Improvement
description: Mike Thibault has watched the Knicks play twice this season. They won both times, but there was a telling difference in their performances.

title: E.E.C. ASKS U.S. TO CUT INTEREST RATE
description: European finance ministers today urged the United States to help reduce the broad gap between interest rates in America and Europe. They said that the substantially higher rates in the United States were the major reason for the dollar's recent steep climb against European currencies.

title: STAGE: AN ABSURDIST'S 'MARY STUART'
description: IN the program for the Dodger Theater production of ''Mary Stuart'' at the Public Theater, there is an elaborate genealogical chart titled ''The English Succession, showing the position of Mary Queen of Scots and Lord Darnley, in relation to the English throne.'' It's an intimidating chart whose calligraphic lettering and profusion of dates promise a windy evening of historical theater. It is also, one eventually and happily discovers, a red herring. The play at the Public isn't about royal family trees. Nor does it have much truck with Lord Darnley, Friedrich von Schiller's ''Mary Stuart,'' or, for that matter, English civilization as we ever knew it. This is Wolfgang Hildesheimer's ''Mary Stuart,'' and it looks very much like the work of a madman.

title: HARRIS JURY CALLED ON BY BOTH SIDES TO FOCUS ON MAXIMUM CHARGE
description: Both sides in the Jean S. Harris murder trial asked the jury of eight women and four men today to consider guilt or innocence only on the charge of murder in the second degree.

title: HOLIDAY GIVES HINT OF SPRING TO SPIRIT OF '76
description: To the staccato roll of drums and the whistle of fifes, 300 marchers moved up Fifth Avenue toward St. Patrick's Cathedral in a whirl of glinting batons and silvered swords in the annual Knights of Columbus Washington's Birthday Parade. At its head, in sashes and ostrich-plumed hats, strode 30 members of the knights' New York chapter.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC PLAYS A SEQUEL IN HARLEM
description: AFTER the rousing success of the New York Philharmonic's first-ever concert in Harlem on April 21, 1980, a return visit seemed both inevitable and mandatory. And so last night Zubin Mehta and the orchestra once again made the trip uptown to the Abyssinian Baptist Church on West 138th Street, and once again a large audience was on hand to hear the Philharmonic play.

title: U.S. BACKS SALVADORAN JUNTA AND STILLS COUP RUMORS
description: The Reagan Administration, three weeks after dismissing Robert E. White as Ambassador to El Salvador, is largely following the same course of action here as the Carter Administration while deliberating what its final policy should be,

title: Tulsa 74, Wichita State 72
description: David Brown hit four free throws in the final 25 seconds of the second overtime to give Tulsa a 74-72 victory over 14th-ranked Wichita State in a Missouri Valley Conference game tonight.

title: OFFICER'S KILLING OF YOUTH: DID VICTIM HAVE A GUN?
description: The fatal shooting of a 17-year-old alleged car thief by an offduty police officer in Brooklyn last Tuesday has provoked disagreement between some community residents and police investigators over whether the youth had a gun at the time the incident occurred.

title: Index; International
description: Notes on the U.N.: A tussle at every turn A2 Thousands of Indian farmers rally in support of Mrs. Gandhi A3 Soviet apparently tried to compro- mise a U.S. Army attache A4 Around the World A5 U.S. still coup rumors in Salvador as it backs junta A11 Government/Politics F.B.I. officials concerned about bureau's priorities A17 General Around the Nation A14 Bell calls for tougher Huntington, leader of U.S. nudism movement D15 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A18

title: Train Crash in India Kills 14
description: Fourteen people were killed and seven injured in a train accident yesterday near Benares, about 400 miles southeast of New Delhi, officials said. They said a passenger tain crashed into an express train after the express had halted when a passenger pulled the emergency cord by mistake.

title: IN SHUTTLE'S SHADOW, THE PIGS AND PALMETTOS ARE UNDISTURBED
description: From the windows of his office in the launching control center George F. Page has an unobstructed view of the space shuttle Columbia in the steel embrace of its launching tower, three miles to the east where the palmetto scrub gives way to sand and to the Atlantic Ocean.

title: PATHYS ADD TO STAKE IN ABITIBI
description: The Pathy family of Montreal won a round today in the battle for control of Abitibi-Price Inc. The family's privately owned shipping company announced the purchase of two blocks of Abitibi stock for $67.7 million (in Canadian dollars, now worth about 85 United States cents each).

title: Deaths in Dublin Fire Put at 44 Rather Than 48
description: The tally of dead in the Saturday disco fire dropped to 44 today as the coroner's office continued to try to identify the victims. Dr. P.J. Bofin, the coroner, said the number of deaths was not 48, as previously believed.

title: This Joy at the White House Was Somewhat Premature
description: When Richard S. Schweiker was named Secretary of Health and Human Services, no one seemed happier than Jerome R. Waldie, the executive director of the White House Conference on Aging.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I no longer am bound. Obviously, I support the President but I will pursue my own program.''

title: Q. Why does your nose run when you go out in the cold?
description: A. Nasal discharge and congestion are normal responses to environmental irritants or stimulants to the nose. Atmospheric conditions, such as hot air or cold air, can trigger a response by the nervous system.

title: JANUARY DISAPPOINTS NEW YORK RETAILERS
description: Retail sales in New York and the metropolitan area proved disappointing in January, averaging gains of 6.9 percent and 6.1 percent, respectively, over the comparable months a year earlier, a monthly spot-check found. The sales advances were the smallest since last September.

title: CLEON JONES NAMED COACH IN METS CHAIN
description: Cleon Jones, one of the most productive members of the Mets' World Series championship team of 1969, is returning as a minor-league instructor, the club announced yesterday.

title: Three on Snowmobiles Drown
description: Three Des Moines residents who had been riding on two snowmobiles drowned in the Saylorville Reservoir Saturday, but a hospital helicopter crew plucked a fourth possible victim from the water.

title: Desaulniers Takes Title In Pro Squash Racquets
description: Michael Desaulniers of Montreal, a Harvard student, won the United States professional squash racquets title yesterday by beating top-seeded Sharif Kahn of Toronto in the final, 18-16, 12-15, 15-9, 15-11.

title: LILY PLEDGING $25 MILLION FOR INDIANAPOLIS STADIUM
description: An endowment set up by Eli Lilly & Company, the pharmaceuticals concern, pledged today to give Indianapolis $25 million to build a 60,000-seat covered sports stadium as the centerpiece of a proposed national amateur athletics complex.

title: ISAAC DON LEVINE, 89, FOE OF SOVIET
description: Isaac Don Levine, a journalist and writer, died Sunday of a heart attack in Venice, Fla. He was 89 years old. Born in Russia and the author of more than a dozen books, Mr. Levine was a militant opponent of the Soviet regime. In the early 1920's he returned to Russia to cover the civil war as a correspondent for American newspapers.

title: Canada Revises Gas and Oil Aid
description: Access to incentive payments for oil and gas exploration by Canadian-owned companies was made easier today under new regulations announced by the Federal Government.

title: Notes on the U.N.
description: To insure an independent international civil service, governments here are not supposed to stake out claims for jobs. But the Soviet Union and the United States are fighting over the post of executive secretary to a Vienna conference promoting peaceful uses of outer space that is due to be held next year.

title: Boston Officials Considering Several New Tax Measures
description: City officials are considering taxing company payrolls, colleges, parking lots, real estate sales, hospitals and hotel rooms to make up for an anticipated decline in property taxes.

title: Helping Atlanta
description: The remains of two more black children were found in Atlanta on Friday, and the toll - after a year and a half -is now 17 dead and 1 missing. One can only hope that recent developments may help to solve this devastating mystery.

title: FIELDS, FRESHMAN CENTER, DROPPED BY U.C.L.A. FIVE
description: Kenny Fields, a frehsman center for U.C.L.A., has been dropped from the basketball team, Coach Larry Brown announced today.

title: Byrd Says Reagan Lacks Grasp of National Issues
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, the Senate minority leader, said in an interview published today that President Reagan was off to a slow start and his programs would be hindered because he ''is very unfamiliar with national government.''

title: Florida Prison Inmates Shot; Hostage Secretary Released
description: Two prison inmates holding a secretary as hostage were shot by rescuers early this morning, according to Florida correction officials. One of the inmates died of his wounds and the other was seriously wounded.

title: YEMEN FREES U.S. PAIR HELD AS SPIES
description: Two American citizens were held by Yemen for a year on charges of being spies in a case never disclosed by the State Department.

title: Dollar Climbs Overseas as Gold Retreats
description: The dollar continued its upward surge on the world's leading currency markets today, its rise fueled by high United States interest rates and what one dealer termed ''tremendous euphoria'' in anticipation of President Reagan's presentation of his economic program to Congress on Wednesday.

title: Picketing Planned in Ohio To Protest Teachers' Jailing
description: Striking teachers vowed today to picket school board members' businesses and otherwise harass them over the jailing of 17 teachers and a union negotiator.

title: Jordanian Bishop Is Named Greek Orthodox Patriarch
description: Archbishop Deodoros, the leader of the Greek Orthodox faith in Jordan, was elected Patriarch of Jerusalem today.

title: Commerzbank Gets New Top Executive
description: Walter Seipp, 55 years old, has joined Commerzbank, West Germany's third-largest bank, as a member of its managing board. The Frankfurt-based institution, which recently completed two successive years of weak profits, also announced that Mr. Seipp would become president and chief executive officer after the annual meeting on May 7.

title: A LIBERAL DEMOCRAT FINDS CONSTITUENTS DEMANDING BUDGET CUTS
description: ''Uncle Sam can't play Santa Claus forever,'' said John Kelly, a lifelong Democrat and former president of the South Lawrence Associates, a men's club here. ''You defend some of these Federal programs and you're going to aggravate a lot of people here,'' he warned.

title: THEATER: 'STARDUST BOYS'
description: SUCH is the unpredictable nature of the music and record business that sudden celebrity is not reserved just for the young. Even an old-fashioned polka band that plays for Middle Western weddings and ladies' clubs can achieve - or at least fantasize - about success. In ''The Legendary Stardust Boys'' at the South Street Theater, D.B. Gilles focuses on a quartet of middle-aged, working-class men in Akron, Ohio, with a perpetual dream of lifting themselves from their mundane environment. All it takes is one hit record.

title: PHYSICISTS AIM BIG GUNS AT DATES OF THE PAST
description: NEW techniques for sorting out atoms and their components are rapidly improving the reliability of scientific estimates of the ages of things as varied as ancestral humans, Renaissance paintings and the universe itself.

title: DEPOSITORIES OF THE HISTORY OF WOMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Asks a Partnership With Warsaw Government
description: The spokesman for the independent Polish trade union said it was seriously considering the Government's call for a 90-day strike truce but stressed that it expected a genuine partnership in return.

title: Zolfo in Place of Satin
description: Throckmorton/Satin Associates, specialists in direct marketing, has changed its name to Throckmorton/ Zolfo Associates, recognizing the presence of Victor Zolfo, for two years vice president and creative director.

title: A GERNADE MARS STOP IN PAKISTAN
description: Pope John Paul II arrived in this most Roman Catholic of Asian nations this morning after a stopover in Karachi, Pakistan, that the Vatican described as a good will gesture toward the world's 800 million Moslems.

title: REAGAN IS LOWERING EXTENT OF TAX CUT FOR THE AFFLUENT
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to give high-income Americans only part of the 30 percent tax cut being proposed for most taxpayers, according to Administration and Congressional sources.

title: BEHIND THE KILLINGS IN GUATEMALA
description: Every day, the morning newspapers report more of the same: 14, or 10, or 12 bodies discovered - another wave of killings. Since 1966, there have been 30,000 deaths. Since Gen. Fernando Romeo Lucas Garcia became President in 1978, there have been 3,000, with more than 600 other persons arrested and unaccounted for. Bodies have been found piled in ravines, dumped at roadsides, buried in mass graves.

title: STRIKE BY BASQUES PROTESTS JAIL DEATH
description: A general strike called to protest the death of a suspected terrorist in police custody paralyzed industrial and commercial activity in the Basque region today.

title: News Analysis
description: Last week four persons - a teen-ager suspected of car theft, a storekeeper beset by robbers, a college student involved in a campus incident and a young man who tried to see his former girlfriend - were killed by metropolitan police officers.

title: ADELPHI HONORS A SLAIN STUDENT WITH SILENT VIGIL
description: More than 1,000 Adelphi University students participated today in a 10-minute silent vigil for Edward Fonseca, a 21-year-old junior from Oakdale, L.I., who was shot and killed by a Garden City policeman early Saturday.

title: F.B.I. OFICIALS ASSERT CRIME FIGHT WILL COST CUTS IN OTHER EFFORTS
description: Top officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have told the agency's Director, William H. Webster, that they could revive the bureau's battle against violent crime but only by adding more agents or reducing priority efforts against organized crime and white collar offenses.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1981
description: International The agreement with Iran that led to the release of the 52 American hostages is expected to be carried out by the Reagan Administration. Officials said that an interagency panel had found no substantial legal obstacles to putting the terms of the agreement negotiated by the Carter Administration into effect. The finding has been sent to the White House for a final decision by President Reagan. (Page A1, Column 1.) Critics of Islamic rule were denounced by Ayatollah Khomeini as 38 Iranian intellectuals circulated a letter charging that Iran was again being subjected to repression. The revolutionary leader asserted that the critics were enemies of Islam and he particularly decried writers. (A6:1-2.)

title: FARMERS TAKE IMPOUNDED SOYBEANS
description: With farmers from more than 15 states standing by, the Federal Government backed down today and gave Wayne Cryts his 31,000 bushels of soybeans.

title: SCIENTISTS AND HUMANISTS TRY SOME CONVERSATION
description: THE issue of noncommunication between scientists and humanists is of long standing. C.P. Snow, the late British physicist and author, suggested that the two groups lived in ''two cultures,'' each with its own way of thinking and appreciating the world. The importance of basing public policy on informed judgments by laymen about scientific issues has been dramatized by events, such as the crisis at the Three Mile Island nuclear facility.

title: THIRD PLACE IN MILE RELAY GIVES FAIRLEIGH TRACK MILE
description: Going into the one-mile relay, the final event of today's 39th annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships, Fairleigh Dickinson and Rutgers were tied for first place. Seton Hall won the race, Fairleigh finished third and Rutgers fourth, so Fairleigh won its first Metropolitan indoor title ever.

title: MRS. THATCHER IS CONFIDENT OF CLOSE TIES WITH REAGAN
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that she expected the traditional ''special relationship'' between Britain and the United States to be enhanced by the fact that she and President Reagan personally were in agreement on so many economic and political issues.

title: Hope on Inflation Trend
description: Inflation hit double figures in most countries last year, but there is a glimmer of hope that the rate may eventually drop, the International Labor Organization said today.

title: Bernstein's 'Mass' Played At the Vienna State Opera
description: It took nearly a decade, but Leonard Bernstein's ''Mass'' finally made it to the Vienna State Opera. The conductor laureate of the New York Philharmonic was present yesterday for a special nationally televised performance of his work. He said a performance of the ''Mass'' in Vienna had been ''the dream of my life.''

title: PACIFIC COAST LEAGUE TEAM GIVES UP PURSUIT OF TIANT
description: The Portland Beavers of the Pacific Coast League announced today that they have abandoned plans to sign Luis Tiant, the veteran pitcher, to a contract.

title: The Ghost of Lake Placid
description: WHEN he walked into the Olympic field house at Lake Placid recently and glanced across the ice, Herb Brooks thought he was seeing ghosts. ''The arena was empty, but it was eerie,'' the United States Olympic hockey coach recalled. ''I could see people in the stands chanting 'U.S.A.' and waving American flags. Out on the ice, I could see certain moments in certain games, like when Mark Johnson scored with only one second remaining in the first period to tie the Soviets at 2-2. That was a big goal.''

title: SCHIZOPHRENIA IN POPULAR BOOKS: A STUDY FINDS TOO MUCH HOPE
description: WHEN Hannah Green wrote her 1964 bestseller, ''I Never Promised You A Rose Garden,'' she plumbed her own early life experience as a mental patient to describe how schizophrenia tormented ''Deborah Blau,'' the book's young heroine: ''On a certain night before falling asleep, Deborah had been reborn as a captured Japanese soldier. From behind the mask of an American-Jewish girl with a past of an American suburb and city, the elliptical eyes of the Enemy looked for the day of his unmasking. The tumor's impossible, insistent anguish was his war wound and his mind, versed in a strange language, rang with dreams of escape.''

title: HENRY S. HUNTINGTON, PIONEER OF NUDISM IN U.S., 99
description: Henry S. Huntington Jr., a former Presbyterian minister and a pioneer in the nudism movement in the United States, died Friday at the Unitarian-Universalist House in Philadelphia, where he lived. He was 99 years old.

title: FOR CHILDREN, REAL ECONOMICS
description: The 47 fifth-graders at Friends School here work at assigned jobs, earn weekly wages in poker chips, gain interest on the chips they deposit in their savings accounts and use the tender to pay for privileges as well as fines for breaking rules.

title: Unwelcome Heralds in Central America
description: Whatever a regime's political color, it takes special pluck to defend human rights in Central America.

title: ...AND THE DISPUTE AS SEEN BY BLACKS
description: Some black parents of children at Intermediate School 231 in Springfield Gardens, Queens, summarize in a few words what they believe underlies the legal battles, rallies, boycotts and sit-ins that white parents have undertaken to keep the school's Rosedale annex open: The majority, they say, is afraid to become the minority.

title: FEW LONG-TERM ISSUES
description: High interest rates are discouraging many potential borrowers and are causing them to delay long-term financings, investment bankers say.

title: Tire Overgrading Is Found
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, in a preliminary finding, says two tire companies overgraded tread-wear ratings. The finding affects the General Tire Company's Polysprint II and the Armstrong Rubber Company's Surveyor 78, both bias-ply tires sold in the replacement market.

title: PLAUSIBLE AND PERILOUS
description: Legitimate public concern about high crime rates has brought back into the news one of those quick-fix proposals that sound good until someone is rude enough to call it by its real name - preventive detention.

title: Chinese Reminded and Cautioned About the Limits on Free Speech
description: The Communist Party told citizens today that they could not have absolute freedom of speech and warned that those who broke the law would be punished.

title: LEECHES STILL HAVE THEIR MEDICAL USES
description: MAINZ, West Germany THE leeches in the drug store window seemed to belong to a scene from ancient medicine, when doctors applied the worms to patients to ''cure'' just about every condition. But here the leeches were in a jar near electronic devices and bottles of modern miracle drugs.

title: People
description: * Robert J. Flaherty has been appointed editor and publisher of OTC Review magazine.

title: Southern Yemen's Embassy In Paris Is Hit by Rockets
description: Two rocket shells blasted into Southern Yemen's Embassy here before dawn today, causing considerable damage but no injuries.

title: Two Saved From Sunken Ship
description: Two men survived four hours trapped in a cargo hold under water when their ship sank in the harbor here today, hospital officials said. The Norwegian cargo ship Jaeren with four crewmen aboard turned over and sank in 30 seconds when part of its cargo of aluminum ingots shifted during unloading. One body has been recovered and the fourth man is missing, the police said.

title: PCB Soot May Shut Building for Years
description: A state office building here may be kept shut for months or even years, officials directing the cleanup of toxic PCB-laden soot now say.

title: FLAWED ATTACK ON THE L.E.A.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Detroit Train in a Mess Over That 'ExSaSuHol'
description: Passengers waiting to board the Amtrak Executive commuter train were delayed for two hours today because two railroad companies had not agreed whether Washington's Birthday was a holiday.

title: INQUIRY OPENED
description: The Westchester County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, said today that someone had illegally placed an electronic listening device in his office, that it had been found early this month and that the District Attorney's office was investigating.

title: FERDINAND MENDENHALL
description: Ferdinand Mendenhall, a vice president of The Daily News of Los Angeles, died of an apparent heart attack here Saturday. He was 72 years old. Mr. Mendenhall, of Beverly Hills, was in Monterey to attend the California Newspaper Publishers Association convention.

title: A TEACHER WHO REFUSED TO FAIL
description: FOUR years ago, Beverly Joyce Bimes, a high school English teacher in St. Louis, thought seriously of quitting her job. Headlines everywhere, she recalls, were screaming that the schools were failing. ''I was angry and depressed,'' she says. ''If I'm failing, I ask myself, why go on?'' After a few days, her depression turned into angry determination. ''Let's show them,'' she said to herself and to her colleagues.

title: Carpenter Technology President Gets Added Post as Chief Officer
description: Paul R. Roedel, the 53-year-old president of the Carpenter Technology Corporation, has been elected to the additional position of chief executive officer, effective March 1. He will succeed Howard O. Beaver Jr., 55, who will remain chairman of the specialtysteel manufacturer with headquarters in Reading, Pa.

title: BARISH BUYS FILM RIGHTS TO FEMINIST MUSICAL 'ACT'
description: Movie rights to ''I'm Getting My Act Together and Taking It on the Road,'' the feminist musical that has been playing Off Broadway for nearly three years, have been purchased for approximately $500,000 by Keith Barish, a Florida real-estate developer who turned movie producer two years ago.

title: EUROPE RECOGNIZES TAIWAN-IN TRADE
description: Wellington Y. Tsao is pleased: In the last couple of years Taiwan discovered Europe, Europe discovered Taiwan - and both liked what they found.

title: COSMOS TIE IN ARGENTINA
description: The Cosmos played a 2-2 tie last night with Deportivo Moron in Buenos Aires. Giorgio Chinaglia scored both goals for the Cosmos. The Cosmos' next game on their 13-game South American tour will be played Thursday in Buenos Aires against Racing.

title: E.E.C. Exchange Rates
description: The E.E.C. finance ministers today decided against modifying exchange rates inside the European Monetary System to reflect the weakness of the German mark, Common Market sources said tonight.

title: Roy Grace Is Climbing The Doyle Dane Ladder
description: Roy Grace is moving up the Doyle Dane Bernbach ladder again.

title: OUR PROPER LINK WITH TAIWAN
description: To the Editor:

title: DEFECTIVE ASSESSMENT BY CHARGE LAINGEN
description: To the Editor:

title: Saving the Earth
description: Leave it to the space nuts to drive concern over environmental risks to new heights. An advisory council to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration urges - apparently with a straight face - a costly project to head off ''extinction by asteroid impact.''

title: Holiday Closings Observed Monday
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges, banks across the nation, including the Federal Reserve Bank, and all commodities markets were closed yesterday in observance of Washington's Birthday.

title: RUPPERT JONES RECALLS A SEASON TO FORGET
description: Ruppert Jones remembers standing in center field in Oakland last August with two runners on base in the scoreless first inning. Tommy John was pitching to Tony Armas when the A's batter powered the ball out toward left-center, and Jones ran to make the catch.

title: SURPRISE STOCK MOVE BY PRIVATE SHIPOWNER
description: A publicity-shunning shipowner whose name has been largely unknown in Canada's financial community has touched off a struggle for control of the world's largest newsprint producer, Abitibi-Price Inc.

title: Swissair and Us Magazine Moving to New Agencies
description: Two account moves in the over-$1 million class: Swissair, which spends $1.2 million to $1.5 million a year on advertising, has split with Waring & LaRosa after about 10 years and looks like it will end up with GrafDesley, whose president and creative editor, Hubert J. Graf, is former ad manager of Swissair.

title: BBDO and Grey Issue Reports on Earnings
description: BBDO International and Grey Advertising issued fourth-quarter earnings statements last week.

title: U.S. ARMY ATTACHE CALLED TARGET OF SOVIET PLOT TO COMPROMISE HIM
description: Maj. James R. Holbrook, an assistant Army attache at the American Embassy, appears to have been the object of an operation by the Soviet security services aimed at compromising him.

title: News Analysis
