description: The Reagan Administration may have adopted a clear line in opposing leftist guerrillas in El Salvador, but its first four weeks in office have left veteran diplomats puzzled about its policies in other areas.

title: Miss Eda-Pierre Out of 'Hamlet'
description: Christiane Eda-Pierre, who is indisposed, has withdrawn from the concert performance of Thomas's opera ''Hamlet,'' to be presented tonight at Carnegie Hall by the Friends of French Opera. She is being replaced by Sharon Bennett.

title: MASSIVE BEETLE INFESTATION DESTROYS PINES IN WEST
description: A beetle blight is spreading in the great forests of the Rocky Mountains. Mountain pine beetles destroyed 935,000 acres of valuable commercial timber last year in 10 national forests and two national parks in Wyoming, Idaho and Montana.

title: Bridge: Long Island School to Have Full Programs at All Levels
description: Although many clubs and other organizations conduct bridge classes, there has been no full-scale bridge school in the New York metropolitan area since the Card School, a famous institution, closed three years ago.

title: 30,000 HAMPSTERS DIE IN A FIRE IN NEW JERSEY
description: At least 30,000 hamsters being raised for scientific research died in a weekend fire, authorities said.

title: Boycott of Chess Match Threatened by Korchnoi
description: Viktor Korchnoi, the emigre chess grandmaster who has won the right to challenge Anatoly Karpov for the world chess championship this summer, has said he will boycott the match unless his wife and son are allowed to leave the Soviet Union, according to officials of the International Chess Federation.

title: Advertising; The Truth About Avocados
description: THE year got off to a hectic start for the nation's advertising self-regulators: In January they resolved 13 challenges to national advertising claims involving such marketplace heavyweights as American Airlines, Chrysler and Beecham Products, and the not-soheavyweight California Avocado Commission - ''Would this body lie to you?''

title: 7 Hostages Are Seized At Mexico University,; But 6 Are Later Freed
description: Three armed preparatory students burst into the office of the rector of the University of Mexico today, took seven people hostage and later freed six of them, witnesses said.

title: 'ELEPHANT MAN' AND 'BULL' UP FOR 8 OSCARS EACH
description: In something of a surprise, two movies about different sorts of grotesque human beings tied with the most nominations for the 53d Academy Awards.

title: LABOR PRESSES CURB ON FLOW OF IMPORTS
description: Declaring that the nation's severe economic problems were being compounded by ''the adverse impact of international trade and finance,'' the A.F.L.-C.I.O. today called for Federal action to protect industries suffering from heavy import competition.

title: NBC-TV LAST IN RATINGS
description: ''Judge us on our performance during the next 60 to 90 days,'' Fred Silverman, president of NBC, said at the beginning of last month. ''We see the season starting in January, when we'll have our new shows on.''

title: A NEW DEATH PENALTY BILL IS APPROVED BY ASSEMBLY
description: The Democratic-led Assembly, in what has become an annual political ritual, approved a bill tonight that would reinstate the death penalty for some cases of murder. But it was a handful of votes short of the margin it would need to override Governor Carey's certain veto.

title: A Sacred but Fat Tuition Cow
description: In looking for ways to help cut the Federal budget, Secretary of Education Bell needed to look no farther than his department's most sacred cow - college student aid. His assault is heresy to colleges and parents who have run up the program to an annual cost of nearly $5 billion. Tuition assistance has grown by 150 percent in just three years, epitomizing the Government's loss of control over spending. Mr. Bell is looking in a fat and proper place.

title: Russsians Suspend Caterpillar Deal
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said that the Soviet Union had suspended negotiations on an $80 million deal involving the purchase of heavy equipment for a proposed Siberian natural gas pipeline project.

title: Aubergine Ni,coise (Eggplant casserole)
description: 1 large eggplant, about 1 1/2 pounds 1/2 cup olive oil 1/2 cup coarsely chopped onion 1 tablespoon finely minced garlic 1/3 cup red wine vinegar 3/4 cup water 1 bay leaf 1 tablespoon coriander seeds 1 teaspoon dried thyme Freshly ground pepper to taste.

title:
RED SMITH;
Henrich's View
description: TOMMY HENRICH played right field and some first base for the New York Yankees for 11 years, which would have been 14 except for time out to fight World War II. He batted as high as .320, hit as many as 31 home runs in a season and drove in as many as 100 runs. As a fully accredited, dues-paying member of a team that won eight pennants and seven World Series in his 11 seasons, he worked his salary up to $40,000 a year. When he or one of the other Yankees would ask for a raise, Ed Barrow, the general manager, would say, ''You got your raise being in the World Series.''

title: 2 PLANS ON JOURNALISTS PRESENTED AT MEETING SPONSORED BY UNESCO
description: Separate resolutions on the question of protection for journalists were presented at a Unesco meeting here today, with Western representatiaves insisting that formalized ''protection'' for jounralists was a thinly disguised scheme for licensing reporters working abroad.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Even in exceptional situations that may at times arise, one can never justify any violation of the fundamental dignity of the human person or of the basic rights that safeguard this dignity.'' - Pope John Paul II. (A1:1.)

title: Swedish Journalists Go on Strike In a Dispute Over Working Hours
description: Swedish journalists began their first strike at nationwide newspapers today in a dispute over working hours and copyrights.

title: News Analysis
description: Last November the armed former guerrillas that are tied to the two political parties in Zimbabwe clashed in a Bulawayo township where they were camped. When the toll was finally counted 56 people, most of them innocent civilians, had been killed.

title: PRESIDENT PLANNING TO ASK BUDGET CUTS OF OVER $41 BILLION
description: President Reagan plans to ask Congress tomorrow for a broad array of budget cuts totaling $41.4 billion next year as part of a sweeping economic package that is to include the largest tax cut in history.

title: SCREEN: 2 FOOTNOTES TO WAJDA'S CAREER
description: NO one interested in the career of Andrzej Wajda, the great Polish film director, will want to miss the program that opens today for a limited run at the Agee Room of the Bleecker Street Cinema - ''Hunting Flies'' (1969), one of the director's rare attempts at comedy, and ''The Birch Wood'' (1970), an absolutely baffling drama.

title: Index; International
description: Unesco meeting hears two draft resolutions on press A2 France evades U.S. request for support on El Salvador A3 Students seize six hostages at the University of Mexico A3 U.N. envoy resumes peace mission to Iraq and Iran A4 Around the World A5 Brunei, nearing independence, builds up its military A10 U.S. endorses French plan for post-Madrid arms parley A10 Canadian Parliament opens final debate on constitution A11 Government/Politics Senate unit hears of threats and payoffs in shipping industry A12 Study calls Koch anticrime proposals ''misguided'' B3 Court rules Bustop must surrender shelters to New York City B3 State Senate leader criticizes transportation department B3 Energy Reagan ends temperature restrictions on buildings A16 General Around the Nation A12 Cleanup begins in Louisville in wake of sewer explosion A12 Murderer to be first to get electric chair in Indiana since 1961 A12 Convicted murderer killed while holding hostage A14 Baltimore's Harborplace: a handsome and popular marketplace A18 Monument built upon 'junk' of U.S. bureaucrats A24 Potential buyers warned of purchasing repossessed soybeans A26 McGuire says officer was not within guidelines in shooting B2 The Region B2 Industry/Labor Labor calls for protection of industry against imports A16 The Living Section Food Flour: Which types to use for what C1

title: Aubergine Ni,coise (Eggplant casserole)
description: 1 large eggplant, about 1 1/2 pounds 1/2 cup olive oil 1/2 cup coarsely chopped onion 1 tablespoon finely minced garlic 1/3 cup red wine vinegar 3/4 cup water 1 bay leaf 1 tablespoon coriander seeds 1 teaspoon dried thyme Freshly ground pepper to taste.

title: Leader of Rumanian Gypsy Clan Buried in California After Slaying
description: Miller Marks, who led a clan of Rumanian Gypsies for 25 years, was buried yesterday in a traditional Gypsy ceremony.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 18, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Blast at Ministry Office in Paris
description: An explosion wrecked an office at the Ministry of Education last night. Corsican nationalists seeking independence from France took responsibility. The police said one person, a policeman who guards the entry to the building, was slightly injured.

title: Accounts
description: * Arm & Hammer Division of Church & Dwight Company, to Ted Chin & Company for its oven cleaner.

title: FUNERAL FOR VICTIM OF DISCO FIRE IN IRELAND
description: FUNERAL FOR VICTIM OF DISCO FIRE IN IRELAND: Thomas Hobbs being helped after services in Dublin for his son, Brian, who was one of 44 people killed at the Stardust disco. Ninety-two people remain in the hospital.

title: BANKER IS NAMED A DEPUTY MAYOR FOR DEVELOPMENT
description: Karen N. Gerard, an economist who is a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, was named by Mayor Koch yesterday to the long-vacant post of Deputy Mayor for Economic Policy and Development. The choice, which came rather abruptly after an eight-month search, was generally met with approval in financial circles.

title: A VERSITILE BUILDER'S 3 MANHATTAN PROJECTS
description: If there were a title for versatility given to an individual builder in Manhattan this year it would probably go to Harry Macklowe.

title: A. DORIS HENRIES, 68, EDUCATOR IN LIBERIA
description: A. Doris Banks Henries, an American who became an educator in Liberia and who was Assistant Minister of Education there before the coup that overthrew the Government of William R. Tolbert Jr. last April, died Monday of cancer at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn. She was 68 years old.

title: FLOUR: WHICH TYPE TO USE FOR WHAT
description: WHEN a 17th-century recipe instructed the American housewife to ''take three-quarters of a peck of fine flower (sic),'' there wasn't the variety of flours at hand that exists today. Supermarkets offer one array of brands, health-food stores another, while a number of millers handle mail orders. In addition, there are the newcomers of special bread flours - market researchers must have discovered a considerable amount of home bread-baking going on - by Pillsbury and Gold Medal. As a result, home bakers of 1981 may well be wondering what flour is all about.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Iroquois Brands has been informed that Acorn Investments, a foreign personal holding company based in England, has purchased 109,900 shares, or about 5.7 percent, of its outstanding common stock in open market transactions.

title: Nippon to Acquire Ehrenreich Photo
description: Nippon Kogaku K.K., the Tokyo-based maker of Nikon cameras, said it had agreed to acquire Ehrenreich Photo-Optical Industries Inc., based in Garden City, L.I.

title: Ivan D. Serbin, Soviet Party Aide In Charge of the Defense Industry
description: Ivan D. Serbin, a Communist Party official in charge of the defense and space program since the late 1950's, has died at the age of 70, the newspaper Pravda said today.

title: SERVED 10 YEARS ON CRIMINAL BENCH
description: f814Justice Bernard Moldow of State Supreme Court died of a heart attack Monday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard THE LIFE OF JOHN O'HARA. By Frank MacShane. Illustrated. 274 pages. Dut- ton. $15.95.

title: LEAFS WIN, 8-5, FROM ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders continued reeling tonight, as if they were still suffering from the drubbing the Rangers handed them five games back. The Islanders have not won since.

title: CHARTER SLIDES 84.9% IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: The Charter Company, a concern whose fortunes rise and fall on the vagaries of the world oil market, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings plunged 84.9 percent from the comparable period in 1979. Even so, analysts expressed surprise the results were as good as they were.

title: New Orleans Exchange
description: The board of directors of the New Orleans Commodities Exchange has voted to begin trading activities on April 9, the exchange's president, Tom Webber, said today. He said the exchange was still awaiting approval from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for trading rough rice, cotton and soybean futures contracts. The commission last week approved the exchange's articles of incorporation and a contract for trading in milled rice.

title: H.F.C. ACQUIRING WALLACE MURRAY
description: The Household Finance Corporation, a consumer finance, manufacturing and transportation company, said yesterday that it had reached agreement in principle to acquire the Wallace Murray Corporation, an industrial equipment maker, for more than $300 million.

title: NO-SALT COOKING WITH VEGETABLES: EGGPLANT
description: THE four foods that seem to lend themselves most naturally to nosalt cookery are tomatoes, onions, mushrooms and eggplants. These vegetables have an innate flavor that is more pronounced when they are cooked, and if treated properly their flavor gratifications need not be enhanced by salt.

title: NIXDORF'S RISE FROM A CELLAR
description: In the early 1950's, a physics student in Frankfurt made an unusual offer to a power utility that was then the largest company in West Germany. With $6,000 and a cellar workroom, he promised to build a calculator that would do the company's bookkeeping.

title: I.B.M. WILL MARKET LOW-PRICED COPIER MADE BY MINOLTA
description: When the International Business Machines Corporation opened its first two American retail stores to sell its office products a few months ago, it marked a significant step toward reaching the smallbusiness man, not traditionally served by the computer giant.

title: POLICE HEAD SAYS AN OFFICER BROKE A RULE IN KILLING
description: The New York City Police Commissioner said yesterday that a police officer who shot a young man Sunday morning when he apparently tried to crash through a fire-escape window into his former girlfriend's apartment had not acted within the department's guidelines in firing at a target he could not fully see.

title: BLUE CHIPS HELP DOW RISE 8.11
description: The stock market ended higher yesterday in slightly more active trading with energy and blue chip issues registering the best gains. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 8.11 points, to 939.68, its first advance in four sessions. Over all, winners on the New York Stock Exchange edged losers by 750 to 735.

title: JUNE TRIAL DATE IS SET IN MERGER DATA CASE
description: Judge Charles S. Haight Jr. of the United States Court for the Southern District of New York yesterday set June 15 as the trial date for the Government's case against a former investment banker at Morgan Stanley & Company and three others who allegedly profited from the use of confidential information on prospective mergers.

title: Overdose of Vitamin A Nearly Kills 3-Year-Old
description: Lacey Taylor's parents thought they were helping to protect her against winter colds with massive doses of vitamin A. Instead it almost killed her.

title: Head of Milan Hospital Slain In His Car by Four Gunmen
description: Four well-dressed men armed with sawed-off shotguns killed the head of one of Milan's largest hospitals today, raking his car with blasts of fire on a busy street.

title: COURT RULING REQUIRES THAT BUSTOP GIVE UP ITS SHELTERS TO THE CITY
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court unanimously ruled yesterday that Bustop Shelters Inc., the company chosen in 1975 to build and maintain shelters at New York City bus stops, must surrender ownership of its 499 bus shelters to the city.

title: MET OPERA: 3 NEW VOICES
description: MONDAY evening's performance of ''Die Zauberflote'' at the Metropolitan Opera offered three singers who had not appeared in the first performance of the opera this season. The result was an honorable representation of this most seraphic of Mozart masterpieces.

title: INTEREST RATES DECLINE WIDELY
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined yesterday as the credit markets reversed direction after a week of rising interest rates.

title: Company Accepts Blame For Bad Taste in Water
description: Officials of the Georgia Pacific Corporation said today that an accidental release of a nasty-tasting chemical from their plant had contributed to a problem with the drinking water for residents of metropolitan New Orleans.

title: Yanks Get Castro Ex-Brewer Reliever
description: The Yankees today signed Bill Castro, a free-agent relief pitcher from the Milwaukee Brewers, to a two-year contract.

title: Baseball Talks Still Stalled Over Compensation Issue
description: Baseball talks between players and management over the compensation issue continued stalled yesterday. ''We had a meeting today, but nothing much was accomplished,'' said Marvin Miller, executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association.

title: Dolph Schayes in Foul Play
description: The officiating in a basketball game between Syracuse and Villanova tonight led the former National Basketball Association star, Dolph Schayes, to leave the stands to challenge the referees.

title: NEW DEPUTY MAYOR
description: Karen N. Gerard, New York City's newly appointed Deputy Mayor for Economic Policy and Development, joins a select company that has a high attrition rate. Mayor Koch, who started with 12 Deputy Mayors, has two left, and will have three when Mrs. Gerard joins his staff next month.

title: MORE SALVADOR AID BACKED IN CONGRESS
description: The Reagan Administration won strong support from key members of Congress today for future increases in American aid to El Salvador to help the Government there to counter what the Administration says is Soviet-bloc assistance to the insurgents in the country.

title: Careers; Learning To Repair Robots
description: TO meet the production demands ahead, more and more robots are being added to assembly lines in the United States. The aim: to increase quality and cut costs so business can compete more effectively, especially with Japanese and West German companies that have been using robots for quite a few years.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BOSTON (AL) - Signed Dave Stapleton, i nfielder. CHICAGO (AL) - Announced arbitrator h ad ruled in favor of the club in salary dis- p ute involving Wayne Nordhagen, outfield- e r. CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Jerry Morales, o utfielder, as free agent and assigned him to I owa of American Association. CINCINNATI (NL) - Announced arbitra- t or had ruled in favor of club in salary dis- p ute involving Mike Vail, outfielder. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Karl Pagel, o utfielder. MONTREAL (NL) - Signed Hal Dues, p itcher. NEW YORK YANKEES (AL) - Signed B ill Castro, pitcher, to two-year contract as f ree agent. OAKLAND (AL) - Announced arbitrator h ad ruled in favor of club in salary dispute i nvolving Tony Armas, outfielder. SEATTLE (AL) - Signed Lenny Randle, i nfielder, as free agent. TEXAS (AL) - Signed Pat Putnam, B ump Wills, Roger Holt, Nelson Norman a nd Mark Wagner, infielders; Steve Comer, p itcher; Larry Cox, catcher, and Jim Norris a nd Billy Sample, outfielders.

title: THERESE KERESEY DURGIN
description: Therese Keresey Durgin, a photographer known professionally as Tess Durgin, died Friday in Marrakesh, Morocco, where she was vacationing with her family. She was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan and Mill Neck, L.I., where she had a studio.

title: INDOOR HERBS, AN ADDRESS BOOK AND A BEAR NECKLACE
description: 1. Indoor Herb Garden

title: Pleas for Garwood Denied; Judge Wishes 'Happiness'
description: The long court-martial of Pfc. Robert R. Garwood ended today with the judge wishing the marine ''peace and happiness'' and rejecting two defense bids to reverse the conviction.

title: G.O.P. STAGING STRATEGY SESSIONS AIMING AT MAJORITY PARTY STATUS
description: Republican Party leaders have begun a series of daylong strategy sessions to develop a plan for becoming the nation's majority party within the next 10 years.

title: NEW INTERCO PRESIDENT
description: Harvey Saligman, the 42-year-old president of Queen Casuals of Philadelphia, has been elected president and chief operating officer of Interco, a leading apparel and footwear manufacturer, which owns Queen Casuals. Mr. Saligman succeeds John Riedy, 64, who has been named to the vacant position of vice chairman.

title: GUATEMALA LEADER ACCUSED BY RIGHTS GROUP IN KILLINGS
description: Amnesty International said today that President Romeo Lucas Garcia of Guatemala directly supervises an intelligence agency that carries out political assassinations.

title: Stassen Says He Hasn't Made a Presidential Race in Vain
description: He's probably the nation's best-known perpetual Presidential candidate, with six unsuccessful bids for the Republican nomination behind him, but Harold E. Stassen says he's convinced not one of his races was in vain.

title: Top Medal for Canadian General
description: Lieut. Gen. Rene Gutknecht of Canada today received Canada's top military medal from Queen Elizabeth in a ceremony at Buckingham Palace. General Guknecht, 50 years old, becomes a commander of the Order of Military Merit of Canada. He is the Canadian military representative at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters in Brussels.

title: An Appraisal
description: This seems to be the year of Baltimore. This old seaport city, which has had a relationship to Washington not unlike that of Oakland to San Francisco or Newark to New York, has put great effort into changing its image. It has built office, apartment and hotel towers downtown, it has restored old town houses and it has turned the Inner Harbor, the portion of the shoreline closest to downtown, into a mixture of shopping, entertainment and cultural facilities.

title: TV: 'GREAT SPACE COASTER,'NEW CHILDREN'S SHOW
description: LEAPING brazenly into the treacherous arena of children's programming, ''The Great Space Coaster'' gives every indication of being one of the few ''quality'' series that could manage to survive outside the awesome factories of the Children's Television Workshop's output on public television. This new commercial-television venture is not a network product. The half-hours are being syndicated nationally and can be seen in New York at 7:30 A.M. Mondays through Fridays on WNEW-TV.

title: CANADA OPENS FINAL DEBATE ON RETRIEVING ITS CHARTER
description: The final debate opened today in the House of Commons on the Government's proposal to complete Canada's independence by gaining control of its constitution from Britain.

title: Miss Allen Finds Her Touch in Tennis
description: Eighteen years ago, Leslie Allen was a tall, bony, clumsy girl who would rather have ridden a bicycle around her home in Washington than, despite her mother's urging, played tennis.

title: BIAGGI ACTS TO SAVE PARK AVE. ARMORY
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of New York, said that he hoped to prod President Reagan into saving the historic Seventh Regiment Armory with a bill he has introduced barring, destruction or changes to the building, at Park Avenue and 66th Street. Mr. Biaggi said at a news conference at the armory that plans by the state's Urban Development Corporation to convert it to a highrise residential complex were "closer than we would like." He was joined at the news conference by Mrs. Douglas Mac Arthur and a retired Air Force colonel, Benjamin Fowler, who head a committee to save the 101-year-old armory.

title: REAGAN ENDS TEMPERATURE CURBS
description: President Reagan today canceled the Carter Administration's energy-saving restrictions that held all public buildings to a maximum temperature of 65 degrees in the winter and no lower than 78 in the summer.

title: Certificates Set at Discount
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the nation's seventh-largest bank, announced yesterday that it had begun to issue large negotiable certificates of deposit in discount form.

title: G.M. AND FORD OFFER CASH REBATES THAT ARE LARGEST EVER FOR INDUSTRY
description: In an apparent response to lagging sales and pleas for assistance from hard-pressed automobile dealers, the General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor Company today announced cash rebate programs that will be the biggest in the industry's history.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A LIVING EYE

title: MURDERER OF FOUR AWAITS ELECTRIC CHAIR IN INDIANA
description: Steven T. Judy jokes with his foster parents about preparations to ''fire up old Betsy,'' the electric chair at the Indiana State Prison, where he is scheduled to die March 9.

title: Social Security Fund Said to Face A Deficit of $63.5 Billion by 1986
description: The trust fund that provides money for Social Security retirement benefits will be depleted by early 1983 and could have a deficit of $63.5 billion by 1986, the Congressional Budget Office said today.

title: Labor Dept. Reviewing Dues Rule Set for Clubs That Discriminate
description: The Labor Department is reviewing a regulation due to have gone into effect today that would bar companies doing business with the Federal Government from paying for their employees' membership in clubs that discriminate on the basis of race, sex or religion.

title: Dance Festival in Queens
description: The Joffrey II ballet company will perform Saturday at the Theater in the Park in Flushing, Queens, in ''Dancelebration '81.''

title: CANADA ANNOUNCES CHRYSLER GUARANTEES
description: - The Canadian Government announced today it had agreed to give the Chrysler Corporation's Canadian subsidiary $150 million (Canadian) in loan guarantees.

title: Top Spain Police Aides Quit Amid Torture Death Furor
description: The national police director and five other top police officials resigned today in a growing political scandal over charges that the police had tortured to death a suspected Basque separatist.

title: Amendments in Iran
description: Without the din around a certain embassy in downtown Teheran, it is now possible to hear some very different cries of complaint there. This week's came from 38 academics, writers and lawyers who insist on reaffirming the cause of human rights against the Shah's successors.

title: Addendum
description: * 50 Plus magazine increasing its circulation rate base 31.6 percent, to 250,000, effective with the April issue. Advertising page rates will increase 42.6 percent.

title: William J. Clew, Editor At The Hartford Courant
description: William J. Clew, who rose from printer's apprentice to managing editor of The Hartford Courant, died yesterday in the Connecticut Hospice in Branford. He was 76 years old.

title: Steel Output Up in Week
description: Steel production rose to 2.4 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.386 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: ARCHITECT OF REAGAN TAX POLICY
description: When President Reagan outlines his tax program to a joint session of Congress tomorrow night, the proposals will reflect in good part the ideas and persistence of Norman B. Ture, the Treasury's prospective Under Secretary for Tax and Economic Policy.

title: ADELPHI STUDENT BURIED AS DISPUTE LINGERSS
description: Edward Fonseca was buried today behind the little white church where he worshiped for most of his life, while his parents and his classmates from Adelphi University wept.

title: Millrose Race Times Official
description: Officials of the Feb. 6 Wanamaker Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden have determined the times for most of the runners in their 5,000-meter race. Suleiman Nyambui of Tanzania finished first in 13 minutes 20.4 seconds, a world indoor best and American all-comers record.

title: Brown and Root Has Exxon Contract
description: Brown and Root Inc. said it had been awarded a multimillion-dollar contract by the Exxon Company U.S.A to build equipment for the Colony Shale Oil Project 50 miles east of Grand Junction, Colo.

title: 185 Recruits Begin State Police Training
description: ALBANY (UPI) - A class of 185 state police recruits - the largest in a decade and the first in 14 months - was sworn in to start 22 weeks of training.

title: PENNY-PINCHERS AND INFLATION-WATCHERS TELL HOW THEY SAVE
description: IF the soaring price of food, fuel and shelter has you down, consider this: a home video recorder that Neiman-Marcus advertised for $34,000 in the 1960's can now be had, far improved, for less than $1,000. Ball-point pens, some selling for $12.50 after World War II, now go for a quarter. A New York-to-Israel telephone call, costing $12 for three minutes in 1950, is down to $5.70 today - and a pay phone call has been a dime since 1951. Coffee in New York markets is 12 percent cheaper than a year ago and lettuce is up only a dime over 1973.

title: U.S. Report on Rights Says Iran Uses Torture; Despite Its Prohibition
description: The State Department, in a review of human rights in Iran issued today, said there were credible reports of torture there last year even though torture was forbidden by the Constitution.

title: Reagan Economic Talk On TV, Radio Tonight
description: President Reagan's State of the Union Message to Congress, which will focus on economics, will be televised live at 9 o'clock tonight on the CBS, NBC and ABC networks, Channels 2, 4 and 7 in New York.

title: Exxon to Increase U.S. Energy Outlay
description: The Exxon Corporation said that it planned to increase sharply its spending in the United States on enhanced energy recovery, the coaxing of oil and natural gas out of properties where deposits cannot be reached by conventional means.

title: Medical College Drive
description: In its 105 years, the Meharry Medical College in Nashville, has educated more black doctors and dentists than any other medical school in the country. Even today, long after blacks have been admitted to other schools, about 40 percent of the nation's black medical and dental practitioners claim Meharry training.

title: GRAND CENTRAL AT FIVE
description: LEONORE POCKMAN

title: The PX That Wants a View
description: People who use and love Gateway, the national park whose sections lie strung along the entrance of New York Harbor from Jamaica Bay to Sandy Hook, have treasured the Congressional promise that Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island will become a full part of it. When the military no longer needs it, said Congress in 1972, the fort's 200 acres at the middle of that sweep of shoreland would afford vistas as splendid as any in the region. Can one imagine, then, any Government agency willing in effect to compromise the Congressional goal for no better reason than to turn the fort into the headquarters of a major chain store?

title: by Patricia Wells; COLOGNE, West Germany
description: When the housewares industry isn't reinventing the wheel, it's recycling it. And in this era of intense international commerce, salesmen know that if a product doesn't sell in Waterloo, it just might fly in Dusseldorf.

title: CONRAIL NARROWS FOURTH-QUARTER LOSS
description: The beleaguered Consolidated Rail Corporation, plagued last year by equipment malfunctions, overcrowding and poor on-time performance, reported yesterday that it had narrowed its loss to $12 million in the the fourth quarter of 1980 from a deficit of $59.7 million in the fourth quarter of 1979. Revenues edged up eight-tenths of 1 percent, the company said.

title: Pandaring
description: In their photographs, Chia-Chia is simultaneously smiling and eating grass. He radiates virility. Ling-Ling is staring into space, head resting on a rock.

title: Market Place; Fox Potential Lures Investors
description: RECENT market action in the shares of 20th Century-Fox suggests that investors are impressed with Fox's potential, whether as the company is constituted at present or in a breakup whereby intrinsic values could be realized.

title: BILINGUAL EDUCATION AND THE CONSTITUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUISVILLE'S CLEANUP BEGINS IN WAKE OF SEWER EXPLOSION
description: In a light afternoon drizzle Perry and Mary Messer, along with their daughter, a daughter-in-law and a granddaughter, urgently carted off clothes and appliances today from the small peeling bungalow that seemed ready to fall into the giant crater that was once Hill Street.

title: WHAT GREAT WITH WHOM?
description: Again and again people say that President Reagan is a great communicator. On the television screen five Washington pundits who agree on nothing else agree that Mr. Reagan is a great communicator. Editorialists say it in print: a great communicator. Persons who disapprove of him trap you in crowded rooms and conclude by saying, ''But one thing I've got to admit - he's a great communicator.''

title: KEY FISCAL GOAL REACHED BY CITY IN BIG NOTE SALE
description: New York City cleared an important symbolic hurdle in its pursuit of fiscal credibility yesterday when it began the sale of $100 million in short-term notes backed only by anticipated city tax money.

title: FRANCE EVADES U.S. BID FOR SUPPORT ON SALVADOR
description: France responded with polite evasiveness today to the United States contention that the conflict in El Salvador is a test case of Western willingness to draw the line against Soviet expansionism.

title: Zimbabwe's Still Patriotic Front
description: The new nation of Zimbabwe seems to have avoided a bitter second round of civil war, this time pitting black against black and tribe against tribe. The day was apparently saved because Joshua Nkomo, the sometime Patriotic Front partner but also rival of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe, chose courageously not to let his political ambition become the focus of any military operation.

title: ABORTION FOE IS CHIEF CANDIDATE TO LEAD BIRTH CONTROL PROGRAMS
description: A prominent antiabortion lobbyist here, Marjory Mecklenburg, is the leading candidate to head the Government office that aids teen-age mothers and counsels on birth control, according to Government officials.

title: 2 Tire Companies To Raise Prices
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said they would raise the price of their replacement tires in March.

title: BANCSHARES OF JERSEY TO WRITE OFF '80 LOSSES
description: Bancshares of New Jersey said yesterday that approximately $12 million of the $16.9 million in losses incurred during 1980 would be written off in the fourth quarter.

title: LAKERS DEFEAT KNICKS
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Jamaal Wilkes combined to score 53 points tonight, leading the Los Angeles Lakers to a 96-87 victory over New York and snapping the Knicks' eight-game winning streak.

title: WASHINGTON
description: The Reagan economic program now moves to Capitol Hill, where the diminished and somewhat subdued Democratic forces are promising to give it the hearing it deserves. The ambiguity in this commitment is no accident.

title: Mrs. Reagan on Vietnam Panel
description: Nancy Reagan will join the National Sponsoring Committee for the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund, which by next year hopes to build a memorial honoring Americans who died in Vietnam, the White House said today. President Carter signed legislation in July providing two acres of Government property northeast of the Lincoln Memorial on the Mall for construction of the memorial.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Avrett Is First Agency For De Lorean Sports Cars
description: Avrett, Free & Fischer, specialists in packaged goods advertising, has been chosen to be the first agency for the De Lorean Motor Company, whose stainless steel, made-in-Northern-Ireland sports cars will make their debut in this country by June.

title: Mayor's Arts Award Is Bestowed on 8; Mayor's Arts Award Given to 8
description: The Mayor's Award of Honor for Arts and Culture was presented last night to eight distinguished New Yorkers in a ceremony at Gracie Mansion.

title: Yugoslavs Try Croatian Historian For Criticism in News Interviews
description: The first major trial of a political dissident in Yugoslavia since the death of President Tito opened today in Zagreb, capital of Croatia.

title: IF PUBLIC SCHOOLS LOSE THE MIDDLE CLASS
description: To the Editor:

title: DART & KRAFT AND HOBART IN $460 MILLION MERGER
description: Dart & Kraft Inc., confirming widespread speculation on Wall Street that it was considering the purchase of the Hobart Corporation, disclosed yesterday that it had reached a $460 million agreement to merge with Hobart, the manufacturer of Kitchen Aid and other foodrelated equipment.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: BLONDIE, the late John Lennon and Rod Stewart were all toppled from the upper reaches of the nation's singles charts last week by Kool and the Gang's ''Celebration,'' a catchy dance tune that is now the country's No. 1 single. It is the first No. 1 single from a black group in several months, and the first ever for Kool and the Gang, a New York based nine-man combo. But as Robert (Kool) Bell remarked recently, ''This has been a long time coming.'' Kool and the Gang have been together for more than 15 years, and their climb to the top has been slow but determined.

title: The Economy
description: President Reagan plans to ask Congress for $41.4 billion in budget cuts for next year in his economic package, which will be unveiled tonight. But spending cuts in the current fiscal year would be only half as large as the $13 billion promised earlier and a budget surplus is not expected until 1984. (Page A1.) Democrats warned that they would challenge the President, particularly on his tax-cut plan. (A1.) Higher-income Americans would not get the full 10 percent annual tax cut proposed, Administration officials said. (A20.)

title: by Terry Robards
description: DEVOTEES of the white wines of Germany who have been accustomed to finding bargains of high quality from the Rhine and Mosel regions in recent years are in for a disappointment. The 1980 vintage in Germany, as in some other parts of Europe, was extremely difficult, and shortages of fine German wines will result.

title: U.S. ENDORSES PROPOSAL BY FRANCE FOR AN ARMS PARLEY AFTER MADRID
description: In an important step toward improving relations with its Western European allies, the Reagan Administration has endorsed a French proposal for monitoring military movements by the Warsaw Pact and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: U.S. Says Bid to Eject Israel From U.N. Would Be Illegal
description: Any move to expel Israel from the United Nations would be illegal and would have grave consequences for future participation of the United States in the world organization, the State Department said today.

title: JET'S CRASH INJURES AT LEAST 34 ON COAST
description: At least 34 people were injured tonight, none critically, when an Air California jetliner crashed while landing at John Wayne Airport near here.

title: DELAYS IN COUNTDOWN MAY POSTPONE TESTING OF SPACECRAFT ENGINES
description: The countdown for a test of the space shuttle Columbia's main rocket engines fell behind schedule tonight, leading to a possible delay of at least a day in the planned 20-second firing.

title: Garden Eyes Hearns-Benitez
description: Madison Square Garden is interested in putting on the Thomas Hearns-Wilfred Benitez welterweight title fight on the same May card with Gerry Cooney and Ken Norton, John Condon said yesterday after meeting with Emanuel Steward, Hearns's manager and trainer.

title: International Red Cross Seeking $46 Million for Help to Africans
description: The two components of the International Committee of the Red Cross appealed today to governments, national Red Cross societies and private agencies for about $46 million for relief work in Africa this year.

title: Esmark Extends Offer
description: Esmark Inc said today that it had extended until next Monday its tender offer to purchase up to 600,000 shares of its common stock at $60 from holders of fewer than 100 shares. The company said about 175,000 shares had been validly tendered by the close of business yesterday.

title: JURY IN HARRIS CASE STARTS TO WEIGH 6 POSSIBLE VERDICTS
description: Jurors in the Jean S. Harris murder trial began deliberations today after Judge Russell R. Leggett told them they could consider not only murder in the second degree but also two less severe charges in the shooting of Dr. Herman Tarnower.

title: BRUNEI'S OIL DOLLARS ARE GOING INTO ARMS
description: As the deadline for this sultanate's full independence from Britain draws nearer, the Sultan has been channeling more and more oil dollars into arms.

title: FINK SAYS HE OPPOSES CAREY'S PALN FOR BARS TO BE OPEN 24 HOURS
description: The Speaker of the State Assembly, Stanley Fink, said tonight that he opposed Governor Carey's proposals to allow some bars to remain open 24 hours a day, and expressed skepticism of Mr. Carey's plan to deregulate the liquor industry. Mr. Fink also said the chances that the State Legislature would approve casino gambling for New York were ''rather remote.''

title: Mitsubishi Turbocharger
description: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries said today that it had developed a small turbocharger that could be adapted to engines in compact cars and motorcycles. The company said the device raised engine power by 30 to 50 percent, using a turbine powered by exhaust gas.

title: Red Wings 6, Jets 4
description: Mark Kirton scored two third-period goals and Jim Korn added two scores in the Detroit victory. Both teams scored twice in the opening period.

title: A RISKY U.S. EQUATION: E
description: ''Troilus and Cressida'' These deeply perceptive words by Shakespeare have their relevance to a sizeable section of United States opinion, official and private, on the Soviet Union.

title: TRIAL BY FIRE
description: To the Editor:

title: SALVADOR FACES LONG WAR AS REBELS RESUME RAIDS
description: A month after the defeat of their ''final offensive,'' leftist guerrillas here are again attacking and the Government is settling in for what now appears will be a protracted guerrilla war.

title: Ms. Editor Honored
description: Patricia T. Carbine, publisher and editor in chief of Ms. magazine, was honored yesterday as Advertising Woman of the Year by the Advertising Women of New York. Who should know better? The luncheon was held in the Waldorf-Astoria and there wasn't an empty seat in the house.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THERE are reasonable buys to be found in eggs, lamb and chicken this week and in some vegetables, but the news in fruit is not good. The cheaper apples and pears we've been seeing in the market lately have gone down in quality; those tasted have been woolly in texture and lacking juice. Large strawberries are arriving from Florida and California, but so far they have been poor. But small California navel oranges are still good at 10 for $1. They are the best buy in fruit, along with bananas at 99 cents for three pounds.

title: WHERE TO GET NATURAL FLOURS
description: The companies listed below carry flours that are naturally grown and traditionally milled. This means that they contained crushed wheat germ, which makes them more prone to spoilage.

title: W. HOWARD LEE
description: W. Howard Lee, an oilman who was the husband of Gene Tierney, the former actress, died yesterday after a long illness.

title: Whatever It Is, It's a Way to Raise Funds
description: When it came time to plan a fund-raising promotion for New York City's municipal radio stations, John Beck, the city's broadcasting director, thought he had a natural - a birthday celebration marking the 40th anniversary of WNYC-FM, which, according to ''The Broadcasting Year Book,'' went on the air in 1941.

title: VOTE IN THE ASSEMBLY ON DEATH-PENALTY BILL
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Assembly approved a bill to reinstate the death penalty for certain cases of murder: FOR THE AMENDMENT - 91 Democrats - 33 Abramson (Queens) Bianchi (East Patchogue) Bragman (Clay) Butler (Queens) Connelly (Staten Island) Dearie (Bronx) Feldman (Brooklyn) Friedman (Bronx) Gorski (Buffalo) Graber (West Seneca) Hirsch (Brooklyn) Keane (Buffalo) Kidder (Jamestown) Lafayette (Queens) Lasher (Brooklyn) Lentol (Brooklyn) Lipschutz (Queens) Montano (Bronx) Murphy (Lockport) Robach (Rochester) Robles (Brooklyn) Ruggiero (Utica) Schimminger (Buffalo) Schmidt (Queens) Seminerio (Queens) Silver (Brooklyn) Smoler (Brooklyn) Walsh, D.B. (F'klinville) Walsh, S.P. (Bronx) Weinstein (Brooklyn) Wilson (Queens) Yevoli (Plainview) Zimmer (Syracuse) Republicans - 58 Burrows (Scarsdale) Bush (Camillus) Casale (Herkimer) Chesbro (Phoenix) Cochrane (Bay Shore) D'Amato (Mineola) D'Andrea (Saratoga Spr.) DiCarlo (Brooklyn) Emery (Geneseo) Esposito (Queens) Flack (Queens) Flanagan (Greenlawn) Hague (Glens Falls) Hanna (Webster) Hannon (Mineola) Harris (Long Lake) Hawley (Batavia) Hoblock (Latham) Howard (Amityville) Kelleher (Troy) Kennedy (Boston) Kisor (Goshen) Kuhl (Hammondsport) Lane (Windham) Larkin (New Windsor) Levy (Spring Valley) Lopresto (Astoria) MacNeil (Ithaca) Madison (Franklin Sq.) Morahan (New City) Nagle (E. Rochester) Nortz (Lowville) O'Neil (Parishville) Parola (Wantagh) Perone (Port Chester) Prescott (Queens) Rappleyea (Norwich) Rath (Brockport) Reilly (Glen Cove) Rettaliata (Huntington) Riford (Auburn) Ryan (Plattsburgh) Saland (Poughkeepsie) Sears (Rome) Sheffer (Williamsville) Siwek (Buffalo) Skelos (Rockville Centre) Spano (Yonkers) Stephens (Brewster) Straniere (Staten Island) Sullivan, F. M. (Brooklyn) Sullivan, P. M. (White Pl.) Talomie (Geneva) Velella (Bronx) Warren (Fishkill) Wemple (Schenectady) Wertz (Smithtown) Winner (Elmira)

title: CLEVELANDERS VOTE FOR INCOME TAX RISE
description: Cleveland voters today approved a hotly disputed measure increasing the city income tax by 33 percent, a step Mayor George V. Voinovich called crucial to the city's chances of recovery from its continuing financial difficulties.

title: Missing: a New Film
description: The small green suitcase contained the only negative of a halfhour television documentary that had taken Jim Gambone a year to make, and when the St. Paul film maker arrived in New York City Monday night he was very careful with it.

title: No Headline
description: ON A BALMY DAY, seagulls fly over Hull, Mass. Temperatures rose above 50 degrees in New England, to 59 in Boston.

title: 30,000 Hamsters Die In a Fire in Jersey
description: At least 30,000 hamsters being raised for scientific research died in a weekend fire, authorities said.

title: TWO EXPONENTS OF RHYTHM-AND-BLUES
description: THE Persuasions and the James Cotton Band, who shared the bill at the Bottom Line last Saturday night, make a fine match, since each represents a different mode of rhythm-and-blues classicism. An a capella quintet from Brooklyn, the Persuasions have earned a high critical reputation as overseers of the best of the 1950's doo-wop tradition, while James Cotton, a disciple of Muddy Waters, deals in unreconstructed Chicago Blues.

title: SENATOR, THAT'S MY PIER YOU'RE TALKING ABOUT
description: To the Editor:

title: FLOUR TYPES: WHEAT, RYE AND BARLEY
description: Flour, according to Larousse Gastronomique, is the finely ground and bolted meal of wheat and other cereals, including rye, buckwheat, rice, oatmeal and maize (corn), but since wheat with its content of gluten is best for bread-making, the word ''flour'' generally connotes wheat flour.

title: EUROPEANS TO MONITOR JAPAN CARS
description: Western Europe made its first joint defensive move against Japanese exports by agreeing today on a plan to monitor imports of Japanese automobiles, color television sets and computercontrolled machine tools.

title: THE CITY;
description: A 34-year-old Brooklyn man yesterday sued New York City for $2 million, charging that he had been wrongfully jailed as a murder suspect for 11 months in a case of mistaken identity.

title: Floyd Concentrates on 60-Yard Dash Mark
description: If people will leave Stanley Floyd alone, he says, he may be able to better the world indoor best time for the 60-yard dash. And he has a time and place picked out - the USA/Mobil indoor track and field championships Feb. 27 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Bridge:; Kaplan House on West 94th A Center for Game in U. S.
description: If an optimistic player in, let us say, Singapore addressed a letter to ''Contract Bridge U.S.A.,'' it might arrive at the American Contract Bridge League in Memphis. But an equally appropriate destination would be a brownstone on New York's Upper West Side.

title: TOWARD A FEDERAL CURB ON HANDGUNS
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN SIGNS ORDER TO CURB REGULATIONS
description: The Reagan Administration today introduced new procedures aimed at relaxing Government regulation of business to find, in the words of Vice President Bush, ''the balance between productivity and jobs, protection of the environment and protection of the workplace.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Scientific Leasing Inc. announced an intial public offering of 750,000 shares of its common stock at $6 a share through a John Muir group.

title: Proxmire Seeks Cuts In Loans
description: The Federal loan guarantee program, which has helped keep New York afloat, Chrysler in business and college students in school, would be cut by $47 billion over the next two years under a plan submitted by Senator William Proxmire.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE is probably some deep meaning behind the way we read newspapers, and it is probably just as well if we never find out what it is. There are enough complexes running around without adding to them just because one turns to the obituaries first, or reads the paper backward.

title: Messenger Indicted In Madison Ave. Fire
description: A 28-year-old messenger has been indicted on arson charges in connection with a fire Jan. 2 in an office used by Newsweek magazine at 477 Madison Avenue, according to spokesmen for the Manhattan District Attorney's office and the Fire Department.

title: Q. There must be an easier way to peel garlic than my way. I have a recipe that calls for three whole clusters, or more than 20 cloves.  It takes hours of hand peeling, and my nails carry the odor for days. Any solution?
description: A. The easiest way, to my mind, is to place each garlic clove on a flat surface and to smack it lightly with a mallet or the flat blade of a chef's knife. The blow must be strong enough to crack the garlic skin. The skin pulls off quite easily if you cut into it with a small paring knife.

title: Interpublic; Foote, Cone Issue 4th-Quarter Reports
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies and Foote, Cone & Belding Communications both released ther fourth-quarter financial statements yesterday.

title: FILLETING KNIVES
description: A FEW weeks ago I wrote about the boning knife, a rigid, forceful instrument intended for big jobs such as butterflying a leg of lamb. A knife that serves a similar purpose is the filleting knife. But since it is meant to negotiate a much more delicate course - the flesh and bones of a flatfish, for instance - it is slender and flexible. A filleting knife also has a very sharp point so that it can neatly pierce the skin of a raw fish.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate, 19.00-19.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT UP IN JANUARY
description: The nation's industrial production rose six-tenths of 1 percent in January despite a continuing decline in auto assemblies, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: MUSIC: FRENCH 'HAMLET'
description: ROBERT LAWRENCE and his Friends of French Opera have performed a tremendously valuable service to American music over the years. The once-popular French repertory had fallen out of favor, except for an occasional ''Faust'' or ''Samson et Dalila,'' but Mr. Lawrence's militancy helped restore a good many works to favor, not the least of which was Berlioz's ''Les Troyens.'' Of course, any advocate of neglected works runs the risk of unearthing some scores that hold more historic interest than artistic value. Ambroise Thomas's ''Hamlet,'' which Mr. Lawrence conducted last night at Carnegie Hall, sounded like one of those antiquated items.

title: Output of Minerals Rises 3.5% in U.S.
description: United States mineral production increased 3.5 percent in 1980, the smallest annual gain since 1977, the Bureau of Mines said today.

title: INFORMER TELLS OF THREATS AND PAYOFFS OF $200,000 IN SHIPPING INDUSTRY
description: A Miami businessman who was a Government infomer and helped obtain the convictions of several International Longshoremen's Association officials and waterfront company executives told a Senate subcommittee today that he had been forced to make nearly $200,000 in payoffs to officials of the union.

title: P.L.O. Says 'Hundreds' Were Trained by Soviet
description: A Palestinian leader said last night that hundreds of senior Palestinian officers had graduated from Soviet military academies.

title: ABORTION'S INHUMANITY
description: To the Editor:

title: FIVE DEMOCRATS NOW IN RACE
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark became the fifth candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New Jersey today. He announced his entry into the June 2 primary election at meetings here and in Paterson, Newark, Jersey City and Camden.

title: Rohatyn to Leave Board of I.T.T.
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the corporate merger specialist whose career blossomed in part from his role as an adviser to Harold S. Geneen, former chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said last night that he would not stand for re-election next spring as a director at I.T.T.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1981
description: International The Pope extolled human rights in Manila as President Ferdinand E. Marcos, his host, sat stolidly beside him. Mr. Marcos, who has been President of the Philippines since 1965, ended eight years of martial law last month and is preparing for an election that is expected to assure him of six more years in power. (Page A1, Col. 1.) More American aid to El Salvador was backed strongly by key members of Congress. The support was expressed after a briefing by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. on the Reagan Administration's assertions that the Soviet bloc is supplying arms to the Salvadoran insurgents. (A1:2.)

title: LUXURY HOTEL PROPOSED FOR OLD POLICE BUILDING
description: The city's Department of General Services has conditionally approved a proposal to convert the former Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan into a European-style luxury hotel with 125 guest rooms and space for activities by community groups.

title: NORTHROP NET OFF 23.4%
description: The Northrop Corporation, a major manufacturer of military aircraft, reported yesterday that planned outlays for the development of its F-5G fighter aircraft helped depress earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 by 23.4 percent, although sales increased 20.7 percent.

title: BIG OIL'S NOT THE FOE
description: Perhaps the easiest argument to put over is that someone evil is responsible for our ills. It is simpler to find scapegoats than to solve the problem, especially if the solution involves sacrifice. The paramount example of this paranoid response during the 1970's was public reaction to oil shortages. The scapegoats were our energy producers, who became evil corporate giants withholding their products in order to obtain obscene profits.

title: EX-HOSTAGE REPORTEDLY AT WORK ON CARTOON PROGRAM OF CAPTIVITY
description: Sgt. James M. Lopez, one of the 52 former American hostages in Iran, is working on an animated cartoon program on his experiences that he hopes to sell to a television network, a spokesman for the Lopez family said yesterday.

title: News of the Theater; Theater Row May Fold, A Victim of Hard Times
description: THEATER ROW, applauded as a gift to Midtown and hailed as a boon to Off Off Broadway, is threatened with collapse. Seven of the eight companies that make up Theater Row, on 42d Street west of Ninth Avenue, have fallen behind in their rents. Simultaneously, they have found that their operating costs are exceeding their incomes, and that the money they had planned to use for plays and musicals must now be used to pay the operating costs of their small theaters. The consequence is that while the companies are unable to mount the plays and musicals, their incomes are declining even further; so is their ability to pay the rent. Only Playwrights Horizon is up to date.

title: Sun Lowers Prices On Heating Oil
description: The Sun Company, the nation's 10th-largest refiner, said that it had lowered its wholesale prices for heating oil by 2 cents a gallon in one United States market - a move analysts speculated could signal the start of late winter price cutting.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Swastikas were painted on the apartment doors of 38 Jewish residents recently in the heavily Orthodox Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, and mezuzahs, small religious scrolls affixed to doorways, were torn and defaced.

title: POLAND'S LEADER SEES EAST GERMAN, A CRITIC OF TRADE UNION MOVEMENT
description: Stanislaw Kania, the Polish Communist Party leader, met today in East Germany with Erich Honecker, the East German leader, for discussions that included what the Polish press agency described as ''certain international problems of the two countries' foreign policies.''

title: PENNEY PLANS TO SELL DISCOUNT CHAIN UNIT
description: The J.C. Penney Company said yesterday that it had decided to drop its Treasury discount store division after nearly two decades because it has found the discount business unprofitable.

title: Vasily A. Kazakov, 64, Minister Of the Soviet Aircraft Industry
description: Vasily A. Kazakov, Minister of the Aircraft Industry, died today after a long illness, the Soviet press agency Tass said.

title: No Headline
description: OLOF PALME OFF AGAIN ON PEACE TRIP TO IRAQ AND IRAN

title: Flyers 4, Penguins 1
description: Bobby Clarke and Tom Gorence scored within the first five minutes for the Flyers. Rick St. Croix, who leads the league in goals-against average, stopped 18 of 19 Pittsburgh shots for his ninth victory against four losses and a tie this season.

title: Mesa Petroleum Profit Off
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company yesterday reported a plunge in its fourth-quarter profit to $34 million, or 98 cents a share, from the 1979 quarter's $225.3 million, or $6.91 a share.

title: POLICE SQUAD KILLS FLORIDA INMATE WHO HELD HOSTAGE IN ESCAPE-EFFORT
description: A nine-man attack squad stormed a prison office in a burst of gunfire today, killing a convicted murderer and rescuing a hostage to end a 10-hour standoff at the Union Correctional Institute, officials said.

title: THE WORD ON WINE ACCORDING TO REGINALD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Leonard S. Bernstein is a writer whose travel book, published by Rand McNally, will appear in June. By LEONARD S. BERNSTEIN

title: Prevention Magazine To Test Newsstand Sales$90$:PHILIP H. DOUGHERTY
description: Prevention, the 30-year-old health and fitness magazine that grew to 2.4 million circulation through subscriptions, is now prepared to test single-copy sales in Chicago with its March issue.

title: First Day
description: Breakfast - Mrs. Laves: glass of orange juice, slice of toast and 2 eggs. Mr. Laves: scoop of cottage cheese, 3 slices of toast, orange juice and 1 cup of coffee. Lunch - Each: 2 peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, 1 banana and 1 cup of instant coffee. Dinner - Each: Meat loaf (from 2.9 pounds of chuck steak), 2 baked pota- toes and water. Bedtime snack - Each: pears.

title: Port Jervis Granted Disaster-Area Status
description: The Federal Small Business Administration declared Port Jervis, N.Y., a disaster area, making its residents eligible for flood damage loans at low interest rates. Following a visit Saturday to the Orange County flood area, Governor Carey asked the Federal agency to survey the damage to determine if Port Jervis was eligible for Federal assistance.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Seeks to Bar Spread of Wales Coal Strike
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher called today for emergency talks after nearly 30,000 coal miners went on strike in South Wales, presenting the biggest challenge to her Conservative government since it took power 21 months ago.

title: Navy Trying to Regain Spit-and-Polish Image
description: In what some sailors see as a return to the ''good old days,'' Navy commanders are beginning strict enforcement of rules for military courtesy, appearance and discipline.

title: A CHILD'S TOOTH DECAY CAN BE PREVENTED
description: HALF the nation's children have one of more cavities by the time they are 2 years old and 80 percent have several decayed teeth by the age of 6. Only 2 percent of school-age children can expect to avoid any decay, and the average American has 14 decayed, filled or missing teeth by the age of 20.

title: Harvester to Sell Unit to Cub Cadet
description: International Harvester said it planned to sell its lawn and garden tractor line to the Cub Cadet Corporation, a move that will mean the layoffs of 400 Harvester workers in Louisville.

title: Charges Delayed in Inquiry On Hotel Fire in Las Vegas
description: The filing of formal charges against an arson suspect was delayed today while investigators searched for someone else who was believed to be setting fires in the Hilton Hotel at the same time.

title: U.S. AIDES WARN POTENTIAL BUYERS OF BEANS REPOSSESSED BY FARMERS
description: Federal officials today warned potential buyers against purchasing soybeans that angry farmers have been repossessing from a bankrupt grain elevator here.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Directors of the Riggs National Bank, which is based in Washington, urged the bank's shareholders yesterday to reject a tender offer for their shares by Joe L. Allbritton, the former publisher of The Washington Star.

title: POPE, WITH MARCOS BESIDE HIM, DELIVERS HUMAN RIGHTS TALK
description: Pope John Paul II delivered a homily on human rights today in Malacanang, the presidential palace, while President Ferdinand E. Marcos, his host, sat beside him.

title: ANALYSIS FAULTS KOCH PROPOSALS TO FIGHT CRIME
description: A report analyzing Mayor Koch's criminal-justice proposals and concluding that they are unlikely to solve the city's crime problems was made public yesterday by the National Council on Crime and Delinquency.

title: WHERE PUDDINGS ARE LAST BUT NOT LEAST
description: LONDON TRADITIONAL English sweets, with their reliance on dried fruits, nuts and egg custards, are particularly warming and satisfying in winter. In Britain, the last bastions of these desserts are the dining rooms of grand hotels. And in London, two in particular specialize in English desserts: Claridge's, with its beloved breadand-butter pudding, and the Dorchester.

title: PERCY SAYS U.S. WILL HONOR IRAN DEAL ON HOSTAGES
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. told a group of Senate leaders this morning that the Reagan Administration would ''fully implement'' the complex financial agreements reached with Iran to obtain the release of the 52 American hostages, Senator Charles H. Percy said today.

title: News Analysis
description: The Arab-Israeli conflict has reached a stage of benign stagnation. Nothing is on the verge of resolution, yet the danger of war seems very low. The military balance stands in Israel's favor. The Arab world is divided against itself. The Palestine Liberation Organization is having less success in its guerrilla operations.

title: Economic Scene; What Reagan Will Propose
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN will lay out his economic plan for stopping inflation and revitalizing the American economy tonight. The American people, according to the White House press secretary, James S. Brady, will be told they have ''no choice'' but to support ''our plan.''

title: PARENTS TO BE SHOWN BENEFITS OF I.S. 231
description: School board members of District 29 in Queens met yesterday with School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola and agreed to try to educate white parents about the predominantly black junior high school to which some have refused to send their youngsters.

title: POTENTIAL BOOK PROJECT OF ABSCAM PROSECUTOR IS ASSAILED BY DEFENSE
description: A Justice Department official who supervised the Abscam investigation and prosecuted four current or former members of Congress on resulting corruption charges said yesterday that he might accept an offer to collaborate on a book about the investigation.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ALTHOUGH my father was mayor of St.-Tonnerre, the small town in Burgundy where I was born, we were not ''well off,'' as they say, financially. But by the standards of that town (the population stood at 399 souls), we weren't poor either.

title: GARDEN DENIES TEAMS MOVING
description: Madison Square Garden wants the city to lower its real estate taxes but has no interest in moving the Knicks or the Rangers, a ranking Garden official said yesterday.

title: PUTTING THE SAUDI 'OIL WEAPON' INTO PERSPECTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrows Defeat Blast, 4-3, In Garden Indoor Soccer
description: The New York Arrows, playing without the injured Shep Messing and Luis Alberto, two of their most consistent players, defeated the Baltimore Blast, 4-3, in a Major Indoor Soccer League game last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Wildcat Stoppage by Coal Miners Appears Ended in West Virginia
description: A wildcat strike by thousands of Logan County coal miners appears over, although negotiations are continuing in two isolated disputes, union officials said today.

title: AS RESERVOIRS GO, DEEPER NEED NOT BE BETTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Traffic?  Follow the Shadow
description: IF you are an advertiser and want to reach radio listeners - the Radio Advertising Bureau will tell you that's 95 percent of the population -and car owners, over and over again, talk to Gerald Levy. He knows a way.

title: Shift at Morgan Stanley
description: Amid all the clamor over big merger deals, top executives at Morgan Stanley & Company have been restructuring their organization. They say the shifts are intended to take advantage of changes in the economy and financial markets.

title: Delay Is Sought In Airline Merger
description: Texas International Airlines said it planned to ask a Federal court to force Continental Air Lines to postpone dates set for stockholder consideration of its proposed merger with Western Airlines.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS TO PRODUCE HEALTH SHOWS ON CABLE
description: In the first commitment by a company to sponsor and produce programming on cable television, the Bristol-Myers Company, the pharmaceutical concern, has signed a 10-year contract to provide health-oriented ''magazine''-format programs for the U.S.A. Network.

title: FRANCES TAYLOR HEARD
description: Frances Taylor Heard, former senior home furnishings editor of House Beautiful magazine, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 87.

title: On George Stevens
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Your article (''The American Film Institute Had to Find a New Home - or Die,'' Jan. 28) on the dinner the American Film Institute gave in our new quarters at Immaculate Heart College to celebrate our acquisition of that property, while generally approving of this important step for us, is marred by the references to George Stevens, the A.F.I.'s founding director and current cochairman. To attack Mr. Stevens in the course of an article of which he's not even the subject, and to do so in terms of anonymous quotes, seems inappropriate for what is still regarded as the nation's newspaper of record.

title: Pollution Restrictions on Utilities Can Be Relaxed, Study Suggests
description: Air-pollution restrictions on electric utilities can be significantly relaxed without risking harm to public health, according to a study by a research arm of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

title: L.I. Woman Killed When Hit by Train
description: A Westbury, L.I., woman was killed yesterday when struck by a Long Island Rail Road train west of the Urban Avenue crossing in New Cassel.

title: MONUMENT TO IMMORTALITY BUILT UPON 'JUNK' OF U.S. BUREAUCRACY
description: By ordinary standards, the life of James Hampton, Government janitor, was uneventful. But what he wrought in years of obsessive midnight labor from discarded bits of Washington life - the busted ''in'' and ''out'' boxes and faded desk blotters of bureaucrats, the jelly jars and dead light bulbs from street trash - has become his phantasmagoric legacy, a work of art unintended for, but on permanent display now, in a premier showcase, the National Museum of American Art, years after Mr. Hampton's death.

title: Economic Report By U.S. Optimistic
description: The Government gave a basically optimistic, though far from exuberant, view of the nation's economic future in a detailed industrial outlook released today by the Commerce Department.

title: OPPOSITION FORMING TO REAGAN PROGRAM
description: With President Reagan ready to lay out his conservative Republican blueprint for economic recovery, elements of the old Democratic coalition are warning that they will challenge him, setting the stage for a vigorous battle over the Administration's plans to put the nation on a different economic and political course.

title: Man Convicted in Slayings Of Five Girls in California
description: Lawrence Bittaker, a 40-year-old Burbank machinist, was convicted of first-degree murder today in the 1979 kidnapping and slaying of five teen-aged girls in a case that was the first felony trial in the state to allow television cameras into the courtroom over the objections of the defendant.

title: Nice Inflation
description: When it first composed the rules for gambling in Atlantic City, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission thought it would be unfair if only the rich could play. The public agreed, and so all casinos were required to provide tables for bets as low as $2.

title: AIDES DENY REAGAN SHIFT ON TAX CUT IN HIGH BRACKET
description: Officials in the Reagan Administration acknowledged today that higher-income Americans would receive less than the full 10 percent annual tax cut proposed for individuals, but they denied that Mr. Reagan was repudiating his campaign pledge to make the tax cut across the board.

title: Dance Photographs on Display
description: Dance photographs by Lois Greenfield will be on exhibition through April 6 at the Dance Theater Workshop Gallery of the American Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street. Miss Greenfield describes her photographs as being ''like fictions inspired by particular movements - perhaps an idiosyncratic gesture or almost imperceptible transitional passage in the works of the choreographers with whom I have collaborated.'' '' The gallery is open Monday through Fridays 11 to 5, Saturday 12 to 5 and Sundays by appointment.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Company has named Andrew M. Davitt vice president-financial standards and procedures.

title: RENE TAUPIN
description: Rene Taupin, former chairman of the Department of Romance Languages at Hunter College, died Friday in Paris, where he had lived since retiring 13 years ago.

title: Philadelphia Water Rate To Be Increased by 50%
description: The city administration announced today that it would raise the combined water and sewer rate for its 520,000 customers by 50 percent on July 1.

title: Acadia Captures Race
description: The 40-foot yacht Acadia sailed a course that took her twice across a windswept Gulf Stream to win the 135-mile Ocean Triangle leg of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference series.

title: Pargas-Sun Gas Tie
description: Pargas Inc. said it was acquiring the retail propane business of Sun Gas Liquids Inc. of Dallas, for $40 million. The Maryland company said it had signed an agreement to pay $21.4 million for fixed assets of Sun Gas and the rest for inventories and accounts receivables.

title: RUSSIANS SAID TO KILL AN AFGHAN POLICE OFFICER IN ERROR
description: A high Afghan police official was reportedly shot and killed by Soviet soldiers four days ago in what a Western diplomatic report described as a case of mistaken identity.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: 2 ANTIQUES SHOW
description: Huntington Antiques Show, Huntington Town House, 124 East Jericho Turn- pike, Huntington Station, L.I.

title: Miami County Approves Deputy-Recruiting Plan
description: Dade County Commissioners have approved a lawenforcement recruiting program proposed by Merret Stierhein, the Dade County Manager, including finder's fees in the form of $500 United States Savings Bonds for people who help recruit successful officers.

title: Ibrahim Abdel Hadi Is Dead at 82; Served as Premier Under Farouk
description: Ibrahim Abdel Hadi, briefly Prime Minister of Egypt under King Farouk, died today at the age of 82 after a long illness, the Middle East News Agency reported.

title: Public Participation Is Assailed As Delaying Reactors' Licensing
description: The chairman of a scientific group favoring nuclear energy said yesterday that the inability of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to license atomic reactors in time was approaching ''a national scandal.''

title: Flagship Bank Stake On Auction Block
description: An 18.2 percent share of Flagship Banks Inc., Florida's fifthlargest banking group, went on the auction block yesterday as the company's two largest shareholders indicated their willingness to sell their holdings.

title: Mexico Will Limit Crude Oil Exports
description: Mexico has decided to limit its crude oil exports to 1.5 million barrels a day, with no more than half of the total going to any single country, a Mexican official said today.

title: Mary Lasker Block Dies; Chicago Cultural Leader
description: Mary Lasker Block, long active in Chicago's cultural affairs, died yesterday at a hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif., where she had a winter home. She was 76 years old.

title: TEXT OF ADMINISTRATION'S STATEMENT ON REVIEW OF HOSTAGE ACCORDS
description: Following is the text of a State Department statement on the Reagan Administration's review of the agreements with Iran that led to the release of the American hostages:

title: HARVARD SELLS CITICORP ISSUES IN APARTHEID PROTEST
description: Harvard University officials said today that they had sold approximately $51 million in long-term bonds and certificates of deposit issued by Citicorp because Citibank, the corporation's banking subsidiary, participated last year in a direct loan to the South African Government.

title: 2 Nicaraguans Plead No Contest In a U.S. Copter-Smuggling Case
description: Two high-ranking officials of the Nicaraguan Air Service pleaded no contest today to charges of attempting to smuggle two helicopters out of the United States.

title: OFFICIALS PLEASED
description: New York City officials completed a sale of $200 million in shortterm municipal notes yesterday, but they did not get the lower interest rates for the securities that they had hoped for.

title: Vasily A. Kazakov, 64, Minister Of the Soviet Aircraft Industry
description: Vasily A. Kazakov, Minister of the Aircraft Industry, died yesterday after a long illness, the Soviet press agency Tass said.

title: PRE-ARRAIGNING FOR MANHATTAN URGED BY POLICE
description: Police officials contend that New York City could put 67 more police officers on patrol each year - half the strength of a mediumsize precinct - with the manpower and overtime money that would be saved if the courts and the Manhattan District Attorney's office adopted the arraignment procedures used in other boroughs.

title: SINATRA TO AID ATLANTA INQUIRY
description: Frank Sinatra will perform at a concert March 10 to raise money for the investigation into the cases of 18 missing or slain black children, Mayor Maynard Jackson said yesterday. Sammy Davis Jr. accepted an invitation earlier to perform at the benefit.

title: POLAND AND THE 'WORST-CASE SCENARIO'
description: Since September, the news from Poland has followed a consistent pattern: mounting confrontations between workers and the party, peasants and the party, students and the party, followed by last-minute negotiations and compromises. Similarly, the reaction in Washington has been consistent: As the clouds gather, doom-laden predictions of a Soviet invasion fill the air; when the predictions fail to come true, officials and newspaper columnists offer elaborate reasons why the Russians have not ''yet'' gone in - but next time, for sure.

title: NABOKOV'S QUEST FOR THE GOOD READER
description: AT one point in Vladimir Nabokov's ''Lectures on Literature,'' edited by Edson Bowers and published last fall by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, it appears as if we are finally going to learn whether we are serious readers of literature or not. In his introductory essay, ''Good Readers and Good Writers,'' Nabokov writes:

title: U.S. INQUIRY OPENS IN COAST JETLINER'S CRASH LANDING
description: Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board arrived from Washington today to determine why an Air California Boeing 737 jetliner crash-landed at John Wayne Airport in suburban Orange County last night.

title: SEARCH FOR A NEW PRESIDENT OF N.Y.U. IS NARROWED
description: The search for a new president of New York University has narrowed to a choice between former Representative John Brademas of Indiana and Thomas Ehrlich, director of the International Development Cooperation Agency, sources close to the selection process said yesterday.

title: POSTMODERN ARCHITECTURE AND ITS ORIGINS
description: THERE are a lot of lessons about architecture and design in this small village, and they are not the ones you expect to learn. Woodstock is one of those New England villages that is often described with words such as perfect, and picture-book, and picturepostcard.

title: Toxic Leak Leads to Evacuation
description: The authorities said that about 300 children were evacuated from an elementary school today when a highly toxic chemical started leaking from drums on a truck stopped on Interstate 40. No injuries were reported.

title: Q. We live in a 70-year-old Cape Cod and the rooms on the second floor have sloping sides. The central portion of the ceiling is flat, so there is a space above this, between this narrow ceiling and the peak. There is no access to this space under the peak, and no sign of vents for that space.
