We have been told that there is probably insulation directly under the roof and we should therefore not vent that space unless we put insulation down on the ceiling. In order to do so we would have to cut an access door in the ceiling. Also, the second floor rooms get very hot in the summer. What do you suggest? - M.G., Washington.
description: A. I suggest cutting that access door so that you can find out what is really doing up there. If insulation is up to the peak, I would put it down onto the top of the ceiling instead, and I would add vents to this space at each end. This will not only help prevent condensation problems (which you may have), it would also help disperse trapped heat in the summer.

title: RECITAL: TOBY APPEL PLAYS VIOLA AT THE Y
description: TOBY APPEL might seem something of a veteran to be joining the Young Concert Artists stable this year. But the violist is still only 28, and his recital Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y, accompanied by the fine British pianist Peter Pettinger, was a most successful one.

title: Brown in Line For Nets' Job?
description: Larry Brown's name has surfaced as a candidate to coach the Nets, but the team would not confirm that report yesterday.

title: IN THE AGE OF TELEVISION, IRISH RELISH RADIO DRAMA
description: The American radio executive who reportedly remarked back in the 1950's that ''radio is dead'' must never have tuned into Irish Radio.

title: 3 FILMS THAT DIDN'T GET NOMINATIONS FOR OSCARS
description: Jean-Luc Godard's ''Every Man for Himself,'' Woody Allen's ''Stardust Memories'' and John Huston's 35-year-old documentary about shell-shocked soldiers in World War II, ''Let There Be Light,'' met a common fate yesterday. Although eligible for Academy Awards, none were nominated.

title: RISE IN WATER SUPPLIES TOUGHENS JOB OF 'SELLING' CONSERVATION
description: When Francis X. McArdle, New York City's Environmental Protection Commissioner, announced that melting snow and a little more than an inch of rain last week had raised reservoir levels to 40 percent of capacity from 32 percent, the reaction of many people was that this simply could not be.

title: Blanton Relatives Indicted In Fraud and Bid-Fixing
description: The brother and uncle of former Gov. Ray Blanton were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of mail fraud and rigging bids on state road contracts.

title: SAUDIS ACT TO FREE 21 JAILED AMERICANS
description: Saudi Arabia, in what Crown Prince Fahd characterized as a ''gesture of good will'' toward the Reagan Administration, is releasing virtually all Americans in Saudi jails, according to John C. West, the United States Ambassador.

title: Fisk Rejects Red Sox Offer
description: Carlton Fisk, the all-star catcher recently declared a free agent, has rejected the latest contract offer from the Boston Red Sox, who will now try to trade for ''catchers and other players,'' the club said today.

title: THE FOLLY OF INCREASING A CITY'S CAR-CARRYING CAPACITY
description: To the Editor:

title: TRADING LIGHT
description: The stock market rose yesterday in light trading as many investors remained on the sidelines awaiting President Reagan's economic message to Congress last night.

title: A.T.& T.'s Dividend Raised 8%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company raised the quarterly dividend on its widely held common stock yesterday to $1.35 from $1.25.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF MESSAGE
description: GENERAL: Spending for the fiscal year 1982, which begins Oct. 1, would be $695.5 billion, or $41.4 below the amount in the Carter budget. Receipts for that year are estimated at $650.5 billion, with a deficit of $45 billion.

title: 'TRENDY BUT ILL-ADVISED' DEREGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Factory Use Gains In Month
description: The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the nation's factories operated at about 80 percent of capacity in January, despite production drops in the auto, steel and paper industries.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WRAP-UP

title: Leaky faucets are easy for the do-it-yourselfer to take care of
description: A RAPID drip from a leaking faucet can waste as much as 50 to 75 gallons of water a day - and if the water that is leaking is hot water, the waste is in energy as well. Fortunately, fixing a leaking faucet is a fairly simple chore that any do-it-yourselfer can handle.

title: 40 IRAN LEGISLATORS WARN OF DRIFT TOWARD ANARCHY
description: Forty members of Parliament, among them five former Cabinet ministers, warned in a letter today that Islamic extremists responsible for increasing street violence were pushing the country toward anarchy and were endangering Iranian independence.

title: State to Give $6,400 To Carey's Neighbor
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan announced that he had approved payment of $6,400 of state money to Dr. Philip D'Arrigo, Governor Carey's Shelter Island neighbor whose land the state tried to seize.

title: KERKORIAN, COLUMBIA IN PEACE PACT
description: In a bold move that took even Columbia Pictures by surprise, Kirk Kerkorian, the multimillionaire film executive, tentatively agreed yesterday to sign a 10-year peace pact with the giant motion picture company.

title: by John Wilson
description: UNTIL three years ago, Cal Collins limited his guitar playing to the area near Cincinnati, where he lives. But then Benny Goodman heard him and asked him to tour with him, and Mr. Collins was soon recording frequently with various groups both as a side-man and as a leader.

title: Senator Tower, in Visit to Oman, Meets the Sultan at Desert Camp
description: Senator John G. Tower of Texas, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, met with the Sultan of this strategic Persian Gulf country today, officials here announced.

title: HOW SOME WOMEN REWARD THEMSELVES FOR JOBS WELL DONE
description: ALL those years, Beverly Sills was dreaming of peanut clusters. There she was, singing Lucia and Violetta and the Queen of the Night on the opera stages of the world, ravishing ears and eyes, stealing hearts away and pounded with ''bravas'' and bouquets. Still, she kept wanting those peanut clusters.

title: 5 File Suit Charging Experiments In Prison Impaired Mental Health
description: Five present and former inmates of the Atlanta Federal penitentiary have filed a $2.5 million lawsuit against the Central Intelligence Agency, saying that they suffered permanent damage from drug experiments financed by the agency 20 years ago.

title: THE $10,000-A-YEAR COLLEGE EDUCATION HAS ARRIVED
description: The price of a college education, which hard-pressed parents have long said is going through the roof, has done just that - only there is apparently no longer a roof. As Gertrude Stein said, ''When you get there, there is no there there.''

title: GREECE ASSERTS TURKEY HAS MISCONSTRUED BID FOR U.S. GUARANTEES
description: Foreign Minister Constantine Mitsotakis said today that Turkey had misinterpreted Greece's intentions in seeking American security guarantees in the Aegean. He said specific American guarantees of Greece's frontiers were not being sought.

title: PLAN FOR MILITARY SPENDING IS MAJOR SHIFT FOR PEACETIME
description: In perhaps the largest shift of financial resources proposed in the nation's peacetime history, President Reagan disclosed tonight that he planned to increase the military budget from 24.1 percent of Federal spending to 32.4 percent over the next three years.

title: ADMIRAL IS RETIRING BUT NOT FROM MEDICINE
description: Although he will retire from the Navy in June, Rear Adm. William M. Lukash, who has looked after the health of Presidents for the last 14 years, is not retiring from medicine.

title: One Dead, 25 Hurt as Truck Crashes in Maryland Town
description: A lumber truck whose brakes failed crashed and exploded here today, killing a woman, injuring at least 25 persons and setting a building on fire.

title: Reagan Was Reference For Sinatra, Report Says
description: The Nevada authorities who deliberated on whether to approve a gambling license for Frank Sinatra were told that Ronald Reagan, then a candidate for President, believed the singer to be an honorable person.

title: 400 INTELLECTUALS FORM 'STRUGGLE FOR FREEDOM' UNIT
description: Four hundred intellectuals, warning that the Soviet Union is an increased danger to democratic societies, have announced the formation of an international committee to lead a ''struggle for freedom.''

title: The Ghost of Summer Yet to Come
description: No matter when the warm weather arrives, even in February, people seem to head for the water. John Ossipinsky donned trunks and ran for the waters of Coney Island in Brooklyn as youngsters in Huntington, L.I., tempted geese with handouts.

title: TAX-CUT PLAN CONCENTRATES ON INCOME AND WRITE-OFFS
description: President Reagan outlined to Congress today a plan for cutting individual and business income taxes that would, if enacted, amount to the largest tax relief ever passed.

title: Algerian Gas Talks End
description: A United States delegation here to discuss the price of Algerian natural gas exports to the El Paso Company left without reaching agreement, informed American sources said today. No date was set for further discussions at the government level, but they could continue between officials of El Paso and Sonatrach, the Algerian state energy company, the sources added.

title: Pro Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Rick Dotson a nd Ken Kravec, pitchers, to one-year con- t racts.

title: ESCAPED SOVIET SPY IS REPORTED SMUGGLING ARMS TO EL SALVADOR
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is investigating a report that Christopher John Boyce, an escaped American who had been convicted of spying for the Soviet Union, is involved in smuggling arms to revolutionaries in El Salvador, according to Government sources.

title: Legislator Demands Minority Programs
description: The ranking black member of the Assembly yesterday threatened to marshal the 23 black and Hispanic legislators to block agreement on a 1981-82 state budget if the Legislature and the state agencies did not include appropriations to aid minority communities.

title: PROBATE JUDGE IN TEXAS RULES THAT NO WILL WAS LEFT BY HOWARD HUGHES
description: Resolution of the tangled affairs that Howard R. Hughes left when he died in 1976 moved a step closer today with the declaration by a probate judge that the eccentric industrialist left no will.

title: Almay Narrows Choice
description: Street talk has it that Almay Inc., has cut the list of competitors for its advertising account to four agencies: Kurtz & Tarlow; Geer, du Bois; Creamer, and Cunningham & Walsh. The talk also says that final presentations will be held the week of March 9. Hicks & Greist has been the agency.

title: 4 Men Wounded on Bronx Street By Shots Fired From Passing Car
description: Four men were wounded on a Bronx street last night when shots were fired at them from a passing car, the police said.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 19, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: United Nations Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M.

title: Advertising; Tampax 'Original' To Return
description: TAMPAX INC., the leading manufacturer of tampons, is bringing back the original version it replaced three years ago after 42 years on the market. Last year's news about toxic shock syndrome is one reason; unexpected consumer demand is another.

title: Georgia Pressing Search For Bootleggers in 6 Deaths
description: Murder or manslaughter indictments will be sought against bootleggers producing moonshine responsible for at least six deaths since October, a police official said today.

title: Interest Rates Inching Up; Key U.S. Issue Yielding 12.85%
description: The credit markets hope that President Reagan can reduce inflation with a package of cuts in taxes and spending, but in advance of the President's speech last night, those hopes were not enough to lower interest rates.

title: Hawks 99, Pacers 96
description: Steve Hawes scored 8 of his game-high 24 points in the fourth quarter to spark Atlanta. The Pacers, who beat Atlanta in their four previous games this season, had their hopes end as Johnny Davis's 3-point shot from 30 feet at the buzzer went in the basket and bounced out.

title: Approval Near For Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation will gain final approval of Federal loan guarantees next week, the Government indicated today. The Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board will meet Feb. 27, the agency said in a statement today, ''so that the closing of the proposed $400 million Government-guaranteed Chrysler note issue can occur on that date.''

title: STAGE: 'CROSSING NIAGARA' IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON ''CROSSING NIAGARA'' by Alonso Alegria, a Peruvian playwright residing in the United States, is an attempt at depicting and understanding daredevilry, a most difficult feat on stage. The play, which has previously been presented in various countries and is now in its American premiere engagement at the Folger Theater Group, is the saga of Blondin, a legendary French wire-walker who crossed Niagara Falls scores of times in the mid-19th century.

title: Sipping Supply Cider
description: The so-what's-new set will have an easy time disaparaging President Reagan's economic recovery plan. Tax cut? What tax cut? First, the bulk of the promised rate reduction was put off until midyear. Indexation to stop ''taxbracket creep,'' so vigorously promised in the campaign, has been put off. The ''unearned income'' tax rate on savings and dividends still goes up to 70 percent, penalizing thrift and chasing money into tax shelters.

title: British to Make Hand-Sized TV Set
description: A privately held British company said it planned to produce, in conjunction with the Timex Corporation, a hand-sized, flat-screen black-and-white television set that would cost about $125.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF STATE OF THE UNION MESSAGE ON ECONOMIC RECOVERY
description: Following is a transcript of the State of the Union Message by President Reagan last night to a joint session of Congress focusing on a program for economic recovery, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: TAXES AND THE CORPORATE LOBBY
description: To the Editor:

title: Zambia Realigns Its Top Officials For Second Time in Two Months
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia replaced the No. 2 and No. 3 officials in the state hierarchy today in his second shake-up of the ruling party and Government in just over two months.

title: No Headline
description: DuWayne Terrell, a slight, graceful 24-year-old with a dazzling smile and a boyish manner that make him seem younger than his experiences and age would suggest, talked today about his imprisonment in Yemen and the tortures that made him confess falsely to being an Israeli spy.

title: REAGAN SHOULD TAKE INITIATIVE ON CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: JURY HEARS CRUCIAL HARRIS TESTIMONY AGAIN
description: The jury in the Jean S. Harris murder trial, deliberating for a second day, asked today to hear again the defendant's own testimony of the night of the shooting - in particular those passages dealing with her state of mind.

title: Deportation Trial Defendant Identified With Nazi Camp
description: An elderly Jewish survivor of the Holocaust recalled today that a Ukrainian named Ivan was ''the biggest devil'' among the guards he knew at the Nazi death camp in Poland called Treblinka.

title: SPANISH LEADER SEEKS BACKING OF LEGISLATORS ON NEW GOVERNMENT
description: Prime Minister-designate Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo urged Parliament today to approve a new government, which he pledged to lead until the next scheduled elections in 1983.

title: 'FOUND OBJECT' FURNITURE AT STUDENTS' EXHIBITION
description: AN exhibition of class projects by interior design students at the Fashion Institute of Technology, including ''found object'' furniture scavenged from industrial parts, will be shown through Monday at the Shirley Goodman Resource Center, 27th Street and Seventh Avenue.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP BY 0.9% IN JANUARY
description: Americans had almost 1 percent more in personal income last month, but they quickly spent that new money and more, the Government reported today.

title: New Medical Publications At Mary Ann Liebert
description: Mary Ann Liebert Inc. has added a second medical publication to its list and has plans for a third and fourth for the spring.

title: President Proposes 83 Major Program Cuts; Tells Congress U.S. Faces Day of Reckoning
description: PRESIDENT PROPOSES 83 MAJOR PROGRAM CUTS; TELLS CONGRESS U.S. FACES DAY B 5 OF RECKONING

title: POLICE SAY GUN TURNED IN BY BOY ISN'T ONE THAT FIGURES IN KILLING
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said yesterday that a starter's pistol turned over to the police by an 11-year-old Brooklyn boy was not the gun that investigators believe was used by the boy's 17-year-old friend to fire at an off-duty policeman in Brooklyn last week.

title: Fire Increases Oil Well's Yield
description: In a technique called ''fireflooding,'' Texaco Inc. said it had set an old oilfield in Louisiana afire 1,000 feet underground to force out supplies of crude that would have been unrecoverable using conventional techniques.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. TO SEEK BIGGER VOICE ON POLITICAL ISSUES AND CANDIDATES
description: Concerned about its dwindling impact on the nation's political life, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. decided today to seek a unified, active and early role in the decision-making of the major political parties.

title: AT LEAST 10 REPORTED KILLED IN A VIRGINIA BUS CRASH
description: A commuter bus crashed through guardrails on Interstate 95 today and hurtled down an 80-foot embankment, killing at least 10 persons, including the driver, according to a state police spokesman. At least 14 persons were reported injured.

title: SENATORS ARE TOLD CRIME FIGURES 'OWNED' LEADER OF LONGSHORMEN
description: A convicted swindler who was intimately involved in waterfront corruption before becoming a Government informer said today at a Senate hearing that he believed Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, was ''owned'' by organized crime.

title: U.S. TO EASE SOME ENERGY-SAVING RULES
description: The Reagan Administration indicated today that it would discard elaborate proposals made by the Carter Administration to impose mandatory standards for the fuel efficiency of home appliances.

title: TRW CLIMBS BY 13.7%CHESEBROUGH UP 18.8%
description: TRW Inc., a diversified electronics, automotive and aerospace products concern, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1980 rose 13.7 percent on a sales increase of 8.3 percent.

title: No Headline
description: Gen. Ariel Sharon, the chief architect of Israel's settlement program on the occupied West Bank, leafed through a folder of small maps dotted with intricate shapes in red, pink, orange and green, and pronounced himself almost satisfied.

title: HUAC? IN '81? TODAY?
description: Most Americans probably have little or no recollection of the dark decades of the House Un-American Activities Committee. For them, it must be difficult to understand the dread many of us feel when we learned of the re-establishment in the Senate Judiciary Committee of an internal-security subcommittee and of possible action in the House of Representatives to reconstitute HUAC.

title: Bridge: Hungarian Studio Qualifies As a Durable Organization
description: When the world team championships were last staged in the United States, in 1964, an official noticed that Australia was playing Brazil. He inquired whether they would like an interpreter, and was advised that it was not necessary: All four players spoke Hungarian.

title: A BOLD AND RISKY VENTURE
description: For all the urgent confidence in President Reagan's address to Congress tonight, his economic program is a bold yet risky venture for both the nation's economy and for the Republican Party that he led to stunning gains last November.

title: 3 EX-OFFICIALS SUPPORT TAPPING INCOME TAX TO FINANCE MEDICARE
description: Three former Social Security Commissioners agreed today that the Medicare health program for the elderly and needy, which is now financed by payroll taxes, should instead be financed by income tax revenues. They suggested that the freed money be shifted to the endangered retirement fund.

title: DEEP CUTS IN AID TO CITIES SEEN UNDER REAGAN PLAN
description: The proposed budget cutbacks announced today by the Reagan Administration would cost New York City and other urban areas billions of dollars in previously expected aid for mass transportation, food stamps and public housing programs.

title: BRITAIN CANCELS ITS PLAN FOR CLOSING COAL MINES
description: The Conservative Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher tonight withdrew its plan to close old coal mining pits. This cleared the way for the return to work by thousands of miners who had begun a widespread strike in opposition to the plan.

title: Israel's Teachers Strike
description: Israel's 60,000 teachers, who earn an average of $110 a week, staged a one-day strike today to press for a wage increase promised by the Government. The Government's decision in principle last month to grant the raise brought the resignation of Finance Minister Yigal Hurvitz, which resulted in the Government coalition losing its majority in Parliament. Negotiations, however, have continued.

title: Trout & Ries on Ads
description: Although it's hard to believe, according to Trout & Ries Advertising, something cost less last year than in 1979: the cost of producing an ad, a trend that the agency has been surveying for the past six years. With information supplied by advertiser questionnaires, T.& R. says the average cost for all types of ads declined by 7 percent. The average cost of producing a one-page, black-and-white ad was $2,685, down from $3,195

title: KEEP CURFEW ON ALCOHOL
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET PRESS SAYS WEST'S RADIO GIVE POLISH STRIKERS INSTRUCTION
description: The Soviet press said today that Western radio stations had been broadcasting directives to Poland ''as to when, where and how to fan up strikes under the slogans of Solidarity,'' the independent labor movement.

title: Official in Store Incident Quits
description: City Manager Gene DeMarie, accused of taking a 79-cent package of screws from a department store on Sunday, resigned yesterday. Mr. DeMarie said he had bought and tried to exchange a package of defective screws but the store refused to take them back without a receipt. A guard said he saw Mr. DeMarie take the package from a display rack, put the screws in his pants pocket and throw the original package on the floor.

title: El Al Order for Pratt
description: United Technologies' Pratt & Whitney Aircraft group said that El Al, Israel's international airline, had selected its JT9D turbofan engines to power the carrier's new fleet of Boeing 767 jetliners. The order, for 11 engines, is worth more than $25 million, a Pratt spokesman said. El Al has ordered four of the 200-seat, wide-body twin-jets for scheduled passenger flights between Israel and Europe.

title: Budget Program Cites Koch's Turn of Phrase
description: Mayor Koch apparently was the only person other than the President referred to by name today in the ''Program for Economic Recovery,'' the book that contained the Admnistration's proposed budget cuts.

title: 76ers 111, Pistons 97
description: Julius Erving scored 13 of his 24 points in the fourth quarter as Philadelphia rallied to defeat Detroit. Steve Mix scored a left-handed layup at 10:52 of the fourth quarter to put Philadelphia ahead by 81-79.

title: Mexican Students Reported To Free Last of 7 Hostages
description: Three preparatory school students who had taken over the rector's office at the University of Mexico freed the last of seven hostages today after the Government agreed to fly them to Cuba, a university spokesman said. There was no immediate confirmation from the Government.

title: BELABORING THE CHOICE FOR INDUSTRIAL COMMISSIONER
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. BANKING UNIT VIEWED AS PROBLEM FOR HELLER CORP.
description: From financing the purchase of the Beech-Nut Corporation, the baby food maker, to factoring - buying the outstanding accounts due - for garment, textile and other companies, the Walter E. Heller International Corporation plays the role of financier and banker to thousands of small and medium-sized businesses.

title: The Price Of Being Civilized
description: President Reagan's economic speech to Congress marks the turn of a long historic tide in American federalism. However successful he turns out to be in getting the details of his program enacted, we know we are at the end of the age in which Americans looked to Washington to meet their every public need.

title: Fotomat Judgment
description: A Federal appeals court upheld a fraud judgment against the Fotomat Corporation, a Wilton, Conn., franchiser of photo stores, but struck down an antitrust verdict and slashed multimillion-dollar damage awards to two franchise holders. The decision, which grew out of Fotomat's appeal of a judgment in a Kansas civil suit, suggested that a damage award totaling $3.3 million be cut to $1.1 million and struck down a separate antitrust judgment for another $2.6 million. The punitive damages awarded to the two franchisees were ''irrational and excessive,'' the court said.

title: Israeli Quits Over Emigration
description: Shmuel Lahis, director general of the Jewish Agency, which oversees immigration, resigned today, saying that the Government was not acting on a report he wrote cautioning against emigration. The report contended that up to 500,000 Israelis were living in the United States alone, and he urged that financial benefits be paid to induce Israelis to return home.

title: FOR STAINED CARPETS AND FABRICS
description: To clean up pet stains on carpets and fabrics, pet specialists recommend some methods that require going no farther than the kitchen. For carpet stains, for instance, pour club soda directly on the spot and then cover with salt; let it dry and brush the salt off.

title: Index; International
description: Israeli satisfied with progress on settlements A2 Japanese Protestants warn of a revival of emperor worship A3 A Soviet Jew held in 1970 hijacking plot is freed A3 Yadin to dissolve his party in Is- rael A4 Saudis, in gesture to Reagan, free virtually all jailed Americans A5 Around the World A7 Text of State Department state- ment on hostage accords A10 General hints that Turkey wants role in Persian Gulf defense A11 Soviet press says Western radios instruct Polish strikers A12 Spain's Premier-designate woos legislators A13 Salvadoran peasants flee war-rav- aged countryside A14 Ireland is still attuned to radio drama A18 400 intellectuals form group to ''struggle for freedom'' A19 Government/Politics Massachusetts court overturns limit on financing of abortions A20 Veteran of dairy lobby calmly awaits assault A26 Prospects dim for 50-cent night surcharge for New York cabs B4 Water level rise toughens New York's conservation campaign B4 Reagan to propose revision in Federal pay to civilians B5 President Reagan's budget cut proposals in summary B6-7 City completes sale of $200 million in short-term notes B20 General Around the Nation A20 Deadline nears on fate of Ameri- can seized in Colombia A26 Fire breaks out at new Manhattan hotel on day of opening B3 Industry/Labor A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders seek a uni- fied front in party politics A28 The Home Section Home Dramatic drop in sterling flat- ware C1

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of two Andrzej Wajda films yesterday gave the location of the showings incorrectly. They are at the Bleecker Street Cinema and are open to the public.

title: Woman to Row In Oxford's Boat
description: A 152-year-old tradition was broken today when Susan Brown, a 22-year-old biochemistry student, became the first woman named to take part in the Oxford-Cambridge university boat race.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Natalia Paramonov, a teacher at the United Nations School on the Frankliln D. Roosevelt Drive and the wife of the first secretary of the Soviet Mission, was mugged by two men as she crossed a footbridge over the drive at 25th Street. Mrs. Paramonov, 28 years old, was robbed of jewelry worth $880. She refused medical attention. ... Five armed men escaped with $15,000 in cash and $30,000 in food stamps from the Cuba Tropical Company, East 151st Street and Cromwell Avenue, the Bronx. They tied up the store's six employees and shot the owner, Alfonso Perez, 50, in a leg.

title: TELLS CONGRESS U.S. FACES DAY B 5 OF RECKONING
description: President Reagan, declaring that the United States was approaching a ''day of reckoning,'' urged upon Congress tonight a sweeping economic program that would cut the size and drastically change the shape of Government programs enacted in the last 20 years.

title: NINE NEW MEMBERS NOMINATED FOR AMEX BOARD OF GOVERNORS
description: The American Stock Exchange has nominated nine new members to its board of governors, including two former top Federal officials and a former treasurer of the Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York.

title: HUMAN-RIGHTS WORKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: GUCCI SON SUES OVER USE OF NAME; Gucci Son Sues Over Use of Name
description: Paolo Gucci, the former designer of Gucci fashion products who left his family's business to work on his own in 1978, filed suit yesterday against Gucci Shops Inc. in an attempt to establish the right to use his family name on his own designs.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate, 19.00-19.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Accounts
description: * Upjohn to Kelly, Nason for two more assignments.

title: JAPAN INDUSTRIALIST: MAJOR FORCE AT 80
description: In Japan, the business of the nation is business. That helps to explain why one of Japan's leading industrialists, Shigeo Nagano, is also a national leader.

title: PRISON SENTENCES IMPOSED ON 10 IN CHICAGO CASE
description: A Federal district judge today imposed prison terms of 55 to 90 years on 10 suspected members of the Puerto Rican terrorist group F.A.L.N. who were found guilty of conspiracy, armed robbery and other crimes.

title: REP. CHISHOLM IS A CANDIDATE FOR COLLEGE JOB
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of Brooklyn, became one of three final candidates for the presidency of City College despite objections by a majority of members on a search committee, according to sources close to the search.

title: Basie and Copland
description: The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which sponsors the annual Grammy awards, doesn't hand out its special trustee awards lightly.

title: MONEY SUPPLY TO BE CURTAILED UNDER PROGRAM
description: In addition to tax reductions, spending cuts and deregulation of business, the White House is counting on a steady decline in the growth of the money supply as a major element of its new economic package.

title: A British Missile Shield Planned for U.S. Bases
description: The United States agreed formally today to purchase British Rapier air-defense missile systems to protect Air Force bases in Britain.

title: OF CUTS AND SPENDING: PUZZLING RELATIONSHIP
description: Question: Why is a budget cut considered a budget cut when Government spending is still going up? Answer: Because of inflation, and a population that is growing in such a way that some of its elements require more services. Rising prices means that in terms of dollars, total Government spending and spending on almost every individual program rise each year -but that increase does not necessarily mean that the size of Government is expanding.

title: PENTAGON CONCLUDES FLASH OF DEC. 16 WAS A METEOR
description: Defense Department analysts have concluded that a flash detected by an early-warning satellite over a remote part of the earth on Dec. 16 was not that of a nuclear weapons test but of a meteor entering the atmosphere. However, they are sticking by their contention that an earlier flash recorded on Sept. 22, 1979, had the signature of a nuclear test.

title: MURDOCH CHOOSES ANEW EDITOR TO TAKE OVER AT LONDON TIMES
description: Harold Evans, the editor of The Sunday Times, will become the new editor of The Times of London, Rupert Murdoch, who bought both newspapers last week, announced today.

title: HENRIETTA GIBSON LEDDEN
description: Henrietta Gibson Ledden, a former treasurer of the women's division of the board of missions of the United Methodist Church, died Tuesday in Asbury Park Village, a retirement complex affiliated with the church in Gaithersburg, Md.

title: Enrico Macias to Begin Tour April 4 at Felt Forum
description: Enrico Macias, absent from the New York stage since 1974, will perform in two concerts at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum on April 4 at 8 P.M. and April 5 at 7:30.

title: CITY BUS TAKEN OVER AND THEN VANDALIZED BY STUDENTS IN QUEENS
description: A group of high school students took over and vandalized a city bus yesterday after its driver walked away from the vehicle in front of a Queens high school, the police said.

title: Market Place; Pension Funds: Results of 1980
description: MANAGERS of the nation's pension funds did not do quite as well last year as the stock market itself, but even so they must have pleased their clients.

title: Technology; Using Machines That Can Read
description: THE public may moan about it, but the Postal Service is serious about switching to a nine-digit ZIP code. Using the longer codes, which will be voluntary and aimed mostly at speeding business mail, machines will be able to read addresses and sort mail far more accurately and swiftly than postal clerks.

title: SOME OF DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST CITE THE ELDERLY
description: Because they are especially vulnerable to neglect and misfortune, the elderly poor are often chosen as beneficiaries of gifts made to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Guadeloupe Bomb Goes Off
description: A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, Feb. 18 (UPI) - A 2.2-pound bomb apparently set by members of the Group for Armed Liberation, an independence movement, shattered a bedroom early today, in the home of Hughes Valandro, a local houseware merchant. The blast shattered the bedroom of his daughter, who suffered shock and light injuries from debris.

title: Retail Expert Has Become A Consultant
description: Herbert Wittkin, 65, who earned a reputation as a turnaround expert during a 33-year career at the Allied Stores Corporation that included the presidency of Stern Brothers, has opened his own retail management consultancy in New York. Mr. Wittkin retired from Allied last month.

title: SALVADORAN PEASANTS FLEE WAR-RAVAGED VILLAGES
description: At midnight a week ago, a rebel force surrounded this small dusty town 45 miles east of San Salvador and blocked the dirt road leading into it.

title: HANDMADE TILES: TAKE YOUR CHOICE
description: THEY tend to crop up all at once. Hand-made tiles, that is - from Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, Manhattan and Brooklyn. ''I make custom ceramic tiles and sterling tiles,'' said Maureen Neumann of The Tuilerie (237-2630), shown above with some of her designs.

title: YADIN DISSOLVES HIS ISRAELI PARTY RATHER THAN RUN IN JUNE VOTING
description: The leadership of Deputy Prime Minister Yigael Yadin's Democratic Movement decided today to disband the party instead of running a slate in the parliamentary elections in June.

title: Strength of Jack Daniel's
description: The big sales gainer last year among the top 10 liquor brands, according to Impact, an industry newsletter, was Jack Daniel's bourbon, which rose 25 percent and is in the No.8 spot on the sales list. Here are the 10 from the top: Bacardi rum, up 8 percent; Smirnoff vodka, down 2 percent; Seagram's 7 Crown, down 5 percent; Seagram's VO, unchanged; Canadian Club, up 1 percent; Jim Beam, another bourbon, up 4 percent; Popov vodka, up 5 percent; Jack Daniel's; Seagram's gin, up 5 percent, and Gordon's Gin, up 4 percent.

title: RANGERS SET BACK MAPLE LEAFS BY 8-3
description: The New York Rangers ended their two-game losing streak by beating the Toronto Maple Leafs last night, 8-3, before a capacity crowd at Madison Square Garden. The defeat stopped a three-game winning streak for Toronto, and the clubs split their four-game season series.

title: EXCERPTS FROM A WHITE HOUSE 'FACT SHEET' DESCRIBING THE ECONOMIC PROGRAM
description: Following are excerpts from a document issued by the White House today as a ''fact sheet'' on President Reagan's economic program:

title: CARDINAL COOKE ASKING PARISH PRAYERS FOR RAIN
description: Roman Catholics in the Archdiocese of New York will be offering special prayers for rain this Sunday.

title: Struggle Continues On Use of S.I. Site
description: The Navy Resale Systems Office will move into Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island from Brooklyn ''within the next week or two,'' Representative Guy V. Molinari said yesterday.

title: Kings 114, Celtics 113
description: Phil Ford hit a 21-foot jump shot at the buzzer to give Kansas City the victory.

title: PLANTS AND PETS-THE TWO SIDES
description: Plants and flowers beckon to cats and dogs. To a pet, the lilacs, tulips and anemones that fill the baccarat vase are no more than legumes to be nibbled.

title: A VIENNESE MASTER'S FURNITURE
description: JOSEF Hoffmann was an architect-designer and a man of impeccable taste whose furniture and objects reflect his mastery of geometric shaping and his delight in creature comforts. Hoffmann, the cofounder with Koloman Moser in 1903 of the Wiener Werkstatte, was the Viennese craft studio's most prolific designer throughout its three decades in existence.

title: Ex-Premier of Japan to Visit U.S.
description: Former Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda will visit the United States in next month to discuss Japan's rising automobile exports and its military buildup with President Reagan.

title: Weyerhaeuser Faces New F.T.C. Attack
description: The Federal Trade Commission stepped up its attack on the proposed $66.3 million purchase of the Menasha Corporation by the Weyerhaeuser Corporation.

title: FOR PUERTO RICAN THEATER, OLD FIREHOUSE IS NEW HOME
description: After 14 years of moving around the city from loft to loft, the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater is about to settle into its first permanent home - a renovated firehouse at 304 West 47th Street. The firehouse, a turn-of-the-century structure converted to a 196-seat theater, was opened to the press yesterday. It will open to the public March 18 with the first of three productions scheduled for this season, ''Death Shall Not Enter the Palace,'' by the late Puerto Rican playwright Rene Marques.

title: 7 Sites for Study Of Wind Power
description: The New York State Power Authority has selected seven potential sites for energy production through the use of wind. The sites, chosen from among 40 surveyed earlier, will be evaluated over a three-month period to decide which would be the best site for the authority's first wind-powered generator.

title: THE TURNAROUND AT U.S. STEEL
description: It was a dramatic turnabout at the United States Steel Corporation - a return to a profitable year. But surprising to industry analysts was the report that even the company's steel division, despite a decline in shipments, was in the black.

title: JAPANESE PROTESTANTS SEE A DANGER OF A REVIVAL OF EMPEROR WORSHIP
description: Japanese Protestant church leaders, alarmed by what they see as a rising tide of right-wing nationalism here, have warned against alleged attempts to revive emperor worship as it was practiced until the end of World War II.

title: DRAMATIC DROP IN STERLING FLATWARE
description: IF you've been contemplating buying some new sterling for your table, or have been waiting for the right time to replace a few of those spoons that got mangled in the disposal, now appears to be as good a time as any.

title: DIGITAL RECORDINGS ARE PROLIFERATING
description: THE Schwann Record & Tape Guide remains an invaluable source of information for anyone interested in music in general and recorded music in particular. A monthly guide published in Boston and distributed at most record stores, the Schwann provides not only information as to what records are avaialable in this country, but also annual statistics that allow one to assess trends of taste in both music and recorded formats.

title: ADELE B. TUNICK
description: Adele B. Tunick, a former New York City high school English teacher and a former president of the United Parents Association, died Monday at the New York University Medical Center. She was 65 years old and lived in Heritage Hills in Somers, N.Y.

title: ROY COHN FINDS POLITICS BRINGS NEW PROMINENCE
description: On the grand piano overflowing with framed photographs that dominates the drawing room of Roy M. Cohn's East Side law office, two items have a place of prominence among the smiling faces and warm wishes: a photograph of President Reagan and a letter of gratitude from him to Mr. Cohn.

title: MOVING TO MANHATTAN: DESIGN ON THE FAMILY PLAN
description: LIKE many other suburban couples before them, Fred and Flora March thought about moving to Manhattan. Not that they hadn't been happy in the large Ardsley, N.Y., house they had lived in for 15 years; they just wanted something new.

title: JAZZ: GILLESPIE AND DREAM BAND, A STAR-STUDDED ENSEMBLE
description: Dizzy Gillespie's Dream Band, a 19-piece ensemble with an established jazz star in virtually every chair playing some of Mr. Gillespie's best-known compositions, was frustrated in the second of two concerts at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening by echoing amplification that turned the ensemble's sound into a mushy blur, compounded by a sound imbalance that constantly obscured the focus of the arrangements. Even an adjunct ''dream'' sextet, that included Gerry Mulligan, Milt Jackson, John Lewis, Max Roach and Mr. Gillespie, suffered from inept balance.

title: No Headline
description: IN the commotion over Madison Square Garden's real estate taxes, the emphasis is backward. The emphasis should not be on why the Garden now has to come up with $3.7 million annually in city taxes. Instead, the emphasis should be on why the Yankees do not pay higher dues to the city that they represent.

title: Clemson Turns Back Wake Forest, 81-71
description: Clarke Bynum, a freshman guard, scored 16 points to lead Clemson to an 81-71 victory over fifth-ranked Wake Forest in an Atlantic Coast Conference tonight.

title: 5,000 Jam San Francisco Office In Search of U.S. Rent Subsidies
description: The police had to be called in after thousands of people crowded into a Housing Authority office seeking help in paying their rents, the authorities reported.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Fisher Scientific filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell $30 million in convertible subodinated debentures due in 2006 through a First Boston group.

title: ADMINISTRATION ASSAILS MAKING OF HOSTAGE DEAL
description: The Reagan Administration said today that although it will observe the terms of the agreements for freeing the 52 hostages, it would not have negotiated with Iran to obtain their release.

title: Dooley Gains Full Control Of Athletic Staff at Georgia
description: Vince Dooley, coach of Georgia's No. 1-ranked football team, got control of the university's athletic department today when Reid Parker, co-athletic director, was replaced by Lee Hayley, a former Auburn athletic director who was named Dooley's assistant.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The taxing power of government must be used to provide revenues for legitimate government purposes.

title: ITALY IN SOCCER UPROAR: IMPOSTER ON BOY'S TEAM
description: Early this month, 80,000 spectators packed the huge River Plate Stadium in Buenos Aires, where Argentina won the 1978 World Cup final, for the final of an international soccer tournament for boys under the age of 14. The team from Internazzionale of Milan, one of the richest clubs in Italy, beat a team from the Tahuichi Club of Bolivia in a close game decided by a series of penalty kicks when the teams were level on goals after extra time. The atmosphere was passionate, the joy of the Inter youngsters immense after their victory.

title: Soviet Dissidents Say Psychiatrist Is Being Held
description: Dr. Anatoly Koryagin, a Soviet psychiatrist living in Kharkov, has been arrested after talking to two Western journalists about a case of alleged abuse of psychiatry for political purposes, according to dissident sources in that city.

title: President Will See Trudeau On Trip to Canada March 10
description: President Reagan will pay a state visit to Canada on March 10 and 11, the White House said today. The visit will be Mr. Reagan's first foreign trip as President.

title: REVUE: INSTANT SUNSHINE
description: comedians in the dry, satiric mode of ''Beyond the Fringe,'' seldom raise their voices above a gentlemanly purr. The group consists of three doctors and an editor of the British humor magazine Punch, and its soft-spoken vaudeville act has gained a cult following in Britain.

title: Guccis in Legal Battle
description: He claims to have designed most of the items in the Gucci catalogue, but after 10 years as the famous leather-goods company's design chief, he thought it would be a good idea to start selling his designs under his own name.

title: ARCHIBISHOP OF NEWARK URGES WOMEN TO TAKE PARISH LEADERS' ROLES
description: Archbishop Peter L. Gerety of Newark is urging women to take their ''equal, if sometimes different'' places alongside men in the ministry of the Roman Catholic church, and has asked parishes to appoint more women to leadership roles.

title: CHIEF QUITS AT UNITED ARTISTS
description: Andy Albeck, the 59-year-old chief executive officer of the United Artists Corporation, stepped down from the post today as the company announced that he had chosen to take early retirement. Norbert Auerbach, president and chief operating officer, succeeds Mr. Albeck.

title: PALME, ON PEACE MISSION, OPENS TALKS WITH IRAQIS
description: A delegation of United Nations officials headed by former Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden opened talks with Iraqi leaders today on ways of ending the war with Iran.

title: VETERAN OF DAIRY LOBBY CALMLY AWAITS ASSAULT
description: There is a time to lobby relentlessly and a time to listen quietly. This evening Patrick B. Healy, for years one of the most successful lobbyists in town in behalf of the nation's well-organized dairy farmers, stayed quietly at home, skipping an invitation to Capitol Hill as he prepared to listen to President Reagan's State of the Union Message on television.

title: CASINO PROSPECTS ARE WANING, SAY ALBANY LEADERS
description: Proposals to legalize casino gambling in New York State are foundering in the Legislature, according to key lawmakers and others state officials.

title: 24-Hour Notice Set For Abitibi Bidder
description: One of the principals in the takeover battle for Abitibi-Price Inc., the world's largest newsprint producer, agreed to give regulatory authorities 24 hours' notice before it purchases any additional shares in the Toronto-based company.

title: JERSEY SETS RULES ON STERILIZATION OF THE RETARDED
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court, in a unanimous opinion, held today that courts, not the parents, must decide whether the sterilization of mentally incompetent persons would be in the subject's best interest and whether the affected person was incapable of participating in the decision.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1981
description: International Poland resolved a 26-day student sit-in at the University of Lodz and was close to settling an even longer dispute with farmers in the city of Rzeszow. The agreement at Lodz provides for the registration of an independent student association that would not be subject to the direct control of the Communist Party. (Page A1, Column 1.) Washington will abide by the terms of the accords with Iran for freeing the 52 hostages, the Reagan Administration said, but it added that it would not have negotiated with Teheran to obtain their release. A spokesman said that ''future acts of state-sponsored terrorism against the U.S. will meet swift and sure punishment.'' (A1:2.)

title: REAGAN TO URGE REVISION IN GOVERNMENT PAY FORMULA
description: President Reagan said today that he would propose a comprehensive revision of the formula used in computing pay rates for 2.9 million civilian employees of the Federal Government.

title: Royalty Wins Election for London University Post
description: Democracy has never played a part in the selection of the chancellor of the University of London. It is an honorary position that since the founding of the university in 1836 has been bestowed on a succession of titled aristocrats and members of the British royal family.

title: WIDER ROLE HINTED FOR TURKISH FORCES
description: A high-ranking Turkish general has hinted that Turkey is interested in playing a role in the defense of the oil-producing countries of the Persian Gulf region against ''any threat'' from outside the area.

title: Censors to the Rescue at Fort Apache
description: ''Whereas, the South Bronx has become a national symbol of urban decay plagued by high rates of unemployment, illiteracy, malnutrition and abandoned buildings ...''

title: BIBLE GROUP PRAYS FOR A MEMBER AS KIDNAPPERS' DEADLINE NEARS
description: ''Never think of people as enemies,'' an 84-year-old North Carolinian often says. ''Look on them as your friends. They may be fighting you because they don't understand. ''

title: 'STAR WARS' IS ABOUT TO ROCKET INTO PUBLIC RADIO'S GALAXY
description: ''Star Wars,'' the 20th Century-Fox movie that grossed $175.6 million at the box office, more than any other film in history, will be a radio program.

title: HOUSING STARTS RISE BY 3.5%
description: The Government today reported an unexpected burst of activity in the housing and construction industry in January, but an industry spokesman immediately disputed the figures.

title: NETS WIN 4TH IN ROW BY BEATING CAVALIERS
description: Cliff Robinson scored 24 points and Mike Newlin had 22 to help the Nets beat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 110-108, tonight at the Rutgers Athletic Center for their fourth straight victory.

title: NIXON, RAISING G.O.P. FUNDS IN OHIO, PRAISES REAGAN STAND ON MILITARY
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon returned to active partisan politics tonight, turning a fund-raising dinner for Republican state Senators into a rally hailing President Reagan.

title: Islander Shake-Up Threatened
description: The Islanders, defending Stanley Cup champions but in a slump that has seen them go five games without a victory, may be facing a shake-up, General Manager Bill Torrey indicated today.

title: BUSINESS LEADERS ARE ENTHUSIASTIC ABOUT PROGRAM
description: President Reagan's program for economic recovery drew an enthusiastic response last night from a cross section of American business. But some corporate executives suggested that the package might contain ingredients that would work at odds with each other and might sustain inflation.

title: N.C.A.A. Again Seeking Balance in Tournament
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is determined to avoid overloading one region with highly ranked teams in the championship basketball tournament and will again send schools hundreds of miles away to avoid imbalance, says Wayne Duke, tournament committee chairman.

title: 50-CENT NIGHT SURCHARGE FOR TAXIS APPEARS UNLIKELY TO BE APPROVED
description: Prospects for a 50-cent surcharge for nighttime taxi rides in New York City all but died yesterday, according to participants in a meeting of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE TEST DELAYED FOR A DAY
description: Space agency officials, learning that it takes longer than expected to get the space shuttle Columbia ready, today announced a 24-hour extension of the countdown for a test firing of the shuttle's main engines. The test will be the first time all three of the shuttle's engines have been fired at once.

title: Farm Export Data Revised
description: The Agriculture Department reduced to $47 billion today its estimate of this fiscal year's agricultural exports. The new figure, though still a record, is $1.5 billion less than predicted last November.

title: Airlines Told to Pay Fees
description: Sixteen international airlines were ordered by a court today to pay about $4.6 million they owe in higher landing fees at Heathrow Airport, despite their pending court challenge of the fee increases. The new fees, announced in November, raise to nearly $10,000, from $7,400, the cost of landing a large jet at Heathrow. The airlines affected are: Air Canada, Air France, Air India, Air Mauritius, Alitalia, BWIA International of Trinidad and Tobago, Lufthansa, Flying Tiger Line of Los Angeles, Gulf Air of Bahrain, Iberia, KLM, Saudia, Scandinavian Airlines System, Swissair, Trans Mediterranean of Beirut and T.W.A.

title: Electric Power: More Use Seen
description: Use of electric power in the United States will grow by 1.5 to 2.5 percent this year, a trade association official predicted yesterday. William McCollam Jr., president of the Edison Electric Institute, said last year's growth was held to 1.5 percent by the sluggish economy.

title: HARLEY HOTEL BESET BY FIRE ON OPENING DAY 14
description: Two hours after an elegant buffet luncheon yesterday marking the official opening of the Harley of New York Hotel on East 42d Street, fire broke out in a generator room, sending thick black smoke billowing up the sides of the 40-story bronze-glass building.

title: 26-DAY SIT-IN ENDED A12)
description: The Polish Government negotiated an end today to a 26-day student sit-in at the University of Lodz and was close to settling an even longer dispute with farmers in the southeastern city of Rzeszow.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Acme Electric Corporation agreed in principle to purchase the assets of Standard Power Inc. of Santa Ana, Calif., for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: What Needs Containing in El Salvador
description: In its attempt to snuff out the flames of revolution in El Salvador, the Reagan Administration is sounding a global fire alarm. It is serving notice on Communist adversaries, Latin neighbors and European allies that any aid to the Salvadoran guerrillas will disturb a nation's relations with the United States. The Soviet Union and Cuba, in particular, are being warned to stay out of a region of primary American influence.

title: by Carolyn G. Heilbrun
description: NOSTALGIA holds no temptations for me; it is an emotion to which I am happily a stranger. I knew once of a woman who, asked if she kept a diary, replied that in her opinion, once a day was done it was done, and the hell with it. I agree. If I look back at all, it is with thankfulness for what has changed. I'm not making great claims for today's world - who could? - but in many ways it is a lot better than when I was young. Though my vocabulary is sometimes antique - is there anyone else who still refers to the ice box and the Victrola, in an age of self-defrosting refrigerators and automatic record changers? - I harbor no longing for the past.

title: KNICKS RALLY TO DEFEAT SONICS
description: Ray Williams sank two free throws with 19 seconds left to give the Knicks a 105-103 victory tonight over the Seattle SuperSonics. It was New York's ninth victory in the last 10 games.

title: U.S. FIRMLY ENDORSES SALVADOR REFORMS
description: As the United States continued to provide its allies and Congress with evidence of what it says are Soviet-bloc arms shipments to El Salvador's left-wing guerrillas, the State Department declared that the United States was firmly backing political and social reforms, as well as security, in El Salvador.

title: FedMart to Go Private
description: The FedMart Corporation, the discount chain that is 88 percent owned by a West German retailer, Hugo Mann, plans to become a private company, company officials said today. Mr. Mann, who paid $22 million for two-thirds of the company in 1974, has been asked to provide the company with $10 million, according to the announcement, and an earlier $10 million subordinated loan by him is to be converted to equity capital. FedMart put its losses at about $8 million in the period from Sept. 1, 1980, to last Jan. 31. Sales totaled $469.5 million for the 17 months.

title: COURT REJECTS CURB ON ABORTION FUNDS
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Court today ordered the state to pay for all ''medically necessary'' abortions for women on public assistance, even if their lives are not in danger.

title: Bache Group Net Up 8.2% in Quarter
description: The Bache Group Inc., parent company of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., reported yesterday that earnings in the second fiscal quarter of 1981 ended Jan. 31 rose 8.2 percent, to $13.2 million, or $1.18 a share, from $12.2 million, or $1.17 a share, in the corresponding quarter of the preceding fiscal year.

title: The Dialogue Fairly Sparkles at a Luncheon of Stars
description: The purpose of a luncheon yesterday at the new Helmsley Palace Hotel, at 50th Street and Madison Avenue, was to announce that what is probably the theater's most cherished charity, the Actors' Fund of America, would mark its centennial next February with an ABC-TV three-hour special, ''Night of 100 Stars,'' including Princess Grace of Monaco.

title: Crangle Wins Support In National Party Race
description: Choosing between two New York State candidates for Democratic national chairman, 17 of the state's 22 members of the Democratic National Committee voted yesterday to support the Erie County Democratic chairman, Joseph F. Crangle.

title: PROGRAMS, AIMS AND POINTS OF DEBATE
description: MEDICAID A joint Federal-state program that pays doctor, hospital, nursing home and other health costs of the poor. The Federal share ranges from 50 to 70 percent, with the highest proportion going to states with the lowest per-capita income. Within broad Federal guidelines, states set rules for eligibility, covered services and payment rates. Eligible persons are entitled to have their bills paid, whatever the total cost. Spending has risen more than 15 percent a year over the last five years, primarily because of higher health costs, and the program would cost the Government more than $18 billion in the fiscal year 1982 if no changes were made. President Reagan would reduce the anticipated Federal grants to the states by $100 million in the current fiscal year and by $1 billion in 1982. After that, the Federal contribution to the program would rise at the same rate as the inflation rate in the economy. States would have to make up the difference, either by changing eligibility requirements, reducing payment rates or making their programs more efficient. States such as New York with the most generous rules would lose the most Federal dollars. Spending would be reduced by $1 billion below current estimates in 1982 and the savings would increase each year until they reached $5 billion in 1985.

title: Black Cast to Stage 'Long Day's Journey'; Black Cast Is Staging 'Long Day's Journey'
description: ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' will be presented by the Richard Allen Center for Culture and Art with a black cast that includes Gloria Foster, Al Freeman Jr., Earle Hyman, Peter Francis-James and Samanatha McCoy. The Eugene O'Neill drama is being directed by Geraldine Fitzgerald.

title: PET-PROOF DECORATING BY KNOWING HANDS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elaine Louie is a freelance writer who specializes in home furnishings and fashion. By ELAINE LOUIE

title: Yanks Give Lefebvre a Shot at Third Base
description: Many of the fans at Fort Lauderdale Stadium watching the free daily workouts and collecting autographs do not recognize the Yankee running down grounders at third base.

title: DEMOCRATS VOW TO WEIGH PACKAGE AS THEY START SHAPING ALTERNATIVES
description: Democratic Congressional leaders today pledged careful scrutiny of President Reagan's economic package to assure ''fairness'' and ''equity'' as Democratic committees in both Houses met to prepare alternative proposals.

title: Who Has a Better Plan?
description: The ship of state is out of control, says the new captain, unfolding his voluminous new charts. Can he use them to keep the ship off the rocks? Maybe so - and he deserves the chance.

title: Rent Strike Settled At Ansonia Hotel
description: A rent strike for the last year by tenants of the Ansonia Hotel, at Broadway and 73d Street, was settled. The 17-story hotel, designed 77 years ago by Sanford White and the home over the years of Caruso, Stravinsky, Theodore Dreiser, Toscanini, Babe Ruth and Florenz Ziegfeld had deteriorated when it was bought three years ago by the current owners.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Feb. 10 on the status of women in law and the judiciary misstated recommendations of the American Bar Association's committee on the Federal judiciary. Seventy percent of the men nominated for judgeships in Federal appeals courts were rated well qualified, as were 40 percent of the women; 54 percent of the men and 8 percent of the women nominated for Federal district judgeships were rated well qualified. All women nominated to both benches were rated qualified.

title: NEARLY AS FINE AS A VALET; by Barbara L. Eisenberg and Mary Smith
description: IN bygone times a gentleman had a valet to keep his clothes looking perfect. Today, good grooming is generally up to the individual. We have found two products to make that job easier.

title: QUEEN'S CANALETTO SHOW WARMS LONDON WINTER
description: LONDON WARMING the winter chill here is a sunlit exhibition of the Venetian painter Giovanni Antonio Canal, known as Canaletto, some 45 paintings, 50 drawings and 10 etchings from the private collection of Queen Elizabeth. Experts here agree that the collection is the finest of Canaletto's work ever assembled, covering the artist's full range, and this exhibition marks the first time the Queen's Canalettos have been seen together by the public.

title: Bid for Riggs Is Defended
description: Joe L. Allbritton, a Washington businessman, said today that he would stand by his $40.5 million offer to buy a controlling interest in the Riggs National Bank despite rejection of the bid by the board of directors of this city's largest commercial bank.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beker Industries, Greenwich, Conn., a manufacturer of chemical fertilizers, has elected to the board Cecil D. Andrus, former Governor of Idaho and United States Secretary of the Interior.

title: LEVELING OFF OF DRUG USE FOUND AMONG STUDENTS
description: Use of illicit drugs by young people in this country shows clear signs of leveling off, according to the results of a survey of high school seniors reported today.

title: Delays on the IRT
description: A subway car with a faulty undercarriage damaged portions of the electrical third rail on the IRT's Lexington Avenue express line, forcing the cancellation of uptown express service in the evening rush hour between the Grand Central station and 125th Street.

title: STARTING TUBEROUS BEGONIAS
description: UNLIKE their cousins, the bedding begonias, tuberous begonias are a breed apart. In shady places where the sun barely touches, tuberous begonias and caladiums can make dramatic statements.

title: SOVIET FREES JEW HELD IN 1970 PLOT
description: Iosif Mendelevich, the last of nine Soviet Jews to be released after imprisonment for a 1970 hijacking plot, arrived here today.

title: Victoria Station Names President
description: Thomas A. Collins, 39 years old, has been named president and chief executive officer of Victoria Station Inc., a chain of more than 100 limited-menu restaurants in the United States and Canada specializing in prime ribs. He succeeds Richard J. Bradley, also 39, who held the post until the beginning of this year and who will continue as chairman of the Larkspur, Calif., corporation until August, when he is expected to resign in favor of Mr. Collins.

title: INSERT STOVES OFFER FIREPLACE EFFICIENCY
description: IF it seems that you just can't get enough heat out of your fireplace this winter, you might consider installing a fireplace stove. It combines the visible charm of a fireplace with the heating efficiency of an airtight stove. But it is a compromise, in that it is not quite as efficient as a free-standing stove and it is not as dramatic as a roaring fireplace.

title: GARWOOD WILL RECEIVE PSYCHIATRIC TREATMENT UNDER A MARINE LEAVE
description: Pfc. Robert R. Garwood will be placed on leave Friday and sent to a civilian hospital in Virginia for voluntary psychiatric treatment, the Marine Corps announced today.

title: Slaying of Milan Hospital Director Is Explained by the Red Brigades
description: Red Brigades terrorists said today that they assassinated Dr. Luigi Marangoni, medical director of Milan's main hospital, yesterday as a protest against attempts to reorganize the state medical service.

title: Computer Sciences' Suspension Lifted
description: The General Services Administration has withdrawn its suspension banning the Computer Sciences Corporation from bidding for new computer time-sharing business from the Federal Government.

title: RIDING THE RAILS IS FREIGHTED WITH DANGER
description: To the Editor:

title: Rosalynn Carter Undergoes Minor Cosmetic Surgery
description: Over last weekend, Rosalynn Carter was in Doctors Memorial Hospital in Atlanta for what a family spokesman described as ''minor eye surgery'' to remove some membrane from both lower eyelids. Mrs. Carter had similar surgery about three years ago.

title: Restaurateur Facing Tax Stealing Charge
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan ruled that Frank Valenza, the owner of Proof of the Pudding and the Palace restaurants, could be charged with grand larceny, a felony, because he did not pay state sales taxes totaling $246,000.

title: Petroleum Data Delayed
description: Due to a delay in statistics gathering, the weekly American Petroleum Institute figures do not appear today. Figures are expected to appear tomorrow..

title: OPERA: 'ETRE OU NE PAS ETRE'-'HAMLET IN FRENCH AT CARNEGIE
description: ROBERT LAWRENCE and his Friends of French Opera have performed a tremendously valuable service to American music over the years. The once-popular French repertory had fallen out of favor, except for an occasional ''Faust'' or ''Samson et Dalila,'' but Mr. Lawrence's militancy helped restore a good many works to favor, not the least of which was Berlioz's ''Les Troyens.'' Of course, any advocate of neglected works runs the risk of unearthing some scores that hold more historic interest than artistic value. Ambroise Thomas's ''Hamlet,'' which Mr. Lawrence conducted in a conscientious but dramatically slack fashion on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, sounded like one of those antiquated items.

title: 'Evening of Love Songs' To Honor Harold Clurman
description: ''An Evening of Love Songs'' in memory of Harold Clurman and to benefit the Harold Clurman Theater, will be held next Thursday at the Metropolitan Club, 1 East 60th Street. It will star Barbara Cook, Yip Harburg, Sheldon Harnick, Michael Moriarty and Joseph Papp.

title: Gretzky Scores 5 Against St. Louis
description: Wayne Gretzky scored five goals, including a record-equaling four in the third period, as the Edmonton Oilers snapped the nine-game unbeaten streak of the St.Louis Blues, 9-2, tonight.

title: China Offshore Oil Hint
description: Total China, a subsidiary of France's Compagnie Fran,caise des Petroles, said today that it had discovered ''significant hydrocarbon shows'' at the site of its first well off the China coast.

title: BEATIFICATION OF 16 CELEBRATED BY POPE
description: Pope John Paul II, on a six-day visit to this overwhelmingly Roman Catholic nation, yesterday celebrated the beatification of 16 martyrs slain in Japan in the 1630's for their faith and spoke to the poor in one of Manila's largest slums.

title: Steinbrenner: Strike Threat Unifies Owners
description: George Steinbrenner, principal owner of the New York Yankees, said today that major league owners are ''more unified and more prepared'' for a strike by the players than at any other time since he has been affiliated with baseball.

title: U.S. IS URGED TO DELAY RETURN OF IRANIAN ASSETS
description: Attorneys and a businessman representing American companies with financial claims against Iran urged today that the United States delay the return of some $3 billion in Iranian assets to test Iran's intentions to settle such claims in an arbitration tribunal.

title: FRED SPARKS
description: Fred Sparks, a newspaperman who in 1951 won a Pulitzer Prize in international reporting for his stories from Berlin for The Chicago Daily News, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. Mr. Sparks, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 65 years old.

title: TO SOME STUDENTS, COLLEGE IS A LESSON IN HIGH DEBT
description: ''If you're paying $7,000 already, when they start tacking on the extra thousands, you don't feel it - you just lose track,'' said Patricia Behre, a Yale College junior from New Orleans, referring to the 13.5 percent rise in fees for 1981-82.

title: MANY NURSES SAY 30% OF OPERATIONS ARE NOT NEEDED
description: NEARLY half the nurses surveyed in a nationwide poll say 3 out of 10 operations are not needed, and many of them say about half of all hospital stays are unnecessary.

title: Peking Reports Some Dissidents Call for a New Cultural Revolution
description: The Chinese Communist Party called today for the suppression of dissident elements that it said were causing trouble and in some cases even calling for a second Cultural Revolution.

title: Arctic Snowmobile Files to Reorganize
description: Arctic Enterprises, the nation's largest manufacturer of snowmobiles, has filed for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws and has sued its lenders for $150 million.

title: Merger in Indianapolis
description: According to the news release, Indianapolis is getting a ''super agency.'' As the result of a pending merger, Montgomery, McQuade, Zukerman & Bloomhorst will be billing in the neighborhood of $25 million. The two agencies getting together are Ruben, Montgomery Associates and McQuade-Bloomhorst Advertising

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard LUCY. The Beginnings of Mankind. By Don- ald Johanson and Maitland Edey. Illus- trated. 409 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Violinist: Joseph Fuchs Plays Wieniawski 'Faust'
description: When the violinist Joseph Fuchs played Wieniawski's ''Faust'' Fantasie in Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, he hardly sounded like an octogenarian fiddler. Supple waltz steps sounded in crystalline harmonics, interrupted by sliding sweeps.

title: REPUBLICANS PLANNING WAYS TO GET PACKAGE PASSED IN FOUR WEEKS
description: Senate Republican leaders planned a legislative strategy today that they hoped would result in Senate approval of a ''substantial'' portion of President Reagan's proposed budget cuts in four weeks.

title: By HILTON KRAMER
description: THERE are exhibitions that give us pleasure, and there are exhibitions that offer us instruction, but there are few exhibitions that combine these functions with quite the same degree of success as that achieved by the show called ''Turner and the Sublime,'' which has now come to the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven.

title: TOP NEW YORK COURT SHARPENS TERMS OF SHOPLIFTING
description: A shoplifting suspect can be found guilty of larceny even without having left a store with stolen goods, New York State's highest court ruled today.

title: AMERICA'S TRANSPORT SYSTEM: THE BOTTOM LINE
description: To the Editor:

title:
RED SMITH;
A Shot Heard Round Baseball
description: THE men who own baseball have fired the gun they have been brandishing since last May, almost surely opening a pitched battle between the clubs and the players. Yesterday Ray Grebey, director of the owners' player relations committee, notified Marvin Miller, head of the players' union, that the clubs had decided to implement their plan for compensating teams that lose players to free agency.

title: 2 Die in New Mexico Motel Fire
description: An early morning fire of undetermined origin today burned through a popular motel at this northern New Mexico ski resort, killing a couple and injuring 12 others, the authorities said. Witnesses said that the Ponderosa Lodge, a two-story wood structure, was destroyed within minutes.

title: TRANSPORT AIDES ARE CONCERNED
description: Spokesmen for airlines, barge companies and for some airplane manufacturers yesterday expressed varying degrees of disapproval of the President's proposed new taxes and users' fees affecting their industries.

title: Iowa Beats Indiana And Leads Big Ten
description: Vince Brookins scored 19 points and Steve Krafcisin 18 as Iowa hit 15 of 16 free throws in the final two minutes and beat Indiana, 78-65, tonight. The victory gave the Hawkeyes sole possession of first place in the Big Ten Conference.

title: F.C.C. EXEMPTIONS URGED FOR CABLE TV
description: A high-level Federal regulator, in a report that could cheer both the cable television and newspaper industries, has urged Congress to avoid applying law on political broadcasting to programs or newspaper articles distributed by cable.

title: UNIROYAL POSTS GAIN IN QUARTER
description: Uniroyal Inc., the nation's third-largest tire maker, reported yesterday that improved domestic and Mexican tire operations helped the company to realize a $4.7 million profit for the fourth quarter of 1980, compared with a loss of $112 million in the fourth quarter of 1979.

title: Boy's Mishap Renews Fears On Two-Decade Mine Fire
description: A fire that has burned through 40 acres of abandoned mine tunnels under Centralia for 19 years aroused renewed alarm after a 12-year-old boy escaped a cave-in.

title: STAGE: JEWISH REPERTORY IN PINTER'S 'BIRTHDAY PARTY'
description: THE Jewish Repertory Theater is presenting Harold Pinter's ''The Birthday Party'' at its Emanu-el Midtown Y headquarters as part of a series of plays that relate to the Jewish experience. It's an interesting perspective on this early Pinter ''comedy of menace.''

title: MOYNIHAN SAYS CUTS ARE THREAT TO CITY
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said last night that the Reagan Administration's proposed cutbacks in urban aid programs could again threaten New York City with bankruptcy.

title: David Garnett, 88, Novelist, Dies; A Member of Bloomsbury Group
description: David Garnett, one of the last surviving members of the Bloomsbury group of British writers and artists, died Tuesday in Le Verger de Charry, Montcuq, France, where he made his home. He was 88 years old.

title: BOSTON MAY LOSE 2 PRO TEAMS
description: Two of Boston's three remaining major league sports teams may leave within a year and a half if a plan to build a $52 million race track, sports arena, convention center and hotel complex 35 miles north of the city in Salem, N.H., is approved.

title: No Headline
description: The hopes and concerns that an estimated 12 million PolishAmericans share with the nearly 40 million Poles in Poland during the current trade-union unrest are being reinforced by a vigorous and growing movement and an exchange of information between the two peoples.

title: MAN AND MITOCHONDRIA
description: Half a century ago, Walter Lippmann noted that science was developing a fragmented view of the universe that undermined thematic 19thcentury philosophies. ''Our political thinking today has no intellectual foundations,'' he said.

title: A THIRD WORLD OF MUSIC THIS WEEKEND
description: People sometimes talk as if the total range of musical styles extended from rock to classical, with jazz somewhere in between. But that is a parochial view of the matter, given the fact that rock, jazz and classical are all forms of Western music and that New York offers exciting examples of non-Western music almost every weekend.

title: SOVIET JEWS FOUND TO RETAIN IDENTITY
description: An unusual opinion survey of 1,500 Jews in the Soviet Union has found a high degree of Jewish identity and interest in Jewish culture, even among those who oppose emigration to Israel.

title: Humbling Tales of Fighting Crime
description: Hard though the task may be, New Jersey's political leaders, judges, prosecutors and public are giving crime-fighting a bad name - in the name of getting tough, of course.

title: OF GUNS, GHOSTS, ENGLISH ACCENTS AND PENGUINS
description: WHEN the late critic Harold Clurman entered a theater, he would ask - addressing the question to his companion or, rhetorically, to the absent playwright - ''Are there any guns in this play?'' He had a deep antipathy to the theatrical use of firearms, and if he spotted a weapon, he would respond with a look of dismay and a glance toward the exit.

title: 2 TOP CHIEFS OF LONGSHOREMEN'S UNION BALK AT SENATORS' QUESTIONS
description: Two officials in the longshoremen's union with reputed ties to organized crime refused today to give information to a Senate subcommittee that had received testimony linking them to payoffs on the Miami waterfront.

title: Colgate Reports Gain in Quarter
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company, an international producer and distributor of household and personal-care products, reported yesterday that it had a net income of $34.5 million, or 42 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980, contrasted to a loss of $26.9 million in the fourth quarter of 1979. Sales increased 13.8 percent, to $1.32 billion, from $1.16 billion.

title: SYNTHETIC FUEL UNITS AT STAKE
description: The future of some major synthetic fuels projects appear uncertain in the wake of the Reagan Administration's plan to eliminate Department of Energy subsidies for such projects and revise the role of the fledgling Synthetic Fuels Corporation, according to some compa-nies involved.

title: RIGHETTI BATTLES NUMBERS GAME
description: ''I like to see every kid in spring training think he has a chance,'' said Gene Michael, the Yankee manager, who watches Dave Righetti throw here each morning. But Righetti, a 22-year-old left-hander, is aware of the numbers and knows he has less chance than most.

title: A PERILOUS EXTENSION OF FREE SPEECH
description: To the Editor:

title: WARM RESPONSE TO BUDGET PLAN
description: Corporate America yesterday welcomed President Reagan's economic program - particularly his proposals to encourage investment - as a long-needed change in Government policy.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * General Felt Industries is offering $85 million of variable-rate debentures due Feb. 5, 2001, through Drexel Burnham. The 12 percent debentures are priced at 70 to yield 17.42 percent to maturity, but the rate will be adjusted quarterly, based on a 133 percent pre- mium over 20-year Treasury issues.

title: VISITORS TO IRAQI-IRANIAN FRONT FIND A STALEMATED WAR OF ARTILLERY FIRE
