description: A visit to the Iraqi-occupied Iranian oil port of Khurramshahr has provided new evidence that the war between the two countries continues in stalemate and is being fought largely through exchanges of artillery fire.

title: PUBLISHING: AUTHORS GET STAR TREATMENT IN JAPAN
description: ALVIN TOFFLER arrived in Japan last November, soon after his latest book, ''The Third Wave,'' made the Japanese best-seller list. Four months later, the author-futurist is still in a state of shock at how seriously the Japanese public takes books and how well Japanese publishers promote them.

title: No Headline
description: STRIKES IN POLAND NEAR END: Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski greeting a worker at a pharmaceutical factory near Warsaw. Only one strike was reported continuing in the country yesterday, and a spokesman for Solidarity, the independent labor movement, said that the strike, by farmers, was expected to be settled shortly.

title: The Region; Three-Hour Strike At Shoreham Plant
description: A union dispute halted construction work at the Long Island Lighting Company's nuclear power plant here for three hours.

title: REAGAN, RISKING ALL, SHOVES IN HIS STACK; by Tom Wicker
description: In politics and poker, Lyndon Johnson used to say, ''sometimes you have to shove in your whole stack.'' President Reagan has done it at the outset. He has staked the success or failure of his Administration on an economic program disputed even by some of his own supporters and which is likely to be judged, finally, by the difficult standard of whether or not it substantially reduces the rate of inflation.

title: ANOTHER PLANE CRASHES ON APPROACH TO WESTCHESTER
description: A small plane went down in fog and rain near Westchester County Airport last night less than a quarter of a mile from the site of the fiery crash that killed eight persons Feb 11 aboard a jet owned by the Texasgulf Inc. of Stamford, Conn.

title: Smith Photojournalism At Fifth Ave. Gallery
description: A comprehensive show of the photographs of the late W. Eugene Smith is on view through April 4 as the inaugural exhibition at Photograph, a new photographic art gallery at 724 Fifth Avenue.

title: The Evening Hours
description: ''L OUIE,'' said the man upstairs at the party at ''21'' the other night. ''I'd like you to meet Louie. And this fellow over here is Louie. Louie, say hello to Louie. And Louie.''

title: Books
description: Calligraphic Cries By Fred Ferretti ISLAND: Poetry and History of Chinese Im- migrants on Angel Island, 1910-40. By Him Mark Lai, Genny Lim, Judy Yung. The San Francisco Study Center, Hoc Doi, P.O. Box 5646, San Francisco. $15 (soft cover $8.95).

title: Advertising; WOR: Live From London
description: WOR Radio, friend of the older crowd, is about to try its most ambitious, live, on-location broadcasting caper, one which, Rick Devlin, vice president, general manager and man of superlatives, thinks could well be the ''biggest package ever sold by a station.'' He means advertising package and he was talking in the neighborhood of $150,000 for the five-day effort.

title: JAPAN'S MISREADING OF THE PALESTINIAN PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Fearful Nicaragua sets out to build 200,000-strong militia A2 Iranian says documents tying 4 Britons to spying were forged A3 Visitors to Iran-Iraq front find war is stalemated A3 Text of State Department docu- ment on Salvadoran guerrillas A4 Survey smuggled to Israel finds Soviet Jews retain identity A7 Around the World A8 Reagan urged to hold up sale of jet gear to Saudis A9 Government/Politics Labor leaders call economic plan unfair A10 U.S. aid to states to buy park land slashed in budget A10 Amtrak budget requests exceeds proposal by Reagan A10 Area Congressmen urge rejection of proposed transit aid cuts A17 Moynihan sees in Reagan budget a threat to New York City A17 Proposed cuts in arts and humani- ties endowments criticized A17 O'Neill says effects of Reagan budget cuts to be devastating A17 Two vie for Democratic National Committee chairmanship A21 Carey revises medicaid takeover plan B3 General Around the Nation A18 Investigation continued on Vir- ginia bus crash that killed 10 A18 Sinatra regains Nevada gaming li- cense A18 Texas paper gets court permit to publish list of bordello clients A20 New office building planned south of World Trade Center B3 3 accused of bilking woman with promise of supernatural cure B3 A new proposal for the Times Square area announced B3 Weekend Weekender Guide C1

title: ENDING TRADE PLAN STIRS LITTLE OPPOSITION
description: Early reaction around the nation indicated that President Reagan may find little resistance in his efforts to eliminate the Economic Development Administration and cut back the trade adjustment assistance program, two cornerstones of the Carter Administration's strategy for fighting economic decline in particular communities and industries. Many of the beneficiaries of the programs interviewed yesterday disputed Mr. Reagan's criticisms of them, but there was also widespread support of the President's contention that a broad range of Government programs needed to be pruned. As a result, there is little sign of active opposition to his proposals.

title: 83 FEDERAL PROGRAMS: A PROFILE OF REAGAN TARGETS
description: New Presidents almost always send Congress proposed changes in the budget submitted by their predecessors. But no President since Franklin D. Roosevelt has proposed changes as extensive as those President Reagan seeks, and none have packaged proposals in such a thorough document.

title: SHE'S A NEW KIND OF FINANCIER
description: Those who think conventionally might mistake her for a glamorous European sophisticate, which she is, or the financial adviser of a fashion business, which she is.

title: JOHN KNUDSEN NORTHROP, AVIATION DESIGN PIONEER, DIES
description: John Knudsen Northrop, founder of the aeronautical company that still bears his name and one of the most accomplished airplane designers the industry has known, died late Wednesday in a Glendale, Calif., hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: Akron Voters Approve Increase in City Income Tax
description: Voters narrowly approved an income tax increase tonight, raising the municipal tax on incomes to 1.8 percent from 1.5 percent this year and to 2 percent next year. Summit County Board of Elections officials said that the unofficial final tally from absentee ballots and 359 precincts was 16,955 for and 15,176 against the increase.

title: TREASURY SECRETARY OFFERS DEFENSE OF UNTESTED PREDICTIONS
description: President Reagan's chief economic spokesman defended the Administration's untested economic strategy today, although he conceded that there was no economic model to support the predictions involved.

title: The City; Water Checkup At Car-Wash Places
description: City inspectors began a check yesterday of about 150 car-washing establishments that failed to file water-recycling plans by the Feb. 18 deadline. Penalties for failing to file such plans could be fines of up to $1,000 and revocation of license. Only 12 car-wash places have filed, according to the Environmental Protection Department.

title: Harper-Atlantic Sales Has Reorganization
description: Harper-Atlantic Sales, the independent national advertsing sales arm of the two magazines, is in the process of change, apparently under the direction of Jerome S. Hardy, former president of the Dreyfus Corporation and publisher of Life magazine, who became chairman of Harper's magazine in December.

title: TV Exports Up 59% in Japan
description: Japan's exports of color television sets last year rose 59 percent over the 1979 figure, to 4.65 million sets, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan said today.

title: A Green Beret's Bravery Gains Additional Recognition
description: A belated Medal of Honor will be awarded by President Reagan to a former Army Green Beret from Texas who was earlier rejected for the nation's highest military honor.

title: by Thomas Bender
description: Recent controversies surrounding historic preservation in New York City, notably the question of landmark status for the Upper East Side and the Rouse Company's proposal to redevelop the South Street Seaport into a mixture of chic boutiques, markets, and restaurants, have traded upon a substantial and growing interest in urban history. Such evidence of pervasive public concern with city history and preservation is heartening, yet the orientation toward the past evident in these discussions in worrisome.

title: Bridge: Computer-Scored Pair Play Is Scheduled for Tomorrow
description: Experts in New York, a large and sophisticated group, seldom show interest in a one-session sectional open pair championship. But the Flight A Open Pair Championship to be played at 1 P.M. tomorrow at the New York Statler Hotel as part of a two-day tournament emphasizing events for novices will be an exception.

title: STAGE: 'STILL LIFE' BY EMILY MANN AT AMERICAN PLACE
description: EMILY MANN'S ''Still Life,'' which opened at the American Place Theater last night, aspires to be a searing account of the lingering aftermath of the Vietnam War. The author's heart seems to be in the right place, but what about her mind? Because of fuzzy-headed writing, Miss Mann has devised a play that not only leaves the audience cold, but also tends to trivialize such issues as the plight of the Vietnam veteran, war atrocities and feminism. Good intentions, I'm afraid, don't stand a chance in the face of sheer incompetence.

title: Around the World
description: The Soviet Foreign Ministry today dismissed an Italian report of a bomb explosion in Moscow last Monday in which a colonel of the K.G.B. security police was said to have been killed.

title: ECONOMIC PLAN REJECTED BY LABOR CHIEFS AS UNFAIR
description: Rejecting President Reagan's economic program, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said today that it was joining with other groups to fight for an alternative program ''that meets the nation's economic needs with fairness and equity.''

title: Around the World; Gunmen Fire on Limousine Of Prelate in Beirut
description: Unidentified gunmen today fired on the limousine of Patriarch Maximos V. Hakim, head of the Greek Catholic Church in the Middle East and the Western Hemisphere, riddling the car with bullets but not hitting the 78-year-old prelate or members of his party.

title: w/pope; Land Mine Kills 16 in Philippines
description: Sixteen civilian security guards were killed and four injured today when their truck ran over a land mine on an American-owned rubber estate in an area of the southern Philippines that is heavily infiltrated by Moslem guerrillas, the police said.

title: The City; 4 Charged in Effort To Smuggle Aliens
description: Four men have been indicted on Federal charges of violating immigration laws in connection with the Feb. 2 seizure of a trailer truck carrying 84 aliens in the South Bronx.

title: VIETNAM AMPUTEE SELECTED BY REAGAN FOR VETERANS POST
description: John Behan, a Long Island athlete who lost both legs in the Vietnam war, is to be nominated tomorrow to head the Veterans Administration, a White House official said today.

title: Texan Convicted of Forcing Aliens to Work as Slaves
description: Benjamin Harrison Nelson, a processing plant operator, has been convicted of kidnapping two illegal aliens and forcing them to work as slaves.

title: No Headline
description: A Bogota newspaper El Bogotano, today published part of a manifesto, of the April 19 movement, asthe guerrillas had demanded,raising hopes that they would not kill Mr. Bitterman.A photograph in the newspaper purported to show him alive and smiling as of Monday.

title: CULTURAL LEADERS DISTURBED BY SLASHES PLANNED FOR ARTS AGENCIES
description: President Reagan's proposed 50 percent cut in the appropriations from the Carter budgets for the National Endowments for the Arts and Humanities has created consternation and some resentment among New York cultural leaders.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Tues- day included outdated information on a Federal investigation of tire grading. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration notified the General Tire and Rubber Company and the Armstrong Rubber Company on Fri- day that it had accepted their tire rat- ings and had dropped its investigation.

title: HARVESTER HAS NET LOSS IN QUARTER OF $96.4 MILLION
description: International Harvester today reported a net loss of $96.4 million for the first quarter of its 1981 fiscal year, which ended on Jan. 31, continuing a string of quarterly losses that totaled $397 million in the 1980 fiscal year.

title: Robeson Tribute Sunday
description: A tribute honoring the late Paul Robeson will be held at the American Museum of Natural History on Sunday.

title: WHERE TO SCOUT THE YOUNGEST TALENT
description: In bright yellow sweatshirts and gleaming smiles, 18 youngsters on a stage in the middle of a restaurant sang out their purpose: ''Lookin' for bookin's, what you get is what you see!'' while casting directors in the audience watched and mothers beamed.

title: Cholera Toll 51 in Mozambique
description: An outbreak of cholera in Mozambique has taken the lives of 51 people since December, the official Mozambique news agency reported today. The agency said that more than 300 victims of the disease had been hospitalized.

title: RECITAL: CASSOLAS IN AMERICAN SONGS
description: CONSTANTINE CASSOLAS, the tenor, joined Elizabeth Wright at the piano Wednesday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall to sing the usually unsung praises of American song.

title: DAVID HOCKNEY'S DESIGNS FOR MET OPERA'S 'PARADE'
description: DAVID HOCKNEY, at the age of 43, is a great many people's favorite English painter. With his paintings, his drawings, his prints and his stage designs (for Stravinsky's ''Rake's Progress'' and Mozart's ''Magic Flute,'' both at the Glyndebourne Opera in England), he has endeared himself to all but a skeptical minority.

title: Rear Adm. Joseph McKinney, 76, Headed School of Naval Warfare
description: Rear Adm. Joseph D. McKinney, retired, a former commander of the Naval Amphibious Warfare School, died Tuesday.

title: GULF CANADA BLOCK HAS CHANGED HANDSZ
description: A 1.2-million-share block of Gulf Canada Ltd. stock that traded on the American Stock Exchange this morning may represent an attempt to increase Canadian ownership in the company under Ottawa's National Energy Program, market analysts suggested here today.

title: STAR OF 'ALTERED STATES'
description: IN ''Altered States,'' Blair Brown plays the perfect wife: a successful anthropologist, a responsible mother, a loving and loyal helpmate. Such equanimity becomes somewhat hard to sustain when her husband - a possibly mad scientist obsessed with his experiments in altered states of consciousness and the genetic regression he believes they can induce -begins to revert to an apelike state, running wild in the streets, bludgeoning passers-by and devouring animals.

title: THE LIFE OF A JAPANESE JOURNALIST IN NEW YORK
description: The whispers from Japan continue to follow her across the Pacific and across the United States. ''Why isn't she home with her husband?'' ''She's lucky because she's a woman.'' ''Those articles were actually written by a man. Asahi arranged the interviews and wrote the questions.''

title: WINGS DEFEAT RANGERS,7-3
description: Dale McCourt scored three goals in a game for the sixth time in his career as the Red Wings defeated the New York Rangers, 7-3, tonight. Detroit broke open the game with three goals in a span of 27 seconds of the third period.

title: REMEMBERING CLAIRE MCCARDELL
description: It was a gathering of stars and lesser luminaries from fashion's golden age. Joseph E. Brooks, the chairman of Lord & Taylor, invited them to lunch at the store to honor the late Claire McCardell, the fashion designer who helped introduce the American look more than 40 years ago.

title: The Region; 9 Seized in Jersey In a Drug Raid
description: NEWARK (AP) - City, county and Federal narcotics officers arrested nine persons to break what they described as a major street-level drug ring selling $12,000 a day in heroin and marijuana.

title: ART: TOTEMS FOR TODAY FROM RICHARD SERRA
description: THE man or woman has yet to be born who does not react strongly in one way or another to the work of Richard Serra. In sculpture, he has a gift for the commanding statement. Not only do we have a sense of enormous forces that are only just in equilibrium, but also we feel that those forces and their possibly perilous future correspond in some way both to the general state of the world and to our own inmost predicaments. They are scary, those sculptures.

title: Fund Buys Interest In Victoria Station
description: Victoria Station Inc. announced that American Values N.V., a Bermuda-based mutual fund, had purchased a 16 percent interest in the company.

title: SPECIAL CHARM OF THE OKRA BAND
description: OLU DARA is a jazz trumpeter best known for his work as a sideman. But off and on since 1978, with different personnel, he has led his own group called the Okra Orchestra, which is subtitled an ''exotic rhythm band.'' Wednesday night the orchestra, now consisting of a particularly impressive constellation of eight performers, began a five-week, two-nights-a-week run at 450, the new jazz club on the 12th floor of 450 West 31st Street.

title: ART: 'THE CLAY FIGURE' AT THE CRAFT MUSEUM
description: SINCE the early 1960's, artists have been breaking down the tradition of clay as a ''pottery'' medium, extending it into the sacrosanct sculptural provinces of stone, wood and metal. The malleability of clay, its range of surface possibilities, its ability to imitate other mediums and the ease of its transformation from raw substance to finished work have contributed to its elevation by artists today from ''craft'' to a more esthetic status.

title: ARISTRAR PICKS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Robert B. Holmes, 49, has been named president and chief executive officer of Aristar Inc., a consumer finance and insurance corporation. He succeeds E. Arnold Lewin, 64, who retired from the Coral Gables, Fla., company.

title: by David Gold and Robert De Grasse Jr.
description: President Reagan's economic program is fatally flawed because his passion for military strength directly conflicts with his goal of economic recovery. His new budget plan will encourage investment in defense production and make it more difficult to find the capital required to revitalize the civilian economy.

title: Tests Planned in New Hampshire On Infants for Arsenic in Water
description: Medical experts said yesterday that they would conduct tests on more than 100 infants in Hudson, N.H., who might have been drinking water contaminated with arsenic.

title: LIVELY STEAKHOUSE, CELEBRITY HANGOUT; by Mimi Sheraton; Lively steakhouse, celebrity hangout.
description: ANYONE who is bothered by noise will be especially unhappy at Auctions, an otherwise stylish and appealing little bar and steakhouse that opened three months ago at the corner of Third Avenue and 80th Street. But not everyone is disturbed by noise and there are some people who even thrive on it, judging by the three-deep crowd at the bar most evenings and the full house that convenes in the adjacent cafe-dining room. Even after so short a trial period, expansion plans are already under way.

title: REAGAN IS URGED TO REJECT SALE OF JET GEAR TO SAUDIS
description: The Reagan Administration was urged in Congress today not to approve Saudi Arabia's request for equipment that could improve the range and firepower of the 60 F-15 fighters it is buying from the United States, a request that Saudi leaders have said is a test of their relations with the new Administration.

title: Antiques Show at Garden
description: The 37th annual National Antiques Show in Madison Square Garden's Exposition Rotunda winds up this weekend.

title: A Weighty Sermon
description: Karol Wojtyla lived 58 years as boy, man, priest and cardinal before he was elevated to the papacy, but it is difficult to imagine him as ever having been anything but a pope. The Pope.

title: The Truly Needy
description: Repeal the New Deal: that used to be an article of conservative faith, a familiar starting point for Republican programs. Not any more. Ronald Reagan, apple of the conservative eye, now says the social welfare programs erected in the 1930's are matters of national conscience, part of the permanent social safety net to protect the truly needy. No, his Administration does not seek to repeal the New Deal. Its aim is to repeal much of the Great Society. Mr. Reagan's budget-cut-ting proposals threaten to tear holes in the social safety net, jeopardizing hundreds of thousands of people who are, by any reasonable definition, truly needy.

title: FOR LOST $1.5 BILLION LAST YEAR
description: The Ford Motor Company today reported a loss of $1.5 billion for 1980, the largest loss in American corporate history. The company attributed the loss to a dramatic decline in the sales of its cars and trucks.

title: STUDENTS' HELPERS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 DEMOCRATS SEEK PARTY CHAIRMANSHIP
description: The field for the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee dwindled to two persons yesterday, with only Joseph F. Crangle of Buffalo remaining as a rival to Charles T. Manatt, the Los Angeles lawyer who appears to hold a commanding advantage.

title: The City; Sanitation Hearings For Restaurants Up
description: The number of restaurants that failed to improve sanitary conditions after an initial inspection jumped by almost 1,200 last year, Health Commissioner Reinaldo A. Ferrer said.

title: ROCK MUSIC IN MANHATTAN
description: Six of New York's most popular new rock groups are performing in London tonight, but here in Manhattan the beat goes on. Tonight, the Ramones are at the Bond International Casino, Broadway and 45th Street, 944-5880.

title: Market Place; Helping Utilities Limit Fuel Use
description: SOMETIMES a company with a solid hold on a good but unexciting market begins to do unusually well by meeting the changing needs of that market. Thus, after years of modest growth, the Electronics Corporation of America is blossoming as a result of the energy crisis and the company's move into advanced microprocessor technology.

title: EX-CARTER AIDES DISCOUNT PACT CONCERNING SHAH'S WEALTH
description: The Carter Administration's agreement to help Iran track down the wealth of the late Shah and his close relatives will have almost no practical effect, according to former Carter Administration officials who testified at a Senate Banking Committee hearing today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt JOHN VON NEUMANN AND NORBERT WIENER. From Mathematics to the Technologies of Life and Death. By Steve J. Heims. 547 pages. Illustrated. M.I.T. Press. $19.95.

title: 3 Ex-Players Said to Testify In Inquiry
description: Federal authorities investigating alleged point-shaving by former Boston College basketball players are more interested in gaining convictions against two reputed crime figures than the players, according to a report in The Boston Globe today.

title: Murphy Breaks Free-Throw Mark
description: Houston's Calvin Murphy broke Rick Barry's National Basketball Association record for consecutive free throws tonight when he hit his 61st straight in the third quarter of the Rockets' 116-99 loss to the San Diego Clippers.

title: by Robert Pear
description: Two law professors told Congress today that Justice Department guidelines governing the use of undercover investigative techniques did not adequately protect privacy or prevent the entrapment of innocent people.

title: Brooklyn Ode to Baseball
description: In recognition of the approach of spring, a reading of poetry and prose about baseball will take place tonight at 8 in St. Ann's School in Brooklyn.

title: POLES IN A JERSEY SUBURB KEEP AN ANXIOUS WATCH
description: A few shopkeepers in this suburb have signs in their windows reading ''Polska Mowa.'' Those who do not have such signs - indicating that Polish is spoken inside - suggest that they are about as necessary in Wallington as ''English Spoken Here'' signs in Indianapolis.

title: PROS AND CONS OF THE FAMILY BED
description: Tine Thevenin says she has received hundreds of letters of confessions from parents who praise her controversial book advocating that children and parents share one bed.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate, 19.00-19.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE ONE-MAN WAYNE GRETZKY SHOW
description: ''You know how to spell his name?'' an Edmonton Oilers publicist asked a telephone caller yesterday. ''It's G-R-E-T-Z-K-Y. Don't forget, Z, not S.''

title: WELCOME FOR POPE IS BIGGEST OF TOUR
description: Pope John Paul II received the most spontaneously enthusiastic welcome today of his three-day-old visit to the Philippines in this most fervent city of this deeply Roman Catholic nation. He responded with two sermons in his most conservative vein.

title: OTHER BUDGET DEVELOPMENTS
description: THE NEW YORK REGION: Reacting to President Reagan's budget message, Mayor Koch said that New York City would have little trouble balancing its budget for the fiscal year 1982 despite the proposed Federal cuts in aid. Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut warned that the proposals could mean the loss of millions in Federal aid in his state, and Governor Byrne of New Jersey forecast a loss for his state of about $1.2 billion. Page A17.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 20, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on the Charter of the U.N. - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Thriller at New Vic
description: ''Dreams,'' a play by Thomas Sharkey, described as a psychological thriller, will be presented today through March 22 by the Shelter West Theater Company at the New Vic Theater, 219 Second Avenue, at 13th Street. Performances are Wednesday through Saturday at 8 P.M., Sundays at 3 P.M. Admission is $4; for students and the elderly, $3 (Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted). For information and reservations, call 673-6341.

title: Leftists Say U.S. Sent 100 Advisers
description: Leftist leaders charged today that 100 United States military advisers were helping prepare a counterinsurgency plan to ''cut off the head of the leftist and intellectual sectors in El Salvador.'' The Salvadoran junta and United States Embassy sources here denied the accusation.

title: 20 YEARS OF STAGE DESIGN BY MONTRESSOR ON DISPLAY
description: In an era when operatic settings more often than not tend toward the forbiddingly abstract and chillingly spare, Beni Montresor's sensual uses of fabrics, forms, color and light proclaim him to be one of the few genuine romantics in the field of operatic stage design. Many New Yorkers are familiar with his lush productions of ''La Gioconda,'' ''Esclarmonde'' and ''The Last Savage'' at the Metropolitan Opera, and the City Opera's repertory contains three notable Montresor conceptions, ''The Magic Flute,'' ''Turandot'' and ''The Daughter of the Regiment.''

title: OFFICE BUILDING PLANNED SOUTH OF TRADE CENTER
description: A 35-story office building directly south of the World Trade Center and overlooking Battery Park City will be constructed starting in April, the Milstein Properties Corporation announced yesterday.

title: IMPRESSIONISTS TO POSTWAR ART
description: IMPRESSIONIST, modern and post World War II art goes on the block at three of New York's top art-auction houses in the next two weeks, although the sales mostly offer works of moderate and lower prices. The first sale is next Wednesday at 2 P.M. at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, where the top lot is a small Renoir painting depicting a young girl, an oil that was once owned by Paulette Goddard, the actress. It is estimated to sell for as much as $100,000. Other notable offerings are Marie Laurencin's ''Woman With Cats,'' a 1920 oil on canvas (up to $70,000); Fernand Leger's ''Man and Melon, No. 2,'' a 1938 oil on canvas (up to $75,000), and Chaim Soutine's ''The Little Girl at the Gate,'' an oil on canvas laid down on board, from about 1939, which was exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art's 1950-51 Soutine retrospective (up to $55,000).

title: High-Speed Winds Blow Man Off Roof in Seattle
description: Driving rain and winds clocked at speeds of up to 110 miles per hour knocked out electricity and toppled two broadcast towers in the Puget Sound area early today, and more than 150,000 people in Western Washington were without power.

title: A DIFFERENT DEBUSSY AT TULLY HALL
description: ''M. Claude Debussy has become the leader of a new religion,'' wrote Jean Lorrain in 1904. ''His neophytes are to be found in the orchestra stall and the first-tier boxes. Their long hair is affectedly parted down the middle, they are plump in face, of matte complexion, and they have deep-set eyes. On the little fingers of their beautiful hands they wear an Egyptian or Byzantine ring, a turquoise scarab or a jewel in green gold.''

title: Fordham 67, Manhattan 54
description: David Maxwell scored 15 points and had 11 rebounds to lead Fordham over visiting Manhattan, 67-54, last night.

title: COALITION TO OPPOSE CUTS IN AID TO POOR
description: A broad coalition of trade unions, civil rights groups and social welfare organizations moved today to blunt the impact of President Reagan's economic program on welfare, food stamps, child nutrition and medical help for the poor.

title: WESTCHESTER CALLS AN EMERGENCY AS A RESULT OF MEASLES OUTBREAK
description: Westchester County is experiencing the biggest outbreak of measles in the country, with more than 50 cases so far this year, and today it declared a health emergency.

title: 83 Programs: A Profile
description: President Reagan's cutback proposal contrasted his six-year spending projections with the Carter Administration's for 83 major programs. Three pages of capsule summaries, with the figures, begin on page A11.

title: POLAROID
description: The Polaroid Corporation, the nation's leading manufacturer of instant developing photographic equipment and film, with about twothirds of the market, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter rose 11.8 percent, to $32.3 million, or 98 cents a share, from $28.9 million, or 88 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979.

title: The Region; Hempstead Studied As a Recycling Site
description: The chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York said his agency was studying the suitablity of building its first garbage recycling plant in the Town of North Hempstead.

title: FIRE AT OPENING OF HARLEY HOTEL IS TERMED ARSON
description: The cause of the fire at the $75 million Harley of New York Hotel when it was officially opened Wednesday was listed as arson yesterday by the New York City Fire Department.

title: OIL RIG THRILLER, NICARAGUA REVOLUTION
description: TV has a monster movie tonight at 8:30 called ''The Intruder Within.'' It seems that an offshore oil rig has been drilling at extreme depths and some strange things have been happening. One young crew member has a dream that all on board will not survive. Someone makes a passing, ominous reference to the Devil.

title: U.S. Rests Case in Trial Over Abuse of Mexicans
description: The Government rested its case today against 26-year-old Patrick Hanigan, one of two brothers accused of torturing and robbing three Mexican illegal aliens.

title: CONNECTICUT FEARS 'DEVASTATING EFFECT'
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that President Reagan's proposed budget cuts would have ''a devastating effect'' on Connecticut's fiscal problems.

title: COURT FREES NEWSPAPER TO PRINT NAMES FROM BORDELLO CLIENT LIST
description: A Federal district judge in Texas ruled yesterday that a monthly newspaper in San Antonio could publish names from a list of what it said were 3,000 clients of a local bordello.

title: McCartney Keeping Rights to Wisconsin's State Song
description: A follow-up: Paul McCartney has turned down a request by the Governor of Wisconsin that he turn over to the state the rights to the official state and university song, ''On, Wisconsin.''

title: No Headline
description: MINE WORKERS PROTEST PROPOSED CUTS: Sam Church, third from right, president of United Mine Workers, leading pickets near White House. They were protest-ing proposed cuts in Government contributions to benefits for workers with black lung disease. Mr. Church said miners would strike if cuts were carried out.

title: Economic Analysis
description: In political shorthand, President Reagan's economic program has been characterized as an effort to repeal the Great Society but not the New Deal.

title: LONGER-TERM FALL IS SMALLER
description: Short-term interest rates declined yesterday on hopes that the Federal Reserve was encouraging a decline in overnight interest rates, but in the long-term bond market the drop in rates was much more subdued as investors and traders worried that inflation might not quickly subside.

title: Royal Birthday Deferral
description: He's second in line to the British throne, but when Prince Andrew turned 21 yesterday, there was no gala coming-of-age celebration. Instead, the Prince, who is studying to become a helicopter pilot, spent the day attending classroom lectures at the Royal Naval Air Station in southwest England and making a training flight in one of the two helicopters at his disposal.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1981
description: International The insurgency in El Salvador has been transformed into ''a textbook case of indirect armed aggression by Communist powers,'' according to a State Department memorandum. The memorandum summarizes what it says is documentary evidence that Nicaragua's leaders have cooperated with Cuba in shipping arms through Nicaragua to the leftist insurgents in El Salvador. (Page A1, Column 1.) A refusal to negotiate with Iran would not have been preferable to the extended talks that resolved the hostage crisis, according to Congressional testimony by former Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie and former Deputy Secretary Warren M. Christopher. If the negotiations had not been held, Mr. Muskie said, ''the hostages would still be in Teheran.'' (A3:1-4.)

title: BASEBALL OWNERS USE RIGHT OF OPTION
description: The threat of a player strike was heightened yesterday when major league baseball's club owners, as expected, announced that they were implementing rules that call for significant compensation to teams that lose certain players through free agency.

title: STAGE: 'JACQUES BREL' IS REVIVED
description: THE songs by Jacques Brel that make up ''Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris'' are proving to be less mortal than Mr. Brel himself. The French songwriter and singer died two years ago, but his songs, as presented in the show that first opened 14 years ago at the Village Gate, live on with a vitality that has not diminished one whit. They are alive and well and vigorous as ever in the production that has moved into Town Hall for three weeks.

title: Article 013196 -- No Title
description: The recent rapid growth of the nation's money market funds continued in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlantic Companies, a property-liability insurance company, has elected to its board David P. Davison, president and chief executive officer of the United States Trust Company of New York.

title: AMTRAK BUDGET REQUEST EXCEEDS PROPSAL BY REAGAN
description: Amtrak today submitted a $716 million operating budget to Congress for the fiscal year 1982. The announcement followed by a day President Reagan's proposal to reduce Amtrak's 1982 budget to $669 million.

title: MUSKIE AND CHRISTOPHER SAY TALKS WERE SOLE WAY TO GET HOSTAGES
description: Former Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie and Warren M. Christopher, his former Deputy Secretary, took issue today with the Reagan Administration's view that it would have been better if the Carter Administration had not negotiated with Iran for release of the 52 American hostages.

title: BYRNE FORESEES $1.2 BILLION LOSS IN AID
description: TRENTON Feb. 19 - Governor Byrne said today that President Reagan's economic plan presaged the possible loss to New Jersey of $1.2 billion or 20 percent of its Federal aid.

title: News Analysis; REAGAN AND THE JAPANESE; Foreign Policy Sixth in a series of occasional articles on international problems facing the Reagan Administration.
description: Japan is facing the 1980's in a mood of selfconfidence that is different from the sometimes cocky and abrasive attitude that resulted from the spectacular growth of its economy in the preceding decades.

title: Baroque in the Bronx
description: The Bronx will go for Baroque this Sunday in a concert by the Bronx Arts Ensemble at 3 P.M. in the Riverdale-Yonkers Ethical Culture Society, 4450 Fieldston Road, in the Riverdale section.

title: Health Agency Disputes Social Security Forecast
description: The Administration said today that the projected deficit in Social Security by 1986 was $23 billion less than Congress estimated and that cuts proposed by President Reagan would reduce that deficit by half.

title: Talking Business with Robert Frosch of Engineering
description: Federation Engineers' Role In Industry

title: SHUTTLE TEST FIRING IS INTO FINAL PHASE
description: Everything about the countdown seemed to be falling behind schedule, but technicians planned to work through the night, even in a period set aside for rest, to get the space shuttle Columbia ready for the test firing of its main engines tomorrow morning.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The United States Export-Import Bank, scheduled for substantial budget cuts by the Reagan Administration, is suspending final approval of new loan applications, the agency's top official said today.

title: Alexander's Board Opposed to Dividend
description: Alexander's Inc., the department store chain, said its board of directors had decided not to consider paying dividends to shareholders until such time as circumstances warrant.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arizona Public Service Company said funds to complete coal and nuclear power plants now under construction make up the majority of its $377 million 1981 construction budget.

title: Gem and Mineral Show
description: Demonstrations of the ancient art of jamb-pegging will be featured at the 19th Gem, Mineral and Jewelry Show this weekend at the Statler Hilton Hotel, Seventh Avenue, between 32d and 33d Streets.

title: INQUIRY CONTINUES IN VIRGINIA BUS CRASH
description: The state police are investigating whether the driver of a commuter bus that crashed, killing 10 people, might have suffered a heart attack or whether the accident was caused by a mechanical defect, a spokesman said today.

title: EUROPEAN BANKS ACT TO SUPPORT CURRENCIES
description: Two of Europe's major central banks took action today to counter high United States interest rates and protect their currencies against further rises by the strong United States dollar.

title: HARRIS JURY READJUSTING ROUTINE AFTER LONG DAY
description: After a 12-hour day that left the judge yawning, a deputy sheriff dozing in his chair and the jurors in the Jean S. Harris murder trial looking strained and numb on Wednesday night, the jury this morning decided to adopt a more civilized routine.

title: Times Dividend Is 25
description: Directors of The New York Times Company yesterday declared a regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on class A and class B common stock, payable on March 26 to shareholders of record March 6. This is the 49th consecutive quarterly dividend paid on the company's common stock since its class A shares were admitted to trading on the American Stock Exchange in 1969. A regular quarterly dividend of $1.375 a share on the 5 1/2 percent cumulative prior preference stock was also declared, payable April 1 to shareholders of record March 6.

title: Model-Plane Show at White Plains Center; Model-Airplane Show At White Plains Center
description: The Westchester County Center in White Plains will be a modelbuilder's paradise tomorrow and Sunday, when the Westchester Radio Aero Modeler's 13th Model Plane, Car and Boat Show takes over the premises. The show, described as the largest of its kind on the East Coast, will include 200 hand-crafted models competing for trophies and more than 100 exhibits by manufacturers of kits, motors, radiocontrol equipment, tools and supplies.

title: No Headline
description: FATAL PILEUPS IN FOG IN TEXAS AND ILLINOIS: Firemen hosing down a section of Interstate 20 near Terrell, Tex., as tow trucks worked to clear highway.

title: HUNTINGTON THEATER FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: In a move to stave off its creditors and continue its season, the financially troubled Performing Arts Foundation in Huntington Station, L.I., has filed in Federal Court under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy law.

title: FILM TREASURES ROTTING IN FEDERAL STORAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: CHELSEA'S BUILDINGS REFLECT CHANGES IN NEIGHBORHOOD
description: The history of the brownstone buildings that the late Louise Gard owned in the Chelsea area of Manhattan reflects the social history of the neighborhood itself.

title: TOP-POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets, singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record. Albums ThisLast WeekWeek 1 6 Hi Infidelity* Reo Speedwagon 2 1 Double Fantasy John Lennon and Yoko Ono 3 3 The Jazz Singer (soundtrack) Neil Diamond 4 4 Paradise Theater* Styx 5 2 Kenny Roger's Greatest Hits Kenny Rogers 6 5 Crimes of Passion Pat Benatar 7 7 Guilty Barbra Streisand 8 8 Back in Black AC/DC 9 10 Autoamerican Blondie 10 11 Gaucho Steely Dan Singles 1 1 9 to 5 Dolly Parton 2 2 Celebration Kool & The Gang 3 3 I Love a Rainy Night* Eddie Rabbitt 4 4 Keep On Loving You* Reo Speedwagon 5 6 Woman* John Lennon 6 5 The Tide Is High Blondie 7 7 The Best of Times* Styx 8 8 Passion Rod Stewart 9 16 Hello Again (from The Jazz Singer)* Neil Diamond 10 22 Rapture* Blondie

title: GAMING LICENSE IN NEVADA GOES TO SINATRA WITH PRAISE
description: Frank Sinatra won back his Nevada gaming license today with the help of a state report clearing him of persistently rumored ties to organized crime.

title: Norris Embry, Painter Who Used Vivid Colors
description: Norris Embry, a painter whose work has appeared in museum and gallery shows in New York since the early 60's, died of a stroke Tuesday in Louisville, Ky. He was 59 years old.

title: Lower Tax-Cut Rates Provided for Wealthy
description: The income tax cuts proposed yesterday by the Administration provide for a substantially smaller reduction in percentage terms for the most wealthy Americans than for those with lower incomes, although the wealthy would still get the bulk of the tax reduction, according to Treasury Department figures.

title: General Food Shares Bought
description: The chairman of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., a diversified manufacturer and holding company based in New Bedford, Mass., disclosed to the Securities and Exchange Commission that he, and unidentified associates, have acquired a 5.2 percent interest in the giant General Foods Corporation for approximately $81 million.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: A team of swindlers who purport to have the knack for turning baser metals into gold hoodwink greedy dupes in Ben Jonson's ''The Alchemist,'' which is being presented through March 1 by the Jean Cocteau Repertory Company at the Bowerie Lane Theater, 330 Bowery. The setting of the farce has been changed from early-17th-century London to the American Wild West. Tonight's performance is at 8. Tickets are $6. Information: 677-0060. HUMOR A CLOWN IN MIDTOWN

title: Rolls-Royce Engine Order
description: Rolls-Royce Ltd. said today that it had received a $12.1 million jet engine order from Monarch Airlines, a British charter carrier.

title: OPERA: WILDERMANN IN 'MERRY WIVES'
description: One of the more charming interludes of last fall's New York City Opera season was its new production of ''The Merry Wives of Windsor,'' with William Wildermann prancing goutily and hilariously through the same Falstaffian part that he had taken 25 years earlier in the company's previous production of Otto Nicolai's light classic. Thursday night, the City Opera opened its spring season with ''The Merry Wives,'' and again it was Mr. Wildermann's show.

title: 18% POWER LOSS DISRUPTS SYSTEM IN CON ED'S AREA
description: The Consolidated Edison Company lost 18 percent of the electrical power needs of New York City and Westchester County during a halfhour period last night, but operators in a control center took emergency actions that averted local blackouts and a wider crisis.

title: FEARFUL NICARAGUANS BUILDING 200,000-STRONG MILITIA
description: Dressed in an assortment of uniforms, T-shirts and even dresses, their ages ranging from 16 to over 60, the ragtag volunteer army of factory workers, housewives and bureaucrats gathered at dusk on an abandoned airfield for their weekly training session in Nicaragua's new militia.

title: The Region; State Says 34 Felons Run Nursing Homes
description: ALBANY (UPI) - Of the 792 nursing homes operating in the State of New York, 34 are run by convicted felons, state health officials said yesterday.

title: Intel Unveils 32-Bit Microprocessor
description: The Intel Corporation, in papers presented at the International Solid State Circuits Conference in Manhattan, disclosed details of its 32,000-bit microprocessor, expected to be the first of the next generation of giant-capability microprocessors.

title: CLEVELAND'S SCHOOLS FACING $45 MILLION BUDGET DEFICIT
description: The Cleveland school system, the largest public school system in Ohio, is again facing financial deficit and charges of mismanagement.

title: 4 Americans in Turkey To Transfer to U.S. Jails
description: Four Americans who have been serving prison terms in Turkey will return to the United States on Sunday, the State Department announced today.

title: Broadway; Ex-film house to get affectionate musical lampooning movies.
description: ''A REEL AMERICAN HERO'' will open at the Rialto on April 9. This musical, its producer says, ''is an affectionate lampoon on what brought us to the values of Ronald Reagan.'' The Rialto is the theater on Broadway and 42d Street that was retrieved from the world of dirty movies and made into a legitimate house last year. In the 1930's and 1940's, however, it showed popular movies that weren't dirty at all. In fact, they were the same movies that inspired ''A Reel American Hero,'' and the musical is more or less about how those movies made us what we are today. Yes, this does sound like Christopher Durang's ''A History of the American Film,'' but only marginally. ''A Reel American Hero'' has lots of song and dance.

title: People
description: * Robert Cohen promoted to publisher of The New Republic.

title: TV REPORT ON LOSS OF FARM GETS $20,000 DUPONT-COLUMBIA PRIZE
description: Two independent producers of a documentary, on an American family farm taken over by agribusiness, and KTEH, the San Jose, Calif., public-television station that broadcast the program, won the $20,000 Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Award in Broadcast Journalism yesterday. It was the first cash prize presented in the 39-year history of the award.

title: NEW ADMINISTRATION, FRESH ENCROACHMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT IF HEROIN WERE FREE?
description: After years of more or less vigorous police action, American governments have failed to stop the importation, sale and use of heroin. As Leslie Maitland reported in last Sunday's Times, the latest wave of drug imports -from the opium fields of Afghanistan, Iran and Pakistan - is running high. So is the damage to addicts, families, neighborhoods. And so is the cost to society, on which addicts prey heavily to support their habit. Their search for the money for an ever more costly fix may be a major cause of street crime.

title: U.S. HELP TO STATES FOR PARKS MAY END
description: Federal money to help states and cities to buy land for parks would be immediately reduced by half and would be entirely eliminated next year under a budget-cutting proposal disclosed today by James G. Watt, the Secretary of the Interior.

title: DEMOCRATS IN HOUSE BALK AT DEADLINE FOR TAX PLAN AND AT ITS 3-YEAR SCOPE
description: The shape of the Congressional battle over President Reagan's tax bill began to emerge today with House Democrats saying the measure could not be enacted in time to take effect July 1 and tax cuts should be limited to one year instead of the three proposed by the Administration.

title: AT A JUNIOR HIGH IN HARLEM, PAST OFFERS HOPE TO PRESENT
description: Twenty-five years ago or more, they sat in classrooms at Junior High School 43 in Harlem and dreamed about making it. Yesterday, they returned to the school. Among them were a lawyer, a psychologist, a financial analyst and the director of a day-care center. They returned with a commitment to help bring about the flowering of some of the dreams now sprouting in the school.

title: KOCH SAYS CITY CAN BALANCE BUDGET DESPITE REAGAN PLAN
description: Mayor Koch, in a tentative assessment of President Reagan's proposed spending cuts, said yesterday that despite the prospect of reduced Federal aid, New York City would have little trouble balancing its budget for the 1982 fiscal year that begins July 1.

title: REPORTERS, TRACKING ARIZONA CRIME AFTER BOLLES DEATH, CLEARED OF LIBEL
description: Five reporters who took part in a series of investigative articles on crime in Arizona were cleared today of libel charges filed by Kemper Marley Sr.

title: RECITAL: ARNONS PLAY 4-HAND PIANO MUSIC
description: MOST compositions for piano, four hands, were written to be played rather than heard. These onetime staples of any self-respecting bourgeois home sound out of place on the concert stage.

title: Campbell Soup Reports Gain
description: The Campbell Soup Company, the nation's largest manufacturer of canned soups, today reported record earnings of $40.7 million for the second quarter of its fiscal year, up 3.8 percent, as sales of canned and frozen foods and confections improved.

title: Modern-Dance Fete At SUNY Purchase
description: The beginnings of American modern dance will be celebrated in ''The Early Years: American Modern Dance from 1900 through the 1930's,'' a four-day festival beginning April 9 at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: Nicaraguan Says He Flew Arms To El Salvador Twice in January
description: A former pilot for Nicaragua's national airline said tonight that he flew to El Salvador twice in January with arms for leftist guerrillas, once in a Nicaraguan Air Force plane.

title: Transactions; AUTO RACING
description: An- n ounced that Dale Inman, a member of the R ichard Petty racing team for more than t wo decades, will become vice president for r acing operations. BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - An arbitrator ruled t hat Paul Moskau, pitcher, be given the sal- a ry set by the team rather than his higher r equest for the coming season. Neither fig- u re was disclosed. CHICAGO (AL) - Announced that an ar- b itrator has ruled in favor of Ed Farmer, t he relief pitcher, in his salary case. Farmer w ill reportedly receive $600,000 this season. T he team had offered $375,000. Signed Ross B aumgarten, pitcher, to a one-year con- t ract. CLEVELAND (AL) - Placed Manny S anguillen, catcher, on waivers. METS (NL) - Signed Mark Bomback, p itcher, to a one-year contract. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed Gorman T homas, outfielder, to a five-year contract b elieved to be worth $2.5 million. MONTREAL (NL) - Signed Ray Burris, p itcher, to a one-year contract. Burris be- c ame a free agent after playing for the Mets l ast year. Announced that Don Kessinger, f ormer manager of the White Sox, will be a c oach for the Expos' Memphis farm team in t he Southern Association. OAKLAND (AL) - Announced that an ar- b itrator had awarded Mike Norris, pitcher, t he team's $325,000 salary offer for 1981. N orris had sought $450,000. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Announced that an ar- b itrator has awarded Tony Scott, outfielder, $ 225,000 for the coming season.

title: Mitsui, 2 Others Get East German Order
description: Three Japanese companies have won an order worth 83 billion yen, or about $400 million, from East Germany's Industrieanlagen-Import to build a factory to make color television tubes.

title: JUST HOW CONFIDENTIAL ARE CENSUS DATA?
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: 3 BY MUSICA AETERNA
description: TWO of the most beautiful works written during little more than a decade ending in 1949 are Francis Poulenc's Concerto for Organ, Strings and Timpani and a Richard Strauss cycle, the Four Last Songs. By happy accident or (more likely) splendid design, the two shared the first half of the Musica Aeterna concert given at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night.

title: RALPH BAKSHI, AN IMMIGRANT'S SON, LOOKS BACK; by Tom Buckley
description: CERTAIN aspects of his own life resonate in ''American Pop,'' Ralph Bakshi was saying the other day. Mr. Bakshi's critically acclaimed animated feature, now playing at RKO Cinerama and Loews New York Twin 1, follows the fortunes of four generations of sons of an immigrant family, all of them involved in music, from the turn of the century to the present.

title: EUROPEANS VOICE CONCERN ABOUT INTEREST RATES AND MONEY SUPPLY
description: European bankers and economic officials view President Reagan's economic program with skepticism, fearing it will keep interest rates high in both the United States and the rest of the industrial world, and perhaps even choke off hopes for a modest economic upswing later this year.

title: TEXT OF STATE DEPARTMENT DOCUMENT ON ARMING OF THE GUERRILLAS IN EL SALVADOR
description: Following is the text of a State Department document issued in support of the Reagan Administration's contention that the Soviet bloc has been supplying arms to guerrillas in El Salvador: Special to the New York Times

title: energywatch
description: FEB. 13 Despite a decline in crude imports and steady refinery output, Crude oil stocks totaled 380.3 million barrels, an increase of 5.4 million barrels.

title: NEW YORK ROCK BANDS EXCITE LONDON
description: A PLATOON of talented bands emerged from Lower Manhattan's crowded, noisy rock clubs back in the mid-70's and proceeded to conquer the rock world. The Talking Heads, the Ramones and the now defunct Television started in these clubs and went on to achieve worldwide commercial success. When these bands were still only local club favorites in New York, English critics and fans were already touting them as rock's New Wave, its Next Big Thing. Now, say the British trend-spotters, a new wave of New York bands is going to be rock's Next Big Thing.

title: Cabby Saves the Show
description: When a New York cabdriver inadvertantly drove off with Jim Gambone's suitcase Monday night, it seemed to spell curtains for a movie project the St. Paul documentary film maker had worked on for a year. The suitcase contained the only negative of a half-hour television film about the defoliant Agent Orange used in Vietnam.

title: DISCOVERING THE HAMPTONS IN WINTER
description: AS a parting gift when it receded 11,000 or so years ago, the last glacier of the Ice Age left the makings of a magnificent ocean beach along Long Island's South Shore. For years that gift has been especially appreciated every summer in the Hamptons, that stretch of beach at the farthest end of the island. But because cold weather and beaches traditionally have not gone together, the Hamptons in the past have all but closed down after Labor Day. Not so any longer.

title: SETON HALL DEFEATS RUTGERS BY 65-56
description: Seton Hall gained a 65-56 upset over Rutgers in the feature game of a college basketball doubleheader Thursday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: 3 HELD ON EXTORTION CHARGES IN AN OCCULT 'CURE' IN JERSEY
description: A woman and two men, who the police say practiced witchcraft in a dilapidated bungalow in the East Keansburg section of this Monmouth County township, were arrested when a diabetic woman complained that she had been bilked of $5,197 and hospitalized after seeking a supernatural cure for her condition.

title: Colombians Said to Delay Killing Kidnapped American
description: The headquarters of the Wycliffe Bible Translators, a worldwide missionary organization, said tonight that the Colombian guerrillas who last month kidnapped a Wycliffe linguist had agreed today not to kill him for 15 days provided the organization made no more public statements on the kidnapping.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Home Section yesterday on sterling silver flatware gave an incorrect price for a four-piece set of Gorham Chantilly at B. Altman & Company. The correct price is $207.63.

title: IRANIAN SAYS SPY CASE AGAINST BRITONS WAS FALSE
description: Four Britons held here since August on suspicion of espionage were arrested on the basis of documents that have been proved to have been forged, Iran's Chief Justice has announced.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe the people are ready. We think that across the aisle, in Congress today, there is a different feeling, and there are more people than anyone realizes who are of the opinion that this has to go forward.''

title: THREE-CENT RATE RISE FOR FIRST-CLASS STAMP URGED BY POSTAL PANEL
description: The Postal Service was given approval today to raise the price of mailing a first-class letter by 3 cents, to 18 cents. In granting that approval, the Postal Rate Commission turned down the Postal Service's request for a 20-cent rate.

title: NEW YORK AREA'S LEGISLATORS ASSAIL REDUCED TRANSIT AID
description: Congressmen from the New York metropolitan area, from the most liberal to the most conservative, called today for rejection of President Reagan's proposal to cut back Federal aid to transportation.

title: WITH HORACE SILVER, HIS PIANO AND HIS MEMORIES
description: HORACE SILVER'S engagement at Fat Tuesday's this weekend is laced with anniversaries and reunions. This is the 30th anniversary of what the pianist and composer considers his real entry into the jazz world - joining Stan Getz in the winter of 1950-51 - and his 25th year as leader of his own groups.

title: DOW DROPS 13.74 IN MODERATE TRADING
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in the aftermath of President Reagan's Wednesday night speech describing in detail his economic recovery program. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 13.74 points, to 933.36, almost erasing its 15 1/2-point advance in the two previous sessions.

title: Around the World; Soviet Protests Over Family That Has Remained in U.S.
description: Soviet officials summoned United States diplomats to the Foreign Ministry here today to protest what the ministry called the ''forcible detainment in the United States'' of a Soviet family.

title: MUSIC: MONTSERRAT CABALLE IN 'GOTTERDAMMERUNG' ARIA
description: In their separate ways, Zubin Mehta and Montserrat Caballe have both been stalking Wagner. At the end of Thursday night's New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall, they joined forces and caught him - their performance had that kind of animal excitement.

title: OPTIMISM ON BUDGET
description: President Reagan insisted today that Congress pass his proposed spending and tax cuts together as his advisers began working with Republican leaders on Capitol Hill to head off possible Democratic attempts to split the package and scale down its size.

title: SOME ECONOMISTS SEE NEW CYCLE OF INFLATION OWING TO REAGAN PLAN
description: Despite President Reagan's promise that his new fiscal package will cut inflation, a wide spectrum of economists fear that the program of tax cuts and limits on spending growth could set in motion a new cycle of inflation and recession.

title: NEW PROPOSAL FOR TIMES SQUARE BLOCK
description: A citizens' group opposing the demolition of three theaters to make room for the proposed Portman Hotel on Times Square is circulating a proposal to redevelop the block bounded by 42d and 43d Streets and Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas. The square block would get three new hotels and a 60-story office building.

title: Borg Routs McEnroe By 6-0, 6-4
description: Bjorn Borg easily defeated John McEnroe today, 6-0, 6-4, in the first of their $1.15 million threematch series, prompting an embarrassed McEnroe to apologize to spectators and millions of television viewers.

title: U.S. SAYS SALVADOR IS 'TEXTBOOK CASE' OF COMMUNIST PLOT
description: The State Department has provided embassies of friendly governments here with a memorandum asserting that ''the insurgency in El Salvador has been progressively transformed into a textbook case of indirect armed aggression by Communist powers.''

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: Source: American Petroleum Institute

title: Bauxite Talks in Jamaica
description: Jamaica's Prime Minister, Edward Seaga, opened talks with bauxite executives today about expanding output here. The Aluminum Company of America, the Aluminium Company of Canada, the Reynolds Metals Company and the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation are among the producers active in Jamaica.

title: CAREY REVISES HIS PLAN FOR MEDICAID TAKEOVER
description: Governor Carey disclosed today that he had revised details of his proposed Medicaid takeover and freeze on county property taxes in response to criticism from the state's mayors and county executives.

title: 6 Choreographers Named For Ballet Workshop
description: Six choreographers have been named to participate in the Ballet Theater Foundation's Workshop's Emerging Artists Laboratory.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 17.

title: 6 ARCHITECTS PONDER DESIGN RATIONALE BEHIND NEW MANHATTAN SKYSCRAPERS ; An Appraisal
description: It will be a very different mid-Manhattan two or three years from now, and if there were any doubts that public interest in the plethora of new towers now going up is high, they were dispelled this week by an event at the Museum of Modern Art. The museum's Junior Council held a symposium Wednesday evening in which six architects building Manhattan skyscrapers presented their work, and it received more than 3,000 requests for tickets. Only 478 could fit into the museum's Roy and Niuta Titus Auditorium, leaving 2,500 with nothing to do, presumably, but wait for the new buildings themselves.

title: Park Slope Renewal
description: A city program aimed at developing both the commercial and residential potential of a decaying area of the Park Slope section of Brooklyn was announced by Mayor Koch.

title: CENSUS BUREAU TOLD TO GIVE JERSEY DATA
description: NEWARK (AP) -- A Federal judge ordered the Census Bureau yesterday to release its population figures for all New Jersey municipalities because of the state's pressing need to draw new election districts.

title: CALIFORNIA BATTLE LINE AGAINST THE FRUIT FLY DRAWN ON TEXAS FRONT
description: California's war against the Mediterranean fruit fly widened to a new front today as the state pledged to fight an order by Texas officials to require fumigation of California fruit and vegetables. On the home front, California officials have said they were prepared to overrule communities that have prevented aerial spraying to eradicate the pest.

title: 6 IN OPEC REPORTED TO PLAN OUTPUT CUT
description: Six key oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries met in secret in Geneva yesterday and the day before and, oil industry sources said, moved toward cutting back oil production to keep prices up in the face of growing supplies and weak demand.

title: DEPRECIATION'S EFFECT ON TAXES
description: President Reagan's proposals to curb taxes on business, presented in his budget message Wednesday, have been welcomed by some as the most far-reaching benefit for corporate America in recent history.

title: Zimbabwe Will Establish Diplomatic Ties With Soviet
description: Zimbabwe announced today that it had decided to establish diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union and would allow it to set up an embassy here.

title: Gerald Ford To Aid Charter
description: The Charter Company, an oil, insurance and communications conglomerate, said today that it had hired former President Gerald R. Ford as a consultant.

title: PCB CLEANUP SHUTS UPSTATE TOWER FOR MONTHS
description: Every morning for the last two weeks, squads of workers equipped with goggles and respirators, and wearing disposable vinyl gloves and white coveralls, have been passed through the police barricades at the State Office Building here to attack the poisonous soot that has infiltrated each floor of the 18-story building.

title: Ecuador Declares Peru Attacked Two Outposts
description: Ecuador accused Peru today of launching new attacks on two contested border outposts despite a cease-fire overseen by the United States and three South American countries.

title: DEMANDS FOR DEMOCRATIC CHANGE PENETRATE POLISH COMMUNIST PARTY
description: Members of the Communist Party, taking part in meetings throughout the country, are raising demands for more democracy and other changes to liberalize the party itself, a movement that could have far-reaching consequences for the future of Polish Communism.

title: I.B.M. to Form Credit Subsidiary
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would establish a wholly owned subsidiary, the IBM Credit Corporation, to finance installment payment agreements with United States customers.

title: Stock Prices Retreat; Dow Industrials Up
description: Stock prices drifted lower yesterday, but showed some resilience after Thursday's sharp setback. While most market indicators registered declines, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 2.73 points, to 936.09, as a result of a late afternoon recovery.

title: MEXICO STRESSES TIES WITH CUBA IN AN APPARENT REBUFF TO REAGAN
description: In an apparent rebuff to the Reagan Administration, President Jose Lopez Portillo has gone out of his way to stress Mexico's close ties with Cuba just three days after a United States delegation arrived here with what it called proof of Havana's support for Salvadoran guerrillas.

title: Chicago Bank Cuts Prime Rate to 19%
description: First National Bank of Chicago, the nation's ninth-largest bank, cut its prime lending rate one-half percentage point yesterday, to 19 percent, making it the second major bank to undercut the rest of the industry.

title: A.M.C. LOSES $22 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: The American Motors Corporation, the small United States auto maker now controlled by Renault of France, today reported a loss of $29 million for last year's fourth quarter and a $197.5 million deficit for all of 1980.

title: Books of The Times
description: Impassioned Exactitudes By ANATOLE BROYARD THE COMPLETE POEMS OF MARIANNE MOORE. 305 pages. Macmillan/Viking. $16.95.

title: Briton Ordered to Trial In the 13 'Ripper' Deaths
description: Peter William Sutcliffe stood before three British magistrates today and listened in silence as they charged him with the 13 ''Yorkshire Ripper'' murders and seven attempted murders that terrorized the women of northern England for six years.

title: Court Censures a Lawyer of Many Talents
description: In effect, what the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court said about Aaron M. Zimmerman, a young Syracuse lawyer, was that his ''overenthusiasm'' was more to be smiled at than censured.

title: UNIFORM FEES SET ON STOCK CLEARING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will permit the nation's largest stock clearing group to charge all brokerage houses the same fees for clearing stock trades regardless of the broker's geographic location, it was disclosed today by commission and industry sources.

title: The Lesson of the Tudor Deal
description: Whether the tale of Tudor City's parks had a happy ending or not, it was the only possible ending. In a complex agreement, New York City exchanged a public park for Tudor City's two private parks, which will become public. Tudor City's owner, Harry Helmsley, will build a new tower on the former city park instead of on the land he owned. He will also contribute $1 million for upgrading park facilities in and around Tudor City and will maintain some of the public areas in perpetuity.

title: Energy Chief Asks Reagan to Bar Cuts in Nuclear Industry Budget
description: Energy Secretary James B. Edwards has asked President Reagan to overrule sharp budget cuts proposed for the nuclear power industry, it was reported today.

title: CHAIRMAN OF KAISER STEEL QUITS
description: The Kaiser Steel Company, the nation's ninth-largest producer, said yesterday that Edgar F. Kaiser Jr., the company's 38-year-old chairman and grandson of the founder, was resigning for undisclosed reasons.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: John Ross shinnies up the base of Cleopatra's Needle in Central Park for a good look at the spot where the 71-foot obelisk is resting on the backs of four large bronze crabs covered with verdigris.

title: DEATHS OF 2 BOYS RAISING CONCERN AT SCHOOL ON L.I.
description: Two young boys, both pupils at the Chestnut Hill School here, have died of unknown causes in the last few weeks, and although there is no evidence that the two deaths were related, many parents plan to keep their children at home on Monday when classes resume after a week's midwinter recess.

title: THE REGION
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Twenty-seven New Jersey residents were poisoned in two separate incidents last year by eating pokeweed salad or loco weed seeds, the Centers for Disease Control reported today.

title: BACARDI IS MOST POPULAR DRINK
description: What's the most popular brand of alcoholic beverage among American consumers? Smirnoff vodka? Seagram's 7 whisky? Canadian Club whisky? None of these. The biggest-selling brand of distilled spirits is Bacardi rum, with sales of 6.85 million cases in 1980.

title: FEDERAL EMPLOYEES LISTED AS DEBTORS
description: The Veterans Administration turned to Government payroll computers hoping to find some of the half million people who owe it a total of $521 million. The agency was rewarded with the names of 66,000 Federal employees.

title: NICOLAS DE GUNZBURG, 76, AFORMER EDITOR OF VOGUE
description: Baron Nicolas de Gunzburg, a former senior fashion editor at Vogue magazine whose panache and sense of quality earned him the reputation of one of the fashion industry's great men of style, died yesterday morning at New York Hospital after suffering a series of strokes. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Buffalo Forge Link To Ogden Amended
description: The Ogden Corporation and the Buffalo Forge Company amended a previously announced merger agreement to provide for Ogden to acquire 850,000 Buffalo Forge shares for $37 a share cash and the balance of Buffalo's outstanding in a share-for-share exchange.

title: Teachers Strike Over Pay In Youngstown, Ohio
description: Teachers went on strike this morning in Youngstown's 17,000-pupil school system. The teachers were ordered to end their walkout by Judge Clyde Osborne of Mahoning County Common Pleas Court, who said he was issuing a temporary restraining order in accord with a law prohibiting strikes by public workers.

title: Your Money; Reducing Costs Of Hotel Stays
description: INCREASING numbers of businesses of all sizes are taking a very close look at the cost of expense-account travel and, in particular, at the cost of hotels and motels. According to Robert J. Logan, a partner at Peat Marwick Mitchell & Co., the national accounting firm, companies are ''definitely reviewing their expense allowances for travel'' and looking for ''more moderate-priced hotel rooms.''

title: 1,056 MORE GRAND FEET
description: No brake system on earth can stop a freight train on a dime, and it is unreasonable to expect President Reagan to end inflation and restore the economy to the uncorrupted glory of the 1950's over the weekend.

title: U.S. AND ISRAELIS DISAGREE ON GEAR FOR SAUDI F-15'S Haig and Ambassador Samuel Lewis
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today after his first meeting with Israel's Foreign Minister that they disagreed over whether the United States should supply Saudi Arabia with additional military equipment for the F-15 fighters it has purchased from this country.

title: DAVIS IS RESIGNED TO BE AN EX-YANKEE
description: Today was Ron Davis's first time in a New York uniform this season, and already he was anticipating a trade that might make him dress in the colors of Oakland, Chicago or Montreal.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Parker-Hannifin Corporation is offering 1.5 million shares of common stock at $28.50 a share through a Kidder, Peabody group.

title: Noranda Aluminum Expansion Cleared
description: The Noranda Aluminum Company, a unit of Canada's Noranda Mines Ltd., said it had won Federal regulatory approval for a $240 million expansion of its primary aluminum facilities here.

title: Sister Margaret R. Healey, 99, A Sisters of Charity Educator
description: Sister Margaret Rosaire Healey, an educator and administrator who for 80 years was a member of the Sisters of Charity, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Yonkers.

title: REAGAN CHOPS WOOD AS TOP AIDES PREPARE TO SELL HIS BUDGET CUTS
description: While President Reagan devoted himself to wood chopping and horseback riding at his mountain retreat near here, his staff pushed ahead today with its public relations campaign to put pressure on Congress to enact Mr. Reagan's economic recovery program.

title: Electrical Explosion Shuts Bronx School
description: An electrical explosion knocked out power at Intermediate School 151 in the Bronx, forcing the cancellation of classes for the next few weeks, the Board of Education said. No one was injured.

title: LEWIS SUPPORTS CAR IMPORT CURBS
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis said today that restraints on imports of Japanese cars should be part of the Administration's upcoming program to assist the domestic automobile industry.

title: CASES OF 2 YOUTHS ADDED TO ATLANTA INQUIRY
description: The cases of two more black children, including one death that was previously ruled accidental, were referred today to a special police task force now investigating the deaths and disappearances of 20 black youths in the Atlanta area in 19 months.

title: Bridge: Novices Come to the Fore In New York City Tourney
description: In almost all tournaments the experts are in the limelight, and their activities overshadow those of the novices. In New York City once a year this procedure is reversed.

title: BUSINESS, IN VICTORY
description: To the extent that victory is possible amid the chaos of American politics, business has won. In just a few years, it has succeeded not only in reversing the momentum toward increased Government regulation but also in transforming the political agenda.

title: Benitez Spurns Hearns, Plans to Meet Maurice Hope
description: Fighting Thomas Hearns, Jimmy Jacobs finally decided, was not worth a half-million dollars more than fighting Maurice Hope when it comes to choosing an opponent for Wilfred Benitez.

title: TARNOWER JURORS APPEAR TO CONCENTRATE ON 'INTENT'
description: The jurors in the Jean S. Harris murder trial, deliberating for their fourth day, asked for new information today that indicated they were continuing to weigh the most severe charge against her: murder in the second degree.

title: WONDER WHAT'LL BECOME OF 'MARY' IN TEHERAN
description: For 444 days, television viewers came to know ''Mary,'' the feisty young student militant in Teheran. The interpreter and spokesman for the group holding the 52 hostages, she became a newsmedia personality, a link between the militants and journalists. We saw her steadily, right from the beginning of the crisis, when she would trot out daily to deliver hostile attacks on the United States, to her final interviews with the hostages, conducted a day before their release.

title: Tass Says U.S. Attache Had a Woman in His Room
description: Tass, the Soviet press agency, asserted today that a United States military attache who left the Soviet Union abruptly last month was caught several days earlier with a woman in his hotel room.

title: CABARET: FRAN WARREN AT MICHAEL'S PUB
description: Fran Warren began her career as a band singer with Charlie Barnet and Claude Thornhill in the days when big bands were the headliners in stage shows at the Paramount, Strand and Capitol Theaters, and West 52d Street was packed with little jazz clubs. This is the setting on which she is basing her current program at Michael's Pub, which, somewhat inexplicably, is called ''My Broadway,'' which suggests the musical shows in which she appeared later in her career.

title: FUTURE IS SHAKY FOR U.S. PROGRAM THAT REVIVED A TOWN IN JERSEY
description: In this depressed industrial town of 8,000 people, it is now possible for tenants in a public housing project to walk across the street and find a job in a rehabilitated factory that had stood vacant for two decades.

title: 76ers 117, Mavericks 109
description: Dallas, the team with the worst record in the N.B.A., led Philadelphia, the team with the best record, for 24 minutes tonight until Darryl Dawkins took over and sparked the 76ers to a 117-109 victory over the Mavericks.

title: THE NO. 1 PROBLEM OF HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: LUCINE AMARA IN 'BALLO'
description: Lucine Amara and the Metropolitan opera have settled their differences -Miss Amara's complaint was that the management had discriminated against her on the ground of age - and the soprano returned to the Met stage on Thursday night, after an absence of four years, as Amelia in ''Un Ballo in Maschera.'' This performance also marked the 30th anniversary of her debut season.

title: Dr. Leonard Bliss Job Dies at 90; Was President of Ithaca College
description: Leonard Bliss Job, the former president of Ithaca College, died Feb. 13 at his home in Lakeland, Fla., after a long illness.

title: Sports of The Times; The Woman Beside Elston Howard
description: THE end of February was always an active time in the Howard household: a birthday for Elston Sr. on Feb. 23 and a trip to spring training for the family.

title: BIG TEN BASKETBALL DIMMED BY LOSS OF LAST SEASON'S TOP STARS
description: Bobby Knight, Indiana's outspoken basketball coach, says he no longer feels that the Big Ten Conference owns bragging rights as the premier league in his favorite sport. He gave those rights back to the Atlantic Coast Conference yesterday.

title: MR. REAGAN'S AND MR. HAIG'S REALISTIC VIEW OF MOSCOW'S WAYS
description: To the Editor:

title: BRING THE CITY BACK TO THE HUDSON
description: To the Editor:

title: POP: THE RAMONES PLAY BOND'S
