description: The Ramones are a one-joke band gone stale. This proto-minimalist quartet, who parody teen-age machismo and knowingly manipulate fascist imagery, originally made their mark as one of America's first and purest punk bands.

title: JAZZ: FIRST ART HODES SOLO IN 31 YEARS
description: Art Hodes, the veteran Chicago pianist who was a very active part of the New York jazz world in the 1940's as performer, disk jockey and magazine publisher, has returned to New York to play solo piano for the first time in 31 years, at Hanratty's, Second Avenue at 90th Street.

title: 2 ARRESTED IN SLAYING OF BOY OVER A COAT
description: Last Christmans, 16 year-old David Collins's mother bought him a new sheepskin coat to replace one stolen from him a year earlier. A few days later, the new coat became the target of thieves, and the youth was shot to death because he refused to give it up.

title: AIRLINE MOVE TO CUT BAGGAGE
description: Latin American tourists, who arrive with nothing but cash and leave with mountains of merchandise, may delight Florida shopkeepers, but at least two airlines are now saying enough is enough.

title: 3 CONSULS ARE ABDUCTED IN SPAIN'S BASQUE AREA
description: Gunmen believed to be Basque separatists kidnapped the honorary consuls of Austria, El Salvador and Uruguay last night in an apparent attempt to dramatize demands for an independent Basque nation.

title: Cubans in Ecuadorean Embassy Free Their Last Three Hostages
description: A group of Cubans demanding asylum in the Ecuadorean Embassy freed their last three hostages last night, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: 2 CITED ON INSIDE DATA
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had issued injunctions against two men charged with using confidential information about proposed mergers that had been leaked by a paralegal at a leading Wall Street law firm.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alcan Aluminum Ltd. said Alcan Aluminio S.A., a Mexican fabricating company in which Alcan has a 48.7 percent interest, planned to spend $32 million to modernize its sheet and foil rolling mills near Mexico City.

title: G.M. SAID TO PLAN 10% STAFF CUT
description: The General Motors Corporation is preparing for a 10 percent reduction of its worldwide salaried work force of 189,000, sources said today. It would be the company's second major retrenchment in less than a year.

title: 2 Juries Weigh Charges Of Abuse of Mexicans
description: A Federal jury hearing the case against Thomas Hanigan, accused of beating and torturing three Mexicans, began deliberations today, several hours after another panel started considering the charges against his brother Patrick.

title: BYRNE ASKS REAGAN FOR AID FOR DROUGHT-RELIEF PROJECTS
description: Governor Byrne appealed to President Reagan yesterday to declare an emergency in 372 New Jersey communities which are under water restrictions. He also asked the President to provide $116.3 million to $123.3 million for major, long-term relief projects to end the water shortage in the northern part of the state.

title: Variety Show at N.Y.U.  To Be Given Wednesday
description: An old-style variety entertainment show, including clowning, juggling, unicycling, quick-change and mime and magic, will be presented on Wednesday at 8 P.M. in the Eisner and Lubin Auditorium of New York University's Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place.

title: Bogota Rebels Threaten To Kill U.S. Missionary
description: Leftist guerrillas holding an American who came here to translate the Bible threatened today to kill him within 24 hours unless his United States-based missionary group agrees to leave Colombia.

title: THE DANCE: 'VARIATIONS'
description: Beth Eisenberg and Meg Harper did something odd but probably unnecessary Thursday night at the American Theater Laboratory. They reinvented Baroque music and dance.

title: Toro Reports Losses
description: The Toro Company, maker of lawn appliances and snow throwers, today reported a loss of $714,000 for the second quarter ended Jan. 30 and a loss of $5.1 million in the first half. The loss for the second quarter was posted on sales of $77.72 million and contrasted with a profit of $4.8 million, or 85 cents a share, a year earlier on sales of $123.88 million. The loss for the half was on sales of $123.12 million and contrasted with a profit a year earlier of $10.41 million, or $1.83 a share, on sales of $225.47 million.

title: PAPP URGES REPLACING U.S. ARTS ENDOWMENT WITH STATE AGENCIES
description: In the wake of President Reagan's proposed 50 percent cut in appropriations from the $173 million Carter budget for the arts, Joseph Papp, head of the New York Shakespeare Festival, called yesterday for the abolition of the National Endowment for the Arts. Mr. Papp proposed that Federal money for the arts be channeled instead to state arts councils to administer the funds.

title:
Patents;
Magnetic Alloys Cut Phone Cost
description: WASHINGTON A FAMILY of new alloys invented by a scientist at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., is expected to reduce greatly the cost of prominent magnets used in telephone receivers and other equipment.

title: L.I. TRUST CALLED TARGET OF FOREIGN TAKEOVER
description: A Chinese financier and a European bank are reported by banking sources to be making separate bids to acquire the Long Island Trust Company, the largest American-owned bank on Long Island.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, FEBRUARY, 21, 1981
description: International A Pentagon report on El Salvador said that its army is so poorly prepared to fight the Marxist guerrillas that it has ''no hope'' of defeating them. A State Department memorandum on a briefing for embassies of allied countries, quoted Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., as saying that the United States ''will not remain passive'' to what he described as a ''systematic, well-financed, sophisticated effort to impose a Communist regime in Central America.'' He also said that Cuba was the main source of the alleged military intervention in El Salvador. (Page 1, Column 1.) El Salvador wants economic aid more than military support, President Jose Napoleon Duarte said in an interview. President Duarte, who heads a civilian-military junta, said the economic crisis caused by guerrilla attacks against the Government was a greater threat to his country than the guerrillas. (1:2.)

title: SHORT-TERM RATES FALL SHARPLY
description: Short-term interest rates declined sharply yesterday amid signs that slow growth in the nation's money supply was encouraging the Federal Reserve to let interest rates move lower.

title: Arts and Letters Institute Elects 9 Members; Arts and Letters Institute Elects Nine Members
description: Nine members have been elected to the American Academy-Institute of Arts and Letters.

title: BELL BIDS F.C.C. EASE LEASE RULE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked the Federal Communications Commission today to reconsider a major provision in its plan to introduce telephone industry deregulation in 1982.

title: Minor Earthquake Shakes Utah
description: A minor earthquake interrupted the sleep of many Utah County residents early today, but there were no reports of injury or damage. Walter J. Arabasz, research seismologist at the University of Utah, said the earthquake at 2:13 A.M. registered 3.6 on the Richter scale of ground motion. He said it occurred on a section of the Wasatch Fault that has been inactive for many years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is of no use to have the greatest and best army in the world if the people are dying from hunger.'' - Jose Napoleon Duarte, President of El Salvador's ruling junta. (1:2.)

title: POPE, IN PHILIPPINES, ASSAILS GAP IN WEALTH
description: In the region of these islands where the contrast between those who labor in the fields and those who live in luxury is the starkest, Pope John Paul II delivered an impassioned homily today on the unjust division of the world's riches.

title: U.N. Campaign to Combat Film and Recording Piracy
description: Actors, authors, musicians and film producers announced Friday a combined attack on recording and movie pirates.

title: U.S. ASKS HIGH COURT TO DELAY THE RELEASE OF TAX AGENCY DATA
description: The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court tonight for an extension of a legal stay that has delayed the public release of Internal Revenue Service information that the Government said could provide a blueprint for cheating on Federal income taxes.

title: Borg Wins 2d in Series
description: Bjorn Borg scored a 6-2, 6-4, victory over John McEnroe tonight in the second of a three-match series. With the victory, Borg clinched the series and a $30,000 gold tennis racquet.

title: MAN GETS 18 YEARS IN NEIGHBOR'S DEATH
description: - A Nassau County judge has sentenced a man to 18 years in prison for the murder of a neighbor slain in a dispute over a parking space.

title: DEFICIT GIVES A TARNISH TO GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE
description: Ten years ago, when tolls were 50 cents, collected only from southbound drivers, the Golden Gate Bridge paid off the $35 million in bonds that financed its construction in the 1930's. Tolls were not removed, or even cut back. They went up to 75 cents in 1973, then to $1, and on March 1, will reach $1.25.

title: SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
description: Those two inevitables, death and taxes, are with us in a new way. What does President Reagan's tax-and budget-cutting plan have to do with New York State's renewed effort to pass a death-penalty law or with Senator Strom Thurmond's intention to put a death-penalty law in the Federal code? You don't know? Apparently, the budgetbalancers and the capital-punishment advocates don't either.

title: 2 PUBLISHERS IN OFFER FOR CABLE TV
description: Dow Jones & Company and Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. yesterday announced a joint offer to acquire UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc., the country's 10th-biggest cable television company, for a total of $237.6 million in cash.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG'S BRIEFING ABOUT EL SALVADOR
description: Following are excerpts from a Feb. 17 briefing on El Salvador presented by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to representatives of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as well as Australia, New Zealand, Japan and Spain.

title: News Analysis
description: Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the special envoy sent by President Reagan to tell the Europeans about Soviet and Cuban arms aid to the Salvadoran guerrillas, wound up his mission today where he started it Monday: in

title: TRANSIT DIRECTOR DOUBTS SCHEDULE FOR BUS REPAIRS
description: John D. Simpson, executive director of the Transit Authority, said yesterday he could not guarantee that the 637 Grumman Flxible buses removed from service two months ago would return to New York City streets according to the timetable set by the manufacturer.

title: Ivory Coast Strikers Defy a Ban
description: Hundreds of state workers in the Ivory Coast defied a Government ban and went on strike today over pay cuts of up to 60 percent.

title: ISRAEL, TOO, SELLS WEAPONS ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Councilman Remains Disbarred
description: Former Democratic City Councilman Eugene F. Mastropieri has failed in a bid to regain his lawyer's license, which he lost when he was convicted of perjury and income tax evasion.

title: People's Temple Member Seeks Dismissal of Charges
description: Larry Layton, a People's Temple member charged in the death of Representative Leo Ryan in Guyana, asked a Federal district judge today to dismiss conspiracy charges against him.

title: Young Blacks, Still Jobless
description: One quick way to solve a social problem is to change the way it is measured until it shrinks into insignificance. That is what seems to be happening in the area of black teen-age unemployment. It has been said, by a recent contributor to our Op-Ed page among others, that the joblessness among minority youth isn't as bad as is generally supposed. How we wish that were so. But it isn't.

title: WESTCHESTER COUNTY AIRPORT CLOSED IN DISPUTE WITH F.A.A. OVER SAFETY
description: Westchester County Airport was closed indefinitely yesterday by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello. He acted after a small plane made a forced landing Thursday evening on an ice-covered lake near the airport and after an angry disagreement with Federal officials over how to deal with safety issues raised by the incident.

title: COGHLAN SETS MILE RECORD OF 3:50.6
description: Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland shattered his world indoor mile record by two seconds tonight with a time of 3 minutes 50.6 seconds in the Jack-in-the-Box Invitational track meet at the San Diego Sports Arena.

title: JURY SAYS PENTHOUSE MAGAZINE LIBELED A FORMER MISS WYOMING
description: A Federal jury awarded $26.5 million in damages to a former Miss Wyoming today in a libel suit against Penthouse Magazine.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on the Style page yesterday misidentified the photographer with Louise Dahl Wolf. He is Horst P. Horst.

title: CHARITY'S LAWYERS SAY IT MAY USE $1 MILLION FROM FEDERAL OFFICIAL
description: One of the four charities that received a total of $4 million in Government funds from a departing official of the Carter Administration has been told by its attorneys that it does not have to give the money back, the organization said today.

title: X-RAY LINK TO CORONARY RISK IS HINTED
description: A new long-term statistical study from Johns Hopkins University suggests a possible link between chronic exposure to X-rays and an increased risk of fatal heart disease.

title: A DONATION TO COPPOLA'S STUDIO HELPS ALLEVIATE FINANCIAL BIND
description: Francis Coppola's Zoetrope Studios, faced with a crisis because of a loss of financing on ''One From the Heart,'' has received a large anonymous gift ''to tide us over for the week,'' a studio representative said Friday.

title: Pingfeng Ngo Chung, 93, Former Chinese Official
description: Pingfeng Ngo Chung, a businessman, engineer and former government official in China, died Wednesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers. Mr. Chung, who was a resident of the Riverdale section of the Bronx, was 93 years old.

title: John Mitchell Is Sued
description: John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General who served a prison term in the Watergate conspiracy, was sued yesterday for recovery of a $50,000 advance that Simon & Schuster paid for his projected memoirs.

title: Mobil Canada Shuts Hibernia Well
description: Mobil Oil Canada said it had plugged and abandoned an 11,300-foot-deep well in the Hibernia field off Newfoundland after it failed to give indications of oil or natural gas. The company said, however, that it planned to drill another well to test the extent of the field's oil and gas deposits.

title: 5 More Meningitis Cases Are Reported in Texas
description: Five new cases of spinal meningitis have been confirmed in Texas, where an epidemic has drawn the attention of national medical experts, health officials said today.

title: Texas Company Accused Of Exploiting Refugees
description: Labor Department officials said today that a company that sponsored Cuban refugees from the refugee center at Fort Chaffee, Ark., had ordered them to work long hours without pay for six months.

title: NETS TOP BLAZERS FOR 5TH IN ROW
description: The New Jersey Nets won their fifth straight game, matching their longest winning streak since joining the National Basketball Association, by beating the Portland Trail Blazers, 123-113, in overtime tonight.

title: UNION LEADERS MEET DONOVAN IN FLORIDA
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and union leaders gave conflicting accounts of what happened today when they met to discuss their differences over President Reagan's economic package.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE* 19.00 19.00 15.75 DISCOUNT RATE** 13.00 13.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 14.50 15.63 14.46 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.03 14.49 13.35 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 13.40 13.85 13.45 TREASURY NOTES 12.91 13.18 13.11 TREASURY BONDS 12.44 12.66 12.48 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 13.51 13.69 13.15 MUNICIPAL BONDS 11.20 11.20 9.00 6-MONTH SAVINGS 15.010 CERTIFICATES * Split rate, 19.00-19.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: At Carnegie Hall, Menuhin Always Keeps His Head
description: He has been giving concerts at Carnegie Hall for 54 years, and tomorrow Yehudi Menuhin will be back for a solo recital. Talking about his longtime association with the hall yesterday, Mr. Menuhin recalled with amusement his violin debut there, at the age of 10, on Nov. 25, 1927.

title: Probation in Killing
description: A former Navy technician received five years' probation for killing a man who had beaten him up.

title: ERNEST A. GRAUPNER
description: Ernest A. Graupner, former president and director of the Texasgulf Corporation, died Wednesday at New York Hospital.

title: Robber Gets $25,000 at L.I. Bank
description: A robber took about $25,000 this afternoon from a Chemical Bank branch, the Nassau County police said.

title: WATER CONSUMPTION CUT SHARPLY IN NEW YORK CITY
description: New York City's water consumption has decreased dramatically since last fall, when Mayor Koch first asked New Yorkers to conserve water because of the drought.

title: COMMUTERS SEEM READY FOR FARE RISES
description: Waiting for the 8:07 this morning at the Greenwich station, Deane Hayden, a salesman, said, ''Everyone will be yelling and screaming at first, but you've got to stop the Government spending.''

title: DEMOCRATS TO SEEK SIGNIFICANT CHANGES IN TAX-CUT PROPOSAL Wright
description: In a formal response to President Reagan's economic package, Congressional Democrats said today that they would propose major revisions in the President's tax plan and lesser changes in his proposal for $41.4 billion in budget cuts.

title: U.S. LIFTS CARTER'S BAN ON TRADE ASSISTANCE FOR CHILE
description: In a good-will gesture toward Chile's military Government, the Reagan Administration today revoked a prohibition imposed by the Carter Administration on United States Government financing of exports to Chile.

title: CALIFORNIA'S SPURIOUS FREE LUNCH
description: To the Editor:

title: JOAN OFFNER, CITY TRANSIT COUNSEL
description: Joan Offner, general counsel for the New York City Transit Authority, was killed yesterday morning when a tractor-trailer crossed a divider on the New Jersey Turnpike near Jersey City and hit her car head-on. She was 48 years old and lived in Edison, N.J.

title: EL PASO DISCONTINUES ALGERIA GAS-IMPORTING PLAN
description: The El Paso Company today decided to write off an investment of up to $375 million in gas-processing equipment because of the collapse of negotiations between the United States and Algeria on the price of liquefied natural gas to be imported by El Paso.

title: Lewis Sets Jump Mark, 27-10 1/4
description: Carl Lewis, the University of Houston's sophomore star, exceeded the world best indoor long jump mark with a leap of 27 feet 10 1/4 inches tonight in the Southwest Conference indoor track and field championships.

title: Caldor-Associated Merger
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation and Caldor Inc. have signed a definitive agreement to merge Caldor into Associated in a $313 million transaction, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Transactions; FRIDAY; BASEBALL
description: NEW YORK METS (NL) - Signed Mark B omback, right-handed pitcher, to one-year c ontract. CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Ross Baum- g artner, left-handed pitcher, to one-year c ontract. Agreed on contract terms with two p layers for Iowa Triple A affiliate: Rod A llen, outfielder, and Richard Barnes, left- h anded pitcher. CINCINNATI (NL) - Completed transfer o f ownership to 13-member partnership h eaded by James and William Williams, the p rincipal owners. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed Gorman T homas, outfielder, to five-year contract w orth an estimated $2.5 million. SEATTLE (AL) - Signed Mike Parrott a nd Jim Beattie, right-handed pitchers, to o ne-year contracts. Signed Dave Skaggs, c atcher formerly with California Angels, to c ontract with Spokane Triple A farm club TORONTO (AL) - Signed five players to o ne-year contracts: Willie Upshaw, first b aseman-outfielder; Pedro Hernandez, s hortstop; Dan Whitmer, catcher; and Mike W illis and Charlie Puleo, pitchers.

title: VETERAN SUPERVISOR OF SPACE FLIGHTS
description: ''He has always been interested in anything that flies,'' Dorie Page said yesterday, and that preoccupation has been borne out repeatedly in the career of her husband, George F. Page, the director of shuttle operations at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: Basketball at Baruch: No Frills but Plenty of Fun
description: Julie Levine, the coach of the Baruch College basketball team, looked up at the bent rim of the basket in the Hunter College gym, his face a taut reflection of the big-time anxiety that rankles in the breast of the small-time college coach.

title: SOUTH AFRICA MAKES TACTICAL RETREAT ON BLACK RIGHTS
description: Festooning his remarks with quotations from a British anti-slavery crusader and Abraham Lincoln, the South African official who by law has vast powers to regulate the lives of the black majority unveiled a package of legislation late last year that, he said, marked the beginning of an irreversible process of betterment for blacks who have managed to establish themselves in urban areas.

title: A Judge Cools Off a Hot L.I.R.R. Commuter
description: Chalk up another victory, of sorts, for Richard M. Kessel, director of a group called Long Island Consumer Action and scourge of the Metropolitan Transit Authority, the Long Island Lighting Company and, most frequently, the Long Island Rail Road.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in The Times yesterday misstated the size of the Postal Service's Federal subsidy. It has been about $1.7 billion a year, but the Reagan Administration has urged reduction by $632 million next year and further in coming years.

title: IRANIAN SEES PALME ON PEACE TERMS
description: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr discussed with a United Nations envoy today the ''principles on which agreement could be reached'' to end the war with Iraq. But he said the primary principle remained that there would be no negotiations until Iraqis withdrew from Iran.

title: FOR A JUDICIOUS CHOICE OF JUDGES
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ISRAEL SPONSOR DEVELOPMENT GROUP
description: The coffee shop at Cincinnati's airport seems an unlikely place in which to promote a business deal involving funds from the United States and Israeli Governments. But not to Abraham I. Mlavsky, who typically finds himself in an Israeli kibbutz one day and an American corporate board room the next.

title: PLAY COSMETICS FOR CHILDREN: DISSENTING VOICES ARE HEARD
description: After Barbie, what? The toy industry has been concerned for a number of years about the lack of playthings for little girls who had outgrown dolls. Except for Barbie and the other so-called fashion dolls that could be dressed up, there wasn't much that could be sold to those of ages 7, 8 and 9.

title: Pistons Give Up On Bob McAdoo
description: Bob McAdoo, the Pistons' forward, will sit out the rest of the season but will be paid, an official of the team said today.

title: Energy
description: Six oil ministers of OPEC, meeting in Geneva, moved toward reducing production to keep prices high. Saudi Arabia was reported ready to increase the basic price of its crude oil to $34 a barrel, from $32, while cutting output about 2 million barrels a day. (Page 1.)

title: SPANISH AIDE FAILS IN FIRST BID TO SET UP GOVERNMENT
description: Deputy Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo failed tonight to win the absolute majority he needed in the lower house of Parliament to form a new Government, forcing another vote in Parliament Monday.

title: RABBI DAVID BERENT
description: Rabbi David Berent, retired spiritual leader of Congregation Beth Jacob, and former rabbi at Beth Judah Synagogue, Wildwood, N.J., died yesterday at Deerfield Beach, Fla.

title: A HIDDEN SUBSIDY FOR PRIVATE EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: TREATING BALDNESS: F.D.A. STEPS IN
description: P RODUCTS that profess to grow hair or prevent its loss appear to be but a hairbreadth away from being relegated to the Food and Drug Administration's Category II, a division reserved for products not generally recognized by the agency as being safe or effective and considered improperly labeled for over-the-counter use. The products under scrutiny -most often they contain such ingredients as lanolin, wheat germ, olive oil and vitamins - are generally sold by mail or through barbers and beauticians.

title: Kings 112, Bucks 109
description: Otis Birdsong scored a basket and Scott Wedman made two free throws in the last minute to help the Kansas City Kings defeat the Milwaukee Bucks, 112-109, tonight. The victory was the fifth straight for Kansas City and its eighth in a row at home.

title: FOTIU SAYS FANS INCITED CLASH
description: Nick Fotiu, who almost certainly faces a league fine if not suspension for leading a Ranger charge into the stands to get at fans after Thursday night's game in Detroit, said yesterday that he and his teammates had been pelted with debris throughout the game.

title: Thomson Buys Litton Unit
description: International Thomson Organization Ltd. said today that it had purchased the money-losing publishing interests of Litton Industries Inc. for about $61 million (United States), subject to United States Government notification requirements.

title: KNICKS, LED BY GLENN'S 21, SET BACK BULLETS BY 124-112
description: Bench strength was the key for the Knicks as they defeated the Washington Bullets, 124-112, last night at Madison Square Garden. Reserve players scored 51 points, including 21 by Mike Glenn in 18 minutes of playing time.

title: Tom Streithorst, Correspondent For NBC News in San Francisco
description: Tom Streithorst, an NBC News correspondent who underwent a heart transplant operation in 1978, died Thursday at Stanford University Medical Center after a heart attack. He was 49 years old.

title: FROM WASHINGTON AND EL SALVADOR, DIFFERING VIEWS ON FIGHTING REBELS
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte, the President of El Salvador's ruling junta, said today that despite the debate in Washington over military aid, economic aid was more important to his country.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. Roy M. Cohn. 2. The Philippines. 3. 83. The military outlays. 4. The Mayor named Mrs. Gerard, an economist, New York City's Deputy Mayor for economic policy and development. 5.

title: HARRY LEDER
description: Harry Leder, chief photographer for United Press International, died Thursday at the Long Island Jewish Hospital, in New Hyde Park.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: What's it like to be a stand-in and sometimes double and stuntman for a movie star for 40 years? ''It's a lot of fun and memories, if the guy you stand in for is Mickey Rooney,'' said Sig Frohlich yesterday. He spoke on the telephone from a set in Los Angeles, just before Mr. Rooney was to throw him an appreciation party for ''all the years we've been together.'

title: SPECIAL PRINCETON ASSISTANT
description: Dr. Frederic E. Fox, keeper of Princetoniana and a familiar figure to generations of Princeton students and alumni, died yesterday at Princeton Hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: Dutch Stand By Submarine Sale
description: Saying that his Government ''must stand by its word,'' Prime Minister Andreas A.M. van Agt gave final approval today for the sale of two submarines to Nationalist China. The decision came despite threats of diplomatic and financial reprisals against the Netherlands by the Peking Government. The parliamentary opposition is expected to use the issue to try to bring down Mr. Van Agt's center-right coalition Government.

title: 10 Indicted in Philadelphia
description: Philip Testa, reputed heir to the late Angelo Bruno as an organized crime leader in Philadelphia, and nine other men were freed on bail today in Federal indictments stemming from an inquiry into racketeering and illegal gambling.

title: THEATER: BERRY'S 'WHALES OF AUGUST'
description: In David Berry's ''The Whales of August,'' at the Trinity Square Repertory Company, it is the mid-1950's, and two elderly sisters are living out the summers of their twilight years on a small island off the coast of Maine. Libby, at 86, is a formidable Yankee lady who is progressively shutting down each of her senses. Sarah, a romantic, at 75 is still youthful and vital, and as she watches her sister's decline she begins to grasp at a renewed hope for her own future; she can change, she can grow. As these close, endearing women search for a calm, we learn their shared and private dreams and we can feel the salt air of their wry recriminations.

title: OPERA: 'MERRY WIVES' BEGINS SPRING SEASON
description: ONE of the more charming interludes of last fall's New York City Opera season was its new production of ''The Merry Wives of Windsor,'' with William Wildermann prancing goutily and hilariously through the same Falstaffian part that he had taken 25 years earlier in the company's previous production of Otto Nicolai's light classic. Last night, the City Opera opened its spring season with ''The Merry Wives,'' and again it was Mr. Wildermann's show.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOUND OF MUSIC

title: Caterpillar Co.  Wins Tax Case
description: The Illinois Supreme Court ruled in favor of the Caterpillar Tractor Company today in a complex tax case that pitted the manufacturer of construction equipment and earth-moving machinery against such corporate concerns as the CocaCola Company and Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: HEROIN SEIZED IN HONG KONG
description: Hong Kong customs officers seized 26 pounds of heroin worth $1.4 million today. A Government spokesman said a man and a woman were arrested.

title: ODD RECIPES: A NEW BATCH
description: The fascination of the bizarre seems just about as strong as the appeal of excellence. That conclusion might easily be drawn from the dozens of letters sent by readers in response to a recent column describing outlandish recipes culled from food packages, magazines, fund-raising cookbooks and advertisements.

title: News Analysis
description: When President Reagan suggested this week that labor leaders were ''out of step'' with their own rank and file in last year's election and in their opposition to his Administration's economic program, union chiefs gathered here indignantly rejected the notion.

title: Pacers 109, Spurs 106
description: George McGinnis converted two turnovers into 4 points in the final 30 seconds to give the Indiana Pacers a 109-106 victory over the San Antonio Spurs tonight. McGinnis, who led the Pacers with 24 points and 12 rebounds, grabbed a ball knocked away by Mike Bantom and hit a layup that gave Indiana a 107-106 lead with 17 seconds to play. Four seconds later, he hit two free throws after recovering the basketball when it was taken away from Paul Griffin of the Spurs.

title: SPECIAL STATE PANEL CALLS FOR TIGHTER ANTIFIRE MEASURES
description: New York State's Special Fire Safety Task Force recommended yesterday that all public buildings in the state be required to install safety devices to halt the spread of fire, possibly including sprinklers. It also called for the creation of statewide fire and building codes that all municipalities would be required to adopt as minimum levels of safety.

title: The Gulf in the Gulf Command
description: The most vital step in any military operation is to appoint a commander to run it. But in preparing to defend Persian Gulf oil, the Carter Administration did this old adage four better: it gave control of the new Rapid Deployment Force to five different military authorities. The force's command structure has been described by one of its highest officers as ''a nightmare.'' And that's in peacetime.

title: MIME: YASS HAKOSHIMA
description: Yass Hakoshima is a mime with an interesting turn of mind. In ''Surgeon,'' one of 11 pieces presented on Thursday at Japan House, he plays a doctor who empties his patient's gut, then climbs into the cavity and is lost in inner space.

title: SOME PHONE CHARGES FREED OF CONTROL
description: State controls on the prices that hotels, motels and hospitals can charge for the use of room telephones for calls within the state will end March 15. The ruling, made today by the Public Service Commission, leaves them free to charge whatever they choose.

title: Chrysler Extends Rebates
description: Chrysler Corporation Chairman Lee Iacocca said today that the ailing auto maker will continue a buyer rebate program after the scheduled Feb. 28 cutoff date now that the firm's competitors have announced similar rebate offers. Mr. Iacocca, in town for a preview of the annual Chicago Auto Show, said the 2 1/2-month rebate program so far has given Chrysler a larger share of the 1981 market than the company had anticipated. Since early December, Chrysler has been giving credit buyers of most vehicles checks equal to 7 percent of the total sticker price of the car.

title: HOUSE'S BUDGET CHIEF TOURS CITY ON VISIT OF FISCAL MERCY
description: In a Coney Island junior high school, on a trash-strewn Borough Park lot where housing is to rise, on a subway car that rolled past graffiti-splotched BMT platforms, the House of Representatives budget chairman searched New York City yesterday for programs that might be spared from budget cuts.

title: Stearns May Be Out Past Season Opener
description: Trouble arrived in the training camp of the New York Mets today as the pitchers and catchers begin arriving for their first workout tomorrow: John Stearns, the No. 1 catcher, said that his right index finger was still swollen and that he was no longer certain he would be ready to open the regular season on April 9.

title: Sunshine Mining Buys Hecla Shares
description: The Sunshine Mining Company said yesterday that it had purchased 370,206 common shares of the Hecla Mining Company, or about 5.3 percent of Hecla's outstanding, and that it might seek to gain control of the silver, zinc and lead producer.

title: MR. REAGAN'S ILLINOIS
description: Tampico, Dixon, Galesburg, Monmouth, Eureka - poking around Ronald Reagan's Illinois, one perceives immediately how close to his roots the President is.

title: GUNS, DEFENDING PROPERTY AND THE LAW
description: Manual Marin's small, two-story house had been invaded by burglars three times before. And so when he saw a man and woman walk around to his back porch, he said, then heard them prying open his door, he called the police and waited in the kitchen, gun in hand.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE ENGINES PASS TEST, BUT WALKOUT THREATENS NEW DELAY
description: The main rocket engines of the space shuttle Columbia roared to full power here today in a brief but crucial test giving project officials confidence that the re-usable spacecraft, after a plague of development troubles, should be ready to fly in April.

title: SCIENCE POST CHANGE WEIGHED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan is reconsidering what kind of science advice he needs, and the duties of the Presidential science adviser may be downgraded or transferred out of the White House, a high-ranking White House official said today.

title: Democrats Plan Move to Declare Rep. Spellman's Seat as Vacant
description: The House Democratic leadership announced Friday that it would move to declare vacant the Congressional seat of Representative Gladys Noon Spellman, Democrat of Maryland, who has been hospitalized since October when she was stricken by a severe heart attack.

title: Amoco of Britain Makes Gas Find
description: Amoco (U.K.) Ltd., a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), said a consortium it leads had made a significant oil and natural gas discovery in the British North Sea.

title: Music; HARTFORD POPS IN TRIBUTE TO FIEDLER
description: IT is going to be a busy two weeks for three of the state's major orchestras, and busiest of all -with four concerts over the next six days - is the Hartford Symphony.

title: AT HOME
description: SOMETHING was wrong. As I drove home from the supermarket, turning each corner slowly so that the bags of groceries in the back of the car would remain upright, the checkout clerk's face flashed in my mind's eye again and again.

title: Taxi Hustlers
description: To the Editor:

title:
On the Isle;
FREE CHAMBER SERIES
description: The Nassau County Office of Cultural Development has arranged for six free chamber music concerts - to be offered from one end of the county to the other. Starting today with I Solisti da Camera, which, under Seymour Benstock's direction, will play the ''Orchestral Suites'' of J.S. Bach at 3 P.M. at Congregation Beth Emeth, 36 Franklin Avenue in Hewlett, the series will surface periodically on Sundays through May 31. For a complete schedule, call 484-9333.JEWISH ROOTS

title: Music: Debuts in Review; William Maiben, Pianist, Offers All-Debussy Bill
description: William Maiben's debut concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday evening was an unusual and a difficult one. The piano music of Debussy filled the entire program - including all 12 of the ''Etudes,'' the early set of ''Images'' from 1894 and scattered exotica from obscurer corners of the Debussy literature.

title: Brigham Young 78 New Mexico 72
description: Danny Ainge and Fred Roberts scored 19 points each as Brigham Young held off New Mexico, 78-72, today in a Western Athletic Conference game.

title: ABOUT TO BE HUMAN
description: LUCY The Beginnings of Humankind. By Donald C. Johanson and Maitland A. Edey. Illustrated. 409 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: HEROINES GROWING UP
description: A GOOD SPORT By Julia Whedon. 197 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $10.95. PRISMS By Marianne Mackay. 376 pp. New York: Seaview Books. $12.95. By BRINA CAPLAN

title: Notes; WORKING IN THE WILDERNESS
description: The American Hiking Society is looking for volunteers to spend two weeks during the summer working in wilderness areas, mostly in the West, with the National Forest Service.

title: North Carolina 75, Clemson 61
description: Al Wood, a senior forward playing in his last home game, scored 23 points to lead North Carolina to a 75-61 victory over Clemson today in an Atlantic Coast Conference game. day.

title: More on Jogging
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: 'PARADE'S' DANCES MADE INTO CURTAIN RAISER
description: Opera companies have traditionally treated ballet as a secondary art form, and this contempt rears its usual head in the new version of ''Parade,'' the ballet that opened the evening of three new productions presented by the Metropolitan Opera on Friday night.

title: Cynthia Carter Fiancee Of Shirley Edward Ayres
description: Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Owen Carter Jr. of Wassaic, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Austin Carter to Shirley Edward Ayres, son of Mrs. James Ernest Ayres of Farmville, Va., and the late Mr. Ayres.

title: Elizabeth J. Liptrot Engaged To Jeffrey William Moos
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Liptrot of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Jane Liptrot, to Jeffrey William Moos, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Moos of Greenfield, Wis.

title: Brooks's New U.S. Six Is Phantom Team
description: A year after his Olympic team beat the Russians on the way to winning the gold medal that glittered briefly around the world, Herb Brooks is again the coach of the American national hockey squad.

title: More on Purse-Slashing
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Journal
description: ANUCLEAR Regulatory Commission official says his agency will conduct ''a re-evaluation of the management structure and technical competence'' next month of the Consolidated Edison Company in connection with its operation of the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant.

title: ATLANTA LABORS TO FIND WHO IS KILLING ITS CHILDREN
description: ''The missing and murdered children'' is spoken as a single word here in a distraught city frustrated by the baffling, unsolved deaths of 18 children and the mysterious disappearances of two others in the past 19 months.

title: Miss Thuerk Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Christina Campbell Thuerk to Steven Pincus has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh D. Thuerk of Easton, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Pincus of Rye, N.Y.

title: VOCATIONAL SCHOOLS GET NEW GUIDELINES
description: In response to allegations of abuses in the industry, the New York State Department of Education has recently overhauled its efforts to monitor the state's 351 proprietary vocational schools.

title: DEPAUL (23-1 TURNS BACK MARQUETTE, 78-71
description: Mark Aguirre scored 24 points tonight but he might have easily made it 30 or more as he led De Paul to its 10th straight victory and 23d of the season by beating Marquette, 78-71, at the Horizon.

title: m Over the years with my husband, who assumes - and other people assume - that he is a math genius, I've seen him add up the check for a group and, more often than not, get the short end of the stick. He later complains that somebody bilked him, since he's had time to go over the details in his head and made a miscalculation originally.
description: He is also a low tipper, and once had a taxi driver fling his paltry tip at our feet. Once, when I dropped him off at work, $20 bills blew away from him on the snow; he must have pushed them into a pocket with a hole.

title: The Real Pfitzner
description: To the Editor:

title: Antiques; THE BIG WORLD OF LITTLE MATCHSAFES
description: At an antiques show 15 years ago, Carol Barden found a Victorian silver matchsafe handsomely embellished with an enamel butterfly. She bought it for $4. ''I liked it and could afford it,'' she recalled the other day. And she used the box, not with the tiny wax friction matches that the striker was made to store, but with big wooden matches.

title: PALME SAYS TALKS IN IRAN PROVE SLOW AND DIFFICULT
description: Olof Palme, the special United Nations envoy who is completing his third peace mission to Teheran, said today that moves toward ending the war between Iran and Iraq were proving slow and difficult.

title: No Headline
description: Coghlan Switches Tactics in Record Mile

title: Itchy Trigger Fingers
description: The ranks of clearly pro-Soviet Afghans are so thin that Moscow can't afford to deplete them accidentally.

title: Wisconsin 77, Ohio State 63
description: Wisconsin, led by Larry Petty's 25 points, took a 15-point first-half lead and then coasted to a 77-63 Big Ten victory over Ohio State today.

title: Diana Dent to Be a Bride June 6
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Bailey Dent of Spartanburg, S.C., of the engagement of their daughter, Diana Gwynn Dent, to Theodore Alexander McGraw Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McGraw of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART Over the past 50 and some years, it has been very difficult to be a young Italian painter. First there was the dead weight of fascism.

title: Plant Service Is in Commercial Field
description: A few weeks ago an article mentioned Margie Taylor and her business, Plant Parenthood (''Empty Houses Get a Checkup,'' Long Island Housing).

title: About Westchester
description: TUCKAHOE THEY were gathered at the offices of the Westchester County Historical Society here, in a house whose rooms are filled with yellowing books and portraits of men and women long dead. They were receiving instructions in how to obtain facts and feelings from those still living, to give an interview, to gently cull from an individual the details that added up to a life.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Economics of Hope

title: No Headline
description: Childhood is not just a period of immaturity but a state of being safely dependent, of being told the rules and being protected. There can be no childhood without having adults in charge.

title: Disease-Monitoring Center Says Epidemic of Flu Is Nearly Ended
description: A sharp decline in influenza and pneumonia deaths throughout the United States has been reported by public health officials, indicating an apparent end to a flu epidemic that started before Christmas.

title: SWINDLER REPORTED TO HAVE PREYED ON FRATERNITIES
description: Nancy J. Cain, indicted by a Federal grand jury this week on charges of fraud by wire and impersonating a Federal officer, has hoodwinked dozens of college fraternity members into buying her clothes, food and travel worth hundreds of thousands of dollars, according to law enforcement officials.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS GRUMBLE THAT LEADERS ARE DRIFTING
description: Liberal and conservative Democrats in the House of Representatives have become increasingly dissatisfied with the party's leadership because of what they perceive as its failure to provide assertive political direction, according to interviews with a wide spectrum of Democratic members and their aides.

title: Dining Out; A BISTRO THAT'S A SOUTH SHORE RARITY
description: CAFE DU PARC in Wantagh is a fairly pleasant French bistro in an area - the South Shore of Nassau County - where restaurants of this type are a rarity. The restaurant is white stucco inside and out, a somewhat austere setting that has been made more felicitous by the use of indirect lighting and the addition of paintings on the walls. The tables are covered with linen and are nicely appointed, but many of them are quite narrow, becoming somewhat cramped when set for four. The dining room staff seems to be kept at a bare minimum, but the servers make every effort to be gracious, concerned and attentive.

title: IMPACT OF HARRIS TRIAL ON COURT CALENDAR
description: WHITE PLAINS ALTHOUGH the murder trial of Jean S. Harris has been the longest in recent memory in Westchester County, law enforcement officials say, it has not had an adverse impact on the judicial system here, which was already overburdened when pretrial hearings in the case began last Oct. 6.

title: LISA A. GRIMALDI TO BE BRIDE OF JAMES CRONIN ON AUG. 8
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Grimaldi of Deer Park, L.I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Ann Grimaldi, to James G. Cronin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Cronin of Richmond Hill, Queens.

title: Celtics Stop Rally, Beat Pistons, 130-119
description: Cedric Maxwell scored 10 of his 26 points in the fourth quarter last night to help the Boston Celtics to a 130-119 victory over the Detroit Pistons in Pontiac, Mich.

title: IN CONCLAVE, KREMLIN FACES A WEB OF DILEMMAS
description: With the same prudence that makes them deploy a company of troops behind the back fence at a popular soccer game, the authorities have been seeding Moscow with extra police and controlling access to the capital. Who knows what excitements might bounce off the 26th Communist Party Congress opening tomorrow inside the Kremlin?

title: Future Events Hither and Yon
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:To Babylon by SubwayFeb. 25 - A reachable place by subway or bus is the Sanctuary of St. Peter's Lutheran Church on Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, where Derek Walcott, author, and Galt MacDermot, composer, will present the first New York concert version of their new musical, ''O, Babylon!'' The plot tells of Rastafarians ready to swap their problems on the island of Jamaica for the good life, such as it was in ancient Babylon. An offering of St. Peter's Jazz Ministry, which believes that spirituality and the arts are bound together inseparably, the new work is part reggae and part other West Indian music sung by five singers backed by the 11-member New Pulse Band. At 8 o'clock, Mr. Walcott will read from his other works and Mr. MacDermot will play from his own before intermission, after which comes ''O, Babylon!'' The audience must enter and leave the Sanctuary by way of the Living Room, where a wine, cheese and fruit reception with all performers ends the evening. Proceeds will support the Common set up by the church in 1976 as a nonsectarian arts and cultural organization that coordinates and produces nonecclesiastical events in St. Peter's public places -the Sanctuary, the Off Broadway Theater, the Living Room, the Music Room and the Studio. Tickets are $25 from 935-2200.

title: CHAMBER: BUSWELL FILLS IN
description: Shlomo Mintz's continuing bout with influenza meant that he was unable to fulfill his guest engagement with the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society in Alice Tully Hall on Friday night. Undaunted, the society called on its resident first violinist, James Buswell, and the concert proceeded without a change in the program.

title: Loughlin Wins 3 At Fordham Meet
description: Bishop Loughlin won three events, and St. John the Baptist, with Lloyd Gellineau running the mile anchor leg in 4 minutes 18.8 seconds, took the distance medley yesterday in a Catholic high schools relay meet.

title: IN MORROCCO,THERE'S A BIT OF LONG ISLAND
description: adorned tomb of his father, Mohammed V, there is a touch of Long Island.

title: Rebecca Peterson Fiancee of Ens. Edward Clark of Navy
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Peck Peterson of Los Altos Hills, Calif., and Sargentville, Me., of the engagement of her daughter, Rebecca Cecilia Peterson, to Ens. Edward Schuyler Clark, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wemple Clark of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: P.A. Magnin Fiance Of Diana E. Walsh
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. James Walsh Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diana Elizabeth Walsh, to Paul Andre Magnin, son of Esta Magnin of Princeton and Dr. Jean-Pierre Magnin of Paris.

title: Labor Leader Cites Legislator's Omissions
description: Representative Christine M. Niedermeier's Jan. 25 article (''For a Tighter Rein on Federal Aid'') lamenting the problems created for state revenue sources by the use of Federal funds was curiously lacking in two major respects.

title: Film View; KEEPING MOVIE AUDIENCES AT A CHILLY DISTANCE
description: ''The Dogs of War'' is not a watershed movie, the sort that somehow changes the look of - and response to - all movies that come after. Yet it represents the kind of movie that, in this era of increasingly predictable entertainments, resolutely refuses to take the easy way. It invites speculation. You might call it a long-shot film.

title: RAPE AND A MURDER
description: ASKING FOR IT By Joan Taylor. 212 pp. New York: Congdon & Lattes. $10.95.

title: LONG BEACH MOVES TO PROTECT ITS WATER
description: LONG BEACH RESIDENTS of this South Shore city are concerned about the possible loss of their drinking water, and as a result they have mounted a strong protest against an attempt by the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center to tap the Lloyd aquifer, the only source of fresh water available to Long Beach and its neighboring communities along the Long Beach barrier island.

title: DISCIPLES OF MERCE CUNNINGHAM ARE TODAY'S AVANT-GARDE
description: Merce Cunningham broke away from the modern dance of Martha Graham to create a radically different style of dance. His was dance that discarded the elements of theme or plot, music, and costumes and decor, concentrating on what the dance photographer James Klosty has called the simple kinetic integrity of the body. Cunningham dance combined the elegance and virtuosity of ballet with the plainness of ordinary activity for a theater of pure movement, spilled out through and layered in stage space to approximate the unexpected and visual complexity of everyday modern life.

title: SOME NEWCOMERS SOUND LIKE OLDTIMERS
description: So powerful were the Republicans last November that, even in the liberal bellwether states of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, many Democrats could offer only scant resistance. As a consequence, the Democratic margin in the region's combined congressional delegations slipped from a commanding 41 to 19 to a less formidable 34 to 26. Those losses must have loomed even larger last week to Democratic leaders in Congress, who confronted the task of staving off President Reagan's cuts in Federal aid.

title: THATCHER COMES CALLING: EVEN GOOD PARTNERS MAY DISAGREE
description: Last month, during the Senate confirmation hearings for Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., an official at 10 Downing Street greeted an American friend with excerpts from the previous day's testimony, received in an overnight diplomatic cable from Washington.

title: FOR EUROPE'S LEFT, SALVADOR HELPS TO FUEL U.S. DISTRUST
description: For a segment of Western Europe's left, El Salvador is a windfall. Exotic, blessedly far from home and potentially confirming a post-Vietnam generation's notions of the misuse of United States power, the controversy over the little war is packed with possibilities for simplistic portrayal.

title: No Headline
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Old-Style Firearms And Their Rituals
description: WHY ever-increasing numbers of hunters in this country go forth with muzzle-loading weapons is something of a puzzle. Nostalgia plays a part in this, to be sure. It is fun to make believe that one is back in the days of Lewis and Clark, but this Miniver Cheevy syndrome does not explain everything.

title: Memorandum to The President
description: In ''Memorandum to the President'' (Jan. 18), Leslie H. Gelb warns President Reagan ''about: (1) the misperceptions (he) might be entertaining ... about the governmental setting in Washington, and (2) the policy mistakes that might be inherent in the intellectual and political baggage (he) and (his) team carry.'' Mr. Reagan has just stepped into office. Do we know for a fact that he has misperceptions about his job and is bringing a clutter of political baggage along that will serve him no good?

title: African Ghosts
description: To the Editor:

title: REDUCTION OF AID TO CITIES 'UNCONSCIONABLE'
description: RECENTLY I spent two weeks in and around some of the cities of Texas, a state of relative economic prosperity and growth. In the whirlwind of development, one understands why Sun Belt residents either do not comprehend or fail to empathize with the plight of those who reside in the Northeast.

title: FORDHAM WINNER BY 66-59
description: Clutch foul shooting in the last five minutes enabled Fordham to defeat Holy Cross, 66-59, yesterday before a capacity crowd of 3,228 at the Rams' Rose Hill Gymnasium.

title: No Headline
description: SNEED 64 GAINS TIE FOR LEAD

title: The Young Tune In, Turn Off to Drugs
description: The romance of drugs, which for the past two decades has held more and more adolescents in thrall, seems to be losing its allure for high school students of today, according to a national survey of drug use released last week.

title: COLLEGES SEEK PROFIT IN RESEARCH
description: NEW HAVEN CONNECTICUT universities, eager to strengthen their finances, are re-examining their relationship with the business community with an eye toward capitalizing on the potentially lucrative research being done in school laboratories.

title: Children's Books
description: McGOOGAN MOVES THE MIGHTY ROCK Written and Illustrated By Dick Gackenbach. 40 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $8.95. (Ages 6 to 9) By GEORGE A.WOODS

title: CAST ALBUMS OF HITS YIELD TWO MISSES
description: The original cast albums of ''42nd St.,'' ''Barnum,'' and ''A Day In Hollywood/A Night in the Ukraine'' illustrate the plight of a Broadway musical theater overdosed on nostalgia and mired in musical formulas. With their success at the box office dependent less on music than on spectacle -all three are lavish fantasies of show business history - only ''Hollywood/ Ukraine'' treats its music as anything more than an adjunct of the production. ''42nd St.'' exudes the brassy vulgarity of a Las Vegas floor show, minus the lubricity, while the score of ''Barnum'' is so weak it has no life at all outside the production.

title: DON MALONEY SCORES 3 AS RANGERS WIN, 6-4
description: Don Maloney, reunited with his regular linemates in the second period, scored three goals within 2 minutes 30 seconds to rally the New York Rangers to a 6-4 victory over the Washington Capitals last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Miss Coleman, Bank Official, Becomes Bride
description: Susan Norton Coleman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Coleman Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill., and Douglas Charles William Greenwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E.D. Greenwood of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., were married yesterday.

title: Cutbacks in Medicaid
description: Localities may suffer as a result of cutbacks in certain Medicaid programs, according to the City Council President, Carol Bellamy, even though the state intends to start phasing in a takeover of the local costs of the program.

title: STEPS ARE TAKEN TO AID ELDERLY IN HOTEL PLIGHT
description: Government and private agencies are taking steps to rebuild the supply of hotel housing for the elderly poor in Manhattan, many of whom have been displaced from single-room occupancy hotels as the buildings convert to market-rate housing.

title:
DINING OUT;
A GOOD BET NEAR THE SPORTS COMPLEX
description: THE Park & Orchard is one of those out-of-the-way little gems one is constantly seeking but seldom discovers. Although it is billed as a natural-food restaurant by its young owners, the dishes are eclectic and substantial enough to appeal to all but the most dedicated meat-and-potato types.

title: UTILITIES ACT TO EASE FEAR OF SERVICE CUTOFF ,
description: Having been detained at her dentist's office, the woman called her home to tell her family that she would be late. A recording interrupted. ''The number you have called has been temporarily disconnected,'' it said.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; IRENE KASSORLA
description: Dr. Irene Kassorla is a glamorous Los Angeles psychologist who has been dubbed ''shrink to the stars'' by Merv Griffin because of her prominent Hollywood patients. And it was the first star she treated, back in 1968 in London, who inspired her to write her current best seller, ''Nice Girls Do.''

title: Betsy Slotnick to Be Married To Jan Wolansky in August
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Slotnick of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Betsy Ann Slotnick, to Jan Robert Wolansky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Wolansky of Cranford, Conn.

title: Iona 68, Central Connecticut 66
description: Jeff Williams hit both ends of a oneand-one free-throw situation with 31 seconds remaining in overtime to give Iona a 68-66 victory over Central Connecticut State today.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: WHEN William Billard was 17 years old, his mother-in-law gave him $5,000, and, instead of buying a sports car with it, he made a down payment on a lot in Fort Lee.

title:
Dining Out;
SOME INNOVATIONS FROM PARIS
description: BUFFET DE LA GARE in Hastings has undergone a change of ownership and kitchen management. It is pleasant to be able to report that the change has done the quality of food no harm; in fact, except for a few minor instances to be noted, the general level of cooking is a bit higher than it was, and it was already very good. Considering the depressing level of French cuisine in the southern part of the county, that is an important reassurance.

title: TV View
description: 'THE GANGSTER CHRONICLES'-A FLASHY PORTRAIT OF SOME UNPRETTY PEOPLE By John J.O'Connor

title: WALL STREET'S AGATHA CHRISTIE
description: There's just no rest for John Putnam Thatcher. You know Mr. Thatcher. He's the senior vice president of the venerable Sloan Guaranty Trust Company, third biggest bank in the world. Here's what's happening: he's out at the Winter Olympics, since Sloan is the official Olympics bank, and he's placidly watching the ski jump practice runs when all of a sudden the French star comes swooping down the ramp and - jumping Eurodollars! -he's shot dead.

title: 10 Missile Warheads Are Found In Building Near Newark Airport
description: Ten conventional missile warheads were discovered in an export warehouse in an industrial area behind Newark International Airport in Elizabeth, N.J., Friday, but officials said yesterday that they were satisfied there had been no danger to the public or violation of law.
