title: EUROPE'S SPACE AGENCY IS TAKING OFF ON ITS OWN
description: A historian at the University of California, Walter A. McDougall, recently observed that between the two world wars one definition of a great power might have been a nation that builds its own airplanes. Today, he said, it might be a nation that launches its own spacecraft.

title: R. S. Paroly Fiance Of Corinne Bernard
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard S. Bernard of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Corinne Bernard, to Richard S. Paroly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Paroly of West Orange, N.J.

title: Peru Bids Neutral Lands Verify Copter's Shooting
description: Peru, charging that one of its helicopters was shot down by Ecuador in yesterday's border clash, invited neutral observers today to verify its accusations.

title: HARD TIMES FOR BLACK WRITERS
description: IN 1969 Hoyt W. Fuller, then editor of the Chicago-based literary magazine Negro Digest, in commenting on the ferment in black writing and publishing, said: ''We are in the middle of a literary renaissance. Black Americans have glimpsed new possibilities in the world, and there is excitement everywhere. The new black writers do not have to court the critical establishment; they have their own publications ... and when the publishing establishment beckons, it must - more often than not - take the black writer on the black writer's terms. That is revolutionary.''

title: Childs Dance Company At Marymount Next Month
description: The Lucinda Childs Dance Company will present the New York premieres of two dances from Miss Childs's new ''Relative Calm'' in a season at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, from March 12 to 15.

title: No Headline
description: With last week's state of the economy message as its bugle call, the Reagan Administration has set out to turn back history, at least as far as the Federal role in education goes.

title: OPPOSITION GROWING TO REPORT ON SLUDGE
description: WHITE PLAINS WESTCHESTER should be allowed to continue dumping sewage sludge in the ocean and, if necessary, should carry it out to the edge of the Continental Shelf, rather than follow a consultant's advice and spread it on open land in the county, County Executive Alfred B. DelBello said last week.

title: FAULKNER WAS WRONG ABOUT 'SANCTUARY'
description: SANCTUARY: THE ORIGINAL TEXT By William Faulkner. Edited, with an Afterword and Notes, by Noel Polk. 311 pp. New York: Random House. $14.95. WILLIAM FAULKNER His Life and Work. By David Minter. 325 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $16.95. By MALCOLM COWLEY

title: A Policy Switch In Sex Education?
description: In keeping with the philosophy that put an avowed advocate of its abolition in charge of the Department of Energy and sought to do the same with the Department of Education, the Reagan Administration last week said that it was seriously considering an antiabortion activist to head the Federal Office of Adolescent Pregnancy Programs.

title: THE WORLD IN SUMMARY
description: The Guatemalan Army is ''a school for murderers'' and its leading graduate, President Romeo Lucas Garcia, supervises the agency that operates ''the Government program of murder and torture,'' Amnesty International charged last week.

title: GOVERNORS WARNED OF EFFECT ON STATES OF REAGAN'S BUDGET
description: The Reagan Administration's budget offers the states greater flexibility in handling Federal aid, but at the cost of revenue cuts that will cause ''dislocation for state budgets,'' the nation's governors were told today.

title: DEBATE OVER SHYLOCK SIMMERS ONCE AGAIN
description: ''Hath not a Jew eyes? Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions? - fed with the same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer as a Christian is? If you prick us, do we not bleed? If you tickle us, do we not laugh? If you poison us, do we not die? And if you wrong us, shall we not revenge?''

title: CAN THIS BE LIBERATION?
description: THE rumble-seat roadster pulls up in front of the little house where the porch light is still burning. A couple in saddle shoes step lightly to the ground, then linger toe to toe under the light for a long moment, until a voice hollers from an upstairs window.

title: Dartmouth 54, Columbia 52
description: Larry Lawrence scored a game-high 21 points in leading Dartmouth to a 54-52 Ivy League victory over Columbia Saturday night at Levien Gymnasium.

title: Va. Tech 71, Memphis St. 70
description: A basket by Mickey Hardy with 1 minute 5 seconds left and two free throws by Reggie Steppe with 14 seconds remaining brought Virginia Tech a 71-70 Metro Conference victory over Memphis State today.

title: Hawks 118, Cavaliers 105
description: John Drew scored 29 points and Eddie Johnson had 24 to lead Atlanta's victory over Cleveland. Johnson scored 17 of his points in the first half, and Drew scored 17 in the second half.

title: Canadiens 4, Red Wings 1
description: Guy Lafleur scored two goals for the Canadiens, who extended their undefeated streak to eight games. Montreal, which is also undefeated in its last 18 games at home, took a 1-0 lead at 8 minutes 55 seconds of the first period on a goal by Lafleur while Detroit had two players in the penalty box.

title: SMITHTOWN WEIGHS FLEA MARKET CURBS
description: SMITHTOWN lawmakers are reviewing an amendment to the town code that could make it more difficult for a flea market to set up in Smithtown than any other town on the Island.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1981
description: International The Pentagon toughened its position toward the NATO allies. Deputy Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci told them that the United States could not be expected to increase its military contribution in Europe or other areas unless the allies contributed their ''fair share.'' Mr. Carlucci, seeking assistance in developing a a ''mature alliance,'' asked the allies to adopt an ''expanded concept of European security'' that would take in the Persian Gulf area. (Page 1, Column 1.) Moscow's anti-Western campaign became more aggressive as the opening of the 26th congress of the Soviet Communist Party approached. Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Soviet Defense Minister, accused the West of conducting an offensive against detente and trying to reopen the cold war. The Soviet press campaign, building up over the last month, appears intended to prepare the people for more sacrifices to counter the West. (1:3-4.)

title: REAGAN MOVING ON START OF FLEET OF NEW BOMBERS
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to ask Congress for about $2.5 billion next year to begin building a fleet of new long-range bombers capable of penetrating Soviet defenses well into the next century, according to Pentagon officials.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST ENERGY FAIR WARMS POLITICIANS
description: IF politics makes for strange bedfellows, it can also produce an unlikely construction crew. The ''Energy Saving Home of the Future'' that will highlight Westchester County's first Energy Fair has brought together politicians who, in the past, have disagreed about energy issues in the county.

title: Lynn T. Kishbaugh Engineer's Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Kishbaugh of Hyde Park, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Tiffany Kishbaugh, to Paul Knut Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. James L.V. Newman of Medfield, Mass.

title: Mary Elizabeth Weis Affianced
description: The engagement of Mary Elizabeth Weis to George Francis Archer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Archer of Farmingdale, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Paul R. Weis of Allentown, Pa. An August wedding is planned.

title: Drilling Thought
description: Venezuela has had the bright idea of appointing the world's first Minister for the Development of Human Intelligence. The new minister, Luis Alberto Machado, is not concerned with spies or moles.

title: On Simla
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT MAKES AN ISLAND? A COLLECTOR'S DEFINITION
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- SAMUEL A. SCHREINER JR. is a novelist who lives in Darien, Conn. By SAMUEL A.SCHREINER JR.

title: No Headline
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ART SAMPLER
description: AT THE Kornbluth Gallery in Fair Lawn, they call it painterly realism; whatever its name, it is beautiful and it is tough. In the show are the works of three artists - Richard Segalman, Wolf Kahn and Jane Freilicher - and they all produce pictures that are both beautifully engaging to the eye and appealing to the mind. These three painters are as much interested in creating challenging compositions that experiment with formal arrangements as they are with making poetic images.

title: ECONOMICS, IDEOLOGY AND FAITH
description: President Reagan presented his program of cuts in Federal spending and taxes as a salvation package. Take it as a whole, he told Congress in his television address; it is a last chance to avoid national economic disaster.

title: No Headline
description: Old photographs show us the way children were ''packaged'' in former times. The little girl on the cover is presented to us in a quite adult, and seductive, way: the careful curls, the dainty, naked toes and the little basket with its indistinguishable trinkets are a studio contrivance (and convention) meant to make the child appear at her most delicate, wistful - and needful of protection.

title: Practical Traveler; CHARTER FLIGHTS ARE CUT AS PROBLEMS PLAGUE OPERATORS
description: After a promising revival at the onset of winter, charter tours are again threatened with severe cutbacks. The outlook still seems favorable for such Caribbean destinations as Aruba, St. Martin and Jamaica this winter and for the Mediterranean countries and Israel in spring and summer. But prospects for other charters, which may be canceled up to 10 days before departure, are uncertain.

title: AN EAGLE WINTERS IN WESTPORT
description: WESTPORT FOR a rare American bald eagle that swooped into town about a month ago, a steady fish diet seems, for the time being at least, to have won out over the call of the wild.

title: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Most business leaders welcomed President Reagan's ambitious economic program last week, especially proposed generous cuts in business taxes. Investors were not so optimistic. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 13.74 points on Thursday, the day after Mr. Reagan detailed his plans. Stocks ended the week, however, at 936.09, with a net gain of 4.52 points.

title: MAKING MUSIC BY HAND AND MACHINE; AT STEINWAY, IT'S ALL CRAFT
description: The most complicated machine in the Steinway factory is the finished grand piano. It looks simple, its sleek black veneer gently turning inward. But beneath the ebony lid, there are more than 12,000 parts - sticks of wood precisely shaped, covered with felt, sprayed with teflon, wrapped in buckskin - with holes drilled, screws meticulously measured, springs pressing. The complexity is not only invisible, it is inaudible. The Steinway is known for its lyrical, supple sound, free of clicks and clatter.

title: Long Island Journal
description: A SHIPMENT of marijuana will soon be heading toward the South Shore of Nassau County, and neither local people nor narcotics agents have any intention of stopping it. It will be made available to Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre under a law passed last year legalizing marijuana for cancer patients.

title: Patricia A. Schaffer Plans June Nuptials
description: The engagement of Patricia Ann Schaffer to Steven Michael Winegar has been announced by Genevieve A. Schaffer of Kettering, Ohio, mother of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of A.L. Winegar, president of the Olivetti Corporation, and Mrs. Winegar of Franklin Lakes, N.J.

title: Cynthia Weeks Engaged to William Lawlor
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Doughty Weeks Jr. of Pelham, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Marie Weeks, to William Lovat Lawlor, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Lawlor, also of Pelham.

title: Walter Kennedy Gains Hall of Fame
description: The late Walter Kennedy, former commissioner of the National Basketball Association, is among four men elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: HOW TO BUY ON MARGIN
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued a routine-sounding announcement last week. New margin customers continued to enter the market in January, as the number of accounts rose by 5,000 to an alltime high of 1,185,000. Money owed to Big Board firms by their margin customers totaled $14 billion at the end of January, down, but only slightly, from the record $14.5 billion one month earlier, and up $2.2 billion from the January, 1980 level.

title: Bill Would Aid Hotel Housing
description: Governor Carey submitted a bill to lawmakers today that would provide $2 million in grants to upgrade single room occupancy residences and $1 million more in loans to rehabilitate shelter homes.

title: OUTLOOK FOR BALD EAGLES IN STATE IMPROVING
description: VINELAND NEAR a large swamp in Cumberland County, the only breeding pair of bald eagles in New Jersey are acting out a flamboyant courtship ritual: looping high together, joining talons in midair and freetumbling for several hundred feet.

title: That Presidential Look
description: President Reagan brings to the White House a sense of style in clothes that can best be described as leisurely California: broad shoulders, lots of elbow room and a loosely fitted waist (''Keeping Up With the Reagans,'' Jan. 18). I seriously doubt this regional image will have any appreciable impact on the American male's choice of style.

title: Czyz: Straight A's In Sweet Science
description: The nose belongs to a fighter, but not the vocabulary. ''I am the antithesis of the stereotype boxer,'' says Bobby Czyz. ''Everybody thinks it's funny I'm a fighter.''

title: Joseph Schildkraut
description: To the Editor:

title:
Long Island Housing;
THE LUXURY MARKET IS BOOMING
description: IN the world of the luxury real-estate market, property taxes, fee costs and mortgage interest rates play a definite second fiddle to the size of the indoor swimming pool, the view from the terrace and what size boat can be accommodated at the dock.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Health Offficials Declare an Alert
description: Along with the winter's usual complement of sniffles and coughs, health officials in the region coped last week with the return of an old foe, with the upsurge of a relatively rare one and with a pair of baffling deaths that were striking in their similarities.

title: SALVADORAN LIBERAL OUSTED BY JUNTA IS UNDER ARREST
description: Col. Arnoldo Majano, an outspoken liberal who has been in hiding since he was ousted as head of the ruling junta here two months ago, has been held under arrest by Government authorities since last Wednesday, according to informed sources.

title: Hong Kong Bombing Injures 23
description: A bomb explosion ripped through a tourist shopping arcade today, injuring 23 people, the police said. The bomb was apparently placed in a trash can in Ocean Terminal, a landmark of this British colony.

title:
Gardening;
WHY A DOGWOOD MAY NOT FLOWER
description: ''WHY doesn't my dogwood tree flower? My neighbor bought one the same time I did, and his has flowered each year since. I give it high nitrogen fertilizer each year, and it has been doing very well as far as growth is concerned. It's almost twice as large as my neighbor's tree.''

title: WESTHAMPTON BEACH LIMITS GROUPERS TO 6
description: IN an effort to control the leasing of houses for the summer season by groups of unrelated people, Wes@thampton Beach has passed a new law regulating such rentals in the village.

title: WHY MORE WOMEN AREN'T SUPERSTARS IN MUSIC
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Eugenia Zukerman is a flutist and the author of a recently-published novel, ''Deceptive Cadence''. By EUGENIA ZUKERMAN

title: IDEAS & TRENDS IN SUMMARY
description: Plagued by crippling mishaps, the space shuttle Columbia had begun to look like an $8.9 billion, 4.5 million pound weakling. It has had a hard time getting out of the hangar, much less off the ground.

title: SALISBURY CATHEDRAL'S NEW PRISONERS OF CONSCIENCE WINDOW
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- FRED FERRETTI is a reporter for The New York Times. By FRED FERRETTI

title: PROFITS FOR POTASH MINERS
description: Rising global demand for food helped make 1980 a good year for major producers of potash, an important component in fertilizers. After several years of slow growth, potash prices jumped more than 30 percent last year, to $68 a ton.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. LEADERSHIP STRUCTURE IN NEED OF AN OVERHAUL
description: To the Editor:

title: Miners Flex Muscle At the 'Iron Lady'
description: Margaret Thatcher may still be Britain's ''iron lady,'' but she melted last week when a miners' strike forced withdrawal of Government closing notices at 23 worn-out coal mines in South Wales. Even her supporters called the backdown a ''humiliating capitulation.''

title: Marie Winn ignores an important influence on today's children:
description: The ceaseless narcissism of the past decade has created parents who prefer to ''do their own thing'' at the expense of their children. It is unfortunate that a generation of parents who strive to find themselves ignore their children in the process. EDWARD E. BIDDLE, Hanover, N.H.

title: J.A. Boylan to Wed Maura A. Mullaney
description: The engagement of Maura Alicia Mullaney to Joseph Anthony Boylan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph I. Boylan of Westfield, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Mullaney of Westfield and Hilton Head, S.C. A wedding in September is planned.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Out of Salem, Mass., Comes Chinoiserie
description: With China a matter of so much interest these days, it seems only fitting that a Salem, Mass., supplier of hand-crafted and handpainted furniture with Oriental scenes and floral designs should open a regional outlet to serve heightened interest in chinoiserie furniture in the New York City area. Katherine Henick originals - each piece bears the name - have been available only through decorators' showrooms or at the factory for the last 40 years.

title: Mary K. Silver Is Affianced to Cantor Neil Schwartz
description: Betty S. Silver of North Tarrytown, N.,Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Katharine Silver, to Cantor Neil Schwartz, son of Shirley Barenbaum of St. Paul, and the late Dr. Bert B. Schwartz.

title: Critics' Choices
description: FOLK/POP MUSIC Kate and Anna McGarrigle, who are at the Bottom Line Thursday through Saturday, are singing sisters from Montreal. Their music inhabits a charmed territory somewhere between French-Canadian folk music, which is a melodious, keening, lonely sound, and the wry, literate sophistication of the best contemporary pop.

title: ECCLES ERROR
description: The key to the tax cut is an expenditure cut. That would avoid increasing the deficit. It is argued that even if the expenditure cut is much smaller than the tax cut, or if it comes next year instead of this, there will be no inflationary effects because of the supplyside effects that the tax cut will generate. Incentives, it is said, will increase work, effort will be up, more people will enter the labor force, and gross national product will rise so much that the enlarged revenues will balance the budget within a couple of years.

title: Nuggets 129, Kings 109
description: Billy McKinney sparked a 10-point outburst midway through the fourth quarter and Alex English scored a game-high 36 points as they led Denver over Kansas City and ended the Kings' five-game winning streak.

title: F.A.A. PLANS A SAFETY STUDY
description: Westchester County Airport, closed by the county on Friday after two recent accidents, was reopened yesterday after the Federal Government agreed to an immediate review of operations there.

title: PRELUDE TO THE SURRENDER OF OUR CHANCERY IN TEHERAN
description: To the Editor:

title: WINTER'S DELIGHTS? NOT AT MY HOUSE
description: I HATE winter - hate it with a purple passion. Naturally I'm not the only Long Islander who feels this way, and the amount of advice I have read about the winter blahs and how to deal with them is plentiful. Lately I have read articles about how enjoyable it is to curl up in front of the fire with a good book, how to keep busy during the frosty season on the East End, how you can escape it all by going to Florida or eat dinner in an exotic Manhattan restaurant and walk to a Broadway play.

title: Nature Watch; NATURE WATCH; AMERICAN EEL; Anguilla rostrata
description: Size: Length to five feet. Color: Dark, blackish olive, washed with yellowish tones on sides; silvery white below.

title: Anne Russo to Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Russo of Roslyn, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Lynn Russo, to Jeffrey B. Meyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Meyer of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Mets Open Camp With Pitching Uncertain
description: The New York Mets opened spring training today with a small army of 24 pitchers and eight catchers in camp, and with huge medical question marks surrounding the top three on the pitching staff.

title: L.S.U. Tops Tennessee, 66 to 65, And Takes Southeastern Title
description: Leonard Mitchell made a pair of free throws after a deliberate foul with seven seconds left, and Louisiana State held off three second-half rallies by Tennessee to score a 66-65 victory today and win the Southeastern Conference championship.

title: Sound; A LITTLE SPEAKER WITH A BIG, CLEAR VOICE
description: Among loudspeakers, as elsewhere, the exceptional is often submerged in the glut of the ordinary, and designs distinguished by subtle differences often fail to gain the recognition they deserve. One such speaker is Wharfedale's Model TSR-108, the smallest in a new series produced by this British company, which had been prominent in the early years of high fidelity and has lately perked up again after a hiatus. Despite its compact size (23 x 12 x 12 inches), this speaker rolls out clear and ample bass. The credit for this goes to a 10-inch woofer employing a self-damping cone of mineral-filled polymer. The properties of this material prevent the formation of false modes of vibration due to flexing and buckling of the cone which would otherwise muddy the lower notes and falsify timbres in the midrange. Evidently this woofer cone represents a successful instance among the numerous current efforts to develop cone materials capable of greater clarity in the lower frequency region. As for range, this woofer reaches down to 50 Hz at the low end, which is quite respectable for a speaker this size.

title: SCHMIDT UNEASY ABOUT U.S. ECONOMIC PLAN
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt voiced concern today that the Reagan Administration's new economic program could lead to a worldwide tightening of credit that could deepen Europe's recession if Congress fails to offset tax cuts with deep cuts in spending.

title: U.S. WARNS ITS ALLIES THEY MUST INCREASE MILITARY SPENDING
description: In what Pentagon officials called a significant hardening of the United States' stance toward its NATO allies, the Deputy Secretary of Defense warned the allies today that the United States could not be expected to enhance its military effort in Europe unless the Europeans increased their contributions.

title: Jeffrey Getty to Wed Katherine Whitehead
description: Katherine Gaynor Whitehead of New York, a loan examiner with the Irving Trust Company, and Jeffrey Schuyler Getty of Baltimore, a loan representative with the First National Bank of Maryland, plan to be married Oct. 10 in Washington, where the ceremony will be performed in the chapel of Georgetown University. The couple are graduates of Georgetown.

title: THE NATION IN SUMMARY
description: Since it began in 1975, a Justice Department investigation of crime on the nation's waterfronts produced convictions of more than 100 shipping company executives and union officials, including one of the biggest, Anothony M. Scotto, president of the International Longshoremen's Association's Local 1814 in Brooklyn.

title:
Antiques;
AN EXPERT IN PORCELAIN REPAIR
description: FRANKLIN TO repair a piece of antique porcelain so carefully that the repair is not noticeable calls for the skill of a craftsman, an artist's knowledge of colors and the patience of the kind of person who once considered scientific research as a profession.

title: GLORIA LEMESKE ENGAGED TO WINTHROP D. PERKINS
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Lemeske of Jacksonville, Fla., have announced t he engagement of their daughter, Gloria Susan Lemeske, to Winthrop D unn Perkins, son of Eleanor L. Perkins of North Reddington Beach, F la., and the late William E. Perkins. T he prospective bride, a student pilot, and her fiance, a p ilot, plan to be married on April 25 at the Wings Club in New Y ork.

title: Michele Anne Murphy Fiancee of R. C. Trifari
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Bunworth Murphy of Forest Hills, Queens, and Dunraven, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michele Anne Murphy, to Raymond Campbell Trifari, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Trifari of Ossining, N.Y.

title: At Home
description: SOMETHING was wrong. As I drove home from the supermarket, turning corners slowly so that the bags of groceries in the back of the car would stay upright, the checkout clerk's face flashed again and again in my mind's eye. It was an improbably youthful face, guileless and small, perched on the shoulders of a tall, muscular, adult male. Obviously a new employee, he had taken an inordinate amount of time to check out the three customers ahead of me in line, engaging each one in small talk between shouted requests for prices to other clerks. Supermarkets have always irritated me, and my day had been crowded with an unusual number of irritants already. I despise people who take out their anger on salespeople, having once been the target of that kind of abuse, and so I made a conscious effort to conceal my annoyance when my turn finally arrived.

title: Maryland 94, Wake Forest 80
description: Albert King and Greg Manning, seniors playing their last home game in Maryland, combined for 34 second-half points and led the Terps to a 94-80 Atlantic Coast Conference victory over fifth-ranked Wake Forest today.

title: No Headline
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, right, meeting Friday in Bonn with Senator John G. Tower, chairman of the Armed Services Committee. Senator Tower was on his way to Munich to attend a seminar on defense.

title: COST OF DRIVING IN U.S. CONTINUES TO ACCELERATE
description: ONE of the best things about owning an old car is that it can transport you away from the new realities. When they get to be too much, you simply jump into the vast front seat of your 1964 Coupe Deville, grin at the genuine metal dash, fire up the 340 horses under the hood, and head for the highway.

title: RED RYDER'S BACK, AT THE BERGENSTAGE
description: PARAMUS BACK in the days when a horse was the major object of a hero's cockeyed passion, movies about the Wild West enthralled millions of matinee devotees. Among others, Ken Maynard, Buck Jones, Charles Starrett, Gene Autry and Roy Rogers proved to be magnets for popcorn addicts, but sagas with fisticuff-ready Lancelots and bony Modreds bore the scent of extinction about them.

title: For the Retarded, a Case for the Courts
description: It may be the wise father that knows his own child, but when the child is retarded and a matter as basic and personal as the freedom to procreate is at stake, the courts are wiser still. So said both the New Jersey Supreme Court and the Virginia legislature last week, giving jurists in their states comprehensive guidelines for ordering involuntary sterilization.

title: IN PHILIPPINE CITY, POLITICS PROVIDES COMIC-OPERA OVERLAY
description: This large, raw settler city, which likes to compare itself to towns of the early American West, exemplifies the essence of political life in the Philippines, often covering deadly serious problems with an overlay of bravado and comic opera.

title: PROBATION FUNDS PUT IN QUESTION
description: THE county's two-year effort to make the director of probation an appointed rather than Civil Service position has met with lukewarm enthusiasm from lawmakers in Albany, whose approval is needed, and with strong opposition from the Civil Service Employees Association. It now appears that the effort may also have caused the county to lose nearly a quarter of a million dollars for several experimental pilot projects financed by Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Administration funds administered by the state.

title: PRO ANTITRUST
description: F ROM articles such as ''Antitrust: Big Business Breathes Easier'' (Feb. 15), one might get the impression that antitrust laws are not only unnecessary but positively harmful. Bigness is better - not bigness is bad - is apparently now the theme of antitrust enforcement in America.

title: ISLANDERS COOL OFF BLACK HAWKS, 6-3
description: After learning that Butch Goring, one of their more popular and hard-working teammates, was being benched, the Islanders responded tonight by routing the Chicago Black Hawks, 6-3, at Nassau Coliseum to snap a five-game nonwinning streak.

title: I was shocked and outraged by the Anderson article, which contends that men can do better restaurant math and do not change their orders. Her article was reminiscent of the 1950's Gracie Allen shows: ''Oh, aren't we the silly ones! We can't even add.''
description: Let me tell you, Ms. Anderson, how men and women figure out a check in a restaurant.

title: SONGS OF THE MIDDLE AGES AND BEYOND
description: Even in this day and age, when companies are busily recording complete editions of the most obscure composers, a four-disk set presenting all the music contained in a Renaissance manuscript is an unprecedented event. Such an album could probably only come from England, one of the major centers for early-music performance today, and the document in question is called ''Le Chansonnier Cordiforme,'' which was compiled in the French duchy of Savoy around 1470 (Oiseau Lyre D186D 4). The performers are members of The Consort of Musicke led by Anthony Rooley, a group familiar for their complete John Dowland project on the same label and dozens of other excellent disks exploring the vast pre-1600 musical literature.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
3 Post Mortems On Deadly Force
description: Last month, at the funeral of a police officer slain in the line of duty, Philip Caruso, head of the Patrolmen's Benovolent Association, suggested that, in the future, officers ''shoot first and shoot to kill'' in potentially violent situations. Last week, after city police officers had killed three civilians and a suburban officer had killed another, disputes over police use of deadly force flared anew.

title: Joan Brooks, J.C. Crumbliss Are Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Benjamin Brooks Jr. of Cresskill, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Kingsland Brooks, to James Clay Crumbliss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Crumbliss Jr. of Lookout Mountain, Tenn.

title: TEXT OF KEY SECTION OF GOVERNORS' REPORT ASSESSING REAGAN'S ECONOMIC PLAN
description: Following is the text of the overview chapter of a report that was released here today by the National Governors Association and the National Conference of State Legislatures responding to President Reagan's economic recovery plan and assessing its impact on the states:

title: Mary M. Cronin Married To John W. Richmond Jr.
description: The marriage of Mary Marguerite Cronin, daughter of Mary Cronin of Fairfield, Conn., and William H. Cronin Jr. of New York, to John Whitney Richmond Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richmond of Newport, R.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., took place in Fairfield yesterday.

title: Crime
description: Carrying on the traditions of the classical British mystery, Patricia Moyes once again brings back Chief Superintendant Henry Tibbett and his wife Emmy in ANGEL DEATH (Holt, Rinehart and Winston, $10.95). They have been solving cases since 1960, and in ''Angel Death'' they are on vacation in the Caribbean when they are drawn into a case involving a nice, peppery retired schoolteacher who has disappeared. As always, one thing leads to another, and a big drug network is finally uncovered.

title: REALISM STANDS OUT IN SHOW BY BLACKS
description: GREAT NECK ADISTINCTIVE feature of the current exhibition by black artists at the Great Neck Library is that there is more imagery concerning black life than one usually sees in shows devoted to art by blacks. Its prominent presence is undoubtedly linked to the current prevalence of realism and the greater penchant to use one's own experiences and immediate surroundings as subjects worthy of artistic consideration.

title: RAIL YARDS INSPIRE PLANS FOR HOUSING AND INDUSTRY
description: After a decade of neglect and deterioration, hundreds of acres of prime waterfront property formerly used mostly as rail yards along the inner harbor in New York and New Jersey are on the way to being reclaimed for residential, recreational and industrial use.

title: McAdoo Will Sit Out Rest of Piston Season
description: Bob McAdoo, the Detroit Pistons' forward, will sit out the rest of the season but will be paid, a team official said yesterday.

title:
ANTIQUES;
PENDULUM CLOCKS HOLD A TIMELESS APPEAL
description: MONTCLAIR ABOUT 150 years ago, artisans in French villages were turning out wall clocks with cases and long pendulums decorated with thin sheets of ornately stamped brass. One of the charms of the clocks, then and now, was the way the metal glinted in the sunlight as the pendulums swung back and forth.

title: Home Clinic; METHODS OF KEEPING THE FIREPLACE FROM SMOKING
description: MOST homeowners have become more reluctant than in the past to use wood-burning fireplaces because of an increasing awareness of their relative inefficiency, especially when the central heating system is working. Even so, many still consider them a comfort on a chilly day.

title: POSTSCRIPT ON CHILE
description: To the Editor:

title: A YEAR-ROUND GARDEN
description: SALISBURY THEY call it Lakeville lettuce because that is where it was first grown - in the middle of winter. Through a cultivation process called hydroponics, which does not use soil, the lettuce was developed four years ago in a tiny greenhouse, the result of substantial research and experimentation by three residents of this area.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Once More, Albany Does a Death Waltz
description: Does capital punishment deter murder? Probably not. Does a gubernatorial veto deter the New York State Assembly from attempting to restore it? Definitely not.

title: Dole Recovering From Surgery
description: Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, was said to be recovering without complication today after more than four hours of surgery Thursday night for removal of a kidney stone. Mr. Dole, 58 years old, has only one kidney as a result of a World War II wound.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error the pro- posed amending formula for the Cana- dian constitution was given incorrectly in The Times Sunday. The formula would require assent by two Atlantic provinces in addition to the two largest provinces, Ontario and Quebec, and two western provinces that have at least 50 percent of the population in that region.

title: Beauty; BENEFICENT BOTANICALS
description: By Jane Ogle

title: Chile Forgiven
description: President Reagan insists on ''con-sistency'' in human rights policy. And Secretary Haig insists that the first target of such policy should be terrorism.

title: Diana Carulli Is Engaged to Bryan Dunlap
description: Announcement has been made by Margaret Lane Carulli of New York of the engagement of her daughter, Diana Marina Carulli, to Bryan Robert Dunlap, son of Dr. Joseph Riggs Dunlap of New York and Leonie Dunlap of Leonia, N.J.

title: DEMOCRATIC DEMOCRACY
description: BEYOND ADVERSARY DEMOCRACY By Jane J. Mansbridge. 398 pp. New York: Basic Books. $20.

title: THE ENDS AND THE MEANS
description: One of the main criticisms of American life over the last generation is that increasingly we have become a divided or separated people, with a growing concern for our personal, local or special interests and a declining sense of the common good or national interest.

title: 2 American Prisoners Wed in a Turkish Jail
description: Two American prisoners, Jo Ann McDaniel of Salem, Ore., and Robert Hubbard of Fort Riley, Kan., were married yesterday in a Turkish jail, two days before their expected transfer to the United States after more than eight years' internment for drug smuggling.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: M.A. Purdy Fiance Of Constance Doyle
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Edward Doyle of Garrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Constance Karen Doyle, to Mark Addison Purdy, son of Mrs. Alan Bradford Purdy of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and the late Mr. Purdy. A September wedding is planned.

title: WILL WE EMERGE IN THE 80'S FROM THE DARK AGES OF ENERGY POLICY
description: THE 1970's were the Dark Ages of America's energy history. As that decade began, most Americans could hardly conceive that there could be energy shortages in the United States. America was a major producer of oil and there was plenty of ''cheap'' foreign oil available.

title: HEAVY RAINS RAISE AREA RESERVOIRS AND CAUSE SOME FLOODING IN JERSEY
description: Parts of New York and New Jersey had both too much and too little water yesterday, as rainfall and runoff continued to add to reservoirs and flood streets in some low-lying areas.

title: Princeton 40, Brown 33
description: Randy Melville scored 14 points as Princeton beat Brown, 40-33, for its ninth straight Ivy League victory at Jadwin Gym tonight.

title: A BOSTON GRANDE DAME GETS A FACELIFT
description: Fifteen years ago the Parker House in Boston, the oldest continuously operated hotel in the United States, appeared to be on the verge of closing its doors. The dowager of the city's Victorianstyle hotels, and its restaurant, Parker's, was dilapidated - along with much of the surrounding downtown area.

title: WEICKER CHALLENGED IN G.O.P. ON '82 RACE
description: HARTFORD EARLY or not, the 1982 campaign for the United States Senate is under way in Connecticut, and the early skirmishing surprisingly is on the Republican side, which already has a formidable incumbent up for re-election.

title: 4 MONEY-RAISING PROSPECTS BOLSTER G.O.P. IN NEW YORK
description: The New York State Republican Party is up to its gunwales in debt from the last gubernatorial campaign, but it has an unusual resource - four wealthy business executives who are politically ambitious and thus strong prospects for party fund-raising.

title: 1958 Army Team Was Undefeated
description: To the Sports Editor: I was somewhat surprised to find an inaccuracy in Red Smith's otherwise superb column of Feb. 2, which extolled the virtues of one of America's great football heroes, Earl (Red) Blaik.

title: PROGRAMS FOR TALENTED STUDENTS GAIN PRAISE AMID CRITICISM
description: FROM the digs of an imaginary civilization to research concerning problems of energy reserves, academically talented students are involved in challenges that can help the bright, the bored or the restless to use their knowledge to solve problems in daily life. In an era that has sought equality in education for slow learners, for the learning disabled and for problem children, Westchester schools are providing special, sometimes controversial programs for gifted students.

title: On Language
description: Haigravations Kimble Mead

title: 20-4 Boston College Trips St. John's, 59-58
description: Boston College, led by John Bagley, took a commanding lead in the second half and then held on for a 59-58 victory over St. John's tonight. For the Redmen, it was the first time they had lost a third consecutive game since the 1971-72 season.

title: ARCHITECTS ADAPT TO EAST END'S LIGHT
description: HOUSES on the Island's East End have always celebrated unique extremes of seasonal light. Be they grandiose 19th-century shinglestyle mansions or spare postmodern residences, they all bask in light reflected from the potato fields, the dunes and the ocean.

title: Peking Bishop Foresees No Reunion With Rome
description: The Catholic Bishop of Peking said today that he saw no clear prospects for reconciliation between the Vatican and the Chinese church, which declared itself independent of Rome more than 20 years ago in order to survive under Communism.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Higher Ante for N.J. Campaign Aid?
description: He may not be a candidate, but that hasn't kept Governor Byrne out of the New Jersey gubernatorial campaign. The reason is the state's public campaign financing law, which enables anyone raising $50,000 privately to qualify for up to $600,000 in state matching funds for use in the primary. Mr. Byrne signed the measure into law a year ago.

title: Pamela J. Richards And Thomas Kern To Marry Sept. 12
description: Mr. and Mrs. James E. Richards of North Caldwell, N.J. and Hilton Head, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Jeanne Richards, to Thomas Griffin Kern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Kern of Garden City, L.I. and Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: About Long Island
description: THE tanned, handsome man with the silver hair sat at a table by himself slowly turning the pages of a newspaper. He wore a black uniform with two gold stripes on the jacket wrists and gold wings on his left chest. At the counter a young man in a leather jacket was having The Breakfast.

description: New York City's Health Department this week released the names of 35 food establishments that it said had violated the health code. The department also named six food establishments that had reopened after correcting earlier violations and one that had been closed for failing to do so. VIOLATIONS Pizza Place, 101 Avenue D. Uncle Paul's Tavern, 8 Christopher St. Peace Bar-B-Que, 599 Academy St. Delicio Coffee Shop, 455 Hudson St. Caffe da Alfredo, 17 Perry St. Angela's Pizza, 82 Second Ave. Leo Lindy's Riverboat Restaurant, 350 Fifth Ave. Spineasy Snack Bar, 3816 Ninth Ave. Ponce de Leon Restaurant, 171 E. 116 St. Silena's Place, 1276 Nelson Ave., Bronx. Luigi's Restaurant, 1469 Westchester Ave., Bronx. Murphy's Resaurant, 5013 Avenue D, Brooklyn. Clar Luncheonette, 2919 Avenue S, Brooklyn. Hollywood Lounge, 1751 Bedford Ave., Brooklyn. Boston Fried Chicken, 486 DeKalb Ave., Brooklyn. Gene's Lunch Fountain, 505 DeKalb Ave., Brooklyn. Cobble Hill Pizza, 269 Court St., Brooklyn. Vic's Pizzeria, 288 Kings Highway, Brooklyn. B & T Tavern, 828 St. John's Pl., Brooklyn. Farrell's Bar & Grill, 215 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. Frank & Vinny's Pizza, 246 Reid Ave., Brooklyn. Mr. Courtesy Pub, 423 Third Ave., Brooklyn. Pinnacle Restaurant, 7419 Third Ave., Brooklyn. Burger King, 457 Fifth Ave., Brooklyn. Chicken Deli, 8511 18th Ave., Brooklyn. Bird Cage Bar & Grill, 514 54th St., Brooklyn.

title: Theater; A ZESTY SHOWCASE FOR COLE PORTER TUNES
description: IF ever a musical was aptly named, it is the 1934 hit, ''Anything Goes,'' a wild amalgam of zany characters and improbable plot shifts, all set aboard an ocean liner sailing from New York to London. The version being presented by the Darien Dinner Theater is the one that was used for the 1960 Off Broadway revival, and it makes as much sense as any I have seen.

title: PLAY BALL!
description: In a city where the two biggest events each year are an automobile race and the state high school basketball tournament, it seems only natural that the mayor would make his ''top priority'' the construction of a new sports complex. But Indianapolis Mayor William H. Hudnut has more than fun and games in mind.

title: SAUDIS EXPECT U.S. TO AGREE ON F-15'S
description: Saudi officials and Western diplomats here and in Jidda seem increasingly certain that the Reagan Administration will approve Saudi Arabia's request for wing fuel tanks, bomb racks and fittings for air-to-air missiles for the 62 F-15 jets the Saudis are buying from the United States.

title: STEEL'S TRIGGER RISES
description: In one of its first official acts of economic policy, the Reagan Administration raised the trigger price mechanism on imported steel by 4.4 percent in the second quarter from its current level. Beginning in April, minimum import prices will rise to $422.95 a ton for integrated steel mill products.

title: PRECISION REFINEMENTS
description: Back in the 1950's virtually every American bridge expert used a standard bidding style, but the success of the Italians in world championships soon made an impact. In the last two decades the number of players using a strong club or some other specialized method has grown steadily. That number is now about 20 percent of the expert population.

title: Connecticut Guide; DANBURY ARTS FESTIVAL
description: For two weeks beginning Monday there will be an abundance of films, lectures, music, art and poetry in the annual Arts Festival at Western Connecticut State College, Danbury. All events are free and open to the public.

title: KNICKS RELISH LAKER REMATCH
description: The Knicks had just beaten the Washington Bullets, 124-112, Friday night for their 10th victory in 11 games. Michael Ray Richardson, in an uncharacteristic cocky mood, spoke of today's nationally televised game against the Los Angeles Lakers at Madison Square Garden .

description: Donald G. McLean of Ambler, Pa., and Mrs. Grant McCargo of Sewickley, Pa., and Edgartown, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Clare McLean, to E. George Cross 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cross 2d of Philadelphia.

title: CONSCIENCE PROMPTS NEEDIEST CASES AID
description: Reflecting on the plight of the destitute in New York City, Harvey J. Lasky of Hollis Hills, Queens, asked, ''If not now - when? If not me - who?''

title: LAUNCH BLITZ TO SELL 'RECOVERY'
description: At midweek, President Reagan was entertaining a delegation of New Right conservatives with some goodnatured grumbling about a favorite nemesis - the New York newspapers. ''They seem to be always looking for splits in the ranks, Mr. Reagan complained in an aside that pointed up one of the President's main chores this week.

title: Indiana 74, Minnesota 63
description: Ray Tolbert scored 19 points and Landon Turner celebrated his return to Indiana's starting lineup with 12 first-half points as the Hoosiers defeated Minnesota, 74-63, in a Big Ten game today.

title: LACK OF FUNDS HALTS STATE CLEANUP EFFORT
description: TRENTON UNLESS emergency measures are taken, New Jersey, whose hazardouswaste cleanup and disposal fund has run out of money, may not be able to fully respond for several months to chemical spills or abandoned dump sites that threaten water supplies.

description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- BETSY WADE is a copy editor on the national news desk of The Times. By BETSY WADE

description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- SHERRY MARKER is a writer who lives in Northampton, Mass. By SHERRY MARKER

description: FREEPORT SOUTH Shore residents have a new source for fresh pasta. Since early January, the Pane & Pasta House in Freeport has been making and serving fresh egg, spinach and whole wheat noodles, cavatelli, tortellini, ravioli with various fillings and sauces to go with them.

title: WAYS TO MAKE TAX CUTS WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: REPEAT PERFORMANCE
description: So successful was a 1980 symposium on endangered and threatened plants and animals in New Jersey that the program will be held again next weekend at the same place: Stockton State College in Pomona. The session brings together scientists, conservationists, amateur and professional naturalists and interested members of the public.

title: Republic Airport: Another View
description: Regarding the recent article ''Takeover of Republic Airport'': The only people debating this are the users and the M.T.A. Airports Authority. Users are being ripped off in many more ways than indicated, by an agency responsible to no one.

title: CRAFTS
description: GERTRUDE SIMON of the Bergen County community of Closter is among a growing number of artists who have turned to handmade paper as a medium in itself. They use it not as a surface on which to draw or print, but as a substance that can be colored, shaped, textured and formed into images while it is being made.

title: No Headline
description: President Reagan has tapped an executive of a Wall Street brokerage firm to be head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, a White House aide said last week.

title: Bucknell 65, Rider 61
description: Deb Okorodudu scored 16 points to lead Bucknell to a 65-61 victory over Rider College today.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
WHEN MONEY IS A BORE
description: OF all dull words of tongue or pen, the dullest are these: ''Bjorn Borg easily defeated John McEnroe today in the first match of their $1.15 million three-match series.''

title: WILL SUCCESS SPOIL NEW YORK'S CONSERVATIVE PARTY?
description: It started like one of those old Mickey Rooney musical movies - one young lawyer saying to another, ''Hey, Dan, why don't we have a political party?''

description: As Rick Cerone walks toward the fence behind home plate, the fans stream down from the stands for autographs and photos, and howl like spectators at a rock concert.

description: To the Editor:

title: Design; SCULPTED HANDWARE
description: Design By Barbara L. Isenberg and Mary Smith Barbara L. Isenberg and Mary Smith write a hardware column for the Home section. he look of household hardware is changing. Today those little things -from faucets and door handles to hinges and hooks -are available in a kaleidoscope of bold primary and, for the postmodernists, muted secondary colors. Space-age materials such as nylon coated with epoxy have made it possible to create shapes that border on the sensuous.

title: DEATH IN THE WEST
description: THE HOUR OF OUR DEATH By Philippe Aries. Translated from the French by Helen Weaver. Illustrated. 651 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $20.

Camera;
THINGS TO CONSIDER WHEN CHOOSING A ZOOM LENS
KIM CRENIER IS ENGAGED TO DR. MICHAEL WRIGHT
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Crenier of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kim Alexandra Crenier, to Dr. Michael David Wright, son of Jean H. Wright of Mount Vernon, Va., and Richard H. Wright of Alexandria, Va. A May wedding is planned in Indian Rocks Beach, Fla.

title: Art View; THE COMPELLING IMAGERY OF HANS BALDUNG GRIEN
description: One of the more curious images in European art is called ''The Groom Bewitched.'' It is a woodcut, dated around 1544, and the action takes place in a stable. On the threshold of the inner stall we see a well-formed and mettlesome horse. ''What happened to room service?,'' he seems to say, as he looks over his shoulder and swishes his big sleek tail. And, sure enough, his groom lies flat on the floor behind him. Seen in extreme foreshortening, with his feet pointing towards the bottom edge of the image, the groom is clearly unconscious. Is he dead? Possessed by evil spirits? Or simply the worse for drink? We don't know, and the artist isn't going to tell us. But the instruments of the groom's office -pitchfork and currycomb - lie in disarray on the floor; and, as sole witness to what went on, an archetypal hag leans in across the window ledge and waves a flaming torch.

title: PROFESSOR,GIRL AND GHOST
description: THE POLYGAMIST By B.H. Friedman. 220 pp. Boston: Atlantic-Little, Brown. $11.95.

title: IF MR. REAGAN'S POLICIES FLOP, THEN WHAT?
description: President Reagan has four years to demonstrate that tax cuts, accompanied by a spectacular increase in the military budget, but balanced by sharp reductions in social and other nonmilitary spending, can put the badly listing economy on an even keel. He must prove that the engine of private enterprise, freed from the shackles of environmental laws and other restrictive regulations, will propel the economy full speed ahead.

title: Anthony Bowling Winner
description: Earl Anthony defeated Roy Buckley, 242-223, today in the final of the $125,000 AMF MagicScore open bowling tournament. The victory was Anthony's second straight on the pro tour.

title: IF ISN'T THIS, ITS THAT
description: TWENTY paradoxes of everyday living: 1. If you haven't found that there's more to life than meets the eye, you haven't seen the light. 2.

title: Suzanne Kermes, a Student, Fiancee of Thomas B. Tobin
description: Suzanne Kermes, who expects to graduate in May from DePauw University, and Thomas Brian Tobin, who expects to graduate then from Indiana University, plan to be married in August.

title: JOB PROJECT AIMS AT 'TOUGH KIDS'
description: THE target of the new Suffolk County youth employment program is probably slouching against a doorframe in the local mall with nothing to do but nurse a headache he got the night before. He was in the same spot yesterday and will probably be in the same spot tomorrow - if he's not in a worse one. A 17-year-old dropout who was a behavior problem all through school, he has no job, no plans for one and no incentive to look for one. He had one once, but it didn't work out.

title: DEREGULATED FUEL PRICES STRAINING BUDGETS
description: PARAMUS THE young woman, her two small children beside her, drove her latemodel car into a gasoline station on Route 17 here and, after getting 15 gallons of regular leaded gasoline, handed the attendant $21.15. The price, marked in black crayon on the pump, was $1.41 a gallon.

title: Theater; 'THE SEA HORSE': TINGES OF O'NEILL WITHOUT THE POWER
description: HERRICKS THE Nassau Repertory Theater ''aims to be your Broadway alternative on Long Island,'' writes Kenneth E. Hahn, managing director, in a program note. In ''The Sea Horse,'' a two-character play by Edward J. Moore, the theater is offering an Off Broadway alternative as well, a departure from the commercially oriented plays presented so far this season - ''Chapter Two'' and ''Same Time, Next Year,'' which did not reflect the theater's philosophy or Mr. Hahn's preference.

title:
Gardening;
WHY A DOGWOOD MAY NOT FLOWER
description: ''WHY doesn't my dogwood tree flower? My neighbor bought one the same time I did, and his has flowered each year since. I give it high nitrogen fertilizer each year, and it has been doing very well as far as growth is concerned. It's almost twice as large as my neighbor's tree.''

title: CABLE TV IS GETTING SERIOUS ABOUT SERIOUS DRAMA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Leticia Kent is a freelance writer who frequently reports on the cultural scene. By LETICIA KENT

title: PROGRAM HIGHLIGHTS
description: When Ronald Reagan accepted the Republican Presidential nomination last July, he promised ''a new beginning.'' With his economic message last week, there was no doubt that Mr. Reagan intended a marked change.

title: Iowa 67, Purdue 62
description: Kenny Arnold and Vince Brookins led a balanced Iowa attack with 16 points apiece today as the Hawkeyes beat Purdue, 67-62, in a Big Ten game.

title: JUNIOR ASSEMBLIES: REMNANT OF BALLROOM DECORUM
description: RIDGEWOOD SOON after school began last September, a rather formal invitation was mailed to sixth- and seventh-graders here. The message, which bore a strong resemblance to one received by their parents 25 years or so ago, was that the time had come for the youngsters to sign up for Mrs. I. W. Thompson's Junior Assemblies.

description: WASHINGTON, D.C. CONNECTICUT and most of the 18 states of the Northeast and the Middle West will continue to trail the nation as a whole in population growth, economic expansion and per capita income gains in the next two decades, according to a new analysis by the NortheastMidwest Institute.

description: For all his Marxist principles, Prime Minister Robert Mugabe waited 10 months after Zimbabwe's independence before establishing diplomatic relations last week with the Soviet Union.

description: BRITAIN

title: HOUSES AND HOUSES OF CARDS
description: The free ride in housing is over. The free ride is the long-term fixed-rate mortgage. The lenders are getting wise. In the 1960's, borrowers were able to get 30-year money at 6 percent and less. The Bowery Savings Bank in New York still has $500 million on its books at 6 percent and less. No matter what happens, the payments stay the same for that group of householders, though, of course, the loans are gradually getting paid off. In the 1970's borrowers got their money for 30 years at 7 and 8 percent.

title: Food; MAKING THE MOST OF VARIETY CUTS
description: More than once we have pointed out that Italian cookery, at long last, is coming into its own in this country. Much of the public has finally been weaned of the notion that food prepared by a fine Italian hand is spaghetti and meatballs or oven-baked lasagna.

description: The parade of foreign leaders to Washington has begun in earnest, with Israel's Foriegn Minister here last week, Britain's Prime Minister and France's Foreign Minister on the way.

title: SMOOTH TRANSITION
description: His intentions, Rupert Murdoch swore to a skeptical British public when he bought The Times of London this month, were strictly honorable. So far, Mr. Murdoch has been true to his word.

description: ''You have not been rejected by everyone. In every country on earth there are people who care about you.'' - Pope John Paul II, speaking to Indochinese refugees in the Philippines. (13:3.)

description: Gov. John W. Carlin vetoed a death penalty bill today, the third time in three years that he has rejected a measure to restore capital punishment in Kansas.

description: DESPITE the women's movement and affirmative action programs, women have assumed relatively few administrative posts in public education in the state in the last decade. In 1970, according to the state's Department of Education, 65 percent of all New Jersey classroom teachers and 17 percent of all school administrators (a category that includes district superintendents, supervisors, principals, assistant principals, vice principals, administrative principals, department heads and coordinators) were women.

Gardening;

description: ''WHY doesn't my dogwood tree flower? My neighbor bought one the same time I did, and his has flowered each year since. I give it high nitrogen fertilizer each year, and it has been doing very well as far as growth is concerned. It's almost twice as large as my neighbor's tree.''

description: I enjoyed Marie Winn's ''What Became of Childhood Innocence?'' (Jan. 25). But as someone born in 1917, I think she overstated the innocence of earlier generations.

description: New York City's tax collections are outstripping both last year's performance and the forecasts that were built into the current year's budget, according to Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: What Price a Soviet Jew?
description: Without a word of explanation, the Soviet Union is again letting Jews leave in large numbers. It may be only an illusion that Moscow regulates the flow of this human traffic with its expectations of American trade or other reward. But the record of a decade and the newest signal suggest such a correlation - a purposeful bartering with a people's fate. It cries out for American authorities to investigate Moscow's price.

title: Children's Books
description: BLACK COW SUMMER By Richard Graber. 212 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $9.95. (Ages 12 to 15) By PAXTON DAVIS

description: ATLANTIC CITY THE gambling casinos here, with Resorts International a notable exception, have long made it clear to the state's Casino Control Commission that they take a dim view of the objectives of the socalled ''2 percent reinvestment tax.''

title: Article About Women Called Sexist and Offensive
description: Normally, I would not even glance at an article such as the one written by Jane Lee Anderson (''Why Can't a Woman Be More Like a Man?'' - Personally Speaking, Jan. 25); it was called to my attention.

And now, the decision by Federal regulators to authorize the accounts nationwide as of Jan. 1 has set off a fierce free-for-all between commercial banks and savings institutions for a share of the depositor's dollar.

description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- FRANK J. PRIAL is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The Times. By FRANK J.PRIAL

description: To hear President Reagan tell it in his address to Congress last week, Government policies are the source of the nation's economic ills and avoiding an economic Armageddon requires his policies. And by Mr. Reagan's analysis, his ''Program for Economic Recovery'' is certain to work miracles on persistently high inflation and a sluggish unemployment rate.

title: NEW FRENCH RAILROAD WILL TAKE STEEP SLOPES IN ITS STRIDE
description: France's new high-speed rail line, which will offer the world's fastest passenger service when it opens in October, is being constructed like an American Interstate highway, with grades that were once considered unthinkable for trains but that allow elimination of most curves.

description: To the chagrin of state officials and the dismay of Connecticut's mayors, the State Education Department has made a $10.7 million mistake in calculating state school aid the municipalities had counted on receiving this year.

title: PETER PAUL LACHAPELLE TO WED CATHLEEN JOAN DEVORE IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Devore, Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cathleen Joan Devore, to Peter Paul Lachapelle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Lachapelle of Massapequa, L.I. A May Wedding is planned. Miss Devore is a data systems engineer with the New England Telephone Company in Boston.

title: THE NEW BRAND OF ECONOMICS
description: W ITH two major speeches, an audit and a gaggle of fact sheets, President Reagan has staged an economic thriller, full of heroes and villains. We can now see the details of the new President's economic vision.

title: Russia Faces an Energy Shortage
description: Every five years, the Soviet Communist Party meets for two weeks to approve a new economic program. When the 26th Congress gets under way in Moscow tomorrow, it will be dealing not only with the nation's well-known agricultural failings but with potential energy problems it hasn't had to face before. The Soviet Union's oil supply, by its own forecast, is growing increasingly tight at a time when coal production is beginning to recede, at least temporarily.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: CHILDREN OF THE SUN, by Martin Green. (Wideview Books, $6.95.) An account of Britain's ''decadent generation,'' a group of writers and artists that, in the years following World War I, revolted against their fathers' values. Its members included Aldous Huxley, Osbert and Sacheverell Sitwell, W.H. Auden, Christopher Isherwood, Stephen Spender, Evelyn Waugh and Cecil Beaton, while D.H. Lawrence, George Orwell and F.R. Leavis constituted a counteracting force. Hilton Kramer, reviewing it here, called it ''a very important book that illuminates a large area of modern cultural history.''

title: THE AGONY OF EL SALVADOR
description: A cherubic, 14-year-old boy in pressed shirt, clean pants and shined shoes led the way up a narrow, twisting mountain path. Behind him came a chunky woman in her early 20's, a rainbow sewn on the front of her maroon sweatshirt, carrying a new grenade launcher made in the United States and covered with protective grease. Another woman followed, the front pockets of her new olive green military jacket bulging with Soviet-made hand grenades; she led a horse burdened with burlap bags of corn in which the shapes of automatic rifles could just barely be seen.

title: Westchester Guide; ILLUMINATING AN ART FORGER
description: An unknown artist known only as the Spanish Forger turned out such exquisite ''medieval'' illuminations in Paris at the turn of the century that they were purchased as the real thing by unsuspecting museums and by no less an art connoisseur than J. P. Morgan, who deposited a large collection of them in the Morgan Library in New York. By now the pieces have achieved a legitimacy of their own, to the extent that they were given a major exhibition at the Morgan a few years ago. The Spanish Forger is believed to have died around 1930.

title: FOUR NOVELS
description: THE PAST By Neil Jordan. 234 pp. New York: George Braziller. $8.95.

title: Carolyn Hess Sets Wedding for June
description: Carolyn Hess and John Richard Abraham 3d, both of New York, plan to be married in June. The bride-to-be, an economist with the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Hess of New Castle, Pa., who announced the engagement. Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Jr. of Glastonbury, Conn., are the parents of the prospective bridegroom, a product manager for the public-finance division of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: REAGAN'S SCHEME TO PROMOTE FITNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Martha O'Reilly, a Designer of Graphics, Wed to James Mcleod Alexander, Banker
description: Martha O'Reilly, a designer of graphics, and James Mcleod Alexander, an associate with the banking division of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, were married yesterday evening in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Frederick B. Northup performed the ceremony.

title: FOR A VOLUNTEER IN FIELD SERVICE, LOVE EXCHANGED
description: IT was 12 years ago that our oldest daughter asked my husband and me to consider being hosts to an American Field Service student from another country. One Japanese daughter, one German daughter and one Brazilian son later, we realize how the shape of our world has changed. Japan, Germany and Brazil are no longer simply countries many miles away, but places where our children live and work, where they have married and given us A.F.S. grandchildren.

title: FAR,FAR FROM HOME
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard Shepard reports on cultural news for The New York Times. MANDARINS, JEWS AND MISSIONARIES The Jewish Experience in the Chinese Empire. By Michael Pollak. Illustrated. 436 pp. Philadelphia: The Jewish Publication Society of America. $14.95.

title: Fathers of Flying
description: That a President of the United States flies home - 3,000 miles - for the weekend, or that a Chicago secretary may spend a two-week vacation in China is so accepted a fact of modern life that one tends to forget how very young the aviation industry is. Until this month two of its pioneers were still among us: Donald W. Douglas, whose DC-3 opened the era of mass airline travel, and John Knudsen Northrop, about whom Mr. Douglas said in the l940's, ''Every major airplane in the skies today has some Jack Northrop in it.''

title: No Headline
description: No matter how informal President Reagan may try to appear at times, his hair has that just-combed appearance, reminiscent of another movie star, Esther Williams, whose filmed swimming sequences always had her emerging from the water depths with magnificently coiffed hair, mysteriously intact.

title: Mat Title to Columbia
description: Jay Craddock, senior heavyweight, closed out his undefeated season by pinning Marty Majeske in 1 minute 25 seconds yesterday as Columbia retained its Ivy League wrestling title by beating Cornell, 22-12. Columbia improved its record to 14-1 over all and 5-0 in the league. Cornell fell to 10-4-1 and 4-1.

title: Fashion; BORROWED FROM MEN
description: Fashion By Mary Russell

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: TWO IS A CROWD IN TINY TOWN HALL
description: LEDYARD FOR Mayor J. Alfred Clark Jr., the Ledyard Town Hall just isn't big enough for two administrations - the town's and the Board of Education's - and so, carrying out a threat, he has asked the board to find new quarters by Sept. 1.

title: Party Discipline
description: The Nassau Democratic organization has dropped its effort to discipline a county committeewoman and Democratic National Convention delegate who had publicly supported Ronald Reagan for President last fall.

title: Takei's 'Light' to Be Danced In Its 10-Hour Entirety
description: Kei Takei's 15-part dance piece ''Light'' will be presented in its entirety for the first time, as part of the Takei Moving Earth company's season from April 21 through April 26 at Larry Richardson's Dance Gallery, 242 East 14th Street.

title: Megan Maguire to Be June Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Laurence Maguire of Madison, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Megan Elizabeth Maguire, to Daniel Carroll de Roulet, son of Mrs. Vincent de Roulet of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Mr. de Roulet, former Ambassador to Jamaica.

title: St. Peter's 57, Army 43
description: St. Peter's College held Army to 13 points in the first half today and sent the Cadets to their 10th straight loss, 57-43.

title: REFORMING THE ELECTORAL REFORMS
description: Cyrus R. Vance was Secretary of State in the Carter Administration. By Cyrus R. Vance In 1980, more than a dozen candidates in 37 primaries spent more than $100 million campaigning for the privilege of being nominated for the Presidency. The experience has produced, among politicians and voters, the growing conviction that we must change the manner in which we choose our Presidential candidates. In fact, the problems are so acute that action is required now, before the imminent start of the 1984 campaign. In a world of rapid change, we can no longer afford an electoral system that tends to hobble the governmental decision-making process for months. This not only harms us at home, but concerns and alarms our friends and allies, and tempts our adversaries.

title: Major Cocaine Seizure Reported
description: Federal and state law enforcement officials said today that they had made the biggest seizure of finished cocaine in history, 826 pounds. A spokesman for the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration said the seizure and two arrests resulted from a twomonth investigation that produced a tip that the cocaine could be found at a Miami home last night. Two Miami men, Alberto Joaquin Cordero, 50 years old, and Angel E. Alvarez, 43, were arrested.

title: No Headline
description: To the Sports Editor: Howie Evans, Fordham's assistant basketball coach, in explaining why he was not recruiting Troy Truesdale, an All Hallows senior, was quoted as saying, ''We can't ... No grades. If I could, I'd be all over him,'' (''Ups and DOwns of Fordham Recruiting,'' The New York Times, Feb. 8).

title: Peking Assails Decision of Dutch To Affirm Taiwan Submarine Deal
description: China today described as regrettable the Dutch decision to go ahead with the sale of two submarines and equipment for nuclear power stations to Taiwan.

title: MEMORIES OF 'COMING HOME AT LAST'
description: RADIO awakens me, delivering the news that the hostages will be released. For an instant, I think that perhaps I am still asleep and dreaming; however, as I swing my legs out of bed, I hear the message repeated. It is true. My eyes fill quickly.

title: COONEY IS'KEEPING LOOSE'
description: WEARING a blue shirt and blue trunks, Gerry Cooney had stuffed his hands into red boxing gloves, and now he held his arms out so that his trainer, Victor Valle, could tie the laces.

title: Seton Hall Upsets Syracuse on Late Shot
description: Matt Piccinich's six-foot jump shot with eight seconds left gave Seton Hall a 66-65 upset victory over Syracuse in a Big East Conference basketball game tonight.

title: THE BIGGEST WATER COMPANY
description: THE headquarters of the American Water Works Company here on the outskirts of town seems to symbolize the obscurity of the nation's water utilities. The compact, single story brick building sits not far from the road, the modest front lawn devoid of fountain, pool or waterfall that would mark the building as home of the nation's largest publicly traded water utility holding company, serving more than 500 communities in 20 states.

title: PIAF REMAINS A MIX OF MYTH AND REALITY
description: PARIS Edith Piaf lies buried at Pere Lachaise cemetery, only 10 blocks from where she was born on the street of Paris's toughest quartier. Between birth and death she rose from street singer to celebrated chanteuse, a roller-coaster life of stardom and failure, comeback and collapse, love and death that touched even the most hardboiled French hearts.

title: WOMEN TAKE A TURN AT HOCKEY
description: HICKSVILLE IN the domed skating rink at Cantiague Park, the chilled air fell silent as a horn blast ended the final period of play in the morning's hockey game. Neither of the two teams exhibited much emotion in the aftermath of their 2-2 deadlock.

title: Iowan Who Wanted Citizenship Dies at 94 After Achieving Goal
description: One week after Edward Francis Graves got his wish and became an American citizen at the age of 94, he died peacefully in his sleep.

title: CORINNE INGRAHAM PIGOTT
description: Corinne Ingraham Pigott, who served with the Voice of America and with the United Nations, died Friday of cancer at New York Hospital. Mrs. Pigott, a resident of Manhattan, was 64 years old.

title: 2,000-HOUSE PLAN WILL TEST MARKET IN RENEWAL AREAS
description: Just how much will a family pay to live in a new house in Coney Island? In Prospect Heights? In South Jamaica? In Bushwick? In the South Bronx?

title: Chun Promises an Amnesty Timed to His Inauguration
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea has promised a large-scale amnesty in conjunction with his March 3 inauguration for a seven-year term, but it will apparently not include leading opposition figures, Seoul newspapers reported today.

title: THE HUGHES WILL, R.I.P.
description: Even if someone could have proven that Howard Hughes wrote a will (and several tried), they'd have been hard put to show he was ''of sound mind'' at the time. As it turned out, no one had to.

title: The Pope Takes His Message to Manila
description: Pope John Paul II last week brought to Asia the same inspirational triptych he has carried to Europe and the Americas - a plea to the state to respect human rights, to the clergy to put religious duty before political activism and to clergy and laity alike to obey the church's conservative tenets on the family and sexuality.

title: Yugoslavia
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 18 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $15.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 2 3 9 ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Putnam's, $12.95.) A man who has made it big in early 20th-century America struggles against the corruption that engulfs his life. 3 4 19 COME POUR THE WINE, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $12.95.) A woman's long journey to self-discovery. 4 2 22 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942. 5 5 27 FIRESTARTER, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) E ightyear-old Charlie can look at anything and turn it into flames. 6 9 6 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) A fantastic tale about the Sun, the Moon and a lost treasure. 7 7 35 RAGE OF ANGELS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $12.95.) An idealistic young woman lawyer triumphs over two vengeful men.

title: Sanitation Worker, 17, Charged in L.I. Slaying
description: A 17-year-old Long Beach, L.I., sanitation worker was charged yesterday with fatally stabbing a computer programmer for the New York Telephone Company in an apparent burglary attempt Wednesday in Long Beach, the Nassau County police said.

title: FAVORED IRISH TOWER IS 3 1 2-LENGTH WINNER
description: Irish Tower scored his third consecutive stakes victory by posting a pacesetting 3 1/2-length victory over Charlie Coast in the $85,350 Grey Lag Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Victoria L. Wagner To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. W. Wagner of Bethesda, Md., has announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Lynne Wagner, to Alan Talkington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard R. Talkington of La Jolla, Calif.

title: Music View; COULD SHOSTAKOVICH BECOME THE MAHLER OF THE '80'S?
description: It was announced recently that the Fitzwilliam String Quartet of Great Britain will present the complete cycle of the 15 Shostakovich quartets at Alice Tully Hall in March of 1982. Unless someone else beats them to it, this will be a New York first. It will not, one can confidently assume, be a last. Predicting the future of musical taste may be even riskier than most prognostications: forecasting with wet tea leaves or the entrails of birds is probably more scientific. Still, it seems likely that Shostakovich's performances will proliferate in coming years. The man threatens to become the Mahler of the 80's.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: A NEW Polish Heritage Room has been established at Felician College in Lodi ''to serve as an inspiration to incoming candidates'' for the Felician order of nuns and to acquaint the general public with the background of the order.

title: Chess; FUELING THE DRAGON
description: (CHESS FOR SUNDAY, FEB. 22 ) By ROBERT BYRNE

title: OFFICIALS FAVOR 'GRASSO AIRPORT'
description: IN a well-orchestrated effort, Connecticut officials who had been searching for a suitable memorial to the late Gov. Ella T. Grasso have rallied around a proposal to rename the state's largest airport, Bradley International Airport, as the Ella T. Grasso International Airport.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFLICTS AND JOYS:LIFE IN A SMALL CO-OP
description: ''There are a lot more sacrifices than first meet the eye,'' said Theodore Bushlow of his move into a seven-family town-house cooperative in Brooklyn Heights. But despite having to live ''in a world of compromise,'' Mr. Bushlow, a lawyer, is happy that he selected a small building.

title: Chemical Tris Is Found In Test of Seminal Fluid
description: A chemical compound known to be a mutagen, or gene-altering agent, which is used to make automobile seat cushions and other consumer products flame resistant, has been found in the semen of college students who participated in a study at Florida State University at Tallahassee.

title: Courtesy in Court
description: The Georgia prosecutor politely addressed the white witnesses in the murder case as ''mister,'' but in questioning the black defendant, he consistently used just his first name, George. The defense attorney, Millard C. Farmer Jr. of Atlanta, objected to the ''racial slur'' and asked that his client also be addressed as mister.

title: VACATION WITHDRAWL SYNDROME
description: ''With the first glimpse of the building, a sense of insufferable gloom pervaded my spirit....
