I looked upon the scene before me - upon the mere house - with an utter depression of soul which I can compare to no earthly sensation more properly than to the after-dream of the reveler upon opium - the bitter lapse into everyday life.'' Edgar Allan Poe

title: IN THE YEAR OF THE DRESS, THEY'RE NO. 1
description: WHEN the midi debacle almost sank the dress business in the early 1970's, most fashion houses sought refuge in sportswear -but not the Albert Nipon Company. When other fashion houses went after the executive woman with an outpouring of tailored suits, Albert Nipon stuck to taffeta and chiffon. And when designers began licensing their initials for everything from sunglasses to jeans, Albert Nipon confined its name to the labels sewn inside its dresses.

title: Soviet Skaters Dominate Trials for Speed Skating
description: The Soviet Union won three of four events in trials of the speed skating world championships today, with Norway taking the fourth event. The finals will be run tomorrow.

title: CHURCH COUNCIL ASKS CITY MEMBERS TO DISTRIBUTE FUNDS FOR ENERGY AID
description: The Council of Churches of the City of New York is asking local churches to disburse most of the $250,000 the council received as part of a grant from the United States Department of Energy during the closing hours of the Carter Administration.

title: PRIMARY FOREIGN AID SURVIVES IN BUDGET
description: The State Department has salvaged the essential parts of the United States foreign economic aid program from proposals by the White House Office of Management and Budget to cut the spending planned by the Carter Administration, but the program still faces an uphill fight in Congress, Government officials said today.

title: HERE COME THE SWORDS AND SORCERERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Owen is a British journalist who often reports on the film scene. By MICHAEL OWEN LONDON

title: REAGAN MAKING THE MOST OF HIS MANDATE
description: At a tense moment in one of the last budget-cutting sessions at the White House, President Reagan and his aides were discussing a domestic program. ''Go ahead and cut it,'' the President commanded. Then he added with a chuckle, ''They're going to hang me in effigy anyway, and it doesn't matter how high.''

title: COURT RESERVES DECISION ON ADJUSTMENT OF NEW YORK'S CENSUS DATA
description: A Federal appeals court has reserved its decision on whether the Census Bureau must adjust the 1980 population figures for New York City and state.

title: A Tale of Two Cities and Taxes
description: The taxpayers' revolt may one day result in unquestioned fiscal responsiblity in city halls all across the land. If Boston is a reliable guide, however, hard times may come first.

title: Sharlene Wonders To Be Wed May 30
description: The engagement of Sharlene D. Wonders to Geoffrey C. Jiranek has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George H. Wonders of Wellsville, Pa., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Jiranek of Minneapolis and Wellsville, Pa.

title: Annie Glidden Betrothed
description: The engagement of Annie Glidden, to Gregory P. Kammerer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Kammerer of Bronxville, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen H. Glidden of Dedham, Mass. An August wedding is planned.

title: CHARTING THE TENSIONS OF AN INFIDELITY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Benedict Nightingale writes on theater for The New Statesman. By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE LONDON Considering they are sometimes called eternal, triangles have been strangely neglected by British dramatists of late. There was a time, well within living memory, when you could hardly enter a theater without finding husband, wife and mistress gamely biting lumps out of each other; and that, of course, was the trouble. The eternal came to seem interminable, and the old geometry went out of fashion in a way and to a degree it never had in life itself.

title: N.A.S.L. Has Deadline to Change 2 Rules
description: An ultimatum has been issued to the North American Soccer League to change two major rules by March 31 or be expelled from the world governing body of soccer.

title: AND MR. JEFFERSON, ON MR. WASHINGTON: 'HIS INTEGRITY WAS MOST PURE'
description: PURE Following are excerpts from a letter that Thomas Jefferson wrote to a Dr. Walter Jones on Jan. 2, 1814. Dr. Jones had written Jefferson saying that he was having trouble, with a historical work under preparation, in depicting George Washington's role during the Federalist-Republican struggle.

title: CUBA SEIZES 29 HOLDING EMBASSY
description: Security forces entered the Ecuadorean Embassy here today and arrested 29 Cubans who seized the building eight days ago, the Cuban Government announced.

title: JACKSON HIGH: SOMETHING EXTRA
description: Slipping sideways into the lane and pumping twice, George Allen of Jackson High School, barely 6 feet tall, slides the ball off his fingers and into the basket. Seconds later, he makes his fourth steal of the period, dunks and leaves the rim shaking.

title: Dance View; A TALE OF LOST SUBSCRIBERS
description: ''You can lead a horse to water...'' One of the most hopeful experiments in audience development for dance was the initiation of the ''Masters of American Dance'' series at the City Center last year. This was a highly sucessful subscription that reached a new public. Its main aspect was the offering of several modern-dance companies to ''virgin'' subscribers - operagoers, for instance, whose names were not on any dance mailing list. The same approach, including the same companies but one, was tried again - with the result that the renewal rate for the currrent and second ''Masters of American Dance'' subscription dropped dramatically low.

title: POLES' NEIGHBORS FEAR SPREAD OF UNREST
description: After six months of alternately ignoring or condemning worker unrest in Poland, the rest of Eastern Europe is showing growing anxiety about a spread of the Polish movement for democratic rights and better standards of living.

title: Miss Heller Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James K. Heller of Milwaukee have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gretchen Heller, to Philip Morgan Farmer, son of Probate Court Judge John Morgan Farmer and Mrs. Farmer, of Litchfield, Conn.

title: Blues 4, Rockies 1
description: Jorgen Pettersson and Blake Dunlop scored power-play goals 30 seconds apart in the third period to lead league-leading St. Louis. Colorado has not won in six games.

title: VETERANS PROGRAMS ESCAPING TRIMS DESPITE CRITICISM OF SOME BENEFITS
description: Almost every department and agency in the Government has been asked to reduce spending for at least some of its programs, but one of the largest agencies, the Veterans Administration, escaped President Reagan's budget knife without a scratch.

title:
Art;
WOOD RELIEFS STRIKE A RIGOROUS BALANCE
description: GARDEN CITY FOR some artists, creativity is anything but the free flight of fancy. Instead of being expressed in terms of intuition, liberation or coloristic verve, the creative impulse is, to them, a means of ordering the universe according to their own rigorous systems.

title: RONALD REAGAN'S RADICAL ECONOMICS
description: STRANGE things are happening in Washington. President Reagan has proposed a huge restructuring of Government, and people are actually taking him seriously. The man, whom we call a conservative, turns out to be downright radical.

title: AMORY HOUGHTON OF CORNING GLASS WORKS
description: Amory Houghton, chairman emeritus of the Corning Glass Works and former United States Ambassador to France, died yesterday at the Medical University Hospital in Charleston, S.C. He was 81 years old and was a resident of Corning, N.Y.

title: Lindsay Richardson Plans Aug. 1 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Bradley Richardson of Milton, Mass., and North Haven, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lindsay Currier Richardson, to Samuel Phillips Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. W.G. Brooks Thomas of Roland Park, Baltimore. An Aug. 1 wedding is planned.

title: State an 'Exporter' Of College-Age Youth
description: John Rosenberg's article on the shrinking enrollments of the state colleges (''Colleges in a Shrinking Market,'' Feb. 8) ignores some crucial data. Although it is true that the traditional pool of 18-year-olds is declining, there are other important untapped sources in Fairfield County which could more than make up for the loss. Currently approximately 63 percent of the high school graduates in the Stamford area continue to college; but less than half the students remain within the state. A similar situation pervades other sections of Connecticut. In other words, the state is an exporter of its college-age youth. This factor is nowhere recognized in the article and is played down by the Board of Higher Education, which only continues to emphasize the downtrend in its projections.

title: Stuart Johnson 3d, Susan M. O'Connell To Be Wed in May
description: Mrs. Joseph Francis O'Connell Jr. of Fort Worth has announced the engagement of her daughter, Susan Murrin O'Connell, to Stuart Holmes Johnson 3d, son of Mrs. Wynant Davis Vanderpool Jr. and Stuart H. Johnson Jr., both of Washington. A May wedding is planned.

title:
Stamps;
ISRAEL HONORS Mrs.Meir
description: A ''tough old lady'' who had the will to persevere on the road to peace was the way President Anwar el-Sadat described Mrs. Gold Meir when he made his historic break-through visit to Israel in 1977. He wished he could have been negotiating with her.

title: AFRICAN SHOW STOPPERS IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK ADAM AND EVE may well have been black and their Garden of Eden the Olduvai Gorge in Tanzania. Yet, except for Egypt and a few other countries around the continent's rim, Africa's history has been short and Colonial, so far as the West is concerned.

title: Putting F.A.L.N. Under Lock and Key
description: Last April, 10 people said to be agents of a terrorist organization that seeks independence for Puerto Rico were arrested in a northern suburb of Chicago. Last week, at the end of a sometimes raucous trial, a Federal judge sentenced them to prison terms ranging from 55 to 90 years.

title: Sunday Observer; THE I.Q. SANCTION
description: The I.Q. Sanction Patrick McDonnell

title: Fire in New York Hilton Causes Minor Damage
description: A two-alarm fire on the second floor of the New York Hilton Hotel in midtown Manhattan last night filling some floors with smoke and causing minor damage. One hotel guest was treated for smoke inhalation at the scene.

title: CONNECTICUT 71, PROVIDENCE 57
description: Mike McKay scored 19 points and Corny Thompson added 14 tonight to lead Connecticut to a 71-57 Big East Conference victory over Providence.

title: New Basque Terror
description: Borrowing a theme from Graham Greene, Basque terrorists kidnapped the honorary consuls of Austria, Uruguay and El Salvador in northern Spain last week, demanding freedom for300 jailed Basques.

title: 42 Political Figures Held in Coup Are Reportedly Freed by Liberia
description: Liberia's military Government has released 42 prominent political prisoners seized in a coup led by the army last April, the Nigerian news agency reported yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: It is worth noting that every one of the parents quoted in Marie Winn's article, including one woman who openly admits having illicit sex in the same house in which her children are sleeping, is raising children alone - and none of them appear to be widowed. It is time that such parents face the fact that their children learn from the example they set, and if the parents have no concern for marital fidelity and chastity outside of marriage - and if they do not make the essential connection between sex and enduring love and affection - there is no reason to expect their children to value those things. CLAYTON ALCORN, Cortland, N.Y.

title: BEAUBOURG'S DIRECTOR REFLECTS ON HIS REIGN
description: Because its essential and vulnerable organs are on the outside - ventilating pipes, heating pipes, pumps, elevators -a walk around the perimeter of the Beaubourg Center is a kind of reiterated prohibition. ''No Access,'' the signs read. ''Forbidden to the Public,'' ''Custodial Personnel Only.''

title: SIMON GRAY TRIES A 'GHOSTLY' COMEDY
description: Simon Gray, author of the Broadway hits ''Otherwise Engaged'' and ''Butley,'' reflected upon his latest work, ''Close of Play,'' and frowned quizzically. ''It's meant to be something of a comedy,'' he said.

title: Realty News
description: A 19-story office building at 291 Broadway has been purchased by an international concern for $7,075,000. ''I expect to hear in a few weeks that it's been sold for $9 million,'' said Joseph A. Pisarro, director of communications for the Young Men's Christian Association National Council.

title: World Federalists Association
description: To the Editor:

title: Nora Kerr, Editor, Is Married to Gordon T. Thompson
description: Nora Kerr, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Pearson Kerr of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Kerr, was married yesterday to Gordon T. Thompson, son of Mrs. Gordon S. Thompson of Evansville, Ind., and the late Mr. Thompson. Edward Hannabury, a Justice of the Peace, performed the ceremony in the Hall of Justice on Shelter Island, L.I.

title:
Dance;
DANCER RETURNING TO BEGINNINGS
description: IN black leotards, tights and legwarmers, Jennifer Muller, a choreographer, sat in a Manhattan loft studio and watched her company rehearse sections of a new work. The founder, director and choreographer of her own eight-member company, Jennifer Muller & The Works, Miss Muller has gained an international reputation over the last six years for her highly energetic, lyrical and theatrical brand of modern dance.

title: Dancing The Guaracha
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Is Termed Qualified For Green Beret Unit
description: Capt. Kathleen Wilder has become the first woman to qualify for the Army's Special Forces, but it may be years before she gets a green beret.

title: No Headline
description: United Press International CLUES SOUGHT TO BUS CRASH: In Quantico, Va., technicians examine the front axle of a bush that crashed Wednesday off Interstate 95, killing 11 persons and injuring 13. A General Motors engineer is at center. A fracture was discovered in the steering mechanism, and tests will be made to determine if it contributed to the accident.

title: THE NATIONAL DEBT: A PRIMER
description: WASHINGTON I N his televised address to a joint session of Congress last Wednesday night, President Reagan told the lawmakers and the American people that ''our national debt is approaching $1 trillion.'' He portrayed the debt as symptomatic of the nation's economic troubles.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Born in Montana, Kathryn Posin has gone back to the Northwest for inspiration in ''Galena Summit,'' a dance about the mountains of Idaho, which will be seen in a program of new works performed at Emanu-El Midtown Y, on Sunday, Saturday and next Sunday, by the Kathryn Posin Dance Company, a long-time staple of the New York dance scene. Commissioned by the Sun Valley Center for the Arts in Sun Valley, Idaho, and set to a score by Steve Reich, ''Galena Summit'' depicts the challenge of a mountain climb and the interdependence of the people who undertake such a venture.

title: MEMORIES OF A MAGICAL TIME: HEADING OUT TO SEA AT DAWN
description: There is an old saying that the only thing better than fishing is thinking about fishing. That is true for me, and I believe it helps explain the sport's popularity.

title: Critics' Choices
description: The Guide

title: An Uneasy Truce Called in Poland
description: For a change, Stanislaw Kania had the right answers last week. The Polish Communist Party leader tried them out on his least fraternal neighbors, Czechoslovakia and East Germany, reporting during quick visits that for the first time in three months there was labor peace back home.
To the Editor:

title: Manhattan 65, Navy 57
description: John Leonard, a junior guard, scored a career-high 31 points yesterday as Manhattan defeated Navy, 65-57, at the Draddy Gymnasium. Leonard, who secured the victory with four free throws in the final minute, had 22 points in the second half as the Jaspers (6-17) snapped a 13-game losing streak.

title: THE SOURCE OF JUSTICE IN THE MIND OF A JUSTICE
description: THE ENIGMA OF FELIX FRANKFURTER By H.N. Hirsch. 253 pp. New York: Basic Books. $14.95.

title: VACATIONING 'V.I.P.' STYLE
description: WHEN I scan the numerous advertisements for winter holiday packages, my attention is drawn to the many that promise travelers ''V.I.P. treatment.'' Remembering our family's experience with an overdose of such special attention, I laugh and silently wish the recipients good luck.

title: McEnroe Salvages Victory Over Borg in Series Finale
description: John McEnroe recovered from two straight resounding defeats and beat Bjorn Borg today, 6-1, 1-6, 7-6, 6-4, in the last of their three-match, $1.1 million challenge series.

title: DECISION IS DEFERRED ON SMITHVILLE PLANS
description: TRENTON THE Coastal Area Review Board, meeting here last Friday, deferred decision on whether the state's Division of Coastal Resources had followed the correct procedure in issuing a building permit to the Historic Smithville Development Co. for the construction of the Towne of Smithville in eastern Galloway Township in Atlantic County.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out; INVITING ATMOSPHERE IN FORMER CLUB
description: NEW HAVEN THE setting at Sherman's Taverne is so convivial that one is tempted to linger, especially on chill winter evenings. The dining room is stylish and attractive any time of year, but it is at its best at night when the crystal chandelier, imposing hearth, dark wood paneling, mirrored wall, arched stained-glass windows, and flickering candles on each table provide a romantic backdrop for dinner.

title: THE TOWN THAT OIL BUILT
description: rich-quick dreamers at its doorstep. Legend has it that an ornery wildcatter shot himself in the foot to raise insurance money to drill a well, while history records that J. Paul Getty started his billion-dollar career here.

title: No Injuries Are Reported In a Barn Fire at Bowie
description: A two-alarm blaze was quickly brought under control in a stable barn at Bowie Race Course early today, Prince Georges County fire officials said.

title: ART MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: DRASTIC REMEDIES MAY WAIT
description: President Reagan, flying west last week after his sorry-state-ofthe-union address, conceded that some elements of his economic recovery plan wouldn't go down easy. His forecast was as sound as the dollar once was.

title: OUT OF THE DROUGHT, TOGETHERNESS
description: THE current water shortage is testing us all. Our community spirit, our patience, our humanity, and our sense of smell are all under attack. Water, once taken so lightly and for granted, now engages much of our thinking.

title: Marie Winn cites a bit of current wisdom
description: ''As historian Philippe Aries has pointed out in his influential study 'Centuries of Childhood,' the very notion of innocent childhood as a separate phase of life did not exist until well after the end of the Middle Ages.''

title: AGREEMENT REACHED IN 3 MILE ISLAND SUIT
description: Just short of two years after the Three Mile Island reactor was partly melted in the worst accident in the history of commercial nuclear power, its owners and builders have reached a $25 million settlement in Harrisburg, Pa., with thousands of claimants who live within a 25-mile radius of the plant.

title: A NEBRASKA LEGISLATOR'S PROPOSAL: PAY THE PLAYERS
description: By ERNIE CHAMBERS Facing up to the undeniable truth that University of Nebraska football is a big business enterprise, I introduced a bill, LB 363, that classifies football players as employees who shall not be deemed professional athletes.

title: MR. WASHINGTON, ON HIS TIMES, LEADERSHIP, NEUTRALITY, TREATIES AND FOREIGN
description: The fathers of nationalist revolutions in our time have provided their followers with epigrammatic nuggets of revolutionary wisdom that are intended to produce continuing reverence in generations to come. Perhaps it is time for a posthumous collection of the same kind to keep our own Revolution on the track. The following excerpts from the sayings of George Washington, taken from his letters, are offered as a guide for his successors.

title: AIDING THE HUMANITIES: ARGUING ENDS AND THE MEANS
description: Oral history is enjoying a boom year at the National Endowment for the Humanities. So are professional ethics, Native Americans, regional and ethnic history and structuralism. But oral history is high on the list of recent Endowment awards. Boys Club members are interviewing the aged in Queens, Native American teen-agers are recording their elders in Iowa, inner city youth are putting tape recorders in front of their neighbors, a scholar is talking with waterfowl hunters south of Detroit, and the Southwestern Library Association is promoting programs on the subject in local libraries.

title: WELFARE RENTALS STUDIED IN SUFFOLK
description: CLAIMS by Suffolk County's 10 town supervisors that the county's Department of Social Services is permitting landlords to lease more than 10,000 substandard homes and apartments to rent-subsidy recipients has renewed a move in the County Legislature to reform the $44-million-a-year program.

title: Margaret Sutton, a Teacher, Engaged to George Khouri
description: Margaret Mary Sutton, a teacher with the New York City Board of Education's Center for Multiple Handicapped Children in Manhattan, and George John Khouri, a lawyer in New York, will be married in July.

title: New York Times Magazine February 22, 1981
description: William Safire 9 On Language Haigravations Russell Baker 14 Sunday Observer The I.Q. Sanction Cyrus R. Vance 16 Reforming the Electoral Reforms A statesman who served in four Administrations reflects on the way we choose Presidential candidates, a result of efforts to democratize the process, and argues that it is time for a change. Holcomb B. Noble 18 Schooling for the Olympics Vermont's Stratton Mountain School has opened its dorms - and its slopes - to gifted young skiers.

title: Panda Mating
description: Hsing-Hsing and Ling-Ling, the two giant pandas that China gave the United States in 1972, appeared to be a compatible couple at the National Zoo in Washington. But at mating times they could not, in the zoo's delicate words, achieve ''an effective breeding posture.'' After trying panda weight-watching without results, the zoo's officials, eager for baby pandas, went to artificial insemination in May 1980. Still no offspring.

title: Israeli Folk Festival
description: The Israeli Folk Dance Festival and Festival of the Arts will take place March 15 at 4 and 7:30 at Town Hall.

title: Reading and Writing; LISTENER WITH A VOICE
description: The three fiction judges voted unanimously last year to give the Pulitzer Prize to Philip Roth for his novel ''The Ghost Writer.'' I was one of them. What impressed us most in the book was the absolute rightness of Roth's voice in the character of Zuckerman. As it turned out, we were overruled in our choice by the very people who had invited us to be judges; but, before we knew that, I was asked to prepare a short tribute to Roth and his work. I took my cue from something Lonoff, the older writer, says about Zuckerman in the book. He compliments Zuckerman on his voice, which he then defines: ''I don't mean style. I mean voice: something that begins at about the back of the knees and reaches well above the head.''

title: ' GOD BLESS MR. BLOOM!
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Islanders; GIVING GLAMOUR TO ECONOMICS
description: MIDWAY through his two-year term as president of Omicron Delta Epsilon, the national economics honor society, Dr. Egon Neuberger of the State University faculty in Stony Brook scheduled a trip to Washington the other day.

title: BARBARA BUSH: THE PALNS IN HER LIFE
description: White-haired Barbara Bush wishes the great American public out there would drop the subject of her hair color. She gets a stream of well-meaning letters suggesting that she dye it a ''younger'' shade. ''It makes me mad as the dickens,'' she said, adding ruefully, ''If I did something like that, I think all of America would fall flat on its face from astonishment.''

title: SALVADOR'S REBELS SAY THEY SEEK MORE ARMS FOR A FRESH OFFENSIVE
description: Four guerrilla commanders have said in an interview here that they are short of weapons at the moment but are resupplying for an offensive.

title: Northwestern 74, Michigan 70
description: Rod Roberson made two free throws with 12 seconds to play and Jim Stack made two more with 4 seconds remaining to help Northwestern to a 74-70 upset over Michigan in a Big Ten game today.

title: YALE TO CONSOLIDATE MUSIC FACILITIES IN NEW PROJECT
description: Yale University will begin work this summer on an ambitious $17.5 million renovation and construction project designed to consolidate undergraduate and graduate music facilities into a one-block campus. Officials announced today the receipt of the first gift to the program - $1.5 million from an anonymous alumnus.

title: SOCIAL WORKERS GO INTO PRIVATE PRACTICE
description: WHILE most of them continue to work on the staffs of agencies, clinics and hospitals, an apparently growing number of the Island's social workers are turning to private practice for both professional and economic reasons.

title: HOMES IN SOUTH WILL OPEN FOR VISITORS
description: Toward the end of next month, dogwoods and azaleas, lilac and daffodils will be flowering in South Carolina and Virginia and signaling the time for the house and garden tours that both states hold each spring.

title: Connecticut Housing; SOME TAX GUIDANCE FOR HOMEOWNER
description: NONTRADITIONAL living arrangements are becoming increasingly more commonplace and are raising a host of new tax considerations for the homeowner.

title: WANTED: A RARE NARWHAL TUSK
description: ONE day about a year ago, George Finckenor and his old friend Oshin Agathon went fishing. They began to tell some fish stories, and eventually the talk turned to whaling.

title: STOCKMAN DISCUSSES STRATEGY AND OUTLOOK
description: As director of the Office of Management and Budget, David A. Stockman is President Reagan's principal tax and spending surgeon. On Friday, Edward Cowan, a reporter in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times, talked with Mr. Stockman about some of the political and economic facets of the budget and tax cuts the President proposed last week. Excerpts of their discussion follow.

title: Television Week
description: Senora PeronAttempts at dramatizing the life of Eva Peron, the wife of Argentine dictator Juan Peron who died in 1952 of cancer at the age of 33 after becoming one of the most powerful women in history, have not met with critical acclaim. Radley Metzger's 1973 film ''Little Mother'' was generally deemed a second-rate melodrama. The musical ''Evita,'' by Tim Rice and Andrew Lloyd Webber, although still going strong on Broadway since opening in September 1979, has been criticized by many for glamorizing a dedicated fascist.

title: Wells Fargo: Stung; For a Third Time?
description: As every Saturday matinee veteran knows, Wells Fargo usually got the best of outlaws in black hats. Now, though, the bad guys are often in white collars and the story line has changed.

title: Rolls-Royces of Ice Cream
description: Haagen-Dazs ice cream comes in pint and half-pint containers with lids that feature a map of Scandinavia, but it's made by a Polish immigrant, all in New Jersey. The label of another brand, Alpen Zauber, touts a ''Swiss commitment to excellence.'' But Alpen Zauber is made entirely in Brooklyn. And Frusen Gladje? The company is incorporated in Stockholm, but every scoop comes from Utica, N.Y.

title: BASEBALL: ANOTHER SPRING SHOWDOWN
description: Spring, the season of hope, is sprouting this week in 26 baseball camps from Palm Springs to Palm Beach. But, for the second straight year, the threat of labor strife is hanging over the 1,100 players, their teams and their negotiating committees.

title: William Staples Fiance of Miss Sendzimir
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Sendzimir of Woodbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Jane Sendzimir of New York, to William Lee Staples of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., son of Marian Staples of Tucson, Ariz., and the late Forrest Millburn Staples.

title: Chinatown Gambling Raids Called 'Insensitive' by Judge
description: Charges against 103 men arrested in gambling raids during the recent Chinese New Year's celebration have been set aside by a judge, who termed the raids ''insensitive.''

title: OPERA: MET'S 'PARADE,' CAPTIVATING TRIPLE BILL
description: Every so often, and sometimes none too soon, something happens at the opera to justify its existence and restore faith in its present and future. That happened Friday night at the premiere of the threelayer slice of Napolean that the Metropolitan Opera served up under the title of ''Parade.''

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: POWER LOSS FOR CON ED THURSDAY IN CITY AND WESTCHESTER WAS 28%
description: The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that it had lost 28 percent of the electrical power needs of New York City and Westchester County during a transmission crisis Thursday night, not 18 percent as originally believed.

title: INTO THE BRAZILIAN INTERIOR ABOARD A 1912 STEAMBOAT
description: We were only 500 miles north of the beaches of Rio de Janeiro and the industrial sprawl of Sao Paulo, but we were at least a century removed from the megalopolis formed by these two Brazilian coastal cities. On a three-day cruise aboard a 1912 paddlewheel steamer on the 1,800-mile-long Sao Francisco River we covered nearly 400 miles - from Pirapora in the state of Minas Gerais northward to Bom Jesus da Lapa in Bahia.

title: Susan Bright Plans Marriage May 16
description: Susan Bright of Morristown, N.J., director of the teacher services center of the Educational Improvement Center in Morris Plains, N.J., plans to be married May 16 to Stephen W. Harvey of Flanders, N.J., a telecommunications consultant with Johnston Communications in Kearny, N.J.

title: THE WORLD IN SUMMARY
description: Just in case the allies had trouble reading between the lines, Administration envoys last week widely circulated what they said was ''a textbook case of indirect armed aggression by Communist powers'' in El Salvador.

title: POPE VISITS INDOCHINA REFUGEES AND CALLS FOR MORE AID
description: Pope John Paul II prayed today for an end to strife in Asia and for compassion toward Indochinese refugees as he visited the Indochinese refugee center in Bataan Province west of Manila and a Roman Catholic radio station in the capital's eastern suburbs.

title: Jo-Ann Zbytniewski, Editor, Is Married to John W. Skeels
description: Jo-Ann Zbytniewski, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Zbytniewski of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to John W. Skeels, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Woodrew Skeels of Winter Haven, Fla. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Susan Wise Fiancee Of Scott A. Nelson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Wise Jr. of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Hilton Head, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Brayton Wise, to Scott Alan Nelson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Scarff Nelson of Yonkers.

title: Greece Complains to U.S.  Over Gas Warfare Exercise
description: The Greek Government has lodged a formal protest with the United States over an incident in which 20 American soldiers wearing protective clothing and gas masks conducted a chemical warfare exercise in the small northern town of Drama.

title: Eleanor Howard Engaged to S. B. Sampson
description: The engagement of Eleanor Tatlock Howard to Stephen Byers Sampson has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James Merriam Howard Jr. of Westport, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Woodbury Sampson of Lewiston, Me.

title: Anne Eckardt, an Editor, Fiancee of Christopher Demas
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Reeves of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Reeves's daughter, Anne Nicholson Eckardt, to Christopher Papalexis Demas, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Demas, also of Greenwich.

title: TARNOWER JURORS SPEND 7 HOURS IN DELIBERATION, LONGEST DAY SO FAR
description: The jury in the trial of Jean S. Harris spent its fifth, and longest, day in deliberations today, apparently unable to reach a decision on the charge of murder in the second degree, the most serious of three possible charges involving the shooting of Dr. Herman Tarnower.

title: Art; TECHNOLOGY AS A MEDIUM FOR ARTISTS; YONKERS
description: OF the two notable, technology-dependent shows now gracing Westchester, one is at the Hudson River Museum and consists of new work by Larry Bell (through March 22). The other, at the Katonah Gallery, 28 Bedford Road, Katonah (through March 8), features three artists presenting, respectively, some holograms, an optical piece and a sound sculpture.

title: Jacilyn Beverly Cohn Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs., William Cohn of Perth Amboy, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jacilyn Beverly Cohn, to Marc Alan Wolfson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Wolfson of Metuchen, N.J. Miss Cohn is a laboratory technician at the Perth Amboy General Hospital. Her fiance is a pharmacist in Woodbridge, N.J. The wedding will take place in December.

title: WHEN THE NEWS IS MAN DIDN'T BITE DOG
description: THE race for Governor of New Jersey has come down to this: Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo, Republican of Union, announced last week that he was not interested in running for the state's top elected office.

title: SCHOOLING FOR THE OLYMPICS
description: Holcomb B. Noble is an editor of The New York Times Magazine. By Holcomb B. Noble Racer No. 58, ready, please.'' The starter's call plunges a cold aluminum ski pole into Louis Gordon's heart as he waits in the warmup hut in near-zero temperature, high winds howling atop Whiteface Mountain at Lake Placid, N.Y. Louis, No. 60, is about to be called to the starting gate. He is gunning for a spot on the United States Men's Alpine Olympic Ski Team in 1984. The course, over which he will run his first downhill race of the season, is very icy and very fast. He is surrounded by other waiting racers and, through a window in the hut, he looks out to the steepest part of the mountain. He sees No. 58 heading toward that pitch, plunging out of sight. ''Oh, my God, oh, my God!'' says Louis. ''What the hell am I doing here?'' But his coaches are with him, and he adds, ''O.K., I'll do it, I'll do it.'' He leaves the hut, and the starter radios to the timers at the finish line that Louis Gordon is ready.

title: At Home
description: SOMETHING was wrong. As I drove home from the supermarket, turning corners slowly so that the bags of groceries in the back of the car would stay upright, the checkout clerk's face flashed again and again in my mind's eye. It was an improbably youthful face, guileless and small, perched on the shoulders of a tall, muscular, adult male. Obviously a new employee, he had taken an inordinate amount of time to check out the three customers ahead of me in line, engaging each one in small talk between shouted requests for prices to other clerks.

title: LOUDSPEAKERS WITH BIG VOICES TURN UP IN SMALL PACKAGES
description: Among loudspeakers, as elsewhere, the exceptional is often submerged in the glut of the ordinary, and designs distinguished by subtle differences often fail to gain the recognition they deserve. One such speaker is Wharfedale's Model TSR-108, the smallest in a new series produced by this British company, which had been prominent in the early years of high fidelity and has lately perked up again after a hiatus. Despite its compact size (23 x 12 x 12 inches), this speaker rolls out clear and ample bass. The credit for this goes to a 10-inch woofer employing a self-damping cone of mineral-filled polymer. The properties of this material prevent the formation of false modes of vibration due to flexing and buckling of the cone which would otherwise muddy the lower notes and falsify timbres in the midrange. Evidently this woofer cone represents a successful instance among the numerous current efforts to develop cone materials capable of greater clarity in the lower frequency region. As for range, this woofer reaches down to 50 Hz at the low end, which is quite respectable for a speaker this size.

title: SOVIET DEFENSE MINISTER SAYS WEST IS TRYING TO REOPEN THE COLD WAR
description: Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Soviet Defense Minister, accused the West today of conducting an offensive against detente and trying to reopen the cold war.

title: Rutgers 87, Fairfield 57
description: Rutgers outscored Fairfield, 29-10, over the first 10 minutes of the second half and coasted to a 87-57 victory tonight at the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: Connors and Lendl Move To Final of Coast Tennis
description: Top-seeded Jimmy Connors and second-seeded Ivan Lendl scored semifinal victories today to advance to the final of the $175,000 Grand Marnier-A.T.P. tournament at the La Quinta Hotel Resort.

title: DEMOCRATS LAG ON CANDIDATES TO OPPOSE PURCELL
description: WITH two leading contenders declining to run, Nassau Democrats are seeking a candidate for what even the Democrats concede is an uphill race against the Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell.

title: A $3.4 Million Bequest Is Received by Columbia
description: Columbia University has received a $3.4 million bequest from the estate of an alumnus to establish the Ludwig Schaefer Fund for Research in Human Physiology for its College of Physicians and Surgeons, university officials announced last week.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Eastward ho! Just four years ago, when Jimmy Carter was getting settled in the White House and the future of publishing seemed certain and bright, Pinnacle Books, a middle-sized paperback house owned by a Dallas-based conglomerate, made a surprising announcement. As it couldn't afford to compete with the large houses in the auctions of reprint rights to blockbuster titles, it had long specialized in women's romances and men's action stories. To gain easy access to southern California's pool of creative talent and to Hollywood's many film tie-in projects, however, it announced it was going to move its headquarters from Manhattan to Los Angeles's Century Park, an office complex on the old 20th Century-Fox lot.

title: Togo
description: To the Editor:

title: FLYNN KEEPS UP REPUTATION FOR WORK
description: ALBANY DURING his 15 years in the State Legislature, Senator John E. Flynn, Republican-Conservative of Yonkers, has sponsored more legislation than any other State Senator or Assemblyman in Albany, according to some top political aides. By his own account, the Senator has had 450 bills signed into law.

title: Buying Wind
description: Reversing the usual role of electric utilities, the Southern California Edison Company offered late last year to buy power from its customers. It invited proposals ''for the sale of electricity generated by wind parks.''

title: Theater; 'ANYTHING GOES,' ZANY COLE PORTER HIT, STILL HAS ZEST
description: IF ever a musical was aptly named, it is the 1934 hit ''Anything Goes,'' which is a wild amalgam of zany characters and improbable plot shifts set aboard an ocean liner sailing from New York to London. The version being presented by the Darien Dinner Theater is the one used for the 1960 Off-Broadway revival and it makes as much sense as any I have seen.

title: Gale Gilleaudeau, Robert K. Stafford To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Alfred Gilleaudeau Jr. of Rye, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gale Ann Gilleaudeau, to Robert Kent Stafford of Westfield, N. J.

title: OASIS OF COLOR IN A FACTORY
description: YONKERS THE sprawling industrial complex along Nepperhan Avenue between Lake and Ashburton Avenues here - known to denizens of the area simply as ''the mill'' - is a picturesque, Dickensian tableau. From 1871 to 1955 the site of the 47-building Alexander Smith Carpet Mills, the mill stands today as a monumental relic of an age gone by.

title: Georgetown 68, Villanova 60
description: Mike Frazier scored 20 points and Eric Floyd 16 today as Georgetown defeated Villanova, 68-60, in a Big East game.

title: Thai Guerrilla Bands Kill 27 In Two Attacks in the South
description: Moslem and Communist guerrillas killed 27 people in two incidents in Thailand's southern provinces, ending six months of relative calm in the region, the authorities said today.

title: THE OPERA: 'GIOVANNI' AT THE CITY
description: The New York City Opera assembled an entirely creditable, even potentially exciting cast for its first ''Don Giovanni'' of the spring season Friday night. But the performance just sat there, stubbornly failing to cohere.

title: CASINOS ASK NEW JERSEY, DEAL OUT A HAND
description: In October the gambling casino industry abandoned the tone it had maintained during its two years of operation in New Jersey and went public with complaints it had made privately to state legislators with little effect.

title: TOWNS BAR TAX BILL AID TO PLANNERS
description: A LEGISLATIVE proposal to provide the state's 14 regional planning agencies with an independent source of tax dollars failed last week to gain the backing that its sponsor in the General Assembly said he was seeking.

title: Basques Holdings Consuls Threaten New Violence
description: Basque separatist guerrillas holding three kidnapped honorary consuls threatened today to stage new attacks to draw international attention to their demands.

title: No Headline
description: Leslie Gelb's remark that liberals are ''far more interested in disputing points of philosophy with one another than in fighting conservatives'' suggests that he has conveniently forgotten that liberals -through the very active means of demonstration, civil disobedience and lobbying - have been instrumental in bringing about recent legislation and events. For example, liberal activity contributed to the adoption of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the resignation of a President whose actions did not represent a ''Government of the people,'' and cessation of a war that was undermining the credibility of American justice.

title: ''Amadeus'' and Salieri
description: To the Editor:

title: Post-Firing Checks Find Space Shuttle Undamaged
description: Technicians inspecting the space shuttle Columbia and its launching pad reported today that the craft apparently survived its rocket firing test with no damage.

title: Dr. James Coles, Bowdoin Ex-President, Marries Dr. Cecily Cannan Selby, a Dean
description: Dr. Cecily Cannan Selby, dean for academic affairs at the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics in Durham and former headmistress of the Lenox School in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. James Stacy Coles of New York. He is president of the Research Corporation, a foundation for the advancement of science, and was president of Bowdoin College from 1952 to 1968.

title: Recordings; SONGS OF THE RENAISSNACE AND THE MIDDLE AGES
description: GUIDE By PETER G. DAVIS

title: Reagan Seeks Boating Fees
description: President Reagan, as part of his sweeping program to rejuvenate the nation's economy, is proposing that a system of annual fees be levied on boat owners.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: INDECISION BY LABOR
description: The mood of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council, now holding its winter meeting in this resort area, seems something like the south Florida weather earlier in the week: gray, foreboding and indecisive.

title: WHERE HAVE ALL THE NURSES GONE?
description: Paula Span is a freelance writer living in Baltimore. By Paula Span The sickest patients at the George Washington University Medical Center in Washington lie in the intensive-care unit, wired to banks of screens where green blips record their blood pressures and heart rates. Hanging intravenous-feeding bottles and bedside pumps supply them with fluids and medications; hissing respirators help them to breathe. Managing the tangle of tubing and machinery, keeping copious records, watching hour after hour for signals - sometimes as subtle as a patient's grimace - is a team of registered nurses in yellow scrub gowns. Ideally, there should be 50 nurses to care for these 16 patients around the clock. There are now only 33 and the number is expected to continue declining.

title: LABOR SECRETARY ORDERS INQUIRY INTO REFORMING LONGSHOREMEN
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan today ordered a ''searching internal inquiry'' to determine what the Labor Department should do to clean up the International Longshoremen's Association.

title: Flight to Israel
description: Iosif Mendelevich finally flew out of the Soviet Union to Israel last week, after spending 11 years in labor camps as punishment for his first attempt to leave.

title: Ellen Rosenberg Fiancee Of Cantor David Tilman
description: The engagement of Ellen Ann Rosenberg to Cantor David F. Tilman, son of Alexander R. Tilman of Albany and the late Hannah B. Tilman, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Rosenberg of Elkins Park, Pa.

title: Westchester Housing; WAYS TO BORROW FOR A MORTGAGE
description: HOMEBUYERS don't just go out and get mortgaged in today's market - they shop among variable, adjustable, renegotiable, and graduated payment mortgages.

title: FARM EQUIPMENT IN SLUMP
description: High interest rates, the Soviet grain embargo and last summer's drought all combined to send sales of farm equipment plummeting last year, according to statistics provided by the Farm and Industrial Equipment Institute. Sales of a wide range of machinery used in field farming, from tractors and combines to hay balers, declined by roughly 20 percent, to 235,000 units.

title: CRAIG M. FERRER TO WED DEBORAH HORAN JULY 11
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard V. Horan of Pound Ridge, N.Y. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Lynne Horan, to Craig Michael Ferrer, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Ferrer of Stuart, Fla., formerly of Wilton, Conn.

title: Siena 75, Wagner 70
description: Vernon Asquith scored 17 points to lead Siena over Wagner, 75-70, Saturday night at Sutter Gymnasium, Grymes Hill, Staten Island.

title: Skiing The Steeps
description: I read and reread Peter Miller's beautifully orchestrated ''Skiing the Steeps''' (Jan. 25).

title: LEGAL AND FINANCIAL STRINGS DANGLE FROM IRAN PACKAGE
description: It didn't negotiate the deal and it claimed it wouldn't have negotiated at all if it found itself in a similar position, but the Reagan Administration grudgingly said last week that it would enforce the bargain Jimmy Carter and his men made with Iran, even its most distasteful provisions.

title: EXCERPTS FROM U.S. SPEECH AT MEETING IN MUNICH
description: Following are excerpts from remarks prepared for delivery by Frank C. Carlucci, Deputy Secretary of Defense, to a privately sponsored annual military policy conference in Munich, West Germany, and made available by the Defense Department here today:

title:
Gardening;
WHY A DOGWOOD MAY NOT FLOWER
description: ''WHY doesn't my dogwood tree flower? My neighbor bought one the same time I did, and his has flowered each year since. I give it high nitrogen fertilizer each year, and it has been doing very well as far as growth is concerned. It's almost twice as large as my neighbor's tree.''

title: THE MEMORY OF CARL SANDBURG LIVES ON IN GALESBURG,ILL.
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JERRY KLEIN is on the staff of The Peoria Journal Star. By JERRY KLEIN

title: THE REGION IN SUMMARY
description: Government officials like to be listened to, but not in the way that someone has been listening to Westchester County Executive Alfred B. DelBello. A ''very angry'' Mr. DelBello disclosed last week that private security consultants had discovered an electronic eavesdropping device in the County Executive office suite in White Plains early this month.

title: Phipps, Scott Winners
description: Ogden M. (Dinny) Phipps and Gene Scott of New York City won the 69th annual United States amateur court tennis doubles championship by defeating Jimmy Bostwick of New York City and William Vogt of Philadelphia, 6-2, 6-1, 6-2, today at the Racquet Club.

title: Pamela B. Smith Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell B. Smith of Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela B. Smith, to Keith M. Lemmons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wiley Lemmons of Pittsburg, Kan.

title: JFK AND FURTHER SINISTER FORCES
description: BEST EVIDENCE Disguise and Deception in the Assassination of John F. Kennedy. By David S. Lifton. Illustrated. 747 pp. New York: Macmillan. $16.95. By HARRISON E.SALISBURY

title: About Delius
description: To the Editor:

title: The Reagan Road to Recovery
description: The bold Reagan economic program cannot be brushed aside as a doctrinaire conservative plan to cut taxes for the rich or slash social programs for the poor. Heavy cuts in both taxes and spending are its main ingredients, but the most important aspect is its grand design.

title: Kentucky 80, Vanderbilt 48
description: Chuck Verderber scored three straight baskets during an 11-2 streak that helped Kentucky to a 80-48 rout of Vanderbilt in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.

title: At Home
description: SOMETHING was wrong. As I drove home from the supermarket, turning corners slowly so that the bags of groceries in the back of the car would stay upright, the checkout clerk's face flashed again and again in my mind's eye. It was an improbably youthful face, guileless and small, perched on the shoulders of a tall, muscular, adult male. Obviously a new employee, he had taken an inordinate amount of time to check out the three customers ahead of me in line, engaging each one in small talk between shouted requests for prices to other clerks. Supermarkets have always irritated me, and my day had been crowded with an unusual number of irritants already. I despise people who take out their anger on salespeople, having once been the target of that kind of abuse, and so I made a conscious effort to conceal my annoyance when my turn finally arrived.

title: EDISONS'S STATE HELPS ASPIRING INVENTORS
description: One man brought an innovative fishing bobber, another a doughnut-shaped device to paint flag poles and yet another a technique for bonding two different metals, such as aluminum and steel.

title: Nancy Coyle, H. J. Mollomo Plan Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Coyle of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Wickes Washburn Coyle, to Lieut. Harold Joseph Mollomo, U.S.A.F., son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Mollomo of Boston.

title: HOMOSEXUAL ADOPTS ANOTHER
description: Under a court decision that appeared to set a precedent, a 23-year-old homosexual man adopted a 27-year-old Friday in a New York City courtroom to establish a legal family relationship that was otherwise unavailable.

title: Engineer Corps General Backs Westway Project
description: An official of the Army Corps of Engineers has concluded that the controversial Westway proposal for New York City is ''an acceptable project.''

title: NEW FEDERAL TASK FORCE TO HELP IN ATLANTA INQUIRY
description: A special Federal task force will be sent to Atlanta to help local officials investigate the deaths or disappearances of at least 20 black children in the last 19 months, Vice President Bush announced today.

title: by Jim Benagh; Eyes of Texas
description: The Dallas Cowboys are so thorough in their study of prospects and players that it would surprise no one if the computer operator were elected the team's most valuable player. The Cowboys not only time players for the 40-yard dash, but also break down the results in 5-yard intervals.

title: SULLIVAN IS FOCUS OF THE RED SOX CRITICS
description: BOSTON HAYWOOD SULLIVAN had to stand up at a luncheon in the Fenway Park press room 11 days ago and announce that an arbitrator had declared Carlton Fisk - arguably the best catcher to ever play for the Red Sox - a free agent because his contract wasn't mailed out on time.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Darrell Waltrip held off challenges from Ricky Rudd and Richard Petty and survived an accident 15 laps from the finish to win the Richmond 400 Grand National stock car race today.

title: Hillman Retires, Sort Of
description: At 58, Murray Hillman, an executive vice president of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is sliding into early retirement. He will reestablish himself with his Strategy Workshop and its four other professionals. Interpublic will be the first client of the unit, which was founded in 1968 as an Interpublic division.

title: WATT'S WRONG CHOICES FOR OFFSHORE DRILLING
description: To the Editor:

title: by Sheldon J. Segan and W. Parker Mauldin
description: There are in the world 1.6 billion young people who are 15 years old or under, and they will be in their prime at the turn of the century. Most of them - 1.3 billion - live in third-world countries. They are the survivors, born with one chance in six of not lasting a year. For every three of them who has managed to reach 15, another has fallen along the way, at the rate of about 17 million a year.

title: HEAD OF BENEFICIAL UNIT
description: Joseph N. Scarpinato, 36, has been appointed president of the Peoples Credit Company, the subsidiary of the Beneficial Corporation that operates its Visa and MasterCard services, effective next Monday. He will succeed Dale Taylor, 34, who resigned his post at the Wilmington, Del., company.

title: 'Bring Back Birdie' Delays Its Premiere to March 5
description: The opening of ''Bring Back Birdie'' as been set back from this Wednesday to March 5.

title: Addenda
description: * Andrea & Associates, a new public relations firm formed by Andrea Mikotajuk Kotuk, located at 245 East 80th Street.

title: SHE'S A FRIEND VIA BOOKS
description: ''What was the first book you ever made?'' asked Tisa Heads of the fourth grade. ''Do you make the title first or the book first?'' asked Jeremy Lieberman of the sixth grade.. The students, under the guidance of their librarian, Norma D. Liss, had been reading their way through the fables and parables of Natalie Babbitt since mid-October. The other day about 75 fourth through eighth graders crammed into the second-floor library of the New Lincoln School on East 77th Street to ask the author, who had become, according to Miss Liss, ''a friend through her books,'' how she goes about her business.

title: Brown Is Struggling To Handle Pressure
description: It was a rough week for Larry Brown, the coach of the U.C.L.A. Bruins. Last Monday, Brown dropped Kenny Fields, a promising freshman center-forward. ''He couldn't accept not starting and he couldn't accept the guidelines of the other players for remaining on the team,'' Brown said.

title: Marajean Marvin Sings An Evening of Lieder
description: The ''Liederabend'' (song evening) presented in Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday by the soprano Marajean Marvin and the pianist Michael Zenge slighted neither the ''lieder'' nor the ''abend.'' Miss Marvin, who teaches voice at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and Mr. Zenge, director of the university's piano clinic, both gave the lieder their due.

title: A PROPOSAL TO CAST THE PRIMARY DIE
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNKIST AND F.T.C. SETTLE SUIT
description: In a move intended to force more competition in the citrus-fruit industry, the Federal Trade Commission today announced an antitrust settlement against the giant Sunkist cooperative.

title: IMPASSE DECLARED IN NEWS TALKS
description: PATERSON, N. J. FEB.22 (AP)A Federal mediator has declared an impasse in contract talks between The News of Paterson and local 103 of the International Typographical Union.

title: Four Arrive in New York Upon Release by Turkey
description: Four Americans who served more than eight years in Turkish jails for drug smuggling were released yesterday and flown to New York under Federal escort.

title: JOE SMITH, 97, A STAR OF VAUDEVILLE AS PART OF COMEDY TEAM 73 YEARS
description: Joe Smith, a partner for 73 years in the vaudeville team of Smith and Dale, died yesterday at the Actors' Fund Home in Englewood, N.J., five days after celebrating his 97th birthday.

title: THE U.N.TODAY
description: Feb.23.,1981 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean 10:30A.M. and 3 P.M. Special committee on the charter of the United Nations and on the strengthening of the role of the organization 10:30A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WHOLE WORLD WATCHING AS SOVIET PARTY CONVENES
description: More than 5,000 delegates from all parts of the Soviet Union gather tomorrow in the glass-and-marble Palace of Congresses inside the red-brick walls of the Kremlin to confirm Leonid I. Brezhnev as their leader for five more years and to approve the national economic strategy for the 1980's.

title: NORTHEAST AREA LAG CHARGED ON HEROIN
description: At a time when the increased flow of heroin into New York is taxing the agencies charged with curbing it, the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration has sharply criticized its Northeast regional office's efforts against the problem.

title: Decision to Rossman
description: Mike Rossman, employing his superior ring experience and showing speed on a variety of combinations in the later rounds, won a unanimous 10-round decision today from Luke Capuano in a nationally televised World Boxing Association lightheavyweight bout.

title: Richard Troeger Plays A Harpsichord Program
description: RICHARD TROEGER played a rich program of harpsichord music at the Abraham Goodman House Saturday evening.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: If a quarterback in a National Football League game throws a pass that deflects off an official and is caught by an eligible receiver before the ball strikes the ground, what is the ruling?

title: News Summary; MONDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1981
description: International Soviet presence in the Middle East will be given priority over resumption of Egyptian-Israeli negotiations on Palestinian self-rule by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who believes, according to American officials, that there is a major Soviet strategic threat to the region. In talks Friday with Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, Mr. Haig was said to have made known the Administration's concerns over the strategic situation in the Middle East and its lack of enthusiasm for pushing the Palestinian autonomy talks to the center of attention. (A1:4.) Punitive action against Cuba ''was entirely possible'' if it continues its alleged shipment of arms to El Salvador's guerrillas, Edwin Meese 3d, President Reagan's chief policy adviser, said in a television interview. Mr. Meese said that it was time that Cuba and the Soviet Union ''wake up to the fact'' that the Administration ''will take the necessary steps to keep the peace any place in the world and that includes El Salvador.'' (A1:2-3.)

title: by Peter G. Davis
description: THE City Opera's first ''Les Contes d'Hoffmann'' of the spring season yesterday afternoon found Antonio de Almeida making his company debut on the podium. This is certainly an appropriate work for Mr. de Almeida, who is known both as a specialist in French opera and as an authority on Offenbach.

title: Ellen Lee Greene Is Married
description: Ellen Lee Greene, daughter of Dr. and Mrs Irwin A. Greene of Huntington L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Michael Lowe of St. James , L.I. Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz, a chaplain at C. W. Post University, performed the ceremony in the Gold and White Room of the Plaza Hotel. The bride, a graduate of Harcum Junior College, is a nursing student. Her husband, is an assistant stationmaster in Jamaica, Queens, for the Long Island Rail Road. Dr. Greene is a dentist.

title: Israel Raids Rebel Base In Lebanon, Killing 10
description: Israeli forces attacked a Palestinian base eight miles inside Lebanon last night, killing 10 suspected guerrillas, the military command announced here today.

title: CHICO MARX, THE LINK FOR ACT AND AUDIENCE
description: I'VE always wanted to sponsor a Chico Marx film festival. The only thing is, I've never been able to figure out how to do it. Those other two busybodies keep getting in the way.

title: Milburn Still Hoping To Defeat Nehemiah
description: Once, he was the world's best high hurdler, first as an amateur and then as a professional. Now he is the old man in a young man's game, a philosopher surrounded by egos, a perfectionist seeking the perfect race.

title: CAMERA'S RETURN MAY ECLIPSE JOBS OF COURT ARTISTS
description: With the jury in the murder trial of Jean Harris out, the courtroom locked and the story of the long dramatic trial waiting numbly for an ending, Robert L. Smith sat sketching the inert lines of a deserted television camera as a symbol of the moment.

title: THE AMERICAN ANTITRUST QUANDARY
description: To the Editor:

title: EMBEZZLING CASE AT WELLS FARGO: KEYS ARE COMPUTERS AND VOLUME
description: Just three months ago, Edward P. Croak, a top Wells Fargo auditing official, wrote in Pacific Banker & Business magazine that the bank was in an ''enviable position'' in the banking community because of its success in controlling embezzlement and fraud.

title: STAGES IN LIFE OF A PARENT
description: W HEN the first baby is born, couples are generally shocked by the realities of parenthood. Then, for months or even years, they may go into another kind of shock. Relationships with their spouses, friends and family change significantly. Attitudes toward careers, life goals and leisure activities are altered. Couples are curiously unprepared for the emergence or intensity of these reorientations.

title: Bird-Feather Crafts Seized In New Mexico Raids
description: Federal and state wildlife agents raided more than 30 dealers of protected bird feathers in three states yesterday, confiscating craft items and more than $50,000 worth of illegal Indian kachina dolls.

title: OPERA: CAROL VANESS IN 'PERLES'
description: THANKS to Bizet's music and four strong principal singers, Saturday night's performance of ''Les Pecheurs de Perles'' at the City Opera was a pleasurable occasion. The production, which came to the company last fall from the Miami Opera, continues to resemble a grade-B film of the ''Road to Ceylon'' class, with enough theatrical cliches to embarrass a high-school drama department.

title: REAGAN AND THE GULF
description: Concerned with the Iraqi-Iranian war and the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, Saudi Arabia and the West's other major oil suppliers in the Persian Gulf area are seeking a way out of a major security predicament. They would like to depend on the United States for their security while giving the impression in the Arab and Islamic world that they do not.

title: KNICKS LOSE TO LAKERS BY 96-93
description: The jump shot, in addition to the devastating sky hook, is beginning to surface more and more in Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's game. He scored 32 points yesterday as the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the Knicks, 96-93, at Madison Square, and five of his dozen baskets came on short jumpers.

title: No Headline
description: Vigneron Ties Best Of 18-8 1/2 In Vault

title: Proud Appeal Wins at Aqueduct
description: Proud Appeal took a step toward a possible trip to the Kentucky Derby with a stakes-record victory yesterday over Triocala in the $54,400 added Woodhaven Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: TV: EVA PERON'S ARGENTINA AND SHYLOCK'S VENICE
description: BY a chance of scheduling, anti-Semitism figures prominently in two major new productions tonight. At 9, NBC-TV is offering the first half of a four-hour film based on the life of Argentina's Eva Peron. At 8 on WNET-TV, Channel 13, the BBC's ''Shakespeare Plays'' project turns to ''The Merchant of Venice'' and the inevitably sensitive question of Shylock.

title: TRISTATE GOVERNORS ASSAIL REAGAN PLAN
description: To Governor Carey, last week's budget proposals by President Reagan were ''half a rabbit and half a horse'' and potentially harmful because, he said today, the tax-cutting proposals could fuel inflation while the spending reductions would require big cuts in needed programs.

title: Plank Ski Victor
description: Herbert Plank won the men's downhill race in the Italian national ski championships today, beating Michael Mair by almost half a second. Giuliano Giardini, who lost time when one of his skis broke, placed third.

title: QUEBEC'S STASTNY BROTHERS ARE ON A STREAK
description: Peter Stastny scored four goals and his brother Anton, along with Jacques Richard, each scored three goals last night, giving the Quebec Nordiques an 11-7 victory over the Capitals in Landover, Md.

title: NATO CHIEF SAYS DETENTE HAS SAPPED WEST'S RESOLVE
description: The Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization said today that recent efforts to ease tensions between the Western alliance and the Soviet bloc had weakened NATO's resolve to maintain an effective military defense.

title: Miltiades Matthias Offers Mitropoulos Piano Scherzo
description: MILTIADES MATTHIAS is a romantic at the piano, and his concert Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall fairly burst with sentimental gestures and grand effects - all thickly coated with pedal. Mr. Matthias's freedom-loving turn of mind had a way of leading him into calamitous adventures. His eccentric tempos in Beethoven C minor Sonata (Op. 10, No. 1), for example, not only rendered Beethoven's sly metric games unintelligible, but they also accelerated Mr. Matthias into high-speed chases beyond his technical means.

title: Gulf, Sun, Sohio Lift Prices
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest refiner, raised home heating oil and kerosene prices 1 cent to 2 cents a gallon in two states, terming the action ''more of a fine-tuning than a price increase.'' The Sun Company raised its wholesale gasoline prices 1 to 2 cents in parts of the Northeast, Middle West and South. The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) lifted its gasoline 1 to 2 cents in Middle Western and East Coast markets.

title: Farm Chemical Account
description: Chalek Dreyer Comerford Lubalin, all of whose principals are local products, have established an agricultural department with a new client, all the pesticides from BASF Wyandotte's Agricultural Chemicals division. The account, formerly with Brewer Advertising, Kansas City subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, is said to be a ''multimillion dollar'' one.

title: ATOM-BOMBED CITIES AWAIT VISIT BY POPE
description: Pope John Paul II, who arrived in Japan today on the start of a five-day visit, will be the first world leader to travel to the atom-bombed cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki since the 1950's, Hiroshima city officials said.

title: BURRELL SMALL
description: Burrell Small, the chief executive of the Mid-America Media Group, died today in Kankakee after a long illness.

title: REAGAN'S MOVES HINTING AT STYLE FOR A PRESIDENCY
description: Ten days before he presented his economic program last Wednesday, President Reagan sat listening to a debate between advisers who wanted to broaden his proposed tax cut and others who feared the political ramifications of a move certain to be taken as a giveaway to the rich.

title: REAGAN AIDE REFUSES TO RULE OUT ACTION AGAINST CUBA ON SALVADOR
description: President Reagan's chief White House policy adviser renewed warnings to Cuba today that the United States ''does not rule out anything'' in its efforts to halt arms deliveries to left-wing guerrillas in El Salvador.

title: ANALYSTS EXPECTING LOWER INFLATION RATE
description: President Reagan's call for the Federal Reserve to reduce the growth of the nation's money supply gradually has reinforced the expectations of many credit market analysts that inflation will ease in future years.

title: THE CARRINGTON SHADOW; by William Safire
description: Not since the days of grand designers Roosevelt and Churchill has there been such a natural affinity between American and British leaders. The meeting this week of conservatives Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher should put the ''special'' back in the special relationship between the English-speaking allies.

title: Another Ford May Run
description: He's been a newspaper publisher and a businessman, but despite a family heritage, he's never run for political office. Now, however, Jack Ford, the 28-year-old son of former President Gerald R.Ford, says he is considering running for state office in California next year.

title: TURKEY DEMANDS RETURN OF STOLEN ART
description: The Minister of Culture has praised the work of archeological teams in Turkey but warned that the activities of some foreign institutes may be curbed if the country's ''stolen treasures'' are not returned soon.

title: An Education for Bell
description: When President Reagan addressed Congress last Wednesday, only one member of his Cabinet - T. H. Bell, the Secretary of Education - was not present.

title: NEW RAINS INCREASE WATER RESERVES AND RAISE HOPES
description: Heavier than normal rains in February have raised the water supplies of the Hackensack Water Company - one of northern New Jersey's largest - to the point where normal spring rainfall would fill the reservoirs, a spokesman for the company said yesterday.

title: NEW POWER FOR TRANSIT CHIEF SOUGHT TO EASE REPAIR CRISIS
description: Saying that one of every 24 subway cars in New York City's fleet is sidelined indefinitely because of out-of-stock parts, the president of the Transit Authority is seeking broad additional powers to award millions of dollars in contracts not only for replacement parts but also for many other goods and services. In many instances, such awards would be made without competitive bidding and without the prior approval of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board.

title: Red Smith;  Headgear As Weapon
description: DAVE CAMERER, who played tackle for Dartmouth in the 1930's when Red Blaik was the coach in Hanover, is on a crusade that makes the campaigns of Richard the Lion-Hearted and the Knights Hospitallers seem like excursions to boy scout camp. Dave is aiming at no modest goals like the early Crusaders, who sought only to recapture the Holy Lands from their Muslim conquerors. He won't be satisfied until all of football, from peewee teams to the National League, gets rid of the steel and plastic helmet and face guard that is de rigueur for the well-dressed gladiator today.

title: TELLING THE MARIA CALLAS STORY
description: Arianna Stassinopoulos says she has always thought of herself as ''a cerebral person,'' and she has the credentials to prove it: she studied economics at Cambridge, graduated with honors and became the first woman to be president of the Cambridge Union, the debating society.

title: NEW OFFERINGS INCREASE, MOSTLY FOR SHORTER TERM
description: The volume of new issues in the corporate and tax-exempt markets is increasing this week. Underwriters have scheduled more than $1 billion of corporate offerings, along with three large issues of state bonds.

title: A MATURE ALLIANCE
description: Drift in the Western alliance has been an endemic diagnosis since it was formed early in the cold war, so there has been a tendency to react to the recurring warnings the way the villagers did to the boy who kept crying wolf.

title: 10 BIGGEST SAVINGS BANKS IN CITY OPERATE AT A LOSS
description: The 10 largest savings banks in New York City reported heavy operating losses in the fourth quarter of 1980 as a result of the high level of interest rates, according to reports filed with the New York State Banking Department.

title: L.S.U. Wins to Bring Streak to 25 Games
description: Louisiana State University outscored Texas A & M by 15-2 in a five-minute period of the first half and went on to a 67-57 victory today.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Participants in Ohio's longest school strike got a promise yesterday that union funds would be withdrawn from banks in the city unless the school board agreed to negotiate with the teachers by Tuesday.

title: Drugs Suspected in Sinking
description: ROME (AP) - The crew of a Greek cargo ship set the vessel afire and jumped overboard to avert discovery of a cargo believed to be hashish and smuggled cigarettes, customs officials said today. Authorities said the ship Giarcos burst into flames and sank 55 miles south of the island of Ponza shortly after a police boat radioed it but got no response.

title: Roenning of Norway Wins Speed Skating
description: Frode Roenning of Norway won the 500 meters and placed sixth in the 1,000 meters today to clinch the world sprint speed-skating title.

title: Water Pik Looking For a New Ad Agency
description: Teledyne Water Pik of Fort Collins, Colo., which installed David K. Mutchler as its new president last August, has been doing a bit of reorganizing of late. While management was at it, they decided to look at the advertising, which has been with the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York for about 10 years.

title: PENN CENTRAL NOT LOOKING BACK
description: A grand old steam locomotive, captured on canvas, dominates one wall of the office of Richard Dicker, the 66-year-old chairman of the Penn Central Corporation. It is a haunting reminder of a troubled corporate past for those trying to turn the biggest American business failure into a success story.

title: Miss Linhart Bride Of R. D. Schmicker
description: Catrina Linhart, an assistant vice president and industrial economist at the Manufaturers Hanover Trust Company, was married yesterday to Robert David Schmicker, a New York lawyer. The Rev. Paul Walsh performed the ceremony in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.

title: A White House View of Iranian Crisis
description: One was there when the key decisions were made, and the other helped get the public message across. And now Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff under President Jimmy Carter, and Gerald Rafshoon, his media adviser, have signed a deal to make a six-hour television ''docudrama'' for CBS about the Iranian crisis and the negotiations to obtain the release of the American hostages.

title: Argentina Oil Search
description: Argentina-Cities Service Exploration Inc. said that the Argentine Government had authorized exploration of a 1,680-square-mile block in Rio Negro and Neuquen provinces. The company, a drilling consortium headed by a unit of the Cities Service Company, signed a contract with Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales, the national petroleum company of Argentina, in October 1980 for a minimum expenditure of $8 million during the first three-year phase of the exploration.

title: MOUNTAINS OF FUN IN THE SMOKIES
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. AT first, the view of the purple Smoky Mountains out my hotel window seemed like a reward in itself, but later a friend reminded me that mountains are for hiking as well as gazing.

title: Baptist Missionary Board Asserts No-Ransom Policy
description: The nation's largest religious missionary organization said today that it would not pay ransom or yield to the demands of anyone who took one of its missionaries hostage.

title: LOSING, WINNING STREAKS END AS MAVERICKS BEAT NETS, 132-109
description: The expansion Dallas Mavericks romped to a 132-109 victory today, ending their 15-game losing streak and also ending the New Jersey Nets' five-game winning streak.

title: Hugh F. McShane, 55, New York State Justice
description: Hugh F. McShane, an acting justice of the State Supreme Court, died Friday of a heart attack at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. Justice McShane, who was a resident of Douglas Manor, Queens, was 55 years old.

title: Westinghouse Gets Order
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it had received an $83 million order from Commision Federal de Electricidad of Mexico City for components, materials and engineering to transform four 95-megawatt combustion turbines into an integrated 486-megawatt combined-cycle power plant. The company said the order followed a previously announced $47 million contract for the four plants, to be installed at the Tula, Hidalgo, power station.

title: EGYPT-ISRAEL TALKS NOT A TOP PRIORITY, U.S. OFFICIALS ASSERT
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. is not inclined to press for an early resumption of Egyptian-Israeli negotiations on Palestinian self-rule but rather to concentrate American efforts on countering what he regards as a major Soviet strategic threat to the Middle East, senior American officials said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COLORFUL WRITING

title: REAGAN'S WORTH PUT AT $4 MILLION
description: President Reagan is estimated to have a net worth of $4 million, based upon a financial disclosure report filed with a Government agency last week, plus other information on his finances.

title: The B-1 Roars Again
description: President Carter cancelled development of the B-1 bomber almost four years ago for the very good reason that it promised to add little to America's strategic forces. Its gold-plating was partly designed to permit flight at supersonic speed - at the supersonic price of $102 million per plane. But these projects do not expire as fast as Presidents.

title: TRADING ENTERPRISE, IN SEEKING GROWTH, URGES BANK LEEWAY
description: Jack Boles is a scholarly, 45-year-old entrepreneur dedicated to creating an American version of the Dutch East India Company of the 17th century, the Hudson's Bay Company of the 18th century or the Mitsubishi Corporation of present-day Japan.

title: DANCE: PURE MOVEMENT AT BARNARD
description: THE level of dancing was so high at Saturday night's Dance Uptown concert sponsored by Barnard College, that one was nearly diverted from noticing the dominant trend among all five choreographers on the program. Nonetheless, the accent was entirely on pure-movement works, with the titles reflecting the formal problems the choreographers had set for themselves.

title: ECUADOR, PERU AND A BORDER IN DISPUTE
description: To the Editor:

title: FOREIGN INVESTMENT RETURNING TO MEXICO
description: There was a time when no self-respecting foreign investor here would risk his money in a company controlled by Mexican capital. And if he were forced by law to become the junior partner in a joint venture, he often preferred not to invest.

title: New Hampshire Testing Detects Arsenic in Water
