description: Federal health officials today urged testing of additional private wells as potentially dangerous levels of arsenic continued to be found in drinking water in southern New Hampshire and in two Massachusetts towns.

title: No Headline
description: CONNORS DEFEATS LENDL, 6-3, 7-6

title: Companies
description: A $700 million takeover bid for 20th Century-Fox was made by Marvin Davis, a wealthy Colorado oil executive. The diversified film company said it would consider the offer at a board meeting Friday. ChrisCraft, Fox's biggest shareholder with 22 percent of the shares, supports the offer. (Page D1.)

title: Swan Calls Himself Lucky, Even With a Sore Pitching Shoulder
description: Craig Swan sat in the locker room of the New York Mets' training camp today and conceded that he had everything: a wife and two children, a home in Connecticut, a boat and a five-year contract for $3 million. He also had a sore right shoulder.

title: Teheran Said to Release 3 Britons After 6 Months
description: Three Britons held in Iran since August were freed in Teheran today and are ready to return home, the British Press Association news agency reported.

title: Segovia Reaches 87
description: Andres Segovia celebrated his 87th birthday last Wednesday, but advanced age didn't stop the classical guitarist from performing a concert in San Francisco yesterday.

title: Grasso Memorial Opposed
description: In Connecticut, politicians of both parties have rallied to a proposal to change the name of the state's largest airport to the Ella T. Grasso International Airport as a memorial to the late Governor.

title: Portuguese Premier Wins Party Test of Strength
description: Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao won a test of strength within his Social Democratic Party tonight and said he considered this a vote of confidence in his leadership.

title: Article 016449 -- No Title
description: The 20th Century-Fox Corporation said today that Marvin Davis, a wealthy Denver oil executive, had offered almost $700 million to purchase the diversified film company, which has been the subject of several abortive takeover attempts during the past three years.

title: ROCK AND FUNK: NONA HENDRYX
description: UNTIL recently, new-wave rock and contemporary rhythm-and-blues styles had little in common but as reggae has become more popular among both black and white American acts, and groups such as Talking Heads continue to experiment with African rhythms, the barriers between rock and funk have begun to erode.

title: REAGAN'S EIGHTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Turkey warns of ban on foreign archeologists over stolen art A3 Around the World A4 Possible attempt to begin Salva- dor negotiations in Bonn is seen A8 Government/Politics About Washington: of politics and poverty A12 San Francisco supervisor criti- cized for letter to Congressman A14 Reagans complain of intrusion on privacy at mountain ranch A17 Tristate Governors assail Reagan program B5 General Around the Nation A12 Drought aids seafood industry on Chesapeake Bay A12 Controversy surrounds death of L.I. university student B1 Tarnower jury remains dead- locked on sixth day B2 Artists at Harris trial assess threat of camera to their jobs B2 The City B3 Obituaries Raymond R. Dickey, Washington lawyer D11 Joe Smith, partner in Smith and Dale comedy team D11 Amory Houghton, Corning Glass Works chairman emeritus D11 Style Relationships B6 An expert on the roles people play in life B6 Telling the Maria Callas story B6 She's a friend via her books B6 News Analysis An assessment of problems Rea- gan faces in Persian Gulf area A6 Drew Middleton on efforts to choose new military strategy A7 Richard Meislin discusses morass of problems hindering Carey B3 SportsMonday Baseball: Ralph Houk, starts over as Red Sox manager C1

title: Advertising; 50 Busy Years for Grohmann
description: BY March 9, when Needham & Grohmann marks its 50th anniversary, H. Victor Grohmann, founder and chairman of the speciality agency, will have eased out of the business.

title: Military Analysis
description: The United States, in the view of Gen. Edward C. Meyer, the Army Chief of Staff, has reached a ''critical instant'' in its history, and the new Administration and the military services have an opportunity to ''design the forces that may be needed in the next decade to support national security objectives.''

title: U.S. TO CUT FUNDS FOR RATIONING
description: The Department of Energy is planning to virtually eliminate from its budget $150 million that would enable the country's emergency gasoline rationing plan to be put into effect within a three-month period instead of the year or more most analysts believe would be required.

title: ISAAC STERN IN CHINA
description: THEY call it ''From Mao to Mozart - Isaac Stern in China,'' and the title of this delightful film that opens today for a five-day run at the Symphony Space gets the general idea across.

title: Bridge: The Computer Brings Back High-Scoring Tournaments
description: Most of the players at the Greater New York Bridge Association's tournament at the New York Statler Hotel during the weekend cannot remember the days when an event might be won by 1,000 points. Until about 1964 it was normal to score knockout team championships by total points, and victories by several thousand points were common. Then the international match point scale - or I.M.P.'s - came into use, following the European practice, and winning by 100 points became rare.

title: News Analysis
description: Governor Carey's pursuit of this year's legislative program and next year's re-election campaign, begun triumphantly last month, has been overwhelmed by a series of setbacks.

title: Market Place; Cloudy Outlook For Harvester
description: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER, which is now marking the 150th anniversary of the reaper invented by the company's founder, Cyrus McCormick, is hardly in the mood for celebration.

title: IRISH END VIRGINIA'S STREAK ON LAST SHOT
description: Any team that is ranked No. 1 and has a long winning streak should hope to avoid Notre Dame. The Irish will apparently beat such a team every time.

title: EMPIRE STATE PIONEERS IN CONSERVING ENERGY
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Polish Negotiators Near Agreement on Labor Law

title: Warriors 104, Kings 96
description: Bernard King scored 17 points in the final period as Golden State rallied for a 104-96 victory over Kansas City. King finished with 30 points, 24 in the second half, and Purvis Short added 19.

title: by Marshall L. Matzz
description: While seeking to cut $1.575 billion from the $3.918 billion child-nutrition budget in fiscal 1982, the Reagan Administration has listed school lunches for the ''truly needy'' as one of seven programs that will not be affected by the drive to reduce Federal spending. On the contrary, poor children will be affected, for millions who qualify for a free or reduced-price lunch under the nutrition program stand to be lopped from it.

title: Goring Unhappy Over Benching
description: Butch Goring, the center who was benched on Saturday night by Coach Al Arbour before the Islanders broke a five-game nonwinning streak with a 6-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks, said yesterday he was unhappy about the benching. He made the comment as the team prepared to fly to Minnesota for a game tonight against the North Stars.

title: OF POLITICS AND POVERTY
description: The lobbyist's cigar smoke vied with the aroma of fresh-cut flowers on his desk as he leaned back, framing still another reason to spare his special program, milk price supports, from the Reagan Administration's ax.

title: Dayton 73, Xavier 64
description: Mike Kanieski scored 32 points and led Dayton to a 73-64 victory over Xavier of Ohio today.

title: SMALL BOOK-PUBLISHING FIRMS FLOURISHING
description: IN an industry dominated by giants, small book publishers are having a bigger impact than ever. Their output is still only a fraction of the total, but some of their titles have sold more than a million copies. And 10 percent of the titles on The New York Times best-seller lists carry such relatively unknown imprints as Stratford Press, Books in Focus, J.P. Tarcher, Workman Publishing and Ten Speed Press.

title: by Jim Benagh; Shot Down
description: A year ago, Bobby Joe Douglas of Marion (La.) High School and Erving Stepp of Phelps (Ky.) High were dueling to post the best average ever recorded by a schoolboy basketball player. By the end of the season, Douglas had won, 54 points a game to 53.7. Both averages were better than the record of 50.9, set by Bennie Fuller of Arkansas School for the Deaf in 1971.

title: Police Officer Edith Linn Bride of Lawrence Abramson
description: Edith Linn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Linn of Plainview, L.I., was married yesterday to Lawrence Abramson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Abramson of Jamaica, Queens. Rabbi Harold Swiss performed the ceremony at Leonard's of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Washington Watch; Helping Sell Reagan Plan
description: WASHINGTON BIG BUSINESS has taken its lumps with the sharp cutback projected for Export-Import Bank lending in the Reagan economic package. But corporate executives are still intent on helping the Administration sell the plan.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE DIAMOND PEOPLE. By Murray Schumach. 255 pages. Illustrated. Nor- ton. $12.95.

title: ERNEST A. GRAUPNER
description: Ernest A. Graupner, former president and director of Sulphur Export Corporation, an affiliate of Texasgulf Inc., died last Wednesday at New York Hospital.

title: Czyz Wins on Points
description: Bobby Czyz, his right eye shut in the fourth by an inadvertent butt, managed to score a clear and unanimous eight-round decision over Teddy Mann today in the featured bout at the Convention Hall.

title: Innovator on the Outside
description: Last fall, when New York's Mayor Koch asked the city's judges to submit ideas on improving the criminal justice system, he got a mixed reaction.

title: WILLIAMS BUSY IN LAST DAYS AT S.E.C.
description: A rush is on at the Securities and Exchange Commission to complete numerous projects during Harold Williams's final days as the agency's chairman.

title: ST. BARTHOLOMEW'S SPLIT GOES BEYOND REAL ESTATE
description: Controversy over the possible sale of a portion of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, sparked by reports last fall of a $100 million offer by an unnamed company, has split members in a debate that goes far beyond the issue of real estate.

title: NEWLY FORMED GEO ELECTS ITS PRESIDENT
description: The Geo International Corporation, an oilfield services and quality assurance company established early this month as a spinoff from the Peabody International Corporation, has elected Anthony J. Giglio, 43 years old, as president and chief operating officer. John E. McConnaughy Jr., the 51-year-old president and chief executive officer of Peabody, also holds the title of chairman and chief executive of Geo.

title: A BURGEONING NEW YORK LOVE AFFAIR
description: To the Editor:

title: MILLER TRIUMPHS BY 2
description: Johnny Miller, who won 19 professional tournaments and then had only one victory in four years, won the $300,000 Glen Campbell-Los Angeles open today by two strokes with a record total of 270.

title: CAR-IMPORT QUOTAS ARE NOT THE ANSWER
description: To the Editor:

title: Duquesne 79 St. Bonaventure 72
description: Bruce Atkins scored 24 points and John Moore 19 as Duquesne pulled away in the second half and defeated St. Bonaventure, 79-72, in an Eastern Eight game today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've got people who are really going to be hurt. We've got to work real hard to minimize that hurt.''

title: TARNOWER, JURORS UNDECIDED AFTER LONGEST DAY OF TALKS
description: The jury in the Jean S. Harris trial remained deadlocked tonight, ending its sixth and longest day of deliberations at 8:40 P.M. Judge Russell R. Leggett said he ''assumed they were still working on the top count,'' second-degree murder, in the shooting of Dr. Herman Tarnower.

title: PIANO: FRANK PLAYS BEETHOVEN
description: WHEN Claude Frank played Beethoven in Alice Tully Hall on Saturday afternoon, it was difficult to separate the pianist's mastery from the music's.

title: by Jim Benagh; A Hold on Wrestling
description: For four decades after the first National Collegiate wrestling championships in 1928, Oklahoma State and Oklahoma had a hammer lock on the N.C.A.A. title. Between them, they won 32 of the first 38 team titles.

title: OFFICE CONSTRUCTION SURGING IN MANHATTAN
description: Office space totaling more than 23 million square feet - the equivalent of about 10 Pan Am Buildings - is being built, or is about to be built, in Manhattan this year. It is the largest burst of new construction since the late 1960's.

title: Pintor Retains Title on Decision
description: Lupe Pintor of Mexico staggered Jose Uziga of Argentina in the 10th, 11th and 15th rounds today to score a unanimous decision and retain his World Boxing Council bantamweight title.

title: RALPH HOUK, AT 61, STARTS OVER IN BOSTON
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla. OUTSIDE the living room window, Ralph Houk's fishing boat, The Thanks Yanks, is docked at the Intracostal Waterway, soon to be loaned to a neighbor. Inside, Houk and his wife, Bette, are packing cartons and covering furniture, preparing to close up their house here for the next eight months.

title: DANCE: POSIN COMPANY OFFERS 'GALENA SUMMIT' AT MIDTOWN Y
description: A CURRENT theory of movement analysis uses the term ''bound flow'' to describe certain dance phrases. The term could well be used for a concert given Saturday by the Kathryn Posin Dance Company at the Emanu-El Midtown Y.M.H.A. It was an ambitious program of new dances by Miss Posin and J. Michael Kane, the company's co-director. And as always, Miss Posin's dancers were sleekly adept. But the ideas behind the dances and the quality of movement seemed constantly to meet impediments.

title: by Jim Benagh; A Different Court
description: Ted Stepien, whose Cleveland Cavaliers have been struggling on the basketball court this season, is trying another court to curb the criticism of himself and his team. Stepien, the first-year owner of the Cavs, has instituted a $10 million suit against radio station WWWE in Cleveland for what he says is a breach of contract.

title: Fordham Gets a Bye
description: Fordham has received a first-round bye in the Metro region of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I basketball playoffs, it was announced yesterday.

title: 15 ARTS GROUPS WIN FEDERAL GRANTS
description: Fifteen community-based cultural arts organizations - including seven in New York City and one in Buffalo -have won the first advancement grants awarded by the National Endowment for the Arts to bolster their management, promotion and fund-raising.

title: Miss Alcott Wins
description: Amy Alcott had six birdies and a bogey today for a five-under-par 67 and a one-stroke victory over the defender, JoAnne Carner, in the $150,000 Bent Tree golf tournament.

title: Pairings Announced For CUNY Tourney
description: Pairings were announced yesterday for the City University of New York conference basketball tournament, which begins tonight at Fitzgerald Gymnasium at Queens College in Flushing. Baruch and Staten Island, champions of the two divisions during regular-season play, drew first-round byes.

title: CREDIT BUYERS' FEE STIRS DEBATE
description: Amid protests from consumer groups and the Federal Trade Commission, Congress is to consider legislation this week that would extend a ban on charging credit card customers an extra fee when they use their cards. The ban expires Friday.

title: RANGERS RALLY TWICE, BUT LOSE TO WHALERS IN WILD 3D PERIOD, 6-5
description: Blaine Stoughton's 29th goal of the season at 16 minutes 49 seconds of the third period gave the Hartford Whalers a 6-5 victory over the New York Rangers tonight in the Civic Center.

title: GOVERNORS DISCUSS EXCHANGING LESS AID FOR LESS RESTRICTION
description: The nation's Governors began three days of meetings with the Reagan Administration today, seeking to trade support for Federal budget cuts for greater power under the Federal system.

title: Commodities; Impact Of Reagan Program
description: BECAUSE the average life of a futures contract is less than a week, commodity traders shrugged off the economic program laid down by the President last week, preferring to concentrate on the usual day-today market conditions.

title: Watchmakers Weigh Merger
description: Switzerland's two largest watchmakers hinted in a joint announcement that they might move toward a merger in the face of growing competition from Asia and the United States.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: About $1.5 million in uninsured jewelry was taken from the penthouse of a Saudi Arabian sheik at the Eden Roc Hotel, the police said today.

title: WEST GERMANS MAY TRY TO BRING SALVADORANS TO BONN TO NEGOTIATE
description: Spokesmen for West Germany's two major political parties said today that there was some possibility that they might become involved in an attempt to bring El Salvador's warring factions together for negotiations in Bonn.

title: More Cuts in Spending Forecast by Stockman
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today that the Reagan Administration would propose additional and substantially larger spending reductions on March 10 than were indicated last week.

title: Owner Threatening To Move Cavaliers
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers' owner, Ted Stepien, is again threatening to move the National Basketball Association franchise to some other city if home attendance does not improve.

title: BALANCHINE BALLET-OPERA DUE ON PBS
description: Taping is scheduled to begin in Nashville today of ''The Spellbound Child/ L'Enfant et les Sortileges,'' a ballet-opera conceived and choreographed by George Balanchine for WNET's ''Dance in Ameria'' series.

title: Gdansk, Brazilian Style
description: Brazil has been uneasily perched in recent years between elective democracy and repressive military rule. Which way this huge country tips may well depend on the outcome of an important political trial that has just begun in Sao Paulo, the industrial capital. The defendants are 13 trade unionists, including Luis Inacio da Silva, nicknamed Lula, a folk-hero who is already seen as a Brazilian equivalent of Poland's Lech Walesa. An awful lot of coffee may vanish down the drain if a military tribunal ignores the lessons of Gdansk.

title: Goldin Charges Lag In School Repairs
description: The New York City Board of Education has been largely unsuccessful in getting delinquent contractors to reduce the work left unfinished or uncorrected on city schools, according to an audit released yesterday by City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin. Some of the uncompleted work has caused safety and security problems in several schools, the report said.

title: January Orders Off for Tools
description: Machine tool orders in the United States fell to $279.6 million in January, down $19.6 million, or 6.5 percent, from December, and 40.1 percent below the January 1980 level, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported today.

title: Jesse Jeans Account Moves in Stages to AR&H
description: J. Breed Clothing has assigned its Jesse Jeans account to AR&H Advertising and promises to spend $3 million for advertising. AR&H, which used to stand for Arthur, Roberts & Hill, is already placing TV advertising for its new client, but they are commercials made by the former agent, Saas Advertising.

title: Knicks Come Pretty Close
description: IN single file, the Knicks were walking through the long corridor to their dressing room at Madison Square Garden after yesterday's 96-93 loss to the Los Angeles Lakers, but even there they could not escape the presence of the player who had been the difference in the game.

title: Speedy Muffler King Splits With Doyle Dane
description: Speedy Muffler King, in far-off Deerfield, Mich., and Doyle Dane Bernbach have developed a terminal rift and reportedly have mutually agreed that the client would be better served by a mid-western agency.

title: Yankee Veterans Find Different Style but Same Routine in Spring
description: When Gene Michael, the Yankee manager, reported to his first spring training in 1959, he had never seen a slider, had never played under the lights, and did not know that major league teams kept count of a player's errors.

title: No Headline
description: Baseball Briefs; Quisenberry Signs Royals' 1-Year Pact

title: DROUGHT BRINGS FULL NETS TO CHESAPEAKE WATERMEN
description: Chesapeake Bay watermen were sipping coffee before dawn in his gas station at Knapps Narrows as Gary Fairbanks gave a name they often use for late-winter days with enough warmth to hint of spring.

title: Mayor Koch Deputizes an Economist
description: Mayor Koch has turned New York's economic exertions in a novel direction by appointing, of all things, an economist as Deputy Mayor for development. Karen Gerard, a vice president for regional economics at the Chase Manhattan Bank, is known as an outstanding student of the problems of metropolitan New York. With her new badge, she will aim to prove that sound policies, efficiently run, can hasten economic growth and retard decay.

title: PRESIDENT CRITICIZES INTRUSIONS ON PRIVACY AT RANCH
description: President Reagan's first California vacation since the inauguration was marred by the unhappiness of Mr. Reagan and his wife, Nancy, over the large number of security and communications personnel encamped on their mountain ranch.

title: A Small Plane Crashes In Jersey Killing Four
description: The pilot of a single-engine plane and his three passengers were killed last night when the aircraft crashed in the central New Jersey community of Montgomery Township, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: AN EXPERT ON THE ROLES PEOPLE PLAY IN LIFE
description: Roving the corridors under the great white dome of Bryce Hospital, Dr. Humphry Osmond was expounding on the many roles that men and women play throughout their lives. As is his custom, he resorted to Shakespearean analogy. ''Each one of us plays a role like Olivier's Hamlet,'' said Dr. Osmond, clinical professor of psychiatry at the University of Alabama in Birmingham. ''Our role is absolutely unique - it can never be reproduced or recreated.''

title: Bond Funds Urged To Improve Subways
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy called on the state yesterday to use $159 million left over from a $600-million transit bond issue in 1967 to make immediate improvements in the city's subway system.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday misstated United Artists' earnings situtation since 1978.

title: OFFICIAL'S LETTER TO CONGRESSMAN WIDELY ASSAILED IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: Carol Ruth Silver, a member of the Board of Supervisors, has come under wide criticism after she caused a sympathetic letter to be sent in the board's name to a Congressman who had been arrested in a Capitol Hill restroom on homosexuality charges.

title: Arrows Win, 10-7
description: Steve Zungul scored three goals and assisted on three others in leading the New York Arrows to a 10-7 victory over the Wichita Wings today at Nassau Coliseum. The game drew 12,487, the second largest crowd in the team's three-year history.

title: Peru Warns Ecuador On New Incursions
description: Peru warned Ecuador today that it would regard any new incursions along its disputed frontier as an act of war.

title: The Police Blotter
description: One person was fatally shot and another wounded in a grocery store robbery in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section Saturday night, the police said. The slain man, Americo Torvino, 37 years old, of 249 Stockholm Street, Booklyn, was believed to be the owner of the store, at 149 Division Avenue.

title: QUESTIONS ABOUT FATAL SHOOTING LINGERING AT ADELPHI
description: Eight days after a 21-year-old student was shot to death on the Adelphi University campus here by a Garden City policeman, fellow students and campus and law enforcement officials have raised troubling questions over what happened and why.

title: Memorex-Japan Tie
description: The Memorex Corporation said it had formed a joint venture in the office-machine supplies field, the Memorex DIC Corporation, with Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc. and said it had transferred its word-processing supplies division to the new venture. Dainippon purchased a 43 percent interest in the venture for undisclosed terms, it added. Dainippon agreed to provide the venture with technology pretaining to Memorex's word-processing supplies products, Memorex said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aeronca Inc., Pineville, N.C., a manufacturer of aerospace components and environmental controls, has elected Joe L. Miller chief executive officer.

title: TRIAL FOR SUSPECT IN SNIPINGS TO START
description: Fifteen weeks ago today, when Joseph Paul Franklin arrived here from Tampa, Fla., he was escorted from the airport to the City Center in a motorcade of three vans, five police motorcycles and several squad cars, but it was not a dignitary's welcome.

title: WAITING FOR THE TOOLMAKER TO POINT THE WAY
description: THERE'S something about the oily gleam of a hardware store that excites the artisan urge, even when nothing at home really needs making or mending. New tools entice, because they imply creation and stretch the imagination.

title: JUSTICES TO WEIGH SUIT ON TRANSFER OF ARMY FACILITY TO CHURCH SCHOOL
description: In a case with implications for the accountability of Federal decision-making, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a citizen can sue to stop Government action said to violate the constitutional separation between church and state.

title: Jersey Man Slain in Missouri
description: A 21-year-old New Jersey man was shot to death early today after allegedly telling a companion pointing a shotgun at him to pull the trigger. The police said that Edward Troxell, of Willingboro, N.J., had died instantly from a shotgun blast to the chest about 1:25 A.M. The 35-year-old resident of the house where the shooting occurred was in custody pending a decision on charges.

title: First City Acquires More Bache Shares
description: The First City Financial Corporation, a diversified holding company controlled by the Belzberg family, of Vancouver, British Columbia, said it had acquired an additional 160,715 shares of the common stock of the Bache Group Inc., raising its total to 2.44 million shares, or 22.6 percent of Bache's outstanding.

title: 'DIVORCING' PARENT FROM CHILD
description: David Brown, a bright, amiable and outwardly average high school student here, ''divorced'' his parents last year by using a new Connecticut law. He was one of more than 100 teenagers and parents in the state who sought legally in 1980 to end their family ties and responsibilities.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Charges Bias in Zoning Laws
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People charged that the town of Huntington, L.I., was pursuing racially discriminatory housing and zoning practices and that the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development ''has encouraged and contributed'' to these practices.

title: PONDERING THE CABLE BID
description: Until now, Robert Rosencrans, the 53-year-old president and chief executive officer of UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc. and one of cable TV's pioneers, has stayed on the sidelines as large corporations have bought up independent cable television properties.

title: Ecuador Accuses Peru Of Air Raid on Border Post
description: Ecuador today accused Peru of attacking one of its military outposts in a disputed border area of the Condor Mountains.

title: Canadian Unit Fails To Raise Hobart Bid
description: Canadian Pacific Enterprises (U.S.) Inc. said yesterday that it would not attempt to match Dart & Kraft Inc.'s $40-a-share offer for the Hobart Corporation, apparently ending an unwelcome merger proposal that touched off substantial political support in the United States on Hobart's behalf.

title: THE SCIENCE OF DIETING: A FIGHT AGAINST MIND AND METABOLISM
description: THE more scientists study the problem of overweight and the difficulty of shedding extra pounds, the more it seems that brain and body chemistry control the outcome.

title: Detroit Edison Net Up
description: The Detroit Edison Company announced yesterday that net earnings rose 15.7 percent for year ended Jan. 31, to $146.8 million, or $1.84 a share, from $126.9 million, or $1.80 a share, in the preceding year. Revenues climbed 9.6 percent, to $1.85 billion, from $1.68 billion.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate, 18.50-19.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A Routine Summit, When the Fog Lifts
description: President Brezhnev is in a mood to travel, preferably to the summit. If President Reagan is interested, the Soviet leader will consider modest changes in the pending arms control treaty. If Afghanistan stands in the way, he'll talk about its ''international aspects,'' perhaps in the context of a Persian Gulf agreement. But if Mr. Reagan persists in ''bellicosity,'' Mr. Brezhnev wants a gathering of top leaders at the United Nations instead - in other words, a propaganda summit, to sow discord among the Western allies.

title: Mental-Health Volunteer Honored
description: Emily Guttchen, director of volunteers at the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst, Queens, was honored yesterday by the Vocational, Evaluation, Testing and Placement Center of the Queens County division of Transitional Services for New York. Mrs. Guttchen was cited for her work with clients of Transitional Services, a mental-health agency that helps people adjust when they leave institutions.

title: G.M. ORDERS RECALL OF MID-SIZE AUTOS
description: General Motors Corporation ordered the recall of 6.4 million cars and light trucks today to replace bolts that could fall out of the rear suspensions and send the vehicles out of control.

title: OPEC Oil Output Tumbled in 1980
description: The war between Iran and Iraq and shrinking world demand depressed oil output by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries by a record 4 million barrels a day in 1980, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly reported yesterday.

title: ARAMCO PROSPECTS FOR WORKERS
description: In the wilderness of the Empty Quarter, amid red sand dunes that rise hundreds of feet and where the mercury can soar above 140 degrees, the working day never ends for Don Harday and Roy Korbut, both Canadian nationals. On an around-theclock basis, they drill for oil, certain that it lies miles below these sandy wastes but unsure exactly where.

title: FOX'S DOLLAR-AND-CENTS ALLURE
description: The house that Darryl F. Zanuck built contains far more riches than meet the casual eye. The rabid interest among a band of corporate suitors of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation stretches beyond a simple desire to be part of the glitter and glamour of making movies. Tucked within the framework of the big film company is a bevy of lucrative assets, including some of the choicest real estate in the world, most of which is carried on the Fox books at well below what the assets might fetch in today's marketplace.

title: LONG REACH OF THE REAGAN STYLE
description: The parties surrounding President Reagan's inauguration in Washington last month have had a ripple effect throughout the country. In cities far from the nation's capital, women are showing increased interest in dressing up and are causing, in some places, shortages of suitably festive long dresses.

title: Henry to Run Again In Suffolk County
description: District Attorney Patrick Henry of Suffolk County announced he would seek re-electon for a second four-year term.

title: PRIME RATE CUT TO 19% FROM 19 1 2%
description: Faced with increasing competition from cheaper sources of credit, most of the nation's large banks yesterday reduced their prime lending rates by half a percentage point, to 19 percent, and several dropped to the 18 1/2 percent level.

title: Casanova, Now a Doctor, Glad He's Out of Football
description: Dr. Tommy Casanova, a former defensive back with the Cincinnati Bengals who quit pro football to study medicine, says he is happy that he got out while he could walk.

title: Bridge: Difficulties With Language No Barrier to Winning Play
description: One of the most satisfying features of bridge as a recreation is that players can and do overcome a variety of handicaps. Consider the case of Mutsumi Komatsu, who came to the United States from Japan almost a year ago knowing almost nothing about the game. Despite the language problem and the handicap of deafness, she took lessons at the Beverly East Club in Manhattan and made rapid progress.

title: GOVERNOR'S OPPOSE REAGAN ON MEDICAID
description: Despite unhappiness about proposed cuts in Federal funds for Medicaid, the Governors of 48 states met today with President Reagan to assure him that they generally supported his efforts to ''restore balance to the Federal system,'' as Gov. George Busbee of Georgia put it.

title: A GENERAL TROUBLE-SHOOTER WHOSE BUSINESS IS BOOMING
description: Ron Alford talks like a man who has no time to spare. ''I tell you what,'' he says. ''You come home, you open the door, and the living room ceiling is on the floor. The water is going 'drip, drip' on your Oriental rug.

title: ENERGY CONCERN FOUNDED
description: Eugene A. Soltero, 37, president and chief executive officer of Dallas-based Moore McCormack Energy Inc., a subsidiary of Moore McCormack Resources Inc., Stamford, Conn., and Roscoe T. Foust, 52, the energy company's vice president in charge of exploration, have resigned to set up their own oil and gas company.

title: The Travels of a Pesticide
description: In the mid-1960's, Iowa farmers spread a peak application of 6.5 million pounds of the insecticides aldrin and dieldrin over some 5 million acres of cornfields. Several years later the Iowa Conservation Commission found that bottom-feeding catfish and carp in some of the state's largest reservoirs had residues of dieldrin far above the levels permitted by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: RIGHTS AND REALPOLITIK
description: Human rights has taken a bum rap. The policy initiated by Jimmy Carter is now widely viewed as a novel way to beat up on friends while letting adversaries get away with bloody murder. Accordingly, the Reagan Administration appears ready to discard this moralistic breast-beating in favor of a new tough-minded pragmatism.

title: HEART INFECTION LINKED TO 2 DEATHS
description: An infection of the heart, presumably from a virus, caused the death earlier this month of one young boy who attended the Chestnut Hill School in Dix Hills, L.I., and is suspected to be the cause of the death of another, according to Dr. Minoru Araki, deputy chief medical examiner of Nassau County.

title: Earthquake Jolts Afghanistan
description: A severe earthquake shook Afghanistan today but there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage, the Kabul radio said in a report monitored here. The news agency Press Trust of India said a mild tremor was felt around Srinagar in Kashmir at about the same time as the Afghan quake.

title: NO NEED FOR ANOTHER G.I. BILL
description: Some powerful groups want to introduce a new G.I. bill. Under the old bills, the Government supported post-secondary education for millions of veterans who served during and after World War II.

title: SUBSIDIZING NUCLEAR NEGLIGENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Phil Ford, Kings' Guard, Undergoes Eye Surgery
description: Phil Ford of the Kansas City Kings underwent surgery today to replace a bone in his left eye that had been shattered when he was accidentally hit during a game yesterday. Ford, a guard, was reported in good condition at Research Medical Center after the operation.

title: PENN CENTRAL SAID TO BID ANEW FOR GK
description: Directors of GK Technologies called a special board meeting last night to consider a friendly takeover bid from the Penn Central Corporation involving an estimated $715 million or more in cash, well-placed Wall Street sources disclosed.

title: A TANGLED DEBATE CENTERS ON COVERAGE OF SCIENCE
description: ASOMETIMES angry tug-of-war is underway among medical researchers, medical reporters and the editors of some medical journals. Depending on who is talking, the prize is more accurate public information about medical advances, professional recognition and possibly commercial gain for the researchers, or simply first crack at the best stories.

title: Johnny Miller Can Play Again
description: TO appreciate what it means to Johnny Miller to be golf's No. 1 money-winner this year, it is necessary to remember what it meant the year he was No. 111.

title: U.S. SHOWS INTEREST IN BREZHNEV'S PLAN
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States was ''very interested'' in the proposal by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, for ''an active dialogue,'' including a meeting with President Reagan.

title: Reagan Disowns Aide's Remarks On Plan to Increase Gasoline Tax
description: President Reagan today disavowed a statement by David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, that the Administration was considering increasing the Federal gasoline tax by two cents a gallon.

title: 2 Men Arrested in Florida In Jewelry Theft From Sheik
description: Two men were arraigned today on charges of stealing $1.5 million in uninsured jewelry from the threestory Miami Beach penthouse of an Arab sheik.

title: Market Place; Kaiser Steel Without Kaiser
description: THE departure of 38-year-old Edgar F. Kaiser Jr. from the steel company that bears the family name has unsettled the market for the shares.

title: State Sells A Bond Issue
description: New York State yesterday sold $115 million of tax-exempt bonds at yields ranging from 7 percent for bonds due 1982 to 9 percent in 1991, 10 percent in 2001 and 10.15 percent in 2011. Underwriters led by Chase Manhattan said late in the day that $51 million of the issue remained unsold.

title: STILL SEEKS THEATER FOR OPENING
description: Lillian Hellman has won her fight to keep her drama ''The Little Foxes,'' starring Elizabeth Taylor in her Broadway debut, out of the cavernous Winter Garden Theater, usually a home for big musicals. ''I've been assured there is no chance the play will go to the Winter Garden,'' Miss Hellman said yesterday.

title: Mobil Refinery
description: The Mobil Corporation said it would spend $50 million to modernize its refinery here, adding a hydrogen plant and a lubricant-dewaxing plant. The expansion will enable the refiner to make a full range of petroleum products from high-sulfur crude oil, Mobil said.

title: THE STAGE: 'INADMISSIBLE EVIDENCE'
description: IN 1965, Nicol Williamson came to New York and scored a huge personal triumph as Bill Maitland, the angry antihero of John Osborne's ''Inadmissible Evidence.'' Last night, Mr. Williamson returned to town in his career-making role - and the evidence on display at the Roundabout suggests that history is about to repeat itself. This marathon performance is a daring, uncompromising feat: Mr. Williamson ushers us into the consciousness of one of the postwar theater's most unappetizing characters and simply refuses to let us escape. If ''Inadmissible Evidence'' is an evening of almost pure pain, it is honest pain, truthful pain - pain that is raised by brilliant acting to the level of art.

title: Chess: Victory for the Home Team In Netherlands Tournament
description: The Dutch grandmasters Genna Sosonko and Jan Timman proved their supremacy on their own turf, winning the 43d Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk-aan-zee with identical 8-to-4 scores. FINAL STANDINGS Player Pts Sosonko 8 Timman 8 Taimanov 7 Sveshnikov 7 Browne 6 1/2 Sax 6 Gheorghiu 6 Andersson 6 Ree 5 1/2 Miles 5 Torre 4 1/2 Unzicker 4 1/2 Langeweg 4

title: COALITION FORMS TO DEFEND FOOD STAMPS;
description: Arnold Mayer is a foot soldier in the Battle of the Budget, 1981. As a vice president of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union, Mr. Mayer helped organize a meeting last Friday of about 150 lobbyists on Capitol Hill to plan the defense of the food stamp program, the target of $1.8 billion in cuts proposed by the Reagan Administration. When the session was over, he made the rounds of the Capitol, seeking out key members of Congressional budget and agriculture committees, the lawmakers who will shape the future of the $11 billion program and its 22 million beneficiaries.

title: Two Sergeants Convicted For Violating Uniform Rule
description: Two Air Force sergeants were convicted today of disobeying regulations by wearing their uniforms while they knelt in prayer while protesting an abortion clinic.

title: De Paul 89, Butler 64
description: Skip Dillard scored all of his 18 points in the first half, including 16 in a 27-5 burst, as De Paul routed Butler, 89-64, tonight.

title: Icebreaker Resumes Journey
description: The Coast Guard icebreaker Polar Sea was under way today after four days of trying to break through a thick ice ridge just southwest of Barrow. The Polar Sea made history last week when she rammed her way to a point farther north than any other American ship had ever reached in winter. Plans called for her to attempt a passage to Prudhoe Bay, about 200 miles east of Barrow, to test the feasibility of year-round shipping to the remote North Slope oil site.

title: METS HOPE TO GET POWER HITTER
description: Joe Torre acknowledged today that the Mets were working on a trade for a power hitter, which promptly revived speculation that Dave Kingman would return to Shea Stadium.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Butler International Inc., Montvale, N.J., has appointed Robert A. Rucinski vice president and controller, and Gerald R. Cioci vice president and treasurer.

title: THOMSON, NU-WEST IN BID FOR ABITIBI
description: Two major Canadian companies have entered the takeover battle for Abitibi-Price Inc., the world's largest newsprint producer, with an offer described as a ''white knight'' bid welcomed by Abitibi's management.

title: INSTITUTE TO EXPAND PROGRAM FOR PRESS
description: An expanded program to give reporters ready access to scientists in major areas of research and public policy discussion was announced last week by the New York-based Scientists' Institute for Public Information.

title: TREASURY BILL RATES OFF SHARPLY
description: The Treasury sold new three-month and six-month bills yesterday with average rates sharply lower than at the last bill auction as the Federal Reserve allowed all short-term interest rates to drop.

title: C.W. Post 67, Southampton 60
description: Jerry Britton led four C.W. Post players in double figures with 17 points as the Pioneers rallied and defeated Southampton, 67-60, tonight.

title: Parole Denied in Spying Case
description: Andrew D. Lee, convicted of selling secrets of American spy satellites to the Soviet Union, has been denied parole by a panel of the United States Parole Commission. Four members voted Friday to deny parole and to set the next hearing for parole in January 1991, it was announced today. He was sentenced to life in prison on espionage charges in 1977.

title: 25% of Continental Shares Tendered
description: Texas International Airlines said that it had been tendered roughly 3.8 million shares of Continental Air Lines' stock, or 25 percent of the outstanding common stock. Continental quickly asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to order the shares returned to their owners.

title: Consolidation Coal Ponders New Mine
description: The Consolidation Coal Company, a subsidiary of Conoco Inc., said it would begin detailed studies of the feasibility of mining an estimated 4 million tons annually of anthracite coal for a consortium of utility companies.

title: TO TURKS, FEUD WITH GREEKS IS PESKY, NOT PERILOUS
description: Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit wrote a poem about Turks and Greeks more than 30 years ago, and this passage from it still holds true: We've sworn at each other, We've drawn knives like enemies, Yet a love lies hidden in us For days of peace.

title: KEVIN MCCANN, EX-COLLEGE CHIEF AND EISENHOWER SPEECH WRITER
description: Kevin McCann, president emeritus of Defiance College in Ohio, who had a long association with President Eisenhower as an adviser and speech writer, died Saturday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Phoenix of complications after surgery. He was 76 years old and lived in Phoenix.

title: PROPONENTS OF '80 FOSTER-CARE BILL DISTRESSED BY REAGAN'S GRANT PALN
description: Legislation seeking Federal protection over the care of 500,000 foster children would be eliminated by the Reagan Administration's economic program, dismaying a wide range of social welfare groups and angering Congressional supporters.

title: Officials Rule Out Crack As Factor in Bus Crash
description: A break in the steering column was not a factor in last week's crash of a commuter bus in northern Virginia that killed 11 people, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: WAS 'FIGHT' ON TV REAL OR STAGED? IT ALL DEPENDS
description: It looked like a spontaneous fistfight on live television. Whether it really happened is a matter of interpretation.

title: APPLICANTS SET THEIR SIGHTS ON CAREERS IN CARPENTRY
description: Standing in a line that began forming Sunday, applicants for positions as apprentice carpenters waited yesterday outside the District Council of Carpenters Labor Technical College on East 26th Street. The union plans to open membership slots for 2,000 apprentices as jobs become available, with 400 positions to be filled immediately.

title: GEORGE Y. SCHOCH, JUDGE IN JERSEY
description: George Y. Schoch, assignment judge of the New Jersey Superior Court, died of cancer Saturday at the American Oncologic Hospital in Philadelphia. Despite a long illness, Judge Schoch had performed his court duties until about a week before his death.

title: GREECE WILL STOP FIXING SOVIET SHIPS
description: Greece has ended its agreement with Moscow to repair supply vessels of the Soviet Mediterranean fleet, apparently at the insistence of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: DREADED NEUTRON BOMB
description: To the Editor:

title: Ivy Leaders: Familiar Rivals
description: The University of Pennsylvania has dominated Ivy League basketball for more than a decade, winning the league championship in nine of the last 12 seasons. The only other team to win the conference title has been Princeton, in 1969, 1976 and 1977.

title: People
description: * Raymond Eyes, president and publisher of McCall's, elected chairman of the Publishers Information Bureau.

title: LAWYERS ASSAIL JUSTICE PACKAGE SHAPED BY KOCH
description: A number of the changes proposed by Mayor Koch in his package to reshape the city's criminal justice system were sharply criticized yesterday during a hearing held by the Public Safety Committee of the City Council.

title: Kwiatkowski Is Named Hofstra's Football Coach
description: Mickey Kwiatkowski, a wing-T formation proponent, was appointed football coach at Hofstra today. Kwiatkowski, 33 years old, who has been offensive coordinator at Southwest Missouri State, succeeded Bill Leete, who resigned in January to become athletic director at the University of New Haven.

title: JAPANESE BUSES TO BE TESTED ON NEW YORK STREETS
description: Three Japanese-made passenger buses will soon be in service on the streets of New York City as part of an experiment to determine whether a Japanese manufacturer will build a bus plant in New York State.

title: AFTER FRANCO'S DEATH, SPAIN RETURNED TO TURMOIL
description: Spain's troubled recent history began with the abolition of the monarchy in favor of a republic in 1931, and Francisco Franco's subsequent rightist uprising, which led to the Civil War of 1936-39.

title: British Petrochemical Pact
description: Three British companies have won a $146 million contract to build a petrochemical plant in Greece, the Department of Trade said today. The three are Simon Engineering Ltd., John Brown and Company Ltd. and Foster Wheeler Ltd., it said. Britain's Export Credits Guarantee Department backed a loan made by Lloyds Bank to finance the project.

title: ABC Profits Down 14.3%
description: The American Broadcasting Companies said yesterday that fourthquarter net profits fell 14.3 percent, to $38.5 million, or $1.36 a share, from $44.9 million, or $1.59 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier, and cited increased programming costs, particularly in prime time and news. Revenues rose 5.1 percent, to $663.8 million, from $631.5 million.

title: Advertising; Cable TV Now Gets Ad Bureau
description: ONE sure sign that cable television is moving into the big time is the creation of a bureau to stimulate its growth as an advertising medium.

title: Robbery Shootout Leaves 3 Wounded
description: A Bronx jewelry store owner had a shootout yesterday morning with two brothers who tried to rob him and all three were wounded, the police said.

title: JUSTICES GET COMMODITY DEFAULT SUIT
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether private investors are entitled to sue commodity brokers and exchanges for damages that result from market manipulation or fraud.

title: SHEP FIELDS, LEADER OF BIG BAND KNOWEN FOR RIPPLING RYTHEM
description: Shep Fields, the band leader who made his fame and fortune in the 1930's and 40's with a unique sound he called Rippling Rythm, died of a heart attack yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 70 years old.

title: SOME NOT BEING GIVEN MANDATORY PRISON TERMS UNDER NEW YORK GUN POSSESSION
description: LAW By SELWYN RAAB

title: St. Francis 78, Manhattan 61
description: Kevin Henry scored 23 points and took 18 rebounds to lead St. Francis of Brooklyn to a 78-61 victory over Manhattan Monday night. St. Francis (10-14) held a 35-27 lead at halftime.

title: Sunshine Seeks 3 Silver Concerns
description: The Sunshine Mining Company, formerly controlled by the Hunt family, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it proposed to acquire the Silver Dollar Mining Company, Sunshine Consolidated Inc. and Silver Syndicate, all of which hold an interest in the Sunshine silver mine in Idaho.

title: Six Die in Yugoslav Avalanche
description: Six people died in an avalanche in the Sar Mountains of southwest Yugoslavia, officials said here today. The victims fell onto cars on a road at the bottom of the mountain and were covered by 23 feet of snow, but two children were rescued after spending more than 30 hours in one of the cars.

title: A JUDGE FINDS SUSPECT IN LOWENSTIEN SLAYING WAS 'NOT RESPONSIBLE'
description: The former civil-rights activist who fatally shot Allard K. Lowenstein was found ''not responsible'' for the crime ''by reason of mental disease or defect'' in a court hearing yesterday in Manhattan and will not have to stand trial.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Since the change of leadership in the White House, candidly bellicose calls and statements have resounded from Washington, especially designed, as it were, to poison the atmosphere of relations between our two countries.

title: Carter Aide Denies Role Of Federal Robin Hood
description: Paul Bloom, the former Energy Department lawyer who turned over $4 million in Federal funds to four charities to help the poor pay their heating bills, said today that he had not been trying to play Robin Hood with oil-company money.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: S OME swore that he was not a baron at all. But, in fact, he was, and this morning services will be held at the St. Vincent Ferrer Church at 11 o'clock for Baron Nicolas de Gunzburg, one of the most influential fashion editors to work at Vogue or Bazaar or Town & Country, who died Friday. He is credited with having discovered Bill Blass, inspiring Calvin Klein and having had one of the keenest fashion eyes in the business.

title: Libyan Steel Works
description: Several West German and Austrian companies have won orders totaling $1.3 billion to build two steel works in Libya, spokesmen for the companies said today.

title: Good Samaritans
description: At a luncheon in the New York Hilton yesterday sponsored by its three affiliated New York organizations, the Washington-based American Advertising Federation gave out its first Good Sam awards. That stands for Good Samaritan and all of the ads are public service ones. In fact, from here on out they will be known as the National Public Service Advertising Adwards.

title: THE SCIENCE OF DIETING: A FIGHT AGAINST MIND AND METABOLISM
description: DESPITE the national obsession with diets and dieting, 80 million Americans are overweight and, a recent national survey showed, the average person today is fatter than ever before. So are the coffers of a largely unregulated $10-billion industry that purports to assist people in shedding unwanted pounds via drugs, devices, salons, special foods and a never-ending stream of best-selling diet schemes.

title: Second Thoughts on Manhattan's $24 Purchase Price
description: Peter Minuit's supposed purchase of Manhattan island in 1626 for the equivalent of $24 has long been considered one of history's great bargains.

title: Arbitration Victory Gives Kemp $600,000
description: Steve Kemp registered his second straight offseason victory over the Detroit Tigers yesterday. The arbitrator Monroe Berkowitz awarded Kemp a salary of $600,000, rejecting the $360,000 offered by the Tigers.

title: PHIL BIEBER, A FOUNDER OF UNIT FOR HORSEMEN
description: Phil Bieber, a thoroughbored horse owner and trainer who in 1940 started a movement that led to the organization of a national horsemen's protective association, died at his home in Coral Gables, Fla., Thursday. He was 81 years old and had been a familiar figure at East Coast race tracks for nearly half a century.

title: Plane Crash Victims Identified in Jersey
description: Authorities tentatively identified four people who died Sunday night when the small private plane they were traveling in crashed into a field in Montgomery Township in Somerset County.

title: No Headline
description: ISRAELI WARNS U.S. TALKS MUST RESUME

title: OSCARS: REAPING PROFITS WITH GLORY Daughter'
description: LOS ANGELES THE surprising eight Academy Award nominations won by ''The Elephant Man'' will probably mean between $3 million and $10 million to Paramount Pictures, which released the movie.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF SMALL, INDEPENDENT OIL REFINERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tiant Gets Pirate Tryout Under Farm-Club Pact
description: Luis Tiant, the 40-year-old righthanded pitcher who has a 227-165 record for 17 seasons in the majors, has signed a contract with the Portland Beavers of the Pacific Coast League, the club said today.

title: ISLANDERS AGAIN BENCH A REGULAR, WIN, 4-1
description: The Islanders unveiled a new hockey tactic tonight - the designated benchwarmer - in a fiery display that gave them a 4-1 victory over the North Stars.

title: OREGON STATE (23-0) WINS, (89-63)
description: Steve Johnson scored 21 of his game-high 24 points in the second half to lead top-ranked Oregon State to an 89-63 victory over Washington in a Pacific-10 game tonight.

title: UNIVERSAL TO MARKET FILMS FROM A.F.D.
description: American Film Distribution Inc., the American and Canadian theatrical marketing arm of Lord Grade's entertainment empire, and MCA Inc. announced an agreement today that will make Universal Pictures, a subsidiary of MCA, the subdistributor of A.F.D. films.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BIG BEAT

title: DR. SOL RUBINOW, STUDIED CANCER
description: Dr. Sol Rubinow, an authority on biomathematics and a leading bridge and chess player, died Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y. He had been hospitalized for two months following complications resulting from brain surgery.

title: Plan to Shut Agency Is Assailed
description: The National Coalition to Ban Handguns said yesterday that President Reagan's plan to eliminate the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms was ''social dynamite'' that probably would result in more crime and violence. The organization, which recently filed a suit to strengthen the bureau, said, ''What is urgently needed is a much greater effort to control handguns, not the Administration's misguided plan to ax the bureau.''

title: Judge Bars Use of Rules On Containerized Cargo
description: A Federal judge in Newark yesterday prohibited longshoremen and shipping companies on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts from further observance of disputed rules governing the handling of container cargo. But the judge, Herbert J. Stern, stayed execution of his injunction until 5 P. M. Friday, giving the union and employers an opportunity to appeal.

title: NEW YORK'S SENATE VOTE TO RAISE WELFARE GRANTS 15%
description: After more than two hours of sometimes emotional debate, the Republican-led State Senate voted today to give welfare recipients a 15 percent increase in the basic grant that they receive each month.

title: Rehnquist Postpones Ruling On Release of U.S. Tax Data
description: A Supreme Court Justice today postponed the carrying out lower court rulings that the Government contends would allow release of information that could teach taxpayers how to cheat and probably get away with it.

title: CURB ON 'INDEPENDANT' POLITICAL GROUPS FACING STUDY
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Constitution allows Congress to limit campaign expenditures by so-called ''independent political committees,'' which spent millions of dollars on behalf of Ronald Reagan in the 1980 Presidential campaign.

title: Venice Stalled by Strike
description: A strike by operators of Venice's motorboat taxis and small ferries virtually halted motorized transportation in the city today, but proved a boon for gondoliers. The strike, in its third day, came when hundreds of thousands of tourists are in Venice for carnival.

title: Ogden Revises Offer For Buffalo Forge
description: The Ogden Corporation said its board had unanimously approved an amendment to the company's merger agreement with the Buffalo Forge Company permitting it to make a $37-a-share cash offer for 850,000 Buffalo shares and a share-for-share exchange for the balance of Buffalo's outstanding. The value of the amended offer was estimated at $71.2 million.

title: JACKSON DISCUSSES LONG-TERM DEAL
description: Reggie Jackson and George Steinbrenner met here today for more than two hours and the Yankee owner discussed a deal that Jackson said could keep him ''in the Yankee family for life.''

title: The Economy
description: The prime rate was lowered half a percentage point, to 19 percent, by most of the nation's large banks and by a point, to 18 1/2 percent, by Continental Illinois and two smaller banks. The moves reflected increasing competition from cheaper sources of credit. Bankers, wary about the economic outlook, cautioned that the decline did not necessarily signal further drops in lending rates. (Page D1.)

title: Assembly Passes Bill Requiring Supermarkets to Keep Labeling
description: Although many supermarkets have installed laborsaving computer scanners at their checkout counters, food stores must continue to mark the price on each item under a bill passed today by the Assembly.

title: 'SLIGHT' DAMAGE CAUSED BY SHUTTLE TEST FIRING
description: Friday's engine test firing slightly damaged some of the delicate ceramic heat shield tiles on the space shuttle Columbia but the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said Monday repairs can be made easily without affecting the scheduled launching date in early April.

title: Department of Energy Plans Drastic Cutbacks
description: The Department of Energy has devised a reorganization plan that, if completely carried out, will lead to the dispersal of several activities to other agencies and a substantial reduction in the number of department employees, an aide to Energy Secretary James B. Edwards disclosed today.

title: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S ECONOMIC 'SHAM'
description: To the Editor:

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Peru tonight denied Ecuador's charge that it had attacked an Ecuadorean military outpost yesterday. Foreign Minister Javier Arias Stella of Peru said the armed forces had informed him that no action took place in the region yesterday.

title: HEAD OF MIAMI JOBS PROGRAM RESIGNS AFTER ARREST IN DRUG INVESTIGATION
description: The director of a federally financed jobs program who was arrested over the weekend on charges of possessing cocaine resigned today after he was freed by a Federal magistrate.

title: HARVARD LAW REVIEW'S ETHNIC SCREENING CRITICIZED
description: Amid a controversy that has extended beyond Harvard Law School to much of the country's legal community, the Harvard Law Review has adopted a plan to consider a student's race, ethnic background or sex in filling some editorial positions.

title: MAYOR CALLS REAGAN'S PLAN TO CUT TRANSIT AID 'DUMB'
description: Mayor Koch sharpened his attack yesterday on President Reagan's plan to eliminate Federal mass-transit subsidies, calling it ''the dumbest thing I've heard of in years.''

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 24, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: United Nations Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M.

title: HUNTER AND JOHN JAY ADVANCE IN TOURNEY
description: Hunter College defeated Medgar Evers, 85-67, and John Jay downed York College, 69-56, last night in preliminary-round games of the sixteenth annual City University of New York postseason basketball tournament at Queens College.

title: Reagan's Tax-Cut Theory
description: Most politicians, surely including President Reagan, are well aware that God must love the common man, since he made so many of them. Yet the huge tax reduction the President would phase in over the next three years is heavily weighted toward the upper tax brackets - a striking reversal of tax-cutting tradition.

title: STATE DEPT. SAYS SALVADOR REBELS GET FEWER ARMS
description: State Department officials said today that a campaign by the United States had apparently slowed the infiltration of what it describes as Soviet-bloc arms shipments through Nicaragua to guerrillas in El Salvador.

title: U.S. Abstains in U.N. Vote Condemning Totalitarianism
description: The United States cast the only abstention in balloting today on a United Nations Human Rights Commission resolution condemning ''all totalitarian or other ideologies and practices.'' The human rights resolution was adopted, 38 to 0.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1981
description: International Spain's Parliament was seized by Civil Guards who took most of the nation's leaders hostage as the legislators were approving a new Government. Army troops briefly took control of the state-run television station outside Madrid, and the head of the Valencia military region proclaimed a state of emergency in his command. The move by rightists appeared aimed at igniting a national military revolt, but there were no signs that other military units had joined the rebellion. King Juan Carlos, appearing on television, denounced the rebels and pledged his faith in democracy. (Page A1, Column 6.) A call for U.S.-Soviet summit talks was issued by Leonid I. Brezhnev in a long speech opening the 26th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party. He proposed the meeting with President Reagan to further ''an active dialogue'' designed to halt a deterioration in relations. The Soviet leader stressed peace, not confrontation in his appeal. (A1:2.)

title: JERSEY BILL VOTED TO OPEN PRIMARY ON GOVERNORSHIP
description: The New Jersey Legislature gave swift approval in both houses today to a bill mandating an open primary for governor in the June 2 primary election.

title: OUTLOOK GLOOMY FOR AMTRAK PLAN
description: Secretary of Transportation Drew Lewis said today that Amtrak's Northeast rail corridor would never carry high-speed passenger trains as long as it must also carry freight.

title: European Jobless Rate Up
description: Unemployment in the 10 Common Market countries rose to a record 8.5 million people, or 7.5 percent of the work force, in January, according to a Common Market report released today. The surge in unemployment hit all 10 countries in the Common Market except Belgium. Its unemployment rate stayed at 10.6 percent, the second-highest level in the Common Market behind Ireland, which had an 11 percent unemployment rate, up from 10.8 percent in December, the report said.

title: ON TRIAL FOR DAMAGING NUCLEAR WARHEAD
description: Correction: February 25, 1981, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

title: STRINGS: TOKYO QUARTET
description: OF the Japanese composers who have emerged on the international scene since World War II, Toru Takemitsu is the best known in this country, and perhaps the best. His Requiem for Strings, ''November Steps'' and ''Green'' made the rounds of the major orchestras a decade or so ago; record collectors know a few pieces such as his ''Asterism'' and ''Stanza I,'' and film enthusiasts may recognize him as the composer of music for ''Woman in the Dunes,'' among other films. Those works, however, hardly scratch the skin of Mr. Takemitsu's substantial body of work. In fact, like many of his Western colleagues, he has spent the last 30 years or so in trying on one compositional style after another, like a dandy who has been let loose overnight in a tailor's shop.

title: 2 Views of Miss Hepburn
description: Just when a magazine article appears in which Katharine Hepburn is raked over the coals as ''an unmitigated pain in the neck,'' another article apears - this one by the actress herself - in which she concedes that she's indeed difficult to work with.

title: MARY CUNNINGHAM TO JOIN SEAGRAM
description: Mary E. Cunningham, who resigned as vice president for strategic planning of the Bendix Corporation last October, will join Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc. as vice president-strategic planning and project development, beginning in mid-March.

title: CAREY BUDGET DRAMA UNFOLDING IN ALBANY
description: The ritual theater opens with the chief actor - the Governor - standing before a backdrop of multicolored charts and promising aid for all in the coming year.

title: Mead Buys Timberland
description: The Mead Corporation has purchased or optioned an additional 214,000 acres of timberland in Michigan's Upper Peninsula, the company said today, increasing its holdings in the area to 672,000 acres. About 94,000 acres were acquired from the United States Steel Corporation and 120,000 acres from the Copper Range Corporation , Mead said. The company did not disclose the value of the transaction.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the review of a recital by the mezzo-soprano Glenda Maurice that appeared on Sunday, the accompanist was named incorrectly. He was David Garvey.

title: Arts Club to Honor Edel
description: The National Arts Club's 1981 Gold Medal for literature will be presented tomorrow to Leon Edel, ''for his contributions to the art of biography and his significant insights into the psychological development of literary artists.''

title: MINNEAPOLIS EXECUTIVE IS SELECTED AS PRESIDENT OF DARTHMOUTH COLLEGE
description: David T. McLaughlin, chairman of the board of trustees at Dartmouth College, was named today as the 14th president of the college.

title: Judge Weighs Fine for Sears
description: A Federal judge said today that he was considering whether to treble an $86,500 damage judgment against Sears, Roebuck and Company, which has been found guilty of patent infringement and unfair competition.

title: DR. SAUL K. PADOVER, AUTHOR, DEAD AT 75
description: Dr. Saul K. Padover, author of more than 30 books, many of them on Thomas Jefferson and Karl Marx, and professor of political science since 1949 at the New School for Social Research, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Does a tree grow year-round below the surface?

title: Polytechnic Rebuts City on Sex Case
description: Polytechnic Institute of New York accused the City Commission on Human Rights of having made ''blatant inaccuracies and distortions'' in a news release last month that reported a $3,250 settlement of a case of alleged sexual harassment involving a former Polytechnic researcher.

title: Topless Ban Nearing, Maybe Only on Paper
description: A two-week grace period allowing joggers to go topless officially ends Wednesday, but the Palm Beach Police Department will not say when the police will begin enforcing the new clothing requirement.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Signed Greg Field and D an O'Brien, pitchers. CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Guy Hoffman, p itcher, and Leo Sutherland, outfielder.

title: 2 PHOTOGRAPHERS SNEAK FILM OUT
description: The photographs that flashed around the world after the seizure of the Spanish Parliament were taken by two Spanish photographers who smuggled them from the building in defiance of the insurgents' orders.

title: Charles Is Said to Plan To Announce Wedding
description: Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, is expected to announce his engagement to Lady Diana Spencer today, with the wedding scheduled for July, The Times of London reported.

title: Armco Plans Caster
description: Armco Inc. said it would spend $90 million to install a continuous caster at its Ashland, Ky., plant to supply steel to the company's seamless-tubular plant in Ambridge, Pa., and to the new seamless-pipe mill it is preparing to build. The company expects to have the caster, with an annual capacity of 720,000 tons, in operation by 1983.

title: GUARDS' LOSSES IN BASQUE AREA BROUGHT ANGER
description: The Spanish Guardia Civil, or Civil Guard, is a paramilitary national police force that became one of the principal instruments of repression under the Franco regime.

title: Talking Business with Shigeru Okada of Mitsukoshi Retail Advice From Japan
description: Mitsukoshi Ltd., Japan's largest department store chain, faces an uncertain economy, as do most retailers everywhere. In 1981, however, the concern's management believes that Mitsukoshi will do well because of what it calls its adoption of the West's ''pragmatic management'' combined with the ''spiritual, intuitive aspects'' of the East. Having learned much during its 300-year history, Mitsukoshi should improve its sales and earnings this year ''because we feel we know how to do well in difficult times,'' its top executives say.

title: Olympic Marathon Run For Women Is Approved
description: The women's marathon was given approval today by the executive board of the International Olympic Committee and is likely to be included in the 1984 Olympic Games here.

title: Biotechnology Pact in Canada
description: John Labatt Ltd., Canada's biggest brewery, the Canada Development Corporation and the Ontario government have announced the formation of a joint venture to develop products and processes based on biotechnology.

title: AN OVERSIZED ISSUE
description: The political agenda, it is reasonable to believe, is so cluttered with pressing and important issues that nonissues recede into oblivion. Not so. Consider the persistent interest in the size of the Government. Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford promised to get the Government off our backs and out of our pockets, Jimmy Carter ran against Washington, and Ronald Reagan has identified Government as the problem.

title: Cooney Accepts Garden's Offer
description: Gerry Cooney did not fight Ken Norton at Madison Square Garden last night, as originally scheduled, but his managers agreed to have Cooney, the No. 1 heavyweight contender, meet Norton at the Garden on May 11.

title: Miss Bergman's Farewell
description: Today's ''say it isn't so'' plea is directed by millions of her fans to Ingrid Bergman, who said over the weekend, ''I'm leaving, and I will not return to the movies or the theater.''

title: UNIVERSITY RETURNS $600,000 LIBYAN GIFT
description: Georgetown University in Washington yesterday returned to the Government of Libya more than $600,000 of a gift it had received to endow a professorship in its Center for Contemporary Arab Studies.

title: Dutch Police and Squatters Clash in Provincial City
description: Two thousand police officers firing tear gas grenades and backed by tanks cleared 3,000 squatters from downtown Nijmegen today, then watched as bulldozers demolished houses in the area.

title: New Twist on Old Saw
description: If coals can be transported to Newcastle, why can't Japanese cherry trees be sent to Japan? Nancy Reagan plans today to give the Japanese Ambassador to Washington, Yoshio Okawara, a 3 1/2-foot Yoshino cherry tree propagated from a tree planted at the Tidal Basin in Washington in 1912 by Mrs. William Howard Taft. That tree came from Japan.

title: Staten I. Transit Line Delayed by Walkout
description: More than 10,000 commuters were delayed when 61 motormen and conductors on the Staten Island Rapid Transit line stopped working during the rush hour in protest against being without a contract for more than three years.

title: TV: CHILD PORNOGRAPHY, SOCIAL DISEASE
description: THIS week's featured social disease on television is child pornography. ''Fallen Angel,'' on CBS-TV tonight at 9 o'clock, is clearly concerned about the problem. The film is also disturbing - in more ways than one.

title: BREZHNEV PROPOSES TALKS WITH REAGAN TO MEND RELATIONS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, today proposed a meeting with President Reagan as a key element in ''an active dialogue'' designed to halt a deterioration in relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Murphy Reaches 73 on Foul Shots
description: Calvin Murphy scored a game-high 38 points, including 6 of 6 foul shots to extend his National Basketball Association record for consecutive free throws to 73, giving the Houston Rockets a 106-102 victory over the Utah Jazz tonight.

title: No Headline
description: D. Gorton ''ISN'T IT BEAUTIFUL,'' said President Reagan as he put his hand on a metal statue presented to him by Senator Barry Goldwater. The 20-inch sculpture was one of two statues given to the President by Mr. Goldwater.

title: BUSINESSES CURTAILING CHINA STAFFS
description: Although they do not want to let the Chinese know about it, many American and other foreign businesses here are quietly putting their operations in China in mothballs after two frustrating years of trying to do business here.

title: Villanova 74, Connecticut 73
description: Stewart Granger scored 3 points in the second overtime and John Pinone had a game-high 23 points tonight to lead Villanova to a 74-73 Big East Conference victory over Connecticut.

title: Private Garwood Indicted On Sexual Felony Counts
description: Pfc. Robert R. Garwood of the Marine Corps, convicted of collaborating with the enemy in Vietnam, was indicted today on felony charges of sexual misconduct involving a 7-year-old girl.

title: SALVADORAN INSURGENTS SAY THEY ARE WILLING TO DISCUSS SETTLEMENT
description: Salvadoran opposition leaders today renewed their offer to negotiate a political settlement in El Salvador with the Reagan Administration. They said that any increase in United States military aid to the governing junta would threaten to prolong and widen the conflict.

title: BULK
description: A group of Civil Guards seized the lower house of Parliament yesterday and took most of the country's leaders as hostages.

title: Bushmen in Namibia Are Fighting for South Africa
description: West Africa (Reuters) - Thousands of Bushmen who supported the Portuguese colonialists during Angola's long independence war are now fighting on the side of South Africa against guerrillas of the South-West Africa People's Organization.

title: Gulf Unit Studies Canadians' Role
description: Gulf Canada Ltd. is studying how to increase Canadian ownership of the company, a spokesman said. The company, which is 60 percent owned by the Gulf Oil Corporation, Pittsburgh, could not comment on a published report that it was involved in a $2 billion pact to raise its Canadian ownership, he added.

title: TEXT OF STATE DEPARTMENT REPORT ON COMMUNIST SUPPORT OF SALVADORAN REBELS
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - Following is the text of a State Department report on Communist support for the insurrection in El Salvador:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Acorn Investments S.A., of Luxembourg, and a group of European investors, said they hold 7.3 percent of Iroquois Brands Ltd.

title: MUSIC: MENUHIN TRIBUTE TO SISTER
description: HISTORY hovered in the air at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night as Yehudi Menuhin gave a violin recital devoted to three major 20thcentury composers. Each man at one time or another had dedicated works to Mr. Menuhin.

title: POLICE HEAD PUT ON SUSPENSION IN WESTCHESTER
description: After more than seven months of public and private wrangling, County Executive Alfred B. DelBello today suspended Thomas J. Delaney, the Commissioner/Sheriff of Westchester. Mr. DelBello charged that Mr. Delaney had ''unlawfully attempted to derive a personal gain'' from his $58,630-a-year position and had failed to ''effectively manage and administer'' his department.

title: No Headline
description: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS BY BREZHNEV TO THE SOVIET COMMUNIST PARTY CONGRESS

title: Judge Mr. Watt Fairly
description: Environmentalists rang their alarms when President Reagan appointed James Watt as Interior Secretary. They feared that Mr. Watt, a forceful advocate of economic development, would promote reckless exploitation of the public lands while neglecting his collateral duty to conserve and protect. Now he has taken his first major action and they believe their worst nightmares are coming true.

title: IU International Earnings Up 13.7%
description: The IU International Corporation, parent of two of the nation's leading motor carriers, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of last year increased 13.7 percent on a sales gain of 6.5 percent.

title: DON'T LET THE MAILMAN HAVE SATURDAY OFF
description: To the Editor:

title: PATRICK CUNNINGHAM IS ACCUSED OF CONSPIRACY IN A U.S. TAX CASE
description: A prosecutor asserted in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday that Patrick J. Cunningham, a former leader of the New York State and Bronx Democratic organizations, had participated in a ''conspiracy to obstruct justice.''

title: PACT REPORTED ON MOB'S NEVADA AND JERSEY ROLES
description: Chicago mobsters were given control over illegal activities in Las Vegas at an underworld conclave attended by top families of the nation's crime syndicate, according to The Chicago Tribune.

title: Qantas Ground Staff Strike
description: Ground staff of Qantas, the Australian international airline, voted today to continue a 10-day strike that has disrupted international flights, but stewards decided to return to work. Workers' leaders had said earlier that the strike would end at midnight last night, but a mass meeting of ground staff decided to continue striking until Wednesday, union officials said.

title: BURKE'S ISSUES CANDID 'PEERAGE' OF U.S. PRESIDENTS
