description: BURKE'S Peerage, Baronetage and Knightage, the last word in tracking the lineage of Britain's kings, queens, princes, dukes, knights, heirs-presumptive and presumptuous heirs, has finally crossed the Atlantic with a definitive edition about the closest to royalty that America has - the American Presidents, from Washington to Reagan.

title: News Analysis
description: ''At the meeting that we had with the President last week, it was just unbelievable,'' Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House, said today of Mr. Reagan's briefing on his economic package. ''He said he wanted it on the floor in a couple of weeks. The President thought he was going to send us a message, it would go to the Ways and Means Committee and come out the same day. Whether he was serious or pulling my leg, I don't know.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly identified an artist who is doing sketches for NBC News at the murder trial of Jean S. Harris. The artist is Ida Libby Dengrove.

title: No Headline
description: IRAN ANNOUNCES THAT IT IS BARRING ALL ACTIVITIES OF ANGLICAN CHURCH

title: Track Notebook
description: Nehemiah and Moses: How to Win and Lose $66,400 in a Flash By FRANK LITSKY

title: Yacht and Plane Seized In the Wells Fargo Case
description: A cabin cruiser and a private airplane belonging to Harold J. Smith, the boxing promoter who is a figure in an alleged $21 million embezzlement scheme involving the Wells Fargo bank, have been seized by sheriff's deputies.

title: FOR POOR, LOBBYING IS CATCH AS CATCH CAN
description: They cannot write large checks to political candidates or hire influential lawyers to talk with legislators over drinks. They have no expense accounts, little influence in their communities, few personal friends in high places. Often, they cannot afford the price of a bus ticket to Albany. Many of them are not even registered to vote.

title: POPE PAYS A CALL ON HIROHITO IN TOKYO
description: Pope John Paul II called on Emperor Hirohito at the Imperial Palace today in a meeting that has caused some dispute here.

title: Large Media Campaign Is Begun by Lorillard
description: Lorillard today began a very expensive newspaper advertising campaign for its Kent III cigarette brand in New York and 13 other markets, and next month will extend it to a list of more than 20 national magazines.

title: FORMULA FOR SUCCESS GIVEN A TEST
description: ALMOST two years ago, a handful of New York City elementary schools armed themselves with what research had suggested could be a formula for effective schools.

title: Budweiser Hires McGavin
description: Darren McGavin, the actor, is to be the new voice for the Budweiser ''This Bud's For You'' campaign. D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/St. Louis is the agency.Do you suppose his playing a reporter on the horror series ''Nightstalker'' helped any?

title: NO ACCORD YET IN A.T.& T. SUIT
description: The Justice Department said today that it had not reached a settlement of its civil antitrust suit to break up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and that the Reagan Administration would not be able to approve any settlement by a March 2 deadline.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE TIMES ATLAS OF THE WORLD. Comprehensive edition. 123 plates. Index, 227 pages. Times Books. $125. THE NEW YORK TIMES ATLAS OF THE WORLD. In collaboration with The Times of London. 147 plates. Index, 87 pages. Times Books. $60.

title: 2 EDUCATORS AND 3D MAN CHARGED IN AIRPORT MARIJUANA SMUGGLING
description: An associate professor at Hunter College and a public school official from Paterson, N.J., were arrested yesterday at Kennedy International Airport and charged with possession of 220 pounds of marijuana, which had been smuggled in from Nigeria, the police said.

title: MORAL MAJORITY HALTS LAWSUIT ON SEX EDUCATION FILM
description: Moral Majority today dropped its lawsuit that sought to force the state library to disclose which public schools had borrowed a sex education film.

title: Three Skiers Hurt in Avalanche
description: Three skiers were injured in an avalanche that crashed yesterday through Mineral Fork Canyon.

title: 1980 CENSUS SHOWS 17% GROWTH OF BLACKS SURPASSED RISE FOR U.S.
description: The nation's black population grew by 17 percent in the last decade, far faster than the 11 percent overall increase in the American population, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: New Harris Facility
description: The Harris Corporation said today that it would build an $8.2 million office and production facility here to accomodate increased demand for its computer-based electronic control instruments for pipelines and electric utilities. When the new building opens in the fall, employment will be increased to 900 from 500, the company said.

title: MCLUHAN'S MISUNDERSTOOD MESSAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: RAIN STRANDS MANY IN CITY AREA
description: Heavy rain last night further alleviated the water shortage in the New York City metropolitan area, but the downpour, accompanied by fog and gusting winds, also caused problems for travelers, stranding many air and rail users in the city for hours and making automobile travel hazardous.

title: FIGHTING VANDALISM WITH CREATIVE ARTS
description: FEW school districts are safe from vandalism. Even fewer, especially in genteel suburbs, like to put the spotlight on the damage. But the district of Bellmore, L.I. is doing just that, with a program intended to turn the problem of vandalism into an opportunity to teach children and mobilize community cooperation. The device is a creative arts program in the North Bellmore elementary schools, aimed at students with special talents in creative writing, drama, music, dance, art and design.

title: The Sweetest Month
description: During the lifetime of New Yorkers not yet in their dotage, chains of candy stores were draped around the nicer avenues of the city. These were not just corner candy stores with dusty Parcheesi sets in the front window and bookies in the back room, but proper candy stores - like Schrafft's, Huyler's, Loft's, Mailliard's -where proper people bought presents for fiancees behind decorated windows that told the seasons.

title: Opening of 'The Survivor' Is Off Until Next Tuesday
description: The opening of ''The Survivor,'' by Susan Nanus, has been postponed from Thursday to next Tuesday.

title: Pole Is Sentenced for Spying
description: A military tribunal in Szczecin has sentenced a Pole, identified only as Stefan R., to three years in prison for spying for a NATO nation, the official Polish press agency reported today. It said he was an employee of a Polish shipping company and had been accused of ''providing military and economic information to a foreign intelligence service.''

title: Nearsighted Protectors of Election Law
description: The Federal Election Commission persists in arming its critics and alarming those who want it to succeed as guardian of the nation's election reforms. A controversy concerning a political story in The Reader's Digest last year has shown the commission at its bureaucratic worst. It's as if the commissioners were looking for constitutional trouble, despite clear warnings from the bench.

title: Jaime Milans del Bosch
description: Lieut. Gen. Jaime Milans del Bosch, who declared a military revolt yesterday in Valencia as supporters seized Parliament in Madrid, is known as a prominent follower of Franco ... 65 years old ... In military since 1934, two years before Franco uprising ... Critic of Spanish democracy as too weak to contain terrorism ... Passed over after Franco's death in 1975 although in line for promotion to army chief of staff ... Sent to command eastern military region of Valencia ... Rumored to have been involved in 1980 conspiracy to capture Prime Minister and his Cabinet ... Reportedly received telephone call yesterday from leader of attack on Parliament: ''Uneventful, my general, all is in hand.'' Antonio Tejero Molina

title: ASH FORCED OUT OF TWO AM POSTS
description: Roy L. Ash, the chairman and chief executive of loss-plagued AM International for four years, has resigned those posts following a clash with directors over sources of critically needed new capital.

title: Sundance Rejects Bid by Canadian
description: The Sundance Oil Company, a mining and energy exploration concern based in Denver, said its directors had rejected as inadequate a takeover offer from an undentified Canadian suitor valued at more than $500 million.

title: S. Carolina 106,Ga. Southern 69
description: Zam Fredrick, the nation's leading scorer, scored 43 points tonight to help South Carolina (17-10) close its regular season with a 106-69 rout of Georgia Southern (5-19). Fredrick, a 6-2 senior guard, raised his average to 28.9 points a game. In his last 13 games, Fredrick has averaged 35 points and has hit about 55 percent of his field-goal attempts.

title: HARRIS JURY ENDS 7TH DAY OF TALK WITHOUT VERDICT
description: In its seventh day of deliberations, the jury in the Jean S. Harris trial apparently failed to resolve an impasse over the charge of murder in the second degree. Mrs. Harris is accused of shooting Dr. Herman Tarnower last March 10.

title: BURRELL L. SMALL
description: Burrell L. Small, president and chairman of the Mid America Media Group and a former publisher of The Kankakee Daily Journal, died yesterday Sunday at the age of 62.

title: Steinbrenner: Guidry Is Safe
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, said today that he has assured Ron Guidry's agent that Guidry will not be traded.

title: Louisville 81, Cincinnati 67
description: Jerry Eaves scored 16 second-half points as Louisville posted its 11th straight victory with a 81-67 Metro Conference decision over Cincinnati tonight.

title: GUIDANCE COUNSELING IS ALIVE AND WELL
description: To the Editor:

title: BRANIFF'S LOSS TOTALS $76.9 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: The Braniff International Corporation yesterday reported a net loss of $76.9 million for 1980's fourth quarter, which brought its losses for the year to $128.5 million, the largest in Braniff's 52-year history and nearly three times 1979's loss of $44.3 million.

title: Blue Chips Strengthen Market
description: A solid performance by blue chips sent the stock market forging ahead yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.14 points, to 945.23, reflecting particular strength in its chemical company components.

title: ONLY 42 ATTEND A SCHOOL ON L.I. AFTER DEATH OF 2
description: Only 42 of 834 pupils showed up at the Chestnut Hill Elementary School today as concern grew among parents over the recent deaths of two young boys who were students at the school.

title: THE SCIENCE OF DIETING: A FIGHT AGAINST MIND AND METABOLISM
description: FOR many people, weight loss turns out to be the most trivial aspect of dieting. Almost everyone can shed pounds on almost any diet, at least for a while, but few can predict or control the sometimes paradoxical psychological accompaniments to dieting: the distorted body images that do not grow slimmer even when real appearance does, the self-loathing and low self-esteem that thwart the efforts to reduce, the relationships that crumble because weight is lost, as well as the anxiety and depression - what one psychologist calls ''the fear of thinness'' - that may set in when the diet is successful.

title: No Headline
description: JUROR SAYS MRS. HARRIS'S TESTIMONY WAS THE KEY TO MURDER CONVICTION

title: THE REGION;
description: A New York State Appeals Court ruled unanimously that a woman who had contracted cancer after her mother used the drug DES during pregnancy could sue any manufacturer of the drug, even if she could not prove which of them had produced the DES her mother purchased.

title: Dr. Francis O'Neill, 73; Was Hospital Director
description: Dr. Francis J. O'Neill, a psychiatrist and former director of the Central Islip State Hospital on Long Island, died Monday at his home in Medford, L.I. He was 73 years old.

title: Spurs 131, Warriors 126
description: George Gervin scored 26 points and George Johnson blocked a team-record 13 shots as the Spurs beat Golden State.

title: Q. Someone has given me a bottle of cider that tastes exactly like plain apple juice. Is there a difference?
description: A. Apple cider comes in two different varieties. Sweet apple cider is simply pure, freshly made apple juice. Hard cider is fermented apple juice. You probably know that apple jack is a distilled spirit that is made from hard cider. In Normandy, this is called Calvados.

title: LIFTING OF GASOLINE CONTROLS CHANGING SALE PATTERN
description: President Reagan's abolition of controls on gasoline is likely to change the way it is sold in the United States, oil industry officials predict.

title: Eldridge Memorial Service
description: A five-minute ceremony in memory of Alex Eldridge, a former University of Massachusetts basketball player out of Taft High School in the Bronx, was held last night before the Pittsburgh-UMass game in Amherst. Eldridge, a former schoolboy all-American, died last June 27 at the age of 24 from a sudden heart ailment.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 25. 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3. P.M.

title: REAGAN VOWS TO HELP SALVADORANS BUT SAYS U.S. WON'T BE LOCKED IN
description: President Reagan said today that he had ''no intention'' of involving the United States inextricably in the fighting in El Salvador, but he declared that his Administration would continue to support the Government there against those committed to its ''violent overthrow.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * The Business Forms Group of SCM Corporation's Allied Paper division plans to build a multimillion-dollar business forms plant at Bellville, Tex.

title: Market Place; Investors Cited In Takeover Bid
description: AN intriguing struggle for control of a Colorado mining company is producing charges that an investor group abused confidential information and relied on a sweetheart bank in its efforts to take over the company.

title: TRIPLE-A BELL BONDS SOLD TO YIELD 14.8% A RECORD
description: Underscoring near-record yields prevailing in the fixed-income market, underwriters sold a triple-A debenture issue of the Bell System yesterday at a record return of 14.80 percent.

title: First Penn Ends Credit
description: The financially troubled First Pennsylvania Bank has informed 13,000 ''revolving cash'' customers that it is canceling their line of credit because doing business with them has become unprofitable.

title: 3 DRUG OFFICIALS TRANSFERRED, 2 FOR POOR NORTHEAST RESULTS
description: Three top officials of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration's Northeast regional office were transferred yesterday by Peter B. Bensinger, administrator of the agency. He said management changes were being made because the region had performed poorly.

title: 8 KILLED IN STRONG QUAKE IN GREECE
description: A strong earthquake struck Athens and parts of southern Greece tonight, killing at least eight people and injuring dozens.

title: Shad to Be Named S.E.C.'s Chairman
description: President Reagan said today that he was nominating John S.R. Shad, vice chairman of the board of the E.F. Hutton Group, to be a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission and would designate him as chairman.

title: 6th Westar Satellite
description: The Western Union Corporation said it had asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to construct and launch a sixth Westar domestic communications satellite. The company currently has three domestic communications satellites in orbit 22,300 miles above the Equator. Two others are under construction and the F.C.C. has approved their scheduled 1982 launchings.

title: CENSUS BUREAU REPORTS A DECLINE IN COMMUTING BY PUBLIC TRANSIT
description: The Census Bureau reported today that, despite rising gasoline prices, the use of public transportation for commuting to work declined from 1970 through 1977 in most of the 20 cities it studied.

title: Segovia to Play March 22 In Single New York Recital
description: Andres Segovia, the guitar virtuoso, will make his only New York appearance of the season on March 22 at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall - his first performance there in over a decade.

title: KNICKS BEAT HAWKS IN OVERTIME, 120-117, ON BASKET BY GLENN
description: Mike Glenn's rebound of a layup with 45 seconds remaining in overtime gave the Knicks a 120-117 comeback victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight at the Omni. Glenn's basket came after Michael Ray Richardson had missed a layup after stripping Art Collins of the ball and racing down the court.

title: Other Low-Cost Foods
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I realize it's not easy for a couple to feed themselves for $5 or less a day, and that the Laves manage to do so is no mean achievement (''A Couple Who Eat For Less, With Careful Planning,'' Feb. 18). Even so, I couldn't help feeling disheartened by the dreariness of their weekly menu.

title: POLISH CHIEF SEEKS TO ASSURE MOSCOW
description: Stanislaw Kania, Poland's Communist Party leader, assured the Soviet Union today that his party had the will and the strength to solve Poland's problems by itself.

title: HIGH COURT BARS SHIFT IN FORMULA CUTTING PRISONER'S GOOD CONDUCT CREDIT
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a Florida law changing the formula to earn a reduction in a prison sentence was an unconstitutional ex post facto law when applied to a man who began serving a sentence before the change was made.

title: Mexico Is Said to Want F-5 Jets; U.S. Approves
description: Mexico has expressed interest in the purchase of F-5 jet fighters from the United States and, if a formal request is made, the sale will be approved, the State Department said today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT IS the all-new, 1981 variation on a traditional theme - only this time it involves (1) a stolen automobile battery, (2) a Broadway play and (3) a suburban couple. The story was brought to the attention of Metropolitan Diary by Kathleen Ryan, who works in Manhattan. Although the names of the principals have been disguised, the events have been verified by the Suffolk County police.

title: ISRAEL MAKES IT A CRIME TO PUBLISH PRIVATE PAPERS WITHOUT APPROVAL
description: The Israeli Parliament passed a law last night making it a crime to copy, publish or read the private correspondence of anyone, including Government officials, without his or her permission.

title: Shooting Erupts at Rome Airport; Two Are Hurt and Four Arrested
description: Two people were injured today when shooting broke out in the arrival lounge at Fiumicino Airport here, the airport news agency Telenews reported.

title: MRS. HARRIS IS PUT UNDER 'SUICIDE WATCH' AT JAIL
description: Jean S. Harris, wearing blue and white prison sneakers, slacks and a blouse, met with her lawyer, Joel Aurnou, at the Women's Correction Unit of the Westchester County Jail tonight and then was placed in separate quarters under a ''suicide watch.''

title: 3 Slain in Bronx In Drug Dispute
description: Two men and a woman, all in their 20's, were shot to death early yesterday in a Bronx apartment in a dispute with an assailant over a drug deal, the police said.

title: Advertising; Kronenbourg Planning $3 Million Promotion
description: Since Heineken, the Netherlands' gift to the local beer drinker, is such a dominant force in the imported beer market, with about 70 percent of sales, it is natural enough for another import with dreams of glory to tie itself to Heineken. And that is what Kronenbourg, a product of Alsace that maintains it is the best-sold bottle beer in Europe, has been doing in its advertising: ''Europeans like Heineken.

title: Rosedale's Parents Suing To Retain School Annex
description: Lawyers for parents in Rosedale, Queens, who are fighting the closing of the Intermediate School 231 annex filed suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday in their latest move to reopen it.

title: COURT LIMITS FREEDOM OF A DIVORCED PARENT IN CHOOSING RESIDENCE
description: A divorced parent's ability to live where he or she chooses may be limited by the right of a child and the other parent to see each other conveniently, the New York State Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, ruled today.

title: ITS ALL THE NEWS ABOUT CHOCOLATE
description: ''THE essential concept to be grasped is the very eminence of chocolate,'' said Milton Zelman, with a far-off look in his eyes. ''It speaks to those who love it. There is something profound about it - but the tragedy is that not enough attention is paid to chocolate.''

title: Fishermen's Plaint: Sewage in the Sea
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) - A group of fishermen who ply the ocean off New York and New Jersey asked the Supreme Court to allow them to sue for damages to fish caused by the dumping of sewage.

title: And Now, a 'Definitive' Book on the Royal Wedding
description: Yesterday's announcement of Prince Charles's engagement and marriage this summer to Lady Diana Spencer was followed quickly, in New York, by Viking Press's announcement it would have on the market, by April 30, the ''definitive'' book about the couple called ''The Royal Wedding.''

title: STAGE: 'HEARTLAND,' RAMPANT HOMICIDE
description: IN Kevin Heelan's ''Heartland,'' which is playing at the Century Theater on Broadway, there is a homicidal maniac on the loose. Eight people have been slaughtered in a small Middle Western town, and everyone shudders at the slightest sound. Skeet, a crude, unemployed redneck and self-appointed vigilante, stands guard over his house with a rifle and several six-packs of beer, fortifying himself against the killer and against an oppressive thirst.

title: Robert Fish, 68, Wrote Novels and Mysteries
description: Robert L. Fish, a consulting engineer who wrote 40 novels and mysteries and 100 short stories and articles, died after a heart attack yesterday at his home in Trumbull, Conn. He was 68 years old.

title: GEORGE A. LANYI
description: George A. Lanyi, professor of government at Oberlin College in Ohio, died Friday in Oberlin of a heart attack.

title: COMPANY ADMITS EVADING IRAN TRADE BAN
description: -A New York electrical company pleaded gulty today to Federal Charges that it conspired to evade a Presidential ban on exports to Iran.

title: GOVERNORS ENDORSE CUT IN U.S. SPENDING BUT SET CONDITIONS
description: The nation's governors today endorsed President Reagan's proposal to cut the growth in Federal spending, but on the conditions that states be given time to adjust, the poor be protected and tax burdens not be shifted to states and localities.

title: Ex-Judge Disbarred In Sex-Favor Case
description: A former Long Island Family Court judge was suspended from the practice of law for two years for demanding sex from a woman in return for a favorable ruling on her court case. The woman charged that the judge threatened to take her two children away from her if she did not comply.

title: AT SITE OF BLAST IN HIROSHIMA, POPE APPEALS FOR PEACE
description: Pope John Paul II today made a strong appeal for peace at the place where the first atomic bomb was detonated on Aug. 6, 1945. ''To remember Hiroshima is to abhor nuclear war,'' he declared. ''To remember Hiroshima is to commit oneself to peace.''

title: Bridge: Rubinow Was a Quiet Man Of Considerable Versatility
description: A quiet, thoughtful man with the air of a university professor won more than his share of New York titles in the 50's and 60's, and appearances were not deceptive. He was Sol Rubinow of Scarsdale, N.Y., who died Sunday at the age of 57.

title: U.S. AMBASSADOR TO 5 COUNTRIES
description: John Moors Cabot, United States Ambassador to five nations between 1954 and 1965 and author of three books on foreign affairs, died here yesterday after a stroke. He was 79 years old.

title: PALME SEES PROGRESS IN HIS IRAN-IRAQ PEACE MISSION
description: Olof Palme, the special United Nations envoy who has just ended his third inconclusive attempt to arrange peace between between Iraq and Iran, insists he is making headway.

title: British Jobless Rate Is 10.2%
description: Britain's jobless rate, already the highest since the Depression, rose by two-tenths of a percent to 10.2 percent this month, the Employment Department announced. It was the ninth consecutive monthly increase.

title: Penn Central Bid For GK Approved
description: Directors of GK Technologies have approved a takeover bid from the Penn Central Corporation valued at $720 million, or about $90 million more than Penn Central's initial offer last July, GK Technologies said today.

title: THE QUESTION OF LIFO VS. FIFO
description: Much of what is wrong with American management is most vividly evident in the way a great many companies account for their inventories. That, at least, is the contention of many respected observers of management practices, including Reginald H. Jones, chairman of the General Electric Company, and Peter F. Drucker, the author and consultant.

title: BOLGER SUPPORTS 9-DIGIT ZIP CODES AS WAY TO HOLD DOWN POSTAL COSTS
description: Postmaster General William F. Bolger told a Senate subcommittee today that the proposed nine-digit ZIP code was the best way to hold down the cost of mail service.

title: News Analysis
description: Although the Reagan Administration has responded with interest to Leonid I. Brezhnev's suggestion of a summit meeting, the Soviet leader's move has raised complications for the Administration's initial strategy of trying to rally support for a harder line toward Moscow.

title: BANK CONCERNS BACKED AS INVESTMENT ADVISERS
description: The Supreme Court lowered the legal barrier between the banking and securities industries today by ruling, 6 to 0, that bank holding companies may serve as investment advisers to closed-end investment companies.

title: I.R.S. SEEKING TO STEM REVOLT ON TAX WITHOLDING
description: The Detroit office of the Internal Revenue Service is moving to quash a burgeoning tax revolt reported among 3,500 Michigan workers, many in the automobile industry, who have avoided having income taxes withheld by claiming as many as 99 dependents.

title: Korvettes Nears Sale Of Six Sites
description: The Allied Stores Corporation and Caldor Inc. have emerged as the largest buyers thus far of department store sites owned by Korvettes Inc., with both companies close to concluding agreements to acquire three Korvettes stores apiece in the metropolitan area, executives of the companies said yesterday.

title: A QUIET DIGNITY DOMINATES AS JURY TELLS OF ITS DECISION
description: The murder trial of Jean S. Harris took 64 days, but when it ended tonight, it required less than 10 minutes for the jury to divest itself of the decision it had wrestled with through eight days of deliberation - guilty of murder.

title: Turkish Politician Charged With Bid for Islamic State
description: A state prosecutor today requested a prison term of 14 to 36 years for Necmettin Erbakan, an Islamic fundamentalist charged with trying to set up an Islamic state.

title: New Housing Off 25% in '80
description: New housing construction plunged 25 percent in 1980 from the year before for its worst performance since 1975, but gained 10 percent in the final quarter of the year, a survey by a business information group showed yesterday.

title: Guthrie and Dylan Songs At Cooper Union Friday
description: Songs by Woody Guthrie, Bob Dylan and other composers of folk and popular music will be performed by Oscar Brand and guests on Friday at 8 P.M. at the Cooper Union, Third Avenue and Seventh Street.

title: Theodore Thayer Dead; A Historian and Writer
description: Dr. Theodore Thayer, professor emeritus of history at Rutgers University in Newark, died Feb. 17 in Alpine, Calif. He was 76 years old and lived in Pasadena, Calif.

title: 1980 CALLED WORST YEAR OF CRIME IN CITY HISTORY
description: Last year was the worst year of crime in New York City history, the Police Department reported yesterday. There were more reported murders, robberies, burglaries and thefts of automobiles and other items than in any previous year since the department began compiling such statistics 49 years ago. In only two of seven categories that make up the crime index - rape and assault - were there declines.

title: SILAS F. SEADLER
description: Silas F. (Si) Seadler, for 40 years Eastern advertising manager for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures, died Feb. 19 in Poconos Hospital in Stroudsburg, Pa.

title: Georgetown Gets $100,000 After Returning Libya Gift
description: Georgetown University received a $100,000 donation today from an investment group that praised its decision to return a $600,000 gift from Libya on the ground that the African nation supports terrorism.

title: Marius Sznajderman Prints To Be at Cayman Gallery
description: A selection of woodcuts, serigraphs and monotypes created since 1971 by Marius Sznajderman, a Venezuela-trained painter and printmaker, of Hackensack, N.J., will be on display March 5 through 28 at the Cayman Gallery, 381 West Broadway.

title: NO-SALT COOKING: MUSHROOMS
description: IF you were to canvass any group of serious cooks and ask the name of the one basic ingredient best suited to a no-salt cookery, you would doubtless receive more answers than the components of a Macedonian salad. I would answer without pause: mushrooms.

title: BYRNE'S FILL-IN SAYS HE'LL SEEK JOB FULL TIME
description: Acting Gov. Joseph P. Merlino, who was substituting for Governor Byrne today for the 162d time, took the opportunity to announce that he wanted the job full time.

title: CITIBANK LOWERS PRIME
description: Citibank, the nation's second-largest commercial bank, yesterday joined most other major banks in lowering its prime lending rate to 19 percent, but failed to match the industry low. The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the nation's seventhlargest commercial bank, is the only one of the 20 largest banks with an 18 1/2 percent prime. It trimmed its rate a full percentage point, and some smaller banks have matched the rate.

title: IN MILAN, A DELICATESSEN AMONG THE FINEST
description: A four-store complex here called Peck has been built by the Stopani brothers into what is arguably Europe's best delicatessen. Unlike Fauchon in Paris, Peck avoids other people's food and a carriage-trade image, making 70 percent of its products itself. Unlike Dallmayr in Munich, it is not limited by its customers' tastes or its nation's cuisine.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO ALTER DECREE ON JOB TEST
description: The Reagan Administration today asked a Federal judge to approve revisions in a court settlement in which the Carter Administration had agreed to eliminate a widely used Civil Service examination that was alleged to discriminate against blacks and Hispanic Americans.

title: GEORGE UNDERWOOD
description: George Underwood, former president of Almay Inc., a New York cosmetics concern, died of a heart attack last Friday in Tampa, Fla. He was 51 years old and lived in Tampa and Park Ridge, N.J.

title: THEATER: 'CLOSE OF PLAY,' BY SIMON GRAY, OPENS
description: IN his best-known plays, Simon Gray places a witty, intellectual hero center stage and then ruthlessly reveals the barrenness of his soul. Mr. Gray's newest comedy, ''Close of Play,'' follows this formula, too - up to a point. The central character is Prof. Jasper Spencer, an esteemed classicist, a celebrated literary man, the recipient of royal honors. Like the younger professor-hero of ''Butley,'' and like Simon, the publisher-hero of ''Otherwise Engaged,'' Jasper finds himself invaded by a procession of visitors - all of whom, we come to realize, are victims of his selfish heart. Yet Jasper doesn't respond to his guests with scabrous insults, as Butley did, and he's not a cool cynic like Simon. Jasper is truly otherwise engaged - he appears to be dead.

title: PRETRIAL JAILING OF 'DANGEROUS' SUSPECTS
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger's recent assault on what he called a ''reign of terror'' by violent criminals has revived a longstanding national debate over whether bail laws should be changed to authorize judges to jail ''dangerous'' criminal defendants before trial.

title: FEB. 11-20 CAR SALES DOWN 23.7% AT BIG 3
description: Sales of the three major American auto makers fell 23.7 percent from the previous year's level in the middle 10 days of February despite the strong impact of rebates at the end of the period.

title: An Unexpected Reward for a Moral Stance
description: When he picked up the paper yesterday morning and read that Georgetown University, concerned about Libyan terrorism, had returned $600,000 that Libya had donated to the school, Alan Greenberg was impressed. So, he said, were the other members of the executive committee at Bear, Stearns & Company, the investment banking concern that Mr. Greenberg serves as chief executive officer.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Edward Robb Ellis lives contentedly with his bibliomania in the space people normally allow for their bookshelves. The rest of his Chelsea apartment is given over to his books - more than 8,000 of them lining shelves, resting on chairs, tables and sofas, stacked waist-high all over the living room, dominating the kitchen, the hallway and the bedroom, forming aisles between rooms.

title: STRIKING BUS DRIVERS AND TEACHERS DIRRUPT SCHOOL FOR 70,000 IN OHIO
description: 14 By The Associated Press

title: When Regulation Is Not the Enemy
description: ''American society experienced a virtual explosion in Government regulation during the past decade .... The result has been higher prices, higher unemployment and lower productivity growth.'' - President Reagan in his report to Congress. Anyone who has ever tried to design an acceptable stepladder, or plowed through the paperwork to set up a small pension plan, knows what Mr. Reagan means. Government involvement in business costs billions and, in some cases, adds little to the quality of life. But if regulation has gone to one extreme in the past, that is no reason to go to the other extreme now and embrace free markets uncritically.

title: Boston Edison Plans A Holding Company
description: The Boston Edison Company said it would reform itself as a holding company to diversify into other energy operations, including possible gas and oil exploration.

title: Westvaco Earnings Rise
description: The Westvaco Corporation, a major producer of paper, packaging and chemicals, reported yesterday that earnings in the first fiscal quarter of 1981, ended Jan. 31, rose 5.4 percent, to $19.6 million, or $1.15 a share, from $18.6 million, or $1.10 a share, in the corresponding fiscal quarter a year ago. Sales increased 9.5 percent, to $362.3 million, from $330.9 million.

title: DAY CARE AND THE WORKING PARENT
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: One of the Soviet leadership's biggest complaints about Jimmy Carter was that he did not understand the uses of secrecy. Diplomatic initiatives, the men in the Kremlin used to say, cannot begin in public; they must be carefully explored in private beforehand.

title: NON-MANHATTANITES NEED NOT APPLY
description: To the Editor:

title: 'I HAD DREAMS OF BECOMING A MILLIOAIRE...'
description: To the Editor:

title: Soupe aux Champignons (Mushroom soup)
description: 4 tablespoons butter 1 cup coarsely chopped onion 1 cup finely chopped celery, optional 1 1/4 pounds mushrooms, thinly sliced, about 7 cups Juice of 1 lemon 1/4 cup flour 6 cups rich, unsalted chicken, veal or beef broth (see recipe) Freshly ground black pepper to taste 1/4 cup dry Sherry wine.

title: EX-CHIEF OF CARE GETS YEAR IN JAIL
description: The former executive director of CARE was sentenced to a year in jail for pocketing $110,000 of the relief agency's funds, according to United Press International. The sentence was imposed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Louis Samia, 56 years old, of Katonah, N.Y., by Justice George F. Roberts, who accepted Mr. Samia's guilty plea last Nov. 13. An investigation disclosed the theft after Mr. Samia resigned f rom his post last May, and he subsequently was indicted on grand l arceny charges.

title: Dow Edges Higher; Volume Up
description: The stock market, buoyed by lower interest rates, made a small advance yesterday in more active trading. In the last two days, most of the nation's banks cut the prime rate to 19 percent from 19 1/2 percent. Several institutions cut the rates they charge their key corporate customers to 18 1/2 percent.

title: REAGAN'S ACTS TO ENFORCE CARTER'S IRAN AGREEMENT
description: President Reagan today ordered the suspension of lawsuits involving claims against Iran that may qualify for international arbitration, and the Treasury Department issued detailed regulations implementing the hostage release agreement with Iran.

title: Oh, What a 'Beautiful Marriage'
description: When Molloy College, a women's school in Rockville Centre, L.I., needed someone to lead the fund-raising effort for its new performing arts center, it turned, appropriately enough, to a performing artist, Joan Roberts, a neighbor who had wowed Broadway in 1943 as the original leading lady of ''Oklahoma!''.

title: BUCKLEY'S 'FIRING LINE' CELEBRATES 15 YEARSS
description: CONVERSATION, the Spanish philosopher Jose Ortega y Gasset once remarked, ''is the socializing instrument par excellence.'' Yesterday conversation was in particularly fine form at the New York Yacht Club, where about 300 of its finest practitioners gathered to celebrate the 15th anniversary of ''Firing Line,'' William F. Buckley Jr.'s weekly colloquy, telecast by the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: PRINCE CHARLES TO WED 19-YEAR-OLD FAMILY FRIEND
description: Buckingham Palace, giving the British people some news that they have waited years to hear, today announced the engagement of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer, a 19-year-old aristocrat who has been a friend of the royal family all her life.

title: BIDDING IS SUSPENDED
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority invoked a state law yesterday for the first time and declared a 90-day ''emergency'' in subway and bus service. The board's action suspended competitive bidding for the purchase of equipment and maintenance supplies and gave the authority to make those purchases to John D. Simpson, the president of the Transit Authority.

title: Berlin Court Rejects a Bid To Free Rudolf Hess
description: A high civil court ruled today that the West German Government was not under a legal obligation to obtain the release of Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's onetime deputy, who is serving a life term in Spandau Prison.

title: Arkansas 47, S.M.U. 33
description: Scott Hastings scored 13 points as Arkansas foiled Southern Methodist's slowdown in the second half and posted a 47-33 victory that gave the Razorbacks their fourth Southwest Conference title in the last five years.

title: New York Juvenile-Offender Law Is Opposed by Citizens' Coalition
description: New York State's juvenile-offender law now forces youths to wait months for court action, then sends most of them back to Family Court or into the streets, a citizens' coalition charged today.

title: PRIMARIES VS. THE DEMOCRATIC PROCESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Lakers 107, Bulls 97
description: Norm Nixon scored 24 points and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Jamaal Wilkes got 23 apiece to lead Los Angeles over the Bulls. After the Bulls overcame a 9-point deficit to grab a 43-42 advantage in the second quarter, the lead changed hand 19 times before Wilkes sank two free throws and a jumper to give the Lakers the lead for good, 73-69, late in the third quarter.

title: STRINGS: TOKYO QUARTET IN A PREMIERE
description: OF the Japanese composers who have emerged on the international scene since World War II, Toru Takemitsu is the best known in this country, and perhaps the best. His Requiem for Strings, ''November Steps'' and ''Green'' made the rounds of the major orchestras a decade or so ago; record collectors know a few pieces such as his ''Asterism'' and ''Stanza I,'' and film enthusiasts may recognize him as the composer of music for ''Woman in the Dunes,'' among other films. Those works, however, hardly scratch the skin of Mr. Takemitsu's substantial body of work. In fact, like many of his Western colleagues, he has spent the last 30 years or so in trying on one compositional style after another, like a dandy who has been let loose overnight in a tailor's shop.

title: Careers; The Trend To Later Retirement
description: LIKE an early election return that indicates a trend, the consensus is gradually emerging that more people nearing retirement age plan to keep their jobs longer.

title: Riggs Requests Halt In Bid by Allbritton
description: The Riggs National Bank of Washington asked a Federal court today for an emergency injunction to prevent the former publisher of The Washington Star from gaining control of the bank.

title: Eugene Wilson, 75, of Amherst; Dean of Admissions in 1946-72
description: Eugene S. Wilson, dean of admissions emeritus of Amherst College, died yesterday at his home in Amherst, Mass., at the age of 75. Mr. Wilson was a native of St. Louis. He was graduated from the Deerfield Academy in Massachusetts and, in 1929, from Amherst.

title: MOSHE NATHANSON
description: Moshe Nathanson, cantor emeritus of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism at 15 West 86th Street in Manhattan, died yesterday at his Manhattan home at the age of 82.

title: ORDER MAY CUT NUMBER OF CITY JAIL INMATES
description: The chairman of the state's Commission of Correction said yesterday that New York City would soon be ordered to reduce the number of inmates in its overcrowded jails. That order, he said, could lead to the release of several hundred inmates held on Rikers Island and in the city's four other big jails.

title: DAY CARE AND THE WORKING PARENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Don Maloney: A Scorer Despite Himself
description: Don Maloney, the 22-year-old New York Ranger left wing, has been scoring goals in recent weeks as if he were born to do so. He probably wasn't.

title: Princess
description: There is a country called Britain that has high unemployment, inflation and taxes. It now occupies a small space in the world.

title: Leek and Potato Soup
description: 2 large leeks 4 or 5 medium potatoes (1 pound) 1 slice bacon 2 tablespoons butter 2 cups chicken broth Salt Freshly ground pepper 1 cup milk 2 tablespoons minced parsley Caerphilly or Cheddar cheese, grated.

title: ROBERT S. ALLEN, POLITICAL COLUMNIST
description: Robert S. Allen, a co-founder of The Washington Merry-Go-Round, one of the first Washington investigative columns, died Monday in his Georgetown home. He was 80 years old.

title: Death Penalty Bill Is Pressed by Koch
description: Mayor Koch sent letters to members of the Assembly urging them to override Governor's Carey's expected veto of a death penalty bill passed by the Assembly, 91 to 51.

title: MET MUSEUM OPENS ASSYRIAN GALLERY
description: WITH the opening today of the Raymond and Beverly Sackler Gallery for Assyrian Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has returned its great collection of ancient Assyrian stone sculpture to public view after an absence of 13 years. The Assyrian collection, consisting of 20 large reliefs and two massive carvings from the palace of King Assurnasirpal II in Nimrud, in what is now northern Iraq, is one of the museum's outstanding treasures in Ancient Near Eastern Art. It was removed from public view in 1968 when construction began on the new permanent installation of the Egyptian collection.

title: Conservatives Win Election In Kuwait by a Landslide
description: Conservative, pro-Government candidates won a landslide victory today in Kuwait's parliamentary election, dealing a resounding defeat to radical Arab nationalist politicians and supporters of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader.

title: THE CITY
description: A 24-year-old man was shot and wounded by an off-duty corrections officer last night, moments after the man allegedly attempted to rob the officer's wife in a Brooklyn subway station, the police reported.

title: PENN SETS BACK PRINCETON, 52-43
description: Penn relied on its free-throw shooting in the second half and a stifling defense to gain a 52-43 victory over Princeton tonight in an important Ivy League game at the Palestra.

title: Cash-Payment Discount Bill
description: The House voted today to make it easier for merchants to give shoppers discounts for paying with cash or checks instead of using credit cards.

title: Focus on Drugs
description: The use of heavy and dangerous narcotics is growing, yet the Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control will be fighting for its life in the House today. The House committee has been working for four years; it deserves to do so for another two.

title: TV: HAWAIIAN 'ALOHA PARADISE' AND FOREST 'FAERIES'
description: ''ALOHA, PARADISE,'' a series entering the ABC lineup tonight at 8 o'clock with a special two-hour premiere, is ''The Love Boat'' beached in Hawaii. Instead of a floating luxury liner captained by Gavin McLeod, we get a lush resort hotel managed by Debbie Reynolds. Each episode will feature several subplots, churned out by different writers and pasted together with a host of second-echelon stars.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: WHEN you go to the dentist, you're usually told to ''open wide.'' But in a proper dental examination, you should also be told to ''close,'' so that the dentist can see how your teeth come together.

title: MEXICAN LEADER CRITICIZES EFFORTS FOR MILITARY SOLUTION IN SALVADOR
description: President Jose Lopez Portillo last night criticized efforts to resolve El Salvador's internal crisis by military means and argued that only a political settlement could prevent the conflict from spreading elsewhere in Central America.

title: THE CITYPhones
description: Rainwater that seeped into a telephone cable line through an apparent ''pinhole'' knocked out telephone service at several businesses in mid-Manhattan, a spokesman for the New York Telephone Company said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He met Miss Right and she met Mr. Right. They just clicked.''

title: BAGS AND BUTTERFLIES, AN OVEN HOOK AND LETTERHEADS
description: Noel Aurell and Ferdinand Di Gennaro are a design team whose specialty is hand-painted furniture. Lately, they have applied the same techniques of building and painting tables and chests to handbags. The result is a series of box-shaped bags made of lightweight wood which are attractive both to carry or to display as objects. Mr. Di Gennaro, who used to do architectural renovation, constructs the bags, while Miss Aurell paints them in wavy stripes of color combined with black, using seven layers of paint. The insides of the bags are as interesting as the outside: they're lined with unusual printed paper the couple found in North Africa. Pizazz, at 1266 Madison Avenue (between 90th and 91st Streets) has the bag illustrated for $90.

title: Reversal by Korchnoi
description: The Soviet-born grandmaster Viktor Korchnoi said yesterday that he had given up plans to scuttle next summer's scheduled world championship chess match as a way of dramatizing the plight of his family in the Soviet Union.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allstate Insurance Companies, Northbrook, Ill., has named Donald B. Cameron president of its training and research subsidiary, TechCor Inc.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday on AM International Inc. incorrectly stated two of the company's balance sheet items. The company had $104.8 million in long-term debt and stockholder equity of $231.9 million at the end of its 1980 fiscal year.

title: Clabir Gains 7.7% Of U.S. Industries
description: The Clabir Corporation, a precision instrument and food services company, said that it had acquired 7.7 percent of United States Industries Inc., a much larger company, and might attempt to purchase a controlling interest.

title: CAREY SEES 'REGIONAL BIAS' IN REAGAN PLAN
description: Governor Carey today attacked portions of President Reagan's budget program as ''obnoxious'' and ''regionally biased'' against the Northeast. He said New York State might lose $700 million in Federal aid in the forthcoming fiscal year if Congress approved all of the President's reductions.

title: HUGE NEW G.M. PLANT, LIKA MANY, TO GET SUBSIDIES
description: Last June the General Motors Corporation announced, to immense joy in Detroit, that if the city could find a suitable site the corporation would construct an assembly plant as part of a $40 billion modernization program, described as one of the most extensive in American business history.

title: Aluminum Suit By Australians
description: An Australian environmentalist group today filed a Federal court suit here in an attempt to block the Aluminum Company of America and the Reynolds Metals Company from expanding a $2 billion bauxite mining and refining operation in Western Australia.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard CITIES OF THE RED NIGHT. By William S. Burroughs. 332 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.95.

title: Oregon State Tops 2 Polls
description: Oregon State regained the top position yesterday in The Associated Press's college-basketball poll of sportswriters and broadcasters, marking the first time in a month that one team has been atop both wire-service rankings.

title: News Analysis
description: Do prisoners have rights? If so, what are they? The questions have long troubled prison officials, legislators, judges, lawyers and others involved with the correction process, as well as prisoners themselves.

title: Westchester Sheriff Fights Suspension
description: Attorneys for the suspended Commissioner/ Sheriff of Westchester County, Thomas J. Delaney, served the county with a show-cause order asking that the suspension be nullified on the ground that the County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, did not have the authority to suspend Mr. Delaney.

title: SPAIN REJOICES OVER SURVIVAL OF DEMOCRACY
description: A late sun, striking along the gentle incline down to the Prado Museum, lit up the Parliament building this afternoon. Television crews from a dozen different countries arranged their cameras and correspondents to get it into focus.

title: AN OLD ESTONIAN TRADITION: PANCAKES FOR SHROVE TUESDAY
Aid Increased To British Steel
description: The British Government will increase aid to the state-owned British Steel Corporation by $339 million, to $2.5 billion, in the current financial year, Industry Secretary Keith Joseph told Parliament today.

title: EL SALVADOR SAYS IT CAN DEFEAT REBELS
description: Salvadoran military leaders here say they can defeat the guerrillas trying to overthrow the Government despite a Pentagon report that describes their army as a ''19th-century constabulary'' that has ''no hope'' of winning the war.

title: REAGAN PLAN: A NEW THEOLOGY
description: Among the lobbyists packed into the opening Congressional hearings today on President Reagan's economic program was Andrew Sundberg, an economic consultant who flew in from Switzerland for an event that he found oddly reassuring. He listened to all the confident testimony about ''static econometric models'' and ''passive income'' and left more convinced than ever that great doubt and wonder is the stuff of economics.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate, 18.50-19.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: McEnroe Upset by Waltke In Memphis by 6-3, 6-4
description: Trey Waltke stunned John McEnroe, the defending champion, by 6-3, 6-4 tonight in the second round of the $200,000 United States indoor tennis championships.

title: OUTLAWS RIDE WITH GUITARS
description: THE OUTLAWS, who played the Palladium last Friday and Saturday, rank among the more commercially successful of the countless Southern rock bands to form in the wake of the Allman Brothers Band and Lynyrd Skynyrd.

title: Greyhound's Choice To Revive Armour
description: John W. Teets, the 48-year-old executive that the Greyhound Corporation on Monday named chairman of its most troubled subsidiary, Armour & Company, has long displayed a kind of impatient aggressiveness.

title: DAY CARE AND THE WORKING PARENT
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOUNGING

title: BROWNE-FORMAN NET IS UP
description: The Browne-Forman Distillers Corporation announced yesterday that net income in the fiscal quarter ended Jan 31 rose 29..2 percent to $17.7 million, or $1.40 s share, from $13.7 million, or $1.08 a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

title: Mistaken
description: Those help-wanted notices for technical jobs, the sort of ads that appear in The Times and The Wall Street Journal, may seem to be written in a foreign language. What, for example, does Arlington County, Va., mean when it advertises for an ''Urban Revitalization Facilitator''? How should one interpret United Technologies' plea for professionals interested in ''shipboard sensor correlation with the AN/SYS automatic detection and tracking system''?

title: CIVIL GUARD COLONEL GIVES UP AS KING KEEPS ARMY'S BACKING
description: Spain's rightist military uprising collapsed today, 18 hours after it began. A mutinous lieutenant colonel in the Civil Guard ended the occupation of the lower house of Parliament and freed its more than 300 members, including the nation's political leadership.

title: Diva Disk Jockey
description: The folks at New York City's municipal radio station thought it would be a good idea to get Anna Moffo, the opera star, to help with the station's fund-raising efforts.

title: Daon Development Seeks Robert Dollar
description: The Daon Development Corporation, a Canadian development company with active interests in several Sun Belt states, confirmed that it was negotiating to buy the Robert Dollar Company, a San Francisco lumber concern that controls nearly a full block of San Francisco financial district property and 56,000 acres of Oregon timberland.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday incorrectly identified the brother of the Rev. Daniel Berrigan. His name is Philip.

title: Shooting Erupts at Rome Airport; 4 Are Injured and 5 Are Arrested
description: Four people were injured today when shooting broke out in the arrival lounge at Fiumicino Airport, the police reported.

title: HIGH LIFE IN THE OPAL OFFICE
description: Hardly anyone recalls the momentous military and political events of the reign of Louis XIV, but everyone remembers that the Sun King lived in staggering splendor at Versailles. Will future generations similarly recollect the prince of the Sun Belt, Ronald Reagan, mainly for his life style?

title: THE WELSH CELEBRATE A SAINT AND THE LEEK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Evan Jones, a Welshman, is the author of ''The World of Cheese'' (Knopf) and ''A Food Lover's Companion'' (Harper & Row). His ''American Food: The Gastronomic Story'' is being issued in a revised edition by Random House (hard cover) and Vintage Books (paperback). By EVAN JONES

title: EX-REP. BRADEMAS IS APPOINTED BY N.Y.U. TO BE 13TH PRESIDENT
description: New York University yesterday chose former Representative John Brademas, Democrat of Indiana, to be the school's 13th president. The 53-year old Mr. Brademas, who was majority whip in the House of Representatives until he was defeated in last fall's Republican landslide, will succeed John C. Sawhill, who resigned last summer after six years in the post. The new president is expected to take over at the country's largest private university at the end of the current academic year.

title: Index; International
description: Pope flies to Hiroshima to deliver speech on world peace A2 Israel makes it a crime to publish private correspondence A2 Polish leader seeks to assure Soviet party congress A3 Despite U.S. view, Salvadorans say rebels can be defeated A4 Around the World A5 Palme says he is making progress in Iran-Iraq peace mission A9 Coalition attacks Reagan's choice for human rights job A10 Government/Politics Reagan aides are divided over education grants A16 Bolger testifies to Senate commit- tee on nine-digit ZIP code A16 Court voids change in prison ''good time'' law A18 City may be ordered to cut num- ber of inmates in jails B7 Jersey's Acting Governor to seek the job full time B7 General Around the Nation A12 General Motors plant, like many, would get public subsidies A12 Promoter in Wells Fargo case re- ported set to come forward A12 Pilot's wife lands plane after hus- band dies at controls A13 Albert Victory, escaped killer of a policeman, captured on Coast A28 After verdict, Jean Harris is put under ''suicide watch'' at jail B2 Sketches of jury members in Westchester trial B2 Mrs.Harris takes verdict with dig- nity B3 Medfical examiner calls deaths of 2 L.I. boys unrelated B3 Obituaries John Moore Cabot, retired Am- bassador B6 Robert S. Allen, a syndicated col- umnist in Washington B6 Ilo Browne Wallace, widow of Vice President Henry Wallace B6 The Living Section Food Wine Talk: Tasting showdown for 1961 Bordeaux C1

title: WOMAN LANDS PLANE AS HUSBAND DIES AT CONTROLS
description: Her husband was slumped over dead in the seat next to her; the plane was wobbling out of control, and Judy Newton did not know how to fly.

title: Expansion Planned For Airport in Jersey
description: ATLANTIC CITY (UPI) - Officials announced plans yesterday to expand the Federal Aviation Administration's airport in Pomona, a move they say is needed to handle the expected increase in commercial air traffic to Atlantic City because of casino gambling.

title: PHILIPPINE MAYOR WAGES WAR ON SIN NEAR U.S. BASE
description: ''People call Olangapo sin city,'' said Richard J. Gordon, the 35-year-old Mayor of this community of 200,000 people connected with the United States naval base at Subic Bay.

title: Gasoline Spill Sets Off Blast
description: A tanker truck overturned yesterday at the toll plaza of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, spilling 1,500 gallons of unleaded gas into the city sewer system and touching off a minor explosion in a nearby home, the police said. There were no injuries reported.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan's Script Draws Skeptics
description: THE main question people are asking about President Reagan's economic program is: ''Will it work?'' The question, of course, assumes that Congress will adopt the program pretty much as the President has proposed it. But even if the President gets nearly all he wants from Congress, he has warned the public not to expect a swift cure for the economy's ills.

title: RESTAURANT GLADDENS CARIBBEAN STOPOVER
description: ST. MARTIN THERE must be a good deal to be said for the charms of St. Martin, for those who dwell here or visit in the homes of friends seem to dote on it. But as a casual tourist who happens to spend a few hours here each year en route to another destination in the Caribbean, I have never been one of its greatest boosters. I find its two capitals, Marigot on the French side and Philipsburg on the Dutch, equally languorous, commercially oriented and uninteresting.

title: Mistrial Declared on Coast In 2d Trial of Hells Angels
description: A mistrial was declared today in the second racketeering and conspiracy trial of 11 members and associates of the Hells Angels motorcycle club because the jury said it was hopelessly deadlocked.

title: ILO BROWNE WALLACE, 92, WIDOW OF A VICE PRESIDENT TO ROOSEVELT
description: Ilo Browne Wallace, widow of Henry A. Wallace, the former Vice President and Cabinet officer, died Sunday at the Wallace farm in South Salem, N.Y., her family said last night. She was 92 years old.

title: The Economy
description: Lower prices may result from the end of controls on gasoline, at least temporarily, but consumer groups worry that a lessening of competition will eventually lead to higher prices. Industry officials said thousands of wholesalers and retailers may be driven out of business by big operators. (Page A1.)

title: STEINBRENNER DISPUTES JACKSON
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, paid his first visit of the spring to Fort Lauderdale Stadium today. Seated in the dugout with a friend, Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, Steinbrenner held court for an hour, and talked about his contract negotiations with Reggie Jackson, his quest for a right-handed starting pitcher, his predictions for the 1981 race in the American League East and his opinions about a possible baseball strike.

title: Not All Wet Yet
description: Yes, it has been raining in New York City and on the watersheds upstate. The water level in the reservoirs has recovered from the frightening lows of below 30 percent to 58 percent of capacity.

title: Law Student Seized As N.Y.U. Arsonist
description: A 27-year-old law student was arrested in connection with attempts to set fires in her residence hall at New York University in Greenwich Village.

title: GIBSON'S JOB: MAKE METS'STAFF AGGRESSIVE
description: ''Bob Gibson wasn't just unfriendly when he was a pitcher,'' Joe Torre remembered today. ''I'd say he was more like hateful. And that's his job here: to teach the Mets' pitchers to be intimidating.''

title: Brezhnev: Let's Talk It Over
description: Secretary of State Haig said the United States was ''very interested'' in the Soviet Union's proposal for a Reagan-Brezhnev meeting and would study it ''very, very carefully,'' but he sounded a little wary.

title: Rep. Spellman's Seat Held Vacant Over Illness Since Heart Attack
description: The House today declared vacant the seat of Representative Gladys Noonan Spellman, Democrat of Maryland, who has been in a ''sleep-like'' state since she suffered a heart attack last year.

title:
RED SMITH;
Brian Oldfield, Return of the Native
description: BRIAN OLDFIELD has two California driver's licenses. One bears a color photograph of a bull-necked young American with light-brown curls in fairly neat array and an expression of manly resolution on his clean-shaven face. The other has a portrait that could be mistaken for John Teach, the pirate chief known as Blackbeard. The mass of uncombed curls grows down to the eyebrows, and below that is shrubbery dense enough to conceal a covey of quail. This is the Brian Oldfield who has thrown a 16-pound ball of lead farther than anyone else in the world and will endeavor to do it again in the U.S.A./Mobil indoor track and field championships in Madison Square Garden Friday.

title: 3 AIR-TRAFFIC CONTROL CENTERS BEGIN USE OF ELECTRONIC BACKUP SYSTEM
description: The Federal Aviation Administration announced yesterday that three of the nation's 20 traffic-control centers had begun use of a new electronic backup system designed to take over in case of failures of radar computers.

title: Bids for Abitibi Delayed to March 4
description: The Ontario Securities Commission, ruling that a joint Thomson Newspapers/Nu-West Group Ltd. tender offer for Abitibi-Price Ltd. constituted an inside bid, delayed until March 4 the last round in a takeover fight for the big newsprint producer. The $31-a-share offer (Canadian) for 45 percent of Abitibi, valued at $263.5 million, is an insider bid because two Thomson newspaper executives are Abitibi directors, the commission ruled.

title: BOXING FIGURE IN WELLS FARGO CASE IS REPORTED READY TO LEAVE HIDING
description: The attorney for the missing boxing promoter Harold J. Smith said today that he had opened negotiations with Federal investigators to arrange for his client to ''present himself'' for questioning about the $21.3 million that the Wells Fargo National Bank charges has been embezzled.

title: Advertising; Jamaica Tourist Board Is Talking to Agencies
description: Reliable sources report that the Jamaica Tourist Board, whose agency is Intermarco Advertising, is talking to other advertising agencies about a $6 million account.

title: SUIT TO ALLEGE SEX BIAS BY TV AND FILM MAKERS
description: Charges of sex discrimination against the 3 major commercial television networks, 6 large movie studios and 11 important independent television production companies will be filed tomorrow with Federal and state agencies by the Directors Guild of America.

title: BEST BUYS
description: DURING the first two weeks of February the average cost of feeding a family of four in New York jumped by 94 cents to a record high of $102.66, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs. The increase was blamed on higher energy costs.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN a recent column, I proposed that a first course for a 60-minute meal was by no means unthinkable, and, in fact, was thoroughly feasible. I gave as an example one of my own favorite first courses, leeks vinaigrette.

title: Advertising; New Way To Classify Consumers
description: HAPPINESS for advertisers, their agencies and the media is being able to typecast you. If you are this old, make this much money and have this kind of personality then you are likely to watch this kind of TV show and read this kind of magazine or newspaper, the advertising industry reasons.

title: TONY ORLANDO TO FILL IN FOR JIM DALE IN 'BARNUM'
description: TONY ORLANDO will replace Jim Dale in ''Barnum'' for three weeks in May while Mr. Dale vacations. The notion, according to Cy Coleman, who wrote the music for ''Barnum'' and is its co-producer, is to turn Mr. Orlando's appearance into ''an event.'' Mr. Orlando, who became famous with television's ''Tony Orlando and Dawn,'' has never appeared on a legitimate stage.

title: PASTA ROLLING PINS
description: AS pasta-making at home becomes so popular that it resembles family recreation, it seems to me that the pasta-making cooks are dividing into two camps. There are those who are thrilled with their handcranked or electric pasta machines as they turn out piles of pasta that is immeasurably better than the mass produced, dried and boxed product.

title: OFFICE MARKET IMPROVES IN THE GRAND CENTRAL SOUTH AREA
description: From afar the Manhattan office market looks like a cloth of one piece, with an estimated 275 million square feet of rentable space in buildings either existing or under construction. But from close up it is a collection of submarkets.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES ADDS 11 ROUTES IN EXPANSION
description: American Airlines announced a sweeping expansion of its route system yesterday, mainly in the South and Southwest, which will substantially increase its air traffic at the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport, a key hub of its operations.

title: SKETCHES OF MEMBERS OF JURY THAT RETURNED VERDICT OF GUILTY IN WESTCHESTER
description: The 12 jurors who deliberated eight days in the Jean S. Harris murder trial before reaching a verdict today were selected over a two-week period in November from a pool of more than 1,000 potential jurors. Chosen in the order indicated below, they began hearing the testimony of more than 90 witnesses on Nov. 21. Much of the biographical information was drawn from answers given during the selection process. The numbers before the jurors' names correspond with the numbers on the sketch. 1. Russell E. Von Glahn Foreman

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1981
description: International Spain's rightist uprising collapsed after 18 hours as a mutinous lieutenant colonel in the Civil Guard ended the seizure of Parliament and released the nation's political leaders. Exhausted and tearful, the legislators filed out of the building after the colonel surrendered to superior officers. Earlier, Civil Guardsmen abandoned him and leaped out of windows. King Juan Carlos, who denounced the attempted uprising, had rallied key military commanders to his side. (Page A1, Column 6.) Spain's young democracy was bruised but joyous over its survival. The 18-hour ordeal was punctuated by radio reports about the loyalty of military units. All the major political parties deplored the seizure of Parliament and backed King Juan Carlos and the democratic Constitution. (A7:1.)

title: Advertising; Hirsh Picks Reis-Michael For Jennifer O'Neill Line
description: Hirsh-Evans, a clothing manufacturer, is going to put a $2 million promotion budget behind its new Jennifer O'Neill separates collection.

title: Former 49er Is Slain
description: Bruce Rhodes, a former defensive back for the San Francisco 49ers, was shot to death last night near Candlestick Park. Rhodes's wife, Iris, was critically injured in the shooting. Rhodes was found dead in the driveway of a house he was visiting.

title: COALITION ASSAILS REAGAN'S CHOICE FOR STATE DEPT. HUMAN RIGHTS JOB
description: President Reagan's nomination of Ernest W. Lefever to be Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs was condemned today by a coalition that advocates increased international efforts to foster human rights.

title: SAVING SALVADOR
description: The Administration seems headed toward disaster in El Salvador. Its obsessive concern to demonstrate that the United States can no longer be pushed around by the Soviet Union and Cuba has tied our prestige to the survival of a brutal military regime. In so doing, it is inviting a confrontation from which, no matter what the outcome, Moscow will emerge a winner.

title: GRAMMYS: HONORING ART OR COMMERCIAL SUCCESS?
description: THE Grammy Awards Show, the American record industry's annual ceremony of self-congratulation, is back in New York City this year, after five years in Los Angeles. CBS-TV will broadcast the 23d Grammy Awards ceremony from Radio City Music Hall tonight at 9 P.M.; for two hours of prime time, top recording stars will exchange repartee, perform their hits and present one another with awards ''for outstanding artistic and technical achievements in the recording field.''

title: Scott Paper's Spending Plans
description: The Scott Paper Company, a leading paper-products manufacturer based in Philadelphia, said yesterday that it would spend $2 billion for capital projects over the next five years, including plans for major projects at its plants in several states.

title: WHY ABOLISH THE STATE LIQUOR AUTHORITY?
description: To the Editor:

title: Macy's Earnings Up
description: R.H. Macy & Company, operator of Macy's department stores, reported second-quarter earnings yesterday of $59.5 million, or $3.68 a share, up 8 percent from $55.2 million, or $3.49 a share, in the 1980 second quarter. Sales climbed 10 percent, to $846.9 million, from $797.3 million in the 1980 quarter, the company said. The company also raised its quarterly dividend to 43.75 cents per common share, payable April 1 to holders of record March 13, from 37.5 cents for the previous quarter.

title: REX WEYANT
description: Rex Weyant, traveling secretary for the New York Yankees from 1942-45 died Feb 15 in Springfield, Mass. He was 75 years old.

title: DURABLES ORDERS OFF IN JANUARY
description: New orders for American-made durable goods fell 2.2 percent in January, the first decline in four months, the Commerce Department reported today. The department put the total value of new orders at $80.9 billion, $1.8 billion less than the $82.6 billion figure in December.

title: Reservoirs at 58%
description: With reservoirs at their highest levels since the fall because of heavy rains and continued cutbacks in water consumption, New York City officials raised the possibility yesterday that Phase 2 of the drought emergency - involving stricter conservation measures and tentatively scheduled to go into effect April 1 - might be postponed.

title: WATT PLEDGES PROJECTS FOR WATER RESOURCES BUT NOT TILL LATE '82
description: The Secretary of the Interior, James G. Watt, said today that the Reagan Administration was committed to developing the nation's water resources but could not afford to propose any new projects because of the poor state of the economy.

title: Marini Helps Revive Islanders' Fortunes
description: With his Buffalo Bill-length black hair and his flowing mustache, Hector Marini fit right into this frontier city when he landed with the Islanders today.

title: U.S. AIDES SPLIT OVER EDUCATION GRANTS
description: Top officials in the Reagan Administration are sharply divided over whether to bar states and localities from using proposed Federal block grants for education to supplant local financing for schools.

title: EXTENDING THE USES OF THE RUBBER BAND
description: Onion growers in California use rubber bands to mark the different grades of scallions. Furniture manufacturers in North Carolina use them to keep sofa flounces from dragging across dirty warehouse floors. Lobster fishermen have found that rubber bands are better than wooden pegs in holding a lobster's claws closed.

title: Mayor's 'Village' Club Encourages Opposition
description: Leaders of the club that launched Mayor Koch into politics - the Village Independent Democrats - have approved a resolution urging ''candidates in addition to the incumbent to run.''

title: POLICEMAN'S KILLER CAPTURED ON COAST
description: Albert Victory, a convicted murderer who bribed two New York prison guards to be taken to his girlfriend's hotel room and then gave them the slip almost three years ago, was captured yesterday in a house outside San Francisco.

title: Heavy Capital Rain Forces Closing of Union Station
description: Heavy rains that poured through the roof of 73-year-old Union Station have forced the National Park Service to close the station as unsafe.

title: 2 BOYS' DEATHS UNRELATED NASSAU OFFICIAL DECLARES
description: Findings from medical tests yesterday showed that the deaths of two young boys who attended the Chestnut Hill School in Dix Hills, L.I., were ''definitely unrelated,'' according to Dr. Minoru Araki, deputy chief medical examiner of Nassau County.

title: Wife of Clippers Owner Dies in Traffic Accident
description: Michelle Levin, wife of the San Diego Clippers owner, Irv Levin, died today after a traffic accident on a rain-slick street in the suburban hillside community of Bel Air, the police said.

title: 3 Slain in Bronx Apartment
description: Two men and a woman were shot to death early yesterday in a Bronx apartment in a dispute with an assailant over a drug deal, the police said. The bodies of the three, all in their 20's, were found at 2270 Walton Avenue in the Fordham section after neighbors called the police to report a shooting about 4:40 A.M.

title: OFFER MADE TO FINISH WATER TUNNEL
description: The chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York has proposed to Governor Carey that the agency buy and complete Water Tunnel No. 3 in New York City.

title: A Little Sanity, Please
description: A gentleman who is all wet writes to ask why his umbrella is always missing when he has to go out in the rain. He has asked the right man. Stimulated by the late Bill Vaughan's seminal work on the history of the umbrella, I have spent years studying this curious invention and have in fact recently been elected chairman of the National Bumbershoot Academy.

title: Fairfield 86, Fairleigh 71
description: With Hank Foster scoring a careerhigh 27 points and Mike Palazzi adding 22, Fairfield rolled to an 86-71 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson tonight.

title: The Mortar of Monarchy in Spain
description: It could have been a Spanish tragedy; it turned out to be opera bouffe. A takeover of Parliament by the Civil Guard ended in less than a day with all captives safely released. ''The only thing that will happen,'' said the colonel who led the attempted coup, ''is that I will have to pay with 30 or 40 years in prison.'' It would be nice to forget the matter entirely and join with the freed members of Parliament in exclaiming, ''Long live democracy!''

title: Date for Strike Expected Today
description: The executive committee of the Major League Baseball Players Association meets today in Tampa, Fla., and is expected to set a strike date.

title: CONGRESS TAKES UP FISCAL PLAN
description: One after another, Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee expressed doubts today about various aspects of President Reagan's proposals to cut taxes and spending, but they offered no Democratic alternative.

title: Supreme Court in Florida Rejects Plea to Bar Execution Next Week
description: The Florida Supreme Court unanimously refused late today to block the execution of a convicted murderer, Thomas Otis Knight, scheduled for March 3.

title: Kerkorian Seems Odd Man Out In Fight for Control of Fox Film
description: One of the apparent losers in the competition for control of 20th Century-Fox Film Company has been the financier Kirk Kerkorian, who owns 47 percent of the M-G-M Film Company and 50 percent of MGM Grand Hotels.

title: MRS. HARRIS FOUND GUILTY OF MURDER AND SHE IS QUICKLY REMOVED TO JAIL
description: Jean S. Harris was convicted tonight of murder in the second degree in the multiple shooting of her companion and lover for 14 years, Dr. Herman Tarnower. Judge Russell R. Leggett set March 20 for sentencing.

title: DEERE OFF 39.6%; MCA, 39.4%
description: Deere & Company, the world's leading producer of farm equipment, reported yesterday that lower industrial equipment sales contributed to an earnings decline of 39.6 percent on a sales drop of 3.6 percent in the first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31.

title: C.B.O.E. Backed On Ginnie Maes
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday gave the Chicago Board Options Exchange permission to trade options on Government National Mortgage Association mortgagebacked securities, known as Ginnie Maes. The decision represents the agency's first approval of exchange trading in a nonstock option.

title: TASTING SHOWDOWN FOR 1961 BORDEAUX
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla. THEY came from London and Dublin, from Malmo, Sweden, from San Juan, P.R., from New Orleans and Houston and Dallas and New York, a group of enthusiasts with a passion for the wines of Bordeaux. They came here for an extraordinary tasting of the celebrated 1961 vintage, to determine whether the wines made in that glorious year are the wines of the century, the greatest reds produced in Bordeaux in a hundred years and possibly the finest ever made.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATES SELLING OF TECHNOLOGY TO SOVIET
description: A Federal grand jury in Los Angeles is investigating charges that semiconductors, military equipment and other merchandise produced by California's high-technology companies is being sold illegally to the Soviet Union and other ''unfriendly nations.''

title: Cosmos Lose in Chile, 1-0
description: A goal by Miranda in the 80th minute gave Colo Colo of Chile a 1-0 victory over the Cosmos in an exhibition soccer match tonight. Colo Colo is Chile's top firstdivision team. The loss dropped the Cosmos' record to 2-1-1 on their South American tour.

title: FRANKFURT OPERA PICKS JUDITH SOMOGI
description: JUDITH SOMOGI, the American conductor, has been appointed ''first conductor'' of the Frankfurt Opera, beginning with the 1982-3 season. Miss Somogi, who has been conducting at the New York City Opera since 1974, will be joining a company that, under Michael Gielen's direction, seems on its way to creating for itself the same progressive reputation that the Hamburg Opera enjoyed in the 1960's.

title: Coke Bottler Posts Profit
