description: The Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York reported yesterday that it earned $1.2 million, or 6 cents a share, in 1980's fourth quarter, in contrast to a loss of $1.9 million in the 1979 fourth quarter.

title: Inquiry on Rhodes Slaying Is Focusing on Drug Ties
description: The police are investigating the possibility that the slaying of Bruce Rhodes, former professional football player, was drug-related.

title: Atlanta Police Say 2 Boys Reported Missing Are Safe
description: The police said today that two black children reported missing in the general area in which 19 others were killed or had disappeared in the last 19 months were found today.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD DEMOCRATS ON RULES TO PICK DELEGATES
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the Democratic Party's right to refuse to seat delegates to its national convention who were not chosen in compliance with the national party's rules.

title: FROM POLITICAL SEAS TO HELM OF N.Y.U.
description: To hear John Brademas describe it, the move from being one of the most powerful Democrats in Washington to president of the largest private university in the country is about as complicated as a stroll up Pennsylvania Avenue. On Tuesday the former 11-term member of the House of Representatives was named New York University's 13th president.

title: NICARAGUAN OFFICER TELLS OF AIDING SALVADOR REBELS
description: A young Nicaraguan lieutenant allegedly captured here three weeks ago said at a news conference yesterday that he had been sent to El Salvador to train guerrillas.

title: Prosecution Rests in Trial Of an Accused Nazi Guard
description: The Federal Government today rested its case against a mechanic accused of hiding his background as a guard at a Nazi death camp in World War II to become an American citizen.

title: Coghlan to Run 3-Mile
description: Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland, who had a world indoor best in the mile last Friday night, will try for another record tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden. But not in the mile.

title: Helpful Hardware; PACKAGING MADE EASIER; by Barbara L.Isenberg and Mary Smith
description: Mechanical devices for closing up packages, whether the package is a box or plastic bag, will help you do the job quickly and securely. The Post Office and United Parcel Service require tape instead of twine (twine gets entangled in the machinery which moves packages along) to seal packages.

title: Advertising; Cable Video Future Is Topic
description: IN at least two locations in town yesterday people were talking in public about the future of cable video. At the Plaza, where the Association of National Advertisers Television Workshop began its two-day stay, the interest was in programming. At the New York Hilton, where the Advertising Research Foundation was finishing up its two-day conference, the stress was on audience measurement.

title: WAKE FOREST UPSETS VIRGINIA IN OVERTIME
description: SALEM, N.C., Feb. 25 (AP) - Frank Johnson scored 6 points in overtime to lead Wake Forest to a 73-66 victory over Virginia in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: LONGSHOREMEN'S UNION ASSAILED ON CONVICTED LEADERS
description: A former United States Attorney told a Senate subcommittee today that the International Longshoremen's Association had demonstrated a ''callous contempt for the law'' by failing to purge officials convicted in waterfront corruption cases.

title: Critic's Notebook; SOCIAL AGONY STILL ATTRACTS COMPOSERS
description: As is known by now, the great social agonies of our century do not easily lend themselves to esthetic treatment. What art work can illuminate the brute force of genocide? Surely Jane Austen and Wolfgang Mozart had it easier; they could find darkness in the human soul and gently sound its limits with refined sensitivity. Who can do the same today when the existence of souls is as doubted as the existence of limits? Who can even pay attention to small-scale suffering when whole peoples are demolished by state machines?

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate, 18.50-19.00** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SETON HALL BEATS ST. JOHN'S, 70-63
description: Howard McNeil hit 9 of 11 field-goal attempts and scored 25 points to lead Seton Hall to a 70-63 victory over St. John's at Walsh Auditorium tonight. The defeat extended the Redmen's losing streak to four games, the longest for St. John's in 18 years and the longest in the 13 seasons that Lou Carnesecca has been head coach.

title: Woman Achievers
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Carolyn Heilbrun, in the ''Hers'' column (Feb. 19), remarks that the St. Agnes Branch of the Public Library, to which she belonged as a child, didn't contain a biography of Agnes, ''whoever she was.''

title: REMOVING GRAFFITI OUTSIDE THE HOUSE
description: ''IHAD some words with neighborhood kids and the next morning obscenities were sprayed all over my stoop, cement work and shingles,'' said Joseph Spedaleri, a Queens homeowner.

title: Reagan Said to Support Tennessee Nuclear Plant
description: President Reagan has decided to propose completion of the controversial Clinch River nuclear breeder reactor project in Tennessee, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, said today.

title: Edith Alt, 78, an Official Of United Hospital Fund
description: Edith G. Alt, the first director of the department of social work at both the United Hospital Fund and the Health Insurance Plan of New York, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Alt lived in Manhattan and was 78 years old.

title: REPAIRING DAMAGE TO YOUR GARDEN
description: GARDENERS who have been trimming and pruning recently have observed distressing signs of winter damage. Leaves of broadleaved evergreens such as holly, mountain laurel, azalea and rhododendrons are brown, not green. Tips of spruce, pine and fir look scorched.

title: CAREY DELAYING DETAILS ON TRANSPORTATION AID
description: - Governor Carey today postponed the announcement of his program to help the state's masstransportation system.

title: CLONING ANTIQUES: MUSEUM REPRODUCTIONS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jim Kemp is an editor and writer in the design field. By JIM KEMP

title: RESTRUCTURING A CITY APARTMENT TO PROVIDE FLEXIBLE LIVING FOR 3
description: IT wasn't until Lisa Cowen, a designer, had looked all over town for a new apartment that she decided to stay in the one she had lived in for ll years.

title: Index; International
description: Reagan faces decisions on policy in Southeast Asia A2 At least 16 killed in crash of U.S. Navy plane off Philippines A2 Study group sees need for greater European military effort A3 Greek quake kills 15 and seriously wounds 53 A3 Pope gets a warm welcome in Nagasaki A4 Queen Mother and Lady Diana have a tete-a-tete A5 Brezhnev aide denies Soviet arms go to Salvadoran rebels A8 Around the World A9 Group plans to protest disappearance of Guatemalan A13 Government/Politics Judge refuses to dismiss suit over F.B.I. informer A14 Wisconsin Democrats and Republicans upset by Court's move A17 Koch attacks group that criticized his anticrime proposals B11 Democrats demand more details on budget B15 General Around the Nation A14 Art Deco buildings at center of Miami Beach conflict A14 Well Fargo discloses details of bank fraud A15 Concern growing over Nassau's overcrowded jail B7 Consumer prices rise 0.8 percent in New York region B12 Chicago financier charged with fraud in search for Peking Man B16 Education/Welfare Ex-Congressman confident as new head of N.Y.U. B8 Features/Notes Notes on People B6 Man in the News: John Brademas, new N.Y.U. president B8 Obituaries Deszo Ernster, bass at the Met B16 The Home Section Home Cloning antiques: Museum reproductions C1

title: 2 L.I. High School Students Held In Shooting of Oceanside Youth
description: Two West Hempstead High School students were arrested today on charges of attempted murder stemming from the shooting of another youth last Saturday in nearby Oceanside.

title: POP:GREECE'S NANA MOUSKOURI OFFERS INTERNATIONAL REPERTORY
description: NANA MOUSKOURI, the internationally renowned Greek pop singer who appeared at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday, has gained a small New York following, having performed here regularly for nearly 15 years. But this year's New York engagement was decidedly uneven.

title: Books of The Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt HIGH IN AMERICA. The True Story Behind Norml and the Politics of Marijuana.'' By Patrick Anderson. 328 pages. Viking. $13.95.

title: RANGERS TOPPLE SABRES
description: The scoring machine recently tuned up by the Rangers was in high gear last night at Madison Square Garden. But after racing to a 3-0 lead, the Rangers sputtered and had to withstand a Buffalo Sabre rally before achieving a 6-3 victory.

title: UA-Columbia Bid Opposed
description: United Artists Theatre Circuit Inc. said yesterday that it would ''vigorously resist, by litigation if necessary,'' the joint bid by Dow Jones & Company and Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. for UA-Columbia Cablevision.

title: Stolen U.S. Weapon Is in Ulster
description: British troops raided a predominantly Roman Catholic district here today, seizing a machine gun stolen from an American armory. The police said that the M-60 was one of seven taken from a National Guard armory north of Boston in 1976.

title: Israel Is Planning to Expand Settler Population by 40%
description: The Jewish population of the occupied West Bank will be expanded more than 40 percent this year in an intensive pre-election settlement drive by Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Government, it was announced today.

title: ANDY HIGH
description: Andy High, a former major league infielder who played on three pennant-winning teams for the St. Louis Cardinals, died Sunday in Toledo, Ohio, where he had lived with his son since suffering a stroke a year ago. He was 83 years old.

title: Topics; A Dome of Kindness
description: The Lilly Endowment of Indianapolis, long a benefactor of its home town and several causes, has announced a most unusual civic gift: $25 million to help build a $65 million, 60,000-seat stadium - complete with dome. Part of an enlarged convention center, the stadium will accommodate collegiate as well as professional football, baseball and soccer teams.

title: Recognition
description: At a boat show in Los Angeles, Michael Reagan, the President's older son, said he was grateful for at least one side effect of a district attorney's investigation of a gasohol development company in which he is involved.

title: 50 West Germans Stage Protest At Nuclear Plant Near Hamburg
description: Fifty antinuclear demonstrators blocked a construction access road to the Brokdorf nuclear power plant for two hours today before policemen dragged them off.

title: Uncertainty Holds Rates Steady
description: Short- and long-term interest rates were little changed yesterday, as many investors stayed on the sidelines waiting for clearer signs about the Federal Reserve's monetary policy, the course of the economy and the Congressional response to President Reagan's economic plan.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Our family room has dark (mahogany finish) paneling on the walls which makes the room quite dark. Is there any way to lighten the color of this finish, or is there anything I can apply over it to make the color lighter? -L.B.C., Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: IRAN SAYS EX-COMMANDER AIDED U.S. RESCUE ATTEMPT
description: The former commander of the Iranian Air Force, Amir-Bahman Baqeri, has been arrested on suspicion of complicity in the aborted mission to rescue the 52 American hostages last April, the official Pars press agency reported today.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEKING MORE DETAILS FROM ADMINISTRATION ON BUDGET
description: Democratic Congressional leaders asked the Reagan Administration today to provide more substance and less pressure concerning the President's economic package.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is entirely appropriate to dispatch noncombat advisers to tell those people how to defend themselves against Cuba.'' - Howard H. Baker, Senate Majority Leader, on El Salvador. (A1:2.)

title: C.A.B. Clears 5.88% Fare Rise
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today gave the nation's airlines permission to raise domestic fares 5.88 percent and increased the base rate for international fares as much as 6 percent because of rising fuel costs.

title: 50'S HUMOR-FOR SALE
description: A sense of humor is what Mark Isaacson, below, feels best characterizes the 50's. Mr. Isaacson, born in 1954, used to deal in Art Deco and Art Nouveau objects. ''In the Paris flea markets,'' he recalled, ''I saw all the wonderful things no one else was looking at, so I just kept buying and putting away.''

title: BANK ROBBERS YOUNGER? HOW ABOUT AGE 9 OR 10?
description: A boy appearing to be 9 or 10 years old used a silvery gun that might have been a .25-caliber automatic pistol yesterday to hold up a teller at a midtown branch of the New York Bank for Savings. He got away with $100.

title: LEWIS D. RAABIN
description: Lewis D. Raabin, a stockbroker who had been a senior member and partner of H. Hentz & Company, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.

title: People
description: * Eleanor Holtzman has returned to McCann-Erickson as executive vice president, director of research services.

title: Jazz Trounce Nets As Dantley Scores 40
description: Adrian Dantley and Darrell Griffith combined for 65 points in leading Utah to a 132-106 rout of the New Jersey Nets last night in Salt Lake City in the widest victory spread of the season for the Jazz.

title: Corporation Failures Down
description: Failures of commercial and industrial corporations slowed to 232 for the holiday week ended Feb. 19, Dun & Bradsteet reported yesterday.

title: ARCO TO SELL BRITAIN'S OBSERVER
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, the country's seventh-biggest oil concern, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell The Observer, Britain's oldest Sunday newspaper, to the George Outram Company, a Glasgow publishing subsidiary of Lonrho Ltd., the British mining conglomerate, in a stock exchange valued at $14 million.

title: Special Session of U.N. Council On Namibia Asked by Guerrillas
description: Guerrillas fighting against South African rule in South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, called today for a special session of the United Nations Security Council to impose sanctions on South Africa.

title: 2 Wire Services at Odds Over New Technology
description: The country's two largest news services, The Associated Press and United Press International, started to send their news reports by satellite this month while continuing a down-to-earth fight about profiting from the new technology.

title: U.S. HIRING FREEZE UPHELD BY COURT
description: A Federal district judge today upheld President Reagan's hiring freeze, ruling that thousands of people who had received written job offers from Nov. 5 to Jan. 20 had not actually been hired.

title: CHRYSLER ANNOUNCES ACCORD WITH BANKS
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it had reached agreement on an accelerated debt repayment plan with its banks, clearing the way for approval of $400 million in Federal loan guarantees.

title: B.P. Set to Resume Nigeria Operations
description: The British Petroleum Company and Nigeria have agreed in principle on a plan to allow B.P. to resume operations in the African country for the first time since its Nigerian interests were nationalized in 1979, industry sources said today.

title: by Jorge I.Dominguez
description: The United States and Cuba are almost certain to be involved in bitter political disputes in coming months. The Reagan Administration, accusing the Cuban Government of interfering in El Salvador's internal affairs, has placed the El Salvador issue at the top of its foreign policy priorities in relations with friends and adversaries. Nonetheless, United States policy must recognize that despite any conflicts with Cuba over El Salvador, or Angola, or Ethiopia, there is an important aspect of the bilateral relationship that should be preserved.

title: 4 Sought by Defense In Slaying of Lennon
description: The lawyer for Mark D. Chapman, who is accused of killing the rock star John Lennon, issued a plea to four people who might have had contact with his client before the shooting to come forward.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Ana Trenchi de Bottazzi Is Heard in Piano Recital
description: Both the virtues and the faults of Ana Maria Trenchi de Bottazzi's pianism in Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon could be heard in the beginning of Haydn's Sonata in B minor (H. XVI: 32). The first measures were sonorous and declarative, announcing with musical certitude the movement's motivic material.

title: 3 Held in Montevideo Bombing
description: The police have arrested three men on charges of firebombing a synagogue and throwing rocks at other Jewish centers in Montevideo, the Interior Ministry said today. Yamandu Lopez Xejas, a 49-year-old businessman, and two 19-yearolds, Marcelo Fuentes Arbini and Fernando Garcia Gaitan, were charged under a World War II-era law against ''promoting race hatred or conflict.''

title: VOLCKER BACKS FULL BUDGET CUT
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the ''full magnitude'' of President Reagan's proposed budget cuts were essential to the anti-inflation fight.

title: Continental Tries to Foil Bid
description: Continental Air Lines Inc., the target of an unwelcome takeover bid from Texas International Airlines Inc,, said yesterday that the merger proposal on file with the Civil Aeronautics Board shows that Texas International is offering Continental shareholders less than half of what their shares are worth.

title: CONCERN IS GROWING OVER NASSAU JAIL'S OVERCROWDING
description: A dim gray light filters through the bars of the Nassau County jail into the tier of cells and narrow corridors where more than 930 prisoners - nearly twice as many as the jail was built to hold - spend the day and sleep head-to-toe at night.

title: TEXTRON POSTS LOSS; REVLON'S NET UP 21%
description: Textron Inc., a diversified company with interests in aerospace, consumer, industrial and metal products, reported yesterday that a loss of $78 million from discontinued operations caused a loss of $31.4 million in the fourth quarter contrasted to earnings of $43.7 million, or $1.16 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979.

title: THEATER:'FREAK', THE LIFE OF EDGAR CAYCE,MYSTIC
description: FROM the bizarre life story of Edgar Cayce, the early 20th-century mystic, psychic and faith healer, Granville Wyche Burgess has created an engrossing new play, ''The Freak'' (at the WPA). The work is directed with a melodramatic tautness by Stephen Zuckerman, who staged Tom Topor's ''Nuts'' last season at the WPA, and, subsequently, on Broadway. Both are old-fashioned plays that ask for a suspension of belief on the part of the audience.

title: Protest Planned In Case Of Missing Guatemalan
description: A group of writers and political activists have scheduled a demonstration for 11 A.M. today in front of the diplomatic mission of Guatemala at Park Avenue near 36th Street to protest the disappearance two months ago of a 65-year-old writer and feminist leader.

title: 3 Careers in Securities
description: Ralph F. Peters, 51 years old, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Discount Corporation of New York, a primary dealer in Treasury and Federal agency securities, effective April 1. He will succeed Robert H. Bethke, who will retire at the mandatory age of 65 after 42 years with the company.

title: John Sotomayor Groundbreaking for a New Housing Project Sounds a Note of Hope in Williamsburg Mayor Koch and City Councilman Luis A. Olmedo touring the site of a low-rise public housing project yesterday in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The $5.5-million, 120-unit project is to include some of the most advanced design concepts for public housing to eliminate the old
description: ''vertical slum'' problem. At the groundbreaking ceremony, Mr. Koch said the project ''helps to demonstrate our concern for this neighborhood and others like it.''

title: Going Out Guide
description: CONCERTED EFFORT

title: Abroad At Home; PIE IN THE SKY?; by Anthony Lewis
description: President Reagan and his economic men have been telling us these days about a magic new idea called supply-side economics. Cut taxes and Government spending, they say, and you will stimulate growth and at the same time vanquish inflation. As the boys' books used to say, ''At one bound Jack was free.''

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 26, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CAREY BACKS AWAY FROM 24-HOUR PLAN FOR SOME BARS
description: Governor Carey today backed away from a proposal he made last month to keep some bars open 24 hours a day, but reiterated his support for the sale of wine and spirits in supermarkets.

title: Firefighters Union To Quit International
description: Members of the Uniformed Firefighters Association have voted, 3,776 to 2,013, to end their affiliation with the International Association of Fire Fighters, A.F.L.-C.I.O., Nicholas Mancuso, president of the U.F.A., announced.

title: LOBBYISTS' ROW ALL ALERT FOR CHANCE AT THE BUDGET
description: On K Street, where the equivalent of a new branch of government is thriving among the glass and steel buildings, Herbert Liebenson is plotting.

title: Why Only a Popgun Tax Cut?
description: America, says President Reagan, needs a tax break to increase productivity. It is hard to disagree. But as the business economist Sam Nakagama puts it, the bang we can expect from the Reagan plan has ''all the potency of a popgun.''

title: FOR LARRY BROWN, A TIME OF DECISION
description: Early in the week, after the one that Larry Brown, the U.C.L.A. basketball coach, had called the worst of his career, one of his problems appeared solved. After a 90-minute meeting this morning with Kenny Fields, 6-foot-7-inch freshman center who was dismissed from the team nine days ago, Brown reinstated him and he returned to practice this afternoon.

title: A Federal Jury Indicts 2 In Immigration Scheme
description: Update: July 9, 2015

title: New Chief at Burger Chef
description: John E. Martin, 35 years old, has been named president and chief executive officer of Burger Chef Systems, the fast-food subsidiary of the General Foods Corporation, effective March 1. He will succeed Thomas A. Collins, 39, who will become president and chief executive officer of Victoria Station Inc., another food chain.

title: Conservation Organization's Ship To Oppose Seal Hunt Off Canada
description: Greenpeace, the international conservation organization, said today that its vessel Rainbow Warrior will sail from Amsterdam next week in an attempt to stop the hunt for hooded seals off Canada's east coast.

title: MAGIC TO REAPPEAR FOR LAKERS TO NIGHT
description: After more than three months away from the daily grind of the National Basketball Association, 45 games away from the Los Angeles Lakers and many trips to the doctor's office, Earvin (Magic) Johnson says he is once again friends with his left knee. A sellout crowd, only the Lakers' third of the season, will watch a game against the Nets tomorrow night and celebrate a renewed friendship.

title: Prior Abitibi Bid to Continue
description: Olympia & York Investments Ltd. said today it would not withdraw its offer to buy 6.75 million shares of Abitibi-Price Inc. at $28 a share (Canadian), even though it had been outbid by a competing group.

title: Fordham 83, L.I.U. 72
description: A 19-point effort by David Maxwell led Fordham to an 83-72 decision over Long Island Wednesday night in Brooklyn.

title: Building Rate Said to Slow
description: Construction contracts will rise by 12 percent in 1981, to $164.5 billion, or about $10 billion less than was predicted six months ago, the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company said yesterday.

title: JANUARY CONSUMER PRICES INCREASED 0.8% IN NEW YORK
description: Consumer prices in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area, pushed upward by rising energy costs, rose 0.8 percent in January, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, reported yesterday.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL COUNCIL CALLED A TARGET OF BUDGET CUTS
description: High-ranking Administration policymakers are weighing the elimination of the Council on Environmental Quality, the Cabinet-level body that advises the President on environmental issues, White House officials said today.

title: An Apology to Cleveland
description: A follow-up: During the inaugural gala before President Reagan last month, the comedian Rich Little said, ''The best way to keep the Russians from invading Poland is to convince them it's Cleveland.''

title: LAWSUIT OVER INFORMER TO PROCEED
description: A Federal judge today refused to dismiss a $2 million lawsuit brought against the Government by the children of Viola Gregg Liuzzo, a civil rights worker slain in 1965.

title: Prime Time Magazine Is Back in Business
description: Barbara V. Hertz, publisher of Prime Time magazine for those approaching the golden days, says that the magazine's financial troubles are past, ''and we're back in business to stay.''

title: Five of Jersey's Mayors Take Tour of Reservoirs
description: This month's above-average rainfall will not solve the state's continuing drought, state officials told five northeastern New Jersey mayors after a tour of parched reservoirs today.

title: U.S. RAISING SECURITY AT ITS EMBASSIES
description: The Reagan Administration told Congress today that it was ''urgently upgrading'' physical security measures at two dozen United States diplomatic missions abroad where there is a ''high threat'' of attack.

title: Bridge: Duplicate and Rubber Club Sharing the Same Premises
description: Duplicate clubs and rubber bridge clubs normally pursue independent parallel tracks. But the tracks met earlier this week when the Manhattan Club, long established at 228 West 71st Street, entered into a marriage of convenience with an even older institution, the Gotham Club. They will share the latter's premises in the penthouse of the Hotel Olcott, 27 West 72d Street, and players are invited to the wedding feast Sunday between sessions of play.

title: Eastern Reports Passenger Record
description: Eastern Airlines, citing Civil Aeronutics Board figures, reported today that it carried more passengers in 1980 than any other airline in the non-Communist world. It was the second successive year that Eastern has claimed the distinction.

title: Where Allies Can Meet
description: Western Europe's post-inaugural trek to Washington is under way. Britain's Prime Minister Thatcher has followed the Foreign Ministers of Italy and France; West Germany's Foreign Minister is due next week, to be followed by Chancellor Schmidt. These consultations are urgently needed. The alliance has been in disarray, especially since the failure of a concerted response to the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan.

title: Harvester Credit's Canadian Bank Line
description: The six largest chartered banks in Canada, led by the Royal Bank of Canada, said that they were providing a $450 million (Canadian) one-year operating standby credit for International Harvester Credit Corporation of Canada, the finance arm of International Harvester Canada Ltd., a major maker of trucks, farm and construction equipment.

title: AT LEAST 16 ARE KILLED AS U.S. PLANE CRASHES INTO SOUTH CHINA SEA
description: A United States Navy C-130 Hercules transport plane crashed into the South China Sea early today, killing at least 16 of the 24 people aboard, a Navy spokesman said.

title: CHARLES A. POINDEXTER
description: Dr. Charles A. Poindexter, a specialist in cardiology and professor of medicine at New York University's College of Medicine, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan.

title: RADIO WARNING KEEPS JETLINER FROM HITTING MAST ON TRADE CENTER
description: An Argentine airline jet, flying in clouds 1,500 feet lower than its assigned altitude, came close to crashing into a television mast atop a World Trade Center tower in downtown Manhattan last Friday at 10:05 P.M., according to Federal officials here.

title: AN ISOLATED HUDSON'S BAY STORE
description: Dan Marion is a mechanic, a shipping expert, a social worker, a fur buyer, a store manager, a banker, an engineer, a teacher, an accountant, a community leader, a janitor, a heating technician and a trilingual public relations officer.

title: ASIA SOCIETY TO OPEN A NEW HOME IN APRIL
description: A new $16.6 million building for the Asia Society, under construction for nearly two years at Park Avenue and 70th Street, will open on April 14. The opening will touch off a two-and-a-halfmonth ''Celebration of Asia'' program, including concerts, films, symposiums and public affairs discussions.

title: BREZHNEV AIDE ASSERTS SLAVADORANS 'NEVER WILL' GET ARMS FROM SOVIET
description: A senior Soviet official today rejected what the Kremlin feels was an attempt by President Reagan to link a meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev to the Salvadoran insurgency.

title: ARMANI'S MEW MEN'S LINE ADDS CASUAL AND MILITARY ELEMENTS
description: IN the last five years, Giorgio Armani has become famous for the rigorous tailoring of his men's clothing, an approach that he is not about to relinquish.

title: Esmark to Spin Off Its Swift Division
description: Esmark, which tried unsuccessfully to sell its Swift & Company fresh meat division last year, said it had decided instead to spin it off as a separate concern.

title: MIAMI BEACH CONFLICT PITS DEVELOPERS AGAINST LOVERS OF ART DECO
description: The buildings, decked with spires and spirals, wrapped with rounded corners and adorned with terrazzo sunbursts and glass flamingos, hint at youth and endless summer, but then they have always traded on illusions.

title: U.N. Agency Says Cambodia Still Faces Food Problems
description: A United Nations agency here reported today that ''widespread starvation and serious malnutrition'' had been overcome in Cambodia but that it still faced food problems.

title: JURORS IN HARRIS TRIAL RE-ENACTED NIGHT OF MURDER DELIBERATIONS
description: Jurors who last night convicted Jean S. Harris of murder recalled their deliberations today and spoke of reenactments, role playing, arguments, tears and three secret ballots before reaching a verdict on the eighth day.

title: HOME SCHOOLING,AN ISSUE FOR PARENTS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elin McCoy writes frequently on childhood and education. By ELIN McCOY

title: WISCONSIN POLITICIANS DISMAYED BY COURT DECISION
description: Wisconsin's Democratic and Republican leaders expressed shock, dismay and anger today at the United States Supreme Court decision upholding national Democratic Party rules that conflict with the state's process of selecting party convention delegates.

title: When Neatness Counts
description: The Secretary of Labor, Raymond J. Donovan, received evidence yesterday that law enforcement officials in Florida are on the job. Mr. Donovan was fined $250 by the Code Enforcement Board of Boca Raton for violating the city's ''clean and neat'' codes by failing to keep boats and trailers at his property out of public view.

title: Addenda
description: * Magazine Specialist Inc., a new magazine consulting firm formed by Milton Lieberman, at 919 Third Avenue.

title: Dueling, Despite Derision, Grows in West Germany
description: West Germany's traditional student dueling fraternities are having a new vogue after years of official disapproval.

title: DISNEY SHOWS TO APPEAR ON CBS-TV NEXT SEASON
description: CBS and Walt Disney Productions have agreed to bring Disney shows to CBS for the 1981-82 television season.

title: CONCERT: A NEW-MUSIC BILL
description: MOST potpourri new-music concerts have their hits and their misses. Monday evening's program at Alice Tully Hall by the American Composers Orchestra, which remains in its fifth season one of New York's nobler manifestations of new-musical activity, offered three hits and two misses. But that is one man's subjective tabulation, and the misses didn't miss by all that much.

title: Radio Warning Keeps Jetliner From Hitting Mast on Trade Center
description: An Argentine airline jet, flying in clouds 1,500 feet lower than its assigned altitude, came close to crashing into a television mast atop a World Trade Center tower in downtown Manhattan last Friday at 10:05 P.M., according to Federal officials here.

title: Noble Nashua Wins Easily
description: Noble Nashua won impressively yesterday in the $54,500 Whirlaway Stakes at Aqueduct, missing the track record for a mile and a sixteenth over the inner track by a fifth of a second.

title: INCREASE IN CONSUMER PRICES SLOWS, WITH 0.7% RISE IN JANUARY INDEX
description: Consumer prices rose last month by seventenths of 1 percent, the first time since August that inflation has increased at less than a double-digit annual rate, the Labor Department reported today.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration's first major international endeavor, to expose what it calls ''a textbook case of indirect armed aggression by Communist powers'' in El Salvador, has so far seemed to have produced mixed results.

title: Design Notebook; A DIFFERENT PERSPECTIVE ON 'INSIDE SPACES'
description: THERE was a time, not so very long ago, when the room meant only one thing to architects and artists of serious intent. It was a ''space,'' an enclosure that was fairly abstract in nature and fairly austere in terms of its content. It was not seen as a means of personal expression, or as a particularly sensual kind of thing. It was generally cool and white and very inward looking - it did not make much reference to the world outside its walls.

title: 'LET'S GET OUR PRIORITIES STRAIGHT' ON IRAN
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE'S MONITORS PRONOUNCE CITY FISCALLY HEALTHY
description: The staff of the state's Financial Control Board said yesterday that New York City's finances had improved to the point where the city was in a position to balance future budgets with little of the pain it had endured in recent years.

title: Home Improvement
description: A FEW minutes spent touching up a scratch or tightening a loose joint in a chair or table can often make the difference between saving that piece of furniture and having to undertake a costly repair or discarding it.

title: Market Place; Behind Surge In Oil Explorer
description: TEXAS INTERNATIONAL scored the best percentage gain of any company traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, even though a possible new oil and gas find, the source of the speculative flurry, is still unconfirmed.

title: Benjamin B. Zavin, 61, Librettist, Playwright and Television Writer
description: Benjamin B. Zavin, who wrote the book for ''The Education of H*Y*M*A*N* K*A*P*L*A*N,'' the 1968 Broadway musical based on short stories by Leo Rosten, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness.

title: The Heart of the Issue
description: The issue that has led the players association to set a strike date is the baseball club owners' demand for significant compensation, in the form of players, to teams that lose veterans through free agency.

title: Caravatt Communications And Doyle Dane Link
description: Scarcely moving from the previous subject, we turn to Doyle Dane Bernbach International, America's ninth-largest ad agency, and Caravatt Communications, which is in the business of producing video cassettes and disk material for not only consumers but also for the educational and industrial markets.

title: Oilers Defeat Flyers; Gretzky Scores Two
description: Wayne Gretzky, the league's top scorer, had two goals, including the game-winner, and two assists last night to help the Oilers to a 6-2 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in Edmonton, Alberta.

title: 169th Graham Work Set For Kennedy Center Gala
description: ''Acts of Light'' by Martha Graham will be performed for the first time this evening in a gala by the Martha Graham Dance Company at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: Steel Output Up 3.1%
description: Steel production rose to 2.474 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, up 3.1 percent from the previous week's 2.4 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 82.6 percent of capacity in the week, up from 80.2 percent in the previous week. Estimated figures for the year to date showed production at 17.767 million net tons, down five-tenths of 1 percent from 17.864 million net tons in the previous year, the institute said.

title: Snowstorm Brings Relief To Northern Ski Areas
description: Disappointed over the recent unseasonably warm weather and heavy rainfall, ski operators in the Northeast were encouraged yesterday by a snowstorm and the return of freezing weather.

title: News Analysis
description: Since the start of this month about 200 children from Rosedale, Queens, have not attended a nearby intermediate school because, their parents contend, it is segregated. The parents have also organized boycotts of two elementary schools, sit-ins and demonstrations and, yesterday, some of them made a protest trip to Washington. On Tuesday, they filed a Federal lawsuit charging that their children's rights were being violated.

title: A.T.&T. Fights Profit Rule
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today formally appealed a regulatory decision that raised its profit margin to 10.87 percent, instead of the 13 percent it had requested.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1981
description: International A dispatch of 150 U.S. military advisers to El Salvador was backed by Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader. After meeting with President Reagan, Mr. Baker said that noncombat advisers were being considered to help the Salvadoran Government in its fight against left-wing insurgents. The Administration has made no final decision. (Page A1, Column 2.) New military aid to Israel is planned by the Reagan Administration to help offset the planned sale of equipment to upgrade Saudi Arabia's F-15 warplanes, according to Capitol Hill sources. They said that Israel was expected to be offered 15 additional F-15's at preferential financing terms. (A1:3.)

title: GREEK QUAKE KILLS 15, SERIOUSLY WOUNDS 53 AND CHIPS PARTHENON
description: The police said today that 15 people died and 53 others were seriously injured in a series of earthquakes that jolted Athens and the surrounding region yesterday.

title: CUT IN ANTITRUST BUDGET PROVOKES A DISPUTE
description: Division has developed within the Reagan Administration over a proposal by David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, to effectively phase out antitrust enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: U.S. Conducts Nuclear Test
description: An underground nuclear test with a yield of less than 20,000 tons of high explosives was conducted today at the Nevada Test Site, Federal officials reported. The explosion took place 665 feet beneath Yucca Flat, 90 miles northwest of here. It was the 568th test reported at the desert test range since the United States ended atmospheric testing in 1963.

title: 4 GRAMMY AWARDS WON BY CHRISTOPHER CROSS
description: Christopher Cross was the surprise quadruple winner at the 23d Grammy Awards ceremony last night. The awards were held for the first time at Radio City Music Hall and for the first time since 1975 in New York, after five straight years in Los Angeles. The most important awards were given out during a more-than-two-hour broadcast on CBS-TV. Paul Simon was the host.

title: LONDON
description: WHY would the English, with their tradition of fine furniture, buy American reproduction pieces? Sales of such pieces are so brisk that one company has comitted an entire store in Knightsbridge to them, and another company opened a five-story showroom last year in Covent Garden and also expanded its display in Harrods.

title: REAGAN FACING LIMITED DECISIONS ON SOUTHEST ASIA
description: As President Reagan begins his term, the people of Indochina - Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos - live under the sway of the Hanoi Government and however uneasy most of them may be, they see nothing on the horizon that presages change.

title: HOLLYWOOD:TIME OF THE LEMMINGS?
description: LOS ANGELES IN Hollywood, there are jokes about everything, and the current joke is that the industry is about to self-destruct, in imitation of News Analysis the towering infernos and earthquakes of its multimillion-dollar disaster movies.

title: POPE IS ACCORDED A WARM WELCOME IN NAGASAKI DESPITE A SNOWSTORM
description: Pope John Paul II arrived here today to the warmest welcome of his tour of Japan as uniformed school girls, aged women in kimonos and middle-aged men in business suits lined his road into town in the midst of a snowstorm.

title: by Richard Scobey
description: Speaking in the San Francisco auditorium where John F. Kennedy 20 years earlier had launched the idea of Peace Corps, Edmund S. Muskie recently said that the Corps ''today is making a difference, in the only way that matters: in the daily lives of individuals whose daily lives are harshest.'' After graduation, a similar conviction led me to volunteer. The Corps epitomized adventurous, activist Camelot idealism, and law school and career plans paled when compared to the opportunity to live and work in a developing country.

title: RESURGENCE OF SWEATSHOPS REPORTED IN NEW YORK
description: violations (page D11) By SANDRA SALMANS

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Jan. 14 about the Bollingen Prize quoted incorrectly from a poem by May Swenson. The selection committee had correctly cited ''the delight she takes in discovering 'the pure suit of happiness' in its unexampled forms.'' The prize is administered by the Yale University Library with proceeds from an endowment from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

title: THE PITFALLS IN REDUCING COLLEGE TUITION AID
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Airco Inc., Montvale, N.J., appointed Keith R. Hampe president of its Temescal division.

title: RCA'S VIDEODISK CAMPAIGN
description: A pep rally was broadcast last night over satellite to 75 cities to excite the company's 5,000 dealers about the product. An all-out advertising blitz, costing close to $20 million, will begin March 16 to exhort consumers to ''bring the magic home.''

title: I.R.S. TIES UP BAPTIST HOSPITAL'S FUNDS
description: The Internal Revenue Service, demanding payment of $1.3 million in back taxes, has stopped Medicare payments to the Baptist Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: Two More Polish Local Officials Are Seized for Abusing Authority
description: Two more Polish officials were arrested yesterday in Myslenice near Cracow on charges of abusing their authority, the Government press agency said today.

title: REAGAN ORDERS CUTS OF $3 BILLION MORE IN SPENDING FOR '82
description: President Reagan today ordered $3 billion to $6 billion in additional budget cuts after he was informed that his advisers had underestimated the growth in Federal spending for the fiscal year 1982.

title: White Consolidated
description: White Consolidated Industries, hard hit by high interest rates and a decline in appliance unit shipments, said that net income in the fourth quarter fell 35.2 percent, to $20.8 million, or $1.46 a share, from $32.1 million, or $2.27 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Signed Ken Dayley, p itcher. YANKEES (AL) - Signed Andy McGaffi- g an, pitcher, to a one-year contract. BASKETBALL GOLDEN STATE (NBA) - Signed Wil- l ima Mayfield, forward, and released Phil C henier, guard.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH COURT BACKS S.E.C. ON FRAUD PROOF STANDARD
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the Securities and Exchange Commission's view of the standard of proof necessary to prove securities fraud.

title: Broad Realignment At Grace Retail Unit
description: Bernard A. Cohen, 38 years old, has been appointed president of Herman's World of Sporting Goods, the 92-unit chain of sporting goods stores owned by W.R. Grace & Company. He succeeds Norman Abramson, 42, who was named senior vice president-special projects of Grace's retail group.

title: PROSECUTION OF HELLS ANGELS IS DROPPED AFTER 2D MISTRIAL
description: The Federal Government's attempt to break up the Oakland Hells Angels motorcycle club through prosecution ended today with dismissal of charges against 11 club members.

title: REACTION OF YANKS, METS TO STRIKE VOTE
description: Following is a sampling of reaction among Mets and Yankees at the training camps to yesterday's strike vote by the executive board of the Players Association.

title: Essay; ESSAY; The Savings of Salvador
description: A generation ago and half a world away, South Korea was chosen to be the place where the line was drawn against Communist expansion. President Reagan has chosen El Salvador to be this generation's and this hemisphere's South Korea.

title: Hers; by Carolyn G.Heilbrun
description: HAD I been asked a year ago if I knew anything about those books the trade calls popular romances, I would have denied it. My ignorance arose partly from a regrettable sense of superiority, but only partly. I had noticed that romances were sold everywhere, but found them quite easy to ignore. Avoidability is not characteristic of popular culture; rock music is not to be evaded while hearing persists. But nobody painting my house insisted on reading romances to me as he worked.

title: BONSAI IN ROCKEFELLER CENTER
description: BONSAI BOX, C12

title: J. McCall Hughes Is Dead at 73; Former President of Mutual Life
description: J. McCall Hughes, former president, chairman and chief executive officer of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, died Monday at his home in St. Croix, V.I., where he had recently moved from Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: Cities Service Plan
description: The Cities Service Company said it planned to build a 450-millionpound-a-year high-density polyethylene production facility at Bay City, Tex., for about $300 million.

title: FIRST NOVELS GARNER TOP PRICES,BUT AVERAGE ADVANCES DECLINE
description: Two unofficial records were claimed recently when New American Library agreed to pay $850,000 for a first novel and St. Martin's Press negotiated a $3.6 million package of subsidiary rights for a forthcoming book of memoirs by the Yorkshire veterinarian James Herriot. At the same time, a growing number of authors and literary agents complain that the average advances for novelists are growing smaller and that it is growing harder to get novels published.

title: John Zimba, 27, Was Star Tackle At Villanova, Then Became Pro
description: John A. Zimba, a Villanova University football star in the early 1970's, died Sunday at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital.

title: A Primary's Not a Free-for-All
description: Now that New Jersey's taxpayers are pledged to pay two-thirds of the cost, every Tom, Dick and Mary wants to run for Governor, says Governor Byrne, who is not eligible to run again. And indeed they do; about a dozen candidates are milling around each party's starting gate. If they can raise the first $50,000 - which is hardly difficult - the state proposes to match every additional $1 contribution with $2, to a maximum of nearly $600,000 in state funds. What was thought to be an offer of $5 million to reduce dependence on private interests now threatens to cost $15 million.

title: Munsingwear Stock Vote Results Due
description: Results of a shareholders' vote on whether to sell 30 percent of Munsingwear Inc., a large clothing manufacturer, to three Japanese companies for $12.5 million in cash are expected in several days, the company said.

title: KOCH ATTACKS SEYMOUR FOR CRITICIZING ANTICRIME PLANS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday attacked a citizens' anticrime group that recently criticized his criminal-justice proposals, using the words ''despicable'' and ''snide'' and saying that Whitney North Seymour Jr., the former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York and chairman of the group, talks ''out of two sides of his mouth.''

title: WELLS FARGO AIDES GIVE FRAUD DETAILS
description: It took only about five minutes a week for an officer of the Wells Fargo National Bank to steal $21.3 million, executives of the bank alleged today.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: Carolyn Heilbrun surely got lost in the wrong corner of that library. If she was looking for women achievers during the Depression, she should have been reading novels - by Edna Ferber, Fannie Hurst, Ellen Glasgow and that darling of the English faculty, Willa Cather. If Ferber and Hurst didn't reach millionaire status, it was only because several hundred thousand dollars then went so much further than a million does today.
description: And among all those biographies, didn't she come across the works of Catherine Drinker Bowen and Frances Winwar? Also, while she was out there playing with Judy Tarcher, she should have occasionally run into her mother, Mary Tarcher. Mary Tarcher was probably no millionaire but she was rightly honored for her lifelong work in shaping domestic relations law. There was life out there before 1950. GLADYS GLICKMAN Manhattan

title: 'MR. EDUCATION' TAKES OVER AT N.Y.U.
description: When John Brademas was a boy, his father, a Greek immigrant, taught him that a good education was essential. ''He said that he wouldn't be able to leave us a lot of money,'' Mr. Brademas recalled yesterday, ''but that we would have a first-rate education.''

title: U.S. Steel Chief Backs Tax Plan
description: The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, today praised President Reagan's business tax reduction proposal as spurring efforts by American industry to compete with foreign companies.

title: F.C.C. Drops Lottery Idea
description: The Federal Communications Commission, in a significant policy reversal, voted behind closed doors today to drop the idea of using a lottery to decide which of two competitors should be allowed to open a new radio station in Media, Pa.

title: Lynnwear Has Filed Under Chapter 11
description: The Lynnwear Corporation, a women's apparel manufacturer and home textiles distributor, has filed for reorganization under Chapter 11.

title: 6,000-Mile Rowing Trip Dropped
description: An Englishman's quest to row alone from the West Coast of North America to Australia came to an abrupt halt today in gale force winds that smashed his boat in two. Peter Bird, 33 years old, decided to halt his 6,000-mile journey at the 2,000-mile mark after directing an operation to salvage his 35-foot boat, which he said was a total loss. Mr. Bird was helped off the boat last night after 105 days at sea.

title: The Oldest Arcade
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: John Russell's article on arcades (''Design Notebook,'' Feb. 19) was delightful, but I must advise your readers that the ''senior specimen'' in this country, which he credited to Cleveland (1890), is the Providence Arcade (1828).

title: U.S. TO OFFER ISRAEL JETS ON EASY TERMS
description: The Reagan Administration is expected to offer Israel 15 additional F-15 fighters at preferential financing terms, to help offset the planned sale of equipment to Saudi Arabia to upgrade its F-15's, Capitol Hill sources said today.

title: FLAMES TROUNCE ISLANDERS, 11-4
description: In an apt Wild West setting, the Islanders yielded the highest goal total in their history tonight while four injured regulars, including three all-stars, watched from the sidelines.

title: Braves Near Matthews Deal
description: Gary Matthews changed his mind today and agreed to accept a trade to the Cincinnati Reds, apparently clearing the way for the Atlanta Braves to acquire the Reds' Dave Collins.

title: TOP GENERAL OUSTED
description: A day after the collapse of a right-wing military uprising, Spain's Parliament reconvened in its bulletscarred chamber today and endorsed a new cabinet to be led by Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo.

title: TROOPERS ASSIGNED TO TRENTON CRIME PATROLS
description: Governor Byrne announced today that within the next 10 days state troopers would begin helping the Trenton Police Department combat violent street crime and armed robberies of commercial establishments.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 17-year-old student at Westinghouse High School in downtown Brooklyn was shot in the back in a school bathroom by another student, who said the gun went off by accident. The victim, Steven Cutchin, of 432 Lafayette Place was listed in fair conditon at Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: U.S. Orders 21 Iranians to Leave
description: Twenty-one Iranian students arrested for visa violations have been ordered this week to leave the United States within 15 days. Janet Graham, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said 2,445 of the 64,000 Iranians in the United States had been asked to leave and 757 had gone. She said 2,900 had asked for political asylum, including three who were ordered to leave yesterday.

title: Diggs Returns to Washington - for Rehabilitation
description: The Federal Government's minimum-security prison in Alabama released another of its famous inmates yesterday. Charles C. Diggs Jr., a former Democratic member of the House of Representatives from Michigan, headed on his own for a rehabilitaton ''halfway house'' in Washington.

title: Duquesne 69, Rutgers 68
description: Ron Dixon scored 27 points and hit a pair of free throws with 13 seconds remaining to give Duquesne a 69-68 victory over Rutgers in Eastern Eight contest at the Rutgers Athletic Center tonight.

title: PHYSICIANS' PEER REVIEW MUST NOT
description: DIE To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times on Tuesday misidentified a new unit of the Scientists Institute for Public Information that provides journalists with material and listings of experts on nuclear power. The unit is the Media Resource Service.

title: F.B.I. DIRECTOR WEIGHS WAR ON DRUG TRAFFICKING
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, says that narcotics traffic has become so widespread and violent that the bureau must assume a bigger role in attacking the problem.

title: PLAYER UNION SETS MAY 29 DEADLINE
description: The executive board of the Major League Baseball Players Association voted unanimously today for a strike beginning May 29 if the dispute over major free-agent compensation is not resolved by then.

title: Sports of The Times; John Ziegler's Law
description: SOONER or later, the Rangers will presumably receive a ruling from John Ziegler, the eminent president and philosopher of the National Hockey League, regarding disciplinary action against seven players who took what little law exists in the N.H.L. into their gnarled hands in Detroit last week.

title: Five Countries Are Facing Expulsion From Olympics
description: The president of the International Olympic Committee warned today that the Olympic committees of five nations may be expelled from the Olympic movement for being under the excessive control of their governments.

title: Genetic Engineering Thrives in Boston Area
description: Last November, just as Harvard University proposed and then quickly abandoned plans to enter the genetic engineering business, a European-based company, Biogen S.A., quietly announced it would open its first United States research and development laboratory near Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: CONGRESSMEN SAY MAIL BACKS REAGAN
description: ''My mail is very demanding, very direct,'' said Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, Democrat of Queens. ''The message is: Do what the President says.''

title: Topics; Doing Time
description: Enough winter already. Last week the ice melted in the city's birdbaths -and the birds are bathing again. The sun has made it from the crabapple past the catalpa, almost to the house.

title: Topics; Have a Nice Trip
description: An acquaintance who takes literally the call to ''get America moving'' offers the following from a recent rainy night: ''My wife was due in New York on the 3 P.M. shuttle from Washington. Five P.M. - no wife.

title: CITY REJECTS CHRISTO PLAN FOR CENTRAL PARK 'GATES'
description: A controversial proposal by the artist Christo to install thousands of bannerlike ''gates'' in Central Park for a two-week period within the next few years has been rejected by Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis. The Commissioner's long-awaited decision on the ''Gates'' project was issued yesterday, in the context of an elaborate 107-page report backed by numerous exhibits and appendices.

title: The Economy
description: President Reagan ordered additional budget cuts of $3 billion to $6 billion after being informed that his advisers had underestimated Federal spending for fiscal 1982. Mr. Reagan, who announced cuts of $41.4 billion on Feb. 18, intends to keep the spending ceiling at $695.5 billion in fiscal 1982. (Page A1.)

title: F.D.A. IS URGED TO LIMIT SALT IN PROCESSED FOODS
description: More than 5,000 health professionals petitioned the Food and Drug Administration today to limit the amount of sodium in processed foods.

title: MIDEAST ROLE PROPOSED FOR EUROPE'S TROOPS
description: Active participation by Western European ground and sea forces in the Middle East and the establishment of a watch committee composed of the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and Japan to deal with developments in Southwest Asia have been proposed by an international study group.

title: BIRD WATCHERS SEEK RARE GODWIT
description: Bird watchers from as far away as Denver have flocked to the Merritt Island Wildlife Refuge, hoping to see a blacktailed godwit, a 16-inch-long bird that somehow wandered 3,500 miles from its native habitat.

title: Request for a Stay of Execution Filed for Convicted Florida Killer
description: Attorneys for Thomas Otis Knight went to Federal court today seeking a postponement of the convicted killer's execution, which is scheduled for next Tuesday.

title: Highway Commercialism
description: Throughout the country, along interstate highways and expressways where billboards have disappeared, a slight glimmer of commercialism is reappearing.

title: Rejuvenated Bullets Beat Knicks, 120-115
description: The Washington Bullets, a struggling team the last two seasons, got a vintage performance from their front line tonight as they beat the Knicks, 120-115, at the Capital Centre.

title: Grumman Expects Revenues to Rise
description: The Grumman Corporation, the Long Island-based aerospace concern and defense contractor, expects 1981 revenues to rise to $2 billion from $1.76 billion in 1980, Michael Pelehach, the president of Grumman International Inc., said here.

title: DIANA CHATS WITH QUEEN MOTHER
description: Lady Diana Spencer, who will marry Prince Charles this summer, had breakfast with Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother today after moving into Clarence House, the official London residence of the 80-year-old grandmother of the Prince.

title: South Korea Electoral Body Backs New Term for Chun
description: President Chun Doo Hwan, who seized power in 1979, won an expected Electoral College victory today and will be inaugurated Tuesday for a seven-year term.

title: Border Patrol Apprehends 55 Salvadorans in Texas
description: Agents of the United States Border Patrol apprehended 55 persons from El Salvador who paid $350 each to be smuggled into the United States and taken to Houston, a patrol spokesman said today.

title: GIVING UNISEX A SPORTING CHANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Syracuse 90, Boston College 86
description: Marty Headd and Dan Schayes led a balanced Syracuse scoring attack tonight as the Orangemen rolled to a big lead and then held off a Boston College rally to beat the Eagles, 90-86, in a Big East Conference game.

title: Cooney-Norton Bout Nearly Wrapped Up
description: After eight hours of meetings yesterday that at one point had Dennis Rappaport, Gerry Cooney's manager, ready to walk out, crying, ''This Is It! I've had it!,'' Madison Square Garden came within the signatures on contracts of holding Cooney's fight with Ken Norton on May 11.

title: FINANCIER IS CHARGED WITH FRAUD IN SEARCH FOR BONES OF PEKING MAN
description: An international search for the missing bones of the prehistoric Peking Man by the Chicago financier Christopher G. Janus was a $640,000 fraud, Federal prosecutors charged today.

title: Fujiwara, Violinist, Plays Wide-Ranging Program
description: Hamao Fujiwara's violin recital Tuesday at Alice Tully Hall was a most polished and intelligent affair - so good that Mr. Fujiwara should not let another five years pass between New York recitals. Mr. Fujiwara is no brilliant, flashy virtuoso; he makes his effects more subtly. But that doesn't mean he is any less of a technician or an artist.

title: Gardening; BONSAI LESSONS FOR THE TERRACE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Linda Yang is a regular contributor of garden articles to The Home Section. By LINDA YANG

title: 3 Brazilian Labor Leaders Given 3 1/2 Years in Prison
description: A military court here today sentenced Brazil's best-known labor leader, Luis Inacio da Silva, to three and a half years' imprisonment for encouraging a strike last year, his lawyer said.

title: Technology; New Machines Hurl Any Pitch
description: THE baseball pitching machine is never going to stand beside the printing press, the telephone or the computer in the technology honor roll. Nevertheless, as spring training gets under way this week for American (and visiting Japanese) baseball teams, it is worth observing that such machines are a remarkable achievement.

title: A Centenarian Takes the Measure of His Longevity
description: Now 100 years old, Andrew Fleischer, who contributed significantly in the early part of the century to the development of systems to measure blood pressure, says that his own longevity can be attributed to keeping his own blood pressure low.

title: Looking for a Leader
description: A talent search has been undertaken by Common Cause, a nonpartisan public affairs lobbying organization, for a successor to David Cohen as president of the Washington-based group.

title: GILBERT IS FOUND GUILTY OF ALL 34 COUNTS OF FRAUD
description: Edward M. Gilbert, a Wall Street financier who once fled to Brazil, was convicted in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday of fraudulently manipulating the 1975 stock prices of the Conrac Corporation.

title: BAKER SUPPORTS ADDED ADVISERS FOR EL SALVADOR
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader, said today after a discussion with President Reagan that he supported sending as many as 150 United States military advisers to El Salvador.

title: LIFE IN JAIL ON THE FIRST DAY
description: Jean S. Harris, having said last night that she didn't ''plan to spend the rest of my life living like an animal locked in a cage,'' refused ''tasteless'' prison meals today in favor of snacks brought by friends. A round-the-clock ''suicide watch'' continued outside her cell in the Women's Correctional Unit in Valhalla.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Electromedics Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 4,000 units of $1,000 principle amount convertible subordinated debentures due 1991, an undisclosed number of shares of common stock, and warrants to purchase some common shares. The securities are to be sold through a First Jersey Securities group.

title: MANDATORY PENSIONS ASKED IN U.S. STUDY
description: A high-level Federal commission, appointed by former President Carter, will urge in a report to Congress today that all private employers provide a minimum income for their retired workers.

title: STATEN ISLAND GAINS CITY U. SEMIFINALS
description: Staten Island and Baruch, co-favorites in the 16th annual City University of New York basketball tournament, advanced to the semifinals yesterday. But City College, the defending champion, was eliminated.

title: Deszo Ernster, 82, Bass; Sang With Met 17 Years
description: Dezso Ernster, a Hungarian bass who sang leading roles with the Metropolitan Opera, died of cancer at his home in Zurich on Feb. 15. He was 82 years old.

title: Senate Backs Agriculture Aide
description: By voice vote, the Senate yesterday confirmed Richard Lyng, former head of the American Meat Institute, to be Deputy Agriculture Secretary, the No. 2 official at the Agriculture Department. Mr. Lyng, 62 years old, served as California agriculture director when President Reagan was Governor of the state. In 1969, Mr. Lyng was named Assistant Agriculture Secretary by President Nixon.

title: A New Ending for a Storybook Romance
description: On May 1, the New York publishing house of Congdon & Lattes was to come out with a romantic novel about Prince Charles in which he falls in love and gets married. But, as it turns out, in the novel he marries the wrong woman.

title: OPEC METTING SOON NOW SEEMS UNLIKELY
description: Last week's meeting of representatives from six members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will not lead to a special meeting of the organization before the regular meeting scheduled May 25, the Indonesian oil minister, Subroto, said yesterday at a news conference in Jakarta.

title: U.S. WARNS ON LOCAL TRANSIT COST
description: The General Accounting Office, the auditing agency of Congress, said today that the growing demand of the nation's public transit systems for operating subsidies was ''approaching crisis proportions.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Blake Resources Ltd. agreed to acquire all the Canadian gas and oil interests of Cobra Oil and Gas Corporation, and of Cobra's investors, for $29.7 million (Canadian).

title: Kaufman Sees Rise In Interest Rates
description: Henry Kaufman, partner and economist at Salomon Brothers, predicted yesterday that the recent declines in short-term interest rates would not last long, and that the prime rate might fall to 17 or 18 percent in a few weeks before increasing to new record highs later this year.

title: COMPANY NEWS; Dairy Queen Inc.  Planning to Test Hard Ice Cream
description: International Dairy Queen Inc., long acknowledged as the leader in frozen dairy desserts, thanks to the popularity of its soft ice cream developed more than 40 years ago, plans to strengthen its product line.

title: INSPIRATION TO HELP THE NEEDIIEST COMES FROM VARIETY OF SOURCES
description: ''It would be too long and strange to recount the ways by which I have been brought to make this contribution,'' Randall N. Pratt of Newark, Del., wrote in a letter accompanying his $50 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which will end its 69th annual appeal on Saturday.

title: Stocks Rise as Dow Gains 8.30
description: Highlighted by an 18-point recovery by the Dow Jones industrial average in the final two hours of trading, the stock market staged a stunning recovery yesterday.

title: ANNE M'CURDY BENSEN
description: Anne McCurdy Bensen, a psychoanalyst and teacher, died yesterday of cancer at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. She was 51 years old and a resident of Croton-on-Hudson.

title: Alumni Gather in a Tribute to American Place Theater
description: Its screenwriter, Steve Tesich, and its director, Peter Yates, had worked together there, and its stars, William Hurt and Sigourney Weaver, had both acted there. So it was only natural that when it came time to hold a benefit premiere for their new movie, ''Eyewitness'' their old homestead, the American Place Theater, was selected as the beneficiary.

title: MARINO CHARGES L.I. COMPANY DUMPED WASTES ILLEGALLY INTO HARBOR
description: A Long Island waste-disposal company has illegally dumped thousands of gallons of toxic chemical wastes into Hempstead Harbor, a State Senator charged here today.

title: League Questions Rangers on Clash
description: The seven Rangers who climbed into the stands in Detroit Feb. 19 in an effort to get at debris-throwing fans discussed the incident privately today, as scheduled, with Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League's executive vice president.

title: Boxing Notebook; Cooney Bout to Garden, But Duran-Pryor Is Lost
description: Madison Square Garden got its heavyweight fight, but for the same $1.75 million it will pay Gerry Cooney and Ken Norton, it might have had a real scrap between Roberto Duran and Aaron Pryor, two of the few fighters who are not afraid of Thomas Hearns.

title: MUSIC:INDIANANS IN CONCERTO PREMIERE
description: THE program for last night's program by the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall looked perfectly plausible on paper. A Berlioz overture is often a good way to begin a concert, because most of them make a happy racket that wakes up the audience and clears out the auricular passages in preparation for possibly subtler things to come. Unfortunately, John Nelson, the orchestra's music director, chose one of Berlioz's most claptrappy efforts in the genre, the Overture to ''Les Francs-Juges,'' and could not adequately explain by his performance exactly why.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; MEDICAL HISTORY IN SOHO
description: When a medical school faces a shortage of cadavers for dissection, two unsavory characters resort to murder to make up the deficiency. A physician at the school, who is obsessed by his work, is told of their activities, but refuses to acknowledge the fact. This is the story of ''The Doctor and the Devils,'' a screenplay that was never made into a movie, but which is being adapted by the SoHo Repertory Theater, 19 Mercer Street, between Canal and Grand Streets, starting tonight at 8. It is based on a true incident of 19th-century Edinburgh, and its author is Dylan Thomas. Tickets are $5. Information: 925-2588. BLACK CINEMA ON ASTOR PL.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1981
description: International British-American amity was stressed as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher met with President Reagan at the White House. Praising Mr. Reagan's economic program, Mrs. Thatcher said that ''we are both determined to sweep away the restrictions that hold back enterprise.'' Her own austerity program has been the subject of much debate in Britain. (Page A1, Column 6.) Alexander Haig has more authority than other recent Secretaries of State but not as much as he originally wanted, under a formula set by the Reagan Administration. The White House said that the State Department would be in charge of numerous interdepartmental working groups but fewer than Mr. Haig had requested. (A1:4-5.)

title: Books of The Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt TICKETS. By Richard P. Brickner. 254 pages. Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Monday incorrectly reported the Securities and Exchange Commission's position on stock options. The commission has ruled that exchanges cannot introduce options that are already traded on other exchanges.

title: PARIS CHEFS FUME OVER FEES
description: Who's killing the great chefs of Paris? The international credit card companies - or so says a group of Paris chefs who have banded together to fight back. Angry over what they consider excessive commission rates levied against them by the companies, the chefs have organized a boycott against the credit card companies, and they are starting to get results.

title: Woman Tells Jury of Date With Racist Before Slayings
description: Mickie McHenry testified yesterday at the Federal trial of Joseph Paul Franklin that she had a date with him on Aug. 16, 1980, four days before a sniper killed two black joggers. The defendant has said publicly that he is a racist.

title: Koren on Koren
description: He acknowledges that he looks remarkably like one of the longnosed, furry people he draws nearly every week for The New Yorker, but, Edward Koren said Wednesday, his own prominent nose, small eyes and shock of wild dark hair were the limits to which his life and art combined.

title: The Editorial Notebook; CARRYING UMBRELLAS TOO FAR; by Jack Rosenthal
description: On July 13, 1977, at 9:35 P.M., Muriel Stokes had just gotten out of the shower in her New York apartment and, while listening to the radio, was about to do her hair. She switched on her dryer and, poof! The lights went out. ''Good grief,'' she thought. ''I've blacked out the whole building.'' She was, of course, wrong. She had blacked out the whole city.

title: Music: Noted in Brief; Rick Nelson Is Back, Leading Five-Piece Band
description: Rick Nelson is an intriguingly contradictory figure in pop history. He was one of rock's earliest teen idols, but in spite of a slickly packaged televison image, he managed to turn out some decent imitation rockabilly hits.

title: THE OMINOUS VACUUM IN REAGAN'S 'NEW BEGINNING'
description: To the Editor:

title: Kaiser Purchases Broncos For More Than $30 Million
description: Barely 48 hours after he had surfaced as a possible purchaser of the Denver Broncos, Edgar F. Kaiser Jr. bought the team today from Gerald H. Phipps, the majority owner.

title: Bridge: A Journey to China Begins For Group of U.S. Players
description: Seven players from the New York City metropolitan area depart today on the first leg of an unusual journey. It will take them via Hong Kong and Peking to Shanghai, where the first international tournament to be played in China begins in a week's time.

title:
RED SMITH;
Unwanted Strike
description: PEOPLE keep asking how baseball players, on a minimum salary of $32,500 and an average several times higher than that, can even consider going on strike. ''You mean they want more?'' the uninformed demand. Dick Wagner, president of the Cincinnati Reds, says he cannot believe that high-salaried players would give up their income for any extended period.

title: M.I.T. TESTING TRANSPLANTATION OF SKIN PRODUCED IN A TEST TUBE
description: An experiment in transplanting human skin produced in a test tube has begun at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. If the transplant succeeds with a single healthy volunteer, it may lead to a permanent replacement for skin lost by burn victims.

title: State Issues Embargo On Processor's Goods
description: The New York State Health Department ordered an embargo today against all canned food products from a Pennsylvania food processor suspected of having reshipped mushrooms involved in a botulism recall.

title: Glenn Gould vs. Chopin, Schubert, Liszt and Beethoven
description: The pianist Glenn Gould hasn't played a concert in 15 years, and he hasn't given many interviews.

title: Newsweek Rules Out Focus Entry for 1981
description: Newsweek Inc. is notifying people who showed interest in its test issue of Focus, a single-topic news magazine, that in spite of its enthusiastic reception the bimonthly publication will not be introduced this year because of the condition of the nation's economy.

title: SALVADOR COMMUNIST DENIES AUTHENTICITY OF DOCUMENTS
description: Shafik Jorge Handal, the secretary general of El Salvador's Communist Party, has denied the authenticity of documents made public by the State Department in which he describes promised arms shipments from Soviet bloc countries to Salvadoran guerrillas.

title: Dollar Moves Upward; Gold Off in Light Trading
description: The dollar rose against major foreign currencies yesterday despite a move by West Germany's central bank to shore up the mark by setting the stage for higher interest rates. Gold prices slumped in light trading, falling as much as $8 an ounce in New York and $13 an ounce in Europe.

title: Cash-Payer Bill Advances
description: The Senate Banking Committee today approved legislation to let merchants offer unlimited discounts to customers paying cash. The bill, like one approved by the House, would continue the present ban on a surcharge for customers using credit cards.

title: Our Own Goals
description: Washington, Feb. 26 - There has been a sharp and widely noted contrast between the harsh signals broadcast by the Reagan Administration so far and the renewed come-hither line of the Soviet leader, Leonid Brezhnev.

title: U.S. ASKS JUDGES TO FREE IRAN ASSETS FOR TRANFER
description: The Reagan Administration told Federal judges around the country today that their orders tying up Iranian assets ''must be vacated'' to clear the way for transfer of the assets by July 19, in accordance with the hostage release agreements.

title: A GRAMMY FOR GEORGE JONES'S PAINS
description: In 1979 a George Jones album came out called ''My Very Special Guests.'' The LP lived up to that title. It consisted of duets (and a couple of trios) between Mr. Jones and a galaxy of country and rock luminaries: Waylon Jennings, James Taylor, Emmylou Harris, Linda Ronstadt, Tammy Wynette, Willie Nelson, Johnny Paycheck, Elvis Costello and members of Dr. Hook and the Staple Singers.

title: OUTSPOKEN HOMOSEXUAL PRIEST WARNED
description: A Roman Catholic priest who is a homosexual has been notified that he will be expelled from his religious order unless he resigns or recants his criticism of the vow of priestly celibacy.

title: Motion by Williams For Dismissal Denied
description: A Federal Judge yesterday rejected motions by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey to dismiss various counts of an indictment charging him with bribery and conspiracy.

title: A TALE OF INFLATIONARY MILK PRICE SUPPORTS
description: To the Editor:

title: MASSEY LOSS GROWS IN QUARTER
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., one of the world's largest producers of farm equipment, reported yesterday that the continued temporary closing of some of its manufacturing facilities resulted in a widened loss in the first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31, to $81.4 million from $12.6 million in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Welland Lathrop, Dies; Avant-Garde Dancer
description: Welland Lathrop, a dancer, choreographer and painter whose San Francisco studio was the training ground for many members of the dance avant-garde, died at his home in San Francisco on Tuesday. He was 75 years old.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 27, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Bolivia's Cabinet Is Shuffled In Attempt to Mend Image
description: President Luis Garcia Meza of Bolivia brought the first two civilians into his military Government today and removed the Interior Minister in a major Cabinet shake-up apparently intended to improve Bolivia's international image.

title: 10 Deny Role in Philadelphia Plot Linked to a Slain Crime Figure
description: Phillip Testa, a reputed organized crime boss, and nine other former associates of the late Angelo Bruno pleaded not guilty today to charges of conspiring to violate Federal racketeering statutes.

title: MRS. HARRIS HAS VISITORS, WORKS IN LIBRARY PRISON
