description: Jean S. Harris appeared today to be adjusting to prison life, speaking rapidly with visitors and rearranging books as a volunteer in the library, according to Albert D. Gray Jr., the Westchester Commissioner of Corrections.

title: PUBLISHING:EVERYONE'S WRITING ABOUT MR.DOOLEY
description: FINLEY PETER DUNNE has been dead 45 years, yet he and Martin Dooley, Dunne's imaginary Chicago saloonkeeper, continue to fascinate biographers. No fewer than than five books about Dunne and his alter ego have recently been published, or are about to be, including a second by Edward J. Bander, head of the law library at Suffolk University in Boston.

title: L.I.R.R. HEAD RESIGNS POST AMID PRESSURE
description: Under pressure resulting from one of the worst winter service records in the history of the Long Island Rail Road, Francis S. Gabreski resigned yesterday as the line's president.

title: Dr. David Shakow, 80;  Noted U.S. Psychologist
description: Dr. David Shakow, a psychologist who had served for the last 13 years as scientist emeritus at the National Institute of Mental Health, died yesterday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington, D.C. He was 80 years old and a resident of Washington.

title: KOCH VISITS BROWNSVILLE AND GETS PASSING GRADE
description: Mayor Koch went to Brooklyn last night to hear what the people of Brownsville thought about the city and how he was running it. They seemed to think that, for the most part, he was doing just fine but they were not so confident about Brownsville.

title: Productivity Data For 1980 Lowered
description: Productivity in private business declined more in the fourth quarter of 1980 and for the full year than original estimates showed, the Labor Department said today.

title: ANNA RUSSELL,MAD AS EVER, IS BACK
description: Anna Russell, perhaps the vocal world's most celebrated failure - certainly its most entertaining one - will be at Carnegie Hall this evening to remind us how ridiculous classical music can be. Tonight's program of stentorian satire will include some of her familiar victims and some new ones. Rest assured that Wagner's ''Ring'' and the Gilbert and Sullivan operas will be made to squirm under the reductio ad absurdum analyses that have delighted audiences for more than 30 years.

title: MONEY FUNDS ADD $3.5 BILLION
description: A record $3.5 billion in new cash flowed into the nation's money market funds during the most recent week, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: 'Jean Brodie' at Hofstra
description: ''The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie,'' the play adapted by Jay Allen from Muriel Spark's novel about a teacher in a Scottish girls' school in the 1930's, will be presented by the drama department of Hofstra University through March 8 at the university's West End Theater in Hempstead, L.I. The director is Dr. Miriam Tulin of the drama department.

title: China to Open Quake Site
description: Foreign scientists will be invited next year to tour Tangshan, center of an earthquake in 1976 that killed 242,000 people, the New China News Agency reported today. The city has been closed to foreigners since the quake struck.

title: 'FISCAL CONSERVATISM' MAULS MASSACHUSETTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Cable Appears Set on an Ad Agency
description: Although CBS Cable declined to confirm this yesterday, it is understood that after two or three months of looking it has decided to give its advertising to Drossman Yustein Clowes.

title: New City Notes Average 10.28%
description: New York City raised $200 million yesterday on two issues of tax and revenue anticipation notes at an average interest cost of 10.28 percent.

title: The Talk of Lake Placid
description: A year after the torch was extinguished at the close of the 1980 Winter Olympics, remnants and reminders of the games linger everywhere in this tiny Adirondack village.

title: Bernadette Devlin Has Left Hospital
description: Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, recovering from an assassination attempt on Jan. 16, left Belfast's Royal Victoria Hospital Tuesday and went to a secret location with her husband and children, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: JET CREW TO BE ASKED ABOUT 'NEAR MISS'
description: Federal officials said yesterday they had asked for statements from the crew of an Argentine jet to aid their inquiry into why the plane, flying in clouds, came close to crashing into a television mast atop a World Trade Center tower in lower Manhattan at 10:05 P.M. last Friday.

title: Treasury Notes Bring 13.79%; Issue-Heavy Market Weak
description: Prices of fixed-income debt issues continued to sag yesterday as the credit markets accommodated the week's numerous large borrowings. But given the reluctance of the retail trade, mainly the large institutions, to buy anything but short-term securities, dealers said the price declines were relatively modest in all sectors of the market.

title: RACE AND THE COLLEGE CAMPUS
description: To the Editor:

title: Sigma Chi Fraud Suspect Pleads Guilty in U.S. Court
description: Nancy J. Cain pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here yesterday to wire fraud and impersonating a Federal employee in a case involving the fraternity Sigma Chi.

title: A Revised 'Heaven's Gate' Will Be Shown on April 18
description: ''Heaven's Gate,'' the $36 million western that had only brief exposure last year before it was withdrawn, will be shown in its re-edited form on April 18, it was announced today.

title: Ford Belgium Plans $290 Million Outlay
description: The Ford Motor Company's Belgium subsidiary said that it will invest nearly $290 million over the next two years to modernize its assembly plants in the city of Genk.

title: SONGS BY ARETHA FRANKLIN, WITH FEELING AND FIREWORKS
description: ARETHA FRANKLIN is one of the great popular singers of our time, but one never knows quite what to expect at her concerts. When Miss Franklin is involved in her material, she uses her extraordinary musicianship to connect emotionally with her audience. But she has often showed an unerring instinct for picking the most inappropriate material and for sabotaging the pacing of her sets with gimmicky, utterly banal stage routines.

title: U.S. Opposes U.N. Plan On Rights Issue in Chile
description: The United States joined Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay today in voting against a resolution authorizing the United Nations Human Rights Commission to continue to give special attention to the human rights situation in Chile.

title: FUEL CORPORATION SALARIES ARE CUT
description: President Reagan, bearing down on high Federal salaries, and apparently on the mission of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation as well, has ordered steep cuts in the pay of six senior officials who have been earning as much as $150,000 a year with the corporation.

title: POPE SAID TO ORDER EXPLORATION OF TIES WITH PEKING
description: Pope John Paul II has asked Vatican aides to examine the possibilities of resuming pastoral work in China and of opening diplomatic relations with Peking, according to Roman Catholic sources here.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Metropolitan Report last Thursday comparing college costs included an incorrect figure for Fordham University. The total annual cost for tuition, room and board will be $6,800 starting in September.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AIC Photo Inc. has elected Arthur Dubroff a vice president.

title: 45 Felled by Fumes in Florida
description: Forty-five persons were treated at hospitals after inhaling fumes from leaking chemicals at a Fort Lauderdale company, Rule Pool Services, officials said today. Leaks of liquid chlorine and muriatic acid last night forced the evacuation of 200 persons at a nearby hotel and restaurant.

title: ART:FIRST SOLO SHOW FOR MANUEL NERI
description: THE exhibition of sculpture and drawings by Manuel Neri that is on view at the Cowles Gallery, 420 West Broadway, is, oddly enough, the first solo show to be devoted to this interesting artist in a New York gallery. Now in his early 50's, Mr. Neri is a well-known figure on the San Francisco art scene, where he has been exhibiting his work fairly regularly for a quarter of a century and where some example of it can usually be seen in one or another gallery or museum. (Just now, there is also a show of his work on view at the Seattle Art Museum.) But it often happens that sculpture ''travels'' slower than painting -for one thing, it is more expensive to crate and ship. And in Mr. Neri's case, the pace was undoubtedly slowed by the fact that he has long worked in an idiom that does not quite conform to any of the fashions that dominate sculptural art.

title: GUS HALL, THE BIT PLAYER, IS STAR AT MOSCOW PARLEY
description: The American's face is square-jawed, with a gauntness about the cheeks; his eyes, under a tuft of white hair, are shy but have an inward certainty. It is the kind of face that would seem appropriate for a farmer in the Middle West.

title: WELL-CONNECTED LATIN REBEL
description: The contact man between El Salvador's guerrilla movement and the Soviet bloc is an old-guard Communist who grew up as a small-town storekeeper's son and was a university student leader.

title: IN BASQUE AREA, A SINGULAR CALM PREVAILS AFTER REVOLT IN MADRID
description: All Monday night, Spaniards clung to their radios to find out whether the military insurgency in Madrid would spread around the country. Through the static came reassurance. From Cadiz, Barcelona, Valladolid, Zaragoza, San Sebastian, the local correspondents repeated the same words: ''Everything is normal.''

title: ECONOMIC PANEL SPLITS ON POLICY
description: Democratic members of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, taking issue with President Reagan's economic program, called today for more moderate monetary and budget policies.

title: Veterans Agency Chief Resigns
description: Max Cleland's resignation as veterans administrator was accepted today by President Reagan, who said Mr. Cleland's willingness to serve throughout the transition was ''greatly appreciated.'' The President named Rufus H. Wilson, the No. 2 man in the Veterans Administration, to be acting administrator. John Behan, a Long Island assemblyman, has been nominated to head the agency.

title: I.R.S. TO ALLOW BAPTIST HOSPITAL ENOUGH FUNDS TO MAKE PAYROLL
description: The Internal Revenue Service agreed yesterday to release part of this week's Medicare payment to the Baptist Medical Center in Brooklyn so that it could meet its payroll for its 800 workers today. The agency had stopped payment in an effort to get the hospital to pay the $1.3 million it owes in back taxes.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Israel Says Egyptians Delay Normalization of Relations

title: Elliott Carter Wins Prize for Orchestral Works
description: One of the most lucrative and highly regarded awards in the world of music, the $78,500 Ernst von Siemens Music Prize, has been won by the New York composer Elliott Carter, it was announced yesterday in Munich.

title: STOCKS RISE 12.41 MORE IN BUSY DAY
description: Extending its spectacular late-Wednesday rally, the stock market moved broadly higher yesterday on a sharp increase in trading volume. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 12.41 points, to 966.81, after rebounding 18 points in Wednesday's final two hours.

title: CITY PATROLS TO COMBAT STREET CRIME WITH $4.5 MILLION IN OVERTIME PAY
description: Mayor Koch's office announced a $4.5 million overtime program yesterday that it said would let the Police Department assign 300 regular officers to fight street crime in 35 neighborhoods throughout New York City. The program will begin March 1 and end June 1.

title: OFFSHORE DRILLING RESISTED ON COAST
description: State and local officials say they will fight Interior Secretary James G. Watt's proposal to reopen four offshore areas for oil and gas exploration.

title: GOODRICH: NOT JUST A TIRE MAKER
description: Akron's rubber executives have long believed the best way to run a tire company is to make as many tires as possible. But the B.F. Goodrich Company is proving that a tire company does not necessarily have to follow that path to make a profit.

title: MORE TOXINS FOUND BY STATE AT ITS BIRMINGHAM BUILDING
description: The New York State Health Department has discovered additional and deadlier toxins in a state office building known to have been contaminated with polychlorinated biphenyls. A cleanup of the building in downtown Binghamton was halted today by the department.

title: Restaurants; by Mimi Sheraton; North Italian fare and a brasserie.
description: NEXT to moving its location, the most trying test for a wellestablished restaurant is a change of chefs. By all indications, based on recent visits, Salta in Bocca, on Madison Avenue between 33d and 34th Streets, has weathered just such a change and during the last four months has exhibited no evidence of disruption in the kitchen's performance, a tribute to the experience and diligence of its owner, Fulvio Tramontina. Since it opened four and a half years ago, this simply decorated, pleasant north Italian restaurant with its rose-glow walls and its abundance of candy-box oil paintings has been mobbed at lunch by business people in the area. The noise and pace at that time of day are frantic and dizzying. But at night, things calm down to an easygoing hum, and on Friday and Saturday nights, when the neighborhood virtually shuts down, Salta in Bocca is an uncrowded and comfortable find, a place worth remembering for a leisurely and elegantly satisfying meal.

title: FOR WOMEN 45 TO 65, A GROUP TO PROMOTE THEIR CAUSES
description: A new organization called the Older Women's League was chartered in Manhattan this week primarily for women between the ages of 45 and 65, a period that some have described as ''that no woman's land between menopause and Medicare.''

title: PUDGY,FIRST LADY OF INSULT, IN TOWN
description: In politics one important professional asset is the ability to ''work a room.'' Images leap to mind of such smooth practitioners of the art as Nelson A. Rockefeller, Louis J. Lefkowitz and Hugh L. Carey, gliding from table to table at a public function, shaking hands, clapping shoulders, grasping elbows, remembering names and all sorts of personal and arcane minutiae, and passing the time of day, all to make the recipient of this political attention feel, for no matter how briefly, important.

title: SUPPLY-SIDE GAFFE
description: To the Editor:

title: KANSAS GAS EXECUTIVE ADDS POST
description: Wilson K. Cadman, 53, president of the Kansas Gas and Electric Company, has been appointed to the additional position of chief executive officer. He succeeds Ralph Fiebach, 63, who continues as chairman and head of the executive committee.

title: Key Rates
description: Split rate, 18.50-19.00** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: No Headline
description: REBELS CONTINUE ATTACKS: According to a caption supplied by an Iranian photographer, photograph shows an abandoned Soviet armored car and truck that were am-bushed by Afghan guerrillas in Rokhai, near Kabul, the site of a Russian base, in Afghanistan. The rebels also said they had killed 12 Soviet soldiers.

title: School's Pupils Back After Virus Scare
description: School officials said that almost threequarters of the 834 students of the Chestnut Hill elementary school were attending classes.

title: 5 Killed as Cars Pile Up in Fog
description: Five persons were killed and 10 seriously injured last night in two multiple collisions involving 16 vehicles on a 20-mile stretch of Interstate 10 shrouded by dense fog and smoke, the state police said.

title: Hynes Is Optimistic On Adding Marshals
description: Fire Commissioner Charles J. Hynes said yesterday that he was optimistic that New York City would provide funds to increase the force of 150 fire marshals to 200. Mr. Hynes, in a news conference at department headquarters, 110 Church Street, said that even this increase would leave the force short. Fire marshals investigate the causes of fires and, in cases of arson, work with the police to develop evidence for arrest and prosecution.

title: SPAIN GETS AN ALL-CIVILIAN CABINET THREE DAYS AFTER ATTEMPTED COUP L eopoldo Calvo Sotelo
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo announced a Cabinet tonight that for the first time since the death of Franco in 1975 has no military member.

title: PATTERSON BEGINS ROAD BACK TO YANKEES
description: Five years ago, Gil Patterson was the brightest pitching prospect in the Yankee organization. This winter he was begging for an invitation to spring training and working as a $5-an-hour parking attendant at a local nightclub in order to help pay his mortgage.

title: 38 Missing as Soviet Ship Sinks
description: All 38 crewmen of a Soviet freighter were reported missing after it sank in stormy seas in the Tsugaru Strait today, the Maritime Safety Agency reported. The agency said it sent patrol boats to the scene after receiving a distress call from the 5,923-ton Komsomolets Nakhodki, which was on its way to the Soviet Union from Muroran, north of Hakodate.

title: by Claudia Wright
description: Under secret agreements, America remains in exclusive control of nuclear weapons that it has placed in Greece. These agreements contradict Greek leaders' public statements to the contrary and proclaimed commitments by Athens and Washington to Greek sovereignty over bases used by American forces and to joint control over nuclear weapons that America stores on Greek territory.

title: The Self-Defense Rush
description: A recent study conducted at the University of Michigan concludes that more than two million handguns are added to the domestic supply each year, and there may be well over 50 million in private hands. That's a lot of firepower. And a lot of just plain citizens, women as well as men, are arming themselves. In Connecticut and Miami, for example, self-defense schools are cropping up that include courses in firearms. In California, there are waiting lists at gun schools. But who is likely to be shot by these new weapons? Not the criminals.

title: FRENCH AIDE, IN U.S., SAYS SOVIET MUST LET POLAND SOLVE ITS CRISIS
description: France's Foreign Minister warned the Soviet Union in a speech here today that Poland ''must be free'' to seek its own solution to its problems ''without foreign interference.''

title: WHERE STORYTELLERS TRADE THEIR TALES
description: ''ONCE upon a time ... '' The words have a magic that cuts through the noise of the surrounding world. Telling a story can be as simple as passing on a bit of news - which may be how the first story got told - or as complicated a thing as the creation of another world. A story may be told in a whisper to the only other person in a moonlit room, or roared out in a rich accent to great crowds. The storyteller - a parent, a friend or an entertainer - draws his listener in, in simple, age-old fashion.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY SLAVADORAN COMMUNIST CHIEF
description: Following is the text of a Feb 9. statement by Shafik Jorge Handal, the secretary general of El Salvador's Communist Party, and translated from the Spanish by The New York Times: Special to the New York Times

title: Asarco Spending to Rise
description: Asarco Inc. plans 1981 capital spending of about $150 million, up from $130 million in 1980, Charles Barber, the company chairman, told analysts in New York yesterday. He said the 1981 capital spending would be used mainly for current projects, to improve productivity and for any investment that would yield above-average returns. The company may also invest in an expansion of its Southern Peru Copper Corporation affiliate's Toquepala copper project, which would cost $200 million, he said.

title: Steinbrenner, Jackson to Talk
description: Steinbrenner said Thursday he planned to meet Sunday with Reggie Jackson regarding the outfielder's contract. ''We have arranged a meeting on Sunday when he reports and I'm planning to be prepared with some concrete proposal regarding the new contract,'' said Steinbrenner. Jackson's five-year contract, signed in 1976, expires at the end of this season.

title: CHAMBER MUSIC: CANTILENA AT Y
description: AN admirable Piano Quartet composed by Sergei Taneyev in 1906 was given its first American performance by the Cantilena Chamber Players on Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y. If it seems strange that a work of quality should have gone unheard here for three-quarters of a century, it should be remembered that although this Russian composer lived from 1856 to 1915, much of his music did not get into print until the 1950's.

title: Slain Youth, 16, Is Added To Death List in Atlanta
description: Sixteen-year-old Patrick Rogers, who died of a blow to the head in December, was added to Atlanta's list of slain and missing black children today, bringing the list's total of unsolved cases to 19 deaths and two disappearances.

title: by William L.Hauser
description: We learned the lessons of Vietnam too well. As a result, we are today exposing our country's vital interests to deadly peril. After 50,000 deaths and untold billions of dollars, we emerged from Vietnam with two truths burned into our national soul. The first is that modern war is so costly in blood and treasure that countries dare wage it only to secure interests truly vital. The second is that lacking a national consensus about our vital interests, war cannot be won against a determined foe. Before Vietnam, the United States intervened militarily in Lebanon, in 1958, and the Dominican Republic, in 1964; since then, we have recoiled from similar involvement in Angola, Ethiopia, and in Iran.

title: KNICKS LOSE, 120-105
description: The score of Wednesday night's game between the Knicks and the Bullets was reported incorrectly yesterday. The score was Bullets 120, Knicks 105.

title: DAVIS IN FOX PLEA TODAY
description: Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman who is offering to pay $60 a share - or nearly $700 million in cash - for the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, will take his bid directly to company executives today.

title: MELANGE OF ART AND CRAFTS
description: More than a hundred works in ceramics, painting, prints, drawings, assemblages, glass, photographs, textiles, furniture and both architectural design and industrial design projects are being exhibited by teachers and students at the Rhode Island School of Design. The show is held every other year at the Providence, R.I., institution, one of the best-known American art and design faculties. ,

title: French Jobless Rate Up
description: France faces another six months of rising unemployment, the national statistics institute said today. In its latest economic survey, the agency said ''a very sharp acceleration'' in the number of unemployed during the first half of this year could be expected despite Government attempts to slow the rise. The institute said 6.7 percent of the population was without work in the last quarter of 1980 compared with 6.4 percent in the third quarter and 6.3 percent in the final 1979 quarter.

title: EL SALVADOR STRUGGLES TO REDUCE ITS NONCOMBAT KILLINGS
description: The old woman described watching the soldiers shoot her husband in the head. She regretted that they had taken the time to go back for the mattresses.

title: Manzoni Requiem Sunday
description: The Manzoni Requiem, Verdi's operatic tribute to the Italian novelist and poet Alessandro Manzoni, who wrote ''I Promessi Sposi'' (''The Betrothed''), will be performed by the choir of St. Bartholomew's Church, with soloists, Sunday at 4 P.M. at the church, Park Avenue at 51st Street.

title: Music: Noted in Brief; Oliver Steiner Performs Series of Violin Sonatas
description: Oliver Steiner, a violinist who teaches at the Eastman School of Music, came to Abraham Goodman Hall on Tuesday night to play sonatas by Vivaldi, Mozart, Beethoven and Grieg and shorter works by Bloch and Wieniawski. He was assisted at the piano by Joseph Werner.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: HARVARD LETTER BY BOK URGES RACIAL UNDERSTANDING
description: In a strongly worded statement about racial issues that have stirred debate on the Harvard campus, Derek C. Bok, the university's president, has reaffirmed Harvard's commitment to affirmative action programs in admitting students and hiring faculty members.

title: MRS. BHUTTO IS HELD BRIEFLY AFTER FOES OF REGIME MEET
description: The widow of President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was hanged in 1979, was arrested briefly today in Lahore, where she had met with other opposition leaders to plan strikes and other measures aimed at bringing down the Government of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. She was reportedly put on a flight for Karachi, where she lives.

title: 3 Men Hanged in Malaysia
description: Three men convicted of firearms offenses were hanged today in a Malaysian prison. Phang Chin Hock, 31 years old, Su Ah Peng, 26, and Hong Yoke Chew, 23, were the first people executed in Malaysia this year. More than a dozen people have been executed since strict firearms laws were introduced in 1975.

title: by Hilton Kramer
description: MORE than 16 years have passed since the late William C. Seitz, then a distinguished curator at the Museum of Modern Art, organized a comprehensive exhibition of contemporary Israeli art at the Jewish Museum. Called ''Art Israel,'' the show traveled extensively on the American museum circuit, and thus introduced the accomplishments of living Israeli painters and sculptors to the American art public.

title: DR. LOUIS J. CAMUTI, CAT SPECIALIST
description: Dr. Louis J. Camuti, a veterinarian in the New York metropolitan area for 60 years whose practice was limited to the treatment of cats, many of them belonging to celebrities, died Tuesday of a heart attack in his automobile on the way to his home in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 87 years old.

title: TV Weekend; A TALE ABOUT WITCHES; PRESIDENTS REMEMBERED
description: LAST Friday's television movie on ABC featured supernatural monsters emerging from the bowels of the earth to attack an offshore oil-drilling station. Tonight at 9, ''Midnight Offerings'' tackles the burning issues of witches today. So far, the trend is scarier than the product.

title: JERRY ROSSMAN
description: Jerry Rossman, an owner of industrial parks, was killed on Monday in an avalanche while skiing in the Canadian Rockies near Banff.

title: BRESHNEV, IN MEETING, ASSURES CASTRO OF SOVIET SUPPORT
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, met today with President Fidel Castro of Cuba and assured him of continuing support in the face of ''an anti-Cuban campaign by United States imperialists,'' according to a statement issued by Tass, the Soviet Government's press agency.

title: ART: JUICY ABSTRACTIONS BY KATHERINE PORTER
description: ART is built upon other art in almost every case. That is not to say that it copies other art, but that particles of energy blow this way and that, the way plants mysteriously turn up on the opposite side of the Atlantic from the one in which they are habitually seen.

title: 49 Hurt in Coast Collision
description: A crowded Municipal Railway bus collided with a flatbed truck carrying gravel near downtown San Francisco in the morning rush-hour today, injuring at least 49 persons, the authorities said.

title: A SINGER DREAMS OF A DUET
description: P LACIDO DOMINGO, who was wearing a black dinner suit, was singing the praises of Barbra Streisand, who was wearing white mink. ''Her phrasing! Her legato! So exciting! I wish some classical singers could do it as well,'' he said. Since both were among the guests at the Grammy party Walter Yetnikoff, president of CBS Records Group, gave at the Four Seasons Wednesday night, an on

title: Waste Cleanup Program Backed
description: A top environmental official said today that the Reagan Administration would not delay carrying out a national program to clean up hazardous waste sites. Michael Cook, deputy assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency's Office of Hazardous Response, told members of a House Commerce subcommittee that there would be ''no disruption of the process.''

title: Attention Must Be Paid
description: The Reagan Administration has produced such a circus of headlines concerning its proposed budget and tax cuts that insufficient attention has been paid to the massive military spending increases also projected.

title: STAGE:WILLIAM HURT IN 'CHILDE BYRON'
description: MAYBE William Hurt has now been discovered by Hollywood (''Altered States,'' ''Eyewitness''), but he hasn't lost any of that crazy intensity that makes him a joy to watch in the theater. What makes this talented actor so special - and, inevitably, a star - is his ability to create his own reality on stage. While he can create a powerful character when he wants to (as he did with Kenneth Talley in the original production of ''Fifth of July''), he's prepared to be fascinating without any help from a playwright. And that's just what he does in Romulus Linney's ''Childe Byron,'' a comic-book version of the life of Lord Byron that opened at the Circle Repertory Company last night.

title: OFFICIAL INDICTED BY WESTCHESTER IN BRIBERY CASE
description: Westchester's deputy commissioner of public safety services was indicted today in connection with an alleged attempt by a doctor to gain his son's admission to New York Medical College through bribery.

title: Porcelains, plain and fancy
description: EUROPEAN porcelains, from the most modest cup and saucer to works with aristocratic pedigrees, will be the subject of three sales next week in New York's auction houses. Included are wares from most of the factories that flourished in the 18th and 19th centuries.

title: World's Tallest Man Dead at 55
description: Don A. Koehler, who was listed in the Guinness Book of Records as the world's tallest man at 8 feet 2 inches, died yesterday at his home in suburban Chicago. He was 55 years old. Relatives said that he had been recuperating from a heart ailment.

title: Court Ruling Allows Suit on False Charge
description: A New York State Appellate Court has ruled that George Whitmore Jr., who was falsely accused of the 1963 murders of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert, can sue the city for ''malicious prosecution.''

title: Fumes Hospitalize Print Plant Workers
description: Seven employees of the Eastern Color Printing Company were hospitalized after being exposed to an ''extremely toxic gas'' that was released when two chemicals were mixed, company officials said.

title: Broadway; Tony Randall plans to direct 'comedy puzzle' from Britain.
description: TONY RANDALL will direct a British comedy, ''Who's Who?'', which is to go into rehearsal on April 21 and open late in May. The comedy, by Keith Waterhouse and Willis Hall - best known for their ''Billy Liar'' - is of the kind most loved by producers: one set, four characters and enough sex to be interesting, without being offensive. ''The producer - I didn't even know her -called and said, 'Do you want to direct this?' and I told her to send me the script,'' Mr. Randall said. ''It's a very clever play, extremely clever, with baffling problems. It's not quite a farce. A comedy puzzle, I call it.''

title: GENENTECH REPORTS INTERFERON-YEAST TIE
description: Genentech Inc. reported yesterday that its scientists, working with researchers from the University of Washington, had succeeded in producing a type of human interferon in genetically engineered yeast.

title: 'SUNDAY LOVERS,' AN INTERNATIONAL MELANGE
description: ''SUNDAY LOVERS,'' which starts today at the Embassy 3 and other theaters, is a four-part sketch-film in which the bad outweighs the good three-to-one. Because the good sketch, ''An Englishman's Home,'' an English farce written by Leslie Bricusse and directed by Bryan Forbes, opens the picture, it's very easy (if one is desperate) to go see it and leave without having to endure the rest of the picture.

title: ANNENBERG GRANTS TV $150 MILLION FOR COURSES
description: Walter H. Annenberg and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting jointly announced today a gift of $150 million from Mr. Annenberg to create an innovative program of college courses for Americans in their own homes.

title: Four Charged On Kickbacks
description: A Federal grand jury charged today that a national trucking concern had paid more than $110,000 in kickbacks to three former American Airlines freight managers over 12 years in return for freight business from the airline.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT'S HIDDEN CHARMS
description: Chris-Craft Industries looks as though it couldn't charm a soul on Wall Street. Earnings are down at its television division and at its chemical unit, the world's largest maker of DDT. Its decision to sell its boat division, for which it is best known, resulted in a $21 million loss and sent 1980 earnings deep into the red.

title: Allbritton Blocked In Riggs Bank Bid
description: A Federal judge issued a temporary restraining order today against a bid by Joe L. Allbritton, former publisher of The Washington Star, to acquire 600,000 shares of the Riggs National Bank, the largest bank in the capital.

title: Braniff Seeking Employee Pay Cuts
description: The Braniff International Corporation is asking its employees to take pay cuts of up to 10 percent to help it recover from huge operating losses, a company spokesman said.

title: PANEL ASKS RISE IN IMMIGRATION, WITH TIGHTER LAW ENFORCEMENT
description: A Federal study commission called today for a ''modest increase'' in legal immigration, a one-time amnesty for most illegal aliens and strict enforcement measures, including penalties for employers who hired illegal aliens.

title: COUNCIL REJECTS CALL FOR BOYCOTT OF 'FORT APACHE'
description: After two and a half hours of impassioned debate, the New York City Council voted yesterday to return to committee a resolution calling for a boycott of the film ''Fort Apache, the Bronx.''

title: IOWA, BIG 10 LEADER, TOPS MICHIGAN, 69-66
description: A pair of free throws by Vince Brookins with 36 seconds left gave Iowa a 3-point lead and allowed the Hawkeyes to beat Michigan, 69-66, tonight in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: 'ONE WILD MOMENT'
description: ''ONE WILD MOMENT,'' a 1977 Claude Berri comedy that opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, gives the impression of having once been a short film that has been drawn out to feature length without anyone's having considered the consequences and obligations. Featurelength films, even French comedies like this one, need to have some sort of point of view.

title: HAIG IS GIVEN BROAD POLICY POWER, BUT LESS THAN HE INITIALLY SOUGHT
description: The Reagan Administration has given Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. more authority than his recent predecessors but not as much as he originally wanted.

title: Index; International
description: Gus Hall, neglected in U.S., is a star at Moscow party congress A2 Brezhnev, in meeting, assures Castro of support A2 U.S. to allow Poland to defer payment on $90 million in debts A3 Iraq says its forces are ready for new drive against Iran A3 Sihanouk ready to talk with Pol Pot supporters A3 Bhutto's widow is arrested briefly in Pakistan A3 In Basque region, a calm prevails after Madrid insurgency A4 Around the World A5 French Foreign Minister, in U.S., warns Soviet on Poland A7 U.S. rejects Salvadoran leftists' offer to hold talks A8 Salvador Communist denies writing documents released by U.S. A8 Text of Salvadoran Communist Party leader's statement A8 Pope tells aides to explore re- sumption of Peking ties A9 Government/Politics Ohio G.O.P. seeks redistricting with aid of computer A13 I.R.S. eases demand for back taxes owed by hospital B3 General Around the Nation A10 Trial of Berrigans and 6 others reminiscent of '60's A10 Kansas court strikes down libel ruling against blacks A12 Hotels finding more interest in fire safety A17 The City B3 Statements sought from jet crew in near miss of Trade Center B3 Health/Science M.I.T. begins test with artificial skin transplant A16 Religion Outspoken homosexual priest gets warning from his order A10 Weekend Weekender Guide C1

title: WILLIAM HURT IN 'EYEWITNESS'
description: A NOTE of warning to that portion of the movie-going public Alfred Hitchcock used to refer to as ''the plausibles'': Stay away from ''Eyewitness,'' a thoroughly delightful but far from plausible mystery melodrama that operates exclusively on high spirits and a no-nonsense intelligence that is never sidetracked by coherence.

title: SIHANOUK IS READY FOR POL POT TALKS
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the one-time Cambodian chief of state, has agreed to talk with supporters of former Prime Minister Pol Pot about forming a resistance movement against the Vietnamese-backed Government now in Phnom Penh.

title: Ella H. Hutch, 57, Dies; A San Francisco Official
description: Ella Hill Hutch, the first black woman elected to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, was found dead in her apartment yesterday. She was 57 years old.

title: Regan Criticizes Visitor On Her Economic Policy
description: Treasury Secretary Donald Regan today criticized Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's handling of the economy.

title: Music:Noted in Brief; Badura-Skoda Performs On Piano at the 92d St. Y
description: When the Viennese virtuoso Paul Badura-Skoda played a piano recital at the 92d Street Y on Sunday night, he knew exactly what he was doing. Each composition was clearly mapped out and forcefully executed.

title: Sexual Politics
description: As a result of several years' planning by the New Jersey Board of Education, the state's schools should be required as of 1983 to teach their pupils about human sexuality, birth control and the facts of family life. But this needed plan will be realized only if the Legislature votes down a bill, just released by the Assembly's Education Committee, that would abolish the program.

title: New York Air
description: New York Air said that it would increase the number of low-price flights on its New York-Washington route to meet increasing demand. The airline, which is challenging Eastern Airlines' dominance in shuttle flights between New York and Washington, said it plans to add four flights a day starting on Sunday. With the additional sevice, the airline will operate 14 round-trip flights between the two cities each weekday and 12 flights on Saturday and Sunday.

title: PLAY:WITH STOPPARD IN SCHNITZLERLAND
description: HARTFORD ''UNDISCOVERED COUNTRY,'' Tom Stoppard's version of Arthur Schnitzler's ''Das Weite Land,'' is a kaleidoscopic study of hedonism in turn-of-the-century Vienna. This is a city in which infidelity and tennis are favorite sports, psychoanalysis is dismissed as a mere ''local pastime,'' and tact is considered ''a third-rate virtue.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM FINAL REPORT OF COMMISSION ON IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEE
description: Following are excerpts from ''U.S. Immigration Policy and the National Interest,'' the final report of the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy:

title: REPORT CITES SWEATSHOP ABUSES
description: Garment trucking companies with ties to organized crime and exploitative Seventh Avenue manufacturers bear a major responsibility for conditions in garment factory sweatshops in New York City, State Senator Franz Leichter charged yesterday.

title: OLD TIMERS GET A NEW BAND
description: A BAND that has hopes of being New York's answer to the New Orleans Preservation Hall Jazz Band - the Harlem Blues and Jazz Band - has moved into the Ginger Man, the restaurant at 51 West 64th Street, to play Thursdays through Saturdays, starting this weekend.

title: KANSAS HIGH COURT VOIDS LIBEL RULING AGAINST BLACKS
description: The Kansas Supreme Court today struck down a libel ruling against four black former medical students at the University of Kansas who had been sued by a white administrator for defamation of character after they filed a civil rights complaint.

title: 200 DALI FORGERIES ARE SEIZED
description: Two hundred forgeries of engravings by Salvador Dali have been seized and two men have been arrested in an effort to trace thousands of the fakes spread across two continents, the police reported yesterday.

title: Less Damage
description: Winding up a court case that has gone on for a decade, a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan has directed that George Harrison, a former Beatle, pay $587,000 for having ''subconsciously'' plagiarized a melody by John Mack for Mr. Harrison's 1971 hit ''My Sweet Lord.''

title: DEMOCRATS ENTANGLED IN DISPUTE OVER PARTY POSITIONS FOR BLACKS
description: The Democratic National Committee began a two-day session today designed to culminate in the election of Charles T. Manatt of Los Angeles as its new chairman, but quickly got entangled in disputes over party offices for blacks.

title: Gulf Keeps Stake In Canada Holding
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said that it did not intend to reduce its 60 percent interest in its Gulf Canada Ltd. unit ''either directly or indirectly,'' contradicting recent press reports that it was seeking to sell all or part of the unit.

title: Article 022184 -- No Title
description: A police raid on an American Legion hall in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn on Wednesday night resulted in the recovery of $75,000 worth of stolen property, including stereo units, office equipment, power tools, clothing and expensive roller skates.

title: NASSAU ORDERED TO REDUCE COUNT FOR JAIL BY 50%
description: A Federal judge found today that the Nassau County jail was unconstitutionally overcrowded and ordered state and county officials to reduce its 930-inmate population by half within 60 days. He warned that if they did not do so he would have no choice but to intervene and take ''appropriate and effective'' action.

title: Missouri Synod Break With Sister Church Asked
description: The Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod theology commission recommended today that the 2.6-million-member church break relations with its sister denomination, the American Lutheran Church.

title: DANCE:MARTHA GRAHAM PRESENTS 'ACTS OF LIGHT'
description: Amid a series of gala events that brought out everyone from Liza Minnelli and Andy Warhol to the Danish diplomatic corps, Martha Graham presented her newest work tonight at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are both determined to sweep away the restrictions that hold back enterprise.

title: Amy Adelson, D.A. Ross, Lawyers, Are Married
description: Amy Adelson and Daniel A. Ross, associates with the New York law firm of Botein, Hays, Sklar & Herzberg, were married at the Windows on the World last evening by Rabbi Judith Lewis.

title: Psychodrama in El Salvador
description: Can it be that there's method in the madness of tying President Reagan's prestige to that of a junta in a coffee-bean republic?

title: CAREY AND REGAN EXCHANGE BARBS ON TRANSIT PLANS
description: Governor Carey and a man presumed to be interested in taking over his job, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, took turns sniping at each other yesterday as they discussed the merits of President Reagan's proposals to reduce Federal spending.

title: OWNERS' STRIKE INSURANCE IN DOUBT
description: Major league baseball's club owners believe they have bought $50 million in strike insurance, but as much as $40 million of it could be in jeopardy, sources in the insurance industry said yesterday.

title: Lebanese Leader to Visit Libya
description: President Elias Sarkis of Lebanon has accepted an invitation from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to visit Libya, a Libyan diplomat said here today. No date has been set so far, the diplomat said.

title: 15.31% NOTE YIELD LURES INVESTORS FOR CHRYSLER
description: Investors, wary about Chrysler's chances for survival even with Government loan guarantees, nevertheless expressed eagerness yesterday to buy $400 million in federally guaranteed notes at a yield of 15.31 percent.

title: Report of a Gunman Causes PATH Delay
description: Thousands of rush-hour commuters were delayed last night when service on PATH trains between Manhattan and Journal Square was suspended for 38 minutes because of a report of a man with a gun on the tracks, the police said.

title: 'WHY NOT LICENSE POTENTIAL CRIMINALS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Pfizer's In-House Operation
description: A DECADE ago, when Pfizer Inc. set up Adforce, its in-house media department, there was grumbling from the pharmaceutical company's advertising agencies, Robert Geller, president of Adforce, recalled yesterday. The agencies complained that the setup, which denied them the full 15 percent media commission, was ''unreasonable.'' And they warned that ''we would quickly learn the error of our ways,'' Mr. Geller said.

title: FRESH FACES GIVE BROADWAY A NEW LOOK
description: CASTS in Broadway shows change, and when they do, the shows change with them. A new actor brings a new chemistry, sometimes - but not always -beneficial, to a play or musical. Sometimes many actors join a show, not all at once, but over the course of time, and yet the show somehow keeps all its old virtues intact. Other times, the show is changed beyond recognition. What follows is a critical look at some Broadway shows, which, for one reason or another, may not look the way they did on opening night.

title: INHERITANCE OF ACQUIRED TRAITS IN MICE IS REPORTED
description: Despite the well-established belief that capabilities acquired by one generation cannot be genetically transferred to the next, two researchers in Toronto have reported that mice that were made tolerant to two foreign substances have passed that tolerance to their offspring. The offspring then transmitted the tolerance to a third generation.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arkansas Louisiana Gas Co. signed a 15-year contract with the Central Louisiana Electric Company to sell the utility up to an average of 100 million cubic feet daily of gas.

title: TRIAL OF BERRIGANS AND 6 RECALLS ANTIWAR ACTIVISM OF '60'S
description: Outside the courthouse were banners for peace and an end to nuclear arms. ''Peace, yes - arms race, no!'' one read. ''Our government is leading us to nuclear death,'' said another. And inside Courtroom B the Berrigan brothers were again on trial.

title: Dome Gold Find
description: Dome Exploration (Canada) Ltd., a unit of Dome Mines Ltd., said it was working on what appeared to be a significant gold discovery in northwestern Ontario. Four diamond drills are in use on a detailed investigation of the discovery, according to the company, which holds a 35 percent interest in the discovery.

title: REAGAN WILL SPEED COLLECTION OF DEBTS ON FEDERAL LOANS
description: The Reagan Administration is planning an ''accelerated debt collection'' program to reclaim more than $1 billion in delinquent loans to students, farmers and clients of the Small Business Administration.

title: CBS Pessimistic About Earnings
description: CBS Inc. anticipates no earnings growth in the first two quarters of this year, but expects a modest increase in per-share earnings for the entire year, Thomas H. Wyman, the company's president, told a group of securities analysts yesterday.

title: An Appraisal
description: On first hearing, the announcement of a plan to redevelop 42d Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenues would seem not to be news at all. There have been as many promises to clean up Times Square over the last few years as there are sex shops and movie theaters to be cleaned up, and these efforts have made little dent in the area's celebrated sleaziness.

title: INJURIES DON'T STOP JONI HUNTLEY
description: Things have turned around for Joni Huntley. Her left foot used to hurt. Now her right foot hurts. Hurt or not, Miss Huntley will seek her sixth national indoor highjump title in eight years tonight in the USA/ Mobil track and field championships at Madison Square Garden. Her task may be easier because three major opponents - Sara Simeoni of Italy, Urszula Kielan of Poland and Colleen Rienstra of Arizona State -have scratched from the meet.

title: 450 Polish Students Occupy Teachers College Offices
description: Some 450 students seized the rector's offices at a teachers college in Olsztyn yesterday in the first outbreak of unrest since a 90-day strike respite went into effect last week, union officials said today.

title: People
description: * Anne Kennedy Griffin has been named senior vice president, director of research, for Chalet, Hirsch, Kurnit & Spector Inc.

title: IRAQ SAYS IT IS READY FOR NEW THRUST
description: Iraq said today that its forces in Iran had completed preparations for a new offensive. Iraqi troops took positions on several hills yesterday in the Dizful area of the oil-producing province of Khuzistan, the military high command said in Baghdad. This was the first report of movement of troops since Iraqi forces beat back an Iranian attempt last month to push them out of the outskirts of Dizful.

title: Trade Center Policy Criticized by Regan
description: Edward V. Regan, the New York State Comptroller, charged that the World Trade Center, in violation of a promise when it was built, had been converted into ''a real estate operation not that much different from many similar properties.''

title: Thatcher AT STATE DINNER, ANGLO-AMERICAN CORDIALITY
description: Margaret Thatcher, Prime Minister of Britain, was the guest of honor tonight at the White House, and it is doubtful that President and Mrs. Reagan could have chosen a more congenial visitor for their first state dinner.

title: U.S. LETS POLAND DEFER PAYMENTS
description: The United States, in a gesture to Poland, announced today that it was allowing the Poles to defer repayment of nearly $90 million in debts over the next four months.

title: Guatemala Law School Professor Killed by Gunmen Firing From Car
description: Gunmen firing from a moving car killed a law school professor today, the police said.

title: MUSIC:HAMPTON AT THE ORGAN
description: THE 1981 edition of the Lincoln Center concert series known as ''Organ Interludes'' got off to an impressive start at Alice Tully Hall late Wednesday afternoon with a recital by Calvin Hampton, the organist whose Friday-midnight concerts in Calvary Episcopal Church at Gramercy Park have become an integral part of New York's offbeat musical life.

title: TELEMANN AND THE CANARY CANTATA
description: The pet singing canary has probably received its greatest tribute in Georg Philipp Telemann's mournful ''Cantata of Funeral Music for an Artistically Trained Canary-Bird Whose Demise Brought the Greatest Sorrow to His Master.''

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CALIFORNIA (AL) - Came to terms w ith Larry Harlow, outfielder.

title: Search Ended in China Sea Crash
description: Rescue teams suspended their search today for seven military personnel missing from the crash of a United States Air Force transport that went down in the South China Sea early today, killing at least 16 people.

title: REARDON, ALLEN BRIGHTEN MET'S FUTURE
description: If the Mets rise from rags to riches in the National League this season, the family jewels will be the right arms of the youngest and maybe the best bull-pen twins in the business: Neil Allen and Jeff Reardon.

title: 1PLAYERS EJECTED
description: In a long night of punching, wrestling and anarchy the Boston Bruins and Minnesota North Stars set six National Hockey League records for brutality tonight, compiling 392 minutes of penalties in a 5-1 Bruin victory. Twelve players were ejected.

title: Bitterman Is Reportedly Well
description: An American missionary group said today that it believed that Chester A. Bitterman 3d, a Bible translator kidnapped by leftist guerrillas on Jan. 19, was alive and in good condition.

title: IRANIANS CHARGE 'TORTURE RACK' RETURNS
description: For the second time in 10 days, Iran's Islamic authorities were accused today by a group of dissident intellectuals of torturing political prisoners and of making ''consistent and increasing attacks upon democratic rights and liberties.''

title: U.S. BARS TALK WITH SALVADORAN LEFT
description: The State Department today rejected an offer from El Salvador's leftist opposition to open talks with the United States on a political settlement of the armed conflict between guerrillas and the military-backed Salvadoran Government.

title: Wells Fargo Is Asked to Support Allegations in Embezzlement Suit
description: Attorneys for Harold J. Smith, the boxing promoter who is a defendant in a $21.3 million embezzlement suit filed by the Wells Fargo Bank, went to court today to force the bank to produce records supporting its allegations against Mr. Smith and other defendants.

title: The Economy
description: Democratic members of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, taking sharp issue with President Reagan's program, called for more moderate monetary and budget policies. The Democrats called for an emphasis on structural changes. (Page D1.)

title: Jim Dale on the Spit
description: The grand ballroom of the Sheraton Centre hotel echoed with the sounds of locker room humor yesterday, but nobody complained. It was a Friars Club roast and that sort of thing is expected.

title: 'APACHE'HEROIN VICTIM IS A PRUDE ABOUT DRUGS
description: IN ''Fort Apache, the Bronx,'' Rachel Ticotin plays a doomed Puerto Rican nurse who, in one of the film's most powerful scenes, overdoses on heroin and wrenchingly staggers to the hospital in her pajamas in an attempt to save her life.

title: MRS. THATCHER GIVES SUPPORT TO REAGAN AS TRIP TO U.S. OPENS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain visited President Reagan at the White House today and offered kind words for Mr. Reagan's domestic economic plans.

title: ACCOUNTANT ELECTED PUBLICKER PRESIDENT
description: Joseph C. Minio, 38 years old, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Publicker Industries, whose primary businesses include marketing alcohol for gasohol and producing industrial alcohols. He succeeds Robert S. Leventhal, 53, who resigned from the Greenwich, Conn., company, in which the Publicker family group owns about 45 percent of the stock.

title: At The Movies; by Chris Chase; For Sigourney Weaver, heady taste of success.
description: WALKING through Central Park on a misty gray day, Sigourney Weaver wears a yellow rain slicker and a cap that sprouts two fuchsiacolored horns. She's a merry sight, a breath of spring.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: OHIO G.O.P. ASKS REDISTRICTING AIDED BY COMPUTER
description: Lacking the votes to insure redistricting by and for Republicans, the Ohio Republican Party has come out for redistricting by computer-assisted geometry.

title: CONCERT: RARITY BY GOTHAM TRIO
description: The Gotham Trio unearthed a rarity for its concert at the Abraham Goodman House on Monday night - a Trio by Enrique Granados apparently never before played in New York. First performed in 1898 with the composer at the piano and Pablo Casals tending to the cello part, the piece lay forgotten until it was published in 1976.

title: HONORARY DOCTOR OF LAWS
description: At Georgetown University, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain receives mantle from the Rev. J. Donald Freeze, left, and the Rev. Timothy S. Healy, right, school president. Page 4.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE* 19.00 19.00 16.50 DISCOUNT RATE** 13.00 13.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 15.69 15.24 16.33 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.32 14.13 13.95 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 13.94 13.80 13.92 TREASURY NOTES 13.64 13.58 12.94 TREASURY BONDS 13.05 12.91 12.10 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 14.05 13.88 12.90 MUNICIPAL BONDS 11.20 11.20 8.95 6-MONTH SAVINGS 13.861 CERTIFICATES * Split rate, 18.50-19.00 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE GLOBAL IMPACT OF AN 'ISLAMIC BOMB'
description: To the Editor:

title: SIX RECORDS SET FOR PENALTIES
description: Following are the six National Hockey League penalty records that were set at Boston Garden on Thursday night in the game between the Boston Bruins and the Minnesota North Stars.

title: DEMOCRATS SELECT MANATT AS CHAIRMAN
description: The Democratic National Committee today elected Charles T. Manatt of Los Angeles as its new chairman, and the veteran party fund-raiser promised to ''renew this party from top to bottom for the challenges of the 1980's and 1990's.''

title: SUIT IS PLANNED BY WESTCHESTER ON PRISON LIMIT
description: Westchester County officials said they were unable to comply with a New York State order to reduce the county's prison population by 200 as of today and announced plans to sue the state within 10 days if it did not designate alternative prison facilities.

title: French Loan to Mexico
description: France has agreed to lend 1.4 billion francs, or about $280 million, to Mexico to finance the construction of the third stage of Mexico City's subway, the Finance Ministry said today. It said 20 percent of the loan would be backed by the French Treasury at an interest rate of 3 1/2 percent over 22 years with a grace period of five and a half years. The rest will be covered by French banking institutions with an interest rate of 7 3/4 percent and a 10-year amortization period.

title: Itel Board Adds 7 Outsiders
description: The Itel Corporation said today that seven new outside directors had been elected to its board, increasing its membership to 17.

title: TWO INSURERS SAID TO DROP OWNERS' POLICY
description: Major league baseball's club owners, facing the possibility of a player strike May 29, continued yesterday to have problems with their strike insurance.

title: OKC CORP. LOOKING FOR FUEL PARTNERS
description: The OKC Corporation disclosed yesterday that it was discussing with unnamed oil and gas companies the possibility of forming a general partnership to share in OKC's worldwide oil and natural gas properties.

title: CRAIG'S DILEMMA
description: BOSTON THE ice has turned mushy for Jim Craig. A year ago he was the goalie on the United States' gold-medal hockey team, but today he is the third-string goalie on a team with no need for three.

title: Your Money; Fine Art Prints: Caveat Emptor
description: THE advertising was carefully worded. Art lovers could buy a ''limited edition'' of 5,000 ''hand-numbered'' reproductions of six of Picasso's finest paintings. Reproduced by the Louvre's own printers and approved by the musuem and Picasso's heirs, a complete, framed set of the six could be bought for $762, or unframed copies of each for prices ranging from $32 to $97.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE The Endless Farewell for Walter Cronkite
description: With his farewell as anchorman of the ''CBS Evening News'' only a week away - his last broadcast is next Friday - Walter Cronkite was lamenting the other day the number of testimonials and awards he's been given lately.

title: N.H.L. WILL STUDY AN ORDER TO FIGHT
description: In the wake of Thursday night's record-breaking brawl in Boston, the National Hockey League faces a decision whether violence is more serious when a coach urges his players to fight than when they do so on their own.

title: Authors Guild Elects Two to Top Positions
description: Anne Edwards and Madeleine L'Engle have been elected president and vice president of the Authors Guild, succeeding Robert A. Caro and Roger Angell.

title: JUDGE TO RULE ON ABC COVERAGE OF FIGURE SKATING
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that he would rule Monday, the day before the opening of the 1981 World Figure Skating Championships, on a challenge to ABC-TV's exclusive television coverage, which involves a ban on any American television station's showing any of the event on its news programs.

title: SLAM PROSPECT CAN DEPEND ON THE UNAVAILABLE POINTS
description: Most textbooks on bidding declare that two balanced hands containing 37 high-card points but lacking a suit fit should contract for seven no-trump. This is true, but it is not the whole truth. Exactly which points are missing can be crucial.

title: Mrs. Bhutto Is Released After a Brief Stay in Jail
description: The widow of the late President, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was released by the police early today after being jailed briefly yesterday in Lahore and Karachi as part of a widespread crackdown on political dissent.

title: OF TIME'S PASSING AND THE RIVER OF MEMORIES
description: A neighbor sends me one of those engraved cards announcing that he has been made a partner in a law firm. High on the list of senior partners I see the name of someone I grew up with on the West Side of Manhattan 40 years ago. ''When you see so-and-so,'' I tell my neighbor, ''tell him the touch football game will be at 'squirrel field' after school. He'll understand the message.''

title: PEACE IN EL SALVADOR
description: The first political issue that the Reagan Administration chose to discuss with Europe was not detente or the neutron bomb, nor the current economic crisis that undermines global stability and progress. Instead, the various diplomatic missions sent from Washington came with the message that the Communists are trying to take over El Salvador.

title: Exxon Daystar Sold
description: The American Solar King Corporation said it had acquired the Exxon Corporation's Daystar subsidiary and the solar-related assets of its solar thermal systems unit.

title: Johnson Challenges Fate Along With a Champion
description: When the $1.5 million he was to get for fighting Eddie Mustafa Muhammad disappeared with Harold Smith and the canceled Madison Square Garden boxing card, it did not seem to matter to Matthew Saad Muhammad whom he would fight instead for onesixth the money. So Saad Muhammad, the World Boxing Council lightheavyweight champion, just closed his eyes and made a stab at the list of light-heavyweight contenders.

title: ANNE M'CURDY BENSEN
description: Anne McCurdy Bensen, a psychoanalyst and teacher, died Thursday of cancer at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. She was 51 years old and a resident of Croton-on-Hudson.

title: DAVIS GAINS IN BID TO TAKE OVER FOX
description: Directors of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, reacting favorably to a nearly $700 million takeover bid from Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman, authorized its management yesterday to meet further with Mr. Davis, to negotiate a formal merger agreement and to give him a look at the company's books.

title: Norwegian Missile Pads End Up in East Germany
description: A load of launch pads for Norwegian surface-to-surface missiles was misdirected to East Germany, Norwegian state railroad officials said today.

title: NATIONAL COALITION TO BATTLE REAGAN BUDGET CUTBACKS
description: A national coalition of trade unions, civil rights groups, religious organizations and social welfare agencies, saying that President Reagan's proposed budget cuts ''could wreak great damage to the fabric of this nation,'' announced a major effort today to blunt the effects the reductions could have on low- and middle-income Americans.

title: REAGAN TO PROPOSE BATTLESHIPS' RETURN
description: The Reagan Administration plans to request funds to reactivate two World War II battleships as soon as possible, and possibly two more later, when it submits a new military budget authorizing nearly $223 billion for the fiscal year 1982 to Congress next Wednesday, Pentagon and Congressional officials disclosed today.

title: HIGH AND LOW MARKS FOR FIRE EXITS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Crude' Wins Ocean Series
description: The winner of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference series is Louisiana Crude, a 42-foot yacht owned by Tom Dreyfus of New Orleans and Dick Jennings of Chicago.

title: QUEENS, STATEN ISLAND IN FINAL
description: Queens College moved into the final of the 16th annual City University of New York Tournament for the third straight year by upsetting Baruch College, 91-87, last night. Queens has been runnerup for the last two years.

title: Islanders Rout Canucks; Bossy Gets No. 57
description: Easily, against an undistinguished club, the Islanders rebounded tonight from their worst loss of the season by trouncing the Vancouver Canucks, 5-1.

title: MASS-TRANSIT FARES EXPECTED TO CLIMB BY UP TO 15 CENTS IN CITY
description: A bus and subway fare increase of 10 cents to 15 cents appears to be a virtual certainty despite the aid provided in the transportation program Governor Carey will present next week, officials familiar with the plan said today.

title: WINFIELD A HIT - AS A SNEEZER
description: Dave Winfield, his highly visible winter behind him, stepped into even greater visibility today when he arrived at the Yankees' spring training camp. Visibility wasn't his problem, though. His problems were sneezing and trying to hit the ball out of the batting cage.

title: Copter Bearing Scientists Crashes on Rim of Crater
description: Whirlwinds over Mount St. Helens spun a helicopter into the ground today on the edge of the volcanic crater, but all five occupants, including four scientists, escaped serious injury.

title: MRS. HARRIS PLANS TO HELP WITH INMATES' EDUCATION
description: Jean S. Harris, the former headmistress who was convicted of murder on Tuesday, agreed today to help educate inmates at the Women's Correctional Unit of the County Jail.

title: DR.KINGSLEY KAY, 68, WIDELY KNOWN EXPERT ON INSECTICIDE TOXICITY
description: Dr. Kingsley Kenneth Kay, an associate professor of environmental medicine at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and an internationally recognized expert in toxicity of insecticides and other environmental contaminants, died Feb. 15 at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 68 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: U.A.W.'s Board Plan Questioned
description: The Government said today that it was uncertain whether a plan for a member of the United Automobile Workers to be elected to the board of directors of the American Motors Corporation violates Federal antitrust laws.

title: Sihanouk Cancels His Plan For Anti-Vietnamese Front
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the one-time Cambodian head of state, said today that he had been forced to cancel his plan to form an anti-Vietnamese united front in his homeland.

title: Rather Withdraws Charges Against Cab Driver
description: A follow-up: Although he still contends that a Chicago cab driver held him captive on a wild ride at high speed, following a dispute over addresses last fall, the CBS correspondent Dan Rather says he'd rather drop the whole thing.

title: Inmate Dies After Prison Fight
description: A state prison guard who tried to break up a knife fight in which an inmate died was in critical condition today with stab wounds. The guard, Louis Jewett, 37 years old, was stabbed four times in the attack last night. The inmate, Bobby C. Garcia, died two hours later.

title: An Appreciation
description: Howard Hanson's claim on history rests, at this moment, more on his work as an educator and as a promoter of American music than on the vitality of his large creative output. For more than half a century he stood like Horatio at the bridge, beating back the faddists, the avant-gardists and the purveyors of what he once termed ''modern musical realism.'' His own music, mostly cast in a post-Romantic style derived from Sibelius, can be acerbic at times, but on the whole it strongly suggests a lost world of antimaccasars and stereopticons. At its best and most characteristic, as in the ''Nordic'' and ''Romantic'' symphonies, it exudes a sincerity and concern for craft that lend it enough legitimacy to warrant occasional revival and reassessment.

title: HELPING COMPANIES TO THWART THE SPY
description: Above a large plaque emblazoned with the company logo, a camera follows visitors as they enter the reception room. Beneath the plaque, two women are seated at a wide desk. They inquire politely into the visitor's identity and purpose. Questions are part of the business.

title: No Headline
description: Sir Harold Wilson, the former Prime Minister, will not run again for Parliament, Labor Party officials announced today.

title: ATLANTA ALERTED TO MAN LURING CHILDREN
description: The police issued an alert today for a white man with blond hair who was seen driving a car equipped with police-type roof lights and who tried to pick up children in a racially mixed area of southeast Atlanta.

title: COMPOSER AND TEACHER
description: Howard Hanson, a Pulitzer Prize-winning composer, and a conductor and pedagogue who directed the Eastman School of Music in Rochester for 40 years, died Thursday night at Strong Memorial Hospital, according to a hospital spokesman. He was 84 years old.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1981
description: International Cuba and Nicaragua were warned against shipments of arms to El Salvador by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who told reporters that Cuban activity has reached a peak no longer acceptable in this hemisphere, whether in El Salvador, Honduras or Guatemala, and that if the ''externally managed'' arms flow continued the United States would ''deal with it at the source.'' (Page 1, Columns 3-4.) Huge demonstrations in Spain hailed the Government's victory over an attempted an attempted military coup. King Juan Carlos I, who halted the coup by rallying key commanders to his side, was repeatedly cheeered in Madrid, where more than 1 million people joined the country's largest demonstration. ''Dictatorship no, democracy yes,'' the crowd shouted. (1:4.)

title: PRESIDENT APPROVES MORE BUDGET CUTS OF UP TO $13 BILLION
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan had decided on additional budget cuts of $10 billion to $13 billion to achieve his goal of reducing the growth of Federal spending and offset a budgetary miscalculation on spending in the next fiscal year.

title: THE SAFETY TRADE-OFF OF FUEL-EFFICIENT CARS
description: To the Editor:

title: Lenders Deferring Payments by Braniff
description: The Braniff International Corporation, parent of troubled Braniff Airways, said its lenders had agreed to defer until July 1 all principal and interest payments on its outstanding debt.

title: RETURNING POPE CITES ARMS PERIL
description: Pope John Paul II returned from his 13-day trip to the Far East today and told well-wishers at the Rome airport that the most moving moments had been his visits to Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the two Japanese cities devastated by atomic bombs.

title: Orbiting Mirror For Signals
description: A PATENT for a mirror, kept high in space by the pressure of electromagnetic radiation to reflect communication signals, was granted this week to Paul L. Csonka of the physics faculty at the University of Oregon in Eugene. He assigned it to the Department of Energy.

title: HOW WILL THE WHITNEY DEVELOP ITS NEW LAND?
description: Thanks to recent, additional purchases of property on Madison Avenue, the Whitney Museum of American Art now owns the entire blockfront on the east side of Madison Avenue between 74th and 75th Streets, with some frontage on 74th Street. The purchases have given rise to reports that the Whitney is considering the addition of a hotel or apartment complex to its present six-story building, opened in 1966.

title: U.S. Industries Net Down
description: U.S. Industries said net income for the final quarter of 1980 fell to $5.4 million, or 19 cents a share, from $11.2 million, or 42 cents, a year earlier. The company said sales fell to $295.03 million in the last quarter from $311.5 million in the 1979 period. Net income for the full year was $21.1 million on sales of $1.14 billion, compared with $51.2 million in 1979 on sales of $1.27 billion.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Babcock and Wilcox Company, a subsidiary of McDermott Inc., received an $8.4 million contract from General Electric Company for nuclear components.

title: THE ULTIMATE TAX CUT
description: To the Editor:

title: FEBRUARY FARM PRICE DIP OF 0.4%
description: Prices that farmers get for their raw products dipped four-tenths of 1 percent in February, but still averaged 10 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: California Loses Court Bid To Bar Texas Quarantine
description: The United States Supreme Court today cleared the way for Texas to impose a March 1 quarantine on fruits and vegetables shipped from California, by deciding to take no action on California's request to enjoin the quarantine.

title: BUDGET MATH: TRACING A REAGAN MISSTEP
description: Only a week after President Reagan proposed to bring the Federal budget under strict control, the White House found itself revising the spending and budget-cutting figures that Mr. Reagan unveiled Feb. 18 in his ''program for economic recovery.''

title: Fraser Takeover Halted by British
description: A bid by Roland Rowland to take over the House of Fraser, Britain's biggest department store chain, which includes the luxury store Harrods of London, was halted today by Government order.

title: Texas Speaker's Widow Refuses To Testify About Night of Killing
description: Vickie Daniel, testifying in a child custody hearing, invoked the Fifth Amendment four times today in refusing to discuss what happened the night she allegedly killed her husband, Price Daniel Jr., a former Speaker of the Texas House.

title: PANEL SEEKS WIDE CHANGES IN REGULATIONS ON AIR PURITY
description: In a report that is likely to influence an imminent Congressional debate, the National Commission on Air Quality has recommended substantial changes in the Clean Air Act, including the elimination of deadlines for meeting health standards in areas with air pollution.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FOR AUTO ENGINEERS, CONVERTING TO SMALL CARS IS A BIG BUSINESS
description: If it is the worst of times for the American automobile industry, in some ways it is the best of times for automotive engineers. Even though the nation's automobile manufacturers lost more than a quarter of their home market and $4 billion last year, it is an exciting time for engineers, or at least for those who have held onto their jobs.

title: Rodents' Radioactive Droppings Found at Damaged Nuclear Plant
description: Three Mile Island officials have hired an exterminator to eliminate rodents that have left radioactive droppings in the basement of a building adjoining the contaminated Unit 2 nuclear reactor.

title: GRAND JURY CLEARS OFFICER IN FATAL ADELPHI SHOOTING
description: A Nassau County grand jury has found no grounds for an indictment of the Garden City, L.I., police officer who shot and killed an Adelphi University student on the campus two weeks ago.

title: TESTS SHOW IMPROVEMENT IN READING IN CITY SCHOOLS
description: Following are the scores, released last week by the Board of Education, on the reading tests given in the city's public elementary schools and junior high schools in April 1980.

title: A Dissenter in Descent
description: A genealogist who has done extensive research on Lady Diana Spencer's ancestry suggests that her great-great-grandfather, Frank Work, may be ''spinning in his grave'' at the idea that his descendant plans to marry Prince Charles.

title: COURSES FOR WOMEN RE-ENTERING JOB MARKET
description: Three times a week since the beginning of September, Barbara Bonthron, a 43-year-old mother who has not held a job for 17 years, has been taking part in a nine-month program that she hopes will not only prepare her for re-entry into the work force, but also put her in line for a managerial position.

title: 2 Snatch $1.2 Million That Fell From Truck
description: The police and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation scoured the city today in search of two motorists who snatched $1.2 million in cash that fell from the back of an armored truck. The loot consisted of 12,000 $100 bills.

title: STOCKS RISE FOR 5TH DAY IN A ROW
description: The stock market, on the strength of mostly institutional buying, scored its fifth consecutive advance yesterday, although the trading pace moderated from Thursday's heavy volume.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the trumpet sounds an uncertain note, then who can prepare for battle? In a $700 billion budget, to have a line saying we're not sure about these numbers in a range of $3 billion to $6 billion - probably common sense would dictate you don't do that.'' - James S. Brady, President Reagan's press secretary. (9:4.)

title: WEST GERMAN SEX CONCERN TO OPEN IN U.S.
description: In a plain-brown-wrapper of a building in an industrial suburb, with all the exoticism of a forklift truck, sits what is probably the world's largest sex business.

title: JAZZ: BY VALERIE CAPERS
description: Valerie Capers, a pianist and composer who uses jazz as a basis for much of her work, has attempted to distill the dramatic essence of the life of Sojourner Truth, the 19th-century freed slave who was a vital voice for emancipation and a pioneer feminist, into a 45-minute musical work, ''Sojourner,'' which she calls ''an opratorio.'' ''Sojourner'' was given its premiere last Sunday night at St. Peter's Church with a chorus and jazz emsemble, including Miss Capers at the piano.

title: No Headline
description: 3 BRITONS LEAVE TEHERAN AFTER 6-MONTH DETENTION

title: NASSAU COUNTY SHERIFF QUITS AMIDST CONTROVERSY ON JAIL
description: Michael P. Seniuk resigned as Nassau County Sheriff today within hours of learning that County Executive Francis T. Purcell was considering his dismissal.

title: LOW-INCOME AREAS CONSERVING WATER
description: The dramatic response by New Yorkers to the city's pleas for water conservation cuts across social, economic and geographic lines, according to the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner, Francis X. McArdle.

title: Lockheed Exchange Offer
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that as of yesterday it had received and accepted about 73 percent of its outstanding 4 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 1992, valued at $74 million principal amount, in response to its recent exchange offer. It has now extended the offer until March 13. The company is exchanging 7.24 shares of $11.25 convertible preferred stock with a $100 share liquidation value for each $1,000 of the debentures.

title: Index; International
