description: Pope, back in Rome, stresses Hiroshima-Nagasaki visits 2 Departing U.S. envoy to Italy is given high marks 2 Thriving West German sex concern to open in U.S. 4 Mrs. Thatcher says West is counting on stronger dollar 4 Around the World 5 Three of four Britons leave Iran after six-month detention 5 Gunmen in Beirut murder 2 employees of the Iraqi Embassy 5 Convicts flee French prison by helicopter during soccer game 24 Government/Politics National coalition to battle Rea- gan budget cuts 9 Westchester officials threaten to sue state over prison facilities 26 General Around the Nation 6 Atlanta issues alert for a man seen luring children 6 Two Miami banks searched in crackdown on drug trafficking 6 The talk of Port Jervis: flood cleanup continues 25 The Region 26 Jean Harris has agreed to help educate other inmates 26 The City 27 Water use cut sharply in poorer neighborhoods 27 Industry/Labor For automotive engineers small is beautiful 6 Longshoremen's leader criticizes Senate rackets inquiry 8 Mine union calls strike to protest cuts in black lung funds 9 Arts/Entertainment Martha Graham troupe opens at the Kennedy Center 11 How will the Whitney develop its new land? 11 Publisher says Naval Academy cancels order for critical novel 11 ''Time Change'' by Hope Cooke reviewed 13 An appreciation of Howard Hanson's contributions to music 19 Mike Wallace says Morley Safer dropped a piece at his urging 47 Judge to rule on television coverage of figure-skating event 47 Style Consumer Saturday 21 Training to re-enter the top job market 21 Gustibus: When the menu in- cludes too much noise 21 Obituaries Dr. Kingsley Kenneth Kay, envi- ronmental expert 19 Sports The Magic is back for Lakers-Nets sellout 14 George Vecsey on Jim Craig's dilemma 14 Johnson fighting Saad Muham- mad and fate in title bout 14 Myricks (26-8 1/4) beats Lewis for 3d straight long-jump title 15 Winfield a hit in Yankee debut - but as a sneezer 15 N.H.L. studying North Star coach's order to fight 15 Islanders and Resch face a trial period 15 Cardinals are baseball's mystery team 15 Insurance executives meet over owners' strike problem 17 Features/Notes Man in the News: Charles Manatt, new Democratic Party chief 7 Going Out Guide 10 Saturday News Quiz 13 About New York 27 47< News Analysis James M. Markham on the coup attempt in Spain 3 Robert Pear discusses reaction to immigration report 7 Howell Raines on revisions in the Reagan budget figures 8 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: Companies
description: The Chrysler Corporation reported a loss of $1.71 billion for 1980, the largest loss in American corporate history. The company said that it would extend its car rebate program until March 20. In Washington, the Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board voted $400 million in loan guarantees for the company. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, who heads the board, said Chrysler's prospects were ''reasonably good.'' Chrysler also sold $400 million of 10-year notes to yield 15.31 percent. (Page 1.)

title: NEW YORK CITY'S 'TUDOR DEAL' IS NOT A DEAL YET
description: To the Editor:

title: AN ADULT FAIRY TALE
description: TIME CHANGE. By Hope Cooke. Illustrated. 285 pages. Simon & Schuster. $14.95. Hope Cooke's mother died while flying her own plane when Hope was 2 years old,. In ''Time Change,'' Miss Cooke says, ''It seemed to me as if the stars in the sky had had some powerful pull on my mother - that she had been caught between the gravitational spheres of Earth and a galaxy where she remained spinning in space.''

title: MADRID PROTEST MARCH AGAINST COUP ATTEMPT DRAWS OVER 1 MILLION
description: More than one million people marched through the center of Madrid tonight to express their support for the nation's young democratic institutions and to condemn this week's failed military coup. Big crowds gathered elsewhere in Spain for similar demonstrations.

title: DEPARTING U.S. ENVOY TO ITALY SEES LINKS ENHANCED
description: If there is one message that Richard N. Gardner, the departing American Ambassador to Italy, could leave to the Republican Administration, it would be: take the Italians seriously; they are better allies than most.

title: Abitibi Directors Favor Stock Sale
description: Directors of Abitibi-Price, the world's largest newsprint producer, have recommended that shareholders accept a $263.5 million (Canadian) offer made jointly by Thomson Newspapers Ltd. and Nu-West Group Ltd. for 46 percent of the company.

title: ARCHBISHOP OF PARIS INSTALLED
description: Msgr. Jean-Marie Lustiger, who converted from Judaism to Catholicism at the age of 14, was enthroned today as Archbishop of Paris. The 54-year-old Archbishop is the son of a Polish couple who emigrated to France between the two world wars.

title: WHEN THE RESTAURANT MENU INCLUDES TOO MUCH NOISE
description: Noise in local restaurants is becoming an increasingly annoying aspect of dining out, and complaints on that score are frequent and abundant. The two main factors contributing to the deafening, headsplitting cacophony in so many New York restaurants are the high price of real estate and the design trend toward interiors lined with metal ceilings, bare floors and glass and mirrored wall panels. High rents induce restaurateurs to jam tables together so that maximum profits are realized on every inch of space. The hard surfaces, instead of absorbing sound, bounce it around and generally intensify it.

title: WHAT'S IN BOOK ON REBATES?
description: W ITH everyone so inflation conscious these days, a book that seems to offer savings on a wide range of household appliances, cars, cosmetics and other goods is likely to have wide appeal.

title: Quake Produced Cracks In Parthenon's Columns
description: The Parthenon suffered significant damage in Tuesday's earthquake, archeologists reported today.

title: Peking Envoy to The Hague Recalled Over Sale of Subs
description: China today announced the ''immediate'' recall of its Ambassador to the Netherlands to protest the Dutch Government's approval of the sale of two submarines to Taiwan.

title: AMTRAK TRAIN DERAILS IN NORTHERN MONTANA, INJURING 19 PASSENGERS
description: The Empire Builder, an Amtrak passenger train traveling from Seattle to Chicago, derailed today on the southern edge of Glacier National Park, injuring 19 of its 225 passengers, the authorities said.

title: Ban on Coed Bathrooms At Massachusetts Protested
description: Students at the University of Massachusetts here today protested an administrative directive ending the sharing of dormitory bathrooms by men and women, a practice for the last 12 years.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 56-year-old Queens man was shot to death and his wife was critically wounded yesterday during a burglary at their 26th-floor apartment in North Shore Towers, 270-26 Grand Central Parkwway, Floral Park. The dead man was identified as Rubin Hyman.

title: VINCENT PULICANO, SUPPORTED HOSPICES
description: The Rev. Vincent Pulicano, a leader in the establishment in New York City of the hospice program that stresses the most comfortable and non-institutional individual care possible for the terminally ill, died Thursday of bone cancer at the Cabrini Medical Center, where he was the director of pastoral care. He was 43 years old and lived at the center.

title: Chinese Accept Quake Relief
description: China's Red Cross Society has accepted almost $90,000 in relief aid for victims of the earthquake in Sichuan Province in January.

title: DANCE: MARTHA GRAHAM IN WASHINGTON
description: Amid a series of gala events that brought out everyone from Liza Minnelli and Andy Warhol to the Danish diplomatic corps, Martha Graham presented her newest work last night at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Two Seized in Robberies At 20 Banks in Midtown
description: The police seized two men yesterday that they called their two most wanted bank robbers - known as the ''do not panic bandits.'' The two men, so-called by the police because of the admonition they included in their notes demanding money, are believed to have been responsible for at least 20 bank robberies in the midtown area in December that netted them more than $15,000, according to Detective Lieut.

title: ECONOMIC INDICATORS SLIP AGAIN
description: The Government index designed to forecast the future of the economy fell in January for the second consecutive month, but economists said that a new recession still did not appear to be on the horizon.

title: J I Case Laying Off 600 Employees
description: J I Case, North America's secondlargest manufacturer of construction equipment, said today that it was laying off 600 workers and cutting production schedules by $100 million nationwide because of the worsening economy.

title: ADMINISTRATION IS SAID TO APPROVE INCREASE IN MILITARY AID TO SALVADOR
description: The National Security Council approved an expanded United States military assistance and training program today for El Salvador's armed forces, according to Pentagon sources.

title: COGHLAN WINS 3-MILE RUN in 2d FASTEST IN-DOOR TIME
description: Eamonn Coghlan sprinted past the finish line and glanced upward at the scoreboard clock in Madison Square Garden last night. The figures read ''12:54.51.'' Thinking that he had broken the world indoor record in the three-mile run, Coghlan raised the index fingers of both hands and began a victory lap in the USA/Mobil indoor track and field championships.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DOWN EAST

title: U.S. GROUP SET TO BUY HARLEY
description: AMF Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its subsidiary, the Harley-Davidson Motor Company, the only United States concern that still makes motorcycles.

title: TRADE GAP WIDENS TO $5.44 BILLION
description: The nation's trade deficit soared to $5.44 billion in January from $3.1 billion in December, the highest in nearly a year, primarily because of increases in imports of oils and autos, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: IN DEFENSE OF A POWER PLANT ON STATEN ISLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: HOOKER CHEMICAL IN JERSEY STRUCK ON TOXIC GAS ARRIVAL
description: All 351 members of a union local have struck a Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corporation plant here after learning that the company had brought a highly toxic gas, nitric oxide, into the plant without consulting the union.

title: LOUIS ROBERTS
description: Louis Roberts, director of the Roberts Technical and Trade School of Manhattan, a private vocational school providing courses in automotive mechanics and allied fields, died Feb. 6 at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SPANISH MILITARY: RELUCTANT DEMOCRATS
description: The seizure of Parliament by some 200 Civil Guards led by a lieutenant colonel had an improbable and mildly theatrical quality that tended to obscure its deeper seriousness.

title: MORALITY'S BANNER
description: Back when women were not considered fit to vote, a variety of claims were made for the suffrage cause. One was simply that denying the vote was morally indefensible. Another that got increased acceptance after turn-of-the-century exposes for civic corruption and crimes of the robber barons was that the ''ladies'' would bring a moral element into politics.

title: STOLEN, BUT NOT LOST
description: Sometime between 3 and 6 on a recent afternoon, on 64th Street just off Fifth Avenue, a thief smashed the right rear window of my car, heaved his body in and across the back seat, and took two book bags and a small shopping bag. He left an open brief-case, full of worn piano music, on the seat. Here is what he got:

title: The Talk of Port Jervis
description: Two days after flood waters and huge ice slabs from the Delaware River poured into the Riverside neighborhood before dawn Feb. 12, Governor Carey looked in on the home of Margaret Nason, where part of the living-room floor, afloat in ankle-deep water, lay atop the raised fireplace hearth.

title: Net Deposits Drop At Savings Units
description: American savers deposited about $550 million more than they withdrew from savings and loan associations in January, the smallest net-deposit volume for that month since 1970, the Government reported today.

title: CHRYSLER REPORTS RECORD U.S. LOSS OF $1.71 BILLION
description: The Chrysler Corporation reported today that it had lost $1.71 billion for 1980, eclipsing the record held briefly by the Ford Motor Company for the largest loss in American corporate history.

title: COMPETITION NEEDS MORE THAN DEREGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: At the White House, President Reagan accepts a gift presented in jest by Interior Secretary James G. Watt. It was a book of Federal regulations, split in two, and the meat cleaver that presumably was used to cut it, all mounted on a board. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, at left, and David A. Stockman, director of the budget, look on.

title: FIRST REVIEWS ON IMMIGRATION PROPOSALS: ENCOURAGING WORDS, UNCERTAIN PROSPECTS
description: A nearly unbroken chorus of favorable comments greeted the final report of the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy today, but the initial public reactions might be deceptive.

title: CARDINALS ARE BASEBALL'S MYSTERY TEAM
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, the heaviest traders in baseball this winter, opened spring training today with Bruce Sutter and Darrell Porter as the stars of a new cast.

title: General Host Losing Part of Cudahy Unit
description: The General Host Corporation said that it planned to divest itself of the fresh and processed meat business of its Cudahy Company unit and that it had set aside a $28.5 million pretax reserve to cover related costs and losses.

title: EASY ON THAT UMBRAGE
description: Man y Americans ask, ''Why are so many newspaper people Democrats?'' The answer is that most newspaper people don't want to go to Russia.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 26.

title: Texas Newspaper to Stop Listing Brothel 'Customers'
description: The editorial board of the monthly newspaper El Pueblo announced today that it had unanimously voted not to print any more names from an alleged list of well-to-do brothel customers kept by Theresa Brown, a convicted madam.

title: WHEN IT COMES TO THE BIG TOWN, NOT ALL CABBIES KMOW THEIR WAY AROUND
description: ''The Coliseum, please,'' the passenger said as he entered the taxicab on Wall Street. ''You mean the one on 34th Street?'' the driver asked, switching on the meter. ''No, the Coliseum. Fifty-Ninth Street.'' ''Oh yeah, sure. I'll take the F.D.R. Drive.'' ''It's on the West Side.'' ''Okay. Then I'll take the West Side Highway.'' ''The West Side Highway is closed.'' ''Really? When did that happen?'' ''Seven years ago.'' ''Oh.'' Nearly every New Yorker, even one who takes taxicabs only occasionally, can relate a similar story. The New York taxi driver - once the street-smart expert on virtually everything from politics to potholes - is increasingly having trouble finding his way around the block.

title: Ampco Raises Offer For Buffalo Forge
description: The Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation raised its tender offer for the Buffalo Forge Company to $37.50 a share, from $34, and extended the deadline for its offer to March 12 from March 2.

title: Navy Fails to Find New Survivors Of U.S. Air Force Crash in Pacific
description: A United States Navy spokesman said today that the military authorities would decide tomorrow whether to continue a search for military personnel missing in Thursday's crash of an Air Force plane in the South China Sea. A search today failed to turn up anything.

title: RUSSIANS URGED TO WORK MORE, WASTE LESS
description: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov appealed today for greater pride in work, more efficiency and improved productivity during the 1980's as keys to overcoming the Soviet Union's economic problems.

title: 2 FLEE FRENCH PRISON BY HELICOPTER DURING SOCCER GAME
description: A hijacked helicopter landed in the middle of a prison soccer game today, picked up two dangerous convicts and flew away in a precisely timed breakout from a maximum security prison 24 miles south of here.

title: MINERS TO PROTEST PLAN ON BLACK LUNG
description: The leadership of the United Mine Workers today called a two-day strike in the coal fields, ordering 170,000 miners off their jobs March 9 and 10 to protest the Reagan Administration's plan to cut Federal funds for the black lung compensation program.

title: Taylor Caldwell Drops Lawsuit Against Daughter
description: Taylor Caldwell, the best-selling novelist, and her husband have decided to withdraw a $5 million defamation-of-character lawsuit against Miss Caldwell's daughter, Margaret Fried.

title: HOW IT FEELS ON DR. REAGAN'S COUCH
description: In discussing economics, the newcomers in Washington sound more like Freudian analysts than politicians. They want tax and spending cuts to break the nation's ''cycle of negative expectations.'' They aim to ''renew optimism and confidence and rekindle the nation's entrepreneurial instincts and creativity.'' What promise in this psychonomics?

title: EASTERN TO BUY 175 JETS
description: Eastern Airlines plans to purchase 175 fuel-efficient jetliners at a cost of perhaps $9 billion over the next 15 years, the airline's spokesman said yesterday.

title: Christine Fokine Biddleman, 61; Ex-Dancer and Teacher of Ballet
description: Christine Fokine Biddleman, a dance educator and former dancer, died in New York on Feb. 18 after a long illness.

title: JUSTICE CAN'T WAIT FOR JOBS
description: Commenting on the defeat of so many liberals last November, Tom Hayden remarked that when it comes to crime, liberals tend to urge mugging victims to be patient until the Humphrey-Hawkins bill brings full employment, while conservatives start recruiting liberals who have been mugged.

title: Judge in Alabama Faces Marijuana Theft Counts
description: An Alabama circuit judge, facing charges of marijuana smuggling in Florida, has been charged with stealing marijuana connected with a court case in which he sentenced the defendant to prison.

title: ACTING L.I.R.R. HEAD SETS 2-MONTH TENURE
description: Daniel T. Scannell, who has been named temporary president of the Long Island Rail Road, said yesterday he would not rule out making changes in top executives, although he has set a two-month time limit for himself in the job.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of editing errors, an article in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly stated the value of two real estate holdings of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation. Some 63 acres in Century City, Calif., are valued by the company on its books at a few million dollars, according to analysts, while the total market value of 2,500 acres of land and other holdings at Pebble Beach, Monterey, cannot be accurately estimated, real estate brokers say.

title: U.N. Official Says 12 to 15 Die Daily in Ethiopian Camp
description: A United Nations refugee official said today that 12 to 15 people were dying each day in Ethiopia's Ogaden region in what he described as the worst refugee camp he had seen in more than 20 years' service.

title: MAGIC RETURNS, HELPS BEAT NETS
description: Outside The Forum, on Manchester Boulevard, the sign said SOLD OUT, an infrequent occurrence when the New Jersey Nets are the attraction. Inside, the bright lights of three television crews were shining when the Nets walked on the court for a brief workout.

title: Proxmire Chides Smith On Confirmation Testimony
description: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that Attorney General William French Smith was less than candid in his confirmation proceedings when asked how he would advise President Reagan about being used as a reference for the entertainer Frank Sinatra.

title: OVERCOMING IN ROSEDALE
description: Parents in the Rosedale section of Queens have sat in at a public school building, picketed, sung ''We Shall Overcome,'' boycotted a school they say is segregated and filed suit in Federal court to secure an integrated education for their children. In all these ways the parents, though overwhelmingly white, portray themselves as successors to the black civil rights movement. But the similarities are those of a caricature. The parents should end their struggle and put their kids back in school.

title: AMBACH BACKS PLAN TO ACCREDIT FOREIGN SCHOOLS
description: Gordon M. Ambach, the state's Education Commissioner, today endorsed a proposal to accredit foreign medical schools so that American students studying abroad can return to the state for training.

title: ALBERTA TO CUT OIL OUTPUT IN DISPUTE OVER PRICES
description: In the latest of a series of regional confrontations threatening Canadian unity, the province of Alberta plans to begin cutting back petroleum production on Sunday.

title: PENALIZING THRIFT
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. THATCHER BIDS U.S. BOLSTER DOLLAR
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said today that the ''free world'' was counting on the Reagan Administration to restore faith in the United States dollar as the primary currency for international trade and banking.

title: A 4-FOOT-5-INCH BOY, 9, GIVES UP IN ROBBERY
description: A 9-year-old suspect in a bank robbery Wednesday that netted $100 surrendered yesterday at the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: CRIMINAL COURT SEEKS RELIEF ON WORSENING CASELOAD
description: With their number depleted by reassignment and retirement, the 18 to 20 judges in Manhattan Criminal Court are more hard pressed than ever to handle the 80,000 cases filed there each year, according to the court's administrative judges.

title: A NEW LEADER FOR THE DEMOCRATS
description: Charles T. Manatt, elected today as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has, according to his father's recollection, ''always been interested in managing things.''

title: MONEY SUPPLY ADVANCES $2 BILLION IN LATEST WEEK
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that there was a $2 billion increase in the nation's money supply for the week ended Feb. 18, a development that left the credit markets uncertain about the future direction of short-term interest rates.

title: AGRICULTURE CHIEF OPTIMISTIC
description: John R. Block, a former paratrooper and hog farmer whose new battlefield is the Department of Agriculture, is one Reagan Cabinet officer already looking beyond the proposed budget cutting. And what he sees are better times for his principal client, the American farm industry.

title: BURROUGHS LINK AFFETED
description: Another managerial tremor hit the Bendix Corporation yesterday with the announcement that three directors were resigning. In effect, the latest shake-up ended an intimate interlocking relationship between Bendix, a diversified manufacturing company based in Southfield, Mich., and the Burroughs Corporation, a computer producer in nearby Detroit.

title: BEIRUT GUNMEN KILL 2 OFFICIALS OF IRAQ EMBASSY
description: Two officials of the Iraqi Embassy were murdered here today while they were on their way to work by car. They were shot from a passing automobile by assailants reportedly armed with machine guns.

title: c12.6
description: Just as Broadway and Hollywood boasted their ''Sunshine Boys'' for years, so has New York's retail trade. Not only are the two retailers star merchandisers, but they are no mean vaudevillians themselves, with a continuing patter of infectious humor.

title: City Sues Pullman For $27.6 Million
description: New York City and the Transit Authority filed suit yesterday seeking $27.6 million in damages from Pullman Inc. in the latest litigation stemming from the R-46 subway cars that Pullman manufactured for the city.

title: UNFLATTERING BOOK UNWELCOME IN NAVY
description: Prentice-Hall says the United States Naval Academy bookstore canceled a large order for a novel because the book is critical of some aspects of the academy, but the academy denies that this was the reason for the cancellation. The book, ''A Sense of Honor,'' was written by James Webb, a 1968 graduate of the Naval Academy who become one of the most decorated marines of the Vietnam era.

title: SUSPECT HELD ON $10 MILLION BOND IN A CRACKDOWN ON DRUGS IN MIAMI
description: Isaac Kattan, a Colombian described by the Federal authorities as the biggest money launderer for major narcotics trafficking organizations in South America, was placed under a $10 million bond today while Federal agents used warrants to search two Miami banks and a securities concern for his assets.

title: ANSWERS
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. Colonel Tejero, together with other rightists, seized the lower house of Parliament as members were approving Spain's new Government and held them hostage for 18 hours until the plot, apparently aimed at igniting a national military revolt, collapsed.

title: UNION HEAD ASSAILS INQUIRY ON RACKETS
description: Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, insisted today that the union was not dominated by organized crime and criticized a Senate panel investigating waterfront corruption for allowing ''persons of low credibility'' to distort the picture.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly reported the position of the Bronx delegation to the City Council on a resolution urging a boycott of the film ''Fort Apache, the Bronx.'' Two of the nine members from the Bronx voted to recommit the resolution to committee, in effect voting against it. They were June M. Eisland, Democrat, and Joseph Savino Jr., Republican.

title: U.N. ATOM AGENCY LAUDS MOVES BY EGYPT AND LIBYA
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency said today that Egypt's decision to sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and Libya's pledge to put its Soviet-built nuclear reactor under the agency's safeguards would extend the agency's power to prevent the use of civilian atomic plants for military purposes.

title: U.S. JUDGE DEFERS DECISION IN WILLIAMS-SONICS CASE
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan reserved decision yesterday after listening to lawyers' arguments on a claim by the Seattle SuperSonics that the team must receive compensation if Gus Williams signs with another club after the season ends in June.
